title: Getting Spliced: Modernism and Sexual Difference
text:
p.099-100 Modernism def'n in poetry cannot explain Women writers 

such as Stein, Marianne Moore, H.D., Mina Loy, Djuna Barnes, Laura Riding.    This is Perloff's critique in The Dance of Intellect.  Esp. those defn's that have adopted the language of Pound for instance.  Focus on parataxis/juxtaposition and the idea  that as "the constellation of 'luminous details' in a pattern of generges that Kenner has described at length (for example, in his claim that in Pound's <i>Homage to Sextus Propertius, 'the words lie flat like the forms on a Cubist surface.')." (98)  Also Poundian modenrism defined acc. to Perloff in terms of "the break with lyric, the use of collage poetics, and the logopoeic 'attitude of mind'..." (100)  

BUT Burke points out that Pound's early theoretical writing on logopoeia mentioned M. Moore and M. Loy as examples even though Pound ignored their gender.  And Burke argues the point is precisely that Pound ignored their gender.  "Genius" was "coded" masculine for him. (100) So it seems Burke says that he assumed, as opposed to the "sentimental poetesses of the nineteenth century, intelligent modern women like Moore and Loy wrote just like men." (100)  But Pound's masculinism prevented him from seeing something important about Loy and Moore's writing: "...because of Pound's self-imposed limitations of thought about the links between gender and creativity (which will be explored briefly in a later section), he could not see that logopoeia in the hands of a female poet might produce a different kind of cultural critique, one that focused on issues of gender." (100)

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text:
p. 483 - 484 Existing Lit on Hunt-Boas collaboration.

They  note a wealth of sources by Ira Jacknis and Judith Berman about the Hunt-Boas partnerhips and correspondence, and they think this material makes possible a detailed examination of discursive practices and language ideology.  They disagree with treatment by others (Jacknis & Berman also?) in that this correspondence is treated as a fragment or special dimension of Boas' work that "esceaped some of the positivist trappings of Boas's historical particularism."  (484)  They want to see these texts as continguous with Boas's larger project and as providing "revealing windows on the manner in which Boas sought to construct anthropology and to locate its practitioners--and the objects of their inquiries--within North American society and within a master narrative of modernity." (484)

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1073- 4 Professional Worker

The Professional Worker, Walkowitz says, was an image that emerged at the end of the 20s, when issues of lack of adequate salary became first and foremost on the minds of social workers.  They were no longer in a "'professional' conciliatory mode ,but [had] ended the decade of the 1920s talking about proletarian issues.  The limits of their professional equality and autonomy, of being consulted but lacking authority in fundamental ways..." (1074)  So he puts forward the Professesional Worker as a "trade unionist" who was explicitly subordiante to men and a "neutered construction."

title: A category of the human mind: the notion of person; the notion of self
text: p. 13 - 17 The Latin "persona" He introduces the idea: "...the Latin persona: a mask, a tragic mask, a ritual mask, and the ancestral mask." (13) India This seems to him to be the oldest "civilization" that was "aware of the notion of the individual, of his consciousness -- may I say, of the 'self' (moi). He examine terminology from this period. But there is discussion about wheter the self is whole or composite. Aham = I and is the same as Indo-European "ego". There is a school samkhya which argues (like Buddhism) that the self is illusory thta it is really composite. (13) China The indiviudal and esp. "his social status" here is "rigorously categorized." (14) Here the term is ming. But he says that "[w]henever they philosophized about it, whenever certain metaphysical schools they have attempted to explain waht it is, they have said of the individual that he is a compose, made up of shen adn kwei -- two ther collective nouns -- in this life. Taoism and Buddhism also went down this road, and the notion of the 'person' (personne) ceased to evolve." (14) --- But it was the Romans or Latins he think that really developed the idea of person, persona, personne in which the 'person'..is more than an organisaitonal fact, more than a name or right to assume a role and a ritual mask. It is a basic fact of law." (14) He notes the basic division between personae, res and actiones in modern law is related to this basic development in Roman law. (14) Original meanig of persona? Latin etymologists say persona -- is per/sonare "the mask through which (per) resounds the voice (of the actor)"...but he htinks this is a "derivation invented afterwards." (14) He roots it in the Etruscans who had many many masks, has a mask civilizaiton in fact. (15) But the Romans gave the word the meaning. They had the same "institutions of the same kind as ceremonies of clans, masks, and paints with which the actors bedeck themselves according to the names they bear." (15) He points to the Hirpi Sorani, the wolves of Soracte, which is connected to the founding myth of the Roman She-Wolf and the Romulus and Remus. (15) He says that the Latins, Etruscans, and Amnites, all stil lived in an "an environment [in which one moved] from personae, masks and names, and individual rights to ritual and privileges." (16) From this he says one single step took to move to the 'person' (personne) --> for the plebs to get the right to full citizenship so that "All freemen of Rome were Roman citizens, all had a civile persona; some became religious personae; some masks, names and ritual remained attached to some privileged famlies of religious collegia" (16) Along with this roman citizens had a right to forenames, surnames an dpseudonyms. (16) He tracks the developmen then in Roman law of the notion of the "persona" as "synonymous with the true nature of the individual." (17) -- but before it was this it was also associated with "an artificial 'character' (personaagepersona" (17) and only slaves were excluded. (17)

title: The Theory of Professions: State of the Art
text:
00 Summary Note 00

In the simplest sense, Freidson is joining the ranks of those that are going against the Parsonian definition of the professions as "honoured servants of  public need."  (E.g. see Parsons' "The Professions and the Social STructure")  Freidson's ideas is actually
that one has to go beyond the notion of the profession by understanding that it is a historically rooted concept.  For instance, he suggests that it is a particularly anglo-saxon construct, or at least that it has a particular meaning in that context, connected to the fact that in England and the United States as opposed to Europe "each occupation [tended] to have to mount its own movement for recognition and protection. Its members loyalties and identities were attached to their indivdiual occupation and its institutions."  (24-25)  In Europe, the state was more active. (25)  Thus he argues that in the Aglo-Americna context the professions gain distinction "less from the prestige of the institutions in which they were educated than from their training and identity as particular, corporately-organised occupations to which specializsed knowledge, ethicality and importance to society are imputed, and for which privilege is claimed." "(25)   Thus he thinks it is true that "professionalism" is the "British disease" or Anglo-American disease as he prefers. (25-26).  He adds, however, that this is not to say that the idea that profession is a "folk concept" is satisfactory, because the work of sociologists in defining professions is part of the definition that takes hold and helps to set the standards that professionals themselves attempt to meet.  (27-31)  What he wants to do then is develop a 
theory of occupations, within which "professions" can fit.  (32)

title: Margaret Mead, the Samoan Girl and the Flapper: Geographies of Selfhood in Coming of Age in Samoa
text:
p. 43 Mead Quote about Timelessness of Samoa

Quoted on 43 from some interview: "...'[l]ife is peaceful, orderly, and gracious in Samoa.  It seems timeless.  Nothing has ever changed.  Nobody is troubled.  No voice is ever raised.  It would be a fine place to die."  (from di Leonardo, Exotics at Home??; hard to tell from Molloy's citation style.)

title: The First Boasian: Alfred Kroeber and Franz Boas, 1896-1905
text:
p.523  Kroeber and 6 Inuit brought to NY 

-- Kroeber apparently heavily involved with the six Inuit brought by explorer Robert Peary in 1897.  Unclear how much K was involved in the fake burial and the use of the skeleton by the AMNH, but Jacknis speculates in footnote #10 that this was a traumatic even for Kroeber, notiing that later both his first wife and Ishi would also die from TB.  See p.522.

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
0 p.xiii-xiv Female Dominion and Work on Women's Experience of Professions

The literature on women's professional experience she notes has observed that women faced a paradox: "Prescriptions for female behavior directly contradicted the solidifying requirements of professional conduct: lingering nineteenth-century feminine ideals urged women toward passivity , humility, and self-sacrifice, while professionalism demanded activity, confidence, and self-assertion.  By validating behaviors traditionally associated iwth men, professionalization put aspiring women into perpetual conflict.  If they donned the behavioral garb appropriate to professional life, they invited criticism for being unfeminine.  If they refused to wear the suit, they lost the aura of professional authority." (xiii)

She notes then that there were different experiences for women in the professions depending on whether they entered male-dominated or female-dominated professions, allso something established by the literature.  (xiii)  

Her female dominion is a study of "female professionalism." (xiv)  in which women had more freedom than in the male-dominated professions.  Specifically they were freer to "reconcile professional ideals with values from female culture, which produced uniquely female ways of being professional." (xiv)

title: The Oversocialized Conception of Man
text:
Notes on "2. The Oversocialized Conception of Man in Modern Sociology" (8/17/10):

(Note this is a reprinting of Wrong's famous and influential article published with the same name in 1961 in the American Sociological Review)

-- In his introductionary comments, Wrong indicates his belief that sociology should be built up around tangible "questions" (he doesn't like the phrase problems b/c it is too reformist).  He dislikes what he describes as a general tendency to develop sociological theory "as the creation of a formal body of knowledge satisfying the logical criteria of scientific theory set up by philosophers and methodologists of natural science." (32)  What he prefers isthe approach of the "historicist conception of sociological knowledge" (32) tha is represnted by Weber, Barrington Moor, Jr., C. Wright Mills (who he says in the forewardto this 1999  ed. book was his teacher).

-- The point here is not to get at laws of development he is careful to point out, but instead how and why can humans form socieities.  He sees these as existential questions on the one hand and questions stemming from Hobbes' basic question--"how men are capable of regulation by social norms and goals that make possible an enduring society" (33)--on the other. The Marxist form of this same question focuses instead on how how "complex societies manage to control and restrain destructive conflicts between social groups." (33)

-- His opinion is that "[m]uch of our theory offers an oversocialized view of man in answering the Hobbesian question and overintegrated view of society in answering the Marxist question." (33) This view he says has been challenged by several writers who he lists in f.n. #3.

-- He starts his critique with T. Parsons who he credits with acknowledging Hobbes as the first to answer the basic question which  Parsons describes as the "problem of order" in his first book, The STructure of Social Action. (33)  Then he states Hobbes construction of the problem (33-34).

-- Modern sociology he says gives two main answers to Hobbes' problem that together "constitute a model of human nature, sometimes clearly stated, more often implicit in accepted concepts,t hat pervades modern sociology." (35)  #1: the idea of "internalization of social norms"; #2: "the view that man is essentially motivated by the desire to achieve a postiive image of self by winning acceptance or status in the eyes of others." (35)  He gives the following quote as an excellent example of hwat he describes as "probably the most influential contemporary sociological conception--and dismissal--of the Hobbesian problem:

To a modern sociologist imbued with the conception that action follows institutionalized patterns, opposition of individual and common interests has only a very limited relevance or is thoroughly unsound. (35, from Francis X. Sutton, The American Business Creed, Cambridge U. Press, 1956, p.304)

His distase for this argument is that it totally erases the original Hobbesian question or "destroys the awareness of rival possibiltiies suggested by the question which accounts for it having been asked in the first place." (35)  It sets up the reverse question, in fact, which is "How it is that vioelnce, conflict, revolution, and the individual's sense of coercion by society manage to exist at all, if this view is correct?" (35) This ways of phrasing things reveals a dialetic but rejects any awareness of it.

-- W shows how Parsons develops this model by his assimilation of Durkheim, wherein he empahsizes Durkheim's alter finding that society's don't so much regulate as "they enter directly into the constitutions of the actors' ends in themselves." (36)  So from this Parsons develops his conception of social norms as "constitutive" (36).  W notes that the original idea of "internalization" that Parsons sets up may well have come from Freud, but emphasizes something totally apart from what Freud did.  His analysis of freud here is interesting, p.36-37.  Freud's view is that when a norm has been internalized it means "no more than that a person will suffer guilt feelings if he fails to live up to it, not that he will in fact live up to it in his behavior." (36)  The person who does conform might in fact be ven more racked with guilt...  He note discussion of deviance as getting closer to what Freud thought on bottomof 37.  "The main explantory fucntion ofthe ocncept [of the superego] is to show how people repress themselves, imposing checks on their own desires and thus turning their inner life into a battlefield of conflicting motives, not matter which side 'wins' by dictating overt action." (37)  So the psychoanalytica view W says is less "deterministic" than the sociological because it is focused on the inner life and not on "overt behavior." (37)

[Note: this would seem to relate to some of my analysis in both chs.3&4.  This idea of internalization is what I have Sapir hitting on when he says that the goals of cutlure became "what the individaul wants" in his more cosnervatie turn  in ch.3.  Similarly, the classificatory discssuion of pschiatric and sociological coneptions of personality used in both chs, plus Mead and Benedict's discussions of deviance, and Benedict's idea of then "normal deviant," plus just in geneal my sense of the relationship of Freud to what they were doing, which from this seems as though it could be drastically enahcned, but I'd need to dip deeper into Freud and also the personality and culture school...]

-- What sociologists have done W notes is to separate the superego from any id concept.  If people are well socialized,then there is no Hobbesian problem at all he says.  And they treat deviant behavior as a consequence of "special circumstances: ambiguous norms, anomie, role conflict, or greater cultural stress on goals than on the approved means ofor attaining them." (38)  They have also, he says, rejected the idea that there coudl be a variety of "motives" for conformity.  "Either someone ihas internalized the norm, or he is 'unsocialized,' a feral or socially isolated child, or a psychoapth." (38)  Freud by contast realied that some people hadn't formed superegos because and therefore could perform "bad deeds" without guilt as long as they were sure they wouldn't be punished. (38)

-- Now he begins a more detailed critique of contemporary sociological developments.  He has an intersting analysis of Reisman, who criticized oversocialized man, but without recognizing that thse types were conceptions rooted in his own profession, and not in fact actual types of human character.  But boht he and Guffman appareantly noted that Riesman's idea of human nature was closer to Freud's thna Parsons' in that "character is defined by superego mechanisms and, like Freud in Civilization and Its Discontents, the socialized individual is defined by what is fobeidden him rather than what society stimulates him to do...[so that] implicit in his typology is a view of society as the enemy both of individuality and of basic drive gratification, a view that contrasts with the at least poentially benign role assigned it by neo-Freudian thinkers oike Fromm and Horney." (40)  [Note: This analysis I think fits with what Mead was hinting at in her review of Reisman and Whyte's book.]

-- He then moves on to othe rlesser-known contemporary sociologists, Hans Zetterberg and RAlf DDahrendorm, where he finds oversocialization acknowledged as a conceptual proposition, not true, but rather in the manner of the abstract idea of homo economicus in economics, an abstractiont that if taken seriously offers up powerful tools.  But here W objecst that sociology was partly born out of a respond in his undersanding to the oversimpliified and exagerated assumptions of nineteenth century theorists, 41-42.  W likes better Veblen, who criticized classical economics.  (42, bottom).

-- He acknowledged the rising interest in man as "role-player" and similarly dislieks it as overly simplistic and a kind of "ad-hoc" sociology.  (43).

-- IN a way that is vaguely similar to Sklansky (though only vaguely) he notes that in this idea of internalized values, there has been a total rejection of "material" and "sensual" satisfication.  "That material interests, sexual drives, and the quest for power have often been overestimated as human motives is not reason to deny their reality.  To do so its to suppress one term of the dialectic beteen conformity and rebellion, social norms and their violation, man and social order, as completely as th eother term is supressed by thos who deny the reality of an's 'normative orientation' or reduce it to the effect of coercion, rational calculation, or mechanical conditioning. "(44)

-- What W wants is a recognition that "in the beginning there is the body." This is nto a return to biological essentialism he says but a recognition of its impact.  He quotes JOhn Dollard on the fact that Freud did not see the "instincts as having a fixed social goal..." (45)  [Note: This Dolalrd quote may be good as a try to go back and tighten the relationship of Freud to my people...]

-- For Freud W says "man is a social animal without being entirely a socialized animal.  His social nature is itself the source of conflicts and antagonisms that create resistance to socailization by the norms of any of the socieites which have existed in the course of human history." (45)

-- W ends the essay nicely...callling essentially for a more complex psychology in sociology..and recognizing the way contemporary sociology and humans in general seek to  covered over the violence that society does to the humans' "drives":  "We must do better if we really wish to win credit outside of our ranks for special understanding of man, that plausible creature whose wagging tongue so often hides the despair and darkness in the heart." (46)

title: The Decline of the German Mandarins:  The German Academic Community, 1890-1933

title: The Naturalized Female Intellect
text:
p.214-216 Characterizing the female mind...

The earliest polemics against women focused on womens' moral qualities.  But Daston writes "because moral and intellectual virtues overlapped in early modern philosophy, debates over women's moral soften widened willy-nilly into debates over their intellect as well." (214)

Daston says that the "locus classicus for sex differences in all species during this period remained a passage from Aristotle's Historia animalum..." which she quotes at length on p.214-5.  She says that this passage "reverberated through centuries, indeed millennia, of European debate about the differences between male and female."  (215)  It set up a "polar opposition between complementary male and female intellect" that was not dissolved until the late nineteenth century (here she cites a 1989 paper of hers entitled: "Weibliche Intelligenz: Geschicthe Einer Idee...") The complementarity of thinking about male/female in Aristotle's though "structured early modern views about sex differences, even with respect to moral injuctions purportedly binding on all Christians.  Thus to vioalte the passive virtues, chief among them chastity, was the cardinal sin for women but merely a pecadillo for men; conversely, timidity was the most easily excused fault in women and the least in men." (215)

But besides this kind of polarity, there were also certain traits taht early-modern authors attributed to feminine intellect again drawing on Aristotle's claims in Historia animalium: "early modern philsopohers, jurists, theologians, and physicians generally agreed that women excelled in memory, ability to learn (where 'learning' was understood in the context of taming and therefore strongly assocaited with docility and pliability of character), cunning, and all aspects of mental mutability, including a quicksilver imagination and hair-trigger emotions.  Just as women were alleged to have less aptitude for the active virtues, such as courage, so they were also branded inferior to men in active intellect, including the exercise of speculative reason." (216)

These traits were "corporeally grounded" in "women's allegedly cold, moist bodily complexion.  Sensory impressions, stamped upon the brain as a seal upon wax, therefore ahered more easily, distinctly, and durably in the soft, humed female matter thanin that of the hot, dry male.  Hence women excelled in memory and also in imagination, for the same complexion was linked to mutalbe mental impressions--as well as to levity, capriciousness, deception, and more intense passions." (216)

title: Pathologies of the Social: the Past and Present of Social Philosophy
text:
General Notes 4/10:

* Marx has to make strong assumptions about "the structures of human self-realization" , ie about what humans are in essence, despite his attempt to formulate a structural account of capitalism's contradictory and crisis producing tendencies... (15)


* That said, he uses a sparse anthropological concept in his later work. He simply assumes that he can say things about the conditions that are necessary in order for self realization to occur. So he can do without a concept of alienation. This move is similar to the one Nancy is making. (15)

* End of the 19th, a new set of phenomena had emerged as sources of crisis, ie conformity, massifs cation, etc. (16)

* Nietzsche key to this analysis of crisis and also innovated a new form of cultural critique , and locating crisis there.(17)


* But N formulates his idea of the ethical standard differently than Rousseau, Hegel, or Marx. He does not universalize his sense of what constitutes self-realization. Rather,meh preserves it as a special life affirming ethical and cultural orientation possessed by an elite few with special  talents. This move had the effect Honneth says of revealing the ethical particular ism of earlier theorists too, so that Rousseau, Marx, and Hegel's theories began to look nonuniversal. This is Hnneth'a way I think of making a point that Megill makes with greater subtlety: that the idea of crisis was gradually exposed to an ironic critique that ultimately uprooted and parodied the idea of a cross account. (17)

* H says that all the founders of sociology were "convinced that modern society was threatened by a process of moral decline that would necessarily lead to server isorders in social reproduction." (18) We're the American sociologists so convinced of this? This is a rather flat statement.

* In modern sociology, characterized by Weber , tönnies, and Simmel, H thinks the problem became a loss of moral orientation produced by the transition from traditional to modern forms. Ths loss was te basis of a crisis that these thinkers imagined that sociology as a new modern science might solve. Pne can see how this formulation leads to Habermas...(18)

* N.b. or interesting that he notes it. The normative ethical critique of the way of life as alienation was submerged in the narrative that it drove... But this is Koselleck's point. And then what H says next that with Nietzsche the veil fell is related to what Megill argues. But H adds a sense here of the role of empirical sociology, and the need to substantiate historical claims in his,topical material. That led also to a filtering out of "nondescriptive" claims. (20)

* Two possible reactions to the problem of the lack of universals around 1920. 1. A tradition of philosophical anthropology, and 2. A new interest in historical-philosophy. (22)

* He traces two solutions that emerged from the philosophical anthroplogical position and the historical philosophical. Both involved attempts to overwhelm a crisis defined by the inability to base a normative view in universals. One started from the anthroplogical philosophical focus on  developing a general concept of the "human form" by going back to a "natural state" and the other by deducing it from history's endpoint. Two books characterize

* Two books representing these competing methods published the same year. Lukas's, History and Class Consciousness. And plessner's The Limita of a community. (23)

* Wow plessner's is awesome! 1. He built his theory upon an analysis of the organization of the human senses. From there he claimed that human's ability to take a "eccentric" position to oneself meant that there identity was non predetermined , I.e. in my language plastic, and this meant they need to engage in a degree of experimentation with multiple identities.  But "community" emphasized authenticityo and made such experimentation harder... (24)


* H's point is that this assessment was based on a "ethical assessment of human life aims, but was instead founded on an analysis of the normative conditions of identity formation." (24)


* Compared to Plessner, Lukacs historical-philosophical account cannot be scientifically or empirically tested.  That is because the claims are made in relation to an unrealized future time, (25)

* Spengler he says was also focusing on historical philosophical critique. (26)

* Then Nazism and fascism arrived and changed the focus of his tradition. (27)

* His note resting point here is that the analysis of capatilist modernization dropped to the background as a result and what came to the fire was an analysis that saw all social pathology as resulting from the condition that made fascism possible. The key node here is the Frankfurt school which with the rise of nazism left behind their historical-philosophical hopes for progress and put fascism at the center. dialectics of En
Ightenment made this possible. (27-28)

* H is critical of the Dialectics because it made a historical-philosophical critique by reference to an early moment of social pathology, ie technical rationalization, that then just plays itself out. History is just then a continuation of that process. They could not see things like legal freedom ,etc as what he calls real advancements. What ah misses here though is that they would have has answers to this critique, for example suspicion that these things were real,advancements. (30)

* H seems to prefer Arendt's analysis as more "modest" and closer to "reality" than Adorno and Horkeimer's. It has a greater interpretive power he thinks. It is closer to reality he seems to think because it examines the effect of technical rationality vv it's social effect of limiting the public domain as a practice necessary for individual self-realization. But what he thinks made it most powerful was that it focused attention on processes that clearly continued after the apex of fascism, and this he thinks made it influential. He thinks all participants of that period in social philosophy were influenced by her, from Habermas in his search for a communication free of domination, C. Taylor in his search for a "freedom guaranteeing public sphere, or Castoriadis' "idea of a revolutionary praxis...." (32)

* Indeed, in his analysis it has been clear that there is no single ethical framework. Some of the studies take a communitarian standard (Hegel, Durkheim, and Lukacs) and others an individualist ideal (Rousseau and Plessner). (36-37)

*  Given those differences, it should be noted that the common frame of reference for social philosophy is the "social living conditions of individuals." (37)  So the "formal concept of he good" that social philosophy uses is the "well-being" of individuals in terms of what is "socially feasible." (37)  The question then becomes how strong e critic imagines social forces to influence the individual, and based on this the analysis becomes either individualist or communitarian. (37)


* Moreover, these accounts make their normative claims either reference to a natural origin or a future moment end of history. But these methods did not emerge in social philosophy until after Nietzsche exposed the particularities basis of previous normative standards. (37-38)

* The problem with social philosophy that makes sharp ethical critiques is not the ethical critiques themselves but that these normative standards are understood as a universal condition when in fact the standards used can be traced to particular ideals. This is the condition that Nietzsche's critiques revealed. (36)

* H describes then that "a path of gradually radicalized doubt" emerged that ultimately undid also claims like this in Plessner or Lukacs to the critique that they were just ethically particular accounts. (38) That process would lead yultimately to the methodological question whether any "any social philosophical analysis" was not ultimately based in ethically particular standards. (38)

* Before hat happened though, one more effort was made in the 60s to lay out a critique based on anthropological assumptions. This was the case with Arendt's work and also a critique by Gehlen  that was "conservatively tinted" and based on his own anthropological work. (39) also Habermas took an empirical account of basic human interests as e basis for his critique of the technologization of the social world in order to give it a "universal foundation." (39) The common thrust of these accounts was that the "acceleration of industrial growth threatens a functionalrequirement of society that belongs to the most essential preconditions of all human life." (39)  but then from here Arendt, Gehlen, and Habermas draw different conclusions as to the specific social pathology produced. None of these accounts however refer to an originally state of humanity. He thinks they must have been shocked and challenged by Foucault's form of social philosophy that like Nietzsche's focused on power and expressed a distaste for universalism. (39)

* But then ultimatley Foucault's ideas do come to the fore. And this ultimately poses a problem to social philospohy as H has traced it in the article: "if, in accordance with its theoretical aim, social philosophy is dependent upon universal criteria whose validity can no longer be indirectly proven by a presupossed anthropology, then its continued existence is wholly contingent upon whether a formal ethics can be justified or not...The future of social philosophy today consequently depends on the possibility of giving a convincing justification of our ethical judgements concerning the necessary requirements of a good and well-lived human life." (40-41)

* He sees three possibilities here. 1) Procedurlization of ethics. Coming otu of Habermas this is the idea that one should view the problem of answering ethical questions as a "task of practical discourses..." i.e. as in law/justice. (41) This is a model the relies on the finding of consensus inside democratically organized contexts. 2) A second possiblity also laid out by Habermas in this Theory of Communicative Action is to use a striped-down anthropology--a "merely formal anthropology" not anchored in "universal pragmatics"--in order to establish a "critical threshold" for claims of social pathology. In Habermas' work just mentioned that has to do with establishing a point behyond which the "penetration of social systemtic imperatives into the social life-world must be regard as a social pathology." (41) Other examples can be found in Martha Nussbaum's writings  such as "human Actiuon and Social Justice" etc... see f.n. 70, and in Charles Taylor's wwork, esp. The Ethics of Authenticity and the Sources of the Self. 3) The third option which also comes out of an other approach laid out by Taylor (other than the #2 formal anthropology that is sparse) is a "historically relativized jsutification of ethics." (42) This involves a "hermeneutic reflection on the ethical values guiding modernity's understanding of itself...[that might lead to a ] insight into which social developmans are to be regarded as social pathologies." (42)  This approach he notes is most consistent with Foucault's intentions.

* The last possibility he seems to like, and he notes that i would not put the aim of social philosophy in question. But it would prevent claims from being made in "context-transcending way" (42). He ends the article by saying that the only way to preserve that kind of social philosophy is through formal anthropology... (42)

title: Verging on Etra-Vagance: Anthropology, Hisotry, Religion, Literature, Arts...Showbiz
text: (7) p. 39-41 Mead's unsettling dichotomies... Boon now has what seems to me a very good insight. He has noted Mead's "subjectivity" (38) now he asks whether this subjectivity which Belo characterizes as Mead's desire to see the dagger in the Balinese witch dance...as something "between a phallus and a baby." So Boon thinks this subjectivity may explain why Mead has provoked so many attacks on herself... He thinks that "Her Lebenswerk unsettled diverse dichotomies, thereby transgressing some identites that may be sacred to Pollmann, Freeman, and other ardent detractors or backers. Among them are male/female, humanist/scientist, journalist/scholar, single issueist/multiperspectivalist, gay/straight, curator/professor, homespun/globetrotter, therapist/relativist, matriarch/feminist, spouse/divorcee, Episcopalian/free-thinker, and various opposings of daughter/mother, grandmother, granddaughter. In such respects Mead's life and work indeed managed 'something between a phallus and a baby'--due cause continually to read her." (40)

title: Friedrich Albert Lange on Neo-Kantianism, Socialist Darwinism, and a Psychology Without a Soul
text:
General Notes 10/2012

#Thomas Teo, "Friedrich Albert Lange on Neo-Kantianism, Socialist Darwinism, and a Psychology Without a Soul" Journal of History of the Behavioral Sciences, v. 38, no.3 (Summer 2002): 285-301.

* Lange's bio: He was born 1828 and died 1875. Received his doctorate in phi8losphy in 1851 and finished his Habilitation in 1855 in philosophy and pedagogy at U. Bonn. He was active in the labor movement and was "reprimanded" for publishing pro-labor ideas in 1866, whereupon he moved to Switzerland. He bcame professor at the Univ. of Zuerich in 1870. He then reisgned during the Franco-German war due to the pro-French sympathies of the Swiss. He then returned to Germany and took a professorship at Marburg, where he staid until his death.(285-286)

* He published his most famous work, The History of Materialism and Criticsim of its Present Importance in 1866. It was translated into English and introduced by Bertrand Russell who called it a "monumental work of the highest value" (286) This was primarily a philosophical text but also did lay out his notion of "psychology without a soul" in the third section entitled Man and the Soul. He challenged "philosphical psychology" (metaphysics?) and tried to offer an alternative framework. Teo argues taht he had "outlined a program for an objective psychology nearly half a century before John B. Watson" and this was something that for exampl eTitchener (1914) acknowleded about Waton's point of view. (286) G. Stanley Hall also knew Lange's work and so did J.M. Baldwin.

* Teo argues that Lange's "programmatic ideas" "ammalgamated" "some of the most important worldviews of the ninteenth century..." (287) They were hesays "a sophisticated combiantion of Kantianism, Darwinism, and socialism" each of which helpd form waht Teo describres as his "antiphilosphical natural scientific pscyhology." (287)

* The first section of the article links Lange with Neo-Kantianism and the idea of psycho-physiological foundations. He starts with a description of Neo-Kantianism, which was he says an "enormously influential and yet divided intellectual movmeent of the ninteenth century". He cites a book by Koehnke (1991) called The Rise of Neo-Kantianism. He says it incouded a variety of exponents: "from natural scientists such as Hermann Helmholtz (1821-1894) or Ernst Mach (1838-1916) to cutlural scientist such as Wilhelm Windelband (1848-1915) or Wilhelm Dilthey (1833-1911). He suggests that the movement was ar esponse to "the fact that philosophers struggling with traditional philosophical topics required a firmer standing than what was provided by the speculative reasoning of Hegel's absolute idealism and systematic philosophical science." (287)

[But didn't Mach reject the subject/object distinction that was important for Kant!! Hacohen for example describes Mach as doing that in his bioraphy of Popper, p. 56.]

* Lange, he says, was the "father" of the Marbrug school of neo-Kantianism, which was generally very influential. Lange's successor at Marburg was Herman Cohen (1842-1918) "who outlined a philosphical justiifcation for Immanuel Kant's transcendental program..." in his Kants Theorie der Erfahrung (1871). Also Paul Natorp who published introdcutory works to neo-Kantianism and provided a specific interpreation of Plato. This "school" came to end when its "leading member" Ernst Casirer lost his professorship in 1933 and emigrated to the United States.

* Lange was among a grup of early neo-Kantians who "introduced a psycho-physiological foundatino for Kant's epistemology." (288) The idea here was that they believed that Kant's idea that came from his Critique of Pure Reason "suggested that human knowledge does not mirror external objects and events but that external events are modeled according to the human mind...", i.e. that "things-in-themselves are essentially unknowable butthat the human mind can nknow and under thier lawfull appearances"--they belived that this could be verified by scienc. E.g. physiologist Johnesses Mueller (1801-1858) "formulated that the mindis not cognizatn of objects and events inthe external world but of states of the nervous system." (288)

* Lange drew on Mueller but more on hermann Helmholtz. In 1855, Helmholtz gave a talk "on visual perception in Koenigsberg, where he provided a physiolgoical interpreation of Kant's theory fo knowledge." (288) Helmholtz concluded that kant's ideas were "still alive" and he denied that there was a difference between philosophy and natural science, ie that that difference only existed if one viewed philosophy as rooted in metaphysics, ie in the kinds of systems that were assocaited with Hegel and SChelling. (288) The essay was "On Human Visison" PUBLISHED IN (1903) IN Vortraege und Reden: Erster Band, pp.81-117.

* Lange believed that Helmholtz's research on the physiology of senses and perception refuted "spistemological materialism and supported a Kantian inspired epistemology." (288) But that epistemology did not rest on kant's intutiion and teh categories, but on the physiological mind that determines what people know. He wrote in 1887 that the "qualities that we perceive do not belong to the things but to our own organization..." (quoted on 288). He did not go so far as to doubt external reality or draw the conclusion that reality did not conform to natural laws. "The senses give us, as Helmholtz says, effects of things, not true picture nor things in themseles." (quoted on 288).

> What is the Body? What is Matter? What is the Physical? And modern physiology, just as much as philosophy, must answer that they are all only our ideas: necessary ideas, ideas resulting according to natural laws, but still never the things themselves." (Quoted on 289, from History of Materialism)

* There are then three more sections in this article. One deals with his critiques of other psychologists--the point here being mostly that he suspects various thinkers--especially phrenologists--as being seduced by a kind of metaphyics, whathe calls in a quote on p. 290 a "metaphysical whirlpool, which in our country at that time mastered even him wh ostruggled against it..." (290) He liked Wundt and Fechner a bit more.

* He himself put forward a notion of a "psychology without a soul" that Teo describes from 291-294. It's here that Lange is contributing to a push toward what Teo  earlier called an "objective psychology" -- or somethign moving toward Watson's behaviroims. Lange was here militating against the psychologicalmethod of using "introspection" -- and one can see here too the hostility to metaphyics. He advocatedinstead the "observation of others" (and I wondered here if Boas might have moved from this to his participant observation). (292). And he thought that human psychology could draw much from animal pscyhology. (293).

* Finally, in the last two section Teo looks at Lange's response to Darwin. He liked Darwina nd thought it would produce interesting lines of psychological research. He accepted that humans had devleoped from animal origins. And he accepted notions of race, and even higher and lower civilizations, but he was opposed to readings of race and darwin that justified European colonialism. He also didn't believe that competition for resources defined human existince. He believed that humans at some poitn --and this sounds like Kroeber -- suspended the laws of selection that Darwin described. So there was bascially here the kernel of a kind of progressive and socialist reading of Darwin that Lange and according to a study by Weingart, Kroll, and Bayertz (1988) was developed  in the 1860s... (295) (294-end).

title: Narratives of enlightenment: cosmopolitan history from Voltaire to Gibbon
text:
Notes Feb 2011:

Introduction

* The work examines five 18th century historians whose goal O'Brien says was to "tranform their reader's sense of national self-awareness through the writing of narrative history." The historians are Voltaire, David Hume, Gibbon, often grouped together she says; and then also William Robertson, a Scottish hsitorian of Scotland, and David Ramsay, a skeptical patriot hsitorian of the Am. Revoluition. (1)

* Her argument does not present a teleological examination of the rise of "an Enlightenment meta-narrative of progress."  (1)  And it is not a study of "authorial influence."  (1)  What she wants to do she says is examine "the play of a cosmopolitan sensibility in each of these works across the political certainties, cultural self-understandings and national prejudices which structured contemporary readings of the past."  (1) 

* The cosmopotitan sensibility that these authors shared she says represented a "cosmopolitan (rather than universalist) recognition that all nations are endowed with valid histories and identities which intersect with, and complete, each other, but that individual states or nations are not, in themselves, intelligible units of historical study." (1-2).  All of the authors she says were commited to "an ideal of Europe as a harmonious system of balancing states." (2)

* She thinks (but is she right in 1997) that the term cosmopolitanism has gone out of favor among intellectual historians because "as an idea, it seems to lack intellectual content; as a category of political thought, it has no referent." (2)  She says that Schlereth's The Cosmpolitan Ideal in Enlightenment Thought (1977) was the last examination of the idea.  (But where is the engagement with all the new writing on cosmopoltianism in the 1990s???)

*  She says she is "reviving" the term because of "it simultaneously encapsulates an attitude of detachment towards national prejudice..., and an intellectual investment in the idea of a common European civilisation." (2)  (But why is this interesting???  Does seh see this useful vv the EU projcet or what??)

* She says that her thinkers exhibit something like what Rorty taked about in refutation of Lyotard's accusation that cosmpolitanism containned the embedded wish for domination of the Europe, namely a "cosmopolitanism without emancipation."  In the works of her writers, this involves a "philosophically informed and politically principled skepticism twoards the grand narratives of their..." (10)  So rather than containing a teleology of European domination in history what she thinks her thinkers have in common is a "descriptive model for the history of Europe through separately periodized, ancient, medieval, and dearelz modern and enlightened modern stages."  (10-11)

title: "How Common Culture Shapes the Separate Lives": Sexuality, Race, and Mid-Twentieth-Century Social Constructionist Thought
text:
Meyerwotiz examines what she sees as the "conjuncture of race and sex in the culture-and-personality vision..." (1058)  She puts this in a historiographical context--noting that there are two standard "metanarratives" of race and sex that "disregard the significant overlap in the mid-twentieth-century intellectual histories or race and sexuality." (1060)  The history of race tends to highlight the work of the Boasians; the examination of sexuality and specificially homosexuality tends to focus around the history of psychology.  The history of cultural relativism vis-a-vis race tends to have a "liberal" political valuence, empahsizing tolerance, but the history of pscyhology shows a different political valence--a tendnecy to see homosexuality as a kind of pathology.  Meyerowitz sees a lot more overlap and the culture-and-personality school is a nexus in which this occurred: Freudian thought was brought together with the cultural relativism of the Boasians.

Meyerowtiz then traces the tension between openness to sexual variation esp w/ regard to homosexuality in the work of Mead and Benedict, and then Otto Klineberg, Ashley Montagu, Abram Kardiner, and the looks at the resurrection of Bendict's ideas in the postwar era...   I

At the end, she has a section "Rethinking the Histories or Race and Sexuality."  She makes a good point here.. She asserts acccurately that if you look at the intellectual history of sexuality and race you see "the ongoing tension between a cultural relativism that situated socially constructed difference primarily as variance and a concept of abnormality that situated socially constructed difference primarily as pathology." (1083)  Then of course she restates her point that the histories of race and sexaulity are not separate.  "The culture-and-personality scholars used Freudian psychoanalysis to understand race as well as sex, and they used Boasian relativism to understand sex as well as race." (1083)  Then also she thinks this helps to see how social constructivism helped generate new "regimes for managing populations."  Continuining, she say:

The now-standard histories of race and seuxality in the mid-twentieth-century United States suggest that social scientists promoted racial integration and intergroup cooperation (whcih some of them indeed did).  But the history of the cutlure-and-personality nexus highlights a larger biopolitical agenda.  The live-and-let-live, let's-be-tolerant message of cultural relativism came conjoined fromthe start with prescriptions for change at home and abroad.  Most of the culture-and-personality scholars called unabashedly for 'social engineering,' some of them reinscribed conventional boundaries dividing 'normal' from 'pathalogical,' and others turned toward a functionalist vision in which they repudiated biologism but nonetheless endorsed adjustement to the mainstream satus quo.  On issues of race, sexuality, and more, the culture-and-personality schlars often translated social and economic injustice into issues of mental health.  Most ambitiously they sometimes imagined the wholesale restructuring of the personalities, behavior, and traits of various groups, subgroups, communiteis, and nations. (1084)

Then she ends the artcile by suggesting that these ideas were put to practical use in multiple domain, which she lists... on 1084.

This article is good; it is pointing in exactly the right direction I think.  I brought together the histories of race and sexaulity in my last chapter, but I did so in order to draw out a more specific model of selfhood and liberal agency in Mead and Benedcit's thought.  My analysis is more complex but lacks the historiographical awareness that Meyerowitz has laid out here and which is excellent.  Her point that there was this tension between the impulse to reimpose conventional boudnaries and the openning up implied by cultural relativism is apt and it is borne out in my analysis of Sapir in particular...if not also Mead...

Does this article make the point I was making in ch.4 but better, or how woudl I position myself in realtion to the points Meyerowitz has made?  Well, for one I haven't really looked deeply into the culture-and-personality school in ch.4.  That is really about a moment that ocmes before, so the question would be what would I find if I look at the culture-and-personality stuff, keeping in mind the questions I have about the fate of the concern for individaul agency that I claim to exist in my dissertation up through the discussion of sexuality... One important point that this article raises is that I need to make a much bigger point of the profession's shift toward pscyhology in the late 20s early 30s.  See p.1061 where she describes this shift...esp re.  Sapir's articles... ACtually, she doesn't really describe it very thoroughly within the context of the proefssions' shifting focus...

The problem w/ Meyerowitz article is that her definitions of the political alternatives on either side is a bit shallow.  The liberalism of cultural relativism is simply the "live-and-let-live, let's-be-tolerant message of cultural relativism" and on the other side it's just "adjustment to the mainstream status quo."  (1083-4)  I can provide a more rigorous definition of the political stakes here vis-a-vis the categories of selfhood and agency esp. if I define these categories well and tie them into modern liberal political theory...

Section 1 - The Concept

Def'n of autonomy.   It puts "moral weight on an individual's ability to govern herself, independent of her place in a metaphysical order or her role in social structures and political institutions ..."

The concept is a "modern development" and so it is also "very much at the vortex of the complex (re)consideration of modernity."

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text:
p.200-  Last Section differentiating Mead and Benedict

Says Mead wanted to develop a "more properly morphological theory involving a variable and limited structural set of contrasting, internally or dialectically related forms." (201)

Benedict never detailed what the conflicts the deviant would encounter when she wrote in Patterns: "when the homosexual response is regarded as a perversion...the invert is immediately exposed to all the conflicts to which aberrants are always exposed."  (p.265 in patterns.  202)  

Mead defined these conflicts arefully and in the squares and she "set emotional predispositions ...against the entor of society and social expectations." (202)

title: Franz Boas, Geographer, and the Problem of Disciplinary Identity
text:
Summarial Note:  

Koelsch's overall argument here is that Boas's dedication to geography in the Humboldtian-Ritterian tradition which he got from Theodore Fischer among others has been underestimated in asessing Boas's professional "identity." 

Koelsch's argument is that Boas turned to ethnography b/c he lost the battle to define ethnography in terms of "his own German-derived, neo-Kantian 'cosmographical' reinterpretation of human geography" to the physiographic approach of other geographers such as Davis.  Koelsch writes that "Davis won the geography wars, but in so doing left Boas a clear field.  As he repackaged his background and recent research studies into a new human sicnece, Boas was both to draw on the German human geographic tradition and to profit from the fact that American geographers did not." (19)

Koelsch's argument in convincing.  He gathers a lot of evidence from archives and from existing accounts, esp. by Cole, that suggests that boas' commitments to geogrpahy were stronger than has been previously noted.  But Koelsch does not really draw out within Boas' thinking and writing the tension between this empahsis on geography and the specific meaning of a turn toward anthropology/ethnography.  That part lies beyond his paper chronologically speaking, so he never really explains what then happened to Boas's cosmographic approach.  How for instance did this merge into Boas's diffusionism?

title: With science as his shield: Teaching race and culture in American public schools, 1900--1954
text: p. 003-4 On the way "culture" was translated into curriculum "With the help of anthropological texts like Races of Mankind, racial discourse in American schools underwent a paradigm shift during the brief span of the Second World War. The most significant part of this transformation was the introduction of the scientific concept of race, as delineated by anthropologists Franz Boas, into American teachers' everyday language. This anthropological definition of human raqce not only narrowed the boundaries of who was identified as a racial minority, but also introduced a new concept--culture--to explain the diversity of human life on Earth. However, as this dissertation shows, public school teachers modified the anthropological concepts of race and culture as they translated these ideas into practice in American schools. The results of this modification were themselves multifaceted and complex. For exmaple, some teachers employed the anthropological definition of human race to challenge racism and social inequality in America, thereby creating some of the most critical antiracist pedagogy o f the twentieth century. Unfortunately, this critical antiracist pedagogy was more the exceptoin than the rule. Most teachers simply translated an essentialist understanding of human 'race' into a softer language of 'culture' that continued to stigmatize minority individuals according to the supposedly natural or inherent characteristics of their group. Throughout this dissertation, I show how educators constructed culture as a foil to race that recase the most damaging aspects of early twentieth century racialisti thinking into a more acceptable, but equally reductionist, discourse of cultural diversity." (3-4)

title: Object Lessons and Ethnographic Displays: Museum Exhibitions and the Making of American Anthropology
text:
00 Summary Note

Jenkens basically critiques museum exhiition practices of US anthropologists, accusing both Boas' predecessors at the BAE and Boas of relying upon a form
of presentation that relied upon techniques of objectification and classification that acted as a subsitution for the object's original context.  His critique of Boas relies heavily upon a theoretical langauge that he takes from an essay but Eugenio Donato called "The Museum's Furnace: Notes toward a Contetual REading of Bouvard and Pecuchet".  and this critique is on pp. 168-170.  Intreestingly, Jenkens critique of the exhibitions of the Washington antropologists is rooted in a connection he sees between the emergence of bureaucratic hierarchies and the systematic way in which they attempted to organize materials. Jenkins notes that massive proliferation of natural history museum in the latter half of the ninteenth-century (244) Then he links these to professionalization: E.g.: 

"The late-nineteenth-century museum exhibition thus defined a new physical space devoted to display, a space in which objects, facts, and images could be arranged and rearranged into pattterns and classificatory shcemes and in which th epublic could be entertained and educated by means of the world's specimens....Although museum collections genreateda a new and increasingly cumbersome body of knowledge, they simultaneously genreated new experts to colect, interpret organize, and display that knowledge." (248)

Then in a section on th emuseum practices of BAE anthropologsts (249-256) he really tries to give a sense of the systematizing and bureaucratic practices of the anthropologists, and more deeply to describe the homogenizing effects of their systematizing techniques as "semiotic homogeneity" i.e. allowing a wookd cut or lithograph to stand in for an object , say a Kachina doll.  Eveyrthing then reduced to the same size.  (see 254).  Notes also that Between 1894 and 1895 15,000 objects were catalogued and 650 labels prepared.  (255)  These homogenized object then to be presented behind the "clearest of glass".  249.   The purpose of these displays also was to provide a broady survey of evolutionary social processes see e.g. quote about Dorse on 249 and 256-7.  

When it ocmes to Boas, though, he asserts a continuum and not a break as Boas thought it was.  Boas emphasizes "life-world" models but Jenkins sees this as just another form of classification that asserts the object as a stand-in for a "whole" culture.  What's more Jenkins' notes that Boas wanted to subordinate objects to the extensive labels and texts that would accompany them.  "By thus assigning priority to discursive langauge, to labels and texts, Boas was already caught up in a classificatory scheme which, as part of the emergence of late nineteenth-century collections world-wide, 'challenged the preminence of emotive, nonverbal forms of experiencing objects, as was the case with the wonder cabinets, and favored the more disciplinary langauges concerned with authenticity, connoisseurship, provenance and patronage that drew some closure on knowledge.'" (267, he's quoteing an article by Carol Breckenridge on "The Aesthetics and Politics of Colonial Collecting..." here.)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism

title: A History of Philosophy in America, 1720-2000
text:
General Notes

 

Pt. 1 Speculative Thought in America, 1720-1868

* Three "components" of dialogue that was participated in by "philosphers" in America:

1) The parish ministers, esp. in New England, who dominated and were part of a conversation among religious elites in Scotland, England, and Germany.  They were not connected to institutiosn of higher education, so he has "sometimes" called them "amateurs." (1)  They exponded a variety of Calivinist Protestantism.  Jonathan Edwards was key, but also Horace Bushnell and Ralph Waldo Emerson, though he and Bushnesll were opearting at "a time whe such thinekrs were deserting their congregations and turning away from traditional Protestant doctrine." (1) 

2) The seminaries in the Northeast and the old Midwest and South.  These were institutions training a professional ministry and unconnected to colleges.  Key figures were Leoanrd Wood of Andover Theological Seminary, Henry Ware of Harvard Diviinity School, Nathaniel William Tay.or of the Yale Divinity School, Chalres Hodge of the Princeton Theological Seminary, and Edwards Amasa Park of Andover... (1) These theologians "controlled the major power bases in the nineteenth century.  They trained the ministers and determined much of what was published.  Their outlook tended to be more narrow and sectarian than taht of those speculative thinkers who were not professors of diviningn..." (2)

3) The "philosphers": these were men who held chairs in mental, moral, or intellectual philosophy at the American colleges of the ninteenth century, colleges which were ""small, sleepy institutions, peripheral to the life of the nation." (2) These philosophers were also ministers and committed Protestants.  "but in addition to showing that reason was congruent with faith they also studied the grounds of the social order and politics, and commented on the affairs of the world.  Their libraries were inadequate, their education mediocre, and the literary culture in which they lived sentimental and unsophisticated."  (2)  They were men like Francis Bowen of Harvard, James McCosh of the College of New Jersey (Princeton), and NOah Porter of Yale. 

1. Calvinism and JOnathan Edwards

* In the 17th century and into the 18th, ministers dominated New England and some of the New Hampshire towns.  They followed the Calvinist "federal" or "convenant" theology.  The idea behidn this theology was that God had created two convenants with humans: the first was that that Adam and Eve violated, and the second, represented by the coming of Christ, revelaed taht "if individuals had faith in Jesus, they would be redeemed.  God knew, the Calvinists argued, that people would continue to sin and would never merit salvation.  They would never be obedient as they could have been before teh Fall, but they could recognize their wickedness,and could be saved by God's grace, his mercy or goodness.  The central event in the Christian life was the gift of grace.  by a supernatural act, God infused sinners with a consciousneess of his glory and love, and enabled tem to turn from the idolatry of self.  Grace mysteriously transformed human selfishness and overwhelmed and humbled Christians." (6)

* Within this tradition the American "federal" theology was a variant of the version of Calvinism as defined by the Dutch Synod of Dort (1618-1619).  The synod defined the heresy of Arminianism, after Jacob Arminius: this was the idea that the sinner could respond to the giving of grace "to do good or eviil as they chose." (6) The synod declared that humans were depaved and could not merit salvation voluntarily.  So they rejected the idea that the sinner could "regulate grace." (6)  But, in New England, in America, the ministers emphasized that the dsinner had to "prepare" to receive grace--an issue that was "entangled with issues of clerical authority and church membership." (6)  Kuklick briefly traces that discussion on 6-8. He sums it up: "From the mid-eighteenth until the end of the nineteenth century the central issue for American thinkers was the connection of God's supremacy to human freedom.  God did not author sin and was not to be blamed for the failure of the covenant of works.  He was still almighty and causally sovereign.  Although God gave faith and was to be praised for the covenant of Grace, people were answerable for their own salvation." (8) 

* Then he introduces Jonathan Edwards who he says "came of age in this speculative world." (8) Edwareds born in 1703 in East Windsor Connecticut, son of  an important minister and grandson on his mom's side of the revivalist preacher Soloman Stoddard.  Edwards spent time at Yale College wehre a library acquired from Jeremiah Dummer, the Dummer Collection, contained important books of European 17th century thought that he absorbed including Newton, and Locke's Essay concerning Human Understanding (1690).

* Summarizing Locke v Descartes: Conventional idea is that Locke successfully challenged Descartes.  Both were metaphysical dualists: ie believed in two sorts of substances: mind and matter.  And both were "representational realists" "form whom knowledge3 of material substances was mediated through the mind." (9)  But for Descartes there were certain innate ideas, whereas Locked believed that the mindlacked andy innate ability to "cogitate, a priori, on the nature of things and could not arrive at truths about the world by itself.  The mind for Locke was only the medium in which the momentarily given presented itself.  Knowledge came from the immediate contents of the mind, called phneomena, experience, or discrete ideas." (9)  Locke, then, was an empiricist and urged "Newtonian-like observations as the basis of knowledge," whereas Descartes the mind itself could serve as the basis of knowledge. (8-9)

* Locke's ideas ultimately have ultimately come to signify for us an anti-absolutist position.  This was so for contextual reason and because of how Locke was read.  Kuklick point to two interpretations by Bishop George Berkeley and David Hume.  Berkeley argued against the idea of underlying matter or material substance by 1) arguign that Locke could not distinguish between primary and secondary qualities (ie between primary qualities like solidity and extension and secondary like taste and color) and 2) he modified Locke's notions of two sorts of ideas sensation and reflection, stating that sensations of the outer world were God's ideas that were imposed on humans and over which they had no control; they could only control reflections which were just weaker copies of God's ideas.  The latter "emanated" from humans and were finite.  Berekely thus became known as an "idealist" for his focus on minds and their contents, and his denial that sensation reflected an outside material wrold.  On the flip side, David Hume aruge dthat all innate wideas, both human and divine, were illegitimate.  "he contrued the mind itself as a seires of ideas"  cobbled together from the disjointed phonemana of experience. Ie "Practical belief was based on subjective impressions and good only so far as we could comfortably act on it." (10) 

* But in the world of the 18th century Edwards would have encountered Locke's ideas in a discourse dominated by philosohpers in the Cartesian tradition and the writings of English "idealists" who were reacting to Locke and Descarte's dualism.  Such thinkers were not blind to the developments of science but even Newton had suggested that "physica described the immaterial structure of God's will working incessantly." (10) Therefore the new science did not need to be read as "implying materialism, uncertainty, or skpeticism but rather as asserting the primacy of midn." (10)  In this context, Kuklick argues, that Locke could be read as not comforting rationalists but many of his ideas could be "controverted, redefined, or given a religious interpretatino." (10)  He was important to Edwards.

* Indeed, Edwards built from Locke and anti-materialist philosophy.  At first he accepted Locke's primary and secondary distinction.  He found in Locke's belief that "the primarcy qualities of matter inhered in the small, hard atomic particles of the Newtonian universe", god.  He conceived such particlesa s centers of energy that were an exertion of God's power.  Edwards wrote: "[T]he substance of bodies as last becoming either nothing, or nothing but the deity acting in that particular manner in those parts of space where he thinks fit.  So that, speaking most strictly, there is no proper substance but God himself..." (quoted on 11).  So in the idea of "solidity" (what Locke saw as a primary quality in the material world) Edwards found an external world, outside the midn's of humans, which was a manifestation of God's power and will.  At first, he accepted the dualist world and the represenational theory, seeing secondary qualities of things as existing only in the mind, but then he moved beyodn this position to argue that both existed outside the mind and were part of the structure of the world created by God's mind.  People directly knew these qualities. (11-12)  Unlike Berkeley, he treated reflective ideas not as "finite" or weak, but as simply fragments of god's ideas.  (12)  Thus essentially Edwards denied both dualisms: the dualism of Locke's between sensation and reflection, and the dualism of Berekeley between God's ideas and it's weaker finite versions in human ideas.  He didn't reject the "felt" difference, but said that the difference was based on two ways of knowing "One way was the world minds knew,; the other way was the minds knowing the world." (13) ?? 

* In his sectionon Edward's book Religious Affections, Kuklick makes some of this more clear.  In particular, he describes Edwards as an empiricist who beleived that experience coveyed the supernatural: e.g. an "experimental Calvinist." (18)  Here too it becomes easier to understand, how Edwards thought connected to the New England Calvinist emphasis on preparation for grace and the way that Edwards handled dualism.  In his account of how God gave grace, Edwards saw Grace as God allowing humans to have a new simple idea, ie a new way of knowing.  (17)  There was a degree of salvation available in reading the Bible.  The Bible provided somethign like a "notional" knowledge of god's plan, but this was different than the more full, simple, and complete form of knowing that one attained after having received God's grace.  Kuklick describes the difference as that between "knowing that honey was sweet and actually experiiencing honey's sweet taste..." (18) 

* Edward's notion of Freedom is laid out 21-24.  Basically, Edward's says that humans have freedom, but that that freedom has no real efficacy.  Volitional activity for Edwards was simply an impulse to act based on a momentary perception of the way the world was.  He distinguished between extternal will and internal will.  Human will never caused anything to happen in the world, only God's effcient will, which was part of the external world, did that.  Sometimes, however, God linked internal human will/volition to external behavior.  It was up to God, i other words, to connect the will with what followed.  Kuklick explains: "If one billiard ball hit as econd, the second moved away from the first.  God established a regular order that licenced the inference that the first caused the movement of the second.  But the only efficient cause was God's will in action, cause the second to move after it contacted the first." (24)  In relation to human morality, it could be said that a selfish will would sin, but that tthat was true, did not mean that a selfish will would sin; that was determined by God's efficient cause. Ie It was up to god to poruce "a given wolitionon the occasion of a preceding volition." (24)

2. Philosophy and Politics

* This chapter is an attempt to take stock of the relationship between philosophy and philosophers and political theory and political statesmen in U.S. history.  Kuklick's claims are very broad (!) and I think problematic.  His basic ideas is that there wasn't  much of a relationship at all.  So he says: "The central point of this chapter is that whatever the substantive connection, the sensibility of the theologians of Edwards's lineage differed fundamentally from that of the politicians." (27) And again a bit later: "The fact is that the scholar has to look for explicit theological, and sometimes even religious, ideas in the work of the Found Fathers and their political opponents, and has to look for distinctive Calvinist expressions of support for, or opposition to, the new politics."  Ie. the idea is that these two worlds were mostly separate (which I find hard to believe!).  To support for example he points to the statement by Franklin at the General Congress in Philadelphia in 1787 where the Coinstituion was framed, which he has introduced as a high point in Enlightenment philosophizing from the point of view of natural rights philosophy, that the idea of starting each session with prayer was ruled out because "The Convention, except for three or four persons, thought Prayers unnecessary." (33)  Similarly, he quotes John Addams, saying that no good "effect" could come of mixing the "sacred character with that of the Statesman." (quoted on 34).  And also then his account of the theologians/philosophers tendency to establish a hierarchy of goals, onklty trying their hand at political problems when they'd solved general philsophical dabates (34-35). 

* A key point of difference here was the way the statesmen, due to their enlightenment views, viewed the relationship of God to the world.  They were Desists, they believed that God had made the world according to a certain design, and then had retreated.  Unlike in the theology/philosophy of Edwards, where God was the sole and ongoing efficient cause in the world, the Deists did not think that God was involved in the world and what happened in it. (29-29)

* An interesting point of analysis here, however, is his brief summary of Benjamin Franklin's early Dissertation on Liberty and Necessity, Pleasure and Pain, which he notes deploys an argumentt about moral determination that has a similar structure to Edwards's, but which Franklin rejected entirely later in his life, finding that it did not account for his own moral feelings... (35-37). 

* The broadest historiographical claim that Kuklick makes here is to say that this separation in philosophy and politics had a an enduring mark on philosophy generally in the United States, i.e. that American philosophy has always been marked by deep interest in mwetaphysics and priorities of "speculative reason" above political theory. He event says that Dewey, Marcuse, and Rorty exhibit this tendency!  He describes these thinekrs as influenced by German organicism and begrudgingly admits that they have some "claims" to being seen as political theorists: "Even in the political evaluations of those philosophers later guided by German organicism--the St Louis Hegelians, Josiah Royce, John Dewey, Herbert Marcuse, and Richard Rorty--the prorities of speculative reason were substantial, although this group had claims to be considered, in my usage, political theorists and not political philosophers." (35)

3. Theological Disputes

*  This chapter is dealing with disputes in theological/philosophical circles after Edwards' death.  There was the "New Divininity"--a body of thought developed by Joseph Bellamy, Samuel Hopkins, Nathaniel Emmons, Jonathan Edwards (the younger), and timothy Dwight that refined Edwards' theology.  The New Divinity influenced liberal religious thought in Boston in the early 1800s, and this liberal thoguht overthrew the old Calvinism at Harvard in the early 1800s.  Kuklick sketches the "social context" on 39-40.  The new movement he summarizes on 40 arose int he aftermath of the Great Awakening as American Calvinism "factionalized".  Liberals in Boston drifted away from the old Calvinism toward Unitarianism, causing controversy.  But the main opposition to the New Divinity came from the "Old Calvinists" who were known for a lack of interest in theological doctrine, and thus had little interest in philosophy.  They though tthe New Divinity elevated theory above "strong orthodox community."  (41)  This resistance achieved its greatest success in the Second Great Awakening.  (40-41).

4. Collegiate Philosophy, 1800-1868

* This chapter is about the development of a philosophical tradition after the decline of the dominance of theology -- ie the development of philosophy as something independent from philosophy, as opposed to a tool used to resolve theological disputes (cf Edwards notion of the relationship between philosophy and theology...which was that theology proposed the design, and philosophy a way to resolve certain theological problems...Kuklick explains this somewhere in his section on Edwards...)

 

* Philosophy as its own thing got it's start "as the Princeton divines struggled to free themselves from New Divinity, and examined epistemology as means to support their ideas of religioius virtue." (58)  Here by the early 19th century, the growing number of colleges provided a venue for this development.  To the old colleges in the east, there were added new colleges in the south and midwest.  The first philosophy was written by professors whose primary goal was to provide "their pupils  with a moral sense of their place in the world." (58)  They attempted to do so in textbooks for their students and it is in these textbooks that philosophy as an indepednent thing had its start. (58). 

* Meanwhile, the tehologians did not like writing textbooks; thus it was the "[d]ivines and not the metaphysicians that wrote the scholarlly monographic literature in the nineteenth century." (58).  Essentially, at the American "ivory towers" the divines/theologians "catered more and mroe to advanced ministerial students and said little to peple outside graduate classrooms." (59)  And they were more and more contemptous of the changes in European thought...thus gradually lost vigour. (59) 

* Ultimately then Philosophy was more recognizably "modern".  -- dealing openly with Hegel and Mill...and not Calvin alone.  So "As colleges gradually claimed the guardianship of the character of the upper-class youth, seminaries became more elevated above, and thus isolated from, ordinary life.  the college philosophers, frequently also the presidents of their institutions, gained recognition as intellectual spokesmen in their communities.  These men inculcated into their pupils the domianavt values of the various local collegiate cultures. ..."

* Scottish philosophy of Thomas Reid and Duglad Steward was influential and processed in one set of textbooks that the philosphers produced.  These textbooks abbreviated for their students the arguments contained with Thomas Reid's Essay on the Intellectua...and Active Powers, and Dugald Stewart's Philosophy of the Human Mind and The Active Moral Powers.  The philosophers divided philosophical questions into two categories: intellectual or mental philosophy and moral philosophy.  The former included epistemology, metaphysics, and logic; the latter included ethics and social science viewed normatively and dealt with the "active" faculties of emotions and the will.  (60)  In the first categorty is where Scottish realism came in.  Reid and Stewart critiqued classicial empricism (see 8-9), arguing that the "date of experience were not the ideas of classical empiricism but judgements accompanying sensations."
