(60).  The idea of this "common sense" realism of Stewart's was that our mind was so constituted that in "sense perception" our minds actually contacted the external world and provided real knowleddge of the world.  Ie "Sensation implied the qualities of objects; perception of the world accompanied sensory experience."  (60)  American philosophers, Kuklick says, tied the Scottish realist view to a "belief in Locke's greatness and the poverty of 'metaphysical' speculation." (60) They thought that Locke's empiricism, use of an inductive method, and rliance on sensory evidencew as good, but critiqued his "representational realism" -- ie the idea that knowledge of the world is mediated by the mind, see 9, top.  By restricting knowledge to the mind int his way, they thought (in some ways like Reid and Stewart) that Locke's thought led to either the "idealism" of Berkeley or the skepticism of Hume.  Kuklick says the Americans read Locke as someone who meant to adopt presentationalism, i.e. presumably the idea that there can be direct unmediated knowledge of the world.  They believed that the Scottish realists had corrected Locke and clarified the tradition of British empiricism.  (60)  In other words, for Locke sensations--like smell, color, etc--were in the mind in response of the nervous system to external sensory input (see p.8).  For the Scottish realists, these qualities that were perceived were not solely in the mind; rather the mind perceived these qualities in the objects more or less accurately.  Kuklick explains the American variants on this by Witherspoon, Levi Frisbie, and Francis Bown on 60-61. 

* In addition to this "presentational theory of knowledge," the Americans also developed a theory of science based in the scientific thought of Francis Bacon.  Before the dominance of Edwards' thought had allowed "theorizing to dominate science," but now the idea of learning about the world through careful observation and carefully forming laws became dominant.  But these laws ony sought to explain the observed.  ie science int his way "codified ordinary experience. (62)  This science could provide an argument for God: ie the existence of design in the observed world. So Baconian scientists believed that science led to religious understanding. (62)lt

* Then in the 19th century also, Kuklick says it was "understood" that empiricism had led to skepticism (ie not in the Us but elsewhere).  This is where Kant comes in.  He tried to settle "competing claims about knowledge intended to secure knowledge in the world of experience but simultaneously to avoid dogmatism about any supra-experiential realm." (62)  Kuklick summarizes his argument on 62-63. 

* He then explains that Kant and the Scottish realists had something in common, namely their critique of Hume's skepticism (and nihilism).  For this link see 64. 

* By the 1830s, Kuklick says "German thought" ie metaphysical thought was making inroads into the United States.  So then it also becomes important to emphaszie that there were disagreements between Kant and the Scottish realists, despite their shared distaste for Humean skepticism.  The Scottish realists believed that what Kant called the noumenal world of things in themselves could be known, but for Kant the answer was no.  Hamilton adjuticated this quarrel Kuklick says ont he British side and was influential in the US.  He fused Kant and Locke in a way.  (64-65).  Through Hamilton, moroever, the Americans philosphers essentially began to shift toward metaphysics, to lose their certainty about the real world. Kuklick explains this on 65-72.  One example, that relied on the thought of Hamilton is the thought of Yale Porter at Harvard that Kuklick explains on 66-67.  Then also the American philosophers move also beyond Hamilton.  By 1840s, Kiklick says they begin to accept Kant's transcendental ideas but without noting the limits that Kant had placed on thought.  (70).  The argumenta bout this tendency is key to Kuklick's larger point that American philosophers have been heavily influenced by metaphysics coming from Germany.  But he qualifiees the claim in an interesting way when he says: "The Americans were not extravagantly metaphysical.  Scottish realism protected them from skepticism and allowed them to enter the world of spirit."  He points out that as the challenges of materialism increased, the philosophers turned toward metaphysics, drawing on Hamilton's putting of "matter beyond deity."  (72)  But they were not willing, he says, to "embrace another metaphysics" and defend it. (72)  He uses Porter again to say that he insisted that the univer "was thoe thought of an individual thinker, fraught with design and including the originaation of forces (matter) and their laws."  (72)  Thus he "stumbled into absolute idealism" and also "pressed Scottish thought to its limits." (72)  Kuklikc says that he's a key example of the "growing discomfort among academic philosophers with the ability of realism to reconcile science and theology." (72)


5.  Innovative Amateurs, 1829-1867

* Kuklick argues that the really creative thought "that would preserve nineteenth-century speculation" was done by what he calls "amateurs" people "at the periphery of the educational system." (75) These thinkers, K says, searched for a vision of the world "less constricted" than what the philosophers and theologians were developing.  He traces five of their strategies: James Marsh, President of Univ. of Vermont's use of Kant to ground a new "philosophy of religion" that would push "New England Theology" in a lesss "intellectualist" direction; Emerson's Transcendetnalism; Horace Bushnell's (Connecticut) grappling with German ideas in a way that moved twoard Hegel; John Williamson Nevein's appropriation of Hegel in Mercesrsburg, in a German reformed seminary in W. Pennsylvania; and finally a group of Hegelians in St. Louis.  (75)

(Not taking as detailed notes here... for the moment)

* Summing up the relationship of the different strategies on 82, K writes: "March applied German speculation to American theology.  Emerson and his followers concentrated on the distinction between nature and spirit and the symbolic aspect of spiritual language.  This focus, along with Emerson's disdain for systematic thought, led him, unlike Marsh, to chart a new career as an American man of letters...."  (82)  This difference meant that ultimately Emerson transcendentalism came to be dominant mostly in academic literary life and also was convincing in ways that Marsh's reasoning wasn't.  Kuklick says that in philosophy of religion, Trascendentalism "contributed to a new avant-garde culture in which relgigion was a matter of symbol and feeling." (82)  But the ideas did not penetrate so much into the "instituationalized" philosophical and theological discussion. (82) 

* Bushnell's thought K says worked more closely with language vv the idea that he felt that there was a split between nature and spirit, see 84 on the split and 85 on the piont about language. 

* K says that eventually in the middle third of the nineteenth century, the thought of these "amateurs" "slowly impressed thinkers in the colleges and seminaries." (94)  German ideas thus slowly gained credibility after the Civil War.  They were also significant because they carved out careers outside of the academies, but that success was short-lived and swept aside after the Civil War. (94)

 

 

﻿

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text: p. 480 - 2 Their Interest: Language Ideologies and Metadiscurive Practices Their goal is not to praise or damn Boas. They are interested in what the "role of language ideologies--representations of the nature of language, communication, speech, and the like--and of what we call metadiscursive practices--techniques for regulating the production, circulation, and reception of discourse--in the making of modernity." (480) They think language ideologies have provided "implicit bases" for certain social and political norms, since the seventeenth-century at least, when oppositions were constructed between "plain, rational discourse and both the ornate rhetoric of the Scholastics and the 'vulgar' speech of women and the lower classes" which assisted "the ascendency of emergent 'modern' elites..." (481) On the flip side, notions of language and "how it creates social bonds" have impued scholarly texts with authority. Here they cite Lock'es Essay Concerning Human Understanding. And they say that today "[m]etadiscursive practices continue to be central means of authorizing particular conceptions of public spheres, citizenship, and political participation, as suggested by recent adoption in California Proposition 227, which attempts to largly eliminate bilingual education." (482) They note that metadiscursive practices and language ideologies also involve "constructing and regulation social Others by projecting pre- or anti-modern discursive practices..." (482) Here they cite as origin John Aubrey (Locke's contemporary) and his Remains of Gentilisme and Judaisme. They note that "substantial bodies of literature" have been generated about the "vanishing languages of the people that modernity is supposedly just about to erase...." (482) Such discourses on vanishing others and their language they think remains a key part of nationalist projects and in "legitimating hierarchical relations between 'modern' and 'backward' or 'traditional' groups, societies, and nations and in naturalizing social inequality with nation-states through assertions of cultural difference." (482)

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text:
p.016 - Professionals Take Control

After H. Baxter Adams professional move to take control of the AHA.  Began in form of rebellsion of group of professors in 1895  who thought the meeting was dull and Washington not an adequate location or center of literary and academic life.  What htey got was a "new policy of rotation that would bring the Association each year to one of the major university communities." (16) 

American Historical Review foundedinitially as an indepdnedent paper , strictly professional. by several ivy league professors.  And J. Franklin Jameson as its managing editor.  In 1915 AHA took formal control after Bancroft and some other accused the editors of fraud and favoritism.  (16-17)

New leadership after 1895 also realized that they coul dnot rely upon the government for support.  AHA appointd its own Historical Manuscripts Commission.  . Alsof formed a Public Archives Commission in 1899.  Did not ignore amateurs, welcomed mebership from anyone interested. Not always a great deal of cooperation between professionals and amateurs but in some cases yes, as in formation of the Mississippi Vally Historicl Ass.  a produced of collaobraiton of proffessional histoirans and state-supported historical agencies. (18-19) 

AHA had also by 1899 gained control of historical instruction below the collegiate level.  The AHA's committe of Seven proposed sweeping revision in 1899, "called for a four-year history requirement in the college preparatory program, encompassing ancient history, medieval and modern Europe, English history, and American history." (19) 

1907 end of an epoch Higham says: 26 volume "american Nation Series" published between 1904 and 1907. It represnted the ""the first great professional synthesis of American history." (20) 

By and large, the AHA stopped choosing patricians as presidents.  Only occasionally (20) . John Franklin Jameson the first professional president. (20)

title: With science as his shield: Teaching race and culture in American public schools, 1900--1954
text:
p.007  Timeline

Covers 50-year period.  Initial context is the attempt to "Americanize"
newcomers, which involved speaking of "'racial' gits and deficits of vairous
European ethnic, national, and religious groups." (5)   Rise of Nazi Germany in
the 1930s provoked shift toward focusing on "the 'cultural' gifts of various 'racial' groups--again typically white ethnics." (5)  Question is at this point raised about how to fight racial prejudcie (5). War in 1939 provokes need to get rid of white racism.  "In fact, for many educators snuffing out racial discrimination was equated with forging national unity." (5)  At this point anthropologists and other socia-scientists enter debate in the 1940s.  they succeed in forcing a shift in how teachers "taught about theconcept of race itself..." (5) The result she says is that teacehrs "stopped refering to white ethnics as 'racial' minorities and reserved the term--and its destructive imploications--for people of African and Asian descent (including Native Americans)." (6)  By 1948, antiracist education is receding.  Here she tries to offer a new analysis -- where others attribute thes hift to the Rise of the ColdWar.  She thinks instead that it was due to the confusion of teachers, faced with "competing versions of tolerance and pedagogy and disillusion by sustaianed evidence of racism in the classroom." (6)  Here she tries to see the teachers as having agency.  They were not forced to stop teaching antiracism,but they chose too (7).

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text:
p.072 Post-WWI Private Initiatives Shape Research 

Patterson say sthree initiatives most important.  

1) The Rockefeller philanthropies, esp. the Social Science Research Council (founded 1923), the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial (LSRM) and the Rockefeller Foundation.  These focused on "porlbem-oriented, interdisciplinary social science." (72)  

2) The National Research Council's "effor tto promote the study o fracial groups and race mixture in the United States." (72)

3) The American Council of Learned Societie's Committee on Research in American Native Language funded by $80,000 grant from Carnegie Co. in 1927 aimed at a salvage operation of native languages.  (72) 

Sapir and "to a lesser extent" Boas were involved in all three Patterson ssays, see 72 bottom.  Sapir was the chair of the NRC's Division of Psych. and Anth. when the his SSRC proposals on acculturation and psychology o fculture (culture and personality) were accepted.  (72)

Patterson says Rockefeller phil. had greatest affect through building of U. Chicago (Sapir also involved b/c he was hired their)  (73)  Rock. phil. very interested in "making the social sciences more sccientific in order to promote social and economic stability, to eliminate subjective studies of social phenomena, and to develop more effective methods of social control." (73)  This interest led to Community studies first of which was Yankee City (73-74)

Meanwhile NRC prompted focus on race beginning in 1920 under direction of Clark Wissler as refelctedin a confidential report of that year.  And this came with dominance of Boas point of view on race.  But both biological and cultural determinism flourished under NRC initiative. (75). Herskovits did his work with NRC grant.  (75-76)  (74-77)



NRC

title: Another Liberalism: Romanticism and the Reconstruction of Liberal Thought
text:
Random Note 1: Rosenblum's Discussion of Lliberalism and Feminism

Rosenblum thinks that liberalism is less likely to exclude women.  In a section where she describes liberal individualism as potentially including the same sort of "extraordinary action" implied by heroic individidualism, she then describes Liberal individualism as definitely not so focused on such herocism as Romanticism.  IN the process, she notes that it is also less "masculine."

 

"...Liberal individualism does not always have this ethos of being for the strong, nor does it always have quite the same masculine aura." (21)

She then also states that liberal indvidualism is more likely to grant rights to women as well as men: "Although liberal individualism historically attributes rights and liberty to men, there is no conceptual barrier to extending them to women.  At least the obstacles to considering women as person are more likely to break down when independence means pursuit of happiness and not militarism.  Plainly, part of the attraction of romantic militarism is its elitism, at twhose heart is exclusion of women.  Women embody the mundane.  They are responsible for the breakfast odors and air of domesticity Chateaubriand despised." (21)

Then later she continues this theme talking about the poet Vigny who had romanticized the army while denigrating the actual army, calling it a "convent."  Rosenblum writes: "once again, exclusion of women, even if unspoken, is central to the rejection of civil society." (23)

This makes sense in lieu of the comment that follows the quote from page 21 just above.  The rejection of women she seems to think is the rejection of civil society itself, something that liberalism basically cannot abide.

"...no matter how much liberal though may identiify individualism with the strong, with self-won independence and the emancipation of desires, it entials respect for others.  It entails a minimum of utilitarian attention to the general happiness.  Liberal individualism is inseparable from calculation and self-control.  These are missing from romantic heroism.  Missing too is the recognition that every action comes up against the action of others.  In liberal thought, neither civil society nor war could ever be a scene of pure self-assertion, because whereever there is more than one person, there is external resistance and constraint.  Action in the world means acknowledging the limits of one's powers and the impossiblity of self-sufficiency.  Recognition of these limits impels men and women to give up natural freedom in the first place; it is what makes consent to government possible." (21)

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text:
p.034  Character of Development of Hisotry Profession after 1907

After summarizing on the prior pages (26-34) the massiv eexpansion of the insitutional complex of profesisonal history, he comments: "what stnads out in this extraordinary proliferation of the instituions of scholarship is the diversity of initiative and the relative weakness of centralized direction...nowhere, since Jameson's heyday, has as single focusof authority and leadership materialized. Intsead of a national center of historical research, Americans have created their own peculiar welter of voluntary associations, special projects, and particular agencies." (34-35)

title: The Pre-Freudian Georges Devereux, the Post-Freudian Alfred Kroeber, and Mohave Sexuality
text:
Quick Notes 7/5/10:

This is an interesting article with several implications.

1) it's usefult to me because it is an instance in which Murray does a critique of the "ethnographic present", see pp. 17, 21.  His basic point is that Devereux seemed to assume, without any basis for doing so, that Mohave sexual practices had always been the same without there being any historical change, despite the radical changese that these poeple had undergone since European contact!  More than that though there are some instances as on p.21 when Devereux seems to interpret the Mohave as a "modern" people!  Now, Murray seems to think this is wrong, and he's write from the point of view of historical epistemology, but then on the other hand as a historian, how interesting that Devereux does this!!

2) The other things going on here is the discussion of sexuality among anthropologist also.  Now Murray doesn't, as he should, place this alongside analyses going on with Benedict and Mead and others. ACtually, he leaves it to Kroeber, whose forward to Devereeux's dissertation he includes here, to mention Mead.  But of course Kroeber never like Mead's text.  Kroeber approves of Devereux's analysis, which in his "Note on Methods" is a "highly abstract reflection [b/c Murray notes that D has very little fieldowrk experience], with allusions to theoretical physics, about th epossiblity of turning cultural materials that are not consistent or rational, and that contain several patterns, into rational (structural) models.  He asserted that 'social science will needd to evolve a symolic logic of their own, little related to mathetmical logic,' and mentioned (Edward) Sapir and (Paul) Radin..." (18)  After this, then, D becomes an orthosdox Freudian and eventually tries to publish abook on Mohave SExuality (and Murray talks about trying to get it published, though he doesn't say why, but notes that the problem was always the fear that it would offend and that D's method was not satisfactory...)

This article made me wonder more about what's not here then what is here.  There's a lot of absences and evasions in Kroeber's introduction.  It deserves a closer read... There's something more to be found in all of this and I would love to look at D's diss and the ms. of the Mohave Sexuality text.

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text:
p.131 Modell on Benedict's Disciplinary Approach

Modell says it clearly: "...'culture wholeness became her disciplinary idea.'" (quoted on 131).

title: The Cultural Return
text:
Notes 3/2012

Hegeman begins the book with a very frank statement of her own contextual relationship to the project:  The book she says is an attempt to make sense of her own "local context as an academic trained in the latter part of one century and yet living in another."  (ix)  She contrasts the earlier period as one in which she was faced with a "host of exciting possibilities broad about by the intellectual challenges of theory and interdisciplinarity" with the latter where she is "reckoning with forces that still evade comprehension: globalization, financiliation, neoliberlaism, and (perhaps most peronally undirgirding it all) what often feel like the final days of the American century's grand experiment in public higher education."  (ix)

Introduction

* Being more specific she states that the "historical context" of the book is the "apparent exhaustion of cultural studies as a central intellectual formation of the the interpretive social sciences, adn the concomittant struggle to identify the terms and methods by which to key these fields to an interpretation of our current global, social, political, economic, and geographical sitaution." (3)

* She says "globalization" is then just a keyword for a "general experience of historical change" within which there are certain key events that are relevant: the post-1989 breakup of the Soviet Union and the "global supremacy" of neoliberal doctrine.  (3)

* She sees as a consequence of these developments a "backlash against the identitarian politics of the 1960s, including both theoretical and state-sanctioned multiculturalism." (3) This involves a turn away from a politics of "recognition" of cultural minorities to a new emphasis on "race-blind" policies and civic integration of minorities. (3) But these shifts are not often linked to reactionary right-wing developments but "buttressed with high-minded reference to state-security, the rights of women and sexual minorities, and the core values of Western liberalism." (3)

* That roll-back of multiculturalism has been accompanied by an unseating of poststructuralist critiques of totalizing theories.  Only, the turn has mostly seen a return of grand narratives of Enlightenment and the West, and not capitalism or socialism.  (4)

* Most interestingly, she says that in the academy this return of master narratives has produced a "renewal of interests in aesthetics, ethics, and even theology." (4) There's a return she says to "literary formalism" and in general a rejection of interdisciplinary muddiness and a demand for disciplinarity clarity.  These demands come along with polemics against "culturalism" and historicism and "content analysis." (3)  She notes that "cultural studies" is usually labeled as the "imperialist" disciplinary villian.  And "[t]othis overreaching, relativistic, anarchic, and hypocritically market-oriented cultural studies is opposed a newly sober, properly disciplined study of the good, the true, and the beautiful." (5) Hence aesthetics...

(Key here I tihnk is that I think for Hegeman aesthetics is understood as a particular ideology of justification of the liberal-bourgeois order... as in Eagleton's article on the subject...? 

* She traces this return to aesthetics on 5-6 /  Alexander Alberro sees it as a response to a contemporary moment defined by a series of "catastrophes" in the face of which it is somehow unsurprising that there has been a call by writers for a "pathos-infused, humanist aesthetics." (5) Alan Badiou sees it as a failure of the left after teh collapse of revolutionary marxism, where the left has adopted the "principles of the established 'Western' order" instead of seeking out "terms of new politics of collective liberation..." (5)

* The reaction to a sense of crisis that is propelling a return to aesthetics she think si also evident in "calls for the return to the aesthetic, where beauty is aligned with a realm of pleasure neglected by the modernist (and political) emphasis on the sublime." (5) She cites Wendy Steiner's Venus in Exile.  But also "more complexly" she points to an arguemnt by Chris Castiglia and Ross Castronovo about how cultural studies "debunked" traditional essentialized identities but did so "without supplying in their stead grounds for collective life that are affectively satisfying as well as theoretically plausible." (quoted on 5)  Castiglia and Castronovo see the tIntroductionurn to aesthetics as a respond to this "putative failure" in that it "traffics in affective sensations that promise--without necessarily providing--post-identity or non-normative forms of collectivism." (quoted on 5)  Castiglia and Castronovo Hegeman points out are interested in "resolving the individualism of aesthetic experience with collectivity: that is, in renegotiating the relationship between aesthetics and politics." (5-6)  She thinks this is pretty typical of the new calls for a consideration of aesthetics, much as she says those (e.g. Nussbaum) calling for a return to ethics are interested in "bridging the gap between humanist universals and the particularities of identity and subjectivity." (6)

* She is not against these kinds of projects that seek to find an "intersection between aesthetics and politics, collective identity and private pleasure, universal and local values, or form and content", but and she sees the present book as involved in such a "dialetical" project. But she is suspicious of these calls. She seems to think that they are anti-dialetical or against the kind of "mediation" that she would assume such a project of finding intersections would entail. She sees these poeple calling for a turn against interdisciplinary studies tha tmarks cutlural studies, and a limitiation of literary to the Literary, film studies to the "Filmic" etc.  And "humanitiesp edagogy in general to either an affective or an ethical encounter with beauty or pleasure." (6) So she suspects these calls are reactionary and that they seek to "carry us back grouhd the various sea changes of the last fifty years." (6)

* So what she wants to do is investigate "why such calls for renovation feel necessary at this particular moment and--perhaps even more centrally--why they even feel like a change or a break at all." (6) 

* The culture concept is ideal for this because within cutlural criticism as she understands it as does Frederic Jameson culture has stood for (quoting Jameson) "the space of mediation betwee society or everday life and art as such." (quoted on 6) .  This is a key "space" for Jameson because it is a domain in which art has the real possiblity of "redeeming" or "transfiguring" a "fallen society." (6)  Jameson further noted that for those who feel a "malaise" about the blurring of boundaries that such criticism involved it "becomes crucial to break the link, to challenge an dphilosophically discredit the conept of culture, in order to protect the space of art against further incursions of contamination." (7)  So culture is for the people that Hegeman is looking at and those making this "call" for a return to clear disciplinary lines  and and a humanist aesthetics and ethics because it is the sign of the "degredation of art" and of hte blurring of disciplinary boudnaries. (7)

[Note: But this does not account for the critique on the left that Nancy for example has made that culture distracted from concerns of resource distribution, ie materialist concerns, political economy etc...  Does Hegeman address these concerns anywhere? ]

* She sees the "repudiation of the concept of culture" as a the "transdiscipolinary phoneomenon that best represents our current perceived movement of intellectual rupture with the recent past." (7) It involves renewed attention she says to aesthetics in art history, literature and film studies, but also certain straings of argumetnation in "historical studies, philosophy political science, and especially anthropology..." (7)

* She notes that a key part of the 1980s and 1990s cultural turn was in fact a full on critique of culture, which was portrayed as "overly rigid, ahistorical, reifying, sneakily polemical or evaluative, racist, normativizing, and elitist." (7) These critiques led to a redefinition of the term as "hybrid, multivocal, migratory, and endlessly contested..." and this shift she notes was only possible after the ground-clearing of the concept that took place int he cultural turn. (7) That is, the cultural turn was marked by a constant discussion about what culture was. (7-8) A lot of that work took place in the field of history of anthropology and was about the Boasians, see 7-8 for her summary.

* Lately, she ntoes Richard Fox and Barbara J. King have argued that anthropologist should get "beyond culture". The discipline they think does not need a consensus on this term. She thinks this turn may then be a sign of the end of the cultural turn, i.e. "[w]hen the worry is over, then indeed it seems that a  new moment int he discourse has emerged that does what so many of its polemicists have proposed: 'forget culture,' get 'beyond culture.'" (8) She notes that Victoria E. bonnel and Lynn Hunt (who was a key figure int he new cultural hsitory) have recently proposed to get beyond culture in a 1999 volume.

* And then there is Michael Denning's book which she describes as being "inflected by world systems analysis" and "exemplary of the disciplinary context of the turn away from the cultural turn." (8) She thinks Denning's book is interesting b/c it highlights how the moment of the turn away also can be understood as a shift in the interdisciplinary relationship between the humanities and the social sciences. Much fo the cultural turn involved an exchange between anthropologya nd the humanities, at the center of which was Geertz's work and the Interpreation of Cultures book which inspired the new historicism and the new cutlural history. Cultural studies also turned toward anthropology, and then also anthropology itself had its own "reflexive turn" in whcih it accepted much fo the poststructural thoery then cutting edge in the humanities. Set against all this, the current repudiation of the cultural turn suggests a end of this interdisciplinary exchange, or better a shift toward a new orientation toward geography and world-systems analysis, as is the case with Denning's book. (8-9)

* BUT Hegeman thinks all this sense of the end of culture is a bit false. She notes that the term is not yet "vanquished." (9) She thinks that the calls to get rid of culture "presuppose a fantasy of purely transparent communication or, worse, an idealism in which concepts somehow operate independently of the contexts in which they are deployed." (9) And she thinsk that culture has not so much gone away as it "has diffused into the woodwork of myriad discursive sites." (9) She goes through a series of example: law (she enters the word culture into Lexis-Nexis) where it is used in case-law in a number of ways; the "culture wars" e.g. Bill O'Reilly etc; the use of culture to describe "corproate culture" for example or national cultures in public; its use by conservatives (11-12). 

* What then does it mean that culture has becmoe avaialble for so many uses? And here she notes the critique (in this case coming from Rorty in Achieving Our Country and from Walter Benn Micahels) that the cultural turn involved a neglect of inequality and problems of distribution. And that those who were impressed with it were either dupes or never interested in issues of economic disparity in the first place. (13) But she says: "To those impressed by arguemtns such as Rorty's, I would ask whetherwe  msut really see the cutlural field as rigidly distinct from isseus of economic inequality. Is the separation, it it exists, really as final and fatal as he suggets.? Analytically, I don't believe it is: When are interethnic conflicts not also inflected with issues of economic exploation and subordination? but rhetorically, I believe we are in danger of ceding the domain of culture to those who we arleady known have a deliberately limiting understanding of it. In other words, we need not only to take back the terms of the public debate, of which I believe 'culture' remains an indisputable part, but to do an overall better job even among ourselves in defining and defending the ground of culture." Here she agrees with Peter Richerson and Robert Boyd who have argued that those on the left have ceded ground on culture's definition. (13)

* IN the interest of regaining control, then, she wants to know what it would mean to develop a "socially progressive" idea of culture. (14) She says that she is here very interested in the "Boasians" use of culture and that of Raymond Williams. Boas and his students she says "theorized 'cutlure' in the context of a very important and in its day quite challenging point that went to the heart of both nineteenth-century racial theory and romatnic nationalism: that there is no necessary relationship or spatial contiguity between natiuon-states, languages, races, and cultures." (14) This she notes seems commonsense now but it was a powerful critique at the time. Similarly, culture was powerful in breaking people out of notions of biological destiny, and she uses Mead's Coming of Age in Samoa example. All this leads her to this sense that culture is -- as she quoted Jameson earlier -- a sign of alternative possibilites: "The cultural was the site of that which was malleable, subject to the processes of history and contact, but most of all subject to change through education--to enlightenment...." (15) And against this one finds a series of actors: conservative cultural warriors [I think of Shannon!!], as well as academic ritics of culture, defenders of "Enlightenmetn", and even popular users of culture. All she says hold a hostility to the "transofrmative possibilities for and through culture..." -- i.e. Jameson's sense of culture as that thing that could redeem a fallsen society. (15) 

* The irony, though, is that although academics today acknowledge the transformative dimension of culture, most often it is sued in precisely the opposite sense, as a term that refers to fixity. It is sued popularlly in a way that hues closely to the word "heritage." Academics are wary of the idea that culture could be used for social engineering. And phrases like drug culture or corporate culture, etc, it is used to indicate "a more or less intractable apttern of group behavior." (15) And even more ironically while "'culture' thus seems increasingly less connotative of alteration, the biological seems, in an odd reversal, increasingly to be a site of plasticity and change." (15)

* That said she thinks there may also ahve been some victories. She notes that few in the U.S. would "acceded to the idea that the United States as a nation is coextensive with one culture, one race, or even one language." (16) She also sees a broader delinking of race, language, and nationality in for example "the international trend in immigration law, which which citizenship is increasingly assigned according to the location of one's birth rather than based on citizenship of one's parents." (16) This breakdown of the link of race, language, and culture to nation is also evident she thinks in the vernacular use of culture to describe drug culture or corporate culture. And it also explains she says the "elaboration of theological, environmentalist, and other usages of the idea of culture that transcend locality and particularity." (16) And she says "culture" is now ensosnced in human rights law, as she shows in her final chapter.

title: The Victorian Connection
text: p. 82 Victorian Connection came into existence mid-1840s to 1860s

title: The Development of Ethnological Theory as Illustrated by Studies of the Plains and Sun Dance
text:
[Summary Note]
This article traces the shifts in theory in relation to the study of the Plains Sun Dance.  It must be taken with a grain of salt because Bennett may want to see a development toward a funcionalist anthropological method because that is what dominates in his era (1944).  There are several moments where he rephrases the insights of the people he is talking about in what seems to be a funcitonalist idiom....eg. 165 "Or rephrased in contemporary terminology..."  
This was first studied by Lowie in the his Sun Dance of the Shoshoni, Ute, and Hidatsa (1919); then by Leslie Spier in his dissertation, The Sun Dance of the PLains Indians (1921); then used by Wissler as an important phase of his proof of the age and culture-area system in The Relation of the nature to Man in Aboriginal America; then Dixon in 1928 in The Building of Cultures and then Kroeber in 1929 criticized Wissler's use of Spier's analysis...  Kroeber publishes on this in The Culture Area-Age Area Concepts of Clark Wissler, criticizing Wissler for misusing Spier, who he represented as sorking toward a more historical picture rather than toward a kind of law of cultural transmission... 
Bennett goes in depth into Spier's analysis essentially arguing that the difference between Speir's account and Lowie's is that Spier was beginning to move away from the conservative Boasian model of historical distribuiton-reconstruction analysis and towards a "more or less funcitonal analysis of orgnaization, mythology, processes of diffusion and modification."  (168)  
Thus for Bennett, Spier is moving away from the historical approach of distribution-reconstruction typical of the 20s that grew from Boas' rigidly empirical brand of anthropology.  (See 162.)
A rereading of this may be in order for what it may reveal about the typica llogic of 20s anthropology...

title: Urbanizing Frontiers: Indigenous Peoples and Settlers in 19th-Century Pacific Rim Cities
text:
General Notes 7/2012

Intro:

* Book starts with a Boas quote about what he saw in Victoria in 1886. Victoria was the provincial capital of British Columbia. It had been founded in 1843 "on the territory of the Lekwammen peoples as a for for the Hudson's Bay Company." Edmonds says that by the late ningteenth century the city "was heralded as one fo the future lights of the British Empire on the Pacific Rim." (3) 

Boas quote is this: "The stranger coming for the first time to Victoria is startled byt he great number of Indians living in this town...we met them everywhere. They dress mostly in European fashion. the men are dock workers, craftsmen or fish vendors; the women are washerwomen or working women...certain Indian tribes have become indispensable to the labour market and without them the province would suffer great economic damage." (quoted on 3, from John Lutz, "After the Fur Trade: The Aboriginal Labouring class of British Columbia, 1849-1890" Journal of the Canadian Historical Association 3, 1 (1992): 82.)

* Edmonds is making a comparative study of pacific rim urbanizing centers as frontier spaces of hybridity and diversity, primarily Victoria and Melbourne.  She wants to look at the history of "disposession and displacement" in these urbanizing centers. She asks: "How should we understrand the story of urban dispossession in these settler colonies, wihch were marked by differing but related sequences of change? And how shold we understand the shifiting constructions of race and segregation in these two urbanizing port cities at the far reaches of Britain's empire?" (5)

* She is making a critique of the way colonial spaces and empire have been studied. "Colonial frontiers did not exist only in the bush, backwoods, or borderlands; they clearly sat at the heart of early town and city building, a process crucial to the settler-colonial project." (5) Then letter in the section "Reiminaing the Colonial Frontier" she describes the description of the frontier she is trying to get away from : "Settler colonialism's nineteenth-century frontier has been routinely conceptualized as a dsitinctly non-urban geogrpahical sapce that sits somewhere out int he country or borderlands. The frontier is frequently portrayed as a liminal zone without rules, a zone that was characterized by violence, forced removal, and disposesion for Indigenous peoples. The frontier has also been inaccurate conceptualized by some historians as a linear phenomenon that marked civilization from savagery, as a site where they can record 'official,' martial-style engagements between males as  areflection of colonial relations.  Instead, I wondered about early cities and towns as developing frontiers, as equally cahrged and often-violent sites of racialized spatial contestations. These frontiers were mosaic-like -- mercurial, transactional, and, importantly, intimate and gendered." (6)

* The point here, which goes to the first paragraph of her book and teh Boas quote, is that natives were present in these cities, and not just on the edge of the "linear" frontier. And the presence of Indians in these frontier cities, she says, has often been erased from memory (6-7) Whereas she says "early towns and cities were often the greatest sites of contesation, as many newspapers and settler reports of the time attested." (7)

* So she will look closely at "race, segregatioin, and Indigenous and non-Indigenous lives int hese two Pacific Rim cities, which were fashioned by British settler colonialism between the years 1835 and 1871, a period that began with the first European settlement at Port Phillip and ended with British Columbia beecoming a province of the Dominion of Candada." (5)

* She sees her self also as taking a "postcolonial perspective" focusing on the "racialized politics of these two settler-colonial landscapes at the spatial, imaginative, social and legal levels and in a comparative context." (5)

* Language gets complex here but what she sees the book as doing also in looking at these sites is that she's looking at these cities and their "racialized transformations" as "formative sites" wehre "bodies and spaces were rapidly transofrmed and mutually imbricated" (confusing sentence) -- but all this in a way that created "plural cultural modernities." (5)

* She wants to look at space as a site of active construction of contested meanings, in combination with race. She notes that a lot more work these days looks at the constructured nature of space and race, seeing them as historically generated, and she cites Henry Lefebvre's book on the The Production of Space (1974) as a major origin of htis line of thinking. (10)

Conclusion

* The narrative here is about the completion of a settler-colonial project of organizing bodies and space. One fo the first sentences of the Conclusion is: "By the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, the reorganization and regulation of bodies and spaces in the desire foramtion of white settle-colonial polities was thoroughgoing. An overt and bigorous transnational discourse of whiteness, white man's land, and white labour had formed through the British settler colonies." (230)

* There was she says a "sharing of restrictive immigration policies among (fomer) British colonies." (230)

*  A major question was what to do about chinese immigrants and the colonies shared anti-Asian policies too. (230-231) Australia, Canada, and New Zealand had by 1885 a "dual-immigrant policy" consisting fo the Immigration Act and Chinese Immigration Act, which was designed to encourage high Euroepan immigrantion and to lower Chinese Immigration. (231)

* She says that notions of Aboriginality became narrower and narrower as "thinking about race become bureaucratized and systemaized." (231) "Indian affairs" became an internal issue after 1871 when British Columbia joined "Confederation" Then the Indian Act of 1876, enacted by Parliament, "provided Canada's federal government excuslive authority to legislate in realtion to 'Indians and Lands Reserved for Indians.'" (231)

* Followiong the Indian Act of 1876, the "most pressing issues" were how Aboriginal land was amnaged. "First Nations wer eplaced under increased pressure to use reserve lands in ways demeed to be civilizerd and in line with the dominant society's expectations; when this did not happen, it was argued that they did not deserve the land.' (232) In general, their is a weakening of claims to native lands in B.C. in the 1870s. Then between 1903 and 1915 the premier Ricahrd McBride asserted that the province had "reversionary rights to both Crown and First Nations lands." (232) There were then significant dislocations of Indian peoples. in 1911, the province bought the Lekwammen Reserve on Victorian's Inner Harbour. The Lekwammen were then "relocated" to a reserve called Maplebank in Esquimalt. The Victoria Daily Colonist wrote the athe "leave taken by the Songhees of their home and that of their fatehrs was marked by dignity, goohed feelin and restraint." (232) Apparently the Lekwammen had on good clothes and the newspaper reproted that onlookers had seen the Lekwammen "driving about the city with their own autos!" (quoted on 232) Then in 1913 the Suamish and Musqueam, who lived in what is now around Burard Street Bridge, lost their land in a similar way. She writes "As they rowed away on the appointed day, with their payments sured by bank books given out to them, their shacks were burned to the ground." (232)

* Similar lines of change with more control in the (australian) colony of Victoria.  Also what she describes as "disicplianry measure and sptatial regimes." (233) These were designed to "reorder notions of gender and class among Aboriginal peoples to align them with modern settler society." (233) Most important bill in this direction was the 1885 Half-Caste Act, passed in the same year as Boas had noted teh presence of Indians in Victoria, Vancouver Island. It reinforced notions of racial purity by banning all mixed-descent indians from livign on the reserves. "The effects of the Act were devestating. It broke up families and forced many Aboriginal people out of missions, where they eked out a difficutl existence ont he outskirs of towns among a white population that generally did not accept them." (234)  Then two years later Thomas Avoca, his wife, and two unrelated children were "placed on display in an ethnographic-style tableeau vivant." (234) -- a point that Edmonds started the book with. Avoca had been actively protesting "infrigngements of his rights at Coranderrk STation..." (234) But here he and his wife were presented preformatively. (Where are their voices in all of this??) When Melbourne joined "Federation" in 1901 the census counted on 36 aboriginal peoples., and only 652 were counted in the whole state, and those were differentiated according to being "pure" or half-caste, the numbers being 217 and 381 repsectively. (235)

* She has this sentence again where she refers to "modernity" -- without defining it it seems. On the end of this section about the laws that solidified notions of racial purity, implemented in the urban sapce of thsi settler-colonial cities she writes: "Internally and extrenally, these former British colonis in the Pacific Rim, in the pursuti of a transcolonial polity  of Anglo-Saxon colonies, had reordered bodies and spaces and, by doing so, systematically made new spaces of modernity." (235)

* She then switches to present day. Her point is that, say, in Melbourne the street names have been given Aboriginal names. But these invocation in fact she thinks reinforces the "epic trajectory of settler-colonial history." (236) But there are ongoing contestations. In March 2006, the Blac GST group "
"(stop genocied, recognize soverity and make treaty)" camped out in King's Domaint to protest, and this drew renewed attention to a problem that never went away, See 236-7. Against this backgorund she points out that the

settler-colonial city should ve biewed as a process rather than as a site of colonial modernity. Close study of Melbourne and Victoria reveal s a key process of settler colonialism: the crucial and rapid transformations of commually owned Indigenous land into private property, which underpinened the colonial order. Inherent in this transformation was the vioelnt and coercive reorganization and production of bodies and spaces to shape white, British, imperial urban landscapes. Inherently racialized processes increaingly sought to regulate and remove Indigenous people fromt he urban frontier and were bolstered by stadial theory; a driving Western historicizing narrative of Anglo-Saxon expansionism; and bourgeois metropolitanism. In the idealized narrative of historical development, the settler city represented the highest and most progressive stage of empire, and its precondition was the absnece of Indigenous peoples. By the mid- to late nineteenth century,a ttempts to shape a white or Anglo-Saxon colonial polity and assocaited struggles over bodies and spaces in the urbanizing frontier were paramount to the success of the settler-colonial enterprise and to each colony's imagined self. that the ity was viewed as  reflection fo the state and as a metaphor for the territory and how to govern reveal s just how deeply ideas about the city as the consummation of empire were entrenched in the imperial imagination. (239)

* Then she also begins to talk about not the creation of a modernity--which was perhaps the goal of the settler-colonial process--but rather the creation plural different "colonial modernities." (240) As such these cities "became anxious sites, nervous terrains" where "increasingly stratified and bureaucratizedideas about race were marked out recursively on bodies and spaces alike." (240  THERE IS A FAIR AMOUNT OF REPETITION IN THIS BOOK!!

* Now she begins some more comparative analysis. A key different was that in B.C. the extractive industries, ie forestry, fishign, etc "required" First Nations people to work, whereas in Melbourne where there was more pastorlaism there was no need for Aboriginal workers and required instead the remove of Aborigines from the land. Also in B.C,. mixed-race relationships that were the legacy of the fur trade were much more common. (240-1) 

* Another interesting comparative note is that although the spaces were linked by common processes of colonization, immmigration,a nd indigenonization in the northwest "notions of whiteness were highly expansive and fugitive."  So "In the city of Victoria, Indigenous peoples and families of mixed descent, the legacy of the fur trade, represented an inidgenized polity." But as settlement in creased and race notions hardened the some mixed-race families tried to "Anglicize" themselves as race lines hardened. In Melbourne, mixed relations had "always been viewed as marginal to middle-calss European mores". As a resutl European mean tried to "disavow or hide" their relations with Aboriginal women. (242)

Some notes on Ch. 8: "Nervous Hybridity: Bodies, Spaces, and the Displacements of Empire [Victoria, British Columbia, 1858-71]

* Chapter starts with a pretty great quote from a British Colonist in 1860: "We will not amalgamate with them. Our race sweeps on, our civilisation knows no halt; and as fast as we cut down the trees the red man disappears." (206)

* What this chapter more or less traces is the somehow impossible but deliberate attempt to eliminate the mixed-race mosaic of races in Victoria, which was the legacy of the fur trade. It was impossible in part because the fur trade had created so many mixed-race families and the intertwining of race as a result was difficult to undo.

* Edmonds traces the growth of settler hostiltiy to racial hybrids especially in relationship to Indian women, who were viewed as prostitutes and dangerous to the white colonial state. Prostitution was seen as vice; Indians were prostitues because of their racial status. And Victoria was feared in particular because it was a port city. Edmonds reads that quote that she heads the chapter with, and which she puts in the text on 222, as the "putting on" of a "brave face" in the face of a very real reality of a mixed-race society in Victoria. (221-222)

* The stakes were raised and the discourse about race and sexual vice in relation to Indigenous peoples was developed in relation to what Edmonds calls the "great Victorian santiary idea" and the fear of sexually transmitted diseases, which she ddeals with in a section starting on 222. She notes taht scholars have "written about santiation as a featur eof urbanizing bourgeois modernity in the colonies, particular how it was harnessed to manage colonized peoples and regulate both urban bodies and spaces." (222) She cites Harriet Deacon, "Racial Segregation and Medical Discourse in Nineteenth-Century Cape Twon," Journal of Southern African Studies 22, 2 (1996): 287-308, and Vivieenne Bickford-Smith, Ethnic and Racial Prejudice in Victorian Cape Town: Group Identity and Social Practice (Cambridge,1988).

* This movmeents comes to Victoria, B.C. in  June 1862 when for the firs time there is an Act discussed "For the appointemnt of  Sanitary Commission for the town of Victoria, and to define the powers thereof." (quotedon on 223). The target was "squaw dancing houses", often owned by white elites in the city, which were noted as "placeds ofmixed-race licentiousness" Edmonds says, but then were ultimately given a kind of "legal ambialence" in regards to the prostituiton that sometimes went on within. Edmonds writes; "This legal ambivalence was also related to the discretionary power in herent in policing. First Nations women were increasingly pushed out of cities and towns, but the continued existence of certain immoral spaces in which they maintained a presence served a purpose -- it secured the 'respectability of white urban cities' and maintained white men's access to First Nations women. We see this in Victoria's streetscape The sexualized exigenciues of colonialism required 'immoral' spaces, justa s racial purity required 'moral' spaces.  The settler-colonial project in both British Columbia and southeastern Australia was indeed one of 'gendered territorialism.' And it was ever so in the urban frontier." (224)

* Then there was a spike in this interest in sanitation vv prositution in 1862-63 with a small pox epidemic.  This propelled segregationist policy and a push to further limit contact between whites and First Nations people. But Edmonds writes:

But this was impossible because of the legacy of the fur trade's mixed marriages and the presence -- as labourers, servants and purveyors and consumers of food and goods -- of First Nations in town. A neat paritioning of the urban frontier was not possible. The British Colonist complained: 'They line our streets, fill the pit in our theatre, are found at nearly every open door during the day, and evening of the town; and are even employed as servants in our dwellings, and in the culinary department of our restaurants and hotels.' Despite attempts to segregate it, the urban frontier was as fluid, intimate, mixed and psychic as it was material. (225)

Nevertheless, she writes the "smallpox epidemic legitimated a series of forced removals." (225) For example in the North, in May 1862, the "Northern Indians" who were blaimed as the source of smallppox were "forced out of harbour by gunboat" -- an act that Edmonds says "led to the spread of smallpox and the deaths of many First Nations farther up the Coast, an even that was devestating in its effect on the Indigenous population." (225) She doesn't give details here. Then in 1866, the colonies of Vancouver Island "passed laws for the whoelsale remove of Aboriginal peoples." (225) Then she quotes from an article entitled "The Seat of Diseasee" in the British Columbian from 1869:

There is a section of this city lying north of Johnson and between Government and Store streets, which bids fair to prove a prolific source of disease during the approaching summer. It is inhabited chiefly by Indians and Chinese, who dwell in low and fitlhy cabins, and display the most profound disregard for all recognized codes of cleanliness...These poeple, as they now conduct themselves, are a nuisance and a plague-spot upon this fair city, and they should be made to either live ads become the civilized beings, and keep their premises in proper condition, or take themselves beyond the limits of the city. (226)

* This new emphasis on medialization and racialization of Indigenous bodies Edmonds says was a key feature of "bourgeois, urbanizing modernity." (226)

* So whereas the vagrancy law hadnot been applied to Indigenous peoles in Victoria in the 1860s (unlike in Melbourne), in 1869 the police chief August F. Pemberton attempted to apply it. (226)

* Edmonds ends the chapter with a work by Matthew MacFie from 1865. MacFie used the polygenist theory of Josiah Clark Nott and Geiorge R Glidden's Types of Mankind to define Victoria as a place containing "twenth-three [racial] crosses, in different degrees, resutling from the belnding of the Caucasian, the aboriginal American, and the Negro." (227) And this caused him fear.  So he was drawing on Nott and Glidden's work to define a defense of Anglo-Saxon racialism. And that's whereEdmonds suggests things were moving in Victoria...

title: History of Germany, 1780-1918
text:
Notes 9/2013:

> These notes taken very selectively. Trying to get a sense of certain themes for Manifold Origins chapter. The themes: role of industrialization, class development, 1848 revolution, emigration, political reactions to industrialization, neo-Kantians, etc.

 

### Ch. 4 Economy and Society Transformed.

#### Industrialization

* 1840s is talked about as the start of German industrialization, but it was till patchy in this decade. Still importanting raw iron and steel for railways. Few join-stock companies. Governemnts followed reestritive credit policy. (135) Following decades were more important and by 1870s, "Germany possessed an unmistakably capitalist market economy." (135)

* Role played by state in industrialization? Nationalist historians have exagerated the role of the states and especially given too much of a role ot the Zollverein. More modern historians ahve been more skeptical, noting "the relatively small amounts that even advanced states like Prussia actually put into fostering economic growth." (140) Also although the state built canals and highways, the German rail network wa smostly in private hands. Though the south German railwas were state-owned. And in Prussia there  was "substantial state investment in railways". (141) The mines of the Saar and parts of Silesia were state-owned. (141) So in the end Blackbourn says: "All this was typical of a Continental rather than an Anglo-Saxon road to industrialization, one marked by closer links between private capitalism and the state." (141) He gives as a great example the fact that German chambers of commmerce, whichi n the Anglo-phone context are imagined as private associations, were in Germany "semipublic, semiprivate institutions, fostered by the state." (141) And the Zollvereiin -- a "growing and dynamic free trade area that was successful enough to persuade businesses from neighbouring Belgium and Siwtzerland to establish themsevles in Germany" (141) -- was also important, esp. after early 1850s when Hannover joined. (140-141)

#### Emigration, Migration, Urbanization

* Emigration was big in Germany in the mid 19th century. There had always been emigration even bbefore to eastern and Southeastern Europe. But in htis period the volume was unprecedented. First wave 1840s, 1.3 millino people left Germany, 1845-1858. Peak year 1854, 1/4 million. Then declining numbers. Another wave in 1880. 860,000 leaving between 1880-1885. 220,000 in 1881 alone. Slowed to a trickly again after 1890s. (145-146)

* Why did people go? Some had religious and political motives. Swabians pietists to Russia, Prussian old-Luterhans to America or Australia. 1848ers left, most noteably Carl Schurz. Socialist and CAatholic victims of political opression after 1870.  Economic distress a major cause. The first wave was mostly small peasants and craftsmen from overpopulated rurla areas in the South: i.e. Baden, Buertenerg the Palatinate. Rural overpopulation also the cause of the second wave. So that Blackbourn describes emigration as the "safety-valve" of rural overpopulation. "it followed the rhythm o rural distress, with a certain time-lag." (146)

* Where did immigrants go? They went to other areas on the Continent, Russia, Blegum, the Nethrelands. Tehre was a large German community in Paris, somewhere around 80,000-100,000 people. But most went to the US, 85% - 90%. 4.5 million Germans left between 1847 and WWWI. 4 Million went to the US. Brazil was a 2nd. w/ 86,000. (147)

* How was all  this opssible? the railways was key, allowing immigrants to reach ports of departure. Increases in capacity and declining costs of transatlatnic passage. At first, much traffic wen through Antwerp and Rotterdam to the US. Later, from Hamburg and Bremen in the north. There were a few of emgiration agencies and associations, who advertised. State agencies and churches also advised emigrants. The communications revolution, making possibl eltters aetc. Letters "encouraged others to follow by painiting an idealized picture of a land of opportunity; the prepaid ticket brought th eopporutnity within reach. By the 1880s the 'uncle in America' was a familiar figure. The them of the frontier also played a part in best-selling novles like Gustav Freytag's Soll und Haben, and appolar litrature arose to trumpet the virutes of American opportunity, likeFriedrich Gerstaecker's Nach Amerika!." (148)

* So ultimately one cn aay that "GErmans had a place in he great nineteenth-century mass movement across the Atlantic. In the third quarter of the century they were rivalled only by the Irish in their contribution to the people of America. The peak period of German mass emigration coincided with that of other north Europeans (British, Irish, Scandinavians), overlapping at the end with the beginnings of growing emigration from southrn and eastern Europe." (148)

#### A New Class Structure

* Blackborn starts by saying "[c]lass is a set of relationships, not a thing, and changes in class structure are even more diffiucult to pin down than a process like industrialization." (157) After 1850, though, class relations set in a differen tway he says. E.g. gorwing diision between masters and men "under the new economic dispensation." (157) Residential segregation, like the separation between middle-class suburbs like Wilmersdorf and Scheneberg and working class areas like Rixdorf or Lichtenberg. Also in the "spheres of reproduction and sociability, dress and cuisine, the everyday realm where class values and mores were expressed." (158) New written works pby political commentators, fashion writers, and authors of etiquette that elaborated the language of class. He gives exap of Wilhelm Heinrich Rielh's book 1851 Die Buergerliche Gesellschaft.(158)

* Blackbourn notes that for a long time German historians downplayed the emergence of a bourgeois class. for reasons that he gets into in his Ch. 8.

---- Reading form that section -----

* Having outlined the new class experience just before the war, 271-6, he takes up the so-called "feudalizaiton" thesis. or Bourgeois feudalization, the idea that the bourgeois were self-abasig themselves by apeing the styles of athe artistocracy, jetissoning their own values. Evidence f this is the acquring of a "von" in front of one's last name and buying a country "Estate." Adolf von Wilke talked about the "new lords of the manor" (278) Blackbourn pushes back against this thesis, saying that many viewed their estates in a pragmatic manner as a good place to entertai. I.e. "Popmp and luuxury were sign of confidene, not self-abasement." (278) Also this was a broad tendency across Europe, for the bourgeoisie to move closer to hte aristocracy. (279) Also there's new evidence that suggests that the bourgeoisie had borken off from the middle-class but without becoming artistocratic in their values. E.g. Some evidence exists in fact that among British entrepreneurs there were three to five times more ennobled individuals. Whereas Kirdorf, the Krupps, thyssen, these major Ruhr industiralizsts, declined enbbolement. Although Blackbourn notes taht this miht ahve been a lot lower among professionals than among entrepreneurs. Dueling...which is often used to support the feudalization thesis... it's not that it wasn't common. it was. But it was "no mere imitation of feudal norms...the duel came to assume a place within a specifically bourgeois code of honour, centered on masculinity, and defined by possession of property, education, and reptuation. Middle-class men did not ape aristocratic models, but --in the words ofUte Frevert -- 'derived their own meanings from thosee models, meaning which directly corresponded to the bourgeois culture of individuality." (280) So ultimately Blackbourn argues tha tthe

"emerging consensus among historians is that the feudalization thiss has been overworked. If we are looking for distinctive features of German bourgois thinking, it makes more sense to consider attitudes towards the state. Attachment to army and reserve officer corps, discussed in the following section, was one aspect of that. The value ascribed to the Commercial Councillor title was another. Parallel titles for nonbusinessmen, like Sanitary Councillor (doctors) and Councillor of Justice (lawyers), were equally prized. The importance of titles does not end there. State examinations or offical service provided rich opportunities to distinguish oneself by title: Herr Dr, Provincial Governor, Professor, Senior Distrit Architect (ret.) -- these and countless other handles become an inseparable part of one'sname. The state provided accrediation and legitmimation. It was a source of prestige, the guardian of organized knowledge, and stood for values that the bourgeoisie held dear: seriousness, respect, rectitude -- the 'manly' virtues.(280)

 

-----------

title: 'If there is nothing beyond the organic...": Heredity and Culture at the Boundaries of Anthropology in the Work of Alfred L. Kroeber
text:
Notes 7/24/10:

Part 1 of her argument:

Kronfeldner is arguing that Kroeber's understanding of culture was strongly influenced by Weismannian notions of genetic inheritance.  The key idea here is that what Kroeber envisioned with his superorganic was a system of hereditary transmission "of another sort."  Here's her key quote on this:

If culture andbiological evolution are as decoupled as Kroeber assumes, then culture becomes clearly visible as a separaet, second system of inheritance and change.  In the end, culture is conceived as being independent of biological heredity (culture as superorganic) and, at the same time, it is conceived as heredity of another sort.  A close epistemic coupling, via contrast and analogy, leads to a conceptual and causal decoupling of heredity and culture. (121)

The basis of her argument is her recongition of the fact that Kroeber referenced Weismann's essays in his debate with Spencer in 1890s, in which Weismann critqiued Spencer's use of the principle of "inheritance of acquired modifications."  K's discussion of this debate on 117-118 is informative.

K thinks that Weismann, in his critique of Spencer, "stated that a point of view such as Spencer's ignores the fact that tradition, or culture in Kroeber's sense, makes Lamackian exaplanations superflous....According to Weismann, Spener confusese achievements (culture or cultural change) with innate abilities (nature or biological evolution).  He thus ignores the fact that the former can change without the latter."  (118)

In other words, in her reading, Weismann had implicitly acknolwedged the existence of culture...which then Kroeber makes explicit in his superorganic essay. K cites Weismann in th eessay dicsusing the question of whether there could be a "Samonaer Mozart"--the answer being theoretically yes in terms of mental capacity, but no for the lack of the traditiosn to facilitate the expression of that capacity. It seems from her analysis that Kroeber dismissed Weismann for becaues he (in Kreober's words) "hastened to the inconsequent conclusiont hat faculties are probably different after all." (quoted on 119, from p.37 in Kroeber's essay).

Nonetheless, she says: "it follows from Weismann's and Kroeber's accounts that cultural evolution can proceed independently from biological evolution."  (119)  She then shows K's graph with the diverging lines of the inorganic, organic and superorganic.

I don't tink her use of th workd "evolution" in cultural evolutoin is right here...I don't think that's what K was talking about.  I think it is fair to say that he was thinking of a system of transmission and development, but I don't think it needed to take an evolutionary form.  I'm not sure the K thinks this either, becuase she seems to have her terminology a bit off on 119 and 120.  She seems to refer to social evolutionists as "progressivists" and the ideas as "progressivism."  She says that Kroeber "tried to distnacehimself from progressivism," but what It hink she means there is really social evolutioinism.  Later she tries to specy by saying that he was opposed to "what I would like to call racist hereditarianism." (120)--by which I think she means social evolutionism because a little father down the page she says that Spencer exemplified this set of ideas.

Rightly, though, she ntoes taht Kroeber accepted a "hereditarian basis for human existence" because he assumed inborn differences and a capacity for "civilization." (120, bottom)

K also notes that Krober imagined that the rift between biology and culture should be reinforced institutioanlly by a divide between biologists and social scientists and this connects with her observations in the first seciton that this was taking place within the competetive framework of professions.  The most interesting point here though is that in fact there was a biologist and Columbia, a geneticist, who recognized th gap as well: Thom H. Morgan who in a 1924 paper called "Human Inheritance" and thn in a book called The Scientific Basis of Evolution talked about social evolution and its "peculiar process of 'social and economic inheritance.'"  He did so saying that this idea shoud replace the notion of Lamarkian inheritance.  Social inheritance she says was "functionally equivalent" to Lamarkianism because efforst to learn are heritable...

Part 2 of her argument:

The next part of K's argument has to do with a set of distinctions she wants to make in relation to the way in which the term culture was being used by Tylor, Boas, and finally Kroeber.  All of these distinctiosn rest on a logical distinction between an explanandum and explanans.  These ideas are commin in philosophy of sceicen she says and were introduced by Hempel and Oppenheim in a 1948  book in their attempt tod describe "deductive-nomonological" explanation.  Her description of these categoreis is supremely confusing, but it appears taht the explanandum means a sentence describing a phenomenon to be explained, whereas the explanans is sentences used to explain or account for a phenomenon.

The argument K makes is that Tylor used culture as a explanandum when he defined that "complex whole".  Boas shes says, in speaking of culture as a kind of environmental factor produing "socail causes," treated it as a explanans.  Kroeber then returns it to being an explanandum, but she says of a different sort, when he describes it as a new sort of heredity.  She hits this point really hard, accusing Stocking, Degler, and Cravens of not appreciating this crucial distinction.  Here is her argument:

Although the early Kroeber thoguht that culture is also the only explanans for culture as explanandum (only culture explains culture), the late Kroeber admitted that many factors are involved in brining about the inter-individual system of change and inheritance he called culture.  That Kroeber weanted to distinguish his concept of culture from that of Boas is also evident from Kroeber/Kluckhohn (1952), a review of varioius definitions and concepts of culture for which the two authors later became famous.  They place Boas together with Tylor into the category of 'descriptive' definitions that use enumerations, and Kroeber into this one and into a second category of 'historical' definitions: definitions with 'empahsis on social heritage'.  My assertionis that the classification offered in 1952, is not revisionary with respect to Tylor's, Boas's,a nd Kroeber's concept of culture; it mathces the original intentions of the early papers under discussion here. (124)

She then hedges her claim by saying that the shift was not that clear and that of course each thinker used both forms of talking about culture, but she's interested in what was "fundamental" to their approach. She seems to think that the importance of this insight is that it reveals that Stocking, say, was wrong in arguign that culture provided a "functionally equivalent subsitute for the older idea of 'race-temperament.'  It explained all the same phenomena, but it did so in strictly non-biological terms, andindeed its full efficacy as an explanaotory concept depended on the rjection of the inheritance of accquried characteristics." (quoted on 125)  She thinks this is "misleading" because it assumes that Boas and Kroeberhad the same concept of culture (she rightly notes that Boas was more skeptical) and then (circularlly!) she says it was misleading because Kroeber's explained different phenomenon because it had "changed its theoretical role from explanans to explanandum." (125)

It's very hard to see waht she's saying here!!  I venture that it is something like this: Boas is reluctant to envision a cultural system...but uses culture in a vague way to explain other phenomena.  As she says, he speaks of "social causes"...Kroeber on the other hand defines a mechanism which itself must be explained, and in doing so he imagines a process that paralells hereditary transmission biologically.

She seems to think of Kroeber as having generated a crucial innovation that Stocking et al overlook which is  precursor to curent multiple-inheritance theorists and in general those who look at "th einteraction between biolgoical evolution and cultural change." (125)  For multiple-iinheritance theorists she says that culture is both explanans and explanandum...and agian she says that "separate second system of inheritance of ideational units that can and needs to be studied in its own right." (125-126)

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text:
p. 280- 281 1st Generation Prof. Women

These women sometimes responded, as Jane Addams argued, to family interests after education.  Other families supported women in prof. careers.  Some women remained isngle on purpose.  Other women seemed freer to explore lesbian relatoinships as is suggested by bio accounts of Jeannette Mraks, Mary Wooley, M. Carey Thomas and Mary Garrett, see f.n. #24.  

At the same time, evidence also suggests that even woment hat married soetimes used marraige as a means to achieve a professional career, ie.. through their husbands authority.  (281)

But more scenarios probalby exist (281-2)

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.020-22  Creation of Female Professional Culture

Beginning in 1890.  They created a distinct profssional culture because"women entered the professional world most successfully when they carved out wholly new areas of expertise in which they did not compete with men for jobs or training." (20) INcomes for these professional also -- because they served children and poor women -- came from wealthy patron and not from their clientelle.  That means they had to convinced both their clients and their patrons of the importance of their work.  Muncy alsoargues that women'sprofessioanl culture sought to "coopeartion of lay people" at a timew hen male professions were "seeking to increase their feesand status by emphasizing their estoric knowledge..." (20)   This meant also that women did a lot of popularizing, and Muncy notes that research hasshown that even earlier in the 19th century women had perfromed a popularizing role in relation to scientific knowledge.  "The persistence of this inclinations suggeststhat the educating role suited Victorian ideals of womanhood.  The cult of true womanhood had envisioned women as the healers of divisions in communities.  By popularizing technicalknowledg,women were fulfilling their obligation to pull groups together, to heal the divisions between the educated and the uneducated, between professionals and potential clients, between elite and mass." (21)  But she notes that men were also forced to popularize -- particularly journalists -- so it was not exclusively a female realm, but for female professions this was a "defining characteristic" (21).
Also female professionalism defined by a "professional ethos"that valued self-sacrifice, in excess of the same among male professionals for whom the ethic of service was vague, requiring as a historianshe quotes notes simply "competent performance" (22) (21-22).  Parlty the emphasis on service came from the peculiar circumstances of women: they needed to demonstrate the service ethic becausetheir wealthy patrons were not interested in supporting professionals but rather providing aid to the poor. (22)

title: 'Race' Speech: 'Culture' Speech: 'Soul' Speech: The Brief Career of Social-Science Language in American Religion During the Fascist Era
text:
00 Summary 00

This article examines the usage of social-scientific language relating to culture in American religion during the 30s.  She traces it in relation to a certain language that developed.  For instance at the National Conference of chiastian and Jews: "As the contributors their faiths as 'a way of life,' they downplayed divisive creeds.  Most important, these were 'religions,' not races, and, indeed, religions anthropologically conceived as sets of customs.  The terms 'democracy,' 'individual,' faith,' and 'religion' all lined up neatly with social meanings and conveyed the wish of religious liberals for hamrony, not just among denominations but between sacred and secular interests."
