(88) Ultimately, however, much like Hegeman & Susman, Rose concludes that in this context culture 1) failed to exclude or fully replace deterministic (even racially deterministic) language(e.g. p.90), and 2) "that the notion of democratic faiths courted equal if opposite dangers of conformism and ostracism." (92)   After World War II, then, there was a new
enthusiasm for discovering religious difference.  "After the search beginning in the 1920s for what was common and comparable in religion, Americans indulged a wish for spiritual self-expression.  These writers spoke as if religions serving the public good required too much neglect of remembered differences and offered too little access to the inward or transcendent.  They wanted faiths with a 'soul,' that inner nub of peculiarity able to anchor and transform identity.  It is impossible to prove--though important to suggests--that this longing for selfhood , revealed in speech, was a key force behind the well-known postwar revival. The people who built, joined, and attended congregations in numbers unprecedented in the twentieth century seemed to act out the meaning of words calling for rcover of religious foundations." (95)  She illustrates this in partiuclar using Will Herberg's "Protestant--Catholic--Jew" (1955).  "...the book also contained a prophetic voice that made iti an insistent jeremiad.  In these portions, social-science words changed from descriptions to accusations.  Americans practiced a 'culture-religion' that idolatrously made democracy its object and used the  'cult of faith' in fatih as a therapeutic crutch.  Herberg rejected this spirit of  accomodation and instead named 'biblical faith' the standard of value." (96)  Toward the end of the article, however, Rose suggests that the experience of how "successive social-theory influenced faith must also have underlined the variability and indeed relativism of pious words." (96)

title: The Decline of the German Mandarins:  The German Academic Community, 1890-1933
text:
p.097-102 German Historical Tradition

Stemming from Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886).  HIs method was set in opposition ot the "intellectual tendences in the West European Enlightenment." (98)

"As German scholars saw it, the historian's greatest sin was to trea tthe past as a collection of examples to be used to glorify man, progress, and the present, to construct general maxims of statecraft, or to chart the advances of science and reason. " (98)

Ringer is carefult  point out that the German historians did not intend to ban all generalization.  "No German historian ever took such a position," he says.  (98)  The goal was to be "historical" by describing "bygone epochs, institutions, and individuals as much as possible 'in their own terms'..." (98)

It relied on the practice of empathy that allowed one to put themselves inthe palce of "historic individuals." (98) So it led to the principle of "individuality" that could be applied to all subjects.  One regarded each historical object as unique, whether a particualr ruler or a epoch or a state.    ONe reconstruted these individualities by drawing upon Dilthey's "objective geist" to find the "suriving 'objectifications' of its spirit." (99) The hstorian seeks meaning in the "patterns of thought and behavior" but not necessarily in the "historical process as a whole." (99)  Thus the emphasis is again on the Geist...and the practice of empathy it enabled...even before Hegel (99)

But the principle of individality he notes probalyy owed more to German Romatnicism and to Idealistic systems.  He referes to a 1923 lecture on "Natural Law and Humanity in World Politics" by Ernst Troeltsch that described to political traditions: the French and Anglo-American based on a secular verison of Stoci and Christian naturallaow and the ideal of "humanity," and another rootedin that rooted in the Lutheran state that had emphasized the "authoritarian implications of Christian natural law." (100)  On this basis he dscribes a product of German Romanticism as the "new, posivie, ethical, and historical principle" of "indivduality." (100)  Long quote on 100-101, shows this as being tied to a conceptin of the relationship between a gorup and its constituent elements.

"Of decisive importance is the mystical-metaphysical sense of this concept of individudality as in each case a particular concretion of the divine spirit in unique persons and in suprapersonal communal organizations.  The basic constiutents of reality are not similar material and social atoms and universal laws...but differing unique personalities and individualizing formative forces...This results...in a different idea of community: The state and the society are not created from the individual by way of contract and pragmatic [zweckrationale] construction, but from the suprapersonal spiritual forces which emanate from the most important and creative individuals, the volk spirit [Volksgeist] or the religious aesthetic idea.  A quite different idea of humanity also results [from this basic coneption]: not the ultimate union of fundamentally equal human beings in a rationally organized total humanity, but the fullness of contending national spirits, which unfold their highest spiritual powers in this contest...[Further, this approach leads to a conception of historical development as a progression] of qualitatively different cultures, in which the leading nation at a given tiime hands the toch to its successor and in which all [cultures] together in mutual complementaiton represent the totality of life." (quoted on 101).

I.e. this is the wholistic idea...the whole is not simply the sum of its parts. (101)

title: The Philosophy of the Enlightenment
text:
Notes June 2011

Preface

Cassirer makes it clear in the preface here that he thinks that any account of the Enlightenment that describes it, as he puts it, by "tracing this development from system to system, from Descartes to Malebranche, from Spinoza to Leibniz, and from Bacon and Hobbes to Locke" (ix) will fail to capture the point of the Enlightenment as he sees it.  So the point he makes over and over again in the book is that the nature or character of this intellectual movement lies in its commitment to questioning and so any account of it needs to capture it "in process": "The fundamental intellectual forces with which we are here concerned can be grasped only in action andin the constantly evolving process ofthought; only in process can the pulation of th inner intellectual life of the Enlightenment be felt."  (ix)

In presenting the Enlightenment through its action, his goal is to resist the most common and he thinks most shallow critique of the Enlightenment: "that it lacked understanding of the historically distant and foreign, and that in naive overconfidence it set up its own standards as the absolute, and only valid and possible, norm for the evaluation of historical events."  (x)  This I think is the German-Romantic critique of the Enlightenment that he is referencing; actually he says so on the next page, saying this is the "verdict" of the Romantic movement (xi).  He doesn't think that that critique is entirely eroneous, but he seems to think that it has been excessively implied, that in fact the Romantic verdict goes too far.  And so he wants to "silence" the critique that takes as its target the "shallow Enlightenment." (xi) 

In making it clear that he thinks some of its critics have too shallowly critiqued the Enlightenment, he also make it clear that he thinks Kant's Critique of Pure Reason has made it "impossible to return to the questions and answers of the Enlightenment." (xi)  But, he says that once the "History of Pure Reason" is written that Kant indicates in his last section of the Critique is written he thinks that "it will have to recall especially the period which discovered and passionately defended the autonomy of reason, and which firmly established this concept in all fields of knowledge."  (xi)

This mention of Kant is interesting because I think Cassirer belonged to the group of German thinkers that are sometimes described as neo-Kantian after the 1870s.  Also as I've read through the first two chapters, I've noticed what may be a tendency in Casirrer to want to read a Kantian understanding of the interplay of reason and experience into the Enlightenment, so perhaps in this account he is reading the history of the Enligthenment through a Kantian lens??  I will point out examples of what I mean in these notes, but here's just one.  See pp. 8-9, where he describes why the Enlightenment was not interested in systems for sytems sake, because it sought to "discover...regularity in the phenomena thesmelves..."  This for me--with my shallow understanding of Kant from reading just parts of the Introduction to the Critique--Kant's understanding of the limits of reason, that it can only know things as they appear in experience, but that at this same time the sense that reason follows certain rules that make it possible to discover regularity in the world...   I will point out other instances of this later...Note: I showed the passage on pp. 8-9 to Brian and he verified that Cassirer seemed to be using Kant's categories, but that somehow it was also "filtered through Hegel...," but I couldn't get him to explain what that meant.

Chapter 1: The Mind of the Enligthenment

C starts about my identifying what was unique about the 18th century.  He goes through an initial examination of the sense of the 18th century thinkers, e.g. D'Alembert, that there was a distinct intellectual movement afoot.  "Reason" was the keyword, but what did this mean?  He explains first by distinguishing it from what the 17th century had been about the philosophical construction of systems.  This is what Descartes, Malebranche, Leibniz and Spinoza had done.  Instead, the 18th century "mind" he says seeks "another concept of truth and philosophy whose function is to extend the boundaries of both and make them more elastic, concrete, and vital."  And it uses "natural science" as the model for doig this...  (7)

A source for this kind of thinking exists in Newton's "Rules of Philosophizing" and not Descartes' Discourse on Method says C.  Newton didn't start with "general concepts and axioms"; he began with phenomena and attempted to move toward general principles: "If the latter are first according to nature...then the former musta always be first to us....Hence the method of physics can never consist in proceeding from any arbitrary a priori starting-point, from a hypothesis, and in completely developing the logical conclusions implicit in it."  (7)  Instead, the goal is to investigate patterns in the material world.  That is not the dualism of Hume, meaning the fact that ideas and the material world are governed by different rules or that there is a "cleavage between experience and thinking, that is, between the realm of bare fact and that of pure thought."  (8)  For Newton and his followers, instead, the goal was to discover "universal order and law in the material world."  (8)  That meant that material facts are not just a random "jumble of discrete elements; on the contrary, facts exhibit an all-pervasive form." (8)

So: "Observation produces the datum of science; the principle and law are the object of the investigation." (8)

The thrust here, though, is not toward a love of systems.  D'Alembert in his "Preliminary Discourse" and Condillac in his Treatise on Systems develop the point that systems are dangerous when not subjected to validation by the phenomena themselves.  Condillac, C says, shows that the 17th century systems failed because they were not put to the "test of historical criticism."  They avoided the "facts" and proceeded instead from some central dogma. 

Now here comes this powerful passage on 8-9 that I mentioend before.  He says that the enthusiasm for system is replaced for a "new alliance between the 'positive' and the 'rational' spirit."  (8)  Not sure what that means?  The positive that spirit that studies facts and the rational that wants to construct principles?  The  other way around? 

But he breaks it down this way: "ONe should not seek order, law, and 'reason' as a rule that may be grasped and expressed prior to the phenomena, astheir a priori,; one should rather discover such regularity in the phenomena themselves, as the form of their immanent connection.  Nor should one attempt to anticipate from the outset such 'reason' in the form of a closed system; one should rather permit this reason to unfold gradually, with every increasing clarity and perfection, as knowledge of the facts progresses." (9) 

This started to sound Kantian to me because of the emphasis on phenomena, as well as the idea that the form of reason/logic has to be developed through the phenomena rather than a priori -- although is reason in fact a priori for Kant?  In any case, C says that the Enlightment rejected the logic of the scholastics as well as the mathemeticians, and sought instead the "logic of facts."  (9)    He speaks of the Enlightment as demanding that the "mind abandon itself to the abundance of phenomena and guage itself completely by them" with a confidence that it will "not get lost, but that instead it will finder here its own real truth and standard." (9)  In other words, it is only through abandoning itself to the phenomena of experience that the mind can discover its true relationship to the world by achieving a "genuine correlation of subject and object, of truth and reality..."  (9)

Later he points out that in another sense the 18th century is not a radical departure from the 17th century, but a shifting of emphasis.  There is still the basic belief--that only Hume's dualism denied--that there is no basic discontinuity between phenomena and principles, the particular or the general--from this "rationalistic postulate of unity." (9)  As d'Alembert put it: "All sciences put together...are nothing but human intelligence, which always remains one and the same, and is always identical with itself, however different the objects may be to which it is applied." (quoted on 23).

The "absolutism" of the unity principle C says loses some power and accepts some limitations in the 18th century, but the basic core of the idea remains intact.  The goal is still unification: "To 'know' a manifold of experience is to place its component parts in such a relationship to one another that, starting from a given point, we can run through them according to a constant and general rule." (23) So to know this ways is also to perform a reduction "from apparent diversity to its basic identity." (23)  This way of thinking, however, is not without its power--or even in a sense a kind of magical quality--as C I think tries to make clear on the next two pages, describing how this capacity of the mind to discover the fundamental relationships between things allows this way of thinking to move beyond mere "quantities" to the world of "qualities" because qualities as well as quantities can be placed "in such a relationshp to one another that they are derviable from one another in a strict order." (24)  For Condillac e.g. in The Language of Calculus, there can no be calculus of pscyhological experience because unlike corporeal substance psychology is not quantifiable, but psychological experience can still be divided into its constituent parts and so is accessible to analytical thought.  Condiallac's proof of this is his famous illutration at the center of his psychology where he descrbies how a marble statue "progressively comes to life and qacquires an incresaingly rich spritiual content because the individual senses engrave their special qualities on the marble." (24)  (The case is a marble statue that only has the capacity to smell, but all the capacities that we associate within being human are

(9)  In other words, it is only through abandoning itself to the phenomena of experience that the mind can discover its true relationship to the world by achieving a "genuine correlation of subject and object, of truth and reality..."  (9)

(9)  As d'Alembert put it: "All sciences put together...are nothing but human intelligence, which always remains one and the same, and is always identical with itself, however different the objects may be to which it is applied." (quoted on 23).

(23) So to know this ways is also to perform a reduction "from apparent diversity to its basic identity." (23)  This way of thinking, however, is not without its power--or even in a sense a kind of magical quality--as C I think tries to make clear on the next two pages, describing how this capacity of the mind to discover the fundamental relationships between things allows this way of thinking to move beyond mere "quantities" to the world of "qualities" because qualities as well as quantities can be placed "in such a relationshp to one another that they are derviable from one another in a strict order." (24)  For Condillac e.g. in The Language of Calculus, there can no be calculus of pscyhological experience because unlike corporeal substance psychology is not quantifiable, but psychological experience can still be divided into its constituent parts and so is accessible to analytical thought.  Condiallac's proof of this is his famous illutration at the center of his psychology where he descrbies how a marble statue "progressively comes to life and qacquires an incresaingly rich spritiual content because the individual senses engrave their special qualities on the marble." (24)  (The case is a marble statue that only has the capacity to smell, but all the capacities that we associate within being human with the human soul are developed as a consequence of this single sense...)  C puts it this way: "Sense perception formsthe borderline between the marble as dead matter and a living being endowed with a soul."  (25)  The point is then that the mind's engagement with phenomena, it's capacity to discover the rules governing a "manifold of experience" is an incredibly powerful ability and it is what the 18th century has become enthralled with:

"The mind neither creates nor invents; it repeats and constructs.  But in this repetition it can exhibit almost inexhaustible powers.  It extends the visible universe beyond all bounds; it traverses the infinity of space and time; and yet it i unceasingly engaged in the production of ever new shapes within itself.  iBut throughout its activities the mind is concerned only with itself and its 'simple ideas.'  These constitute the solid ground on which the entire edifice constructed by the mind, both in its 'external' and in its 'internal' aspects, rests--and from which the mind can never depart." (25)

C describes how Condillac's attempt to "show that all psychological reality is a transformation, a metamorphosis" is continued by Helvetius in his book On the Mind,which he clearly does not like and does not think is a good representative account of 18th century thought, except in that it describes the same "methodology" which finds sensation to be the basis of all thought (and ethical judgement etc)--only I think C dislikes C because he's toooo reductive and narrow minded--the kind of thinker who is represedntative of the "shallow Enlighenment." (25-27)

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text: p. 480-481 Advocates of post-structuralist anthropology liked Boas's texts They write that "ethnopoetics" and post-structuralist critiques of anthropology positively evaluated Boas's ethnographic texts of the sort that Boas sought to develop with Hunt. The authors list Dell Hymes, James Clifford, George Marcus and Micahel Fischer, and Arnold Krupat.

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text:
p.019-20 Columbia 

Not so successful.  In 1929, Boas is sitll the only full-time prof.  Madden notes that he had trouble finding funding and wihtout citing any of his conflicts with Butler etc... Madden explains it in terms of the "vaguenss" of Boas' proposals: "His proposals to the Rockefeller Foundation and the Social Science Research Council were vague and did not convey a coherent research enterprise.  Since the leaders of both organizations wished to fund research dedicated to specific social problems, Boas' proposals meet a critical audience at the funding organizations." (19-20) 

Boas Madden says only received $20,000 between 1930 and 1934, whereas Harvard received $75,000 for the same period. (20) 

Benedict helped fill the teaching needs of the dept,but she could not teach linguistics (due to hearing problem) or physical anthropology or archaeology.  Boas hired Euroepans to suplement the needs.  (20)

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text: p.035-39 Autonomy Autonomy importnat to her considering her interesting in both negative and positive liberty. She notes thatthe traditional idea of autonojmy as "self-rule overlaps a great deal with both negative and positive conceptions of liberty. It shares the extreme individualism of negative liberty, defining itself in terms of absolute freedom from any influence of others, and at the same time the extreme sense of self-control that often characterizes positive liberty, the notion of a rational, reflective, self-ruling agent who is concerned not just to choose but to make the best choice, the right choice." (35) But some theorists explicitly identitfy autonomy with positive liberty, such as John Christman. But she ultimately pushes away from the concept. She notes that some say autonomy is a precondition of freedom and some the other way around. Thus she thinks freedom is "both braoder and narrower than autonomy." (36) She explains later...

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
p. 054 - 68 Matilda Stevenson

-- Matilda Stevenson also worked in Zuni, but she was agressive and O-L accuses her of being responsible for "some of the hostility toward anthropologists that continues in the Southwestern pueblos." (55) 

-- Stevenson distresse dby "commericalism" in among the Zuni (55)

-- Stevenson became an "anthropologist by marriage" to James Stenevenson.  Matilda vorn Matilda Evans in Texas in 1850.  James Stevenson worked as a geologist for the U.S. Geological Survey.  In 1879 she went with him on an anthropological expedition that included Fran H. Cushing and J.K. Hillers.   They remainedin Zuni for 6 months ( 56) 

-- Stevenson organized a cleaning service in Zuni and chose a transvestite named We'-wha.  (56-57)

-- Recognized by E.B. Tylor in his 1881 speach to the Anth. Ass. in Washington., though she had already pub. a thirty-five page study of Zuni and the Zunians privately.  in 1881.  (58)

-- She "concentrated purposefully on affairs concerning women and children in the belief that as a woman she could obtain particularly complete information, a point tha tifgured in the philosophy of the Women's Anthropological Society founded and first presided over by Matidla Stevenson." (58)

-- Once she nursed W. H. Holmes through an illness in the field and he recalled her as "able, self-reliant, and fearless, generous, helpful and self-sacrificing." (59) (58-59)  [Note: interesting mixture of male and female traits.]

-- She was not as taken in by the Zuni as Alice Fletcher (see 55) and she took data from the Zuni even when they didn't want her to.  Seh sketched things secretly even when they had tole her thatey "feared having things 'carried away on paper'" (59)  And once she was held prisoner in a Kiva at the Hopie pueblo of Oraibi until resuced.  This event was reported in the Illustrated Police News of March 6, 1886 in a way to denegrate the maliness of Indians.  The headline was: "Cowed by a AWoman: A Craven Red Devel Weakins in the Face of a Resolute White Heroine."  (59)  (59-60).  Also see illustration at end of documentof Stevenson shaking her fist in the scared Hopi man's face.  

-- Matthew Stirling who headed the Bureau of am. EThn. in 1928, that Stevenson was still famous for her antics.  O-L then has a text in which Stevenson interrupted a ceremony by charging in un-announced.  (60-61)    

-- A most interesting story: STevenson had a hand-drean copy of a reproduction of a photograph of a Sia alter made.  In the photograph there were also two ceramic dogs from China.  In the reproduction, they were removed -- presumably the rep. of commercialism? (61)

-- Matilda Stevenson also felt that the Zuni had suffered a moral degredation , writing "...but alas, the Zuni as a man and a good citizen has fallen far below what he was before he came into contact with White man."  Part of her evidene, was their willingness to deceive anthropologists.  (63) (62-3)

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text: p.123 Handler sets Sapir against Benedict interms of the individual v. culture tension.  I think Handler is a bit off on his treatment of the core of Benedict's ideas.  He for instance describes in this introduction that "Pound is to Eliot as Sapir is to Benedict.  Put less cryptically, the contrast between Pound's iconoclasm and Eliot's Catholicism is similar to that between Sapir's emphaiss on the individual and Benedict's championing of culture." (123)  But I think it is reductive in the wrong direction to say that Benedict "championed" culture.  If she saw culture as determinative, this was not necessarily to champion it, and we must ask why she tended to see it as determinative.  Handler is aware of gender but he doesn't seem to consider the significance of gender in Benedict's tendency to see culture as determinative.

title: The Other Within: The Marranos: Split Identity and Emerging Modernity
American Moderns: Bohemian New York and the Creation of a New Century
text:
p. 302 - 304 Dramatic Adoption of Fee Love Sex Talk	

Stansell discusses here the adoption of what she has described earlier in this chapter "Talking about Sex" as sex talk among and popularity of free love ideology among New York Bohemians.

It was first present she says in Floyd Dell's "he said, she said" format plays for the Liberal Club Players which he founded in 1913, a group he formed based on exp. with the idea of the Little Theater in Jackson Park.   Stansell describes it this way: "...Dell took lovers' quarrels, men's promiscuity, women's resentments, and the difficulties of marriage and staged it all at the Liberal Club, mostly as a farce.  Some of the plays were thematic and ideological, fleshed out with speeches ont he inevitable failure of monogamy and the death of love in marriage--not so different form an Emma Goldman lecture.  Others were self/mocking treatments of what Dell referred to as 'everybody's private affairs.'" (301)

S thinks these plays "replicated the openness and purported symmetry of the free-love dialogue." (301) But it also mocked it: "The self-dramatics of free love turn out to be as flimy as Liberal Club produtions..." (302) She notes that "heterosexual honesty" became in its failures the thing that drvoe the plots.  (302)

She notes that this "theater of sex" had little to do with Freud at this stage., i.e. before 1920.  The focus on sex behavior she notes had a root in a focus esp. on womens' problems (hysteria still powerful here) and mixed gynecology and advice.     (302)

More serious focus grew out of Lieberal Club Players in 1916 when a group hanging out in Provincetown on Cape Cod "decided to replicate their Manhattan venture with a greater degree of seriousness." (302) Involved were Eugene O'Neil, Mabel Dodge, Hapgood and Boyce and John Reed....   

Her conclusion here is that these plays revealed a tension between bohemian men and women, in which men dominated with their talk.  After quoting Boyce's role in a play written by Boyce and Hapgood, in which Boyce talks about how Hapgood had crushed her soul, Stansell writes: "Pent-up energies were at work, an alternative understanding of the marriage and Boyce's own role in it that had long been suppressed by the pressures of bohemian ideology." (303)

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text:
p.185 Sullivan's Summary of her view of the Person

"For Mead, as shall become apparent, there must e both a human person with innate propensities inherited from his or her direct ancestors, a specific life experience and a culture, organized in a given fashion, of some greater or lesser scale, transmitted in particular and specifiable ways that include the locally pertinent practices of child rearing." (185)

title: Occidentalism: the West in the eyes of its enemies
text:
Notes Winter 2014

### War Against the West

This is a book claiming to trace something like what Said traced regarding the idea of the Orient, but for the Occident, the West, which is also identified with the "modern" or "modernity" but also "colonialism" and "capitalism." The target is slippery.

* The authors start the intro with a group of Japanese intellectuals who met in 1942 to discuss how to "overcome the modern." But they insist that this discourse has a much broader history and that it has become more and more inspirational to more people, especially radical Muslims. (4-5). The U.S. also has become a symbol of this, say, for muslims (5).

* It is not about left/right (5). It's broader than that. The people who fall into this pattern of thinking they are calling "Occidentalism" do so for different reasons, and don't necessary share much. I.e. a romantic who hates modern, commercial metropolises does not have much in common with a religious radical: one seeks a "pastoral arcadia", the other a kingdom of God. (5) And so on.

* So in defining their topic more specifically they say these more piecemeal likes and dislieks is not their target. They use the language of pathology and disease: "Symptoms become interesting only when they develop into a full-blown disease." (5) I.e. they are not interestedin those who simply do not like pop culture or global capitalism or what have you. What they are interested in is the "desire to declare a war on the West for such a reason..." (5) What they call Occidentalism is "[t]he dehumanizing picture of the West painted by its enemies..." (5) They call it a "cluster of prejudices" and they want to trace their "historical roots." (5-6)

* They insist that it is clear that this is anot a particular Islamic problem. (6) Again here they use the language of disease, i.e. "occidentalism cannot be reduced to a Middle Eastern sicknes..." (6)

* They argue that it was born in Europe before it was transferred elsewhere. (6)

* vv Anti-Americanism: anti-Americanis plays a key role in Occidentalism, but they insist on 9 that it is only a part. The two are not the same thing. America seems to be a symbol of the machine-like and soulless. But it's not always the Americans that representthis, for example the German Jews were viewed by Eastern Jews in a similar way, as cold and soulless. (I'm thinking of Joseph Roth's characterization!) (9-10)

* They refer to Occidentalism as a "venemous brew" (10)

* What they are interested in critiquing is the "dehumanization" that is involved in Occidentalism as much as Orientalism, the reduction of a whole set of people to being soulless etc. They are also not interested in mere "prejudices" but a set of ideas that has developed "revolutionary force" (11)

* They note that one way to trace this tradition would b "to trace the history of all its links and overlaps, from the Counter-Reformation to the Counter-Enlightenment in Europe, to the many varieties of fascism and national socialism in East and West, to anticapitalism and antiglobalization, and finally to the religious extremism that rages in so many places today." (11) But they won't do that because of the need for concision, so they have chosen instead to avoid this chrnological appraoch and to instead identify partiuclar "strands" that are linked to a "chain of hostility". These strands are: hostility to the city, to the "mind of the West," to the bourgeois, to the infidel... (11)

* They are not interested in collecting ammunition for the war on terror. (11-12).

* Also their account has no clear defined geographical border. (12)

### Seeds of Revolution (conclusion)

* Authors start with a novel by Herzel of all peopel that envisions a socialist Jewish utopia in which Arabas and Jews live side by side, all happy because the benefits of Enlightenment rationality, modernity, and modernization have made everything better. Then they authors talk about the resistance to this. It has not always taken the same form but they make a big deal of the way those who have opposed this "Western" modern thing have done so with ideas tht originated in Europe. Iranian revolutionary Ali Ahsari'ati spent timein Paris translating Frantz Fanon and Che Guevara. He interpreted Islam as "pracical socialism." (145) Ba'athism, the ideology of the Syrian and former Iraqi govenrments, came to life int he 1930s and 1940s in tehw ake of collapse of the Ottoman Epire forged by Sati' Husri and Michel 'Aflaq. Husri had read the German Romantics, Fichte and Herder, drew on their notion of a voelkish nation. (145-6). He used the idea of asabiyya drawn from the 14th century thinker Ibn Khaldun. (146) Even Zionists such as Hans Kohn in his his memoir noted drawing inspiration from Fichte !!! (146)

* Then in the last pages, dissapointingly, they move the question to how to "protect the idea of the West--that is to say, the world's liberal democracies--against its enemeies." (147).  I really don't like this turn. Why raise this issue this way? It jsut seems simplistic. But they mean it. They see a kind of war of ideas going on, not a war of civlizations. They describe a "worldwide, loosely organized, mostly underground revolutionary movement." (147) But they don't think it's about national, ethnic, or religious borders; they think it is  "in some respects the same as the one that was fought several generations ago against various versions of fascism and state socialism." (147) This is super vague!!!

title: Of Feys and Culture Planners: Margaret Mead and Purposive Activity as Value
text: (1) p.101-102 Feys v Culture Planners Essay comes out of a quote of Meads in which she opposes Bali and the US, that is a fey culture with a culture of culture planners. she wrote to to Geoffrey Gorer in early March 1936: "I continue to think that European civilization may be going somewhere, whereas Balinese [civilization] distinctly is not and never has been. They demonstrate very prettily under what conditions a fey culture can survive, by means of an iron-clad social system, and I am interested in documenting that, but I don't think God meant feys as culture planners." (101-102, from Mead to Gorer, October 1, 1936, Mead/LC, N5:4.)

title: In Pursuit of Equity: Women, Men, and the Quest for Economic Citizenship in 20th-Century America
text:
p.007-8 Background for this gender system

K-H says, referencing Carol Pateman's The Sexual Contract, that this system has been traced by political scientists and philosophers at least as far back as the seventeenth-century.  Pateman she said has argued that "most contract theorists believed that only men possessed 'the attributes of free and equal individuals.'" (7)  So they "took for granted the natural subordination of women, a trade-off that allowed them to challenge the God-given authority of kings while maintaining conjugal order." (7)  Male independence was located first in property and then in "an income sufficient for a working man to maintain himself and his family." (7)  By the late ninteenth-century, this wage plus the "services of a wife" were the basis of male citizenship. (7-8)

MOst women accepted this idea.  There were some dissenting voices.  J.S. Mill and Mary Wolstonecraft argued for equal education for women.  French Olympia de Gouges and Jean Derouin argued fro equal political rights and right to work as intertwined goals. Their work known to Ameircans like Elizabeth Cady STanton and Frances Wright who advocated womens' rights. Also the Grimke Sisters, Charlote Forten, Virginia Penny, Charlotte Perkins Gilman, and Emma Goldman all believed economic  indepdnence the basis of having a political voice and political equality... (8)

Then too middle-class feminists excluded the interests and concerns of working-class and balck women.  (9)  And even in the 1920s when feminism became more mainstream, few feminists "eagerly advocated the rote of absolute economic independence."  (9)  Even Eleanor Roosevelt and Women's Bureau chief Mary Anderson "rejected untrammeled statements of sexual equality like that embodeid in an equal rights amendment to the Constitution for fear that they would eliminate the special labor laws that protected the personal and family well-being of the wage earners among them." (9)

Women had a hard time cutting across race barriers where men more commonly reached across race barriers to secure and shape their right to work.  (9-10)

title: Transcritique: On Kant and Marx
text:
Notes 7/2014:

## Preface

The book is a reflection on Kant and Marx. Usually, Marx is read in connection to Hegel; he came to think that Marx should be read in connection with Kant. There is a kind of Kantian Marxism that has been lost. It is not without its weaknesses. It is admirable because of its strong sense of ethics, but it is weak in its sense of its sense of "th eforces of the social relations that compel people." (ix) It is in this sense a bit anarchistic, and that's what K originally liked about it; his politics being a bit anarchistic. So Marx is neccessary.

The connection with Marx is a hard one to see righta way. He thinks capital is not simply a book critiquing classical economics, and economy. It is a "project that elucidates the nature and limits of capital's drive [Trieb], and furthermore reveals, on the basis of that drive, an essential difficulty ential in the human act of exchange (or more broadly, communication.) Capital does not offer an easy exist; rather only by its very exitlessness does it suggest a possibilty of practical intervention." (ix)

The link to Kant seems to be that he started to see Kant as somone who in seeking to reveal the *limits* of morality, also revealed a "possiblity of practice." (ix) It seems he thinks that Kant is more forward-looking than Marx, who spoke very little of communism, i..e offered no out. Is that what Kant offers to Karatani? He says up until 1989 he was also not incline to hink of futures, but after 1989 that seemed more necessary. (ix)

Now in the 1980s hthere was a revival of Kant in works by Arendtd, Lyotard and Habermas, who turned it to a "communicative rationality." The point taken he says was that "'universality'--a sine qua non for the judgement of taste--cannot be achieved, in reality, among a multitude of conflicting subjects." (x) This was of course not Kant's point, because he "assumed a transcendental subjectivity that watches over universality." (x) So what was this return, well it was a "criticsm of communism qua 'metaphysics'". (x) And this of course was part of the broader push for deconstruction etc that happened in the wake of Stalinism. So: "the reexamination of Marxism has involved public conssensus and negotation among multiple language games as opposed to the central control of reason, and heterogenity of experience or complexity of causality as opposed to a rationalist (metaphysical) view of history; on the other hand, the present, which has hitherto been sacrificed by telos, is reaffirmed in its qualitative heterogeneity (or in the sense of Bergsonian duration.)" (x) He says he too was part of this. He realized later that it only had critical impact only while "Marxism actually ruled the poeple of many nation-states." (x) In the 1990s that was not the case anymore. So once that was no longer the case: "Skeptical relativism, multiple language games (or public consesnsu), aesthetic affirmation fo the present, empriical historicism, appreciation of subcultures (or cultural studies), and so forth lost their most subversive potenticess an dhence bamce th edominant, ruling thought." (xi)

## Introduction

* What's transcritique? He starts with Kant. Basically, Kant wanted to move from the view within one's own subjectivity to the view of another's. This produces what Kant calls in *Dreams of a Visionary* a "pronounced parallax" . He sees thisas the only way of "prevenint the optical delusion, and of putting the concept of the power of knowledge in huma nnature into its true place." (1) Karatani connects this to Marx, who critqiued the Hegelian's in German Ideology -- that Karatani says Marx came to see as only an attempt to create ideally what England had created materially -- and then moving to England, where he experienced a "pronounced parallax" that brought him into contact with "the reality thatis exposed through difference (parallax)." (3) The reason that Karatani wants to think of Marx in connection with Kant is because of this subjective shift, this pronoucned parallax. He explains in this quote:

> What is important is the fact that Marx's critique was always born from migration and the pronounced parallax that results form it. Hegel criticized Kant's subjectivism and emphasized objectivity. But in Hegel, the pronoucned parallax discovered by Kant is extinguished. Likewise, the pronounced parallax discovereed by Marx was extinguished by Engels and other Marxists. As a result, one is left with an image of Kant  and Marx as thinkers who constructed solid immovable systems.  A closer reading, however, revelas that they were in fact practicing constant transposition, and thta the move to different discursive systems was what brought about the proncounced parallax. This is obvious in the case of the exiled Marx, but the same thing can be observed in Kant as well. Kant wasa not an exile in spatial terms--he never moved away from his hometown of Koenigsberg. Rather, it was his stance that made him a kind of exile, a man indepednent from the state: Kant rejected a promotion to a post in Berlin, the center of state academia, instead insisting on cosmopolitanism. Kant is generally understood to have executed the transcendental critique from a plaece that lies between rationalism and empiricism. However, upon reading his strangely self-deprecating *Dreams of a Vision Explained by Dreams of Metaphysics*, one finds it impossible to say that he was simply thinking from a place between these two poles. Instead, it is the "parallax" between positons that acts. Kant, too, performed a critical osciallation: He continuously confronted the dominant rationalism with empiricism, and the dominant empiricism with rationalism. The Kantian critique exists within this moment itself. The transcendental critqiue is not some kind of stable third position. It cannot exist without a transverasal and transpositional movement. It is for this reason that I have chosen to name the dynamic critqiuqes of kant and Marx -- which are both transcendental and transversal --"transcritique". (3-4)

* So where does this go: it goes to the critique of value it seems. In Karatani, Engels is a "historical mateiralist", but Marx is not that, he's more(3-4). The critique of value is key here, a turn that Marx took in the middle of his career in the move from *Grundrisse* to *Capital*. What provoked the shift Karatani says was his introduction to "skepticism" in the form of Bailey's critique of Ricardo's labor theory fo value, i.e. the idea that the value of a commodity "eixsts only in its relationship with other commodities,a dnt ehere fore the labor value that Ricardo insists is inherent in a commodity is an illusion." (5) Karatani compares Bailey's skepticism vv labor theory of value to Hume's critique of the Carteasian ego cogito that so provoked Kant. Kat's answer to Hume's claim that there was no such ego was: "...yes, an ego is just an illusion, but functioning there is the transcendental apperception X. But whaat one knows as metaphysics is that which consdiers the X as soemthing substantial. Nevertheless, one cannot really escape from the drive [Trieb] to it it as an empirical substance in various contexts. If so, it is possible to say that an ego is not just an illusion, but a transcendental illusion." (6) Marx, like Kant, must have been similarly stricken by Bailey Karatni thinks, and yet he too moved in a unique direction, i.e. not toward one side or the other, but toward what K calls the "transcendental reflection on value." (6)

* So what is this "transcendental reflection on value." Karatani quickly describes it from 6 onward. Classical economics treated comodoties as if they had an inherent value, an internalized "labor value." But they don't: "in raelity, commodities can have values only after their relationship is synthesized by money, and each one of them is given its value." (6) This was Bailey's point. But Bailey did not why it is that these commodities are related to each other in the way that they are; he didn't question the system that achieved this. From Marx's point of view, then, both Ricardo and Bailey didn't go to this deeper level. Bailey only erased moeny superficially. He criticized both Bailey and Ricardo in order to elucidate a "*form* that constitutes the commodity economy." (6)  He focused then on the "relational system i which objects are placed." (7)

* Historical materialists here also make the same mistake: they analyze the relationships between nature and humans, but they lack any analysis of the "capitalist economy that organizes the tansformation/development" of that realtionship between nature and humans. (7)

* In order to do this, then, to think of value in this way on emust "take into consdieration the dimension of exchange, and why exchanage inexorably takes the form of  value." (7)

* Karatani in fact really pillories the position he attributes to historical materialists and to Engels as an extension of classical economic thought. Classical economists he insisits "had the conviction that they could see all aspects of sociial relations transparently from the vantage point of production." (8) They allowed "social exchange" to remain "opaque", as something that just was and could thus not be changed or abolished. They ignored the ways in which it was constituted as a form by commodity exchange it he capitalist system. Engels continues this as far as Karatani is concerned. "Engels' conviction that we should control the anarachic drive of capitalist prodcution and transform it into a planned economy was little more than an extension of classical economists' thought. And Engels's stance was, of cousre, the source of centralist communism." (8)

title: Lost Manhood Found: Male Sexual Impotence and Victorian Culture in the United States
text:
p. 47 - 52  Crisis of Masculinity and Pscyhological Turn in 1920s

Mumford sees this as a product of sexual and not gendered crisis.  As Beard's work indicated: "By the late ninteenth century, the regime of male continence had become part and parcel of late Victorian respectability.  But middle-class men's achievement of civilized self-restraint seemed to signify more their social superiority than their attainment of manhood." (48) 

There occured then a reaction against Beardian science c. 1910.  Mumford write s that a survey of scientific literature between 1910 and 1930 shows that a "scientific concensus on what caused impotence and how to treat it was shifting gradually away from a Beardian model of scarcity, depletion, and saving toward a psychological model of abundance repression and spending." (49)   So a new focus on "psychic impotence" (49).   By 1920s he says a new "psychological theory of impotence had overtaken the theory of neurasthenia." (50)  E.g. new attitudes about masturbation, not seein git as depleting.  New focus on sexual release and expression.  Freud's critiqued Beard  in 1908 "Sexual Morlaity and Modern Nervousness."  psychoanalyst Wilhelm Stekel in 1920 totally rejected continence. (51).

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.068- Helen Thompson's Research on Sex difference...

Summation of existing beliefs at the time about mental traits of sex, based on Thompson's literature survey. (69-71). Basically, the cellular theory, and what Thompson did was to point out the contradictions. "Women are said to repsenent concentration, patience, and stability in emotional life. One might logically conclude that prolongedconcentration of attention and unbiased generalization would be their intellectual characteristics. But these are the very characteristics assigned to men. Women, though more stable in their emotions, are more influenced by them, and, although the represent patience and concentration, they are incapalbe of prolonged effort." (quoted on 70). And she noted that if the role of anabolic egg and katabolic sperm then the arguments of evolutionsists would hav ebeen better served: "In that case, the female cell, smaller and more agile than the male, would represent woman with her smaller size, her excitable nervous system, and her incapacity for sustained effort of attention; while the male cell, large, calm, and self-contained, would image the size and strength, the impartial reason, and the easy concentration of men." (70) For her study then, Thompson chose fifty Chicago undergrads. Then in german experimental tradition, she testsed them for different motor skills: reaction times, auditory and visiual, rapidity of finger movement, ability to strike a target, pain threshold, ability to discriminate between hot and cold. What she found overall was that the differences were slight. (71-72). She dreww these conclusions partly because she drew on Galton's method of graphing the differences and examining the distribution. (72) Clark Wissler who was working in Cattell's lab at Columbia, and also using Galton's distribution analsysis as well as the attempt to find correlations, drew conclusoins that supported Thompson: namely that differences in reaction times etc could not be used as the basis for classificationsof mental ability. (72-73). Wissler did not explicitly examine sex difference, but he noted that the exististing tests of reaction time wouldn't shed light on the matter. (73) Thompson had to devise her own tests then. She drew on work by Mary Calkins at Wellesley Calkins had wnated to prove HUme and the associationists right. She had demonstrated it in relation to sex along with Joseph Jastrow at Wisconsin by asking women to right one hudnred words down as rapidly as possible. Jastrow fond that the women shoed a "strong preference of the feminine mind ofr certain concrete and familiar classes of words." (quoted on 74). But Calkins argued that "such associations were produced by haibt and did not derive from innate predisposition..." (Rosenberg's words 74). Thompson sided with Calkins but Rosenberg notes she found "the technical prolems ofconvincing the jastrow doubters insurmountable." (75) But the problem was more than technical Rosenberg also notes: it had to do with the underlying assumptions about the nature of the differences tht might exist: were they learned or innate? (75) thompson tried to get at this but could not. She regularly found differences that she then dismissed based on the learned skills that men or women might hav egained. E..g men were better at puzzles b/c of the emphasis on mechanical ability. (75). Thompson fell down on the side of trained ability influencing the reuslts see 79-80.

title: A category of the human mind: the notion of person; the notion of self
text:
p. 20-22 Person as Category and consciouesness, "psychological being"

So the next step which he thinks is taken in the modern era was to be coceived as a category.  Here it is then make clear and more specific, "becoming identified with self-knowledge and the psychological consciousness." (20) 

He discusses ongoing discussions until 17th and 18th centuries "about "knowing whtheer the individual soul is a substance, or supported by a substance: whether it is the nature of man, or whether it is only one of the two natures of man; whether it is one and individual, or divisialbe and separable; whether it is free, the absolute source of all action, o rwhether it is determined fettered by other destinies, by predestination." (20) 

Important he says were the "sectarian movmeents" i.e. the Moravian Brothers, the Puritans, the Wesleyans, and the Pietists that helped conceptualize the person as "only consciousness" (21) "...the 'person'...equals the 'self' (moi); the 'self' (moi) equals consciousness, and is its primordial category." (21) 

He says this is not very old  Required Hume talking about soul as only "'states of consciousness', 'perceptions.'" (22)  But Hume hesitated to make self the "basic category of conscoiusness" (22).  He thinks it is with Kant, pietist, that the "individisble" self is made clear.  But he think Kant posed the question and then it was answered by Fichte.  (22) Then "individual conscoiusness" becomes the "category of the 'self' (moi), the condition of consciousness and of science, of Pure Reason." (22)

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
0 p.xiv Relationship between Professinalism and Reform

Muncy thinks that "female professions created during the Progressive era contained as part of their professional creeds many of the commitments of the progressive reformers who gave them birth."  (xiv)  And as longas they were able to train proteges "they were able to use their power and patronage tosocialize subsequent generations of women into a common reform culture." (xiv)  I.e. the female dominion sort of preserved the reform impulse in the professional culture!! 

This leads to a different analysis than the historiography on the relationship between professionalism and progressive era reform suggests: namely, whereas the existing literature "on feminism correctly blames professionalization for dividing the community of women and distracting professionals from their commitment to public activity on behalf of their sex" she has found something different.  The female dominion nurtured an ethos of reform to some extent she thinks.  (xiv)  She's not challenging the overall idea that a tension existed between professionalism and reform but that the professionalism was not a monolith and in the female domion such as social work, public health nursing, home economics, and some others professionalism actually "embraced reform, nurtured it, and cradled it across the 1920s." (xiv)

title: Age of Fracture
text:
General Thoughts for Discussion with Crisis Group 11/2012

* In the Prologue, R goes lays out the general idea of what he means by fracturing of what he calls at one point the "strong readings of society" that "had been one of the major intellectual projets of the middle decades of the twentieth century." (4) There is then a language that develops about flexible and dynamic markets, think notions of power, fluid identities, and lots of personal expression. WHAT is the causal factor here? Or does Rodgers feel he needs to provide one? He is providing a very cultural history argument. He insists on 5 "[t]h terrian of this process was the field of ideas and perception, not, in first instance, society itself." (5) He uses Robert Putnam's "Bowling Alone" thesis to say that when Putnam's argument was critique it turne dout there was still alot of social activity. So society was not he thinks actually thinning (see top of 6) but: "What changed, across a multitude of fronts, were the ideas and metpahors capable of holding in focus the aggregate aspects of human life as opposed to its smaller, fluid, individual ones." (6)

Ok then so is this just intellectual, cultural, ideational change? Is it totally disconnected from structural shifts? Between 6-10 he goes through three arguments: 1) A shift to a kind of egotistical selfishness -- what Wolfe called the "me decade." 2) The advent of conservative intelelctual to fight a war of ideas backed by powerful institutesion like the Olin Foundation. 3) A STRUCTURAL ARGUMENT, ie. Jameson's argument about late capitalism and postmodernism. But even when he gets to this last structural argument he hedges, not wanting to give economics priority. "Economies are rooted not only in strutures of echange but also, and just as fundamentally, in ideas, practices, norms, and conventions." -- i.e. here again is cultural history.Another interestin reference to a structural factor that he sneaks in is on p.2 when he refers to what seem to be shifts in the structural conditions of media circulation: "Novel forms of intellectual prodcution and dissemination--more politically oriented think tanks, new journals of scholarly debate and opinion, more argumenatively structure media--now began to move ideas more aggressively into circulation." All this thought and he does not commit to any causal formulation. So one is left with the question, how did this happen?

He refers to the era's diebates as defined by a "contagion of metaphors" on 10 and then says also that it was "an age of such contagions" -- that is as opposed to concrete or singular ideas. But what made this happen? That is, if this description is accurate? Where's the sense of where this came from and where it's going?

Also I noticed these sentences in Ch.1 on presidential rhetoric where he lists a series of causal/historical sources for the new disaggregated rheotric that has left behind responsbility for dreams and then increasingly indivdiualized and privatized dreams: p. 28 sentence beginning with "Whether because..." He's admitting not knowing the distinc tcause, or not wanting to specify.

If pressed, I think he sees this as a cultural/intellectual trend. Ie he notes at the end of his chapter on presidential speech that although Reagan was no intellectual his new lanaguage and style "was connected to intellectual trends" that supported his basic thrust...he lists these a bit farther down...these are the main arguments of the book: the increasingly subtle conceptions of power, notions of gender and race that were less and less stable, and disagregated, and so on. (39)

But still no indication of where these intellectual trends came from or not yet anyway.

* VV Nancy Fraser's themes what is releavant here??

* Upon reading "Rediscovery of the Market" chapter: Key question here I think is is this simply a "rediscovery" of the market -- ie of the notion of the market that existed in the nineteenth century and in the works of classical political economists? Rodgers suggests not and that in fact even the marginalists, like Alfred Marshall, had works that assumed the existence of city markets, not the globalized, abstract, and electronic forms of exchange that were in place by the 1970s, see 44-45. I wish he had developed this point a bit more explicitly. What was the new vision? In the section on the "rational expectation" ecnomissts he comes closest when he desscribes their imagined subject as a clever "long-term calculators," who acted cleverly in time in relation to fluctuating money values, see bottom 65-66: "The economics actors at their models' center were skilled inflation managers: not the produces of the classical economists', not even Marshall's cotton dalesr minding the telegraph at Manchester [this is a reference to marginalist Alfred Marshall], but lightening calculators and instant discounters of time, able to work out a life-earnings function on the way to the savings bank, to project with ease the comparative returns of the new global investment instruments coming ever more rabildy on line, or to see through the illusion of a tax cut that someone, sometime, would have to pay back. Rational expectations was economics for an inflationary decade, when the time-dependency of value was a lesson of day-to-day experience." (6

Aso useful is the pages 74-75 where he describes the new global faith in the wisdom and efficiency of markets and then say that it was not only that, but that markets were see as a source of "boundless freedom" and in fact that they "accomplished what theorists had imagined democracy to do." They expressed people's intentions and desires, acted as referenda taking machines. He cites Citibank's Walter Wrison in 1992 saying that markets are "voting machines." And then Friedman who said that markets had "turned the whole world into a parliamentary system." Rodgers then writes: "Unlike deliberative politics, markets were the realm of freedom. Loosed from instiutitons and power, they silently did their work: optimizing, signaling, making tangible the domain of choice." (75)

This last quote got me thinking about my thing on culture: the argument that cultural discourse ultimately unveiled a new domain of private or personal politics that was primary to public politics and also constituted it..

A GENERAL OBSERVATION re the argument about fraxture: it seems at times that Rodgers is talking about a social language that is describing a fragmented or fractured society; but it also seems at times that he's talking about a "language" that iself has fragmented, or that is circulating in ways that makes it fragmented or prone to a kind of recombination etc that treats the language as he calls it like a "contagion of metaphors." When he describes the "novel forms of intellectual production and circulation" at the start (but without talking about its structural bases) on p.2 is one instance in which he gets at the idea that the language is  eing ussed in a way that fragments it. Another instance in the thick of his description (and there are others) is when he is describign the discusison of vouchers in the "Little Platoons" chapter and he says that the "terms combined and recombined in strange configurations."  (218) What he's described is the way a set of ideas developed within one domain of poltics is taken up in another domain for different reasons. He describes this scenario in virtually every chapter. But then is this what he means when he says, fo rexample at the start of the "Wrinkle in Time" chapter that "As very very language for society threatened to break into fragments..." ???

title: The Averaged American: Surveys, Citizens, and the Making of a Mass Public
text:
p. 12-13 Lack of focus on consequences of Statistical Knowledge

Igo notes that there is a lack of focuson the consequences of statistical knowledge.  Even historians that use such data as evidence have failed to look at it.  And historians of the social sciences have focusedon "professionalization and disciplinary consolidation." (13)  Even those she says who were interestedin social scientific authority only asked how "elites--whether states, corporations, or courts--mobilized empirical data for particular ends.  Few have paid attention to what ordinary people, 'the studied,' did withthe same kinds of information." (13)

title: The Intellectual History of Anthropological Thought in the Age of Enlightenment
text:
00 Summary 00

The largest point of this introduction to this book of essays on anthropology and enligthenment is, not suprisingly, that cultural relativism was central to enlightened thought.  The author starts with Montesquieu's Persian Letters and Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels, moves to Voltaire and Rousseau, Alberto Fortis, Cook, and then also Herder and Sade.

Gulliver's Travels described an experience of travel that created a "cultural" comparison: "The relative comparison of cultures had destabilized Gulliver's relaiton to his own, leaving him in a condition of anthropological ambivalence." (7)  Wolff argues that that experience of travel become well known by he mid 18th century even if it was not at the time Gulliver's Travels was publoished i the 1720s.

So Wolff argues that in contrast to the Renaissance which has long been associated with "[t]he representation of objects in relative and proportional size, dpending upon their perceived three-dimensioal depth in a two-dimensional painting or drawin...[and] a revolution in reflections on human perception in relation to physical space.  The Enlightenment may be correspondingly characterized by the discovery of cultural perspective, with its revolutionary destabilization of the eighteenth-century observe who found herself returning not to Old England, bur rather to a new kind of anthropolgical space, globally demarcated by the principle of cultural relativity, imbuded with the unfamiliar flavors of Greek wines, African fruits, and Houyhnhnm virtues." (7-8)

title: Beyond Freedom and Slavery: Autonomy, Virtue, and Resistance in Early American Political Discourse
text:
paragraph 3: Francois's Def'n of Autonomy

"This essay argues that the American Revolution joined liberal, republican, and
religious traditions, or the capacity for human agency--that is, individual's ability to act in secular time and shape their circumstances."

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
0 p.xiv-xv Relationship to Lit on Welfare State

"I see one source of New Deal policies -- the ofundation of hte US welfare state -- in the peculiar predicament of turn-of-the-century women searching for professional niches.". (xv).   I'm not sure whatshe means here exactly, but she ends up noting that women noted that men would cede control "to ackonlwedge the female right to expertise in instances where women or children were the only clients."  (xv)  Thus these women defined social problems in terms that made women and children central.  Which in turn led them to "blame their nonprofessional sisters for all children's ills" and this led in turn to a shortening of the "leash that tied most women to home and children."  Thus "Insistence on the primacy of the mother-child relationship in child development, the obligation of mothers to stay at home, and fathers to earn a family's living were critical tenets in shaping welfare policies oppressive to women.  Andthere is no denying the central role that female policymakers played in perpetuating those tenets and drafting those policies." (xv) 

I.e. it is partly the conditions of female professionals -- their strategic needs -- that shaped the policy... interesting argument!! 

Her last paragraph says she doesn't want to critique these women, but rather theworld that made it necesssary to take these strategies in finding a place as professoinals...

title: Liberalism Repatriated: Prospects of an Anthropology of Antiracism
text:
p.332 Humanity and Multicultural Naitonal Project

Humanity he defines as an "idea defined through shared value concepts...[that] includes all those who believe in well established goods such as 'freedom' and sovereignty'" (332)  

Multinational nation project: U.S. invovled attempt to embed notions of humanity in institutions combined with an "effort to reconcile institutionalized values with real deviations, heterogeneity, hybridity, and polyglossia, presented by the variety of cultural idioms brought by immigrants from Eastern and Southern Europe, and to a lesser degree Latin American and Asai." (332) Sums this up saying that the US "had to combine mechanisms to institutionalize values at the highest level (albeit nominally bracketing religioisity) in tandemn with mechanisms to incorporate challenges to those values through rational judgement." (332)  

These two activities he says form the "two sides fo the multicultural naitonal project." (332)   

He uses Elisabeth Povinelli's "The Cunning of Recognition" to futher elaborate.  The two sides she has named "moral sensibility" and "critical rational knowledge" and they have a complicated relationship.  Moral sensibility is something "that refers always to something beyond discosures...[that]makes an appeal to some tacit, 'pre-theoretical' way of thinking." (332) Critical rational knowledge is "that kind" of knowledge that "is able to reflect on itself." (332)  But critical rational knowledge has a postive relationship to moral sensibility: "The goal of critical rational knowledge is to not simply to allow routinized procedures to deliver a just conclusion; it is also to reinforce the value concepts that underly its assumptions.  So although value judgements are made separate from that which is considered ratoinal knowledge [ due to professionalizaiton??], the separation between the two fields is not a logical impasse but the result of great labor to evacuate the appareance of morality from the realm of rationality.  Moral sensiblity, therefore, brackets questions of rationality in the very act of being the very foundation on which its mechanisms are based.  Without the distinction, however, a moral sensiblity could not be treated as universal [page break] and rational judgement could not appear to relativize to consider specific practical dilemmas." (332)

title: Anti-Americanism in Twentieth-Century Europe
text:
Notes Dec 2015:

 

He seems to agree with Gienow Hecht in disliking Diner's view of Anti-Americanism in Germany. Compares Rogers' anti-Americanism book to Diner's. Likes Armus' more... (1130, bottom).His basic point seems to be in the second half of this piece that the anti-Americanism has yet to be well defined -- in a way, he notes, that would be meet the standards of the Geschichtliche Grundbegriffe... (1138-1139). The negative association with America is not enough, but in his words their needs to be a certain degree of "radicalism" and "coherence" to the usage. (1138). The work in the book that he seems to be most enthusiastic about is Armus's book I observed.

title: Intertwined Lives: Margaret Mead, Ruth Benedict, and Their Circle
text:
Notes:

 

Notes:

  • p.021 Mead & Benedict Styles Banner says that neither Mead nor Benedict dressed "like Village radicals". Mead she says "liked clothing that was frilly and feminine; she loved wearing hats, small ones, 'with a bit of whimsy--a rose perched up front perhaps.'" (21) She work skirts and white gloves before the 60s. And in the 50s she wore dresses by Italian designer Fabiani "that were bell-shaped, with small wrists and full skirts held out by layers of ruffled taffeta, a style fashionable in that decade." (21) Benedict she says "preferred more tailored attire, dresses and fitted suits in soft shades of grayed blue and green that matched her sense of constrain and the ambiguity of her smile, with a frilly blouse, so she looked both professional and feminine." (21)

    Tags:

    • Margaret Mead
    • Ruth Benedict

  • p.025 College Enrollments of Women By 1870 College Enrollments 21% women, 1880 32% by 1910, 40%.

    Tags:

    • Statistics
    • Women's History

  • p.030-36 Mead - Benedict and Female Friendship Banner notes that there was a tradition of close female friendship in the U.S. Some of it she said rooted in Victorian culture and demographic factors, lack of men who had gone to frontier. e.g. She references term "Boston Marriages" which meant woen who lived toegeher as adults. That sphere also existed among kids she notes and writes: "Middle-class women's sphere of activity and friendship extended to girls, who were allowed to have close, even passionate, relationships with other girls. Such friendships were viewed as an innocent outgrowth of the emotionality of adolescence and as a way of preparing girls for the emotinal bonding of the adult female community and of marriage. Moreover, they deterred seduction by males and possible pregnancy at a time when the age of first marriage was rising...Girls were expcted to have a 'best' friend or a 'bosom' firend;such relationships were often called 'smashes' or 'crushes.' " (30)

    Tags:

    • Female Friendship
    • Victorianism

  • p.126-7 Theseus and Ariadne and Gender Banner writes that Ruth thought about the Theseus and Ariadne myth. Theseus trapped in labyrinth by the Minotaur and rescued by Ariadne. Banner writes "Ruth wrote that she felt like Theseus trapped in the labyrinth, with no Ariadne to guide her out. The simile expressed her sense of herself as a bifurcated being, both male and female, and one trapped in a labyrinth--even then a metaphor for the contradictions of the internal self."... (127) Reference to this in At Work, 119, 122.

    Tags:

    • The Self
  • p.022-24 Both Mead and Benedict had familial roots in Reform Movements that opened ed. to women. By 1870 College Enrollments 21% women, 1880 32% by 1910, 40%. (25) Mead's grandmother, Emily Fogg , daughter of James Fogg, Chicago seed merchant. She wnet to Wellesley for two years then Fogg's seed business went bankrupt and she had ot work to fund the rest of her education at U. chicago, graduating in 1896. She then worked as a teacher in girls' school near New York City. (25) Mead's mother Emily fogg Mead, was active as a volunteer in many reform organization's including the Amer. Ass. of University Women, the YWCA, the woman suffrage organization, the Women's Trade Union League and the ACLU after WWI and the Women's International Leage for Peace and Freedom. (29)
  • p.025 Banner says Mead's mother, emily fogg Mead, respected the breadwinner ethic She never worked even when her father had money troubles
  • p.045, 46 Mask As an adult Banner writes "Benedict suffered from severe depresssions that were punctutated by emotional highs. In public she hid her turmoil through the blank expression on her face, the mask that she wore; in private she retrated into the fantasy world of her 'delectable mountains'--or into elaborate suiidde fantasies, in which she visualized the reactions of each of her friends if whe were to take her life." (45) So then Banner wonders whether Benedict's" mask" was about being a stranger in a strange land? Or whether it "may have been related to a sense of sexual difference on her part." (64) She notes that Mead had said: "When Ruth Benedict asked the question, 'Would I have been happy in another country--Egypt perhaps? she was making an assumption about a part of herself that was innate and significant.'" (64) And Banner thinks perhaps that innate part was homosexuality...

    Tags:

    • Performance
    • Sexuality
  • P.067 Masculine style of autobgioraphy Banner argues that Mead "recase the classic form of maloe autobiography, the heroic journey narrative of overcoming difficulties through individual self-creation--a narrative immortalized by Benjamin Franklin in his autobiography about rising from poverty to fame.--by describing her parents' influence o nher and then demonstrating how her path to success fulfilld her early promise..." (67)

    Tags:

    • Autobiography
    • Gender
  • p.067 Motivations for Blackberry Winter Banner describes that the motivations for writing the text were multiple. Mead "want young people to read it, for in the 1970s, when she was writing Blackberry Winter, she had positioned herself as an intermediary between the younger, rebellious generation and their more conservative elders, and she wanted both groups to know about her parents' progressive child-reaching techniques....Yetin a draft introduction to the autobiography that was omitted from the final version, Mead suggested that organizing it in terms of her parents' child-rearing practices wasn't her original plan. Rather, she had initially intended to chart the development of her sexual identity and to end 'a forty-year silence on the subject.' Draft chapters on her childhood focus on her participation in the cutlure of romantic friendships between girls, although much of that material was eliminated from the published version." (67)
  • p.126 Philosophy reduced to atttitudes... Benedict readign the philosophers was apparently dissatisfied findin gthat they were "attitudes taken by different temperaments." (quoted on 126, from Anthropologist at Work, 126). She writes this January 1913.

    Tags:

    • Psychology
    • Temperament
  • p.127 B's Opinions of unmarried convnetional women In Pasadena she met a group of unmarried conventional women that she didn't like. Banner writes: "The most unpleaseant one took Ruth to her room and opened a trunk to show her the cookbooks that she had collected for her marriage....To Ruth the experience was dismal; seh found this woman so unattractive that she couldn't imagine a man desiring her and so 'padlocked with reticence' that she had beecome 'thick-coated with mannerisms.'" (127)
  • p.129-130 Benedict's decision to marry After being in Pasadena with the "old maids" she decides to marry but she understands this in terms of the biological notoin that women must be fulfilled by child-rearing. (129-130) Quotes from Anthropologist at Work, pgs. 141, 123. About the desire to have a child being "stored up in us [women] as a great battery charged by the accumulated instincts of uncounted generations." (quoted on 127). In the end, Benedict's answer was to embrace this noiton of feminine nature Banner says. Desc. of agreeing ot marry him on 129-30 of nthropologist at Work.
  • p.133 Ellen Key's bio of Rahel Varnhagen influences Benedict to write her bio of Mary Wolstone craft. Banner found the link in a fragment where Benedcit's discusses the importance of the book to her. (133, f.n. # 30, 472).

    Tags:

    • Ellen Key
  • p.136-138 Marriage to S. Benedict. Benedict was happy at first and wrote of "this satisfying comradeship, this ardent delight, this transforming love." (quoted on 136). She wrote also a poem that indicates some ambivalence of how he introduced her to the ways of heterosexual love I ran with the panic of virginity; But close, close Resting his warm body at my back, Wrapping his arms lingeringly across my breasts, Without effort and without statement, The south wint held me in his embrace.... For the voluptuous wind Was stronger than I was, And older, and infinitely wiser, And I knew he would compel me to learn his secret. (136-137, This is an unplished poem, entitled "South Wind" that Banner found Vassar col. 48.26). Eventually though it soured. Banner writes: "...once they settled into a domestic routine, he [Stanley] became rigid and demanding. His colleagues at Cornell Medical School found him austere, with a bad temper and a tendency to make harsh judgements....His mother was a published author and one of his sisters became president of Sweet Briar College, but he turned out to be a traditional male, obsessd with his work. He put up with Ruth's career, but he would have preferred a stay-at-home-wife. Ruth's failure to conceive a child was disappointing to both of them." (137) She couldn't leave him though, and preferred silence instead. they didn't separate until 1930. They never divorced and were friendly until Stanley died in 1936.
  • p.139 No Evidence that B particpated in Feminist org. She knew about Heterodoxy but though it was no good. Mabel Dodge and Inzez Milholland were both in Ny but she doesn't seem ot have contacted them. Of Heterodxy: "'No one who has subjected himself to a half dozen of its [Heterodoxy's] meetings...could have an iota of hope for it left.' It seems she didn't like the self-involved nature of thos emetints, the way in which individuals talk about their lives. They did so to increase their feminist self-image, much like the 'consciousness raising' of second wave feminists. Ruth, however, preferred to keep her personal life to herlsef; she also preferred organizaiton that included men." (139)

    Tags:

    • Heterodoxy
  • p.140-141 The War's effect on Benedict Banner thinks Benedict was deeply affected by the war and that she more or less explicitly connected it with the masculine type. Banner reads this out of Benedict's story the "Bo-Cu Plant".
