In the story there are a bunch of men smokin cigars and one tell sthe theory of the Bo Cu plant., a bunch of surveyers sent to see this region and one falls in love with local owman, Nita whosse mother palced a curse on her that she would never find sxual fulmillment in marraige. Husband kills Nita with an ax when bride turns into devel on weeding day. Banner says the story included image of "female Amazons" turning on men, image of Key and others. And it has many male characters who manipulate women and the environment. Banner's interpretation is that these men represent the male imperisalists that many thought had brought on WWI. (141) Banner sees this story as rejecting conventional masculinity even more strongly (141) Benedict wrote in her journal in May 1917: "How useless to attempt anything but a steady day-by-day living with this tornado of world-horror over our heads." (quoted on 141) Banner notes that Benedict saw like many others that the war destroyedthe optimism of the 19th century. So the ideals of neo-Romantics like Key were no longer possible to think about. She remembered in college a teacher sayin that Hobbe's Leviathan was outdated b/c no Leviathan's in sight. But htis was not longer true during the war (141). And Banner notes that in Benedict's books images of Leviathan and Behemoth, the beats of the Battle of Armageddon appear in her poetry, and in her Bo-Cu plant story the "devel became the deux ex machina" (141) Banner refers also to brutla imagery in her poem "Resurgam" and another poem about the young poet Rubert Brooke who was called in the war and who became a "transatlantic symbol of youth wasted" Banner says (141) In this context, Feminism focused onhumanism. Beatric Forbes-Robertson Hale wrote in a survey of feminism: "We are being wrecked by an over-masculinized race...Feminism only comes of age when it develops into humanism." (quoted on 142, from What Women Want) Banner also cites several other sources here: Lorine Livingston Pruette, "The Evolution of Disenchantment" in These Modern Women: Autobiographyical Essay sfrom the TWenties, ed. Elaine Showalter 1978; Linda Schott, Women Against War: Pacifism, Feminism, and Social Justice in the United States, 1915-1941 (Phd. Diss, 1985).; William L. O'Neill, Everyone was Brave: The Rise and Faall of Feminism in America, (1969); Ellen Carol Dubois, Harriot Stanton Blatch and the Winning of Women Suffrage (1997). In this context Mead called for a women's movement focsued on "personality," Banner writes:. "...on attaining the creative individuality that Key--and Nietzsche--had called for. 'The ultimate objective, the high goal, remains an inward affair, a matter of attitude,' Benedict wrote. What women needed was not a 'semi-political party' but--using a religious metaphor--a 'new birth' to a new self. 'We can harldy drag back form oblivion,' she conlude, 'the vital questions that were life and death to us in the early summer of 1914'--questions that concerned suffrage and women's rights." (142-143) Banner's quote here is compiled from material in draft intro to "Adventures in Womanhood" and a diary entry in 146 in Anthrop. at Work.

    Tags:

    • Feminism
    • World War I
  • p.143 - Adventures in Womanhood. Benedict conceived the project "Adventures in Womanhood" in order to explore the problem of female personality, which she saw as the proper question for feminism during the war. So she though of writing bios of Marry Wollstonecraft, Margaret Fuller, Olve Schreiner and putting them in one voulme. Banner writes: "Wollstonecraft represented the rational egalitarianism of the Enlightenement, Ruller the organic and gender-crossing strains of Romanticism, and Olive Schreiner the early twentieth century's neo-Romanticism and feminism. All of them called for independent, gender-balanced individuals; Wolstonecraft and Fuller both had romantic friendships with women when young and then married when older and had children. All three supported humanitarian reform and the advancement of women, although none was a militant rights advocate..." (143) Banner goes through Benedict's essay on Wollstonecraft, nothing specially revealing in her analysis, but the evident discusion of ideal female personality. Relatoins with women, with men, how independent, how passionate etc. ??? Fuller was revealing on these issues Banner notes and had written in Women in the Nineteenth Century (her major work of 1845) that "male and female are perpetually passing into one another..." (145) and "there is no wholly masculine man or purely feminine woman." (146) But Fuller also wrote: "Were they free, were they wise fully to deveop the strength and beauty of woman, they would never wish to be man, or man-like." (quoted o 146). The project was ulimtately rejected by Houghton Mifflin and then she gave it up. App. Benedict herself was not suprirsed since she had dected a "falsetto note" in the bwriteing. And Banner writes: "Indeed, 'Mary Wollstonecraft' has a melodramatic quality that read likes a holdover from 'The Bo-Cu Plant.'" (146)

    Tags:

    • Feminism
    • World War I
  • p.195-196 Brief blurb about New York German-Jewish commnity in NY that was background of many o fthe anthropologists The men were either German-Jewish or Eastern-European. Lowie came fromVienna (not jewish?), Goldenweiser from Kiev, Radin from Lodz, Sapir from Pomerania. They were not from the same social classes. "Kroeber's father was a wealthy importer; Lowei's a small businessman, Radin's a former rabbi, Goldenweiser's a radical intellectual; Sapir's an impoverished cantor." (196) They were she says in NY connected "by networks of community and ethnicity...Radin and Lowie had been friends since childhood, and Goldenweiser joined their cirlce when he meth tham as undergraduates at City College. Kroeber wasn't Jewish, butlike Boas he came from the German-Jewish community in New York, which was closely knit and intermarried (Kroeber was German, as was Boas's wife) . Infused with the democratic values of the revolution of 1848, that community was politically liberal and ethnically assimilationist." (196) See also f.n. #48, p.482-483, for sources about this community.

    Tags:

    • Jews
    • New York
  • p.197 Discussion of Boas' relation to Feminism and Women Banner notes that Boas did not write about or participate in a womens' rights movement. But he was close to Mary Putnam Jacobi, the wife of his uncle Abraham Jacobi (see 190), who was an "eminen physician and women's rights activist who supported equality for women in the proessions" and Banner writes "one assumes she pressured him to treat his women students fairly." (197) Banner also points out that he used the women to help bolster his anthropological project and he "In 1925 engineered the election of [Ruth] Bunzel, Benedict, and [Gladys] Reichard to the council of the American Anthropological Association." (197)

    Tags:

    • Franz Boas
  • p.197 Feminization of Anthropology after WWI Banner claims that the outbreak of WWI caused a dropp-off in enrollment of young men into anthropology. And that after the war it was primarily women that helped keep the business of the dept. going. "By the outbreak of World War I, however, the constituency of graduate studentsin anthropology at Columbia had shifted. Male enrollment dropped off, as young men enlisted in the army, while the war undermined the unity in the German-Jewish community, which split along pro-German and pro-Allied lines. The Columbia admnistration offended liberal Jews by introducing discriminatory tests as requirement for admission to the college, while Boas's dispute with Nicholas Murray Butler over the war resulted in a reduction of the anthropology department's funds and faculty lines. By 1919 only two graduate students were in residence, and one was Gladys Reichard. Boas and Elsie Clews Parsons decided that women could replace the missing men. Boas's male students could be difficult, often exhibiting, in Mead's words, 'stiff-necked opposition' and 'disgruntled yielding.'" (197)

    Tags:

    • History of Anthropology
    • World War I
  • p.207 - 209 Female Modernists of Greenwich Village and Benedict American Female modernists in U.S. Poetry Journals flourished after the war. Harriet Monroe had established the magainze Poetry in Chicago in 1912. Women in this circle: Amy Lowell, Gertrude Stein, H.D., Marianne Moore, Edna St. Vincent Millay, Louise Bogan (Mead's friend). These women palyed with masculine persona's and some of them almost completelytook on male personas in their poetry such as Stein, Lowell, and Bogan. Banner writes that these women used a tradition of lyrical poetry but with a strong intelelctualism: "They defied male modernists like Eliot and Pound, who were often antiwoman in their verse, by writing poetry in women's traditional lyric style, yet with an intellectualism and emotionalism unmatched by men." (207) And they were popular. Millya, for instance, became the public model of the flapper. The goal Banner says was to distance themsevles from the "nightingale" tradition of sentimental women poets. Those which Banner suggests T.S. Eliot refered to in the opening of "The Lovesong of J. Alfred Prufrock" "In the room the women come and go /Talking of Michelangelo..." (208) These women also drew upon the symbolidsts like Yeats andPount but also metaphysical poets like Donne "who wrote about reason and emotion, love and death, suffering and salvation in the same breath..." (208) Banner suggests that they outdid even Eliot in playing with these themes. She writes: "For they identified with emotionalism--that was decidedly female territory--but they tried to control it. 'They absorbed the male modernists and then used them to elaborate female themes of love and madness.' They were 'anti-modern modernists.'" (208) That classification of them as anti-modern modernists comes from Susan McCabe in "'A Queer Lot' and the Lesbian Talent: Amy Lowell, Gertrude Stein, and H.D." in Challenging Boundaries, ed. Warren (2000) Other sources she cites here on modernist women. Marilyn Farwell, "Toward a Definition of the Lsbian Literary Imagination," Signs 14: 100-118; Gloria Bowels, Louis Bogan's Aesthetic of Limitation (1987); Susan Friedman, Peneloope's Web: Gender, Modernity, H.d.'s Fiction (1990); Gillian Hanscombe and Vigin smyers, Writing for Their Lives: The Modernist Women, 1910-1940 (1987). On use of myth: "Susan Gubar, "Mother, Maiden, and the Marriage of Death: Women Writers and Ancinet Myth" in Women's Studies 6 (1979): 301-15; On sentimentalism: Elizabeth Frank, "A doll's Heart: The Girl in the Poetry of Edna St. Vincent Millay and Louise Bogan" in Critical Essays on Louise Bogan (1984) IN CONTRAST: Benedict did not use the first-person singular in her poetry. She also shifted bewteen male and female voices Banner says (208). In her poetry, men Banner says are "often trapped: Theseus is trapped in the labyrinth; Orion is confined to the heavens; Christ suffers and is crucified . Sometimes a female exists who can release them, as Ariadne rescures Theseus." (208)

    Tags:

    • Gender
    • Greenwich Village
    • Modernism

  • p.214 Benedict report on Dewey Human Nature & Conduct When Mead was getting to know Benedict, she saw Benedict give a talk about Dewey's Human Nature and Conduct at Columbia anthro. seminar. In the book Dewey refers, Banner says, to 2 schools of reform: "The first, dominant before the war, focused on modifying social institutions; the second, dominant after it, focused on modifying individual attitudes. Dewey wanted the two approaches combined, and he praised anthropologists for their input. 'The reason fo rthe present great development of scientific interest in primitive human nature,' he wrote, 'is the interest in progress and reform.'" (214)

    Tags:

    • John Dewey

  • p.214 Mead & Benedict more interested in personality than social movements "The ultimate object remains an inward affair, a matter of attitude,' wrote Benedict. 'My generation,' wrote Mead, 'was more concerned with individuals than with social movements,' with 'the potentialities of the human spirit.'" (214) Neither Banner says were members of women's organizaitons like the League of Women Voters. And Mead had critiqued "radical" feminists for looking down on women who stayed in the home. She said they had produced a 'new tyranny.' (214) In the realm of social reform, Banner argues they were concerned with "educatoin" or what we call "socialization" or "the moolding of the childing by the family and society as much as by the school." (214) She writes that they were also committed to relativism and cultural pluralism: "They saw themselves as part of a group of younger intellectuals who embraced the relativity of cultures and looked ot the formation ofa naitonal culture in the United States that would combine racesa and ethnicities into a mix called 'cultural pluralism.'" She mentions Horace Kallen saying he was a "favforite social philosopher of theirs. For these latter claims about their "generation" she refers to a letter MM to RFB in Anth at Work, p.285, Aug 30, 1924. She says she has drawn on Westbrook's John Dewey; Wilcox, V.F. Calverton: Radical in the American Grain; Kloppenberg, Uncertain Victory; Blake, Beloved Community. And she notes that Mead referred to Kallen's influence in And Keep Your Powder Dry, 325.

    Tags:

    • 1920s
    • Cultural Pluralism
    • Horace Kallen

  • p.216-218 Mead & Sex Manuals Banner reports that Mead was familiar with several Sex manuals. W.F. Robie, The Art of Love. "Mead was a fan of the manual, which includes information about genital manipulation and lubrication, positions in intercourse, and oral sex." (216) Robie though was freelove and homosexuality. He wanted to liberate sex in the marraige to reinvigorate the institution. Mead reviewed sex manuals in a 1931 Birth Control Review. REview of Ingram's the Modern Attitude to the Sex Problem and H. Wright' The Sex Factor in Marriage in Birth Control Review 15 (april 1931): 120-1. Banner thinks Mead's Free-Love position was fixed by her marriage to Luther and their open marraige form. Banner notes that it had a manipulative side and a "gentle and egalitarian" one like that in Ellis and CArpenter. She notes that Mead saw it as an "ethical position, almost a religion." (218)

    Tags:

    • Sexuality
  • p.222 Mead's Poetry Friends "Margaret also became close to a number of young women poets whom she met through Leonie Adams, and Ruth did too. The group included Eda Lou Walton and Louise Bogan, probably their most gifted members. ...All wrote in the lyrical, antimodern modernist style of women poets of this era; most had grown up outside New York and moved to Manhattan, as Benedict and Mead had. The found one another through publishing in poetry journals and speaking at poetry readings, held throughout New York City in a time when poetry was very popular. They held poetry evenings and parties at which they drank cootleg liquor and played rhyming games...." (222)
  • p.225 Ruth convinces Mead to bi-sexuality Banner thinks that by end of 1924 Benedict and Mead had become lovers and Ruth had "persuaded Mead to abandon her 'foolish one-sided preference'--for a heterosexual relationship with Luther--and brought her into the 'great glowing affirmation of reciprocity.'" (225)
  • p.225 Ruth didn't go through analysis in early 20s prob. Banner says that Ruth was advised by Marguerite Arnold to seek analysis for "the controlled and sitant self she displayed..." But Ruth was ambivalent about these theories. (225)

  • p.226-230 TSapir & oronto Convention with Jung, and analysis of JUng Mead met Sapir as Sapir was organizing the Toronto meetint of the British Ass. for the Adv. of Science. held in Sept. 1924. At the meeting C.G. Seligman praised C.G. Jung's "introvert and extravert" typologies. (227) Banner makes the intersting argument that Jung didn't "tread on" the territory of the anthropologists the way Freud had in Totem and Taboo and so that Jung's theory as more acceptable to them. "Jung roamed over history, concluding that the East, with its mystical religions, was introverted, while the West, expansive and imperalist, was extraverted." (228) Jung Banner writes had also raised gender question. He "maintained that males possessed a female 'anima' and females a male 'animus'--in what seems a variation on contemporary notions of inversion. Most present-day feminists take Jung as a misogynist,on the grounds that he usually rated the animus superior to the anima, but he had feminist followers in New York." Beatrice Hinkle was one. She was a member of Heterodoxy. Banner points outthat Hinkle's partner advocated bi-sexuality in a way that reminds Banner of Ruth and Mead. (229)

  • p.229- Mead's Sapir Affair Banner thinks that Sapir and Mead were mutually interested, but Sapir wanted Mead to be his wife and shew asn't having. Banner also thinks that Benedict tampered in it from both sides, manipulating both Sapir and Benedict. Mead tried to cool Sapir's interest by faking nerovus attacks but it didn't work. He was more interested. Ultiamtely he decided htat she had a "prostitution complex" "that resulted from her girlhood conviction that she was unattractive and that drove her to have promiscuous intercourse with men to prove her desirability." (231) Then Sapir decided to appeal to Mead's masochism. He "announced that he intended to reshape her, to 'hew right and left, as a sculptor flakes oof his marble bits with courage and coolness'..." (232, ES to RFB Aug 18, 1925) Then he wrote that to Benedcit htat Mead need to have achild to cool her 'erotic impulse.'" (232, from ES to RFB Oct 14, 1925) Then Sapir chided Ruth for encouraging what he saw as "psychic irregularities.". He accused her as "something cruel, Ruth, in your love for psychic irregularities." (quoted on 232, from ES to RFB , oct 13, 1925) The whoel thing ended with Ruuth and Mead's trip to Grand Canyon, which Banner connects to Bendict's fantasy world and the ravine in Mead's chilldhood. (233) And it led to the letter to Mead's grandmother about their different reactions, which Banner reads in terms of sexual symbolism Mead's being masculine admiring "miles of pinnacled clay,' with a 'new shadowing cloud' showing endless possibilities.'" (233) Whereas Benedict seeks secrecy in the river, a female symbol. (233) Mead kept writing to Sapir after that but Sapir gave her an ultimatum after he met another woman and then when she didn't respond he married th other woman. Mead then burned his letters (234). Source here letters from Sapir to RFB in Mead Library of Congress, S-15.

    Tags:

    • Edward Sapir
  • p.235-238 Banner's account of Freeman's critique She sides with those that Mead was not duped but her product wasinfluenced by who she was and the focus she had taken.

  • p.238 Boas & Field Method Boas told Mead while in Samoa that he though tinformants didn't open up until just before one left the field (238)

  • p.247 Banner contrasts Benedict and Mead's 1926 appraoches to anth "On the ship to the United States [afterfight in Rome], Mead and Benedict began an intense discussion about anthropology that, according to Mead, lasted 'for years.' Mead made a stand: she asserted, following Jung, that the way to connect a culture and human behavior and thus to establish an intellectual direction for the field of anthropology was to find a theory that established a systematic relationship between universal characteristics of humans and their representations in specific cultures. Benedict disagreed. She though that no theory was necessarily any better than any other and that cultures had little coherence. That was her psotion in the fall of 1926, a position that reflected both the stance she had taken in her dissertation and her gloomin Europe over Mead's behavior. Yet a year later she changed her mind, insprired by a new impetus from her fieldwork among the Puetblo Indians and a new turn in her relationshp with Mead." (247) Here Banner cites, Mead's Ruthe Benedict P. 34, 35.

  • p.262 Summer 1927: Benedict in field to Pueblo This is an important trip in which she according to Banner realizes her configuration concept. Banner writes: "While she was studying the Pima Indians, a tribal society immediately to the southwest of the Zuñi, her perceptions fell into place: she had the experience of sudden intuition common to creative discovery, as she realized with 'a sense of revelation' that Pima culture resembled that of the Indians of the Plains and that it was different from the culture of the Zuñi and the other Pueblo Indians--even though, according to the principle of diffusion, the Pima and the Zuñi cultures, which were geographically so lose, ought to have been similar." (263) Here Banner quotes Anthrop. at Work, 201-212 and Mead's Ruth Benedic,t p.35.

  • p.264 Dream books, Homosexuality, Fear of Exposure Reo had worked on a book on dream,s and Margaret started hers also. Banner describes it as a psychological project. involved collecting account sof dreams from her friends Leonie, Louise and David. Put together a questionaire. Never published. In it she talks about a dream acquring a passport to Reo's heterosexual world. And she wrote "The whole business...is an expression of a suppressed fear that after all I am primarily a homosexual person." And then Banner says that she had corssed out homosexual and wrote in heterosexual. (266) She also wrote that her dreams about a dead baby "is a heterosexual attitude neglected and starved, and finally dead and rotting, but hidden away from everyone." (quoted on 266) Banner writes on 268 that Mead had a fear of exposure ofbeing homosexual. esp. in the context of the turn against homosexuality in the late 20s. The Wanda Neff novel may have heightened that fear. (268-9) Ruth answered it too. See Dream Research File in Mead, Library ofCongress On Homosexuality also see her review of Flloyd Dell's Love in the Machine Age in which he charged tat increase in homosexuals would destroy Western civilization. Apparently Banner writes Mead only "mildly protested" Dell's claims. (269) But Mead was reading book with homosexual themes. Banner lists robert Herrick's, The End of Desire; David Garnett's Go she Must (1927); Rosamond Lehmann's Dusty Answer (1927); Virginia Woolf's Orlando (1928); Marcle Prousit's Cities of the Plain (1927). ( 269) In 1935 Mead also again referred to fear of having her sexual identity exposed in a Forum article. It had to do with perceptions of people with non-membership in their sex: "By 1935, in an article she wrote for the journal Forum, a public interest magazine, she alludd to that fear--and she linked it to the issue of sexual identity. 'A Person without full sex membership' she wrote, 'is worse off than a man without a country.' In many professional fields, Mead implied, successful women faced being identitified as mannish and thus homosexual. That possiblity was a 'handicap' that generated a 'paralyzing fear.' 'Every woman who enters a field where in proportion as she is successful she will be voted unwomanly,' Mead concluded,' works under a handicap, a handicap of paralyzing fear.'" (271)

  • p.277 Mead's "The Ultimate Book on Individuality" & Morris Crawford, art conoisseur Mead has affair with Morris Crawford that Banner calls an "art conoisseur." (276) He tried to seduce her Banner says and "proposed fantastic schemes: a famous dress designer would dress her, and she would write a popular treatise on dress. They would live in New Bedford, Massachusetts, with whaling vessels nearby; he would pain and she would write...They would visit a 'crazy' couple who always tried to seduce their guests and who practiced 'a highly rareified from of the spectator perversion.' She would analyze everybody and 'explain everything'; he would produce ood types to 'dance for her.' She would write a book about it all. Indeed, Among her letters to Ruth after she left New York to marry Reo is a page of notes for a chpater in 'The Ultimate Book on Individuality.' It would focus on some sexual abnormality like exhibitionism or spectatorship and then illustrate it in the behavior of indiviudals 'in a graded scale of complexity.' After all, she wrote, everyone has the same drives. 'Finally,' she speculated, 'you would have samples where sophistication, education, wealth were all bent in an elaborate and complex pattern to the satisfaction of exactly the same basic need as when it was found in the simplest physiological terms.'" (277)

  • p.280 - Sapir's Attack on Mead Article "Observations on the Problem of Sex". Also published in Child Study (March 1930): 519-34. And Benedict says Banner reports in Intertwined lIves, p.498, f.n. 101, that it was also published “in a book on marriage that was edited by an assisant minsiter at her brother-in-law's church and issued by a religious press., see RFB to MM June 10, 1931 LC, S-5. Banner argues that this text is “damning Mead and the book—without mentioning her or it by name.” (280, Intertwined Lives). In it Banner says that he “called her a 'bored adventurer' 'a hetaera,' and a 'prostitute' so jaded that she was sexuall frigid. He attacked her for failing to realize the importance of jealousy in a committed relationship, for a 'true lover' in his view couldn't stand any hint of infidelity. He accused her of having misinterpreted her data, charging that her belief in the 'enrichment of personality' through 'multiple experience' prevented her from viewing 'organisational responses skeptically.' He asserted that all 'primitive' societies had rigid taboos on sex and that none permitted sexual license. “ (280-281) Banner also argues that Sapir seems to have tried to publish this text in as many places as possible. He wanted people to see it. (280) Banner, though, argues that Sapir's "vendetta against Mead" existed before Coming of Age and continued long after. That he was criticziing her in 1925 when she was in Samoa and he was with Malinowski on a tour of anthropology depts. in the U.S. (281) In 1929, he writes to Benedict that "Mead was a 'loathesome bitch,' a 'malodorous symbol' of everything that he hated in American culture." (281, ES to RFB April 29, 1929, Mead Papers, LC, S-5) And apparently Mead reported tha tSapir was telling his verison of their affair to other men in the profession. And that she thought he was trying to do them in. (281, MM to RFB, Dec.2, 1932). But in 1930 Banner reports in f.n. #498, p281: "Mead had Leonie Adams write to Edmund Wilson at the New Republic, asking him not to send her book on the Manus to Sapir to review, since 'he has a bad case of prejudice in that quarter.' (Leonie Adams to Wilson, Oct. 5, 1930, Edmund Wilson Papers.)" In 1937 Banner says that Mead complained "to Benedict that she wasn't being consulted in the profession becaues of the old canard spread by Sapir and Malinowski." (281) Banner notes that Mead responded in an article on Jealousy for CAlverton and SChamlhausen's complilation of articles on cultural trends. (281)

  • p.286 The Modernism of Benedict's Patterns of Culture Banner writes: "In Patterns of Culture Benedict followed the modernist project of assembling reality around abstract patterns, although she stressed that the psychological terms she applied to her societies--Dionysian, Appolonian, paranoid, megalomaniac--might not fit any other society than the ones to which she applied those terms. 'It would be absurd,' she wrote, 'to cut every culture down ot the Procrustean bed of some catchword characterization.' Her 'modernism' wasn't simple: it always encompassed on some level the emphasis on variety of her doctoral dissertation, the breaking down of absolutes. Moreover, she argued that Western categories for mental disturbances, like schizophrenia and manic-depressive disorder, probably didn't hold for non-Western socities: she terby challenged their validity even for the United States. She implied a similar possiblity with regard to gender, point thie way to Mead's revisions in this area." (286) For challenges to categories of mental disturbances: "anthropology and the Abnormal.", 59-82. For challenges to gender in Mead, "Temperamental Differences and Sexual Dimorphism," p. 179 where she wrote: "Benedict believed in temperament (genetic makeup) to a degreee, but she never had any theory of temperament." (499, f.n. #6)

  • p.286 Women in Benedict * Mead's Ethnography Banner argues that Benedict concluded in Patterns that "men control most societies and that women are oppressed in most of them." (286) Mead she says also had demonstrated this in her works on Manus and an Omaha community in Nebraska (Growing up in New Guinea (1930) & The Changing Culture of an Indian Tribe (1932). Banner gives no page # in Growing up, but p. 150 in Changing Culture. Banner sums it up this way: "The Manus women are pawns in a system of exchanges accompanying marriage; the Omaha women are so enmeshed in their traditional culture that they don't take advantage of their legal rights under the laws of the United States. IN both societies group rape is glorified by men. In her article on jealousy (1931), Mead asserted that 'throughout history women have been the <i>insecure</i> sex. Their status, the freedom of action, their very economic existence, their right over their own children, has been dependent upon their preservation of their personal relations with men.' In 1935, in an article on women in tribal societies, she identified a 'widespread and biologically defined political disability of women.'" (286)

  • p.288 Patterns of Culture & Tensions with Male Anthrop. Banner thinks that Sapir had encouraged Benedict to write the book on theory that Boas didn't. Sapir thought the "dyed-in-the-wool anthropologists" woulnd't b/c they were too "proud of their 'erudite negativism' to write a book that would appeal to the public." (288) (ES to RFB, Aug. 23, 1924, Philip Sapir letters, Bethesda Maryland) But Sapir didn't like the book in the end. He wanted to write his own: "The Psychology of Culture" and he proposed writing a series of articles on tribal societies forthe <i>American Mercury</i>, but Mencken turned him down. (288) Ultimately, he disliked Benedict's approach. He didn't like her Appolonian/Dionysian division. and her focus on abnormality and cultural configs. He critiqued her of avoiding the individual in "The Emergence of the Concept of Personality in a STudy of Cultures" Journal of Social Psych 5 (1933): 408-15. He accused her moroever Banner says of "focusing on the concept of culture rather than the individual as a way of hiding her own self, and of failing to realize that cultures were mainly collections of individual who interpreted cultural patterns in 'endlessly differetn ways.'" (288) And Banner thinks that in say the las tpart Sapir was influenced by Harry Stack Sullivan's self-spychology. Sapir had promoted the Personality-and-culture" approach. (288) Benedict rejected Sapir's criticism in 1932 in "Configurations of Culture in North America". And in a letter to Mead after hearing a speech of his that he was "slighting the power of societies to shape their members..." (Banner's words, 289, RFb to MM, Nov, 30, 1932, Anth at Work, p. 325). Kroeber: Benedict was more amiable with Kroeeber, but she also felat that he ignored her work when he wasat Columbia in the spring semester of 1932 but then he taught a course "Personality and Culture" in which he "analyzed 'half a dozen cultures for whether Superman could have ben bred i them.' Predictably, according ot Benedict, he 'gave the laurels to the Plains [Indians]'" (289, quote from RFB toMM, April 2, 1932, Lib. cong, S-5. According to Meadin her Ruth Benedict, Benedict was so angry at Kroeber that she began Patterns, see Mead, Ruth Bendict, p.38.

  • p.292 Benedict's Reputation Benedict had a high reputation in the field by the mid-30s. Science had in 1932 listed her as one of the five leading anthropologists. Andin 1933 American Men of Science starred her name as of the 1,250 outsanding scientists along with Boas, Parosns, Sapir, Lowie, Kroeber... (292).   • p.294-5 Benedict's Link between disc. of Lesbian Self and Writing Patterns Banner thinks that giving up men, deciding on lesbianism, and emphasizing a masculine self in tandem with her feminine one, helped her write Patterns.

  • p.294, 298-9 Neo-Freduians, Self-Discovery, Karen Horney & Abraham Maslow 294:Horney & Maslow, both friends of Benedict's, had begn to emphasize the idea of discovering one's true self. This was more broadly a neo-Freudian approach. One had to just strip of the "anxiety endemic to Western civilization" in order to discover one's "'true' self, peaceful, resourceful, careing." (294) This idea Banner noted, of true self, was also important for eastern mystical religions liked Budhism and Sufism. 298-9: Benedict, Banner says, can be lumped with the Neo-Freudians many of whom were friends. She mtions Horney, Erich From. But Bendict only cited psychologist GArdner Murphy, a friend. She critiqued scientism of psychologists by using Apollonian/Dionysian Banner notes. (298). Banner describes Benedict as an "eclectic" drawing from Adler, Jung,Freud... She used Freud's idea of "wish fulfillment" in his dream book to "explain the content of folktales." (298) But she didn't like "his theories of individual development--the libidio, the Oedipus complex, and his categorizations for infant development based on oral, anla, and genital zones." (298-99) She wrote about this in a 1938 review of Horney's Neurotic Personality of Our time. Banner thinks however that Bendict may have been influenced by Freud's notion of the primal horde and his reaction to WWI: "Freud's theory of civilization as growing out of the conflicts within a 'primal horde' and his post-World War I social psychology focusd o the irrationality of modern society may have influenced her: in <i>Patterns of Culture</i> she seems ot have plunged into Freud's tumultous 'unconscious.'" (299) (Freud stated the idea of the primal horde in Totem and Taboo and in "Group Psychology and the Analysis of Ego.")

  • p.299 Benedict as Reformer Deeplyinfluenced Banner thinks by John Dewey. "espcially to his emphases on education and on social engineering through the leadership of experts in the social sciences." (299) She rejected Marx's idea that "economoic system determines culture..." (299) Emphaiszing the importance of creative acts that were regulated by an "impersonal force". In "Science of Custom" she wrote: "Man evolves always elaborate traditional ways of doing things, great superstructures of the most varying designs, and without very striking correlations with the underpinnings on which they must each and all eventually rest." (299) Benedict was never attracted to socilism Banner writes, and she thinks that Benedict attracted Mead to Dewey away from Socialism. (299) Byut then in the 1930s, she followed Dwey into embracing a "modified state socialism and supporting the New Deal andits more radical programs for housing and welfare." (299)

  • p.300- 302 Literary Influences on Benedict Virginia Woolf's The WAves. George Santayana and Robinson Jeffers. Her use of three societies she notes matched Santayana's Three Philosophical Poets. She rejected Edmund Wilson's critique of the Symbolism and call for return to realism in Axel's Castle. Thus she was intrigued by Jeffers. Banner says these tenencies are evident in "The Bo-Cu Plant" and "The Uses of Cannibalism" both unpublished.
  • p.302- Analysis of Benedict's Patterns Notes a "sense of irony" in the book . 302. Geertz "defined her as engaging in a process of 'self-nativising,' as juxtaposing 'the all-too-familiar and the wildly exotic in such a way that they change places.'" (302). Banner thinks Geertz doesn't capture the way Benedict was engaging with the "contemporary historical period and her feminism..." (302) Banner argues that the work shares the structure ofa journey that she claims most "masucline epics" of the time had. The Journey motif she says B used was the one of a hero's descent to hell before ascent to heaven. Dionyusus going to Hades to rescuse his mother, Dane, etc... Bunyan's pilgram. It begins with the peaceful Zuni, then descends to the hell of the Dobuans and the Kwakiutl. Then it gets to a middle ground, which is? Perhaps Zuni, but she didn't like their self-control and conformity. She might then have preferreed the Plains Indians who had this individualistic vision quest. But she didn't like their warlike tendencies. And Banner note sthat her most positive description of any group is of thePlains Indians, the men-women of the Plains Indians. Shje was drawaing on Elsie Clews Parsons work! about berdaches. They were ridiculted among the Zuni, but not so much among the Plains indians. "where there role was more fully developed than in any other Native American culture area." (304) But they were there regarded as superior b/c they could excell in both men's and women's occupations. She wrote that the berdache's house was "a model for all households through the sole efforts of the berdache.' For the man-woman had 'two strings to his bow,' wrote Benedict, and 'no one in the culture was richer.'" (304) Banner adds that this celebratio nof the berdache can also be seen as a critique of Kroebe'rs "celebration of the masucline of the Plains Indians in his lectres at Columbia in 1932." Banner speculates: "The institution of th berdache made the male anthropologists uncomfortable, and they avoided it, often assuming that effete males took on the role to avoid becoming warriors and that they were ridiculed for doing so." (304) Though she notes that Kroeber argued that antihomosexual attitudes were not good in "Psychosis or Social Sanction" in Characterand personality 3 (1940): 210. And Lowie Banner notes was ambivalent, and she cites Primitive Religion (orig. pub. 1924, 1973) pp. 1818, 243-46. He called it perversion apparently but praised connection to spirituality in some tribes. (see f.n. 74, p502.)

    Tags:

    • Gender
  • p.304-306 Shift in Benedict's attitude by writing Patterns Banner argues that once Benedict wrote Patterns she had excised her deeper angst. And that the book also had a more pragmatic reformist side. Banner writes "By this point she had largely solved the issues of religion and reason and of emotion and self-realization that had long troubled her. She could write about the horrors of the religion of the Kwakiutl because she had resolved them for herself. In a series of entries she wrote for the Encyclopaedia of the Social Sciences on religion, magic, and myth, Benedict took a stand in favor of a rational skepticism and a social-psychological point of view. Thus she maintained that myth and folklore were no more than wish fulfillment, and magic was mechanistic. It involved a philosophy, not a mysterious connection between animate objects and a spirit world. Even the Zuni snake dance, with priests handling the dread rattlesnake, winding it around their bodies and putting its head into their mouths, wasn't dangerous, since they removed the poison from the snake's poison sac before they danced with it. Benedict now viewed magic as dangerous in a new way, for it could lead to 'fear neuroses' such as those that troubled Freud's 'obsessional neurotics.'" (306) {para} When Beneidct completed these articles, not much was left of her earlier espousal of Pater an Yeats and the search for secular ecstasy thorugh symbols that might lead to a sense of unity with an all-encompassing universe. 'Scientific advance,' she wrote, 'is always furthered by giving up patheism.' God was not more than the trickster figure of American Indian religions--or he was a 'doddering old woman.' These articles...sugested that reason had come to predominate in Bendedict's life. She had become the rational male that becoming homosexual implied to her." (305-6)

  • p.313 Mead & Manus Mead Banner says did not like Manus "with its materialism, Puritanism, and sexual double standard, ut its parallels to the United States in thises matters fascinated her. She revisited it five times between 1950 and 1971, as its people adapted to Westernization." Banner lists comments on Manus in Mead, "Meaning of Freedom in Education" 107-111; "An Investigation of the Though of Primitive Children, with Special REference to Animism" Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute 62 (1932): 173-90; "Kinship in the Admiralty Islands" Anthropological Papers of the American Museum of Natural History 34, 2 (New York, 1934) 183-358. f.n. 2 p. 504.

  • p.314 Mead's Fascination w/ Berdache in Omaha summer of 1930 Banner writes: "During that summer Margaret became fascinated by a young Omaha man who was becoming a berdache. His behavior was so ambiguous that she couldn't tell if he was male or female. Tribal members were calling him 'her'; he was turning from doing men's work to doing women's work. In tribal dances, dressed as a man, he began dancing among the men, and then, putting on jewelry, he danced among the women. Reo's homosexual friend Max Bickerton came to visit from Japan, and he thought that the young man's walk was exactly like that of male prostitutes in Japan. Margaret thought that he didn't walk the way women walked; his movements in walking seemed to come from some fantasy of his about how women moved. The tribe's prostitute refused to have sex with him; tribal members made fun of him. When he was a young boy, she was told, several women had examined his genitalia." (314) Banner says that this made a big impression on Mead. She had seen male "perverts" and female "mixed types" . She had seen casual homosexual behav. in Manus apparently. But she had never seen someon in the act of becoming. So Banner htinks she wondered was he a "congenital invert' womeone with an innate drive twoard homosexuality?" Was he a transvestite, heterosexual cross dresser? Was he a hermaphrodite? Banner thinks this challenged her differences with Benedict. Her dubiousness about Benedit's cultural determinism, especially when it came to gender, because Banner thinks that Mead was "so certain that culture was paramount when it came to gender: she felt intuivitely that heredity was important, as in the differences between herself and her siblings." (314)

    Tags:

    • Cultural Determinism
    • Culture Concept
    • Gender

  • p.315-316 Mead's Attitude about Culture & Gender Before going to Sepik Mead was perhaps not clear on gender when she went to New Guinea (Sepik) the second time with Reo. She knew that she wanted to study roles of men and women. There is evidence that at this point she felt that societies operated in binary: "She thought she had to study cultures that separate masculine from feminine, although at this point she thought that most societies operated in terms of that binar, as she stated in <i>Sex and Temperament</i>: 'I shared the general belief of our society that there was a natural sex-temperament which could at the most only be distorted or diverted from normal expression.' She had considered even mixed types, she wrote, to be composed of men with feminine temperaments and women with masculine ones. [see Sex & Temp. p. xiv]" (315) Banner further describes that she thought she needed to take herdity into account, but neither she nor Reo knew biology. Then Banner says she decided that it was wise to address how cultural differences were determined culturally before biologically which Banner says is what William Fielding Ogburn "had stressed in his class at Barnard..." (316) Here Banner has no citation for this claim about Ogburn. Banner also argues the Mead's sexual binarism was "overdrawn" considering that Beatrice Hinkle did work breaking down this binary, and the "existence of the bisexual chic of the 1920s." (316) But the "mannish lesbian" (i.e. the kind of figure that Mead was thinking of with her woman with masculine traits) was also a strong figure at the time. She notes Radclyffe Hall's <i>Well of Loneliness</i>; Freud's assertion in the "Psychogenesis of a Case of Homosexuality in a Woman" that "...'bodily and mental traits belonging to the opposite sex are apt to coincide.'" (quoted on 316) as contributing to the image. (316) Anthropological work on the subject had been done by Edward Westermarck <i>Origin and Development of the Moral Ideas</i>. There he had said that sexuality ranged between inversion and normal sexuality, but that homosexual were "inverts." (316) William McDougal a Harvard scienceists had said that he didn't know the connection bewteen homosexuality and inversion, but that homosexuality did exist. And in the popular <i>The Dominant Sex</i> a feminist work of 1920s, Mathilde Vaerting argued that in societies where women controlled men, they became masculine in behavior. In Patterns, Benedict used homosexuality and invert interchangeably, see p.262 of patterns.

    Tags:

    • Cultural Determinism
    • Gender
    • William Fielding Ogburn

(318) This was in summer 1930 when they headed to Sepik (she and Reo). No footenote indicating which letter in Banner.

    Tags:

    • A.R. Radcliffe-Brown
    • British-American Anthropology Tension
    • History of Anthropology
  • p.320-324 Bateson and why he appealed He was from a family that traced roots to inelletual aristocracy of England. They were freethinkers. People like the Darwins and Huxleys. They had bene Quakers and businessmen in early 19t-century. Know held positions at Oxford and Cambridge. Bateson's father , William Bateson, was a famous genetecist at Cambridge, and had coined the word "genetic." Gregory was named after Gregor Mendel. (320-1) Bateson held free-love views. He may or may not have been the lover of Noel Teulon Porter, the free-love sexologist that ran the Half Moon hostel a in Cambridge. Porter was tied in with Havelock Ellis and Edward Carpenter. Porter had called for a combination of sexology, anthropology, biology and botany -- a discipline which he together called "ecology." (321) Bateson also may have been in a romantic relationship with Porter and another., probably Elizabeth Stevenson. He called Porter "Johnny" and Stevenson "Steve." He described later his relationship with Porter as like that of Mead's to Benedict. (322)

    Tags:

    • Gregory Bateson
    • Noel Porter
    • Sexology
    • The New Moralism
  • p.324 Episode of the Goats Mead and BAteson fell in love after apparently Reo, Margaret and Bateson climbed a mountain to investigate a tribe and Bateson suggested they bathe nude. Margaret joined in and Reo was bothered. At some point they sat across a table talking for 15min and Banner writes "established a spiritual connection." This was the episode of the goats, as they cameto call it. Goats refers to ghosts Banenr notes in f.n. 48, p507. There are many references to it throughout their letters she says. (507) And she quotes Lipset's Gregory Bateson: "In 'Summary Statement on Culture and Personality' Mead contended that passive individuals, left alone without mental stimulation, would 'see ghosts.' But when two passive individuals came together and exchanged ideas, deep spirituality would result. The episode of the 'first goats' would have been their first meeting, when she and Reo picked up Greogry to take him to the Christmas celebration at Ambunti, and she and Gregory wereimmediately attractedto each other." (507)
  • p.333-4 Mead challenges Benedict's Homosexuality In March 1933, Mead challenged B's homosexuality in a letter. B had just decided on her identity more or less after being abandoned by Tom Mount. Mead wrote: "The kind of feeling which you classified as 'homosexual' and 'heterosexual' is really sex adopted to like or understood temperaments versus sex adopted to a relationship of strangeness and difference. I believe every person of ordinary sex endowmen has a capacity of diffuse 'homosexual' sex expression and specific climax--according to the temperamental situation. To call men who prefer the diffuse experience 'feminine' or women who feel only the specific 'masculine' or both 'mixed types' is a lot of obfuscation--or nonsense. ." Mead also wrote "You're a perfectly good woman...who prefers different temperamental types and responds differently to them." (334) (333-334, MM to RFB, March 29, 1933, Lib. Cong, R-7). Ruth apparently didn't reply (334)
  • p.339 Benedict's Response to the Squares It wans't good at first. But then she gave in and accepted it. This apparently accoridng to Banne restored their friendship when it was not good. (339)
  • p.342-343 Mead's attempt to secure reputation Between fall 1933 when coming back ffom Sydney and spring of 1936 when she went to Singapore to marry Bateson, Banner says she wrote articles to secure her reptuation. 1931 article on fieldwork methodology: "More Comprehensive Field Methods" AA 35 (1933): 37-53. She answers attacks of Sapir and other Male Boasians about her method. 1934: Article pub. in character and Personality about config. theory. "The Use of Primitive Material in the Study of Personality" Charachter and Personality 3 (1934) 3-16. Also Review of The Riddle of the Sphinx by Geza Roheim... shows knowledge of Freudian theory.
  • p.342 - Getting close to Psychologists 1935 Mead and Benedict get close to Karen Horney. Esp. Benedict Banner says. (342) That was the same year that Horney b/c a Neo-Freudian, a change which Banner says was "ratified" by Benedict's cultural determinism (342). Erich Fromm also in NY and Fromm, Horney, Mead and Bendict also spent evenings together. (342) Mead also befriended John dollard, who helped her understand Freudian theory and the life-history approach. (343)

    Tags:

    • History of Anthropology
    • History of Psychology
    • Neo-Freudianism
  • p.344-5 Geoffrey Gorer Imporant male friend. She and Benedict gave him a course in fieldwork methods. they met him atend of 1935 when he was in New York promoting his book Africa Dances. He was attractive to Mead b/c of his feminine masculinity, sophistication, aristocracy. He knew W.H. Auden. He had written populr stuided of Marquis de Sade and Balinese Culture. Acc. to squares Geoffrey wrote that he and she were southerners. and to Bateson she described him as a "Southern excitor" (

  • p.499, f.n. 1 Original title of Benedict's Patterns of Culture was "Primitive Peoples: An Introduction to Cultural Types". See Anthropologist at Work, p. 322. Mead counseled Benedict to abandon this title b/c of the problemswith the category primitive. Mead suggested that Benedict describe them as "homogenous" instead. For familiarity of "primitive" Mead, review of <i>The Riddle of the Sphinx, by Geza Roheim, Character and Personality 4 (Sept. 1935): 90. Benedict

    Tags:

    • History of Anthropology
  • p.504, f.n. #5 Sources on Mead's Omaha work "On mead and the Omaha berdache, see Margaret Mead, 'Summary Statement of the Problem of Culture and Personality,' March 1933, New Guinea Field Notes, Tchambuli, LC, N-102; handwritten, untitled comments by Gregory Bateson on the Omaha berdache, undated, unsighed, in Bateson's letters in the R file, LC; Mead, Sex and Temperament, p.295; MM to George Devereux, July 26, 1938, LC, R-10; and Mead, "Cultural Determinants of Sexual Behavior,' pp. 1452-53."
