title: The Knower and the Artificer, with Postcript 1993
text:
# David Hollinger, "The Knower and the Artificer, *with* Postscript 1993" in *Modernist Impulses in the Human Science, 1870-1930, ed. Dorothy Ross (Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 1994),  46-53.

> Note Session: July 2012. I am reading this for my "Manifold Origins" paper. Dorothy I suggested that I look at it in regards to the historiographical point that I am trying to make re modernism and postmodernism. She thought that in the historiography the whole discussion about modernism v  postmodernism and what they are is less and less important, but that the issues of universalism v particularism continue to be argued. I wonder what it means that there is a move away from arguing the modernism/postmodernism thing. Certainly, it is tiresome! Especially, the way it seems to be breaking here in Berliin, and in my conversations with Anselm. The whole turn against postmodernism as a negative thing...which misrepresents the goals of postmodernism and describes it as a return of the "barbaric." This being part of a celebration of Enlightenment and of what Hollinger hear calls "cognitivism." I just wonder if the desire to move away from postmodernism is just a way of turning back toward cognitivism in the end; because those who see postmodern ideas as useful **need** to answer their critics in the post-9/11 world. Hollinger in his "The Knower and the Artificer" essay is I think somewhat dismissive of the critique of cognitivism that was made at the end of the 19th Century by Nietzsche and the like. I think that by separating the Knower and the Artificer as two types he wants to isolate the two lines of thought in a way that forces a choice and leads anyone with a scientific impulse to turn toward cognitivism. I am not 100% sure that is what he is doing but it is my basic understanding and I do not like it. Dorothy, however, suggested I look at the postscript here with the following statement:

>>Re the historiographical issue, modernist and postmodern insights can be seen as intertwined at their late 19th century origin. Dorothy wrote to me: "Postmoderns have often accused modernists of lack of courage in seeing them through - Defenders of the enlightenment would see that as a wise resistance to irrationality. Boas seems to have a foot in both camps. I think you can pick up some of this in Hollinger's Postscript to his essay in my Modernist Impulses volume."

> I am like these postmoderns in accusing the defenders of the englightenment of a lack of courage in seeing through what Dorothy describes as the late 19th century intertwining of modernist and postmodernist insights. But what is this intertwining? I was making an argument like this in the Manifold Origins article. The "modernist impulse" as well as the postmodernist impulse, I argue,  are linked to the recognition of the problem of subjectivity at the end of the 19th century -- a development that had many causes and which produced many reactions. Modernism and postmodernism are names for one branching of those responses: the modernist, I think, still confronts the problem of subjectivity but tries, if she is a scientist, to use it as a basis to reconstruct a new scientific approach that recognizes the problem. Dewey and Peirce and Weber are examples it seems. Then there is the postmodernist reaction, which is grounded in aestheticism, in a tendency to collapse the scientific-cognitivist project of the Enlightenment into something else, not concerned with accurate representation of the extenral world and so on. What I have found in Boas is somebody containing both of these impulses, linked together, each having more or less clear advantages and disadvantages.  Pehaps Hollinger's postscript will help me clarify the terms again...but also Dorothy's argument was that I should downplay the discussion of modernism and postmodernism and focus instead on my sense that what is important is "how we think today in a globalizing world about cosmopolitanism..." and the positions of univerality v hybridity...

> Starting notes with the Postscript...I should re-read the actual essay, but for the moment here is the basic sense of his argument that I will be working with. I must have notes somewhere. But the idea is, I think, that he distrusts the word modernism, which he thinks is unclear and has acquired a kind of culture mystique in the academy at the time of his writing, which was in the 70s. And in particular he has noted that what is not clear is whether those people who still want to make something of science can be considered part of "modernism," or whether it is just a kind of Nietzschean aestheticization of science that counts as modernism. He thinks modernism includes both scientists and artists who do want to continued making something of science. So he wants to included what he calls "cognitivism" -- as distinct from artifice -- in modernism. I do not have a problem with this claim...it seems true...he gives some examples, saying even that Nietzsche was interested in the knower, at the same time as he gave the artificer langauge to critique the nower with. He is thinking, he says in f.n. 24, of Nietzsche's discussions of a "will to truth." And he refers their to some articles on Nietzsche's notion of truth. I wonder what he would make of Megill's treatment of N's theory of truth? In any case, Hollinger also points out James as someone engaging in an *"effort to bring the Artificer to bear on a theory of science."* (36) This all makes sense to me.  But to call it cognitivism, then, is to too strongly identify the cognitive aim as dominant and the aesthetic one as subordinate. It rips asunder a project that may have  been more ambivalently testing out the different possibilities of nineteenth and early twentieth-century modernity. In my treatment of Boas, I am trying to capture the closeness of these two "impulses" in Boas' thought.

## Postscript 1993

* He starts out the postscript already on a polemical footing that was a bit more buried in the essay perhaps. "The Knower is maligned more than ever as we move into our *fin de siecle*, yet the values this figure embodies are simultaneously invoked with renewed insistence by critics of postmodernism." (46) His point in the postscript is that he thinks there is a pattern of "constructions of *modernism* current within the postmodernist debate render all the more appropriate an effort by historians to confront what I call cognitivism." (46)

* The pattern he is speaking of is the tendency in the literature that seeks to define postmodernism to identify "modernism" as denoting the "Enlightenment tradition." (46) Hollinger sees something of a consensus here in the literature:
>...the modernism invoked as a contrast to postmodernism by postmodernism's advocates, critics, and commentators turns out again and again, to be rooted less in the artistic and literary avant gardes of 1890-1930 and more in the scientific enthusiasms of Descartes, Kant, and the multitude of rationalists, realists, positivists, objectivists, and social engineers of the nineteenth century. Historians accustomed to thinking of modernism as a revolt against positivism may be instructed by references to the 'positivist-modernist tradition,' a historical presence invoked confidently, for example, in the introduction to a breathlessly up-to-date-book entitled *Life after Postmodernism*. (46) He gives some more details of the langauge he is talking about, including a notion that modernism was about the Cartesian "I" for example. (46-47)

* This seems to embolden Hollinger in the claims that he has wanted to make about the Knower being central to modernism. He writes: " How did modernism get here? Well, 'here' -- the Enlightenment -- is where it has always been, for some people." (47) Ie he is suggesting that the pattern has recognized what he had sensed in the original article. He writes more and a bit ambiguously: "The postmodernist debates have accelerated a process by which two quite distinctive revolts against two disparate modernisms have become coexistent, and to some extent integrated, within a single discourse." (47) The two revolts he means are:

 1) the revolt against high modernism in literature and the arts--typical in the work of John Cage, Thomas Pynchon, and John Barth, celebarted by Susan Sontag, Leslie Fiedler, and Ihab Hassan, who stressed this revolt's "dynamism and authenticity in contrast to canonical modnerism said to have long lost its capacity to function as an avant garde." (47) Hollinger also points to a class 1973 paper: "The Myth of Postmodernist Breakthrough" by Gerald Graff, that laid out this revolt against modernism. Hollinger writes: "Descartes, Kant, and Miller were far from central to salient modernism, although complaints did attribute to the American cultural scence a caution, a prudence, and a formal rationality that could be seen as the legacies of a desiccated Enlightenment insufficiently renounced." (48)

 2)  The second was the postmodernist revolt of grand theorists -- not artists -- in France, who were operating in a setting where modernity was "understood to have begun with Descartes." (48) This revolt involved the poststructuralist critiques of Foucautl, Derrida, Lyotard and Baudrillard, who "responded not to literary and artistic cannon but to ideas about language and the human subject inscribed in the prevailing discourses of philospohy, psychology, and politics, especially in France." (48) They drew on the earlier critiqes of Nietzsche and Heidegger, who HOllinger notes were known by that time in the Anglophone world as modernists "loosely comparable to the artist-heroes of the modern cannon." (48) These writers were not primarily known as postmodernists until after Lyotard's 1984 *Postmodern Condition*.

* What Hollinger wants to say is that these two revolts were "amalgamated." (48, he uses this word). These two distinct reactions against distinct modernisms, Hollinger thinks, would not necessarily have been lumped together in the US "had not so many American intellectuals been held in thrall by the quaint belief that there is but a single torch to be passed, requiring that each cultural moment, however multitudinous, be named as though it were an individual or an organization charged with institutionalized responsibility." (48) This amalgamation was further helped by Rorty's engagement with the French movement. Same also with Jameson, whose 1984 "Postmodernism, or the Cultural Logic of Late Capitalism" was key. And many American followers of the Frankfurt School were engaged with postmodernism by Habermas's "attacks on the French postmodernists and on Hans-Georg Gadamer for betraying the Enlightenment project" (49) Then by the late 1980s there were "a host of all-encompassing assessments of postmodernism, touchign upon film, architecture, poetry, epistemology, social theory, fiction, and political economy." (49) The best of these being Harvey's *Condition of Postmodernity*. (49)

* Then here is the kicker line of the essay maybe. What has all this done in relation to his Knower/Artificer essay?
>It has directed attention to the cognitivism dervied from the Enlightenment and has largely approrpriated for postmodernism those elements of late-nine-teenth- and early-twentieth-century "modernism" direected against the Enlightenment Nietzsche turns out to be a precursor, if not a founder, of postmodernism, and the same is sometimes said of William James. (49)

* Now his analysis of the patterns of interpretation this has produced gets quite good. He suggests that there is in these works a kind of "protohistoriography" of the 1890-1930 period that imagines the tension between knowing and artifice was not so strongly felt, ie it is "relaxed," with the aim of suggesting a "stark confrontation between a more radical aestheticism -- postmodernism -- and  more rigidly rationalist and objectivist Enlightenement." (49) In other words, what Hollinger thinks--and what he laid out in the Knower/Artificer article--is that modernism always included attempts by those we call modernists to reassemble a kind of way to "know" while confronting the problem of subjectivity. But in this postmodern "protohistorigoraphy" the resonance between the scientific-cognitive outlook and the problem of subjectivity is forgotten or "evacuated." What is lost is the "hermeneutic sophistication of James and Dilthey, of WEber and Dewey and their contemporaries addressed in this volume and elswehere..." (49) He drops in a quote on 49-50, showing how this sophisticated is relegated to the importance of a footnote.

* The effect of this shift has been he thinks to further confuse--and make less useful--the label modernism beyond even the point of chaos he had found it in when he first wrote the Knower/Artifer essay. How can a term that is used to define defenders of Enlightenment also be used to describe T.S. Eliot for example. He critiques Marshall Berman who seems to have published an essay entitled "Why Modernism Still Matters in an edited Book *Modernity and Identity* (1992) -- Berman seems from HOllinger's point of view to be linking very many people together, perhaps retaining a more flexible sense of the tensions inherent to modernism apart from the figure of moderism presneted in the posstmodernist literature, but in a way that stretches thin the sensibility of the label.

* So again he advises abandoing the modernist-postmodernist debate. He thinks that what has happened since he wrote Knower/Artificer has simply reinforced his belief that "the concept of cognitivism can serve us in the ways I described." (50) He thinks it will be most useful as a term if it is understood to "embrace a great range of science-centered strategies commonly distinguisshed from one another on the basis of epistemological and ontological doctrine." (51) He gives an example by showing how Ian Hacking--who believes that we do come to know small portions of the world in itself--and Karl Pearson--who retreated to a more skeptical position--can be linked through a cognitivist label despite not having the same epistemological/ontological framework. Both were enthusiasitc about since. (51)  So:
>A virtue of the concept of cognitivism is hence that it calls attention to a faith in the cultural capacities of *wissenschaftliche* knowing that transcends standard epistemological divides. If the term *cognitivism* is too gross to help distinguish Bacon from Hume, Mill from Pearson, or Hacking from Habermas, neither do the terms that can perform these valuable labors help to identify the science-centered program forculture that partake of, but surely do not exhaust, the Enlightenment project. (52)

* The other value of cognitivism is that it is a non-teleological concept -- unlike both modernism and postmodernism he thinks. (52)

* He ends again by referring to the reassertion of "cognitive" values that has accompanying the postmodern debates. One node of course is Habermas, but he gives Ernest Gellner as another example in his *Postmodernism, Reason, and REligion*.

title: America in the Eyes of the Germans: An Essay on Anti-Americanism
text:
General Notes 3/2013:

 

Preface

* He notes that when he's talkign about antiamericanism he is not interested in using it as a way to dismiss legitimate criticism of the United States. It is not a catch all term for him. He is interested rather in "biased foreign pereption of America, in particular its German form and specificities." (vii) He does not think that anti-americnaism is a specfically German phenomenon. It is, he says, a "universal phenomenon." (iix)

* He intends the books as a polemic, but at the same time he says that it is focusing on a "discourse with a long tradition." (iix) The materials selcted he says are "entirely representative for the phenomenon of historically durable prejudicial images of America." (iix) That does not mean however that Germans will "see themselves" in these materials. But then he says "such moritifications are part and parcel of any critique -- in Germany and beyond." (iix)

* The book was "triggered" by "the reactions of the Germa public to American involvement in the Gulf War of 1991." It was clear to him then that the images that emerged -- at a moment when there was a shift from the Cold war to a new "unkown world" -- were not spontaneous but had emerged from a long tradition. (ix)]

Ch. 1 Reversals

* He starts out with Locke's quote vv the "New World". "In the beginnign, all the world was America." from his 1690 Two Treatises of Civil Government. There was a second wave of such sentiment after the American Revolution. He then says that therefore the "discovery of America resembled a founding act. The world appeared to be created anew from that moment on, to the extent that it had to be rethought." (4)

* In these representations, two figures emerge. America as "untamed nature", that could be civilized and christianized, and America as "innocent nature" subsequently ruined by "that very civilization that has since been  named 'America' and -- today -- is ocndemned as the epitome of modernity and corrupter of the world." (5)

* In these two images there is the commonality that "America remains the counterworld to Europe, a complementary continent of occidental civilization and a screen upon which to project all the images and metaphors arising from its contrast to Europe: a screen upon which to project isolated portions of self-hate owning mainly to modernity, but blamed only on the New World." (5)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.043 But women "overwhelming" male power in universities

At chicago in 1892 whnen hte university opened women were 40% of the student body.  By 1902, their enrollment had "outstripped that of men, and many feared that withing a few years, if nothign was done to prevent it, the university would become a women's school." (44)   Similarly, by the turn of the century women outnumbrered men Rosenberg says at California, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Michicagan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska,Ohio, Texas, Washington, and Wisconsin. (44)

title: Prophets of Extremity: Nietzsche, Heidegger, Foucault, Derrida
text:
Notes for Prague Metacrisis Paper

Goal: My goal in these notes is to focus on Megill's notion of crisis vv late nineteenth and early twentieth century thought.

Preface

* Right off the bat he says that his book is an interpretation of the thought of Nietzsche, Heidegger, Foucault and Derrida that seeks to place them within the "context of a crisis-oriented modernism and post-modernism that have been the source of much of what is most original and creative in twentieth-century art and thought." (xi)  It's a book about modernism and post-modernism he says.

* The book's interpretation of the the first three thinkers he says is heavily influenced by his reaction to the last: Derrida.  Though he emphasizes that he's not a Derridean and he's uncomfortable with Derrida's claims, esp. the political ones.  He doesn't see Derrida as a political radical.  (xii)  Derrida, he says, helped him "see my own mind clearly...[and] bring to light and to articulate long-held, deeply felt, but ...latent skepticisms concerning the claims and procedures of modernism and postmodernism in art and thought." (xii)

* His focus on modernism and postmodernism he says has led him to focto us on "the aesthetically inclined elements" in the thinkers, ie not Nietzsche the naturalist or Heidgger the analyst of human existence, and so on... (xii)

* And modernism and postmodernism has led him to focus on a specific notion of crisis viz cultural crisis.  He wants to specify what he means. 

a) The crisis he's *not* talking about is the usual notion of crisis, related he says to the "continental philosohpical tradition and out of the theology" of that tradition... (xii)  He means the collapse of the "God of the Philosphers" or the "God of the Bible that occurs with Kant's first critique and in the Bibilical cricisim of David Friedrich Strauss and other "practitioners of historical criticism." (xii-xiii).  The idea is that a "loss of the transcendent dimension, prompted by the notion of Kritik as a pervasive power, leads to modern man's homelessness in the world." (xiii)  He says it's a loss of "authoritative standards of the good, the true, and the beautiful to which reason has access, coupled with loss of the Word of God in the Bible." (xiii)

b) The crisis he's specifying is different.  It's the crisis of historicism, circa 1880-1920.  Ie a crisis of "hsitoricism and of the faith in progress that was the widely diffused, vulgarized form of historicism." (xiii) In this crisis the dominant metaphor, unlike the theological one that he listed above that focuses on the image of the abyss, is the break: "This presupposes something to be broken, nameyl, history; and in order to conceive of the possiblity of history's breaking, one needs to think of it as a line or a movement." (xiii)  So historicism in the theological notion of crisis is the product of crisis; it emerges when absolute standards dissapear and nothing is outside of history.  The crisis of historicism is thus dependent on thinking of history as linear. Otherwise, you couldn't image in to be broken.  Finally, he says, these kinds of crisis thinkers tend ot think of the present as borken, and so also as "undirected, null, degraded" And they tend to project this vision forwards and backwards. (xiii)

* He also calls this a "posthistoricist notion of crisis" rather than a "posttheological notion" (xiii)

* He makes a couple of important references to his own distance from the basic point of view of the thinkers he's writing about.  (xiv, bottom)  He describes Derrida as an "antihistoricist" and then says that his book his historicist thought.  (xv)  But he says his book's "interpretive construction is aestheticist., and also therapeutic..." (xv)  Not clear what he nmeans, but he tries to explain below.  Something about it creating a new world for the reader, that he hopes is also liberating and also, in his treatment of the achivement of Derrida, something that cauess "awe and rapture before a truth unviled by Derrida..." (xv) 

Introduction

* Def'n of Aestheticism: He's not suing it in its' usual sense where it means to be enclosed in a world that is separate from the "real world."  He's referring to a it as an "attempt to expand the aesthetic to embrace the whole of reality.  To put it in another way, I am using it to refer to a tendency to see 'art' or 'language' or 'discourse' or 'text' as constituting the primary realm of human experience." (2)  

* He provides a useful and interesting summary of the modernism/post-modernism relationship vv his notion of the aesthetic: "The irony that pervaded modernism tried to uncover a Man or Culture or Nature or History underlying the flux of surface experience.  In postmodernism, this has given way to a new irony, one that holds these erstwhile realities to be textual fictions.  We are seen as cut off from 'things' and confined to a confrontation with 'words' alone." (2)

* This is the basic def'n of aestheticism, but the details are in the difn't modes that he'll show in the four thinkers.  (2)   [-- This bears a resemblance to Calinescu's Five Faces of Modernity ???]  He gives some elaboration using the words of his thinkers on 2-3. 

* He relates his readings to a book by Stanley Rosen: Nihilism: a Philophsical Essay.  He agrees with Rosen who emphasizes the role of poetics in these thinkers and who also relates the projects of these thinkers to Kan'ts third critique. (4)  But he differs from Rosen in that he's not calling for a return to the "classical linkage of the good, the true, and the beautiful." (4) What is key here is that he's seeing his work as a "study of the continuing impact on us of the thought of the Enlightenment." (4)  He says this because he thinks that what's going on with these thinkers is that they are reacting to "the Enlightement pretension to construct a science of society modeled on natural science." (4)  And the "intellectual problems" that this project created are evident in Kant!  Ie he thinks that Rosen's complaint about the isolation of reason, the good, and beauty is "translatable into a complaint about the Kantian separation of the practical, the theoretical, and the aesthetic." (4)  This is key because he's saying that this crisis of historicism or posthistoricist crisis is an after effect of the enlightement project of creating a science of society...one that is visible esp in Kant's project--which can be seen to have had both a positive and negative impact..(Later of course, Megill will trace the aehsetic idea to the autonomy that Kant gave to aeshetics..)

* The rebellion against Kant ties these thinkers to Romanticism , one of hte first movement to identify the "failure" of the Enlightenment, to react to Kant, and to use his own tools to fight him (7).  He insists that despite the variety of Romaniticisms, they viewed the Enlightenment as having failed to "provide the hoped-for synthesis" and thus their period was a period of transition involved in a confrontation with that failure. (6-7)  This view syncs with what he said vv Enlightenent and crisis on (4)

* Second point of contact with the Romantics is the elevation of the aesthetic, the idea that art was elevated even above the artist: "As the objective embodiment of fleeting, inarticulate insight, art was seen as allowing access to a dimension of reality from which the merely analytical understanding was entirely barred." (7)  This attitude also connects to the thinkers he's looking at.  He deals with difficulties of making this link between Romantics and his thinkers on 8-9. 

* Developing his Kant link further.  He thinks Kant is key because he "stands as the crucial figure between the Enlightenment, Romanticism, and the new thought initiated by Nietzsche." (9)  Megill states that "In Nietzsche's eyes, Kant was a deeply subversive thinker, who had unwittingly underminded the optimistic logic of the Enlightenment." (9)  He argues that Kant pplays a huge role in th ewritings of Heidegger, Foucault and Derrida.  As wella s for the Romantics.  Megill describes Kant as an "ambivalent philosopher" and focuses on the tension between his first and second critiques, the Critique of Pure Reason (1781) and the Critique of Practical Reason (1788).  The internals of these theories is not the point for Megil, but rather "the more general problem of the relationship of the two theories to each other..." (9-10)  This was a problem felt by the Romantics deeply.  The problem highlights a contradiction inherent to the Enlightenment project itself, as begun by Descartes.  The problem is as follows: The background is the idea that the Enlightenment was to construct a science of society on the model of the Natural sciences.  Newton, e.g. had done this with his theory of universal gravitation.  The problem was, as Megill states it, that "Natural science attributes a determinism to the objects of its concern.  [But] If things were free rather than determined, they could not be the objects of science." (10)  If Enlightenment thinkers wanted to construct a science of society, then they would be admitting that individuals were not free, but rather their actions were determined by laws, just like those that determined the movement of the planets and the stars.  The problem was that Enlightenment philosophers also believed in moral codes.  "But the existence of a moral code presupposes that people are free to govern their own actions, since entities incapable of governing their own actions obviously cannot be judged in moral terms." (10)  Megill also restates this in a useful way, stating that one can see science as dealing with a realm of unfree objects and morality (religion?) as dealing with a realm of free objects.  Kant, like Descartes, whom he also criticizes, operates with the assumption that there is a stark division between subject and object (the relam of freedom and the realm of unfreedom, or morality and science), but because he deals with the subject of morality directly he reveals, Megill argues, the deep contradiction in the Enlightenment project. 

* Heidegger, Nietzsche, and Foucault, are all frustrated with this subject/object division, as were Romantics like Fichte, Schilling, and Hegel.  the German idealisets, eh says, were all trying to "attain a unity of subject and object, of ego and non-ego." (11)

* Kant himself suggests, Megill says, severral ways out of the dilemma, but the only one that he's concerned with is that which Kant laid out in the third critique, The Critique of the Power of Judgement, which he says is the least powerful performance of Kant's but nonetheless had a huge impact, in partiuclar on the Romantics.  Why?  Because it "unequivocally maintains the autonomy of the aesthetic judgement.  In doing so, it appears to suggest that there exists an indepedent realm of the aesthetic, a realm quite distinct from the other realms of morality and nature. " (11-12)  Megill positions Kant as making a stand, on the one hand, against Hutchesoin and Shaftesbury who had linked aesthetic and moral judgement and thus "in effect assimilated the former to the latter" (12), and those like Saint-Evremond and La Mettrie, who had linked aesthetic pleasure to sensual pleasure via physiology and psychology, on the other hand. (12)  The divergence here is made in Kant's idea of the "disinterestedness" of aesthetic pleasure.  Megill says Kant denies the existence of a third realm apart form nature and freedom, but he does insist on the "existence of an autonomuos realm of the aesthetic, a realm whose function is to mediate bretween the other two." (12) 

*Finally, also essential to Kant's view on aeshetics is the relationship of beauty/art to truth.  Because art/aesthetics operates in an autonomous domain it does not immediatley have truth value -- ie it is a realm of disinterested pleasure.  BUT although art cannot produce knowledge, Kant hitns that the beautiful may put us into contact or point toward somethign that cannot be known conceptually or through experience.  When someone says something is beautiful they are not only registered a disitnerested pleasure but also the idea that that delight should be "necessary and universal." (12)  Megill explains that in the finals stages of his "transcendental deduction of the judgement of taste" Kant touches on the issue of morality, because he suggests that "underlying the judgemetn of aesthetic taste is the concept of the purposiveness of nature." (12) Ie "teleology" ??  Megill quotes Kant as saying that the "determining ground" of the concept of purposiveness in nature "lies perhaps in the concept of that which may be regarded as the supersensible substrate of humanity." (quoted on 12-13).  That substrate, Megill says, is the one that he uncovers in the Critique of Practical Reason, so that beauty becomes Kant argues "the symbol of the morally good." (quoted on 13)  Ie it indicates the existence of the morally good, stimulates the cultivation of reason as he says in his letter quoted in Guyer's "Editor's Introduction" on xvi in the Critique of the Power of Judgement.  Beauty thus leads the individual toward universal reason/morality through disinterested aehsetic delight.  Megill says: "Beauty thsu points towards the realm of morality, of which it gives sensual intimations." (13)

* Also key to the idea that aesthetics are autonomous is Kant's idea of an "aeshetic idea" Megill says.  He quotes Kant this way: "An 'aesthetic idea' is a 'representation of the imagination which occasions much thought' but for which 'an adequate concept can never be found,' and which consequently 'cannot be completely encompassed and made intelligibile by language.'" (13)

* So to sum up: the aesthetic is autonomous, associated with a disinterested and sensual aesthetic pleasure, but it also points toward a kind of experience that cannot be articulated in language, and which is related to the underlying "substratum" of moral law that governs free subjects. 

Conclusion

* Megill reiterates his idea that these thinkers are reaction to the Enlightenment idea of structuring science on a natural science model.  He states that he thinks much of "modern Western intellectual history has up to now been mainly defineed by the thought of the Enlightenment." (340)  He notes also that even in the East "current intellectual debates in, say, India or China often have an eerily nineteenth-century quality to them." (340)  Ie he thinks an "unquestioning faith in such Enlightenment and post-Enlightenment values as science and progress." (340) BUT now he says he thinks that "the primacy of the Enlightenment--its importance in setting the terms of our discourse will not continue much longer." (340)  Why?  He says you can think of four "deconstructive" moments emerging out of Enlightenment thought: Descartes, Kant, Hegel, and then perhaps Nietzsche.  He notes taht Marxism was the most enduring "remnant" of the nineteenth century dialectic -- "embodying a Cartesian faith in science, a Kantian faith in human nature, and an Hegelian faith in reason and history." (341)  But now he notes even Marxism is in crisis and his point is that this has to do with a general "crisis of the Enlightenment", which in turn is connected to a "persistent failure of our institutions to live up to expectation." (341) 

* Here is where these thinkers come in: he thinks they are and Nietzsche and Heidegger potentially going to play an important role in this "important transformation in the history of ideas" going beyond the Enlightenment. (341)  There are those he says who think they can dismiss these thinkers and the best criticism he sees is the one which argues taht the "overlook or totally misconstrue the truly pressing realities of human life." (341)  This is due to an "idealism" that's part of their thought, and he notes that Rorty has made a link between nineteenth-century idealism and twentieth-century textualism that he finds compelling if too sketchily drawn.  (341)  But he thinks this is something like throwing the baby out with the bathwater.  Specifically, he thinks that these thinkers contain an "edifying" discourse that is usefull in that, again using Rorty, it "takes us out of our old selves by the power of strangeness, to aid us in becoming new beings." (341)  He calls this ekstasis and defines it as "that imaginative ability that we possess to transcend our own situations, to get outside ourselves in time and space." (341)  Ekstasis he claism is also "the capacity...that enables us to function as moral beings, allow us to see ourselves in the guise of those upon whom we act." (341) Yet it is the kind of project, he thinks, that's been left out of sociology entirely--actually he thinks "excluded."  And he thinks his prophets of extremity are "committed to ending this exclusion or repression." (342)

* He also restates what these poeple are about differently here vv the Kant theme of the separation between ideas and experience.  Ie he refers to the fact that the attempt "to reintegrate what in the Enlightenment view remains divided answers a widely felt need." (342)  This needs in what Nietzsche and Heidegger are dealing with... What he means by the idea that the Enlightenment project will cease to be so influential is that for a long time since the 18th century the most significant intellectual projects have tried to "provide better, more detailed, more sophisticated answers to questions first raised by eighteenth-century philosophers."  He doesn't think this will last.  He thinks rather that now "in the future it will be a matter of developign or criticizing the thought that Nietzsche and Heidegger have given us." (342)  Foucualt and Derrida are doing just that.

* What is aestheticism then?  -- this thing that Nietzsche and Heidegger laid out. 

  • He now says that in its essence it's about "an attempt to bring back into thought and into our lives that form of edification, that reawakening of ekstasis, which in the Enlightenment and post-Enlightenment view as been largely confined to the realm of art." (342)
  • Ontologically, he says it's the idea that "the world" is a "work of art that gives birth to itself" -- or in another formulation, in the conviction that "the world itself is nothing other than art." (quoted, the latter is Nietzsche, from 342)
  • This cocneption leads in two direction: 1) passive contemplation; 2) radical creativity -- here the reference is ot the creativity of the genius artist who creates from nothing and who stands as the "successor to the radical creativity of God." (343)  The poet brings the wrold into existence; discourse creates its own world.  The latter is an important sub-theme in Nietzsche of 1880s and also Heidegger.  (343) 

* Megill says that one would have to be mad to believe literally in these theses, and eh thinks it's clear that these ideas are not to be taken literally even thought the rhetorical affect of the theses requires that they be taken seriously.  Here is the paradox of aestheticism he says. He quotes Schiller to the effect that the "aesthetic semblance" is never in danger of being taken for truth, but Megill says that is false!  He notes on the next few pages how many of the students of Foucault or Nietzsche have tken their lcaims as truth, wheraes he insists they never meant for that to be done!  )(343) He undercuts or specifies the idea of the "truth of the work of art"--that idea he thinks is just protection for the interpreter of the work of art e"protecting trhem form the critical examiation to which they ought to be subjected." (344)  But if we are suspicious of this idea of the truth of art, we must also be suspicious of the "creative lie" that is key to Nietzsche.  The same problem occurs: the "creative lie" can be seen as true whereas it is in fact a reflection of the writers unexamined prejudices.  He thinks the danger in this is esp. clear with Foucault when his claims are applied in a way to take them seriously then the "view that everything is discourse or text or fiction, [then] the realia are trivialized." (345) 

* So one should read these prophets of extremity with Irony!! he says.  Not literally.  Viewing their owrk as we do the work of artists.  (345)  He sees, e.g., Foucault as the "dobule of conventional historians, who challeng, and aought to be challenged by, his work." (345) 

* Crisis: he thinks similarly to the way in which we ought to be suspicious of the notion of radical creativity and the truth of art we ought also to be suspicious of the concept of crisis articulated by Nietzsche and Heidegger.  Several points here:

  • Logical critique: these theorists of crisis presuppose the idea of History as structured and linear in order to say it is borken.  "Hence, to the extent that the proponents of the crisis notion are successful in making their point, they undermine the basis of their own view." (346) 
  • Rhetorically, the notion of a "crisis of our time" has become a substitute for thought rather than a prompt to thought.  (3460

Notes for Prague Metacrisis Paper

Goal: My goal in these notes is to focus on Megill's notion of crisis vv late nineteenth and early twentieth century thought.

Preface

* Right off the bat he says that his book is an interpretation of the thought of Nietzsche, Heidegger, Foucault and Derrida that seeks to place them within the "context of a crisis-oriented modernism and post-modernism that have been the source of much of what is most original and creative in twentieth-century art and thought." (xi)  It's a book about modernism and post-modernism he says.

* The book's interpretation of the the first three thinkers he says is heavily influenced by his reaction to the last: Derrida.  Though he emphasizes that he's not a Derridean and he's uncomfortable with Derrida's claims, esp. the political ones.  He doesn't see Derrida as a political radical.  (xii)  Derrida, he says, helped him "see my own mind clearly...[and] bring to light and to articulate long-held, deeply felt, but ...latent skepticisms concerning the claims and procedures of modernism and postmodernism in art and thought." (xii)

* His focus on modernism and postmodernism he says has led him to focto us on "the aesthetically inclined elements" in the thinkers, ie not Nietzsche the naturalist or Heidgger the analyst of human existence, and so on... (xii)

* And modernism and postmodernism has led him to focus on a specific notion of crisis viz cultural crisis.  He wants to specify what he means. 

a) The crisis he's *not* talking about is the usual notion of crisis, related he says to the "continental philosohpical tradition and out of the theology" of that tradition... (xii)  He means the collapse of the "God of the Philosphers" or the "God of the Bible that occurs with Kant's first critique and in the Bibilical cricisim of David Friedrich Strauss and other "practitioners of historical criticism." (xii-xiii).  The idea is that a "loss of the transcendent dimension, prompted by the notion of Kritik as a pervasive power, leads to modern man's homelessness in the world." (xiii)  He says it's a loss of "authoritative standards of the good, the true, and the beautiful to which reason has access, coupled with loss of the Word of God in the Bible." (xiii)

b) The crisis he's specifying is different.  It's the crisis of historicism, circa 1880-1920.  Ie a crisis of "hsitoricism and of the faith in progress that was the widely diffused, vulgarized form of historicism." (xiii) In this crisis the dominant metaphor, unlike the theological one that he listed above that focuses on the image of the abyss, is the break: "This presupposes something to be broken, nameyl, history; and in order to conceive of the possiblity of history's breaking, one needs to think of it as a line or a movement." (xiii)  So historicism in the tehological notion of crisis is the product of crisis; it emerges when absolute standards dissapear and nothing is outside of history.  The crisis of historicism is thus dependent on thinking of history as linear. Otherwise, you couldn't image in to be broken.  Finally, he says, these kinds of crisis thinkers tend ot think of the present as borken, and so also as "undirected, null, degraded" And they tend to project this vision forwards and backwards. (xiii)

* He also calls this a "posthistoricist notion of crisis" rather than a "posttheological notion" (xiii)

* He makes a couple of important references to his own distance from the basic point of view of the thinkers he's writing about.  (xiv, bottom)  He describes Derrida as an "antihistoricist" and then says that his book his historicist thought.  (xv)  But he says his book's "interpretive construction is aestheticist., and also therapeutic..." (xv)  Not clear what he nmeans, but he tries to explain below.  Something about it creating a new world for the reader, that he hopes is also liberating and also, in his treatment of the achivement of Derrida, something that cauess "awe and rapture before a truth unviled by Derrida..." (xv) 

Introduction

* Def'n of Aestheticism: He's not suing it in its' usual sense where it means to be enclosed in a world that is separate from the "real world."  He's referring to a it as an "attempt to expand the aesthetic to embrace the whole of reality.  To put it in another way, I am using it to refer to a tendency to see 'art' or 'language' or 'discourse' or 'text' as constituting the primary realm of human experience." (2)  

* He provides a useful and interesting summary of the modernism/post-modernism relationship vv his notion of the aesthetic: "The irony that pervaded modernism tried to uncover a Man or Culture or Nature or History underlying the flux of surface experience.  In postmodernism, this has given way to a new irony, one that holds these erstwhile realities to be textual fictions.  We are seen as cut off from 'things' and confined to a confrontation with 'words' alone." (2)

* This is the basic def'n of aestheticism, but the details are in the difn't modes that he'll show in the four thinkers.  (2)   [-- This bears a resemblance to Calinescu's Five Faces of Modernity ???]  He gives some elaboration using the words of his thinkers on 2-3. 

* He relates his readings to a book by Stanley Rosen: Nihilism: a Philophsical Essay.  He agrees with Rosen who emphasizes the role of poetics in these thinkers and who also relates the projects of these thinkers to Kan'ts third critique. (4)  But he differs from Rosen in that he's not calling for a return to the "classical linkage of the good, the true, and the beautiful." (4) What is key here is that he's seeing his work as a "study of the continuing impact on us of the thought of the Enlightenment." (4)  He says this because he thinks that what's going on with these thinkers is that they are reacting to "the Enlightement pretension to construct a science of society modeled on natural science." (4)  And the "intellectual problems" that this project created are evident in Kant!  Ie he thinks that Rosen's complaint about the isolation of reason, the good, and beauty is "translatable into a complaint about the Kantian separation of the practical, the theoretical, and the aesthetic." (4)  This is key because he's saying that this crisis of historicism or posthistoricist crisis is an after effect of the enlightement project of creating a science of society...one that is visible esp in Kant's project--which can be seen to have had both a positive and negative impact..(Later of course, Megill will trace the aehsetic idea to the autonomy that Kant gave to aeshetics..)

* The rebellion against Kant ties these thinkers to Romanticism , one of hte first movement to identify the "failure" of the Enlightenment, to react to Kant, and to use his own tools to fight him (7).  He insists that despite the variety of Romaniticisms, they viewed the Enlightenment as having failed to "provide the hoped-for synthesis" and thus their period was a period of transition involved in a confrontation with that failure. (6-7)  This view syncs with what he said vv Enlightenent and crisis on (4)

* Second point of contact with the Romantics is the elevation of the aesthetic, the idea that art was elevated even above the artist: "As the objective embodiment of fleeing, inarticulate insight, art was seen as allowing access to a dimension of reality from which the merely analytical understanding was entirely barred." (7)  This attitude also connects to the thinkers he's looking at.  He deals with difficulties of making this link between Romantics and his thinkers on 8-9. 

* Developing his Kant link further.  He thinks Kant is key because he "stands as the crucial figure between the Enlightenment, Romanticism, and the new thought initiated by Nietzsche." (9)  Megill states that "In Nietzsche's eyes, Kant was a deeply subversive thinker, who had unwittingly underminded the optimistic logic of the Enlightenment." (9)  He argues that Kant pplays a huge role in th ewritings of Heidegger, Foucault and Derrida.  As wella s for the Romantics.  Megill describes Kant as an "ambivalent philosopher" and focuses on the tension between his first and second critiques, the Critique of Pure Reason (1781) and the Critique of Practical Reason (1788).  The internals of these theories is not the point for Megil, but rather "the more general problem of the relationship of the two theories to each other..." (9-10)  This was a problem felt by the Romantics deeply.  The problem highlights a contradiction inherent to the Enlightenment project itself, as begun by Descartes.  The problem is as follows: The background is the idea that the Enlightenment was to construct a science of society on the model of the Natural sciences.  Newton, e.g. had done this with his theory of universal gravitation.  The problem was, as Megill states it, that "Natural science attributes a determinism to the objects of its concern.  [But] If things were free rather than determined, they could not be the objects of science." (10)  If Enlightenment thinkers wanted to construct a science of society, then they would be admitting that individuals were not free, but rather their actions were determined by laws, just like those that determined the movement of the planets and the stars.  The problem was that Enlightenment philosphers also believed in moral codes.  "But the existence of a moral code presupposes that people are free to govern their own actions, since entities incapable of governing their own actions obviously cannot be judged in moral terms." (10)  Megill also restates this in a useful way, stating that one can see science as dealing with a realm of unfree objects and morality (religion?) as dealing with a realm of free objects.  Kant, like Descartes, whom he also criticizes, operates with the assumption that there is a stark division between subject and object (the relam of freedom and the realm of unfreedom, or morality and science), but because he deals with the subject of morality directly he reveals, Megill argues, the deep contradiction in the Enlightenment project. 

* Heidegger, Nietzsche, and Foucault, are all frustrated with this subject/object division, as were Romantics like Fichte, Schilling, and Hegel.  the German idealisets, eh says, were all trying to "attain a unity of subject and object, of ego and non-ego." (11)

* Kant himself suggests, Megill says, severral ways out of the dilemma, but the only one that he's concerned with is that which Kant laid out in the third critique, The Critique of the Power of Judgement, which he says is the least powerful performance of Kant's but nonetheless had a huge impact, in partiuclar on the Romantics.  Why?  Because it "unequivocally maintains the autonomy of the aesthetic judgement.  In doing so, it appears to suggest that there exists an indepedent realm of the aesthetic, a realm quite distinct from the other realms of morality and nature. " (11-12)  Megill positions Kant as making a stand, on the one hand, against Hutchesoin and Shaftesbury who had linked aesthetic and moral judgement and thus "in effect assimilated the former to the latter" (12), and those like Saint-Evremond and La Mettrie, who had linked aesthetic pleasure to sensual pleasure via physiology and psychology, on the other hand. (12)  The divergence here is made in Kant's idea of the "disinterestedness" of aesthetic pleasure.  Megill says Kant denies the existence of a third realm apart form nature and freedom, but he does insist on the "existence of an autonomuos realm of the aesthetic, a realm whose function is to mediate bretween the other two." (12) 

*Finally, also essential to Kant's view on aeshetics is the relationship of beauty/art to truth.  Because art/aesthetics operates in an autonomous domain it does not immediatley have truth value -- ie it is a realm of disinterested pleasure.  BUT although art cannot produce knowledge, Kant hitns that the beautiful may put us into contact or point toward somethign that cannot be known conceptually or through experience.  When someone says something is beautiful they are not only registered a disitnerested pleasure but also the idea that that delight should be "necessary and universal." (12)  Megill explains that in the finals stages of his "transcendental deduction of the judgement of taste" Kant touches on the issue of morality, because he suggests that "underlying the judgemetn of aesthetic taste is the concept of the purposiveness of nature." (12) Ie "teleology" ??  Megill quotes Kant as saying that the "determining ground" of the concept of purposiveness in nature "lies perhaps in the ocncept of that which may be regarded as the supersensible substrate of humanity." (quoted on 12-13).  That substrate, Megill says, is the one that he uncovers in the Critique of Practical Reason, so that beauty becomes Kant argues "the symbol of the morally good." (quoted on 13)  Ie it indicates the existence of the morally good, stimulates the cultivation of reason as he says in his letter quoted in Guyer's "Editor's Introduction" on xvi in the Critique of the Power of Judgement.  Beauty thus leads the individual toward universal reason/morality through disinterested aehsetic delight.  Megill says: "Beauty thsu points towards the realm of morality, of which it gives sensual intimations." (13)

* Also key to the idea that aesthetics are autonomous is Kant's idea of an "aeshetic idea" Megill says.  He quotes Kant this way: "An 'aehsetic idea' is a 'representation of the imagination which occasions much thought' but for which 'an adequate concept can never be found,' and which consequently 'cannot be completely encompassed and made intelligibile by language.'" (13)

* So to sum up: the aesthetic is autonomous, associated with a disinterested and sensual aesthetic pleasure, but it also points toward a kind of experience that cannot be articulated in language, and which is related to the underlying "substratum" of moral law that governs free subjects.

* Crisis: he thinks similarly to the way in which we ought to be suspicious of the notion of radical creativity and the truth of art we ought also to be suspicious of the concept of crisis articulated by Nietzsche and Heidegger.  Several points here:

  • Logical critique: these theorists of crisis presuppose the idea of History as structured and linear in order to say it is borken.  "Hence, to the extent that the proponents of the crisis notion are successful in making their point, they undermine the basis of their own view." (346) 

Rhetorically, the notion of a "crisis of our time" has become a substitute for thought rather than a prompt to thought.  (346) 

  • Pragmatic critiuqe: even if there is a crisis, so what?  what difference?  He think it makes no difference whatsoever.  Even if the seies of pragmatic problems that we face are linked to the "Death of God", so what?  "The problem with the crisis notion is that it can only speak in vague generalities." (347) 
  • Here he thinks these prophets of extremity are maybe unhelpful because they are beleivers in apocalypse generally.  "Heidegger's conviction that only a god can save use is harldy calculated to help us evade the crisis of which he speaks; Foucault's belief in unendign protest--his hostility to every order--may only move us closer to disaster." (347)

* In sum, he thinks the crisis concept may be in crisis -- here he's referring to the notion of crisis of historicism--not the first notio of crisis out of which Enlightenment emerged. Waht he's referrign to his how combining the three critiques above, these thinkers notion of crisis has not been useful.  The concept hsa instead moved into the hands of fundamenalists, e.g. in America, for whom crisis viz apocalypse is an ancient mythical theme tied to the "crisis of the City of Man--its destruction, making way for the City of God..." (347) -- and all out war between good and evil and so on.  He thinks that Nietzsche, Heidegger and Foucault cannot be held responsible for such views but they too were fascinated by crisis.  and its "cleansing power."  But if we don't think the present is totally degraded, Megill suggests, "there ought to be compulsion to actively oppose the crisis notion." (348)

* Yet he also thinks the Prophets of Extremity are uesful because their thought critiques the idea of "one true way"...and this is useful he thinks in the context of a moment when the weaponry exists (he's also writing still during the Cold War) to actually end the wrold.  In this context, the unermining of the idea of one true way is useful.  (348-9) 

Body of the book...

(no notes yet on earlier chapters...)

 


Part IV. On the Meaning of Jacques Derrida

Ch.7.  The Deconstruction of Crisis

* Derrida he describes interestingly as the "modern Penelope, unraveling by night what he weaves by day--or rather, raveling and unraveling at the same time, as he waits for a Ulysses who will never come home." (259)   In comparison to the other thinkers, Derrida is more radically ironic he says. (260) 

*  He starts out by trying to evaluate why modernism and postmodernism are useful.  He says he holds no "brief" for these movements.  Meaning he's not pushing them and he's not also saying that we all ought to be modernists and postmodernists because these movements have been so important for the twentieth century avante-garde.  But he thinks they are "imporant aspects of our historical and intellectual experience." (261)  And he thinks their assumptions have been carried into "areas of thought that we do not usually think of" in aesthetic terms--ie the implications of tehse ideas extends outside of the realm of art.  (261).  He says he will draw out the latter point esp in ch.8.  (261)

* He lays out the influence of Derridean thought on so-called postmodern literary criticism in the 1980s on 262-3, but he's not particularly interested in this consequence, which is mainly that those who use these ideas in literarture believe that "interpretation is really only a variety of misinterpretation." (262) He's only interested in a part of this debate.

* So why is he interested in Derrida?  He says on to pof 262 that he thinks Derrida's thought needs to be considered in a wider perspective.  He sees the key issue being wrapped up in the question "what is a work of art?" (263)  Derrida 's work can be seen as "an important exploration of this question." (263)  We live in a "post-Kantian world" ie in the shadows of Kant's distinctions between the theoretical, the practical, and the aesthetic, out of which comes also the distinction between theory and praxis and a distinction between the aesthetic and the nonaesthetic.  Derrida is esp. (interested in attacking the latter dualism between the aesthetic and nonaesthetic (or art and reality) -- a dualism that typically for modernists like Yeats, Pound and Eliot (and also for the so-called "New Critics") was key! Postmodernism is anti-Kantian in this sense because it calls into question the distinction between art and reality.  Derrida too calls this distinction into question although Megill will argue that he is not postmodern, despite the obvious affinities. 

* Caveat re Kant:  It is wrong to say that Kant's view of art was aesthetic or to say that he was "unequivocally asserting art's autonomy." (264)  But it is fair to say that his "Critique of Judgement did point in these directions, and the direction was taken up by Kant's successors , beginning with Schiller.  A separate sphere was carved out for art; a division between the aesthetic and the nonaesthetic was established and canonized." (264)

* In this context, Nietzsche lays out a reactive response to that idea of the autonomy of art. "There exist artists of art; there also exist artists of politics, science, religion." (264)  Once with Nietzsche you recognize the "affinity between aesthetic creativity and creativity in its more 'serious' sense", then you begin to see that the separation of art from reality covers up a lot of questions.  (264)  The idea is taht artists have had a hand in the construction of reality; as Shelley put it in "Defence of Poetry," poets are "the unacknowledged legislators of the world..." (264)  Two often intermingled misperceptions emerge from this view: the "aesthetic" view that sees art as "simply an internal play of formal possibilities" (264) and the "ontological" view of art as a privileged from of truth.  (265) Combined these two misperceptions make it possile to view what is initially thought of as a self-contained sand inward aesthetic universe as having "cognitive authority" about the wrold at large.  (265) He cites Northrop Frye as an example of this in f.n. #10. 

So Derrida is good:

#1 So the first value of Derrida according  to Megill is that he makes it impsosible to sustain this view: "...he so radically undermines the Kantian distinction between art and reality that we can no longer view it in any way except ironically.  He shows us that it is not a matter of opting either for 'realism' against 'aestheticism' or for 'aestheticism' against 'realism.'  It is a matter, rather, of calling into question the initial distinction upon which such a choice is founded." (265) Key here is the fact that Megill sees Kant's thought as "suggesting" a solution to the problem of the division between art and reality: namely the "reinterpretation of knowledge as a form of aesthetic fiction or creativity..." which then becomes central to Nietzsche and Heidegger and Derrida, even though he undoes it.

#2 Aestheticism has a precondition in the idea of crisis , Megill says.  "The notion that the prsent is null opens the way to an aesthetic creation.  The world's giving birth to itself as work of art presupposes that its present existence is derelict, that it indeed needs to be reborn...Art best exercices its ex nihilo creativity whre there is a nullity out of which this creation can emerge." (265)  This is tied up with Nietzsche, Heidegger, and Foucault's utopianism and sense of alienation from the "modern world."  They "want to make a leap into a utopia that radically negates this reality... (265)  Thus there's a nihilism in this sense of crisis that is the precondition for aestheticism,b ut this nihilism is itself only a problem, Megill says, "within the context of an historicist reading of history." (265)  He defines historicism: it's a sense of hsitory having a "directionality" as being a development that one can understand.  Crisis "denotes a turning,a  point of decision."  (264)  He refers to its original meaning vv disease and quotes the OED where it is a turning point that is crucial in terms of the body healing itself.  But his poitn is that unless you first conceive of history has having direction that it cannot lose, you cannot form this notion of "crisis." (266)  Derrida shows how questionable is the idea of history having directionality in the first place. 

* In section 267-271, Megill explains Derrida's relationship to Nietzsche, Heidegger, Foucault and Hegel. 

  • D identifies Nietzsche as a "crisis thinker" who is functioning outside "the tradition" (I think he means the Enlightenment tradition).  D understands that N got outside of that tradition by making what Megill calls the "aestheticist move," which D understands to be the "liberation of the signifier from its dependence or derivation with respect to the logos and the related concept of truth or the primary signified..." (quoted on 268).  Megill explains: "There is the idea, here, of a text liberated from its formerly subordinate status with regard to Truth, with regard to the 'original' or 'transcendental' signified.  This is why reading and writing become 'originary' operations: they involve not the 'discovery' of truth but its invention.  The text is endowed with the attributes of the work of art as conceived in post-Romantic aesthetics..." (269) 
  • vv Heidegger is important for Derrida but he's not a Heideggerian.  In Positions, Derrida says he thinks that Heidegger is defending in a powerful way "what I attempt to put into quetion under the ribric of the thought of presence." (269) But he is aware of teh moral ambiguities of Heidegger's thought and he wants in particular, Megill thinks, to resit the element of nostalgia in Heidegger that Megill identifies in his section on Heidegger as perhaps the place where Heidegger got himself into trouble.  Derrida plays Nietzsche off Heidegger in "Differance" Megill says, quoting: "There will be no unique name, even if it were the name of Being.  And we must think this without nostalgia; that is, outside of the myth of a purely maternal or paternal language, a lost native country of thought.  On the contrary, we must affirm this, in the sense in which Nietzsche puts affirmation in to play, in a certain laughter and a certaiun step of the dance." (quoted on 260-270). Megill adds that whereas Heidegger is concerned with discovering the "proper" names, Derrida is "concerned not with 'proper' names but with 'improper' ones..." (270)
  • In relation to Foucault, Derrida sees Foucault--who was evidentl his teacher at one point--as another crisis thinker.  Megill adds that the divergence between Derrida and Foucault is not in in "Derrida's entrapment in the 'text,' as distinguished from Foucault's concern with the broader field of 'history'."  It is instead in "their different patternings of the historical process." (270) Derrida states re Foucault's History of Madness that "nowhere else and never beter has the concept of crisis been able to enrich and reassemble all its potentialities, all the energy of its meaning as much, perhaps, as in Michel Foucault's boook." (270-271)  Megill thinks D is right and that thsi is also true in F's alter texts.  Megill notest hat "Foucult seeks to build a politics (or metapolitics) of crisis."  While Derrida's "real interest, especially in his later work, seems to be in opening us up to the hermeneutical possibilities of the written word--using the term "hermenuetical" in Rorty's rather than Schleirmacher's sense, as a continuing conversation rather than as an unveiling of truth.  And beyond this, Derrida engages in a sustained attempt to criticize the notion of crisis, to show the limitations of the crisis view." (271) 
  • Hegel.  Megill says that it is Hegel that "makes possible the thought of crisis."  (271)  [HOW SO?  Has he explained this elsewhere?]  Hegelianism is persistnat target for Derrida apparently.  e.g. in a 1967 essay on Bataille and Hegel.  Where he says "Misconstrued, treated lightly, Hegelianism only extends to its historical domination, finally unfolding its immense envoloping resources without obstacle.  Hegelian self-evidence seems lighter than ever at the moment when it finally bears down with its full weight." (271)  Megill says that D deploys a kind of ironic critique of the dialectic. D's "anti-Hegilian strategy" M says can be "characterized as a perpetual witholding operation." (273) All his writing is "preforatory" and avoids conclusino.  Megill writes: "A logorrehea results, an immense outpouring of words around an unsayable center." (272)  

* M goes deeper into this strategy of perpetual withholding in the next section on "The rule of four."  The basic idea is that "four" is a key part of that strategy.  The Preforatory text is the "fourth" moment of the dialectic that undoes the dialectic is the idea.  The dialectic is triangular: position, negation, and negation of negation.  The fourth mooment is the "preface"  and it is an undoing of the "trinatory horizon," which is a key motif (M says motif rather than theme suits D better) in D's thought.  So: "The fourth moment of the dialectic is the deconstructive moment: position, negation, negation of the negation, deconstruction (or: Nietzsche, Heidegger, Foucault, and Derrida.)" (274)  So M says that D "engages in fore-thinking, or four-thinking, that ie explictily driected against the three-thinking of Hegel." (274)  (272-4)

* The next section is complex and seeks to situation Derrida's thought in the special context of Parisian and French thought in the 1940s and 1950s.  Might need to re-read here, but the part that resonated most was when he explains the interest in Hegel and Marx vv "history".  Megill writes: "sensitized to hsitory by the massive congruence of Hegel and Marx, French phenomenologists approached Husserl in the hope of deriving from him a phenomenology of history." (278)  This led to a question of how "history is to be understood phenomenologically"--something that Megill thinks Derrida is taking up in an early essay.  (see bottom 278)  So this was an interesting in how to udnerstand history,b ut it was also accompanied, M says, by an interest or preoccupation about the "possibility of its end."  (279)  This came out of Hegel who had a notion of philosophy's end which in some cases was construed as an end of history itself.  (279)  There was an influential account of an end of history in Hegel in by Kojeve.  Also coming otu of Heidegger's essay "The End of Philosphy and the Task of Thinking." (279)   Megill says that the idea of "end" is tied up with "crisis."  End does not need to lead to crisis always; there can always be smooth transitions, but he says strangely that this had not often been the acse in the 20th century so it was possible to link crisis with end.  And in the 1960s he also notes there was a lot of talk of an end of philosophy.  He quotes someone named Descombes:  "It was thought that the Western ratio, its resources exhausted, was nearing the end of its run." (279)  He references's Jean Wahl's Toward the end of Ontology (1956) and Merlau-Ponty's The Visible and the Invisible (1964).  Foucault e.g. also said in The Order of Things that "if the disvoery of the Return is indeed the end of philosophy, then the end of man, for its part, is the return of the beginning of philosophy." (279) 

* While this is the context that provides the "grist for the mill" M says, the mill material came from postmodern avante-garde art.  He says that D was really into Mallarme, Artaud, Bataille, Solers.  And later Ponge.  These writers, eh said, are all alike in that "[i]nstead of attempting to create the illusion of an exxternal world, as writers in a more realist tradition do, these figures engage in a species of textual play..." (280) He has a quote from Derrida explaining his interest in such works on 280.

* Megill reads Derrida's interest in literature from which the "mill" comes from through the novelist Maurice Blanchot who had a distinction between parole brute and parole essentielle.  The first is language that is concerned with the reality of things.  It "represents" and attempt to "give us things in their presence." (281)  It is language functioning as  an "instrument in a world full of instruments; it connections us with the life of the world and with the ends governing that life." (281) Here language is attempting to "efface itseklf as language and to become pure representation..." (281)  Parole essentielle has the opposite effect it "dsistnces us from things, making them dissapear." (281)  Here language does not efface itself but instead seeks to "impose itself--though in impoosing itself it imposes nothing outside itself." (281)  It is the language of th epoet and it is langauge being used as itself an essential thing.  The language becomes an end in itself. (281)

* Now he comes to what is postmodern...It can be seen he thinks in Blanchot's distinction.  Blanchot he says is "reproducing the sense of crisis or division that is fundmaental to both modernism and postmodernism."  (282) But he says the difference is that Blanchot and teh postmodern does not seek tio "countenance the reconstituting of truth on the level of literature." -- whereas the modernist would.  Using Alan Wilde, he says, there's a lack of an "anironic" impulse in the postmodern thinker that is central to the modernist: "the impulse to create an appearance of order to counterbalance ahotic reality..." (282)  This he says dissapears in postmodernism.  What Blanchot is ddoing is imagining the "impersonality" of art, Megill says.  Something like Heidegger whose idea "die Sprache Spricht"--that it is not man but language that speaks--moves in the same direction, only with a greater degree of nostalgia for the "world of ancient Greece as a refuge again st the ironic, unhoming, fragmeniting character of modern technology..."  (282)  Whereas in Blanchot there is nothing anironic Megill insists. 

* Megill notes that he does tnot know what influence Blanchot had on D, but he does think that there's an affinity and that's waht counts.  They are both open to what Megill has defined as the postmodern in literature.  Can be seen as his lack of anironic impulse, his interest in paraody, his preference for postmodern artists, but also in the "literary" or "artistic" nature of his philosophical enterprise.  What Derrida does that is typical of the postmodernis that he will "reject what modernist instellectual still accept--namely, the notion of science as a haven or a refuge, as an ironic protection (however uncertain) against the irony of existence..." (282)  Ie D like postmodernists no longer can "take seriously the distinction between scientific discourse and non-scientific discourse, or between critisim and art." (282) 

* So in Blanchot's case Megill says that his criticism is not "radically divergent" from his fictions or vice versa.  Same with Derrida he insists.  Especially evident in his work Glas, where he deals withHegel and Jean Genet!!  Here Megill says he basically is creating a kind of "literary-philosophical collage." (283)  Megill says the link between Blanchot and Derrida are especially clearin his essay "The Double Session" about Mallarme's "mimicry".  The idea is that mime language goes outside the Western "logocentric" tradition.  Miming does not try to represent reality but it "produces mere 'reality-effects'..." (183)  Or "the refereant is lifted, but reference remains; what is left is only the writing of dreams, a fiction that is not imaginary, mimicry without imitation, without verisimilitude, without truth or falsity...There remain only traces, foretelling, recallings, fore-blows and after-blows which no present will hav preceded or followed and which cannot be arranged on a line." (283)  [Good stuff potentially re the breakdown in shape or repatterning of history...]  So Megill says that Derrida is describing a "literature of crisis" that "marks out an absolute alienation from the extant world by refusing in any way to repreat, to 're-present it'.  This is why imitation, verisimilitude, truth, and falsity are all excluded." (284)  This kidn of literature is then "supremely ironical" and not only in the sense of "saying one thing and meaning another" but more deeply "in the heightened sense of saying one thing and meaning, or 'wishing to say,' nothing at all."  This leads inevitably to parody as a resource.  (284) 

* So then what does this mean about writing, what is the larger point of this "literary crisis."  Or waht is this literary crisis?  Megill says that to the extent that Derrida dervies a thesis it is that in the west writing was dismissed for speech, where speech is much more like Blanchot's parole brutal.  "Speech stands for immediaacy--or more precisely for intelligibility, for the possibility of contact with Truth, with the 'trascendental signified.'" (285)  So in Of Grammatalogy, D writes: "writing, the sensible inscription, has always been considered by Western tradition as the body and matter external to the spirit, to breath, to speech, and to the logos." (quoted on 285)  By condemning this, Derrida is seeking to condemt the "Western tradition for its commitment to the ultimate possibility of literal truth." (286)  Derrida tracks this preference for speech over writing to Socrates attack on writing near the end of the dialogue in Plato's Phaedrus.  "Writing, Socrates here maintains, is only an image of living speech; speech is far prefarable to it.  Writing weakens the memory.  Writings get out of hand of the writer and come to be misinterpreted.  Writings hsould serve only as a reminder to the reader o fturths that he already understands." (286)  Blanchot also had noticed this attack on writing whereas most critics pass over it.  Blanchot thinks that Socrates is diusmayed  by the silence of art and draws this out in some writing on Rene Char, the poet.  (see 287-288) .  Heidegger's view--die Sprache Spricht--that Megill has said D also picks up on (thought without the nostalgia) is a way to note how language speaks without the author.  (287-288) What Socrates is attacking is the "impersonality of art" -- its independence along with language from the author -- that is important for Blanchot.  Against this idea that speech can get at something that is simply true--that the author knows indepdently of language, that the language is amere vehicle--Blanchot like Heidegger sees in art a kind of not a simple expression of an independent truth, but a way of "indicating".  Blanchot quotes Heraclitus: "The Lord whose oracle is at Delphia neiter expresses nor conceals but indicates."  And this Megill thinks is what Blanchot and Heidegger see in art, he quotes again: "saying nothing, hiding nothing, openinga  space, opening it to whoever opens himself to its access." (Blanchot? quoted on 288). 

* But what does alll this add up to?  It's an anti-ontological position.  Megill quotes him amazingly as reimagining Plato's cave totally reconfigured in an anti-ontological way such that: "Imagine that the mirrors would not be in the wrold, simply, incluied in the totality of all onta and their images, but that things 'present,'  on the contrary, would be in them.  Imagine that mirrors (shadows, reflections, phantasms, etc.) would no longer be comprehended within the structure of the ontology and myth of the cave...but would rather envelop it in its entirey, porudinc here or there a particular, extremely determinate effect.  The whole hierarchy described in the Republic, in its cave and in its line, would once again find itself at stake and in question in the theater of Numbers." (quoted on 289) 

* Megill says that for English readers the French names that Derrida sees as expliyfing an anti-ontological stance won't be significance ecept Mallarme, but he sees a link in Duchamp's urinal, in Magritte's "puning paintings and drawings" and in the James Joyce of Finnegan's Wake, and not in the Joyce of Ulysses.  Because in Ulysses Joyce was interested in "restoring art to 'its contenxt in expereince'..." (289)  Megill thinks in that novel you can read that Joyce wanted to challenge concepts like "naturalness and literatlity"... (289) 

* Megill thinks the conflict can be understood in part as a conflict between hermeneutics and epistemology as Rorty distinguishes them.  Here  Rorty defines epistemology as the ideal that we understand perfectly what is happening.  By contrast, hermeneutics is when we don't understand what is happening and can admit that.  (289)  Megill says that crisis is wound up with this notion of hermeneutics because "in crisis we do not understand what is happening: we sense a turning but do not know where the turning will end." (290) 

* Now Megill get's deeper into the implications for crisis--ie Derrida's decontruction of it.  It begins with the paradox that the "heremeneut" says there's nothing outside the text, and then he also justifies the hermeneutic enterprise "on the grounds that we are in crisis."  (290)  Derrida highlights this problem because he forces us to ask "What becomes of the crisis when he [Derrida] denies that we can possibly know that such a thing as a crisis can take place outside the confines of the text?" (291)  Megill insists that D is aware of the paradox and he deals with its by writing "as if" literature had entered into a crisis and then "to work out the implications of such a crisis." (291) But it's not totally clear that he thinks such a crisis actually exists.
