* But if it does, it's not just a "literary crisis."  Literary crisis is just a subset of a broad crisis in the Western tradition.  Why?  Literatary criticism has just been a "stalking horse" in D's mind for the comm itment to "presence."--ie the idea that things exists in their reality and can be known and stated through "speech."  Megill explains that D thinks that literary criticism has simply "treated literature under the category of 'presence', thus subjecting it to 'Western philosophy'" (291)  It has then repressed thsoe parts of literature that dont' "accord with presentist, memtological, intological, metaphysical assumptions." (292)  It does this by seeking to "determine a mean ing through a text, to pronounce a decision upon it, to decide that this or taht is a meaning and that it is meaningful, to say that this meaning is posed, posable, or trnaspoableas such: a theme".  (quoted on 292)  So then if there's a crisis in literature vv presence, there is then also a crisis in the Western tradition.  Megill quotes extensively to illustrate wthat that crisis would be on 292-294.  It's an "exhaustion" or "closure" of this Western enthusiasm for "logocentric metaphysics."  (293)  D sees this in what he calls on quote on 293 the "death of the book" or a "death of speech" or "full speech" and a "new mutation in the history of writing, in history as writing." (293)  Megill points otu that one could see a parallel to Foucault's crisis calls at the End of the Order of Thigns when "the death of the modern episteme is gleefuly proclaimed." (293)  But there's no similar forcce or apocalypticism in Derrida.  Megill suggest there is instead a kind of paraody of "crisis thought itself" -- ie not a parody of Cartesian thought, but of crisis thought, of the kind of thinking begun by Nietzsche and completed in Foucault. "It is this kind of confident apocalypticism--invented by Nietzsche and run into teh ground by Foucault--that Drrida makes fun of." (294) 

* Key moment in Megill's argument: If we take Nietzsche, Foucault, and H as crisis thinkers.  And there are others he ntoes!!  (see 294)  Here he wants to make his point that these notiosn of crisis "coexist with a deep interset in history..."  (295) IE their claims of crisis depend upon a notion of historicism as as directional historical development.  (295-296) So then "Nineeenth-century historicism gave way to the twentieth-cnetury crisis commitment." (296) And the latter depends on the former.  He lays out this idea in a bit more detail 295-296.

* Buyt in Derrida "the thought of crisis finally undermines itself, for Derrida turns his critical attention to the whole notion of history as linear...." (297) In his deconstruction of Foucault's History of Madness, D critiques F for implicitly involving a notion of an "original presence" -- in much the same way that Megill is saying that the notion of crisis presumes the existince of historicism.  (297)  And in Of Grammatology, Megill says it is "precisely the notion of history as an ordered line of poresents--history with a capital H--that Derrida criticizes..." (297)  And he writes: "the word history has no doubt always been associated with a linear scheme of the unfolding of the presence, where the line relates the final presence to teh originary presence accrding to the straight line or the circle." (quoted on 297-8)  Megill thinsk that this is sort of pronvincial because hsitory has not always been thought of that way, but in the "porphecy of extremity and in historicism" it has been so he says.  And Derrida is exposing the interdependence of historicism and crisis.  So Megill thinks he sees through this problem in the crisis thinkers. "Seeing through the myth of the tradition, he undermines the crisis view.  The knell of hsitoricism is also the knell of crisis." (298)

* The last gesture of the cahpter is that in Nietzsche, Foucualt, and Heidegger there was already a kind of view that gets at a kind of relationshp to history in which there's no burden of history felt.  Where the various moments just exist in no sequential order. Things have bee cast free so to speak.  And he says in thsi sense Derrida was just making expklicit a view that existed in inchoate form in the tought of the others. (298) 

Ch. 8  The Deconstruction of Art

(taking fewer notes here for the sake of time)

* As the ttile indicates, he's dealing with Derrida's deconstruction of art here.  He states at the outset the D is more directly concerned with aesthetics and with artists than the others.  (299)

* He reflects on misreadings of D's strong aestheticism and his use of different writing styles... ..a tendency to compartmentalize his works.  (300-301)  He reiterates that he think to be consistent with D's idea this can't be done because for D there was not such thing as a purely "sscholarly, political, or aesthetic problem..." and that conclusion is a resutl of his "own attempts to undermine the Kantian distinction between the theoretical, the practical, and the aesthetic." (302)

* He rejects the idea that D's goal was to remove "pathos" from literature.  He sees pathos in D's works (not in comparison in Paul De Man's).  (303)

* D's radical irony he says is dependent on the "historical existence of a tradition that lends it pathos" and which is "intertwined with that of the logocentric, phonocentric West, to such an extent that the two now seem almost inseparable." (303)  He means Judaism!

* This is a complex thing to say.  First step, is that he thinks it is "clear that Derrida writes in the shadow of the Holocaust." (303)  Though it is never present in a "vulgar" way.  He insists  that "Derrida's appeal to Judaism as a marginal tradition, present wtihin the interstices and along the edges of the 'Western' tradtion, gives to his writing a  much greater sense of alienation from that tradition that one finds in Nietzsche and Heidegger. If "his predecessors can appeal to the pre-Socratics and sophists, Derrida cannot--for these, too, are part of the tradition that he wishes to attack." (303-304)  

* In raising this issue, Megill says he's dealing with a huge and complex problem that is hard to deal with. (304)  But he insists it is the "hidden center and motivation for other issues that might at first glance seem to be entirely unrelated to it..."  (304)  He list four issues: the question of the "other", esp vv Emannuel Livanas; the question of 'writing' or secondariness, vv Edmond Jabes; third, the question of "interpretation, vv Freud, and fourthe the question of "art," vv Kant.  (304)  He sumes up these issues on 304-305. 

*  In the section "Levinas and the pursuit of the 'other'",  Levinas has a critique of German romantics and Husserl interest in unity as a philosphy interested in the "same" -- a discourse ultimately about power and exclusion.  Derrida undermines this a bit, imagining that wheresa Levinas sees the interest in the same as a desire to remove the Jewish alter ego, Derrida "maintains that 'the themes of nonpresence' work over phenomenology unceasingly,..." (310)  ... ie the problem of the other, of its infinite alterity, is always present.  He's trying, Megill thinks, to deconstruct Levina's "conception of a Hebraism that would stand in opposition to Western philsophy."  (310)  He's removing the possiblity for thinking of a "pristine Judasim".  (311)  and wants instead to think o fthe "inevitable complicity of Judasim with the totality it seeks to oppose."  (311)  So he's trying to erase the powerful "distinction between Hebraism and Hellenism" that appears often,  BUT it remains in his thought.  His erasure is a mere concealment, not an absence Megill says.  He qutoes a fascination quote where D talking about Levinas, imagines Levinas to be suggesting that there be a second patricide, of the Greek father who is still dominant, and then by asking the question "will a non-Greek ever succed in doing what  Greek in this case could nto do, except by digusuing himself as Greek, be speaking Greek, by feigning to speak Greek in order to get near the king?" (quoted on 311)  Megill thus speculates that D was engaged in a project of dehellinization even after his critique of Levinas.  He writes Harold Bloom has suggest this e.g. as well that "Derrida substiutes the Hebrew davhar, with its connection to the act and marks of writing, for the ethereal Greek logos." (312)  Also G. Douglis Atkins, is clear on the "Hebraic" elements in Derrida.  Atkins sees D as "engaged in a sysetmatic project of dehellinization, an attack on the values of clarity, transparency, and intellecutal maastery that are so deeply imbedded within Western consciousness." (312)

title: Getting Spliced: Modernism and Sexual Difference
text:
p.111-116 Moore analysis...

Burke analyzes Moore here.  Elliot, Pound and William Carlos Williams saw these women as the most intelligent.  They fed into their competition.  She shows how Moore, who was a bit jealous of Loy's sophistication, subjects that sophistication to inspection, and then that also enters into her poem "Marriage" ... which critiques marraige, revealing the problem of sex difference, the problem of union that is built upon others coming together -- which Burke says is "perhaps the central 'contrarity' for a poects based on what Kenneth Burke calls 'the motif of the spinster...and the tehme of the spirited feminie indepdneence'" (114) -- and also the implicit male power in marriage -- Moore writes that she is not so interested in an marraige, which she calls an enterprise, that "works according to the principle of 'that which is great because something else is small.'" (115).  

Burke concludes the section with Williams' insight that Moore disliked "connectives." Burke writes: "Her dislike of connectives keeps all the partners in the verbal dance at a discrete (and discreet) distance from each other--'unnicked'--while the intelligence moves them about in new choreographies, without, however, resolving their figures back into the two-steps of social dancing." (115)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text: p.170- Parsons leaves behind evolutionism Parsons left behind evolutionism. She then became accoridng somebody a de facto functionalist before functionalism was present. (171) Perhaps because she saw the origins of human behavior as unconscious Rosenberg thinks this is apt. (171) So then she wanted to know why certain habits and customs held:. She never answered definitely. One asnwer was the sense that people needed to sheild themselves from difference. (171) Men saw women as anomalous, so men's fear of women was a fear of difference. (171-172). So she thought a woman takes up a man's arm in order also to "raise up an imperceptible kind of barrier between us, a barrier converlty soothig to the snese of disquiet, extremely slight in this circumstance of course, the difference in sex arouses. As a gesture of sex, taking a man's arm is a kind of innoculation agianst sex." (quoted on 172). So fear central, fear of declassificaiton, men don't want to desexualize women; women don't want to be desexualized. (172). But it wasn't just fear, their was also a "will to power" : thus classification served the function of "social rule." (173) as she wrote in her book Social Rule. These ideas here touche don those of Freud and Nietzsche. (173) Parsons in fact helped spread the use of psychoanlytica theory, but using it in her own distinctive way like many Americans. (174)

title: Multiculturalism: Examining the Politics of Recognition
text:
Notes on Taylor's Essay

Notes on Taylor on Multiculturalism

* T starts by saying that much of contemporary politics turns on "the need, sometimes the demand for recognition." (25) Recognition underlies nationalist movements, in he claims of he subaltern, in some forms of feminism, and in multiculturalism.

* The demand for recognition he says is given "urgency" by the "supposed links between recognition and identity, where this latter term designates something like a person's understanding of who they are, of their fundamental charachteristics as a human being." (25) Recognition is important because if a person is not recognized or falsely recognized and represeented he idea is that this can cause harm and is a form of oppression that imprisons a person or a people in a "false, distorted, ans reduced mode if being." (25) e.g. feminists have argued that women have internalized a social representation of their own inferiority. A similar afgument has been allied to he subjects of European colonization.

* Taylor wants to give he historical origins of this politics of recognition and identity. Bevelled was the first to develop the notion of recognition in his famous dialectic if the master and slave. But there is an earlier narrative origin in T's account. He roots it in the collapse of social hierarchy and the notion of honor, which presumed inequality. What replaced honor was the "modern notion of dignity." (27) The idea here he says was that everyone shares in dignity and this introduced the principle of equal recognition, which has been central to democratic societies. But what ultimately modified and "intensified" the principle of recognition was the new notion of individual identity that emerged at the end if the 18th century along with a notion of being true to oneself that Taylor calls "authenticity" following Trilling's study "Sincerity and Authenticity." (28). He gives a god and brief account of the rise of this ideal on 28 and 29. Basically, it originates in the late 18th century idea that humans have a moral source inside themselves. Whereas before being a full humans being meant being in touch with an external moral source, now that source is "deep within us." (29). So T says this is part of the "massive subjective turn of modern culture, a new form of unsafeness, in which we come to think of ourselves as beings with inner depths." (29). Rousseau was crucial in developing this idea. (29-30). But the notion of authenticity developed as the result ifbwhat Taylor calls a "displacement of the moral accent" in the idea hat we had a moral source within us. The original idea included the idea that it was important to be untouched with one's "moral feelings" in order to know what is right to do. The displacement he is talking about "comes about when bejng in touch with our feelings takes in crucial moral significance." (28). This shift takes place after Rousseau and T associates it with Herder, who he says "put forward the idea that each of us has an original way of being human: each person has his or her own 'measure.'" (30) This idea he says has "burrowed" deep into modern consciousness and it is quite new because nobody before would have assigned such moral importance to the differences between humans." (30). Herder applied this principle both to individuals and to groups, ie the Germans should not pretend to be French.

* Once the idea of authenticity is in place in relation to individual identity, however, it became tied to the principle of recognition. It's not clear from T's analysis how orbit Herder dealt with recognition, although he says it first came up in Hegel. But what he does is pointbout mentikningbGeorge Herbert Mead that our "identities" cannog be purely "monologically" developed inwardly. That is because human life has a "fundamentally dialogical charachter." Our identities are developed through the acquisition of languages--in a broad sense including expressions and gestures--and through exchange with what Mead called "significant others." (32). So one's identity is not worked out in isolation. T thinks this has always been true. Such sependence in others did not rise with the importance of authenticity. It was always there in the social categories that everyone took for granted. What happened in modem times wwas the possibility that recognition could fail. So in premodern times "people didn't speak if "identity" and recognition--not because people didn't have (what we call) identities, or because these didn't depend on recognition, but rather because these were then too unproblematic to be thematized as such." (35)

* The result of the rise of a politics of recognition has been the development of a discourse of identity formation in the "intimate sphere" where we understand the formation of the self to be taking place "in a continuing dialogue and struggle with significant others." (37).  Because the individual needs and is vulnerable to significant others in this culture of authenticity relationships of all sorts but especially love relationships took on greater importance. (36)  This is the realm that Ibwas describing in my last dissertation chapter. Then the politics of recognition is also felt in the realm of the public sphere where its role has taken on more importance. He points out that in this social sphere the idea that identities aee dialogically formed has "made the politics of recognition more.central.and stressful." (36). And even more it has raised the stakes because the refusal of recognition it is understood can cause harm. (36) Taylor wants to focus on the latter in the- analysis that follows. (37). He indicates he links between the two levels are numerous...but ions strand has emerged outvoted psychologically oriented feminism. He points to Nancy Chodrow's Feminism and Psychoanalytic Theory and also Jessica Benjamin's Bonds of Love .

* What happened in public sphere: move from honor to dignity created a politics of universalism that- militated against privilege. Then the notions of authenticity and identity created a "politics of difference" in which we are supposed to recognize the individual or group's distinctness. The universalism of the original.universalism is now seen asnoriblematic precisely because it villolates that distinctness and forces assimilation or conformity to the dominant majority identity. (38). He notes an example of this charge from a feminist perspective in Carol Gilligan's critique of Kohlberg's Beirut of mtoral.development in In a Different Voice. Underlying thisbpolitics of difference is a universalism. It too opposes privilege but the demands of universalism are limited sharply by the demands of the politics of difference: "we give due acknowledgment only to what is universally present--everyone has an identity--thriuh recognizing what is peculiar to each. The universal demand powers an acknowledgement of specificity." (39)

* Another consequence was that the politics if difference generated an aawareness if a new kind of secknd class citizenship, ie not a kind as before conditioned by poverty but instead by lack of recognition of difference. (39). His led to new prrograms such as affirmative action that seemed to be "undue favoritism " for those who he says had "nit gone along" with the way the politics if difference altered the nilotion of equality. (39) ie for those who stick to the original notion of dignity programs destined tobpreserve and protect some cultural heritage "seem like a reversal, a betrayal, a simple negation of their cherished principle." (40)

* The point here then is that the politics if universal dignity and the politics of difference begin to diverge even though they both originate in the original shift to dignit

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text: p.022 -26 Intellectual "Structure" in early 30s Madden's theme resurfaces "Anthropology as a body of knowledge was not entirely secure inthe early 1930s... " (22) Now he traces a break in linguistics and anthropology, rooted in a difference between Sapir and Leonard Bloomfield's theory emerged in his 1933 book on Language. The difference had to do with the degree to which linguistis were allowed to deal with "meaning" as opposed to structure and syntax. Bloomfield's thoeries left less meaning for an examination of meaning, and that his shoudl be left to anthropologists and psychologists. This turn led eventually to chomsky's Syntactic Structures in the 50s. (22-24). Another problem M identifies is lack of centralization in terms of the different cultures of anth. knowledge developing at different universiteis where anthropology maintianed relaitons with different depts. This lack of uniformity Madden however suggests was not fragmenting partly b/c most anthropologists "remained eclectic" and "did not use these different approaches to promote models, 'schools of thought,' or paradigms..." (24), i.e. they were "pre-paradigmatic" as he argues in the intro. (24) Chicago: Close intellectual ties with sociology among anthropologists at Chiacgo despite break. Redffield trained under Robert Park and married his daughter. (24) Radcliffe-Brown came to Chiacgo in 1931 and imported British structuralist anth., a theory based heavily on Durkheim's notions of social organizaiton. R-B stayed at Chicago until 1937 influence Redfield and Fred Eggan. 1934 R-B chairman of Diviosn of the Social Sciences aat Chicago. 1935 he hires another "structuralist anthropologist": William LloydWarner, trained by Lowie and Kroeber at Berkeley, but who came under R-B's influence while doing fieldwork in Australia. (25) Madden argues that R-B's appraoch was "pardigmatic in that [he]d defined a single research agenda and emphasized particular kinds of data at the expense of others." (25) But R-B's ideas did not have power. Madden says anthropolosts did not want to abandon "holistic notions of culture" or more gneerally "diachronic" forms of analysis (25-26) Columbia: Was forming closer ties with psychology. "In 1929, the anthropology department at Columbia had moved from the Journalism Building to the fourth floor of Skermerhorn Extension and shared a wing with the psychology department. Students of both disciplines shared a common reading room." (26)

title: Anthropology and Antihumanism in Imperial Germany
text:
p.045 [Poor recepiton of Boas' habilitation work]
Zimmerman argues that a poor reception of Boas' work reflected the marginality of antrhopology in 1886 Germany.  
He quotes the first evaluator of the work, the meteorologist Wilhelm von Bezold as writing: "This research deals with a region far removed from the centers of human culture and can by its very nature arouse little general interest." (quoted on 45).  Zimmerman also quotes geography Heinrich Kiepert as making a similar point. 
Boas left Germany the next year.

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.034 COMMENT: Huntington uses culture as Kronfeldner would say as an explanandum (something that explains)

Witness this quote speaking of the conflicts between U.S. and Japan v. U.S. and Europe: "The basic values, attitudes, behavioral patterns of the two societies could hardly be more different.  The economic issues between the United States and Europeare no less serious than those between the United States and Japan, but they do not have the same political salience and emotional intensity because the differences between American culture and European culture are so much less." (34)

title: 'The Value of Person Lies in His Herzensbildung': Franz Boas' Baffin Island Letter-Diary 1883-1884
text:
Notes 7/9/2012

Ok...glancing at this article now for two reasons. 1) How does it support the whole conversion-fieldwork motif that is told vv Boas, and subsequently becomes key for anthropology, as Julia Liss states it at the outset of her "Patterns of Strangeness."? 2) Is there any thing in the reproduction of the thing that I can use for my claims vv Kant and Boas?

Number 1 is easy:

" This isn't an article so much as a reproduction/ translation of parts of the letter-diary that Boas kept. Cole gives a useful description of the circumstances in which Boas wrote it: namely, that it was in many ways an extended love letter to Marie, who he had recently become engaged to, and also a kind of field-journal.

" Cole also describes what Boas intended to do in the Arctic. Boas had finished a dissertation in 1881 from Kiel in physics, but had begun to move in the direction of geography, which up until then he'd studied as a minor field. (13) By April 1882, when he was doing his military service, he was already planning, in his words, "an investigation of the dependence of contemporyr Eskimo migrations upon the physical relationships and forms of their land. (BPP: FB/A. Jacobi 4/10/82: cf. Kluckhohn & Prufer 1959, Stocking 1968)."

* He chose the Eskimo or Inuit, Cole think, partly because it was not overstudied. And maybe because as early as 1870 he had told his sister Toni of his desire to take an expedition to the north or south pole. See BPP: FB to Toni 12/3/70).  (14)

* His goal in research had to do with his reading and contribution to the geographical literature on the Arctic in the year he spent preparing to go to the arctic in Berlin. He wrote an article on the "homeland of the Netsilik Eskimo" in which he described and "postulated extensive routes of trade and travel between Inuit groups of the central an eastern Arctic.  Accoridng to the article, these well-established routets extended from Ugulik, a settlement at the western tip of King William Island, eastward through Iglulik on Fury and Hecla Strait, and from there in two direction on Baffin island--to Pond Inlet at the northern end, and down along the western coast, connecting eastwards to Cumberland Sound." (15) Cole says that these "interests and postulates" structured his plan for investigation in Cumberland ound.  He was to do cartographic and meteorological research, but also to student "Eskimo migration, hunting areas, trade routes, and the realtionships of one group to another." (15)  Cole describes:

he would travel in the summer and fall of 1883 to Lake Kennedy (Lake Nettilling), an island sheet of fresh water, and from there attempt to reach the west coast of Baffin Island and follow it north to Iglulik. Returning to winter in Cumberland Sound, he would 'collect ethnographic material and make a thorough study of the language, customs and habigts of the Esktiomo' (BFP: 'Als Ausgangspunkt' n.d.) In the spring he would return to Ilulik and then, by the route postuated in his article, travel north to Pond Inlet, perhaps yet farther north to Devon Island. He would return to Cumbelrand Sound in July along the Davis Strait, and ail home in the fall aboard a whaler. (15)

Note that Cole is quoting that he would collect ethnographic data. This I think is the subtle way in which the emphasis comes to rest on ethnographic research into cultures? Or is this too strong an accustation of Cole's intentions?

* Cole also notes that Boas hoped tht the trip would end with him being pciked up by an "American whaler." So that he could go to NY and see Marie Krackowiyer, the daughter of Dr. Ernst Krackowiyer, an austrian 1848er and friend of Abraham Jacob, Boas uncle (by marriage). (15) Cole describes how that relationship developed 15-16. 

* Now skipping to the end, Cole says that the trip was mostly a failure in terms of Boas' original intentions. (49) And then the key argument: "Retrospectively, of course, the most significant aspect of Boas' experience in Baffin Island was his ethnographic immersion among the Inuit. His life and reputation were to be made in anthropology, and this was his initiation." Cole means initiation into ethnography. The idea of initiation is what Liss is talking about in her "Patterns of Strangeness." Cole also then says that Boas at this point began to "see the tasks of ethnography as 'more pressing'." Here he is quoting Boas from FB/Bell 3/19/86)

* The repulsion that Boas felt for the Eskimo at first he emphasized in his first three Tageblatt articles, which dealt with his initial impressions of the Eskimo. Cole quoteson the disgust fromDie Eskmos des Cumberland-Sundes und der Davisstrasse Berliner Tageblatt, Nov.2. 1884:

Had someone then told me that in a short time I would be living without resistance in the same conditions, I would have denied such impuatation with indignation. It was not long, however, before the force of circumstances had brought me to share the native caribou-hide dwelling and cook in the same kettle--though I usuall took the precaustion of having my own kettle... (quoted on 21)

This quote does seem to confirm in a way some of what I am saying in my article. The way he notes the transition from a reistance to a certain form of living, and then a gettin gused to it. A habitual acquiescence or something. He takes to the new way of being in other words...

* Boas also notes, interestingly, that he is able to get on with the Eskimo mostly because they all speak English!! He writes: "I have found such a kind and friendly welcome here that I feel quite at home. I get along well in English and most of the Eskimo understand and talk English." (22)

* On Sept. 24in Kikkerton, he writes to Marie (he is able to write to her) that he will stay in the viccinity of Kikkerton until Christmas, and then he will travel with the Eskimo in Januar when they "against start to travel." (22)

* He has met a Mr. Mutch who promises to help him, who seems not to be German.  He was a servant of a Mr. Noble,,.  He will take im to an Eskimo whom he knows at the sea, and the Eskimo man can take him further... (22-23)

* Next Boas took a strip on Sept. 25th to an "oil cache" on Warham Island. They got stuck and he wasn't able to return to Kikerton until October 4th. Then Boas traveled with on "Signa's whaler". Then he travels with Wilhelm (his servant from home, Signa, Utjutjak, who Cole says is called Yankee and is a nephew of Signa, along the "length of Pangnirtung Fjord." (23)

* A good example of this sense of wanting to take something sacred. On October 11th, he writes: "...At noon we stopped to rest on a plant-covered terrace and while dinner was being cooked, I climbed up and found three old well-preserved skulls, but I did not dare on account fo the Eskimo, whom I would have greatly offended. So I had to row on without aying anything abut my discovery..." (23)

* Around October 22, Boas was confined to Kikkerton because ice began to form on the Sound. And he couldn't go until early December when the ice was strong enough to bear a sled. He thus set up a tent ont he ice, Cole says, to "measure the tides" and chart the islands and its surroundings. He also got help from Mr. Mutch to study the Inuit, focusing in aprticualr on their "geogrpahical knowledge." Cole says. (24) Cole quotes from an 1884 article "A journey in Cumberland Sound and on the West Short of Davis Strait in 1883 and 1884" printed in the Am. Geog Society, N.Y.. Bulleting, 16, 242-72:

Every night I spent with the natives whole told me about the configuration of the land, about their travels, etc. They related the old stoories handed over to them by their ancestors, sang the old songs after the old monotonous tunes, and I saw them playing the old games, with which they shorten th elong, dark winter nights... (quoted on 24)

* He reports that he is called upon as a "doctor" and they call him Doctoradluk [I couldn't copy the special characters].  So he is taking care of these people's dieing kids or people with pneumonia and he feels a sense of responsibility because he cannot do anything. (24-25) He reports thi to Marie on November 18, Kikkerton, an says he's writing her for solace for his heavy heart.

* He reports on Nov.25, still in Kikkerton that life is "rought: "Marie, truly it is a rought life her among the Eskimo. I oftne painfully miss the voice of a friend, but you help me bear all this and I shalll return to you as I left..." (25)

* Then on Dec 2, Kikkerton he reports being happier. He talks about how he plays often with the children. "Usually we sing together and play, whereby I always have the secret intention of learning their games." Then he says how it is good there.

"I wish you could see me among the Eskimo. It is not nearly as bad as you imagine. I am as comfortable warm in my fur clothes  as I could wish to be. I took a two-hour walk today only for pleaure and in spite of the wind and [-23 C] cold I was as  warm as in the house. I will be happy when I can show you photographs of all the places where I have been! I go about Kikkerton in order to take them an in the evening I have important conversations with the Eskimo about customs, songs, religion, etc. Mr. Mutch is very helpful as interpreter and gives me a great deal of information about all possible things. Now they are all busy making caribou cltohing and I hope they will be finished this week. Then I can again think of travelling and hop first to go northward. In the next month I ntend to set up a depot of provisions, etc. for Davis Strait and then to go to Lake Kennedy..."

* KEY KEY: In this quote, Boas says a few things that are juxtaposed. He talks about his belief that happiness "as a member of humanity as whole" requires working with "all one's energy' with the "masses". (27):

Dec 12, near Nixtung: Dear Marie! I am not two days distant from Kikkerton, at the same place where I was a long time ago in a boat where I met the Eskimo who were returnign from Nittiling. What great differences exist between now and then...Although it is [-35c] col,d I did not feel cold while I walked. My caribou clothing was almost too warm. I almost wen off alone with Signa, because Wilhelmä's clothing was not ready, but Mr. Mutch took pity on me and lent me his things. I hope they will send uus th emissing things next week....Do you know that for a while I believed I had no heart, because I did not take things so much to heart as others idid. But I know better now. You, my Marie, have taught me that I am still able to feel. How happy we will be! But I am wandering from m y excursion to Augpalugtung. (You wrote me once I should not use logic in my letters--don't you do that in this case.) I believe that one can be really happy only as a member of humanity as a whole, if one works with all one's energy together withthe masses towards his goals. I think if one always felt that way it wouldbe much  easier to bear hardships and one would be more thankful for every joy. But now good night! I only want ot say once again that I always, always, love you immeasurably, that I long r the moment that shall take me back to you and with longin gI picture the time when nothing shall separate us. And now sleep well, dearest, Dream of your Franz. (28)

Interesting here, one the reference to a common humanity, in the context of the masses, which is 1848 politics vv cosmopolitanism? And he's discussing also the idea of feeling with her. Feeling more. He seems to have discovered that he can feel more. Of course, the background of this may be that move away from his materialism that has accompanied his retreat from physics, that other scholars have noted. But feeelng is one the mind...

* Dec. 13th, again t near Nixtang, the weather seems tohave gotten worse. There is a lot of fog. And he is writing something to Marie in a bit difficult circumstances. He seesm to want to communicate how the life is a bit hard. The daily life. He wants to give her a picture of that. He says the iglu is so cole that it hard to write. Then he says it has warmed a bit and he "still I feel quite comfortable."  Then he says: Feelings of comfort and discomfort are really quite relative." (28) This discusison of feelings again vv relativity. But a relativity of the preception of them... This is perhaps the kind of relativity in the strong fomr which is what I am maybe arguing againnst in the Manifold origins paper?

* The Kant reference: OOn Dec. 16th, he has had a hard day of travel trying to near American Harbor. Then he says:

Do you know how I pass the time these long evenings? I have a copy of Kant with me, which I am stuying, sot hat I shall not be so completly uneducated when I return. Life her really make one dull and stupid (only at times however--whenI et back to Kikkerton I will be sharp again). I have to blush when I remember that during our meal tonigh I though how good a pudding with plum sauce would taste. But you have no idea what an effect privations and hunger, real hunger, have on a person. Maybe Mr. Kant is a good antidote! The contrast is almost unbelievable when I rmember that a year ago I was in societty and observed all the rules of good taste, and tonight I sit in this snow hut with Wilhelm and an Eskimo eatinga piece of raw, fronzen seal meat which had first to be hacked up with an ax, and greedily gulping my coffeee. Is that not as great a contradcition as once can think of ? ... (29)

P.3 dec 23, he refers to a Inuit custom as beautiful.  And then compares their society with his own... This is the letter where he refers to here's idling and where he halos seems to refer to the "relativity of cultivation"

P. 33 also he notes that he can still not understand the Inuit when they are telling stories.

P. 35 He complains about not being able to speak a "sensible word" with the Inuit. So he feels that it is hard "not to have any one with whom to speak a sensible word, no one who is in any way close to you." He gets into this because it is New Year, dec31, and he imagines how Marie is around "among your people...among those whom you love."

P. 36 Jan, 21, Tininixdjuax.  He is noting how the Eskimo have come to believe tht he is the cause of a disease going around. Cole describes the situation here, indeed the likely possibility that the disease came with the germania and the Catherine. The Eskimo then decide at the behest of a shaman apparently that Boas not be allowed into their igloo. (36) Boas reaction was that this "hostility" ought not be "allowed to prevail". (36) this reaction is interesting. Clearly, it does involve a kind of arrogant reaction to what Boas could see still as superstitious belief, even though it probably was not. But there is also a more complex background here. One has to think of the fondness Boas had developed for the igloo, for the experience of entering them after being very cold.  He says this in the letter from Jan. 22, on 36-37, where the point is in fact that his point of view has shifted in the way that Cole notes oin his editor note on p.21, ie this is the kind of shift in the appreciation of what is beautiful that I am getting at in my Mamifold article.

P.37 the quote re igloo's being beautiful, related to Cole's note on 21, form letter Jan. 22: "You have no idea how anxiously one looks for the appearance of the icefoot on the horizon, and then when one is near to land with joy one greets the sign of an iglu. It is impossible to tell how comfortable and beautiful it seems when one enters into these dirty, narrow spaces, at the appearance of which I at first turned away in horror..." (36-37)

P. 37 Also in this Jan 22 letter is an important reflection on not wanting a "German professorship." With what is here alone it is hard to know exactly what Boas means. He talks about the idea that he would be "restricted to my science and to teaching". Does he mean that he would be restricted to physics and teaching? for which he now says he has "little inclination." (37) But then he says that in the United States he can further the "ideas for which I live." but which ideas? Scientific ideas? Maybe but maybe not beau as a bit further along he says: "What I want to live and die for, is equal rights for all, equal possibilities to learn and work for poor and rich alike! Don't you believe that to have done even the smallest bit for this, is more than all science together? I do not think I would be allowed to do this in Germany." (37) So there is no reference here to his being blocked as a Jew. The clearest reference is to a restriction to his science, whatever that means. But perhaps it need not be said to Marie because she knows already, or on the other hand why would he not be free to reference the role of his Jewishness in is calculation with Marie? I need to look in Cole's biography because I think he has a reference from Boas to the Jewishness problem in this calculation....

Also interesting here is that he moves on after this to a reference to a harsh reality. He refers romantically tomMarie and how she will help him and give him strength to do all this, an dthen he writes: "But I must return to harsh reality! The activities of the Eskimo, the howling of e dogs, the screaming of the children, all in this small iglu , call me back." obviously this is just a transition out of the letter, but the juxtapositions are interesting between a discussion of ideas, even ideals, and love for Marie, and then a reference to. Harsh reality that again does not seem so bad. Chaotic perhaps but it is happening in e small iglu, which he has fought to regain entrance into, and he is "called" back, not forced back.

Also then at the end of this Another relativity reference. He has referred to the situation in the iglu, then he says he wonders what she is doing, and again the theme from before and discussion of new years activity on 34-35, the theme of her being among her people: "At least you have the advantage of being able to speak with them [whatever company she is keeping]. I have, however, sometimes found that what one hears in "society" is worth [no more for me than] the conversation of these people here." (37-38) here the second brackets are Cole's.

* Letter February 14, Anarnitung. He is trying to go seal hunting, and there are parts of it that are intriguing him. He doesn't succeed in getting anything, but he describes the experience: "There I sat, like an Eskimo, behind my ice hole at the water's edge and patietnialy waiting for a head to appear. You cannot imainge  what an impression it makes in this cold season to sit so near the edge of the water and t hear the roaring and foaming. Thick frog from the cold water envelops me. At my feet the water foams and hisses. Only a strong current keeps the water from freezing here. My resing place shakes and trembles as the pieces of ice strike it.  These are finally pulled under by th eforce of the current and I can feel them drifting about under my feet. Suddenly another large piece breaks off and I must retreat quickly in order to to be too close to the water. In a few minutes there is wild chaos where I stood...I shall try my luck again tomorrow. I want to bring back one seal..." (40)

The next day then he is also not successful. But now he says he is entirely an eskimo: "Today I unted just as an eskimo, with a pear and all that goes with it. I sat beside the water just as ptiential as they do..."  Then a bit farther on: "As you see Marie, I am now a true Eskimo. I live as they do, hunt with them and belong to the men of Anarnitung. I have hardly any European food left, eat only rseal and drink coffee." And the a bit farther on: "Although seal hunging bores me drreadfully I do it as it is the onlyway of obtaining what I need...." (40) -- that it is the only way for him to get what he needs he probably means is proof also that he IS Eskimo.

* Febrary 16, Anarnitung --  Letter is interesting because he describes the scene of the inside of an iglu. He describes it with appreciation, detial, and affectionit seems. But then immediately after he ends that description, with a description of an old man who tells him stories that he seems to like in "beautiful" pidgin English, he then goes again into his "longing" for people who understand him and with whom he can have "sensible conversation". : "There is one old man named Metik (duck) whom I especially enjoy. As soon as he sees me comeing he calls out 'asshoyoutioli!,' which means 'how are you,' and follows, in the most beautiful pidgein English used by the Eskimo who know English words, with all kinds of stories. Thus I live day after day. Now wonder I long for sensible conversation andf ro someone who really understands me!" ( 42) Then he describes how he has not brought a book and reads the ads on the Koelnische Zeitung.

 

* February 18th to March 7th letters, report the "dog sickness" -- sickness affecting the sled dogs -- has returned and it's depressing and also I think ruining Boas plans. In the March 7th letter he's talking about wanting to go back in the summer to Marie. He says he feels "depressed and hopeless" (44)  He says he wants to get courage from her and the like. And he's then getting all wrapped up in masculinity stuff about courage and th elike: "I must press you to my heart. Oh , I harddly know myself what I am writing. Now you see what has become of my much boasted courage...You see what a weakling your Franz is!" (44) Of course, this is all likely  in part to dramatize his courage and strength in the usual manner of men. He does however seem upset, and then he comes to the followinig conclusion: "I realize more surely from day to day that I am not meant to live in loneliness. I need people very much, people who really have a right to the name. I feel much better nowt hat I have poured out my heart. .. " (44) I think the reference to the people who have a right to the name here is n ot the Eskimo--perhaps--but more directly the people on the American shipthat he also refers to in this letter as being horrible. But also in the letter of February 16th, he was getting lonely again and refering to -- after his description of the iglu -- his longing for "sensible convesration" as it has been tranlsated. Whatever that means.

* march 19, Ukiadliving: His spirits lighten because he has purchased 10 dogs in Ukiadliving, where he is greeted with cries because he's one of the first Europeans to have gone there. (44-45)

 

* April 23, He is enjoying the spring weather. (47)

* March 29, Nexemiarbing: He reports that he has heard that American ships had visited Padli the previous summer. So he thinks he may be able to go to America to see Marie. (45) 

 

* Things get bad again. he is affected by snow blindness anda  tooth ache among other things. (48-49). Then on July 4 he is partly relieved as Cole says that he meets an Eskimo man doing the last of his work who had travelled to Niaxonaujang from Igluling via Foxe channel to Nettilling. Cole writes: "This was welcome conrimation of his travel route thesis." (49)

* On August 26, he hears of two ship. The next day the Wolf, an american ship, arrives and he takes it to St. John's. Then his trip from Newfoundland port on Sept. 7th to NYC is "frustratingly slow" Cole says. He arrives finally on teh 21st. And then two days later is "reunited" with Marie at Lake George.

title: Cosmopolitan Style: Modernism Beyond the Nation
text:
Notes Feb 2012:

 

    Introduction

* Walkowitz wants to work with a kind of "critical cosmpolitanism" that she sees as being distinct from "planetary humanism".  (2)  For planetary humanism she cites Gilroy's Against Race: Imagining Political Culture Beyond the Color Line (2000).  She also cites Nussbaum's "Patriotism and Cosmplitanism?" and Ross Posnock Color and Culture: Black Writers and the Making of the Modern Intellectual.  See f.n. 4., p. 172.  By attaching critical to the term she wants to refer to critical theory.  And critical in this tradition she thinks "tends to imply double consciousness, comparison, negation, and persistent self-reflection: an 'unwillingness to rest,' the attempt to operate 'in the world... [while] preserving a posture of resistance,' the entanglement of 'domestic and international perspectives,' and the 'self-reflexive repositioning of the self in the global sphere.'' (2-3)  That sentence is cobbled together with quotes from Edward Said, Jacques Lezra, Benjamin Lee and Melba Cuddy-Keane, see f.n. 5, p.172.  Then she says that this notion of cosmpolitnaism refers to a type that has been defined by several others, and in f.n. 8 she lists Bruce Robbins's cosmpolitics, Melba Cuddy-Keane's critical globalization, James Clifford's discrepant cosmpoloitanism, and Homi Bhabbha's vernacular cosmopolitanism.  (172) 

* She tries to explain closely how this fits with critical theory and both supplements and critique's Kant's model on p.3.  The two "gestures of critique" she wants to pick up on from critical theory are 1 what she calls the distiction between "traditional" and "critical" theory, and 2 the "critique of critique" which sees in her "modernist" writers.  (3)  Critical rather than traditional theory, as Horkheimer defined it, does not see categories as neutral and seeks "to position knowledge in history, to investigate the social uses of knowledge, and to evaluate political interests that knowledge served." (3) It does not reject the notion of social progress  but tries to focus greater self-reflexive critique on categories.  But such crtiqiue she notes has also often moved away from Horkheimer's program of crtique of categories toward a critqiue of the "affective conditions (rationaly, purpose, coherence, detachment) that have seemed to make argumetn or engagement possible." (3)  This icnludes Adorno's suspcion of isntrumetnal action in his later 1960s essays and Hall's emphasis "in the 1990s on a cultural politics that is rooted in differentiation rather than in negation." (3)  AND it has also led cultural historians to "assocaite critique with a greater range of social dynamics and embodied affects."  She refers to Michael Warner's studies of "reverence" and Jordana Rosenberg on "enthrallment" and Sianne Ngai on "ugly feelings".  (3)  Such subjects don't necessarily easily fit with critical theory since "Enlightenment ideas of critique so much depend on the value of autonomous thinking and the freedom from religious political authority."  (3-4)  BUT she notes that Ngai in particular believes that "ugly feelings" reveal that 20thc century artists have developed "models of subjectivity, collectivity, and agency not entirely foreseen by past theorists of the commonwealth." (quoted on 3).  And more Ngai insists that to focus on the "abnegation of agency" in such "ugly feelings" can, in Walkowitz's words, "can create opportunities  for new refelection, reasoning, and self-cultivation" just as thinking about the "power of powerlessness."  (Walkotizy sitees p.18 and 14 in Ngai's study.  Walkowitz adds in a phrase that has some power I thiink: "...indeed, the willingness to relinquish physical or psychological control, to become temporarily and purposefully inattentive, or 'disconcertedÄ as Ngai puts it, is centralto early-twentieth-century conceptions of self-knowledge and of the limits of self-knowledge." (4) 

* In any case, this is how she approaches cosmpotianism and specifically hernotion of a "cosmpolitan style."  She says that "Cosmpoltian style is concerned with writers who have used naturalness, triviality, evasion, mix-ups, treason, and vertigo to generate specific projects of democratic individualism, onthe one hand, and of antifascism or anti-imperialiism , on the other."  (4)  This comes out a "new distrust of civilizing processes,a nd of hte role of art in these processes" (4) that leads these writers to develop a "critical cosmpolitanism" that expresses an ambivalence about "collective social projects."  (4)  She thinks that cosmpolitanism has alwas involved a "negotiation between distance and proximity." (4)  That said, the critical cosmopolitanism of her 20th and 21st century writers goes one step further into the dynamics bound up with notions lke distance and proximity when they "emphasize conditions of limited or suspended agency, and they ask us to consider how conceptions of belonging are bound up in the production, classification, and reception of literary narratives." (4)   Later she notes that this ina  different way saying that "it is in their additional refletion on the relationships between narrative and political ideas of progress, aesthetic and social demands for literalism, and sexual and conceptual decorousness, that Conrad, Woolf, and Joyce make their most significant contributions to the analytic project of critical cosmopolitanism." (5)  

* One idea embbed here and indicated in the term "style" is that to examine cosmopolitanism critically is to see its role in history and that this  means as she says on bottom of 4 not only seeing that cosmpolijntansim can support certain notions of imperialism, but also that it cosmpolitanism can involve certain "analytical postures" such that, for example, "a commitment to collective agency may be a style rather than an index of transnational politics." (4)  But that style, she seems to imply, still has real and powerful consequences...

* Here is where her analysis of cosmpolitanism begins to intersect with modernism.  She first defines modernism on 6.  She says it "involves strategies that respond to and engage with the experience of modernity, a condition of industrialization and 'spirit of critique,' as Dilip Parameshwar Gaonakr puts it, that shcoalrs now assocaiting not only with the past and with the West but also with the emergent practices of 'non-Western people everywhere.'" (6)  (She also uses Foucualt and Dipesh Chakrabarty to define it).  Thus modernism for her involves strategies or styles that attempt to respond to modernity.  Then her take on cosmpotlian style becomes one in which she seeks to diverge from thinkers like Terry Eagleton and Caren Kaplan who have argued that "early-twentieth century writers used metaphors of exile to represnt various experiences of idsplacement" by instead noting the power and effect of these gestures as styles or strategies.  She thus argues instead that "modernist writers troubled the distinction between local and global that most conceptions of exile have presuppposed." In this sense, she is working with modernism in the way that Perciles Lewis, Jessica Berman, and Jed Esty have done she says, (6) (She could also add Susan Hegeman I think!) 

(NOte that there is also here a link to the critique that Hollinger made in his essay "Ethnic Diverstiiy, Cosmpolitanism, and the Emergence of the American Liberal Intelligentsia," when he notest that the theme of exile in the literature of the Am. liberals, e.g. Bourne, Cowley etc, is one that misses the positive content of these liberals' discourse... Hollinger doesn't  think modenrism is a distinc thing it seems, and he means something else, ie he wants to critique their cosmpolitanism for being elitist, a fact that the exile/alienation theme implies and reproduces...)   

* Drawing on what she describes as a growing notion that many early 20th century writers following Walter Pater and Oscar Wilde saw "individualism as a social and political cause" (10-11)  and the Chantal Mouffe's notion of politics as antagonistic and taking myriad forms, she wants to see the cosmpolitanism of her writers as forming a distinct kind of political consciousness:  "I argue that syncretic but less-than-rational tradition of cosmpolitanism, which is often associated with aesthetecism, dandyism, and flanarie at the fin de siecle, helped to establish a new analysis of perception and alternative tones of political consciousness among early modernist writers."  (12) Ie she is seeing a politics in the late-Victorian tradition of aeshetic decadence, central to British modernism, that involved "a repertoire of excessive and purposefully deviant cultural strategies whose values include pleasure, consumption, szncretism, and perversity." (12)  This tradition she says "amplifies the place of transcience and artificiality within models of national culture and tansnational mobility." (12) She critiques existing studies of "international modernism" for having avoided this influence and focusing onyl on the "outward-looking ntaure of cosmpolitanism" and associating the avanteßgard only with "tones of antagonism, timeliness, and heroci certainty." (13) She sees as aligned with her project the attempts by Mica Nava, Monica L. Miller, Arjun Appadurai and Amitava Kumar to define a cosmpolitanism that does not only focus on people who travel, ie one that argues for the "inclusion of consumption, imagination, longing, and fantasy among cosmopolitan pracctices in the twentietht century." (13)  She gives as an example Nava's insistnce that the exotic clothing of middle-class English women although it is not part of "politics" because "it does not act within or on political institutions" but it is part of the "politcial" because "it shapes social relations of gender, bodily display, urban mobility, and transnational fantasy." (13)

*  She has here a very good and much moe concise section on "modernist cosmpolitanism" the main point of which is that the contemporary discussions eschew modernism, and in some cases reject it, but at the same time describe practices, techniques and practices that she thinks are inherent to modernism.  So she ultimately argues quite forcefully that "there is nos criticial cosmopolitanism without modernist practices" (18) and by consequence that to take critical cosmpolitanism seriously assuming that it relies on such practices means that we must "change what we claim about the relationship between idiosyncratic expression of culture and the conditions of international sympathy or reparation." (18)  I think what she means by the secon point is that we can't assume that a middle-class british woman buying exotic clothes is simply a close-minded consumer participating in a narrow form of identiity unrelated to a true cosmopolitan outlook.  She sees Bruce Robbins Feeling Global book as one that seeks to exclude modernism, as he saw it in Sontag's demand that we participate in modernist aims of "disorientation, defamiliarization, making strange."  And yet she notes that Robbins' cosmpoltianism is like modernism because it involves estrangement and hesitation and she inssits that he has in many ways been "the strongest advocate of a theory of cosmpolitanism that requires rather than rejects aesthetic experience, 'strategic acquiescening,' and models of conscience tha are 'rooted in routine duties and pleasures as well as in once-in-a-lifetime renunciations.'" (15) Another example is Walter Mignolo who limists cosmpolitanism to only those who have emerged from "various spatial and historical lcaotion of the colonial  difference" but then talks about "border thinking" as involving bricolage, a key technique of the modernist tradition of aesthetic decadence. (16)  

 * What is clear is that Walkowitz sees the focus on style and posture even in consumption as a way to democratize the approach to cosmpolitan politics.  She says it here when specifying what she thinks are the consequences of her accoutn of crticial and alternative cosmpolanism: 1 she says that it "suggestes that cultural strategies of posture have a significant role in even those cosmpolitan paradigms that involve actors who are not social elites or whose position in the world is not in all ways privileged" (17)  And this means that it may not be beste to critqiue cosmpolitanism by attempting to "'dissociate' cosmpolitanism from the lienaments of 'class, hierarchy, and affluence'' but instead one should acknowledge the analytic complexities of the cosmpolitan traditoin." (17-18) That's why she say that there is no critical cosmpolitanism withotu modernism.

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
p. 039 Demographics  of American Anthropological Ass. & Am. Ethn. Soc. & Others

It included from the beginning female charter members.  The American Ethnological Society "made no explicit exclusion of women, but did not number women among its charter members in 1848 or for many years thereafter." (39)  But when it was reorganized (when?) it included women (39)

Internaitonal Americanists also included women: including Celia Nuttall and Caecilie Seler of Germany in 1892.  (39-40)

title: Alain L. Locke: The Biography of a Philosopher
text:
p.003 Cultural Pluralism

The authors maintain that "[c]ultural pluralism--and to use one of Locke's more technical terms for it, intercultural reciprocity--served as the common ground fro his three concerns of race relations, value theory, and esthetic experience.  The story of Locke's life show that cultural pluralism is the governing idea behind all that Locke produced." (3)

title: When Wall Street Met Main Street: The Quest for an Investors' Democracy
text:
# Julia C. Ott, *When Wall Street Met Main Street: The Quest for an Investors' Democracy* (London, England: Harvard University Press, 2011)

> Summary: Julia Ott's book describes the formation of an ideology of a "shareholder democracy" (5) or "mass investment society" (225) in the 1920s. Her point is that this idea is the basis for more recent forms of modern conservatism that are perhaps more frequently traced to neoliberal thinkers such as Hayek and Milton Friedman. Her critical point is that this notion of "broad-based invesment as a social, political, and economic goal" ought to be reassessed by Americans. Although this idea of a shareholder democracy has "sometimes" supported regulation and "managerial restraint" it has, she says, "tended to marginalize questions about the distribution of economic wealth, security, and power. There has been wealth gained by some individuals, but because "securities investment requires significant disposable income, the wealthiest segments of society have enjoyed its benefits most." (225)

 

## Ch. 1 - The Problem with Financial Securities
* This chapter describes the emergence of a new "political-economic ideal--in which mass investment in financial securities would democratize modern captialism and restore propertied status to the citizenry." (34-35) 
* This new ideal was a response to the loss of property-based conceptions of citizenship in the face of mass industrialization, a problem highlighted by the Populist party and the critiques of Tom Watson. (12-21) 
* This new idea emerged gradually in three places, first, the U.S. Senate's Industrial Commiission investigation, initiated by McKinley after the election of 1898; then in the ideas of economicists Robert Ely, Jeremiah Jenks, and John Bates Clark, and in the ideas of U.s. District court Judge Peter S.  Grosscup; then finally in the Pujo Committee report. The basic idea here was to embrace economic concentration but reject the laissez-faire form; that is, to say that if properly regulated, shareholding might prrovide a way to democratize modern capitalism and introduce something like property-ownershiop back into the society. That is, this new ideal emerged **with** progressive era reform...

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text: p.002-37 CHAPTER 1

title: Essays in Radical Empiricism (Selections)
text:
General Notes for Pragmatism Course

A. Does Consciousness Exist?

* James starts by making a critique of the notion of consciousness.  He wants too deny that it exists. 

* He's really critiquing the metaphysical dualism that he blames on Kant: "At first, 'spirit and matter,' 'soul and body,' stood for a pair of equipollent substances quite on a par in weight and interest.  Btu one day Kant undermined the soul and brought in the transcendental ego, and ever since then the bipolar relation has bene very much off its balance.  The transcendental ego seems nowadays in rationalist quarters to stand for everything, in empiricist quarters for almost nothing." (162)

* He wants to move instead toward a notion of experience.  He says that he has for some time "suggested the nonexistence [of consioucsness], and tried to give them its pragmatijc equivalent in realities of experience." (163)  Again experience: "My thesis is that if we start with the supposition that there is only one primary stuff or material in the world, a stuff of which everything is composed, and if we call that stuff 'pure experience,' then knowing can easily be explained as a pqarticular sort of relation twoards one another into which portions of pure experience may enter.  The relation itself is part of pure experience..." (163) 

* He goes through a refutation of the "alternative view" in which consciousness is central. He takes as a starting point neo-Kantian thought about which he says "the evaporation of the definite soul-substance has proceeded as far as it can go without being yet complete." (163)

1-> For the neo-Kantians, he says the notion of consciousenss "does no more than signalize the fact that expeirence is indefeasibly dualistic in structure." (164)  He goes on: "To consciousness as such nothing can happen, for, timeless itself, it is only a witness of happenings in time, in which it plays no part.  It is, in a word, but the logical correlative of 'content' in an Experience of which the peculiarity is that fact comes to light in it, that awareness of content takes place.  Consciousness as such is entirely impersonal--'self' and its activiteis belong to content.  To say that I am self-conscious, or conscious of putting forth volition, means only that certain contents, for which 'self' and 'effort of will' are the names, are not without witness as they occur." (164) 

2-> But at the same time they suggest that we also have "an immediate consciosusenss of consciousness itself." (164)  The idea, he notes, is that the idea of consciousnesss can be determined through analysis, ie that through analysis (he gives metaphor of separating the menstruum in pain from the pigment) conscousness can be demonstrated to be seaprate from the content of consciousness.  (164-165)

*  But he rejects this idea that there is a duplicity in experience.  (165)  Experience he says is a "double-barelled" term...it is both subjective and objective.  He lists a series of other double-barrled terms that he thinks are replacing the single-barelled notions of thougth and thing: "The dualism connoted by such double-barrleed terms as 'experience,' phenomenon,' 'datum,' 'Vorfindung'--terms which, in philosphy at any rate, tend more and more to replace single-barrelled erms of 'thought' and 'thing'--that dualism, I say, is still preserved in thiis account, but reinterpreted, so that, instead of being mysterious and elusive, it becomes verifiable and concrete." (166)

* He roots the source of this way of thinkingin Locke and Berkeley interestingly... (166)

* He gives a long explanation vv a room and one's consicousness of it/relationship to it.  The basic problem in philosphy he thinks ahs been how to know how a thing exists in the world and also in the the mind.  He notes that "represenative " theories "avoid the logical paradox, but on the other hand they vioalte the reader's sense oflife, which knows no intervening metnal image but seems to see the room and the book immediately jsut as they physically exist." (167) 

* He summarizes the issue about how an object can be in the mind and in the world, but saying that it's like the problem of how a single point can be on two lines, and the answer is that it can if it lies where the lines intersect.  This the case with the room example.  Take the example of a room.  It can be seen as lieing at the intersection of multiple processes.  And the "pure experience" of the room can be thought of as lieing at an intersection.  (167)  Ie the experience of the room can be thought of a "a member diverse processes that can be followed away from it along entirely different lines." (167)  It is both in the context of one's "field of consciousnses" and also "the room in which you sit."  (167)  "it enters both contexts in its whoeleness,g giving no pretext for being said to attach itself to consciousness by one of its parts or aspects, and to outer reality by another." (167)  These two contexts are two procesess: the one the biography of the person, the other "the histors of the house of which the room is part." (167)  He contarsts these two processes on 167-8 in a nubmer of ways. 

* Now he applies the same principlpe to concepts as he just has to percepts.  (168)  "If we take conceptual manifolds, or memories, or fancies, they also are in their first intention mere bits of pure experience, and, as such, are single thats which act in one context as objects, and in another context figure as mental states." (168)   He quotes Muensterberg to demonstrates this "objectivity of non-perceptual experiences..." (169) 

*  This means there's a kind of "doubling-up of experience"...ie "jsuta s the seen room...is also a field of consciousness, so the conceived or recollected room is also a state of mind..." (171)  The common ground of this doubling up of experience is the fact that in pure experience the same experience is an intersecting point of a series of lines of context and processes...  Ie the basis is experience it seems.

* The doubling-up, though, doe snot imply division: "As 'subjective' we say that the experience represents; as 'objective' it is represented.  What represents, and what is represented, is here numerically the same; but we must remember that no dualism of being represented and representing resides in the experience per se.  In its pure state, or when isolated, there is no self-splitting of it into conscoiusness and what the consciousness is 'of.' Its subjectivity and objectivity are functional attributes solely, realized only when the experience is 'taken,' i.e. talked of, twice, considered along with its two different contexts respectively, by a new retrospective experience, of which that whole past complication now forms the fresh content." (172) 

*  So the "pure experience" is that which lies prior to this "taken" experience where the object is considered in relation to its two contexts, ie as seen object or idea.  "The instant field of the present it all times what I call the 'pure' experience.  It is only virtually or poentially weither object or subject as yet.  For the tie being, it is plain, unqualified actuality, or existence, a simple that..." (172)  This is the naive immediacty of expeirence prior to reflection...

* So  he sums up that consciousness does not itelf exists but "connotes a kind of external relation..." (172)  "The peculiarity of our experiences, that they not only are, but are known, which their 'conscious' quality is invoked to explain, is better explianed by their relations--these relations themselves being experiences--to one another." (173)  Ie our experiences are peculiar because they both exist and we know about them,a nd what we call consciousness is simply a way to refer to that fact; but it would be more accurate to simply talk about the 1) the relationships between the things existence and our knowledge of it, and 2) how those relationship are also part of our experience...

* Now he deals with objections to his idea... in ther est of this essay.  173-178.  Key points:

  • Things are for example "extended" in space, but thoughts not.  Things are red or hot, etc, but thoughts not.  This difference and the difficulty of explaining it would be explained by metaphysical dualism. But James challenges whether it's so true that, say, thoughts are not extended.  He notes that everyone agrees that thoughts and things share certain properties, say their relationship to time.  Also "[b]oth are of kinds, can be compared, added and subtracted and arranged in serieal orders." (174)  Rer extension, he insists that our thoughts do have extension, say if we think of a foot-rule.  "The difference between objective and subjective extension is one of relation to a context solely.  In the mIe ind the various extents maintain no necesssarily stubborn order relative to each other, while in the physical world they bound each other stably, and, added together, made the great envoloping Unit which we believe an and call real Space." (175)  The point then is that the difference is not that objects have qualities that our thoughts do not have, but that the relations of the qualities to things and the relationships of things in space is more definite for things.  Another way to put this is that qualities in the objective world have consequences.  A fire burns in a way that the thought of a fire does not.  He's good on this on 175-6.  Our sense of the subject/object distinction comes from the fact that "as the general chaos of all our experiences gets sifted, we find that there are some fires that will always burn sticks and always warm our bodies, and that there are some waters that will always put our fires; while there are other firest that will not act at all."  (175-6)  And later: "With 'real' objects, on the contrary, conseqences always acrue;and thus the real experiences get sifted from the mental ones, the things from our thoughts of them, fanciful or true, and precipitated together as the stable part of the whole experience-chaos, under the name of the physical world.  Of this our perceptual experiences are the nucleus, they being the originally strong experiences.  We add a lot of concetual experiences to them, making these strong also in imagination, and building out the remoter parts of the physical world by their means; and around this core of reality the world of laxly connected fantasies and mere rhapsodical objects floats like a bank of clouds.  In the clouds, all sorts of rules are violated which in the core are kept.  Extensions there can be indefinitely located; motion there obeys no Newton's law." (176)
  • Another critique that he brings up, the rationalist one?, that we are aware of our own consciousenss.  That we know it.  Here James refers to his materialistic sense of the "stream of thinking" which is just really a "careless name for what, when scrutinized, reveals itself to consist chiefly of the stream of my breathing..." (178).  He writes; "The 'I think' which Kant said must be able to accompany all my objects, is the 'i breathe' which actually does accompany them.' (178) 

B. A World of Pure Experience

* What would a radical empriicism be then for James?  -->  It's got to not include anything that is not "directly experience" or exclude anything that is directly experienced.  So that means that "relations that connect experiences must themselves be experienced relations, and any kind of relation experienced must be accounted as 'real' as anything else in the system." (178) 

* This definitin runs counter to "ordinary empricism" that in his view "has always shown a tendency to do away with the connections of things, and to insist most on the disjunctions." (179)  He references Berkeley's nominalism, Hume's idea that "whatever things we distinguish are as 'loose and separate' as if they had 'no manner of connection...'".  Also James Mill and John Mill.  And so on.  He speaks also of John Mill's "account of both physcial things and selves as composed of discontinuous possibilities, and the general pulverization of all Experience by assocaition and the mind-dust theory..." (179)  And he notes that the "natural result of such a world-picture has been the efforts of rationalism to corret its incoherencies byt he addition of transexperiential agents of unification, substances, intellectual categories and powers, or Selves..." (179)  His sense is that "if empiricism had only been radical and taken everything that comes without disfavor, conjunction as well as separation, each at its face value, the results would have called for no such artificial correction." (179)

* Taht is, he thinks that "radical empricism" can account for "conjuctive relations" without relying on a notion that they are true in some "supernal way, as if the unity of things and their variety belonged to different orders of truth and vitality altogether." (179)  Ie he thinks that the rationalists accusation that empiricists can't account for how the world of sensations holds together is false...

* He provides a useful metaphor to speak of the two traditions: "Prima facie, if you should liken the universe of absolute idealism to an aquarium, a crystal globe in which goldfish are swimming, you would have to compare the empiricist universe to something more like one of those dried human heads with which the Dyaks of Borneo deck their lodges.  The skull forms a solid nucleus; but innumerable feathers, leaves, stings, beads, and loose appendices of every description float and dangle from it, and, save that they terminate in it, seem to have nothing to do with one another.  Even so my experiences and yours float and dangle, terminating, it is true, in a nucleus of common perception but fo rth emost part out of sight and irrelevant and unimaginable to one another." (180)  He thinks that what he calls this "imperfect intimacy" of things with each other... or  their "bar e realtion of withness between some parts of the sum total of experiencea nd other parts" is what empricism over-emphasizes and rationalism tries to ignore.  Whereas his "radical empiricism" he think "is fair to both the unity and the disconnection..." (181)

* The "conjunctive relation" ie relatinon of connection, that has he says been most tbouelsome to philosphy is the "co-conscious transition...by which one experiences passes into another when both belong to the same self." (181)  "Personal histories are processes of change in time , and the change itself is one of the things immediately experienced.  'Change' in this case means continuous as opposed to discontinuous transition." (181)  This idea of continous transitiion is "one sort of conjunective relation" but he says to be a "radical empiricist is to focus on this kind of connection because it is where he ays so much corrupt thinking (ie "Metaphysical fictions") have entered in.  It is then to take this relation at "face value, enither less nor more; and to take it at its face value means first of all to take it just as we feel it, and not to confuse ourselves with abstract talk about it, involving words that drive us to invent secondary conceptions in order to neturalize their suggestions and to make our actual experience again seem rationally possible." (181) 

* What is key is that continuity is a "definite sort of experience," different from the experience of disctontinuity. (181)  And he says that's it.  There's no other "whatness" to the experience of change and development other than the "absence of break and this sense of continuity in that most intimate of all conjunctive relations, the passing of one experience into another when they belong to the same self." (182)  This is all there is to it, but he notes that "all experiences have their conditions" and what has happened he thinks is that "over-subtle intellects" have in asking how those conditions are possible, subsutited conceptions for the pure experience.  That's how one has got to these notions of Absolutes or Substances.  (182) 

* The cognitive relation.  This kind of radical empricism he thinks can save us from a pitfall common to philosphy, namely metpahysical dualism which he refers to as  "an artificial conception of the relations between knower and known" in which there an absolute discontinuity has always been posited.  He quicly summarizes the attempts to resolve the problem: by common-sense theorists, by representative associationalism, and by transcendentalists.  (183)  BUT he notes that all the while there was in the "very bosom of finite experience" already the answer.  He lists three cases on 183 of which he develops an exampel of #2, ie the case in which  the knower and the known are "two pieces of actual experience belonging to the same subject, with definite tracts of conjunctive transitional experience..."
