(183)  The example he uses is him sitting in the library at Cambridge and thinking of Harvard's Memorial Hall.   He may have a clear image of it in his mind, or just know it's name.  Then he asks you to suppose that he's got to lead you to the hall, and he fails to do so.  Then you might rightly say that whatever the image in his head, it was not that hall that was "meant."  On the other hand, if he succesfully leads you to the Hall, then the idea seems to have been "terminated", however imperfect it was to begin with.  "In this continuing and corroborating, taken in no transcendental sense, but denoting definitely felt transitions, lies all that the knowing of a percept by an idea can possibly contain or signify.  Whereever such transitions are felt, the first experience knows the last one.  Where they do not, or where even as possibiles they can not, intervene, there can be no pretence fo knowing.  In the latter case the extremes will be connected, if connected at all, by inferior relations--bare likeness or succession, or by 'withness' alone.  Knowledge of sensibile realities thus come to life inside the tissue of experience.  It is made; and made by realtions that unroll themselves in time." (185)  So somewhat as he'd said with the notion of conjunctive in the experi(ence of a self that that experiecne is just the experience of the absence of break, nothing more nothing less, here too knowing is just this kind of link between a thought and it's termination. It provides a sensation of greater and greater fulfillment as an idea leads to a sensible experience of a percept.  And this is all there is to knowing. 

* He puts it another way.  We know no "more real kind of union aliunde".  So "unions by continuous transition" are all we know.  Even if there were "more absolute unions realized" we would still only know them through the same "conjunctive results."  (186)  Why? To put it another way, if there were an Absolute, it would override experience where a knower knowing something else in experience would be gone.  Otherness would be just an illusion.  (186)  But on the other hand if the world is one "where both the terms and their distinctions are affairs of experience, conjunctions taht are experienced must be at least as real as anything else." (186)

* He sums up the process of a thougth moving to fulfulment of a percept, in which the percept simply verifies the concept on bottom 186.

* Substiuttion. What's so important about this kind of knowing for human life is that an experience (like an idea) that "knows another can figure as its represenative, not in any quasi-miraculous 'epistemological' sense, but in the definite practical sense of being its substitute in various operations, sometimes physical and sometimes mental, which leads us to its assocaites and results." (187)  We then can "experiment on our ideas of reality" without needing to experiment on the "real experiences which they severally mean." (187)   And these ideas "form related systems, corresponding point for point to the systems which the realities form; and by letting an ideal term call up its associates systematically, we may be led to a terminus whch the corresponding real term would have led to in case we had operated on the real world." (187)  This is substitution.  This is key...   What does it mean?  For James, experience is a process unfodling in time that can be conjunctive or disjunctive.  The experiences he's interested here are those that build on previous experiences and that bring one nearer a goal.  They can in a way be said to fulfill a function.  To think this way about function vv a world of pure experience is to say that the only events that occcur are transitions and arrivals/terminations, but transitions and terminations can happen by many paths.  When two experiences lead to the same termination/end by different paths they are functionally equivalent.  And now "the whole system of experiences as they are immeidately given presents itself as a quasi-chaos through which one can pass out of an initial term in many directions and yet end in the same terminus, moving from next to next by a great many posible paths." (188)  Some paths might be better than others, however, in certain cirumstances, and James says that "the paths that run through conceptual experiences, that is, through 'thoughts' or 'ideas' that 'know' the things in which tley terminate, are highly advantageous paths to follow." (188)  That's because 1) they often involve rapid transitions, and 2) they have a universal character often and a "capacity for association with one another in great systems" that means they "outstrip the tardy consecutions of the things themselves, and sweep us towards our ultimate termini in a far more labor-saving way than the following of trains of sensible perception ever could." (188)  Now he says most "thought-paths" are "substitutees for nothing actual" and simply "end outside the real world altogether , in wayward fancies, utopias, fictions or mistakes." (188)  But he says where they do "re-enter reality" we "substitute them always." (188)  And "with these substiutes pass the greater number of our hours." (188)

* Now he has an oustanding paragarph on 188-189, where he brings back the metaphor of the Dayak heads.  He calls experience a "quasi-chaos" because there is "vastly more discontinuity in the sum total of experiences that we commonly suppose."  The "objective nucleus" of each person's experience is the body, which is itself a "continuous percept".  But outside of it there is a distant physical world "at all times absent from us".  Its parts "form conceptual objects merely, into whcih the preceptual reality of which our life inserts itself at points discrete and realtively rare." (189)  Individual thinkers working around their "several objective nuclei"  of the real world, which are partly shared and partly discrete, "trace paths that intersect one another only at discontinuous perceptual points, and the rest of the time are quite incongruent; and around all the nuclei of shared 'reality,' as around the Dyak's head of my late metaphor, floats the vast cloud of expereinces that are wholly subjective [ie that are not substitutes of any actual real world experience], that are non-substitutional, that find not even an eventual ending for themselves in the perceptual world--the mere day-dreams and joys and sufferings and wishes of the individual minds." (189)

title: Lost and Found: Remembering Modernism, Rethinking Feminism
text:
Quick Summary 6/29/10

This article provdides a good survey of the lit on women, gender, and modernism.  It's overall argument as the title indicates is to suggest that future readings should move beyond the attempt to claim women as modernists true propogators and men and mysogynists or the reverse.  She calls for a more "culturally based criticism" that is at the same time historically specific and  interdisciplinary (12)  And she wants  more subtle readings that show the tensions between conventionality and modernism in both male and female modernists.  She ends with a good quote from Eysteinsson's The Concept of Modernism (1990) in which he is critizing one of the major texts trying to resituate modernism as in the field of women writers by Gilbert and Gubar No Man's Land (a multivolume work).  He writes:

"How do male modenrists support patriarchal laws, and how are they at the same time 'otherwise avant-garde'?  Are some of them perhaps torn between deep-rooted and patriarchal social habits, still guiding their individual lives, and a radical new view of human subjectivity expressed through language or whatever their artistic medium might be?  If such were the case, we might come to the conclusion that whatever their individual positions as social beings, their literary discourse works to disrupt patriarchal structures?" (15)

title: Reading Obama: Dreams, Hope, and the American Political Tradition
text:
3. Chapter 2

*  This is a complex chapter in which K traces currents of "intellectual life" in the last half of the twentieth century. At the outset, he says that Obama "captured the central dynamic" in the start of Dreams when he describes his grandparents as entertaining a "useful fiction" that they were kliving in a "bright new world where differences or race and cutlure would instruct and amuse and perhaps even ennoble." (86)  But for Obama this "useful fiction" was something that "haunted' him and his family. (86)

* The key to understanding why this "fiction" would "haunt" Obama, K says one must understand the "struggle between different worldviews that developed in America--and not only in America... " (87)  K thinks that focusing on the "towering figure" of John Rawls is a helpful way to simplify the compelxity of the late 20th century intellectual life in America.  He says that he will use "themes from Rawls's life and work to trace an arc that characterizes much of American thought in recent decades.  Unless we understand that arc, we cannot understand the amalgam of deeply held principles and frankly admitted uncertainties that characterizes Obama's approach to public life." (87)

* American social thought since mid-century K says has been "marked by a struggle between the champions of foundationalism and universalism--that 'useful fiction' animating champions of international law and interracial harmony--and challengers who deny the existence of unchanging truths." (88)  Obama's "sensibility" K says is a product of that struggle... (88)  When Obama speaks of being "haunted" by the ideals of h is parents and grandparents...it is the attraction of these universal ideals that he is feeling K says.

title: Vigorous Male and Aspiring Female: Poetry, Personality, and Culture in Edward Sapir and Ruth Benedict
text:
Summary Note

Handler here examines the interactions between Sapir and Benedict from the point of view of the new culture of "personality" and the stress on developing a certain "hardness," a term Handler takes from Pound's explanation of the relatoinship between self-expression and poetic form.  This was manifested in "an absolutely original use of language, because the individual's unique experience could not be conveyed through conventional language, encumbered as it is ith dead metaphors and cliche." (98)  Or as Croce put it Handler says as a "direct intijon of reality" (99)  Handler examines Sapir and Benedict's relaiton to this ideal, one which is troublesome for both but especially for Benedict, because "hardness" has masculine characteristics.  (Though he demonstrates that it was problematic for both, and thus in a way that gender was in general not clear in this time. See Monroe critique of Sapir, 110).    Then Handler interprets it in terms of Sapir and Benedict's differing theories of culture.  (116-119), Benedict reified culture in relation to the problem of culture.  For Sapir it was "spuriousness" which Handler empahsizes as being the "therapeutic" culture of the U.S.; whereas Benedict emphasizes the "maleability" of the individual and therefore intolerance became the problem.  Finally, Handler breaks this difference down in terms of the approach to 'social engineering', the idea being that Benedict's approach lent itself to this by stressing the maleability of the individual and Sapir's did not b/c he expected only great artists to be creative and because he thought it useless to try to become aware of one's rationality. (119-122)    Interestingly, Handler concludes saying that in contrast to Sapir who retreated from poetry into what he called "purely technical lingusitic erudition..." (quoted on 121, 121-122), Benedict "discovered her convincing sense of selfhood not simply in anthropology as scholarship but in the role of the technical expert, the scientific creator who puts her individual talents at the service of the collectivity." (122) [i.e. public intellctual.] And Handler is in fact very optimistic about their tact: "One could play such a role cautiously (Benedict) or boldly (Mead), but in either case it uaranteed a genuine self and at least the promise of a genuine culture--one in which hardness and softeness would no longer matter." (122)

I'm not sure that Handler earned that final discrimination between Sapir and Benedict.  How could Mead and Benedict have achieved a "genuine self" when the hadn't redefined, or at least he hasn't stated that they did redefine, what selfhood was?  And what was the basis of such selfhood if personality was "maleable"?  What he's missing I think is what I try to provide which is a more concrete context for the discussion of selfhood.  Selfhood can be reconceived around the general political-philosophical problem of the individual's need to react to coercion in modern institutions.  I.e. Sapir's is a reaction to that problem.  Mead and Benedict's too...but it cuts in a different way, partly because they are women who have been allowed to finally take a somewhat authoratative role within these institutions.  Their approach to them is going to be all different.  Handler provides evidence for that here but no demonstrates no analytical understanding of it.

title: The Culture of the Thirties
text: p. 153-154 Claim about Domestication of Culture "In sketching this structure, o fact is more significant than the general and even popular 'discovery' of the concept of culture. Obviously, the idea of culture was anything but new in the 1930s, but there is a special sense in which the idea became widespread in the period. what had been discovered was 'the inescapable interrelatedness of...things' so that culture could no longer be considered what Matthew Arnold and the intellectuals of previous generations had often meant--the knowledge of the highest achievements of men and of intellect and art through history--but rather reference to 'allthings that a group of people inhabiting a common geographical area do, the ways they do things and their values and symbols.' The remarkable popularity of Ruth Benedict's Patterns of Culture (1934)--surely one of the most widley read works of professional anthropology every published in the United States--provides us iwht a symoblic landmark. Its impact was significant; but more important, her anlaysis of the possibility of different cultural patterns and the way such patterns shape and account for individual behavior was part of a more genral discovery of the idea itself, the sense of awareness of what it means to be a culture, or the search to become a kind of culture. 'The quest for culture,' one studnet of the problem suggests,'is the search for meaning and value.' It is not too extreme to porpose that it was during the Thirties that the idea of culture was domesticated, with important consequences. American then began thinking in terms of patterns of beahvior and belief, values and life-styles, symbols and meanings. It was during this period that we find, for the first time, frequent reference to an 'American Way of Life." (153-154).

title: Mysteries of Sex: Tracing Women & Men through American History
text:
p.220-2   New 1920s Emphasis on Heterosexuality / Sex is Healthy

New focus not just on personal but on "intimacy" e.g. in Heterodoxy and in Henry Roth's Call It Sleep... (220)

Men spent less time in homosocial atmosphere of 1890s: polling places, party caucuses, lodges, saloons.  They spent more time going to movies, dating, watching spectator sports.  Or at home, listening to the radio or on the front porch.  Textbooks on "Marriage and the Family" informed highschool and college students that they needed to develop "healthy heterosexuality" and a "satisfying emotional life." (quoted on 221)  Women who were working in reform were accused of being "castrated men" and also that a "life without sexual love was not entirely without joy." (quoted on 221).

Ryan notes this wsa a new course not just from home to work or prviate to public but "in an obliquely lateral direction, form the social to the intimate and the personal." (221)

Like Stansell, Ryan discusses the inequality within the new "intimacy", bringing up the relationship between Hutchins Hapgood and Neil Boyce...she doesn't add much but an idea gloeaned from someone else that women had trouble establishing "sexual sovereignty."  She talks about a relationship related by Anzi Yezierska that indicatd this kind of submission inthe context of heightened expectations about "intimacy" and these acconts were apparently about her relatoinship with John Dewey.  Then Ryan has a more negative and honest quote speaking ofa  "sense of drowing" at his touch that is from Yezierska's 1950s autobiography.  (222)

All this led menand women to get married earlier!  So a steady drop in marriage age between 1980 and 1950, from a peak of 22 to a nadir of 20.3 for women and 3-4 years older fro men.  (222)

title: Eccentric Flows and Cosmopolitan Culture
text:
Summary Notes Feb 2012:

William Connolly, “Eccentric Flows and Cosmpolitan Culture” in Neuropolitics: Thinking, Culture and Speed (Minneapolis & London: Univerisity of Minnesotta Press, 2002), 176-202.

    Connolly wants to argue against the “concentric model of political culture” (184), which he finds variably in Kant, Samuel Huntington and Martha Nussbaum.  The idea is that identity flows outward concentrically from the individual to the family to the neighborhood to the community to the nation and then to Western civilization and so on.  That idea precludes the possibility of what Connolly calls “eccentric connections” that cut across concentric forms of affiliation and solidarity and indeed against the “connotation of isolation, perversity, and marginalization” that is involved in the concentric model of political culturre and identity.  To focus on eccentric connections is to “identify eccentric flows of flight, compassion, connection, allegiance, identification, legitimacy, responsiveness and responsibility that exceed the concentric image of how political culture does and must function.” (185) 
Recognizing such connections is also to take advantage, Connolly thinks, of the kinds of opportunities that social acceleration (he is drawin on the work of Paul Virilio who only sees the negative sides, and not drawing on Hartmut Rosa’s work) provides, for such eccentric connections become more likely in our tightly integrated and accelerated world of communication and transportation.  Connolly’s sense is that we must with some urgency recognize the way our accelerated world makes possible eccentric flows and connections in order to have a chance to salvage a cosmopolitan possibility.  He writes at the end of the article: “...the jig is up.  As the hope to secure a single regulative idea [ie Kant’s idea that extends through to Nussbaum] is shaken by a world spinning faster and faster than heretofore, a small window of opportunity opens to negotiate a plural matrix of cosmpolitanisms.” (199)
The philosophical core of the article comes in a section “Toward a New Matrix of Cosmpolitanism,” where he attempts to critique Kant’s understanding of universal morality as a single “regulative idea.”  He has articluated Kant’s take on this earlier in the article, pp. 180-182, as relying primarily on a highly suspect “apodictic recognition”, ie it is true because it must be true according to Kant.  In this section, he tries to say that Kant’s regulative idea, if modified, might still be helpful.  What has to be jettisoned is the idea that there’s only one regulative idea.  From his point of view, in addition to the highly suspect reliance of this notion apodictive form of proof, this is also just no longer a sustainable position, given that Europeans are now so aware of the existence of multiple regulative ideas.  Awareness of genealogy, deconstruction and political disturbance (ie those things that poststructuralist and postmodern critiques hav eprovide) can be deployed to call into question the idea that certain moral sources are incontestable, but positive work he thinks may require some sort of “regulative idea”.  He thinks we can recognize the existence of a plurality of regulative ideas in the world, and also recognize the way we need these ideas, but without putting one up over another.  (195)  Eccentric connections can thus give us a chance to locate “creative lines of connection to other orientations.” (196)

title: Mass Culture as Woman: Modernism's Other
text:
Notes 6/26/10

* H starts by pointing out that Flaubert--a father of modernist aesthetics--read romance novels and yet the Madame Bovary ends up dieing while he becomes a hero of a new aesthetics "based on the uncompromising repudiation of what Emma Bovary loved to read." (45)  IN fact, Flaubert famously said: "Madame Bovary, c'est moi."

* So H sees the presentation of woman as the "avid consumer of pulp" as paradigmatic to modernism (46).  The same idea is also central, he notes, to woman writers with ambitions like those of the "great (male) modernist".  He says Christa Wolf (who he has been citign) cites the work of Ingeborg Bachmann and quotes Wolf: "...Bachmann is that nameless woman in Malina, she is the woman Franza in the novel fragment The Franza CAse who simply cannot get a grip on her life, cannot give it a form; who simply cannot manage to make her experience into a presnetable story, cannot produce it out of herslef as an artistic product." (46) -- i.e. like M. Bovary.

* H now notes that the problem of "saying I" for a woman, which Wolf he says has also highlighted in her own novels, is also a problem of any "post-romantic [i.e. modenrist]":  "Having first created the determining conditions for a certain historically specific type of subjectivity (the Cartesian cogito and the epistemological subject in Kant, as well as the bourgeois entrepreneur and the modern scientist), modernity itself has increasingly hollowed out such subjectivity and rendered its articulation highly problematic.  Most artists, male or female, know that." (46)

* But H wants to say: there is a difference in terms of how the problem presents itself to the woman writer and the man.  I.e. Flaubert's statement Madame Bovary, c'est moi is different than the "impassibilite'" of the novel's style H says.  "Given the fundamentally differing social and psychological constitution and validation of male and female subjectivity in modern bourgeois soceity, the difficulty of saying 'I' must of necessity be different for a woman writer, who may not find 'impassibilite'' and the concomitatng reification of self in the aesthetic product quite as attractive and compelling an ideal as the male writer.  The male, after all, can easily deny his own subjectivity for the benefit of a higher aesthetic goal, as long as he can take it for granted on an experiential level in everyday life." (46)  So he quotes Wolf agian that modernist aesthetics is not tyring to help people get closer but rather farther away from "reality"...So H says that this seems right, that what is being warded off in work from Flaubert to Roland Barthes, is the ""realities of modern life and the ominous expansion of mass culture thoughout the social realm" which of course is usually presented in the image of a woman.

* H concludes the first section of his essay then by saying that this link (insofar for example as it is evident in Flaubert) between moernist aesthetics and a flight from mass culture is central to the modernism.  "Mass cutlure has always beeen the hidden subtext of the modernist project." (47)

* INterestingly, H notes that the equation of mass culture with the feminine has been abandoned by more recent critics, e.g. Adorno and Horkheimer, in favor of "streamlining, technological reproduction, adminsitration and SAchlichkeit" which would be assigned to the male realm, but he notes that the feminine identification still makes its appearance, e.g. in Kracauer's Tiller Girls in his important esssay on "mass ornament." (48)

* H critiques a thread of french literary criticism (associated with Kristeva e.g.) that has attempted to "claim the space of modernist and avant-garde writing as predominantly feminine..." (49)  This he thinks is "highly questionable" because it ignores the "powerful masculinist and misogynist current within the trajectory of modernism, a current which time and again openly states its contempt for women and for the masses and which had Nietzsche as its most eloquent and influential representative." (49)

* Now he gives some quick examples of how mass culture was gendered feminine (p.50-51).  Then he states ..."the gendering of an inferior mass cutlure as feminine goes hand in hand with the emergence of a male mystique in modernism (especially in painting), which as been documented thoroughly by feminist scholarship.  He points to essays by CArol Duncan and Norma Broude in FEminism and Art History.  Also Valerie Jaudon and Joyce Kozloff, "ARt Hysterial Notions' of Progress and Cutlure," Heresies , 1, no.4 (Winter 1978): 38-42.

* Then oin the 2nd half of the 19th century he says what happens is a "certain chain effect of signification: from the obsessively argued inferiority of woman as artist (clasically argued by Karl Scheffler in Die Frau und die Kunst, 1908) to the assocation of womanwith mass culture (witness Hawthorne's 'the damned mob of scribbling women') to the identification of woman iwth the masses as a poltiical threat." (50)

* Nietzche is key here becuase he ascribes feminine characteristics to the mob and this is always tied to "his aeshetic vision of the artist-philosoher-hero, the suffering loner who stands in irreconcialble opposition to modern democracy and its inauthentic culture." (51)  This comes out in particular in his polemic against Wanger apparently, who was corrupted by "adoring women." Then he transforms music into "mere spectacle, theater, delusion..." (51)  So N says that WAgner signifies the "emergence of the actor in music..." (quoted on 51).  So Wagner signifies the same thing as Victor Hugo in "declining cultures, wherever the decision comes to rest with masses, authetncitiy bcomes superfluous, disadvantageous, a liability. Only the actors still arouses great enthusiasm." (quoted on 51)  So then H writes that "WAgner, the theater, the mass, woman--all become a web of signification outside of, and in opposition to, true art: 'No one brings along the finest sense of his art to the theater; whatever is perfect suffers no witnesses.  In the theater one becomes people, herd, female, pharisee, voting cattle, patron, idiot--Wagnerian.'" (51)

* So whta is being chastised her is the "spectacle" or what Baudrillard calls the simulacrum.  It's no accident H notes that the theater is what is being criticized since this was one of the few spaces that bourgeois society allowed women to enter in public, "preicsley because acting was seen as imitative and reproductive, rather than original and productive." (51)

* When H quotes N again here now it is the inifinte and the sea (cf Theweleit) that one encoutners: in WAgner's "infinite melody" one "walks into the sea, gradually loses one's secure footing, and finally surrenders onself to the elements without reservation." (N quoted on 51).

* This is all political H points out.  He notes that int he late 19th century "a specific traditional male image of woman served as a receptacle for all kinds of projections, displaced fears, and anxieties (both personal and political), which were brought about by modernization and the new social conflicts, as well as by the specific historical events such as the 1848 revolution,t he 1870 Commune, and the rise of reactionary mass movements which, as in Austria, threatened the liberal order." (52)  So now he cites Theweleit's stuffa bout the mob being represented as an engulfing feminine flood: "Images of the raging mov as hysterical, of the engulfing floods of revolut and revolution, of the swamp of big city life, of the pspreading ooze of massification, of the figure of the red whore at the barricades--all of these pervade the wriign of the mainstream media, as well as that of right-wing ideolgoues of the late 19th can dearly 20th centuries whose social pscyholgy Klaus Theweleit has perceptively anlyzed in his study of Male Phantasies.  The fear of the masses in this age of declining liberalism is always also a fear of woman, a fear of nature out of control, a fear of unconscious, of sexuality, of the loss of identity and stable ego boundaries in the mass." (52)   This is exemplified in Gustave Le Bon's The Crowd in which "the male fear of woman and the bourgeois fear of the masses become indistinguishable." (52) All this justifies the male fear of losing the self's "stable ego boundaries" and the revolt against devalued cutlural forms which have been gendered as feminine. (52-53)

* This makes modernism look more like  'reaction formation" (53) rather than something heroic.  The fact that modernsim would considering this insight seem less heroic is, H says, appropriate: "...the powerful masculinist mystique which is explicit in modernists such as Marineetti, Junger, Benn, Wyndham Lewis, Celine, et al. (not to speak of Marx, Nietzsche and Freud), and implicit in many others, has to be somehow related to the persitent gendering of mass cutlure as feminine and inferior--even if, as a result, the heroism of the modern won't look quite as heroic any more." (55)  And now H insists that the "modernists insistence on purity and authonomy in art, Freud's privileging of the ego over the id and his insistence on stable, if flexible, ego boundaries, andMarx's privileging of production over consumption" are all homologically related in opposition to the fear of losing one's self in a feminine mass culture... (55)

* But what then is the relationship of modernism to modernity that gave rise to it...Here he hits on the point that to "our postmodern age" modernism appears to have been "deeply implicated in the processes andp ressure ofthe same mundane modernization it so ostensibly repudiates." (56)  He uses Adorno and Greenberg--who are defenders of modernism--to show that they both always understood modernism to be a "reaction formation" and therefore a product of captialism as much as mass culture.  Indeed, he has a quote from Adorno to Walter Benjamin: "Both [modernist art and mass culture] bears the scars of captialism, both contain elements of change.  Both are torn halves of freedom to which, howeer, they do not add up." (58)  But H adds to this: "But the discussion cannot end here.  The postmodern crisis of high modernism and its classical accounts has to be seen as a crisis both of captialist modernization itself and of the deeply patriarchal structures that support it." (58)

title: The Anthropologist as Hero
text:
Notes 7/29/10:

Reading this essay again to see if it might be useful for the Conclusion of the dissertation.

Sontag's essay starts by stating that "serious" modern literature deals with the theme of "homelessness."

The felt unreliability of human experience brought about by the inhuman acceleration of historical change has led every sensitive modern mind to the recording of some kind of nausea, of intellectual virtigo.(69)

Then solution

...seems to be, at least initially, to exacerbate it.  Modern thought is pleged to a kind of applied Hegeleanism: seeking its Self in its Other.  Europe seeks itself in the exotic--in Asia, in the Middle East, among pre-literate peoples, in a mythic America; a fatigued rationality seeks itself in the impersonal energies of sexual exctasy or drugs; consicousness seeks it meaning in unconsicouness; humanistic problems seek their oblivion in scientific 'value neutrality' and quantification.  Th 'other' is expereinced as a harsh purification of the 'self.  But at the same time the 'self' is busy colonizing all strange domains of experience.  Modern sensibility moves between two seeminly contradictory but actually related impulses: surrender to the exotic, the strange, the other; and the domestication of the exotic, chiefly through science. (69-70)

Ok...so where does anthropology fit in.  Philosphers have contributed to ur understanding of this modern problem, but it is poets, novelist, and some painters that have lived it.  Then she turns to Levi-Strauss, whom she says "invented anthropollgy as a total occupation, invoving a spiritual commitment like that of the creative artist or the adventurer or pscyhoanalyst." (70)

She notes that he is a scholar and not a "man of letters."  But she says that his Tristes Tropique is a work of genius with a "human voice." But what is he saying here that she finds most interesting?

She notes that Simone de Beauvoir recalled Levi-STrauss as a "young philosophy student-teacher expounding 'in his detached voice, and with a deadpan expression...the folly of passsions." (72)  Sontag builds on this noting that L-S prefaced his book with a motto by Lucretius: De rerum natura.  She says; L-S's "aim is very much like Lucretius, the Graecophile Roman who urged the study of the natural sciences as a mode of ethical psychotherapy.  The aim of Lucretius was not independent scientific knowledge, but the reduction of emotional anxiety." (72)  She describes that Lucreitus saw man as divided by sexual pleasure, emotional loss, superstituion, and fear.  Science was  for him a way to regain "pscyhological gracefullness." (73)

She says that L-S sees humans with "Lucretian pessimism," but the problem is history, which has laid ruin to everything.  The tropics are tristes, she notes.  What L-S proposes then is not the kind of seeking of dramatic oblivion, but the same technique as a kind of practice, what L-S calls "anthropological doubt," which he installs as a technique in his Structural Anthropology.  She quotes him: "This 'anthropological doubt' consists not merely in knowning that one knows nothing but in resolutely exposing what one knows, even one's own ignorance, to the insults and denials inflicted on one's dearest ideas and habits by those ideas and habits which may contradict them to the highest degree." (quoted on 73)

So then Sontag observes that anthropology provides a unique solution to the problem of modern alienation: "Anthropology conquers the estranging function of the intellect by institutionalizing it.  The anthropologists is not simply a neutral observer.  He is a man of control of, and even consciously exploiting, his own intellectual alientation." (74)  (L-S she says call his profession a "technique de depayesment"  (this word I think can mean exile, change of environment, habits, etc..)

It's interesting here that Sontag reads this as a form of mastery--as if L-S is reacting to the problem of homelessness in a truly masculine way.  She even says: Anthropology "is one of the rare intellectual vocations which do not demand a sacrifice of one's manhood.  Courage, love of adventure, and physical hardiness--as well as brains--are all called upon." (74)

Sontag says that the anths world is divided between "'home' and 'out there,' the domestic and the exotic, the urban academic world and the tropics.  ... So she says he becomes the "very model of the 20th century consciouness: a 'critic at home' and a 'conformist elsehwere.'" (74)  As a resutl, also, the anthropologist cannot act as a citizen, and apparently L-S acknowledges this...stating that he can "only be a critical dissenting voice." (74)

Funnily, she think American anthropologists were mere "data-collectors."  How wrong!  (75)

Interstingly, also, she has Levi-Strauss saying that the purpose of the fieldwork is actually to produce they "pscyholgoical revolution" which is the decisive poitn in the training of the anthropologist. (75)

She keeps reading L-S against the A. Anthropologists, but she gets them wrong I think.  Maybe that's the way anthropology was in the 50s' 60's?  Dont' think so though...it's all about neturality she thinks, but that doesn't make sense to me.  She does not however that L-S conceived of his method after reading Lowie...

Then she says something strangely put but probably true, that his ideas are closer to "the more avante-garde methodologies of economics, neurology, linguistics, and game theory."  (75-76) Avante-garde, in what sense?  L-S she says sees linguistics as a kind of "natural science" that will finally allow social scientists to transalt etheir science into a pure science...so she writes: "...the man who submits himself to the exotic to confirm his own inner alienation as an urban intellectual ends by aiming to vanquish his subject by translating it into a purely formal code....The anthropologists, as a man, is engaged in saving his own soul. But he is also committed to recording and understanding his subject by a very high-powered mode of formal analysis--which obliterates all traces of of his personal experience and truly effaces the human features of his subject, a given primitive society." (77) L-s calls this "anecodotique geometrique."  Structure is the "broom" she says that performing a great cleansing operation.  He's applying a ridid formalism to the analysis of non-western peoples.

She notes that L-S distinguishes his structuralism from the naturalistic British fucntionalism which in Sontag's words "interprets the variety of custom as different strategies for producing universal social ends." (78)  For L-S, she says anthropology can be neither descriptive nor inductive..."occupies itsself only with the formal features that differentiate one society from another." (78)

Re kinship, e.g., the fucntionalists see kinship as rooted in biological relations [true?], but L-S, along with Boas and Lowie, see kinship as an artificial construction.

She ends by comparing L-S with Saartre, with whom she has compared L-S as one of the most powerful and influential thinkers in France.  She ntoes that she is not totally convinced by L-S critique of Saartre in Le pensee sauvage, last chapter.  But they are different.  Saartre is moved by Jean Genet above all, but Genet is all artifice and "masturbatory revel."  She links L-S to a different french tradition: "the cult of aloofness, l'esprit geometrique."  She says this tradition can be found innovelists like Nathalie Sarraute, Alain Robbe-Grillet, and Micahel Butor who seeks "infinence precision" and have "narrow dehydrated matter and cool microscopic styles".  She also mentions filmmakers like Alain Renais.  She says this tradition mixes "pathos and coldness." (79)

But she say a good critique of L-S must look at his formalism as a moral choice.  Now she is good here, so I will quote t length:

...his extreme formalism is a moral choice, and (more suprisingly) a vision of social perfection.  Radically anti-historicist, he refuses to differentiate between 'primitive' and 'historical' societies.  Primitives have a history; but it is unknown to us.  And historical consciousness (which they do not have), he argues in the attack on Saartre, is not a privileged mode of consciosness.  There are only what he calls 'hot' and 'cold' societies.  The hot societies are the modern ones, driven by the demons of historical progress.  The cold socieites are the primitive ones, static, crystalline, harmonious.  Utopia, for Levi-Strauss, would be a great lowering of the historical temperature.  In his auguarl lecture at the College de France, Levi-STrauss outlined a post-Marxist vision of freedom in whcih man would finally be freed from the obligation to progress, and from 'the age-old curse which force it to enslave men in order to make progress possible.'  Then:...

Now she quotes L-S:

...[then] history would henceforth be quite alone, and society, placed outside and above history, would once again be able to assume that regular and quasi-crystalline structure whcih, the best-preserved primitive societies teach us, is not contradcitory to humanity.  It is in this admittedly Utopian view that social anthropology would find its highest justification, since the forms of life and thought which it studies would no longer be of mere historic and comparative interest.  They would correspond to a permanent possibilty for man, over whcih socail anthropology would have a mission to stand watch, especially in man's darkest hours.

Wow!

She ends this essay, saying that "the anthropologist" is enacting a "modern pessmism"...

NOtes:

One obvious and significant thing is that structural anthropology is nto all anthropology, and the Boasians, e.g., were not merely data mongers. Their was something more there...

But is this something that I could use in my Conclusion?  My original idea was that I could do the old invoke and the differentiate from, but that was in my memory of it and focused on that idea of the modern self seeking its "oblviion" in the other.  That's not quite what's going on here is it?

L-S and structural anthropology as she sees it is after a kind of permanence and stability...a kind of spatial-structural crystalline strength (presumably built around the right ideas) that would serve as  a defense against the destructive and horrrible effects of history (WWI and II, is obviously in the background here though she doesn't mention it...)

Perhaps that's what Sapir was after too...he's after-all the closest thing to a structuralist, with his focus on languag, but his sense of language was still humanistic (language followed grooves in the mind, not structures... as he says in his book on Language).

The thing to ask, given my thesis, is where's the individual in this?  It's gone...but was it ever that important for L-S given that, as Sontag also notes L-S thinking, he is an anti-Durkheimian but also in that line of thought... So... I could use this article as a way to work backward through all these flawed ideas about what Am. Anth was to what I think it is...

title: The American Woman's Pre-World War I Freedom in Manners and Morals
text:
p. 318 -   Desc. of Moral Change & Individualization

The sociological origin of the notion of moral change that McGovern deploys here ought not to be ignored, and also dates to the period he is studying, a fact that McGovern does not really take into account. 

His description is on 318-319.  It has to do with a "deterioration of external controls over morality" which he says occurs before 1920.  That deterioration was the result of, he says, the "dissolution of moral authority,which formerly had centered in the family and the small community." (318-9)  I.e. it had to do with urbanization and the inapplicability of "family values" and instiutions to urban life.  "As against primary controls and contacts based on face-to-face association where the norms of family, church, and small community, usually reinforcing each other, could be internalized, the city made for a type of 'individualization' through its distant, casual, specialized, and transient clusters of secondary associations.".  You can see th eorigins of this sociological argument in his f.n. at the end of the previous sentence.  He cites Soctt Nearing and nellie M.S. Nearing, "Woman and Social Progress" (New York, 1912) and of course W.I. Thomas's The Unadjusted Girl: With Cases and Standpoint for Behavior Analysis (Boston, 1923).  and Ernest R. Mowrer, Family Disorganization (Chicago, 1927).

McGovern also refers to this as "individualization".  (319)  I feel it is a bit reactionary.  McGovern, for instance, has a quote on 320 which seems extereme (and which would lead naturally to Lash's Haven in a Heartless World): "Individualizaiton of members served to disrupt confidence between generations of the family, if not to threaten parents with the role of anachronistic irrelevance." (320)

title: The Categories
text:
Notes

Part I -- he defines his categories.

* What's a category?  He says it's an "element of phenomena of the first rank of generality."  He thinks this def'n holds for Aristotle, Kant, and Hegel.  (179)  Then categories are borken down into two types: 1) Universal, which belong to all phenomena, although maybe to a greater or lesser extent in each case; 2) particular, which "form a series, or a set of series, only on of each series being present, or at least predominatn in any one phenomenon." (179)

His categoreis:

1) Presentness or just pure quality.  He says Hegel was almost right witih his word Immediacy, but he was wrong in imaginging it to be ssomething abstract and that the concerete blinded one to the abstract.  For Peirce presentness as an abstract "cannot be abstracted." (180)  He says just go outside "under the bloue doem of heaven aand look at what is present as it appears ot the artists' eye." (180)  The "abstracted is what the concerete, which gives it what ever being ith as, makes it to be." (180)  The present he says can be understood by imagining a "consciousness in which there is no comparison, no relation, no recognized multiplicity...no change, no imagination of any modification of what is postiively there,  no reflexion--nothign but a simple postiive character." (180)

[What is pragmatic here?  Perhaps this critique of Hegel's understanding of abstraction...the abstractness of presence is simply the pure unmodified consciousness of the thing in itself...as it is.  This is also anti-Kantian, becaues he's thinking that we actually do perceive these things.]

2) Struggle ie relation/interaction.  Here's where presenetneess is made more complex through interaction. He gives the example of a ladder hitting you  on the head. You've resisted the ladder even if you think you've not.  He defends this category as a universal category for most of the section.  A key momvent, however, key to pragmatism, is on 186 re expereince.  Here the notion of resistance/relation/interaction is related to the role of experience in correcting our false ideas:

"But without being longer roudn the bush, let us come to close quarters.  Experience is our only teacher.  Far be it fromme to uenunciate any doctrine of tabula rasa.  For, as I said a few minutes ago, there manifestly is not one drop of principle in the whole vast reservoir of established scientific theory that has sprung from any other source thn the power of the mind to originate ideas that are true.  But this power, for all it has accomplished, is so feeble that as ideas flrow from their springs in the soul, the truths are almost drwoned in a flood of false notions; and that which experience does is gradually, and by a sort of fractionation, to precipitate and filter off the false ideas, eliminating them and letting the turth pour on its mighty current." ((186) 

* Then also on 187, the lessons of experience, give rise to the ego as he explains there.  CF the description of self-consciousness in "Questions Concerning Certain Faculties... "

3) The lats one is harder...here he's arguign for the existence of non-mechanical causation in things...a kind of existince of general principles??

Part II

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text:
p.187-188  Desire for STable Temperament 

In quote from "Summary Statement" Mead writes "There is no sex inheritance, there are only family lines, bequeathing ot their lineal descendants regardless of sex, one of two temperaments, a certain physical type and an adaptive body chemistry.  There are cultures which have stabilized temperament so completely all cultural forms proclaim it..." (187)  

Here in those lines you can see this ideal of a "stabilized temperament."   Later Sulivan notes that elsewhere Mead had noted they had speculated on the "circumstances by which multiple strains of inheritance could become sufficeintly characteristic of a populaiton so that that population could obtain a more or less recognizable coherence or stability." (188)  And she had noted Europen attempts to "maintain such 'culturally achieved balances' under the rubric of race and other similar attempts under the categories of caste, the important conclusion of this reasoning wa s that a given temperamental type could become a general characteristic of a populaiton and thereby influence the ethos or emotional tenor of its society..." (188) 

This last is in an untitlted document that Sullivan is sure was written by Mead though it is not in her normal handwriting,  it is in Library of Congress S11:8.

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.016-26 Polticial Economy, Human Nature and Class Consicous politics

At the base of political economy was a new science of human nature.  A notion of universal human nature, rooted originally in Christian conceptions of the "solitary soul." (16)  These Christian conceptions provided a "point of departure" for the Enlightenment psychology of "Reason." (16)  An view of the individual as "abstracted" from social relations.  Yet Sklansky thinks that this social science took  heed of "nurture," rather they undestood the human faculties of learning and self-improvement as the basis for a project of "social engineering." (16)

Good explanation of the basis of the view of human nature (16-18).  Key part of Sklansky's argument is his explanation of how this view was rooted in a sense of class conflict.  As he builds up his view of human nature, it ultimately leads from Reason through to conscience and then to "interest" or self-interest, and then to enlightened self-interest which is not the same as selfishness. (17-18).  This is all related to the idea that labor, not leisure, was the basic human condition (18, bottom).  And thus he finally points out that this view of political economy was one that was rooted in the view that labor underlay all economic value.  "...the classical economists defined 'value' as an absolute magnitude or measure of the cost of producing goods, meaning on the most basic level the required expenditure of soical effort." (19)  This was the "natural price."

Because they rooted value in natural price they became concerned with surplus value and "[t]hey located the source of that critical surplus not in trade butin the social relations that emerged in the production of wealth, or class relations." (19) So he sees Smith for instance as being interested in the relatoinship between one's work and one' sposition in society.  And he sees Smith's distinction of productive and unproductive classes as the basis for a revolutoinary critique of the aristocracy.  This in other words is the kind of critique that was eclipsed by later notions of the social self, which no longer concerned themselves with the root of autonomy in labor and productivity in the sense of a notion of value as being rooted in work...This mean in other words that they under stood trade as the exchange of labor, see 19, middle paragraph.

The end point of this though is that political economy encourages what he later calls the "newly class-conscious politics of the Revolutionary Era."  (28)  Because property ownership was the basis of political representation, the "ideal of popular sovereignty therefore entailed a vsision of representative goernment as an arean of cometing class interests."   Thus the early debates over popular sovereignty "focused upon how to represent and reconcile different forms of property within a single state, as Charles A. Beard argued nearly a century ago." (25)

So critics of the Constitution (antifederalists?) saw those lower orders not represented as facing ruin and James Madison meanwhil estated that "Those who hold, and those who are without property, have every fromed distinct interest in society." (quoted o 25, from Federalist No.10) Thus the basic task of the government was to regulate these opposing class-based interests accordingto Madison (25-26).

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.45 Confucian-Islamic connection main obstacle to Eastern cleaving to West.

The latin American and Eastern European countries can most easily redefine themselves in this western mode (45)

But those that can't ally themselves with eachother, develop miltiary and economoic power, and promove internal development: "The most prominent form of this cooperation is the Confucian-Islamic connection that has emerged to challenge Western interests, values and power." (45)

There is he says an arms race in East-Asia w/ China at the head.  He then speaks of a "Confucian-Islam military connection..." (47)  But he suggests this is unbalanced b/c the West he argues is disarming, non-proliferation, he sees as one of its characteristic civlization goals (45-46) and this marks the arms race in this stage, where one side is arming and the other disarming while trying "not to balance but to limit and prevent that arms build-up while at the same time reducing its own military capabilities." (48)

title: The Scientific Reaction Against Cultural Anthropology, 1917-1920
text:
[Stocking's take on Boas Censure]
Stocking's take on the Censure of Boas at the Decemeber 1919 AA meeting in Cambridge is that it had to do mainly with conflicts between the Maya-Washington crowd and the Boasian cultural anthropologists.  He also describes it on p.273 as being about the relatoinship between anthropology and other disciploines but I don't htink this is really born out in his analysis (read again for this).
He gives a whole history of the conflict between these two groups that is immensely useful and which I will need to re-read for the Professionalism chapter (276-296), but also he points out in terms of the those who voted for and those who voted agianst (275-6)
The problem with his analysis I think is that he doesn't get what Boas is saying  in the letter, i.e. that his opposititon to scientists acting as spies has to do with the fact that scientists ought to be critiquing the function of the state, not serving it.  When Stocking analyzes the letter on 273-5, he doesn't quite get this.

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.032 COMMENT: Evidence of his teological approach to history.

In the midst of discussing aftermath of the first Iraq War, Huntington explains why he thinks democracy is emerging in the middle east: "Many Arab countries, in addition to the oil exporters, are reaching levels of economic and social development where autocratic forms of government become inappropriate and efforts to introduce democracy become stronger.  Some openings in Arab political systems have already occured." (32)  That teleology is interesting--why should wealth not be suited to aristocracy??  He must explain this.  Though Huntington smartly points out that the beneficiaries of this trend have been "islamist movements." (32)

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text: p.017- Shift to University...and Localism As anthropologists came into the university they came into closer contact with other social scientists of various sorts. Anthropologists worked in universities with sociologist, psychologists, geographers, etc... Thus "The specific content of ideas and the infleucnes of other branches of knowledge on anthropology as a discipline varied from university to university. This discipline of anthropology was the aggregate of a collection of local configurations of knowledge specific to the anthropologists who worked in various university departments." (17) See also Charles Camic article on localism in Social Sciences Prio to 1930, also, Madden argues that "anthropologists worked on a very small scale in American universities. Most departments only had one or two full-time faculty members, and at many, if not most, universities, anthropologists did not have separate departments. " (18) This led to further problems "preparing new experts in the four fields that comprised the anthropological body of knowledge." (18) Madden insists that in many cases where anthropology was in the same dept. as sociology it was subordinate and the "agenda of sociologists threatened to fragment th discipline of anthropology." (18) Madden describes an "implicit divisoin of labor": "Anthropologists at Harvard trained physical anthropologists and archaeologists. Those at Columbia trained the cultural anthropologists. Neither department coudl boast of a strong tradition in all four fields.". (18) Nonetheless power rested in the hands of the "Boasians": "During the 1920s, boas's students from Columbia occupied most of the key positions in anthropology, including editorship of the American Anthropologist and the chairs of most graduate programs in anthropology, and the common educational background of these students provided what little organization what little organization the disicpline had." (18)

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text:
p. 275-6 Traditional structural-funcitonal Desc. of Professions Left out Women	

So standard definitions of professsions by strcutural-fucntional approach "excludes fields dominated by women because they seem to lack the qualities of autonomy and expertise central to professional power." (275)  Such descriptions evident e.g. in Robert MacIver, "The Social Significance of Professional Ethics," The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science (May 1922): 5-11; Talcott Parsons, "The Professions and Social Structure" Social Forces 17 (May 1939): 457-467; Ernest Greenwood, "Attributes and Social STructure" Social Work 2, 3 (July 1957): 44-55.

title: Anthropology and Antihumanism in Imperial Germany
text: p.048 [Adolf Bastian, subjectivity in G. Historicism] Adolf Bastian criticized German history saying it had usurped its position as the "queen of sciences" because it had become too sujective: He wrote in Ethnologie und Deschiche in ihren Beruhrungspunkten unter Bezugnahme auf Indien, vol. 2, Ideale Weltin in Wort und Bild (Berlin: Emil Felber, 1892), 21... "Since history must constnatly orbit in narrow...circles around the center of its own national consicouness [Volksbewusstseins]--in that it thereby raises itself to a queen of the sciences because it comprehends naitonal life in its realizations--it can never escape subjectivity, niether in its subject matter nor in relation to the historian himself." (quoted on 48). As Zimmerman sums it up: "History was entrapped in subjectivity, both because it dealt with the national self and because it had necessarily to describe the subjective experiences of the period that it portrayed." Bastian of course thought that Ethnology avoided that fault, so it was not just a supplement to culturla history it was a superior alternative. Bastian wrot also in Ethnologie, v.2 but p.27: "Ethnology maintains a standpoint of pure objective observation, sharply distinguished from history, which cannot rid itself of a subjective coloraiton because even when kept freem from calculating or doctrinaire positions, it is nevertheless based on 'reserach into motives.'"

title: The Victorian Barmaid as Cultural Prototype
text:
*  Bailey says that there's a lot about sexuality, but that most studies have focused on certain areas: "the submerged histories of 'deviant' groups; the ideology of written texts; controversies over regulation; andindividual cases of that remarkable phenomeon, closet heterosexuality." (151)  What's missing he says is a look at the "'middle' ground of sexualitym, not as another exclusive territory, but as an extensive ensemble of sites, practices, and occasions that mediate across the frontiers fo the putative public/private divide." (151)

*  He posits a new category: parasexuality.  It is para in denoting something almost or beside or secondary as in paramedic he says but also in denoting the idea of protection as in parachute: "Parasexuality then is sexuality that is deployed but contained, carefully channelled rather than fully discharged..." (151)

* Sow hat is a parasexuality a modification of?  He indicates that it is the model built up around the "language of discharge" and the phallocentric model of sexuality sometimes referre to as the "hydraulic model...in which sex is a limited but powerful energy system, a permatic economy whose force must always be either fully released orsuppressed, its prime expression being the male orgasm." (152)  This model also entailed the objectification of women and has been examined in relation to the "pathologies of scopophilia and fetishism..." (152)

* So he further defines parasexuality at this point: "Parasexuality identifies a significant historical initiative as a managed version of the fraught imperatives of release or suppression in orthodox bourgeois sexuality." (152)  He notes that the idea of "management" is appropriate int he context of "the increasingly rationalised operations of an emergent leisure industry in the nineteenth century..." (152)  So the key distinction here from previous relationship to bourgeois sexuality ist hat parasexuality in pubcs, music halls and popular theatres is that "sexuality was a natural resource rather than a natural enemy.  Thus while parasexuality was certainly a form of control, it started from a point of acknowledgement and accomodation rather than denial and punishment..." (152)  A bit later he refers to parasexuality as a kind of "normalisation of sexuality." (152)  But it wa also an "exercise in framed liminality orcontained license that constituted a reworking rather than a dismantling of hegemony." (152)

*  Parasexualty was controversial and earned crtics.  These issues were debated by industry managers and its critics, but also explored in the every-day exchanges of participants. (152-153)

* The Barmaid: she is for the "unreconstructed male" an "instant cue for the knowing smile," while for the feminist she is the "classic token woman." (153) The essay whill show that she has  a history one of whose important themes "is her glamorous embodiment of a distinct form of modernity -- parasexuality." (153)

The essay then proceeds in three sections he says: 1) barmaid in relation to the "modernisation of the Victorian pub." 2) The concept of glamour in relation to graphic "texts" of barmaid and "what they suggest of male subjectivities in relationship to the barmaid." 3) Consideration of thiese matters in relation to the "material context" of the barmaid.  4) Last sections ituations barmaids in relationship to othe female service workers and speculates upon the "implications for sexuali politics in the critical years of the late Victorian period." (153)

I.

* Barmaid was the produt of a transformation of the "urban public house" when the tavern around the 1830s was rpalced by the "gin palace with its dramatic innovations of scale, plan, management and style." (153)  Whereas many old pubs were "little morthan parlours or kitchens of private houses," the new pub was bigger and catered to a more anonymous urban crowd.  Importantly, sales were made "across a bar counter which separated customers from the drink supply and made for a more efficient and secure operation." (154)  The capacity was increased by getting rid of chairs and tables, which also ensured more rapid turnover in customers.  "Any feeling of contestion was relieved by the upward spaciousness of high ceilings and the illusory roominess controved by the generous use of mirrors and plate glass..." (154)  The barmaid was needed as staff but also as an "allurement among its mirrors and mahogany, its brassware and coloured tile." (154)

* Older alehouses had also had womenb, tu in many cases they were simly wives or daughters "exploited as an extension of their domestic duties." (154)  What made the barmaid distinct was partly the new context: "she was not physically separated fromthe public by the novel device of the bar counter, part of the pub's duplication of the apparatus of the retail shop which formalised selling and begn that conversiton of its clientele from gues to customers.  The bar was now also a boundary or cordon sanitaire which kept the barmaid almost literally out of reach of the customer (or vice versa), and met the publican's new concern for respectability to protect his license and greater business investment in ta time of tighete licensing controls and reform hostility." (154)

* But Bailiey notes "if the romaning wanto of the alehouse had now become contianed with the closed territory of the serving era," her separation had also made her role "more conspicuous and seductive." (154)  The bar coutner was "the visual as well as transactional focus of the pub-gin palace and provided a framing effect that gave it the dramatic properties of a stage... " (154)  The theatrical quality Bailey notes was increased by the "flaring quality of the new gas lighting and the reflectinos of the pub's numerous mirrors..." (154)  The fact that she shared the stage with the commodties suggested that "she herself might be an article for purchase and consumption." (154)

* What was significant here Bailey says is not so much woman as sex object however, but "the woman as bearer of glamour, arguably a distinctively mnodern visual property,  and central to parasexulity in its practice of managed arousal." (156) Glamour is usually associated with 1930s Hollywood stars.  Film historians define it as "alluring charm or fascination, often based on illusion, that transforms or glorifies a person or thing." (156)  Even older usage in the nineteenth century by Sir Walter Scott denotes a "magic or fictitious beauty." (156)  The crucial point for Bailey in realtion to parasexuality: that "[d]istance not only sustains and protects the magical property that is commonly recognised in glamour, but also heightens desire through the tension generated by the psearation fo the galmour object and the consummation of desire." (156) Distance can be achieved in lots of ways: you can put as in Scott's usage your loved one on a pedestal I.e courtly love or you can look throug a shop window or on television or photography as we do now, but it was this distance afforded by the bar--its aspect as a stage that isolated teh barmaid and made her distant--that gave her the qualities of glamour. (156)

II.

* Won't go through all Bailey's analyses here.  He first references Manet's barmaid clerk (famous painting) and discusses a reading of it by T.J. Clark which saw Manet's image that reeads it as a illsutratinof the disjunctions of modernityl...and the emptiness of the barmaids face as a example of alientation.  But then Bailey analyses more popular graphical representations and finds something very different.  In these images the man has penetrated behind the counter and is regarded appealingly by the barmaids.  Bailey's reading of these is too good to summarize here, but the point is ultimately that Clark's reading may not hold up for these other more popular representations which he thinks get at the reality a bit better: "In this context, the beholder is less the voyeur or predator than the ultimate participant in a flattering drama of opportunity and incluesion in the press and rush of big city life.  Should we say that the vision of the avant garde is distrubing yet probalbly more accurate, while that of the more popular aesthetic is reassuring yet ultimately deceitful?  Maybe; but it shoudl be noted that whatever the element of fantasy and manipulation in the latter, there is a conserable grounding in reality.  It is the particular genius loci of the pub, as it was with the popular theatre and music hall, to be an intermediate institution that combines the properites of both public and private domains.  Its internal space is in part firmly ordered between the open and closed, but much of it remains negotiable, including that across the bar counter -- and from both sides." (162)

...

title: The transformation of German Jewry, 1780-1840
text:
General Notes

Note Session 10/12: Reading very selectively. Trying to map out the newer literature on Bildung. Although this isn't the newest book, it seems to be well respected. Sorkin is Mosse's student I thin#David Sorkin, *The Transformation of German Jewry, 1780-1840* (New York: Oxford University Press, 1987)

Note Session 10/12: Reading very selectively. Trying to map out the newer literature on Bildung. Although this isn't the newest book, it seems to be well respected. Sorkin is Mosse's student I think. This book is cited in the newer books that touch upon the subject of Bildung and the Jewish middle class that I have looked at so far, Hacohen's book about Popper, and Marion Kaplan's book on the making of the Jewish middle class.    

Critical Note: I think that Sorkin's point of view has a lot to do with Mosse, who I think was his teacher. Interestingly, Dirk seems to think that Mosee's work is no good, that he his perpetuating the *Sonderweg* thesis because he tells a story of Bildung's decline. I am not sure that this decline narrative is not justified in fact, esp. vv the expeirence of Jews. But Dirk has also pointed to the Kocka book about Bildung, which seems important since Kocka is one of thsoe who has critiqued the *Sonderweg*.     
My sense is that Sorkin builds on Mosse but tells a more detailed and differentiated intellectual history, one that is in fact less fixated on the inevitability and all-ecompassing centrality of Germany ethnonationalist turn.

> It is also noteworth here that Sorkin is using "community" and sub-culture. The vision of as Rodgers put it "little platoons of society"...

## Intro

* This is a study of "German Jewry" between 1780 and 1840. It takes off from a deisre to "explain why the nature of the most visible Jewry in modern Europe remained essentially invisible to its own members and to subsequent genreations." (3)

* This group he says has attracted so much attentiuon because "in its history all of the hallmarks of modernity seemed to have converged in their fullest and most volatile forms." (3)

* He describes German Jewry as being involved in a "twofold revolution." 1) "a protracted process of political emancipation, a far-reaching social transformation, and a racial anti-Semitism which eventually achieved power." (3) 2) an "encounter with the surrounding culture [that] resulted in an intense culturla productivity rivaled in earlier Jewish history only by the symbioses of the Hellenistic period and the Golden Age in Spain." (3)

* Sorkin thinsk that the novelty and productivy of this group's twofold reovlution has meant that it has attracted a great deal of attention, and indeed it has served as a sort of model for WEstern European Jewish experience generally. (3)
 
* His goal seems not to challenge paradigmatic status...but rather to note that in descriptions of thiis twofold revolution, there has been far greater attention paid to the intellectual/cultural side, and not to the social revolution. On the flip side, more recent studies that do focus on the social revolution, have ignored the cultural and intellectual dimensions. He will not. (So one can see this book as sitting in that moment of early cultural history, post-Wingspan, where there was a sense of the dissatisfaction with pure social histroy and a recognition of a need to dealwith the cultural and intellectual.)

* The results of the exclusively cultural focus he thinks was to set up a literature that interpreted the meaning of "assimilaiton" as a kind of self-denial or loss of a distinctly Jewish culture. Sorkign points out that this "definition of assimilation...is based on static, anachronistic categories." (4) The nationalist saw the "Jew" as opposed to the "German." The religioninst opposed the "Jew" to the "Christian." And both of these points of interprettion saw "emancipation" as being "based on an act of hopeless bad faith." (4) That was so because whatever gains German Jews might achieve it would in their view always come at the cost of "self-denial." (4) It was hopeless because Germans would never assume Jews as equals. So emanciipation was thougth to involve self-dianial and self-hatred and in turn hatred of others. So these accounts created a kind of "continuum between self-denial and anti-Semetism" and so "lilnked emancipation teleologically to the events of the twentieth century." (4)

* What Sorkin intends to do is to replace this kind of account with another that by focusing on the twofold revolution  -- ie social and cultural tranformations -- will trace the emergence "of a new ideal of man from the last decades of the eighteenth century until 1840." (4)  This new ideal was develooped by a "new intellectual group" who he calls the "ideologues of emancipation" who shaped an ideology "in response to emanciaption" that involved a "radicalizing of the Hebrew Enlightenment, the *Haskala*, which had arisen from the disaffection of traditional rabbinic and new lay elites with an autonomous community deteriorating from extreme social differentiation." (5)

* The new ideal, he says, "had a definite conviction that German Jewry was degenerate" (5) but also argued that regeneration would require equal rights as a precondition. (5) Equal rights would permit a process of rengeration and that process would in the end "lead to the formation of a new kind of Jew and a new kind of Jewish community based on its ideal of man." (5) The Jewish middle class "bourgeoisie" created by the "transformation of German society" readily adopted that ideal, thought without conforming to the ideologues ivision of regneration. But it did use the ideal to "shape a new kind of Jewish community--a public sphere and a public social world -- informed iwth a new ideal of man." (5) That new community nd ideal of man, Sorkin argues, "represnted a new form of Jewish identity" (5) that "rested heavily on borrowings from the majority culture: its ideal, the formationof the individaul, *Bildung*, acme from the German bourgeoisie of education (*Gebildeten*)." (5) Jews saw this bourgeooise as their "model for emulation and a target for integration." (5) And, Sorkin says, "[l]ooking at German society from the outside," the  Jews treated the bourgeoisie as the "culture of the majority soceity." (5)

* The key idea here in the Jewish community was that there was a quid pro quo: "rights for regeneration, for the creation of a new Jewish identity took place under the auspeices of political emancipation." (5)

* That is key because the social fact that Jewish integration remained incomplete for over almost a century. And it remained so. Sorkin thinks that what he is calling the "ideology of emancipation" would have had little relevant if emancipation had occured quickly and if Jews had been accepted in to German society after rights were given, but they were not. Emanciption remained incomplete and integration partial. Btu this situation "comprised the conditions for the ideology becoming the basisi  of a new kind of identity." (5)

* The dientity that emerged, he says, was a "subculture." (5) And by that he mans a "minority-group use of the majority culture that has two aspects..." (6) Such a subcutlure is "composed of elemnts of the majority culture" but is at the same time totally "distinct and functions as a self-contained system of ideas and symbols." (6) SO H E IS OPERATING WITH A KIND OF CULTURE OCNCEPT HERE...  but he states outright that for such a subcutlrue the "boundaries seaprating the subjculture from the majority culture were shifting and permeable..." but there were boudnaries he says. And he notes that there was a "creative element" wherein Jews "appropriated" certain ideas of the majority culture in a way that differed from other Germans "if only in nuances, social weight, and its fuision with elements of Judaism." (6)

* A key component of this subculture were a set of "secular fact ors--cultural, eonomic, demographic, social--which it utrnedinto the basis of a separate existence." (6) This means that this community cannot be understood in any simple or static way as defined by either religion or nationality. "The identity must be seen instead as the subculture of a minority gorup, the specifially German-Jewish." (6) This German-Jewish culture remained, however, unassimilated. Intermarriage, conversion, or denial of connection with Jews was not a dominant expeirence. More penetrating, Sorkin notes that due tot he lack of assimilation a certain "sense of indignity and furstration" was central to the community's expeirence and an "aspect of its solidarity." (6)

* To answer his initial quesiton,this identiy and subculture remained invisible to German-Jews because of the ideology of emancipation, which "proclaimed the absence or imminent disappearance of the social and political bonds that had unified Jews in the autonomous community, because their existence would have vitiated the claim to emancipation. That new cultural, social and poitical bonds came to exist, adn taht they did so through the ideology of emancipation, was a paradox that the ideologues could not comprehend. They could neither recogniye nor acknowledge that their ideology, deisgned to foster integration, had become a basis of separation. The bourgeoisie ould not see that its acculturation made it not German but German-Jewish." (7)

* The way Sorkin explaisn this then is to say that the "community's invisibility...resulted from the disparity between ideology and socail reality." (7) To say this, allows him also to say that what was going on here was not self-denial but the fact that these German-Jews were not able to "fully understand the nature of their nascent community..." **So this is a story, he says, not of "self-denail but of irony--the consequences of the discrepancy between German Jewry's actual and its imagined situation." (7)**

* It is also because of the fact  that this community was invisible to its own menmbers and that they denied its existence that the earlier studies, which focused on the cultural side of the twofold revolution, took those pronouncements at face value and told a story of self-denial as the cost of emancipation. That interpretation has played a central role in subsequent formulations of Jewish identity, and he givse the example of Zionism, which it seems he is probably critiquing here...and trying to present other forms of identity.

* VV culture he echoes his earlier hedging on the self-contained idea, apparently trying to say he uses the concept but not as a key frame: "...I have attempted to treat culture as neither determined nor determinant, but as one structural factor among others in an overall process of historical development." (7) He is not using an explicit theory, but has observed the "culture played a role in the overall transformation of German Jewry", which has meant that he had to pay attention to it but could also not "treat it as the primary phenomenon or...reduce it to an epiphenomenon..." (8)

* His book though is structured around culture. The first half looks at the "genesis of a cultural formation" and the second looks at the "historical role of that cultural formatioon.. "(8)

* Sorkin hopes that the book sheds some light on the German-Jewish question (ie why was it invisible and why wasit so culturally productive). But he also sees the book as useful for thinking about "the afterlife of the German Enlightenment, the *Aufklärung*, in the culture of liberalism." (8) It is useful here becasue the ideology of emancipation projected "*Aufklärung* modes of thought well into the nineteenth century." (8) He says that this ideology was at times "clouded" by neo-humanist and romantic ideas, but he seeems to see it as remaining true to that core tradition--whcih he thinks is still valuable? He also notes that the "successors of the ideologues"--who?--still used the same ideas in the 20th century "to generate new positions within the subculture..." ie he seems to think it still valuable as a source of liberal ideas???  Perhaps he and Hacohen are  on the same page in this ???
