> Note: To what extent is Sorkin just projecting a kind of American vision of a fissured society, a kind of mixture of Madisonian democracy, and mid-1980s idenity politics/liberal political theory in the Walzerian frame?


##  Conclusion

> It is in the conclusion it seems where Sorkin really takes up the issue of Bildung? Or at least, k. This book is cited in the newer books that touch upon the subject of Bildung and the Jewish middle class that I have looked at so far, Hacohen's book about Popper, and Marion Kaplan's book on the making of the Jewish middle class.

title: Alain L. Locke: The Biography of a Philosopher
text: p.005-027 CH1: The Lockes of Philadelphia

title: From Physics to Ethnology
text:
Notes 11/12/12:

> Reading for Manifold Origins article. What was the influence of neo-Kantianism and psychophysics?

* Stocking is trying to make more subtle the account that has dominated the discussion of Boas' intellectual roots. He's working against the critique of Boas' developed by the subsequent generation of anthropologists that maligned Boas as an arch anti-evolutionist... He wants to focus on what happened to Boas on his trip to the Canadian Arctic. (135-137)

* He lays out a series of letters Boas' wrote to Jacobi in 1882 and 1883 where he describes his developing interests. In one letter from January 2, 1882, he says that he'd like to study "the mechanism of the life of organisms and especially of peoples that is before my eyes." (137) Already he states his intention to work on geography, and that he will "leave psychophysics in peace, since it leads me too far afiield, even if I shoudl find an unusually rich field of work in science." (137) Afield from ?? "the life of organisms and especially of peoples..." ? (137) Then he states his larger goal vv geography: "to investigate the influence of the configuration of the land on the acquaintance of peopples with their neaer and far neighborhood." (138) He thinks to be fruitful in thsi study he will need to make trips, and also to become acquainted with physiology and sociology. (138)

* Then in April 10, 1882, he's sent his *vita* to Jacobi. Here is where he states his feeling that he need to move away from his materilaist *Weltanschauung*. "In the course of time, I became convinced that my previous materialistic *Weltanschauung*--for a phsyicsit a very understandable one--was untenable, and I gained thus a new standpoint which revaled to me the importance of studying the interaction between the organic and the inorganic, above all between the life of a people and their physical enviornment. Thus arose my plan to regard as my life's task the [following] investigation: How far may we consider the phenomena of organic life, and especially those of the psychic life, from a mechanistic ponit of view, and what conclusions can be drawn from such a consideration?"  Here too he thinks he'll need a knowledge of other sciences: physiology, psychology, and sociology. And he's turned to the Eskimo for this reason, thinking that they are an ideal peopel to study the "dependene of the migration of present-day Eskimo on the configuration and physical conditions of the land..." (139)

* At this point Boas fails to get a scholarship at Johns Hopkins, and instead goes to Berlin where he meets Rudolf Virchow and Adolf Bastian. He there studies things like astronomical determination of location and cartography in order to prepare for "scientific travel." (139)

* In another letter of May 2, 1883, as his planning for his trip to the Arctic is coming ot an end, he writes again to Jacobi. Now he says his goal is to "work [out] a physiological and psychological mechanics, if I may use that term." (quotedon 139) He says he would begin with pscyhophysics. and has an exact outline of a book on that. But he thinks me must begin with "geogrpahy, since that is the science that I have thoroughly learned." (140) So he says he has "slected a geographically perteinent problem -- the dependence of knowledge of the land, [a relatiopnship] whcih accoridngoit my knowledge to date of exiting material can probably be worked out." (140) He said he chose the Eskinmo because they were a people living "in the simples possible circumstances" but there too he says "conditions are much too complicated" (140) Then he also says that the "general study will be about the knolwedge of peoples have of the local geography, which will be followed by a pscyhological study about the casues for the limitations of the spreading of peoples." (140) 

* Stocking says based on all this that Boas WAS NOT going to the Canadian Articie to examine the "Eskimo perception of sea water" or becasue he was interested purely in geography as has been charged in earlier works. (140)

* Stocking suggests as the proper context for understnaidn gBoas' motives what Charles Gillispie has cllaed the "German 'syncretisimm' of 'the historicist spirit of romantic idaelism and the hairy philosophy of monistic materialism'..." (140) He notes that Boas was raised on Schiller and Goethe but then began to feel "some of the ambiguities and tensions of Gillispie's syncretism. (140)  -- Stocking notes Boas' own statemnt that he had to develop a compromise between his interest in math an dphysics and an "intesnive emotional itneret in the phenomena of the world" in his Anthropologist's Credo. (140-141)

* Stocking suggests that "in understanding Boas' later shift to ethnology" it is important to realize that there was a big overlap between ethnolgocial and geopgraphical work in German historical geography. , esp followers of Karl Ritter who was the intellectual guide of Theobold Fischer who worked with Boas in the earlyl 1880s. Ritter "focus was on the interaction of man and enviornment--the 'relationshio of all the phenomena oand forces of nature to the human race.'" (141) He tried to formulate a law o migrations of primitive peoples which was part of a "prevolutionary ethnology." (141) Ritter also founded the Gesellschaft feur Erdkunde* in Berlin, and had intended to found an ethnological society. Bastian did that instead, founding hte *Berliner Gesellschaft fpeur Antrhopologie, Ethnologie, und Urgeschichte* in 1858. And Bastian, who was then head of the Gesllschaft feur Erdkunde, conceived of it as a branch of that society. (141)

* Stocking has a quote from a letter from Fischer to Boas on 1882 giving him advice. It's really rich. What seems to come out of it is a real emphasis on the unity of the development of physical geographical studies and of the grwoth of scientific knowledge. Heres' the really bizarre quote:

> The natural scientist, to be sure, resists fromt he beginning tracing everywhere the connections with man. But in order for him to seek completely new conceptions, in order for new ideas to come to him in abundance, he msut become conscious of the fact that the unity of natural science, with its various branches mutually influencing and conditioning each other, and all together constituting the condtiions of nature which influence the life of humanity everywhere, will be restored on the surface of our planet." It is indeed a pslendid remakr that Ritter once made, that geography is the secure foundation of study and teaching in physical and historical sciences.It is in geography in which both find themselves gain, [and] in this sense, the unity of science in general is restored in it." (141-142)

What does this all mean?  Stocking does not really interpret this all, except to say that there is an emphaisis on the "holistic, affective understanding of the relationshp of man and the natural world..." (142) But Fischer is saying something more here. He's saying that geography is the basis for relating human knowledge to the perception of the real world, yes, but also that in that it is the basis for re-unifying all human knowledge. That phrase is powerful that is through geography that the unity of natural science "will be restored on the surface of our planet."

* Boas work in physics and pscyho physics at the same time "raised problem which also took him along path toward the study of man's interaction with the extenral world." (142) In his doctoral dissertation, Boas had perforemd experiments that dealt with the absorption of light in samples of water. But at points the measurement depended on Boas' subjective judgement. This led Boas to "the problem of thresholds below which differences in stimuli produced no perceptible sensory differnece and to the question of 'just noticeable differences' in sensory stimuli, both of where were central to Fechnerian psychophysics." (142) Boas then writes six article during the year of hsi miltiary sericce on psychophysics, that cuulmiantes in a discussion of "The Basic Tasks of Pscyhophysics" (142) Stocking does not go into detail on these articles, saying that they were fairly in line with what the secondary lit says on psychophysics, but he says that the general cahter of Boas'statements indicate a concern with the situational factors that affect the experimenter's perecption, i.e. subjectiivty. "More fundamentally, he suggested that various differences which traditinal psychophysics assumed to be *qualitative* (e.g. in the intesnsity of light) were in fact *qualitative*. On the basis of such arguments Boas called into question the very possiblity of all perceptions or of a general law governing the relationship of stimulus and perception." (143)  Later in 1939 he wrote that these experiments taugh t him that "there are domains of our expeirence in which the concepts of quantity...with which [as a physicist] I was accustomed to operate, are not applicable." (143)

* Appropriately, Stocking shifts to Boas' contact with neo-kantianism here. Since the end point, the idea that some domains of experience are not accessible to scientific knowledge is a deeply Kantian insight. He notes that in his April 1882 vita, Boas had indicated that he was spending much time with philosophy in the last 4 semesters at Kiel. He was under the influence of Benno Erdmann, a leading Kant scholar. Erdmann, Stocking says, "was especially interested in problems of logic, epistemology, and pscyhology." (143) Boas sent Erdmann his articles on pscyhophysics, and Erdmann evidently commented on them. Boas' close friend Rudolf Lehmann, was also involved in the neo-Kantian movement. And Boas studied Kant on his trip. (143)

* Having noted this influence, Stocking attempts a kind of interpretation that I don't find so compelling, although it's not bad. His turn away from his materialism, expressed in his letters to Jacobi indicates a desire to question his materialism, not a full rejection. His work in physics and psychophysics led him to a concern with subjectivity in experimental perception. Now Stocking adds his take on the Kantian influence: "Kantian philosophy--which in this period was impelling a number of men to a realization that the interpretive activity of the human mind had a great deal to do with the chracater of the objects observed in the 'external' world--must have also impelled him to a consideration of epistemological problems." (145) I.e. what Stocking is saying here is just that neo-Kantianism reinforced Boas' confrontation with the problem of subjectivity. But I'm not sure that Stocking has got right his little quick summary of the neo-Kantians. To be sure they were concerned with the interaction between subject and object, but it seems to me from what I've read that they were in fact seeking to redefine science as something that could account for both material and immaterial phenomena, and the interaction between them, by grounding perception in physiology. What we can now about the world is defined by physiology and pscyohology; what we cannot know is things-in-themeslves. My account here is also totally weak, but it's more than Stocking gets at... There's also the Theobold Fischer quote that sounds a lot like the Kuno Fischer, whom Liss says Boas' was influenced by in her *Cosmopolitan Imagination.* K.Fischer published these critiques of Kant in the *Journal of Specualtive Philosophy* that sound a bit lilke T. Fischer in terms of this world-historical growth of human scientific knowledge.

* Stocking's argument then about Baffin Island takes a very subtle form. All the above influences involve a kind of need to compromise between varied scientific interests, and compromise was "based on an underlying epistemological concern which runs beyond the Arctic trip through all of Boas' early work": namely, the tension between subjectivity/reflexivity and objectivity. (144)

Note: I would put this even more strongly: because Boas was perhaps seeing a possiblity for unity in knowledge; that was somehow fragmenting; and the reason for that had to do with the roblem of subjectivity. Perhaps the neo-kantians had the confidence that they could overcome the disunity of knowledge by taking subjectivity "scientificcally" into account in, say, the study of pscyhophysics, and in knowing the pshcyological and physiological basis of subjectivity, but they were a very divided camp, and Boas, as Stocking notes, had pushed back against their ability to quantify phenomena that were in his view essentialy qualitiative, so he may ahve been even more skeptical of that claim to unity. So he had the desire to unify knowledge, perhaps, but the growing sense that that was not possible. His anthropology, as Liss gets at, was a way to try to hold things together,i.e. hold the unity of knowledge together...but that wasn't working. I'm really taken by this idea though that is perhaps in both Fischer's of geography as the basis of a unified scientific human knowledge that would expand with knowledge and understanding of the physical world. Must go all the way back to  A. Humboldt, but given here a very different configuration and contextual meaning? Is this really a thing,though? Need to go back to that K. Fischer article and follow it out. I bet this is also in FA Lange.

* Now Stocking turns ot the question of the impact of the trip to Baffin Island. He first distances himself from the idea that the field experience is for anthropologists perceived as a kind of spiritual converstion, and he wants to suggest that this may have influenced interpretations of the impact of that experience on Boas. (144-145)

* Stocking in an interesting paragraph on 147-148 that goes from a reference to Boas' relationship to his parents and a tendency to revolt against authority, to a discussion of his reactions to the Eskimo, to wehther or not he changed his point of view, suggests that Boas **did not** experience the kind of transformation that, for instance, Laura Bohannan describes in her interpsecitive account of the modern anthropolgoists' experience.  Note: I agree that Boas did not change in the way Bohannan describes probably, but one thing I notice here is that Stocking puts this in terms of the idea that Boas' "European identity" was not shaken. He cites as evidence Boas' regularly stated desires to speak with someone sensible, and his revulssion to the Eskimo culture. What I notice though is that Stocking misses that Boas' "European identity" was already unstable because of his Jewish background, i.e. in what Liss gets at about Boas, but also waht Sorkin has described in general...

* Stocking then goes on to contradict this claim, after trotting out the Herzensbildung quote.  That quote he says obviously reflected a change in attitude of the sort that then became very dominant in *The Mind of Primitive Man*. Stocking's point here is rather to give a more deflationary account of the transformation. He wants to say that what Boas was doing here was in fact reacting to a growing sense of alienation from Germany, rooted in his devotion of the politics of 1848 and his sense that in Germany h e would be unable to do work and speak out in a way consistent with his politics. In this connection, he brings up the antisemetism in Germany. And then he says that due to this Boas was attracted to the "wholeness of a society in which one did one's work without complain and shared food as one shared deprivation; in which the rule of tradition was accepted without hypocritical pretense to superior rationality; in which the *Bildung* of the heart rather than of the mind was the measure of a person's worth." (150) I think Stokcing puts a lot of words in Boas' mouth here.

* From here Stocking speculates that upon his return to Germany -- a year in which he, following the advice of T. Fischer, attempted to become a privat dozent based on his Baffin-Land text (the first he produced on the trip) and spent time working under Bastian with other young ethnologists -- that he transformed scientifically away from physics to ethnology. Stocking notes the influecne of Bastian, who was an ethnologist. Boas' ethnology Stocking says was like Bastian's a "pscyhologial study". He notes that Boas' in fact call it folk-pscyhology referring to it's comparative dimenions, a prhase that eferred to Bastian's work. And like Bastian's work comparative study of *Voelkergedanken* or ethnic *Weltanschauungen*, Boas' basic unity of observation was the psychic life of each *Volk* as an organic whole, and its analystica goal was to get behind the modifying action of geography or hsitory to the fundamental 'lelements of the character of a people,' whichh could then be treated comparatively. Like Bastian, although to a greater degree, Boas was disinclined to cast the development of fundamental ideas in evolutionary terms." (152) That said, Stocking thinsk that Boas saw the relationhsip bewteen *Elementargedanken* and *Voelkergedanken* as being more complex than Basian. Specifically, he thinks that Boas was influenced by Bastian's "conception of 'geographical provinces of cutlural similarities'" and yet he was beginning to cut against such geographical determinism by "weighting" that perspective itth "historical meaning, emaphsizing the process of diffusion which  made the mythology of a given province such as 'inextricable mixture' of 'fundamental ideas.' Indeed, it is in this sense of the hiotoricity of ethnic phenonmena, which is not chractersitic of Bastian, that is the most notewrothy aspect of Boas' early ethnological theorizing." (152)

NOte: This is good! Thsi is what I'm emphasziing, and which Liss has too. So this is firmly grounded in Boas' thought.

* Stocking says that the origins of the emaphsis on historicity may have come from Dilthey! "whose attempt to free the historical sciences from the domination of the epistemological assumptions of positivistic natural science had appeared in 1883, and who had in the prceedig year assumed a chair at the University of Berlin." (152) Stokcing says that Boas made it clear that dilthey had influence dhim in later comments and he speculates that it was during his eyar in Beriln that he may ahve read or even heard him speak. (152)

* Stocking also notes that this historical orientation may have developed from Boas experience in the Arctic. He notes that Boas did not find the simplicity that he'd hoped to in the Arctic among the Eskimo. Stocking quotes from not sure what here: "...'the influence of geographical surroundings' was an 'extremely complex' matter which was affected by any number of 'pscyhological' factors, whcih in turn were influenced by hsitory. 'The longer I studied [after returning to Germany] the more I became convinced that the phenomena such as customs, traditions, and migrations are far too complex in their origin, as to enable us to study their pscyhological causes without a thorough knjowledge of their history'" (153)  (F.n. #27, shows these are letters to Powell and Bastian. The first is perhaps to Powell, 6/12/1887, and the second to Bastian 1/5/86)

* Stocking says it was in this context that Boas conceived of ethnographic projecst in the Pacific Northwest. He planned a whole project that Bastian rejected in January 1886.  In spring 1886, he was finally qualified as a dozent, but was soon off to British Columbia. And Stocking says that here he was very interested in history. Quoting him: "I considered it necessary to see a poeple among which hstorical facts are of greater iinfluence than the surroundings, and selcted for this purpose Northwest America." (153)

Notes: What is strange in Stocking's language though is that he here then says "indeed, the letter diaries of this trip indicate thiat his motives were by this time ethnological..." (153) What does he mean by ethnologicalhere???  Is this becasue he's taking for granted an endpoint in the form of ethnology he takes to be central to American anthropology? What is ethnology here?

* On hsis return to New York in early 1887, he accepts a postiion as a geographical editor at *Science*. Again on this weird thing about "ethnology" Stocking feels he needs to explain the fact that this was a geographical editorship away by saying onjce again that Boas' focus was "ethnological." (153-4)

* On 154-155, Stocking goes through Boas' key "The Study of Geography" in order to argue basically that Boas had turned toward an "ethnological" perspective, which Stocking associates with the description Boas gives of the historicist-romantic view. See esp the end of the paragarph on top of 155. Where he defines that article as "essentially a justification--to physical scientists generally, and to himself--of the study of phenomena whose only unity was 'the connection in which they appear to the mind of the observer,' which could nto be subjected to quantitative deetermination or to law, but which could only be 'understood' historically." (155)

Note: This sounds very phenomenological. Having just read Boring's A History of Experimental Pschology, and thinking of Stocking's use of the word *Weltanschauung* and given the known link to Fechner and Helmholtz, this sounds like Anschauung -- sense-perception mixed with what Helmholtz called unconscious inference -- mixed with Fechner pscyholgocial aesthetics also. So I see where Stocking is going here, but I think he jumps to quickly. It's also a bit mixed up. He's implying it seems that Boas was mixing old romantic-historicism with the new psychology, and taking only interest in the conjnection of phenomena in the mind of a people. Also is that Boas' phrase...the connection of things in the midn of the person?

Note: Also Stocking in analyzing this essay notes the separation of logical/aesthetic and affective desire. This is really the key point somehow, as it gets into that changing meaning of the aesthetic in the transformation of *Bildung*.

* From here, Stocking shows how Boas applied the same distinction between the impulse to generalize and the impusle ot focus on individualities to his critiques of museum organization. Then finally on 156-167 he pionts out that there was therefore no conversion experience but instead a "gradual and continous" development "out of his family and cultural background, his work in physics and psychophysics, his geographical interests, his contact with German Romantic idealist and historical traditions,a nd his work with Bastian, all inthe context of his feild of experience. In short, it flowed from his total life experience." (157)

* The culmination of this point of view he thinks was in the 1888 article "On Alternating Sounds." This article he thinks brought together all the strands just mentioned above. His analysis is on 157-159. The concerns of pscyhophysics are brought together with culture.

*Stocking then ends on a note that destabilizees his claims a bit because he shows quotes where Boas is talking about wantig to find the "pscyhological origin of the implicit belief in the authority of tradition" and he cites that 1887 review of Bastian's book where Boas hits this note.

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text:
p.139-139 B against "modernist self-doubt"?

Here H says that "[i]n Patterns of Culture, Benedict discovered the authentic, holisitc cultures she sought nd from whichthe modern world had xcluded her as a participant." (139)  Then H notes that B perhaps accepts even those cultures that repress individual expression because it does not seem to be done coercively?  [Note: But the whole role of culture itself is coercive in the way she describes it...it molds plastic people...] H thinks B rejected Sapir's "genuine culture" model resting on "sincerity" because "sincerity implies self-consciousnss, and Benedict sought worlds in which meaniningfulness and participation could exist wihtout such awareness.  The Northwest Coast potlacher could pursue megalomaniacal successes unhindered by modernist self-doubt." (139)

then..."Benedict wrote into being the holisitic, enuine cultures that no longer existed in the modernist's world. At the same time, she preserved her own indivduality, controlling and inviolate as a narrrative voice..." (139)

title: Ideas and Institutions in American Anthropology: Thoughts Toward a History of the Interwar Years
text: [3] [On Boas' "Experiential Standpoint"] Stocking has a statement here that coincides with my ideas: the idea that the Boas' critique grew out of a distinct perspective formed by a kind of outsiders position. This outsider position was defined by the influence of the neo-Kanitan German philosophers (and that Germano-Romantic tradition of thiought), his "cultural marginality" as a German-Jew, and his early professional alienation... Two things about this. 1) It seems similar to my attempt to describe the Boasian point of view in the first chapter as the emergence of a distinct "point of view" and one that grew out of the alienated position of the discipline... Stocking however describes the above factors as causing an "experiental standpoint from which a systematic critique could be developed." (3) 2) Stocking's descriptions also highlight the point for the second chapter which is that this position of marginality is also about a larger cultural conflict between the positivistic and the historical intellectual tradition... (3) E.g. Stocking writes "For those who felt no serious alienation from the machine-driven civilization celebrated at the universal exhibition, there was apparent reason enough for such an assumption [i.e. the assumptions of Social Darwinism that Stocking pointed out attempted to legitimate the already assumed notion of cultural superiority of European civilization]. But Boas' cultural marginality as Jewish German, his early fiedl experieince, and his difficulties establishing himself professsionally in the United States helped to create an experiential standpoint from which a systmatic critique could be developed." (3)

title: Verging on Etra-Vagance: Anthropology, Hisotry, Religion, Literature, Arts...Showbiz
text:
(6) p. 30 - 38 Mead's "Subjectivity"

In two sections here Boon basically examines the treatment of menstruation in Benedict, Mead and Belo,
showing how the three built up their statements on this
theme.  Finally, he shows how Belo built in Mead's statements about a dance ritual in Bali in a text that Benedict read the year she died and allegedly approved of -- the point being that Belo inserted Mead as a counter-point to her own conclusions about the ritual and what it said about gendered female identity...  This mode of citing he sees as something like his ultra-objectivity.  "...it is critical to note that Belo cites Mead's 'objective' description interrupted by Mead's own 'subjective' commeon on Balinese women's witch-likeness.  But before Belo returns to the next day of her own description of eight months beforehand (Sindoe, April 27, 1937), she interjects a dissenting commentary on Mead's description plus comment.  I reiterate: Belo interrupts Mead's own self-interrupting notes--notes that Belo had use to interrupt her own 'notes' that form the bulk of her study's evidence...."  (38) The analysis that Belo than provides Boon describes as "arresting"...she describes Mead's sense of the daggers that the women use to stab themselves as "between a phallus and a baby." (38) and her statement that Mead seems to see something evil withc-like in the ritual whereas she doesn't.   and on the next page then Boon states: "I kinow no more powerful insight into a 'subjectivity' possibly guiding Mead's endeavors overall--in Samoa, Manus, Omaha, New Guinea, Bali--than Belo's critical insight.

title: A Manifesto for Feminine Modernism: Dorothy Richardson's Pilgrimage
text:
Quick Notes 7/5/10

Felber sees in the writer Dorothy Richardson's thirteen volume Pilgrimage , a work produced between 1915-1967, a femine modernism that exhibits modernist characteristics and takes up (in thew ords of Rita FElski) "takes up feminist concerns: if, for example, the text seeks to undermine an obviously patriarchal ideological position." (25)  This is what Felbert thinks Ricahrdson's text does by rejecting male-patriarchal logocentric writing techniques.

A couple of example that came through on my quick reading of this article

1) She gives an example right of the bat by saying that Richardson pursued an aesthetic that "privileges writing which is nonhierarchical and flowing..." (25)  Felbert notes that this is indicated in her formal choice of a sequence novel or roman-fleuve, which apparently literally means "river novel,"  This puts Ricahrdson in the zone of "stream-of-consciousness," but Felbert notes that Richardson dislikes that phrase.  She calls it instead "shroud of consciousness": "Her objection is elucidated as she explains that 'stream of consciousness is a muddle-head phrase.  I'ts not a stream, it's a pool, a sea, an ocean.  It has depth and greater depth adn when you think you have reached its bottom and there is nothing there, and when you give yourself up to one current, you are suddenly possessed by another.'  She rejects 'stream of consciousness' as too restrictive both in its unidirectional flow, bounded by its banks, and in its forward-moving linearity.  In contrast with the bounded male language, Richardson advocates a 'feminine prose,' which she defines in the introduction to Pilgrimage as 'unpunctuated, moving from point to point without formal obstructions.'" (25)

2) On 28-29, Felber develops this rejection of the boundedness of male langauge in Richardson's preference for silence as a rejection of male logocentrism.  In fact, this ties to an earlier point in whihc the "internal" is a kind of feminine world that cannot be adequately expressed in the "external" langauge of men (or that language as it has been defined by men, thus creating the need for a new kind of feminine writing, 26-27.  [Note: it's interesting to think in relation to this of Simmel's arguments about "objective" culture as being a mascuine thing and "subjective culture" as being feminine.  This is essentially the same argument it seems?]

3) The new method of writing it seems is found in Pilgrimage by the main character Miriam when Miriam encounters a new wrigin stile in one of hte other characters named Amabel.  The two see in eahc other "qualities no man cn see." (31, elber's words.)  Miriam encounters this in a letter from Amabel, which provokes an "aeshetic revelation."  (32)  It's the cahracter of the hand-writing in part whcih "evokes the writer's presence" as well as evoking the "female ibody in the manner advocated by the French feminists: 'Each word, eaech letter, was Amabel, was one of the many poses of her body, upright as a plant is upright, elegant as a decorative plant, support its embellishing cuves just as th eclean uprights of the letters supported the curves that belong to them.'"  (32)  So Felber says that the letter becaomes an example of "ecriture feminine" and of modernist narrative coming together.  Longer quote on 32-33 illustrates the coming together and othe rmodernist qualities.  The idea of words as hieroglyphs...gaps between letters etc etc. "...the writing is spatial and synchronous, creating a picture, transcending the bound quality of male wriing which moves 'from word to word.'" (Felber, 33).  Miriam responds to the ltter in a way that Felber says "makes clear tha the letter represents a new gendreed tradition in writing:

"Instead of calling her attention to the way the pen was held, to the many expressivenesses of a given handwriing, apart from what it was being used to express, instead of bringing as did the majority of letters, expecially those written by men, a picture of the writer seated and thoughtfully using a medium of communication, recognizing its limiations and remaining docile within them so that the letter itself seemed quite as much to express the impossibility as the possiblity of exchange by any means of the written word, it called her directly to the girl herself, making her, and not the letter, the medium of expression." (34)

---

Felber ends the essay by saying that "Miriam disocvers how to articulate her true essence and write in an inherently feminine style."  This in turn allows her to "transcend the impasse of the binary opposition of speech-silence: She has discovered a language which speaks a silence and feminine essence, an laternative language to the restrictive male discourse." (35) She quotes Irigary as saying that a feminine language would be one in which "every dichotomizing--and ta the same time redoubling--break, including the one between enunciation and utterance has to be disrupted." (from Power of Discousrse, 79-80, her on 35.)  Ricahrdson's work Felber says anticipates "the so-called French feminist position." (35)  She anticipates critiques that would suggest that by saying that such writing celebrates essential female qualities and in this way suports essentialism is wrong.  Here she says: "femininity is valorized to emphasize the absurdity of the traditional denigration of qualities attributed to women." (36)

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.047-48 Securing a female head for chidl bureau

As soon as Taft had signed the children bureau bill in 1912, the female reformers mad their move to secure Lathrop as head.  Lathrop was uniquely qualified , Muncy says, because she self-consciosly courted the pose of a lady and did not offend men.  (see 49).

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text:
p.011-12  Political view of Languages in New World

Big part of research used to back this was research into language...attempting to show a "common origin" of languages.  (10-11).  Many people involved in this research: In 1786, George Washington asked government agents in Ohio to collect linguistic data.  (11).  Big studies conducted y Pter S. Du Ponceau as part of Historical and Literary Committee of the American Philosophical Society est. in 1815 with Jefferson's support.  (11)   Theory of "polysynthesis" of languages spooken in Americas fro mGreenland to Tierra del Fueogo..."they sharedcomplex structure and grammatical forms that distinguished them from all the Old World languages."  (11)   He also thought they were superior in that they were a "more effective system than their Old World counteprarts for combining the greatest number of ideas in the least number of words." (11)  In this they resembled the classical "ancient" languages such as Latin, Greek,and Slavic (12).

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.034 Talbot connected to Hull House

Talbot maintained close connection with Hull House a "primarily woman's institution" (34, cf Muncy female dominion).  Talbot "directed" women htere.  In decade after Chicago's opening, many women came to the university to study social sciences and do social work.  Talbot and these women believed that as woemn they were sutied to study social work, but they did not see social activism as a "feminine undertaking."  (35) "Marion Talbot, in particular, believed that nothing better demonstrated the need to transcend Victorian's society's separation of male and female spheres than did the disease and pollution of the modern city.  While women confined their concern for the quality of life to their homes, and while men confined their techological expertise to industrial expansion, public life deteriorated for want of attention from either group." (35)

title: The Naturalized Female Intellect
text:
p.220 19th Century Rise of General Intelligence

The oppositiuon between concrete detials and general principles might have been not allt hat important had it remained "one of several oppositions, attached to the several mental faculties that distinguished male from female..." (220) but that is nto what happened.  In the middle decades of the nineteenth century, "pychologists increasingly preferred as single, overarching intelligence ot a mind crammed with disparate faculties.  The defining property of this new, general intelligence was the ability to sythesize genral principles from the teeming detail of experience.  Thus with the ascent of general intelligence the intellect effectively became masculinized to an unprecedented degree." (221) Before female mental abilities had been seen as virtues and abilities even though tthey were seen as being of a "second magnitude," but now "[w]ith the homogenization of theintellectual facutlies into a single, all-purpose intelligence and the identification of that intelligence with the capacity for extracting genearl principles from experiential particulars, the link bretween 'female' and 'intellect' was all but severed." (221)  This applied to savages and children.

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text:
p.135 Contradition in Benedict's Approach to Culture

Handler says that Benedict in her dissertation issues a "programmatic call to her colleagues to reorient field research in order to document the patterns of particualr cultures (Benedict 1932:7)".  (135)  

This call he contrasts with the position Sapir took in "Unconscious Patterning..." that observers of other cultures are likely to get the meaning of a ritual wrong. (134-5) See original article 546-547 for Sapir quote.  The ability of the anthropologist to describe such patterns, Handler says, was never in doubt for Benedict. (135)  

Handler says, though, that there was a contradiction.  Citing Boon's Verging on Extra-Vagance he says her "method is fundamentally comparative and hermeneutic.  It thus implies the impossibility of objective descriptions of individual cultures--or, more precisely, of descriptions constructed by an observer occupying neutral ground." (135)

title: Another Liberalism: Romanticism and the Reconstruction of Liberal Thought
text:
Notes Spring 2011:

1.  Introduction

She's trying to capture an aesthetic or affective response to liberalism by romantics.  She thinks there are elements in liberalism that appeal to romantics.  She thinks romanticism might be the return of the repressed.  She describes how romantics see liberalism--as cold and rational.  She looks at romantic individuals who think liberalism can be redeemed, and vice versa.  Her own context is the 60s and 70s attacks on liberalism, and seeing it as being resilient and adaptable.

2. Ch.1  Romantic Militarism versus Civil Society

* Romantic militarism poses a threat to liberalism because "[l]iberalism stands for, among other things, security of expectations, civilianism, and peace."  (9)  Romantic militarism contrasts because it holds out "romantic dreams" and a tendency to "imagin[e] war as the prime occasion for perfect freedom and self-expression." (9)  Romantic militarism disregards the military as a bureaucracy "marked by coercion, obediance, and routine." (9)

*  But it's not only about "opposition" because romantic miltiarism can also "appear as a series of exuberant variations on liberal themes." (10)

1) For romantics whose "formative experience" was French Revolution, liberalism was a revolutionary doctrine.  And for them romantic militarism was "perpetual insurrection" that did not end in the creation of a new establishment.  Here "Romantic militarism is an exaggerated echo of a fundamental liberal dilemma--that the ideal of personal freedom can never be fully encompassed by any catalogue of rights and benefits and will always be frustrated by the actualities of even limited government." (10)

2) Romantic miltiarism as opposed to civil society takes asserts a "heroic indvidualism" and in this form it "exploits liberal ideas."  It accepts the emphasis on the individual, but jettisons the "moderate" understanding of the individual as driven by prosaic ambitions.  It replaces "moral autonomy with amoral expressivism." (10)

* She uses Wordsworth's "Convention of Cintra" to illustrate romantic militarism that leads to a desire for revolutionary liberation.  The title is from the armistice the British and French signed to put an end to their conflict in Iberia. For Wordsworth, the war satisfied a desrie for action that would satisfied intense human desires.  So as he sees it "an expedient act of state is transformed into an expression of genius." (11)  What Wordsworth particularly liked was that even after the convention was signed the British and Spanish were "inspired" to fight on--that inspiration was an "intangible" and "spontaneous" force. But Wordsworth's story has a complex relationship to liberalism.  Rosenblum thinks Wordswroth's "Convention" was not--though it could be read this way--a republican warning of the loss of virtue that can occur if a people don't experience threats from without, and thus a part of that civic humanist tradition that saw war as a way to avoid corruption.  (12)  It was for him about "intensity of desire".  (12)  BUT Rosenblum says that "even when inspired, Wordsworth's people preserve the ethos of liberalism. They are r enthusiasm for private individuals united in their enthusiasm for liberty." (12)  So his idealized people she says "are suspicious of government and opposed to tyranny, a nation of men and not citizens..." (13)  So Wordsworth wants his people as R puts it wewll to "love independence, not to use it."  (13)  Wordsworth's version of romantic militarism she says is born of combination of French Revolution, nationalist wars of independence, and the British state which was not centralized or marked by an adminsttrative zeal.

*  She turns to Humboldt whose vision of miltiarism did grew out of the political expeirence of a centralized bureacuratic state.  Therefore "Humboldt is more scrupulous about insulating individuals from government and less sanguine about their capacity for genius."  (14)  Humboldt sees all modern states as "enlightened despotisms" and he views their administrative efficiency as a force that enervates "the free play of personal energies and homogenize individual differences." (14) "German efficiency" causes Humboldt to celebrate citizen-soliders cultivating individuality in war--and so he regrets the dissapearance of war.  But Humboldt is also realistic and he knows that in fact soldiering for the modern state involves some of the most intense forms of homogenization.  So ultimately "Humboldt resigns himself to the view that individuality and spontaneity must be cultivated privately, apart from war." (16)  In doing so, R states that Humboldt "charts a course back to liberalism that will be taken by other romantic sensibilities, moving from the exhuberant dream of heroism to a stern recommendation of private life under limited government. He reconciles himself to legalism and to the pacific private sphere liberalism provides." (16) His The Sphere and Duties of Government she says is the prodcut of this "odyssey".  And in it H presents a theory of the liberal "nightwatchman state"--a small govenrment that simply "provides seecurity against external enemies and a framework of laws to regulate conflict." (16)  It leave the "inner person alone."  (16)  In this way, R notes "[l]imited government and private liberty are transformed into conditions for the development of beautiful individuality." (17)

* Another romantic reaction to liberalism was the push toward "heroism."  Heroism was a response to the move, associated with liberalism, away from "passion" to "interest"--the gradual replacement of the chivalric tradition and the aristocratic ideal of military service with a focus on commercial "interest." (18)  R cites Albert O. Hirschman's The Passions and the Intrests as presenting one version of this narrative.  In this narrative, commerical economies were justified because "money-making activities were rational and benign comparedwith disruptive military service." (18) The reaction to this was one that resurrected "heroism" as an attack on "economic man."  There were different attacks from this angle: repubilcan advocates of civic virtue saw the "military ethos and personal courage" as resistant to corruption and the anciem regime equated heroism with aristocratic honor and nobility and advocated the aristocracy's returnt o power as a "recover natioanl glory." (18)  Romantic heroism was differnet because it had no "concrete and social content"; in fact, it was appealing precisely because it mean "just one thing: unconstrained self-assertion." (19)  "Unlike republican courage and aristocratic service, romantic heroism is opposed not to egoism, but to then arrow selfishness of commerical types." (19)  H notes that the appeal of heroic self assertion is that it "offers proof" of the indivdiual's "inner sense of limitless power." (19) Napolean is the model for e.g Alfred de Vigny. (19-20)  Here too R finds a route back to liberalism: "a romanticism that identifies personal dignity with independence, and independence with extraordinary action, is not as remote from liberal individualism as might seem.  After all, classical liberal thought describes an individualism for the strong.  This is especially true of Locke and Kant, for whom enlightenment requires 'heroic' action, the throwing off of priestly and political authorities and striving for personal independence.  Autonomy demands struggle against tyrrannies on every front and against ingrained habits and prejudices.  Enlightenment is soemthing that can only be done by oneself, not by or for others.  Individuals are not simple beneficiaries of liberty, then, but aggressive personalities who need to assert themselves to win it in the first place." (21)--though R qualifies saying this that liberalism doesn't have the exlusive meanign of being for the strong, and is not so explicitly masuline.  Althought it was historically linked to men, "there is no conceptual barrier to extending [its rights] to women." (21)  And liberalism does always entail "respect for others" -- a "minimum of utiltiarian attention to the general happiness." (21)

* Romantics may also simply "feel aversion to prosaic civil society" without indulging a "compensatory" stance like heroic self-assertion.  She uses alfred de Vigny to illustrate; he ultimately advises "stoic resignation." (22-23).  Then using Mill, who is open to romantic sensibilities and

Part II -- Liberalism and Romanticism at the Margins

ch.3 The Penumbra of Privacy

* another contrasting of liberalosm and romanticism:  "The romantic is always on the verge of extreme privitization...". It resists "conventional engagements and constraints" of public life and seeks detachment as a technique for "self-development, self-expression, and artistic creation..." (59). For liberals on the other hand, "'private' refers to society...", which is created by protecting society from governmentm with civil liberties. (59).  Romantics are less concerned about limiting government's power.  But after the ninetheenth century, these contrasts have lessened.  As a result liberal "rationales for private life have expanded and multiplied, sometimes appropriating romantic perspectives,the notion of private life has emerged as a critical idea on the margins.". (59-60).

* Account of classical liberalism:  separated public from private, as much to create an autonomous public realm as to create autonmous private realm (60), But the public realm had a responsibility to limit the power private groups exercised over individuals.  Hence Madison's pluralism implied access to private groups as well as the capacity to exit. [Interesting re my description of Boas' cosmopolitanism...as requiring both] (60). Neither public or private groups should absorb the individual. At the same time, the individual has no social responsibility--that's why communitarians have critiqued it.  Public authorities create a space in which the individual can pursue happiness, and so long as his actions remain lawful, the individual is not accountable for their consequences. (61)  But this is not total anomie or pure individualism either.  "Private life means life in civil society..." (61).   Liberalism makes possible group membership and group activities that have a public-political significance.  So civil society is an "array of 'partial publics'...". (61). Hobbes and Locke believed that private liberty would promote public discussion and group membership.  It would impact policu and form a "bulwark against Bonapartism, mass politics, and totalitarianism." (62) so R says classical liberalism provided "'public' rationales for private life." (63)

* Free speech is valuable negatively because of "suspicion of government's purpose" etc, but also positively because of its benefits for civil society and its task of monitoring publlic authorities.  (63).

* liberalism evaluates speech in terms of its ability to rationally communicate therefore and not for self-expression.  So attempts to expand free speech rights are not about whether kanguage is "sincere" or "authentic.". (63). The idea that speech is itself good is not a liberal concept.  For Rosenblum it is a mark of the "vulnerability" of liberalism to romantic ideals.  (63)

* But as time has gone on liberls have recognized that there is not only tension between individuals and government, but indeed between individuals and private associations, ie any organized group.  So that the notion of private has started to be identidied with the personal-intimate.  And: "The conflict is no longr between official and unofficial obligations but between the demands of life in society and the felt imperatives of individuality and personal life." (63). As a result then "liberal privacy begins to converge with romantic notions of detachment." (63)

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1056 -1057 Contradictory Def'n of Prof. Identity

But Walkowitz points out that they had contradictory def'n of the professional identity.  "Social workers were encouraged to play traditional nurturing roles, butin the 1920s they also came to believe that they could distinguish their work from that of unpaid volunteers and from women's 'usual' domestic nurturing in the home by becoming 'efficient,' dispassionate 'professionals.' " (1056)    

But this produced gender trouble b/c "To succeed, the Good Mother had to adopt attributes of passionlessness and objectivity generally associated with men, traits that easily allowed others to stereotype her as desexed or androgynous." (1056)

title: Iron Wall: Israel and the Arab World
text:
Notes 10/2015:

 

Shlaim is one of the key "new" revisionist historians. It's significant that this book starts with a statement of his father: "The Jews prayed for a state of their own for two thousand years, and they prayed in vain; did it have to happen in my lifetime?!" Then Shlaim writes in the following sentence: "This book is dedicated to his memory." (pg xvi).

I haven't read his whole account but it seems to me that this speaks volumes about his perspective: a one-rich Iraqi Jew, who lost the position that Jews held in Iraq, and blames that (why?) on Israel. He's rich nonetheless, and has the best education, landing him at Oxford.

The two prefaces are useful. The second, especially, because it traces some of the more recent developments with regard to the revisionist historians, in particular the split inside that group with Benny MOrris now placing more "blame" on the Arabs and the Palestinians. Shlaim disagrees with Morris, but he acknowledges in that summary that the revisionist historians now no longer agree among themselves. (xxiii)

With regard to the current book:

The point of his analysis in the book, he says, is to examine "Israel's policy toward the Arab world." (xxvi). The focus then is on Israel and Isareli thought and behavior.

## Prologue:

A good quick summary of the early zionist leaders: Herzl, Chaim Weizman, Jabotinsky, and Ben Gurion. He seems to like Jabotinsky the most, perhaps because he acknoweldged the problem, although he thinks that Jabotinsky's legacy has not been honored since he also wanted a settlement, and this part has been forgotten or avoided. Perhaps this is why he seems in particular to like Ben Gurion and Weizman who negotiated in a two-faced manner, courting the British and othe rpowers, whilst only appearing to seek a settlement with the Arabs. This is I think a theme of the book.

## 1. The Emergence of Israel

* He asks if the Israelis had an option other than dealing with King Abudullah of Jordan instead of negotiating with the Palestinians after acceptance of the UN Partition plan (UN resolution 181 from 29 Nov 1947). HIs answer is no! Becuase Hajj Amin al-Husseini had lead the Palestinian nationalist movement to an outright hostility toward Zionism that was as strong in the 1940s as it was in the 1930s. (30). This seems like a key moment in the book where he is willing to grant that Israelis were right to make an end run around the Palestianians. -- A rare moment probably.

* Talks about the "popular-heroic-moralistic version of the 1948 war" that is popular and widely taught in Israel. He then challenges it. (36), first by rejecting the idea that the Arabs always had a superior military power; this was not true. RAther, the opposite. Ultimately, Israel fielded more troops (36-37). Secondly, the Arab's war aims wer enot united in opposition to Israel, in a desire to destroy it; rather the Arab countries, and King Abudullah, all had their own aims. So he writes: "Each of the other Arab states were also moved by dynaistic or national iterests, which were hidden behind the fig leaf of securing Palestine for the Palestinians. The inability fo the Arabs to coordinate their diplomatic and military plans was in no small measure responsible for the disaster that overwhelmed them." (37).

* He faults the Israelis in the war after Egypt violated the UN armistice for gaining strategic ground outside the UN partition plans area alotted to Israel. (39).

[It's hard for me to understand in this account how he can blame the Israelis for gaining as much ground as they could. The Holocaust had just occurred; the age of imperial play in the region was not exactly over. He seems to judge them from a standard that at the time was yet to be established, and that today still i sunstable.]

title: How 'Jewish' Was Theatre in Imperial Berlin
text:
General Note 9/19/2013

Jelavich looks at the theatre culture of Imperial Berlin. It was not exclusively Jewish but there was considerable participation among Jews. Otto Brahm, e.g., had found ed the Freie Bühne, in Berlin in 1889. He wanted to put on shows that were free from censorship, so that he could stage "potentially ontroversial" modern plays like those of Ibsen and othe rmodenr playwrights. He organized the theatre as a private "association" in order to avoid the censors. But then teh question is how important was it that Brahm was Jewish since he was not staging explicitly "Jewish" plays?

The answer the Jelavich gives is that it was important, in part because Brahm's theatre was supported by a range of Jewish patrons. And even a police observer in 1894 noted that its vistors were mostly "of Jewish elements." (41) What was going on here? Was there something "Jewish" about the naturalist modern plays that Brahm wanted to stage? Jelavihc's answer is not in terms of content, but in terms of teh kinds of spaces that these Jews were hoping to create. Rather than trying to stage Jewish themes, or on the flip side, to participate in theatre in order to become respectable within the braoder German Biludngsbürgertum, Jelavich argues that what these people were doing was "sponsoring a cultural space that explicitly fostered aesthetic pluralism and experimentation." (42) And this Jelavich argues was these Jewish people's vision of liberalism: "Having been subjected to discrimiatnion for so many geneartions, Berlin's Jews, like their coreligionists in other countries, had a vested interest in supporting a worldview that championed diversity of opinion in politics and in the arts." (42)

Jelavich ties his argument to the Jewish relationship to the concept of Bildung, that was also changing in this period. Jewish emancipation he says had begun in the Napoleonic era and was completed with the Founding of the  German Emprei in 1871. (42) Jewish people in Germany pursued Bildung. Jewish men were disproproraitonaly represented in the German Gymnasia. He notes that in 1906 in Berlin 18 precent of Gymanias sutdents were Jewish, 5x their actual percentage of that state's population. (43) Yet still very few Jews achieved the credentials that they sought: 1895, 65% of Jewis were in trade and commerce and 60% of those were self-employed. (43) So in fact the Jews that hlped shape Berlin's theatre culture were not Bildungsbürger. What shaped this scence then was what Arnold Zweig in his 1928 book Jews on the German stage, was their "unprejeduced attitude toward the new", a phenomeono was not in itself Jewish but rather metropolitan, like what one saw in Paris, London, and Madrid. But Jews had a reason to be this way accroding to Zweig, being newcomters to the German aesthetic tradtion. (43)

For those Bildungsbuerger that were a part of the theatre audience, however, their reaction was wrapped up with the changing cahracter of Bildung:

...even they [the Jewish middle class elemnets] could hardly be considered 'assimilating,' because the notion of Bildung that they embraced had long since mutated in German society at large, as George Mosse has argued. Mosse notes that the 'German culture' that Jews found so attractive was the cosmopolitan vision of the German Enlightenment and of German classicism, which was pluralistic, tolerant, heterogenous, and amdire of 'world culture.' That ideal enviiosned in the eighteenth century, however, became profoundly distorted over the course of Germany's national conslidation in the nineteenth century. The global dimension was lost, and a cnaon of national literature and art was established that excluded foreign elements or nationalized themthrough specious rhetoric, such as the claim that Shakespeaer was actually a German(ic) author. The cosmpolitanism of the eighteenth century gave way to a nineteenth-century project to establish cultural homogeneity: to create a Germa culture that was increasingly coded as patriotic, Christian, xenophobic--and anti-Semitic. Universities, were the royal roads  to bildungsbürgerliche credentials, were at the forefront of that shift. While student fraternities became hotbeds of anti-Semitism, professors created discriminatory cannons of German culture. A decade before the founding of the Freie Bühne, the prominent historian Heinrich von Treitschke of the University of Berlin touched off the "Berlin anti-Semitism debate" with the proclamation: "the Jews are our misfortune" ("die Juden sind unser Unglück"). (43-44)

A tthe same time, he notes that Jews were often denied employmetn in the "official" institutions of higher edcuation and culture: i.e. unis, court theatres, operas, and museums. This experience of antisemeteism, enlightenment (along with zionism) have helped shaped modern Jewish identity. He cites Micahel Meyer's book on that theme. In reaction, he notes, "Jews created new cutlural spheres, open nont only to Jewish participation to but a plurality of styles, including novel and experimenta forms... " (44)

This is the general theme here. And then he provides evidence vv the efforts of Max Reinhardt vv Theatre. He then also shows the realtionshp of this theme to Cabaret culture, which he says would have been "Unthinkable" without Jews. And finally film.

title: Kant and the Experience of Freedom: Essays on Aesthetics and Morality
text:
General Notes

Introduction

* Reference to the way Kant's Critique of the Power of Judgement has been taken up as "the archetypal work of postmodernism, revealing the contradictions inherent in every idea of knowledge, rationality, culture, and art which it has suddenly become so fashionable to discover." (1)

* He wants to show that this is not the case, or rather that Kant was not simply intrested in works of art in terms of a "narrow formalism," despite the seeming centrality of that idea to "certain sections of the opening of the 'Analytics of the Beautiful'..." (2)  He wants to show that it's reductive to present Kant as the "founding father of the idea of 'art for art's sake.'" (2) 

* I think much of Guyer's larger argument here can be summed up in this sentence: "Kant believed in the intrinsic and indepednent value of of aesthetic experience but also in the uniquely unconditional value of morality, or the primacy of practical reason (that is, the use of reason to determine what we ought to do rather than what is the case).  One of my chief purposes in the following essays is to show how Kant tried to make these two beliefs not merely compatibile but interdependent." (2)

title: Anti-Romantic Romanticism: Edward Sapir and the Critique of American Individualism
text: p.006: Notes that the war was not always seen as negative. It was seen also to present certain opportunities. He quotes a statement by the poet Harriet Monroe from Poetry magazine: "At first [war] seems merely a murderous violator, hideously interrupting all the good works of the world...And yet war is a builder. Out of the ruins of eras it tumbles together foundation-stones for new ones." From "What May War Do" Poetry, 10: 142-145.

title: On Creating a Usable Culture: Margaret Mead and the Emergence of American Cosmopolitanism
text:
2. The Problem of American Culture

p. 19.  She sees the years 1909 and 1911 as crcuial for understanding Mead's intellectual influences.  1909 because of Freud's visit to Clark and Croly's publishing of The Promise of American Life.  Then 1911 because of the publishing of Boas' The Mind of Primitive Man.  This she says was the "first time the idea of culture as a distinct lifeways appears in his writing."  (19)  [Is this really true?  The claim needs to be further specififed...I think he makes this point earlier... for example in his article from 1901 by the same title...butt this is certainly more important a text and widely read...]  Also in this year Santayanna gives his lecture "The Genteel Tradition in American Philosophy" and also Bourne's set of essay scollected as "Youth and Life."  Molloy sums up her paragraph with: "The rethinking of America around the idea of culture had begun." (19)

p.19-20: The influence of Freudian theory led to what M. Cowley described as the "Greenwich Village doctrine": "We are unhappy because we are maladjusted, and maladjusted becase we are repressed."  (quoted on 20).  So there was a need to discover "hidden motives" and undo repression.  This gave freedom a new meaning Molloy articles making it something more than "just a political and economic right."  "It now meant health, well-being, 'normalcy." " (21)

p.21-22: She makes good use of Croly's The Promise of American Life.  He's advocating a new relationship between thenation and the individual, challenging the separation betwen the two, enviioning a way in which "each [individual] finds a special niche or function within the nation such that the distinction between national and individual interest disappears and '[t]he individual becomes a nation in miniature,...[and] [t]he nation becomes an enlarged individual." (22)  For this to occur, there needed to be better regulation of political and economic systems so that the intellect could be set free...Croly then founds the New REpublic with money from wealthy liberals including Elsie Clews Parsons. (22) The influence of this organ is at its greatest during the Wilson admin "whne it was regarded by some as an unofficail government organ." (22)

p. 26-27: In Bourne, she quotes Mary Esteve who describes Bourne's notion of the "experimental life" as standing for "nonconformity" on the one hand and also a sober "calm disinterestedness" and "detached enthusiasm"... a kind of "scinetific consciousness quoting born: "to take life not with their naked fists, but more scientifically--to stand with mind and soul alert, ceaselessly testing and criticizing, taking and rejecting, poised for opportunity, and sensitive to all good influences." (26)  Molloy alsothinks Bourne's Trans-National America article also influenced Mead heavily, describing it as a critique of the melting pot.

p. 27-28: Van Wyck Brooks she says saw the "relation betweeen the individual and nation as much more organic."  I.e. she thinks for him it was rooted in a notion of race.  She sums up all three this way: "Where Croly saw the unity of nation and individaul coming out of individual [pursuit of excellence, Brooks saw the relation between individual and nation as much more oranic.  For Brooks, the relationship between individual and society preceded indivdiual choice or activities.  Croly still worked with the idea of the self-made man, the man who shapes and is haped by the events, cutlure, and opportunities America could provide; Brooks foreshadowed the shift to a mroe determined American: one who expresses an inherence 'race.'  Bourne, on the other hand, while valuing 'racial' or 'cultural' difference, was committed to the idea of conversation, between individuals and between cultures."  (28-29)

p.29: She notes in a quote from Casey Blake that all three thinkers used different conceptions of culture, using it both in an Arnoldian and a Boasian sense... (29) Yet there wer also differences.  Bourne criticized the ARnoldian conception in his essay "The Cutl of the Best" in 1916.  Molloy thinks Bourne had "Boasian roots" (29)  Brooks she describes as more "conservative" than Bourne, "more ocncerned with the creation of a unified national culture in which arts and letters could flourish, and perplexed about how that could be achieved in the face of cutlural pluralism in the United States, whereas their ersthle mento, Croly came increasingly to support the repression of cultural difference and the "Americanization" of immigrants." (29)

p. 29: For these critics, "alienation" wasn important theme when describing their realtiuonship to "main street".  The sense of alieantion she asserts had much to do with a sense of "provincialism" to which cosmpolitanism was the alternative.  And she notes that "[a]nthropology, and the devleopment of the idea of culture as way of life, clearly had a role to play in enabling the emergence of cosmopoitanism, providing both the theoretical concepts and the empirical evidence not only for human variety but also for the intrinsic and extrinsic value of other ways of life." (30)  In this desire for cosmpolitanism, howeer, Molloy intelligently picks up on the intellectuals' split attrtaction to the transcendence of "ethnic limitations" on the one hand and yet their sense of "older communitarian ways of life" as model sof "un-alienated life". (30)

p.30: Molloy thinks this "cultural-nationalist" movement was big but short,lasting from 1909 to 1918 more or less.  She gives periodization on 30.  It's at its peak in 1915 and then is broken apart by the war and also by the death of Bourne in 1918.  (31)

p.32...Molloy shifts to Mead, saying "We hqve yet to understand how it is that 'culture' passed into the vernancular during this period, but Margaret Mead was certainly one of the vectors of these ideas."  Mead she said had taken in the ideas of the cultural nationalists. She had discussed Puritanism and American Cutlure with her friends.  (no evidence here).  She submitted an article to Nation entitled "The WAste of theProtocracy" while a masters student in 1924.  She wrote an essay on Bourne's Youth and Life for Benedict and in a letter to B she "regarded him as having won 'real victories over very live and vicious enemies, these battles...with which my gneration has nothing to do, but calmly accepts the fruits of victory." (33)  She also admired the way he was able to in Molloy's words "control his emotional affects 'without theunpelasent deviceds of Electra and Oedipus notions' and that he had 'achieved tolerance and a sense of the place of Puritanism as a rather peurile access to Paganism rather than a veritable menace to be assaulted.'" (33) In general, Mead was exposed to this work Molloy says through the "little magazines." (34)

p.34: Importantly, Molloy argues that as Mead entered college the "Progressive impulse to integrate American arts, economy, and politics into an 'organic whole' had begun to disintegrate." (34)  This coincides she says with a shift away from what Groman calls the "link bewteen lierary-aesthetic and poltiical radicalism" that M thinks characterized the cultural-nationalist movement...and amove toward a purly literary-aesthetic ethos....a "modernism based on formal aesthetic criteria..." (34)  This was a reaction to the post-wwI disillusionment, to the failure of the League of Nation, rampant materialism, and "boosterism" she says.  She sees Freud's writings being used to "support the notion that the cure for what ailed America lay in the individual." (35)  At the same time, she describes a seires of develompents: rising nubmer of college graduates, a book and print culture emerging out of flood of new publishing houses, and the popularity of books like Fitzgerald's This Side of Paradise and S. Lewis' Main STreet.  that indicated she thinks that it wasn't only the "intelligentsia" that was "dissatisfied with the 'genteel tradition'... and that the broader middle class was interested in "getting cultured.  (35-36).  She indicates a growing consciousness that linked being cultured with an awareness and rejection of small-town rural American sensibilities.  (36)  And at the ssame time, she notes the move toward Prohibition and the National Origins Act and Johnson Acts that restricted access to the U.S.  (37)

p.37:  Mead she says was at the middle of all of this.  Boas was ana ctivie opponent of the immigration acts.  And Molloy notes well: "In the hullabaloo about the sexual content of Coming of Age, we are sometimes apt to foret that it was prompted not by concerns abou sex but by concerns about biological determinism." (38)

title: Getting Spliced: Modernism and Sexual Difference
text: p.100-102 Stein, Gender and Modernism Burke explains that this connection between a certain (logopoetic?) mode of modernist writing led to (required?) rethinking gender and sexuality. She points to Stein's sentence "...'a splice is something that causes a connection.'" (quoted on 100). She notes then on 101 that according to Richard Bridgman "when Gertrude Stein spoke of the sentence, she was likely to be making symbolic formulations that referred to human relationship as well as verbal ones.'" (quoted on 101, from Gertrude Stein in Pieces, 197). Burke points out that "splice" was a word used in 19th-century english novels to indicate marriage and she thinks Stein probably was aware of the connection. Her point is that Stein's "formulation of modernist technique--for the splice makes possible one kind of juxtaposition--contains a poetics of gender hidden within its apparently formalist concerns." (101) PUshing futher seh notes that Stein seemed to operate with an "implicit parallel between verbal connectives and the modes of human intercourse..." (101) Burke quotes an account of a discussion with Dashiell Hammett in 1934-34 tour while in California. In this quote, she suggests that there is a vital link between literary representation and gender-sex. She notes that men created many types of men in the 19thcentury and women didn't and that the situation had been reversed in the 20th. Then Burke also quotes her saying "...'literature--creative literature--unconnected with sex is inconceivable,' then observed cautiously 'but not literary sex, because sex is a part of something of which the other parts are not sex at all.'" (101) This literary rep. is connected to gender she expands in her notion of "composition" that she formulated in the course of thinking about modernism. Each generation differed in the "way life is conducted" (uoted on 102) which is "authentically speak, composition." (quoted on 102) She thought that people that lived within a particular "composition" rejected its representation and were not aware of that composition; thus writers that reflected it only came to greatness after their death. But she thought WWI had shifted that: "...'every one became consciously became aware of the existence of the authenticity of the modern composition' [sic]. In fact, the 'war may be said to have advanced a general recognition of the experession of the contemporary composition almost by thirty years.'" (102) Burke writes: "Since Stein's account of this 'modern composition' includes the patterns of relationships of those who live within it, we may assume that these comprise the patterns of connections evoked in G.M.P and celebrated in Tender Buttons...Moreover, Stein's phrase implies a parallel between what we no wcall the culture of an era and the way in which the people of that era write: the cultural 'composition' of a given society is reflected in the formal structures of its literary 'compositions.'" (102) Note: c.f. with Jameson's idea that modernism vs. post-modernism reflecting shifting social, political, economic circumstances.

title: The Victorian Connection
text: p. 86-88 Liberalism and the Victorian Connection Hall points out that "Victorian liberalism was tempered by the awareness of the dangers inherent in democracy, and by a preference or experience over any doctrinaire scheme." (86) Hall argues that many Victorian liberals found the right balance in Mill who had drawn upon Coleredige and Bentham. Mill was popular, and also in the U.S. He was exelcted a "corresponding member" of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in 1857. Frederick Law Olmsted's dedicated his The Cotton Kingdom (1861) to him; he communicated with Americans Chauncey Wright and Charles Norton. He was sseen as a "prophet" by a number of young men, e.g. E.L. Godkin and John Morley who respectively began the Nation in 1865 andthe Fortnightly Reviewin 1867. (86) Specific connections: liberal-minded English visistiors that visited the U.S. to see for themselves the success of the "American experiment" made connections with members of the Cambridge-Boston group. E.g. Godkin who stayed in the US. became friends with Lowell, Norton and the Jameses in Boston and Olmsted, George Ripley and George William Curtis in New York. Goldwin Smith came in 1864 and was greeted by Norton who description of him is revealing on 86-87. Hall thinks Charles Eliot Norton very important in the "transatlantic network." (87) He had inhereted ties to Unitarians in both the United States and Britain fro mhis family. He edited with Lowell the Norrth American Review. "Norton aw the need for another kind of periodical to teach liberalism, and his support enabled the Nation to be founded." (87) He belonged to a cosmpolitan community of the "best men" Hall says, and Hall also stresses that this community did not (yet) enjoy culturla hegemony.. Hegemony was still primarily in the hands of the evangelicals and the entrepreneurs he says (87-88) He notes that The Atlantic MonthLY which "flew proudly the flag of humanism" under the leadership of Howells would not run a story of Mark Twains for fear of alienating religious-evangelical readers.. (88)

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text:
p. 494 - 8   Boas' Textual Authority

-- Boas tried to validate Hunt's writings, but not via Hunt as an "individual."  Boas appears to downplay or even hide details about Hunt's identity.  (494)  

-- It is possible that Boas obscured Hunt's role to protect Hunt from laws forbidding participation in certain ceremonies. (495)

-- Boas enacted as set of "erasures" which hid the "complexity of life in Fort Ruper as well as the embeddedness of the texts in white-Native American relations." (495)  This was what they would call a "detextualization" of the production of the text and they note that since Boas excluded Hunt's own accounts  of wher eand how he acquired texts, that "Boas...retained control over the metadiscursive practices tha shped its authority." (495) 

-- Boas also noted furstration with the problem that the texts came from Hunt alone.  This raised questions about whether these texts reflected an individual or a tribal ivew point.  Boas tried to re-request certain texts or to confirm them with his own fieldwork, and when confirmed the authors note that boas "minimized the textual gaps" between repeated accounts. (496)  

-- Boas also resisted the attempts of Henry W. Tate to excercise his own metadiscursive authority...when Boas realized through comparing his texts with those collected by Tate, that TAte had as Boas put it "felt it incumbent upon himself to omit some of those traits of the myths of his poele that seem inappropriate to us, and there is no doubt that in this respect the tales do not quite express the odl type of Tsimshian traditions." (quoted on 496, from p.31 Tsimshian Mythology).  Boas was however more troubled when he realized that Tate had begun to read collections of tales that he had already published.  Boas wrote then: "...I called his attention at once to the necessity of keeping strictly to the form in which the traditions are told by the Tsimshian." (quoted on 496, from "Tsimshian Mythology" in Thirty-First Annual Report of the Bureau of American Ethnology
(Washington, D.C., 1916), 291037. p. 31)  But Boas did not have the same concerns when Hunt read colelctions (496) Still Boas resisted Hunt's attempts to excercise an authorial metadiscursive control.. (496-7)

-- Boas justification of resisting his informants metadiscursive control came from his ability to confirm and cross-check the accuracy of informatoin he receieved, and in his writing o fthe preface of collections of stories.  Therefore co-authoring did not necessarily mean that boas shared authorial control (497-8)

title: Liberalism Repatriated: Prospects of an Anthropology of Antiracism
text:
p. 334 Boasians as Progressive critqiues of racism

A line linking into the historiography of Boasians as critiques of racism: "Even once this biologistic version of race theory came under fire from progressive strands in the human sciences, namely Boasian anthropologists, racial difference came to mean immanent cultural difference." (333-334)  

I.e. He's traces racism from civilization v. kultur to biological racism...and puts Boas in conflict with this traditoin.

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text:
p. 505- 6 - the Critique
