The critique here is this: "Boas's framework could have provided him with a basis ffrom which to collect narratives that documented ongoing struggles by Native American communities for survival, certain types of narratives, exhorations, and ht like are grossly underplayed in the extant corpus.  The broader issue here invovles not only selectivity but the political effects of using metadiscursive practices that systematically sever connections between texts and the complex historical circumstances in which they were collected.  Boas's genuine concern for invovling Native Americans in the process of etnographic documentation and for seeing indigenous communities through indigenous lenses did not induce him to surrender control over the metadiscursive practices that shaped the production and reception of texts." (505-506)

title: Historiography and Enlightenment
text:
[Summary Card]
This essay by Pocock is a review/response to John Robertson's The Case for the Enlightenment: Scotland and Naples, 1680-1760.  Robertson's book apparently refers to what Pocock calls a "friendly debate" between a view of the  Enlightenment as a single process taking place in a number of places and a view that , in Pocock's words, "reduces it to a family of distinnguishable processes taking place in a number of historical contexts--some of which, horrible dictu, were national and provided by nation states--with the result that there ceases to be any such thing as 'the Enlightenment'...".  
What Pocock does in the article is distinguish a separate process that is deserving of the title of enlightenment but which is not the process described by Robertson.  The process he describes is one carried out mostly by historians and which deals with a challenge to the sacred authority of the church by anlayzing the historiography of philosophy wherein the attempts by humans to understand how Word of God was made Flesh in Jesus Christ are seen as a struggle fo humans with language.  This has the effect of removing the sacred quality of theology and seeing it instead as history.  This is a process of Enlightenment Pocock says, and it is one that Robertson's history, which deals with philosophers attempts to conceptualize the growth of human civil society through stages, does not deal with at all.
Pocock then goes on to argue that the presence of this alternate process, which he admits converges at points with the philsophers' Enlightenment, means that Robertson cannot term his Enlightenment "the Enlightenment."  
There are many things about this account that I find useful.  The main thing at this point is, in the writing of my "War Chapter," that this article could be cited in as evidence for the claim that there was a notion of historical advancement and progress that was conceivable within a historiographical tradition, and which was carried out in England!  Thus this is an artilce that helps to establish that within England and other nations associated with natural philosophy, there was also a strong and important tradition of historical thought ongoing...

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text: p.190-1 Four-Field Humanity Mead's Types elaborated in this Squares Theory. First focused on Male and Female. or Northern and Southerner. There were many diagrams. But Sullivan thinks that there were no particular general meanings ass. with these directions. In "summary Statement" Mead also talks about fey and Turk. These types were not opposites they she said to her sister Elizabeth Stieg "have a great deal in comoon with each other' while also 'being antithetical'" (191) She sought to create psych tests for this (191-2) had to do with sadism and masochism. In "Summary Statmeent" she these types in terms of reaction to suffering. She writes in commentary for Rapaport ( see Lib. Congress S11:7) that "These two positions [North and South] are reciprocals on the 'sado-masochisticic' axis, that is those in the N[orthern] position can laugh at a joke about cruelty, but can not face a real situation of suffering [while] those in the S[outhern] positon seen othing to laugh about in the jokes about cruelty, but see the real situation clearly and without defenses exception soometimes a grimace and nervous laugh." (192) The East-West axis on the other hand was different. Dealt with " "unreality or reality of events" . That means also that as Mead said (again in letter to Rappaport) about relations between "onself and other people"...or as she said to sister "If Northerners and Southerners deal with things, it si primarily as symbolic of relationships". (quoted on 193) East-West axis about "relatoins between oneself and the universe qua universe, or the wider-than-merley human world, 'rathe than the self and other human beings.' ((193)
