title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.031 Sklanksy's defense of political economy

As a conclusion to chapter 1, Sklansky notes that political economy in the next step of his book will be seen to provoke a Romantic critique of classical political economy.  But he states here already that its view of "economic man as a soulless autonomaton" was "grossly caricatured" (31)  Then he lays out a defense of classical political economy:

He acknowledges that the notion of the autonomos self-governing individual (with a rational will and ability to labor) was tied to notions of white male supremacy and privilege.  But he gives a nod to the idea that this "radically egalitarian understanding of human nature and society" exceeded the limits of classical political eocnomy: "If political economy concealed essential aspects of social life, it also revealed the material basis of 'commerical society' in ways that proved more effective in inciting rebellion than in promoting the harmony and stability of the new social order." (31)

So two things 1) Sklansky seems to like classical political economy because it promoted class-consicous politics and undermined itself.  2) It's because classical political economy undermined itself that a new social science was needed which began with these Romantic critiques of classical political economy...

title: Culture: The Anthropologist's Account
text:
p. x-xi  Kuper thinks the word culture should be avoided.  The point of this book.

"...the more one considers the best modern work on culture by anthropologists, the more advisable it must appear to avoid the hyper-referential word altogether, and to talk more precisely of knowledge, or belief, or art, or technology, or tradition, or even of ideology (though similar problems are raised by that multivalent concept).  There are fundamental epistemological problems, and these cannot be solved by tiptoeing around the notion of culture, or by refining definitions.  The difficulties become most acute when...culture shift from something to be described, interpreted, even perhaps explained, and is treated instead as a source of explanation itself...appeals to culture can offer only a partial explanation of why people think and behave as they do, and of what causes them to alter their ways.  Political and economic forces, social institutions, and biological processes cannot be wished away, or assimilated to systems of knowledge and belief."  (x-xi)

title: The Politics of Sex and Gender: Benhabib and Butler Debate Subjectivity
text:
Notes 7/10/10:

Webster analyzes a debate between Seyla Benhabib and Judith Butler about subjectivity and selfhood the political subject of feminism.  The question at the center of the essay is the idea of a crisis in feminist theory relating to the sense that the categories of sex and gender have become so complex and unstable that they no longer serve as a useful basis for feminist politics or for "women's agency" more specifically.  Webster purports to undestands to be at work in so-called postmodern theory" and then at Butler's notion of performative agency.

Benhabib along with other feminists cited in fn#2 have critiqued postmodern theory for creating a "identity crisis" for feminism.  Webster says that Benhabib thinks that postmodernism in its "strong form" (?) "promotes a dissolution of the subject which in turn dissolves the concepts of intentionallity, accountability, self-reflexivity and autonomy." (3) The autonomous suject is then repalced with a "fractured, opaque self." (3)  Benhabib thinks this is problematic for women in particular, given that their subject position and autonomy in western society is already weak.

Butler's performative conception of agency is laid out in Gender Trouble.  Webster defines it this way: "...gender is performative...in the sense that it it is not a stable or fixed point of agency, but rather is an identity category created and constituted through 'a stylized repetition of acts.'  Its meaning is constituted dramatically and contingently through sustained social performances which take place in the context of the regulatory conventions and norms dominant in society.  The ultimate effect of these repeated performances is an appearance of substance, an appearance of gender as a natural expression of particular bodies.  This repeition rigidifies and institutionalizes gender.  At the same time, the very activity of this repetition of norms suggets for Butler the possibility that those norms can be subverted.  Indeed, it is precisely in this variation in the way in which subjects actively repeat norms that Butler locates agency." (4)

Benhabib's critique of Butler's critique of agency targets the "sorts of social research paradigms" that Butler uses.  She says that in her words Butler "still presupposes a remarkably deterministic view of individuation and socialization processes whcih falls short of the currently available social-scientific refletions on the subject." (quoted on 4).  She thinks basically that Butler grants too much power to culture and too little power to individuals (i.e. Butler is essentially too Foucaultian.) Second, Benhabib critiques Butler's account of agency because it, again in her words, "wants to extend the limits of reflexivity in thinking about the self beyond the dichotomy of 'sex' and 'gender.'" (quoted on 5)  The problem is that Butler wants to locate agency "beyond" the binary sex/gender dichotomy. Butler understands sex as "always already gender" (5), i.e. sex does not "pre-exist gender." (5)  In Situating the Selfi, Benhabib would agree that sex is not just anatomical; the definition of sex is for her also, in her words, "a social and historical process...Sex and gender are not related to each other as nature to culture." (quoted on 5).  But she dislikes Butler's use of performativity because it cannot "do justice to the complexities of the ontogenetic origins of gender in the human person." (B qutoed on 5) It doesn't give an adequate account in her mind of the "strutural and developmental processes which are in fact involvedin individual socialization..." (6) and it doesn't account of the "capacities individuals possess for som degree of self-determination." (6)

So there is a point of stand off here.  Butler in her words wants to say "there is no ontologically intact reflexivity to the subject which is then placed within a cultural context..." (6).  That conclusion meanwhile is exactly waht Benhabib is trying to resist.  She talks about "ontogenetic origins" of gender and says Butler doens't account for them.  Yet importantly Benhabib is not positing an "autonomous" self that acts outside of its cutlural context.  She argues that "subjects have the capacity to to challenge their 'situatedness,' to contribute to the constitution of their own identity and to their own place in the world..." (6)  Reflexivity is an important word for her. On another level, Webster notes, Benhabib also wonders whether it is necessary to dissolve concepts of agency, autonomy, and selfhood in order to challenge the "heterosexist and dualist positions in the women's movement"; i.e. does Butler "need" to take such a radical position.

Butler's response.  Butler doesn't think feminism needs a stable subject.  She thinks there is a "specific version of politics" available by recognizing the instability of such categories: "...the character of the political arena is itself brought into question once the premises upon which it is based (premises such as the very 'stability' or 'unity' of the subject) are shown to be problematic." (7) i.e. Butler wonders what kind of political domain wold neccesitate a stable female subject in order to actualize women's agency?

Most importantly, Butler's concept of agency: Butler rejects Simone de Beuavoir's sex/gender distinction "on the grounds that it presupposes an account of the subjet at some point 'free' from gender and as capable of deliberately 'taking up' their gender."  For Butler, there  is no "doer behind the deed"--an idea which she says is built into liberal formulations of agency, which likes to assign "blame and accountability." (8).  The "doer" for Butler is instead constituted by the "deed."  But this does nto disallow agency she does not think.  It is precisely because the "subject is the site of endless transformation that and resignification" that resistance and therefore agency is possible.  Butler thinks that Benhabib misunderstands her theory of performativity, in her words, by "grammatically reinstalling the subject 'behind' the deed, and by reducing...the notion of performativity to theatrical performance." (quoted on 8).

Their difference conceptions of the poltiical domain is also a critical difference: Butler challenges the idea that political life has certain norms or requirements, whereas Benhabib talksabout the "importance of striving toward autonomy as an ideal in political life." (9)

Webster wonders whether Butler's conception fo the political domain offers any "programmatic" assistance ot the feminist movement, and thinks that there are real limits there.  This is where others, like Susan Hekman, have critiqued Butler for giving up "the basis for a feminist politics." (i.e. see Hekman, "Subjects and Agents: The Question for Feminism" in Provoking agents: Gender and agency in theory and practice, ed. Gardiner (1995).  Webster pinpoints Butler's sense that the category of woman is constantly being reconstructed, and is a site of contest.  Apparently, Butler takes this in part of Slovoj Zizek's idea that political signifiers are "empty signs which come to bear phantasmic investment of various kinds..."

[Note: It seems clear to me that in fact feminism has made much "programmatic" use out of the idea that the notion of woman cannot be defined...I mean really this goes back to the historical debate that cropped up after the 19th Ammendment, this idea that women shouldn't push for ERA because this would undermine the specific rights they had gained for women, as such...]

Webster rightly notes that Butler's critique interprets agency as "resistance," whereas Benhabib and Beauvoir deifne it as a capacity for generating intentional effects. (11, bottom).  Webster summarizes the different positions on bottom of 11 too.

title: Conspicuous Criticism: Tradition, the Individual, and Culture in American Social Thought, from Veblen to Mills
text:
# General Notes: 1/2013

## Introduction

* Shannon links culture to a way of thinking and “being in the world” (xii) that set reason against tradition. His aim? To describe culture as an extension of that point of view inward, onto our “souls,” in order to expose them to rationality and objectivity. In the very first paragraph of the book he talks about wanting to question the “larger social-scientific project of the rational control of society.” (ix) I’m into that, but I (1) don’t do it in order to defend a relationship to the soul contained in Catholic theology, however subtle (Shannon I think is catholic, although he doesnt’ give this away in his book) and (2) because I would narrate the link between culture and Cartesian radical doubt differently. Culture, in my account, is a way to describe a different self...

 

* Very revealing sentence (when combined with a statement earlier that he’s not providing “a causal account so much as an account of causality” (xi)):

 

>Freed from preconceptions as to any “natural” order, Cartesian philosophy saw man creating order by analyzing nature into its constituent parts and synthesizing those parts into a causal order capable of being redirected toward chosen ends. With nature reduced to the mechanical laws of cause and effect, the limits of the possible stood as the only objective limits on human desire.” (xi)

 

* He sees Cartesianism a bit like Adorno and Horkheimer as reducing nature to a mechanistic and atomizing gaze, but then he also combines it with a sense of a human desire that has lost all limiting norms. He’s the Catholic Adorno and Horkheimer!

 

* He sees cultural thought, like all social scientific thought, as complicit or basically carrying out the same basic function as capitalism, which is to expose more and more of life to control and manipulation by human desire; the emphasis on a human desire out of control in this regard is important because it is also what links social scientific thought to capitalism; one can easily see how in his mind the Enlightenment freed human desire to rationalize human existence, which then capitalism has hitched to mechanisms of value production and in commercial society also the production of desire itself. (See e.g. xii-xii)

 

* He even refers to “the moral anarchy latent in the social-scientific instrumentalization of all social relations.” (xiii), saying that "American intellectuals have struggled" with it. (xiii) And he says they've had two responses: 1) segregation, i.e. exempting certain domains of life from the "instrumental logic of the market", i.e. the doctrine of "separate spheres" for men and women. (xiii); or 2) (which is the mainstream of social-scientific thought, he thinks) the "strategy of integration" through which the "dynamic isntrumentalizatino of values" is itself taken as a a "value capable of rpomoting social order if proeprtly extended to every aspect of life." And this is impulse is what he thinks has led to the idea of "culture as a whole way of life." (xiii)

 

* He says this strategy of integration took shape with Veblen's 1899 *Theory of the Leisure Class*. (xiii-ix), which  he thinks is interesting because of its economic approach to culture (rather than the other way around). He means the way Veblen viewed things like leisure, religion, marrtiage, etc (ie cultural activiteis) as extra and the basis of "invidious comparison" and "pecuniary manipulation" and so on. Veblen he says had a notion of "primary utility" that had to do with industrial relations, which somehow Veblen he thinks like to an idea of the "fullness of life of the indivudal, taken in absolute terms." (Veblen, quoted xiv). Shannon's problem with this is not only that Veblen took such a narrow view of the individual vv cultural activities, but also his relentless critique that sought to define the individual in "absolute terms." He says this tradition of critiuqe is **conspicuous** because it has failed to "acknowledge or articulate a normative order in which such a goal [achieving the fullness of life of the indivdiual] could have any meaning." (xiv)

 

* He then jumps to culture cncept. The idea of a "pattern of values" he says indicated "a kind of normative ordering principle", but then he says that culture "remained an objective social whole with no power over the inquiring subject." (xiv) [Here, I see what he means vv the idea that culture's were treated as objectivities -- judgement withheld -- but not that these entities were seen as having no power over individuals; a cultural enttity could not exist but for its ability to power (or empower) individuals recreate the pattern of values.]

 

* The next paragraph clarifies even more what he does not like. The relationship between autonomous subject and "objective social whole" that the cutlure concept points up becomes in modern life a "substitute for the constitutive relations of tradition that united subject and object in premodern thought." (xiv) So he's nostalgic or desirous of tradition that sustains the unified self; i.e. true autonomy for him requires tradition, and not critical doubt.

 

* This previous point : culture -> uproots traditon -> uproots the unity of subject object then forms a chiasmus with capitalism. So this social-scientific tradition of "conspicuous criticism" is complicit with capitalism because both are committed to "the critical project of uprooting all received traditons." So: social-scientific tradition destroys traditon: destroyed tradition opens society to the instrumetnal logic of the market. (xiv) The problem is then not consumption but in fact the producer ideal that goes much deeper; notions of "work ethic" or "workmanhship." (xiv) In the domain of poltiical economy has "served as a single standard of instruemtnality hostile to all normative ordering principles and proximate ends or values." (xiv) And historically he thinks it was a substitute for "the mediating rites and devotional practices of the Catholic Church" for Protestants who used it to find a way to connect their lives to God "through an abstract, personal discipline that could be cultivated in the everyday world of work and famiily." (xv)

 

* As an alternate notion of critique, he assciates himself with the "Roman Catholic instisnce that reaeson, belief, and even unblief make sense only in the context of osme received tradition of inquiry." (xv) He says of this kind of critique that it is not "free or open" but involves "submission" to the "community of knowers" and also that "its end is to some degree always present in its beginning." (xv)  This last point seems important as one objection he has to the critical tradition he wants to critique is that it is always trying to revise and reinterpret so as to get "beyond" the critique that came before (179); in the process it genereates a whole mess of relations of facts and interpretations that create a kind of "waste" also -- and here he jabs at Veblen for having critique conspicuous consumption and also this is what he menas by conspicuous criticism -- that it is wasteful. (ssee xiv, 179).

 

## 5. Culture for What?

 

> Note: This chapter is where Shannon really rolls out his sense of culture as a key category through which the social-scientific ethos that he's describing really achieves its reimagining of social life as "culture."

 

* What is culture for he thinks? In the 1930s he thinks there is a shift from seeing culture as a "tool for objective analysis to seeing the idea of culture as itself a normative ording principle for social life." He says this shift reached its "culmination" in Lynd's 1939 *Knowledge for What?*. (105)

 

* He says for instance that for Lynd culture is not so much a rational technocratic order as a "reality principle": "For Lynd, culture serves not so much as a principle of order as a reality principle that smashes accepted theory." (107)

* There is a complexity to the realtionship between the individual and culture in his analysis. But the notion of the self that is being developed he thinks is based on that of the social scientists:

> ...the stakes of agency shift from having motivations -- or perhapsit is safer to say having reasons for one's actions -- to explaining reasons and motivations. If people make culture, so, too, culture makes people; to be a conscious person one must be able to see oneself in a causal chain in whcih one is both cause and effect. To be a person, one must become a social scientist, on the boundaries of one's own culture, transgressing cultural norms." (110)

* Shannon thinks that as part of this use of culture, the social scientists is given access to the domain of values, but at the same time this access is premised ona  suspicion of traditional values, and a desire to bring those values "down to earth" and reduce them to "cravings." (110-111, esp. 111, top of the page)

* A key passage here is 113, the full paragraph, where Shannon finally lets loose his critique of Lynd's vision of culture. The social sceintists he says gets full access to domains of the self that had previouly not been attended to, to thumb-sucking or bed-wetting. The point being that the individual should start to see themselves as a mere effect, a conscience of themselves as being a point in a long chain of causality, that should offer the opportunity to control and liberate, that is a kind of democratic control. [Ultiamtely, what he's targeting here is social control, it seems to me; so his frame is accurate but too narrow...] Thus the educated citizen is really the one that is basically a asocial scientist him or herself. He notes "Witness in our own time, how the most successful products of drug rehabilitation programs tend to become counceslors themsevles.) (113)

* For Lynd the problem in all of this is that there is a kind of distinction enforced upon the population where only certain people get access to expesnsive specilized services, and what he wants is a universalization of social science. (113)

* But Shannon does not want to join others who have accussed Lynd of sliding into a technocratic view with this book. He thinks that's not the poitn. The point is the conception of agency that Lynd was developiong, whcih linked up with that of Veblen and Benedict. The point here is "The opening up of all aspects of life to social-scientific inquire signals not a surrender to techocratic domination but a surrender of one's previously causal attitude toward one's own life." (114)

* In this surrender, what is being forced out is a form of self-regulation that was adapted to the market, for a kind of self-regulation in the social-scientific mode. BUT he argues that this shift obscures the deeper continuity, for social science also embodies a laissez-faire attitue he notes in its all-out assault on traditional restrictions. (115) He notes the "separate spheres" idea of the nineteenth-century marked out a limit to the market principle; but in Lynd he sees a total invasion of this domain. He writes: "It is as if the market had experienced a failure of nerve in its assault on tradition, with only social science left to take up the fight." (115)

> Note: Here is where a Polanyian critique totally supercedes Shannon's critique. Because it allows us to think about this invasion of the domain of social protection in different terms, even though it does retain (as Fraser has noted) a degree of Shannon's essentialism.

* He sums up his view again on 116 in a way that gets at the thrus of the critique: "This public experiences the bracking of all assumptions, the detachment fromall loyalties not voluntarily entered into, and the relenteless examination of every aspect of one's life as liberation. This public has everything to gain from the ascendency fo th social-scientific worldivew of *Knowledge for What?*, a worldview that demands only that everyone submit to the discipline of becoming self-creating individuals." (116)

 

 

 

 

 

 

## Conclusion

 

* He critiques a culture of irony, or a "capitulation to irony" that has emerged from the tradition of critique (tied to a "Critical Ideal").  Mill is one apotheosis of thsi tradition. Rorty's postmodernist bourgeois liberalism also. The focus in this tradition is on "maximum material prosperity for all combined with an 'aestheticized culture' of self-creating individuals." (176) Here he has a sharp critique:

> This schizophrenic consensus on social meliorism and philosophic nihilism would have people shuttle back and forth between a practical quest for certainty in their 'public,' social lives,a nd an equally practical rejection of all certtainty in their 'private,' individual lives. Acceptance of this schizophrenia then stands as the mark of a mature responsible, ironic self. (176-177)

 

* He then just says that he hates this "culture of irony" and that for those committed to it he has "northing more to say." (177) He is interested in engaging "premodern thought in an attempt to live within some kind of nonironic social and intellectual world..." (177) To get at this he will look at some antimodern critiques of the Enlightenment, the work of Christopher Lasche, aqnd then also the philsophy of Hannah Arrendt which he thinks might provide a useful philosohpical jumping off piont..." (177)

 

* Before getting into these attempts, he does a bit more criticla clearing. He wants to debunk "modernity's self-proclaimed monpoly on complexity and uncertainty." (177) He targets Dewey's Quest for Certainty essay, which he thinks misreads history and creates a narrative within which present is more mature than primitive or immature past in that it is "tolerant of ambiguity  rather than demanding clarity." (177) This reading he says treats premodern thought arrogantly as "imperfect versions of modern science, as if modern and premodern thought were somehow commensurable due to a common concern for controlling nature." (177) He'll admit that premodern thought that was directed at control was not particularly great, but what this account misses are those parts of premodern thought not directed at control that moderns he thinks either don't udnerstand or don't care to. (177-178) Here then is an atlernative notion of "complexity," -- this area that premodern thought addressed well he seems to think. He develops it with Roberto Unger's ideas on 178. It has to do with ambiguity of meaning as a "central trope" of the "ancient humanistic arts" -- aprocess that was without end etc... Basically, eh presents this as a more complex treatment of the hermeneutic circle, one that does not need to clearly distincguish between "description or evalution"...and this goes back to his point in the intro about a form of criqiue that is embedded in a tradition, and the point of which is already present at the beginning.

 

* This point of view that he ddescribes on 178, he then contrasts with the modern social scientific one, that he gets at in part by looking at the sociology of religion, which is always trying to separate the object (religion) from the description (the scientists, and the science). This creates a radical self-reflexivity and a "suspicion of the very process of studying the object..." (179)  ther eis a suspicion he says not just of the non (or pre) theoretical but also of the past theoretical, ie preivous theories. And so it sets up a process of revision, "a refinement of method that incorporates and explains both a greater number of facts and a greater number of relations between facts in such a way as to make previous accounts obsolete." (179) WHEREAS his version of critique rooted in "moral community" avoids this by assuming a "tautology of tradition" as a preconditino for critiique, for knowing anything at all." (179) So one should submit to this tradition and thereby gain the capacityto think and critique. In his case, this means sumbmitting to Catholic tradition and to the "priority of the moral community as a guarantor of rationalty" (180). It also means he says submitting in order to become a certain kind fo person that can think. (179). The modern social-scientific tradition, he thinks, in rejecting this ideaq and turning to 'epistemology" has "fostered a social ideal of an isoalted individual consciousness as exsiting somehow prior to or apart form a community of inquiry..." (180)

 

[Note: There seems to be a big mistake in his account, or soemthign his missing from his account of modernity. Because the professions do in fact involve the process of submission he's talking about. It's INCREDIBLY relevant that, as I show in my book, the anthropologists associated culture with the professions. So he's just wrong there. But it's also relevant that the last part of his argument in the previous bullet point, that the turn to epistemology involved the positing of an isolated consciousness that is prior to the community...well that is true of Cartesianism, but not of Dewey or James or the kind of modern scientism that developed at the end of the nineteenth century. So he's kind of setting up a straw man of modern thought/cutlure here, which is not surprising given his catholicism. The point is that he doesn't want just any normative order: he wants a Catholic normative order!]

 

* VV the indvidiual and culture. The positing of an isolated consciousness he thinks has shifted the attention away from the "tautology of community to the soilipsism of the indiuvidual." (180) This solipsism has been created by the "initial braceting of all traditions, beliefs, and 'social conditions'" (180) and it has then been renered positively as "autonomy" (whereas he thinks real autonomy comes from being embedded in tradition, which secures as he said in the intro the unity of subject and object). Modern social though tthen also pictureed a "rational social order" named the "social whole" that has he says "been a substitute for the premodern notion of tradition" (180), but this ideal of the social whole has ever been elusive since it was set up in the 18th century. In the U.s., the idea of "community" emerged as an alternative to the market; then culture in the 20th century as an alternative to the "potentially alientating social whole of bureacuracy." (180). On culture:

> At its height in the 'consensus' era of the 1950s, the idea of cutlure as a whole way of life promised to synthesize tradition (necessity) and the individual (freedom). Culture has since proven itself to be yet another objective social whole engaged in a  ceaseless dialectical struggle with autonomous subjects." (180)

 

[Note: this take on culture is useful and clever. It's useful because it confirms my feeling that I need to have last chapter that looks at culture in this moment of "consensus" . Also vv his critique, it is clever because he saw through what I think is true, that some of these 50s social scientists using the concept did treat it as a kind of ideal linking up of tradition and freedom. Parsons may be the best soruce here (and also interesting to consider how Habermas is figuring in, given that you can here echoes of life-/systems-world themes here). But he's right! That what it did produce in the end was just more dialectical struggle, only that is GOOOOOOD!! in my book.]

 

# Chapter 1 - The Perspective of Workmanship

 

* This chapter presents a very interesting interpretation of Veblen, that focuses in particularly on his book the *Instinct of Workmanship*. The point Shannon wants to make is that contrary to most accounts who have interpreted Veblen as someone who critiqued consumerist society in favor of production, whilst unwittingly defending technocracy, Shannon things this critique misses the point of his work. He presents Veblen's account of history from the point of view of workmanship. Indeed, Veblen does celebrate the handworker in the guild context, but he's optimistic about the transitional moment of the present. The key when it comes to Veblen's interpretation of modernity is his notion of a machine age and the machine process, but the point here is not the machine, but the machine as metaphor: the machine as a metaphor for a kind of process and mentality that in Shannon's reading involves a kind of "iconoclastic" individual. That is, Veblen's worker is not a conformist, but rather is conforming to a kind of iconoclastic social type, a type who is not a passive actor but who is a "creative participant" in the wokr process. This is the "discipline of thought," as Veblen terms it, that the machine represents. (see esp. 18-21). For Shannon, what is mean by "culture" is this machine "discipline of thought" in which the iconoclastic worker is participating, see his substitution on 21 of culture for "mechanical process" in the quote first presented on 20.

 

* This sets up Shannon's difference with other interpreters of progressivism. He notes that the theme that is consistent between Veblen and thinkers like Dewey or Jane Addams is that of giving "the worker a sense of his place in the whole process." (22) That of course is what Veblen means by the idea of the iconoclastic "creative participant" worker. (see quotes on 20). This theme has led interpreters to interpret progressives either as emphasizing a "demcoratic" inclusion of the worker in the work process, or a kind of technocratic "therapeutic" industrial psychology. Both interpretations mistake these thinkers for talking about "actual jobs," whereas he thinks they were emphasizing a certain mentality, a "perception of a process," a way of thinking about "work as a process that has a history, that has developed over time, and that has certain distinct stages." (22) He talks about Addams' workers museum. The *Instinct of Workmanship*he points out is itself an embodiment of this machine process mentality.   To put it very clearly, he says, the "potentialities" that are consistent with the machine process are " the iconoclastic habit of mind and the matter-of-fact apprehnension of men and things." (22)

 

* The link between workers and intellectuals is based on this iconoclasm: "The interdependence fostered by the modern machine process binds workers and intellectuals together not by allowing for technocratic manipulation of wokeres by intelelctuals but by spreading the single standard of critical thinking to every social class." (23)

 

* Shannon the ends his chapter -- appropriately but also somewhat bizarely -- with a discussion of Veblen's essay on "The Intellectual Pre-Eminence of Jews in Modern Europe," an essay that emphasizes the way Jews have reached their cultural preeminence through their embrace of hybridity -- hybridity is a principle that Veblen himself celebrates and that Shannon discusses earlier in the chapter, see 6-7. For VEblen, Shannon says, it is the boundary crossing -- the hybridity -- that creates the skeptical frame of mind. His account of this frame of mind is pretty sneering, and even verges on the old antisemetic trope -- the destructive criticism of the jew is the same destructiveness of capitalism:

> Such an understanding of the world, however, issues in alienation from the world. The outsider/intellectual "becomes a disturber of the way intellectual peace, but only t the cost of becoming an intellectual way-faring man, a wanderer in the intellectual no-man's-land, seeking another place to rest, farther along the road, somewhere over the horizon. The are neither a complaistant nor a contended lot, these aliens of the uneasy feet; but that is, after all, not the point in question." (IPJE," 22). What is the point in question? Simply the constant intellectual wandering that is criticism. Critiism may liberate, or it may alienate, but it  must be free to wander, and in that wandering be free to uproot any tradition it may find. With criticism, as with capitalism, all that is solid melts into the air. (25)

 

* Shannon sees this machine process basically as a symbol of a clearing ideal that will uproot all tradition... he hates it.

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
p. 043 - 54 Alice Fletcher

-- Born 1838.  Born in Cuba.  There appears to have been wealth.  Began work at Peabody through a special fellowship set up by Mr.s Mary Copley Thaw of Pistburg in 1891.  (43)

-- She was committed to social welfare work which O-L thinks "blindered her to the persistent force of soial identity among American Indian poeples and the real significance of interelationpships between economics and other aspects of culture." (44)

-- Still O-L describes her ethnographic work as accurate and as "among the classics of American anthropology" (44) 

-- When she died in 1923 she was descibed in mixed ways by men.  O-L does not really explicitly note this, but these reflect real ambivalence by the men on gendered level. O-L quotes "Some of her opponents never were quite sure what quiet, deep river had just drifted along and left them stranded far from their selfish hopes.  She didn't fight--any more than the snowflake and the sunbeam fight. Like them, she Just Kept On." (45)   Another quote describes her as a "dreafully opinionated woman".  (45)  O-L doesn't cite the page numbers here, but she cites Charles F. Lummis, "In Memoriam, Alice C. Fletcher" Art and Archeology, XV (1923) and "Alice C. Fletcher Memorial Meeting," El Palacio, XVI (1923), 83-88.  

-- She went into the field with Thomas Henry Tibbles -- minister, journalist, and 1904 Populist Party vice Presidential candidate.   He was dubious of her ability to deal with the conditions of the field. (45-46).   She first went into the field o Sept. 1. 1881 among the Omaha (where later Mead would work for a summer.) (46)  She worked with Tibbles, and his Omaha helper Wajapa. O-L critizies her for not being aware of the effect of going into the field with Tibbles and his "assimialted" assistant.  (47) 

-- Most interesting is that Alice Fletcher drafted a precursor to the Dawes Act: her Omaha Act of 1882, which was designed to help the Omaha, who were afraid of losing their land like the Ponca, est. grants for farms. They had asked her for help.  She decided that they should be given plots of land.  In the ACt she drafted they would be "allotted eighty acresto remain tax-free and held in trust by the govenrment for a period of twenty-five years after which time adult, competent Indians would be granted fee patents and control over their holdings. Lands loeft over after distribution of allotments were to be sold for th ebeneift of the tribe to finance development of their farms." (49).  O-L thinks b/c she had powerful friends, the Act was passed on August 7, 1882.  She was appointed a "special agent" to oversee it.     This Act a precursor to the Dawes Several Act of 1887 (or 1886?).  (49)  The ACt iddn't work so well and she goes through this as well as Mead's assessment of the idea and of Fletcher  50-51

--  This sincere drafting of this Act nonetheless still had the solution of trying to destroy Indian customs.  O-L faults Fletcher for this. 52-53.  See also Hoxie, A Final Promise.  Doe she mention Fletcher??

title: The Feminization of Academe
text: For notes see the entry for the whole book "Beyond Separate Spheres"

title: Cosmopolitanism & Solidarity: Studies in Ethnoracial, Religious, and Professional Affiliation in the United States
text:
Notes June 2011

 

Preface

-----------

* First problem is that of solidarity.  He cheesily calls it the "we" question.  He defines it as "an experiece of willed solidarity." (xi) It is more he insists than simply a group classification...ie the wawy the word community is often used to specify say the gay community or the scientitific community and so on.  (xi)  He expalins this in a couple of ways.  Solidarity requires "conscious commitment" (xi) or it is he sax "more performative than community." (xi) So then also "a solidarity" as he starts to use the word is not a "community of fate", that is a group of people whose lives have been touched by some set of historical contraints.  (xii)  The Jews are often described as a community of fate he says but they do not all feel the same level of solidarity.  Or: "Feminism is a solidarity, but womanhood is not." (xii)  He notes finally that "global apitalist economy" has shaped the problem of solidarity.  (xiii-xiv) At the same time, in learned circles there is a tendency to describe all "population groups" as "constructions."  (xiv)  His point in all of this is to say that he think that "among the great problems of the twenty-first century is the problem of willed affiliation, the problem of solidarity." (xv) The nub of this is that th etendency to imagine all solidarities to be highly contingent as opposed to absolute and fixed has created a tension that is exacerbated by the rise of global capitalism and that has a social psychological character...  That tension is between:

the needs for 1) a deep feeling of social belonging, enabling intimacy and promoting mutual exchange, and 2) a broad alliance, enabling mutual defense and facilitating a greater range of social and cultural experience.  Solidariteies narrow enough to serve the need for belonging threaten to close people off from thelarger world of realities some of which may damage them if not engaged.  Solidarities broaden enough to be consistently engaged with this larger wolrd threaten to become too braoad to sustain a sense of belonging.  This tension between the impulse for concentration and the impulse for incocpration is heightened as eonomic and communications systems allow ostensibly distant forces to impinge on one's 'home.'  Global wwarming is a convienient example of a threat to everyone that is difficult to engage from the point of view of any solidarity smaller than the species.  But any solidarity capacious enough to act effectively on problem slocated in a large arena is poorly suited to satisfy the human need for belonging. And any solidarity tight enough to serve the need for belonign cannot be expected to respond effectively to challenges common to a larger and more heterogenous population. (xvi)

At the same time, solidarity is also a question of political economy because solidarity is a "commodity distributed by power." (xvi) Ie nationalism has created state authority to reinforce certain national identities.

* Cosmpolitanism comes in beecause it is he says a "family of responses to the problem of solidarity." (xvii)  He argues that it seeks to "maximiye the authority of individual wills and to iminimiye that of ascribed idenitities." (xvii)  Cosmpolitanism has been critiqued int he past as being too insensitive to diversity and particularity and lcoal traditions as much as the realities of power, but recently there has been a new take on new forms of cosmpolitanism ie "rooted cosmpolitnaism" or other adjectives such as critical, discreptant, sitauted, patriotic and so on.  (xviii).  The point of these modifications is to distinguish cosmpolitanism and unviersalism.  As he sees it and as he says he laid it out in his book Postethnic America "we can...distinguish between a universalist will to find common ground and a cosmpolitan will to engage human diversity." (xviii) He feels that cosmpolitans share with universalists a "suspicion of enclosures," but also understancd "the necessity of enclosures in their capacity as contingent and provisionally bounded domains in which people can form intimate and sustaining relationships, can create diversity, and can protect threatned constitutencies against outside forces." (xviii)  And he say that it "urges each individual and collective unit to absorb as much varied experience as it can while retaining its capacity to achieve self-definition and to adacnce its own aims effectively." (xviii)  He insists that this type of cosmplitanism respects the difficulties that people have in forming bonds of solidarity with those that are perceived as different. 

* He is carefulto point out that cosmpolitanism is not the same as pluralism.  It is he says "more liberal in style; it is more oriented to the individual, and supposes that individuals will be simultaneously affiliated with a number of groups, including civic and religious communiteis as all as communities of descent." (xix) By contrast, "Pluralism is more conservative in style; it is oriented to the preexisting group, and it is likely to ascribe to each individual a primary identiy within a single community of descent.  Pluralists are more concerned to protect and perpetuate cultures of groups already well established at the time the ideal of pluralism is invoked, while cosmpolitanisms are more inclinced to encourage the voluntary formations of new communities of wider scope made possible by altered histirical circumstances and demographic mixing. " (xix-xx)  In his book Postethnic America he defined cosmpolitnaism as "affiliation by revocable consent." (xxi)

* He believes that the increasing popularity of cosmpolitanism is a result of the "world-historical events" that have made the "old, racialist forms of anti-racism" less valuable, ie global capitalism, inreased international migration, belief in the constructed character of all identities.  A tone of people have b een writing on cosmpolitanism he thinks and he gives names: Alexander Aleinikoff, Kwame Anthony Appiah, Roger Baubock, Ulrich Beck, Thomas Bender, Sezly Benhabib, Rogers Brubaker, Craig CAlhoun, Phen Cheah, Amos Elon, Paul Gilroy, Amy gutmann, David Held, Jennifer Hochschild, Michael Ignatieff, Mary Kaldor, Bruno Latour, John Lie, Bharati Mukherjee, Bhikhu Parekh, Ross Posnock, Bruce Robbins, Salman Rushdie SamuelScheffler, RRogers Smith, Amartya Sen, Werner Sollors, and Jeremy Waldron.  He summarizes what he thinks these writers have in common: "if you do not take on as much of the world as yu can, the wworld will come to you, and on terms tover which you will have even less control than youd did previously." (xxii)

* Lastly he think that the US is of "special interest" here.  It has been a "major site for many of the processes that now produce the problem of solidarity elsewhere." And it has been a "testing ground" for responses.  He puts it this way: "The more contingent become the groups to which individuals through the world belong, the more relevant the history of the United States appears to be." (xxii)

title: Lost Manhood Found: Male Sexual Impotence and Victorian Culture in the United States
text:
p. 35 Critique of "crisis of masculinity" theory

There is a widely recognized notion of "crisis of masculinity" in the 1890s, when many men felt they had lost their manhood.  Mumford thinks that detailed studies of sexuality may give specificity to that theory rather than disproving it.  Notes critique of idea by Clyde Griffen in "Reconstrucing Masculinity from the Evangelical Revival to the Waning of Progressivism: A Speculative Synthesis" in Meanings for Manhood, ed. Griffen and Carnes (1990)

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text: p.024 - Mound Builders discussion Continued focuson native Americansin 1850s, new focus on the mound builders. First volume in Smithsonian's publication series was E.g. Squier and Edwin Davis's Ancient Monuments of the Mississippi Valley (1848) about the moundbuilders. Davis and Squier felt that contemporary Indians and their ancestors were not capable of building such a thing. (24) They felt contemporary peoples to be hunters and foragers not agriculturalists, and thus they supported the Lockean logic justifying claims to Indian lands. (24) New opinions in the 1850s. Schoolcraft, and Samuel Haven (secretary of Antiquarian Society) thought they could have been built by people at the "barabarian level of culture." (26) Haven and Schoolcraft emphasized that there were no mounds and antiquitiees west of Mississippi, helping to undermine Indian claims in that region. (26) Then Morgan...he revived a monogenist type argument, emphasizing unity basedon kinship structures and believed that the American Indians had come from Asia and origins may be in Turanian speakers of that continent. (Haven and Schoolcraft also thought this). (27) He compared them with kindship structures of the Tamil and Dravidian tribes of South India and found they were th esame (27) So he found there was a single but diverse human species (27) He believed that the kinship similarity also signaled a biological similarity. I.e. he linked culture and heredity. (27) Patterson then continues to explain in a very useful and brief way Morgan's ideas (27-32), but the point is that Morgan introduces this question of historical development which understoodthe male middle class as the advancing wave of historical progres....see great Bruce Trigger quoteon 33: "they wer eplease to view themseleves as a wave of progress that was inherent in human nature and perhapseven in the constitution of the universe." (33)

title: Prophets of Extremity: Nietzsche, Heidegger, Foucault, Derrida
text:
Notes Taken Sept 2011 for USIH Paper on Boas' Cosmopolitanism and Crisis Group:

 

Just read Megill's account of Romanticism and this one paragraph jumped out at me because of the way he describes the notion of genius, again was thinking of Boas.  Nothing new here but might enrich my account of Boas' thought.  

"Finally, one needs to note how the Romantic idea of genius, with its stress on the unconscious, unlearnable character of artistic creation, appeared to suggest that even the artist himself was unequal to his work.  Thus, art was seen as allowing access to a dimension of reality from which the merely analytical understanding was entirely barred."  (Megill, Prophets of Extremity, 7)

Again re Boas and this line of thinking that MeGill is tracing.  He looks at Kant in his Intro.  There is a section where he traces Kant's ideas about aesthetics.  Kant was read as giving aesthetics an autonomy from the spheres of morality and freedom (ie from the sphere of practical reason on the one hand and of pure reason/science on the other.)  Kant describes moral pleasure as disinterested sataisfaction, or interesslosses Wohlgefallen, and form as purposiveness without purpose.  This reminds me of the way Boas talks about myths and esp. artistic form in Indian cutlrures.  Its form is independent from the realm of morality an dmeaning, although it is given meaning.  The form is the motive.  

Anyhooo, Megill notes also that Kant does contradict this view.  He draws a link between beauty and moral goodness when he notes that to say that something is beautiful is to make a claim on universality.  As Megill puts it beauty "points toward the realm of morality" for Kant. (13)  

All this is interesting vis-a-vis my claim that I did not fully lay out in the dissertation that Boas saw aesthetics as pointing to universality and affection as pointing the other way, toward particular historical communities, regardless of their universality.  

The other link between aesthetics and morality is that Kant's notion that while art cannot provide knowledge, it can represent things that cannot be expressed in language as a concept. It is autonomous. It can express the inexpressable, as Megill puts it, and this means that art is not simply a purveyor of disinterested pleasure...

-------------------
9/19/2011

More insights while reading Megill's Prophets of Extremity.  Megill's description of Nietzsche as an advocate of what he calls "aestheticism" led him at one point to describe Nietzsche's version of an aversion to conceptual knowledge -- that is a revision of a general tendency in 19th century Romantic thought (observed by Maurice Mandelbaum, see pp. 47-50) to distrust conceptual knowledge for its failure to "re-present" things in their essence, see esp. 48 -- a kind of defect of concepts to grasp reality.  
Megill points out that Nietzsche's take is distinct from similar critiques of kowledge by "neo-positivists, pragmatists, and existentialists" because of the "aesthetic bent" of his thought.  Nietzsche shares the Kantian view that aesthetic experience cannot be represented in words and concepts (an idea Megill gets at in Kant in his Introduction).  But Nietzsche believes that the asethetic realm offers "an alternative to the mediating and complexifying influence of concepts." (48)

Where I see a connection to Boas is in the idea that this realm of aesthetic experience is somehow independent from "reality."  This is hard to map to Boas' terms, though, at least as I have interpreted them so far.  I saw Boas' notion of aesthetic impulse as hewing toward universality and affection as hewing  toward particularity.  But let's leave the specific terms for a second...

Megill writes: "Nietzsche...accords primacy to the aesthetic precisely because it does not give us insight into 'reality.'  Indeed, it does not even claim to do so.  On the contrary, it is explicitly a realm of illusion, and as such it stands in opposition to the unacknowledged illusion of logic and dialectic.  Man, in Nietzsche's view, has no access to reality whatsoever.  He is only arguably a rational being.  His much-vaunted abstractions turn out to be metaphors in disguise, and his language, far from embodying logical truth, embodies rather this innate talent for aesethic creation." (50)  

Where I hear Boas is in this idea that concepts, read here mythological concepts, do not offer insight into reality, and in the idea that man's abstractions turn out to be metaphors.  Nietzsche is specifically thinking about art in European culture, works specifically cocneivedd self-consciously as art, and yet as Megill insists he is enlarging the signifiance of art beyond the realm of "artists" to man in general.  Boas is looking at myths in societies that do not differentiate as modern societies do between art and science, ie precisely the kind of thinking that Nietzsche for other reasons is suggesting is more trustworthy.  Boas refuses to dismiss myth as impure reason (like the volutionsists) or as pure "natural" ideas (like Bastian), so in a way he implicilty takes up something like an aestheticist position that Megill is describing right?  
For him, as for Nietzsche, human thought is essentially creative without revealing "reality."  Boas' myths, like Nietzsche's conceptual scientific modern thought, is the product of human reactions to the natural world without it being accurate.  I saw a link between that quote where Boas talks about how mtyhs are related to the reaction to the sun, mountains, thunderstorms etc and a quote Megill uses: "...however stern and solid it [scientific/conceptual knowlege] it may seem, the coneptual world is only the hardened product of 'a  mass of images that originally poured forth, in a fiery fluidty, from the primal faculty of human fantasy." (51) That sounds a lot like Boas to me when Boas is saying how all these myths have no relationship to the natural world except that they capture the sense of awe nature inspires in us...  

So what is the significance of this observation for this paper?  For one, it gives me a more historically contemporaneous way to describe Boas' appraoch to myth than saying he was a proto-postmodernist/post-structuralist as I did in the dissertation.  Secondly, it might be a nice way to point out how Bunzl doesn't quite get it right: ie Boas is not so squarely in this German historicist tradition...

What is complex here, though, is if Boas is in this tradition, what of his commitment to science and truth?  For Nietzsche this goes in radically anti-foundational directions.  Truth says nothing about reality.  Megill quotes one of his most famous phrase: "[truth is] a mobile army of metaphors, metonymies, anthropomorphisms: in short a sum of human relations which have been poetically and rhetorically intsenfied, transposed, adorned, and after long usage seem to a nation fixed, canonical, and binding; truths are illusions of which one has forgotten that this is what they are; metaphors which have become worn out and have lost their sensual power; coins which have lost their pictures and now are no longer of account as coins but merely as metal." (51)  

This is hard to work out and I need to think this through more carefully.  Where Nietzsche takes this according to Megill is into the complex ambivalent view of the imediacy of reality that he has--ie concepts provide structure and stability to human existence that is necessary, and yet that stability can become to stable, the concepts stilted and stale, see p.52, and 40-41.  This dichotomy that Megill attributes to Nietzsche is THE SAME ONE THAT SAPIR RELATES!!!, which makes sense given the Sapir's tendency to go more fully into a radically modernist stance.  

Megill makes another point about N that may be useful here.  He wants to distinguish N's sense of the conceptual world as being independent of reality from the notion that Kant puts forth in Critique of Pure Reason that humans can only have knowledge of apperances and no of things-in-themsevles.  The differences are 1) that Kant sees his categories as central to all humans, and thus he is working with a concept of human nature; 2) Kant sees "the imposition of the categories upon the noumenal realm as an ordering of reality, whereas Nietzsche view it as Verstellung--that is, as a dissimulation, or (to attempt a more literal translation) as a displacing or disarranging." (53)  Both these seem to put Boas closer to Nietzsche than Kant to my mind. Indeed, this word dissimulation reminds me a bit of the part where Boas describres the disintegration of myths through diffusion and integration.  

Ultimatley, for N, truth is a not reality, but this changes teh concept of what a liar is...a liar is someone who attempts to treat concepts as though they were real, who uses, in N's words, "the valid designations, the words, in order to make the unreal appear as real..." (54)  So the linguistic realm becomes important as an aesthetic realm in which humans play with concepts.  And finally, in N's world, men do not hate deception, Megill says, but only certain types of description that produce "evile, hostile consequences..." (54)  

9/21

Continuing from yesterday, Megill has a whole chapter on N and Myth and I will take notes on it re my thinking about Boas here:

Megill's Ch.2 "Nietzsche and Myth"

* Megill starts out by explaining that N sees "myth as the ground of art, the foundation on which all aesthetic creation must be built.  Just as art is always seeking to reemerge, even with the confines of a culture that regards itself as a wholly scientific in bearing, so also is myth." (65)  For N, both art and myth are a "fundamental impulse of man".  In Megill's words, "his impulse toward the formation of metaphors, toward the continually creative substitution of one element for another within his language." (65)  That impulse has in modern culture "been overlaid by a rigid structure of concepts, but it has not thereby been defeated or even subdued, for it 'seeks for itself a new realm of action and another river-bed, and finds it in Mythos and more generally in art.'" (65)  

* With regard to myth, as opposed to art, Megill says there is a bigger difference between mature and immature N.  So he wants to look at the shift that takes place in N's "middle" or "positivistic" period.  Basically, N turns away from his celebration of the artist--definitely distancing himself from the Romantics--due in part to his biographical dissapointment with Wagner at the first great festival and Bayreuth, so instead he begins to celebrate the scientists, seeing the artist as someone whose artistic impulse led them away from serious intellectual engagement or the pursuit of truth toward an almost childish "belief in gods and daemons, to a spiritualization of nature, to a hatred of science..." (67)  He is not, however, leaving behind his sense that "logic is fiction" that Megill had attributed to him in Ch.1.  Likewise, his ideal is still immediate contact with "reality".  But since that contact is iimpossible (agian sse ch.1), "he is forced to think in terms of a rigidly dichotomous realtion between  'knowledge' and 'reality,' in which man creates a reality of his own precisely because he cannot know reality as it actually is." (69)  Then so his view of modern scientific conceptions of the world is that on some level it is myth also, and here we arrive at a passage that really reminds me of Boas: Nietzsche suggests that what we now call the world is in fact the result of a 'crowd of errors and fantasies whcih arose gradually in the general development of organic being...and are now inherited by us as the accumulated treasure of all the past." (69, that is from Human, All too Human)  This mythological character of modern conceptions of the world is however not a bad thing, as Megill puts it these "errors are not only inescapable but are also...a benefit to mankind.  Indeed, our sympathy depends upon them, for it only such errors (above all, the suppositions of equality and of identity) that have allowed the development of human reason." (69)  Point here too is that even in this positivisitic phase N sees modern science as art. (70)

title: Vigorous Male and Aspiring Female: Poetry, Personality, and Culture in Edward Sapir and Ruth Benedict
text: Gender and "Hardness" A nice part of Handler's argument here is that he is talking about gender in relation to this ideal of hardness. His first point is that given this ideal, which he thinks Benedict also is interested in through Walter Pater (100-102), Benedict has a harder time with it because as he says at the outset "'hardness' has obvious sexual implications..." (97) But if Benedict had trouble with it, as Handler shows in his discussion of the tensions between Sapir and Benedict over poetry resulting in the Sapir's "Sex Problem in America" paper (102-116), Sapir also had trouble with it, and was not always sure how "hard" he should be as Handler shows on 110 and his ultimate feelig of ailure as a poet: "Sapir's poetic voice tended to be soft and sentiental, one the one hand, or aloof and distanced, on the other. In any case, it lacked the intensity and 'hardness' that were in demand but that he equated with 'bluff'. As I will show, 'bluff' or Sapir was symptomatic of spurious personality, epitmoized in the distorted sexuality of women who aspired to hardness." (110) That quote really begins to show the complexity of the matter and Sapir's own confusion and contradition over it. He himself was not hard, but he despised women that tried to get hard.

title: Culture: The Anthropologist's Account
text:
p. 10 Culture as Explanation of Failure of Modernization/Globalization?

Kuper makes a frankly strange argument here.  In the pages before (5-7) he has
given a very brief account of the rise of culture in the conflicts over civilization and kultur in the era of enlightenments.  Now he moves to the modern period and in the first pages makes a strange assertion as to the reason culture emerged into discussion:

"In the twentieth century, the idea of a progressive, scientific world-civilization was translated into the theory of modernization, and then the theory of globalization.  In the short run, culture was a barrier to modernization (or industrialization, or globalization), but modern civilization would in the end trample over local, less efficient traditions.  Culture was invoked when it became necessary to expalin why epople were clinging to irrational goals and self-destructive strategies...  Culture was the fallback, to explain apparently irrational behavior.  culture also accounted for the disappointing outcome of many political reforms." (10)

There is a certain truth to this -- it is reflected for instance in the simple version of my War Chapter -- but it is also a highly reductive explanation.  Or one might say that it excludes the second part of culture's purpose.  1) Culture was used to explain irrational thought and thus 2) it was a term that focused and brought to the fore a new language for discussing the role of tradition and symbolic systems in our lives...   Kuper seems to disregard the second part as though it were a priori ridiculous.  Cf. with his suggestion in the introduction that problems should be addressed by their specific names and not through culture...this suggests this more deliberate, rational, instrumental form of political activity that I ultimately trace in the last chapters of my dissertation...

title: Selection from Section IX. On the empirical use of the regulative principle
text:
General Notes

(This section is wh ere Kant is dealing with the relationship between two forms of causality, one in the realm of freedom and the other in the realm of nature.)

 

III. Resolution of the cosmological idea of the totality of the derivation of occurrences in the world from their causes

* Two ways to think of causality: "either according to nature or from freedom." (532)

* The first kind, that having to do with nature or "the world of sense" is a "causality of appearnaces" that rest on "temporal conditions." (532)

* The second, the causality of freedom, is "transcendental".  It is a kind of causality that is distinct in part because it is has the "faculty of beginning a state from itself" (533).  It does not in other words "stand under another cause determining it in time in accordance with the law of nature." (533)  This is why it is transcendental. 

* It is based on this transcendental idea of freedom that the "[f]reedom in the practical sense" is grounded. (533)  Ie in the idea of "independence of the power of  choice from necessitation by impulses of sensibility." (533)  Where sensibility refers to a choices in the realm of nature that are determined "pathologically affected (through moving-causes of sensiblity)..." (533)  Ie the impulses of sensibiility reflect an "animal power of choice" and not the "human power of choice" that is not rendered necessary by "sensibilty" but is instead based on the "faculty of determining oneself from oneself, independently of necessitation by sensible impulses." (533)

* If all causality, he says, were "in the world of sense" ie natural causation, then this would involve the "abolition of transcendental freedom" and also "practical freedom."  (533-534).  Why is that?  To imagine that the world as we perceive it is all the wrold, he says, is to imagine (as had some empricisits) that "apperances were things in themslves, and hence space and time were the forms of things in themselves".  (534)  And if that were the case then causality would belong to that series of events in space-time.  But the kind of freedom he's talking about exists outside of that series because it beings from things in themselves. (533-534)

* So the question he's facing he thinks is whether first of all a causality of freedom exists at all, and if so if it "can exist together with the universality of the natural law of causality...[whether] every effect in the world must arise either from nature or  freedom, or whether instead both, each in a different relation, might be able to take place simultaneously in one and the same occurrence." (534) 

* If, as the empiricists assume, there is an "absolute reality of appearance" then "freecom cannot be saved."  Because nature, ie the causality of apperances, is a "completely determining cause, sufficient in itself, of every occurence, and teh condition for the occurrence is alays contained only in the series of appearances that, along with their effect, are necessary under the law of nature." (535)

* But if apperances "do not count for any more than they are...namely not things in themselves but only for mere representations connected in accordance with empirical laws" then, Kant says, "they themselves must have grounds that are not appearances..." )(535)  This he calls an "intellegible cause." (535)  This cause is outside the series of causes of apperances in nature, even though its "effects" are encountered in the "series of empirical conditions." (535) 

* What he means by "intelligible" is that "in an object of sense which is not itself appearance." (535) So if objects have a faculty that is not the way in which the thing exists in the realm of appearances then an object can be condiered as  "intelligible in its action as a thing in itself, and as sensible in the effects of that action as an appearance in the wrold of sense." (535)  Kant also says then that an object's causality has an "empirical character" ie through which its action as appearances can be understood and "intelligible character" "through which it is indeed the cause of those actiuons as apperacnes, but which does not stand under any conditons of sensibility and is not itself apperance." (536) 

* He also notes that this "acting subject" or "intelligible character" is not also under the condition of time.  And it can also not be "known immediately, because we cannot perceive anyting except insofar as it appear..." (536) 

*  Now he makes an important statement about the relationship of the intellible character of the object and its empirical.  He says that in its empirical character as an appearance the the subject would "be subject to the causal connection, in accordance with all the laws of determination; and to the extent it would be nothing but a part of the world of sense, whose effects, like those of any other appearance, would flow inevitably from nature..." (537)

* But at the same time in its intelligible character the same subject is not subject to determination by in the realm of sensiblity.  (537)  Even though we can "have nothing more than merely the general concept of it [the intelligible character]" (537), insofar at is is a "noumenon" he says, then it is also "free of all influences of sensibility and determination bhy appearances..." (537)  This means that as a noumenon "it begins its effects in the sensible world from itself, without its action beginning in itself..." The point he's trying to make is that this intelligible character can provoke "from itself" an action that appears in the world of appearances and in conformity with the laws of that realm, without that meaning that effectts in the world of senses, in general, begin from themselves (ie are their own cause) because in the empirical world all effects are caused by something else in a series.

* So now the problem that he wants to solve should be clear.  The idea is can you understand taht there is a realm of causality in freedom where things in themselves are their own causes, at the same time as in the realm of apperances that we known empirically things are always caused in a series according to the laws of natural causation as we can define them. (537)  He thinks the answer is yes, as he sketched in particualr on 536-537.  And the fact that he thinks the answer is yes means also that "freedom and nature,e ach in its full significance, would both be found in the same actions, simultaneously and without any contradiction, according to whether one compares them with thier intelligible or their sensible cause." (537) 

* Another key point here is that Kant sees this as a "transcendental problem"; that is, a problem of philsophy and reason, and not a psychological problem because it is a problem otuside the bounds of experience.  See short paragaraph mid page on 534.

From 537 on he now moves beyodn the "silhouette" of the solution to the "course of reason" that one needs to really solve it...

* He again explains how the idea of causality according to the law of nature is a causality in time, in which he effect is caused by one preceding it.  But then he asks does it need to be the case that the causality of the cause of an effect in this realm of appearances is always or "solely" empirical?  "Is it not rather possible that although for every effect in appearance there is required a connection with its cause in accordance with the laws of empirical causality, this empirical causality itself, without the least interruption of its connection with natural cause, could nevertheless be an effect of a causality taht is not empirical, but rather intelligibile, i.e. an original action of ac ause in regard to appearances, which to that extent is not appearance but in accordance with this faculty intelligible, even though otherwise, as a link in the chain of nature, it must be counted entirely as belonging to the wrold of sense?" (539) 

* To sum up: In other words, why can't both forms of causality coincide and support each other? He's saying why can't we imagine that there are causes in nature but also causes on a transcedent level even if we can't know them.   Subjects could be part of a law of causation in nature, then, and also "contain certain conditoin that, if one would ascend from empirical objects to transcendental ones, would have to be regarded as merely intelligible".  (ie not appearance) (539)  His point is in part that these two kinds of causation exist without interfering with each other, esp since we can't have  any absolute knowledge of the intelligible cahracter of a thing.: "...if we follow the rule of nature only in that which might be the cause among appearances, then we need not worry aobut what sort of ground is thought for these appearances and their connection in the transcendental subject, which is empirically unknown to us.  This intelligible ground does not touch the empirical questions at all..." (539)

[Note: you could see how the Americans, e.g. James Marsh, could avoid the limits of knowledge part, and imagine this to be one great perfect unity...that we can known, through God! ]

* Now going deeper into the problem he applies it to humans.  Humans are he says "one of the appearances in the world of sense." (539)  As such, they are also one of the "natural causes" whose causality "must stand under empirical laws" like all other natural things. (540) .  But the human being is also "knows himself also through apperception, and indeed in actions and inner determinations which cannot be accounted atall among impressiosn of sense..." (540)  So the human being is one part empirical and one part intelligibile.  The latter part of the human has to do with this faculties for "Undersanding and reason"--and these faculties operate with ideas and concepts, Kant says.  Ie here were ware in the realm of noumena.  (540). 

* Reason has to do with a kind of causality having to do with what "ought" to e.  and this is a "species of necessity" that has nothing to do with the causality of nature.  (540)  "In anutre the understanding can cognize only what exists, orhas been, or will be.  It is impossible that something in it ought to be other than what, in all these time-relations, it in fact is; indeed, the ought, if one has merely the course of nature before one's eyes, has no significance whatever.  We cannot ask at all what ought to happen in anture, any more tha we can ask what properties a circle ought to have; but we must rather ask what happens in nature, or what properties a circle has." (540) 

* The ought then expresses a "possible action" that must also be possible under "natural conditions."  (540)  Yet reason does not "give in to those grounds which are empirically given" (541) Kant says.  It "decclares actino to be necessary that yet have not occurred and perhaps will not occur, nevertheless presupposing of all such actions that reason could have causality in relation to them..." (541)  If you apply this again to humans, to say that human reason has a causality that conforms to the law of nature would be to say that "there is no freedom" because only actions that were possibly in the law of natural causation could occur.  This he says is waht happens when you look at humans from this perspective of the law of natural causation according to the "moving causes of his actions psychologically." (542)  But if you consider the samea ctions in realtion to reason you get a different view.  Here is is particularly good:

...if we consider the very same actions [that have been considered from a psychological pointf of view of he law of natural causation] in relation to reason...in order to explain them as regards their origin, but insofar as reason is the casue of producing them by themselves--in a word, if we comapre them with reason in a practical respect -- then we find a rule and order that is entirely other than the natural order.  For perhaps everything that has happened in the course of nature, and on empirical grounds inevitably had to happen, nevertheless ought not to have happened.  At many times, however, we find, or at least believe we have found, that the ideas of reason have actually proved their causality in regard to the actions of  human beings as appearances, and that therefore tehse actions have occurred not through empirical causes, no, but because they were determined by the grounds of reason. (542)

* He now tries again to work out the relationsships between these two forms of causality.  How can it be that an action that is caused by reason--by the ought--is also in the realm of appearances.  It is reason that determines the empriical cahracter he says; "The empirical character is once again determined in the intelligible character (in the modes of thought)." (542)  Since we can't know the origin of reason (because it originates in the subject tiself, the thing in itself, which we cannot know) then we are "not aquainted" with its original character although it is "indicated through appearances..." (542)  This form of causation through reason, this intelligible faculty, does not operate in time because it is outside the realm of appearances which operates in space-time.  so It "is not subject to the form of time, and hence cont subjec tto the conditions of the temporal sequence."  It dies not "start working aa certain time in producinng an effect." (542)  It does in a sense not even begin.  BUT this intelligible causes emanating from reason "this very same cause in another relation also belongs to the series of appearances." (543) 

* So reason has both a negative and a postiive relationship to the causality of nature and appearnces.  1) Negative in that reason, because it is indepednent of all prior causation, can "only be regarded negatively, as independence from empriical conditions..."  (543)  Thus Kant says "Reason is thus the persisting condition of all voluntary actions under which the human being appers."  2) And the positive connection is that Because "in reason itself nothing begins" but it is able to begin something in the temporal series of appearances: i.e. "positively by a faculty of beginning a series of occurences from itself, in such a way that in reason itself nothing begins, but as the unconditioned condition of every voluntary action, it allows of now condition prior to it in time, wehreas its effect begins in the series of appearance, but can never constitute an absolutely first beginning in this series." (543)

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.023-24 What Huntington means by "civilization."

Huntington first says that: "A civilization is a cultural entity." He says that a village, an ethnic group, a nationality, a religion, "all have distinct cultures at different levels of cultural heterogeneity." (24) (23-4)  A civilization, however, is not just any cultural entity.  It is one of the highest order.  Germans and Italians may share a European culture, so they are independently not civilizations.  "A civilization is thus the highest cultural grouping of people and the broadest level of cultural identity people have short of that which distinguishes humans from other species."  (24)  Examples of these for Huntington are as follows: "Arabs, Chinese and Westerners, however, are not part of any broader cultural entity.  They constitute civilizations." (24)

He further argues that these civilizations have their subdivisoins (or don't, in the case of China which he quotes Lucian Pye as saying is a "civilization pretending to be a state" (24)).  The West he says as "two major variants, European and North American"; Islam has Arab, Turkic and Malay divisions.  

Finally he notes that these entities are fungible, they rise, fall, divide and merge, and dissappear.  (24)
