title: Legitimation Crisis
text:
Notes November 2014:

> Prepping for trying to write a second and expanded draft of metacrisis idea. Going in my sense of this book from conversations with others is that this is Habermas being more radical than he later became in the Theory of Communiative Action. Here he examines crisis tendencies in late capitalism, and not it's stabilizing mechanisms. It may be a book characteristic of the 70s, when the fissures in the social democratic systems created after the war became visible. I also remember a comment made by David Strecker that this was one of the last attempts to talk about crisis, perahps in the 20th century, in the critical sociology tradition that comes out of the Frankfurt School. And it failed, I think he said, or was deemed unworthy because of the problem of situating a crisis crtiique that is not also normative, and therefore based on specific assumptions? I dont' know that I understood perfectly David's point but we'll see.

 

Thomas McCarthy's Introduction:

> I'm going through this a bit because Habermas is hard to grasp.

* Basically McCarthy describes this work as having the goal, parlty quoting H himself, of the "'clarification' of very general structures of hypotheses' relating to the dynamics and development of contemporary capitalism. Habermas aim' is no less than that of survyeying most of the important literature on advacned capitalist society and organizing it around a continuous line of argument." (viiii). McCarthy emphasizes in his introduction that this is a difficult text and partly because it is wroking through, as he noted, so many different literatures on advanced capitalism. Three of these key contexts are: 1) Writings in the Marxist tradition; 2) The dimension of "systems theory" and in particular his critqiue of Parsons and Luhmann. and 3) his own project, already begun, i.e. his "theory of cummunicative competence.". McCarthy says already on page x that he will sepdn the rest of the time expalining this latter dimension as that is the least well known in the English speaking context.

* Pages x-xiii, McCarthy works quickly through some of the work of the critical theorists of the Frankfurt School in order to place Habermas' project. The division between moral and thereotical knowledge he begins was one that critical social theory could not abide because it was focused on overcoming that division, and the devision between theory and practice. This is the project of the Frankfruth School carried out in particular by Horkheimer and Marcuse in the *Zeitschrift feur Sozialforschung*. (x) Horkheimer starts this by taking up Hegel's dialectics. Knowledge is not merely transitory but its negation, its finitude, is part of a total system of truth. That was Hegel. But that doesn't work for  materialist critique because it is part of an idealist system. Hegel thinks this is all an inner development of spirit. Horkheimer then seeks to "radicalize" Hegel by giving up the teleological (theological) view of progress, by distancing himself from any sort of totalizing perspective, by and accepting that  all critique is finite and located in actual history. (xi)

* So then how can critical theory legitimate its own standpoint? For Horkheimer and others critical theory was about the capacity of individuals to exercise a rational will in order to take control of history and achieve a more rational organization of society. Moreover, as Horkheimer says on a quote on xii, the opint here is that indiviudals do not always grasp the problem.

The viewpoints which critical theory draws from historical analysis as the goals of human activity, especially the idea of a reasonable organization of society that will meet the needs of the whole community, are immaentn in huma work, but are not correctly grasped by individuals or by the common mind. (xii)

But how could practitioners of this kind of critique know that their views were not just another experession of particular interest, either culture-bound, class-bound or otherwise? But Here he thinks that Horkheimer and others in the *Zeitschrift* did not sufficiently establish their point of view. He accusses them of rejecting Hegel through Marx, and taking up the "notion of the coincidence of reason" (?), without dealing with what it mean to reject Hegel's idealism. McCarthy: "...what is required, and what is lacking int he *Zeitschrift* essays, is a philosophical elucidation of thought on materialist presuppositions, which, while overcoming Hegel's idealism, does not fall below the level of insight he achieved." (xiii)

* This then is where McCarthy starts his discussion of Habermas' project vv the Frankfurt SChool. Habermas characterizes langauge as a "universal medium" alongside "work" and "domination." (xiii). But conemporary analyses and idealism and hermeneutics have not adequatley understood language. What is needed is to understand it in terms of a "universal pragmatics that exhibits the normative basis of all communication *and* explains the possiblity of systemtatically distorted communication." (xiii, McCarthy's words).

* So then McCarthy wants to draw together Habermas' "theory of communicative competenece". (xiii) He does so in the rest of this sub-section I. (xiii-xviii). Key point here is in part that I think this is where Habermas starts to integrate that work of the anglophone analytical tradition (wittegenstein et al) in thinking about "language games." His point in very brief form as I glean it from a too quick reading here is this: there are a series of language games involved in a normal speech act: "claims that the utterance is understandable, that its propositional conctnet is true, and that the speaker is sincere in uttering it, and that it is right or appropriate for the speaker to be performing the speech act." (xiii-xiv). Mostly these validity claims are met, bu tthere are situation in which they are not. Then there are some ways of resolving those situations by entering into a kind of discussion aimed at resolving those disputes, i.e. discourse. This McCarthy describes quickly on xiv.

* Now, on the other hand, Habermas knows that although we know that most of the time the "model of pure communiciative action" that he describes does not hold, we "cannot avoid counterfactually proceeding as if" they did. (Habermas quoted on xiv). How can this be explained? Well Habermas thinks because it is possible to develop a theory of the way communication is systematically distorted. What that means, basically, is that there are "ruling systems of norms" that exist that act anchor certain beliefs and serves as "systematic barriers to will-forming communciation." (Habermas quoted from great quote on xv). Basically then ruling systems of norm that support a "fiction," and also prevent its being discovered as such. (xv) But at this point Habermas has merely arrived at the point that McCarthy says the Frankfurt school had arrived at: i.e. that individuals falsely assess the situation they are in, fail to through their own will formulate an analysis that would point the way to a more rational organizaiton of society. (xv)

* Habermas still needs to supply a method for determining what is a fiction, and what is not. (This does seem to me to be a quesiton also at the core of analytical philosophy: i.e. what kind of statements are true and which not?) But in doing so, he can't just suggest some criteria; that would just produce a circle, because then that criteria would need to be justified and so on. He therefore takes the pragmatisits route: what kind of pragmatic speech situation creates the conditions in which systematic distortion can be eliminated? McCarthy says that his thesis is that "the structure is free from contraint only when for all participants there is a symmetrical distribution of chances ot select and employ speech acts, when there is an effective equality of chaces to assume disalogue roles." (xvi-xvii). I.e. this can only work if there is a situaiton of where unlimited discussion is possible, and where there there are not constrains from domination, whether conscious or uncionscious (i.e. neuroses or ideology). (xvii) This means that "the conditions for the ideal discourse are connected with condition for an ideal for of life; they include linguistic conceptionalizations of the traditional ideas of freedom and justice. 'Truth,' therefore, cannot be analyzed independently of 'freedom' and 'justice.' (xvii) (!!!) This is key. This gets the basic gist. McCarthy, however, somes it up nicely again right at the end; "His arguemnt is, simply, that the emancipated form of life that is the goal of criticla theory is inherent in the notio nof truth: it is anticipated in every act of communication." (xviii).

* Okay, now in section II of this intro McCarthy sets up the context a bit more widely of the text itself vv Marxist critqiue and the history of capitalism. First he goes through Marx, xviii-xx; then the Frankfurt School and discusses the Dialectic of the Enlightenment text. Point is vv Marx that there was a tension in Marx between a sensitivity to the functioning of ideology versus a kind of reductive economism. This is traced very nciely and one can really see the tension in the quote on xix, and the way McCarthy draws it out. Then there is the quesiton: well how did this tension get resolved in "official" Marxism? HIs answer is thought an emphasis on the reductive side. But then this is what the Frankfruth School was correcting in their focus on culture. Moreover, post-WWI capitalism seemed to demand a different approach. capitalism was no longer of the liberal variant. There was an internventionist state, the rationalization and bureucratization of social institutions, interdependence of science and technology, "reificiation" of consciousness.. (not sure what the altter is). This is what came under critique in Dialectic of Enlightenment. Lukacs had begun this already. McCarthy explains their arguemnt this way:

"For Marx, natural science was the paradigm of a mode of thinking that had constantly proved its truth in practice; itwas philosophy that had to be overcome. For Horkheimer and Adorno, it was the contrary: the critique of scientism was the precondition of restoring Marxist theory as critique. Philosophical idealism, in which th eideals of reason and freedom were kept alive--albet in a distored form--was repalced by positivistic materialism as the chief enemy of critical thought. The critique of instrumetnal reason became the fundamental task of critical social theory. For in creasing the objective possibility of a truly free society, the progressive mastery of nature through science and technology simultaneously transformed the potential subjects of emancipation. The reification of consciousness was the price paid for the progressive liberation from material necessity." (xxj)

title: The First Boasian: Alfred Kroeber and Franz Boas, 1896-1905
text:
p.523-524 Female Network influening UC Berkeley?

Jacknis notes that while Kroeber was finishing hi sdegree that "Boas consulted with patron Phoebe Hearst; her friend, prehistorian Zelia Nutall, and Frederic Putnam in the  spring of 1901".  (523).  Boas advised against starting a program at Berkeley, which would have been the first anthropological program in the west.  He didn't think his students, Kroeber included wer eready.  Ultimately, though the plans went ahead a year later and boas waas dropped from thecommittee that organized the dept.  This was part of Boas' deetiorating relationship with Putnam too.  (524).    Note also that later Boas is trying to direct K's efforst in california, and K is rebutting him, protecting his own territory, see 524-525.

Fletcher was in charger of the Indian exhibits at New Orleans Industirla exposition of 1884-85. And the Chicago World's Fair of 1894 also involved Fletcher and Zeiliaa Nuttall and Matilda Stevenson in a special "Congress of Anthropology." (40)

title: What Happened to Kant in Neo-Kantian Aesthetics? Cohen, Cohn, and Dilthey
text:
# Paul Guyer, "What Happened to Kant in Neo-Kantian Aesthetics? Cohen, Cohn, and Dilthey" The Philosophical Forum, v.39, no.2 (2008): 143-176

 

* Neo-Kantianism must be understood Guyer says in two intellectual contexts: 1) A push back against the speculative or "absolute" idealism of Hegel, Schelling and Fichte that emerged in the post-Kantian period, and 2) a desire to try to "ground philosophy on empirical pscyhology by Helmholtz and others that had been a previous response to post-Kantian idealism." (143)

* But neo-Kantians did not necessarily stick to the ideas of Kant, and this was the case with their aesthetics. (143-144)

* He characterizes the aesthetics of Bohen and Cohn as having a common character, despite their different version of neo-Kantianism. That approach wsa an altternative both to Schelling and Hegel's "speculative, metaphysical aesthetics" and the "psychological aesthetics" of Helmholtz and Fechner. (144)

* Their appraoch was also reflective a "general tendency of aesthetics in their own times" and this is interesting he thinks because it may alogn with other related works such as those by Edward Bullough and R.G. Collingwood "constitute an enduring contibute to the field of aesthetics." (144)

## Cohen's Aesthetic Theory

* Guyer traces two key assumptions of Cohen's argument.

1. is that following Kant he sees the cognitive faculty as having "two domains" one in nature and the other in relation to freedom (morality).  He sees science and morality as differeing in terms of the "direction of consciousenss": in nature the direction is twoard a reality indepdnent of our consciousness, that is to explain that reality; whereas in moality it is not twoard such an external reality but instead toward "the future of reailty." (Cohehn quoted on 149). In Guyer's words: "...in morality the points is not to form our concepts ot fit nature, but to transform nature to realize our moral goals." (149) BUT Cohen also holds, unlike Kant, that to understand aesthetic experience and art we suol dhave to know "what a third direction of consciousness ould be that could be the goal of aesthetic experience and the production of art." (149)

2. is that Cohen's mode of argumentation is based on Kant's "analytical" style of argument in  *The Prolegomena to Any Future Metaphysics*, which is not how Kant had ultiamtely described aethetic expereince in the third Critique where he'd used the "synthetic"  style. The distinction is between (the synthetic) mode of describing how a certain kind of judgement (ie scientici, moral, aesthetic) is possible at all, vertsus the (the analytic) whihc Guyer says starts from the assumption that "fact" that such forms of judgement exist and then tries to find the rules or laws juding those domains of judgement.

* Guyer thinks it may be due to the use of the analytic method by Cohen that his aesthetics reflects the contemporary appraoch of his period and also ends up being more like our contemporary aesthetics than Kant's. (150)

* So what then is Cohen's idea of aesthetics.

1. Art he thinks is the "expression of the feelings associated with our reprenstations of nature and our own volitions and actino--that is, science and moraity--that are not captured by the concepts of those two domains, adn taht the pleaure of beauty is the pleasure of enjoying those feelings." (150)

2. Feeling he think is the wrapped up in an initial level of consciousness: so that as Guyer writes "feeling" is 'in the first place, this consciousness of being-conscious, and second, everything about this consciousness taht will not be captured by our subsequence conceptualization of our consciousness, whether that take the form of a conceptualized representation [of nature] of an object or of a determination of the [moral] will." (151) See Cohen quote on 151-2 that expresses it pretty clearly. Guyer describes this as a "two-level view" (152)

3. So the unique direction of aesthetic consciousness is oward these "primordial feelings of becoming conscious that precede determinate sensation and coneptualization of objects and dterminations of the are not taken up into them." (152) In Cohen's words:

> No single object, even were it the highest, counts as the content that is to be determine [in aesthetic experience and art], but consciousness itself grasped in the totality of its directions, and this totality organized as proportion; this interweaving of all objects in a mere relationship is the aesthetic content. And this interweaving of objects itself forms the new object: feeling as feeling, and not as an annex of sensation and representation. (152)

4. VV the pleasure or displeasure of art, Guyer seems to think that Cohen's ideas are not so well worked out. He says that Cohen seems to think that 1) pleasure and pain are one part of the primordial consciousness, and that 2) are is something taht captures this one dimenision and then communicates it to the audience of art. (153) Guyer thinks this is not well worked out, though, brecause it presumes a theory of empathy that is not worked out.

5. Regardless, Guyer thinks that Cohen's idea is basically that pleasure results from primoridal feelings because aesthetic experience is not directed at any partiuclar objective content. That is, it is only directed at the "motility" of conscousness -- that is its capacity for spontaneous movement. Cohen's words: "the feeling of animation and of the disposition of consciousness to activity in general." (153)

6. This idea of aesthetic pleasure as being linked to the animation of consciousenss that goes toward no particular object is where Cohen connects his ideas to Kant's notion of free-play. But Guyer thinks that while Cohen is accurate in identifying Kant as a source of the idea that there is pleausre in the free play of the mind (although he accusses Cohen of being a German nationailst in not citing e.g. Alexsander Gerard's *Essay on Taste* (1759) as anothe rsource) BUT he does notes that Cohen's notion of aesthetic pleasure as constituting something *distinct* that is not expressed in partical or theoretical concepts. Kant does not "reocoginze the existence of other aspects of primordial consciousness" in this way. He simply sees "the paradigmatic content of art is *ideas* of pure reason that is , typically, moral ideas, which need to be intimated by the wealth of imagery in a successful work of art because they *outrun* or can never be fully captured by ordinary experience but not because they in any way *precede* or *underlie* ordinary experience." (154-55)

7. So in the end he says Kant's theory is very different. And specifically Cohen "cannot appeal to Kant for his theory of aeshthetic *contents*." (155) Guyer thinks that Cohen has invented this on his own and it reflects ideas about aesthetics more typical of his (and our?) time: namely, the tendnecy to place an empahsis on "feelings or the subjective dimensions of experience in general as the special subject of art taht we find in such representative writers of the next half-century as bullough and Collingwood." (155)

8. From 155-159, Guyer tries to show how Cohen's different appraoch to aesthetics produces different results. The fact that Cohen uses an analytical approach -- starting from the "fact" that art and artistic genius exists as a basis for belieivng that art expresses a lawfulness of aeshtetic consciousness and that judgements of taste have a universal basic -- whereas Kant "Kant intoruces his conception of genius as an ability to create universally accesible works o fart only after he has, at least to his own satisfaction, deduced th epossiblityof universally valid judgemnts of taste from the commonality of huma cognitive powers... " (156)  -- This difference plays a key role in Guyer's spinning out of what i unique in Cohen's approach. The eeffect seems to be that Cohen is drawing heavily on a particular experience of art -- one that is perhaps peculiar to his own life and times -- and not to Kant's. In th eprocess of doing this, Cohen sets art a "higher task" of bing a vehicle for the idealization of nature in an image of morality. (156) It's job then is to depict a "ntural object as an object of morailty" and in so doing tranform "natural and morality into art-feeling." (157) This could be said to be inspired by Kan'ts idea that "we have an intellectual interest in the beauty of nature insofar as it gives us a hint that our moral purposes can be realized in nature." (157) But Cohen says that Cohen's claim goes much much further because it does not mererely posit a parallel between natural beauty and moral success or Kant's idea that  all art "must ultiamtely concern ideas of reason" -- it suggest further that "all art ultiamtely *directly* concerns the realiation of morality in  anture or the possiblity of a higher degree of that realization taht we ordinarily experience." (157) Kant did not advocate such a strong and direct position. And Guyer thinks that in getting here Cohen had drawn on "a supposed fact about the arts rather than any *a priori* arguemnt..." (157) Guyer thinks that Cohen may owe an "explanation" of this ideal function of art and "its function of expressing our priimordial feelings underlying our representations of both nature and morality..." (157) He guess that it may be that Cohen thinks that "among our primordial feelings is a never-fully expressed yearning that nature and morality full coincide, and that we expressing thsi feeling through art." (157)

This is consistent with this reinterpration of Kant's idea about "supersensible substrarum" of both humanity and nature -- the thing-in-itself. This is complex: Kant only problematically deals with the "antimony of taste" -- that on the one hand judgements of taste are not rule governed, and yet they have a claim to universal validity. He seems to resolve it by saying that these response are based on free play, but then it's not clear why he "should suddenly resort to the metaphysical conception of a supersensible substrarum or common noumenal characer of all manking to explain the possiblity of agreement in taste or to a common supersensibl substartum of both mankingd and nature to explain the natural existence of things we find beautiful." (157-8) Cohen gets aroudn this by denying the metaphysical gesture. Instead he tsays that Kant's idea here was not metaphysical but "more like a practical conception of an infinitte task the realization of which we cna approach only asymptotically..." (158) Ie we never fully gain knowledge of nature or of morality. VV asethetics this may be, Guyer thinks, the idea of a "realization of our primoredial desire for a unification of the naturl and the moral that can never be fully realized in reality nor full expressed in art." (158) He quotes Cohen on 158. In part
Cohen writes: "Aesthetic purposiveness also presents such a task as the aesthetic idea, as a 'supersensible ground,' as a thing in itself of consciousnes." (158)  This idea that art is the "thing in itself of consciouenss" is far far far afield from Kant Guyer says. Such an idea would have been self-contraditroy for Kant. He notes that Cohen is clearly using Kant's term for very different purposes. And in the best part here, he specifies what he thinsk this might be: namely a different expereince of art, where art is directed more exclusively to the arousal of emotions, and he quotes Cohen on 158-9, in a very striking quote.

NOTE: What Guyer is talkiung about here it seems to me, although nto really wanting to say it, is the turn in aesthetics away from that Greek ideal, where beauty is about harmony and precision in represneation, to one where it is more about emotional enthusiasm. The same shift that Mosse perhaps identifies in the rise of German ethnonationalism, a desire to feel emotion as a way of idenitfying with a certain experience of German cultivation. It's significant here that Guyer also cirticizes Cohen at several points for being a Geramn nationalist....

* In the section on Cohn and then on Dilthey, Guyer shows how they trace a similar line grounding their aesthetics more on what Dilthey ultimately calls "lived experience" while also placing more emphasis on heightened emotions. Both Cohn and Dilthey, however, go much further than did Cohen when specifying how their aesthetics is grounded in the "fact" of aesthetic experience.

* Cohn grounds aesthetic experience in an ability to access and sympathize with the inner life of others and this, in turn, allows people to escape the narrowness of their own experience. Cohn writes: "For us human beings the inner life of anothers is in general accessible only insofar as we grasp intuited movements or other sensibly perceivable processes as experssion and with their assistance sympathetically experience [miterleben] what is expressed. The only possiblity for us to esacpe the narrowness of our own individualiity, or expanidng our personality beyond its limits, lies in this sympathetic life [Mitleben.]" (quoted on 162) So Cohn replaces Kan'ts free play of faculties definition of aesthetic expereince with "our apprecation of the epxression of the inner life of other livign beings".

* Guyer notes that this suggetss a "very different relation between the aesthetic and the moral" than Kant's as well: "For Kant as we have seen, the experience of th beautiful and the sublime may *prepare* us for morality in certain ways, the beautiful may be a *symbol* of the morally good, and we m ay taken an 'empirical interest' in the fact that our pleasure in beautiful objects is shared, that is, take an additional enjoyment from the fact thtat we enjoyt he same things as others, but for Kant all of these are *consequences* of our basic enjoyment of the beautiful becasue of the free play of our cognitive powers that it stimulates, whereas for Cohn our essentially moral desire to empathize with others is the *basis* for our apprecaition of the beautiful, and aour enjoyment of occasion for successful communcation of feelings with or at least from others is constitutive of the pleasure of the beautiful." (163) In grounding aesthetic experience in his own experience of art of his time, Cohn does not want to collapse the moral into the aesthetic. He identifies what is unique about the aesthetic by arguign that we expeirence theinner life of others in a "determinate form [*Gestaltung*]" and unliked Kant-- who linked dealt with form and content differently , see 163 -- but he defines it as that thing that llows what is "essential ni the epxression" of others to come forth as being central to this definite form. (163) Much of his work is focused then on "description of the ways in which the different media of the arts allow the epxression of th einner life to become clear..." (163) The value of aesthetics for Cohen (moral value) has to do  with thefact that he sees the need to express oursevles to others as a key human need. Aesthetic expereince is important becuase it "allows us to transcend the boudnaries of our individuality and to communicate with others..." (164) And unlilke Cohen, eh thinks that unlike in sciene and ethics, "in aesthetic experience we can and do attain the completion that we long for elsewhere." Cohn: "The aesthetic is completed in present intutiion [als Anschauung vorhanden[, it attains fulfillment, it is not longing but posession. Thereby it elevates the human being above the narrowness of his own life." (164)  KEY THOUGH is that although Cohn argues this he maintains the Kantian (and neo-Kantian) insistence tht "the asethetic gives us actual knowledge of the idea or a genuine guarantee of the possiblity of the complete realization of the dmands and  goals of morality." (164) In grounding aesthetic experience in actual human experience and in the value of transcending the narrowness of one's own exitence by coming to know theinner life of others, however, Cohn more closely links aesthetics and morality than did Kant. That is because, by defining aesthetics as essentially a "medium for insight not into the external world in general but into the feelings of others...the value of the aesthetic is ultimately founded in the importance of such cognition of the inner life of others for the achievment of a cultural community, thus for the achievment  of the essential goal of morality." (164-5)

* So Guyer says that both Cohen and Cohn as proponents of a neo-Kantian aesthetics have, by rejecting Kant's notion of free-play as the bsais of aesthetics and in their emphasis on the human feelings, heightened the specific "cognitive and moral significance of the asethetic" in a way that Kant did not consider. (165) Guyer notes that this can be considered their contribution to aesthetics. But he also thinks that Kant's more modest claims may sometimes be "salubrious, a strong cup of coffeee that needs to be drunk after induglling in some of the more intoxicating claims" both of absolute idealists, and in Guyer's interpreation, the "neo-Kantians..." (165)

title: Manifesting, Producing, and Mobilizing Historical Consciosness in the 'Postmodern Condition'
text:
Summary Note

 

Toews reviews a 2007 edited collection of essays entitled Manifestoes for History, edited by Keith Jenkins, Sue Morgan, and Alan Munslow.  The collection, which purports to provide a diverse point of view, Toews points out is dominated by "those who recognize and affirm a modern/postmodern divide." (259)

Toews breaks down the quesitons addressed in the volume into three parts which he lays out on 259-260:

1) Are the theoretical and discplinary conflicts of the last 1/4 of the 20th century simply typical of the "continual process of reviisson that sustains the very idea of historical consicosness" or was there an "epochal shift"?  If there was an end to the "experiment of modernity"--which the authors take as axiomatic he points out--then does this mean we have aslo reached the "end" of history?  What defines the current activity of historical consciousness?  Is it limited to professional historians?

2) Related to #1, but more "specific": The past is understood by the editors as "an aggregate of representations, interpretations, or constructions." The past is always "absent" then "not just in the epistemological sense that we can only know it as a stissue of representations and not as  objective, empirically verifiable reality, but also in the ontological sense that the being of the past is unavailable to us.  However much we may desire to touch, feel, smell, hear, that is 'experience' the past, such encounters will always remain beyond our reach.  The past has no agency, no independent voice in our actions and conversations" (259) That claim he links to a belief that the "linguistic turn" in historiography and historical theory is "irreversable." (259, bottom).  But that idea has bene udner attack he says for a long time, and not "just from 'conservative' believers in the autonomous, centered subject of modernity and its ability to tell the truth about the past or judge the events of the past on the basis of universalizable, ethical codes obligating all autonomous subjects." (260)  It has been attacked in relation to the idea that the linguistic turn in its reductive and totlaizing forms, esp as represnted by an old guard, must be broken.  So: "has the focus on linguistic representation and textualized constrution of meaning unduly restrited the scope and diversity of debates concernting the contemporary crisis in historical conscoiusness?  Should the 'linguistic turn' give way to a more complex view of the post modern condition, perhaps one that recognizes the continuing, tangible presence in the present of the ruins or fragements of the past life that persistently make their own demands to be heard as we construct our representations, and that recognizes more obviously the role of mateiral practice in the construction of historical experience?" (260) Toews also notes that in the volume the index contains no links to Walter Benjamin, but does reference W.G. Sebald as a "somewhat ghostly presence witnessing to the complex contradictions, ambiguities, and hybridities, to the entanglement of textual construction and material presence, in current debates about the production of historical consciousness 'after' the linguistic turn." (260)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.050 Sexual segregation fueled by fear of socialism in Harper

Rosenberg argues that Harper's desire to demonstrat ethe utility of science to businessmen and to avoid identification of sociology with socialism drove sexual segregation (50) -- which isolated reform as in creation of a school of social work.  

Harper's concern came after Pullman STrike in 1894 when economist Edward Bemis, who advocated socializaiton of municipal services, defnded the railroad's case against the strikers (50)  Harper chasties Bemis and Bemis was soon dismissed from the University.  (50)  Albion Small did not defend Bemis much, writing him that "I do not say tha tyour conclusions are wrong, but in theese days a manis not considered scientific, who claims to speak on more than one small corner of a subject." (Samll quoted on 50).  Now Rosenberg writes; "Because many women, both inside and outside the university, tended to be more outspoken on political issues than eihte rSmall or Harper though proper, prompting the identification of socialism not just with sociologists but with feminist sociologists in particulra, sexual segregation seemed all the more crucial to those who would protect the university's reputation as abastion of authority and respectability." (51)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.040-41 W.I. Thomas's diss develops theory of female uniqueness 

Using Geddes (who work addressed Weismann's) Thomas established a notion of difference of females  and males at the cellular level.  (40) At cellular level, maleness an expending of energy; femaleness a conserving of energy.   He combined Ward's gynecocentric thoery and Geddes' theory of sexual metabolism.  He linked female "anabolism" (versus kataboolism, to woman's reproductive system.  and used it to explain her "superior psychological irritability..."  (41)    but although he saw man as more advanced, he also argued that "evolutionary development had achieved such complexity that man's katabolic destructiveness, militarism, and competetiveness were posing a serious social danger." (41, Rosenberg's words)  And Thomas thought (his words) that "It is now beginning to be true that the energies of women may find expression in forms of activity appropriate to their nature...and this will doubtless, in thelong run, favor construtive, as over against destructive, modes of social interaction." (quoted on 41).

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text: p.035-65 CHAPTER 2: Anthropology in the Liberal Age, 1879-1929

title: The Radicalism of the American Revolution
text:
D Part III -- Democracy

15. The Assault on Aristocracy

* By the end of the 18th century, W says, the Federalist leaders "relatively speaking, had already lost most of the substantial economic and social pwoer that had made aristocracies traditionally viable." (271)

* Wood explains in detail the arguments of Abraham Bishop of Connecticut who had been college educated at Yale in 1778, but became an ardent opponent of the Constitution and of the Federalists.  His critique was typical of the rhetoric of the Republican party in that he attacked the Federalists as corrupt leaders who were in the process of setting up a financial structure that was "a British funding system, Americanized." (272)   But what was unique is that he possessed an "acutely modern understanding of culture."  (272)  He realized that American's ideas were often in a "state of most absolute subordination to mere human invention."  (272)  He wanted Americans to deconstruct their artificial belief that certain men were better able to lead.  He wanted to convince people that their sense of inferority to a gentry elite was based on delusion.  But in saying this, he admitted that these elite were superior in education and manner, but these qualities made them less able to lead, not more.  He questioned the assumption that such "great men" were better leaders.  He noted that these men were different so that their claim to represent the common people was wrong.  (271-274). Bishops' not the only attack on aristocracy, but the most oustlandish.

*  Everywhere Wood says aristocrats were "besieged" relentleslly by common people who had never gone to college.  These men were sick, Wood says, of being depicted as "factious, narrow, parochial, and illiberal and were unwilling to defer any longer.." (276)

* Wood thinks this was the central transformation of the Revolutinon.  All these attacks by ordinary men on aristocrats weakened the northern gentry, underminging their ability to rule, even Wood says, Jefferson's "natural aristocracy."  "Here in this destruction of aristocracy...was the real American Revolution--a radical alteration in the nature of American society whose effects are still being felt today." (276)

* Most critics of the gentry did not, as Bishop, emphasize differences between commoners and gentry, but rather emphasizeed their similarity so as to undermine their claims to distinctiveness and privilege. (276)

* The meaning of work/lesiure shifted.  Whereas aristocrats tried to show how little they worked, that was not any longer something people did.  There was a new emphasis on the importance and dignity of work. (277)  This porduced new attacks on aristocratic idleness, affecting in particular southern society where the aristocracy existed in a life of leisrue based on the work of salves.  (277-278).

*

title: The Origins of American Social Science
text:
[54-] [DR on Intellectual Authority ]
In Gilded Age: 
Dorothy tells the story of the rise of the professions in relation to a problem of intellectual authority.  It is a problem of maintaining the nationalist exceptionalist ideology in the face of the growing power of science and the discrediting of religious providential determinants of America's special course:
"The problem of intellectual authority developed during the 1860s and 1870s, as the harmony between science and religion declared by virtually all segments of Protestant Christianity proved incresaingly difficult to maintain."  (54)  
Not going into this right now, but need to re-read these pages in terms of this problem...for she tells the story through it.   The attempt to found sciences is part of an attempt reassert intellectual authority and maintain this nationalist ideology.  
In Progressive Era: 156-162.

title: Questions Concerning Certain Faculties Claimed For Man
text:
General Notes for Class

(not teaching so light notes)

Q1 :

* Def'n inutition: "inutition will be taken as signifying a cognition not determined by a previous cognition of the same object, and therefore so determined by something out of the consciousness." (18) He also said it  can be thought of as a "premiss not itself a conclusion" (18) 

* He says right off the bat: "There is no evidence that we have this faculty, except that we seem to feel that we have it." (19) 

* He sees a similarity in our acceptance of the existence of intutition with the Medieval acceptance of the idea of "external authority". (19)  "...the credibility of authority was regarded by men of that time siply as an ultimate premiss, as a cognition not determined by a previous cognition of the same object, or in our terms, as an intuition." (19)  But those claims of authority were called into doubt becasue there were disagreements about what authority meant; so too can intuition be called into doubt.  (19-20)

* He shows how the intuitive faculty of having knowledge can be complicated in any number of examples 19-25.  He's showing often that intuited knowledge is not always purely intuited, or it is hard for us to know what is simply known and what is perceived, or what is misperceived in fact.  Take his example on 22-24 about how we perceive space: is this a form of intuited "immediate knowledge."  He suggests not because, drawing on pscyhological/neurological ideas, we can explain it in other ways., which he does on 23.  Point is that there's a perception of "phenomena of extreme complexity" and he says it is well-known in this case that when that is the case and when those phebnomena can be "reduced to order or mediate simplicity by the application of a certain conception, that conception sooner or later arises in application to those phenomena."  (24)  In this case, that concept is the concept of "extension" (of space). 

* Having given these examples, he points out that since we can explain these facts without recourse to an intuitive faculty, then "there are ...very strong reasons for disbelieving the existience of thsi facutly." (25) 

IN the next series of questions, he will show why we should doubt the existence of this intuitive facutly:

Q2: Do we have an intuitive self-consciousness?

* Self-consciousness is not the same as consciousness, from the internal sense, or from "pure apperception." (26)  All cognition he says is "a consciousness of the object as represented" (26)  Self-consciousness refers to a "knowledge of ourselves." (26)  Pure apperception is "the self-assertion of THE ego; the self-consciousness here meant is the recognition of my private self." (26)  But hoow then do we have this self-consiousness?

* It is not obvious taht we have an intutitive faculty (Q1) because we can't distinguish an intuitive power of understanding from a cognitive one as he showed vv spatial perception.  (26) So can we do the same with self-consciousess, explain it in other ways than intuition?

* He takes as his case in point children.  They have no self-consciousness or an imperfect one.  But they have powers of cognition.  Their body is very imporrtant, it is the center of the world, and "Only what it touches has any actual and present feeling; only what it faces has any actual color; only what is on its tongue has any actual taste." (27) 

* Going further in this explanation of child's development he argues that as the child learns he begins to undertand language, and the link between souds and actions or facts.  And Peirce thins that ti is is a"about this time" that the cihld "beings to find that what these people about him say is the very best evidence of fact.  So much, so that testimony is even a stronger mark of fact than the facts themselves, or rather than what we must now be thought of as the appearances themselves." (28)  So what people say -- or testimony -- becomes important, more important than the facts. 

* But then the child is told the stove is hot, but he think not, and then he touches it and it is, and then he discovers ignorance and error.  Here Peirce thinks that self-consciousness begins.  Indeed he says: "Ignorance and error are all that distinguish our private selves fromt he absolute ego of pure apperception." (29) 

* Here then is an explanation of self-consciousness not stemming from intutition.  So then he says at the end that the only "argument worth noticing for the exstience of an intuitive self-consciousness is this: We are more certain of our own exitence than of any other fact; a premiss can not determine a conclusion to be more certain than it is itself; hence, our own existence cannot have been inferred from any other fact." (29)  The first part of this argument--that we are so certain of our own existence--is ok, but the second logical arugment is false he says.  Because in fact "A conclusion cannot be more certain than that some one of the facts which support it is true, but it may easily be more certain than any one of those facts."  He gives an example of witnesses of events who testify.  Believing them depends on the fact that they are to be believed.  But he says "the fact testified to is made more certain than that any one of those men is generally to be believed."  (30)  Applying this to the idea of self-consciousness, he says that "to the developed mind of man, his own existence is supported by every other fact, and is, therefore, incomparably more certain than any one of these facts.  But it cannot be said to be more certain than that there is another fact, since there is no doubt perceptible in either case." (30) 

[ This part seems key!!  Our self-consciousness as he explains in disproving the intuitive notion is grounded in testimony, that causes us to become aware at some point of our own ignorance and error.  That testimony is also of a socail nature--it happens in groups.  Groups of witnesses make claims about the world of facts that become more important than the facts themselves.  Then also as eh reasons at the end while disproving the logical argument for intuitive self-consciousness, these testimonies become truer, more certain, than the credibility/accuracy of those making them; ie there can always be a different set of testimonies.  He's using a kind of pragmatic logic perhaps--pragmatic because it's based on an awareness of the effect of belief--to undo certainty about intuitive self-consciousenss....we rely on testimony and its effect for our self-consciousenss, and our reliance on testimony also means we can't logically justify a necessary belief in an intuitive self-consciousnes...]

Q3: Can we distinguish intuitively between the subjective and objective elements of a cognition?

* What's a cognition? It's "something represented, or that of which we are conscious, and some action or passion of the self whereby it becomes represented." (30) The cognition has a subjective and objective element: the subjective element is I think the "action or passion" that causes the objectve to re represneted; the objective is the representation?? His langauge is very unclear here.  But the subjective element is "not necessarily immediately known" awhereas the "cognition itself is an intutition of its objective element..." (30)

* The question is whether there is also an inutition of the subjective element that comes along with each cognition?

* At first, eh says the asnwers seems to be yes, simply because we seem to be able to distinguish dreams from reality, or we know the difference "between seein a color and imagining it..." (30) 

* But since we "cannot intutiively know that a cognition is intuitive" (Q1 and Q2) (31)  we cannot know that we have this faculty intuitively. 

* So is it "necessary" to imagine that we have this ability to distinguish subjective and objective elements of cognition?  The evidence of knowing the difference between dreams and reality is not convincing, because what is at issue is not whether we are aware of different situations in what "is present to th emind" but whether we can know of diffeerent "modes of consciousness" "indepdently of any such distinctions in the immediate objects of consciousness." (31)  And in this case of dreams, the difference is created by the different in the immediate objects of consciousness... (31) 

* Another distinction: belief versus conception.  We know the difference.  But is this due to some intuitive sense?  He says we distinguish the two by "a peculiar feeling of conviction" that accompanies belief.  Then he says we see belief as "that judgement which is accompanied by this feeilng, or as that judgement from which a man will act."  (31)  The former can be called sensational judgement and the latter active.  But returning to the point he made above.  The difference is again here not based on intutiion.  In the case of sensational judgement, the capacity is only to feel the sensations of the judgement, not intution.  In the case of active judgement, again it's not intutiton, but rather the understanding of its existence is "discovered by the observation of external facts and by inference from the sensation of conviction which usually accompanies it." (32)  IE initution is not needed!!

Q4: Wehther we know the world introspectively or "whether our whole knowledge of he internal wordl is dervied from the observation of external facts"  (32)

* He's not trying to say the external world is real, only that "there is a certain set of facts which are ordinarily regarded as external, while others are regarded as internal." (32)  IE He's not neccessarily legitimizing metaphysical dualism as true. 

* Introspecition means "a direct perception of the internal world, but not necessarily a perception of it as internal." (32) 

* He says that perception has an "internal element" in one sense.  Ie that "every sensation is partly determined by internal conditon."  He gives the exampel of "redness."  As a sensation, redness is somehow sensed in the way it is "owing to the constitution of the mind" and in that sense it is "something internal."  But it arises only as a "predicate of something external." (32)  This  isn't tryue for all sesnations, such as emotions "which appear to arise in the first place,  not as predciates at all." (32)  So then given the existence of emotins maybe some "knowledge of the mind may be obtained, which is not inferred from any character of outward things." (32)

* But because we have no way to distinguish different subjective modes of consciousness (Q3), we cannot know intuitively or self-evidently that we possess this capacity.  (32-33)

* Then he attacks the idea that he just presented that emotions arise without any predicate.  He says that although they have no "determinate and constant character in its object," the emotion is still "some relative character in the outward thing which makes him angry..." (33)  The difference between emotion and an "objective intellectual judgement" he says is that the latter is "relative to human nature or to mind in general" whereas the latter is relative to the "particular circumstances and disposition of a particular man at a particular time." (33)  And this he says is true also for moral judgement and for beauty!!! "Good and bad are feeling which first arise as predicates, and therefore are either predicates of the not-I, or are determined by previous cognitions (there being no intuitive power of distinguishing subjective elements of consciousness.)" (33) 

* This means then that we may not really be dealing with anything that is purely introspective even with emotions, morality, and beauty.  This is surely a jab at Kant.  (33)

* Then he asks, do we need to think this introspective power exists for the saking of "willing".  And he rejects this saying that the capcaity for volition is just "the power of concentrating the attention, of abstractign." (33) And this power can be "inferred" from the existence of abstract objects, just as the power of seeing can be inferred from the existence of colored things. (33)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.103-106 By WWI Ideas of male and female intellect eroded

Woolley and Thompson put together reviews of the literature on sex difference in spcyhology between 1910 and 1918.  They traced a growing conssensus that "intelligence should no longer be considered a secondary sex characteristic." (103)  And later Rosenberg rwrites that "By 1918 references to sex differences in intelligence were beginning to go out of style in psychology.  As Hollingwroth remarked: 'It was formerly kind of convention to include in the summary or results of a study where obth male and female subjects participated, a paragarph on 'sex differences.'  There seems now to be a growing tendency among those who have studied individual differences most extensively to omit this customary paragarph.'" (105)

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text:
p.036 Setting for this era of Ant is social change

Backdrop he uses.  Advance of "white civilization" into Ohio and Mississippi Valleys.  Development of new urban industrial centers.  End of Indian Wars in 1880s but new calls for imperialism in Carribbean, Latin America, Pacific and farther east.  Creation and expansion of Federal bureaucracy, increase in # of colleges, new professions.  (35-36)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.049  Talbot abandons hope to make santiary sccience or public health focus of social and physical sciences...

1902 Sheasks haperto put her in charge of departmet devoted to the "household." (49) So Harper eliinates two years later the field of sanitary science within sociology and establishes a separate dpt. called "householdadministration." (49)  This Rosenberg says "eliminated the androgynous tone of the field she had first sough to create." (49) It limited Talbot's field of competetivence.  "Thus the trned toward sepcialization merged with traditional assumptions regarding sex roles to limit women's inlfuence within the university...[and] Talbot fell victim to the very process of academic sexual segregation that she was trying to fight." (49)

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text: p.006-34 CHAPTER 1: "Anthropology in the New Republic 1776-1879"

title: The First Boasian: Alfred Kroeber and Franz Boas, 1896-1905
text:
00 Summary 00

Jacknis' goal in this essay is a bit unclear to me.  He seems to be making an argument at the end that despite Kroeber and Boas' differences (and in particular Boas' dissapointment with Kroeber's work) that their similarities in outlook were greater than their differences.  See 529-529.  

However, lot's of a good detail information in this article.

title: Professions and Patriarchy
text:
Chapter 2

This chapter is particualrly useful and I might want to return to it occasionally for its survey of the literature on professions.

She starts out with a look and the analysis of Professions and Power.  Johnson (1972) reocneptualized the profession as not an "occupation per se but a mode of controlling an occupation" and this has become the "new ortodoxy in the sociology of profssions." (40)

There has been a "conceptual revolution in the sociology of professions from the dominance of the 'trait' and 'fucntionliast' paradigms through to the jostling for position between neo-Weberian and neo-Marxist paradigms..." Cropmpton 1990 analyzes this.  Parsons 1954 article was the fucntionlaist paradigm.  It "empahised the distinctiveness of modern professions, lcoating their development with the rationalising tendencies of the wider society." (40)

"'Trait' approaches attempted to identify precisely what constitued this distinctiveness, looking for essential attributes or traits (cf Greenwood 1957)." (40)

She also notes Wilenskiy's 1964 article that discussed the "process" whereby an occupation turned itself into a profession.  She says this was less "static." (40)

She says that these approaches "fondered on the sheer diversity of elements tha various authors identiifed as providing the ssence of profession..." (40)

Johnson's critique entered at this point and the "kernel" of the critique was in Johnson's words:

"Not only do 'trait' approaches tend to incoroporate the professionals' own definitions of themselves in seemingly neutral categories, but the categories tend to be derived from the analysis of a very few professional bodies and included features of professional organisation nd practice which found full epxression on in Anglo-American culture at a particular time in the historical development of the professions." (quoted on 41)

Johnsons' critique has persisted in a neo-Weberian perspective on preofessionalisation.  Neo-Weberian conepts hav been deployed to support this idea of the profession as ameans of control over an occupation.  She cites Freidson 1970a and 1970b and Parkin 1979 and Parry and Parry 1976.  All have defined "professionalisation as a strategy of social closure and a means of collective social mobility..." (42)

Of these only Parry and Parry touched upon gender, however.

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text:
p. 484 -486 Further Specification of Metadiscourse

They describe three processes: entextualizaiton, detextualization, and retextualization.

The first is like Boas teaching Hunt how to write certain words and critiquing his texts; the second is the erasure of that process, the detextualization of the process of production of the text, and retexutalization is when the finsihed text enters into a new textual context of professsoinal anthropology.

So herein the authors have already critiqued Boas's erasure of the process of production of the text.

title: The First Boasian: Alfred Kroeber and Franz Boas, 1896-1905
text:
p.522  Kroeber Diss: reject search for origins

Kroeber's dissertation Jacknis describes as an "important contribution to the developing Boasian critique of cultural evolution." (522)  He cites a further 1922 article by himself "The Artist Himself..." in The Early Years of Native American History..., 134-161.  As well as a piece by Thoresent "Art, Evolution, and History: A CAse Study of Paradigm Change in Anthropology" Journal of hIsotry of Behavioral Sciences 13: 107-125.  The subject was whether "Arapaho specimens could shed light on the origins of decorative designs in realistic or geometric impulses, as well as th erleation between form and meaning, an important concern of 19th-century evolutionists, which was then under review by Boas.  Finding both tendencies to be present and equally developed in Arapaho art, Kroeber conlcuded that the evolutionists' search for origins was futile." (523).

so he Kroeber wrote: "The fundamental error of the common anthropological [comparative] method is that it isolates phenomena and seeks isolated causes fo rthem.  IN reality, ethnic phenomena doo not exist separately: they have their being only in culture." (quoted on 523, see diss, 1901, p. 335).

title: Liberalism Repatriated: Prospects of an Anthropology of Antiracism
text:
p.333-4 The Problem 1st via the French Example

Tejani describes the French law banning the hijab this way: the decision to ban it was a rational/practical decision based on the concerns of teachers that hijab suggested a student had been coerced, and yet that decision was influenced by the underlying moral sensibility which saw the hijab as a religious sign which indicated religious coercion, i.e. the basic underlying French moral sensibility that "a cultural symbol with any religious connotation to be a sign of religious passion and thus offensive to ppers..." (333).

The moral sensibility which cannot reflect on itself, that sees itself as universal, thus supports the rational decision to ban the hijab.  

The relationship between moral sensibility and critical rational knowledge in relation to differences between humans he roots in the civilization v. kultur difference, a tradition which he presnets as being a protean form of racial thought which developed into racial thought, and then more explicitly racial-biological notions of colonialism.  

But given these differences, as what he calls the "diaspora of liberalism" -- i.e. its spread to the rest of the world -- raised teh question of how these peoples, whose values were so different, could be assimilated.  

This ultimately creates what he calls an "assimilationsist liberalism" -- which he refers to noting Povinelli again, only occured once the colonial populations had been essentially destroyed.

title: Classical Social Theory and the Origins of Modern Sociology
text:
General Notes


Giddens executes a critique of the standard history of sociology in this article, attempting to dispel a set of "myths" (laid out in works by Parsons, Nisbet, and Dahrendorf) about the discipline's development: namely, the myth that "order" is the central concern of sociology, the myth that the classical sociologists, Durkheim and Weber, were motivated by a conservative reactino against revolution, and finally the myth of schism--that the only two solution to the problem of order are that of Parsons', i.e. consensus, or that most clearly expressed in Marx, ie emphasis on conflict.  The overall effect Giddens seems to be aiming to achieve is to debunk a set of quasi-historical interpretations of the hsitory of sociological theory that serve to limit sociology's ability to develop in the new directinos that Giddens thinks are necessary to grapple with the problems of the future (that is, the context for the article is, as stated on 715-716 that sociology is at a "crossroads" having, I think< to do with the critique of structural-functioanlism)

After dispelliing a series of myths about sociology's epistemological development, contained in the "myths" just listed, Giddens then seeks to blow up the "substantive correlate" (718) of structural-functionalism: the "theory of industrial society," which Giddens thinks is an inadequate focal point of this tradition of sociology, belonging in fact to that generation of writers from 1890-1920 for whom the main tension was in fact the tension between traditional agrarian  society and the new urban industrialized society.  This is no longer a useful theory in the 20th century when "the main 'internal' divisions and strains in the advacned societies are no longer, as in the 19th and early 20th centuries, based upon the tensions between urban-industrial centers and the centrifugal pull of the rural hinterland.  He also argues that the theory of industrial society has a similarly "time-bound" "antipolitical bias," a product of the fact that in the 19th century there existed a "covert assumption" that "the State is subordinate to society, and that consequently politics can be explained, or, more accurately, explained away, by reference ot more deply layered social phenomena." (719) He explains other related assumptions on 720.  And then describes the possibilites of a sociology that has borken free of the industrial theory of society on 721-722.

The most relevant argument in this article for my purposes re the understanding of the history of sociology is a product of his dispelling all of these other myths.  Parsons method (or reason) for destructing these myths is a desire to weaken the largest narrative idea of a "great divide" between what he calls the "prehistory of social theory, when it had not yet been disentangled from speculative philosophy or the philosophy of history" and the thinkers of the period from 1890 to 1920--Durkheim, Weber as well as Pareto, Michels, Simmel... (703-704).  This narrative of the "great dividde" was most powerfully established as orthodoxy by Parsons' The Structure of Social Action.  By attacking they myths described above Giddens is essentially weakening arguments about the distinctiveness of this generation.  The reason for this critique becomes clear in a last section in which he brushes aside claims that in this generation socials cience was cfinally becomign "scientific" as well as the claim that their writings were a "conservative" defense of bourgeois society.  He points out that each writer wrote in a different socio-political context--his explanation is good on 724-725--and that ultimately "[b]oth conservatism and socialism thus figure in the political backgrounds of both Kurkheim and Weber."  The work of each, Giddens finally argues, is "an attem[pt to rethink the foundation of liberalism in conditions in which liberal individualism and its base in social theory, namely, utilitarian philosophy, developed in the British situation, were manifestly inappropriate." (725-726).  The different situations against which Durkheim and Weber wrote altered their projects: "Weber worked against the backdrop not of  asuccessful revolution (1789) but of a failed one (1848) and in the shadow of Bismarck's unification of the German state through military triumph...Durkheim's Division of Labor and the theory of the state which he later elaborated were directed twoard resolving the 'legacy of the Revolution' as he saw it: the distance between the ideals of freedom and equality heralded in 1789, and the reality of social stagnation and resistance to cahnge which he thought were epitomized by the disasters of the war of 1870--the very war which sealed German unity--and by the repression of the Commune." (726)

Ultimately, Giddens isn't saying that the 1890-1920 generation was not distinct, but not in the way that Parsons, Nisbet, and Dahrendorf have described.  Here's what he thinks made them unique: "First, as I've already tried to show, an attempt to rethinking the foundations of liberalism in the face of the twin challenge of revolutionary socialism and conservatism.  Second, the successful beginning of sociology as an accepted subject in the university curriculum....Third, a greatly heightened sensitivity to the study of other cultures and a breaking away from European ethnocentrism.  Foruth, and not unconnected with the third point, a general resurgence of concern with the soruces of unreason in human social existence (see Hughes 1958)."  (726)  NOTE: He's citing Huges' Consciousness and Society.

title: The Making of the Modern University: Intellectual Transformation and The Marginalization of Morality
text:
p.003 Old conception of turth: "unity of truth" institutionalized in colleges

"unity of truth" was institutionalized into higher ed in first half of the 19th-century. it
was "frankly normative: it informed students of their dutues to their family, their community, their 
country, and God." (3)

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text: p.013-053 CHAPTER 1: EXPERTS ALL

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.015 Political Economy caused revolutionin family relations...

Crucial to Sklansky's argument is the ideathat "the social scientific model of universal human rights incited feminist as well as antislavery thought in the early republic, along with a 'revolution agianst patriarchal authority' within the family itself." (15)  This despite the fact that political economy largely excluded consideration of family relations among other things.

 

This is crucial to his argument because he is making a defense of classical political economy...

title: Verging on Etra-Vagance: Anthropology, Hisotry, Religion, Literature, Arts...Showbiz
text: (2) p.23-24 Ultra-Objectivity Concept for Boon, gegen the dichotomy between objectivity and subjectivity (i.e. the critique of early Anth as not objective by people who proposed to be doing objective work). Ultraobjectivity is a concept he tries to define via Webster's as something that "is 'intersubjectively observable' in the 'extreme ....beyond what is ordinary, proper.'" (23) He also calls it , via W. James, "radical empiricism." {that relation would need at least to be epxlained a bit] My impression is that it is something like a kind of objectivity gained by being honest about not knowing for sure what something is.... I also got this sense from earlier quote: "I side with interpretive skepticism regarding objectivity in cultural matters. However, far from simply disavowing 'objectivity,' I object to narrow positivism in hopes of a fuller objectivity..." (23) Methodologically this has a lot do with open reading. Because what he calls "Salutary doubt," he says, "springs from empircial and textual details of intricate social , political, and linguistic configurations. " (24) As well as he suggests in "circumstances of conflictual translation--the very circumstances where anthropology transpires." (i..e the "field"). (24) This then leads to Benedict since he things that approached "rituals as 'readings'" and he will perform the ritual of re-reading her text. (24)

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1051 - 1052 Basic Question: Is Social Work a Profession?

This question asked in 1930 essay in Survey, a journal of social service reform.  Here Miss Case-Worker" named Jane is set against Lady Bountiful, the old-fashioned, voluntary social worker. 

 The answer given is yes she is.   But Walkowiz points out that the answer was no so easy, in particular "objectivity and raitonality were conventionally associated with male professional culture ...[so] the scientific model created its own tensions for female social workers." (1051)

Hi spoint is that they were struggling to construct a "work identity" as part of a "transformed white-collar work force.  

See also his f.n. #4, with many citations of work on professions dominated by women.  Melosh in particular concludes in Physician's hand as quotedin f.n.: "...in broader cultural terms, nursing by definition cannot be a profession because most nurses are women." (f.n. #4 1052)  After giving the citations Walkowitz writes: "These studies all identify the problem of understanding women in these profession as a conflict between professionalization and femininity or between professionalization and proletarinization, implicitly assuming these dyads were mutually exclusive or antagonistic categories. " (f.n. #4 1052)

Ultimately, Walkowitz sets out the idea that the search for this new work identity failed: "...this post-war, post-suffrage generation sought both a career and family, albeit not necessarily at the same time.  The burgeoning consumer family economy in the 1920s further complicated women's work expectations.  A professional standard of living dictated new levels of material acquisition supposedly appropriate to a white-collar middle-class occupations stratum.  This consumer culture and ambiguities about respectable women's public roles compelled women to seek a new work identity.  But none of the available ideologies and representations produced by mass media or by union an dprofessional associations could serve to orient female social workers in a world of work shaped by the contradictory imperatives of domesticity, career, and consumption. " (1052)  

What emerged he argues were two categories, that didn't come into explicit use until the 60s: the Professional Woman "a female social worker who accepted the 'male' ideology" (1052) and the Professional Worker, "a 'neutered' white-collar proletarian" (1052).  W thinks that neither "adequately expressed the gendered character of social work." (1052)

title: Transnational History in Historical Perspective: Bastian's Museum Project
text:
Notes 9/2013:

Penny is here revisiting Bastian who he has worked on before. Having delved a bit into global/transnational history literature, he comes across quotes in Bastian's oevre that give him a different view of the man. He sees ways in which Bastian was avoiding closure in his theoretical vision. The most compelling places in which Penny sees this are in Bastian's vision of his museum exhibits, which were to be open and not bounded, with few borders. A particularly compelling quote from an 1877 essay entitled "Ethnologische Erörterung" sounds like this:

the drive for a systematic closure is a natural wish in the human heart, but not every wish on earth can find its fulfillment. If the obvious impossibility of completing the entere building in the existing generation stands in front of ethnology, then there is no use in building ephemeral houses of cards to appease the impactience of spectators. (52)

Penny then writes:

For Bastian, the ideal ethnographic museum would contain material culture from all areas of the world and all periods of history. But it would not be constructed to articulate pointed narratives. Bastian favored open collections in which objects were arranged in cabinets made of glass and steel, flooded by natural light from large windows and glass ceilings, and position in such a way that scientists could move easily through the goegraphically organized displays, gain an overview of the objects from entire regions, and mae mental connections between the material cultures of people living in different times and places. This design differed markedly from art museum, ntural history museums, or even colonial musums and exhibitions taht gained populatiy alter in the century. No particular object, grouping,  or arrangement was supposed to stand out or be emphasized; there was no developmental series of artificats; and the museum's goal was not explicitly pedagogical. Bastian's ddisplays were expcted to facilitate the location and exploration of the elementary characteristics of a unitary humanity -- the fundamental nature of "the" human being (52)

On this quote, Penny cites Bastian, "Führer durch die Ethnograpische Abtheilung" (Berlin: W. Spemann) , p.3 and Königliche Museen zu Berlin, Führer durch das Museum für Völkerkunde, 2nd ed., Berlin, p.7

Ultimately, what Penny is up to  is that he wants to point out that Bastian is a key precursor to transnational historigoraphy. Apparently, Osterhammel has already cited the Boasians as theorists of globalization: "Osterhammel's eigtheen and nineteenth centuries are full of global thinkers who ultimately produce the Boasians we continue to embrace; thinkers whose work on globzieation he reminds us, should not only be noted, but taken seirously." (53) Penny wants to add that Bastian may be helpful in showing us the link fro Alexander Humboldt to Boas, but also for his "insights into the multiplicity of humanit and the flows of  human histories." (54)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.039  Veblen also did not see subordination of women as good.

He supported women's rejection of paternalism.  Saw it as a "reeassertion of ancient habits of thought"...leading to an ideal of workmanship that would replace privat eproperty (39)

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text:
p. 486 - 491 The "Collaborative Production" of Texts

They focus on Boas' relatiopnship to Hunt (and don't conside rhis relation to Henry Tate and others).  

-- Boas encountered resistance from some sources who had forgotten tales or would not relate them.  Boas wrote about recalcitrant Clatsop speakers: "The women were not able to grasp what I wanted; they claimed to have forgotten their myths and traditions, and could not or would not give me any connected texts."  (quoted from Chinook Texts Bureau of Ethnology, Bulletin No. 20 (Washington, D.C., 1894).  The authors describe Boas's attempts to overcome such resistance as a "synecdochic instance of colonial relations." (487)  Why? Their was objectification of people's traditions -- for "sale"  and so they say the scientific enterprise was "part of larger structures of political-economic exchange." (487)    f.n. 18 in Berman's book, she notes that Hunt asked for funds to pay elders for stories.  And Boas was in a position of power here and used money as a threat, so he threatened hunt that the museum would cut off funds if Hunt did not produce work.  (487)  And Stocking noted that Boas notes recurring "..."expressions of vexation when an uncooperative Indian slowed up Boas's work or wwasted his time with an 'idiotic' story, or when he found it necesssary to become 'a little rough' with informats in order to make 'their attitude improve.'" (486-487).   (that from 204 in Stockings Race, Culture...") 

-- The authors also note that Boas' instructions to hunt steered Hunt toward the collection of "old" objects and associated stories or texts -- and "[t]his reciprocal associaiton between texts and artifacts increased the value of both sets of objects through reciprocal processes of traditionalization and authentification." (489  Boas they say was particularly interested in "traditional speech." (489)  He wrote to Leohnhard Shultze-Jena t Phillips University in Marburg (Germany) to say "We are at the present time engaged in a systematic study of American Languages.  We want particularly to rescue the vanishing forms of speech." (quoted on 489, from Boas to Schultze-Jena, 10 Sept.1928, American Phil. Soc).

-- Boas also instructed Huntn about the thematic focus and long-range interests of his work and the collections than needed to be done.  The authors describe these instructions as "a guide to the entextualizaiton of 'Kwakiutl' culture" (490)  They say his focus shifted "over the years from technology and foodways to ethnozoology and ethnobotany to social organization and finally to 'the way the Indians think and feel.'" (490)

-- And Boas sent the end-products of Hunt's work to Hunt.  The authors note that such a tome might have suggested to Hunt not only that "geographically bounded Native Ameircan communities could be represented through a variety of texts publishe din book form" but also they would have "provided models of the sorts of narrative structures, rhetorical parameters, and stylistic features that constitute this type of representation." (490)  But the authors note that Boas did not allow Hunt to develop this kind of awareness which they desire as "intertextual relations" (490) Instead, Boas remained dubious of the quality of their work, its syntactic accuracy and of Hunt's "authority to represent 'Kwakiutl culture'" (491)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text: p.162- 168 Exposure to Ethnology Moves to D.C. when her husband is elected in 1905. Is there until 1911. Not an easy time. D.C. more conventional. But she stays with ethnology. She goes to Phillipines on congressional junket with William Taft in 1905, and it is a kind of exposure to fieldwork Rosenberg says. (162). Also her look at D.C. culture is a kind of fieldwork. (162). Rosenberg says that Parsons was alwyas skeptical of Giddings evolutionism. She liked Bosa' work Rosenbergg says. Rosenberg quotes Boas from 1942 about why anthropology appealed to Parsons as a woman. This is interesting, but a bit anachronistic for her to use in this context. (164). Boas' she notes was more egalitarian, and he also believed that social habit constructed people's abilities (like Helen Thompson e.g.), but Rosenberg also notes thatwhile he was open to women's participation he did not necssariy encourage it. (see 166)...Women came into the department hwne he was exile d to Banard durin gWWI. and women came to him as they had Giddings (166). Also Rosenberg notes that Boas was older and so not threatened by the women. (166) Parsons thought ethnology could be helpful. Sociology she said "never seriously considered societies other than those related to or constituting our own civilization." (166) Rosenberg makes a funny observation: "In a curious way, Parsons complemented Boas's work among primitive peoples. Whereas Boaslooked at the Eskmos and saw himself, Parsons looked at her friends and saw primitive people. " (167). Parsons fieldwork was limiited prior to WWI, but she went to the field in the Southwest in 1910, 1912, and 1913. By 1915 Rosenberg says she was "addicted" to fieldwork trips. (167)

title: A category of the human mind: the notion of person; the notion of self
text:
p. 03 Recency of the Self 

Says that the word, used philosophically, the category and the idea of "respect" of self "in particular the respect of others (its normal state)". (3)  is new.  

NOTES: What is this of the self in terms of the Other?

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text:
p. 279 - 281  Women in 19th Century Workforce & 1st Generation of Prof. Women
