Note that the "powerful idea of a leisured female class, busily perpetuating a 'cult of domesticity,' has diverted our attention from the very real economic necessity that moved many women who were neither urban, immigrants, nor laboring poor into the work force." (279)

They note that rural New Englanders sent their daughters into teaching and millwork for the skae of a "family economic strategy"  regarding such training "as a good investment for a daughter's future, inasmuch as it provided skills for marriage, allowed for the possiblity of accumulating a meager dowry, and protected against a destitute widowhood." (279) 

Moreover the disruption of the "family economy" sent some women to work, when they lost a male head of househood for eample.  Two examples are writing or placement in the expanding federal bureaucracy.  Cindy Aaron has written of the latter in "To Barter their Souls for Gold: Female Clerks in Federal Govenment Offices, 1862-1890, JAH 67, 4 (March 1981): 833-53.  Ann Douglas has written of the writing option, but can't find citation in paper.

Such need to support oneself drove some women to work, but the authors' speculate that once they went to work, other motives developed.  they find this argment in Scott & Tilly's book Woman, Family and Work.  "In other words," they write"a familial orientation toward work gave way to a more autonomous impulse to develop or fulfill one's own interests and aspirations." (279) (279-280) 

Work then could b ea way to achieve independence from family constraints, but the tensions between the two were very difficult (280).  Tensions between family and work could be very difficult as seen in biographies of feminists such as Angelina Grimke and Charlotte Perkins Gilman, see bios by Mary Hill and Gerda Lerner.

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text:
p.072 Break down of historians' public at turn of century

Higham say s that audience or public of historians that had existed in the
19th-century began to disssapear.  "Beneath the obvious ferment of progressivism, a deeper change in the intellectual temper--less specific, less easy to define--worked in the same antihistorical direction.  The genteel and conservative cultural standards with which history had long associated itself were breaking down.  A passion for intense life, for the vitality of immediate experience, was challenging the dignified, elevated attitudes that history had always suggested.  The impetuous modern temper did not become fully evident until the 1920's, whereupon a reaction against it appeared; but the historical spirit was already reaching a low point as early as 1905, when even the costume novel went clearly out of fashion." 

Higham then also reports a failure to speak to a general audience.  Beard's An Economic Interpretation of the Constitution (1913) sold fewer than 8,000 copies over four decades "and then only with the aid of asecond edition published during the Constitutional crisis of the 1930's." (72)  

Witness quote by AHA secretary in 1917: "It is customary, he said, to regard historical scholarship as 'a harmless,though amiable pursuit, butone of little if any 'practical' use, and to look upon the student of history as a perosn who, having too few red corpuscles in his blood, is content to bury his head in the dust of the past, oblivious to the interests and exigencies of the present." (72) 

Also come control over curriculum began to wane just prior to WWI.  "First civics, then other contemporary 'social studies,' demanded recognition for ocontributing to 'social efficiency.' History had patriotic uses; otherwise it was something of a bore." (73)

title: Margaret Mead, the Samoan Girl and the Flapper: Geographies of Selfhood in Coming of Age in Samoa
text:
00 Summarial Note 00 

Firstly, this article is a good source for the popular reception and interpretation of Mead's book.  It quotes and categories many of the responses contianed in reviews of her book.  Overall the response to the book was positive by the popular press (39).  Elite magazines were more skeptical such as Menken who disliked Mead's applications of the problems to American life.  (39)

The basic argument of the book is that Mead's Coming of Age in Samoa contributed to a popularly conceived "social problem" : the flapper, see 35-36.  The flapper being a product of mass culture who was rebellious and stood for heteroxeual fun.  She spent time in movie houses, automobiles, speakeasies, and jazz clubs.  She appeared in movies and in Lewis's Main Street as Carole Milford and in F. Scott Fitzgerald's novels, women like Myra St. Calire, Isabelle, rosalind connage, Eleanor Savage, and Jill in This Side of Paradise who "compel Amory Blaine to self-knowledge..." (35) 

The article summarizes the book and the circumstances of its publication.  Then towards the end it starts to make arguments about a connection between modern conceptions of selfhood, spatialized selfhood as a hidden selfhood and self as child which she draws from a book by Carolyn Steedman, and the Samoan girl that Mead uses to characterize the Samoan culture.  She describes in the end through the reception of Mead's book that the book was received ambivalently, such that there was a mixture of envy and superiority in relation to the Samoan girl.  But her argument vis-a-vis the self is not clear.

so Molloy ultimately suggests that Coming of Age in Samoa emerged in the midst of an era in wich the "flapper with all her association of freedom, modernity, and rejection of the constraints of traditional femininity, represented lost gender, generational and sexual certainty."  (46)  She also notes that Mead's attempted to mediate these problems and suggest that anthropology through its study of these people could offers solutions... but Molloy does note here the flow of th Other into the modern self... 

Also interesting is Molloy's point that Mead was often pictured as a Samoan girl...and described as the "girl anthropologist" or the "girl scientist" and some reviewers Molloy noted that the success of her work was "due to the fact that she had 'identified herself so completely with the Samoan youth.'" (46)

title: Lost Manhood Found: Male Sexual Impotence and Victorian Culture in the United States
text:
p. 41 -2  Late 19th Century Focus on External Cause of Impotence: Overcivilization & Neurasthenia

I.e. keeping the distinction between male/female bodies, they  move away from a focus on morality in terms of the male body.  They now look to "external social pressures" as a cause, and define "overcivilization."  George M. Beard's work is central here: he deifnes neurasthenia as a result of what circumstances of modern environment, e.g. "...the 'necessity of punctuality,' 'railway travel,' and the 'disorderly city'" (42)  Beard also described Sexual Neurasthenia but never finished his work, though book was published in 1884: "Like general neurasthenia, sexual neurasthenia stemmed from the depletion of nervous energy, cauesd by overcivilization and the stifling quality of rationalized culture." (42)

Neurasthenia treated body as a "closed-energy system" or what G.J. Barker-Benfield descirbes as a "spermatic economy." (42)  Again male/female body distinction maintained.  Sexual neurasthenia in women seen as causing infertility still.  Females also a closed-energy system, but within there is a "cycle of fertility." (42-3)

Beard's notion of neurasthenia rooted also in Spencerian social development.  Notion of "arrested development" is there.  The idea that certain people can't control impulses, in particular sexual instincts.  Beard and others used these ideas.  White working-class men and blacks therfore were seen as sexual potent and immune to neurasthenia (for blacks see 45-48
).  White middle-class men then were in a kiind of crisis: they were over-civilized, controled but sexually impotent.  (44)  This led to an idealization of the artisan or working  classes: "Thus some middle-class men idealized (or paraodied) the artisan, even as they became more and more enmeshed in corporate bureaucratices that eroded the autonomy and appropriated the skills of the craftsmen." (45)

In conclusion, Mumford says that "Beardian Science"  represented full development of 19th century debility theory.  But on the other , in its recognition of the difficult conflict between civilization and sexual impotence, it indicated the next development...

title: Proletarianization and Educated Labor
text: 00 Summary Note 00 Larsons' s discussion of professionalization is useful primarily from the theoretical perspective, but also historical-empirical. His question here is primarily to assess the position of the professional classes in relation to Marx's theory of alienation, by questioning whether the professional classes experienced a process of "proletarianization." The article is useful both because of the conclusion it draws and its summary of Marx's theory of alienation and proletarianization. Whereas Larson describes Marx's description of the alienation of the manufacturing classes as having three stages (economic, organizational, and technical) which he says all "fuse", the last of these, technical alienation, is not something that professionals experience, nor is the fusing of the three forms of alienation. See 138-140, for descriptio nof alienation of the manufacturing class. This is significant because it technical alienation that in Larson's words "simplification and homogenization of industrial tasks eliminate preexisting skills and destroy the individual's indpendent assets, his bargaining power on the labor market." (139) Larsons analysis of the professional case folows p. 139 and his conclusion as stated above is made through a fairly detailed sociological analysis. pgs, 147, 170 for absence of tech. alienation and no fusing. Larson stresses in particular that b/c the professional system provides a relative degree of advantages that it offers also "a wide field for individual experiences of relative deprivation which, under certain conditions, may come to beinterpreted subjectively as 'proletarianization.'" (145) That said he maintains that b/c there is no technological alienation and no fusing of the three forms of alienation (147), the "choice of getting a degree can still be seen as an individual strategy against proletarianization in the labor market." (147) -- and on 147, top, he also notes that the credential is a defensive measure against comp. with those who have no degree at all. That said there are factors that make the "objective" situation of the professional different than the ideal situation of the professional, and Larson stresses intelligently that the professional can experience this as a very large betrayal. E.g.: "...oversupply and internal stratification can bring bout under-utilization and wastage of knowledge and skills for specific cohorts and categories of educated workers. the waste of one's abilities is, ast least, an experience of stunted growth which may be lived as a deep social betrayal of the self." (151) Larson also picks up this theme at the end again when he writes "[o]rganizational alienation may still be lived by many educated workers with unconscious reference to an image of the autonomous professional, entitled to privilege by his education and by his benign contributions to the social welfare. The failure to secure expected rewards is...an important experience. Its effeccts depend on the complex relationship between a worker's sense of 'entitlement,' his or her actual owrk life and the compensations of life out of work. When a society promises advancement through education but witholds its rewards, cynicism and anger are easy..." (170) There is a lot here, especially in terms of description of the particular forms of alienation that professionals experience and their causes. It is worth reading more closely when necessary. Didn't take full notes due to time. Other issues.

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.038-52 Sklansky's analysis of Emerson

39 -- Notion of "individualism" arrives in U.S. from European critics of liberl democracy, e.g. Alexis de Toqueville...concern over the break down of traditoinal authority and social bonds (39)

39 -- Emerson is aware of this critique, but has also inhereited the New England emphasis on independence...  Result is his notion of "self-reliance."

39 -- Scholarship on Emerson has shifted.  Post-WWII "New Critics," upset with advance of capitalism and conformity and banality, saw Emerson as the "poetic exscape from history and society..." (39)  Newer analyses by postmodern critics have rather "called intoo question the sharp distinction between romance and reality that guided their predecessors, while reclaiming his work as a sustained reponse to, not a retreat from, his time and place." (39)  Sklansky's analysis falls into this latter category to some extent...in seeing Emerson as repsonding to shifts in the socio-economic order...See f.n. #17 for great series of citatatoins...

40 - 41 -- Situates Emerson (born in 1803) as a member of a cooor of Boston elites that were "uncomfortable with its place in the emerging market society, unfulfilled by its classical educaiton in Enlightenment thought and rationalistic religion, and uncerain of how to reconcile its new knowledge with a sustaining faith in a Christian God and a moral order." (41)  Death of his wife in 1831 cuts him loose from church and society in Boston... (41)

42 -- Emerson divides the self from the owrld...referring "Nature and the Soul", that is by nature he meant "everything other than the soul." (42)  The "ME" and "NOT ME." (42)

42-43 -- Sklansky ties this into a "pervasive concern in antebellum New England with the rupture of the conventional relationship between self and world due to the market revolution." (42)  That is, to the "breakup of the nity of human labor and means of production (farmland, workshop) that formed the basis of indivdual agency (civic virtue as well as self-interest) in the ealry republic." (42) In classical political economy this appeared to be a "division of the sovereign self," but Emerson reinterpreted the symptom.  The trouble in Emerson's analysis was the "soul's alienation from nature" (42) which was itself the product of classical political economy itself...because it had linked the selfhood to property ownership, to a notion of selfhood based on mastery... (42) On "Understanding" in Coleredige's use of the term to mean the opposite of Reason and Intuition... (see 36-37).

43 -- Emerson maintained that becoming receptive rather than masterful the individual would acquire "property" in the "spiritual kingdom." (443)  E.g. "The charming landscape which I saw this mornig, is indubitably  made up of some twenty or thirty farms...Miller owns this field, Locke that, and Manning the woodland beyond.  But none of them owns the landscape.  There is a property in the horizon which no man has but he whose eye can integrate all the parts, that is, the poet.  This is the best part of thes men's farms, yet to this their warranty-deeds give no title." (Emerson quoted on 43, from Nature. )

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text:
p.190 Embodiment

Sullivan argues taht Mead and Bateson sought what is now called "embodiment" and he cites Csordas , Embodiment and Experience (1994); Csordas Introduction: The body as representation and being-in-the-world (1994b)

He quotes Mead's statement to the Committee for Research in Dementia Praecox.  She wanted by "working in a closed 'area of homogenous culture andcommon racial background,' she hoped to find a society in which temperament and character joing together in a sufficiently coherent and clear pattern--itself consistent with the culture as a whole--that she and Bateson could adequately control for variations of temperament and character in the target population." (190)  

Sullivan puts it like this: "...Mead was seeking what metaphorically one could call elementary forms of these conjunctions of relations between temperament, character, and culture, forms each with their own distinct morphological developments, and hence what would now be understandable as their own distinct process of embodiment." (190)

title: Herbert Spencer on Women: A Study in Personal and Political Disillusion
text:
(( Summarial Note ))

The basic argument here is that Spencer's views on women changed -- form espousing equality in hi s early volume Social Statistics (1851) to gutting this view and espousing women's role in the household in his later works such as the revise and abridged version of Social Statistics (1892) -- due to his own failure to form a strong bond to a woman.   Gray calls this a "psychological" development.  (256)    And says that Spencer attrivbuted his failure to develop a relaitonship "to the deficiencies of the opposite sex." (256)   

The first two parts of the essay track the original statement s of Spencer on women and then track the changes.  The last section examines the "psychological development"  that Gray thinks provide the rational for Spencer's shift.

The argument here is kind of great.  There is lots good material on Spencer's views on women and on his frustration.  The point seems to be 1) that he was afraid of the family, saw it as akin to slavery, and 2) that he was more deeply also afraid of a perceived threat of a woman's intense love to his "bodily integrity."  (263)  In the conclusion to the article, Gray points out that Spencer feared the same incursion on his body from the state: "Women were a symbol of his fear of loss of bodily integrity, he could not bring himself to submit his person to the state.  The two threats become interwoven: women and the state were onjoined in his imagination. If women participated in the state, there would be no security for personal integrity.  Spencer's crusade against the state had become embodied in a crusade agianst women." (267-8)  I think Gray is speculating here, for he has not presnted evidence of this latter claim through Spencer's own words, and the last sentence seems to me to be an exageration.  But it is plausible that Spencer connected these two.

title: Karl Popper -- The Formative Years, 1902-1945
text:
# Malachi Haim Hacohen, Karl Popper -- The Formative Years, 1902-1945 (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000)

> Notes 10/12: The point here was to get a sense of the way Hacohen treats what earlier German historians talked about as Bildung and the dilemmas of Jewish middle-class liberals in Central Europe in general...Dirk had said that the lit on Jewish culture int his period has changed a lot since the critique of the Sonderweg that still dominated in the 1970s. So even text's like Mosse's German Jews Beyond Judaism is still  under the sway of this basic narrative, whcih is perhaps also as Dirk put it, a "narrative of decline." How is Hacohen different, or is he? In a way, as Dirk also acknowledged, he is still partaking of this kind of decline narrative in order to support his identification of Jews -- and Popper specifically -- as having devleoped a kind of Jewish cosmopolitanism.... I am not so sure about the politics or tendencies of Dirk's critique. To what extent does his critique come from a jsutified and valuable desire not to reproduce the Sonderweg vv German history as a whole, but a general disinterest or even suspicion that exceeds my own about identify politics -- (ie in this case vv Jews)?

# Introduction

* Key point here is that he's presenting Popper as someone who confronted the modernist currents of  "nonfoundationalism" that circulated in fin-de-siecle Vienna (see Toulmin and Janik's Wittegenstein's Vienna), but without giving up his progressive and outlook. A key quote is on p.3, where Hachohen brings up Rorty's Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature and Rorty's nonfoundationalism in general:

> Nonfoudnationalism reflected the crisis of representation, the recognition that language not only described the world but also created it. Subjects did not conceive of objects; rather, subjectivity and objectivity were themselves historically contingent discursive chimeras, a prodcut of modern philosophy since Descartes. The postmodern rid itself of them. Rorty used Dewey, Heidegger, and Wittgenstein to illustrate nonfoundationalist options. Had he used Popper, he might have saved the contemporary academy some detours. Contemporary debates are a deja vu to anyone familiar with the fin-de-siecle and interwar scences, especially in Vienna. Popper and his interwar interlocutors recognized 'poststructuralist' dilemmas -- they simply opted for different solutions. I am eager to recommend their solutions as against poststructuralist ones." (3)

* Later he writes: "Popper refused to split the life of reason or action, or give up on the 'scientific worldview' that he had intherited from the Viennese late enlightenment (Spaetauflaerung)..." (5) He then drops in a quote from Popper on 5. On the first page of Ch.1, Hacohen repeats this basic point saying that Popper is the Spaetauflaerung's "most renowned twentieth-century represenative." (23)

* Popper was launching his critique, Hacohen says, from a "marginal Kantian perspective foreign to logical positivism." (6) And his basic cosmopolitanism "originated as a solution to the dilemmas of ethnic idnetify faced by the assimilated Jewish-Viennaese intelligentsia." (5) At the end of this last stence, Hacohen cites his article on the "Dilemmas of Cosmopolitanism" that has made such an impression on me.  Popper's "Open Society" he says expressed this groups "hopes of integration into a community that discounted religion, ethnicity, and nationality." (5)

# Ch.1 "Progressive Philosophy and the Politics of Jewish Assimilation in Late Imperial Vienna"

* Popper's intellectual and cultural context, Hacohen implies was somehow not represented in the picture of fin-de-siecle Viennese modernist culture that have emerged, e.g. in toulmin and Janik's Witgenstein's Vienna. And Popper himself objected to Toulmin and Janik's account. As Hachohen writes; "The vienna he knew -- progressive, optimistic, reform oriented -- virtually disappeared from accounts of modernism. Social reform, not cultural crisis, prevailed in his Vienna 1900." (23)

* Popper's household he says "embodied the ideals of Besitz (property), Recht (law), and Kultur (culture) that were held in the highest esteem by Viennese liberals." (24) Hacohen describes the family as having "renounced their membership in the Jewish community..." (24) by converting to Lutheranism. Simon Popper, Karl's father, "preferred the Aufklaerung's religion." (24) But thiese ideas and their conversion did not break the "barriers of ethnicity." (24) Hacohen says that "[t]he assimilated Jewish intelligentsia constructed bridges to progressive secular Austrians opposed to anti-Semetism, but therew were relatively few of these." "Secular pgoressive Germans," he says, "were marginal to their own ethnic group." (24) And German-Austrians did not socialize with Jews. So "The Poppers spent much of their life int he company of Jews." (24)

* At the same time, though, Popper was srurounded by "progressive intellectuals" who critiqued "the social conservtaism of mainstream liberalism" and "soughta nd opening for workers." (24) They "opted for a bourgeois-proletarian alliance, under the auspices of bureaucracy, that would promote social legilistaion, economic modernization, and scientific education." (24)

* Hacohen sets up Popper as someone who spent "much of his life refashioning progressive philsophy and politics." (25) He pushed opposition to ethnonationalism farther, rejecting the notion of Deutschtum, that was for his parent's generation all a piece and he began to advocate a radical cosmoplitanism. He also rejected all religion and advocated for an international legal order and defended teh Enlightenment and Open Society. (25)

* In setting up the context, Hacohen describes "Viennese Jery in the Age of Franz Joseph" in the first section of the chatper.  This ear (1830-1916) was short-lived as a golden age. Austria had been referred to as the "alnd of blood" after the the murder and expuslion of Jews in 1420-1. (25) Emancipation came with the 1848 revolution: they were granted equal citizneship and residential and occupational restritions were abolished. (25)

* 26-30 He goes through some family details, ahving said that their families' history "refelected general migration patterns for Habsburg Jews." (26) On 30-34 he deals with the sociolgoical dimensions and dynamics of Jewish assimilation vv Simon Popper. This is the part most interesting to me. Simon Popper he describes as somone who "joined Besitz with Kultur." (29) He worked hard and he read widely, had a huge library of 14K volumes. (29) "The young Popper found himself surrounded wiht culture at its best." (29) In general, Hacohen explains the Jewish population. There were 72K in Vienna by 1880 and 175K by 1910. They were merchants and professionals (but for every 1 Jewish merchant there were 4 catholic ones.). (29) 1/2 of medical doctors were Jewish and 3/5 of lawyers. They also owned most of the papers and espeically the Neue Freie Presse which was a major "organ oof libreal public opinion." (30) According to Steven Beller, the rise to culutral prominent of Jews had to do with the eduational patterns. Only a very few of the non_jewish Middle class sent their children to the gymnasia, wich was a basis for university admission and a profssional career.And most sons of Austrians went either into teaching or adminstration. (30) 

* Acculturation to German culture, Hacohen says, "created a crisis of identity" for Jews. "Jews resopnded variously, some endeavoring to assimilate, others reaffirming traditional identity, yet others inventing secular Jewish nationalism." (30) In Popper's family the response was narrower between German acculturation and limited partiaption in the Jewish community. (30-31) The ilmits to assimilation were  1) that Austrian-Germans "were not willing to accept Jews." (31) So that both assimilated and non-assimilated Jews "belong to the same social networks." (31) 2) Ethnicity therefore still determined residential patterns. (32) 3) Educational patterns reinforced these separations, as Jews were concentrated and the majority in certain schools of the city (1st, seocnd and ninth). Poitn was that in  the end Viennese Jews were not Austrian Germans; they "constituted a German-Jewish community fo their own, united by ethnic origins, social class, German education, the Enlightenment's ethos, liberal politics, and of course, the anti-Semitie's malice." (32-33)

* Until WWI, liberal Jews controlled the Kultusgemeinde which was an "organization to which every Jews was required by law to belong..." (33) What he describes as modern "western or liberal Jews were a majority in Vienna and in the Behomenan crown lands. (33) To the extent taht they viewed Jews as a Volk or Stamm the leaders of this group believed Jews to be "united by religion aleon." (33) Moreover, the "liberals read the German Aufkalerung into Judasim and psoke of Jews' universal mission: sprading monotheism, the golden rule, egalitarian citizenship, and cosmopolitanism." (33) The Viennese fhief rabbi Adolf Jellinek, 1865-1891, argued that "Jewish people transcended national existence and testified to cosmopolitanism's viability by becomeing exemplary citizens in their repsective nations.In Austria, this meant that Jews were German: Aufklaerung, Emanzipation (emancipation), Bildung, and Deutschtum were all one." (33) [Notably he does nto specify here how this might ahve been different for Jews in Germany... or was there not yet a Germany then and so not relevant. But waht about Boas' family, all the way up in Minden.]

* This reading of the Aufklaerung into Judasim was not as momon among "Eastern" Jews -- those who were a majority in Galacia. "They regarded Jews a sa seprate popekle, united by observance of Jewish law,  religious tradition, language (Yiddish), and common ancestry." (33)  In the 1880s, Ostjuden began to arrive in Vienna, and showed little interest in the Kultusgemeinde. (34)

* In a section on Liberalism and anti-semetism and Vienesse progressivism, 34-46, Hacohen describes the growth and transformation of Vienesse liberalism among non-Jews. It was dealt a blow after the 1848 revolution but had a resurgence in 1860 after the defeaetd in teh Italian War. See 34-35. Beteween 1867-and 1879, liberal "led almost al Austrian cabinets..." (35) Liberals he says spoke of Duetschtum anad that meant full citizenship for all "who exhibited the solid character of German Buerger." (35) He notes that Deutschtum was both "culturally and socially acquired -- Jews who attained property and education were, in principle, welcome." (36). Liberals also believed that German culture needed to be "spread to backward nationalist in Central and Eastern Europe." (36)

* He then traces the challenge posed to liberals by rising ethnocentric German nationalism and anti-semetism, whcih in Austria was  in part a result of  the "ineluctable dilemmas of Austrian-German national identity." (37)": "In a multinational empire, German nationailsm could only mean the dismemberment of the Austrian state that libearls aspired to lead." (37)  The liberals had turned to German nationalism as a source for a much needed "new vision to unify the middle classes under their leadership." (36)  This move was typial across Europe Hacohen notes where liberal elites "faced with democratization deployed social reform or natioanilsm, or both, to fashion new communities." (37) But in Austria wehre there were many ethno-natioanlist tensions, "the cominbatyion was deadly. Resurgent populist German and Czech nationalism collided, and the Jews were caugh in between." (37) In 1880, the liberal set up the Deutscher Schulverein (German school association) with the aim of promoting German langagueand culture. At this moement, they also "religuished pretensions [held earlier, see p.36)] to being the state's party and becamea dvocates of particular ethnic interests. They now aimed to secure, they said, the Natioanl Besitzstand (national property ownership). Within two decades, an ever-diminishing and fragemented liberal camp normalized anti-Semetism and undermined its own preivous universalist ideals." (37)

* In 1885, then, the United Left(Vereinigte Linke) split over whether Autrian should e put in its title. Then the populist nationalist left set up their own Deutscher Club. The question was who belogned in their vision of the German nation? In 1882, Jews along with anti-Semites were still included in the "progressive nationlist" 1882 Linz program. (37) But this changed. Local branches soon moved to exclude Jews. The liberal leadership tried to disovle the local brnaches. And then in response there were defections in 1886, of the future Pan-German leader George von Schoenereer and the popular nationalists. For these people Jews were not German because "Deutschtum  was ethniuc (or racial) not cultural." (37)

* This shift had great consequences for Jews becasue the liberals were the "only party committed to retaining Jewish emancipation." (38) Hacohen describes this shift as causing the closing of doors that had only just opened. (38, bottom). Mnay liberal Jews thsu relized in response taht they "shared a common interest with the goverment, the emperor, and the Verwaltung in preserving the multinational empire's integrity, even against the German nationalists." (39) But increasingly the government could not manage the tensions in various parts of the empire that emerged along with German nationalism, for instance in Bohemia where German nationalism triggered reactions among the Young Czechs. The government ruled more and more by ijmperial decree. (39) 

* In the midst of this, Vienesse progressives, were frustratedwith liberailsm. "They represented a small liberal minority that remained largely immunite to anti-Semetic populism. They continued their close cfooperating with the Jewish intelligentsia and were moving toward the socailkists." (40)

* Simon Popper was evidently still attached to boutgeois liberalism in his lifetime. Hacohen describes his politics on 41-43). Then he describes others in Popper's family that could inspire with a more pgoressove vision, ie his uncle Walter Schiff. (43-45). Popper was indeed a defender of this progressive vision. Later he would defend it against the critique of people like Hayek (45-46).

* For progressives, ethnonationailsm was the "greatest enemy." But according to Hacohen they underestimated the threat. They fought anti-Semetism but "they could see no harm in expanding the German cultural sphere (Kulturbereich) in Central Europe and regarded Slavic nationailsm as reactionary." (46) They thought, in general,that ethnonationalism would dissapear with "divergence socioeconomic development in the provicnes..." (46) And they thought that anti-Semetism was rooted in "religious prejudice" and so opposed "clericalilsm" as their greatest enemy and not nationalism. (46)

* Progressives' imagined cpmmunities, though, were thoroughly universalist. They did not imagine their cosmopolitacal community as aggressively as did Kant, but still they "denationalized the state." (46) They did not define the a good social order according to cutlrual differences, but they were still attached to notions of Germanness: "Undoubtedly, they confounded Aufklaerung and Deutschtum, but, for many, it seems, Deutschtum was an instrument for realizing Aufklaerung, rather than the opposite. They were less nationalists in a cosmopolitan guise than cosmpolitans in a German guise." (47)

* Among progressives, then, the Popper family "represented the cosmopolitan-pacifist pole" (47) -- this pole was given clearest expression by freemasons and pacifists. (47) They were not interested in nationalism and saw Austria as a multinational empire. They thought that as such this empire was a "higher development" than the nation-state. Such cosmopolitans were Austrian patriots because of this support for the empire. Freemason cosmopolitans also had no paln for reform they were happy simply to see thesmelves as defenders of liberal values and as an "intellectual elite of a huge states whose composition gave it the apperance of the international order of humankind in miniature." (47)

* This kind of cosmopolitanism was rare though. Even the Habsburg court circles and the military bureaucracy did not present such an ideology.  They presented a vision of an Austrian imperial idea or Staatsgedanke but this lacked a cosmopolitan ideology. (47-48).

* Jews were hoewever ethnusiastic bearers of this kind of cosmpolitanism in Austria. Rabbi Jellinke wrote: "If one could construct a specifically Austrian nationalisty...Jews woudl form its foundation." (quoted on 48). Hachohen says also taht Jews had a hard time understanding why other nationalisties were not so enthusaistic about their dreams; "Why sould Czechs not be equally content with integration into the German cultural sphere?" (49)

* Not all Jews were by default cosmopolitan aptriots of Austria. They had to work to overcome their vision of Austria linked to the violence and pogroms of the past. Traditionalist Jews worked, e.g. Rabbi Bloch, "made special efforts to reconcile orthodox Judaism with multinationalism" but did not develop "imperial cosmopolitan designs." (49)Meanwhile, liberal Jews encountered identity struggles. They "professed cosmpolitanism, but their cosmopolitanism conflicted with their German natioanlism, and anti-Semetism brought their Jewish-German synthesis, a mark of genuine cross-cultural interaction, into crisis. As long as Deutschtum was defined culturally, liberal Jews could regard themselves as its messengers to the Ostjuden and Slavs. Once it became racially defined, they faced exclusion from the German nation." (50)  Freud, Adler, and Friedjung -- alla ctive in German student asssociations -- encoutnered this early on as their fraternities chose to exclude Jews. (50)

* The liberal-cosmopolitanism of Detuschtum fell apart sby the mid 1890s. Even liberal Jews then had begunto have dbouts. Hachoen quotes from a 1897 meeting of the Oesterrichisch-Israelitische Union that called for a "return to the pgoram of reconciliation of peoples (Voelker) and nationalities (Staemme), of all denominations, estates and classes in our fatherland, in the name of free thought and progress, of justice and equal rights of all citizens." (50)

* Liberal Jews "affirmed their cosmopolitanism" most directly in their stand again Zionism. See 50-52).

* Popper's milieu was fully anti-Zionist. (51). Progressives and socialists both denied outright that Jews were a "nationality." (51) When in 1905 in Bukovina "the center of Jewish Disaspora nationalism", there was an attempt to establish a "Jewish curia" in themidst of electoral reform, progressive Jews in Vienna "led a chage against the 'electoral ghetto' (Wahl-Getto)." (52) Progressives "repreresented a gorup that, to emancipate itself from its own ethnicty, neeeded to dissolve all ethncity an recover universalhumanity -- Marx's universal class," Hacohen writes.

*  But this whole denial of ethnonationalism among progressives  "flew in the face of historical reality." (52) Progressivism "remained marignal." (52)  And he says "ethnonationalism reisteed imperial management." (52) There were attempts in the 1900s to accomodate these nationailst energies through compromises that set up national curiae in Moravia, Galcia, and Bukovina that reflected a ":search for equal rights of nationalisties." (53) But these also supported notiosn of antioanl autonomy. A 1879 decision of the administrative high court  that turned on how to decide the natioanl idenitty of bilingual members cited "subjective" factors: "Belonging (Zugeoerighkeit) to a certain nationality [is] essentially a matter of consciousness and feeling." (quoted on 53) But in the face of hypernationalists' attempts to exclude dissentiment memers Hacohen says the courts increasingly relied on "tangible evidence." (53)  Ultimately Galcian Jews were denied citiznehip on racial grounds in the interwar period. "Ethnonatioanlism turned multiculturalism on its head by reifying nationali idenity as race." (53)

* Given this end Hachoen asks why the surpsise that Popper "wished to cut throught he knot of national identity by decalring it false?" (53) He says Popper say the dissolution of the Habsburg empire as an "unmitigated disaster and held natioanilsm, especially German nationalism, repsonsible." (53)

* His response was to reject both his German and Jewish natioanlism, a rare reposnse. and to "favor an uncompromising nationalism." (53) But this "radicalism," Hacohen says," "left Popper a permanent exile, a citizne oinly in an imaignary Republic of Science." (53)

* Section on Austrian Progressive Philosophy makes some useful points vv how philosophy developed differently in the Austrian context. Key was the "government repression of Kantianism during the French Revolution, the severe limits imposed on teaching philosophy in Austrian universities during the Vormaerz period (pre-1848), and the sanctioning of an official anti-idealist educational philosohpy in the aftermant of the great educational reform of 1853 that created the background fo the emergence of a scientific philoosphy." (54) There was Hacohen says a tendency to pursue "Catholic, scholaistic, and Lebnizian traditions that regarded the unviersa as a rational order and language as a reflecting a universal logic" that survived in Austria while it was decimated by Kant's critiques elsewhere. (54) Prague philosphyer and priest Bernard Bolzano (1781-1848) articutelated tehse ideas and had a lasting inlufence. Also the anti-Kantian empiricist and Prussian philosopher Johann Friedrich Herbart (1776-1841). The most prominent philsopher, promoted by the ducation ministry, Robert Zimmermann (1824-98) become a professor in Vienna and his work synthesized Heberat and Bolzano. (54-55) Austria was howeer a backwater philosphically until Brentanto established his school. Brentano's philsophy "used intentioanlity to distinguish etween mental and physical states, opening the door both to empirical inductrive approaches (Meinong) and to phneomenology (Husserl)." (55) Brentano was also an enthusiiast of British empiricism, helping to introduce Mill's Logic. At the turn of the century, GE. Moore and Bertrand Russell became interested in the empirical bent of Austrian philosphers (their opposition to Kant and Hegel). And Moore and Russell's logic influence the Vienna Circle. : "An Anglo-Austrian analytic axis emerged, empirical in its method, realist (anti-idealisti) in epistemology, respectful of natural science and pretheoretical commoon sense, and concerned with logical analysis." (55) 

* The confrontation between Hume and Kant became key in the Austrian context. Hume was an important philosopher and widely read. For Austrian empiricists and Kantian opponents (.e.g alois Riehl and robert Reininger), the Hume-Kant confrontation was key. Popper studied this confrnotation in the 1930s and unlike many Austrians declared allegiance to Kant. (56)

* Ernst Mach was hugely influential, and his "netural monism," "senatioanlism" or "phenomenalism" as it was variously called. Popper thought it "pernicious". (56) But machwas influential. He rejected the subjet/object distinction (ie was not a Kantian) and saw "expereince" as "nothing but a stream of sensations (Fluss der Empfindungen)." (56)

> Science described sense data. "Reality" or "substance" were unknown. In science, the world appeared as a constellation of elements (*Weltelemente*), a structure of functional relationships of phenomena. Scientific theories described them in the simples and most ecnoomical terms, simpifying experience, and making prediction easier. Theories described, rather than judged, sense data. They were conventional, not true or false, but more or less useful. Causality , lawfulness, so-called  natural laws, were scientists' creation, hypohtheses facilitating the organzation of experience and the making of predictions. Knowledge's sole criterion was reduction to expeirence....Immediate expeirence alone sanctioned a transition from common sense ot scientific knowledge. Any attempt to go bedyond experience woudl result in errors. Philosophy outside of sicence was futile." (57)

* Mach thus suggested the science's "mthodological unity" needed to reset on "physiolgocail terms": on 1) psychology, ie the attempt to determine the assocations (Verbindugen) of represenations; 2) physics, the attempt to discover the laws of assocaition of sensations."; nd 3) psychophysics, the attempt to "clarify the laws of the association between sensations and representations). (57)

* Popper rejected Mach's view as early as his 1928 dissertation on methods of cognitive psych. He "would develop an itneractions view of body and mind, supporting objetive knowledge." (57)

* Mach, however, was very influential and Hachohen says "virtually became the official philsopher of Viennese progressivism." (57)

* But Mach also inspired a pessimistic resopnse in Firtz Mauthner, whose language critique, which servered langauge frmo reality was widely read in Vienna, though he lived in Berlin. (59-60)Mauthner basically saw langauge as only being able to show the limits of language. Hacohen writes that his "critique began as an emancipatory project, endeavoring to free thought from verbal supersittiion (religion and metaphysics), but ended, like Wittgenstein, with mysticism and a call for silence." (60)

* But Hacohen says, "*Spaetaufklarung*" could not proceed on such gruonds [as Mauthner established]." (60) And he says sthat the Vienna circle and Popper "had to find answers." So they attempted to "reconstruct scientific langauge". Popper thought that goal a mistake b"but had to offer some way of closing the gap between reality and language. "Expeirence (or scientific experiment), he argued, could show language (or theory) to have been wrong. No guarantee it would do so, but one could learn from error." (60)

* The presence of the critiqeu of language (Mach-Mauthner axis) Hacohen says "discloses the proximity of late enlightenment and Viennese modernism." (60) Here is Hacohen's historiographical piont coutner Schorske and a vision of Viennese culture that "originated in the 1960s and 1970s". According to Schorske it was this moderni pessimism that was dominant: "To Schorske, liberalism's retreat and 'politics in a new key' gave rise to modenrism in literature and the arts. Modernism reflected the dissolution of bourgeois orderliness and progress. Bildung foundered; the ideal of a well-formed charachter, of psychological balance and ethical responsibility, vanished. In stepped visions of a chaotic universe, social decadence, instinctual life, psychologcal torment, and morbitidy. Self-expression became the guiding principle. Intellectuals withdrew from politics to their studies and studios, surriptittiously disclosing their political anxieties in science, art, and literature." (60).  BUT Hacohen thinks this picture does not capture the people in Popper's mileu.!! Among these progressives, there was continuity with the "old liberalism" and a certain "hope in humankind's future" as well as a dedication to "social reform." (61) He even attributes to them an "effusive optimisim in the face of intractable imperial problems." (61) The Enlightenment was allive in their thought he thinks. Basically he thinks they faced up to modernism. He refers to an account of Jodl in Schorsek's essay on Klimt, where Jodle appears as a "bewildered liberal who delved into the Modernismusstreit (modernist controversy) to reaffirm told enlightenment against modernism." (61) But Hacohen insists that "he was a plolitically engaged philsopher, whose vice was not cultural despair but dogmatism, political naivete, and German nationlalism." (61) He notes that Schopenhauer and Nietzsche did not so much heral liberalism's collapse in this mileu as they were widely read and "calmly absorbed." (61) He says that Popper faced the modernism with "serenity."

title: The Victorian Connection
text:
p. 82-83 Nonconformity (religious) background 

These thinkers have background in religious nonconformity.  In evangelicalism...   They are "modern missionaries" also in that they believe in protesting the surrounding cutloure and offering something spritually higher.  
They ranked spiritual things higher than material.  (83)  Unitarianism imporant.  Hall says it was akind of "halfway house on the road away from orthodoxy to 'free religion' and skepticism." (83)  E.g. J.S. Mill had relationship with Unitarianism. William J. Fox an important go-between beteween Philsophical Radicals and Untiarians.   But what came out of this was a "connetion" Hall says neither Unitarian nor Radical.

title: The New Woman: Changing Views of Women in the 1920s
text:
p. 387 -  390   60s Sees Historians Open to Questions

-- Period makred by civil rights.  Kennedy had established a Commission on the Status of Women... (387).  Friedan's The Feminine Mystique published, sparking feminist revival. (387)

-- Two historan, established, publish articles in 1964. David POtter, "American Women and the American Character" in John A. Hague, ed. Americna Character and Culture: Some Twentieth Century Perspectives (1964): 65-84; Carl Degler, "Revolution Without Ideology: The Changing Place of Women in America" Robert Jay Lifton, ed., The Woman in America (1964). Degler and Potter found that women still experienced discrimination.  Degler in particular though women had been consumed with individual interests and had abandoned ideology like many. (388)

-- Other historians looked beyond flapper in the 20s and found women more actively politically engaged.  Groups like the Naitonal Women's Trade Union League, the Naitonal League of Women Voters and the National Consumer's league seemed to provide evidence that women were involved in progressivism in the 20s.  (389)  

-- Others like James R. McGovern questioned the thoery of moral revolution (w/ flapper) in 1920s.  McGovern located it before WWI instead, downplaying the 20s emancipation period.  See McGovern "The American Woman's Pre-World War I Freedom in Manners and Morals" JAH LV (1968): 315-333. (390)

These historians Freedman say indicate a new "attitude twoard women's history." They looked at things more closely and at the political lives of women in the 20s.  "While they were eager to praise the role women had played in political movements, their researched laid the foundaiton for recent works which are critical of failures of thewomen's movements to achieve lasting reform." (390).  

-- She then treats these books that were critical: William O'Neil's Rise and Fall of Feminism, which she doesn't like.  He provided antifeminist assessment of women's suffrage. and noted little progress in nonpolitical realms.  (391)  she likes bettere Chaf'e sstudy of changing roles of American Wpomen between 1920 and 1970. (391-2)

-- Critiques recent studies b/c they treat women as monolithic, don't recognize racial divisions.  (393)

title: The Naturalized Female Intellect
text:
p.221-  Nature/Nurture

To demonstrate new emphasis on general intelligence, She cites now Spencer who described women as being (in DAston's words first) "enmired in first impressions, 'incapable of balancing evidence" (221)

For Spencer this wasa product partly of lack of experience, but not exclusively.  Tehre were other factors: small brain size and and "under-developed nervous system." (221)

What is going on here is new.  There is a link to the descriptions of female intellect of the late 18th century, but now there is also a new "explanatory space, reocgnizably ordered along the divison between nature and nurture."  (221)  (i.e. references to brian size and nervous system, and not only experience.  Women's position is not only or even mainly for Spencer a problem of use/disuse, which is the explanation that had been given before for the traits of the female intellect.

In Spencer this nature/nurture divison is not fully solid yet.  He used both use/disuse arguments and nature/nurture.  Daston asays it was later hteorists of intelligence like Galton that woudl finally separate the two into "either/or compoenetns, utlimately to be qualifited by correlationsal statistics." (221)  Galton supported the nature side, but his opponents used the same "explanatory framework." (221)

title: Approaches to Human Personality: William James and Sigmund Freud
text:
00 Summary Note 00

Lasswell looks at both Freud and James -- as two men who have influenced the vocabulary that is used to describe humans in the 20th Century -- and attempts to analyze both of the men in terms of a definition of series of potential factors roughly divided into circumstances + personality.  

The article is not all that useful for me and it is hard to say (though I read it quickly) what exactly he is arguing.  What is useful is his definition of personality on 56: "...a term that designates basic stabilities of pattern observable during any selected cross-section of an individual's career from cradle to crypt.  We identify personality structure by examining how people act in relation to themselves and others in concrete situations.  Within the total 'process' we differentiatiate 'structure' and 'function' by assigning the term 'structure' to the principle predispositions with which an individual approaches a situation....Detached study might show that personality structure remained remarkably stable from early years; or we might isolate epochs of rapid oscillation or re-stabilization." (56)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.046-  Breeakdown in notion of female uniqueness

Dewey hadintiially been wary of coeducation.  But he changed his mind (45-46).
Rosenberg thinks that "The idealized view of womanly uniqueness, to which Dewey and his colleagues had all been bred in sexually segregated Victorian society, and which many of them had used to champion women's widening sphere, was beginning to break down in the face of simple quotidian experience. " (46)  E.g. also Thomas changed his mind slightly after writing his dissertation, saying "I do not wish to imply that this [sexual] difference is altogether inherent in the male and female disposition; it is, in fact, partly a matter of habit and attention." (46)

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text: p.010-013 Positive Lib & Social Constructivism Her critique of Taylor's defense of Pos. Liberty leads to another way that pos. lib. attacks neg. lib. Social construction includes the idea of "adapative preferences" and "oppressive socialization" but it goes further, see esp. 12-13. "By suggesting that people are produced through social formations, and not simply limited by them, the idea of social construction thereby calls into question of what is genuine or true to the self and what is false. As Kathy Ferguson puts it, 'It is not simply that [we are] being socialized; rather, a subject on whom socialization can do its work is being produced.'... ...Who we are--the 'choosing subject'--exists within and is formed by particular contexts; the ideal of the naturalized and unified subject utilized by most freedom theory is thus deeply problematic and simplistically overdrawn. The contexts in which we live, patriarchal, sexist, racist, and calssists though they may be, have produced women's, indeed everyone's agency." (12-13)

title: We Have Never Been Modern
text:
Notes Summer 2014:

 

Section I: Crisis

Latour inveighs in this book against what he defines as the "modern". The modern is defined for him I think first and foremost by the effort to differentiate areas of knowledge into their own discrete categories and disciplines, all disciplines and categories in general, but expecially the divide between nature and culture. This is what he sees as the role of what he calls "science studies": "...we are always attempting to retie the Gordian know  by crisscrossing, as often as we have to, the divide that separates exact knowledge and the exercise of power -- let us say nature and culture." (3) He  believes that "[o]ur intellectual life is out of kilter" (5) as a result of this separation. Continues: "Epistemology, the social sciences, th esciences of texts -- all have their privileged vantage point, provided that they remain separate. If the creatures we are purusing cross all three spaces, we are no longer understood..." (5)

In taking up this issue, he's dealing with the issue of crisis of critique. See section 1.3, traces three responses: naturalization, socialization, and deconstruction. (5) These correspond to the subjects, respectively, of facts, power and discourse. (6) His point is that these things go together, always. And this is what he means by networks. And he says you can't basically have it both ways: either there are these "networks", or each of these themes -- power, facts, and discourse -- must be treated distinctly.

Anthropology, he thinks, has already shown what it is like to deal with networks in this manner. Because  it treats all as linked inthe life of peoples, has shown the "seamless fabric of...'nature-culture'..." (7) This seems obvious, because these networks, these hybrids, are more obviously existant for the subjects of anthropology than they are for those of us who are supposed to be modern. "...we are not savages; no anthropologist studies us that way, and it is impossible to do with our own culture... Our fabric is no longe rseamless. Analytic continuity has become impossible...." (7)  So then the question about why these networks are not studies is altered a bit...is it the case that there is not this seamlessnss in modern life, and thus it is impossible to analyze the linnks? He will ultimately say no! Because as the title of the book goes: "We have never been modern..." 

In section 1.4, he suggests 1989 is a date after which the existence of these networks has become clearer...(8-10). I find this sectiona  bit hard to parse. Post-1989...nature no longer seems limitless, there has been damage to ecology, the triumph of liberalism is confronted with new organization on the global level to confront global ecological crisis. But not exactly clear to me how this brings up networks??

title: Ernst Cassirer: The Last Philosopher of Culture
text:
Notes Winter 2014:

 

Ch. 1

 

Ch. 2 Marburg School

 

* Summary of the Neo-Kantians relationship to Kant on 27-33. Key phrase that I found useful, that neo-Kantianism was born of a new "ascetism" in philosophy after 1848. (27)

* This was not a going back to Kant in an orthodox sense, but to fix the notion of aprorism. See O. Liebmann quote on 27-28.

* Notes that the first generation of neo-Kantians were understanding apriorism in a "naturalistic sense." (28) i..e they believed that these a priori categories of understanding that Kant had set up were grounded in the organization of our sensory system. (28).

* Skidelsky's focus though is the Marburg school, and here the focus was different: the point was by Cohen to go back to what he saw as the "transcendental" sense of Kant's notion of a priori. I.e. the point was not to look at psychological organization to ground the a priori, but to see the apriori categories as (quoting Cohen) "formal or constitutional conditions of experience." (quoted on 28). The point in other owrds, which Skidelsky gets to on the next page, is that "[t]he transcendental question was no longer leveled at experience in general, but at experience as embodied in the concrete public institution of science." (29) So that in effect "all the key terms in Kant's transcendental theory undergo a change of meaning; they lose their foothold in in eternity, so to speak, and descend into human history." (30) On 31 this starts to sound almost Habermassian (i.e. in terms of ideal speach sitution) when Sk. writes that this was about how "the demand for universal validity remains the one fixed a priori of science." (31)

* Section on how this was maybe also going back to Hegel that I've skipped for the moment.

* Then a section on the ways in which Neo-Kantianism and Kant in general was of appeal to Jews, i.e. Cohen Cassirer etc. (37-42) Why Kant? Because he'd created a philosophical space in which Jews and Christians could communicate, such that assimilation Sk. writes need no longer require "the humiliation of baptism..." (38) He goes on that Kant also being identified as a German philosopher was important: insofar as Kant was German, and he espoused this idea of a universal community, then he rperesented a Germany devoted to a "Germany of the spirit." Sk writes that Jews held up this ideal "as an encouragement and a reproach to--and also sometimes as an escape from--the real Germany of Heinrich von Treitschke and Houston Stuart Chamberlin." (38) These "motives" he says you could see in Cohen, and in Cohen's "Jewish-German" synthesis. He pegs an essay from Bruno Bauch, an influential philsopher and editor of Kant-Studien, as one in which the spectre of anti-Semetism was first raised in 1916. Bauch saw Kant's main revoluitonary aspect in his discovery of a sphere of "validity and value." But this significance was German according to Bauch. And he viewed Cohen as unable to understand this as a Jew. Lurking behind this was the question of whether to interpret Kant as a methodologist of science or a philosopher of culture -- and Bacuh's argument belongs to the latter, which connects him with the Southwest school of Neo-Kantianism, which was more conservative and "mandarin" than the Marburg school. ( 39-40) Bauch, though, Sk. notes was hitting Cohen at the most sensitive spot: because by claiming Kant as German, he was cutting of Cohen's Jewish-German synthesis. Bauch blocked Cohen from the whole German tradition: "Anyone with an inkling of the spirit of German idealism can of course disregard the preoccupation of [certain]...Jews with 'ethics according to Kant, Schiller, and Fries.' However, I believe that not even a Jew of Cohen's intellectual rank can be properyly included in this spirit." (quoted on 40.) Then Sk. interestingly goes on to look at the response in the Jewish community, which then also turned to a kind of nationalism, that of Rosenzweig and Martin Bububer... (41-42).

title: Franz Boas: The Early Years, 1858-1906
text:
p.133-136 Description of Boas' early Method and Conceptualization of Anth

The description here is not incredibly technical.  In my quick reading, I got these key points:

Boas is emphasizing the study of socil traits and eschewing physical anthropology.  He beings by sutdying the myths customs and tradition of the Northwets Coast Indians in 1887-1888.  He saw himself as using a "statistical method" (134) in which eh "built up...a card catalogue of myth 'elements,' discreet portions of Ameican Indian myths arranged systematically to reval the occurence and absence of such elements amog vairous peoples across the continent." (134)  He is strying to understand "thre growth of myths and their migrations" as he says in 1891 (134) .  A focus on "psychology of dissemination and ammalgamation" (134) Directed against independent invention. His cards showed that certain phenomena were always present.  He finds that there is a common civilizaiton developing in th earea of the Northwest Coast.  But there are also persistnet differneces, esp present on the level of "distinct divison of social organization." (135).

Overall goal described in 1887 as "outlining the early history of mankind and working out the psycholgy of nations." (Cole's words).   Iits aim is "the description of the history of mankind...beinginning from the first traces we find buries deep under the surface, up to the present time and in all parts of the globe."  To do this qould require that anths "trace the history and distribution of every single phenomenon relation to th esocial life of man and to the pysical appearance of tribes." This is from p. 231 in "Anthropology in the american and British Associations for the Advancement of Science" (1887)  Two years later in 1889 attacks on Mason See 61-66 in Stocking Shaping of American Anthropology, Boas puts it in terms of communicating "the fact that civilization is not something absolute, but that it is relative, and that our ideas and conceptions are true only so far as our civilization goes." (66)

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text:
p. 511 - 515 Authoritative Discourse 

So they think Boas's texts can be described as an authoritative discourse as Bakhtin defines it.  "...practices that are used in erasing dimensions of context-sensitivity (what linguists often refer to as 'indexicality') and intertextuality in producing the illusion of boundedness, stability, and impermeability."  (511)  

They inteligently note that Boas had deliberately drawn on the model of classical philology and pedagogy, and hoped to present Native American texts that might "transmit" the same authority and authenticity.  He sought to set these text up as "artificats" tha would require reinterpretation in the future, just like classical texts: He wrote: "As we require a new point of view now, so future times will require new points of view and for these the texts, and sample texts, must be made available." (quoted on 512, from  Boas to Holmes, 24 July 1905; quoted in Stocking, The Shaping of American Anthropology, 123)

Now the authors make a key argument, which is one that I disagree with: that is they connect Boas too closely to older attempts in this history of the metadiscursive practices of modernity to the likes of John Aubrey, who sough tas they write so clearly to "promote modern epistemology and modern subjects by construing a sphere of 'Ignorance,' 'Absurdity' and 'Errours' that defined modernity negatively as contrasting maximally with the world of illiterate and superstitious 'poor people' and 'woomen.'  This opposition granted modernity an historical location and a trajectory by deeming it to e anew social and intellectual formation whose ascendancy was as certain as was the inevitable disappearance of its traditional predecessor." (513)  Aubrey positioned himself they say as a mediator, conducting an act of salvage.  

They then move from Aubrey to Herder and the Grimms and then to Schoolcraft's attempt to draw upon Native Americans to produce a distinctly American text.  (513-514).

They want to put Boas' in this tradition.He also positioned himself as a mediator they say (515).  They pull back then saying his project was not "identical" to Aubrey, Herder and the Grimms.  They then try to situate it in a modernist context using DR's writing about U.S. sociologists' misxture of enthusiasm and fear of capitalism and revolution.  They seem to see Boas's salvage operation as providing a soothing balm to these people: "A key aspect of Boas's  intervention into the social and political debates of his day lay in his
characterization of Native Americans as people who would necessarily fall victim to modernization. This perceived displacement of pre-modern peoples by civilization served as the primary warrant for Boas's research efforts. The preservation of Native American cultural knowledge through anthropological
intervention was for the benefit of 'civilization,' since the people themselves were bound to perish." (515)  

So then this salvage operation provided a kind of recognition that these people were supposed to pass away, but that this textualized and traditionalized Other would be available for analysis.  But what the authors cannot account for is the Boasians rhetoric that these primitive others were so similar,which was also present in their analysis.

The core of their argument is this idea that Boas' believed that primitive texts could not provide an accurate analysis of events as they occured.  They repeat this and then drawn on section of the Mind of Primitive Man where he confirms the accuracy of modern knowledge (while acknowledge that it requires repression of emotion).  This difference I think they exagerate: i.e. he may have seen modern knowledge as better and different, but it was not as I have explained in Ch.2 & 3 as invulnerable to becoming inaccurate.  They even subject that Boas' modernity was "transcendent" (518)  which is the opposite of what I have been trying to argue.  (516-518)

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text: p.0016-17  Strong intimacy at theHullHouse, almost family like

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1053-1056 Brief history of Dev. of Profession

Notable points: 

-- In 1915, Abraham Flexner described social work as "poorly paid and unprofessional." (1053) 

-- Schools opened in New York, Boston, and Chicago between 1898 and 1908.  (1053)

-- Between 1918 and 1926, medical and psychiatric workers organized their own associations.  (1054) and Americna Associations of Social Workers formed in 1921 and had journal The Compass.  (1054)

-- So by 1930 he says it was a profession (1054); Marcy Richmond's Social Diagnosis (1917) the manual.   and in 1930 federal census gave "social and welfare workers" their own category (1054)

-- Between 1900 and 1930 percentage of employed women grew from 8.2 to 14.2 and "women constituted a disproportionately large number within the professions than within the labor force in general." (1055) And Walkowitz writes: "Among the occupations in which women congregated such as nursing and librarianship, only 'schoolteachers' was more feminized than social work.  By 1930, four of every five people in or preparing for a career in teaching or soial work were female.  A decade earlier, fewer than three in five social workers had been female." (1055)

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
p. 064-68 Zelia Nuttall

This section not so interesting... Haven't recorded.  But the gist is that Nuttall was a more successfull and independent scholar in her own right.  And that she practiced anthropology in a way more acceptable ot the author.

title: The Age of Empire, 1875-1914
text:
Ch.5 -  Workers of the World

* Rise of a mass of unskilled workers.  In Germany, went from half a million in 1875 to 1.7 million in 1907, i.e. 10 to 16% of workforce.  In 1913, in Britain, 1.5 million.  Then these groups organize so that by 1914 every major industrialized nations (even the USA) had "mass socialist parties" (117).  IN the US, the socialist party candidate in 1912 polled a million votes.  Germany and Scandanavia had the largest, up to 35-40% of the vote.  (117).  Many contemporaries felt it was only a matter of time before these parties polled above 50%.  So one anthem of world socialism said: "The Internationale will be the human race." (117)  Their was reason for optimism given the rise of mass socialist parties since the 1880s...

* But these masses of unskilled workers were not necessarily united...and had been reerred to as the "working classes" (plural) before the rise of the new mass parties.  They were divided by relgion, by occupation (female cotton weavers did not necessarily have much to do with coal miners), by migration, language, nationality.  H writes: "For what, from one point of view, looked like a concentration of men and women in a single 'working class', could be seen from another as a gigantic scattering of the fragments of societies, a diaspora of old and new communities." (119) Description of the difficulties of unifiying this group dealt with in detail in Section II.

* Section III: how were these groups unified.  Ideology was key.  The unskilled workers to some extent lacked an identity.  "Workers were unknown and forgotten people in proportion as they were a new social group." (124)  The socialists were in many cases the first people to come to these forgotton people sand they gave them a "single identity: that of 'the proletarian.'" (124)  The socialists who brought this identity also brought "organization":  "the structured collective action without which the working class could not exist as a class, and through organization they acquired that cadre of spokesmen who could articualte the feelings and hopes of men and women who were unable to do so themselves.  These possessed or found the words for the truths they felt.  Without this organized collectivity, they were only poor labouring folk.  For the ancient corpus of wisome -- proverbs, sayings, songs -- which formulated the Weltanschauung of the labouring poor of the pre-industrial world was no longer enough.  They were a new social reality, requiring new reflection." (125)

* The ideology teaching the injustice of the social order was one thing but "the crux of their experience was their relation with their employers.  The new socialist labour movement was inseparable from the discontents of the workplace..." (126)

* The working class was also increasingly separated from "those above" by the "tertiary sector" -- ie lower middle classes who stressed the differences they had with the working classes and what they hoped they shared with their "social superiors." (127)

* What also helped to unify the working classes was the development of the capitalist system and the growth of industrial sectors that led workers to move beyond concerns for their own partiuclar coal mine or pit and link their fate with workers in a whole industiral sector.  "Fiercely attached though British coal-miners were to the autonomy of their coalfield or even their pit, conscious of the specificity of their problems and customs, South Wales and Northumberland, Fife and Staffordshire, they found themselves for this reason inevitably drawn together between 1888 and 1908 into national organization." (128)

* The state also helped.  "...electoral democratization imposed the class unity its rulers hoped to avoid.  The fight for the extension of citizen rights itself inevitably took on a class tinge for workers, since the central question at issue (at least for men) was the right to vote of the propertyless citizen." (128)  Many, esp. anarchists were bothered by this because it took attention away from revolution.  But mainly this force was unavoidable b/c increasingly as the state took shape every group had to pursue its poitical aims by "exerting pressure on the national government, in favour of or against the legislation and adminisitration of national laws." (129) And the working class had a particular need to use national law to repair aspects of the system that would strengthen their a capacity for collective action."  (129)  As a consequence, then, the "force of working-class unification withing each nation inevitably replaced the hopes and theoretical assertions of working-class internationalism, except for a noble-minority of militants and activists." (129)

* Section IV deals more with the cultural side of class "consciousness", including the role of Marx's teachings.  INterestingly, he notes that the leaders of these mass movements "took it for granted that they wanted a social revolution, or that their activities implied one." (132) This drew upon Mark in some cases, but also to 1789 and 1776.  Some, on the right, like Eduard Bernstein recommendd focusing on immediate eneds and argued that Marx's theories should be revised in light of the success of capitalism.  (133) But in many cases in Germany for example, Marx's theories were not particularly influenctial in the work ing classes.  Rather the leaders were smitten with a kind of scientific ethos as against the threat of "ignorance and supersittion."  So the German SDP which had declared itself Marxist in 1891, only printed editions of the Communist Manifesto in editions of 2000-3000 copies, whereas the most popular title was Darwin versus Moses.  (135)  Most Marxist leaders were imported from points farther east, from the Hapsburg Empire.  E.g. Kautsky and Hilferding, and Rosa Luxemburg.  (135)

* H insists that what motivated socailists, hwoever, was not revolution but the possibility of the "significant amelioration" that came from their action and unification.  E.g. in places in Italy where mass socialist parties were strong, there was far less migration.  (135-136)

* Another problem facing the labour movement was the fact that the working calss was not the majority fo the population, so they had to figure out how to appeal more broadly.  But this also threatened the revolutionary aspirations as Marx had described them.  Agrarian populations, for example, were in theory supposed to dissapear.  But these parties did appeal beyond the "proletariat".  A ig part of it was the link between socalism and the idea of Progress (138-139).  And where parties appealed outside the proletariat it did tend to turn them into "parties of government" rather than revolutionary parties, andthis happened particulary after 1918.

* At the end of the chapter, H makes an important point that you can't really write the history fo the urban poor in terms of "class consciousness".  He describes an apolitical poor.  A great many of the poor he says did not think of themselves as proletarian; "They saw themselves as belonging to the eternal category of the poor, the outcast, the unlucky or the marginal.  If they were migrants into the big city fromt he countryside or some foreign region, they might live in a ghetto whcih could overlap wth the working-class slum, but was more likely to be dominated by the street, the market, the innumberable petty ways, legal or non-legal, in which poor families kept body and soul together, only some of which were in any real sense of wage-work.  What counted for them was not union or class-party, but neighbours, family, patrons who could o favours or provide jobs, otherwise avoiding rather than pressuring public authorities, priests, poeple from the sampe place in the old country, anybody and anything that made life in a new and unknown environment possible....The ironic, shoulder-shrugging, accepting, utterly a-political world of English music-hall song, whic had its golden age in these years, is closer to that of the conscious working clss, but its themes--mothers-in-law, wives, no money for the rent--belonged to any community of nineteenth-century urban underdogs." (140) BUT he notes "the culture of th eplebian pooor, even the world of traditional outcasts, shded over into that of class consciousness where both existed."  So he notes that in Berlin or in Hamburg "even the pimps, thieves and fences wouldpay their respect to it."  (140)

title: Worldly Provincialism: German Anthropology in the Age of Empire
text:
Notes 10/2014:

Notes taken while doing revision for the

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
p. 035  Demogrpahics of Anthropological Society

She notes that membership in the Anthropological Society of Washington was exclusively  male, but thinks this was "not so much conscious as automatic, and reflected the usual organization of groups in the national center." (35) It had been founded in 1879 and a notice had been put in a local newspaper announcing a meeting open to interested persons.  She notes that "records show, no women put in an appearance, nor, in the next few years did it seem to have occured to women to request membership in the group."

title: American Moderns: Bohemian New York and the Creation of a New Century
text:
p. 304 - 308 Bohemian Mysogyny  or Antifeminism or...

In this section, S describes via Hapgood (and Boyce) the way men developed a new form of dominance even in the explicitly feminist (or explicitly not antifeminist) bohemianism of their day.  She refers to Hapgood's story of his relationship with Boyce: Story of a Lover (1919).  She describes it this way: "The book is extraordinary in many ways, not least in the feat of describing in detail the actions of a depressed woman without ever acknowledging she is depressed." (305) But more importantly she sees the book as revealing a new form of criticism of women within the bohemian idiom, "what would become a vigorous, long-lasting tradition of male complaint founded on psychological wounds rather than political objections." (305)

But it's more than that still.  It's also after more dominance in the same-old way: "Like John Reed's stories, Hapgood's book questions the credibility of the female voice.  His heroine is so remote that she barely speaks, and when she does speak it is better if she hadn't: 'Because it was [page] unnatural for her to express herself in sound, when she did so, the sounds, if those of exasperated discomfort, were peculiarly irritating.'" (306)  S notes Hapgood tires to portray Boyce as an "inarticulate object" (306)  

Stansell situates the future of this sex-talk within the general narrative of the declension of feminism in the 20s, the commercialization of sexual liberalism in the flapper and youth culture... (307)  But she notes that the discourse on sex was problematic from its 1910s origins, a new construction of the New Woman in a way that suggested power but in reality didn't deliver: "Bohemian sex talk can be seen as an early contribution to the annals of 'men talk, women listen,' a chronicle that has played a large part in our understanding and experience of sexual modernism.
