The fusion of modernity with emancipated femininity simplified both, assigning the New Woman an overweening symbolic role that promised power but in reality imprisoned.  The sexually free woman became a frame for propositions about the modern and the feminine that reduced both to a matter of their effect on male authority.  It was left for women to display their spiritual and erotic riches and others--men--to speak for them." (307) 

Of this New Woman Stansell writes: "The positive outlook and putative towering self-confidence of the free-loving woman became a seductive model of action, will, and sexual agency, but these ascribed powers left women little room to address their actual needs and difficulties.  It was rare for women to give back as good as they got when they talked about sex." (307) 

NOTE: But Mead may have!!

title: The Present Dilemma in Philosophy
text:
General Notes:

* Philosophy is a matter of a "clash of human temperaments". (488)  "Of whatever temperament a professional philsopher is, he tries, when philosophizing to sink the fact of temperament....Yet his temperament really gives him a stronger bias than any of his more strictly objective premises.  It loads evidence for him one way or the other, making for a more sentimental or a more hard-hearted view of the universe, just as this fact or that principle would.  He trusts his temperament.  Wanting a universe that suits it, he believes in any representation of the universe that does suit it." (488-489)

* He says that this is true of philosophers, but most people "most of us" he says, have "no very definite intellectual temperament, we are a mixture of opposite ingredients, each one present very moderately...." (489)  People are influenced by their local philospher he says...

*  No he wants to trace the different temperaments that are significant for talking of philosophy.  He says temperament affects all areas of social and cutlrual life. It's their in art, literature, government etc.  In philosphy the key temperamental distinctions are between the "rationalist" and the "empiricist".  He says rationalist are also referred to as intellectualists and empriicists as sensationalists.  He characterizes these temperaments on 490-492. The classification is the tought v. the tender minded. 

* He notes that most of us who aren't philosophers, because we mix things, mix these temperamental inclinations too.  He shows some of the mixtgures on 491-492. 

* But then eh says this mixing is also somehow true for philsophers of one or the other inclination.  Ie empriciists he says have still a kind of religious. temper.  (492-493).  And ratioanlist-idealists + common-sense realists.  These are the options on th tender-midned side.  The critique here is that these systems that they construct lose contact with the world.  He makes this point through a critique of Leibniz on 495-99.  The wrold in all its complexit is boxed out.   He ends this critique with a critqiue bya an anarchist (499-500).  That critique ends with a reference to teh "mental world" as a physical thing of "atoms" and "sub-atoms" as the "consumate factor of all conscious experience", as apart from the absolute idealists' understanding of "Reality" as a what White calls a "absolute phase of the universe" unconnected to the concrete world. 

* Then James begins to name his own "solution" ie "the oddly-named thing pragmatism" which he sees as a "philospphy that can satisfy  both kinds of demand.  It can remain religious like the rationalism but at the same time, like the empiricisms, it can preserve the richest intimacy with facts." (500-501)

* He says he won't go into this now, leaving it to the next lecture: What is Pragmatism?  But he ends by going over his idea that one should pay heed to temperament.  (501-503)  Key parts it seems to me are when he says that on 502-3 that everyonhe as "his own peculiar sense of a certain total character in the universe, and of the inadequacy fully to match it of the peculiar systems that he knows." (503) H ereers taen to Plato, Locke, Spinoza, Mill, Caird, Hegel--each of them he says his hearers think of as "little more than reminders of as many curious personal ways of falling short." (503)  then he saqys "It would be an obvious abusridty if such ways of taking the universe were actually true." (503) -- this last bit, in what sense would this be absurd?  I think because they are closed systems--ie not admitting of the fundamental openness as he refered to it earlier of the concrete/factual world... To this point he ends by attacking the Spencer's take as an "abstract outline"  and then asking why nonetheless does "half of England" want to "bury him in Westminster Abbey." (503)

title: In Search of Human Nature: The Decline and Revival of Social Darwinism in American Social Thought
text:
p. 70-71 Degler on Boas' Use of "Culture"

Stocking traced Boas's use of the word culture.  Until 1890 he uses it to mean "high culture."  By end of the 1890s thouhg he uses it in a pluralzied 		form, though still within a conception of stages of development so "civilizatoin" is the highest cultural achievment. Stocking also found that there was no use of culture in a plural form between prior to 1895 except by Boas.  After 1910 it became common.  (70-71).

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.039  The Western Civilization he thinks is at the height of its power.

He says war is unthinkable between Western powers.  There is no other super-power outside of the West.  Indeed, its power is evident in its attempt to represent its interests as being identical with the world: "Decisions made at the U.N. Security Council or in the International Monetary Fund that reflect the interests of the West are presented to the world as reflecting the desires of the world community.  The very phrase 'the world community' has become the euphemistic collective noun (replacing 'the Free World') to give global legitimacy to actions reflecting the interests of the United States and other Western powers." (39)  He notes in f.n.# 4 on p.39 that P.M. John Major "referred to the actions 'the West' was taking against Saddam Hussein.  He quickly corrected himself and subsequently referred to 'the world community.' He was, however, right when he erred." (39)

He argues that these "international organizations" support Western interests: "The West in effect is using international institutions, military power and economic resources to run the world in way that will maintain Western predominance, protect Western interests and promote Western political and economic values." (40)

This dominance, though exercised in military and economic power is ultimately in defense, Huntington says, of culture: "Differences in culture, that is basic values and beliefs, are a second source of conflict." (40)  He argues that while the West has perceived its culture as "universal" in fact "Western ideas of individualism, liberalism, constitutionalism, human rights, equality, liberty, the rule of law, democracy, free markets, the separation of church and state, often have little resonance in Islamci, Confucian, Japanese, Hindu, Buddhist or Orthodox cultures." (40) -- indeed, the idea of  a univeral society, he notes, is also Western (41).

He insists that Asian societies are more particularist (41)

He suggest than that the central conflict of the futre will be in the phrase of Kishore Mahbubani: "the West and the Rest" (that phrase comes from Mahbubani's "The West and the Rest" in The Naitonal Intersts, Summer 1992, p3 -13.

three options exist for the "rest": isolation (like N. Korea and Burma); "band-wagoning" that is joining the West, accepting "its values and institutions." (41); and balancing the West "by developing economic and military power and cooperating with other non-Western societies against the West, while preserving indigenous values and institutions; in short, to modernize but not to Westernize." (41)

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.034-28 Chapter Argument Intro

There's economic and financial panic in 1837, contraction of cash and credit.  This leads to renewed claims for the redistribution ofwealth, for instance by Orestes Brownson, but also to a Romantic critique of classical political economy's "proprietary" understanding of the autonomous self.  Sklansky is explicit that the American romantics' complaints were "less with capitalism itself than with the political economy that naturalized and rationalized it--the 'dismal science,' in Carlyl'es enduring epithet, of 'economic man.'" (36) That critique, born out of Romantic's elevation of Intuition above Reason, produced a "fundamentally diferent kind of critique, one that essentially dispensed with ownership and the political rights that accompanied it." (38) This was a "speration of citzenship from ownership" that promised to liberate "the self from its proprietary confines." (38)

Ralph Waldo Emerson, Horace Bushnell, and Margaret Fuller, the key theorists of this critique...

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text:
p.28-30  Individualism keeps Pettit from seeing; Feminist framework for understanding patriarchy requires rejection of Individualism


complex relationship between domination and interference...  this:

"Social norms do not come into being by themselves and they cannot persist without people's actively calling on and deploying them.  So the domination that might resutl from such norms cannot persist without individuals' acting with larger frameworks of cultural meaning to interfere with other individuals' self-conceptions, desires, and choices.  But that the same time, the power of norms, practices, an dmeanings far exceeds the grasp and control of any individual, so that his power can be used and called into play without the explicit awareness of anyone, either dominus or dominated." (28)

She thinks Petitt cannot see this b/c of his commitment to "the individualist conception of freedom, wherein interference always requires an agent  who acts intentionally and purposefully." (28)

She points out that Pettit: "maintains that we can have domination without interference.  That is, the only way for him to claim that freedom can be restricted without intention and purpose of being exercised--a claim which I obviously support--and yet retain individualism is to reject 'non-interference' as the defining feature of freedom."  (28)

This, she says, does not resolve the basic question which is what would freedom look like to a feminist... b/c Pettit's theory cannot answer where the forces of domination which don't require interference originated from... 

To answer that question H thinks, to provide a framewokr that can explain "how it is that social forces like patriarchy are able to restrict women's freedom" (29)  She think you must reject "individualism as a guiding principle." (29)

title: Adam Smith and the Circles of Sympathy: Cosmopolitanism and Moral Theory
text:
Notes Feb 2012:

(For Cosmpotitanism article...)

   Introduction

* FB believes sees Adam Smith as an anti-cosmpolitan, but she believes that the way in which Smith struggled with the problem of spatial distance in his moral philosophy "provides a framework for thinking in fresh ways about new sorts of human connection that emerge in a global age, for reflecting on what William Connolly has recently called 'eccentric' connections that emerge in an age of speed and compressed distance--'crosscutting allegiances' that 'exceed,' 'complicate,' and often 'compromise' the concentric connections of place that governed in ages when people lived slow, local lives." (5-6) So what she is doing here is saying that Smith's thought

* Smith is an anti-cosmpolitan FB says because he rejected the Stoic idea of oikeiosis.  Oikos refers to the private realm of the home as opposed to the public or polis.  "Oikeiosis was a Stoic extrapolation from the familiarity that develops over time among those who inhabit the oikos, among those who very literally share physical space.  Most fully developed byy Cicero and Hierocles, oikeiosis was the notion that human affection weakens as it radiates outward in degrees from the self.  Thus, the Stoics mapped our affections concentrcially, arguing that our affecions are strongest at the center, closest and most familiar to the self, and that thez weaken progressively as an object is removed further and further away." (8)  Ie for the Stoics "human affection and care are ordered spatially around the self in a concentric pattern." (8)  Smith appropriated this idea in that he saw it as an "empirical fact", FB says, but he was ambivalent about it and rejected the Stoics insistence that the individual should "cultivate 'apathy' toward the near and dear, learn to resist oikeiosis (the natural affection born of familiarity), to collapse the circles, and become 'citizens of the world.'" (8)  

* Smith's ambivalent appropriation of oikeiosis produced in his moral philosophy a certain take on the interelationship between ethics and spatial distance that FB thinks speaks directly to contemporaray debates about cosmopolitanism, and especially the "concentric model of ethical concern" that comes from Stoic thought but which is also "commonplace in ethics discourse today" (9)-- she  highliights in particular Martha Nussbaum as someone who has drawn this model from the Stoics in her work on cosmpolitnaism (see 10-11). 

* The reason she suggests that Smith is useful for a discussion of contemporary cosmpolitanism is precisely because he engaged this model, even though he rejected the Stoic's cosmpolitan vision.  His rejections of that model in fact may help us understand and work through our own engagement with the term, which as she points out at the beginning of her introduction (pp.1-3) very much seeks to figure out ways to cope with the way in which the local limits the universalist ethical thrust of cosmpolitan desires.  Here is how she puts it:

The arguments he mounted against the Stoic project add a fresh, distinctively Scottish sociological and moral psychological texture and depth to the steady onslaught of localist, communitarian, and culturalist challenges leveled against the cosmpoitan project today.  Like us, Smith struggled with surmounting spatial obstacles to human understanding and care, bringing his ethical thought front and center, and transforming Smith from a stodgy Scot long rebuffed by political theorists and moral philosophers for his vexing defense of free market capitalism in the Wealth of Nations and into a worthy interlocutor in the cosmpolitan debates who richly appreciated the local texture of human identity and can help us, in this sense, to grasp some of the limits of our own aspirations. (11)

title: The Rise of Neo-kantianism: German Academic Philosophy between Idealism and Positivism
text:
Notes Part II (5/2013)

 

## Part II: Philosophy in the post-March period and the neo-Kantian programmata (1849-1865)

### 3. Philosophical trends of the post-March period and the programmata of the 'Sceptical Gernation'

* Köhnke argues that the 1848 revolution and the general politicization contributed to a key development in late ninteenth century philosophy in Germany. The system building impulse of German idealism had already come unders doubt in the 1840s. Because, in part, the idea that oen could deduce a system from principle had come under dobut, but also becasue there were mutliple and contradictory systems, and these systems also made strong political claims about culture and history. So when in the 1840s there emerged a new political polarization this had a big impact, because philosophical systems were linked up with ideological parties. (69-70) You  had on the one hand the materialism and "panthesism" of the Left Hegelians and the "aristocratic realism" of the Herbartians and idealistic "theosophic speculation" of Schelling and Stahl on the other. (70-71)

* Following the failued revolution in 1848, however, thign developed further in away that ultimately led a sharp separation of practical from theoretical philsophy.  Before the revolution already most philosohpers recognized a need for a non-speculative philosophy, but "it required the failure of a revolution wholly to banish questions of practical politics -- and with them the entire political philosphy of the opposition -- fromt he life of the university: it was beacsue Germany had not become even a constitutional monarchy, let alone a republic, that the German university could likewise not become a republic of science..." (71) Instead, K notes, the ultra-conservative tendencies ie specualtive philsophy and the modern "spitemologically oriented philsophers" remained in the unviersity,while all those tendnecies in which philosophy engaged the public remained outside. (71)

* K then traces two key developments here. One, the framing of Schopenhauer by Julius Frauenstädt in a 1849 article "Opinons on Arthur Schopenhauer" that produced what K describes as this important alternative view of philosohpy: that emphasized the philosopher as opposed to the system; the individualism of the philosopher; the literary prowess of the philospher and their "free-thinking qualities" -- and all this long before the "Nietzsche cult." (71-74) On the flip side, he describes Johann Eduward Erdmann's use of Herbart as an empiricist who nontheless traeted the individual and "the given" as the reality -- that is a kind of conservative empricisism. (74-77) These two positions formed an antithesis, but K wants to empahsize the key point is also that both Schopenhauer and Herbart constituted a new synthesis that inspired a "reinvigorated reference back to Kant: Schopenhauer predominantly to the idalist, Herbart predominantly to the realist elements of the Kantian philosophy." (77)

* Then also cleverly K notes the development of an external and internal constraint in academic philosphy. There was on the one hand a sense of the alienation of academic philosophy from the public, e.g. in the foreward composed by IH Fichte, H Ulrice, JU Wirth for the revived *Zeitschrift f
ür Philosophie und philosophische Kritik in 1852, see great quote on 77-78.  The response to their sense of aileantion was to advocate a pure science that would not address "interest" or what K calls *Weltanschauung*. (78) So K dates what he calls the "epoch of modern philosophy -- and that means the eopoch in whcih it beacme within the university a mere 'branch of learning,' a learned discipline beside others, and itself abandoned all claim to be in any respecting anything more..." (79) to March 1852.  This was the "internal constraint." But there was also an external cosntraint -- namely, that the rise of such a purely secular philosohy was still regarded by the universities in some cases as hostile -- ie they could not believe that this new pure science was not an attack on the church. So he describes how both Carl Prantl and Kuno Fischer were excluded from the universities for attempting such secular philosophical projects. (79-83)

* These external and internal constraints together make acaemic philosophy largely irrelevant culturally. (83) Students only took note of philosophy only through history of philosophy and its involvement with aprticualr individual sceinces. (83-84) At this point, though, the philosophy that sought closer assocation with 'other' sciences did so more as an end in itself, and less in the way that Trendelendburg for exmaple had meant that engaement in the pre-March period. (83-84)

* He rolls out Kiel professor Friedrich Harms (1816-1880) as an example of someone who provided the "first prospectus for a purely scientifici philosphy of this kind." (84) What he notes is particualrly interesting is that Harms' text has the "twofold assualt on materialism and German idealism that was to be typical of the later neo-Kantian progrmamata." (84) He quotes on 84-85. The thrust here is that philosophy must seek "fundamental principles and a method of knowledge" unerlying the indviidual sceinces by examining "the nature of th emind itself." (Harm's words, 84). "It [philosophy] has to explain and offer grounds for the definition, the conept of science whose validity is presupposed in every particualr science. This task it alloted to it by the nature our mind, whcih strives to attain insight into its own essnetial character, and by the essential character of the particular sciences, which demand for their elucidation a primary anda  basic science." (quoted 84-85). --> K says Harms was talking about not "enroaching upon the mterial domains of other practical sciences" as had natural philosphy (materialism) and philosophy of history (idealism), but a "critical theory of the science of hsitory which made it its task to secure the foudnations of this science." (85)

* The reason there is interest in this kind of science is , K notes, because the conflit over mateiralism had made it clear that the "methods and reults of the individual sciences proved to be politically and *weltanschaulich* highly contensious." (86) He sees this in a 30 March 1854 article by Andrewas Ludwig Kym, six months before  the dispute over materalism began. (86) The article "The *Weltanschauungen* and their Consequences"  argues that the individual sciecnes each create theri own *Weltanschauungen*. "Each attempt...by human thought to pentrrate the given world represents the origination of a science. The different soceities are the diferetn ways in which human thought strives to comprehend the soure of all life and all spirit. Thus there are as many possible *Weltanschauungen* as there are sceicnes." (quoted on 86) From here Kym, says there is a need for a "universal science" that can reveal what is in common. That is philosophy. So K writes that it was not only the attempt to found philosophy anew on the basis of indivdual sceneces that lead to an itnerest in epsitemology and methodology, but also "the 'one-sidededness' of the *Weltanschauungen* that proceed from the various sciences to promote an interest in this domain. It is because the siecnes now acquire the *function of founding Weltanschauungen* that there now appears the need for a supreme court of control t adjucucate border dispute which --long before neo-Kantianism -- philosophy feels itself called upon to be." (87)  

* Key and interesting here I think,though, is that ultimately Kym rejects the idea that there are infinite Weltanschauungen for the idea that there are only two: naturwissenschaft and geisteswissenschaft.  

NOTE: This is what Boas does too.

* K says that although Kym did not realize it what he was doing was providing an early critique of postiviism or the "view that the individuals sciences can furnish the knoweldge that is to replace philosophical knowledge." (87)

* This goes to a historigoraphic piont that K is very exercised in making -- because it apparently corrects an oft-repated error -- that Mill's Logik der Geisteswissenschaften appeared in 1849 and initiated a German concern with the relationship between philosophy and science, when in fact his point is that that interest existed long before. So there was in fact little interest in Comtean postiivism or Mill because the profession was already fighting in the 1850s against "Fuerbach and the anthropologism he origianted  which through a universal naturalization of aoll spiritual phenomena threatened to replace philosophy with inquire confiend to natural science (prantl, Harms); against empriidcal natural-sceientific pscyhology (Drobish, Waitz) and the materialism which was an even crasser manifestation of it... and, finally, against the imporation of foreign positivist or inductive logics such as those of Herschel, Comte, Mill, Opzoomer, whcih were likewise incompatibile with any traditional conception of philosphy's tasks or themes." (89)

* K's bigger point here seems to be that the difficulty opositivism had in catching on in Germany had to do with the sharp "antithesis" between the independent sciences and the still idealist pretnesions of academic philosoophy. "Here materialist and naturalist tendencies were, like positivism, and not only in the 1850s, graded as 'dangerous' on account of their propsensity to undermine all morality and idealism in just the same way as was the secular conception of philosphy as 'pantheism'." And this he thinks -- giong back to the thesis that began this chapter -- was one of the "consequences of the political and ecclesiasticcal repression" in Germany as opposed to in France or England... that made it hard to respond to the rise of natural sciences and of technology and industry in by a "philosophical theorizing in this sense 'appropriate to the age.'" (90)

* So now in a section on the "Skeptical Generation" of the 1850s. (90-96) He lays out what he sees as a social history argument to explain why the neo-Kantian pioneers of the new criticism emerged. He lists them as Hermann Helholtz (1821), Ruduolf Hayan  (1821), Kuno Fischer (1824), Friedrich Ueberweg (1826) and Juergen Bona Meyer (1829). (94) they were born in the 1820s. They faced a situation marked first by 1848 and the failued revolution that created a "prohibition of all free *Weltanschaulich* philosophical discussion" (95) and then by the 1854 reaction to materialism that created a situation in which one iether had to move back toward a Christian Weltanschauung or opt for a mechanistic picture of the world.  Plus -- moreover -- the context of repression of secular philosophy (the external constraint) created a situation in which choosing philosophy required economic hardship. These men did not receive their professorship until in their 40s. They on average married at 33. They experienced the "*weltanschaunlich* polarization" at ages between 26 and 35. So their bvasic position K says was of "seeking a philosophical justification for an attitude of 'neither-nor' or one of 'this as well as that.'" (96) (94-96)  This leads to a situation in which they combined mechanistic views with idealist ones. He says Lange was like this; and that Helmholtz and Meyer advocated a critical standpoint based in neither-nor to the end that "in theoretical philosphy their argumetns were predominantly materialist but in practical philosphiy predominatly idealist." (96) Bloch called this "dobule-entry book-keeping under sicence and idealism" (quoted on 96).

* Now getting into the earliest neo-Kantians in a fourth section in this chapter. The movement saw Helmholtz as key as Also Riehl sad of him that he restored a collaboration between science and philosophy. That is, K says, that in this equation "Kantianism and a connection with the individual sciences were henceforeth equated with one another." (96) Helhomltz was key because being a natural scientist and physician he "seemed to have learned in the school of *nature* rather than in that of *philosophy*." (97) This was not true, however, K notes, because Helmholtz had really been schooled in the line of philosophy etending back to von Berger, and through IH. Fichte to his father that K has been tracing. (97-98)

* Key here was a refuation of materialism that used a recognition of the physiolgoical basis of senses -- and what they conttributed to external objects -- as a way to refute materialism. F.A. Lange put it in his *History of Materialism* this way:
> There is a domain of exact natural science which prevents our contemporary materialists from angrily turning their backs on all doubts as to the reality of the phenomenal world: it is the physiology of the sense-organs...Once it has been demonstrated that the quality of our sense-perceptions is wholly determined by the nature of our organs we can no longer dismiss with the predicate 'irrefutable or absurd' the postulate that the entire connected cohesion to which we reduce these sense-perceptions, in short our whole experience, is determined by a spiritual oranization which compels us to experience as we experience, to think as we think... (quoted on 97)

  That motif of refutation of materialism already existed in Helmholtz, K says. Kant and Fichte, whom Helmholtz linked together, represneted a "principle of an idealist epistemology". (98) Helmholtz achieved the same thing by fusing Johannes Müller's thoery of specific energies of the senses -- the idea that the quality of our sensations came from energy transmitted to objects by our sense-organs -- with Kan'ts theory of pure forms of perception. So that he argued that the "character of our perceptions is conditinoed as much by the nature of our senses as it is by external objects..." and that this idea confirmed by natural science demosntates "by empirical means...the same thing that Kant, by setting forth the part played in the formation of our ideas by the particular innate laws of the mind, as it were the organization of the mind, earlier sought to demosntrate with regarde to the idea of the human mind in general." (quoted on 98)

* From here, more importantly, Helmholtz then speculated on the relationship of the will to senses. He said that the idea of causation in the wrold is an a priori upon which our abiltiyt o have knowledge of the world depends precisely because we cannot derive it from self-reflection, and we cannot do that precisely because "we regard the self-aware acts of our thought and will as free, i.e. we deny that they are the necessary effects of sufficient causes." (Helmtholtz, quoted on 99) Here then you have the preservation of the separation of practical and theoretical knowledge in separate registers. Likewise, when his fatehr tried to confront him over the issue of materialism, he remained skeptical abut the enlarged claims of materalists in the realm of *Weltanschuungen*.

* From Helmholtz "purely empirical" neo-Kantianism, K moves on to two other versions (the three beign laid out repsectively in 1855, 1856, and 1857). The other two are Jürgen Meyer's criticalist neo-Kantiaism, and Haym's liberalist neo-Kantianism. (see 105).

* Meyer's criticalism has a more uncomplicated critique of materialism -- which is a bit harder to see, though also true of, in Helmholtz. This is not yet FA Lange's criticalism because philosophy does not yet "stand above" K says. (101).  Meyer also studied medicine and natural sciences, at Bonn, and then in 1853 began to study philosophy. (101) He gets into a convention over body and soul, where hedefends against the idea that materialism necessarily means a rejection of free will and consciousness. (101)  In what K calls the first neo-Kantian book *Zum Streit über Leib und Seele* he lays out a "criticalism" that basically is rooted in an awareness of "the boundaries of our knowledge" and yet a desire within that awareness to strive "with unidivided strength for what is possible within these limits." (quoted on 102, see whole long quote). K emphasiszes it is an ateempt to "segregate philosophical, epistemological and scientific-theoretical preoblems from very political and *weltanschaulich contention." (102)

### 4. The Philosophical Crisis at the Time of the  'New Era'

* Here Koehnke has been describing how there was a kind of push for a "philosophy of mediation" in the "New Era" i.e. the post-March period. There was a growing emphasis on the need for a form of inquiry that would "resolve the subject-object probem in such a way that neither the share o the subjective nor that of the objective  would be made one-sidedly, and thus uncritically, absolute." (113) Even though the back to Kant movement had not yet obviously begun then here Kant was already referred to because he was a good starting point for the kind of epistemology that such a philosophy would require. See quote by Eduard Zeller on 113.The drive Koehnke says wa toward "the conversion of an absolute opposition [between idealism and materialism] into a relative one, of a confrontation into a synthesis." (114) Kant was taken by Zeller, quote on 113 and 114, as someone who denied the absolute truth of either perspective buth thought both had something important.(113-114)

> Note: I noted here too that in this search for a synthesis for a breakdown of the stark opposition this begins to sound a lot like the basic push of Isaacs in *Working Knowledge*. Makes sense then also that he sites the neo-Kantians in his intro.

* In the next section, K deals with a kind of renaissance of philosophy aroudn Fichte, that turns in part on an epistemologicla dispute that is thematized around differing versions of Kant. (116)

* Kuno Fischer's presentation of Kant -- which was idealist -- fueled this a bit. See Juergen Bona Meyer reflections on this on 116-117. Fischer it seems was reading Kant as a kind of "empirical idealist" -- i.e. attributing to Kant's categories a kind of objective validity, i.e. such that what is external to us i.e. space pertains to "things-in-themselves" -- only it our knowledge of those things-in-themselves is in question. (116-117)

* But then through these kind of debates there began a certain renaissance of "German philosophY". It first took place around discussions of the 'body-soul problem" that had been discussed since 1854 in many brochures and small monogrphas many of which took aim at materialism. (118) And also around the celbration of Schiller (Kant's pupil) as a kind of national hero, celebrations that coincided with the entry of Prussia and the German Confederation into the Franco-Austrian war. (118) Following on these Schiller celebrations then also there were more references to Kant, and an attitude toward him developed that treated him as a contemporary, i.e. not dealing with irrelevant problems. As Karl Fortlage put it in the *Litearische Centralbaltt* in 1860: "Kant is not old, Kant is younger than any of us." (See whole quote on 119). But this enthusiasm was of ac ertain line of interpreation that linked Schiller-Fichte and Kant, i.e. a kind of idealist version of Kant. Thus Fortlage continued his recognition of this Kant revival with a review of Kuno Fischer's presentation of Kant. (119)

* K speaks of Kant being "Fichteanized on 120, i.e. a sense of the service that Kant had 'rendered to pure idealism in practical philosophy." (120). People even spoke of "Kantian-Fichtean philosophy. (123)

* This Fichteanized Kant that Kuno Fischer propagated was the basis for the South--West Geramn school of Neo-Kantianism. Fischer says it's history began on 19 May 1862. (124)

* Section 3 here then goes into "The Neo-Idealism and Erkenntnistheorie of Kuno Fischer". K describes his owrk as a "one-sidedly idealist explication of Kant" (125). He goes into this in great detail, but a good sense of what K thinks Fischer was diong comes on 133, when he notes after a quote in which Fischer writes that "Space and time are always there..." that whereas Kant had wanted to submit the "'ideas' we commonly construct for ourselves of knowledge, the worl,d the soul and God to a critique of theroetical and practical reason," Fischer has essentially reversed this impulse. He wanted to in his "criticalism" do the opposite...to set oup a "system of critical philosphy" and a "system of pure reason." Or what K calls a "positive sysetm of pure reason". And hewas able to do this just because hw as so convinced of his own pure reason K says, bottom 133.

* So what was the appeal here? Well this certain that Fischer felt and his neo-idealism seemed to give philosophy a certain autonomy in relation to the other science, "and this autonomy rested quite direclty on a demonstration rof the a prior, of the presuppositionality of the 'pure' forms of perception that enter into all processes of cognition." (134)

* That autonomy and apriority K then notes gurgher seemed to also ensure "in the realm of practical philophy that human freedom of will seemed to be immune from all naturalist or materialist encroachments... " I.e. it secured the self against a kind of subordination to naturalist causality... (134)

* Great quote on 135, that what Fischer offered in the 1860s was a neo-idealism that was appealing due to a readiness among a "large part of the public" and espeically the "academic public" to "make this self-consciouness of the individual the starting-point of all (pseudo-)philosphical reflection." (135) This cocktail was a powerful force pushing back agains the materialistc threat. and it's succes pushed aside for some time the "realist elements of Kantian philosophy" focusin insetad on the "subjective and formal elements in the process of congition." (135) 

> Note: Cf with the Mosse thesis that at some point the Bildungideal needed mor" that it became grounded in emotion ...

* Now in the next section K deals with Otto Liebman who put forth a Neo-Kantian Programmata.

* Three things had come together to make Neokantianism possible says K: the theory of knowledge as a "systematic concern", a new idealism as a weltanschaulich concern, and a new relationship to tradition. (136)

* N.b Neo-kantianism emerged from many things flowing together... The phenomenon was first noticed by its critics, but the most common feature was simply the reference to Kant... 137

* Excellent summary of the variou lines or types of argument that were present within the back to Kant movement. (148)

1) One line is a critique of "pure thought" or "system philosophy in the way that K has shown Schleiermacheer, Beneke, and Trendelenburg wanted. (148)

2) Another was through the idea that in the line from Fichte to Hegel, German philosphy had "misdeveloped" and the way to get back on the right course was through a reconnection with Kant. (Beneke, Weisse, Fischer and Liebmann).

3) Either a) maining the imortance of greater  involvement with the individual sciences and in partiuclar on seeking a "sensual-physiological" foundation for Kantian Erkenntnistheorie. (Helmholtz and Lange), or b) rejecting invovlement with the individaul sciences and in partticular natural science (i.e. rejecting anthropologistm, empriicism, positivism,  materalism, and pscyhologism) in order to rebuild philosophy as an autonomous field. (Harms, Haym, Fischer, and Liebmann).

4) A kind of critique of knowlege whose goal should be to use scholarly and scientific means to "determine the limits beyond which matters of *weltanschaulich* dispute cannot be decided...  (Hlemholtz, Noack, J.B. Meyer, Zeller, and Lange).

## Part III - The dissmenation of neo-Kantianism (1865-1881)

### 5. From Lange's critique of materialism to Cohen's critique of experience

* First section deals with Lange.

* Good summary and contextual inaction of Lange's text here to show that Lange's success was particularly in managing the tensions between the critique I'd metaphysics and the critique of materialism. According o winded and here quoted, Lange did this by demonstrating that materialism is metaphysics. (162). In any case the point is that the context for Neokantianism and Lange's woke was this weltanschaunngen divide between stahl and other Christian metaphysicians and Feurebach and other materialists on the other. (161-162)

* Very important passages here for understanding Lange and also Boas. In contrast to neo idealist Neokantianism like Kuno Fischer, who admitted the single point of Kant's work that experience conformed to our concepts of it and not the other way around but used this as a basis for setting up the autonomy of philosophy based on a return to a priori reason, Lange put the emphasis on experience and on the idea that the objectivity of experience is not an absolute objectivity, but only for humans and other similarly organized beings. That move K says was driven by a mistaken reading of Kant's notion of apriorism, where the a priori was taken to indicate "the natural disposition of our senses and our understanding." (163) So unlike Kant who was interested in determining the "presuppositions of a priori knowledge", Lange was inclined to treat a priori knowledge as a fiction and focus on the way the "'knowledge apparatus' of man places a decisive stamp on our experience of the external world." (163) What K refers to as the "participation of the subject in the act of perception" had raised a doubt about the "reality" of the phenomenal world, he says, and this precept was at the same time "regularly transgressed" both by materialists and metaphysicians. So K says that Lange's neo Kantianism was much closer to a form of naturalism than the others neo idealist Zneo Kantians.

All this helps vv Boas, who read Lange twice through. In particular, the focus on the way human sense perception stamps experience... The suspicion of the a priori as well which then weakens the singularity of the ways in which experience is stamped by humans. At one point here, K notes in somewhat obscure language that Kant's exploration of theoretical knowledge was underpinned by a "transcendental aesthetic" that itself rested on the quasi scientific notion of the "physiology of the senses". I think what am is referring to here is Kant's idea that humans' aesthetic reactions are grounded in the universal physiological organization of human sense organs. Lange seems to push against this a bit if only because he is willing to pay more attention to the actual sciences if physiology of the period in a way that would pluralize or at least complicate Kant's assumptions about the singularity if human physiology. Then Boas obviously takes this further in the ways that I suggest. (163)

* Thisquote seems key to what I am sensing in Boas. K includes it here in a passage intended to illustrate how closely Lange hewed to a form of naturalism ,or rather how non idealist he was. He is rejecting the notion if transcendental ideas, except for te following: "Only the Idea of the soul as the Idea of the unified subject for the multiplicity of sensations and perception can perhaps be called necessary." (164) O's focus alights a bit later in the quote on Lange's denial that the Idea of God as a "rational originator" could be seen as having a "natural quality." 164) his point is that Ideas in Lange were valid only if they possessed a "natural quality." Hence.His "naturalism." 163-164

* K suggests that this insistence on the unified subject was common to all the neo Kantians,. (164)

* Lange's insistence on the unified subject as a "natural quality" when it came to free will led him to a kind of determinism That tied perception absolutely to the psycho-physical organization of the senses. K thus quips that the question of philosophy would have to be determined in helmholtz's laboratory. (164)

* New section begins here that deals with the Fischer-Trendelenburg Debate... this is a debatea bout the gap between "the emirical and a complete and absolute conception of totality." (167)

* Here too I am provoked to think of Boas. This gap, deeply Kantian and neo-kantian, seems to set up the context in which Boas' manifold conception of cultures would resemble a novel solution. (167)

* Right so what really makes Lange distinct is this "sense-psychological interpretation..." 168

* Interesting vv Boss weird statement in the journal to Marie that there Kant meant that space and time were nothing. That romantic moment might have been just that, or is there something else going on there? A pushing back against a more aggressive neo idealism a la Trendelenburg, ie that would link the ideal and the real? Prob not. Boas wanted to say the meaning of space and time was not so great because these were just concepts. But he leaves out their dominance implying that one could think without them. (169)

* Cohen like like Trendelenburgg hoped to establish link between real and ideal and so was a critic of Lange. (170)

* Summary here of Marburg neo kantian ism. A la Cohen. 178

--- Now notes here on the section on Cohen ---

 

### 6. The preconditions of the rapid dissemination of neo-Kantianism in the 1870s

* New stage of neo kantianism end of 1870s. There was a kind of resurrection of philosophy, and this ha s been acknow ledges by other accounts by eg Ueber web have noted. But these accounts do not question what caused the decline from which there was then a resurrection. They treat it as a kind of accident out and that is because such accounts have an idealist emphasis and can only imagine that  a true philosophy is not materialist or positivist eg(198)

* K explains here on 201-203 how it was the broader conditions if expansion in the education system in the  Q1870s that played a role in allowing for the rapid spread of a neo-Kantian movement, and not xclusvely as has often Ben raged these thinkers acceptance of the demands of the state, party or class. Although I think K may stuff off these questions  too easily. (201-203)

* K is now distinguishing between a Sceptical generation, ie Lange and Fischer I think, and a younger neo-Kantian one. And one thing dividing
them is that this younger generation got jobs much more quickly. (202)

* This is key. What K repeats here as being key to the Neo-Kantian turn above all is not any particular opposition to materialism or idealism, but a desire to see both as a threat to the autonomous individual. So a liberal stance to be sure. A fear of the weltanschaulich, and a sense that as K puts it such ideas were the case of social conflicts as well as there effect. So K sees in their work a commitment to a certain "image of man" that drove at a certain kind o  "moral personality" (209) in which the emphasis was on man "as a free, moral and autonomous individual..."( 210)

* And then here the most useful link to Boas of all!! The idea K lays out is that vv this moral personality concept it was Lange that was most influential, Esp compared with K Fischer. And this was the case despite Lange's evident naturalism. Specifically, K notes that Lange started from a critique e of the ideas if the present, ie of all the Weltanschaulich ideas, and thus could speak clearly to a younger generation. The students' own perspectives were most likely naturalistic as well , and this was totally the case with Boas!, and so he took them to a position where they could make some sort of leap to idealism... See K's quote here, as it is excellent. (210)

* This younger Neo-Kantian generation also tended to be materialist...(211)

* Okay so after going through a whole account of the new cultural politics of the Gründerzeit, ie the period of economic boom and industrial progress following the Franco-Prussian war, including the critique of the pessimist movement, e.g. The neo-kantianism again appear as defenders of a kind of critical ism that views these movements as Weltanschaunlich and is invested in the defense of a kind of immunity of philosophy and science from ideology. (219) by he account of pessimism on the previous pages is very interesting in its own right..., he sees it as a kind of philosophy of history and a critique not of society but if civilization. I wonder what Nietzscheand Spengler's relationship to it is... (219...)

* Now K deals with the link to the Kulturkampf. Lange as a guardian of the immunity of the sciences had inveigled against certain firms of conservative catholic and idealist thought, ie against the kind of ideas contained in the doctrine of papal infallibility and neo-scholasticism that would launch the culture war in the early 1870s  in a pamphlet published in 1865. Some years later after the culture war had begun, and when the liberal education minister Falk took over the office from the more conservative Müller, Falk helped Lange acquire the professorship in Marburg. Cohen also took up a position eventually at Marburg and he was a Jew. K's point is that although it is not clear whether Falk saw himself as an exponent or ally of Neo-kantianism, it would not have been possible for Lange as a suspected materialist and socialist or Cohen as a Jew to have such opportunities. (221) in Parliament these kinds of policies were also upheld by a new policy toward the churches that curtsied their rights, leading Conservatives to abandon Bismark. (221-222) then in the elections of 10 January 1874, the conservatives suffered heavy losses and the national liberals could then achieve a series of reforms that had long been part of their platforms, such as separation of church and state, subordination of schools and clergy to state, and immunity of science from outside interference. (222) the point being that it was in this period that as Jürgen Bona Meyer put it scientific freedom became a reality, ie c. 1874.  (219-222)

* Of the younger generation of neo-kantianism, one of the first to enter the Kururkampf was Alois Riehl, with his Morality and Dogma of 1872.
(222) K goes through his analysis on next few pages, ending with a reference to Kant as the thinker that realized the way the universal transcended mere dogma. (224)  What K is building to here is quite interesting, a complex sense of the linkages between neo-kantianism and the foundation of the Reich. There was a conning together of several factors that mingled together: so he describes an "indissoluble union of varying aspects of the history of philosophy in the decade of the foundation of the Reich", including Connections between Kant, the Kulturkampf, Falk, and the need to fill sports in an expanding university system. These intermingling factors cannot he thinks be subordinated to a singular causal chain as has been the case on many other accounts of neo-kantianism. (224) This younger generation thus also was different than the earlier Sceptical generation because with academic freedom a reality they could push forvseculaization... (224) ie where in 1865 Lange had to publish his polemic against catholic dogma anonymously this younger generation did nt.  and in fact most of the kulturkampf propgandist belonged to the Neo-kantian camp, says K. (224-225)

* K describes a kind of mania for progress, in which the divine and the rational seemed to have come palpably close, that was swept up in a
"universal" enthusiasm for modernization, and which included neo-kantianism, who seemed satisfied with the society around them.  So In this way it these neo-kantians saw themselves as modernizers of
philosophy, snd as having further a defensive role to play on the  behalf of national liberalism against conservatism and the Catholic
center faction. ( 226)

* But here too he resists other accounts that have accused these philosophers of the Second Reich of taking up arms against the international proletariat, and thus also as being implicated in the crimes of the Third Reich. (226) this he thinks goes way too far, ESP. As these philosophers were helpful to Bismark but never in fact powerful or needed.

* Now returning to the epistemological questions, K gets into Liebman's notion of a priori reason, and its relationship to his sense of the identity of philosophy and of science. For Liebman's a priorism involved formalism. Sciences should be formal and maintain such a relationship to their object, ie always evaluating their own terms, precepts and concts. Then philosophy stood as the science which served as a court to evaluate the claims of the individual sciences. And this was a decidedly negative concept of philosophy! (228-229)

* Interesting critique here of Cohen's notion of the a priori. K is making the point that te Neo-Kantian approach to a priori also devolved into something of a chaos of conflicting accounts, once Neo-kantianism had triumphed as the dominant philosophical form in the German context. In one instance of disagreement, K describes Vokelt,'s critique of Cohen based on the idea that since Cohen had interpreted away the thing-in-itself, he could no longer account for the relationship between knowledge and objective things. Thus also he could not "derive the material from the subject", like Fichte. Verkolt highlighted this by asking then "how...does it happen that the a priori forms of the subject are filled with this rich, variegated empirical content? Cohen has broken this bridge that leads from this diversity to the subject, and likewise that which leads to the object; it is thus a miracle that any experience occurs, that the senses do not gaze out into emptiness, and that understanding has not long since fallen asleep for lack of occupation." (229)

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text: p.053-54  Account of Boas' Censure

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.051-52 Gender based patronage (not political)

Muncy describes a patronage system inside the bureau based on gender and professional cutlure.  Men were therefore maginalized and did not hold decision making positions in the bureau.  (52) Similar culture in the Bureau as in the settlement houses: "...Some women formed close personal as well as professoinal relationships.  Sometimes they lived or at least dined together.  Most workers loived in boarding houses or apartment hotels.  Hotels provided individual kitchens but also supplied meals in a common dining room.  Women who lived in either a boarding house or a hotel thus enjoyed many of the advantages offered by settlements: private rooms, freedom from cooking, and communal dining arrangement..." (52)  More details 52-53: including intimacy among staff, and the responsiveness of the Bureau to the letters and pleas for help that were received.

title: Franz Boas and the Humboldtian Tradition: From Volkgeist and Nationalcharakter to an Anthropological Concept of Culture
text:
Notes Taken for Revision of Manifold Origins, Summer 2014:

* B Notes that Boas read Kant and Herder. (18) But Bunzl thinks that the
specific influences of especially the Humboldts has been overlooked.
(18)

* Humboldt early on took up Herderian ideas, say in an early study of
Greece. And he then also met Fichte and Schiller in Jena when he moved
there in 1794. (21)

* Herder's holism described. (20). Part of Bunzl's narration of the
development of German philosophy. (19-)

* Bunzl notes Herders genuine universalism, in the Humanitawtsideal... (20)

* Humboldts "Plan for a Comparative Anthropology" fused Herder and
Bildung. Like Herder, the common humanity is expressed through
individual characters" ie of a people. The character of a Volk
revealed in turn the level of Bildung.
This plan was an attempt, Bumz
Points out, to fuse Herder and Kant. (22)

* By 1822, the year H presented his Historiographical treatise, Bunzl
says Romantic nationalism had taken over. (25) Humboldt was also
affected by this shift and the "anti-rationalism" as Bunzl calls it
that came with it. Bunzl describes this balance here on 25-26.
Humboldt here accepts that there are mechanistic and physiological
factors that affect history in a regular and lawful manner, but these
were not the real forces in history. The real forces were non
rational, and these were those related to "abilities, feelings,
dispositions and desires". -- the charachter of a people-- and these
needed to be studied under

* 1808 Humboldt becomes secretary of education, and in 1809 founds the
University of Berlin. 1810 he enters politics as a envoy to Vienna but
is removed in 1819 for his liberal politics. After 1819 until 1835, he
attempts to realize his vision in the "Plan for a Comparative
Anthropology". (24)he influenced German historical writing with his
Über die Aufgabe des Geschichtsschreibers" and also influenced
Voelkerpsychologie. And his writings on language introduced a
comparative study of language. (24) AND all of these lines, bunzl
argues, "converged in a  Franz Boas." (24)

* Link from Humboldt to Ranke and then to Droysen. (26-27)

* Boas cited Dilthey!! (27)

* Voelkerpsychologie (27)

* Voelkerpsychologie extends idea if Volksgeiet, genius of a people,
that Bunzl says came from Herder. (28) But Bunzl points put also that
the ultimate goal for Lazarus and Steinthal was to find "the laws that
governed the psychological development of a people." (28) in their
conception, the essence of mankind was divided in to Voelker, so the
laws of all people's psychology would have to slowly emerge. (28)

* This sounds a lot like the Bastian and the kind of position I am
saying that boas pivoted against. (28)

* Humboldts linguistic work began after his forced retirement in 1819.
(29) key text, much respected, is H's pisthumously published intro to
the Kawa-Werk... (29)

* Key to his method, a break with the use of European grammatical
categories to analyze other languages. Instead, H analyzed languages
according to their distinct structural features, foreshadowing
structural linguistics. (31)

* Only after describing the inner structure of these languages did he
move on to the analysis of these languages genetic relationship. (32)
here he dealt with inter influence and mixing. (32) but Bunzl makes
clear that H really understood this mixing only as a force that had in
fact helped to create he individual languages in the first place. Thus
really there was no way to get At the grenealogival relationships. So here Humboldt really shies away
from focusing on the  diffusion. His focus is instead as Bumz
Then says I the relationship between language and Nationalcharakter,
and here if course language is an expression of the volksgeist, the
charachter of. Apeople shaped the language... (32) and language in
turn shaped the world view of a people, the weltansicht. (32-33)

* Here again is precisely the move in direction of the unique closed
people that I think Boas was resisting. Will have to see what Bunzl
does with this when we get to Boas...

* Bunzl says here that Humboldt has basically developed a more
systematic approach to national charachter than Herder or Hamann.
G33)

* Here again Bunzl pushes back insisting that Humboldt still
appreciated the universality of language. Ie I language was expressed
the human cavity for language, and of course all humans could learn
many languages. (34)

* Now this general tension, to understand that in the particular one
could also work backward to the general is typical of German
historicist Thought, and yet what I think Bumzl is not getting is that
1) the neo Kantians reversed this stream, actually trying to get to
the universal, as did Lazarus and Steinthal I think, but 2) that boas
was attracted to this but ultimately moved in another direction. (34)

* It was Steinthal and Lazarus that carried forward Humboldts
linguistics, while others ignored his work. (35)

* In Alexaander Humboldt identifies the idea -- unity in diversity -- that I trace as being a
key part of the neo-Kantian thing, the way geography was the key
science in this context. And it is against this view that I see Boas
pivoting... (38)

* Ritter was trying to establish a law of migrations... Boas must have
known this. (41)

* Ratzel... 41-43. Bunzl places him in the line of Ritter...

* Waitz and Bastian, counter-enlightenment!?!? I can sort of see that
but they retained a strong universalism. They were the liberal German
anthropologists!!

* Waitz notion of the psychic unity of mankind distinct from the French
universalism (46)

* Waitz moved closer to the relativism of Boas in his Anthropologie set
Nanaturvolker, though obviously maintaining the nature people culture
people distinction. (46)

* Hmmm. I don't see a huge commonality btw Humboldt and the
Volksgeister...Humboldt was more into the individual essence, whereas
Steinthal and Lazarus and in particular Bastian were interested
getting to the universal level. (49)

* I need to examine these claims a bit re Bastian's use of Humboldt a
bit...49-50

* Very interesting quote from Bastian in which he suggests a loss of
hope that ethnology can help solve the fragmentation of culture. Bunzl
says this foreshadows Boas... (50)

* Bastian nonetheless emphasized independent invention over diffusion,
thus conflicting with Ratzel. 51

* I don't think Bunzl's use of the term counter enlightenment works
here.  I also disagree with Zimmerman's use of anti humanism bit that
is better. I think Bastisn would have seen himself as an enlightenment
thinker... (52)

* Bunzl sees Boas Naffin-a land text as clearly marked by Ratzel's
geographical determinism. (53) Bunzl also calls it a "straightforward
anthropo-geographical investigation combining formal description of the
physical geography of the area with an analysis of the relation of its
inhabitants to their local surroundings..." (53)

* Yes but the missing context for this is neo-Kantianism it seems to
me... This uniting of the physical, the psychological and the
historical, this was neo-Kantian... (52)

* Now in Boas section, mention of philosophers -- but no mention of who
-- that influenced Boas to move away from Fechnerian psychophysics....
(52)

* How is this. Echoing Kant? Simply the notion of the division of
domains of knowledge!? This is not sufficient. (55)

* Boas granted equal value to those desires affective and aesthetic,
no! Not in my reading. (55) this may be a point where I want to assert
my contrast with Bunzl?

* Bunzl, like Stocking, sees Boas abandoning his geographical
determinism at the Ethnographic Museum. (55) here Bunzl says that Boas
had concluded from his Arctic studies that geographical causes were
not sufficient. He quotes Boas as saying that his Baffin island study
was a failure. And that there were other no external causes. (55) so
Boas shifts focus to the Northwest coast. Bunzl does not discuss Boas
the "Central Eskimo," which I think bears the imprint of the kind of
approach to culture I traced. (55)

* This is what shocks me, how the antisemetic context comes in merely
as an aside and nit an influence in his thought. Here Bunzl simply
cites it as a reason for his immigration as though this were
irrelevant to his thought. (56)

* I really don't see why this must be a Humboldtian gloss...I don't
recall Boas himself citing Humboldt and at the end of the nineteenth
century this principle could have come from any number of sources.
Boas cites Goethe in The a study of Geography. Bryond that he gives
his own gloss on the distinction that Windelband had set up. Again
,here the neo-Kantian context seems more proximate!! (57)

* Now the quote from the Museum debate that points most toward holism. (57)

* Now here Bunzl brings up the two fold dimension of Boas ethnographic
project: 1) the examination of geographical distribution, 2) the focus
on physical and psychical charachter.

* This is key and Lewis brings it up in a different way, more useful to
me, in his Boas and Darwinism paper. It is the oing into a ore
sophisticated examination of the individual in culture, that is where
I think Boas goes after WWI. (57, bottom)

* Apparently boas criticized the Natuervoelker idea in The aims of
Ethnology. (59)

* But is this really cultural relativism already? In my analysis I
think it is not. (59)

* Need to look at this essay, but no, it seems not THAT similar. He is
not positing a volksgeist in the same way, because he is also saying
that there is no original basis for the existence of certain myths
among any given people. (59)

* Interesting, that one of the responses to Boas theory from Powell was
that it would be too expensive and inefficient! (58)

* Bunzl speaks of an aesthetic turn, by which he means the way BoAs
turned back toward a universalist physicist direction (Bunzl's
categories not mine) in his Aims of ethology, albeit as Bunzl tries to
show  in the paragraphs that preceed in a relativistic frame. (59)

* Bunzl says that at first in "Aims of Ethnology", Boas tried to
accommodate" the evolutionist views, so that this essay sounds like
the physicist Boas. (58)

* I want to argue with Bunzl here perhaps in the foots: the point
being that Boas was actually straddling these two points of view. I
already get at this in my analysis of the Study of Geography,when I
talk about how boas subordinated both points to history, which of
course connects to the point that here Bumzl makes next, the critique
if the Naturvoelker idea. (58)

* Now Bunzl argues that Boas developed his link to Humboldtian
tendencies as Bunzl understands them in ethnographic works btw
1891-1896. Later on this page  he calls these tarte-distribution
studies. These are exactly the pieces out of which I would reconstruct
a distinct story. (60) Bunzl sort of appropriately relates boas method
to that of Ratzel, ie tracing the relations between peoples as created
by diffusion.mhe pushers back on this assertion noting the also that
Boas also allowed for indedent invention, but he fails to make
anything of Boas doing this,a s though it were just a minor difference
with Ratzel. And then he says that boas had at this point "returned to
the theoretical stance that he had taken in the museum controversy.
(60) but really? Just a return? There is too much of a I ray view on
this essay, between physics and human sciences that boS is just sento
tack back and forth across rather than  actually work with. (60)

* It is in "Limitations.." That Boas thinks all this
counter-enlightenment thought come together. (61) I am not impressed.
The elements are 1) skepticism regarding universal laws, 2) rejection
of the psychic unity of humankind, 3)focus on individuality of
phenomena, 4) emphasis on actual history. 1 I think is true enough,
but 2 is wrong in my view. What is universal has just changed. It is
the individuals oness to socialization. 3 and 4 are true enough but
not very theoretically significant. (61)

* Boas Bunzl says only presented his view of theory to the public after
gaining a positional the A!NH in 1895, in his 1896 "Limitations...
Essay. boas presented the paper at the meeting of the AAA, where the
year before Brinton had given a paper, called the "Aims of
Anthropolgy" where he insistedon the doctrine of indedent
invention. (60)

* Bunzl says Boas Alternate method was this investigation of customs in
relation to the total culture of the tribe, and this is another of
this key holistic phrases. I need to deal with this probably. Was this
really the pointBoas was making in Limitations? (62)

* Boas never mentioned Humboldt except in one essay on Mexico, but
Bunzl still thinks he was "intimately familiar" with Humboldt. (63)
rperhaps because he met Steinthal personally at the museum and
Steinthal may have directed hi directed hi to his own edition of
Humbldts writings on language. (63)

* Then Bunzlends the section by making tenuous connections to Alexander
Humboldt, iesuggesting a "cosmographical mapping" (62)

* Right so now Bunzl just sees the Humboldtian approach to language as
systems with their own inner structure etc become central... This is
just the holistic point of view, this is just echoing Stocking's point
on the alternating sounds essay that Bunzl also discusses here, that
this is really Boas clearest statement about holism and relativism, ie
holistic culture. (64-65)

* Bunzl says Boas Handbook is a realization of Humboldts plan for the
study of languages... (66)

* Bunzl's take on how the handbook related to Boas' thinking about
culture, which he s was not systematic, but the Handbook and the
focus on language evidently helped boas to understand the
psychological problem of how diffused elements were acculturated, that
he had noticed as a problem I his trait distribution studies. (69)
indeed this makes sense, but my point would be that the this focus did
not really take odd until WWI. Not that it wasn't there, which it was
even earlier, but it did not become dominant in the discipline. (69)

* Secondary rationalization (71)

* The idea is that language provided an "un obstructed" point of view
into the workings of culture...the culture indicated here is the
holistic culture concept. Bunzl is just maintaining the party line...
(71)

* No I think it shouldn't be traced to Humboldt or to Herder. That is
what I am arguing against. He had his own non Humboldtian historicist
gloss" on this stuff. So this is perhaps what I need to make more
clear in my revision. (72-73)

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text:
p. 498 -   Boas's Textual Ideology

-- Why was Boas so focused on text- collection?  The authors link this to Boas' connection to a "European philological tradition" rooted in Herder and which came to Boas perhas through Heymann Steinthal, who had been a pupil of Alexander von Humboldt.    for citations f.n. 68.

--The authors, esp. f.n. 68 note that a philological tradition was long established in the American tradition.  

-- They quote Boas as seeing anthropology as needing to develop the same knowledge in language as those who studied ancient history could boast.  He saw philology as the key.  So texts taken down in Native language were the most valuable form of text.  (499-500) 

-- Authors note that Stocking saw Boas' approach to "primtiive literarture" as expressing a Herderian perspective of the literature as revealing a people's "...'whole ocncpet of the world,' its 'individuality'--one might almost say, its 'genius.'" (500, quoted from Stocking Race, Culture...p. 224.)  They also site another article of theirs on Herder entitled "Langauge Philosophy as Language Ideology: John Locke and Johnaa Gottfried Herder" in Regimes of Language,)

-- The authors note Boas's focus also on primitive literature as art also...That is art as plastic form (material culture) as well as something which carries meaning.  This dualism of art was helpful to him they say in managing the tensions between the universal and the particular (500-501)

-- REgards the content of primitive literature...Boas developed confidence over his career that such texts could provide a phenomenological account of how a given tribe saw things of which things interested them.  (501-502)

-- They note that Boas also understood that art/stories could "shape experience"...they acted as symbols.  (502)

-- The focus on texts, also functioned as an "indirect" way into the history of the native groups, for whom no other form of information was available... (502)

title: The Victorian Connection
text:
00 Summary 00

Hall traces a connection between U.S. and British elite intellectuals whose views are influenced by a conjunction of Unitarianism and Liberalism.  Their interest in democracy is rooted not only in nonconformity but also a sense of  need for an elite who posessess intellectual authority and guides the masses.  He traces this connection very well, both in terms of specifying the personal contacts that formed the "Victorian connection" and in terms of establishing its basic political point of view

title: Getting Spliced: Modernism and Sexual Difference
text: p.103-106 Pound and Gender Pound's idea "about relatoins bewteen the sexes can only be described as increasingly phallic in emphasis." (103) He wrote to M. Moore in 1919 a letter that open with a poem in place of a saluation: "...it began: 'The female is a chaos/the male/is a fixed point of stupidity.'" (103) In his preface to a translaoitn of Gourmon't Physique de l'amour his thinking becomes clearer for he worte "...'it is more than likely that the brain itself, is...only a sort of great clot of gential fluid held in suspense or reserve,' he posits that the act of thought occurs with 'man really the phallus or spermaozoide charging, head-on, the female chaos.'...'Even oneself has felt it, driving any new idea into the great passive vulva of London.'" (103-4) The female chaos then is " a sort of negation" a passivity. (104) More interesting, though, is the idea that Pound's conception of masculinity was actually threatened, the old feeling of the male being overwhelmed and Burke (like Banner about the anthropologist men) connects this to ways in which an expat intellectual in London was seen in Ford Madox Ford's words as "something less than a man" (quoted on 104). (104-105) And Burke sees heightened moment of this in meeting btw Pound and the sculptor Henri Gaudier-Brzeska in 1914 when Pount explained that the suffragist movmenet was ridiculous because: "Why do [women] trouble themselves about these matters--why worry about their battle for emancipation--since they're strong enough to dominate us." (quoted on 105) and then he described how he admired the Roman matron Marozia who became powerful in Rome by marrying important men. (105) Then Gaudier-Brzeska dcied to sculpt a bust of Pound that would illustrate his ideas and Hugh Kenner sa this as a "crucial and heroic momen in the development of Pound's aeshtetic." (105) Burke writes that you can also see it as "emblematic Pound's increasing anxiety about the connections between artistic genius and sexual difference." (105) And she notes that Gaudier-Brzeska "approached the monumental three-foot marble block that Pound gave him as if it were a megalith from the Easter Islands, endowed with primitive sexual energy. His 'Hieractic Head of Ezra Pound,' or 'Ezra in the form of a marble phallus' (Wyndham Lewis' words), takes literally the idea of 'Pound as the seminal figure of modern poetry,' as well as his theory of the link between mascuinity and creative genius." (105) It also foreshadows his post-Vortacist call for "a modern poetic language that would be 'harder and saner...'nearer the bone'...as much like granite as it can be, 'a masculine language free from the 'emotional slither' of nineteenth-century poetry.'" (105) But she points out that the opp. btw male and female forms of writing was already part of his Vortacism and she talks about a man as 1) a perceiving entity and 2) a directing entity, whereas he wants to be more the latter...again she connects this to his anxiety about mascuinity (105-6) So what of his celebration of Moore and Loy. He celebrated them for the wrong reasons, acc. to his own program and not considering the intent of their own poetry. (104) So therefore Pound "cannot recognize the ways in which their awareness of themselves as women writers produced poetry that is at once part of the overall modernist project, yet distinct from it..." (106)

title: Bürger und Bürgerlichkeit im 19. Jahrhundert
text:
General Note March, 2013

Jürgen Kocka, "Einletiung"

* The book emerged from an interdiscplianry symposium at the Zentrum fuer interdisziplinaere Forchung (ZiF) in Bielefeld 12-14 March 1985. It brought together hitorians, literary, social, and art historians.(7)

* He traces some of the different meanings/uses of the term in the different disciplines on 7-8. He question though for the ZiF symposium was whether the term could function as a interdisciplinary key concept (Schlüsselbegriff) for research on the 19th century. (9) In other words, could the concept make it possible for the different scientists to treat their different objects of study in ways that allowed for asking questions that linked up with each other. (9-10)

* He then says that in addition to the interdisciplinary question, the question of Bürgerlichkeit was also important for the big question of german history, the Sonderweg thesis. He summarizes this thesis very nicely on 11. And then raises the critique

> Diese Sonderweg-These hat sich nie allgemein durchgesetzt, kaum jemand vertrat sie zur Gänze, und die Kritik an ihr nahm in den letzten Jahren zu. Man wandte gegen sie ein, sie idealiere "den Westen", unterschätze die riesigen Unterschiede zwischen den westeuropäischen Staaten und interpretiere die deutsche Geschichte zu selektiv, zu negative-teleologisch. (11)

He goes on from here and what seems key is the idea also that the nineteenth century was not only the for-history of national socailism but also of the DDR and of the Bundesrepublik, and that there are llines of continuity with these developments as well. The concecept of Bürgerlichkeit comes in because as part of questioning this thesis, one also wants to ask how different was German from France or the US. Was it really true that Germany lacked a true Bürgerlichkeit? (11-12) In order to answer this question it was necessarz to explore the requirements of comparison, and in order to do that one had to define Bürgerlichkeit ina  gernal sense in order to then make a comparison, or perhaps also discover that there were multiple variants of Bürgerlichkeit. (12-13)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.091-95  New Psych and Experimental Perspective

Between 1900 and 1910, Columbia was an "important center for the growing attack on armchair, evolutionary thinking, as a new generation of psychologists completed their doctorates and began ooking with jaundiced eye at the current understanding of the human and anmial minds." (91)  Men like Edward Thorndike, Robert Woodworth, and Clark Wissler, who were "less encumbered with the religious and philosophical baggage of the past than their mentors" were part of this.  (91)  And Rosenberg argues "[f]or all of thei rprejudices against women, they slowly put together the skeptical elements of a psychological system that could accomodate a very different view of feminine behavior from the one their own biases allowed." (91)  In doing this, they moved against men like Lester Frank War and G. Stanley Hall, "who indulged in romanti specualtions about the origins of human societ and intelligence." (91)

Thorndiek cast doubt on "animal instinct" and he ocnlucded that neitheranimals nor humans could rely as "heavily on either instinct or ratiocination as most social theorists assumed." (92)

Clark Wissler in a 1901 doctoral thesis failed to find a correlation between lower mental activity and intelligence.  Then in further work he contiually failed to find a connection between morophology and ideas and this meant that Cattell's "initila faith in the possiblity of constructing tests of intelligence basedo on simple motor tests would have to be abandoned." (92) By 1909, Thorndie state d that "sensory discrimination had little to do with general intelligence" (92, a quote is on 92-93).

Further erosion of the evolutionary point of view, came with an attack on the Spencerian assumptiont hat "mind and body formed a closed-energy system" and that when demands on energy increased and became too much the mind also would weaken and nervous disease ensue.  [neurasthenia?]  Robert Woodworthy reversed this in 1906 based on experiements that showed that the the brain did not nescessarily weaken and that mental exhaustion was in part an "emotional affair, a feeling of fatigue not a true fatige in the sense of incapacity." (93)

In 1906, a debate between the old and new guard emerged sponsored by the New York Independent.  Lester War and G. STanley Hall on one siide and the youn Columbia cytoloigst Edmund Wilson and Wissler on the other.  Wilson attacked Ward's "anthroporphic description f the origins of sexual differentiaition, in which eh assumed that lowly organisms discriminated among seual contenders in the same way that human beings do" (94).  Wissler challengedthe "imposition of physiological laws onto human intelligence. "It is curious...that it has always seemed necessary to carry the theory of evolution up through morphology into the psychic life of animals and men and finally into those human practices that are designated conventional. While there is doubtless some connection between the fundamental elements of psychic life and physiological function, the direct connection between the details of ideas and such function is not clear." (94)

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.027-31  Hull House, Reform and Progressive Era

Muncy argues that women were among the first professionals to turn to the state as a means to solving a social problem.
