" Becaue their professional situtions thus predisposed them to see governmental intervention as the solution to social problems, women at Hull House counte d among America'sfirst progressives." (27) 

So Muncy thinks these women have a special meaning for Progressivism.  Progressivism characterized perhaps by emphasis on "efficiency" and on the invovlmentof the state in private life. These factors distinguisedh "Gilded Age agitators" from Progressives.  

Giventhis def'n women "loomed large in progressive reform."  (30) But women did not set out to be reformers.  They were rather :"women trying to fulfill existing social expectations for self-sacrificing female service while at the same time satisying their need for public recognition, authority, and independence." (30)  Women were thus  "one of the causes of Progressive reform..."  (30)

She turns to Florence Kelley and speaks of how she pioneered social research as a means to lobbying government to change law (prohibit child labor), but after when Kelley worked as a factory inspector she was removed and her law gutted.  Wtihout the vote the only way to gain infuence was by "replacing the patronage system with hiring based on expertise..." (31)  

34-37: shedescribes how women reachedout to form a national network of reformers in progressive era.

title: The Victorian Connection
text:
p. 91 -   Doubts and Method sfor Acheiving their Goals

Theoretically the publishing revolution of the 1830s and 1840s was supposed to aid them.  Low price of books and magazines.  But they didn't the marketplace created the conditions for the ind of education of public opinion that they desired.  (91)  Wroried for isntance about the contents of the New York ledger.. (91)  This was the basis for the founding of periodicals like Putnam's (1853), the Atlantic Monthly (1857); the Nation (1865); the Galaxy (1866) and in England the Saturday Review (1855) and the Fortnightly Review (1865).  (92)

They also sought to use the university.  "Apart from establishing journla which were undre their own controo, they also proposed to refashion the university into an instrument for training the right sort of leaders." (93) (93-94)

Hall concludes by suggesting that they succeeded saying that they "transformed the structure of cultural authority." (94)

title: The Effect of Bureaucracy on the Professional Autonomy of Professions
text:
00 Summary Note 00 

This is an empirical study of the effective of bureaucracy on autonomy.  It's basic
claim, based on responses to a series of questionaires given to physicians in a variety of bureucratic circumstnaces, is that large, medium and small bureaucratic organizations effect different aspects of physisians' sense of auotnomy in different and unpredictable ways.  I am not interested in the articles' particular findings, but it has a series of definitions and insights that are of interest to me. 

Most writers on the professions -- the author cites Weber , Mills, and Robert Merton -- have indicated the belief that bureaucracies undermine the professional autonomy that is necessary for professionals to do their work successfully (30).  Engles points out however that in the case of doctors modern medicine is often seen as relying upon bureaucracies: "Today, quality service involves specialization, the employment of large and expensive equipment, and coordination of the activities of groups of specialists.  Since these are characteristics which we have defined as bureaucratic, and since they are now important for the rendering of quality medical care, it is apparent that developments in medical practice have imposed bureaucratic requirements on the profession, and tha tthe two strutures have become more compatible."  (33)

title: The Victorian Connection
text:
p. 84-85 Victorian Connection...described in detail

Emerson went to England where he was mocked except by merchant-manufacturers and scholar thinkers.  Here the connetion began.  Emerson connects with Arthur Hugh Clough then a tutor at Oxford.  Clough wasunable to "reconcile hi radical views on religionand politics with an academic position.  1852 he comes to Boston where he establishes himself a a member of the literary community.  Clough helps popularize Matthew Arnold.  (85)  Clough, Hall says, was alluring "as a representative man, for the crisis of faith he felt so intensely was felt also by the intellectuals of Concord-Cambridge-Boston."  (86)  Hall describes that they had a desire to "learn a middle way between doubt and affirmation." (86)

title: Citizens as Consumers: Considerations on the New Politics of Consumption
text:
General Notes 5/2013:

* Streeck’s argument is as follows: There’s been a shift in the way in the “modes of provisioning” after the breakdown of Fordism. Fordism involved what he calls a “provisioning economy” in which people needed to make careful choices in acquiring products that they’d never before had -- cars, refrigerators, etc. What happens later Streek calls a profound restructuring of production and provisioning. Key quote on p. 31 starting with “By the 1980s... “  

* The point is that production is now wedded to a market in which customers are encouraged to refine their tasts -- and shed the old compromises that they needed to make between their individual desries and stardardized products, i.e. the Ford dictum that you cna have a model T in any color you want as long as its black -- and instead to pay “more attentio to their individual wants, on top of the ocmmon needs served by standardized products.” (31) Streeck calls this elsewhere the “customization of commoodities.” (32)

 

* He then ties it to a marketing procesS that develops needs and proposes wants and in so doing “co-opts consumers as co-designers” in an effort to “haul jmore of their as-yet commercially idle wants, or potential wants, into market relations.” (32) These marketing procesess he says are key parts of the process that Rosa Luxemburg called Landnahme in her The Accumulation of Capital, meaning “the secular invasion of social life by ‘market forces’ under capitalism...” (32)

 

* But also this new move to pay more attention t the customer, he notes, suggstred itself as a “way out of stagnation when markets had become saturated and, it seemed to some, when material incentives among the working classes to exert thesmelves for economic growth appeardon the brinkg of being critically weakend.” (32-33)

 

* All this, Steeck says added up to a new kind of “sociation” , this is Simmel’s concept Vergesellschaftung -- i.e. a “way for individuals to link up to others and thereby define their place in the world.” (35) Sociation by consumer choice appeared to be voluntary, “resulting in social bonds and identities that are less restrictive--indeed, entirely free from obligations, apart from what Marx and Engels called bare Zahlung, or naked cash.” (35) Consumers did not need to make any compromise; they could choose from an endless array of specialized options. “In fact the only other actors that one encounter operating in a social structure of advanced consumption are firms whose marketing departments specialize in guessing your every want and striving to satisfy them.” (35) Steeck says then that sociation by consumption “monological rather than dialogical in nature, volutnary rather than obligatory, individual rather than collective.” (35)

 

* The crucial step in his article though is to say that this shift has its analogy in politics. He introduces this first on 36. “In politics, the hope is to deploy the new technology to compensate for the increasing atrophy of traditional party organizations...the time is coming when Angela Merkel will instantly inform her ‘followers’ how much she enjoyed the opera performance she just attended.” (36) He then illustrates the basis in a new transformation or “marketization” of the publis sphere, see SEction III. My question here was -- was the public sphere operating before the 1970s???

 

* As a result of this shift, the relationship between citizens and states has changed say Streeck. “Inevitably the material base for the legitimacy of states as states began to shrink. The decline of poltiical legitimacy did not , however, stop in the area of service provision [i.e. the government thinking of itself as offering services to citizen-consumers, i.e. the Arbeitsamt becomes the Arbeitsagentur]. Gradually it extended into the very core of citizenship, where the traditional relationship between citizens and the state became increasingly subject to unfavourable comparison with the relationship between customers and producers in the refurbished post-Fordist markets for consumer goods. To be more explicit: I would argue that the restructuring of consumption aimed at restoring the dynamics of capitalist accumulation after the crisis of the 1970s made possible -- indeed, invited and cultivated -- attitudes and expectations on the part of customers-cum-citizens that inexorably began to radiate into what remained fo the public sphere.” (39)

 

* Here Streeck wants to take a stand. He thinks that there’s a contradiction in the idea of citzens as consumers. “...citizenship is by its very essence less comfortable than cusomership, and if measured by the same criteria must inevtiably lose out.” (41) What does he mean? It’s the way in which the new consumer never needs to compromise that is incompatible with the essence of citiznenship. The citizen “must subject their cpsecific collectively unexamined ‘raw’ wants to critical scrutiny in some sort of public dialogue”; and later: “Political participation in a democracy demands, in particular, a preparedness to justify and recalibrate one’s choices in the light of general principles, developing preferences not in the sne of diversifying, but rather of aggregating and unifyign them.” (41) Because he sees this as the essence of citizenship he argues that “citizenship is bound to look structurally similar to customership inthe mass markets of old...” (41)

 

* Here I noticed that what Streeck is doing is bringing in a certain kind of republicanism. And on 42 he even says: “Political communities are republics...” (42)  I don’t like this line so much, or at least it seems that it will break up on the rocks of the Nietzschean ethical particualrism critique. More interesting was a sentence that comes later about how “[p]olitics is centrally about the creation and regulation of social order, [such that] its reults cannot be decomposed into different individual products catering to individual tasetes...” (42)

 

* Also interseting was his figuration of this “new market mode” as sometihing that “leaches laterally into the public sphere...” (43), with the result that the old “politics as politics” is modified... (42-43)


* One effect of politics as consumpiton, si that it serves the middle-classes particularly well, sincethey have the resources to satisfy their needs, thus they become less interested in politics. (43)

* The strongest most useful part of Streeck's argument is where he notes that as a result of this shift to a politics of consumption people have lost the resources or "civic skills" as he puts it (using his republican freaming) to think in ways that would make it possible for them to participate in party politics: "After a certain amount of time, it may no longer be possible to stop the rot [note again corruption wording]: expectations of what politics can do may have eroded so far, and the civic skills and organizatinoal structures needed to develop effective public demand may have atrophied byond redemption, while the political personnel themselves may have adapted so entirely to specializing in the management of appearances rather than the representation of some version, however biased, of the public interest." (46)

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
p. 068-72  Frances Densmore

Focused on music.  Her work not so appealing to anthropologists because of its technical focus on music itself.

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text: p.009-010 Overlap between professional scholars and patricians They mixed socially, sartorially, and hheld similar social ideals: "Both groups conceived of themselves as guides for a democratic society that overestimated material success and undervalued 'the higher ideals of life.' Both felt a common mission to civilize the masses on the one hand and subdue the upstart nouveaux riches on the other. Both echoed the Nation and the Atlantic in calling for 'an educated class amongst us, to be the guardians of the traditions and feelings and aspirations of high culture, and the diffuser of an atmosphere of thought and study--a kind of barrier, too, agianst the gross materialism of the time, the growing tendency to estimate the value of everything in dollars and cents, and to despise or shirk all discipline of mind or body which does not promise a speedy return in hard cash.' This class would constitute, said William T. Harris, U.S. Commissioner of Education, an 'aristocracy of culture,' disputing alike the claims of mere wealth and the prerogatives of birth.'" (10)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.148 -155   Parsons...

Background parents opposed to working woman.  Went to Barnard.  AT time she began Barnard (founded in 1889) was integrating more clsoely with Columbia due President of Columbia Seth Low. (148-149).   Giddings came to Columbia from Bryn Mawr as part of creation of two new chairs in history an dosociology that came a in exchange with Dean John Burgess for devoting teaching horus to teaching Barnard students. (149)   Giddings had begun with Spencer but also like Ward had recated against that point of view, thinking that humans had reached a point of social development in which they could correct things through reform and control.  (150).  Women attracted to his courses because he taught about philanthropy  and understood sociology as the "scientific groundwork on which a true philanthropy must build." (quoted on 151).  He also attracted them, as had WArd, Small, Dewey and Mead, because of the approach which tried to cut a line between idealism and positivism, and these ideas were appealing to women trying to understand the meaning of sexual division. (151) 

Gidding had an idea of "self-realization" the greater facility of which among humans would result from progress which he defined in terms of a growing unity, of "increasing intercourse, a multiplication of relationships, an advance in material well-being, a growth of population, an evolution of rational conduct." (quoted on 151).  

Self-realization appealed to Parsons, Rosenberg says, because it was seen as a "weapon against the constraints that middle-class Victorian society imposed on female achievement." (152) Even though Giddings was not a supporter of women's movement. (152) 

Parsons went to graduate school, first worked wit h Nicholas Murray butler in philosophy, writing on colonial management in her first book.  Then with Giddings on poor relief. .  (154)  She did not see family life as a hindrance to her work.  (153-4).  Married and then went back to work as a teacher at Barnard until 1905, when her husband's political career began.  

Sociological work was within the reform strategy as a young woman.  Believed that problems of poor required regulation and management.  She believed in porgress and advancement of her own society (155).

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text:
p.010-11  1870s and 80s German Exchange and Histoirans' Notions of Serving State

Historians he says saw their "scholarly activity as an essential component of the whole movement for consolidating American culture." (11)  Their sense of the professional and specialized nature of their work he says the got from Germany and this helped separate them from amateurs, but they also "foundin Germany an example of a professoriat active in civic enterprise." (11) And: "The German idea of the professor as the conscience of the state corresponded roughly to the American ideal of an aristocracy of culture." (11)   Thus John Burgess, German-trained historian who inaugurated graduate work at Colmba in history and polisci, "hoped to prodduce statesmen and public officials as well as scholars.  The first American guidebook to historical scholarship, Charles Kendall Adams' pioneering <i>Manual of Historical Literature (1882), contianed a long digression on current national problems that would require historically informed leaders.  Early meetins of the American Historial Association reverberated with pleas to historians to serve society, raise th elevel of political debate, and restore integrity in political life." (11)

title: Transcending a Patriarchal Past: Teaching the History of Women in Sociology
text:
Random Note 1: Women in the Sociology Profession

Deegan argues that women's work reflected the "sexual division of labor" as in all other academic disciplines.  Women's work in sociology "stressed an applied compassionate world view.  Women labored in the community, often in settlement houses in the poorer districts of cities.  The more 'cerebral' work of theory development occured in the academy and 'belonged' to the realm of men.  Prior to World War I, this sexual division of labor was cooperative and permeable.  After 1918, these worlds became distinct, often hostile, and sharply segregated." (143)  She says the "golden age" of women's particpation ended after 1918, when "a massive, male-orchestrated erosion of their thought and practice ensued.  Structurally, the female sociologists were pushed out of sociology and transferred en masse to other fields, often social work.  They were no longer identified as professional sociologists, male-identified historians of the discipline erased their contributions from the annals of sociology." (144)

title: The Decline of the German Mandarins:  The German Academic Community, 1890-1933
text:
p.086-090 Opposition btw Kultur & Civilization

So Ringer clearly posits the idea that the German mandarins (as part of their "unique" reaction to modernity) developed this opposition between civilization and "Kultur."  He lays out this argument in these pages.

His argument goes like this: The German mandarins were focused on presreving moral implications of Christianity.  They furhter opposed the utilitirian components of Anglo-French Enlightenment, which the yhad to fight in their own land at the University of Halle where there had been a search for useful knowledge. (86)

They utlimately expressed their "ideal of leanring as the direct antithesis of practical knowledge" in the notion sof Bildung and Kultur.  These terms, Ringer says, "became current in Germany during the cultural revival of the later eighteenth century." (86) Ringer also argues that these words were part of a "semantic conquest" that "established the leadership of the mandarins...the newly introduced vocabularly revealed the full extent of the elite's claim to special authority." (86)

Bildung

The meaning of Bildung revealed in Der grosse Brockhaus, a standard eencyclopedia published between 1928 and 1935.  It defined the word this way: "The fundamental concept of pedagogy since Pestalozzi, Bildung means forming the soul by means of the cultural environment.  Bildung requires: (a) an individuality whcih, as the nique starting point, is to be developed into a formed or value-saturated perosnality; (b) a certain universality, meaning richness of mind and person, which is attained thorught he empathetic undeerstanding and experiencing [Verstehen und Erleben] of the objective cultural values; (c) totality, meaning inner unity and firmness of character." (Quoted on 86)  This was about self-formation in other words and to that end Karl Jaspers in 1923 distinguished between instruction (Unterricht) and education (Erziehung) noting that only the latter was capable of "forming the personality in accordance with an ideal of Bildung, with ethical norms..." (quoted on 87)

Ringer tries to cahracterize the concept: it is about "inner growth" based in religious and neohumanist conceptions; it is based on an "experience" of "objective" cultural values.  The terminology he says is "Idalist or neo-Idealist." (87)

Kultur

This word came from Cicero's cultura animi and was adapted by Samuel Pufendorf and Gottfried von Herder.  It was closely tied to Bildung, represneteing at first a "personal culture," an ideal of well-formed mind and spirit, a unity.  Then it began to be used more generally in Germany, but the same trasnsition did not occur in France,where culture remained on the personal level: culture de l'esprit.  Instead in France civilisation which had been introduced by physiocrat Marqui de Mirabeau came to "stand for the totality of  man's social and intellectual creaitons and arrgangements." (88)  ONce these two distinct usages developed, Ringer says "a fascinating chain of assocaiitons led German intellectuals to see an antithesis between the two concepts." (88)  He says that in 18th century Germany the "worldly manners" of German aristocrats were modeled on the French.  He implies that it was a total and complete importation and that the German mandarins saw it that way: "[The German mandarin] did not often encounter well-educated courtiers, and when he did, he generally found men who could imitate French forms without being able to think for themselves." (88)  Ringer insists that on this basis a "pattern of assocaitaitons...grew up around the contrast between sophisticated social forms, skilled manners,   and worldly knowledge on theone hand, and genuine spirituality or cultivated wisdom on the other."  He says that Norbert Elias described these and refers to his Uber den Prozess der zivilisation, vol 1: Wandlungen des Verhaltens in den weltlichen Obsersichten des Abendlandes (1939), pp. 1-64.  He notes that Kant had distinguished between civilization and culture identifying civ. with good manners and oscial niceities and culture with art, learning and morality, but Kant had not develpeop the line tha tblamed the French.  (88)Elias he says was interestedin this latter development.  He summarizes it this way: "The French continued to identify with an internationally conceived mission of civilization.  The Germans, finding it difficult and yet desirable to define themselves as a nation, tended to see uniquely German characteristics in their prerference of culture over civilization." (89)  Ringer further suggests that this distinction did not fade because it "continued to be nourished by a social reality," (89) i.e. the way it "reflected the mandarins' interested preference for  a paritcular ocnception ofknowedge." (89)

title: Steppin' Out: New York Nightlife and the Transformation of American Culture, 1890-1930
text:
Chapter 1: Victorian Culture and Amusements

* Americans in the second half of the nineteenth century "underwent a process of consolidation and refinement" which came from a "desire for greater rational order..." (5) Erenberg links this to studies by Higham, Danield Walker Howe, Wiebe that link a emphasis on "formalism" and "gentility" to industrialism, urbanization, mass immigration.  SEe f.n. #1 where he discusses these texts.  Note his explanation of HIgham's thesis in particular from From Boudnlessness to Consllidation...that the above three factors provoked a "need to impose social control on rampnant individualism in the urban context." (25)

* They did this in part to distinguish themselves from "the lower orderrs by their refined moral standards, hard work, and elevated leisure pursuits." This meant that they set up sets of standards about what types of amusements were ok and which were too "fast".  Much of these restrictions rested upon women, whereas men had a "greater run of public life."  (5)

* Erenberg uses memoirs of Henry Seidel Canby who was the editro of the Saturday REview from 1924 to 1936 as a window in to this Protestant America.  He grew up in Wilmington, DE.  Important values were "faith, hard work, self-sufficiency, and a belief in moral progress grounded in the refined woman and the autonomous family." (6)  These values understood to be unique posession of protestant whites and not of Irish and blacks: the workers.  "Business success" of particualr important virtue.  The young male learned in the family and the schoolroom "that his path to succses lay in his 'pioneer's training in self dependence, his sense o froom at the top, and his certainty that work can get him there.' For Protestants, the economy represented a moral frontier, where individuals who practiced self-discipline and willpower whiile husbanding their scarce energy would be rewarded by mobility and ordered progress." (7)

* Women played a "separate role in the private world of the home."  In the home, Erenberg writes, mothers taugh their chilren the sense of duty and "ought".  (7)  But though women's power increased in the home, they rarely entered the "public world of men" Erenberrg writes, except he say quote CAnby in an "attempt to make that world Our American home." (7) [This latter move shoudl perhaps n ot be discounted as much as Erenberg seems to.]

* While women were meant to teach duty, the danger was that they might arouse passion.  Thus "wives and daughters were expected to conform to the 'kind of sexual relationship that made the least trouble.  Women had to be what men were not--refined, controlled, nurturing, self-effacing, and stable--so as to provide the one noncompetetive and nurturing environment in the anarchic and hostile owrld of nineteenth-century economic competition." (7)  [i.e. this idea that women should provide an "elysium" for men]. (7)  This placed a kind of double standard on women wehre they were supposed to be pure and "above the demands of the body and above the sexual status of men." (7)  Thsu romance and sexuality were distinct things for Victorians.  As CAnby put it, woman "carried with her the sanctions and refusals of society." (8)  They were meant to be the source of order, stabilizing men's identities.

* Key event in Wilmington was the annual ball.  These were women's debuts in public, but also reflected the concerns of "female morality, class status, and privacy."  (8)  E quotes CAnby: "A girl at a ball was still a woman on show, a custodian of honor and the home." (8)  And: "Wiles were allowed her, but only to advertise her charms.  She could flirt and be gay and tease and be teased, but one hint of the sexual made her 'common,' which was only owe word above vulgar." (8)

* In NY City things different: more money, people from all regions, people making fortunes in mercantile and banking pursuits and those who had succeeded in industrial enterprises.  The elite was free from interactions with the lower classes that were a more present "other" in Wilmington.  But here to the same concerns wtih "decorum, social distinction, and self-control that CAnby found in Wilmington..." (9)

* Account of Delmonico's, which began in 1848 and became more fancy as time went on.  Under direction of Lorenzo Delmonico it became a "civilized and orderly culinary institution."  He trained his waters in deferential service.  His menus were sophisticated.  Delmonico's moved up Broadway and then Fifth Ave over time.  By 1860, it was at 5th Ave. and 14th STreet.  Delmonico had then added a great French che, Charles Ranhoffer and he was there from 1863to 1895.  He is mannerisms of the postwar Europeans "acted as leaven for rough democratic habits."  And this sign of European cultivation instead of becoming a sign of distinction "was rapidly becoming the basis forr the identies of fashionable urbanites." (10)  Delmonico's became a sociqal institution and a "premier place for fashionable dining." (10)  The empahsis was not on abundance as it had been in 1842 when Charles Dickens first dined there, but on "a greater delight in 'economy, order, balance, and smooth progression of courses.'" (10)  It was a center of "national , polical, social and business life." (10)  And it was a symbol to its patrons of "order, progress, and stability.  Aristocracy and democracy could reside together in ultimate harmony." (10-11)

* One of the things that set Delmonico's apart was that by 1860 it allowed women, making them comfortable "because no unescorted women were permitted." (11)  Erenberg notes that the "dining room thus became a respectable place for even the most refined, an orderly extension of the proper private dining room."  (11)  But Delmonico's also had a "men's cafe" where the double standard of Victorian morality was maintained and where men "took their drinks, cigars, and heratier sociability, all removed from the more elvated and formal public world inhabited by respectable women." (11)

title: Editor's Introduction
text:
Notes trying to get understanding of Kant's Aesthetics

* Kant had no plan for a series of three critiques (ie Critique of Pure Reason, Critique of Practical Reason, and the Critique of the Power of Judgement) at firs.  Kant had originally thought that the Critique of Pure Reason alone would be sufficient to "erect a system of theoretical and practical philosophy, or as he called them the metaphysics of nature and the metaphysics of morals..." (xiii)  Guyer notes that he did provide the first in the Metaphysical Foundations of Natural Science and the second eventually in the 1797 Metaphysics of Morals--the second after a "delay" while he wrote the Critique of the Power of Judgement and by the 1793 religion within the Boundaries of Mere Reason and the 1795 Toward Perpetual Peace.  (xiii) 

* Guyer quotes a letter to Karl Leonhard Reinhold, who was helping to popularize Kan'ts writings.  The letter came after Kant's completion of the Critique of Practical Reason. The letter suggests that he'd realized that it was necessary to create three critiques, one for each of the three faculties of the mind: cognition, feeling, and desire.  (xiii-xiv)  Kant associates the faculty of feeling with taste/aesthetics.  Cognition with pure reason and desire with practical reason or morals.

* Guyer wants to review Kan'ts earlier thinking about aesthetics and theology.  In his first series of publications 1755-56 he was mostly concerned with science and metaphsyics and did not write on aesthetics or teleology.  But in texts written between 1762 and 1766, he did.  In an essay on The only Possible Basis for a Proof of the Existence of God in which he critiqued Descartes' "ontological" argument, he "touched on teleology".  In Observations on the Feeling of the Beautiful and Sublime (1764), which was influenced by Burke's 1757,  A Philosophical Enquiry into the Original of Our Ideas of the Sublime and the Beautiful, he examines the "differences int he capacities ofr these feelings [of eauty] between the two sexes and among diverse cultures and nations." (xv) 

* In disscussion of his lectures for the winter semester of 1765-66 on metaphysics, logic, ethics, and physical geography..., he also expalined why he would discuss aesthetics:

I shall be lecturing on logic of the first type [a crituqe and canon of sound understanding].  To be more specific, I shall base my lectures on Meier's hand-book, for he...stimulates us to an understanding, not only of the cultivation of reason in its more refined and learned form, but also of the development of the ordinary understanding, which is nonetheless active and sound.  The former serves the life of contemplation, while the latter serves the life of action and society.  And in this, the very close relationship of the materials under examination leads us at the same time, in the critique of reason, to pay some attention to the critique of taste, that is to say, aesthetics.  The rules of the one at all times serve to elucidate the rules of the other.  Defining the limits of the two is a means to a better undersanding of them both." (xvi) \

So Kant saw aesthetics as a way to stimulate a cultivation of reason on and "ordinary" level of understanding related to every day life and society.  Interesting!!

*  Guyer says Kant includes more discussion of aesthetics re his lectures on "anthropology" in winter semester 1772-1773.  These lectures went about the "proper and aberrant functioning of human cognition, feeling, and ddesire, with an emphasis on both individual and cultural differences in the function and use of these faculties." (xvi)  Guyer concludes that as early as 1772-1773 then Kant had already formed his notion of the tripartite divison of the human mind (cognition, feeling, desire), and also the association of taste and feeling.  Guyer thus argues that the "central thought" of the Critique of the Power of Judgement was already established in Kant's mind.  That ideas was...

that in a judgement of taste a person can claim intersubjective validity for the feeling of pleasure that she experiences in response to a beautiful object because the pleasure is produced, in an attitude of disinterested contemplation, not by a practical concern for utility or advantage in the possession of the object, but by the free and harmonious play of the cognitive faculties of imagination and understanding that the beautiful object induces, and taht seh can rightly claim such validity for her feeling because we all share these cognitive faculties and they must work pretty much the same way in all of us..." (xvii)

* That he had formed this understanding though is distinct from any plan to write a critique of taste.  He originally thought only to write one critie, the Critique of Pure Reason and that he then could provide a systematic metaphsics of nature and morality, and perhaps Guyer guess, also principles of feeling, without a critique of the faculty of feeling, "any more than he would need an additional critique of the faculty of desire or practical reason before he could write his metaphysics of morals." (xviii)

* When Kant wrote the first critique, however, he seemed to doubt that there was any possibility of writing a sysetmatic metaphysics of the principles of taste.  (xviii)  This seems to ahve to do with what people describe as the autonomy that Kant gave to aesthetics.  Guyer quotes Kant on xix importantly from the Critique of Pure Reason where Kant was expalaing his "theory of space and time as nothign but the pure forms of the human mind for the intuition of external objets and our own inner sstates." (xix) 

The Germans are the only one who now employ the word "aeshtetics" to designate that which others call the critique of taste.  The ground for this is a failed hope, held by the excellent analyst Baumgarten, of bringing the critical judging of the beautiful under principles of reason, and elevating its rules to a science.  But this effort is futile.  For the putative rules or critera are merely empirical as far as their sources are concerned, and can therefore never serve as a priori rules according to which our judgements of taste must be directed, rather the latter constitutes the genuine touchstone of the correctness of the former.  For this reason it is advisable again to desist from the use of this term and to save it for that doctirne which is true science. (quoted on xix).

Ie Guyer says that this means that here Kant believed, and thsi was consistent with what Kant had written in his lectures on anthropology, judgements of taste were empirical, even if they involved claims about how others should respond in terms of feelings of pleasure.  This meant, and Kant had written this before, that people *learn* from society to make the correct judgements.  Without society they won't know how to respond.  So Guyer thinks that in 1781 Kant did not think that a systematic treatment of the principles/metaphyiscs of taste was possible.  (xix)

* So then Guyer returns to his central question, having to do with what Kant seemed to discover after completing the Critique of Practical Reason that led him to believe he could establish a critique of taste.  Guyer thinks it must have been based in a new  a priori principle, specifically ap principle relatin got the "similarities among human minds, for that is what judgements of taste claim, withotu depending upondeterminate predicates of particular objects, for that is what Kant abjures." (xxi) Guyer further guess: "And perhaps this is what in the most general way teleology suggested to Kant: an a priori principle about the relation between the human mind and the nature that surroudns it, including other human minds, that can give us confidence in the validity of our judgements without directly giving use new concepts of objects." (xxi)

* This new a priori principle that Kant saw himself formulating in the Critique of the Power of Judgement was key for Kant to the cirtique of taste and teleology.  (xxi)

* Kant also revealed a a new kind of judgement: "namely the idea that both judgements of taste and jdugements about the purposiveness of natural objects are forms of a hitherto uncrecognized kind of judgement, which Kant calls reflecting judgement..." (xxi)  Before Kant had seen the "ordinary function of judgement as that of subsuming a particular under a universal that is antecedently given to us, such as a pure concept in mathematics or an empiricial concept in scientific classification,..." (xxii)  Now Kant calls that "determining judgement" and distinguishes it from "reflecting judgement" "in which we are not given a concept under which to subsume a particular but are instead given a particular for which we must seek to find a universal, a concept or rule of some kind that we are not immediately given." (xxii)   A lot of interpretation of Kant's third critqiue is about whether thsi notion is really new vv Kant's thought. 

* The deepest connection betweeen taste/aesthetics and teleology for Kant, Guyer says, has to do with something he writes in the concluding section of the Introduction to the third critique: "the power of j dugement provides the mediating concept between the concept of nature and teh concept of freedom, which makes possible the transition from the purely theoretical to the purely practical, from lawfulness in accordance with the former to the final end in accordance with the latter,

title: German Jews beyond Judaism
text:
General Notes 10/12

# George L. Mosse, *German Jews Beyond Judaism* (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, c1985)

> Note session 10/2012: Reading for Manifold Origins article. Wanting to get a better idea of German-Jewish identity in Germany in the mid-ninteenth century vv the kind of claims that Hacohen makes about Austrian Jews: that they embraced a kind of cosmopolitan universalism wrapped up with being German. What's confusing about Hacohen's article is that he's talking about Vienna. Does this apply to German-Jews? Were they more nationalistically German? Where's the line and the difference?

>Critical Notes:
>>* Mosse seems centrally concerned with the concept of "identity" and with the search for new identities. It shows up in his Preface when he notes that in courses he was teching at U Wisconsin in the 1960s there were "young people searching for a new identity." (ix) And he notes that the ideas he will discuss in this book supplied "an inspiration which their own American tradition had somehow failed to provide." (ix) Then he admits to having had "similar experiences in German in recent years. Some of the German ideas which had provided German-Jewish intellectuals with their identity were familiar, but their Jewish context was all but forgotten." (ix) He's dancing around something here. Is this a Jewish idnetity that is also confidently universalist and enlightened? That American identity has failed to provide? For Jews, or for all American kids?
>>* VV the Manifold Origins article, this piece provoked an idea about how I might argue vv Boas and aesthetics. The key point that provoked this idea that point that Mosse makes on p.11 that the turn away from the classical ideal of *Bildung* saw a "detachment" of the concept, and the aesthetic ideal, from the notion of individuality. As a result, the notion of aesthetics was linked more with a kind of emotionality and not so much to the notion that beauty reinforced in the individual an attentiveness to rational clarity and simplicity, as Mosse describes on 6-7. *Bildung* then, Mosse says, is turned into a kind of collective adoration of certain notions of the good and the beautiful, both German and bourgeois. It is, in other words, rooted in more concrete forms, and treated less as an abstract ideal. And it becomes a way of "gilding" bourgeois materialism. How does this link to my argument in Manifold Origins? It changes slightly how I would narrate the shift I trace in Boas' thoguht I think. If there is a tendency to link the aesthetic (and Bildung) with an emotional undercurrent rooted in specifically German experiences...then what is Boas doing by contrast? He's reading Kant; he's allowing his emotional enthusiasm flow into a life that is entirely distinct while simultaneously insisting on

## 1. A Cultural Emancipation

* The German-Jewish dialogue he maintains "determined what we perceive as Weimar culture (although this was only one of its aspects)--Jews interacting with Geramns on many levels of art and literature." (1)

* German Jews numbered only about 500-600K between 1871 and 1933, while the general population of Germany grew from 41 to 65 million. So Jews were a small minority of the German population: only about 1%. *

* The liberation of Jews in Germany implied a "dialogue" Mosse wants to say and that dialogue involved shifts in German Jewish identity, but not a rejection of Jewishness: "That Jewish identity had to be redefined, as Jewish emancipation led to Jewish assimilation, did not mean a rejection of that identity, as is often asserted in retrospect; German Jews were for the most part fully aware of their Jewish origins. As a 1930 article in the journal of the Central association of German Jews (C.V. Zeitung) put it, we must place the highest value on humanity as a whole, while at the same time loving the German people and our specific Jewishness." (2) 

* On Bildung. Some good stuff. Very clear. "The word *Bildung* combines the meaning carried by the English word 'education' with notion of character formation and moral education." (3) Herder he says described it more or less as the "Uoflding of his personality until he becomes an harmonious, autonomous individual exemplifying both the continuing quest for knowledge and the moral imperative." (3) Goethe's phrase: "much selbst, ganz wie ich da bin, auszubilden" -- to cultive my self just as I am. (3) He says the proceses referred to an inward process,  but not one focused on "instinctual drives or emotional preferences". One focused rather on "the cultivation of reason and aesthetic taste; its purpose was to lead the individual from supersititon to enlightenment." (3) He also empahsizes its processual dimension: "self-cultivation was a continual process which was never supposed to end during one's life. Thus those who followed thisideal saw themselves as part of a process rather than as finished porducts of education." (3) This concept he thinkw  was "ideal ready-made for Jewish assimilation, because it transcended all differences of nationality and religion through the unfolding of the individual personality." (3)

* Herder Mosse argues "had already envisioned the concept of *Bildung* as a means of overcoming the inequality between men. He wanteeed to level the differences between the bourgeoisie and the aristocracy by confronting the nobility with an ideal which would deflate its pretensions." (4) That same instrument Mosse notes could also be used to "transcend the differences between teh German and the Jewish middle classes." (4) Then he asserts that as such the *Bildung* ideal is essential to understanding "German-Jewish consciousness" (phrases like this show how this text may be dated): "it was basic to Jewish engagement with liberalism and socialism, fundamental to the search for a new Jewish identity after emancipation." (4)

* He discusses the work of Berthold Auerbach who he says was "considered by his fellow Jews to be one of the most representative German Jews of the nineteenth century" (4) (whatever that means) whose in his *Schrift und Volk* "called for relgion to become *Bildung*--'an inner liberation and deliverance of man, his true rebirth; not thorugh words or customs, but through his deeds, his character, the totality of his life, the cleansing and healing of all human labor.'"(4) Later this kind of hope was to become impossible, after the rise of a different kind of nationalism not rooted in Enlightened notions. e.g. he quotes Rabbi Ignaz Maybaum in 1939 in London who said that at this point those who did not believe in God faced a choice between "faith and barbarism." (4)

* Mosse also points out that ther eason Jews took up the ideal of *Bildung* to the degree that they did had to do with their "social structure" ie the fact that although most of them were poor,a nd therre was only a small middle class, they accepted the idealof the "bourgeoisie into which they had been emancipated" because unlike other poor Germans they lacked "organic or family ties to the lower classes and no experience with German popular piety and German popular cutlure." (5) [ I wonder if that was really so true.. ] Anyway, what he means i sthat there was a kind of unusual alliance between the German liberal middle class and German Jews who were relatively poor by comaprison. As evidence of that Auerbach as the author of the *Black Forest Peasant Tales* (1843) "enjoyed an unprecedented esteem and popularity among Jews and gentiles a like." (5) In his *Schrfit und Volk* where he defined peasent society the "peasants reflected a middle-class outlook on the world." (5) Auerbach was born in a village. His peasents are "assimilated into bourgeois society as they break out of their narrow regional vision and religious bigotry." (5) Why? Because "whatever one's class or station in life, 'the development of the human spirit knows no boundaries and cannot be confined by religious dogma.'" (5) -- there's the *Bildung* idea. Jews, Mosse notes, rarely appear in these stories, and when Auerbach planned to write about a Jewish village, he stopped without explanation, Mosse thinks, because the "subject was not congenial to one committed to transcending religious differenes through *Bildung*. That suffices, sort of, as an explantion; but perhaps also Auerbrach didn't want to try to tell the same story about Jews transcending their parochial attachments for fear of how it would be read in an era of increasing anti-Semetism as evidence of Jewish infiltration of the German nation?

* In any caes, with the decline of *Bildung* as there occured a rise of a nationalism that showed "peasents who exemplified the ideal of rootedness in the nation which they made their own" (5), Auerbach's popularity declined. His peasant tales were now less popular than Hermann Löns *Der Wehrwolf* (1910) where the peasent sybmolized "the elemental forces of Germanic nature, coursing beneath the surface, as they defend their land during the Thirty Years War; cruetly was accepted as a part of everyday life." (5) Mosse contrasts this iwth Auerbach's *Barfüssle* where he says the moral is about transcending an impulse for revenge. This process gained speed at the end of nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries: "*Bildung* and the Enlightenment, the substance of Auerbach's Jewishness, respected during the nineteenth century, were being repudiated at the beginning of the twentieth." (5-6)

* Now Mosse goes into the links between *Bildung* and the Enlightenment, saying that several "presuppositions" of the Enlightenment "were basic to the concept of *Bildung*." (6) He lists the following: "the optimism about the potential of human nature and the autonomy of man; the belief that acquired knowledge would activate the moral imperative; and, last but not least, the belief that all who were willing to use and develop their reason could attain this ideal." (6) Great quote by *Sulamith*: "The possession of a higher *Bildung* is the knighthood of modernity." (quoted on 6). This "knighthood" was more equal because accessible to everyone, Jews included.

* Harmony was also key to the idea and this touched on the aesthetic. The emphasis on harmony was a reaction he says to "a Germany touched by the industrialzation of Europe, frigented by the French Revolution." (6) The aesthetic was key here becuase it was the "keystone...linking the intellectual and the moral." (6) Mosse says this is hard to understand for our age in which "beauty has become relative and the aesthetic is either regarded as a luxury or trivialized into the knickknacks of daily life." (6) But then there was, say for Humboldt, the powerful influence of the Greeks and the idea of "Ancient beauty" that Mosse says "seemed to give form and direction to individual and communal ideals." (6) The classics were thought to provide "the modes of thought and taste essential to the cultivation of the personality. The aeshthetic was linked to the intellectual faculty, and both activated the mroal imperative which resided in every man." (6) Here the beautiful was understood not in the romantic mode but as something linked to reason. Like Greek sculputure, the beautiful was conveived as "harmonious and well proportioned, wthout any excess or false note which might disrupt its quiet greatness." (6) Beauty then aided in "controlling the passions, not in unleashing them, emphasizing self-control which the bourgeois prized so highly." (6) Thus beauty for Humbold, for Goethe, and for Schiller symbolized an "ideal of a shared humanity toward which *Bildung* must strive." (7) Beauty then was a disciplining presence, keeping "cruely, slackness, and perversity" at bay. On this last point, Mosse sites Friedrich Schiller's *Über die ästhetische Erziehung des Menschen*, citing p. 36 in a 1965 Stuttgarrt edition. So then the role of the artist could be to reveal "true *Bildung*".(7)  Jewish writers participated in this tradition, and he notes that when Germans tried to "nationalize and romanticize" the idea toward th ened of the 19th century, Jewish writers became this concept of Bildung's main "custodians." (7) Re aesthetics, the transformation that the Germans follow is one in which beauty comes to serve more "emotional needs rather than strengthening rationality and self-discipline." (7)

* Interestingly, Mosse notes that the emphasis on *Bildung* vv aesthetics was in addition to being an attempt to maintain control in the contenxt of poltiical and social disruption set off by the French Revolution and industrialization, it was also in its emphasis on aesthetics a response to "the fact that the nineteenth century was becoming increasingly visually oriented age as the largely illiterate masses were integrated into politics and culture though the use of symbols--from cheap reproductions to national monuments." (7) Eventually, this was a disadvantage for Jews who could be targeted through "visual sterotypes", but at first it worked in their favor, making it easy for Jews to "embrace Europe" as Sulamith said (7, bottom). in 1837 in Hamburg Rabbi Gotthold Saloman could praise King David as a man of *Bildung*. (7-8) And Ludwig Philippson's journal for rabbis could draw "a sharp distinction in 1834 between the ceremonial culture of the ancient Jews and modern *Bildung*." (8)

* The Bildung idea was set against the vision of "the masses." The Jews who were emancipated in Germany at the same time as the "German masses" entered social and political life (8), reached for the *Bildung* idea in a way that the German masses did not. This commitment to Humbodlt's *Bildung* thus helped to alienate them from the "German masses." (What is this German masses??? ) (8)

* Jews were also "emancipated into" the German wars of libreration against Napoliean. He describes taht Jews fought in these wars. Mentions a painting of 1835 by Moritz Oppenheim that depicts a Jewish volunteer returning hoem from war to celebrate sabbath. (9) The Jewish community of Berlin he says could exhort its departing soldiers: "Never forget that all warriors are part of a common humanity." (quoted on 9).  The point here is that German natinoailsm at this stage was still "at the crossroads" and "patriotism and cosmopolitanism were often joined" (9) .  He cites the poet Klopstock as a "fanatic" of German unification who he says "held that Germans were ennobled by their tolerance toward other peoples." (9) He says that following the Prussian victory over the French at the battle of Leipzig in 1814 "there was a feeling of pride that Jews joined in the singing of Christian chorales during the celebrations and that 'cultured' men and women rejoined in the victory of German arms withotu regard to their religious differences." (9) His way of summing thi sup is to say that "Patriotism retained its eighteenth-century menaing of solidarity rather than domination." (9)

* In this line, Ernst Moritz Arndt, who exhorted Germans to fight for freedom against the French, tended to equates "German freedom with the freedom of all mankind." (9) -- interesting parallel here to that kindo f patriotism that is American in origin, that indicates a nationalism that is great vv the whole world, and not a particualr people.  But Arndt also criticized those whose patriotism, as that of Nathan in Lessing's *Nathan der Weise* (1779), was "one which loved the whole world while those at home were left to freeze int he cold." (9) Eventually, this kind of critique targeted Jews who were then described as "a cosmopolitan *Bildungsb*uuml;rger" and "made into a symbol for a commitment to *Bildung* and the Enlightenment that was said to have caused Germany's defeat by the French--and previoiusly enlightened thinkers such as Fichte, under the growing weight of nationalism, came to share this outlook." (9)

* Jews, however, did not follow this line from patriot to nationalist. *Bildung* implied instead a kind of autonomous development that led to a political stance vv the state. Humboldt had argued that self-cultivation would lead a man to enter poltiical life "spontaenously".  And Humboldt warned against the idea of a strong state. (10)  So within the *Bildung* ideal citizenship and individual freedom did not run counter to each other. Indeed, one could not exist without the other. "What counted," Mosse says, "was individual self-cultivation and the network of personal realtionshiops." Auerbach wrote: "The further modern *Bildung* progresses...the more it is based upon the individual from out of hiw own unique personlaity joines the state." (quoted on 10). Mosse adds that in fact the "eighteenth-century culture of friendship in Germany was part of the ideal of *Bildung* itself--differences of personality and character must be recognized adn then submerged in a common effort at self-cultivation." (10) He cites Goethe's *Wilhelm Meiserter's Apprenticeship* where greatest happines comes from "giving and receiveing out of each friend's richness of personality developed trhough mutual self-cultivation." (10) In Lessing's *Die Juden* (1749) there is a Jew that meets a strange and says: "I saw that although you indicated hostility toward my nation [the Jews], you were favorably disposed toward me. And a man's friendship, whoever he be, will always be invaluable to me." (10) This ideal of freindship was important to Jews. And he notes that as in the frontispiece to his book--a painting by Moritz Oppenheim--Moses Mendelssohn "was usually pictured walking or talking with his Jewish and Christian friends." (10) Ludwig Geigher, at the end of the 19th, reflected on the literary salons that had existed in Berlin almost a century earlier, imagining that those friendships were solid and durable. (10-11). Cite is Ludwig Geiger, *Geschichte der Juden in Berlin* (Berlin, 1871), p. 107.  After the 1880s, there were breaks in these friendships that some Jews had believed to be sturdy, he cites his own *Nationalism and Sexuality*, ch. IV.
> ![picture](http://im.glogster.com/media/4/33/16/35/33163536.jpg "Moses Mendelssohn discussant avec Gotthold Ephraim lessing (1860)")

* What happened though utlimately was that *Bildung*'s purpose for the bourgeoisie had less to do with the universal ideal. That is utlimately he writtes *Bildung* served two purposes: 1) it "legitiimzied the middl class compared to the upper and lower classes..." (11) and 2) it helped create a "boutrgeois elite which, as Humboldt intended, would provie better civil servants for the Prussian state." (11)

* What happened to *Bildung* then was that it was "detached" from the ideal of autonomous individuality.  This is really key!! And MOsse has a lovely sentence that carries a lot of interpretive power here: "With the passage of time, *Bildung* itself, like its aesthetic component, became detached from the individual and his struggle for self-culvation and was transformed into a kind of religion--the worship of the true, the good, and the beautiful." (11) This sentence is powerful. His reference to the shift vv the aesthetic is that the aesthetic was attached more to these strands of emotional enthusiasm, what he had described before as an aesthetics that satisfied emotinoal needs and which was not, as originally in *Bildung* and the Greek ideal of beauty, a support of rationality and self-discipline. VV *Biludng* in general what he means is that the the ideal as a kind of "religion" served more as a "means of bilding bourgeois materialism..." (11, bottom).

* In taking up the idealistic side of *Bildung*, Jews had been "chasing a noble illusion" he thinks. (12). He notes that from the beginning in Germany "nationailsm had come to the resuce in order to reinforce cohesion of society against the onslaught of modernity." (12) He references a spin fichte had put on the defintiion of *Bildung* that had again appeared in Friedriuch Paulsen's *Das Deutsche Bilungswesen* (1912) that treated the concept as "a means of reshaping reality through the power of ideas" and Fichte had added that these "ideas" were tied to German character. Jews then "seem scaracely to have realized that both borugeois society and the peopel themselves needed more tangible signposts in order to make the abstract concrete." (12) What a great sentence!!! He mentions Bloch's statements about the ened of "daydreams" to efforts to change the world.

* Indeed, in the end it was not jsut "tangible signsposts" that were needed in Germany, but forms of discipline that could actually be used to keep "control over public and private life." (12) So that in the end somehow "[d]iscipline and conformity...took precedence over self-cultivation and spontaneity of citizenship." (12) He ntoes that in the *Volkschule*, where most Germans received their edcuation, *Bildung* had always been about discipline and conformity. And this was increainsly the case. The ideal of *Bildung* that "should have been opten to all" was increasingly "controlledd by a self-perpetuating elite." (12) And this system utlimately was very effective in creating an elite who viewed hemselves as the "conscience of the nation." Germany was so succesful at this that it became a model for the world. But he suspects more than being a "conscience" they were in the end "guardians of the existing order." (13)

* At this point the cult of friendship definietly declined, and Fichte's idea set out during the French occupation of Prussia--that "man could not love hismelf or anything outside himself unless ideas rooted in the German characer were part of the system of belief--became more common coin. He cites his Mosse, "Friendship and Nationhood: About the Promise and Fulfillment of German Nationalsim," *Journal of Contemporary History* 17 (April, 1982): 358. (13-14)

* The erosion of the *Bildung* ideal he note happened gradually, and gained steam particularly after World War I. (14) Even after the rise of antisemetism in the 1880s, Jews struck to the ideal of *Bildung*.

* He refers to Lessing's *Nathan der Weise* as the "Magna Charta of German Jewry..." (15) --- a testament to "love for humanity regardless of religion, a love exemmplified by his close firendship with Moses Mendelssohn." (15)

* As Germans turned away from the classical ideal of Bildung, treating it in a narrower and narrow mode, Jews were increasingly exluded from the mandarin class. Some tried therefore to try to join the German working class "but once they had done so, they were often singled out as troublesmoe intellectuals who refused to do their duty as foot soliders in the workers' movement." (19) Others he said tried to continue int heir role as intelelctuals and "exorcise the irrational by examinig it rationally and dissecting it in the rational mind." (19) He gives the example of Stefan Zweig, who although he was Austrian was treated as a German writer. He tried to focus on all humanity and to infuse his work with the ideal of *Bildung*. (19)

title: How To Make Our Ideas Clear
text:
Notes

* Section I goes through a critique of the rationalist logical notions of descartes and Leibniz...then moves to the ncessity of "making our ideas clear."

II

* Referring to the first paper in the series ie "Fixation of Belief," Peirce reiterate the principle of the "irritation of doubt": "thea ction of thought is excited by the irritation of doubt, and ceases when belief is attained; so that the production of belief is the sole function of thought." (132)

* He goes through a more detailed examiantion of the processes leading to belief on 133-134, using the  metaphor of music.  He tries to thereby distinguish to "elements of consciousness."  The tone itself which "may be prolonged for an hour or a day, and it exists as perfectly in each seocnd of that time as in the whole taken together; so that, as long as it is soundmking, it might be present to as esne from which everything in the past was as copletely absent as the future itself." (133)  Then there is the "air"--and this makes little sense--because he's talkign about "perceiving it" -- perceving the air??  Does he mean the individual sound as it is carried by theair.  He does say "We certainly only perceive the air by hearing the separate ntoes; yet we cannot be said to direclty hear it, for we hear only what is present at that instant." (133-4)  In any case, the poitn is that to perceive it we need a "continuity of consciousness which makes every lapse of a time present to us." (133)  The point iseems to be that we are immediately consciousnes of the tone and only mediately conscious of the air, and this he says holds for all consciousness.  (134)  Sensations are "completely present at every instant"  whereas other elmenemts (like thoguth) have "beginning, middle, and and, and consist in a congruence in the sucession of sensations which flow throught the mind." (134)  Reaching back to his metaphor: "Though is a thread of melody running through the succession of our sensations." (134) 

[ Is this rationalist or empiricist?  It sounds more empiricist to me...and that makes sense.  But is it empiricist really?  It sounds somehow like Locke--sensations are tied to gether in the mind trhough reflection?... But is  it?]

* Now thoguht produces belief and what is belief?  It has three properties: 1) it's something we are aware of; 2) it "appeases the irritation of doubt." 3) "it involves the establishment in our nature of a rule of action, or, say for short, a habit." (134-5)  So thought produces belief which is habit. 

*  And more importantly, if two diuffrent beliefs produce the same rule of action, then they aren't really distinct.  (135)  This is now getting into the idea of distinction -- ie to replace the kind of distinction that Descartes and Leibniz used -- that is "practical."  So "what a think means is simply what habits it involves." (137)  To distinguish between two ideas that have the same habit results is wrong for him. 

"Thus we come down to what is tangible and practical, as the root of every real distinction of thought, no matter how subitle it may be; and there is no distinction of meaning so fine as to consist in anything but a possible difference of practice." (137)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.048 Other forces assisting segregation...

"...as chicago exanded, professional ambition, combined with the belief that specialization was necessary to scientific advance, led to the breakup of the interdisciplinary departments of the university's beginnings and facilitated the task of those who would segregate the sexes within the university." (48) E.g. she quotes Laughlin oting that the number of wome students was partly due to the fac tthat the women used the combination of courses available in one dept to prepare as teachers.  Then Rosenberg writes "but he believed that once the university suceeded in establishing its professional schools and in identifying the professional utility of departments like economics and sociology, it would be able to secure its reputation as a distinctively male institution training men for identifiably male work." (49)

title: The Dainty and the Hungry Man: Literature and Anthropology in the Work of Edward Sapir
text:
p.058-65  Sapir's Poetic and Literary Theory Writings

Handler now goes into Sapir poetry.  He notes a sense of alienation and helplessness on 58-59.  Back on 55 he notes that this feeling of helplessness and iscontent had also been provoked by WWI, which had also affected him by causing a loss of funding (here he cites Murray's article on "Edward Sapir's Canadian 'Winter'", p.65)

Handle'rs description of Sapir through his poetry: "Self-doubt and a feeling of being at oddes iwth one's true self are implies in several blunt, sarcastic pieces aimed at academicians.  The metaphysician is a dog chasing his tail, the philosopher constructs daily a new system to epxlin the universe.  'Professors in War-Time' chides those who stand aloof, refusing to apply their wisdom and skill 'while all the world is soaked in blood and groans with pain.'" (59)

He cites at length a poem "Helpless Revolt":

I hve no respect for what is.

I can not mend and patch,

I can not bend my soul to the twist

That will make it fit with the brutal fact,

That will make it yield to the tyrant world.

My soul stands firm.

It would annihilate all in its rage and build anew,

Rather than bend.

Therefore it breaks, and the brutal fact remains

And the tyrant world wags on.

---------

Key idea though is in "Dainty versus Hengry Man".  These two ideals of a person.  The Dainty Man is an aesthete and desires the beauty of form; Hungry Man desires the "crassness of life." Hungry Man, though, does not want a "meaningless asemblage" (H's words), but also the "inner truths of the heart."  [Note: Basically, the former is the liberal; the fomrer the romantic... ] (59-60)

The next key part comes in Sapir's two writingson writing "Twilight of Rhyme" and "REalism in Prose Fiction". (61)

First establishes principle that niether the Dainty Man's interest in general form nor the Hungry Man's interest in the "crassnesss of life" are sufficeient unto themselves. (60-62)

In the second, Sapir establishes a method of a "profound and all embracing realistic art" that satisifes both the desires of the Hungry Man for the knowledge of "individual hearts and collective life." (H's words, 63)

This is th eline that H follows: the desire to conceptualize the whole, but without losing sight of the "individual hearts." He next moves to Sapir's critique of the superorganic.  He sees a parellel between Sair's rjeection of a "superorganic level of reality that coerces individuals and nullifies their creative possibilities..." (64) with Sapir's desire not to lose sight of the individual while conceiving a whole.

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.016 Addams marriage-like relationship with Mary Rozet Smith

Addams had formed a close relationship that took on the characteristics of a Victorian marriage with Mary Smith.  Muncy relates this relationship to the conditions of women.  Women faced a choice between marriage or career.  Combining the twonot easy,esp.considerin glack of birth control.  This tended to support strong intimate relationships betweenwomen.
