title: Bildung
text:
General Notes 2/2013



* Bildung seems to have a special meaning in relation to enlighenment (aufklärung) in Germany. The author says a parallel exists in relation to the difference between Zivilisation and Kultur in Germany, as the authors of the G.B. have noted in another essay. (508-509)

* In 1784, the term -- when the quote by Mendelssohn that starts the essay was written -- the term was not new, but it had taken on a new application, namely it had bedcome a key term in an intellectual discussion among people who say themselves as writers and well read. In every day language it was not often used. and when it was it was used to refer either to the development of the eucatiuonal system (ie institutions) or to education as a kind of social status. But this was enough to allow the word to enter into political language, so that Bildung is seen as the most important process in the creation of equal conditions... (509)

* This is super interesting...the heart of taste...this can bear directly on Boas' rue formulation. Herzensbildung. Is he reversing it? The taste of heart? (515)

* So the link between bildung and nationalization created a notion of political Bildung, but this meaning was still scattered in the late18th...(515)

* With the enlightenment thinking Bildung takes on more weight than Erziehung... It was used especially with reference to forming or shaping (Formung), the self improvement of the human soul's capacities (Seelenkräfte), taste or herzen.(515)

* Herder's take on Bildung. It is an independent concept such that he can speak of he spirit of education. It is independent like other words, Kultur, Geist, Humanität. And he understood it as a natural and universal process that like destiny,...

* The increased attention to Bildung is not the reasonw that Education was more and more important. There was at this Time a "comprehensive change in the Image of humans". (517)

* With Goethe's understanding over Herders, a certain Genius is attributed to the well educated. But a genius that also involved a relentless self consciousness about self cultivation and pedagogy. (518)

* The tension or discrepancy between the new humanist classical Bildungskonzept and the bürgerliche "Stands- und Berufsbildung" concept as the utilitarian absolutist state envisioned it led to conflicts of priority. 519)

* Amazing quote, shows in particular that Herzensbildung was part of this classical humanist conception somehow.

* The French Revolution introduces a new suspicion of the Bildugsideal, as something inherently revolutionary... (522)

* The suspicion of Bildung then became a part of the battle over political mentalities and the debate over educational policy. But at the same time the intellectual elite and liberals felt compelled to argue that "true" Bildung was hindering the revolution because it created a reform mentality among both the governed and thebgoverning. They believed that this reform disposition was a source of progress, but they believed it led to not on Y the valuing of Bildung but also of the observation of reform practice of enlightened absolutism. When one focuse only on Bildung as leading to te unfolding of human capacities in the individual, only a minority of the educated could affirm the political revolution as inevitable. (523) In the end this leads to an identification of Bildnung with Ordnung, that Goethe was understood as the chief witness of... (523)

* Here is what the author calls an anti revolutionary concept of political Bildung. Which be comes characteristic of Gebildeten. (524)

* Fichte's take on Bildung as the way for the German nation to establish itself, but only as a form of Bildung that erased class distinctions, that was truly universal.

* The idea of Menschendbildung developed as a reaction to the idea of Bildung as an intellectual and impractical thing. It emerged in accounts that determined the meaning of Bildung in a detailed manner in relation to aetheics, military life, literature, etc...

* It was the neohumanist idea that set the tone of the pedagogical discussion in the first part of he 19th. This ideal reconciled the idea of Bildung as a individual unfolding no related to any profession or practical concern ,by reserving that part I it for the adolescent and young adult years. After that point it was work with the goal of making the individual useful to society. (529)

* Prussia was the state in which the Bildung ideal was most leading, for example at Humboldt. (530)

* There was then also a reaction against Bildung. There was a sense for example that what was called Bildung was not, that it was too high, did not include the lower classes, and was really just a matter of style, and a form of corruption. True conservatives imagined that echte Bildung would create a feeling for order, law, and security... (531)

* This section is important because it explains how the educated classes bult into Bildung their own interests as a class, and how that then also integrated them into a process of state and constitutional reform then taking place. Through them and through the neohumanist idea of Bildung the process of constitutional reform was linked to a process of the inner human development linked o the human sciences. (531-4)

* Hegel they say defined the inner relationship between Geist and Bildung, racially through one's building of oneself in the image of a profession in the Geisteswissenschaften... (535)

* The tight linkage btw Bildung and the Geisteswissenschaften is evident in the fact that the implementation of a newly dynamic and historical blanket concept of Bildung was a requirement for the development of the Geisteswissenschaften in Germany. Hegel and Humboldt were key here. (536)

& In the Vormärz period the awareness of the way Bildung was conditioned by state and social relations became more pronounced. It was commonly accepted that the constitutional state should not just guarantee property rights but also the right to education. Key to this relationship was the linking of political maturity and the cultivation of people. This then involved the question of equality because thelack of Bildung among the lower classes was understood as a danger if the lower classes were also given the vote. (542)

* The social meaning of Bildung developed in this period such that the concept became tightly related to the concept of property ownership. Bildung became a kind of verification of property ownership and in a way that served the interests of the educated middle class It became self evident that someone with Bildungbwas not poor. Many viewed the meeting of poverty and cultivation as unhealthy and the conservatives viewed it dangerous. That was linked to a concern that too much studying and too little productivity would lead to more pauperism and ultimately to radicalism. (543)

* This idea of Bildung as linked to freedom, equality, and order was also a way of making critical demands with respect to the present. Either to make clear that the progress of the constitutional politics depended on the education of the property owning and well educated classes, or to say that only through the development of constitutional politics could broad education and political education be demanded. The concept of political Bildung became especially important in the 1830s. There was a sense in this period that did not last among those who expressed it that the provincialism of the Germans supplied a basis for the rapid development of the capacity for political Bildung. What is Political Bildung? It is the idea of linking diversity through a critical awareness? The article quotes the Staats-lexicon from 1839 which put it this way: "der Begriff der politischen Bildung fasse eine on tausend Farbe erscheinende bunte Mannigfaltigkeit in eine zusammen und sei gleichbedeutend mit dem Idee des Volkes." That is the signified the idea of summarizing a great and emerging diversity into one and was thus linked to the idea of the volk... (543)

* Here there were two ways of thinking about Bildung. It could be thought to refer to social equilibration or redistribution (sozial ausgleichende) or to in reverse contribute to greater sozial differentiation. The authors to through some fears of how Bildung would create fundamental differences. Hegel pointed this out. J. G. Hoffman for example divided the national citizenry into groups based on work and education level and was afraid that among the educated working middle class an abstract relationship to work could lead to a kind of intellectual darkness and apathy, anarchism, etc... The authors see in this kind of warning a certain high minded perspective that suggested a tendeny toward social exclusivity. On the other hand, others such as C. Welcker divided the state intothose who had studied and those who had not. In this line, August Von Struve, the 1848 radical democrat, noted that only the rich could get access to education and as a radical democrat laid out the principle of universal free education for all people as a basic right. (544)

* This discussion about expanding access to education to more people as not new, but in the 30s it took on a stronger cautionary tone. Here Struve again was forceful. (545)

* Conservatives both Christian and "organic" liberals opposed radical democratic calls for universal education on the basis that it was unnatural. Rohmer 1844 put it that the radicals thought that Kultur and Bildung could replace nature. More Rohmer thought that volksunterrichts would lead to the destruction of their inherent power (Volkskraft) and to their coming under the influenzier of the Maß Zeitgeist. (545)

* Interesting that if one thinks about the notion of character this was way more

* In the late 18th and 19th centuries, the Bildung ideal became central to the self understanding of the German educated classes. In this sense, education was a form of spiritual commodity that marked the difference between the properties and the unpropertied. And in this sense, the meaning of Bildung had more to do with belonging and not belonging to the group of well educated than it did with the actual content of education. An 1864 book entitled "The education and the Educated" put this in terms of a need for education to be based on forms that could are the basis of a general humanity and that could then create an ideal type, but this required subordinating or finding a happy medium between a general ethical pattern and the freedom of individual personality. These ideas formed the basis of a critique of more humanist notions of education, and ultimately led to a more tense attempt in some even more humanist texts to conform/constrain education to a practical social domain. (547-548) * More detail please!!!

* The authors account of a kulturkritik of Bildung by Nietzsche and Lagarde, that in their description seemed to pick up on the idea that Bildung hadnjust become a sign of membership in the Gebildeten, and that education just supported an uncritical notion at the educated German was in every possible way the representative of German culture. Nietzsche thus suggested a concentration and narrowing of Bildung as well as an increased emphasis on the self-sufficiency I'd education. In Lagarde's case a similar critique led to the suggestion of a stronger nationalistic education for the elite, whereas the general population should be satisfied with A very basic education. (549-550)

* Lagarde's critique led through other critiques of reason and thus to a focus on the strengthening of the body to national socialism and thus the Bildungsbegriff has come into question, and so also leads often to an agreement with the neohumanist idea of Bildung. But the concept has also been challenged by the concrete changes, for example population increase, specialization in professions, wider access to education, as well as as a result of the emergence of new sciences such as anthropology, psychology, pedagogy, etc...

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text:
p. 005- 8  Theoretical Basis and Argument

This thesis focuses on the interaction between institutional and disciplinary features of twentieht-century anthropology in the United States.  His interest,
drawing on Foucault, is to look at the way anthropology excluded and included certain forms of inquiry over time.  (5)  He follows Foucault to be senseitive to "clusters of 'statements', or ideas...'discursive formations.'" (6).

He also draws upon Kuhn's paradigm idea as well.  He notes that Kuhn's concept implied an "interpersonal element" within the community of scientists.  (6)  He writes that "In the postwar years, the anthropologists' desire for pradigms and desire to emulate the ideal of the 'scientist' came to be the motifs that bound together forms of anthropological knowledge and divided anthropological knowledge." (6) 

The thesis notes a substantive change in the anthropology before and after WWII.  Madden thinks that anthropology was, using Kuhn's phrase, "pre-paradigmatic" prior to WWII in that no single theory "was a model with which anthropologists could explain cultural processes or organize cultural research definitively." (7) 

After WWII he thinks they changed up.  "Anthropologists tried to organize facts in hierarchical fashion according to various models.  'Schools of thought' formed around these attempts to establish models, and for some schools of anthropologists, pardigms did emerge with which anthropologists organized anthropological research.  Other anthropologists, particularly the linguistic anthropologists and the symbolic anthropologists, were unable to formulate models despite their best efforts...." (7-8)

title: Critique of the Power of Judgement
text:
Kant's Definition of Culture

 

This definition is in a section 83 "On the ultimate end of nature as a teleological system":

*  He starts with the idea that he says he has developed up until this point in the text that "we have sufficient cause to judge the human being not merely, like any organized being, as a natural end, but also as the ultimate end of nature here on earth, in relation to which all other natural things constitute a system of ends in accordance with fundamental principles of reason..."  (297).  I can't follow this exactly at this stage not having read the book up until this point, but he is saying then that humans are the ultimate end of nature and that all things are organized such as to create a system of ends supporting the human.

*  Then he says ok if we are going to pinpoint "that which is to be promoted as an end" in human's connection to nature as the ultimate end in the human, then that thing "must be" something that "can be satisfied by the beneficience of nature itself", ie what nature itself provides??, or it is "the aptitude and skill for all sorts of ends for which he [the human?] can use nature (external and internal).", ie the ways humans can take advantage of nature, build on it?  (second nature? culture?)  He then says that the first and second end of nature are "the happiness" and "the culture of the human being." (297)

* Happiness he defines as "a mere idea" (as opposed to something "abstracted from his instincts and thus derived from the animality in himself") of a "state" in which "he would make his instincts adequate under merely empirical conditions (which is impossible)." (297)  Nature he says does not make happiness its end, even if human beings are nature's ultimate end.  Nature he says has not protected humans and more than any other beings from "its destructive effects" AND he says humans themselves possess "natural predispositions" that also works against his own happeiness int he fro of "plagues that he invents for himself"--ie war, opression, etc.  (298)  SO: this means that even if nature had set human happiness as its end "that end would not be attained in a system mof nature upon the earth, because the nature inside of us is not receptive to that." (298) So he says that what this means is that humans are, even thought they are the ultiamte end of nature, "always only a link in the change of natural ends".  As "the sole being on earth who has reason" he says that when nature is seen as a teleological system, it is human's "vocation to be the ultimate end of nature" (298), but "always only conditionally, that is subject to the conditiont hat he [the human] has the understanding and the will to give to nature and to himself a relation to an end that can be sufficient for itself independently of nature, which can thus be a final end, which, however, must not be sought in nature at all." (298)  Ie the condition of humankinds vocation as the ultiamte end of nature is that they recognize that the securing of their own happiness is not nature's goal/end.  So as the ultimate end of nature, it is human kinds' job/duty? to realize to set himself and nature in a relationship that produces a final end that is "sufficient for itself independently of nature"--but that end is not happines, which is a mere idea a he said at the outset. Perhaps this can be reduced to the idea that as the ultimate end of nature (that is as the sole beings with reason) humans must themselves develop a relationship to nature that will allow them to pursue an end which must be "sufficient for itself", ie we cannot expect it to be something secured for us by nature.  We must support it.

* So then to find where in the human is the "ultimate end of n ature" we must think about what nature does in us that prepares us to do what we must do "in order to be a final end."  He says that we have to separate then those ends whose possibility depends on conditions that nature establishes, from those things that humans themselves msut do.  "Earthly happiness" is one of those ends that can only be produced from conditoins establishe by nature, an end that is only possible "through nature inside and outside of the human being."  So humans cannot make it their end, and if they did this would prvent them from "setting a final end" for their own existence.  All that is left, Kant says, among humans' "ends in nature" is "the formal, subjective condition, namely the aptitude for setting himself ends at all and...using nature as a means appropriate to the maxims of his free ends in general, as that which nature can accomplish with a view to the final end that lies outside of it and which can therefore be regarded as its ultimate end." (298-299)  So by the end that humans uniquely can establish as "sufficient by itself" is also nature's "ultimate end" even though it "lies outside of it".   

* This is where culture comes in: "The production of the aptitude of a rational being for any ends in general (thus those of his freedom) is culture." (299) Ie culture is what produces in humans the ability or capacity to develop pursue ends that humans' freedom allow them to define.So "only culture can be the ultimat end that one has cause to ascribe to nature in regard to the human species..." (299) -- ie human happiness is not the utlimate end of nature nor is the idea that humans should be the "foremost instrument of establishin gorder and consensus in irrational nature outside him." (299) 

*  But he says not all kinds of culture are "adequate for this ultimate end in nature."  (299)  He says the "culture of skill" --by which he refers to cultures of certain skills that allow humans to use nature for their own ends?--is not enough because it is not "sufficient for promoting the will in the determination and choice of its ends" and this is essential "for an aptitude for ends." (299)  What is needed he says is a kind of culture, which he terms the "culture of training (discipline)," that is "negative, and consists in the liberation of the will from the despotism of desires, by which we are made, attached as we are to certain things of nature, incapable of choosing for ourselves, while we turn into fetters the drives that nature has given us merely for guidance in order not to neglect o reven injure the determination of the animality in us, while yet we are fre enought ot tighten or lossen them, to lengthen or shorten them, as the ends of reason require." (299)

*  He says that the culture of skill cannot be easily developed without inequality among humans.  The "majority" he says provides the "necessities of life" to the mintority wh produce the less necessary parts of culture, ie science and art.  But this situation as it develops on both sides produces "calamities" on both sides he says: on the side of the majority because of the violence imposed, and onthe side of the rich "because of dissatisfaction from within" (299)  All this, though, he says is "bound up with the development of nature itself, even if it is not our end.." (299)  But our end, which is the utlimate end of nature, is only attained in "that constitution  in the relations of human beings with one another in which the abuses of reciprocally conflicting freedom is opposed by lawful power in a whole, which is called civil society..."  (299-300)  !!!!  Ie there is this whole within which the infringement of one person's freedom o n another's is "opposed" by a "lawful power".... 

*  But he says for a civil society to exist there msut be--"even if humans were clever enough to discover it and wise enough to subject themselves willingly to its coercion"--a "cosmpolitan whole" by which  he means a "system of all states that are at risk of detrimentally affecting each other..." (300)  Without this, he says, war will occur and "is inevitable" esp because of ambition, love of power, and greed "on the part of those who are in power..." (300)  And he reflects that it may be possible to imagine that war "is a deeply hidden by perhaps intentional effort of supreme wisdom if not to establish then at least to prepare the way for lawfulness together with the freedom of the states and by means of that the unity of a morally grounded system of them..." (300) And war also, he says, is "one more incentive...for developing to their highest degree all the talenta that serve for culture." (300)

title: Difference to  Sameness: Gender Ideology in Sexual Science
text:
** Summarial Note **

This article examines the interconnections between gender ideology (specifically, sexologist's shifting statements about sexual sameness
v. difference in man and women) and the broader social context as
sexologists sought professional legitimation and authority. 

They note that it was only with Kinsey that sexologists began to reverse
the typically Victorian claim about the physiological and sexual difference
of men and women -- a difference that sexologists like Havelock Ellis 
perpetuated.  The emphasis on sameness was pursued futher by Masters & 
Johnson.

The most useful part of this article is Irvin's analysis of the weaknesses of 
sexologists' claims about sexual sameness rooted in the purely physiological
level at which sexologists asserted sameness.  Irvine writes: "This sexual essentialism not only locates the totality of sexual expression in the body, but equates sexuality with physiological process.  Modern sexual scientists have simply inverted Ellis' logic that different sexual anatomy should give rise to a separate and unequal social structure.  Now, instead, whatever is physiologically similar is considered the same and therefore equal.  Misunderstandings or anger between men and women should vanish once they understand that their bodies responsd similarly to orgasm; homophobia will cease once heterosxuals recognize that gay people arenot physiologically different."  (21)  In other words, the sexologists' argument perpetuated Victorian and Darwinisitic links between sex difference and social structure, and as a result it also failed to account for the persistence of conflicts that were perpetauted on a social level...they ignored "gender" in other words.   (See 19-22 for analysis of the weakness of sexologists' claims for equality.)

She does not make this point but opens it up:  that these claims for inequality were thus weak, because they could not very well resist the arguments of those who insisted that the self, after all, should not be rooted in sexuality.  E.g. Sapir's article on the "Observations of the Sex Problem in America."

title: Antiromantic Romanticism: Sapir's Critique of American Individualism
text:
p.075-83 Linking Sapir to Arnold & Bourne re Desire for "Genuine Culture"

In this section, H links Sapir with critiques by both Arnold & Bourne to a desire for a "Genuine Culture."

He starts with letter about Bourne published in the Dial after Bourne's death that is very praiseworthy and holds Bourne up as an ideal type.  He had the "will to see things as they are" as well as the "warmth of idealism" [Hungry and Dainty Man combined?] but this "haunts" Sapir.  I.e. this iss not all about warm feelings.  It makes me think of his description of the individual with the will to stand outside of received ideas that he describes i nhis review of Jung's types.  Also noteworthy praise of Bourne's occasional "bitterness" which Sapir says "was in reality but the ken edige of a remorseless sincerity and that  he would have been as eager to cut and change his own soul with it as anyone else's." (76)  This image of cutting into one's soul come up again...

H note that Bouren has been resusciated as a "forgotten prophet" and a "cultural radical" of this ttime, cites Casey Balke's work as well as two books by Vaughan (1997) and Clayton (1984).

For this generation of radicals he cites May culture was important.  Here he is citing May's The End of American Innocence, but also Hegeman (1999) and Manganaro (2002).It was important in the sense that there was a "culture championed by the American patricians and intelletuals, and aspired to by the middle classes," which was "elitist an, evolutionary, unitary, and European." (76)  It was Arnold's def'n of culture, H says.

Now he picks up the point Manganaro makes also: that while Arnold's culture seems the opposite of Boas' relativistic version, this was not the case.  He cites the Stocking point that "concern for integration and holism made Arnold's notion of culture closer in some respects to the modern anthropological notion than was that of Arnold's concempaory, E.B. Tylor. " (76-77)  He then suggests that Bourne's geneartion was gripped by "naitonalistic quest for an American culture distinct from European culture." (77) That was the case atthe same moment that European culture seemed to be destroying itself in WWI and so this was about separating off Americna culture, which was developing arund the th epower of its industry in part.... nationalists felt that Ameican culture might be moving in a different adirection.  "Thus, in addition to conentoinal elitist notions of cultural standareds, discussions of culture in the teens and twneties could draw on a naitonalistic (and ultimatley romantic) conception of culturla plurality, if not on anthropological relativism." (77)

[Notes: Some of this above seems off: to suggest to much similarity between Arnold and Bourne seems dangerous.  Naitonalism was part of this, but also wasn't there really somethign deeper going on related to the apparent destruction of Euroepean humanism?]

Now he goes through Bourne's critique of Arnold.  in essays published in the New Republic, Atlantic Monthly and the Dial.  Bourne critiques an uncritical reception of Arnold in "Our Cultural Humility."  (78) He critiques Arnold for being vaue about culture.  Says it appeals to Americans because it is "quantitative" and "democratic" and critiques the American "acquisitive" attitude toward culoture.  In "Cult of the Best" Bourne also goes after the division between a Lowbrow and highbrow, where culture is "reserved only for the few." (79)

H notes a similarity of Bourne's rhetoric to Sapir's in Culture, Genuine and Spurious which was finished he thinks based on letters to Lowie in 1918, a time when he says "Sapir would regularly have read Bourne." (79)

He starts to go through Culture, Genuine and Spurious again on 79.  He picks  up the themes of 1) harmony - "unified and consistent attitude toward life"; 2) :nothing to do with efficiency or technical progress"; 3) theme where individual is not irrelevant to culture.  (79-80)

Here H beings to emphasize that "cutlural goals or rends are not to be mechanically  imposed upon the members of a culture".." (80)

[Note: H gets close to the bureaucratization them that I want to empahsize at this point, but does not go straight for it.  ]

H ssays he does not know if Sapir took the term "genuine culture" from Bourne, but says it seems likely. He also says they are simialr b/c they express a "mild sympathy" at this stage in 1918.

Now H moves onto linking Sapir with Arnold, which I think s more probelmatic.  This is an argument that Manganaro makes too, that there is a consistent tradition of cultural thinking here betwteen Bourne, Arnold, etc...all rooted in the idea of culture as order posited against disorder/anarchy (see notes on Manganaro in Zotero).

The similarities that H sees are: 1) Focus on a true culture as "internal", though he notes they use the word differnetly.  But for both it refesrs to spiritiual accomplishments.  [Is that enough?]; Opposition to civilization, as external and mechanical.  He compares Arnold and Sapir's disdain for mecanical organizational industrial achievements.  2) Both see "culture as  astimulus to creativity and a challenge to unthinking routine." (81) Again they are settig this against differnet things--Arnold Protestant work ethic; Sapir priggish high-cultural snobishness.  3) "notion of harmonious development" (81) Here he has a harder time because Arnold's harmonious devleopment is in the develpment of traditional high culture whereas Sapir's is "sociological".  (81)

Again on 82 he is forced to note the differences between them, esp. since Arnold would not have been able to hold up a primitive tribe as an ideal of genuine culture the way Sapir does!! He also notes the two idioms in which character/personality are reversed in terms of being good things.  (82)

Nonetheless he makes thesame argment that Manganaro does: "these differneces should not lead us to overlook the fact that Sapir , Bourne, and Arnold particpatedin a shared discourse heavily influence dby romantic thought.  Liek the romantics in general, all three sought a way to recover genuine culture in the post-Enlightenment world of rationality, antitradition, and industiral democracy." (83)

He also attributes to Sapir and Bourne a moment of optimism in circa 1918 that quickly fades. He quotes the last paragraph of Sapir's essay when Sapir predictes that genuine cultures "will grace our lives".  [Note: Ithink that here he has missed the fact that these comments re genuine culture are made in context of prediciton of the dissolution ofthe modern political state and the rise of an international order, which will allow culotures to adhere to regioal locals, smaller, better suited to hte individual see 329-331 in Culture, Genuine and Spurious in Mandelbaum collection]

title: Alain L. Locke: The Biography of a Philosopher
text:
p.005-6 Parents

 

Locke was born on September 3, 1885 to Pliny Locke and Mary Hawkins Locke.  Pliny was a "man of some note" (5).  He was connected to Liberia as his parent's had been missionaries there and had "particapted in the training and education of the indigenous black population before th country's independence in 1947." (3) His father, IshamAfter el, had been a freeborn black person and a teacher at the African American school in Salem, NJ beginning in 1843.  The school had been organized by the Coloured SChool Assocation of Friends.  Ishmael allegedly attended Cambridge University, but there is no proof.  Ishmale met his wife in Liberia, Mathilda Saunders, who was born of a black mother and a white father of GErman origin.

Pliny graduated from the Institute for Colored Youth in Philadelphia and hoped to teach math.  But he volunteered in a Reconstruction school.  and then after decided to enter Howard University Law School, graduating in 1874 at the top of his class.  He gave a speech at the end of his law school on "Equity" an in it "he discussed the millenial possiblity of a reign of justice and reason, themese that he would pass down to his son." (6)  After law school he worked for a man named GEner Oliver O. Howard as a personal secretary, but then could not continue in the job because he refused to give up smoking.  He then joined the civil service in 1876 and taugh tschool for years, becoming a principal in a school in Chester, Penn.  In 1883, he was appointed by the REpublican Administration to be a supervisor in the Philadelphia Post Office with a salary of $600/annually. He was the first black person to hold the job.  Then he married Mary Hawkins after a lengthy engagement.  Eventually he became an inspector in the Civil Service Commission, but then in 1890 he was again teachin gschool.  The authors write: "His career, oscillating between a restricted range of civil service jobs and the 'profession' of a pulic schoolteacher, epitmoizes the economic and social opportunities available to African Americans in this relatively liberal Northern city." (7)

Locke's mom was also an educator.  Mary Hawkins' mother was also involved in setting up school in Liberia.  Mary Hawkins wa s a devoted teacher and took great pride in teaching.  "[E]steem for education permeated the atmosphere in the Lockes' Philadelphia home. This pride was transmitted to their son as a sense of -privilege, or at least a feeling that race and skin color were ultimately irrelevant, or should be, when set against one's ability to learn and teach any manner of subject."  (7)  Mary Hawkins became ultimately devoted to Felix Adler's Ethical Culture movement, "which virutally made a religion of education." (7)

title: Camelot at Yale: The Construction and Dismantling of the Sapirian Synthesis, 1931-1939
text:
p.362  Shift in Sapir's lingusitic interests...

Darnell thinks Sapir's interests in historical linguistics (the kind Boas preferred) declined after his 1929 six-unit classifiation of American Indian languages.  His 1925 and 1933 articles on the phoneme "reached toward more abstract representations of sound patterning, to the acute distress of Boas, who argued thatphonetic detail was lost irretrievably by such a methodology." (362)

(62)

title: The Cosmopolitan Imagination: Franz Boas and the Development of American Anthropology
text:
Notes 3/2012:

Going through Part I that covers Boas' early life

Ch.1

Intro:

* L says Boas was influenced by liberalism of 1848 which she describes as inovling an ideal to "liberate the individual from the social and personal constraints imposed by tradition." (19) And also the German notion of Bildung "as a model of individual cultivation." (15)  (see 15-17)  She also develops a thesis, using some ideas by F. Jameson about how late nineteenth century bourgeoisie had internalized in the family structure the conflicting values that constitued liberalsim, that Boas was seeing himself in the light of conflicting ideals represented by his parents: his mother representing "political engagement, science, idealism, and a source of freedom"; , and his father representing "liberalism, amorphous politics, religious heritage and, eslewhere, practicality material concerns, and authority."  (21)

* Notes that Boas did not seem to have a "positive religious identification" with Judaism and was instead "motivated by anti-semetism and the forced, negative identity it generated." (23)

Building the story of him:

* Nature important to him in his youth.  MOther encourages the children to explore nature, to heighten their powers of observation.  He took himself seriously as a "scientist" very early on.  This involved an interest in "our immediate environmemtn" as he wrote in the Curriculum Vitae he was forced to write when leaving Gymnaasium in 1876-77 (that is inthe archives).  This interest in nature involved an interest in geography in its focus not onpolitics but on physical history, and in geography, mineroalogy, astronomy etc.  An interest in the physical environment.  and alrady an interest in for instance geographical distribution.  Liss notes he made a map of "the geographical distributionn of lichen and mosses near Minden." (26)  Later he picks up an interest in the "comparative" approach to nature and science.  He writes in his CV that all these books about nature: 

had the disadvantage of teaching me to  pay attention to details only, while they awoke no understanding at all for nature in  general.  this may also ahve been due to the fact that I was too young then to be able to ahave an eye for more than details, an aiblity whin in any case I lacked for along time.  Also the fact tha at the time I gathered together an herbarium of vairous kinds of moss hsows how much I was accustomed to pay attention only to details.  Perhaps, however, it shows also that I possessed the inclingation to compare isolated things with each other. (quoted on 27)

So then he takes up an interest in "natural history" -- which Liss defines as "the itnerraltion of things and their structures." (27)  Then Boas writes that "True science...does not consist in describing single plants but in the knowledge of their structure and life in the comparison of all classes of plants with one another." (28) 

* At the point that Boas makes this shift, a shift that he sees as a shift and dividing line in his life.  Liss narrates this bys aying that "science became a source of identity and an escape from turmoil which neither religious affiliation nor the demands of academic success coudl provide." (29)

* Now she goes into his relationship to religious heritage.  Their family was Liss writes Jewish "more for reasons of tradition and family loyalty than faith." (29) Boas father Meier kept the family religious--and Boas's sister Franziska recalled that Boas was raised as orthodox roginally--it was doen mostly optu of respect for his reliugiuos mother.   So they received religious education even thought their family were "free thinkers."  Boas, Liss writes, "saw this combination as a blance between emotional attachment and intellect: 'My parents had broken throught ehs hackles of dogma,' he wrote.  'My father had retained abn emotional affection for the cedremonial of his parental home without allow it to influence his intellectual freedom.'" (29-30)   But Boas also "found religious experimentation important." (30)  He and his sister Toni discussed mysiticism and prayed together and punished each themselves for sinning.  (30) Liss writes that Boas "felt that his lack of religious education made it difficult to understand th power of religious belief for others and blamed his upbrining for the shock of finding that a friend ahered to the 'authority of tradition.'" (30)  And he criticized his "free thinking" mother for "being ignorant of his own spiritual questioning." (30) Here Liss makes an odd turn in her interpretation, stating that Boas "scientific interests helped reconcile these tensions" between religious belief and free thinking.  (30)  In the page that follows, she quotes Boas' letter to his wife about their kids' curiousity about God, and what Boas does there is refer to a kind of general transcendental absolute the awareness of whcih can be comforting--and this was the kind of idealism that was on offer at the time, and to which William James critiques in, I think, The Will to Believe.  But I don't see here science medaiting a tension.  (see 30-31)

 

Chapter 7:

This chapter is key because it is where Liss makes the central points of her thesis, ie 1) that Boas's cosmopolitanism temporaraily intertwined with the interests and the cosmpolitanism of NY elites, 2) that this unity failed because of the divergence of these two forms of cosmpolitanism, ie Boas was interested in science as a means to transcend truth and the NY elites were interested in cosmopolitanism as social ideology of local justification as she calls it, and 3) that cosmpolitanism as a set of ideas focused on the transcendence of particularity could not confront directly the issues of power and local domination with which it was intertwined.

 

First she shows how Boas used his studies to emphasize interconnectedneess, ie her sense of "Anthropology as a Cosmopolitan Project," 315-336. 

Then a key part is her account of how Boas gets placed in NY.  Here she is showing Boas appealing to NY elite cosmopolitanisms and she ends that section 336-348 with a witty metaphor:"...Boas'coming to New York gathered the threads of cosmopolitanism but the knot was much harder to tie." (348) 

She explains the trouble that Boas faces in an important section on Boas' conflict with Jessup, Bumbus and ultimately Osborn at the American Natural History Museum.  Here is wheree the divergence emerges because Bumpus and Jessup find Boas' mode of organization inaccessible to the lay person. Here is where Liss makes her key argument about cosmpolitanism when she writes:

As explicit as thse differences were [ie the conception of the right mode of organization and what anthropological science should be like], Boas fought in 1905 in the more abstract name of science, authority, and independence.  Although to an extent these were masks for the ideological battle which was a stake, it was typical of the cosmopolitan discourse that higher ends, ostensibly not tied to the issues of power or irreconcilably different views, should be the explicit issue. ( 356)

But I think Liss sort of reveals the weakness of her critique of cosmopolitanism and indeed her conception of it vv Boas in this quote.  Because immediately what is at issue here is precisely power and not simply cosmopolitanism but in fact as she puts it "science, authority, and," especially, "independence."  A few sentences later she refers to the factthat what was going on was that Bumpus was exerting "artbitrary authority over Boas' legitimate authority and individualism."  So she is right that power is very much at issue here but if cosmopolitanism is what is being deployed here it is not cosmpolitanism as she has defined it as as an apolitical focus on the "transcendence of particulars" through scientific knowledge.  It is being enlisted to combat the authority of local elites, and that is not insignificant.  By the end of this same paragraph it is even more extreme beecause she quotes Boas writing to Osborn on 6 May 1905 that Bumpus had: "undermined the 'absolute control' and discipline Boas needed 'by constantly countermanding my orders' and running 'the Museum as a military organization, in which the fifrst purpose is subordination...'"!!!!   Anti-Militarism!!!! 

* Key also to Liss's critique is that Boas' cosmpolitanism  and that which he sahred with NY elites was utopian in that it was abstract, ie she says it "relied on an abstract and formal resolution of tensions between locallism and universalism and of difference as if the ocnflicts were essentially problems of communication." (181)

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text:
p.130 Benedict Serrano fieldwork

Benedict apparently did fieldwork the summer before completing her dissertation "The Concept of the Guardian Spirit in North America".   She worked with the Serrano in Southern California, but Handler says it is unclear whether she stayed with them for a long period of time or lived with her moth and sister in Los Angeles. Handler sites Modell, 1983, 169-171; Caffrey 1989, 104-5, 365-66 on this.

title: Economists as Experts: The Rise of an Academic Profession in the United States, 1870-1920
text: p.593 Historicism worked against economists' claim to "expertise" "Any profession's claim to that combination of autonomy vis-a-vis the larger society and authority over certain issues which affect that larger society must rest on a belief that profesisonals, by dint of their special training, have skills, techiniques, and knowledge that the rest of thesociety does not possess....[parg] The economists could professionalize more readily around neoclassical theory than around the doctrines of the historical, inductive school. The historical school's view that economic generalizations were relative and that each economic problem must be approached de novo undermined the academic economists' claim that his superior training made his views more authoratative than thoseof men without that training. Although few members of the historical school advanced the extreme relativist position of which their doctrine was capable, many of that school's American critics identified just htis tendency to eschew generlaized and widely applicable principles as the inductive approach's great weakness." (593)

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.206-207 Sklansky's Account of Social Change

Sklansky gives his account of social change toward modern corporations on 206-207.  It fits with what I understood.  INterestingly, he does not site the Visible Hand.  The other thing I noted is that he said prior to the rise of corporations, which he said had its roots in state "charters" given during the Early Republic, "the prevailing form of business organization in the postbellum period remained the family firm or partnership, owned and operated by its founding entrepreneurs, mainly financed internally from its own profits, engaged in speciazlied production for a local or regional market." (206)

This is useful to me because even though  now it seems obvious before I hadn't understood how business was done prior to the corporate form.  I should read up on this.  He cites Licht, Industrializing America, p.166 and David M. Gordon, Ricahrd Edwards, and Michael REich, Segmented Work, Divided Workers: The Historical Transformation of Labor in the U.S., (1982).

title: The Averaged American: Surveys, Citizens, and the Making of a Mass Public
text:
p. 037-39  Transmission of Culture Idea to Lynds

Igo points out explains how the Lynds decided to pick up the anthropological perspective in the process of trying to understand how to treat the mass of non-qualitative data they had gathered in an objective fashion.  I.e. how to "look at the life of a city objectively." (quoted on 37).  Lynd said " I hit on the idea of trying to do what an anthropologist w'd do if he studied an Amer. community." 

Igo emphasizes that the Lynds did not pick up the specific theories that were around at the time i.e. the American "culturalist" one or the British functional one.  She writes: "...with no training in the field, what Lynd really mean by this was a loose collection of tools and a framework, 'some kind of scheme for throwing familiar things into less immediate, more universal categories.'" (37)  
She then argues, however, that he picked up a few specific tools.  
One of these was the participant-observation method or as he had phrased it the idea of the "naive observer."  (This was common to both).  She notes that they though they qualified as outsiders even though Helen was from Illinois and Rovert from Indiana because they had a New Yorker's perspective, but they also thought a Chinese anthropologists would have been ideal.  

The second thing they picked up was more functionalist and came from W.H.R. Rivers and A.R. Radcliffe Brown.  This was the idea of "fundamental human activities" (or basically the functionalist idea that every society is basically organized in order to solve fundamental functional and economic problems) such that as the Lynds wrote "Whether in an Arunta village in Central Australia or in our own seemingly intricate instituitonal life of corporations, dividends, coming-out parties, praryer meetings, freshmen, and Congress...huaman behavior appears to consist in variations upon a few major lines of human activity." (quoted on 38)
Most generally, however, Igo notes that they picked up the anthropological trope of making the familiar exotic, or more soberly stated looking objectively at the patterns of behavior in modern life just as in "primitive."  They wrote: "To many of us who might be quite willing to discuss dispassionately the quaintly patterned ways of behaving that make up the customs of uncivilized peoples, it is distinctly distasteful to turn with equal candor to the life of which we are a local ornament.  Yet nothing can be more enlighteneing than to gain precisely that degree of objectivity and perspective with which we view 'savage' peoples." (38)

Igo notes that the people who sponsored th eproject at the Institute for Social and Religious Research (see 30 about this) thought the anthropological approach a gimmick and a distraction, but the Lynds meant it seriously.  (38-39)

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
p. 035 - 39   Women's Anthropological Society

Women, mainly due to efforts of Matilda Stevenson, started their own anthropological society in 1885, which lasted for fourteen years.  it's goals were stated in the "the Organization and Constituion of the Women's Anthropological Society" printed in Washington, D.C. in 1885.  O-L analyzes it in detail.  (35-37)  It had as its goal to bring women into science and to encourage their cooperation in the "development of science" (35-36).  She notes that they "did not imagine themselves as innovators in anthropology, but as contributors of special information which would enrich a defined discipline.  They appeared willing to tackle almost anyting but they emphasized the special work they could do as women."  (36)  O-L concludes also that they had "clearly accepted their role as women" (37) and that conflicts between career and marriage would only come later. (37)  Their was a charity dimension to their work and they even invovleved themselves at one point in helping to fund low-rent housing in Washington.  (39)  At a joint meeting with the Anthropological Society, Zelia Nuttall presented a paper on "The Mexican Calednar system" Nuttall was presented by Alice fletcher, the president of the women's group, theat meetin was April 9, 1895.  (38)

title: The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism, The Revised 1920 Edition
text:
# General Notes on Max Weber, **The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism**, trans. Stephen Kalberg (Oxford, 20011), 4/2013:

##Ch. 1: "Religious Affiliation and Social Stratification"

* He starts out with the question why is it that so many protestants are in positions in which they own the means of production, i.e. are employers or capitalists, are more highly skilled etc.? He then notes that this dominance of protestantism is strange, given that the rejection of religious authority is so dominant. Why then have the middle classes (buergerlichen Mittelklassen) allowed this "Puritan tyranny" and even developed a heroic justification of it? (67-69)

* The explanation is not he says is not the economic one: that Protestatns tended to own more cpital, etc... (69)

* The answer -- the "causal relationship" -- he says is "undoubtedly one in which a learned inner quality decides a person's choice of occupation and futher course of occupational development." (70)  -- So here he brings in a cultural explanation.

* Then he pushes this further saying that in the case of Protestants this "inner qualty" has created a "specific tendency toward economic rationalism..." (71)

* This same quality is not presetn in Catholics as he discusses in great detail. (70-72)

* That said, he dismisses the shallow contrast between Catholic's "alleged" Weltfremdheit and the materialism of Protestants. He notes that really there may be an "inner affinity" between "estrangement from the world, ascetism, and church-based piety on the one hand, and the earning of one's living under capitalism on the other... " (72) I.e. he notices that many of the most pious ffigures "came from business-oriented social circles." (73) But then in fact where Calvinism has occured, he notes, there is a surprising linking of piety and busness sense, that is there are many cases in which "a capitalist's virtuoso business sense combines in the same person, and group of persons, with the most intense forms of piety that pentetrate and order that bleiever's entire life." (73) And this has been historically the case he notes where Calivinism has occured. i.e. monks and industrialists were high percentage of those prosletized into the Huguenot churches in France...other examples here on 73-74.

* Given this the link between Protestnatism and capitlaism cannot come from the allged materialism of Protestants, their so-called enjoyment of life's pleasures...rather this "inner affinity" must come from their piety. He notes that Montesqueiu saw the English success in commerce as related to their piety. Is this the link, he asks? If so, he says, we must "attempt to penetrate the characteristic qualities and distinctiveness of the great religious worlds of thought given to us historically in the diverse forms of Christianity." (75)

* But first, he says, he needs to specific the "phenomenon" (i.e. capitalism?) for which he wants to "offer an historical explanation..." (75)

## Ch. 2: The "Spirit" of Capitalism

* The chapter begins the effor to specific the phenomenon. He points out that the nature of this "spirit of capitalism" cannot be stated simply, but nevertheless he will provide a "provisional illustration" to get things started. (76-77)

* The way in which he sets up this object "the spirit of capitalism" is also expalined vv a methodology that he quickly relates on 77. Basically he takes what appears to be a historical approach. The researcher has a particular point of view; that point of view must be identified; and it is not the only one that is possible; the piont then is not to "trap reality in abstract, general concepts" but to form "historical concepts" that "order reality into tangible, causal connections" but which are themselves "unique in character..." (77)

* In his provisional illustratino of the concept, it is Franklin that stands as the basis for this "spirit." He quotes him at length on 77-78. What he finds here is the idea of "the duty of the individual to increase his wealth..." (79) This duty then becoes an "ethically oriented maxim for the organization of life" which is specific to "modern capitalism." (79)

* This notion of "duty" which he says is not at all "self-evident" is in fact the "characteristic of the 'social ethic' of modern capitalist culture." (81)
Here we get some of the first language about a "casing" (or cage?):

> ...the capitalist economic order of today is a vast cosmos into which a person is born. It simply exists, to each person, as a factually unalterable casing (unabaenderliches Gehaeuse) in which he or she must live. To the extent that people are interwoven into the context of capitalism's market forces, the norms of its economic action are forced onto them. Every factory owner who operates in the long term against these norms will inevitably be eliminated from the economy. With the same degree of inevitabilty, every worker who cannot or will not adapt to the norms of the marketplace will become unemployed." (81)

* This then is a form of socialization carried out by "economic selection": "through a process of economic selection, the capitalism that today dominates economic life socializes and creates the economic functionaries that it needs, both owners of businesses and workers." (81)

* Again, the spirit in question here is duty and not merely greed or self-agrandizement. In fact, capitailsm he makes clear has no use for pure greed, or auri sacra fames [the lust for gold.]: "[Modern] capitalism has as little use for *liberum arbitrium* [easygoing] persons as laborers as it has for the businessman fully without scruples in the running of his company, as we have already learned from Franklin." (83) Modern capitalism then is linked with duty and with "a rational use of capital in a managed manner and a systematic capitalist organization of work became the domiannt forces determining the orientation of economic activity." (84)

## Ch. 3: Luther's Conception of the Calling

* The chapter tracks Luther's ideas about the calling, up through Calvinism. The point is that the notion of the calling was itself a historical thing, ie. he's doing a kind of intellectual history here. The "present-day meaning of the term derives from *Bible translations*--indeed *not* from the spirit of the original but from the spirit of the translators." (99) He even notes later on 107 -- when explaining that the link between practical daily life and religious work that was the result of Calvinist thought came about merely as a consequence of the reilgious though of such thinekrs as George Fox (Quakers), or John Wesley (Methodists), etc... -- that his study might be seen as a "contribution to the illumination of the way in which 'ideas' become generally effective in history." (107)

* He traces Luther's thought on the subject, and then points out that Luther's conception of the calling "remained tied to economic traditionalism." (104) What he means is that the idea of the calling that Luther laid out understood the calling -- that is in terms of the work that a given person is tasked with in life -- as a "special command of God" so that wherever an individual is located in the "objective historical order" the work they are doing is the result of the manifestation of God's will and thus they are obligated to perform it. They must therefore "stay" in this calling. Luther develops this view in particular after the peasent uprisings of 1524-25. So his economic traditionalism -- here that means the sense that one should work, but not work in order to achieve one's own economic gain -- is at first rooted in a "Pauline indifference to the world" but then is anchored in his  increasing sense "Divine Providence that identified an unconditional obediance to God." (104)

* The point is then that Luther did not make the link in his understanding of the calling beteween "practical life and religious belief", this link was made by other sects, and in particular Calvinism. Weber cites a passage from Milton's *Paradise Lost* to illustrate the way this link sounded, see 105-106, calling it also a "Puritan turning-to-the world." One finds this same point inn Pocock too. I noted it in my grad school exams for DR.

## Ch. 4 The Religious Foundations of This-Worldly Ascestism

* Weber uses "Puritanism" to refere generally to the "ascetic movement" in Protestanism -- for instance that was opposed to Anglicanism -- that is ascetic Protestantism. (114) Across these movmements -- he counts four: Calvinism, Pietism, Methodism, and what he calls the Baptizing Sects  -- he finds "identical manifestations of the moral organization of life", including "similar ethical maxims" and "highly influential literary devices employed in the organized care of the soul" ... (114) 

* He notes that one could here focus on the "moral practices" of these groups, and disregard their "dogmatic foundations." But this would not be wise. Ascetic morality he says was originally linked to dogmas the "next life." And these ideas of the "next life" he ays "absolutely dominated people's religious thinking at that time. The moral awakening, which considerably influenced the practical life of believers, would not have been set in motion without the overarching power held by the next life over the believer." (115)  However, Weber is after something more specific than the practical significance, he wants to "ascertain which psychological motivations gave direction to the organization of the believer's life and held the individual firmly to it." (115) But to understand these pscyhological motivations -- to understand the degree to which "[p]eople at the time brooded over seemingly abstract dogmas" (115) -- is only understandable when examining the "connection of these dogmas with practical-religious interests." (115)

* He now looks at these main carriers listed above:

1) Calvinism

* Main doctrine is the doctrine of predestination. This was also prevalent in Luther's thought, but declined in importance, whereas in Calvinism it became more important.  The point of this doctrine was u ltimately to promote a profound isolation of individuals from each other. "...the mood of a generation that devoted itself to the randiose consistency of the doctrine of predestination, its melancholy inhumanity must have had one result above all: a feeling of unimaginable inner loneliness of the solitary individual. The question of eternal salvation constituted people's primary life concern during the Reformation epoch, yet they were directed to pursue their life's journey in solitude. Moreover, the destiny they would encounter at journey's end has been unalterably set for them since eternity. And no one could help them." (119)

* This doctrine coincided with the "absolute disappearance of all aids to salvation through the church and the sacraments..." (120) Here is the famous disenchantment thesis I think, because Weber then says that this was part of an "overarching process in the history of religion -- the elimination of magic from the world's occurences (Entzauberung der Welt)..." which in the doctrine of predestination found "its final stage..." (121)

* Psychologically, the consequences of this elimination the sacramental confession removed a "mechanism...that had provided regular 'release' of an emotion-laden consciousness of guilt..." (121) The result was that the "interaction of the Calvinist with his God too place in a deep spiritual isolation." (121) He cites John Bunyan's book Pilgrim's Progress as an esample of this mindset.

* But how did this impact the way in which Calvinism produced a certain orientation to social organization? Here Weber points out that although it would seem paradoxical that a social idea that produced absolute isolation would produce a "superior" form of social organization. (I think he means superior here ironically?? ) It has to do with the new meaning that "brotherly love" was given. The thought goes as follows: The world exists to serve the Glory of God. So God wants the Christian to work in the community in order to serve the Glory of God. So then also the "soical work" that the Calvinist does is to serve God. "It follows that work in a calling is also affected by this aim, and hence this-wordly work stands in service to the community as a whole." (122) The result then is that brotherly love "because it can only be in service to God's glory and not to fulfilly physical desires, is expressed primarily in the fulfillment of the tasks of a calling--tasks that are given by *lex naturae*. In the process, work in a calling becomes endowed with a peculiarly objective, impersonal character, one in the esrvice of the rational formation of the scoietal cosmos surrounding us." (123) 

* Elaborating this further, Weber discusses how such a view could have been supported, i.e. the idea that one was either saved or damned. He traces two ideas both of which support the image he's starting to build about the way calling and work were put forward as an absolute obligation. First, "it became a matter of duty pure and ismple for believers to consider themselves among the elect few and to repel every doubt about their state of grace as nothing more than temptations of the devil." (125) To think otherwise meant inssuficient faith and a lack of God's grace. That is, Weber says, Calvin as opposed to Luther bred "self-confident 'saints'. They were found often in those steel-hard (stahlharten) Puritan merchangts of capitalism's heroci epoch. Indeed, these 'saints' are occasionally found even today." (125) Second, for those who were uncertain, work without rest was recommended as the best way to regain faith. (125)

[So you can really see here his iron cage being built...]

* He contrasts the whole issue of work's relation to salvation by contrasting it with the Catholic notion of good works -- and some Lutherans criticized Calvinism, saying that  what was going on in it was just a (Catholic) doctrine of good works (128). But Weber points out that for the Catholic good works were not rationailzed into a whole system of work that reflected God's glory. The Catholic's good works were isolated acts carried out in specific situations. They were bound up with teh "magic" of the Priest and the sacrament and transubstantiation, and they provided the Catholic with a "relief" from the sense of guilt. But the elimination of the sacrament in Calvinism meant that the Calvinists was meant to "live inserperable from this tension [between his own weakness and God's expectations]." (129) So the Calvinist needed not merely good works, but an "intensification of good works into a system." (129) Weber notes that it is not mistake that the work "methodism" is attached to the "carriers of the alast great reawakening of Puritan ideas in the eighteenth century, just as the term Precisians (which is substantively fully snonymous with Methodism) was used to refer to their [Dutch] seventeenth-century spiritual ancestors." (129) The potin is that now the goal was a "fundamental transformation o fthe meaning of one's entirely life -- in every hour and every action" that had the goal of "raising of believers out of the status naturae [natural state] and into the status gratieae [state of grace]... " (129) The saint here had a transcendent goal, and that is exactly why it's "this-wordly, pratical course was thoroughly rationalized and exclusively domionated by a single point-view: to increase god's glory on EArth. " (129) Weber pushes this further, though, noting that this was understood to be achievable only through "constant reflection" so that with this new rationalized impulse that drove at an "ethical organization of life" the Puritan's took over Descartes' cogito ergo sum... (130)

* He notes that here there was also the basis of its "inner affinity" and "contrast" with CAtholicism. The "inner affinity" being that in order for this rationalization to be possible what had to be destroyed was teh "instinct-driven enjoyment of life" which was also a part of Catholic monasticism. But the contrast was that with the Reformation, whereas the monks insofar as they lived ascetic lives were separated from every-day life, now in the Reformation as the German mystic and popular aruthor Sebastian Frank saw it "now every Christian must be a monk for an entirely lifetime." (132)

* He brings back in Franklin here vv this methodocalism, and specifically Franklin's daily accounting of his moral failings in the tabular-statistical form. These offer a "classic example" Weber says of the extension of the "systemization of a life organized around ethical principles..." (134) He offers a short summation of this whole process that is worth quoting: "As he monitored his own behavior, the later Puritan montioried also the behavior of God and discovered His finger in every single detail of life. Moreover, and in opposition to the teachings of Calvin himself, the Puritan knew why god had decied in htis way or taht way. hence the striving to make life holy and sanctified could almost assume the character of a business. A penetrating Christianization of the entire being was the consequence of this methodicalness now required for the leading of a life organized around ethical principles." (134-5) Calvinism forced this on the believer in a way that Luthernaism did not he says. (135)

title: The Decline of the German Mandarins:  The German Academic Community, 1890-1933
text:
p.005-006  Book will focus on an ideal "type": the "Mandarin"

 

This derives from the referenc eto the Chinese elite.  He means by it "simply...a socila an dcultural elite which owes its status primairly to educational qualifications, rather than to hereditary rights or wealth." (5)

He understands the "mandarin"as a social "type" also typical of what he seems to describe as a kind of "stage" (social historian? what's his relationship to Bielefeld school?).  "They thrive between the primary ararian level of economic organization and  full industrialization.  At that intermediate stage, the ownership of significant amounts of liquid capital has not yet become either widespread or widely accepted as a qualifiaction for social status, and hereditary titles based on land holding, while still relevant, are no longer absolute prerequisites." (7)

He then describes their whoel world view, noteably, in a very generalistic manner, without any evidence, as if this class of peole everywhere will always see things this way and udnerstand themselves in this way.  (7-9)  The base of it seems to be the principle that these mandarins understand their value as beig derived from their education which provides spiritual rewards and that from this base they then set about to increase the influence of themselves over the state and civil society.

What is strange abou thow he describes these mandarins in asuch a generla manner is that he started the whole section by suggesting that he thought that the German madarins represneted a "special case" because of the speed of industrialization in Germany (see bottom p.2)

Out of their attmepts to reinforce their own authority omes a certain idea of the state Ringer suggets: "...mandarin intellectuals tend to develop a complex of thoeries to defend and to increase the elite's share in the management of the state, partly at the expense of the monarch.  Thus they launch a concerted attack upon 'arbitrary' goernment in the name of legality.  they inssist that governmet should no longer be considered a private affair between princes and aristocrats, nor the dominion the ruler's property.  To combat these notions, they create the idea of an abstract and raitonal state which 'runs itself' according ot fixed and logical principles and which stands above both rulers and ruled.  Thier inclination in this respect is natural, for it s they who will utlimately be in a position to interpret the reason and law of the state.  They supply an ever growing portion of the state officials, and the more rational and complicated adminstrative processes become, the more it is the mandarin bureaucrats who come to execute the abstract will of reasonable government in practice." (9)

With respect to legality, he says they are interested in civil liberties, but not in popular participation.  For they are a minority he points out and "[i]n a voting situation...they would carry little weight." (10)

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.162  Limits to Reform Visison

Lathrop in 1919 advised the National Conerence of Social Work in way that shows the commitment to working man and at-home mother.  She wrote: "Let us not deceive ourselves: the power to maintain a decent family living standard is the primary essential of child welfare.  This means a living wage and whole-some working life for the man, a good and skillful mother at home to keep the house and comfort all within it." (quoted on 162).  

Likewise, these groups didn't "publicly advocate birth control or a re-creation of the family in which mothers worked outside their homes and relingquished childrearing to professional day-care centers. .." (162)

title: Pragmatism's Conception of Truth
text:
General Notes

Truths themselves:

* Starts out by saying that pragmatists and "intellectualists" share a common defintiion of truth as a property that "means their 'agreement,' as falsity means their disagreement, with 'reality.'" (112)

* The trouble comes in when one considers what is meant by "agreement" he says.  The "popular notion" he says is to imagine that "a true idea must copy its reality." (113)  But then he notes that that is rarely the case.  Gives the example of a clock.  If we imagine it then we can have a picture of a clock that is a copy of it in our heads.  But then unless we are clockmakers we cannot have a copy of its inner workings.  So a problem emerges on the empricial side.  The idealist response he ntoes is to "seem to say that they [our ideas] are true when they are what God means that we ought to think about that object.  Others hold the copy-view all through, and spoeak as if our ideas possessed truth just in proportion as they approach to being copies of the Absolute's eternal way of thinking." (113)

* The pragmatists sees in the solution of the empiricist and the idealist a common treatement of truth as "essentially an inert static relation." (113)  Ie the idea that when you have a truth "there an end of the matter.  You're in possession; you know; you have fulfilled your thinking destiny.  You are where you ought to e metnally; you have obeyed your categorial imperative; and niothing mroe need follow on that climax of your rational destiny.  Epistemologically your are in a stable equilibrium." (113)

* The pragmatist asks the question which James says is standard (and which he also states in the chapter of Pragmatism "What Pragmatism Means") about "what concrete difference will its being true making in anyone's actual life?" (113)  Or as he puts it also "What, in short, is the truth's cash-value in experiential terms?" (114)  This reveals that "True ideas are those that we can assimilate, validate, corroborate and verify.  False ideas are those that we cannot." (114)  That means that turth is not inherent; rather "Truth happens to an idea.  It becomes true, is made true by events.  Its verity is  in fact an event, a process: the process namely of its verifying itself, its veri-fication.  Its validity is the process of its valid-ation." (114)

* Ideas he says "lead."  "They lead us, namely, through the acts and other ideas which they instigate, into  or up to, or towards, other parts of experience with which we feel all the while--such feeling being among our potentialities--that the original ideas remain in agreement." (114) 

* The point is in another way that "The possession of truth, so far from being here an end in itself" is only a preliminary means towards other vital satisfactions." (115)

* So an idea that is true is one that produces a state of mind and "the truth of a state of mind means this function of a leading that is worth while." (116) It is worthwhile if "its leading to no frustration or contradiction." (117)  If so, then it is also verified.

* So truth is really about "truth-processes": "They turn us towards direct verification; lead us inot the surroundings of the objects they evisage; and then, if everything runs on harmonoiously, we are so sure that verification is possible that we omit it, and are usually justified by all that happens." (117) 

* Such truth processes are also social.  He doesn't emphasize this enough I don't think, but it seems key.  For instance, he says; "Truth lives, in fact, for the most part on a credit system.  Our thoughts and beliefs 'pass', so long as nothing challenges them, just as bank-notes pass so long as nobody refuses them.   But this all points to direct face-to-face verifications somewhere, with-out which the fabric of truth collapses like a financial system with no cash-basis whatever."  Then here comes the social dimension: "You accept my verification of one thing, I yours of another.  We trade on each other's truth.  But beliefs verified concretely by somebody are the post of the whole super-structure." (117) 

Relations of ideas/truths:

* Now James moves away from the "matters of fact" but to the "relations" among them.  Because "Relations among purely mental ideas form another sphere wehre true and false beliefs obtain, and here the beliefs are absolute, or unconditional." (118) This seems to be the level of theory or principle or definition that he's alluding to ie when such relations are true he says "they bear the name of either definitions or of principles." (118)  He gives some examples, liek that "white differs less from gray than it does black..." (118)  or that 2 + 1= 3.  The ideas is that these relationships become true in a unverified way? "The objects here are mental objects.  Their relations are perceptually obvious at a glance, and no sense-verification is necessary.  Moreover, once true, always true, of those same mental objects." (118) I'm wondering if this relates to the kind of ideas Peirce had on the relations between inductive, deductive, and abductive reasoning... for he says; "It is but a case of ascertaining the kind, and then applying the law of its kind to the particular object.  You are sure to get truth if you can but name the kind rightly, for your mental relations hold good of everything of that kind without exception." (118) 

*  The sesnse is that we cosntruct these ideal and abstract theoretical structures.  "We relate one abstract idea with another, framing in the end great systems of logical and mathematical truth, under the respective terms of which the sensible facts of experience eventually arrange themselves, so that our eternal truths hold good of realities also." (118) That sounds a bit like an idealist speaking, but James says here too in "realm of mental relations, truth again is an affair of leading." (118)  There is a marriage of fact and theory james says that is "endlessly fertile" and this is not a process of "special verification" but something that is "alrready true in advance of special verification, if we have subusmed our objects rightly." (118)  So that althouh these relational systems coerce us we are also coerced by the world of things, the "sensible order"  as well.  So that there is a very tight fit between our theories and the world of objects that we "subsume."  We cannot "play fast and loose with these abstract relations..."  (119) "Between the coercsions of the sensible order and those of the ideal order, our mind is thus wedged tightly.  Our ideas must agree with realities, be such realities concrete or abstract, be they facts or be they principles, under penalty of endless inconsistency and frustration." (119) 

And now what does "agreement" mean...

* So James thjinks that up until now the intellectualist and the pragmatist will largely agree.  but the departure in these two viewpoints comes with the question of understanding what "agreement" between ideas and reality mean (that being the agreed def'n of truth.) (119)

* He defines agreement: "To 'agree' in the widest sense with a reality, can only mean to be guided either straight up to it or into its surroundings, or to be put into such working touch with it as to handle either it or somethign connected with it better than if we disagreed." (119)  He adds usefully also that "often agreement will only mean the engative fact that nothing contradictory from the quarter of that raelity comes to interfere with the way in which our ideas guide us elsewhere." (120) 

* So copying reality is important to something being true and "agreeing" with reality.  But it  is not the only essential part: "The essential thing is the process of being guided.  Any idea that helps us to deal, wehther practically or intellectually, with either the reality or its belongings, that doesn't entangle our progress in frustrations, that fits, in fact, and adapts our life to the reality's whole setting, will agree sufficiently to meet the requirement..." (120)

*  Here too the social dimension returns as being key: "All human thinking gets discursified; we exchange ideas; we lend and borrow verifications, get them from one another by means of socail intercourse.  All truth thus gets verbally built out, stored up, and made available for everyone."
