(120)  This leads to a kind of ethic: "Hence, we must talk consistently justa s we must think consistently." (120)

* In agreement again, "leading" is key.  It's the leading that agreement rerpesents that engages the individuadl mind effectively and which also actualizes socia discourse: "Agreement thus turns out to be an affair of leading--leading that is useful becasue it is into quarters that contain objects that are important.  True ideas lead us into useful verbal and conceptual quarters as well as directly up to useful sensible termini.  The lead us to consistency, stability, and flowing human intercourse.  They lead away from excentricity and isolation, from foiled and barren thinking.  The untrammeled flowing of the leading process, its general freedom from clash and contradiction, passes for its indirect verification; but all roads lead to Rome, and in the end and eventually, all true processes must lead to the fact of directly verifying sensible experiences somewhere, which somebody's ideas have copied." (121) 

*

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text:
p. 277-278 Call for focus on complxity of Women's Experience of Proffessionalization

1) Deployment of comparative approach, focus on different experiences in diferent professions... 

2) A focus as practiced by historian of women in 19th century -- e.g. Joan Soctt, Louise Tilly, Virginia Yans-McLaughlin, Thomas Dublin, Tamara Hareven -- and not simply structure the history around the notion of exclusion...

title: The Twentieth Century: A People's History
text:
p. 83 - 84 No Evidence that People Wanted WWI

"The govenrment quickly succeeded in creating such a consensus, according to traditional histories.  Woodrow Wilson's biographer Arthur Link  wrote: 'In the final analysis American policy was determined by the President and public opinion.'  In fact, there is no way of measuring public opinion at that time, and there is no persuasive evidence that the public wanted war.  The government had to work hard to create its consensus.  That there was no spontaneous urge to fight is suggested by the strong measrues taken: a draft of young men, an elaborate propaganda campaign throughout the country, and harsh punishment for those who refused to get in line." (83)

title: Liberalism Repatriated: Prospects of an Anthropology of Antiracism
text:
p. 335-338  Thesis??

Tejani then lays out a kind of difficult to follow analysis of the understanding of difference.  He deploys this idea he has culled from Povinelli that critical rational discourses must refer to some pretheoreticla moral ground.  He discusses this in relation to the contrast between universalism and relativism (which he links only to Montagne and Seneca and not the German romantics).  Both relativism and universalism refer to a pretheoretical moral ground  ...and he wants to use this insight to point out that the practice of anti-racism -- its organizaational deployment -- are more complicated "fuzzier" than are immediately apparent.  I.e. so then he wants to look closer at the practices of anti-racist groups in france... and his "repatriated liberalism" is set against Povinelli's "diasporic liberalism"...as the functioning of anti-racist groups when they go to the center...

title: The Naturalized Female Intellect
text: 00 Summary Note 00 Daston's article analyzes the shifts in conceptions of "women's" nature in relation to shifting conceptions of nature through the Early-Modern to the modern period. Her argument is thus two-pronged. She wants to complicate what she sees as an oversimplified sense of the meaning of nature used in "context-dominanted sciences studies of the last decade" that correctly interpret "naturlaization" as a strategy used to legitimae certain theories, but which "take the sharp boundary between 'nature' and 'cutlure' largely for granted..." (210) Specifically, Daston shows that nature in the early-modern period was not understood in stark contrast to "culture." She traces this in particular through shifting conceptions of "intelligence" which in the early-modern period were heavily moralized and not yet associated with the modern concept of "general intelligence," or the ability to "extracting general principles from experiential particulars..." (221) With the respect to gender, this means that women's nature was described differently over this long period. ...

title: Lost Manhood Found: Male Sexual Impotence and Victorian Culture in the United States
text:
p. 35 Sex/Gender System

Mumford refers to a shift in the "sex/gender  system" as underlying shings in 1920 understanding of male impotence.  He says that he has taken the work from Gayle Rubin's classic article "The Traffic in Women..." But he doesn't really specify what it means.

title: Metahistory: the Historical Imagination in Nineteenth-Century Europe
text: p.013 Notions of the Nature of Historical REality White describes here four different approaches/paradigms (following Stephen Pepper's Worldy Hypotheses) regarding the nature of historical reality. They are the Formist, Organicist, Mechanistic, and Contextualist. Formist: - "aims at the unique characteristics of objects inhabiting the historical field." (14) - explanation complete when object accurately defined. (14) - goal of explanation is to dispel sense of similarity between (unique) historical objects. (14) - found in Herder, Carylyle, Michelet and Niebuhr, Mommsen and Treveylyan. (14) - Formism is "dispersive" not "integrative" (15) Organicist: - integrative and reductive (15) - at its heart a "metaphysical commitment to the paradigm of the microcosmic-macrocosmic relationship; and the Organicist historian will tend to be governed by the desire to see individual entities as components of processes which aggregate into wholes that are greater than, or qualitatively different from, the sum of their parts." (15) - typical of Ranke and "nationalistic" historians like von Sybel, Mommsen, Treitschke, Stubbs,Maitland. (15) - narratives depict "consolidation or crystallization" (15) - they are interested in depicting "integrative" processess, hence their works seem "abstract". (16) - they eschew the search for laws. instead talk of "principles" or "ideas" that "inform the indivdiual processes taken as a whole. These principles are seen as imaging or prefiguring the end toward which the process as a whole tends." but are not causal agents. such principles are not restrictions moreover but actually :guarantors of an essentialhuman freedom. (16) Mechanistic: - also integrative, but "reductive rather than synthetic." (16) - oriented towards the "'acts' of the 'agents' inhabiting the historical field as minfestations of extrahistorical 'agencies' that have their origins in the "scence' within which the 'action' depicted in the narrative unfolds." (17) - agents in historical field "construed as existing in the moddality of part-part relationships, the specific configurations of which are fdetermined by such laws that are presumed to govern their interactions." (17) - Buckle, Taine, Marx, are mechanists. (17) - explanation is complete only when the laws that govern history have been discovered (17) Contextualist: - as a theory of truth a functional conception of meaning of events in historical field (17) - basic idea "events can be explained by being set within the 'context' of their occurrence." (17-18) - colligation is method by which meaning of vents related to context: "In this operation the aim of explanation is to identify the 'threads' that link the individual or institution under study to its specious sociocultural 'present.'" (18) - this method is in almost every historian, but is dominant in Burckhardt. (18) - Contextualist approach combines the dispersive impulse of Formism and the integrative impulse of Organicism. (19) - But its truth claims seem modest. Indeed it is an "ambiguous solution to the problem of constructing a narrative model of the processes discerned in the historical field. "Flow" of history has a "wave-like" form.

title: The German Idea Of Militarism : Radical and Socialist Critics, 1866-1914.
text:
p.013-016 Goal of Book

He notes that militarism today is mostly important for political "rhetoric" rather than political theory.  He notes that "it was resistance to militarsm that justified British and American participation in two world wars, not to mentionall the little wars since, down to the Fallands and the Gulf.  'Militarism' describes not just a pathological state of affairs; it is also the liberal's call to arms." (13)

His motivation is to stop trying to give militarism theoretical menaing and simply t o "go back to its origins and discover how it came to possess the vairous and mutually contraditory meanings it does." (13)

His interest then will fall on the way the diversity of definitions of militarism in imperial German indicated the rise of civil society.  He will look at what wa smeant by militarism and what (political/rhetorical) purposes it served.

Part I, shows rise of an "anti-militarist" tradition i nGermany in particular in the 1890s, a decade in which mass politics emerged and Social Democracy became the "only major political foce to carrythe anti-miliatairst banner." (15)  Karl Kautsky, the "doyyen" of the party's orthodoxy, tried to construct a political theory out of this tradition.

y

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text:
p.050 -  51 Restructuing of Anthropology at Turn of Cent.

Two dimensions of restructing.  

1) Formation of AAA and its journal the American Anthropologist.  Debate about
memership.  "the Washington anthropologists wanted an inclusive membership policy for the new organization, whle Boas preferred one that 
limited membership to professionals.  McGee and the other members of the
Washington group prevailed until the organization created an Executive Committee in 1912, which marked the beginning of a shift in the blanace of power in the profession from individuals employed by the government and
museums to those with academic credentials and university affiliations., see
Stocking 1958, 283-5.  (50)

2) Emergence of graduate training programs at Harvard, Columbia, chicago, The University of Pennsylvania, and the University of California at Berkeley.  By 1912, 20 doctorates given to twenty men.  Next two decades a fourfold increase.  By 1928, fifty-three men and nine women had received PhDs in anthropology.  Harvard and Columbia leading.  24 men had PhD's from Harvard; Boas had trained 15 men and 7 women.

title: The Limits of Experience and Explanation: F.A. Lange and Ernst Mach on Things In Themselves
text:
Notes from annotations from reading Sept 2014:

 

Annotations Summary of
Scott_Edgar__The_Limits_of_Experience_and_Explanation_-_FA_Lange___Ernst_Mach_on_Things_in_Themselves-libre.pdf.

PAGE 2:

Note
"Problem with Helmholtz and Lange: they maintained 1) that we can
infer the existence of things-in-themselves as the cause of our
sensations , and 2) that these inferences are justified by a
physiological propensity toward to " structure our representations as
causes and effects. " (2) the two undercut each other.because as a
result of 2, our inference vv causality and things-in-themselves  is
not justified, because is simply a result of our own physiognomy, not
the things-in-themselves. (2)"

Underline
"The source of the problem was Kant’s idea of things in themselves,
that is, objects considered independently of our experience of them.
Neo-Kantians like Lange and Hermann von Helmholtz wanted to maintain
that we can infer the existence of things in themselves as the causes
of our sensations, and thus as the explanation for why we have any
sensations at all. But at the same time, that inference was ruled out
by their view that our causal inferences are justified by a
physiologically conditioned instinct to structure our representations
as causes and effects. Lange, Helmholtz and others recognized this
incoherence in their views, and over the course of the 1860s and 1870s
attempted to articulate fully consistent accounts of things in
themselves. To varying degrees, they failed. 4 These Neo-Kantians’
problems with things in themselves were fully solved only by Ernst
Mach, in the context of the uncompromisingly austere theory of
knowledge he developed in the early 1880s, in his 1882 ‘The Economical
Nature of Physical Inquiry’ and his 1884 Contributions to the Analysis
of Sensations."

Underline
"But Mach also articulated a coherent denial that things in themselves exist."

PAGE 3:

Underline
"‘the world is our sensation’ (Mach 1898 [1882], 209)."

Note
"He will partly try to answer why Helmholtz and Lange persisted in
asserting the logical contradiction he explains before. (3)"

PAGE 4:

Underline
"Lange agreed with Kant that philosophy investigates knowledge by
investigating the subjective conditions that give rise to it. But he
also thought that investigation was a matter of empirical psychology.
Helmholtz and Lange argued that the physiology of the sense organs in
particular confirmed the broad outlines, while revising the details,
of Kant’s theory of knowledge."

Underline
"Lange developed a philosophical account of knowledge that was
explicitly indebted to the physiological research of both Mu ̈ller and
Helmholtz."

Underline
"Lange claims that the basis of causal inference is the ‘concept of
cause’. On his account, that concept turns out to be nothing but a
physiological disposition to structure our appearances as, for
example, following one another without exception, or so that one set
of appearances represents a causal mechanism and another set
represents the phenomena that mechanism produces. As he puts it,
‘[p]erhaps someday the basis of the idea of cause may be found in the
mechanism of reflex action and sympathetic excitation; we should then
have translated Kant’s pure reason into physiology . . . ’ (Lange
1866, 263/1873–5, 2:44/1925, 2:211)."

PAGE 5:

Underline
"For Mach, causal knowledge has authority for us precisely because it
is biologically primitive in this sense: we could no more choose not
to structure our representations causally than we could choose not to
digest food."

Underline
"These accounts of the basis of causal inference have an important
consequence: they restrict the domain in which we can know causal
relations and, consequently, the domain in which causal inferences can
extend our knowledge. Lange understands this perfectly well. He
acknowledges that since the concept of cause is a disposition to
structure our appearances in certain ways, and since those appearances
are ultimately composed of sense- perceptions, we can know causal
relations only within experience. That is, the valid application of
the concept of cause is restricted to experience. Conversely, we
cannot know causal relations among things that exist beyond our
experience and are not the objects of any possible sense- perception.
These causal relations and inferences would have, Lange insists, ‘no
meaning’ for us (Lange 1866, 264/1873–5, 2:45/1925, 2:212). Thus, we
cannot claim to know causal relations between things in themselves.
Even causal relations between appearances and things in themselves
would extend beyond the limits of experience. Lange must thus deny
that we could ever claim to know that things in themselves cause
appearances. The same consequence follows for Mach: his account of
causal inference entails that we could never know that sensations are
caused by things in themselves."

PAGE 6:

Underline
"Lange argues that our use of the concept of cause within the domain
of appearances necessarily leads to the idea of something beyond
appearances and so beyond experience, a world of things in
themselves."

Underline
"Lange’s discussion of the distinction between nature and appearance
has the effect of introducing an additional component to his account
of the concept of cause: the idea that the concept imposes on us a
demand for explanations. For Lange, when we use the concept of cause,
we feel a demand for an explanation whenever we are faced with new
phenomena. We feel this demand ubiquitously (‘above all’ he says) in
the empirical world, because the demand, no less than the concept of
cause that produces it, is ‘conditioned by our organization’ (Lange
1866, 268). That is, Lange thinks that when we are presented with one
set of representations, we are physiologically disposed to take those
representations as phenomena that need an explanation, and then to
seek further representations that serve to explain the first set."

Underline
"Lange thinks this physiological disposition ultimately furnishes us
with the idea of things in themselves."

Underline
"we inevitably move beyond considering this or that particular
appearance and come to consider the totality of all our appearances as
a single set of representations."

PAGE 7:

Underline
"But once we do that, the disposition to structure our representations
as phenomena and their physical causes leads us to conceive of the
totality of our appearances as something that needs an explanation."

Underline
"This is the stronger of the two strains in Lange’s account of things
in themselves. It involves more than just the claim that the concept
of cause allows us to establish where the limits of our appearances
are."

PAGE 8:

Underline
"But even if we cannot know anything else about things in themselves,
we can at least know that they exist. Thus on this strain of Lange’s
thinking, since the concept of cause disposes us physiologically to
conceive of things in themselves as things that would, if they
existed, explain our appearances’ existence, it ultimately entitles
him to claim that things in themselves exist."

Underline
"This argument depends on an abductive inference: since things in
themselves would be the best (only?) explanation for our appearances’
existence, and since our appearances in fact exist, we may posit
things in themselves as the explanation for our appearances’
existence."

Note
"Explanation of why Lange's account of cause as a proof that
things-in-themselves exist is a problem... (8)"

Underline
"However, in at least one sentence of Lange’s 1866 discussion of
things in themselves, he suggests a weaker strain of thinking that
avoids this problem."

Note
"Weaker claim vv. Ausakity as proof of things in themselves avoids the
problem. (8)"

Underline
"But Lange says that things in themselves so conceived are ‘unknown’
to us (Lange 1866, 268). Thus while the concept of cause might, as a
physiological disposition, produce the concept of things in themselves
in us, the concept of things in themselves nevertheless remains a
concept ‘about which we do not know whether it has any significance
beyond our experience’ (Lange 1866, 268)."

PAGE 9:

Note
"In second edition, Lange does not solve the problem. (9)"

Underline
"The revisions have the effect of eliminating the stronger strain’s
inference that things in themselves exist from the second edition’s
version of ‘Kant and Materialism’."

PAGE 10:

Underline
"Second, immediately following the paragraph from which he deletes his
earlier claim to know that things in themselves exist, he inserts this
passage: We do not, then, really know whether a thing in itself
exists. We know only that the logical application of our laws of
thought leads us to the notion of an entirely problematical something
that we assume as the cause of the appearances as soon as we have
recognized that our world can only be a world of representation."

Underline
"However, while Lange eliminates any equivocation from the second
edition version of his Kant chapter, he decisively undermines those
efforts in ‘The Standpoint of the Ideal’, the final chapter of the
second edition of History of Materialism. Among other aims in ‘The
Standpoint of the Ideal’, Lange wants to distance his views from a
form of idealism (such as Fichte’s, or perhaps Hegel’s), according to
which our knowledge and the world that is its object are nothing but
products of our mind’s activity. To distinguish himself from this form
of idealism, Lange wants to maintain that there is a world that exists
independently of our selves and that the world presents us with facts
that are beyond our control. Thus in the final chapter of his book,
Lange once again finds himself facing the question of the existence of
things in themselves."

PAGE 12:

Underline
"But here in the second edition he is far more clear, and he offers a
different account of the feature of our appearances that is at issue:
he is concerned with the relations between our appearances that are
not under the control of our will. However, besides that difference,
the argument from ‘The Standpoint of the Ideal’ differs from the
argument of the strong strain in the first edition only to the extent
that it clarifies and makes more explicit the form of the argument
that in the first edition Lange had left largely implicit. Lange now
says explicitly that a certain feature of our appearances furnishes us
with ‘evidence’ for the existence of things in themselves. But no less
than in the first edition, for Lange it is nothing but the concept of
cause that disposes us to regard a set of representations as demanding
an explanation, and then to seek an explanation that satisfies that
demand. Consequently, if we accept that things in themselves explain
certain relations between our appearances (e.g. the ones that are not
subject to our will), by Lange’s account we commit ourselves to the
view that things in themselves stand in a causal relation to those
relations between our appearances. That is, for Lange, we commit
ourselves to the claim that things in themselves cause those relations
between our appearances."

Note
"So why is Langevso dependent in the idea that we can know that things
in themselves exist? (12)"

PAGE 13:

Underline
"For Lange, we come to have the concept of things in themselves,
because the concept of cause imposes on us a demand to explain certain
features of our appearances (e.g. their existence). We thus form the
concept of that which would, if it existed and we could know it,
explain that feature of our appearances. But at the same time, the
concept of cause entails that we could never claim to know the
explanatory relation between things in themselves and appearances.
That follows from Lange’s views that explanatory relations are (or are
a class of) causal relations and that the basis of our knowledge of
causal relations restricts that knowledge to causal relations within
experience. Lange’s account of the concept of cause thus imposes on us
a demand for explanations that outstrips the domain in which we can
have causal or explanatory knowledge. It imposes on us a demand for
explanations that we could satisfy only with causal knowledge we can
never have. Of course, it is possible to maintain unequivocally that
we can never have knowledge of the causal relation between things in
themselves and appearances, and thus that there are certain features
of our appearances that we can never explain. This is just what Lange
wants to maintain on his weaker strain. But while this view is
logically consistent, it is an unstable position in at least one clear
sense. The demand for explanations imposed on us by the concept of
cause does not entail that we must attempt to satisfy it, but it does
motivate such an attempt. It thus provides Lange with the motivation
to posit things in themselves as the explanation for certain features
of our appearances, and so to commit himself to an explanatory, and
thus for him causal, relation between things in themselves and
appearances. To be sure, there is no inconsistency in the idea that we
could face demands for explanations we could never satisfy. That might
well be our epistemic lot. But there is a tension in that idea that
helps explain why Lange never managed to eliminate from his
discussions of things in themselves the problematic claim that things
in themselves stand in a causal relation to appearances. Even if it
was possible for him to maintain his weaker strain unequivocally, as a
matter of fact he was unable to resist the motivation (he thinks) the
concept of cause provides to posit things in themselves as the
explanation for certain features of our appearances."

Note
"Mach'a solution: he avoids the tension that Lange falls into because
he flatly says that things in themselves do not exist. (13)"

PAGE 14:

Highlight
"the rough tactile elements we come to associate with bark, the bright
citrus odour we associate with pine and so on. That complex of
sensations is relatively stable: that is, most of the relations
between its constituent sensations are relatively constant. For Mach,
that constancy is partly a fact about relations between elements that
is independent of our efforts to organize our experience. But it is
also partly a function of our attending to certain relations between
elements and ignoring others, in order to organize our experience in a
way that serves our purposes. In any case, Mach thinks, we come to
regard that relatively stable complex as the representation of a body.
But strikingly, for Mach the body is nothing but this relatively
stable complex of sensation-like elements. Thus, for Mach, the world
does not consist of substances that exist independently of our
sensations and that cause our sensations by affecting us. Rather, as
he puts it, ‘the world is our sensation’ (Mach 1898 [1882], 209). 11"
and Note
"Mach's understanding of perception..."

Underline
"Mach thinks we make causal inferences because we are physiologically
disposed to structure our representations as causes and effects.
Further, Mach thinks that explanatory relations are essentially causal
relations. Thus for Mach no less than for Lange, if we commit
ourselves to explanatory relations between things in themselves and
sensations, we thereby commit ourselves to causal relations between
them."

Highlight
"Mach does not maintain that we face a demand for explanations that
outstrips the causal knowledge that is available to us, and thus a
demand for explanations that we can never satisfy."
and Note
"Like Lange does..."

PAGE 15:

Underline
"For Mach, discovering these relatively constant relations allows us
to marshal our experience in ‘economic and perspicuous’ order (Mach
1898 [1882], 210–1)."

PAGE 16:

Highlight
"Lange argued that the concept of cause furnishes us with the concept
of things in themselves, because it imposes on us a demand to explain
our appearances’ existence."
and Note
"Anther good summary of Lange's position..."

Highlight
"But from Mach’s perspective, this is confused. For him, we need an
explanation only if our experience has in some way contradicted our
expectations of it. But what expectations could be contradicted by the
fact that we have any appearances at all? For Lange, appearances are
themselves elements that constitute our experience as a whole. Thus,
we could not have any experience without at the same time having
appearances and so could never have experiences that lead us to expect
an absence of appearances. So for Mach, in contrast with Lange, there
is simply nothing to explain about the fact that we have appearances.
Thus, Lange must be wrong that the concept of cause furnishes us with
the concept of things in themselves as the concept of that which
would, if they existed, explain our appearances’ existence."
and Note
"And the contrast between Mach and Lange: for Mach appearances are
simply that stable organzation of elements of sensations. There s
nothing to explain and this no need for the concept if cause until
something diverges from our expectations about the origins of those
sensations. (16)"

PAGE 17:

Highlight
"However, for Mach even if we need to explain constant relations
between our appearances that are not subject to our wills, we do not
give that explanation by positing things in themselves. Rather, for
Mach we provide that explanation the same way we provide any
explanation – by discovering the relatively constant relations between
elements that let us bring our expectations into line with experience.
13"
and Note
"Interesting, so given that Mach denies that things in themselves
exist, how would he account for permanence in appearances, or the
persistence of appearances independent of our individual will? We
would so do. Y discovering the "relatively constant relations""

PAGE 18:

Highlight
"With luck we would discover the common features of the constant
relations that are subject to our wills and common features of those
that are not subject to our wills. We could then compare the common
features of these different relations, to discover how they differ. Of
course, these ‘common features’ are themselves just certain
higher-order similarity relations. So, our task would be to discover
the higher-order relations that let us distinguish which lower-order
relations are, and are not, subject to our wills. We could then begin
to predict which lower-order relations are subject to our wills and
which are not. In fact, for Mach we are already at least beginning to
attend to just these higher-order relations when we designate some
complexes of sensations as ‘bodies’ and others as ‘ego’. ‘Bodies’ are
just those complexes containing relations between their constituent
sensations that are (on the whole, if not absolutely) less subject to
our wills than many of the relations between constituent sensations in
the complex each of us calls ‘ego’."
and Note
"The task would be to explain which sensations arevsubjectbto our
wills ans which are not. (18)"

Note
"Once the difference between these sensations has been established
there is no more to explain. Noting the contradiction, and then moving
from there to the idea that things in themselves exist as causes of
those sensations or appearances that are beyond our will, would be
just an overextension of our desire to posit causes, which has
psychological origins. (18)"

PAGE 19:

Highlight
"In a context where German-speaking philosophers were responding in a
variety of ways to a rapid accumulation of results in experimental
psychology and the physiology of the sense organs, Mach’s views of
knowledge from the 1880s are in certain central respects continuous
with the psychologistic epistemology that Back to Kant Neo-Kantians
sought to articulate over the course of the 1860s and 1870s."
and Note
"The context for late 19th century neo Kantianism is this experimental
psychology. (19) also interesting that this might be the common link
to Tarde, where Tarde includes the psychological where Durkheim
excludes it. (19)"

PAGE 20:

Note
"Author suggests that Mach is in fact not a neo-Kantian because he
does not belive that things-in-themselves exist. (20)

And yet: "But the Back to Kant figures never took their Kantianism to
consist in their (muddled) commitment to the existence of things in
themselves. Rather, they took their Neo-Kantianism to consist in
precisely the epistemological commitments they shared with Mach: the
views that the philosophical foundations of scientific knowledge must
be laid by investigating what Kant called the subjective conditions of
knowledge, and that empirical psychology and the physiology of the
sense organs provide us with the scientific means of carrying that
investigation out." (20)"

Highlight
"Rather, Mach differs from the Neo-Kantians in his attitude towards
his own relation to Kant and to philosophy in general. Back to Kant
figures such as Lange and Helmholtz explicitly and emphatically
presented their psychologically and physiologically informed
epistemologies as confirming, revising and continuous with an
essentially Kantian philosophical project. They viewed empirical
psychology and physiology of the sense organs as a means of
reconciling natural science with a specifically Kantian vision of
philosophy (in contrast with the opposition between science and
philosophy they associated with Hegel). 15 In contrast, Mach shows
almost no interest in presenting his views as continuous with Kant’s.
In fact, Mach has no interest in presenting his views as philosophy.
In the preface to his Analysis of Sensations, Mach flatly denies being
a philosopher (Mach 1896 [1884], vii). He conceives of himself as a
scientist, and of his epistemology as a way of arranging science ‘in
economical order’ (1898 [1882], 197), justified not by abstract
philosophical argument (much less by appeals to philosophical
pedigree), but by its usefulness in, for example, providing a unified
foundation for physics and psychophysics."
and Note
"Importantly, though, Mach did not see his thought as extending Kant's
philosophy. Lange and Helmholtz did. (20)"

title: The Claims of Culture: Equality and Diversity in the Global Era
text:
Notes July 2011

Preface

* She wants to critique a "social dynamic" in which "global integration is proceeding alongside sociocultural disintegration, the resurgence of various separatisms, and international terrorism." (viii)  This has happened before--a  reaction against "economic, cutlural, and social homogenization" by those who want to "guard the autonomy of their waxs of life and value systems." (viii) These contemporary movements have been identified under a series of phrases which she lists: "struggles for recognition" by Charles Taylor, Nancy Fraser, and Axel Honneth; "identity/difference movements" by Iris Young, William Connolly; and "movements for cultural righst and multicultural citizenship" by Will Kymlicka.  (viii)  B's position is that the presence of these movements--this "strange multiplicity" she calls it borrowing a phrase from James Tully--is that there has been a

premature normativism in much contemporary political theory, that is, an all-too-quick reification of given group identities,a  failure to interrogate the meaning of cultural identity, and a turning away from the sociological and historical literature on these topics, which are dominated by methodological 'constructivism.'  This premature normativism has reuslted in hasty policy recommendations that run the risk of freeying existing group differences. (viii-ix)

She thinks this normativism->reification of culture is wrong headed because she belives that "cultures are constitued through contested practices" (viii).  She does not believe in the "purity of cultures, or even the possibility of identifying them as meaningfully discrete wholes."  She thinks of cultures as "complex human practices of signification and representation, or organization and attribution, which are internally riven by conflicting dialogues with other cultures." (ix) She also believes that in many cultures there is a "degree of internal differentaiton" that makes the dialogue with other(s) an internal process.  Her preferred model is then a "deliberative democratic model that permits maximum cultural contestation within the public sphere, in and through the institutions  and assocaitons of civil society." Thus there are "certain kinds of legal pluralism" that she believes to be consistent with deliberative democratic approaches.  And in general she thinks that moral and political universalism is not necessarily incompatabile with "democratic negotiation of certain forms of difference." (xi) 

* In this book, as opposed to Situating the Self, she is focusing on the problem of reconciling certain forms of moral and political universalism with a sensitivity to difference within deliberative democratic ideals...but the locus of difference are certain lifeways (ie cutlure) not gender. (xi)

 

1. Introduction on the Use and Abuse of Culture

* At the book's core is a critique of the culture concept as she thinks it has come into use.  She gives a brief narrative of the concept's origin from p. 2-5.  She uses the usual suspects: Kultur v. Civilization, drawing on Herder and so on, but also noting that the FRankfurt school emigres also apppplied it to mass society and that these ideas were introduced in the United States.  Against this background however she notes that looking at contemporary discussion what she is struck by is the "obsolence of the old, value-laden contrast between Kultur and Zivilisation."  Instead, she notes that what dominates is "an egalitarian understanding of culture drawn from the social anthropology of Bronislaw Malinowski, Evans Pritchard, Margaret Mead, and Claude Levi-Strauss, who were critical of European cultural presumptions." (3).  She notes that their conception of cutlure is as an autonmous totality: "the totality of social systems and practices of signification, representation, and symbolism that have an autonomous logic of their own, a logic separated from and not reducible to the intentions of those through whose actions and doings it emerges and is reproduced." (3)  What she sees here is that the conflict between civilization and culture is largely excluded from this discussion of culture, which she later calls the "reductionist sociology of culture." (4)  The old civilization/Kultur conflict in the Frankfurt school created some concern about mass culture, but this is gone in these new works.  That is, the binary conflict that made culture "a term of critique in opposition to the concept of civilization" is gone.(3)  Instead, the notion of autonmous culture is linked to the notion of identity. (3)  She sees this as an alliance between French structuralism and British social anthropology.

* Contemporary politics then fromher point of view is often a strange mixture of "the anthropological view of democratic equality of all cultural forms of expression and the Romantic, Herderian emphasis on each form's irreducible uniqueness..." (3)  There is an assumption that everyone has some culture and that these cultures should be perpetuated.  Conservatives draw on this idea to argue that peoples shuould be kept separate, and as with Huntington's clash of civilizations thesis, they imagine conflicts that "closely follow cultural-identity rifts..." (4)   

* She quotes Terence Turner on the critique of the epistemological assumptions of this reductionist view of culture.  The Turner article is "Anthropology and Multiculturalism: What is Anthropology that Multiculturalists Should BE Mindful Of It?" Cultural Anthropology 8 (no.4): 411-429.

* The point of all this though is to defeend what she calls "social constructivism against attempts in normative political theory that reify cultural groups and their struggles for recognition." (5) Social constructivism contains as she understands it includes a conception of culture that she describes from 5-11.  Basically, her view rests on the experience of culture as one that is mediated by traditions of stories, rituals, symbols. tools and forms of material living that are shared, but most importantly are also contested.  So that "From within, a culture need not appear as a whole; rather, it forms a horizon that recedes each time on approaches it." (5)  Views of cultural wholes in  her mind are the product of the "social observer"--the 18th century chronicler, the 19th century "general, linguist, or education reformer," the 20th century athrokpolgoist or secret agent and so on.  (5)  These people impose often "along with local elites" a vision of the culture as coherent and unified.  (5)  She gives a useful example of the way colonial agents along with certain local elites defined the practice of sati--a woman mounting the funeral pyre of her hsuband--as a cultureal practice.  (5-6)  So  her view o fuclture is that it is always "narratively contested"--here think back to her sense that the civilization culture binary was a loss. (6).  She explains why she thinks culture is contested--because we expalin what we do in lanaguage and narratives and b ecause these narratives are evaluated... (6-7)

* Sociological constructivism does not see cu;tural diffences as "shallow or somenow unreal or 'fictional.'  Cultural differneces run very deep and are very real.  The imagined boundaries between them are not phantoms in derganged minds..." (7)  The point is that one cannot take "groups' and individuals' cultural narratives at face value."  Intead, and here she is a bit vague, "to explain human behavior, the student should seek to understand the totality of circumstances of which culture is an aspect." (7)  ie culture is jsut one dimension of experience... but this is imprecise...what kind of power does it have then and in relation to what other factors? 

* She states clearly that she dislikes waht she calls "strong multiculturalism" or "mosaic multiculturalism" on p.7-8.  By this she means the idea that "human groups and cultures are clearly delineated and identifable entites that coexist, while maintaining firm boundaries, as wold pieces of a moasic." (8)

* She wants to view cultures as "constant creations"--part of a process of self construction: "A self is a self only because it distinguishes itself from a real, or more often than not imagined, 'other.'" (8)  She thinks that both on an individual and collective (national) level it is hard to "accept the 'other' as deeply different while recognizing his/her fundamental human equality and dignity." (8)  In this way, mosaic modernism avoids the key problem.  Her view is that democratic equality in a given society rests not on preserving group mosaics but on creating "impartial institutions int he public sphere and civil society where this struggle for the recognition of cultural differences and the contestation for cutlurla n arratives can take place without domination." (8)

* She is highly supicious of nationalist ideologies then because she thinks that the "reject the constitutive 'otherness' at the source of all culture; more often than not,t hey seek to 'purge' the culture of its impure or foreign elements and thus render it whole again." (8)  She refers there to Bhabha's essay "DissemiNation" in his The Location of Culture.  She gives an example of the process whereby nations rejection culturla otherness in Ataturk's Turkey... (9-10) 

* In layzing out, how she will think about the "cultural politics of capitalist societies," she says her position relies on the "normative principles" that she laid out in Situating the Self.  She is here building on Habermas' notion of communicative or discourse ethics and she laid out the norms of universal respect and egalitarian reciprocity.  These terms are only valid she says "only if all who would be affected by their consequences can e participants in a practical discourse through which the norms are adopted." (11)  These nroms she insists already undergird "practices of discursive argumentation" and must be "presupposed in some for for practical discourses."  (11) In discourses, these norms are validated intersubjectively hence she defines discourses as "procedures of recursive validation through which abstract norms and principles are concretized and legitimized." (12)  Claims that we respect each other must be validated and squared with "practices and judgements" that may be experienced by one or another person as disrepect.  So practical discourses "in the broadest sense, include moral discourses about universal norms of justice, ethical discourses about forms of the good life, and political-pragmatic discourses about the feasible."  (12) She conceives of these processes as "dialogic" and their goal is to "concretize and contextualize the meaning of such norms" as well as to "determine what kind of problem is being debated." (12) AND also she instistus, and this seems imortant, that participants must not just have an understanidn gof the norms but a "situational understanding of these norms' intended application." (12) Here comes the complex part about multicultural societies then...she instists that it is in this realm of situational  understanding that in such societies their is a need for negotiation, siince "What kind of practice we think a specific cutlural practice is--religious or aesthetic, moral or legal--will determine which norms we think should apply to it." (12)  

* In relation to this idea that situational understandiing requires negotation she again she gives an example, noting that the British colonial administration in India sought to apply the lessons of its history and the priiinciple of religious tolerance, meaning that "[a]s long as a practice was considerd central to one's religion, some tolerance was to be shown.  But it if twas not religious but merely cultural, in the sense that members of the same religion felt free to engage in it or not, colonial adminsitrators presumed that it should be less protected from colonial intervention, especiallz if the practice in quesiton could also be consdiered odious and offensive to human dignity." (12) The point is not that they were wrong or that the distinction is wrong, and she notes that many liberal democracies still employ this kind of distinction, but rather to point out that "very often we do not know what type of practice is in question, for we do not share ac ommon understanding of the disputed practice itself."  Ie is it religious, cultural, or morality she asks? And she notes it can also be that the meaning of such practices is shifting and changing as with the veiling practices of different groups of muslim women.  (13)  Ie practices are constnatly being resignified.  A practical discourses she says in a process "through which such resignificants can unfold."  She believes and hopes that " [a]ttention to such processes of resignification and narrative retelling will alter the line between the universalizable content of moral discourses and the ethical discourses of the good life without erasing it altogether."

The above is key!!!

* Now she revises her view of universalism...  she says that the likes of Kant and Rawls had a "subsitutionalist" universalism that proceeded from a "certain defintiion of human agency and rationality." (14) These models she says either limit practical discourse to what an individual "can will or chose, in conjunction with allo, to be a universal law" or to principles of a just society that "rational agents, placed behind the epistemic strictures of a 'veil of ignorance,' would agree." (14)  These theories are useful she instsits because they are "able to provide a more determinate or concrete content of choice and deliberation." (14)  Yet that concreteness comesa t the cost, she insists, of "abstracting away from the identity of individuals involved." (14)  So "[s]ubstitutionalist moral theories view individuals as generalized, not as concrete, others." (14)  Instead, Benhabib proposes what she calls a interactive universalism.  This privileges all people as "potential moral conversation partners." (14) and does not privilege philosophers or other certain observers.  So it does not limit the "boundaries of moral disocurse" to only rational individuals.  One must rather leanr the "whoness" of others "only through their narratives of self-identification." (14) This kind of universalism is central to multicultural societies because cultural narratives are crucial to the constitution of the self... (14)

* Her conception of interactive universalism rests on her conception of self-formation as sometime that is medaited through multiple narratives provided by multiple cultural backgrounds that the individual dialogically weaves together to create a personal identity.  She describes this on 15.  She mentiions Heidegger  Here is how it sounds: "To be and bcome a self is to insert onself into webs of interlocution; it is to now how to answer when one isaddressed and to now hot to address others.  Strictly speaking, we never really insert ourselves, but rather are thrown into these webs of interlocution, in the Heidegerrian sense of 'throwness' as Geworfenheit: We are born into webs of interlocution or narrative, from familial and gender narratives to linguistic ones and to the macronarratives of collective identity.  We become aware of who we are by learning to become conversation partners in these narratives...." (15) 

* So she says her approach to multiculti is throug these three components: discourse theroy of ethics that she shares with Habermas, the idea of the "narrative constitution of the self", and her sense of "discourses as deliberative practices that center not only on nroms of action and interaction, but also on negotiating situationally shared understandings across multicultural divides." (16) 

* Then she lays out her view of multicultarlism and legal pluralism.  She doesn't think it is useless but that it mst conform to basic coditions that are essential for universalist deliberative democracy: egalitarian reciprocity, voluntary self-ascription, and freedom of exist and association. (19)  What she gets at here seems quite similar to Holinger's notion of "association by revocable consent."

 

2. Nous et les Autres - Is Univeralism Ethnocentric?

* She says this question haunts "the West."  She points out on 24-25 that the "classical tradition" was kept alive by jewisha and islamic scholars like Ibn Sina, Ibn Rushd, Moshe ben Maimon, and Ibn GAbirol.  So she wonders when we ask the question about the ethnocentric nature of universalism are we taking int consideration this "complex global dialogue across cultures and civilizations"? (25)  A good point.  She rejects the main axis of this debate that rests on a strict moral relativism and the holistic view of cultures as internally coherent and seamless wholes.  (25)  She belives that cultures are open and polyvocal and that the "right to cultural self-expression needs to be grounded upon, rather than consdiered an alternative to, universally recogniyed citizenship rights." (26) 

* She traces out th elines of the recent discussion of univeralism.  Basically ther eis the idea that human nature consists of "stable and predicatable passions, instincts and emotions, all of which can be studied." (26)  Thi sis the view of Hobbes, Hume, ASmith, Helvetius, d'Holbach.  But this view doesn't require essentialism.  She also includes Rousseau and Kant for whom one doesn't need to define an essential human nature to discover an ability to formulate universals by whcih peopple can live.  Then also there is Sartre who she says repudiated claims about the human condition and says that human life has no meaning but we must make choices to give it meaning... (26)

* Then there are those that have rejected the above views and see universalism instead as a "justification strategy." (26)  Here she includes hermeneuticists like Gadamer and "strong contextualists" like Rorty and "postmodern skpetics" like <Lyotard.  as well as power/knowledge theorists like Foucault.  Frot hese thinkers as she puts it univeralism is a strategy for justification that is really "trapped within historical horizons and in cultural, social, and pszchological currents." (27)  She uses Thomas McCarthy's phrase to illustrate that these thinkers have a "critique of impure reason" :)  (2)  Then you have these strict universalists like Karl Otto-Apel, Hilary Putnam, Juergen Habermas, Ronald Dworkin, Thomas Nagel,Thomas Scanlon, and Johnn Rawls.  They are not essentialists necessarily but "all share strong beliefes in the normative content of human reason--that is, in the validity of procedures of inquiry, evidence, and questioning..." (27) 

* Then also univeralism has a moral meaning that she identifies as the idea of equality and moral respect.  (27)  And a legal meaning associated with notions of rights, from indivdiual rights to socioeconoimc rights.  (27-28)

* She believes that the views of contextualists or "framework relativists" fail because "the very process of individudating and identifying frameworks contradicts the claims of framework relativism.  Framework could be individuated only if there were framework-transcending criteria of evaluation, comparison and individuation.  So framework relativists' storng distinction between being 'within' and 'outside' a framework cannot be maintained."  (29)

[Note: I find this dismissal weak.  The kind of framework-transcending criteria she is requiring to define coherent contexts/cultures is only necessary to define contexts that are hermetically sealed in the way that the holistic concept of culture that she dislikes would suggest.  Are these strong contextualists really imaginging contexts as holistic cultures? I think not. Isn't she setting up a straw man here?]

...

Ch. 3 "From Redistribution to Recognition? The Paradigm Change of Contemporary Politics.

* She now begins three chapters that examine the "politics of multiculturalism" and not the epistemological concerns in thinking about universalism-cosmopolitanism, culture vis-a-vis the self that she was examining in the previous two chapters.  In this chapter, she's examining the shift from "redistribution to recognition" in contemporary political discourse that in particular Charles Taylor identified in his 1992 essay "Multiculturalism and the Politics of Recognition."  She also quotes Nancy Fraser from her Justice Interruptus at length.  Fraser states taht a "postsocialist" condition is characteritized by a "hshift in the grammer of political claims-making" in which the emphasis is all on "recognition of group difference".  This can be seen in "identity politics" and the "decentering of class so and and so on.  But also in she says a "shift in the political imaginary, especially in the way in which justice is imagined...The result is a decoupling of cultural politics from social politics and the relative eclipse of the latter by the former." (quoted on 49)

* She notes at the start that Taylor's essay extracts the term recognition from the German idealist tradition, specifically "the famous episode of the struggle between two self-consciousnesses, as represented in Hegel's Phenomenology of Spirit..." (50) I think she means to slightly cut against the legitimacy of the term or reveal it's nationalistic-illiberal origins by making this connection... (50)

* She's gonna walk through this shift and position herself by looking at Taylor, then Kymlicka, and then some observations on the interdependence or recognition and redistribution...(50)

* What she dislikes in Taylor's essay is that he assujmes taht individuals' struggles for recognition are one and the same as a the collectivity they are part of.  "Just as oppressed minorities may have the individual and collective resources to bear with pride and fortitude the wounds and the indignities inflicted upon them, individual claims to authentic self-expression need not run in tandem with collective aspirations to cultural recognition.  They may even contradict one another." (52)  For Taylor, this politics of recognition emerged out of the shift away from the aristocratic code of honor to the "bourgeois notion of dignity." (52)  In this process, according to TAylor, the old idea of dignity acquired new meaning, relating to the search for an "authentic" identity.  Benhabib picks up the word authenticity here I think from Taylor, but she should give it more critical attention.  Instead, she defines it quicly to mean an individual's search for a "unique identity."  (52)  Wihtout questioning the notion of authenticitiy then, Benhabib's problem is with Taylor's presumption that such a search must "take the form of a search for collective self-expression..."  (52)  She thinks this is just wrong theoreticallly and also "politically dangerous" (53)  It is wrong theoretically because it "comes from the homology drawn between individual and collective claims" (53) and it is politically dangerous because it "subordinates moral autonomy to movements of collective identity."  (53)  Indeed, she makes a decently good point that this reverses things since in her view historically the "right of the modern self to authentic self-expression derives from the moral right of the modern self to the autonomous pursuit of the good life, not vice versa..." (53) 

*Here she catches Taylor in a possible contradiction, stating that he must also believe autonomy and authenticity to be "complementary normative principles" since he states, she quotes him, that "everyone should be recognized for his or her unique identity." (53)  And if so, she notes that he must recognize that there are moments when collective movements may conflict with individual claims to autonomy. (53)  She gives an example from the debates about the rights of First Nations in Canada.  Their women are not allowed to be the basis of the special rights afforded to members of the First Nations even though that asymmetry contradicted the Canadian Charater of Rights and Freedom of 1982 that granted women equal civial and political status... (54)  Faced with such a dilemma, Taylor's response is to say that certain immunities from individual rights have to be made for cultural claims.  (54-55) She thinks this is plausible, but skirts around the problem, which is that the principles must be ordered to create a "clear differentiation between the claims of autonomy and those of authenticity." (55) As she sees it, the principle of the right to autonomy is more important and runs prior to any right to collective self-expression.  She makes this point on 55-57.  She notes that Taylor draws on Herder's sense of language and culture as the necessary basis of self-identification...Taylor uses the idea that our subjectivities are all tied up in a "web of interlocution" and that these are the basis of our search for self-expression.  From her point of view, it is only because the individaul needs these linguistic cultural contexts to achieve autonomy that collective rights have legitimacy.  "In other words, the individual can be seen to have a 'right'--that is, a morally justifiable claim of some sort--to the recognition by others of structures of interlocution within which he or she articulates her identity, only if it is also accept that each individual is equally worthy of equal treatment and respect." (56) 

* But all of this she now points out is also extremely idealistic because it all presumes a "seamless web of interlocution through which individuals are held together." (57)  That's not how it is, though.  There is conflict and complex questions of justice and limited resources, and all of this is somehow left out of the politics of authenticity/recognition. (57)  In a way, she notes, it assumes that justice and equal distribution of resources already exists.  "Claims to authenticity presuppose claims to justice; or the pursuit Bof collective difference presupposes a framework sustained by the premises of individual equality." (57) But because these questions of justice have not been resolved there are conflicts that are unavoidable. Taylor recognizes these conflicts, but she seems to say resorts to a language of cultural inferiority/superiority based on degrees of respect for equal dignity that they afrord their members.  She is uncomfortable with this language, again, because it uses what she has called this reductionist socialogy of culture, which she hates.  (57-58).

 

 

)

title: Of Feys and Culture Planners: Margaret Mead and Purposive Activity as Value
text: p. 110 - 111 Mead's Notion of Freedom (her Liberalism) Sullivan says she only described it negatively. It wasn't a prodcut of "repression" but a "endless free imaginative elaboration of an obsessional pattern." (110) Apparently, Mead somehow connected this with a lack of "full genital activity" but Sullivan sort of dismisses the idea and can't explain the connection. He then notes however, that Mead may here have something in common with all liberal theorists: Locke and Hobbes and Dewey. He notes that Dewey had written "freedom is found in that kind of interaction which maintains an environment in which human desire and choice count for something." (quoted on 110, source of quote not clear, Sullivan cites Dewey's Human Nature and Conduct, pgs. 10, 303). He also cites several bios of Mead etc and claims that Mead had carried a copy of this book with her as a undergrad. (110) COMMENTS: 1) The idea of freedom not coming from "repression" but from repetition of an "obsessional pattern" is interesting in that it connects with my argument in Ch.2 & 3 that coercion was being perceived by these people as a force which the individuals perpetuated by themselves perhaps unconsciously. It is interesting also that she didn't see it as repression (Freudian?) ...since that distinction makes Freud's account of internal division seem to be a simple internalization of coercion... Sullivan also develops this further in ways that suggest (though he doesn't say it) that she became involved in the thinking about the authoritarian personality. In a passage for which Sullivan cites letters between Mead and Erich Fromm and Dollard he writes: "In accord with the climate of opinion associated with such liberal theorists, Mead developed a constellation of related traits that constituted ground against which her notion of freedom might be understood. Among these traits, Mead included a lack of intellectual enterprise, a paralysis of initiative, a refusal to perceive strange or intrusive facts, an unresponsiveness, and a preference for admitting ignorance. Freedom would be manifested as intellectual enterprise, initiative, responsiveness, and affect, as well as an unwillingness to admit ignorance. In the Balinese case, the absence of freedom and conscience was made tenable by the iron-clad system." (111) COMMENT: The traits he listed as indicating non-freedom seem to have something in common with the "authoritarian personality" traits, see related "The Strange Death of the Authoritarian Personality". How closely was mead tied into this community of people, who pursued understanding of the authoritarian personality. This is also interesting because it is early...before the war! When did Fromm come to the US? Were these guys already doing this study in Germany? When did their US studies begin, only after the war?

title: Alain L. Locke: The Biography of a Philosopher
text:
p.008-10 Dad's essay 20th Ann of Emancipation Proclamation

Alaine kept a copy of this essay until the ned of his life.  IN it, Pliny goes into the history of slavery and emphasizes the need of Negroies to move beyond dependence on the REpublican Party.

The "tone" the authors say is cpatured in this quote: "For years we have furnished the muscle, let us now add to it brains, and we shall soon assume among the nations of the earth that rank and station to which we are entitled."  (quoted on 10)  The authors seem to think that the "we" here is ambiguous: is it a reference to African Americans or to all the "citizens of the Republic"? (10)  The authors note that Graveyist separatism did not emerged until later.  (10)

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text: p. 491 - 494 Hunt's Authority -- Hunt's method was to listen to a performance and then to go home and reconstruct the story. (491) -- Hunt attempted to define speech styles that he thought to be authentic and traditional. (491) The authors describe that "Hunt attempts to infuse his writings with authority..." (491) They drop in an amazing quote here where Hunt relates how all stories are reconstructions, but that his reconstructions are better are "true History Paintings" (492) Therefore they argue "Hunt's writing constructs texts in such a way as to not only traditionalize but to mark the social identity of the narrator--Hunt--as being a high-ranking possessor of authoritative knowledge of tradition." (492) -- Hunt they say drew on a "range of practices "to traditionalize the texts and artifcats he colelcted by linking them to antecedent forms, practices and discourses." (492). They describe his attempts to explain how he obtained a text, the origin of a cusom, his own expeirence with it as a young boy. Or he would explain that hi special relations with people made them tell him a sotry that they would not tell others. (492-3) Hunt would also try to increase the monetary value of particularly authentic sotries, as in a sotry he obtained from his ex-wife. (493) -- The authors note that in Hunt's work with Curtis his humor is more apparent than in his work with Boas. Thus they conclude: "Hunt attempted to construct his authority vis-a-vis that of Boas." (493)

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1055-1056 Women wanted to Reconcile Professional and Feminine Identity

1920s Social worker was not a do-gooder or altruist.  She say "public welfare as respectable work that permitted and even sustained middle-class leisure activities." (1055) Moreover she expected to have a family and work.  Walkowitz refers to a set of articles appearing in The Nation republished in These Modern Women: Autobiographical Essays from the Twenties, ed. Showalter (1978) and then he says "elite professional women openly voiced the desire to reconcile the public and private spheres of their lives." (1055)  

Marriage however remained an "ultimate goal" and also a "strategy for economic surival.." (1056)

title: Social Knowledge Creation in Online Research Environments. Hamburg, Germany.
text:
* Project enhancing textual criticism -- old practice: "Social Edition of the  Devonshire Manuscript".  The project challenges authority, because it invited "citizen researchers." The final product that was produced. Some people liked the "speed" of the process of peer review.

* The project he's now working on comes out of this.

Different kinds of project framings involving the public. Contributory: designed by professional researchers, the public contributes data; "Collaborative": Designed by researchers, but the public may help to refine the project, design, analyze data,  disseminate findings; "Co-created": hardest, designed by researchers and members of the public.

Important digital humanities concepts: "Iterative critical making." Integrates previously distant fields of design and building with the usually abstract domain of critical theory. Somehow expressed thorugh ideas about "learning by donig" and hands-on collaboration. Focus on "social knowledge production." More literal use of the term "production."

His other project is "Renaissance

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.036 Suspicousness at Spencer's theories

Rosenberg notes that almost all sociologists begna with spencer and quotes: "'I imagine that nearly all of us who took up sociology between 1870, say, and 1890 did so at the instigation of Spencer,' wrote one sociolgist."  But she writes, "By the 1890s,...disillusionment over crime, class conflict, financial panics, and other economic and socila problems, made serious social thinkers suspicious of Spencer's faith that evolution proceeds efficiently." (36-37)

title: Anti-Romantic Romanticism: Edward Sapir and the Critique of American Individualism
text:
p.011:Sapir's Reification of the Self?

Handler quesitons along with Stephen Murray whether Sapir reified the self at the expsense of culture.  (Murray's critique on p.91 is "Sapir was quite ready to reify...'the personality,' while critical of reifying 'the culture.'" (91))  Handler pushes back against this critique: "Wehn Sapir wrote that 'every individual is...a representative of at least one sub-culture,' he added that 'frequently...he is a representative of more than one.' That qualification directs attention away from individuals understood as self-contained monads and toward individuals multiply defined, as it were, in terms of their participation in a range of varying social relations.  Moreover, Sapir's focus in this passage is on culture locatedin 'the interactions of specific individuals,' a phrase that suggests ongoing experience as the object of the anthropologist's study.  On the other hand, Sapir tended to treat personality as 'a reactive system which is in some sense stable or typologicall;y defined for a long period of time, perhaps for life.'  When he challenged the 'givenness' of culture by urging study of 'the culture-acquiring child,' he attribute, at least by implication, a fixity to 'personality definitions and potentials'--present 'from the very beginning' of the child's life--that he explicitly denied to culture." (11)

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text:
p. 284 - 289 Professional Women and Women's Culture

-- Relation between work and culture?  In 19th century, Nancy Cott, Mary Ryan etc posited a "casual relaitonship bewteen the nineteenth-century sphere of women, with its sex-specific language, customs and institutions, and female participation in larger public spheres." (284-5)

-- When it comes to professions and women's culture, attention must be focused on relatoinship between professional women and volunteering.  In 19th century, work outside the home was done as volunteer work often, as philanthropy e.g.  Many women ventured into professional realm as volunteers, contributing to professional work from the "periphery" as it were.  (285)

-- Women also often took the role of popularizers of scientific info (285) "According to Kohlstedt'[s schema, the activities of the amateur and popularizer gradually helped to legitimate an institutional role for the woman scientist, albeit a small one." (285) See Sally Kohlstedt, "In From the Periphery: American Women in Science, 1830 - 1880" SIGNS 4, 1 (Autumn 1978): 81-96.

-- Women functioned as local historians whereas academic historians alwyas men.  That schema captured in 1919 law in NY State that mandated the appointment of a historian in every municipality.  In 1981, 80 percent of these local historians were women over 55.  At writing of article, there were still about 1600 such volunteer historians.  (285-286)

-- Also upturns and downturns in involvement in professoinal life.  1900 to 1920 there were more women doctors than any other time in American history.  Decline in involvement in professional fields by women occured sometime between 1920s and 1950s and had continued until time very recent to writing of the article.  Estelle Freedman argued that this declining presence had to do with the abandonment of the women's sphere, i.e. this argument that "Women gave up mahny of the strengths of the female sphere without gaining equally from the man's world they entered." (quoted on 286, see her "Seperatism as Strategy").  

-- Professional Women may have imbibed from culture of professoinalism hostility to amateur and volutneer and therefore to forms of activity outside the home in the women's sphere (286)  They note that nurses often seemed to sympathize more with doctors than other women. (286) 

--  Finally authors put forward a hypothesis, that the relegation of women to the fringe "helping" or "semi" professions, speeded what Abbott has identifiedas a "process [in professionalization] of 'regression' or retreat from 'front line' contact with all but hte most rewarding and mannerly of clients..." (288)

title: Ugly Feelings
text:
General Notes:

> 12/10/2012: Read for crisis group...and the idea of metacrisis.  Discussion with Kate Moran, James Dorson, and Peter Fischer for 12/12.

 

##Introduction

* Book deals with an "aesthetics of negative emotions." (1) Bartelby the Scrivner is the key figure. Is he merely depressed when he says "I prefer not" in order to wihthodl his labor, or is his inertness "part of a volitional strategy that anticipates styles of nonviolent political activism to come..." (1)

* Ngai says that she is taking off on Melville's figure to imagine the possiblity fo the latter. She "dwells" on "affective gaps and illegibilities, dysphoric feelings, and other sites of emotional negativity in literature, film, and theoretical writings, to explroe similarly ambivalent situations of suspended agency." (1)

* In doing so, she says she is drawing togetehr Arendt and Spinoza. Ie Arendt's notion that "what makes man a political being is his faculty of action" and Spinoza's notion that emotions are a "wavering of the mind" that can increase or decrease a person's ability to act. (2)

* More reflexively she suggest that the book is also a meditation upon the "circumscribed standpiont" of literature in modern society: i.e. the "modern" idea that art and literature are "realtively autonomous" and cordoned-off in an increasingly specialized and differentiated society may be related to the "powerful powerlessness" that she finds interesting in Bartelby the Scrivner. (2) And she wonders whether this self-reflesive preoccupation with its own powerlessness which is typical of "bourgeois art" may in fact be precisely the thing that "makes it capalbe of theorizing social powerlessness in a manner unrivaled by other forms of cultural praxis." (2)

* From here she suggest that lit may be an ideal "space" within this differentiated society to explore "ugly feelings" that are generally significant. Her point is that these feelings, which are literature's focus in some way, deal with a "situation of restricted agency" which is typical of all the other professions within a world that is "highly differentiated and totally commodified..." (2)That is bourgeois art in the modern world increasingly accepts a resigned, passive, and pessimistic view of its own relatinoship to political action, which is thematized in these "situtatinos of passivity" that she will epxlore (3)

* Thus each of the emotion that she will explore in her different chapters can be thougth of as "a mediatino between the aesthetic and the political..." (3)

* She wants to look at these links between negative affect and politics in order to recover the "critical productivity" of these ideas. She acknowledges that these negative feelings are ambivalent; they can "seem to be the psychic fuel on which capitalist society runs", but she also thinks they can resist "reduction to mrere expressions of class ressentiment...[or] their counter valorization as therapeutic 'solutions' to theproblems they highlight and condense." (3)

* She takes Virno as a strong warning. That all these fears and negative affects are translated in modern professioanl life into a mandate for flexibility and adaptability. "Here we see how capitalism's classif affects of disaffection (and thus of potential social conflict and political antagonism) are neatly reabsorbed by the wage system and reconfigured into professional ideals." (4) She notes taht this Virno-ian thesis runs strongly coutner to Jameson's thesis about the "waning" of negative affect in the contemporary moment, i.e. his idea that postmodernism celebrates all this empty positive reinvention through "play"?

* What also interesting about Virno's account is that he shows that tehse negative affects have become "perversely functional".  they have become he suggets "the very lubricants of the economic system which they orignally came into being to oppose." (4) [That is, these ideas have also been used by capitalism] Virno also insistst very interestingly that the functional development and significance of these negative affects are "open to radically conflicting developments." (virno, quoted on 4).  She gives this interesting example, that opportunism, which is one of these negative affects (?), has changed our relation to the world so that, in virno's words, "our relation with the world tends to articulate itself primarily through possibilities, opportunities, and chances, instead of according to linear and univocal directions." (4)

* No it gets really good. She says that she thinks we could argue that there is a moment in "transnational cpaitalism" today wherein "emotions no longer link up as securely as they once did with the models of social action and transformation theorized by Aristotle, Thomas Hobbes, and others under the signs of relatively unambigous emotions like anger or fear." (5) I.e. these feelings provide a key or index to a changed state of the "sociopolitical", and that's why looking at them can be helpful. Feeilngs like opportunism, for all its "pettiness," can call "attention to a real social experience and certain kind of historical truth." (5)

* Ngai notes that "emotions" are generally ignored in political philosophy, except for Hobbes and Machiavelli. Emotions ahve traditionally played a role in the philosophy of aesthetics, where they were discussed i relation to so-called aesthetic emotions, ie. emotions aroused by encounters with art. The first such instance of this was Aristotle's description of catharsis in response to greek tragedy, but for both Hobbes and Machiavelli, and for philosophy of aesthetics, anger and fear (ie cathartic, moralistic) emotions have been the most important. (5-6)

* By contrast, her book's negative emotions are "amoral and noncathartic, offering no satisfaction of virtue, however oblique, nor any therapeutic or purifying release. In fact, most of these feelings tend to interfere with the outpourring of other emotions. Moods like irritation and anxiety, for instance, are defined by a flatness or ongoingness entirely opposed to the 'suddenness' on which Arisotle's aesthetics of fear depends." (6-7)

* She wants to dintinguish her book from similar histories of "specific" emotions because it is dealing with the question -- more theoretical and critical -- of how a focus on negative affects might expand the discourseon emotions in general. So she's participating in the converastion about emotions, but does not want to particpate in these cultural histories of emotion. (6) Her work is thus more theoretical than  historical she says (8), but she has chosen to explore different emotiosn within differn socio-historical contexts in which it seems particualrly to be at stake (7).

* She sees a link between certain emotions and certain forms of literature, and this has guided her choice of texts. (9). She goes a bit further saying that she thinks noncathartic emotions have created a certain kind of art that has a "noncathartic aesthetic: art that produces and foregrounds a failure of emotional release (another form of suspened 'action') and does so as a kind of politics." (9)

* She sees also a special link between negative emotiosn and irony -- irony entials a certain "meta-response" or "meta-feeling".  A TEndency to have negative feelings about feelings. Ie "I feel ashamed about being envious." So negative feelings she thinks are better at creating a kind of "ironic distance" than "grander and more prestigious passion." (10)

* Talkinga bout two film noir films that she will analyze -- Double Indemnity (1944) and The Conspiracy (1974) -- she describes moments in which there is a stretching out of narrative time in which "discourse time" outweights "story time." She describes these as "moments of conspicuous inactivity" in which there is she think an "affective disorienttaion." (14) She means what might be described as "feeling vaguely 'unsettled' or 'confused'...a meta-feeling in which one feels confused about *what* one is feeling." (14) She says this is affective confusion and is different thatn an "epistemological sense of indeterminacy"; this is bewilderment, affective indeterminacy. (14)

 

## Ch.1 Tone

* What is tone? The New Critics were the first to try to define it, but in a way that she finds inadequate essentially it seems because while, for instance, IA Richards distinguished tone and feeling, his definition of the two in her view was inadequate. Feeling pertained to the "state of affairs" created by the poem, while tone referred to the relationship between speaker and listener. Ngai dös not think these two domains can be so easily seprated. (41-42)
