* She thinks the messy definition of tone of the New Critics had something to do with a discomfort in relation to the idea that when talking about feelings, one simply comes up with "soft" impressions, i.e. subjective accounts. There was thus a certain inattentiveness to everyday implications of the objectivity of emotions, which she sees for example in phrases like "I don't like your tone. You won't get anywhere with that tone." (42)

* But that is where she will focus her understanding of tone: on this objectivity of emotions that are in a sense "public." She refers to Heidegger's account of moods, ie moods as "attunements" (Stimmungen) "that arise from and shape or modulate the totality of Being-in-the-world, disclosing the 'situatedness' (*Befindlichkeit*) that enables things to *matter* in determinate ways." (42-43) She quotes Charles Guignon, who notes that following such a way of thinking our moods are not simply private "but rather essentialyy public, part of the 'world' instead of something *in* the 'self'." (43)

* In Ngai's words then tone is something like a "global and hyperrelational concept of *feeling* that encompasses attitue: a literary text's affective bearing, orientation, or 'set toward' its audience and world." (43) She notes that it is something like what allows us historians to describe a "collective mood", e.g. Cold War paranoia. (43)

* She says that in thinking about tone this way Susanne Langer's idea of "significant form" is helpful. Langer bases her theory in turn on Otto Baensch's notion of "objective feeling" (see 44-45) that refers to certain nonsensroy qualities of feeling that "surroudn and permetate" an art object -- like a landscape. Langer speaks of a "semblance of feeling", reference to Schilleräs notion of *Schein*. Ngai also begins to use the word affect here (46), referring to it as having a "fugitive presence." She acknowledges again that this notion of tone is difficult to define, but insists that that may be because we lack a vocabulary to tlak about it, its forms and structures. And she insists that it is a real thing (has an ontology of sorts) and also has an "impact" on a person's subjective responses to things.... (46)

* She describes tone then as an "affective relay between subject and object" (46).

* She thinks this is important for theory, especially when trying to understand ideology. Here things get good. She assert in fact hat understanding ideology may require some accounting for tone. She quotes Grossberg to say that "Affect is the missing term in an adequate understanding of ideology..." because it offers what he calls a "psychology of belief". Ngai notes that in fact the "generality and abstractness" ((47) of tone is suited to understanding ideology precisely because as "the materially embodied representation of an *imaginary relationship* to a holistic complex of real conditions," ideology "clearly shares tone's virtual, diffused, but also immanent character." (47)

* In next seection, Ngai says she will show tone's effect in an interpreation of Melville's *Confidence-Man*. The analysis is good here.
    1. The characters in the book are Functionally interchangeable and not particularly distinguishable. She describes the book as giving a sense of "ironies constantly missed or passing over" .. a "meta-ironic feeling of an irony intended for and available to everyone but oneself." (52) As a result, she says, there is not a focus on characters with emotions, but rather of "objectified emotions" -- or affect. (52)

     2. She uses some theorist named Tomkins to talk about affect (52-55) as something that creates (affective) analogs to real-world events which allow us to have a concern or care about the world.  Tomkins also has a notion of affect's combinatory function, 55.

    3. The connection to Confidence Man is that the confidence man demonstrates this kind of "combinatory flexiblity" of affect, or in fact uses it. Massumi has a notion of "affective escape" in which affect  continually escapes the forms in which it has been "captured." Ngai argues that in Melville's novel, there is a "vocabulary of affective 'transfer' or transaction, subtended throughout by financial transactions in which values become disconnected from their token in the very act of exchange." (56) She develops this point well on 56 and 57. The book is set i a period before the intorduction of paper money or greenbacks; it is a period in which there is a flourishing of forms of paper money and written scripts, at a time when the actual value was continually "escaping" the money form intended to capture it -- and all this against the background of slavery, and the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850. So she's describing this: escape of affect from characters/forms <=> escape of value from money form ==> ambivalence of this escape, highlighted by the meaning of escape and capture against the background of slavery. (57)

    4. IN a quote on 58, by Chicago Mayor in 1876, referring to the incredible number of scripts being circulated, their lack of value, and the fear/lack of confidence that this prodcued, the objective emotional/affect link comes in too. Ie the affective tone in this atmosphere in which capitalist money form is so unstable is precisely a lack of confidence, a want of "conviviality" (see 59)

  5. The confidence man moreover describes himself as using a philosphy of "analogy" - where money and confidence are linked, and even become interchangeable. The confidence man's trick is precisely to be able to tranform negative emotions (ie lack of confidence) into confidence, which because of the analogic link between money and confidence, is a commodity. 60-61

   6. There is the critique of the book then: that "cofidence" is the tone of capitalism, as she puts it on 62. -- this ability, as demonstrated by the novel, to turn the negative emotions into confidence, the dysphoric into the euphoric. (61) So the confidence man says in the novel: "Confidence is the indidspensable basis of all sorts of business transactions. Without it, commerce between man and man, as between country and country would, like a watch, run down and stop." (quoted on 62)

   7. Ngai shows in an example how the book -- perhaps its  critical componnent -- shows how thereis even a confusion about whether an exchange process is an exchange of goods or confidence. See her example on 62, re exchange with an herb-doctor.

   8. Although ultimately, and again perhaps here is the critique, there is a kind of failure of the exchange process between affect and money, that leads to a rheotric replacement of analogy with anaphora that disrupts the signifying processes that make the analogic exchange of confidence and money possible. She shows this in a long analysis of an exchange between the confidence man and  miser, where the confidence man asks for confidence instead of money, but then asks for money to verify the exchange, at which point the miser breaks down into a kind of repetetive non-sensical language. This is a breakdown in communicative lanaguge that happens throughout the novel, and signals a failure of some sort.

    9. So what you have then is a double-meaning for this kind of affect. It supports capitalism, but can also disrupt it. When does it disrupt? It disrupts when there is an "amplification" creating a "feedback" (this language is metaphorical and comes to Ngai I think from S. Tomkins , who links affective reponse and electric response). The feedback in this case is a result of the reflexive recognition of the links between affect, money, and langaue that in her interpretation undergird antebellum capitalism in Melville's novel. The result is that the "unfeltness" of the affect of confidence (affect and tone being things, as she noted in the introduction, that are not felt subjectively primarily, but which are general and abstract, are fugitive presences.)  The reconition of this unfeltness produces the communicative breakdown.

* So after this analysis she thinks she can say what the problem is that is posed by tone, vv an analysis of literature and ideology. The point is that the "orld of the novel's story *runs on a feeling that no  one actually feels.*" (69) That is, she says that they cannot veryify, even with the aid of "tokens" ie money. Their is a danger of a potential failure to be able to acknowledge the "subjective ownership of 'confidence'..." and that can cause panic. (69) It can even threaten the system itself she says on 70. At the same time, the unfelt statu of the feeling is what allows the system to operate. So Melville's *Confidence-Man* can (as Michael Rogin has argued) show the empty core of the market, but it also shows the power of this illusion or unfelt affect. (70) The trouble then is the proximity of subjective feeling and affect -- and indeed this is the same difficulty that causes the literary theorist concern, lest they mistake one for the other, hence the centrality of the problem of tone to analysis of literature and ideology. (on this see comment on 69, that literary theorists panic too when they might mistake real for virtual feeling, and then on 71, discussion of Langer's struggle with the same probem.)

* She then spends a number of pages going back to Tomkins on 71- 75.  The point is basically that the "noise" that she sees as entering into the affective saystem of Melville's novel -- ie the reflexive awareness -- also enters into Tomkins theoretical project. He comes up with a notion of magnification, where affective respones are not simply "amplified" or made louder while staying the same, but multiply and produce something new, a new set of scences (he was a playwright) along with a script for interpreting this multplicity. But then there arrives also a degree of distoration or feedback, that reveals exceess and "soemthing separate" (74) that Ngai compares to that scence witht the miser when the confidence-man engages in a transcation that reveals the illusory chater of confidence. But then Tomkins defines an additional idea of ideo-affective resonance, crucial to ideology, whereby one set of ideas is able to create resonance and "sympathetic coordination" between different individuals, with different ideas, despite those difference. Tomkins writes: "IT is possible and indeed common for different individuals to resonace in different manners to the same ideology." (quoted on 75) Ngai points out that in addition to beieng a parasite, an analog amplifier, the confidence man may also be an ideo-affective resonater. (75)

* To end, however, Ngai points out that tone is a negative affect precisely because it involves the feeling of the unfelt nature of emotion (e.g. confidence).  Teh confidence-man continually recognizes the unfelt nature of this feeling of confidence.  Whent hat happens there is this extra "noise" and that noise reveals the unfelt nature of the confidence that undergirds what she notes Jaean Christoph-Agnew has called the "placelessness" of the market, ie its dependence on "virtual feeling." The point of doing this for Melville's confidence man, however, is not to prodcue disruption, but to show how the market works. (bottom 76) .  That was Melville#s goal Ngai thinks  in his most antipyschological novel, that focuses instead on the political uses of affect, of that is the semblance of feeling rather than actually experience feeling.

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text: p. 278-9 Suggestion for Study of Women in Professions 19th Century women historians (Joan Scott, Tilly, etc) have shown that "the entrance of working class women into the industrial labor force invovled the complex interaction of economic, structural and cultural forces." (278) The make suggestions in following pages about how a similar approach might suit study of womens' entrance into the professional field.

title: American Moderns: Bohemian New York and the Creation of a New Century
text:
p. 227, 233-34 Paradoxes of Sexual Modernism

1) "...the structures of sexual modernism proved highly elastic in their ability to accommodate elements of the old sexual hierarchies.  The persistence, even the consolidation, of men's privileges within an egalitarian framework would prove a defining feature of twentieth-century American society." (227)

2) It celebrated women at the same time as it negated femininity, aimed at a "human sex." (233)   Note: This is typical of modernism's search for ideal forms...

See R. Bourne quote on 234

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.013-15  The New Science of Political Economy

The founders were interested in the new science of society rooted in belief that society and the behavior of individual followed certain immutable laws discoverable by scientific thought.  This science known as "political economy."  This science existed alongside Christianity but excluded this realm from consideration.  Religion, family relations, relations between masters and servants, parents and children, etc, all this was outside of political economy.  (15)

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text:
p.131 Benedict impression of Serrano as Fragmented Culture

Benedict apparently equated Serrano with moderns.  Handler writes: "From her sperspective, the Serrano, like the anthropologist herself, faced the dilemma of a meaningless existence: 'It is largely by guess-work that they can give the meaning of any of the ceremonial songs; and any religious connotation in such practices as rock-painting, for instance, is unkown." (131)

title: Alain L. Locke: The Biography of a Philosopher
text:
p.016-19  Tension between "individual integrity and group identity"?

The authors transition from the account of his mother's treatment of Locke as a child to an issue of tension between the family and the outside, expressed in a quote on 15 in relation to his being taught, despite all the affection, not to be too openly affection even with his mother, but also especialy not outsiders.  The authors some it up interestingly this way--although without really showing evidence in Locke's words:

"The inwardness that attaches to a certain understanding of individualism was not necessarily of a radical subjectivity--in which only the inward is true--but rather is seen by Locke as a term in a dialectic relation with how and under what condition one should make oneself available or visible to others." (16)  This of course ties into the theme of "frantic respectability" that they had discussed before when noting the afront to his mother's respectabiity made by the newspaper. The authors seem to think that ocke viewed social values in human experience as a kind of source of "pollution" (16).

The authors then bring up Locke's homosexuality...but very akwardly, as though it were something incidental to his existence.  They argue that his mother came to "represent all the ideal that he felt were worth striving for..." (16)  IN a quote on 16-17, he talks about his mother dipping him "as a very young child in the magic waters of cold cynicism and haught distrust and disdain of public opinion" and that this made him almost an "hurt-proof child," but that there was always the "all too vulnerable Achilles Hell of homosexuality--which she may have suspected was there, both for her own sake and my own safety--I kept in an armored shoe or servere and haughty caution.  I realize that to bask in the usnshine of public favor I would have to bathe in the dangerous pool of publicity." (17)

The issue of public exposure also came up in relation to race.  Here again the authors emphasize self-awarness in his family.  The quote Locke stating that laughter was outlawed in their house as "the antidote of being Negro--the distinguished protest of the 2nd & 34d genreaiton away from slavery..."( quoted on 17).  His father dealt with this informal prohibtion Locke noted by whistling, a sublimation that he authors link to the "gift" of education... (17)

On p.18, a paragraph that indicates a sense of the family as having barricaded itself against public exposure...but being honest "behind closed doors." (18)  The authors trace the theme of open/closed tension now through a fear of social pollution to a metaphor of war: the barricade.  (18)

title: The German Idea Of Militarism : Radical and Socialist Critics, 1866-1914.
text:
p.010-013 Description of Post-War German Historiography Re Militarism

Stargardt has an excellent analysis of the post-war German historiography that sough to explain the rise of Nazism both in East and West Germany.  Good brief and critical.

Particularly valuable critique of the Wehler and the Bilefeld School on 11-12.

All of these accounts are insufficient he end sup saying and shifting to the turns of historiography in the "new" unified Germany he says he does not know where things will go.  He likes the impulse, part of semiotics, poststructuralism, postmodernism, etc to destruct the "blocks"...He suggests that militarism is a "term of critical analysis" and that "[i]t never was nor could be an objective category of analysis..." (13)

title: 'Let Us Be Sisters Forever': The Sororal Model of Nineteenth-Century Female Friendship
text:
00 Summarial Note 00

Lasser intervenes into the discussion of ninteenth-century "female friendship" first begun by Caroll Smith-Rosenberg, "The Female world of Love and Ritual" article (1975).  Her historiographical argument is that previous studies (see f.n. #9) have not focused enough on "kinship ties" in female friendship.  They have instead involved themselves in a discussion of the presnece or absence of sexual underpinnings to these relationships. (161-162)

Lasser, noting the conspicuous use of the term "sister" between female friends, presents intead a "sororal model" within which she argues that women in many cases formed quite literal kinship ties out of what would be termed today "fictive kin" ties.  (163-4)   On the way such ties became literal see 168.  For uses of "sister" terminology see examples on 1650-168.  Particularly interesting is the case of Lucy Scott and Antoinette Blackwell who married brothers thereby giving their sisterhood a legal basis (178-179)

Lasser argues aditionally that the use of "fictive kinship" by the wome paralells its similar use by slaves at the turn of the century identified by Herbert Gutman.  The point was that it allowed these women to build familiar relations where they lacked them.  But Lasser is also clear that these sororal relations allowed women to combat the isolating effects of the separate spheres model (see her description of the three level on which the women experienced sisterhood on 164-165.)

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text:
p.009 Re Culture and Professional Dev

"As anthropologists attempted to reconfigure their discipline in the years immediately preceding and following the Second World War, the subject matter of anthropology changed.  IN the prewar years, anthropologists viewed culture as their common subject matter.  The concept of culture, therefore, provided a boudnary to the discipline of anthropology.  Anthropologists, however, never were able to articulate precisely what constituted culture.  They argued that culture was a 'whole' or 'totality' that bound together people.  They suggested that culture had patterns, but they did not specify precisely what the relationship was between the various traits within the patterns of specific cultures." (9) 

Then, fitting with his idea that the discipline changed after WWII, there is a post-war attempt to reduce the concept: "Since culture remained a vague concept and anthropologists observed the relations between the elements of cultural patterns as implicit, culture did not lend itself to systematic, pardigmatic, or scientific study.  After the war, various groups of anthropologists redcued the concept of culture to component parts in an effort to make the relations between the elements of culture explicit and study culture systematically...." (9)  He then briefly describes the different attempts...

title: With science as his shield: Teaching race and culture in American public schools, 1900--1954
text:
p. 004 Innovation in Relation to other Lit

She notes work by Michaols Montalto, James A. Banks, Diana Selig, and Chery McGee Banks on the "emergence and decline of tolerance education in the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s" and says that her work is the "first to evaluate this curriculum in terms of its influence on racial ideologies in America."  (4)   In doing so, she says, she undrestands the schools to "have the ability to inscribe particular notions about racial difference as part of the knoweldge set of the educated citizen." (4)

title: The Dainty and the Hungry Man: Literature and Anthropology in the Work of Edward Sapir
text:
p.050-51 Interpretation of Boas' re Holism

Handler pretty much accepts Stocking's interpretation on Boas, citing him directly.

"Caught  between element and whole, boas never developed a consistently holistic or structuralist conception of culture.  But the quesitons he raised were to prove so suggestive that 'much of twentieth-century American anthropology may be viewed as the working out in time of various implications in Boas' own position."  (51, quote is from Stocking's "The Basic Assumptions of Anthropology" in The Shaping of American Anthropology, p. 17)

Handler also notes that Hymes on p.90 of "Review of Anthropology of Franz Boas, edited by Wlater Goldschmidt" notes that Boas' anthropology was "pre-structural."

title: Working Knowledge: Making the Human Sciences from Parsons to Kuhn
text:
General Notes 2/2013:

## Prologue

* The book seeks to define a "largely forgotten conversation" that he says belongs to a world of "postpositivism" in which there was a detailed conversation about the "sources and validity of knowledge in the human sciences" that treated "epistemology, pratices of scientific research, regimes of profesisonal training, adn the theory of knowledge...[as] intriactely related and mutually reinforcing enterprises." (4)

* Rather than this being a desire to reduce knowledge to simple formulas -- as with positivism -- but  a focus on the idea that knowledge must be "made" in a "craft-like" manner. (5)

* This language or "culture of inquiry" (5) was based in Harvard. It stemmed from a focus on Kant, especially on his theory of knowledge and the "structures of cognition" through which people gained knowledge of the world, and yet also in a desire to seek replacements for Kant's transcendental categories of a prior intuition and understanding. They looked for these in the "actual techniques" of math and science as practices. (5) 

* This culture formed the basis for Parson's "grand theory," for W.V.O. Quine's Philosophy, for Kuhn's theory of science, and B.F. Skinner's behaviorism. (6)

* There was also a very unique instituitonal character at Harvard, which he calls the Harvard complex, through which this discussion of epistemology, disciplinary practice and training, and theory of knowledge wer emediated. He wants to empahsiszed that it was a "practice-oriented tradition of epistemology" that emerged of an instituional domain that was "interstitial" and "underinstitutionalized." (6)

* Hence his title "working knowledge." Some will see this as a study of positivism, but he would rather that they not reduce it to that -ism. And after all these catch-all terms he thinks miss the "everyday" practice of science, which was in the case of his subjects, the whole point. So he says that he would hope that his readers would realize that his subjects had a "refined sense of the importance of research practice and pedagogy, and not merely the desire to reduce the content of the human sciences to the material world limned by the natural sciences." (7)

# Ch. 1 - The Interstitial Academy: Harvard and the Rise of the American University

* This chapter traces the rise of what Issac is calling the "interstitial academy" and the "Harvard complex." It is basically a very innovative analysis of how Harvard's university structure developed in a way that was ad hoc in nature, as a result of a set of competing interests and pressures. Those pressures included professionalization and specialization and the emergence of a marked for professional academics (after Daniel Coit Gilman stole professors from Harvard), one hand, and the embedded-ness of Harvard in the metropole of Boston and its class structures. "The story of Harvard from the Webber to the Eliot administrations is the story of how problems of this nature were endlessly finessed rather than systematically addressed..." (61) Systematic transformation in technical education at the land-grant universities such as Cornell or MIT, in graduate training at Cornell, Hopkins, and Clark; and in deparmtental social sciences at Chicago. (61) By contrast, Harvard is notable for its interstitial programs and seminars... This is all interesting though for his argument because of what he says on the last page: there was in the middle decades of the twentieth century a "drawn-out process of revision" of the social sciences and in this process he says "scientific philosophy and the interstitial academy would be centrally invovled in these developments. What emerged from this synthesis was an intellectual culture in which the human sciences engaged epistemology and the natural sciences in way deeply mediated by institutional reform, pedagogical experimentation, and a sensitivity to the knowledge-making practices of working scientists." (62)

# Ch.2: Making a Case: the Harvard Pareto Circle

* This chapter lays out a key intellectual context   the interstitial university that Issac is describing and the "first example of the Harvard complex--the combination of scientific philosophy, the interstitial academy, and the marginal human sciences." (65)  That context is based in an engagement with Vilfredo Pareto's Trattato di Sociologia Generale, published in 1916, that took place within a group of Harvard faculty and students that began to meet in a weekly seminar in autumn of 1932 to discuss the book. The seminar was called "Pareto and Methods of Scientific Investigation." This seminar has been treated as one of the key sources of "structural-functional" sociology in US thought, and has also been viewed as a conservative reaction to Depression era politics. Issac thinks these interpretations miss 1) that it was Pareto's "theory of scientific knowledge" and not his critique of social democracy that interested the seminar's main initiatino Lawrence Joseph Henderson and 2) that the "Pareto vogue found its strongest influence and support within the interstitial academy." (64)

* Why was Pareto appealing? For Henderson it had to do with the way Pareto helped him deal with what Issac calls a "metaphysical self-consciousness" that he had developed from his "generalization of Josiah Willard Gibbs's model of physicochemical system" into many different fields of scientific inquiry. This work had made him aware Issac says of the "explicitly conventional nature of the systems studied in the physical and biological sciences..." (66) Gibbs' framework may have been an abstraction but it had a real power: it "made possible the collection and interpretation of facts." (66) This sense of Henderson's had been underwritten by his reading of works by philosopher scientists like Henri Poincare and Ernst Mach who were making "man-made symbolic conventions and a priori frrameworks...respectable..." (66) So Henderson's interest in "the concepts of system and organization" made him cutting-edge. Issac writes: "In physics, the mechanical world picture had been toppled by relativity theory, after a long crisis during the ninteenth century; the concept of the organized system, spurred by developments in biology, was now the order of the day." (67) And here is where Pareto came in brecause his ideas appealed to Henderson becasue they provided a way to thinking about "non-logical" motivations in social and political life. Pareto called the non-rational ideas that socail agents acted upon "resideues." (67) His framework also included the categories of sentiemnts and derivations. Togetehr these categories framed up for Henderson a general system of equilibrium that appealed to him. Issac writes: 'Her was a system of mutually dependent elements existing in dynamic equilibrium much like those Hnderson had studied in other departments of science." (68) Such a framework Issac said was for Henderson just like a tool: it was artificial but useful. (68-69)

[Note: this sounds so much like Peirce! It is surprising that he does not make an appearance at this point in the book, as a forerunner... ]

* Through Henderson's seminars several faculty and students were linked into this Pareto "network" as Issac calls it: Joseph Schumpeter, Pitirim Sorkokin, thomas North Whitehead, Fritz Roethlisberger, Hans Zinsser, Clude Kluckhohn, W. Lloyd Warner, Henry Murray, Elton Mayo, Crane Bringon, Bernard DeVoto and Talcoatt Parsons. Students included: Robert K. Merton, William Foote Whyte, Kingsley Davis, Gorge C. Homans, and James Grier Miller. (63)

* The next section on Mapping the Pareto Network shows how this interest in Pareto was not contained to one discipline. Henderson taught a seminar Sociology 23 and also one on Concrete Sociology, both also formed around Pareto.  (71)Through Henderson the Pareto influence touched many disciplines through other than his own. Conrad Arensberg taught in Henderson's Sociology 23 seminar, even though eh ultimately turned more to the social anthropologists Malinowski and Radcliffe-Brown. (71) Henderson's Pareto interest also became the basis for the reformulation of the Harvard Graduate School of Busineess Adminsitration and the Business school through Wallace Donham, such that the focus on business adminjsitration came to be one on "human relations" and their management (72-73)!  "Far from being confined to the sminar on Pareto, then, the Harvard Pareto cicle was institutionally eclectic: it connected various schools, departmetns, and research facilities." (74) This was partly due to Henderson's position in the University. He was a "trusted lieutenant" of President Lowell and after Lowell's retiremetn in 1933 his position increased. So that in the end even though a biochemist he "moved freely through the weakly professionalized human sciences at Harvard, gathering around him as he went a heterodox band of anthropologists, sociologists, and management scientists." (74)

 

# Ch. 3: What do the Science-Makers Do? Migrations of Operationalism

* This chapter traces another important intellectual strand of the interstitial academy at Harvard: operationalism. This line of thinking came from Percy Bridgman's 1927 *The Logic of Modern Physics*. It was also central to Harvard in the psychology dept. Key figures here were :philosopher of science Herbert Feigl, Edward Boring, B.F. Skinner, and Stanley Smith Stevens, Ewdward Tolman.  (92-93)

* Operationism appealed Issac says to "practitioners of weakly institutionalized human sciences." (94) As with Henerson's "case-based concetpual scheme" (explained in ch.2) what operationism did was give reseaerch practices an epsitemological status. Issac says it this way: "we can identify in operationism an ipstemological conceit that placed the practices of research--in thise case, the procedures of the experimental pscyhologist--into epistemic roles. To instist that scientific concepts by synonymous with the operations through which they were applied was to say that the scientific procedures of the laboratory were the content of empirical concepts." (94)

* Issaac says that what "licensed" this intellectual move was the "tradition of scientific philosophy" that he is tracing. He describes this chapter's treatment of operationalism as in part a "parallel case" to Henderson's theory of social systems. (94) In reaity, what Issac is doing here is laying the second plank of the "Harvard Complex" appraoch to the study of the human sciences. Operationalism represented a push from the pscyhological direction within the interstitial academy at Harvard to work out a "empiricist epistemology free from the metaphysical flights of fancy and a prior stipulations of traditional philosophical accounts of knowledge." (124) Ultimately, he says at the end of the chapter, Skinner and Stevens were joined in this enterprise by the renewed Vienna Cricle of logical empiricism that also formed in Harvard's interstitial academy in the 1930s, and which also sought to establish a solid empirical epistemology. Logical empiricism is the subject of Ch.3. (see end of 124 for this connection).

# Ch. 4:

* This chapter sort of brings all this together describing with WWII and its aftermath the growth of a new kind of interdisciplinarity and "behavioral sciences" that was both a product of a kind of "scientific revolution" brought about by the money and organization and experience generated by wartime and military interest in managing "human resources." Central here is Parsons and the founding of the Department of Human Relations.

 

* Parsons' strategic failures in DSR led to tensions. Key were disagreements around the word "functionalist". Parsons who believed based on the background of Pareto and the Harvard complex that theory was the way to forge an overarching theory, insisted on an understanding that there were clear functional categories, whereas other members (the "younger" members who according to Parsons' organization were set apart from teh "senior" members), pointed out that the "function" of something depended entirely on what perspective it was viewed from. What was functional from the point of view of the army was not functional fromt he point of view of the officers or their families, see 183.  Parsons insisted that one had to understand what was functional as what was functional to the overall system. (182-184). In the end Parsons' drafted the General theory mostly by himself... (184).

* Chapter then goes into a very wonderful, innovative, and subtle analysis of the way that theoretical knoweldge was understood to exist vv empricial knowledge inside of DSR. It was understood Isaac says that the theoretical knoweldge ahd to be verified in an empirical sense, but not in the way one would assume that it must be verified. Rather in what Issaac describes as a late instance o fthe same emphasis on theoretical constructs as "tools" that had been key to the "scientific philosophy" tradition he is tracing from the beginning, these theoretical ideas needed to be verified "in practice". And one of the main ways that Parsons and Shils did that was through diagrams used to illustrate in a tool the entire "action frame of reference", or also even more through the idea of "pattern variables" which were axes of perspective orientation in the actor that determined what orientaiton/position teh actor would take. These Isaac said were meant as "transcendental conditions of action" that worked out in practice. (185-187).  The whole enterprise of theorization, moreover, was treated as a kind of empricial practice. Conceptual breakthroughs were udnerstood as "events" and described that way on several occasions. (188-189).

* But in 1951, despite all of this, there was no way that the book that Shils and Parsons ultimately produced, The Genral Theory, could serve as a focus of an overaching approach. Homans for one totally disagreed that it should be viewed that way as did Stouffer even within DSR. (189-190)

* But for Isaac this does not matter so much because what he's interested is in the approach, the "loose weave" which could not support that kind of overarching interdisciplinaryity that Parsons had in mind. He seems ot think taht is a good idea. And I agree with him. He writes at the end of the chapter: "...the DSR, it seemed, was in no position to create such a synthesis [as Parsons wanted]. The loose weave of the Harvar complex could not, in the end, service the interdisciplinary ambitions of Parsons, Kluckhohn, and Stouffer." (190)

# Ch. 5:

* This chapter as the title indicates tries to estimate the impact of the form of scientific philosophy that developed in the Harvard Complex and the interstitial academy. Kuhn and his Scientific Revolutions book form the center of this effort. He forms the center because Isaac takes him as an example of a thinker whose intellectual socialization took place entirely and exclusively within the interstitial academy, and thus through him one can see what the effect of a "scientific philosphy" in which "epistemology, pedagogy, and reseach practices were interchangeable" might be like. (192).

* There's an interesting coming together of the language that Isaac has used throughout the book in the first few pages of this chapter that informally weigh the postivies and negatives of this interstitial academy at the outset. In the first two paragraphs for example he already describes how the interstitial academy was "too diverse and amorphous to provide the basis for a coherent independent department or an integrated general theory." (191) But the on the other hand, at the start of the next paragraph the interstitial academy he says did provide an "education that escaped the confines of professional socialization." (191) ON this later point, many of the figures that Isaac has already dealt with received this education, but only Kuhn, he says, was a pure product of the "interstitial mind." (192) (191-192)

* Kuhn's own theory of science, however, was not unprecedented. L.J. Henderson had begun the tradition at Harvard with his founding of a history of science course at Harvard in 1911. Other schoolars such as Robert Merton, George Sarton, Philip Frank, Bernard Barber, James Conan Bryant, all contributed as well. But these questions about the relationship of scientific inquiry and science -- which revolved around questions like: to what extent could science be conceived of as a social inquiry? and what were the beneifts of scientific thinking to society? -- became more important in the age of the atomic bomb and in the "context oriented scientific philosophy promoted by the Harvard Complex." (193) (192-193)

* Isaac usefully situates the war and the bomb in relation to this increased attention on the relations between scientific inquiry and society 194-196. The bomb on the one hand forced the issue because it make the high stakes clear, but more deeply -- and here Isaac cites Gallison -- was "Big Science" -- ie the growth of science as a new estate consisting of trained scientists and experts, a new class, that was visible on the landscape. Isaac point was that it eventually dawned on people that this new group of people, whose practices and self-identity was largely unknown to most people, was a new social estate, and the question was how did they fit into the existing poitical traditions and social norms. (196).

* As well, a debate develops already in the 1930s, sparked by a paper by Boris Hesen, a soviet scientists that had come with Nicolai Burkharin, to a conference that was called "The Social and Economic Roots of Newton's Principia" and which crudely interpreted Newtonian science as satisfying the needs of the English capitalism of the time. The paper led to a whole set of debates in Britain. The Marxist molecular biologist J.D. Bernal as well as some other set up a dept. The Social Relations of Science that rather than exploring the social basis of science pushed instead for science's socialization. "Bernalists" Isaac says wanted to see science put to the use of social planning., and many of them saw WWII as a chance to make this happen. This push was opposed by Micahel Polanyi, a professor of chemistry at Manchester, who was disgusted with the Bernalists "utilitarian" conception of science and favored instead a way to value science as a kind of craft complete with intuitive emphases. The Bernalists came to be" called "extenralists" and Polanyi an "internalist." (196-8)

* At Harvard both internalist and externalist approaches were weclomed. But the externalist approach of Bernal was eventually severed from the notion of social planning. As Isaac puts it, "external studies of the social and historical development of science were to be welcomed. For to speak of the 'social relations of science' implied neither the harnessing of science to ends set by the state, nor the determination of scientific knowledge by the means and relations of production, but rather the affirmation of democratic values that, by their very existence, created a climate for the serendipitous discovery of the truths of nature. From World War to Cold War, the ideological imperative of anti-totalitarianism had severed, at least in the United States, the links Bernal had traced between the results of scientific inquiry and its social organization." (200)

* That said, there was a consensus about the precise relationship between the "social support of science and the truths scientists could be expected to adduce..." It emerged slowly after 1945. Isaac takes Philip Frank's attempts to revive a Unity of Science program in Cambridge as an example. He formed the Inter-Scientific Discussion Group in Sept. 1944. Parlty the goal here was to revive the Vienna Circle for a new age of nuclear energy and electrical engineering... What Isaac means by the Vienna Cricle here was the philosophy of logical empricisim that was brough tto the US by some former members of the Vienna Circle during the 1930s..., see 125-126. He ultimatley gainedd funding from the Rockeller Foundation and the American Academy of Arts and Science for a new institute of Unity of Science. In his formulation, there would be more empahsis on the socio-psychological dimensions as well as the logical -empricial analyiss of science. Specifically, Frank was concerned with the threat posed to "liberal education" (201) by specialization and fragmentation.  He felt there was a way to recover some unity, by focusing on the "cross-connections" between the sciences. He promised a new coordination of the human sciences under the banner of physics. (201) The problem he construed as linguistic, several fields used "the same words in totally different meanings and, what is worse, in slightly different meanings." (Frank quoted on 201). Frank thought the tools of logical-empiricism could address and possibly resolve this issue. (201-202) There was also a pedagogical side to Frank's goals: he though that bridges could also be constructed by making clear the "human values which are intrinsic in science itself." (202) nd here too he thought logical-empiricism could help. (202) Isaac desribes Frank's ambitions as "a rehabilitation of the cultural ambitions of the [Vienna] Circle, which had encomapssed adult edution, urban and eocnomic planning, and architectural modernism." (203) Isaac says tha tmostly Frank was able to "fit these activities into the internal/external divide that characerized this history and philosophy of science at Harvard." (203) But also in some of his discussion of the "'behavioral' aspect of the validation of scientific theories" the different interesting in scientific control fo science that went back to "Neurath's socialist faith in the potential for scientific ocntrol of science showed through... " (203)

* Another approach -- that Isaac says was more squarely planted in the Harvard Complex tradition -- was devleoped by President Conant in his attempts to formulate a plan for "general education." He too was concerned with fragmentation. He had earlier attempted to solve the problem via a course on American history, but this was viewed as a failure. He tried again in the 1940s, and came to focus on the case-study as a way to teach an understanding of scientific process -- in particular the "challenges" of overcoming certain intellectual problems in science case-by-case -- to people who were not trained as scientists and thus lacked a scientific. Isaac notes that Contant's interest in the "challenges" faced in overcoming certain problems betrays a sympathy of the internalist "artisanal" conception of epistemology. (209) A striking quote by Contant that really shows Isaac's point about this use of the Harvard Complex's artisanal conception of epistemology:

> The texture of modern science is the result of the interweaving of the fruitful concepts. The test of a new idea is therefore not only its success in correlating the then-known facts but more more its success or failure in stimulating further experimentation or observation which is in turn fruitful. The dynamic quality of science viewed not as a practical undertaking but as development of conceptual schemes seems to me to be close to the heart of the best definition [of science]. It is this quality which can be demonstrated only by the historical approach, or else learned by direction professional experience. (208)

* So Conant believed that the effect of science could only be demonstrated via the "case method" (see 208-209), and in this shift Isaac notes a transformation of the Harvard Complex: "The artisanl conception of epistmeology that the merging of pedagogy, research practice, and knowledge-making had created in the era of Henderson had changed its meaning in the early years of the Cold War. Now the case study was being used not to make or validate practitioners of a craft, but as away or encouraging those who did not possess a scientific conceptual scheme to apprecaite the activities of those who did. Instead of seeding disciplines, the pedagogy-cum-epistemology of the Harvard Complex was attached to a general education program the purpose of which was to reach beyond disciplinary boundaries." (209-210)

* Kuhn reconceived of Conant's solution. Contant's theory had ideas about how one could "demonstrate" the scientific method to nonscientists, but he did not understand how scientists themselves acquired the ability to conduct scientific investigations. His theory here which emphaszied the "stumbling" way in which problems were overcome just glossed a great men type of theory that went back to Henderson's artisanal view of the history of science. Kuhn fixed this by collapsing the distinction between how one would demonstrate scientific inquiry to nonscientists themselves worked. In his 1962 The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, he "pushed Henderson's and Conant's pedagagoy into the analysis of science itselfand thereby combined it with an account of research practice and the creation of empirical knowledge." (211) His book contained a "novel synthesis of the theories of pedaggoy, epistemology, and research that had developed in the Harard complex since World War I." (211)

* Isaac describes Kuhn's own epistemological views on 210-217. Key is the fact that he himself grew out of a education that noteably lacked much disciplinary training. Key is a moment in which Kuhn is reading Aristotle's Physics and has an eiphany in which he sees the world through the whole set of assumptions that Aristotle had employed to animate his physics. This shift of view forms the basis of Kuhn's basic ideas in which it is taken as axiomatic that the underpinnings of the scientists' working method is secured and reinforced and animated by a wide set of commitments, or what he calls in Structures a "world view." (see also 222 for that wording).  The views that he developed on the way to this broader claim, Isaac traces in notes on reading he did in history and philosophy of science:  1) a criticism of the idea that the "relationship between theory and experiment, or between a concept and its application, could be accounted for in the terms of logical postivism or operationism." (216). For him, most scientific statements according to "verification theory" or "operational analysis" would be meaningless because they "did not lead directly to confirmation in immediate experience." (216) But the point here was ultimately about language: "how language both conditioned thought and mapped onto experience." (216). 2) Coming out of child learning, esp. Piaget's idea abot how children developed conceptuaizations that filtered the physical world's complexity; this led to a distinction between the "physically visible world" and the "pscyhologcially visible world." (216) All this comes together in a quote on 216-217, which is great, where he puts this together: we great gestalt's/conceptualizations of the world, we isolate objects and give them names. So "We are thus consciousn of the phys[ical] r[eal] w[orld], but can only 'see' and can only talk about the psych[ological] r[eal] w[orld]." (217) Then science he says is an attempt to "minimize the verbal equipment implied by (or inherent in) the" psychologcial real world. So then sicence changes the psychological real world, and brings "new features" into it, ultimately "expand"ing it. He ends the quote: "Thus the process is contuing." (217)

* Then Isaac traces the move to Structure. The key historiographical point seems to be at the end when he notes that while Kuhn's hero in terms of the "priority of paradigms over rules" (ie. because in the earlier draft of the book, Kuhn has spoken not of paradigms but of rules, and then moved twoard paradigms, which stresses more the unconscious nonconsensual but merely existing factors securing certain ways of thinking and operating) was Wittegenstein, that in fact it could also have been Henderson and Conant, for his "description of paradigm-based pedagogy was similar in may respects to the practitioner's logic of cases and instrumental, resarch-enabling coneptual schemes outlined by Henderson and Conant." (225) For further proof of this, Isaac notes that Kuhn did not actually describe any "pedagogical regimes in particular fields" that he at the same time insisted were "so vital in explaining the potency of paradigms." (225) I.e. there was no systematica historical study of such institutions and their effects on figures like Newton, Einstein or Boyle were initiated into their disciplines. Isaac asserts "It would seem that Kuhn eschewed the history of science pedagogy and relied, in addtion the novel fifth chapter of Structure [in which he lays out the theory of paradigms], on his own familiarity with the pedagogy of the case history in the teaching of non-scientists." (226) What Isaac means here is that Kuhn somehow used the "pedagogy of the case history" that Hendreson and Conant drew on in making his argument... I think. ...  Then in the next paragraph, he assserts that Kuhn was always involved in the pedagogical side, and that the point was to disabuse students of the "textbook" view of science in whcih science was seen as an "imposing body of knowledge" and not a process. So then what Kuhn did was to take this case-based thing futher, as Isaac said at the start. He had used the case-based pedagogy as a teacher and also applied it to the "knowledge-making activities" of scientists; that is, unlike Henderson or Contant, "Kuhn used pedagogy to explain the historical cases of scientific advancement he employed in the education of non-scientists."

* Isaac ends this chapter cleverly: "This [Kuhn's use of case-based pedagogy used to education non-scientists as a way to explain scientific advancement] was not quite a closed circle or a feedback loop. What we see in Structure is yet another combination of pedagogy, research, and epistemology in the Harvard complex." (226) What does this mean? It means that this approach of Kuhn's was another form of the scientific philosophy tradition of the Harvard Complex...

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text:
Summary and Critique

In this article Handler presents the dilemma facing Benedict in he rprocess of self-formation.  He explains her attempts to work that out in anthropology and the ultimat efailure of that project on the level of individualism (138-139), at least in terms of standards of addressing the political and structrual reality that she was in,  i.e. the growht of corporate hierarchies that destroyed "individuality."  

Nonetheless, Handler, perhaps because he needs an out, says in the end that Benedict finds her identity as the objective scientist, and he makes a compelling case for this, presenting some of her confident language from Chrysanthemum and then dropping a quote by Joyce about the modernist artist's non-personality (as opposed to sstream-of-consciousness).  But then he goes to far, saying "Benedict ...in her anthropological writing achieved the integral personality that she and so many of her contemporaries sought."  (140)  The trouble with this claim is that it doesn't answer the charge that Sapir would have made that a scientific identity is not an authentic identity at all.  Handler senses this, though, in the last sentence: "That postcolonial, postmodern anthropology has produced a spate of biographies, histories, and literary-critical analyses of our ancestors testifies, perhaps, to an inauthenticity that we perceive in ourselves and that we try to escape by writing the storied lives of others." (140).

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text:
p.132 Handler's version of Benedict's key idea

"Benedict's key ideas was that cultures are configured or integrated around one or a few dominant drives, themes, or patterns.  The obverse of the ongoing diffusion of culture traits is the absorption of borrowed traits into a preexistent culture whole.  Benedict argued (in almost unavoidably personifying terms) that each culture selects from material available ot be borrowed, as well as from the creative productions of its own members, and reinterprets the materials that it 'chooses' to incorporate.  Such selection and reinterpretation are to be accounted for by the existence of a 'fundamental psychological set' or 'configuration' that can be taken to characterize and permeate the culture as a whole." (132)

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.022-22Basic Hypothesis

Huntington notes the various theories about the "new phase" of politics: "--the end of history, the return of traditional rivalries between nation states, and the decline of the nation state from the conflicting pulls of tribalism and globalism, among others."  (22)  

He thinks these all catch "aspects of the emerging reality." (22)  

That reality will be defined he says by "cultural" clashes:  "It is my hypothesis that the fundamental source of conflict in this new world will not be primarily ideological or primarily economic.  The great divisions among humankind and the dominating source of conflict will be cultural.  Nation states will remain the most powerful actors in world affairs, but the principal conflicts of global politics will occur between nations and groups of different civilizations.  The clash of civlizations will dominate global politics.  The fault lines between civilizations will be the battle lines of the future." (22)

title: The Dainty and the Hungry Man: Literature and Anthropology in the Work of Edward Sapir
text:
p.051-52 Sapir's interesting in "apprehending subjectivities"

Handlers say that Sapir became interested in "aprehending subjectivities rather than developing abstracted overviews of an objective reality." (51)

That interest is expressed in his writings on art as well as his critique of the superorganic he says.

And: "These insights are combined in the issue tha tmost interested Sapir at htis time, the relationship between the individual creativity and given cultural forms." (51)

Second plank: that "a cultural pattern, a patterning of values and attitudes, would be something like the formal paterns of art and language".  Handler cites Hymes, Linguistic Method in Ethnography, 260-1.

Both blanks united he says i the notion of "unconscoius patterning....The idea that individuals "intuit" pattern and that this intution allows them to participate in patterned social action without at the same time being coerced by 'society'--the intitution allows them,in short, to communicate with others in interaction without thereby surrending the possibility of creativity--cements a theory of culture that accounts both for given form (Iculture) and the sujective experience of individuals." (52)

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text:
p.015 - 24 Rise of polygenism and anthropometry 

Patterson goes over the development of the polygenism v. monogenism debate here.  There is in general a growing belief in polygenism rooted in physical anthropology or anthropometric  studies of brain size and a move away from studies of language which had generally served to prove common origin.  By 1840s intellectuals very synthetic to theories of degeneration and polygenism.  (22)  Decline in study of language i 1850s (22-23).

title: Autonomy in Moral and Political Philosophy (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
text:
Section 1.3 Autonomy in Moral Philosophy

This discussion begins with Kant.  Kant understood that the "self-imposition of universal moral law is the ground of both moral obligation generally and the respect others owe to us (and we ourselves)."

Practical reason in his mind "pressuposses that we understand ourselves as free."

Freedom implies that there are no external barries, bu tit also "reuqires that we utilize  a law to guide our deisions, a law that can  come to us only by an act of our own will."

So for Kant "self-imposiion of the moral law is autonomy."

Kant's Categorical Imperative is firstly that "by virtue of our being autonomous we must act only on those maxims that we can consistently will as a universl law."

Because this moral law is univeral we also owe respet to everybody else in relatoin to their capacity for autonomy...

More recent discusison of Kantian autonomu downplay the "transcendental nature of practical reason"

She moves on to critiuqes of "autonomy-based moral views"...

(84).  Stocking also cites other publications of his: Race, Culture and Evolution p. 141, and What is in a Name? The Origins of the Royal Anthropological Institute: 1837-1871" Man 6 (1971): 369-390; "Franz Boas.' Dionary of American Biography Supp. (1973).
