title: Critique and Crisis: Enlightenment and the Pathogenesis of Modern Society
text:
Notes for thinking on Crisis:

Koselleck describes the effect of the absolutist state as forcing a wedge into the consciousness of the subject. The sovereign took the entire responsiblity for ruling and thus pacified the subject. The subject in turn submerged their conscience, which placed upon them a huge burden of guilt -- presumbly becuase their conscience would lead them to act in certain ways, but that right had been ceded to the sovereign, who had all responsiblity, but not guilt because he acted.

Then later Hobbes, who is aware of this situation because he expereinced the rise of the Absolutist state in France, when Henry IV was assasinated.  His answer to the problem it seems according to Koselleck was to relieve the pressure created by the separatiton of guilt and responsiblity in the conscience of the subject by interpreting the subject as always driven by "passion" "by a ceaseless striving for power which iends only in death" (25) In his analysis, the subversion of ethics to politics in the Absolutist state is less significant or meaningful beacause in his analysis the key and deeper difference is between the subject's struggle for power (war) versus his desire for an escape from this struggle (peace). Koseeleck writes: "The need to foudn a State transforms the moral alternative of good and evil into the political alternative of peace and war." (25)

Anyway, here you have "passion" as a key guide for...the Hobbesian anthorpology of human nature. As I am tracking the idea of which emotions are central this is key. Need to see how Koselleck develops this...

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.095 Women Challenge the ideas about women's natures

Having noted the empirical pscyholoigsts attacks on the links betwen morphology and human intelligence, Rosenberg argues that it was women that drew out the implicaitons of these ideas: "Not until scientists began training women as researchers did the revolutionary implications of some of these experiments for the understanding of woman's nature become evident." (95)

title: The Origins of American Social Science
text:
[Convergence/Divergence in DR's Story]
In DR's chapter "The discovery of modernity" i noticed that convergence/divergence is an issue.  She tells in essence a sotry of divergence starting on 10 with a description of the variants of liberalism, tracing those varitants into a divergent course of scientific thought, positivistic v. historicist, these two traditions increasingly becoming mutually exclusive.  
She's after a science that does both.  And she puts this interms of convergence at the very end of the chapter.  On the one hand she notes that by the mid-nineteenth-century "more positivistic varints of social science and a more historicist historiography beagn to assume distinct and sometimes conflicting identities." (20)  Ranke is the historicist who charged Hegel's "rationalistic system" violated empritical standards of historigorpahy; historians criticizes Buckle's attempts to find deterministic laws of history in Egnalnd.  Comte and Spencer both urging "sociologists to look beneath the vents chroniclaed by historiography and did not feel obliged to test their theories agians the full complexity of the historical record."  (20) 
Still she says "substantial areas of congurence and contiutiy remained..."  She mentions Marx and Toqueville (having just pointed out that Marx's sociology unliked either Specner or Comte "worked from close contextual study of the historical record.")  (20)  And she's also taling about "political science and history [which were] intertwined around the study of national political institutions." (20)  
Then she says, however, that divergence was the trend.  In the second to last paragraph that in the  early nineeenth century under the "pressure of social conflict"  the "liberal social sciences of the Enligthenment split into conflicting ideological programs and liberal social scientists defensively reasserted their vision of modern social harmony.  In contrast to historiograhpy, a major spheres of social sicence became more abstract and systematic, seeking positivistic scientific laws to stabilize the uncertain course of history and gain the authority of nature of rtheir contested social programs." (21)  
Then the last pargarph notes however that these factors were wieghted differently in each national context.  (21)  In that manner she sets up her next chapter analysis of the way it was weighte in the U.S.  
===
The thing is here that her wholse story is in fact an attempt to trace this divergence and label it as a bad thing.  She implies then that the appropriate kind of sociological study is one that balances historicist and positivist methods... 
It makes me think of the last sentence of her introduction in which she speak sof the hermeneutic circle of the historian.   After noting Pocock's problem of the fate of the republic in time is the question of her social scientist...she says this is the basic problem that sustained her because it allowed her to grapple at a "deeper level" with the menaing of the Republic on the one hand and the problem of historical relativism on th eother... i..e on the univerality of the republic? and the potential that it is jsut one solution that will also pass away???  
I.e. the basic question of historicism v. postivism at the bases of the republic itself?  In any cases, she then points out that "Such grappling is the only answer there is to the historian's endless regress of contextuality.  The hermeneutic cirlce, fo rall the limitations it places upon knowledge, gives us access to the happenings of history and the experience of life." (xxii)

title: 'Passionlessness': An Interpretation of Victorian Sexual Ideology, 1790-1850
text:
00 Summarial Note 00

Cott presents the female Victorian sexual ideology of "passionlessness" -- the idea that women by nature lacked lustfulness -- as an ideology through which women were able to claim to possess the characteristics typical of "moral beings" that is rational and intellectual beings.  Cott writes: "The correlation between passionlessness and a distinctly improved view of women's character and social purpose begins to suggest the appeal of the concept to women.  By replacing sexual with moral motives and determinants, the ideology of passionlessness favored  women's power and self-respect.  It reversed the tradition of Christian mistrust based on women's sexual treacherousness.  It elevated women above the exalted purity, felicity, and glory.  It postulated that woman's influence was not ensnaring but disinterested.  It routed women out of the cul-de-sac of education for attractiveness, thus allowing more intellectual breadth.  To women who wanted means of self-preservation and self-contorl, this view of female nature may well have appealed..." (228)

title: Ideas and Institutions in American Anthropology: Thoughts Toward a History of the Interwar Years
text: [4] [Stockings' Narrative of Rise of Culture Concept] Stocking makes the argument here as he does in "Franz Boas and the Culture Concept" that the idea of culture was implicit in Boas' ideas even though Boas didn't articulate it. Statements to this effect in this article... "Boas' thinking about the problem of classification may in fact be interpreted as containing in germ most of the assumptions of his anthropology, both in its critical, and less obviously, in its constructive aspects...[then two paragraph later] Building from the assumptions such as these, Boas developed the systematic critique of evolutionism which, along with the puritanical methodological posture implicit in it, is often seen as comprising almost the whole of his anthropological viewpoint. But although never systematically elaborated, there was implicit in this negative critique a more positive orientation. By a kind of inversion of the process of anthropological undeerstanding, one could generate a picture of the fundamental processes of culture." (4)

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text:
p. 282 - 4   Occupational Segregation

THIS SECTION VERY IMPORTANT


Description of women's entry into female profession: "The development of predominantly female professions paralleled the expansion of education and welfare institutions.  By the 1840s, the spread of the public school system had brought middle class women into teaching just as the antebellum 'print revolution' facilitated their careers as authors.  In the late nineteenth century, the proliferation of urban welfare services, hospitals, and public libraries led to the entry of women into social work, nursing and librarianship.  In all these areas th eneed for a cheap, abundant labor force harmonized with prevailing notions of 'innate' female abilities." (282)

They ask what is the consequence of this "feminization" of the professions.  Much literature describes the consequences as negative.  E.g. Ann Douglas, The Feminization of American Culture (1977) and Suggs Motherteacher: The FEminization of American Education (1978).  "DDouglas links the vapidity and sentimentality of Victorian culture to the hegemony of women; Sugg asserts that the sibustitution of female for male teachers subverted acadmeic authority and led to a 'pedagagy of love' which fostered anti-intellectualism in American schools." (283) 

In health care, more positive argument argues that "women fostered a noninterventionist, holistic, prevention-oriented approach toward health." (283) 


Why was there segregation/feminization of certain professions?

1) because of perceived "...'fit' between economic need and cultural conceptions of gender roles." (283)

What was the segregation? 
Engineeering, law and ministry were not accessible to women in 19th century.  Some gains between 1850 and 1890 in medicine.

Where gains were made again often b/c of special raitonalized need for feminine traits: "The idea that innate feminine modesty and virtue necessitated treatment by women doctors stimulated the growth of a small but significant female presence within medicine, espeically in obstetrics, gynecology, and psychiatry." (284)

This idea that women could also perform special task b/c they could go into certain areas that men could not access, e.g. with Boas and with Protestant evangelical missionaries, who though women could get into places where "heathen" women were secluded.  

Their conclusion then: "Although the entry of middle class women into the professional workplace appeared quite revolutionary at the time , the patterns of occupational segregation an distribution that developed reflected and sustained male authority.  The feminized service or 'semiprofessions' remained low in autonomy, prestige, and financial reward.  The highest positions of power within the women's fields, i.e. t, the school superintendent, head librarian, and the agency director, were usually occupied by men.  In nursing, where a female-headed hierarchy did developm, women still operated under the formal and informal guidance of doctors and hospital administrators; in contrast, in the develpment of home economics as a professional field, women retained control of the educational institutions until th epremier genreation of careerists retired and was replaced by male social scientists, genreally in the 1960s." (284)

title: Organizing Knowledge and Behavior at Yale's Institute of Human Relations
text:
p.226-7 Institute of Psychology at Yale

Founded in 1924 at Yale under impetus of James Angell (new president of the Uni and long-time proponent of functionalism) and Robert Yerkes.  The goal was to provide a central research station that would increase Yale's limited stature in Psychology compared to Chicago and Columbia (Yale had only produced 8 PhDs between 1903 and 1921) compared to Chicago's 51 and columbia's 46).  In 1924, Yal ereceived a five-year trial funding of $40K per year.

"Yerkes's idea of a centralized research station was well received, and the management combintaion of Angell, Yekes and the Memorial was fertile.  At the turn of the century Angell had been one of the Unitersity of Chicago's foremost proponents of functional psychology.  Through is administrative experience during the war and then as president of the Carnegie Coroporation he had developed functionalist arguments for creating cooperative, well-managed, and generously endowed research programss in the human sciences." (226)  Morawkksi sites Angell's Psychology: An Introductory Study of the Structure and Functions of Human Consciosuness (1904) as his most famous book on functioinalist psych.  She also points to his article "The Province of Functional Psychology" in Psychology Rev (1907), v.14: 69-91.  For other cites see M's f.n.#21.

Ultimatley, though, M says it failed: "The institued proved to be sipmly a high-powered psyhology department where members, exonerated from undergraduate teaching and equipped with new laboratories, were free to pursue their independent research projects." (227)

title: The Culture of the Thirties
text: p. 168-170  Culture, Threat to Self and "commitment"

title: The New Woman: Changing Views of Women in the 1920s
text:
p. 375 -8 Social Commentators Views on New Woman in 1920s

Freedman argues that there were optimistic but mixed assessments overall.  

-- Women seen as poorly utilizing the vote in a 1920 statistical study and that they hadn't voted predictably.  The implication of the study was however that "women were politically handicapped--bot by a psychological incapacity for politics, as some critics claimed, but only by lack of experience." (376)

-- She notes a 1927 forum in "Current History" which include positive comments and negative ones.  Charolotte Perkins Gilman wrote here and Carrie Chapman Catt.  Detractor artiles were for example: Anthony Ludovici, 'Women's Encroachment on Man's Domain" Current History, 27 (1927): 21-25;  Hugh L. McMenamin, "Evils of Woman's Revolt Against the Old Standards" ibid., 30-32.

-- V.F. Calverton who she describes as a "[r]adical editor" saw economic indep. as more important than political enfranchisement. (376)

-- Many including Calverton noted the persistence of anti-feminist attitudes.  376-377.  

Freedman summarizes like this: "In spite of indications that only limited women's rights and not braoder feminist goals had been advanced, the optimistic writers of the 1920s generally hailed the participation of women in American society and the end of discrimination." (377)  She argues a bit later that writers "strained to emphasize the positive..." (377) "...they confidently portrayed the period as one in which feminist goals were well on their way to fulfillment." (378)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.095-103  Women's Researches

In these pages, Rosenberg desribes the research done by Hollingworth ain undermining traditional assumptoins about female physiology which was used to argue for the lesser capacity of women to perform professional work.

Hollingworth's first research began in response to noticing that in a study of her husbands on the effects of caffeine on metnal and motora abilities, that no mention was made of the impact of menstrual periods on women subjets even though he had had women record these occurences.  She could not in the end find any correlation between menstruation and any periodic incapacity.  (95-97).  Instead, she "attributed the 'strinking disparity' between received wisdom on this subjet and her empirical findings to the bias of most authorities." (98)

Hollingworth also drewon a study by a woman doctor named Clelia Duel Mosher on the impact of menstruation.  Mosher had found that there was little evidence that peirodic incapacity occured as a rule. (98-99)

These conclusions confimed what Thorndiek, Woodworth, and others had also found with regard to fatigue: that "the mind enjoys a certain independence from the body." (99)  This was not Rosenberg says a return to Descarte's mind-body dualism: "they all accepted the post-Darwinian belief that the mind is rooted in physical structure and physiological forces.  They increasinly doubted, however, that the lik between the body and mind was s simple and predictable as Darwin's early followers had thought." (99)

Next Hollingworth attacked the thesis that men were more variable that women and that therefore men tended to reach the peaks of ability as well as the lows.  Holloing worth began this study after she received a full time job as the New York first civil serice position at the Clearing House for Mental Defecives, run by the City of New York.  Hollingworth noted that the reason there were so many more retarded males at her clinic was because of "there eing mahy more boys under siteen years of age than there were girls of the same age." (100)  She speculated that there weres social rathe rthan natural cuases for this fact, which would have previosly been explained with reference to the theory of male's increased variablity.  Because boys were less restricted, she said, they more often enocuntered the law, whereas women were proteted.  Women encoutnered the law perhaps only afte rthe deaht of her hsuband or after ecoming a prostitute.  she wrote: "there seems to be no occupation which supports feebleminded men as well as housework and prostitution support feebleminded women..." (quoted on 100-101).  These observations reinforcd her bleief that women were just as variable as men. (101-102).

The last line of defense Rosenber says of men when it came to women wa sto assert a "maternal instinct" as a last word in matters of sex difference.  Thorndiek for exmaple contineud to believe in maternal instnaict even after he had discarded the idea of instinct in regard to self-preservation as too vague.  (102)  At this point Holliongworth, accused experimental psychologists of using a double standard when it came to women.  "In most of their work, they condemned anthropomorphic thinking and the careless definition of instincts...[and]insisted that researchers should subjet the assumptions that dominated pscyhological work to th emost searching criticisms."  But then when dstudying sex differnecs they returned to voentional platitude.

Hollingworth thus wrote: "Thsu in time, may be written a psychology basedon truth, not on opinion; on precise not on acecdotal evidence; on accurate data rather than on remnant of magic.  Thus may scientific light be caset upon the quesiton so widely discussed at present and for several decades past,--whether women may at last contribute their best intellectual effort toward human progress, or, whether it will be expedient forthem to remain in the future as they have in the past, the matrix fromwhich proceed the dynamic agents of society." (quoted on 103).

title: Anthropology and Antihumanism in Imperial Germany
text:
p.068 German Anthropologists on Darwinism]
German anthropologists disliked Darwinism.  They referred to it dirisively as the "monkey doctrine" (Affenlehre).  They disliked it because it 1) interpreted nature as changing and historical, whereas they wanted to see nature as static, 2) because it implied that the "human could not be understood as a single idea but rather was part of a continuum that also included animals." (68) Also referred to this as "transformationism." (68)

title: The New Woman: Changing Views of Women in the 1920s
text:
p. 378 - 380   Historians' Views on New Woman

-- First histories pub. in the 30s, but reflected views of years before '29.   (378)

-- Charles & Mary Beard e.g.  Women had they had greater role in shaping numerous realms.  But they saw some negatives too: were wworried about "the decline in authority of fathers, defiant and divorce-prone women, and the 'more intransigent' demand for "'absolute and unconditional equal opportunity' in every sphere" of an equal rights ammendment." (378)

-- Slosson and Allen both treated positively shifts in fashion, sexual revolution etc which were seen as zones of liberation, see Slosson 378.  Allen saw dep changes in "feminine ideal" in fashion shifts.  

Freedman argues that these historical views refelect the tendency in the 20s to present women as "flappers, more concerned with clothing and sex than with politics.  Women had by choice, the accounts suggested, rejected political emancipation and found sexual freedom." (379)  The term feminism she ays "nearly dissapeared from historical accounts. (379).

Women writing histories about women tended to focus more on the political and less on the flapper, though.  (379)

-- She notes critical history by Sophonisba Breckinridge's Women in the Twentieth Century.  It offered a"sobering contrast" and suggested that "perhaps women were not the emancipated, satisfied participants in Amerian society that historians were describing." (379) But her work was not widely consulted (379-380)

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text: p.008-9 Prof. Historians' and Amateur Hist. Raise Level of Culture Higham links historians' snese of purpose to the edication of "culture" in the US in the 1880s. "Niether a professional ethic nor a mature professional organization came into being over night in 1884. These developed gradually and did not become distinct until the twentieth century. The new school of Ph.D.'s, although quite self-consious in the eighties, had not yet found its place in American culture. It needed the help and sought the aid of everyone seriously interested in history. Aid was readily extended, for the better amateur historians fully shared the professionals' interest in raising the standard s of cultural activity in America." (8) So 1) Goal is to raise level of culture; 2) Amateurand Prof historians collaborating on this in early years. Note also Higham uses language of "maturity" when discussing the prof. "organization." Other "agencies" involved in attempting to raise the level of culture. The metropolitan art museums (most est. in 1870s), nondenominational magazines (the Nation, Atlantic Monthly, the Century, Scrbiner's) "labored to elevate and guide a national middle-class audience in the pursuit of culture and respectability." (9) The Naiton the most important: "[t]hroughout the last third of the nineteenth century it was the authoritative voice of the patrician and academic intelligentsia." (9) E.L. Godkin recognized lack of organization in that "chaotic mass of persons scattered from Maine to California to whom mental culture is of the great objects of the mortal life." (quoted on 9). Higham writes: "By the end of the century the chaotic mass had undergone an organizational revolution comparable ot the trust movement in American business. There was even, after 1898, a National Institute of Arts and Letters, an honorific, self-appointed body modeled on the great European academies." (9)

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1053 Existing accounts examine professioanlization without Gender

He provides citations.  He also charges them with accepting a model of professionalism that came from teh professionals themselves. (1053)

title: Liberalism Repatriated: Prospects of an Anthropology of Antiracism
text:
p.334-5   Multiculturalism

In this context he defines multiculturalism as:                                                        "Multiculturalism is one form of assimilationism, which says ‘you are different from us, but we accept you as such’." (334)  

Such multiculturalism grew out of the account of the development of assimilationist liberalism, but it had inherent paradoxes.   B/c he wants to say it expressed tolerance of difference, but a difference that was not "Real" because it was a difference capable of institutional representation.  

In a circular logic then he defines "Real" difference  as difference that is "beyond institutional representation." (335)  He sees instutionalization of difference as a "flattening out" of Real difference, one that requires that the "aborigine" perform an authentic identity, which in fact it is impossible to perform.   An identity "that is idealized by politico-legal apparatus.[sic]" (334) -- in particular Povinelli's quote on 334 specifies that that identity must be "a domesticated nonconflictual 'traditional' form of sociality and (inter)subjectivity." (334)

This distinction of Real v. institutianlized difference he links to Zizek's critique of multiculturalism as a a "postmodern racism" that consistst of a "sanitized multiculturalism" which presents no "real Other"...i.e. a form of difference that can not be "subsumed under the logical of transnational Capital." (335) 

[But then doesn't one risk an alternate idealization of Otherness -- in which the Other must be impossible form commercial society to subsume?]

title: Shipwreck and Autonomy: Rawls, Riesman, and Oppen in the 1960s
text: 00 Summary Note 00 Esteve is mounting a criticism of the New Left or portions of it that she says depended on a "countercultural logic of alienation." These people including the likes of Mario Savio urged that they and others were alienated (327) and that the solution was to be found in "authenticity" which she says means simply "being true to one's experience" (328). She picks up Dou g Rossinow's critique of this that, as she paraphrases it, "countercultural authenticity grounded itself not in abstract reason, but in such neo-Romantic and Christian-existentialist ideals as inner spirituality and personal and communal affection." (328) It is the eschewing of abstract principles that she finds troubling, and she wants to argue that Rawls, Riesman, and Oppen develop an argument, sympathetic though critical of the New Left, that offers Autonomy (which she interpetes as free will , see 324, top) as an alternative to autonomy/alienation (argment stated in brief in intro, 323-325). The discussion of this is good. The stuff about Oppen is particularly interesting b/c it gets into poetics a direct engagement in his book On Being Numerous with the 60s radicals some of whom are his literal children. He holds back from their "spirit of fatalism" (which Esteve described excellently in relatoin to the logic of alienation on 330). But he embraces a notion of catastrophe as a useful experience for the building of autonomous persons and this is a theme that Esteve pull througout the three men's arguments, that certain circumstances build autonomy, i..e the difficult historical experience of the 60s youths is a basis for something in these men's eyes ( see in particular, 339-341, 344-5). In the section on Oppen and explaining this use of catastrphe that Oppen conceives of, she also brings in R. Bourne's essay on the "experimental life" where the issue of nonconformity also comes up (337-339). Nonconformity in this essay is given a sort of ambivalent treatment, for it is sometimes associated with the 60s radicals arbitrary rebellion (i.e. not rooted in a project of building themselves into autonomous selves based on real values). An interesting issue that I don't understand, has to do with commentary on the "absolute singular" in Oppen's work. As I understand it this is category that comes from Heidegger. Esteve refers to the "Heideggerian disclosure of singularity under erasure" (340) . In Esteve's description of Oppen's poem, the "absolute singular" is transformed into the main leitmotif of Oppen's book: "the bright light of the shipwreck" (which is the condition in which one can build an autonomy, build something.). See 340-1.

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text: p.013- 14 Westward Expansion & Stripping of Native Lands The plan to move westward into "Indian territories" began a week after hostilities with Englandin April 1783. No officila Indian policy howevr utnil 1789., when constiution was ratified. 1801 Jefferson "adopted the policies that encouraged Indians to become farmers in order to bobtain new land for settlers," but he also advised intermarriage "to redeuce friction between the two and to destroy the distinctioin between savage and civlized people." (13) But as settlers moved in, many such as Lewis Cass -- who became "one of the leadings architects of federal Indian policy in the 1820s and 1830s" -- however began to think the Indians were "unchangeable, in their physical and moral habits, unable to appreicate their own condition, and resistant to education and other attempts to ameliorate their circumstnaces." (13). Ethnology effort came with westward expansion. Jefferson instructed Meriwether Lews and William Clark to gather ethnological info. (13) Cass desgined a questionaire to be filled out by traders, military agents, and indian agents. (14). Many of these accounts confirmed Cass's outlook. In 1823 supreme court case Johjns and Graham's Lessee v. McIntosh "denied that Indians possessed an unqualified right to their lands and vested tht right instead in the settleers who discovered those lands." (14) Even before the logic that the Indians were nomads and not farmers and couldn't change had supported this conclusion via the kinds of argments made by Lock in his Second Treatise on Government that right to land came from the land being transformed through a farmer's labor. (14) 1830, Cherokee forced off their lands in George and sent on a "death march" known as the Trail of Tears to Oklahoma. (14)

title: Of Feys and Culture Planners: Margaret Mead and Purposive Activity as Value
text:
p. 106 - 110   The Fey type and why Bali was Iron-Clad

He anlayses Mead's developing thought about the Fey type.  On bottom of 109, it explains that Mead's idea was that the fey could be stable because there were no internal divisoins.  The fey was not reactive and had little guilt or consicnece or "internalized monitors".  (109)  Sullivan notes that in particular for Mead they  had not internalized the notion of their parents as this internal authority.  

And this was something that Mead generally did not like and he has a wonderful quote from her from a letter to Gorer on August 20, 1936: "No, I don't think I shall eve like Bali as much as New Guinea.  I suppose I put too high a premium on free energy, either free intelligence or free emotion, and these people have neither." (quoted on 109-110, Mead to Gorer, August 20, 1936, N5:4 LOC).  And another to Dollard that Gorer thought the "Balinese happy and I consider that happiness isn't worth buying at such a price.  Not an ounce of free intelligence or free libido in the whole culture." (quoted on 110, from Mead to Dollard, September 23, 1936, Mead/LOC, N5:4).

So in the end Mead had some notion of a free intelligence or libido which she preferred.

title: The 'Warfare State': History of a Concept
text:
Summary Note

The article is best described as a round up of arguments about militarism.  It attempts a classification of these ideas that is useful but not nearly as good as that presented by Nicholas Stargardt in The German Idea of Militarism.  The article is also good in indicating the history of scholarship on the subject especailly from the American point of view.

The categories the author erects are: fear of the ruler's desire to wage war at the expense of his/her people; fear of the warrior; and fear that the merchang might find affinity with war.  So these are anti-political, anti-military, and anti-economic. (130).

The author argues that anti-militarism "fell of in the nineteenth century under the impact of industrializaoitn and Social Dawrinism" but "experieneced a vigorous rebirth in the 18990s in response to rising navalism, jingoism, and imperialism." (131)

Betewen 1900 and 1917, he says all three traditions emerged to prominence.  He notes a difference between Europe and the US.  In Europe, "socialists were carrying the principal burden of reform" and so "it wasw naturally the capitalists who were most frequently blamed...for rampant 'militarism.' (133) But in America "where the middle class was a t the heart of both progressivism and the peace movement" and so it was the soldier and the ruler that were targeted.  (133)

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text:
p.188  McDougal-Mead v. Benedict-Dewey

Sullivan contrasts McDougal's innate temperament with Dewey's "interpration of habits" (he cites Dewey's Human Nature and Conduct, 1930, orig 1922, p. 38) ....  Was McDougal's distinction? Sullivan's wiritng suggests that, and he cites p.22 of 1908/1960 McDougal book.  

Sullivan then connects Dewey and Benedict and notes that Mead had also received a copy of Patterns.  He suggests that Mead's thinking about Temperament and the types outlined in Sex & Temperament evolved from her need to think about types that Patterns provoked.  She was thinking about child rearing and Sullivan thinks she started wondering about a quesiton that Robert Sessions Woodworth, a Psych Prof, had asked: "Wen does an Indian become an Indian?" (189)  By 1935 Sullivan say sthat Mead and Bateson had formulated an idea that "personality" is formed through interaction bewteen "(1) the individuals' original constitution, most specifically the innate propensities toward specific psychological tendencies, inherited from the person's own diret ancestors, (2) the patternsof the individuals' upbringing in a specific society, (3) the accidents of the individual's life, and (4) what Bateson (Mead LC N6:2) specifically called '[t]he norms of behaviours in teh culture in which he has grown up and lives...even though he may react violently against it.'" (189)

title: The History of Ethnological Theory
text:
[3] [Definition of Culture]
Here is a description of cutlure.
"Ethnography is the scence which deals with the 'cultures' of human groups.  By culture we understand the sum total of what an individual acquires from his society--those beliefs, customs, artistic norms, food-habits, and crafts which come to him not by his own creative activity but as alegacy from the past, conveyed by formal or informal education." (3)
This definition seems to draw heavily on Kroeber's description of the superorganic, rather than, say, Benedict's idea of culture which is based on the predicated on the homology of individual "personality."   Kroeber spends a good deal of time designating culture as an accretion of values, habits, skills, etc passed down at a level above the "creative activity" of individuals.

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text: p.

title: The System of Professions: An Essay on the Division of Expert Labor
text:
[125-9, 351-2] [Professionalization and Gender]
 Abbott speaks of feminization of professions as one of the most familiar forms of a process he calls "degraded recruitment."  (128)  This is one of a set of proccesses he explains in his chapter on "internal differentiation" within the disciplines in which a profession divies labor into routine and non-routine pars in order often to become more productive and response to added strains (for examples and explanation see 125-9).  In th eprocess, what had once been seen as professional work is no longer deemed to be and Abbott notes the degredation fo the work is "sometimes accompanied by the degredation of those who do the work." (126) 
 In a f.n. #23, 351-2 he, however, he rejects the idea that "the very of notion of 'profession,' both as real-world label and as social-science concept, is gender- or class-based, and that consequently gender and/or class have been the central determinants of professional development since the Industrial Revolution." (352)  He is not rejecting the connections between professionalism, status, and gender/class concepts.  He suggests that his own theory--which he doesn't specify here and it seems he's referring to his whole book--explains some of the things that the idea that profession is dependent on gender/class ideas more effectively.  
This opinion should be compared with Galambos' statement on p.9 of Public Image of Big Business which i cited in the proposal (in that professionalism opened new opportunities for women b/c it was a more meritocratic system, and Habermas' idea that the destruction of the public sphere was coincident w/ the rejection of paternal authority.  
Abbott's f.n. #23, pgs 351-2, also includes many useful citation on this quesiton, many of them historical.  He say in the f.n. that he prefers the analysis of the connections between gender, status, and profession presented by Maack, "Women Librarians in France," Journal of Library History 18: 407-9.

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text:
p.194	 Mead's Declining Reputation

Sullivan specultes that Mead's disposition to study "affect" or what Bateson called "ethos" (the structure of emotiuon") rather than what Bateson alled eidos "the structure of ideas" accounts for her declining popularity.  

Bateson was apparently imporant for cognitive anthropology, and Sullivan here cites Stephen Tyler's Cognitive Anthropology (1969). 

(194)

title: A category of the human mind: the notion of person; the notion of self

title: The Knower and the Artificer, with Postcript 1993
text:
Summary of Argument

 

Holinger expresses frustration with the term "modernism" and its vagueness.  It is has been used he notes to describe some American political scienitsts and their faith in scientific knowledge and its ability to deal wiith modern problems (26).  But this sense that sceince can restore and order is quite different than the empahiss upon "artist heroes" assocaited with Joyce, Kafka, Eliot, Lawrence, etc... (27)

One link , basically the that knowledge "of the external world was not so easy to come by, that contradictions persisted in human experience, that a real price was paid for the beneifts of bureaucratic rationality, that a large measure of uncertainty was an enduring condition of life, that human beings had a propensity to act irrationally, that it was difficutl to find an unchanging standards for moral judgements, that God might be dead, and that many sensitive indivduals felt alienated from industrial society."  (27)  These things he says both aesthetes and scientific intellectuals thought.  (27)

So what about strategies for dealing with this?  Modenrism he notes is linked to staregies of artifice.  This is the idea that one has to "make meanings anew, our of the reosurces of the self." (28) Idea of the self artist as creative genius and draws upon romantic heritage.

But what about strategies of "reference"?  Are these part of modernism?  He notes (as did DR in the "INtroduction" t othis book, p8) that "modernism" linked to the former and no tthe latter.  He thinks this is an important question and sets up two types: The Knower and the Artificer.  He thinks that the question of whether the the knower, who continues to try to make something out of science, even though knowledge is fragmented, is part of modernism.

His argument is in fact that it is central.  He thinks it may be a better word to describe things going on in this time than modernism.  Anad so he coins the notion of cognitivism, as a cultural ideal common to both modern artists and some modern scientists...(he rejects positivism and scientism on the way to this term...30-35).  Def'n of Cognitivism on 35.

On 36-41, he shows this cultural ideal as being important to some American modernists, typically thought of as advocating artifice: JOseph Wood Krutch in "Modern Temper," Wilson's "Axel's Castle," and Gatsby...

So Holling is trying to put "cognitivism" in the place of modernism, and in so doing, he would try to give the "Knower" his cultural ideal of knowing despite the recognition of fractured subjectivity at the center, and he would sideline the strategies of artifice of the Artificer...

Hollinger also links postmodernism and modernism...noting that postmodernism critics of modernism, criticize modernists for not being referential: "Canonical modernism, it woudl seem, did not go far enough in exactly the directions that most distinguished that modernism from the cognitivist tradition." (44)

His postcript pushes his argument further.  The postmoderni critique, he notes, has increasingly tended to argue that modernists were too cognitivist, even identifying them with the enligthenment tradition.  He thinks this critique is just right...and reveals the centrality of strategies of reference (cognitivism) over strategies of artifice... (

title: The American Woman's Pre-World War I Freedom in Manners and Morals
text:
p. 322(b) De-Sexing of the Woman

"Young--whether in fact or fancy -- assertive, and independent,she experimented with intimate dancing, permissive favors, and casual courtships or affairs.  She joined men as comrades, and the differences in behavior of the sexes were narrowed. She became in fact in some degree desexualized.  She might ask herself, 'Am I Not a Boy?  Yes, I Am -- Not.'  Her speech, inter interest in thrills and excitement, her dress  and hair, her more aggressive seuxlaity, even perhaps her elaborate beautification, which wa sa statement of intentions, all point to this...Indeed, the term sexual revolution as applied to the Progressive era means reversal in the traditional role of women just as it describes a pronounced familiarity of the sexes." (322)

Note: His emphasis on the "reversal" ... this too leading to the anti-feminist argument that women had become "men"... 

Again you can see this a few pages later in more stark terms: "Since young women were working side by side with men and recreating more freely and intimately with them, it was inevitable that they behave like men." (324)

title: The American Woman's Pre-World War I Freedom in Manners and Morals
text:
p. 321 - 2 Shifts in advertisement images of women by 1910

1900: women "are well rounded, have gentle, motherly expressions, soft billowy hair, and delicate hands." (321) 

1910: "they are depicted as more active figures iwth more of their activity taking place outside their homes." (321) 

Women are also being encouraged by advertisements by Campbells or others to get out and be active (321-2)

title: The New Woman: Changing Views of Women in the 1920s
text:
p. 380-383 30s to 40s declin in focu son feminism

From 30s to 40s, Feminism still not a popular subject for historians.  30s and 40s had shifted attitudes toward women's working in context of depression; women forced or pressured to leave jobs.  Later when war created ample opp. for women, there was still no consensus on the "proper place" of women in Americna society (381)  Themes can be deduced from textbooks and "broad surveys of American thought" (381):

-- Connected urbanization -- argument was: "a rising standard of living, more household appliances, and compulsory public education provided women with unprecedented leisure time which enable them to join wome's clubs or to enter the work force." (381)

-- Some authors seemed to relate emancipation and family decline.  They didn't do it explicilty but wrote in a way that "brough them together in the midn of the reader." (381)

-- In terms of enfranchisement, historians "portrayed post-1920 women as emancipated by the vote and by an urbanized, industrialized society, but choosing to remain for the most part in the home." (385) But they did so without acknowledging discrimination.  (384-5)

title: The Effect of Bureaucracy on the Professional Autonomy of Professions
text:
p. 31 Profession Def'n

Engel's summary of the existing definitions is that there isn't any consensus, but that there is sa lot of congruence in the various descriptions.  She cites several people's ideas.  Wilenksy  she says "foucses on both the acquisitin of systematic knowledge and a set of norm which guide the professional's behavior."  (31) This emphasis on acquire dnorms is emphsaized by Sherlock & Morris who se quotes saying it is a "comibination of systematic, often esoteric, knowledge, technique, and self-control throug a system of ethics--all developed to a high degree--which ...differentiates the professional man as an ideal type form members of other vocations." (Quoted on 31).  Others she notes emphasize a "service" orientation, e.g. Goode, 1960.  "Encroachment, charlatanism, and the emerging profession: spychology, sociology, medicine American Sociological Review 25 (Dec.): 902-914.  The Wilensky article is "The Professioalization of Everyone?"

title: Back to Kant: the revival of Kantianism in German social and historical thought, 1860-1914
text:
Notes September 2014:

General comment:

Upon a quick reading of this book's intro and conclusion, what's going on here? Willey frames the book with the late nineteenth-century crisis of the self and crisis o fliberalism. He speaks of the shattering of the Crystal Palace and the emergence of Dostoevsky's Underground Man and Freuyd's libido. But he says there was a "countertendency" -- the "revival of idealism," of which neo-Kantianism was the most important. By a revival of idealism, Willey means the following:

> "The aims of neo-idealism were to reassert the role of human consciousness in the historical process, to establish a methodology for humanistic studies different fro mthat of the physical sciences, and to defend the efficacy of moral striving in th epolitical arean against hte claims of economic determinism." (9)

He puts neo-Kantianism in the broader context of efforts by people like T.H. Green in England and Jean Jaures in France. Key here he thinkw as an effor to "bring liberalism and socialism into line with the new realities of mass industrial society in the closing decades of the century."

This political context is key. Willey sees in neo-Kantianism a potentially useful philosophical movement that might have renewed a liberal individualism whilst also building a bridge to social democratic politics. So he's something like a centrist social democrat. The key context for his historical evaluation of neo-Kantianism  seems to be this bridge. On the one hand, he defines neo-Kantianism in this way: "

> Neo-Kantianism careted an alliance of political sympathy between a handful of left-wing liberals and a number of socialist intellectuals who were dissatisfied with doctrinaire Marxism. It was a promising alliance, prefiguring in part the Weimar Coalition, and potentially capable of closing the chasm of mistrust between liberalism and social democracy." (21)

But by the end of the book that promise of an alliance across liberal-left lines has failed. So the conclusion begins:

> Marburg neo-Kantianism was politically important because it held out the possiblity of an intellectual alliance between liberal reformism and working-class socialism; obstianate prejudices on both sides, however, stood int he way. Prestiguous libearl reformers would hav had to dicard thier bias against the proletriat because of its lack of education and to assuage the bourgeois fear of social evolution. The working-class socialists, on the other hand, would have had to suppress revolutionary cant and to abandon the doctrine of class irreconciliabilty." (179)

In the Preface, anyway, he blaims the failure to succed on the "weakness of the German Reichstag under Bismark's constitution..." (10). But in the conclusion,also, he seems to get at the inherent divides between liberal midddle class professors and working class socailists. This seems to me to be the key issue of the book anyway: why did it fail? And how Willey answers that will determine a lot about 1) his politics, and 2) the qualitiy of his analysis.

Increasingly, having read this, I suspet that Willey is a social democrat; and I thin the critique on the neo-Kantians he is willing ot entertain is that their philosophy was not strong enough to forge a political alliance with  the working class, and that therefore it failed to estalvish the social democratic welfare capitalism that I think he think sis a basicly good  thing, and which he says exists in Post-War Germany, see .eg. p. 103 in his commentary on the Marburg school. Here, for example, he says (in response to Mosse) that they failed to assess "social, institutional, and cultural obstacles in their path..." He means the Old Regime. And in a way that is slightly chilling in terms of the historical caclulus that he sees as turning out somethign good in the end he says : "it took the Hitler period and the catastrophe of 1945 to reduce these obstacles to sufficiently to permit the rise of the broad social liberalism characteristic of the Federal Republic today." (103)

## Preface

## 1. The Political and Intellectual Setting

* The 19th century was the century of the German middle-class' self-invention. Willey describes the nineteenth century as the "age of the German bourgeoisie." (13) He points to great thinkers like Einstein, Planck, Hisenberg, and Ranke. A period ending with Friedrich Nietzsche. It was he says a "seculary Great Awakening of bourgeois talent." But it created contradictory tendencies, and this is where neo-Kantianism begins to fit in. Because the "same generation which celebrated Sadowa and SEdan and flocked to Bayreuth produced the Kantian revival with its critqiue of Hegelian metaphysics and its insistence on rational limits and moral values." (14) It also produced Nietzsche, who was a sharp and rigorous critic of "national hubris as exemplified by his one-time idol, Wagner." (14)

* German middle-classes were also successful economically. Already conditions were set for economic success prior to 1848, with "the establishment of the Customs Union, the mechanization of teiles an mining, the application of chemstry to agriculture, the development of internal transport, and the creation of credit facilities..." (14) But in 1848 the political consciousness of the middle-classes shifted, revealing a "lack of revolutionary realism and a myopic social vison on the part of the middle-class liberal." (14) He also say sthat the economic vision expressed by bourgeois liberals at Frankfurt was "largely self-serving" and this "derpvied them of masds uppport and destoryed the spontaneous revoultionary front of early spring." (14)

* Willey notes that historians have argued that German libearals were not so narrowly laissez faire as their British counterparts. There were fewer absuses he thinks in the factories, and German thought in Fichte, Hegel and List had experessed a more positive idea of hte state. Also because German liberalism developed in the context of "princely and bureaucratic absolutism" there was no real hostility to "social welfare." All these things made German libearlism a bit different, and between 1879 and 1889 the National Liberal party shifted from free trade and laissez-faire to protectionism and social welfare confirms this tendency. But he still thinks that German liberals stood close to Adam Smith. Their interest in regulation to end factory abuses was limited. They did not want to meddle with the Prussian decrees of September 7, 1811 and January 17, 1848 taht "legalized" laissez-faire. All this contributed to the rift between labor and liberalism, which caused the failure of the 1848 revolution, and then depeend in the 1860s. (14-15)

* It was this rift that had become "of great concern to a group of neo-Kantian philosphers at the University of Marburg who attempted to  close the ideological gap with a new kind of social iberalism basedd on the ethics of Kant." (15)

* Contributing to this rift was the German middle classes ideology of classical humanism, ensconcsed in the notion of *Bildung*, and in their support of the monarchy. The point here is a complex one. Willey thinks that the liberal alliance with the monarchy were "designed to justify middle-class recognition by and particiaption in government..." (15) But he notes that the end-result was that "social prejudice militated against success." I think what he means is that the middle-calsses ended up seeing themselves as superior to the working-classes. This feeling deepened during the 1848 revolution, but also it was a product of the ideology of classical humanism. Such a standard, he notes, was "well beyodn the reach of the lowerclasses; it was also irrelevant to their nees  and interests." (16) Ultimately, this ideology, which had begun in a reovlt against artistocratic absolutism, became instead a source of arrogance and the assumption that "they were the exclusive agents of progress and universal rights." (16) Expressive of this bias, was the fact that citizenship required "Bildung und Besitz" -- education and property. And this made German democracy much liek that shaped by the French Constituion of 1791 and the English Reform Bill of 1832. (16)

* From all this Willey concludes that the liberal drive for political opwer and influence did not match its drive for cultural success: "while the middle class was acquiring property, culture, and knowledge to a remarkable degree, its drive for political influence commensurate with its wealth and education was faltering." (16) The problem was that the party was anti-Democratic. So that when Weber and Friedrich Naumann for instance finally got to the democratic point of view, thye were "already outflanked on both sides by the socailist and  Catholic parties." (16)

* Bismark was key here,a nd the liberal reaction to him. He was able to subordinate their political will. He realized their "welath and talent" were necessary for a strong Germany, but he was able to thwart their drive for political aparternship in representative institutions. (17). The liberals fo rtheir part were "dazzled by the brillian vcitories of the Prussian army...[and thus] render ecstatic homate to blood and iron, indemnified the Prussian minister president, and therey traded liberty for unity and national power." (17)

[ It strikes me that it is this that Boas was criticizing so extremely in his political statements in the late 1870s! This drive toward "practical goals" that he identified. ]

* Continuing this last point, Willey writes: "What the liberals had sought for decades to achieve with their own resources was accomplished in a few weeks by the authoritarian state with its order, its army, and its discipline. The expression 'Now one sould accept the accomplished fact' ("Jetzt müsse man sich mit der vollendeten Tatsache abfinden"--according to Ziekursch , a slogan of the victorious hour) was by most accounts a fitting epitaph for German liberalism." (17)

* Here Willey makes an interesting intervention vv the Sonderweg idea. The German liberals in being anti-democratic were not so different than other European liberals. The difference was the context: the "dilemma of liberty and power did not present itself so starkly" for other Euroepan liberals "for to them national unity was a reality of long standing." (18) That it wasn't in Germany, mean that for Germanliberals it was "half a loaf or nothing" (18). They could accept half a loaf and then "look ahead to the prospect of agenuine parliamentatry and lawful state which he could now beging to develop within the new nation created on the field of battle." (18) But that this "evolution did not take place" was Willey thinks a "fault" of this defensive social philosophy among Geramn liberals, just as much as it was a result of the "much-criticized nationalistic trahison des clercs." (18)

* Nonetheless, left-liberalism did not dissapear, even after the indemnity vote of Septbmer 3, 1866. This event was  key shift in liberal attempts to start to work with Bismark, and no longer oppose his military budgts. The indemnity vote came after an election on the same day as the victory over Austria at the BAttle of Koeniggraetz on July 3, 1866, when liberal slost significant ground. The in the indemntiy vote Bismark retrocactively approved the military budgets from 1862 to 1866. But Progressives continued to fight, and under Eugen Richter "vigorusly" opposed Bismark. They reached aa new elcotral peak in 1881, when they brought 105 deputites, becoming the second largest party. In 1890, they had another brief resurgence. Also in 1912. So Progressives werenot dead after 1866. Rather, in the 1890s left-liberals had begunt o consider "at least a tactical alliance with the socialists against Junderdom, autocracy, and big, business." (18) This proccess culmianted in 1912 when the socialists became the largest party in the Reichstag because of assistance from left-liberasls. (18) But Willey says it was "too late." (18)

* The problem he thinks was that the Progressives feared democracy. They never opted for a political democracy but wanted a "constitutional nation-state." (19) E;.g. many progressives participated in the *Nationalverein*, which had begun in 1859 and were aimed at that producing German unity and consitiontual ity under Prussia. (19)

* There were a few that tried to preven tthe working-class liberal split. E.g. Leopold Sonnenmann, Ludwig Buechner, Ludwig Eckhardt, and neo-Kantian F.A. Lange. They wanted to "unite labor with democratic elements of the middle class in common oppositn to social injsutice and the Prussian hegemony." (19) But this didn't work. Most stuck to the "petty bourgeois ...doctrine of *Selbsthilfe*..." (20)

...

 

## 2. Back to Criticism: Rudolf Hermann Lotze

* Lotze was not in any clear sense a neo-Kantian, but his texts becaem important for the neo-Kantians. (40) He is not well-known today but he was very imporant and influential a tthe turn of the century, especially in the US> George Santayana, Josia Royce, William James, etc. Protestant philosophers of the 1880s and 1890s found his work useful. Willey even says that by the 1870s that Lotze waws the most well-known scholar outside of Germany. (41)

* Lotze philsophical develo[ment too kplace "between the classsical era of Goethe and Hegel and the rebirth of idealism in his own lifetime." (41) Born May 21, 1817. His parents were civil servants around Dresden,. He went to Gymnasium in Zittau, near Bohemian border. (41-42)

* Lotze wrote a novel, with a characther named Lotha who Willey says was "an idealized mirror of the author." Lothar was a good example of Bildungsaristokratie, scornful of politics and of the "common people." (42) Lotze thus began from a very classist point of but as he developed his views changed slightly, so that at one point he could be described as expressing an "'idealism fitted to democracy and industrial civilization'" (42)

* In another novel, die Deutschen, he tries to express a metaphysical theory that he never abandoned, namely that there is a spirit in all things, naimate and inanmiate. (42)

* This foray into literature helped him forge the central themes of his philosophy. Nameyl, how could one reconcile metaphysical unity with a m echanistic view of nature? (43)  This led him "back to kant":

> His effort to harmonize metaphysical unity and moral idealism with the mechanical procesess of natured guided him back to the critical and practical philosophy of Kant -- pr pushed him forward to Kant, since he began with the metaphysics of Liebniz and Spinoza. (42)

* Lots was influenced by Fechner:

> Lotze agreed with his Leipzig professor Gustav Fechner that all things possess spiritual pr properites and that God is the ultiamte consciousness of the universe. But he did not follow Fechner into his hteory of parallelsim between pscyhical and physical vents, which was his [Fechner's] solution to the mind-body problem and the problem of knowledge. (42)

* And also Fichte's notion of an "ultimate moral principleexpressing itself in finite objects, and thus creating a teleological unity," which formed a part of his theory of value. (43)

* His thoery of value was his main "bequest" to the Baden neo-Kantians. (43)

* Christian Weisse was his first philosophical mentor at Leipzig, where Lotze began his studies in 1834.  Weisse was a Hegelian. (43)

* He began a medical degree in 1838, but then in 1840 was accepted by the philosophy faculty at Leipzig in 1840. Hen then began work on his marjor work Metaphsik. (44)

* At Leipzig he was part of a elite academic cirlce that included Frechner, Salamon HIrzel, Weisse, The schumanns, and Mendelssohn. (44) This was "German intellectual aristocracy in microcosm." (44)

* In 1844 he goes to Fottingen to accept the chair of philosophy abandoned by Herbart. (44) This made sense given their shared pluralistic view of the unvierse. Infact, Lotze's "pluralist view of the universe and his belief that the taks of philosophy is to find unity behind the manifold of experience wer indebted to Herbart's anti-Hegelian postulate that the world is compsed fundamentally of amny real things." (44) Herbart's influence also explains the interest in Lucretius and Leibniz. (44)

* Lotze was pretty apolitical and during the 1848 revolution he in fact wanted to join a Free Corp that supported the regime! (44) So his reaction to 1848 was "dour and pessimistic" Willey says. He was more interested in working on a new edition of his book *Pathologie* and he turned down na offer to participate in a gvoernment reoganization committte.  H ewrote that in Gotteingen "Whenever possible the subject of politics is avoided." (45) (44-45)

* Lotze was drawin into the Materialismusstreit that occcurred around the convention of naturla scientists in Goettingen in 1845, September. He surprised some given his mechanistic view, that he sided with the anti-materialists. He then became a favorite of anti-scientific people. After this he began to speak more and more in the language of "philosophical criticism." (45-46)

* In genearl the Materialismusstreit was important a key eearly stimulus for early neo-Kantainism, Willey argues, and it brought the "problem of knowledge" inot th elimelight, despite being possibly the nadir of German philosohy. (46)

* Lotze became somewhat political when during and after 1863, during Bismark's battle with the Prussian Diet, he chaffed a bit against the effect of Prussian politics on the university in Goettingen. He was not impresssed with some of the effects of Prussian organization. But he was able to make peace with the Prussian force utlimately. (46-47)

### Lotze on the Limtis of Conceptual Thought

* *Metaphysik* was his break with Hegelianism, and it set him apart fro his teach Weissse, establishing his Kantian orientation, i.e. toward "epistemological criticism" based on the "foundations of Kant." (48)

* Willey say sthat Lotze anticipated Windelband and Rickert in seeing 1) as he put it in Metaphysik "the beginnings of metaphysics is not in itself but in ethics..." (48), and 2) in seeing that although the "unity of phenomena may e grasped in scientific ocncepts, that the "true essence of being is the individual, the particular." (48) The latter anticpated Windelband's division of science into genearlizing and individualizing methods. So this is a way o fthinking that of ourse alligns with what Iggers called the "German conception of history" -- i.e. from Ranke the notion that (against Hegel) "the unfolding of history is not the exfoliation of an abstract Idea--this was Ranke's objection to Hegel--rather,it is the manifestation of the Diviine Personality in concrete meoments of real historical process." (48) The historian in this conception has to search for that menaning in the finite pattern of events. (48)

* So this is an anti-Hegelian idealism of sorts. Lotze said that Hegels' error was to have "identified thought with reality, and converted th erich, living world of concrete facts into a fixed system of abstract categories." (48) I.e. Willey writes that Lotze and the Baden neo-Kantians believed that "conceptual reason cannot be exhaustive; it cannot do justice to individuality or the richness of experience." (48) Willey gives an example of this in a quote from Lotze from *Mirkokosmus*: "What evertyhing is in itself, what its true nature is by which it exists...this may remain forever inaccessbille to thought." And yet: "[Idealism] believes that in nowning the import of what thus happens it possess all essential truth: that isi only for the realization of this truth that things exist." (48-49) **Importantly, this idea cut both against materialists and the Hegelians: "[Lotze] believed that the immediate, phenomenal world exists not for itself but for some purpose -- for something that ought to be. He used this doctrine against the panlogism of the Hegelians who, in his opnion, had said that all meaning and purpose are ventually relaizedin thought--and he also used it against those materilaists who denied taht realitis posssess any transcendent significance." (49)

* Willey says that this tension between "thought and things" is key to Lotze. He argued that thought was inadequate for absolute certainty: "thought, in the last resort, is tentative, and is debarred bythe frailty of human knowledge from the possibility fo arriving at absolute certainty." (qquoted on 49). Willey links this to Kant's phrase in the *Critique of Pure REason* that he wanted to demolish thought to make room for faith. So for Lotze, faith was what was important: "The spiritual link between purpose and necessity, between values and mechanical laws, is a personal God. Much like Kant, he set definite limits to cognitive knowledge, and assigned ultimate metaphysical questions to teh category of nescessary assumptions, regulative ideas, and faith." (49)

* For Lotze, as a result of his desire to limit the hegemony of thought, it was utlimately experience and its irreducibility that became key for him. "In the *Metaphysik* Lotze presented a strong case for immediate percepetion as opposed to the reduction of exprience in concepts. We are, he said, immediately aware that the content of consciousness is too rich to be exhausted in thought." (49) He was aware that this was a dangerous position. In going this way, the philosophy opened up a situion in which the future dpeend on what he called the "chained spirit of cirticism" that could more easily destroy then reconstruct. And indeed he critiqued Kant for this too, for failing to build up a philosophy of immediate experience. But he too, Willey, says ended with a similar solution to Kant's, relying on practical reason as the only guide. (49-50)

[ more notes to be taken here on Lotze's views...]

## 3. Hegelian Manques: Kuno Fischer and Eduard Zeller

* Fischer and Zeller, Willey says, "liberated philosophy from the old tradition of studying philosophical systems in a historical vacuum." (58)

* Bio of Fischer from 59-62. Family was associated with Protestant church. Father was a minister. Mother a daughter of Prussian cavalry officer. (59)

* Willey sees a progress from Fischer and Lotze, through Windelband to Heinrich Rickerrt -- a line of "descent that moved from belief in the immanent and irresistible progressn of the Hegelian Idea in history to a reasesertion of the individual consciousness and will in the form of Kantian and Fichtean voluntarism, a rebellion of individual personality against the seeming fatalism of Hegel." (59) This Willey says was a "protest of the bourgeois liberal spirit in Germany against historical passivity." (59) And it  was he thinks partly a response to the emergence of Prussian power...

* On 62-63, Willey describes a kind of "network of relationships" among the early neo-Kantians in which Fischer was involved. These inclued Strauss, the teacher of Eduard Zeller, Otto Liebmann, who Fischer befriended at Berlin. In 1872, Fischer left Jena for Heidelberg to fill a chair abandoned by Zeller, who had moved to Berlin. Berlin lured Lotze from Goettingen, suceeding in 1881. When Lotze died, Fischer was invited to Berlin, but he declined. etc etc..This is the network Wilely means, a series of "informal associaitons"...

 

### 4. F.A. Lange

 

83-84: Lange wanted to place the "social question" at the center of his work, and to "imbue the working class with a sense of independence and political awareness..." And this putbhim well beuoks the liberal orthodoxy. On the other hand, he was an "individualist ” but believed that "individual effort could be effective only through social cooperation..." (83) He played an important role in the radical movement of the 1860s. (83) He is remembered today for his Geschichte des Materialismus. He was science minded, but like Helmholtz believed that science had limits that needed to be revealed with Kantian epistemology. He accepted what Willey calls the "physiology of the mind" interpretation of Kant. Willey writes that he believed brain science to be "corrected or developed' Kantianism. (84) He used Kant to go "beyond the boundaries of liberalism." (84)

84: Born sept. 28, 1828 in Wald bei Sollingen. Father a minister and later a professor of theology at Bonn. GradFather was a draymen. Wore Blauekittel of the paesent. Sobhe had peasant ancestry. (84)

84-85: He heard Hegel's lectures on phenomenology, but exhibited later little Hegelian influence. He studied Herbart's mathematical psychology. But this to he cast aside. Willey thinks it might have strengthened his "empirical or realist tendancy" (85)

85: April 1848 he goes to Zurich University. Has a conversation with a radical on boat trip to Rhine City and learns of the new "social ideas of the revolutionary era." (85) He did not immediately become a social Democrat. But he did find himself impressed by the national Parliament and he shifted toward agnosticism. Willey suggests that his "appeal to the comparative method of reducing all religions to their anthropological rudiments, and his acknowledgement of science as the secular creed of post-religious man were typical reactions of the educated to free thought at the time. (85) He d
Did not participate in the 1848 revolution, discouraged in part by his parents. But he was filled with a cosmopolitan spirit and like many liberals saw no conflict between nationalism and cosmopolitanism. He wroteva friend. "Within you own borders build an altar to cosmopolitanism." (85) he joined the Novemberverein at Bonn, a group dedicated to discussion of culture, but he did not increasingly like the idea of keeping Bildung from the general population. He wrote that he had a "burning need for the practical and immediate life." (85)

86-87: Had this belief in the link between physical exercise and free thinking typical also of the Turnervereine. Reminds me really of the folks in the We are the Revolutionists book.

87-88: Lange began planning in summer 1857 a lecture series on the history of materialism, and this was the beginning of his opus, Die Gesschichte des Materialismus, that emerged nine years lter. Between 1858 and 1862 he was an instructor at Giuisburg, where he had previously been a student. This was a period in which his interest in Kant increased. W quotes a letter:

> "I think that Hegel's system," Lange wrote, "is a regression to scholasticism." Speculative philosophy is passe. "Herbart," he continued, "with whom I originally agreed, was for me only a bridge to Kant, to whom many genuine schoalars are now returning." But Kant went only halfway. It would still be necessary to destroy metaphysics completely. "I believe that every metaphysics is a form of delusion, with only aesthetic or subjective justification. My logic is probability statistic, my ethics is moral statistics, and my psychology rests entirely on physiology." (87-88)

88: W then makes some useful observations vv neo-kantianism and Lange's developing views. He notes, succinctly, what I already thought to be true: "It was characteristic of early neo-Kantianism to e very suspciious of metaphysics..." (88) Lange, he said, however, often went much further to the ponit he says of falling into "cliches of popular empiricism." (88) But his "uncritical empricism" was W says "mellowed by an appreciation of music and art." (88)

88: Drawing out this influence of Kant a bit more, W reflects more generally on Kant's initial role vv early neo-Kantiansim. The "original resurrection of Kant", he says, was "inspired by suspicion of metaphysical monism, both Hegelian and materialist." (88)

88: Following his history of materialism, Lange, he notes, wanted to write a book on psychology. But he never wrote it. This W says links Kant to other early neo-Kantians eho "equated Kant's transcendental method with psychological analysis of the mind." (88)

91-92: Lange's realtionship to socliasm: Lange active in politics between 1862 and 1870. He wrote a polemical work, Die Arbeiterfrage. Here his being a grandson of a peasant mule skinner meant, W thinks, that Lange did not feel "constrained by the conventions of intellectual liberalism." (91) In 1862 he clashed with the educational bureuacracy more intensely and he began to sound, W says, like an English Benthanmite. (91). i.e. local control of schools, society should be semi-autonomous assocaitions; state whould only have police power. etc. His model was English cooperative assocaitions and he started a cooperative assocation in Dusiburg based on this example in 1862. Looked forward to consumer cooperatives on Lousi Blanc's national work schop schemee. (91) He worried also about socialism's neglect of rural labor, and the creation of a what W calls a "blue collar aristocracy." (91) Because he liked cooperatives, he iked Hermann Schulze Delitzsch's work, but again critiqued the focus on the elite of labor at the expense of the *Lumbenproletariat*. (92) Nonetheless, his views were close enough to the socialists that he particiapted in the Arbeitervereine conferences in the early 1860s and had the respect of August Bebel and Marx and Engels, although they saw him W says as no more than a "sympathetic bourgeois fellow-traveler but recognized that his introdcution of the urgnet social question to democractic circles was very important." (92) In Oct 1864, he was a delegate to the convention o th German Arbeitervereine and was eelcted to tthe steering committe with Bebel, Hirsch, and Sonnemann. This W says happened during the perio dof "cordial if short lived relations between socialist and democrats." (92) He separated from the labor movement in 1866 but before that he spoke a great deal throughout the Ruhr valle and in these talks W says he singled otu the acceptance in germany of "everything fromt he top." (92) He wanted the labor mvomvent to "assert its strength through its own economic and political institutions." (92)

92-95: Die Arbeiterfrage, published in 1865 by his own company. First edition was propagandistic, by his own admission. Second edition was more thoughtful. He conducts an excursus of Malthus and Darwin in first chapter. The struggle for surival that Darwin described had been transmuted into industrial society, but at the same time people ahd lost the means of production. (93) So the worker can never rise above basic subsistence. "Society" he interpreted as a "industrialized version of Darwinian nature" that could only be improved by democratijc evolution and "cooperative efforts of an independent proletariat." (Willey's workds, 93) On the other hand, Willey explains that for Lange "[c]onflict is not inherent in human relations; it is the pernciicous consequence of maldistributed political and economic power." (93) That seems to be a contraadiction in a way with Lange's willingness to use the struggle for surivial of Darwin as a the basic frame. Willey doesn't go into this. (93) But the point seems to be that Lange believed that there was a historical process underwawy that would transcend conflict: "Since the 1840s, rational and moral considerations ahd begun to mitigate the struggle. Either in fear of revolution or out of genuine sympathy the capitalist class wasgradually curbing the excesses of industrialism. Urban life itself, by bringing poeple of difference classes into closer contact with one another, was producing an empathy that cut across class lines. The social conscience of Western Euroep had been awakened. And the worker himself, through trade unions and cooperatives, was becoming self-reliant. The union movemet, as Laange accurately observed, had not made the proletariat more revolution but more conservative. The trade unions were an escape valve for class hostility, a source of working-class solidarity, and a constructive means of improve the worker's lot." (93) He was, in other words, looking forward to a "equaitable worker's capitalism" as Willey puts it (94), that would grow out of cooperatives and credit unions. He didn't think you could abolish private property on the small scale, but you could on th elarge scale increase "social proeprty" (Willye's phrase, 94). Willey quotes, presumably Lange, in saying that his vision of social progress would "enrage the Marxists and please the pragmatists." (94) Willey compares him to the French "possibilitsts". I.e. firs tworkers acquire political influence, then they organize cooperatives, then they break up herditary property rights, et c etc.Interestingly he rejected Locke in Kantian terms, rejecting it on the the idea that "the freedom of one should not diminist the freedom of others." (94) And the utlimate goal here was to encourage the unfolding of the self's full capacities in th way that Bildung indicates. But in this sense, he treated Bildung as a "social ideal" Willey says, and not as a "prerequeisit for political activity" as was the case for many German liberals. (94) He remained skeptical of Bismark's policies because o fhis indvidualism, writing in 1865 in the *Landbote*: "Germany must be free and unified; however, a unity in which freedom is oppressed and despotic military government is introduced is not progress but the greatest of conceivable dangers." (quoted on 94) By the 1870s, though, Willey says that Lange had tired of fighting politics in writing. (94-95) Ultimately, Willey says that Lange moved from being a liberal to a social democrat, but in doing so he held onto his 1) individualism and 2) hostility to revolution. (95)

95-99: Lang's critique of materialism. What was materialism in Germany? It became the "philosophical persuasion" of "democratic intellectuals," W says, in 1848. and then came under criticism in the 1850s by "those who found it an inadequate basis for science or politics." (95) So before Lange wrote, people like Buechner, Moleschott had "denied the independence of consciousness from matter, of mind from the physical processes of the body." (95-96) This was the "struggle for the soul." (96) And it began first in public at the Goettingen convention of natural scientists in 1854, and had become less important by 1860, because people like Liebig, Helmholtz, and Lotze "had repudiated the rather primitive materalism of Buechner and his associates." (96) So the value of the materialist debate was that it called attention to the limits of science and cut against crude scientism. Kant was therefore useful because he could be pitted against this crude materialism. Kant "argued that our scientific knowledge is limited by the modes of perception which determine the form of sensuous experience. Our minds work in conjunction with sensuous experience, but th emodes of percepti9on are a priori." (96) Willey then puts the value of Kant for the anti-materialist cause very clearly: his concept of pure reason was valuable "becaue it preserved the autonomy of consciousnss, while neither making ungrounded metaphysical claims for its powers nor denying the indispensability of experience." (96) Now Lange followed Helmholtz in to his critique. He had heard Helmholtza at Bonn in 1857. Lange believed that materialists had not explained consciousness.
