Lange thought that modern psychology and physiology had "shown that the world investigated by physical scientists is a world that depends on our perceptions; it does not have an independent existence -- nor is the observer a mere reflector of it." (96) So W says Lange's objection was epistemological and not spiritual or religious. That is key! (96) But Lange did not want to fall from materialism into skeptcism. Thus, although Kant was good for attacking materialism, he was less good in generating an enduring system: hence the "neo" Kantianism. Lange and others wanted to regenrate Kantian criticism for a new project, and the source of new energe for Lange and other early neo-Kantians came from what Willey calls their "psychologism": their belief that recent discovries in the nature of the sense organs had in Lange's terms "develoepd or corrected Kantianism." (97) So this "hard turn" shows that neo-Kantianism, in it early phase, was a revolt against "scientism" bu tnot against science Willey points out. (97) In Lange';s history he dated the end of idealism and the beginning of materailism in Germany to the July Revolution in France. That was the moment that as Lange put it: "philosophy lost its magic the moment it was palced in the service of absolutism." He saw Heine's migration to Paris as symptomatic of the situation after 1830. (97) Lange also blamed Hegel and his left-wing disciples for materialism's problems. Willey writes: "Hegel had confused reality with its manner of appearing to us; then Ludgwig Feuerbach transformed Hegel's identity principle into quasi-materialism with his equation, 'truth, equality, and sense are identitical.'" So Feuerbach ets equated "sensibility with reality..." This was an "anthropocentric modification of Hegel" that could be used to attack religious and secular authority, Willeysays. [Note: it's very hard to see here where Laange's analsysis ends and Willey's starts]. Then Arnold Ruge's *Hallische Jahrbuecher* formed these radical Hegelian ideas into a "weapon of political opposition." (98) Basically, all these moves ignored, from Lange's point of view, what Willey calls the "phenomenal nature of experience" that Kant had demosntrated. Reality is forever inaccessible etc etc. But the point here is that because this materilist turn came also from the Hegelian/idealist side, which ran so deep in Germany, Lange was attacking both the materialists and the Hegelians. One had to resist the anthropocentric humanism of the materialists, and the metaphysical absolutism of the Hegelians. (98-99)

99-100: VV ethics. In line with his desire to resist both materialism and metaphysical absolutism, Lange did not trust the idea of moral absolutism or that there was a way to reach a scientific foundation for ethics. So he had to downplay or he did not know well those latter work of Kant in the send and third critqiues, where as Willey puts it "the limtis of theoretical reason are surpassed by moral and aesthetic judgement." (99) How did Lange see Kant? Willey says he saw him as "a demolisher of dogmatic metaphysics, of Humean skepticism, and as a fideist in morality and religious beliefs." (99) He liked Kant the empiricisit still. Willey describes Lang'e smoral philosopy as a "mixture of eudaemonism and teleological idealism with a voluntaristic twist typical of early neo-Kantian ethical philosophy. It's somehow the voluntarism that is key for Willey. He says that Lange's moral philosp[hy was "designed to inspire practical action." (100)

 

### 5. Neo-Kantian Socialism

102-3: Marbrug school is associated with Herman Cohen, and marks a new phase in the history of neo-Kantianism. These philosophers left b ehind the psychologism of Lange and rejected what Willey characterizes as the "untenable analogy between brain psychology and Kant's forms of perception." (102) They hewed more closely to Kant and were less enthusiastic positivists. But they retained Lange's democratic socialism, and the goal of getting the working class interested in neo-Kantian politics. There was a turn here, though, back toward "transcendental critique." (102) and toward a "purely logical inquiry into the prior conditions of thought." (102) Key figures: Herman Cohen, Paul Natorp, Rudolf Stammler. Plus younger followers: Franz Staudinger, Karl Vorlaender, Kurt Eisner, August Stadler, and Leonard Nelson. (103) Mosee apparently, in the *Germans and the Jews*, argues that these guys attempted to "solve the problems of the modern age by creating a force that could eliminate the unpalatably capitalist and materialist present." " (103) Willey agrees, but rejects Mosse's further argument that they rejected pract ical compromise and gradual reform for an ethical absolute represente by Kant's categorical iimperative. (103) He thinks they saw "history and politics as a process of education guided by reason and by the moral idea of free men exercising their rrights and responsibilities in a constitutional state." (103) There was an elitisim, he admits, and a notion that they as a philosophers could see the shape of Utopia, but he thinks they did not "porpose a conflict free utopia in some mythical new Germany". They pointed he thinks to "the social welfare capitalism realized in West Germamy today." (103). So, as I note above at the head of these notes as well, he criticizes the Marburg school here for failing to see the obstacles that stood in their way, but not for being impractical or rigid in their critique.

104: He notes that the goal of the Marburg neo-Kantians was to "propsoe a new democratic, evolutionary socialism as an alternative to both the revolutionary dialectics of Marx and the bourgeois liberalism of the educated classes." (104) But they failed also in terms of timing. They aroused some interest among social democrats, but the thinks too late. The middle classes already committed ot the Hohenzollern military monarchy. I.e. the "apogee of Marburg neo-Kantianism unfortunately coincided with Wilhelmine *Weltpolitik*, the Pan-German movement, the rise of gian industry, the spread of fashioanble irarationalism, and the erractic diplomacy of Bismark's successors. The social liberalism, humanism, and moral rationalism of the Masrburg philosophy were overwhelmed by the political rhetoric and clanking machinery of empire." (104) Then the Marburg group shattered. And Paul Natorp became a "latter-day propheet of the German soul; during the war he preached about the incompatibility of German *Kultur* and Western civilization." (104) Willey notes wisely -- and this coincides with my suspicion of the weakness of neo-Kantiansm -- that "[h]is Kantian ideals had no foolrppof protection aginst nationalism." (104) Cohen and Stammler were also "militant patriots," he says, but they worke dout a middle gorund, while Cassirer ramined a bit closer to the Marburg tradition. Then Cohen died iin 1918 and the Marburg mostly died out until eclipsed by the philosophies of Husserl and Heidegger, two Marburg students. (104) \

....

 

### 6. The Southwestern School

* This school was Wilhelm Windelband and Heinrich Rickert. Also known as the Baden philosophers or Willey refers to them as the Baden sages. The Baden philsophers were more interested in practical than theoretical reason. In moral questions. than the Marburg philsophers. They were less interested in epistemologijcal criticism. The division can be drawn too starkly, though, Willey says. The Marburg philosophers were also interested i n ethics. And the Baden philsophers were interested in logic, but as it related to history and to the humanities. Thus: "they differed from the Cohen group in their greater intereste in a critical philosphy of values for the understanding of history rather than in the logical structure of the natural sciences, bua greed that there was a conceptual division of reality and purpose, or Being and Values, and that reality and purpose unite in moral action." (132) Compared ot the Marburg school they were much less interested in pract ical politics or social problems! (132) There was an admiration of Fichte, whom they admired sometimes fmore thyan Kant. Rickert published an aritcle saying that any future "political science on idealist liens wolud have ot follw in form Fichte's *The Closed Commercial STate*."( 132) Willey, of course, wants to defend them a bit. But less os here. He seems to prefer the Marburg school. He seems somehow more willing to accept criticism of them in the form of Ralf Dahlendsorf's accusation taht they wwere "deficient in their liberal idealism." (132) Stil he says strangely their "cultural philosophy had characteristics which implied human of an undeniably Westenr provenance and scope." (132) He descirges their "Weltanschaung" this way:

> The Baden Weltanschauung believed in a world under the order of rational moral precepts, a historical process infused with the ideal purposes o f men, and a cultural life measured b y enduring, universal standardsof value. As opponents of historicism , Windelband and Rickert sought the universal nature of values, while Stammler looked for the universal nature of law. This was a reutrn to the mode, not the substance, of natural law thinking characteristic of eighteenth-century Enlightenment. The Baden philosophers wrote extensively on the signifiacne of individuality in history--a strait of Romatnic historiography-- but basically they were rationalists. They wanted to find the univerasl value represtend in each unique historical event; therefore, Baden neo-Kantianism was inherently ihumnanistic and universal. (133)

* Having said all this, though, Willey really lets tham have it for their iealism. Their desire to "establish permanent values" he thinks got them in trouble. The idealism led them to "dissolve real problems into spiritual and moral categories..." Here he qutoes Ringer: "The analysis of polticial realities was neglected, and realtively little attention was pasid to quesiton sof political technique. These matters were felt to be trivial." (133) Cohen worked ith politics, abut Windelband and Rickert W says were "consistently engaged at a veyr high level of abstraction, and their preoccupation with cultural values doubltess drew their attention away from everyday issuees." (133)

 

### 7. Individuality, Society and Humanity

* This chapter is key in terms of the overall historical questions taht Willey wants to deal with. The point is that that the German state had by the end of the century been established, but this consolidation of power had revealed the state to be frequently amoral and often to involve ethically questionable expediencies and compromises. The old idealist notion of Hegel that the "Immanent Reason" would be revealed in the state, and that the state would express both power and liberalism unified, had fallen away, but the succesful consoldiation of the German state had raised a new problem: namely that the "actual power" of the state raised this tension between the "ethical absolutes of German idealism" and the demands of actual power in an amoral world. This was the old Kantian question, the tension between practical and theoretical reason. And the neo-Kantians were in a good position to analyze it, Willey wants to say, but they faced serious challenges: especially, the power of the state itself, but also the political awakening of the masses. Would their philosophical system become just a defense of bourgeois right -- as the Marxists' susepcted -- or would it be able to build a real progressive force? There was a failure, that much Willey admits, in 1930!! (154) But he thinks this was not predetermined and he thinks that the neo-Kantians were positioned to help. Their influecne was felt strongly after 1890. There was a massive increase in interest in Kant, marked by the coming into existence of journals like the *Kant-Studien* or *Logos*. (155-156). But this fad of Kant was not always about libearlism: some read Kant as a defnse of mindless bureaucratic and miltiaristic obedience, e.g. Eichmann quoted Kant in his trial! (156)

* Troeltsch, Weber, and Meinecke were all influenced by the neo-Kantians, by the problem of the tension between relativism in history and permanent or universal values. They were haunted by these questions. Troeltsch appreciated Rickert's attempt to bridge the gap between the historicist-relativist apprecition of individualities, and universal history and rational principle, but he thought he failed. See quote on 159. He thought that the historian was stuck with immanent analysis and he couldn't accept Rickert's transcendental critique. He thought that Rickert's attempt to reach rational principles in history ended up smothering individuality and immanence, and he ultimately preserved an interest in immanence. During the wary, although he was less nationalistic than the likes of Paul Natorp and other supporters of the "Ideas of 1914", he was concerned that the "special virtues of German life" would be overrun, and so he proposed a central European confederation consisting of Germany, the Danubian monarchy and its sattelites as a bulwark against the West. (160). Weber was also inspired by Rickert and the neo-Kantians, and by Simmel as well. But his goal was "value free inquiry" and so made much of Rickerts' separation of the two domains of science: history and natural cience. He thought it possible to characterize values as a historian, without judging them. And this critique was directed in part at Natorp and others who were using their position as Professors to "preach Germany's cultural mission" as Willey puts it. ( 164) The comment he directed at them, quoted on 163, was: "I hold that a lecture is different than a speech." (163). I.e. Natorp et al were giving "speeches," mixing their subjective value judgement with the representation of the role of values in history. ( 161-165)

title: Anthropology and Antihumanism in Imperial Germany
text:
p.01-3 Humanism and "The Other"

Zimmerman notes that the humanities in Germany (=Geisteswissenschaften)
had been informed by imperialism.  "For Hegel, Franke, and the ensuing tradition of historicism, the subject of humanistic knowledge was identified as European through the self-consscious exclusion of Africans, Asians, and others.  The goal of history, for both Hegel and Ranke, was self-knowledge, and the self was defined in Manichean ethnic  terms.  The paradox of non-Europeans for the European human sciences -- a paradox that dated back at least ot sixteenth-century debates about the inhabitants of the Americas or perhaps even to Aristotle's theorizing about slavery -- was that they were human yet could not be acknowledged as possessing full 'humanity.'    Humanists notions of the self were both defined and profoundly threatened by the extinction of humans whom Europeans regarded as inferior.  A number of scholars have recently shown how this very notion of a European self was worked on in the colonies so that the 'self' of humanism and the 'other' of imperialism were twin births.  For all its provincialism, German humanism was, from the beginning, a global discourse that made sense of the colonial enounter by defining a European self unaffected by it." (2-3)  

The books he quotes in relation to the working out of the humanisitc self in realtion to imperialism's other are: Cooper and Stoler, eds., Tensions of Empire: Colonial Cultures in a Bourgeois Wrold (1997); Mary Louise Pratt, Imperial Eyes: Travel Writing and Transcultuation (1992); Ann Sstoler, Race and the Eeducation of Desire: Foucault's History of SExuality and the Colonial Order of Things (1995); Gauri Viwanathan, Masks of Conquest: Literary Study and British Rule in India (1989).

title: The American Woman's Pre-World War I Freedom in Manners and Morals
text:
00 Summarial Note 00

One of the central points in this article, as referred to in Freedman's article "The New Woman: Changing Views of Women in the 1920s" (1974), was to destruct the idea that the revolution sexual morals that many saw in the 1920s, was really accomplished in the 1920s.  Rather, McGovern argues here that it occurred earier in the 1910s at least.  

McGovern makes this argument quite clearly at the outset, see 315-316.

title: Lost Manhood Found: Male Sexual Impotence and Victorian Culture in the United States
text:
p. 36-37 In Early Republic Impotence is Fertility Problem

Within what D'Emilio and Estelle Freedman have called a "reproductive matrix" which was a "family-centered system that encouraged sexual relations within marriage and treated nonprocreative acts as sings against God..." (36) -- within this system it is logical that fertility problems and sexual impotence were seen as one and the same thing.

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.085-  Leta Hollingworth Bio

Hollingowrth married to Henry while they are still in college at the University of Nebraska.  They get married but it turns out that Leta cannot work as a teacher in NY becasue married women were not allowed to teach.  (85) She becomes depressed, but her husband is sympathetic and recognizes her need to work, see quote on 85.  Henry finishes his PhD in 1909 and decides to support Leta in a program in educational pscyhology at the Teacher's Colelge (85).

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1057-1058 Failure to Provide Status & Autonomy.

Professionalism promised status & autonomy.  Walkowitz thinks their record was mixed on this.  

Status: "Status came from the social worker's position of authority over lower-class clients, who were dependent on her judgement.  To her middle-class peers, however, the lower-class background of such clients minimized the status of social work." (1058) 

Autonomy: After WWI "many city agencies consolidated and centralized social services in organizations like the Community Chest and the Federation for Jewish Philanthropies. Administrators and board officers endorsed rationalization--specialized assignments with supervision, casework procedures, and stadardized report forms--as improvements in work. " (1058)
At the Jewish Board of Guardians in NYC an affiliate of the Federation for Jewish Philanthropies "the most highly trained professional staffs, bore the brunt of the increased rationalization." (1058) 

Walkowitz argues that despite the argument f Sharon Hartman Strom that rationalization may ultimately have been to advantage of empoloyees b/c it minimized "abitrariness" and defined jobs (1058), that nobody liked it.  And in fact "social workers complained of overwork and condemened their jobs as dependent and routinized.  In annual reports, the JBG executives, who were themselves usually trained social workers, confirmed what caseworkers experienced every day: high case loads and low salaries persistently undermined professional achievment." (1058) 

In f.n.# 24  Walkowitz has an oustanding quote by Harold Silver of the Jewish School of Social Work regarding this feeling of being routinzed in 1929. 

Men were often given preference within the profession over women for "privileged aminitrative positions. (1059)

Women also increasingly had to defer to men with medical jobs such as doctors or psychiatrists. (1059)

title: An Essay on Taste
text: Paul Guyer describes this book as an origin of the idea in the Scottish tradition of the free play of the mind as pleasurable that also appears in Kant (coming from Leibniz and Sulzer). He says this on p.154 of "What Happend to Kant in Neo-kantian Aeshtetics? Cohen, cohn, and Dilthey" Philsophy Forum, v39.no2 (2008).

title: Jewish renaissance in the Russian revolution
text: The time for words has passed -- The constitution of culture -- Unfettering Hebrew and Yiddish culture -- To make our masses intellectual -- The liberation of the Jewish individual -- The imperatives of revolution -- Making Jewish culture Bolshevik

title: The Varieties of Religious Experience
text:
Chapter 1:

p.13-14: distinction between "existential judgement"--into the origin and causes of a thing--and "spiritual judgement'--into the meaning of a thing "once here" (13).  Ie the Bible may be evaluated in terms of a whole # of questions about who created it, how, why etc, but these quesitons of "historical fact" can still leave open another quesiton about the "revalation-value" of the text....ie with all its errors the Bible may be seen as having value "if it be a true record of the inner experiences of great-souled persons werestling with thecrises of their fate..." (14)

p. 19-20: In footnote critiquing the tendency he ses arouund him to explain (away) religious experience as a product of some variety of "perverted sexuality", James notes that "[t]he plain truth is that to interpret religion one must in the end look at the immediate content of the religious consciousness." (20) The point in the footnote as in the text on these pages is that one cannot and should not explain "our own exalted soul-flights by calling them 'nothing but' expressions of our organic dispositions..." (19-20) He finishes this off as a critique of what he calls "medical materialism"...

p.26: So the text for the "empirical philosophy" (pragmatism" is not the "origin" of religion but "the way in which it works on the whole...This is our empiricist criterion..." (26) And James insisits that even the "stoutest insisters upon supernatural origin" have ultimately had to use this criterion as well, to determine what sorts of religious expereince are legitimate and which are just silly.  He says Jonathan Edwards' Treatise on Religious Affection is of this order.  "Practice" is the only sure proof to others and ourselves that "we are genuinely Christian." (26)

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text: p.014-15 Very Stocking Type Account of Boas' Critique of Evolutionists

title: The History Manifesto
text:
Notes 5/2015:

Introduction

* World is undergoing a crisis: "We live in a moment of accelerating crisis that is characterised by the shortage of long-term thinking." (1)

* They are basically advocating for "thinking about the past in order to see the future..." (4)

* The way humanities appears irrelevant to power and policy problems leading to a sense of "crisis" in the humanities: "The humanities can appear 'soft' and indistinct in their findings compared to the so-called 'hard' sciences. they can seem to be a luxury, even an indulgence, in contrast to disciplines oriented totowards professional careers, like economics or law. They rarely compete in the push to recruit high-profit relationships with software, engineering, and pharmaceutical clientele. And they can be vulnerable to new technologies that might render the humantiees' distinctive methods, such as close reading of texts, an apprecaition for abstract values. and the promotion of critical thinking over instrumental reasoning jejune. The humanities are incidental (not instrumental), obscolescent (not effervescent), increasingly culnerable  (nto technologically adaptable) -- or so their enemies and sceptics would have us believe." (6)

* Way to address this they think is to be creative basically, and to draw on history. "Indeed, in a crisis of short-termism, our world needs somewhere to turn to for information about the relationship between the past and the future. Our argument is that History -- the discipline and its subject-matter -- can be just the arbiter we need at this critical time." (7)

* They talk about the "compression of time in historical work" -- most dissertations between 1975 and 2005 focused on at most a 50 year period of time. In 1900, the average number of years covered in a diss was 75; in 1975, closer to 30. They link this to a process whtouhg which "professional historians ceded the task of synthesising historical knowledge to unaccredited writers and simultaneously lost whatever influence they might once have had ove rpolicy to colleagues it nhe social sciences, most spectactularly economists." (8)

* But this is changing the authors say. There is now "an expanding universe of historical horizons, from the 'deep history' of the human past, stretching over 40,000 years, to 'big history' going back to the ig Bang, 13.8 millsion years ago. Across many fields of history, big is definitely back." (8)

* Importantly, they link this as well to the "rise of big data and problems such as long-term climate change, governanace, and inequality..." (9) And they site a new "sense of responsibility"  and they urge a sense, quoting Richard Drayton from an article "Imperial History and the HUman Future" that "how they [historians] tell the story of the past shapes how the presnet udnerstands its potential, and isthus an intervention in the future of the world" (9)

* The say that none of this is new and site the longue durree ofFernand Braudel. But this is not the same as that. "The new longue duree has emerged within a very different ecosystem of intellectual alternaties. It possesses a dynamism and flexibility earlier versions did not have. It has a new relationship to the abounding sources of big data available in our time -- data ecological, governmental, economic, and cultural in nature, moch of it newly available ot the ens of digital analysis." (9) DIGITAL ANALYSIS!!!

 

 

 

 

Big Questions, Big data

* Section talking about how historians are trained to analyze data in a particularly useful way and should take the lead in the "arbitration of data" (107)

* In particular, historians are good at "noticing instituitonal bias in the data, thinking about where data come from, comparing data of different kinds, resisting the powerful pull of received mythology, and understanding that there are different kinds of causes." (108)

* "Historians are trained to look at various kinds of data, even when they come from radically different sources. These are skills that are often overlooked in the training of other kinds of analysts; the reading of temporally generated sequences of hterogenous data is a historian's speciality." (108)

* He is talking about a shift to long duree that would be able to integrate lots of different forms about big data, large-scale cultural change, grand-scale trade evidence, mimgration & displacement, biodiversity data, etc. (111-112)

* This means investment in certain kinds of tools: "We should invest in tools and forms of analysis that look critically at big data from multiple sources about the history and future of our institutions and societies." (112)

* Taking this role, they think, might mean that historians have to "take a more active role in the many public institutions that govern the data about our past and future..." (112)

* The new role of the historians that embrace big data: "If historians -- or any other historically minded scholars, from sutdents of literature to sociologists -- take up this challenge, they may find thsemlves in the avant grade of information design. They could collaborate with archivists, data scientists, economists and climate scientists in the curating of larger and more synthetic database for studying change over time. In the future, historians' expertise could be sought out in sectors beyond the university. Historians may become tool-builders and tool-reviewers as well as tool-consumers and tool-teachers. Indeed, these changes have the potential to revolutionisse the life of some professional historains, as faculty provide data analysis for legislative committees, advicse activist campaigns, or consult with Silicon Valley startups, and thereby regain the public role they traditionally cocupied and deserve once more to regain..." (114)

* These digital projects might entail. Analyses of data that make "interventions" into single-historian produced histories. That they also can "overlay" data from multiple sources -- economic, emographic, political, and intellectual...(114)

title: The Intellectual Legacy of  George Herbert Mead
text:
General Notes

* He makes the claim that Mead's work is not easily undertood because he neve rpublished a book.  Apparently, the book we have is a compliation of his lectures, put together posthumously.  He cites works by Hans Joas, Gary Cook, David Miller, Israel Scheffler, John Baldwin, and Mitchell Boulafia that is important fo r understanding.  (207-208). 

* Mead was born 27 Feb 1963 in South Hadley, MA.  His father, ReverendHiram Mead, was a Professor of Homiletics at Oberlin College.  His mother, Elizbeth Storrs Mead, was educated in a seminary and worked as a schoolteacher.  Little is known about his childhood.  More is known about his early college years at Oberlin.  Oberlin at the time, Hannan says, "offered the sort of liberal arts programme typical of American colleges then under the suffocating and represesive spell of the Church." (209)  But Mead and his friend Henry Castle Albert Mead, questioned Christian belief.  They studied with the common senseea realits James Faircdhild and John M. Ellis to explore Christian ideas and also to question those ideas.  After college, Mead took a job in 1883 teaching at a grade school in Berlin Heights, Ohio.  He was studying Kant's Critique of Pure REason and the Prolegomna to Any Future Metaphysics.  And he began to think about going to Germany.  He took more jobs first ofr the Wisconsin Railroad and then working as a tutor.  In 1885 he learned taht Castle had gone to Berlin and he became more ambitious.  He decided to study philosophy at Harvard.  Joas thinks that Mead was attracted to Harvard becauseit was more liberal.  (210)  He was interested in Josia Royce.  He did not study with William James but was a tutor to James' students and so go to know him that way.  IN 1888, he went to Germany, and enrolled at the University of Leipzig.  Mead studied with Wundt who had set oup a psychology program at Leipzig.  In 1889, he transferred to U of Berlin.  He studied more philosphy and psychology. (211). 

* Hannan mentions importantly, although too briefly, that Mead wanted to reformulate Kant's epistemology because he believed that Kant had "drawn a false distinction between space as 'a form of sensibility' and space as 'a construction of our eye and hand and ear.'" (211) He worked on this problem in his dissertation which was supervised by Dilthey!! This seems key because basically it shows a similar desire to revisit the epistmelogical distinctions Kant made by thinking about the organic basis (eyes and ears) of pscyhological awarness of an external reality (idea about space).  (211)

* Mead takes up a teaching post at Ann Arbor in autumn 1891.  There he meets John Dewey, but also Alfred Lloyd and Chrles H. Cooley!  Hannan writes: "Cooley had himself been influenced by Adam Smith's notion of the looking-glass self, according to which a buyer in the marketplace sees him or herlsef throught the eyes of the seller, while the seller, likewise, sees him or herself through the eyes of the buyer." (212)  Cooley described this as "sympathetic imagination." (212).  Apparently, from Cooley, Mead was influenced to start thinking about "language and the self" as things that "arise from social interaction." (212)  Dewey and Lloyd were still at the time working within a Hegelian frame, but Dewey had already begun his shift away from Hegelianism, and picking up on psychological functionanlism.  Hannan mentions his "Reflex Arc" article.  (212) 

* In 1894, Dewey was offered a position at Chicago, and he accepted on the condition that Mead would be given a postiion too.  It was at Chicago that Mead developed his "social psychology, his theory of self, his ideas for social and educational reform, and, eventually, his moral theory." (213)

* First key development in his thinkin g at Chicago was "his synthesis of Hegelianism and progressivism." (213)  He critiqued Hegelianism in an article in 1901 entitled "A New Criticism of Hegelianism: Is it valid?".  His poit was that Hegel's thought was being mis interpreted by people attempting to bring to "consciousness the form in which essential problems present themselves and the formwhich their solution must take." (quoted on 213).  What Mead insisted is that the task of philosphy was to discover the dialectic process in "practical situations". ie, he though the process of thesis, antithesis, and synthesis was evident in the working out of problems, and most importantly in the activity of the self, which, Hannan writes, "is perpetually engaged in the process of a creative overcoming of contradictory objects of thougth and desire." (214) 

* Hannan argues (in what seems to me to be an unclea rstatement) that Mead  saw himself as "develping a scientific approach to social reform."  And that he believed that "all social problems were amenable to scientififc solutions." (214) Mead he says worked on the idea that the social realm, like the physical realm is governed by laws, but he also wa convinced that human behavior was dialectical in nature.  I cna't quite follow Hannan here, and I suspect his language is off, but he writes of an article by Hannan called "The Working Hypothesis in Social Reform" from 1899 that "Mead argued in favour of laws that establish the conditions for the free reign of dialectical interchange and opposed laws that mistakenly sought to determine the outcome of social relations." (214)  Hannan's point is that in his "scientific" outlook on social life, Mead "opposed fixed programmes and solutions that do not permit creative growth and discovery." (214)  He like science because of it's open-ended methodology of inquiry, a bit like Charles Peirce it seems. 

* Dewey said that Mead's initial "haunting question."

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text:
p.051-52 Continued small ness of Anth

One reason it was still "small" and not "centralized" was the persistence of
local or regional anth. societies that challenged hegemony of Washington
Anths and Boas.  E.g. Edgar Lee Hewett who founded the Archaeological society of New Mexico in 1898 and became a spokesman of arcchaeology in the West.  Hewett succeeeded when a bill of his went oup agianst a bill backed by the Smithsonian, the AAA and the Arhchaeological Inst of America, and Hewett's won with the help partly of Charles Lummisof LA who was politically powerful.  (51)   Hewett also lobbied the Arch. Insitutte of American to establish a School of American Aracheology in Santa Fe, himselfas director.  1907 he launched a field school attended by Harvard students Alfred Kidder and Sylvanus Morley who late bcame prominent.  By 1910 Hewett consolidated his influence and could counter the arguments and criticism of others.  E.g. in 1990 Putnam,, Boas and Bowditch took criticisms to annual meeting of the Archeological Institute of American and lost.  Hewitt's programs took money that boas wanted for his international school in Mexico.  (51)  Hewett also attacked Boas's integrity apparently in 1910.  (52)

title: Introduction
text:
Notes Summer 2014:

 

* Born in Bordeaux 1843. Father was a military officer, and then turned to law. Father died, he was raised by his monther. He was close to her throughout his life. Attempted to write poetry first, but left it. Was fascinated by math. Considered attending Ecole Polytechnique. But ended up stdying the less demanding law. 1869-1894 he held regional court posts around Sarlat. He read a lot. Read Spencer, where he discovered the "analogical thinking" that tried to discern general principles underlying different domains. From Hegel, he learneda bout dialetic. And John Sutart Mill provided a model of logic and science. He married in 1877, Mlle Marthe Bardy -Delisle, daugheter of a mgistrate. Had three kids. Became interested in crim and Italian criminiologists. Published articles criticizing the Italian school. This became his first book: *La criminalite comparee*, which established him as a leading criminologist. He published in 1890 Les Lois de l'imitation, the laws of imitation. In 1894, he was named director of criminal statistics at the Ministry of Justice in Paris. In 1890s he was frequently in Paris and asked to lecture a great deal. No sociology taught in Paris unil 1902, Clark says, when Durkheim was called from Bordeaux, but there was a lot of interest in "social issues," and this is what Tarde was asked to lecture on. He was asked to teach a course every two years at Ecole Libre des Science POlitiques. Thjese ultimately bcaeme Les tranofrmations du pouvoir (1899). In 1899, eh tried to presnet his candidacy for a chair in modern philosopy at the College de France, recently vacated by Nourrisson, but it did not work. But he was then appointed in 1900 over Henri Bergoson. He died, however, in 1902. (2-6)

 

* Clark says that Durkheim and Tarde represent the influence of two competing traditions in France. Durkheim represents "Cartestianism", identified with "reason, order, and authority, and housed in the bureaucratic institutions exemplifying this esprit de geometrie: the church, the governmental administration, the army, and the state university system." The bouregoisie after the Revolution and under Napolean had raised this orientation quasi-official ideology. But it was with the "creation of the Third Republic after 1870 that assured the ascendancy of the Cartesian mentality..." (8) On the flip side, was the mentality of Spontaneity: the "mentality of artistic reation, romantic subjectivism, and personal invention guided by an *esprit de finesse*." (8) "As the bourgeoisie and Cartesianism came to be more and more identifyed with the established instiuttions in the last part of the nineteenth century, their opponents grew increasingly anti-bourgeois, antiinstiutitonal, anticollective, and, occassionally, revolutionary. Aesthetic, oplitical, and economic attacks were fused in antibourgeois ideologies put forth by the heirs of the traditional nobility, the rural peasantry, or the urban proletariat. Against bourgeois republicn ideologues Renouver and Littre, and parliamentary leaders Cleamenceau and Combes, wer ethe champions of Spontaneity of the left--the anarachists, anarcho-syndicalists, and certain socialists--complemented by the advocates of Spontaneity of the right--the romantic nationalists. Ocassionally, when anti-bourgeois sentiments grew sufficeintly strong, and social ties sufficiently weak, individuals could move from Spontaneity of the left to that of the right without excessive difficulty. The most outstanding example was the theoretician of orgiastic violence, Georges Sorel, who, from an intellectual leader of anarcho-syndicalism, became an esteemed guide fo the Actio Francaise and eventually for fascism." (8-9) In terms of schools, Ecole Polytechnique was the home of Carteianism, opposed by the Sorbonne where Spontaneity found a voice. It's major spokesman Victor Cousin. (9) This was true fo the Sorbonne until the demise of the Second Empire, which was seen Clark says as a "defeat for loose living and unsystematic thinking," and the "new University" was remade in ways that excluded the likes of Victor Cousin, and the reformers tried to emobody the ideals of Cometean positivism, patterning the institutions also after the German research-oriented universities. This happened 1880s and 1890s. Durkheim was the r guy here. Clark writes in Durkheim these reformers "felt t that they had found the man who could best extend the mentality and methods of Cartesianism to the study of society." (10) His work fit perfectly to the idoelogical deamnds of the differnet parts of society, Clark says,: "to the anticlericals he contributed a philosophical basis for a secular morality to replace the earlier Catholic dogmas; to the radical and radical socialist politicians of 'solidarity,' he offered a more systematic grounding for their political philosophy; for the Dreyfusards he provided coherent intellectual guidance." (10) At the Sorbonne, Durkheim came into close contact ith the Minsitry of Education and became "one fo the most powerful university politicains in France." (10) Tarde by contrast had been exose to a more Spontaneous tradition after his own negative reaction to the Cartesian aspect of the Jesuits, at Tolouse and and the Paris Faculties of Law. These places had students who were not radicals but social prominent you men who still glorified the ideology of Spontaneity. He was exosed at College de France to philosophers like Paul Janet, who had apparently made Durkehim delete a chapter form his thesis that was complimentary about Comte, and Jean Zoulet, who was much opposed to the teaching of Durkheim in France's Normal schools, seeing it a "national peril." (see quote on 10). The successor of Tarde at College was Henri Bergson, who Clark says is the apotheosis of the Spontaneous tradition. (11) And TArde's son, Alfred de Trade, a law student, also became very negative about Durkehim. (11)

 

* Clark then goes through Durkheim and Tarde's similarities because they did not oppose each other on every level. In fact, Clark says that Tarde and Durkheim held a whole set of common beliefs about social science. They both recognized: 1) certain key antecedents for sociology, e.g. Montesquieu, Comte, Quetetlet, and Spencer. So they agreed on some common historical roots for the discipline. And this set them apart from French social statisticians fo the time and the disciples of Le Play who would not have agreed. (12) 2) They agreed in what Clark calls their "taxonomies of sociological work", i.e. on the relationship of certain kinds of labor. Both saw colleting data as the loest level and they admitted an eclectic range of data, including ethnographic materials, personal doucuments, legal reecords, government statistics, research-collected data. They believed that meaningful analysis could only come from the specialization of individuals and narrow topics, i.e. on religion, law, the family, the economy, and so on. This allowed for close attention to empirical data. But they also believed that induction itself was not sufficeient. This work just provided a basis for a more general conceptual framework, and so Clark says they resisted what he sees as the German sociologists tendency to ignore theory. (12-13) 3) Their "logic of analysis" (13). Both drew on J.S. Mill heavily for certain "rules of investigation..." that highlighted the importance of comparative analysis. (13-14) They both tended to work by examining multiple explanations for a given phenomeona and then drawing out the valid pieces from each. (14) 4) Both rejected utilitarian theory and the assumption that accompanied it that "society consisted of an aggregate of atomistic individuals..." (14)

 

* Divergence: Tarde believed that "a prerequisitie for any science was the reptition of some basic measurable phenomenon." (15) Art in his view focused on the indivdiuality of phenomena; science must focus on generalization based on repetetive phenomena. But social science in focusing on the social must be distinguished its subject from biology and psychology: what was left for Tarde, Clark says, was the "inter-mental" (16) And: "The basic process by which this inter-mental influence takes palce, and the basic social fact for sociology, Tarde holds, is imitation. Social relations are essential imitative relationships." (16) He also believe dthat there were two basic forms of imitation: the cognitive, which was related to belief, and the emotoinal, which is related to desire. (16) "The final result of imitation for the indiviudal is a 'mental imprint,' an impression on the mind similar to the imprint on a photographic plate. Thus, psychology cannot be excluded fro sociology as social processes consist, in the final analysis, of inter-mental relations." (16) **Durkheim, however,** believed that the social fact was not something imitated but rather something that was "exterior" to the individual, something imposed, a constraint. (16) He also rejected pscyhology as a necessary basis for sociological analysis. (16) That is, for Durkheim to some extent the social was osmething completely outside of all its members. For Tarde this was absurd and it implied another version of the "scholastic ontology", i.e that if you were to remove all the individuals of a group, the social characteristics would somehow remain. (18) Tarde apparently referred to this as Durkheim's "ontological Phantasmagoria" (!!). (17) Clark tries to balance these two ponts of view diplomatically, ssaying that Durkheim did sometimes move to far toward this kind of ontological error; while although in Clarke's view Tarde had a "more sophisticated view of the relationship bewteen the individual and society," he "underestimated the importance of certain collective influences." (17)

 

* Clark sums up the diffeences between them curtly here: "Growing largely from the commitment of Tare to an emphasis on the autonomy of the individual and a grounding of his behavior in Spontaneity, and of Durkheim to the predominance of the collectivity and a Cartesian striving for order, the difference between the two men was reflected in several other issues." (18) Tarde focused on the "centrality fo the creative individual in suggestiing new lines of development which the collectivity would subsequently adopt" and Durkheim on the "structural conditions which predisoposed a given collectivity to change..." (18)

 

* VV Social control, Tarde's thoery "grew out of social interaction, and was extended through larger social groupings with such deellopmetn as extensive mass communications..." (18) Durkheim focused on "the constraining influences of values and norms." (18)

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.107-109 Impact of Womeno on Pscyh

By 1920, Rosenberg arguesthat American psycholoigst had "buried the doctrine of female uniqueness." (107)  They had rejected in otherwords the kind of statement that G. Stanley Hall had made: "that with civilzation the dimensions of the woman's body, her life and her psychic traits become more different from those of men rather than less so." (107)

Rosenberg argues that his was directly linked to the entrance of women into the professoin and to the rise of coeducation.  She notes men's tendency to let their critical faculties "lapse" when it came to sex difference (107)  Women she says "forced male colleagues to live up to their critical ideals when dealing with the issue of sex differences..."  (107)

But they also "contributed in an important way to the trend toward enviornmentalism in American psychology" (107-108).  "To doubt the physiological basis of feminine psychological differences was considerably to loosen the keystone of the arch of biological determinism." (108)

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text: p.185 Mead wanted to Study Individual in Culture Mead rejected simple apporach that would have explained "psychological formations" by child-rearing practices (185) Sullivan quotes her: "[i?] had wanted to talk about the way each of us belongs to a sex and has a temperament, a temperament shared with others of our own sex and others of the opposite sex." (185, Sex & Temp, Preface, italics original) He also says that she preferred the focus on "the individual in culture" to "culture and personality" Which she apparently explained in her "The cultural approach to personality" ency. article of 1946. p. 480. She had taught an extension course t Columbia on "The Study of the Individual in Culture" in 1935, see Librarcy of Congress file J8:11.)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text: p.041-42 Jane Addams' Gave voice to Thomas and Geddes Addams who was a friend of Thomas' and Geddes' "gave popular expression to their psychological analyses in Democrayc and Social Ethics , arguing that ssocial progress depended on the moral insights of women." (41) Addams thought that women's interest in public activity was a result not of a "wish for a career or selfish fulfilment" (Rosenberg, 41) but a product of the fact that in the industrialized world the family was less important. Thus in pursing a career women were ismply folloiwng their natural emotional interest in the "social claim." (41) Thus these thinkers who rooted women's difference in biological difference at the cellular level were as interested in the woman's movement as were Lamarkcinas like Ward, Gilman and Veblen (41)

title: Critique and Crisis: Enlightenment and the Pathogenesis of Modern Society
text:
# Reinhart Koselleck, *Critique and Crisis: Enlightenment and the Pathogenesis of Modern Society* (Cambridge: MIT Press, 1988, originally published 1959)

## Introduction:

* At the start: the point is that this is grounded in a ntoion of European that has become world history: "Europe's history has broadened; it has becom eworld history and will run its course as that, having allowed the whole world to drift into a state of permanent crisis." (5)  What a massive claim!!!  What he means a tad more specifically is "bourgeois society was the first to cover the globe..."  And then he adds something about the "present crisis": it "stems from a mainly Utopian self-conception on the part of the philosophers of history..." (5)  When he's referring to the "present crisis" I think he's referring to the Cold War.  This he sees in broad strokes as a product of the Enlightenment and the expansion of European "bourgeois society" across the globe.  Bourgeois society "saw itself as the new world, laying intellectual claim to the whole world and simultaneously denying the old." (6) He's presenting it as something thatitis this r's is aggressively trying to see itself as universal: ie he says it "grew out of the territories of the Euroepan states, and in dissolving this link developed a progressive philosophy in line with the process." Thus "its subject was mankind".  Then he jumps to the present wehre he iomagines that this conception has expanded into "a single global world" that "is claimed" in the name of these universal philosophies of history but which has become dichotomous in that there are these two sides that each see a different vision of progress: "One half, sworn to progress like the other, lives by that other's imagined reaction.  Two halves block each other's way, but it is this very fact that gives them identity They mutually segregate each other in order to feign a non-existent unity.  Their testimony is therefore on of terror and fear.  The world's Utopian unity reproduces its own fission." (6)

* The goal of the book is to examine the 18th century, a time when the European bourgeoisie "externally encompassed the whole world and in so doing postulateed one mankind" and in so doing attack the "Absolutist order."  And Koselleck sees this as a moment when "philsophers of history prepared and made available the concepts by which the rise and the role of the bourgeoisie of that time were justified."  (6)  And this eighteenth century, he thinks, can be seen as the "antechamber to our present epoch, one whose tensions have been increasingly exacerbated since the French Revolution..." (6) 

* The goal is not to exmaine the "contents" of these philosophies of history, but the goal is instead to see its linnk with the "beginnings of the political crisis" by trying to "understand the philosophical sense of history by studying the political situation of the bourgeoisie in the Absolutist state." (6) The point he's making here is methodological.  He's not going to focus primarily on the ideas, but on their use or their relationship to social groups, classes, and so on.  He says this a bit later: "The method used is thus a combination of analyses from the history of ideas and analyses of sociological conditions." (8) The ideas are not in themselves the focus, but only the way the ideas had political significance. 

* Also key is that what he's doin is to reveal the "link between the origins of modern philosophy and the start of the crisis which, initially in Europe, has been determining political events ever since 1789..." (6) 

* The start is with the Absolutist state because it was the way the Absolutist state fell apart that "enabled a Utopian modernism to unfold." (7) 

* Key passage on 9 v crisis.  What is the relationship between crisis and this "Utopian modernism"?  The 18th century thinkers did not themselves see the link between its critique and the looming crisis.  But that is key to Koselleck's thesis which is 1) that the critical process created the crisis and 2) that the significance of that crisis remained hidden. (9)  "...that the critical process of enlightenment conjured up the crisis in the same measure in which the political significance of that crisis remained hidden from it.  The crisis was as much exacerbated as it was obfuscated in the philosophy of history.  Never politically grarsped, it remained concealed in historico-philosophical images of the future which caused the day's events to pale -- events that became so much less inhibited in heading for an unexpected decision." (9)  

Ch.1 The Absolutist State, Raison d'Etat and the Emergence of the Apolitical Sphere (Barclay, D'Aubigne)

* Two "epochal events" he says mark the beginnig and the end of "classical Absolutism." (15)  One is the religious civil wars and then the French Revolution.  (15)

* England's position is "exceptional" because both of these "chains of events" coincided.  On the continent instead the Abslutist state remained "the time-bound outcome of the post-Reformation disorders." (15)The state emerged out of these orders and established its powers: "Its policies were the theme of the seventeenth century; their paths outlined the history of Absolutism" (15) 

* The next era is called Enlightenment and K sees it as a dialectical prodcut of ABsolutism: "It was from Absolutism that the Enlightenment evolved--initially as its inner consequence, later as its dialectical counterpart and antagonist, destined to lead the Absolutist State to its demise." (15) And carrying this dialectical explanation further he goes backward: "Just as the Enlightenment's political point of departure lay within the Absolutist systm, so that of Absolutism lay in the religious wars." (16) And pushing this further he says there is an "inner link" between the completion of Absolutism and its end, and he points out that Enlightenment "reached its zenith" in France "the very country in which the Absolutist system had for the first time, and most decisively, overcome the internal religious conflict." (16)He says that Louis XIV's abuse of power "accelerated the process, in the course of which this same citizen would one day storm the Bastille." (16) That happened when the citizen no longer saw the Absolutist state as a response to religious strife. 

* The first goal K says is to specify how initially the Absolutist state emerged and was justified in its emergence against the background of religious conflict.  The "princely State" K says "developed a supra-religious, rationalistic field of action..."  The goal of the monarchs was to "elminiate or neturalise all instituinos with an independent base.  Everything would be considered only in terms of its usefullness to the state.  Eg mercanistilism.  Religion too was considered in this way.  (16) 

* The doctrine under which this was given theoreticla expression was raison d'etat.  The idea was that poltiics should function independently of morality.

Montesquieu: "Dans les monarchies, la politique fait faire les grandes choses avec le moins de vertu qu'elle peut." (1748). 

K notes that when Montesquieu made this point it had already ceased to be understandable to the "Enlighteners." But the doctrine meerged out of the 16th century when religious conflict had caused the "entire social order" to become "unhinged" .  So the quesiton became how to make peace and the Absolutist state was the answer to that problem. 

* In laying out the answer to this K comes at it in an interesting way from both sides: "...the State could not be constitueted as such until it had found its specific answer to religious civil warfare.  What was this answer?  What did it mean to the monarch?  And to the subject?" This is an interesting approach to look at it from both perspective---

*  In order to dominate over the warring religious partiesunless they "challenged the primacy of religion." (17) This was the only way to subordinate the parties to the State.  A key "vindication of absolute monarchy" came from John Barclay's *Argenis*, a roman a' clef published in 1621.  It was translated into all Euroepan languages and widely known.  Barclay was a humanist whose point of view had been shaped by the Gunpowder plot.  He challenged the sovereign this way: "Either give the people back their freedom or assure the domestic tranquility for who se sake they relinquished that freedom." (18) Barclay preferred the latter and in his work trasnferred all rights to the sovereign.  In the view of this text forberarance was seen as more destructive that stringency "for the consequences of clemcency were bloodier and more devestating than those of severity." (18) The book also pointed out that the King would have to "subjugate all or no one would be subjugated." (18)

* This meant, K says, that there was "a deep breach...laid in the subjects' position.  Previously they had their place in a manifold, if loose, structure of responsibilities: as members of a Church, as dependant vassals, in the framework of their own political institutions or of the feudal order of estates.  But the more the sense of this pluralistic world was reversed into the senselessness of civil warfare, the more the subjects faced a similarly cogent alternative as that facing the King himself: 'Know then that almost all men have been reduced to this point: to be on bad terms either with their conscience or with the course of the century.'"  The person who survived in other words was the person who did not live according to their conscinece and this was a point developed by Agrippe de'Aubigne' in the voice of the politician de Sancy.  "To survive, the subject must submerge his conscinece." (19)

* Developing this further K interestingly talks about the distribution of guilt and responsibility that this particular way of thinking that justified the Absolutist state created.  Conscience he defines as the "intrinsic relationship bwteen responsibility and guilt" (19-20) For the subject "the ruler was freed from all guilt, but he accumulated all responsibility.  The subject, on the other hand, was relieved of all political responsibility but threatened, in exhcange, with a twofold guilt: externally when acting counter to his sovereign's interesting--something the sovereign had the sole right to determine--and inwardly be seeking refuge in anonymity." (20)

*  But this "fission within the horizon of religious civil warfare paved the way for the 'innocence of power.'" (20) The prince alone could be innocent K says, but he had great responsibility because of it.  This meant that the prince had increainslgy to act with incredibly and calculated foresignt, and also to make sure that he could act approrpiately according to this calculatino he also had to augment his power, which also created chances that he might fail to use power correctly, or abuse it.  (20) "The scope of the innocence of power remained narrowly circumscribed by the guidelines of a shaprened morality of action." (20)

* These ideas were accepted both by politicians and the "teachers of secular eiths" until the 18th century.  Spinoza for exmaple "continued to maintain that only theologians believed that statesmen were bound by the smae rules of piety as were private indivduals." (21) "Every power," K writes, "which in those days sought to equip itself with authority and a generally binding nature required this exclusion of the private conscience in which the bonds of religion or of feudal loyalty were anchored." (21) Thus in 1640 when Parliament wanted to strip Charles I of power they argued that the King's conscience too needed to bow to the interests of the State.

* Hobbes who will be the subject of the next chapter is "paradigmatic for the modern
State theory's genesis." (21)

## Ch.2 Hobbesian Rationality and the Origins of the Enlightenment

* In this chapter, K describes how Hobbes responds to the situation created by civil war and the rise of the Absolutist state in which their had occured a painful separation of conscience and act -- where in order to survive as K explains in the last chapter, the individual must submerge his conscience. Hobbes' solution is to exclude conscience from political morality, ie. the morality of the state. He does this by developing an anthropology of human nature -- inspired by his own experience of religious war -- in which humans are motivated by passion alone, that is by a struggle for power and the opposite, a longing for peace and a release from this struggle. (24-25)

* Hobbes therefore replaces the discussion of good and evil (ie conscience) with a discussion of war and peace, and considers what must be necessary for a state of peace to be ensured. Conscience he decides is mere opinion -- purely subjective (26-27). The religious wars were destructive because these subjective positions had become the basis for states of mind and action that involved battling others in an attempt to defeat them outwardly and inwardly -- ie making them accept these states of mind (27-28) Hobbes worked against this tendency by ceasing to argue from the inner conscience outward, but rather the reverse. (29) -- And there's a very interesting account of how Hobbes dealth with the old theme of inner/outer separation in the western tradition in f.n. #28.  He conceived of the purpose of moral philosophy as that of trying to understand how, given a situation of civil war, wher eit is not clear what is right and wrong, it is possible to transform the comandment to make peace -- rooted in natural law -- into "a law that can be satisfied by concrete extension." (30)

* The resutl of that inquiry was the justification of the Absolutist state as a "structure in which private mentalities are deprived of their political effect." (30) Crucially, then "[t]he public interest, about which the sovereign alone has the right to decide, no longer lies in the jurisdiction of conscience. Conscience, which becomes alienated from the State, turns into private morality. 'Auctorits, non verits facit legem' -- laws made by authority, not by truth." (31)

* So Hobbes morality of reason is a "morality that accepts the ruler's absolute political sovereignty as a moral necessity." (31) IN the war of all against all, the individual is in a state of constant fear; that individual fears not anything in particular but everything, death, but that indiviudal will "flee to the State, and protection is therefore the State's highest moral obligation." (31)

* But Hobbes did not think that morality alone would produce the sitaution that would end civil war. "Peace is guaranateed only if political morality, the quality that makes men cede their rights to the sovereign representing them, is transformed in the act of state-founding into a duty to obey." (32) So therefore what makes the State what it is is the "interrelation of proection and obedience" as well as the absolute power of the prince. (32-34)

* Key point in Koselleck's borader argument: So what you have in Locke is a juncture that is stil "situational" (34) -- ie. defined by a philosophy guided by the experience of Civil War -- that creates a "juncture" of Absolutism and rationalist philosophy. (34) : "Reason, rising from the turmoil of religious warfare, at first remains under the spell of that warfare and founds the State"  (34) This is a key point in K's argument because it explains why Hobbes failed to see the effect of his exclusion of conscience from public interest. Hobbes starting point was his own experience of civil war. Thus he has been accused of being very subjective, i,e, the crique that he "inferred what out to be from what is, that he had his well-ordered State arise from a state of nature in which men act like wolves towards each other." (40) Dilthey evidently spoke of Hobbes 'Impetusous subjectivity." (quoted on 40)

* What Hobbes could not see, however, is that once the State "Uspressed and neturalised religous conflict" then "progressive reason could unfodl in the newly vacated space." For Hobbes, history was just a vacillation between war and peace; his interest was thus only that the State succeed in demanding obedience and supressing civil war. But his "formalistion of the soverign concept of law" still rested on "the distinction between conscience and action," ie. Hobbes, who cared not for the substance of laws, but only the fact that citizens must submit to them, could only think this way if the act of obediance was separated from the content of the act itself, ie if act and conscience were perceived as seprate. (36) Thus this distinction, which Hobbes had tried to abolish, remained. It became a a central dynamic of the Absolutist state. "Hobbes's man is factured, split into private and public halves; his actions are totally subject to the law of the land while his mind remains free, 'in secret free.' From here on the individual is free to migrate into his state of mind without being responsible for it. The sovereign command relieved the subject of all responsiblity: 'The Law is the publique Conscience -- priate Consciences...are but private opinions.'" (37) But then if the individual's conscience ventured into a "jurisdiction which the State reserved to itself" then the "individual had to mystify himself." This meant that under the Absolutist state: "The dialectic of mystery and enlightenment, of mystification and unmasking, was already one of the roots of the Absolutist State."

* What Enlightenment would do then is to expand the "mind's inner space". Under the Absolutist state, humans were human only ion private; in public they were citizen's. So "That a man was human was  his secret; as such he was bound to escape the sovereign's notice." But this is where, K says, the Enlightnement would aim its attack.  The State had "conceded to the individual an inner space that did not much impair the sovereign decision..." (38) The State in fact remain morally neutral and if it did not it would lose its legtiimacy. But then what ultimately occured is that the "State created a new order" and then "in genuinely historical fashion -- fell prety to that order." --> "The authority of coscience remained an unconquered remnant of the state of nature, protruding into the formally perfected State." (39)

* But when it returned, morality had been secularized -- in party by the States' "neutralisation of conscience" (39) --> "A crumbling of the faith in revelation that had necessitated the creation of the State doomed the same State as the old themes recurred in secualrised from. A morality striving to become political would be the great theme of the eighteenth century." (39)

* Enlightenment then was partly about a movement that no longer understood "the distinction between man and subject"--"Publicly man was to realise himself as a human being, with the resulting decay of the Absolutist State." (39)

title: Alain L. Locke: The Biography of a Philosopher
text: p.001-4 INTRODUCTION

title: Wilhelm von Humboldt: The Theory and Practice of Self-Formation (Bildung), 1791-1810
text:
General Notes 10/12

#David Sorkin, "Wilhelm von Humboldt: The Theory and Practice of Self-Formation (Bildung), 1791-1810" Journal of the History of Ideas, v.44, no.1 (Jan.-Mar., 1983): 55-73.

* Sorkin traces the development of Humboldt's ideas about Bildung. The interesting part of this article is to see how Humboldt tried to navigate the various challenges by different political programs and pressure to the theory of self-formation that he was developing in order to develop a pedagogical notion and concrete reform that would sustain the growth of indivdual autonomy and the emergence of a minimal state whose existence served to support the grwoth of such indivduals and was also sustained or produced out of the assocaition of such individuals. It's a complex account.

* A key consideration here is whether or  not Humboldt's original description of Bildung in his political theory of 1791-2 was consistent with the reform he effect as Education minister in 1809-1810. "Could the reform of education by the state be compatible with a thoery that advocated private eduation free from state interference?" (55) Many liberal historians (Haym to Meineck) have mainted that he was consistent. This issue is important because hsi theory of Bildung "has been consdiered the doctrine that legitimized the alliance of the intelligentsia and the state through the university." Thus the question is if he was inconsistent "can his metamorphosis be seen as representative of the capitultion of th eliberal intelligentsia to the Prussian state? Was that capitulation the inevitable resutl fo the concept of Bildung?" (56)

* Humboldt's biography "turns on a confilct between training and charachter..." He was destinged cor a career in state service but was "irresistibly drawn toward self-cultivation." (56) Part of this tension camme from Humboldt but it also derived from broader cultural and osciuological chagnes. "The larger historical roots of this genearl emphasis on the individual and self-cultivation are to be found int h deterioriation fo the estate structure adn the search for new forms of sociability (witness the proliferation of secret societies, lodgs, and salons) in the increasing power of the absolutist state and the grwoth of a bureacuratic intelligentsia, as well as in the cultural movements of th eperio, the sentimantal turn of the late Enlightenment followed by neo-humanism and romanticism." (56)

* Humbodlt's political theory, the Limits of StateAction,  was written after Humboldt retired from state service.  It has been seen as a defense tof hsi retirement and a response to the French Revolution. "Humbodt emraces the ideals of political freedom but rejects revolution in favor of a stable model of organic development, anticipatin Burke in fearing the unforeseen consequences of action that depart from that model." (58) But the central idea Sorkin says predates these influences. He noes an essay "On Religion" written between August 1788 and July 1789 that calls for political thinking that stars from ideas inherent to Rousseau's pedagogy. Sorkin quotes:

> When will man finally cease to regard the outward consequences of action with greater esteem than the inward spiritual frame of mind from which they flow; when will someon eappear who will be fore legislation what Rousseau was for education, who will withdraw the point of vangage fromthe otuward physical results to the inward cultivation (bildung) of men? (quoted on 58).

* So the idea struturin ghis political theory is a dichotomy between "the inward development of man and the outward action of the citizen..." (58) Limits then describes a kind of political sovereignty vv man's inward process of devleopment and this "specific image of man" Humboldt dervied from a close reading of Leibniz. Sorkin explains:

> Humboldt evisages man as a dynamic organism uniquely characterized by his energy: ' Energy (Kraft) appears to me to be the first and unique virtue of mankind.' An individula's development depends upon finding appropriate outlets for his energy so that eh can engage in activity by means of which he realizes his poentialities and iucnreases his abilities. One essential condition for such activity is freedom: one must be assured of the freedom to act for onself, that is, to be self-reliant. A second essential condition is 'social intercourse': one develops through the voluntary interchange of one's indivdiualitywith that of others. Self-formation, in other words, requires social bonds. (58-59)

* This two-part formulation introduces the problem that Sorkin wants to trace. The Limits focused on the notion of inner development and less on social intercourse. Sorkin suggest that Humboldt had acquired from Leibniz the central problem of mutatis mutandis: "Leibniz had predicated his concept of individual monads of energy on the metaphysical presupposition of the 'pre-establish harmony' of the universal. Only with such a concept of metaphysical harmony could Liebniz account for the interaction of the individual monads...as well as maintain a notion of a unified world." (59) But for Humboldt harmony could not be stablished metaphysically: "it is a political and social harmony which must be achieved in the modern state." (60)

* Humboldt thought such a thing existed in ancient Greece. (60) But he did not think that the the modern state could emulate the polis because it was to eudaemonistic, attending to well-being and happiness. It's goal was bascially to supress huamn energies "in favor of obtaining a prodcutive and obedient citizen." (60) Therefore the modern state must be given a negative function. (60)

* Limiting the state helped provide for the self's inner formation, but it did not establish the conditions for the second condition of self-cultivation: socail intercoruse and social bonds. He noted teh failure of existing state institutions to allow the grwoth of such indivudals. but the hope for a set of institutions that would adequately provide for such social intercourse remained utopian in his saccount. (60-61).

* He addressed the second issue more in his role as reform in 1809-1810. In between, Sorkin says he had u"discovered" the nation as a "mediating concept between the individaul and humanity" and as a "concrete entity in his own life." (61) He also developed a sense of himself as "German" and an emotional feeling toward Prussia. (61), Although this "incipient nationalism" did not lead him away from his political ideas. In reforming state education he wanted to return "control of education to the nation". "If the nation were made responsible for educatino, and if freedom prevailed within the educational institutions themselves, he thought, then the nation would develop an associational life in and around the educational system that would foster the interchange requisite to Bildung." (61)  But at the same time he thought that cuodl honly happen when his own SEction for Education ceased to exist. (61)  -- since the state as he saw it was a legal and not an educational institution.

* In his reform he laid out a 3-point program. 1) The nation would take financial responsibility for the schools. The idea was that hte citizenry would become involved in the school sif the responsiblity for the schools fell on the nation. (62) 2) He proposed that barriers to education be removed because these were inimiatal to natioanl unity. Ie removal of the policiesw that" segregated the estates and trained students for different functions." (62) He proposed the abolition of military schools taht catered to the nobility. All woudl attend school together. He wrote: "The organization of the schools pays heed to no caste, to no single corporation, and not even to the scholar." (62) The idea here was consistent with the Rousseauist principle that informed the limits: taht the person is more than a citizen.Anda t the same time Sorkin thinks it also created "the precondition for new social bonds." (63), allowing "Bildung..to function as the basis for the new social interaction essential to Bildung." (63) 3) The curriculum of the school would be as follows: in elementary school students would learn basic skills. In high school (Schule) they would learn how to learn. A student woudl be considered "mature" when he "had learned enough from others to be able to learn by himself." (quoted on 63). The university's goal was to bring students together into a "community devoted to learning (Wissenschaft)" and to provide them the freedom to intearact in such an environment. This would involve cooperation and interaction but also a "heightening of one's energies (Kraefte)" (63).

* Sorkin's interpretation then is that Humboldt's reforms were in fact consistent with his earlier theory in the Limits. "By returning the schools to the nation, creating an egalitarian system suited to the person rather than to the citizen, and by providing a general education in an atmosphere of freedom, Humboldt hoped to foster the social bonds necessary to Bildung. His nascent natioanlism provided the basis for his internal consistency; it did not compel him to abjure his earlier principles, as critics of his inconsistency have maintained." (63)

* Yet Sorkin wants to suggest that his consistency here involved a meshing of neo-humanist ideas with Aufklaerung in a way that was "not unalloyed." (63) Humboldt had to reconcile neo-humanist and Aufklaerung ideas because "the Prussian state had appropriated Bildung as its official pedagogy and demoted it from an autonomus ideal to an instrumental role.  In its tranlation from high into applied culture, then,  Bildung had been essentially betrayed. That very task of application was to be one of Humboldt's contributions to the history of Bildung... " (64) Humboldt achieved this by "assigning Aufklaerung functions to neo-humanist ideas..." (64), meaning that he saw the goals of service to the state (ie the applied notion of Aufklaerung that the Prussians had adopted) as being "realized indirectly as the intended yet incidental consequences of Bildung." Ie Humboldt argued that "persons educated to be free individuals will ultimately be better citizens than  men educated to be citizens, just as science left to its own devices will be more fruitful than science supervised by the state." (64)

* This theoretical reconcialiation of neo-humanism and Aufklaerung notions of service to teh state was also played out on a personal level as Humboldt found in his reform position an opportunity to reconcile his personal tensions between self-cultivation and service.(65-66)

*BUT Sorkin thinks there was a cost to this reconciliation. Anmd this is a key part of his ultimate argument. In order to make the point he contrasts Humboldt's notion of bildung with those extant in the period. At the end of the 18th century there were two notions: "one conception emphasized theitnernal spiritualized prodcess by which man attained self-realization, and the other focused on the social activity integral to and coincident with Bildung's consummation in man's self-harmony." (66-67) Both of these concepts were present in Humboldt's Limits, and Sorkin explains precisely how 67-69. But in the 1809-10 memoranda laying otu his reform Sorkin say that this "civiic conception" does not appear. "In the one passage where [it does appear]...it has been totally assimilated to the inward process of Bildung." (69) What is lost then is the idea that the individual's process of inner development is "consumated" and copmleted through social itneraction: "The concept of persons achieving innher harmony withinthe web of socail interrelations has disappeared and so, too, has the activity issuing from that concept, the activity whereby man judges political relations by the standards of his own harmoney." (69)
