* The significance of this interpretation is as follows: Liberals from Haym to Meinecke have held that Humbotltd's reforms were "entirely of a piece with the reforms of Prussia proposed by Stein (1806-1808)" and which laid out a program for a renewal and revival of local government, including a program to promote local assemblies that woudl include commoners. Stein's insight was that "a reform of the educational system woudl be necessary to prepare the bourgeoisie for particpation in political life." (69) But the fact that Humboldt let go of the civic coneption of Bildung in his reform memoranda means that "although Humboldt counted himself among the reformers, attempting to return the edducational system to the nation and to foster freedom and new social bonds, the political imperative that could have animated the schools was lost. The schools would not advance notions of civic activity but would remain an instrument of autocratic rule producing obedient if not apolitical subjects." (69)

* Why did Humboldt drop the cicic conception? Sorkin thinks it had to do with his opposition to a middle-class movement for national education (Nationalerziehung) that had as one of its leading supporters Fichte. The movement that fichte aderessed in his 1808 "Addresses to the German Nation" was an attempt to "reconcile the free self-reliant intellectual and ultimately moral activity of the individual--the avowed basis of regeneration--with a system of education that subordinates the individual to the nation with the aim of producing loyal and patriotic citizens." (70) The students were to be taught using the tecniques of Pestalozzi that did emphasize self-activity, but the schools were to be "strictly regimented (chidlren are to be removed from their parents' homes and raised in economically autarchic communities where teachers serve as confessors as well as instructors)." (70) Sorkin's argument is that Humboldt eliminated the civic conception of Bildung because due to certain overlaps it had with this movement for natioanl education. "It empahsized the product rather than the process of Bildung although it did not determine the final content of the prodcut but onkly its form, harmony. In addition, the civic conception had direct political implications, unlike the inward conception which Humbodt put indirectly to Aufklaerung purposes." Sorkin thinks that because of these similarities Humboldt feared that "the atuonomy of Bildung would be endangered were he to maintain the civic conception." (72) Ie that there could be a confusion of his ideas with the Fichtean ideas, and Sorkin thinks this fear was reasonable. (72)

* Yet Sorkin's feeling is that the absence of the civic conception weakened the reform that Humboldt laid out and "adumbrated" its "political fate." (73) 1) Despite the egalitarian principles, the reform utlimately "became the social and ideological basis of a new elite lacking the itnernal imperative of political acitvity and wedded to the state in exchange for teh state's identification with culture." (73) -- he's citing Ringer's Decline fo the German Mandarins here. 2) The balance between serice and autonomy that Humboldt had tried to create was Sorkin tihnks "shattered" by a process of "insitutionalization" that was complete by 1820. Thus "Bildung...became the first servant of the Prussian state. Humboldt's reorientation of political thought and his reconcilation of neo-humanism with Aufklaerung was subverted at he state-subordinated edcuational program of the eighteenth century-continued in new guise into the nineteenth century."(73)

* So Sorkin's last line is: "While Humobldt had not departed from his liberalism, his edcuational reform did in the end become a bais for the capitualation of the intelligentsia to the state." (73)

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.031 Velvet v. Iron Curtain

"The Velvet Curtain of culture has replaced the Iron Curtain of ideology as the most significant dividing line in Europe." (24)

title: The Idea of the Self: Thought and Experience in Europe Since the 17th Century
text:
General Notes 2/2013:

## Chapter 1: "Dimensions and contexts of selfhood"

* His book starts out of a "sense of concern (mainly skeptical) about these [postmodern] notions [of the end of the individual]..." (4) He found these arguments in Claude Levi-Strauus, Maurice Merlau-Ponty, Roland Barthes, and Michel Foucault. And anticipating them Marchel Duchamp.

* His feelings is that the demand of unity that many critics of unitary selfhood identify is more charachteristics of those critics than it is of those who have sough to conceive of the individual as a center of action. That "paradox" he says lies at the center of our "modern culture" and its highly contested disputes about the self.

> "...attempts to loate or promote such untrammeled modes of self-existence arise ore often and more characteristically out of the negation of the common-sense understanding of individuals as centers of action and consciousness than out of their affirmation; the sense that human beings must be all in order to escape being nothing has belonged more to those who have sough some kind of fulfillment by way of it." (5)

* He says there are three dimensions along which "the basis of selfhood" has been sought in "Western culture." (5): 1) the bodily or material, 2) the relational, and 3) the reflective. He describes these on 5-7.

*Underlying these three dimensions there is a broader binary dimension: that of multi-dimensional and one-dimensional accounts of the self. (7) In his account, it is the one-dimensional account of the self that is suspect. For the paradox he mentioned before -- that "paradoxcial conjunction between radically narrowing the self's independence or autonomy and inflating it beyond limits" (7) -- is primarily a product he thinks of conceiving of the self one-dimensionally. He has a good quote explaining this on 9:

> What is perhaps surprising about one-dimensinoal modesl of the self is the capaicty they often display to transfigure life, by envisioning a rapid passage between -- or sometimes coexistence of -- images that confine human agency within rigid limits and one that give the widest possible scope to it. It is just such metamorphoses that generate the pattern remarked above, in which denials of the self's independence lodge together with its radical exaltation. The same thinkers who image a self so deeply infused with the conditions of its material nature or surroundings that it possesses little or no capacity for going beyond them turn out to be those who imagine one capable of constituting itself wholly by some kind of profoundly liberating self-directedness. The Cartesian ego suddenly enters into the truth of its own self-referential subjectivity just at the point when its subjection to worldly confusion and uncertainty seems most complete. (9)

* By contrast, a multi-dimensional understanding of the self does not absolutely negate the unity of the self. "To acknoweldge these strains and stresses [in a multidimensional account] is not] is not the same as to deny that indivdiuals can attain to a measure of stable unity and integrity..." (7)

* Seigel gives special place to the dimension of reflexivity in accounts of these different possibilities for the self. Reflectivity he says is the domain "most likely to be exalted or diminished" where the self' autonomy is in question. "Only reflectivity can claim to found the radical freedom of the self, and only its eradication can issue in a self that is totally absorbed into some set of external determinations." (10)

* What he thinks very often determines whether a thinker uses a one- or multi-dimensional view of the self is often "that person's way of settting reflectivity in relation to other attributes." (10)

* He suggests as well that the tendency to discount the self's capacity for reflectivity is often accompanied by a critical arrogance: "those who theorize the radical circumscription of the self must speak from outside the position in which the theory seems to put them." (11)

* So what is reflectivity? He says it is the "ingredient of intelletual self-awareness in selfhood, the contribution made to it by the mind." (12) It is a kind of reflection that tends to create thoughts and questions about what ideas an dimpressions of the outside world "indicate about our own being." (12) These questions then create a "'second-order' relationship to the contents of experience" that creates a kind of distance from immediate experience. He also refers to this as a kind of "doubling" that can continue in order to create greater distance. (12)

* He wants to differentiate reflectivity from reflexivity, which he says are often linked indicating the whole problem: for reflexivity he thinks refers to more unconsciousor passive kinds of reflectivity that occur in "involuntary reflexes or in a mirror..." (12-13)

* If one looks at the etymology of the words self or subject, and also language he says in a nice bit of exposition, the two concepts of the self as passive or active are often in close proximity. (13-14)

* Also if one looks at the classic dispute between Hegel and Kant vv experience, there is the same tension. (15) Hume looked inside himself and found no self, and only "feelings,impressions, or iddeas that occupied him at particular moments, so that the self was a kind of empty theater, the passive container wher various scences succeed each other." (15) Kant rejected that account, arguing that "wherever there is experence of any sort, beginning with sesnse impressions, an active subject must be at work." (15)

* In Kant's account, there is a "passage" from passive to active subjecthood that arises when one connects one experience with another... The terms "slef and subject oth bear th esigns of inhabiting this passage." (15)

* Identity. Same mixture of activity and passivity is there. Same also with the notion of person. (15-16). So all toether these terms all bear passive and active forms. And together they constitute a "vocabulary of selfhood, a linguistic register from whci we single out one or another depending on the contexxt in which we employ the idea, or the particular purpose we ask it to serve." (16)

* Now he comes out with his preference: He prefesrs the multi-dimensional accounts of the self. This he thinks is the basis for our reflective control. Precisely because we are both corporeal and relational he says, we must "take a certain distance from each..." (17) Through reflectivity we can accomplish this and this allows us "in some degree" to deal with the "tensions or conflicts between what biology demands and what social and cultural existence imposes or allows." (17) This is the precondition for managig both "material" and "external" (ie cultural) pressures. "The capacity to objectify and in part determine our own relation to the competing condition of our own existence is a prerequisite for surviving the complexity of being human, even in what are sometimes called 'simple' societies." (18)

 

### Ch.9 Autonomy, limitation, and the purposiveness of Nature: Kant

* A here places Heidegger, Nietzsche and Schopenhauer at the basis of
challenges to "notions of selfhood and subjectivity". He sees them as
the key inspirations for the powerful challenges that developedˇˇ later
in French thought. The interpretation is problematic I think. Totally
based in a Lind of crude Sonderweg line, as one he says Nietzsche and
Heidegger were "unmistakably" German and "unimaginable" in "any other
cultural tradition." Strangely also he then roots both thinkers in
Kant who he says was the founder of modern idealism, as if there were
no other side to Kant. (295)

* Here on 295-295 S gives his account of Kant's separation of science
and religion, but he suggests that Kant's ultimate motive was to make
room for faith, which seems simplistic and ideological as an
interpretation. Ie he says that what Kant had done was to "leave a
sense that human actions can be free [in the noumenal realm] protected
 (296)

* The root of the move By Kant S finds in Leibniz's  theory of monads.
The idea of individuals as fully unified and unique, expressing in
themselves a pre-existing harmony, and also expressing a unity in
humanity established by god. S describes this as a "homology" between
the individual and the world - or isomorphism of the self (298) --that
Kant preserves while trying to ground it in Universal rationality.
(297) , thus making it less "baroque". 296-298

> "Kant conceived it (and as their successors would too, in their
different ways) was reflective: the inner relations of its parts were
patterned on the self-relatedness of consciousness."

* Vv his own argument, S notes that this was a " reflective" model of
the self because the "inner relations" of the self's parts were
"patterned on the self-relatedness of consciousness." (298) but the
course of self fulfillment could in the end not derail the
teleological course of self development driven by the self's folding.
(298)

> "However great the power attributed to nature, society, or culture in
shaping the self, these otherwise non-reflective dimen- sions could be
drawn back into the reflective one by virtue of the whole world’s
inner conformity to the principle of self-relatedness."

> "Kant’s organized the idea of selfhood around the notion of autonomy;
the self achieved freedom by following the self-made laws of its own
rational nature. Such selfhood was universal in that all rational
individuals were, in principle, equally capable of achieving it, and
all did so by following the same rules. Leibniz’s model was different:
it projected a self that was free in the sense of not being determined
by external objects or relations, but it did not legislate rules for
itself and others; it simply followed the innate principle of its own
nature. Such selves achieved realization as individuals, not as
bearers of a universal reason, and they did not necessarily transcend
material existence, since material monads followed their inner notion just as spiritual ones did."

* Yep okay so then S boils this all down to two models of the self, one
grounds the self in a certain reflective autonomy, and the other in an
expressionist form of the self. The former is Kant's and roots the
self in an autonomy won through the unfolding of a rational nature,
and he other was Leibnizian with a focus on the way the self was
"free" by being free from external constraints in nature, but not as
possessors of universal reason. Yet both required a kind of
isomorphism of the self. (298-299)

> "The two forms of selfhood were thus internally related to each other,
and it should be no surprise that the Leibnizian one was given new
life in Kant’s time by his wayward student Johann Gottfried Herder,
and by others who drew on Herder’s organic and harmonious universe.
Herder’s expressivism would be combined with versions of Kantian
autonomy by post-Kantians, notably by Fichte, Schelling, and Hegel."

* Herder breathed new life into the Leibniziam form. (299) a bit
farther down the page here he says that Goethe and Humboldt also
represented exponents of the expressionist form (299). And also both
could express a sense of radical individualism or limits. Limits in
the Jantian autonomous sense because the self was part material and
natural, and the expressionist because one had to live in a world of
others.

> "Both were capable of supporting radical notions of self-realization,
since they posited a world in harmony with the self; but each was also
capable of assigning limits to the self in the present, Kantian
autonomy by its recognition that humans were material creatures as
well as rational ones, and expressivism through the acknowledgment
that every self had to inhabit a world occupied at the same time by
others. Kant himself exemplified the moderation with which the idea of
autonomy could be developed, as Herder, Goethe, and Humboldt did for
the expressivist one."

* This sense of limits "justifies" S says a view -- and he quotes some
scholars -- that Kant and Idealism were not about a total
transcendence of every limit. But S does not think this is the whole
story. S thinks that his desire to preserve a realm for "pure
reflective freedom" invited a transcendence of the limits he himself
accepted and that is exactly what many of his followers did.... Ie
Feurbach, Marx, and Heidegger all in different ways. (300-301)

> "Prussia was exemplary but not unique in making aristocrats its
partners in state-building, relying on them not only for army officers
but also for bureaucrats and officials, while leaving their local
power intact as a recompense"

> "Thus German political life was marked by what Leonard Krieger called
a “continuum between noble subject and noble sovereign,” strengthened
by the prince’s success in “defin- ing his power as the synthesis of
their liberties.” Where commoners became state servants they found
their opportunities for personal and professional advance inside the
same structures. O"

* S tries to track the basis the german idealist spirit. It has to do
with the 1) te nature of political absolutism in Germany where unlike
the centralizing tendency in France that gave prominent place to civil
servants as , the Prussian state made aristocrats its partner in
state-building, giving them rights as bureaucrats.  At the same time,
comsiderable autonomy persisted in small hometowns where there was a
great focus on religiouus life. (300-301). 2) the influence of
Protestntism, with the emphasis on "inner freedom", the tendency to
feel that this freedom could not be compromised with the external
world. (301-302)

> "The opposition of manners and values the two terms evoked referred
also to what underlay them, the contrast in social and polit- ical
structures between a society animated by a centralizing monarchy whose
court and official culture set the tone for both the aristocratic and
bourgeois groups who were drawn into its train, and one where the
absence of central integration allowed various forms of local, often
modest and simple, but self-consciously inward-looking life to develop
relatively undisturbed.8"

* The lack of cultural integration in Germany meant that culture played
a particularly powerful role in developing the basis for a atonal life
in Germany. There was before 1720 in Germany no common literary
language and by mid century there was a profound and self-conscious
desire to build one, a desire for an expanded world, that led to
Auglaerung...there was a new thirst for travel accounts, newspapers,
reading clubs, etc. (302) this then also led to Bildung, which S *s
well was not just education but a process of self formation. (302-303)
Here S traces these influences into the terms Bildung and Kultur.
Kultur was contrasted to external civilization in reference to French
centralized bureaucracy. It indicated a aftermathn emphasis on inner
Spiritual life and honesty. It fit a society S notes in which a lack
of cultural integration "allowed various forms of local, often modest
and simple, but self-consciously inward-looking life to develop
relatively undisturbed." (302)

> "All these cultural forms contributed to Bildung, which referred not
just to formal education, but more generally to the process of
personal forma- tion that wider experience of the world helped to
bring about"

* States, in connection with the continuum between the state and the
aristocracy mentioned before, were also seen as a source of Vildung,
which meant also that to "One reason for seeking Bildung or for
claiming to embody it was precisely that it constituted a claim to
service in the ranks of officialdom that were expected to further
reform." 303) this created in some cases a deeper continuity between
"inwardness and power" that was evident in many lives, and
specifically in Kant's. His parents were pietistic and modest, his
father was a saddler. But he was then given a chance to devel his
intellectual talents by pastor . What S is trying to get at is a link
between an earlier private world of state sponsored Protestantism and
its new formulation in a Bildung and Kultur. (303-304)

> "Freedom and progress for him were always deeply tied up with the
world of inner life rooted in Protestantism and unfolded as Kultur and
Bildung."

* S suggests here that Kant developed this link in a somewhat
apolitical direction, making freedom and progress a matter of morality
and inner development. s says he did this concretely by "he
transferred Rousseau’s notion of autonomy as obedience to self-made
laws from the realm of politics where the Genevan had located it to
the domain of moral action in general, making suitability for
universal legislation the principle not of the political general will,
but of the good will in the wider realm of ethical behavior. Later he
would welcome the French Revolution as the sign of humanity’s capacity
to emancipate itself and live in freedom, but in a peculiar way:
according to him the historical manifestation of this capacity was not
in the actions of the Revolutionaries, but in the sympathy their
doings aroused in the hearts and minds of foreign spectators, whose
disinterested enthusiasm could only be explained as the effect of a
“moral disposition within the human race,” an inner aptitude for
freedom." (304)

> "he transferred Rousseau’s notion of autonomy as obedience to
self-made laws from the realm of politics where the Genevan had
located it to the domain of moral action in general, making
suitability for universal legislation the principle not of the
political general will, but of the good will in the wider realm of
ethical behavior."

> "Kant set up a series of problems for himself and his successors, all
deriving from the question of how the different modes of the self were
related to each other."

> "What appears as the rela- tionship between the egoistic and
pluralistic modes of self-existence in the Anthropology becomes, in
his more formal writings, the question of how the rational and
empirical selves can be unified as a single moral actor."

> "His assumption seems to have been that being a rational creature
requires a kind of unity, a need met in one way by transcendental
subjectivity when it organizes perceptions into the unity of
consciousness, and in another by the categorical imperative, which
organizes desires and impulses into a singleness of moral purpose that
frees the person from material determination."

* Important point a bout Kant's notion of freedom, that it is
"spontaneous" as Henry Allison puts it. It is based in the capacity of
the free will to "set its own ends." (313) This quality of spontaneity
S distinguishes from autonomy. Autonomy here is the categorical
imperative that gives the self the qualities that make it possible
that it can act freely, ie independently of external control. But
spontaneity is that capacity to define ones of ends. It is more
"emphatic." The two are often confused, but the point is that to trace
the basis of our autonomy does not release us from nature for it does
not account for what allows us to set our own ends.  (313) Note: Cf
with Morris-Reich's idea of the difference between autonomy and
individuality in Simmel.

* Here S start a section in which he suggests that the radicalism of
Kant's spontaneous conception of freedom drove him toward the end of
his life to inject a sense of rational purpose into nature. This was
the case because a spontaneous self could not exist where external
determinations from nature intervened. The ideal of such freedom was
too radical. But if one imagined that nature too was structured "in
accord" with human moral purposiveness than such an ideal was
possible, ie Kant spoke in the Critique of Judgement of if humans
getting "help from nature" to "fulfill a condition beyond our
abilities." (314)

* This need to establish a sense of rational purpose in the world S
locates earlier in the first critique when he tries to account for the
way in which the three levels of the self work together and cannot
without attributing a basic harmony or unity in our faculties to a
creative agency that brought them into being. The move Dieter
Helinrich has described as a reworking of Liebniz's notion of a
pre-established teleological harmony in he self and the world, only in
Kant it is based on a division within the self. (314-315)

* Here S is saying that Kant ultimately was tempted to attribute to
this rational purpose in nature a kind of constitutive quality,
despite the fact that officially he saw it as a merely "regulative
principle", ie something that served merely to clarify the idea that
it made sense for humans to seek knowledge about the world because it
was in fact an organized and sense ridden thing.  (315-316)

* Key to S argument here is that the fact that Kant both insisted on
this division between material and spiritual, nature and unity of
purpose, ie freedom, suggests how much he wanted to preserve for the
self a radical kind of freedom. Only by denying that the material and
rational-intelligible forms of the self intermingled could he preserve
the possibility of such a radical rationality, even if he was clear
that we could not fully know that ends of that purpose. He was thus
incredibly restrained. And S says it was his "restraint that bore the
seeds of their [his sucessors] determination to break through it"
(317) by providing a unified conception of the self. (316-317)


* "S is very determined here to read Kant in terms ofma basic desire to
overcome the restraints that he also hemmed to practice. That is, in
terms of a desire to see in Kant a tendency to posit an isomorphism
between the idea of harmonious self development in nature and in the
domain mod moral reason and human history. Interesting though to
compare this interpretive thrust with Köhnke's story about in his book
about the neo Kantians, ie that this was first in idealism a Mi's
reading of Kant, and then also in Kuno Fischer's neo idealism again a
misreading. That is for Köhnke's Kant is all about restraint... (327)"


### Ch.10 Homology and Bildung: Herder, Humboldt, and Goethe

* "S starts this chapter with reference to his interpretation in which
Kant introduced a sense of purposiveness into nature, thus playing on
Leibniz's move to introduce a teleological structure into the world.
This was a way to escape scientific determinism. "If monads followed
their own internal principles, then their actions and destinies were
not the products of exter- nal, mechanical causes." (332) Yet S notes
there could also be a passive side to the monad, ie S wants to say
that positing an isomorphism of self and world could also lead one to
develop a sense of the limits of the self's capacity for reflective
self determination. Both potentials were developed by Kant's
successors, but in this chapter S will look at Herder and Goethe who
both hewed closer to Leibniz in "seeking not Kantian freedom, but a
kind of spontaneity and integrity for individual forms of being that
guaranteed to each its own particular character." (332)"

> "Central to Herder’s thinking was the idea that every living form of
existence worked out its own mode of being, constituted partly from an
inner germ or seed, and partly from the environment where it appeared,
and on which it nurtured itself. In the human world this notion
applied equally to individuals and to collectivities, notably
nations."

> "Thus human history was an organic process of development and
interaction, part of the larger schema of nature, within which
everything lived out the process of becoming what it was."

* "Herder developed a voting of human communities developing out of a
common seed. The consequences of this S said was that the self's
capacity for reflection could be diminished. But it was not gone from
Herder's theory.

> But reflectivity was an essential element in it all the same, since any life-form that developed according to an inner principle exhibited a conceptual unity between all the stages of its history: each moment was a mirror of all the others, and of the self-constituting purpose that was their common germ. Moreover, the world where individuals were formed was animated by inner purposive- ness too; thus there was something outside individuals that displayed the principle of their own being back to them, strengthening their integrity. The material being and the relational content that constituted the non- reflective dimensions of the self had, each in its way, a reflective character, so that in some degree the two non-reflective dimensions were taken up into reflectivity. (333)"

* "This view of Herder's was closely linked to the view of Bildung: "as
a process of personal formation in which the singular potential
inherent in particular individuals could find realization in the
world: life in society helped bring the self to cognizance of its own
needs and powers because the persons and conditions it encountered
there helped to reveal the inner structure of its own being." (333)"



* "But Herder was not as e.g. Taylor has implied rejecting universality.
"Every individuality has its own shape and destiny in Herder’s view,
but humanity is a quality shared by all human beings, and exhibited in
every human culture..." (334)"

* "S says that Herder felt isolated as a result of his academic success.
Unlike Kant who was able to merge his Protestantism into the new mode
of autonomy implied by Bildung and Kultur, Herder felt more isolated
and reacted against a kind of cosmopolitanism. (334)"

> "Herder developed these notions into a theory of universal powers or
forces (Kr ̈afte) that operated everywhere in the universe"



> "Herder made it into what Michael Beddow has called “an ontological
postulate, the metaphysical ground of phenomena.”"

> "The most fundamental powers, or Urkr ̈afte, never become part of
experience, but they forever work beneath it, making every object and
being in the universe the product of dynamic processes that follow an
innate principle. What distinguished the bearers of these powers from
Leibnizian monads was that in Herder’s universe beings and substances
could communicate with and influence each other. As each entity
developed, it drew on those around it, taking sustenance from them,
and enriching its own being through what it found nurturing in theirs.
In this way Herder portrayed the whole of existence as “a colossal
organism, a whole which is constituted by the complex interactions of
countless subordinate entities, each of which is in itself organic in
nature.”3"

* "The presentation of a world organism undergirded by such ontological
forces erased the distinction that Kant had tried to crea te between
nature and reason. (335)"

> "for Kant the realm of material nature to which such phenomena
belonged had to be sharply separated from the sphere of reason.
Herder’s chief point was that the two realms were really one, since
the same deep powers of purposiveness operated everywhere. Nature thus
became, as for Aristotle, the ground of both physics and metaphysics,
endowed with active powers that pressed toward the transcendence of
their own materiality. Human life, in providing the stage where this
play of forces found its fullest expression, also opened a window on
the larger cosmic drama that made it possible. “For the individual to
express his own nature is to participate in the expression of the
cosmic whole: each person’s self-realization is part of the
realization of the vast system of interactions that is the
universe.”5"



> "Diderot like Rousseau regarded the impress of social relations on
individuals as denaturing, imposing forms of living and thinking
foreign to people’s inner needs (as in the case of Rameau’s nephew,
and to some degree in his own); hence he favored the kind of strong,
even “despotic” inner organization that kept external influences at
bay, the condition achieved by Doctor Bordeu, or by the ideal actor.
By contrast, Herder’s openness to a positive valuation of the power
external situations exercised over individuals was what allowed him to
theorize cultural difference in a way that pointed toward modern
ethnographic anthropology."



> "From this perspective Herder saw individuals as deeply stamped with
the influence of the world around them, but he also insisted that any
per- son’s character developed from its own inner springs"



* "S argues that although Herder included a sense of the way individuals
develop themselves, his accounts of the influence of culture on the
individual were far better developed. (338)"



> "To introduce individual differences on behalf of collective ones was
typical of Herder’s thought: the passage cited above in which he spoke
in the first person about assimilat- ing only what is “akin to my
nature” was a preface to “The Greek adopts as much of the Roman, the
Roman of the Greek, as he needs for him- self . . . the rest falls to
the earth,” followed by other collective instances. In the few places
where he referred to questions of individual psychology, he did so in
order to suggest the homology between individual and collective
experience. Thus the mind’s “tendency to build up associations between
what it sees and what it has seen,” on the basis of which “the mind
creates a progressive unity out of the multiplicity of its states,”
was mentioned as a springboard for a discussion of its larger
counterpart, namely “the chain of unity” and continuity between
generations. The ability of individuals to unify their experiences
served as both a vehicle and an analogy for the unification of the
experience of the whole human race through education and culture.
“Each individual as a human being is capable of consciously grasping
the chain of continuity within his own life. Each individual is son or
daughter, molded by education; consequently he or she receives from
the earliest moments in life part of the cultural treasures of the
ancestral heritage.” The same power of unification that operates in
individual life operates for the species: “I can do no act, think no
thought, which in some measure has not some effect on the
inexhaustible fullness of my own life; neither is there any other
being of my species whose acts and thoughts do not in some way affect
the whole species and its progressive development.” Human existence
was like a great sea in which every act or thought made a wave whose
motion was transmitted to the whole.14"



* "Herder's rresentatipn of the s elf, though, was based in a sense of
the self's weakness and their need for assistance in self development.
That assistance comes in the form of the education that humans alone
provide and which depends on the fa ulty of reason. So: "Culture,
therefore, in all its senses, is the goal nature has in mind for
humanity when she gives reason to human beings. And it is reason that
triumphs in history and culture, for Herder no less than for Kant."
(342) this then is where overlap exists between Kant and Herder, on a
sense of reason and culture emerging out of a basic purposiveness
existing in nature. (342)"



* "Here S argues that despite Herder's polemics against reason in e.g.
yet Another Philosophy of History that reason was key to the force
underlying historical development in his work. (343)

> Thus there are firm grounds for concluding that the self-referential prin- ciple of development Herder saw operative in both individuals and col- lectivities rested on reason as an essential agent of its reflectivity. Herder never quite said, as Leibniz had, that the model for the substantive unity exhibited by monadic existences was rational selfhood, but there are many intimations of this in the citations given above. In taking from their envi- ronment what will nourish them and rejecting the rest, human individuals and groups are like plants and animals; but in the human case this inde- pendence was powered by a rational principle that was also independent of mere passion, and that would eventually realize its inherent power to give a specifically human form to life. This vision would find many echoes in Herder’s successors. (343)"

* "Now Humboldt takes up his account of Humboldt who he sees as
developing the opposite side of the coin vv Herder, ie "developing the
homology between self and world in order to ascribe to selves the
powers and values that Herder assigned principally to culture." (343)"



> "either produced or justified. On the most general level, Humboldt
believed that two interconnected conditions were necessary for
realizing “the true end of man,” w"

> "The first necessity was freedom, the second “variety of situations.”"

> "Human diversity was a product of freedom, since left to themselves
people naturally develop in distinct ways, but it was also a
precondition for freedom’s ability to bring humanity to its goal,
because only variety overcomes a certain tendency to one-sidedness in
human existence. This potential narrowness had both a psychological
and a social mode. Psychologically it derived from the need to
concentrate on one thing at a time in order to develop our talents and
energies, engaging in a single form of activity at any given moment.
Such concentration can be limiting, but each individual has the
capacity to ward off that danger “by bringing into spontaneous
cooperation, at each period of his life, the dying sparks of one
activity, and those which the future will kindle,” and by engaging in
activities that call on different personal capacities at the same
time. ("

> "rich collective resources of all the others.”21 Here the formative
benefits that individuals derive from social rela- tions run parallel
to ones they can procure by virtue of their own inner powers; we will
return to this point in a moment."



> "In a way Humboldt fits Charles Taylor’s description of a person for
whom “my humanity is something unique, not equivalent to yours” better
than Herder: in principle the notion that specific forms of life
absorb what can nurture their particular nature from things around
them, and ignore what cannot, applied to languages and cultures for
both; but Humboldt seems seldom to have employed it that way,
concentrating much more on individuals, and there were times when he
described what language provided not as nurture from without but as a
spur to the discovery of inner personal resources. He justified
individual withdrawal for the sake of self-development (and acted on
his own principle) in ways Herder would not have done."



> "For this reason the narrative of selfhood provided in the novel
mostly passes over certain questions we encountered in figures dealt
with so far – about where the self ’s stability or unity comes from
and how fully they can be attained, or about the persisting tensions
between its elements or dimensions. It does, however, foreshadow some
later treatments of selfhood as above all a question of personal
identity, a fit between inner nature and outer station."



> "What allows the self to progress from the first of these phases to
the sec- ond, from pre-reflective existence to reflective being, is
the self’s activity. It is in the activity through which we interact
with the world and with others that we come to know ourselves: “we are
only really able to observe or eaves- drop on ourselves when we are
engaged in activity.” The notion that the self makes its being visible
in the world through its activity is just what Herder’s image of
entities whose lives express their inner forces or powers entails. For
Goethe as for Herder, activity can issue in an undistorted manifesta-
tion of an individual’s inner nature because the world where action
takes"



> "place is isomorphic with the individual life-forms that together
constitute it: their path to self-development and self-understanding
runs through a world whose form of being corresponds to their own. For
both writers, this structural relation between self and world means
that the former comes to know itself in knowing its limits, since it
must find itself in a world whose existence transcends its own."

> "By bringing the two currents together, Fichte would produce an image
of the self as pure activity; just for that reason it would possess
the power to explode the limits his predecessors had ascribed to it."

 

## Epilogue

* I read quickly here, but he seems to end with a great deal of enthusiasm for Freud, whose account of the self I think appeals to him 1) because it was multi-dimensional, and 2) it held a mirror up to the hidden recesses of the pscyhe without requiring the kind of critical arrogance and assumption of an "outside" psotion that he criticizes of those who see the self as totally invaded by external (cultural) forces, see p.11.

 

## **Critical Comments**

* At several points here it becomes apparent that part of Siegel's preference for multi-dimensional accounts of the self, and his three dimensional schema for thinking about the self, is an intention to include, tentatively, the biological/corporeal domain.  In the Epilogue, he refers to a sense that biology has a role in augmenting certain domains of kjowledge that bear upon the self -- ie the body and sociology-- but he is hesitant to leap in this direction. He seems appropriately skeptical. (652) Still, his inclusion of the biological domain -- his openness to it -- is (somewhat like the Critical Realists like Margaret Archer, David Elder-Vass, and Andrew Sayer -- a way to reassert a domain distinct from the cultural, which thinkers like Foucault, etc might be perceived to allow to encompass everything -- or at least I suspect that would be his concern I suspect.

*

title: Antiromantic Romanticism: Sapir's Critique of American Individualism
text:
p.073-75  Sapir's attack on "romanticism"

H quotes Sapir in "The Grammarian and His Language" proclaiming his allegiance to the discipline of linguistics and celebrating its "classical spirit" which expressed itself in the "freedom in restraint" that he found in disicplines like lingusitics, mathematics and music.  He contrasts that classical spirit with the "romanticism" or "frenetic desire" that is "rampant in America today." (73)

[Note: Freedom in restraint sounds like the German idea of freedom?]

But H describes this as an "anti-romantic romanticism".  What Sapir means by romanticism is the same which Whyndam Lewis criticized as something sentimantal and emotional, "a self-indulget habit of mind or a tendency to shut the eyes to what is unpleasent, in favour of things arbitrarily chosen for their falttering pleasantness." (quoted on 74...)

But H then connects this to "Romanticism" as it is understood by "literary histoirans and critics" e.g. M.L. Abrams in his The Mirror and the Lamp.  [Note: I.e. H picks up the adversarial strain in romanticism which is also common to modernism, which in some strains grew out of romanticism, although recognizing greater ocmplexity by realizing that the source of transcendence was not simply to be found by intuitively connecting onself to Nature.]

So H says: "Self-expression, creativity, sincerity, spontaneity, the foundaitonal rather than merely decorative role of metaphor, technique as perosnal discovery rather than traditional canon: these themese that Abrams finds at the heart of romanticism are central to Sapir's aesthetic theory and are prominanet as well in his anthropology and linguistics." (74)

H asserts although without much evidence that this "romantic strain has obvious connects to Herder and the German romantic tradition, and it came to modern American anthropology by way of Franz Boas." (75)

H says that the romantic strain in terms of a desire for an organic culture emerges i "Culture, Genuine and Spurious" only to dissapear later, giving way to "increasing distress concerning what he saw as the spurious--and romantic, in Lewis's sense--individualism of modern American culture." (75)  Sapir's critique of American indivdiualism, H says, in turn had to do with the romantic's cultiation of anti-self-conscoiusness, which H gets from Geoffrey Hartman's 1970 article "Anti-Self-Consciousness" in Harold Bloom, ed., Romanticism and Consciousness, 46-56.)

title: The Radicalism of the American Revolution
text:
C Part II -- Republicanism

VI. The Republicanization of Modernity

* Starts this section this way: "In the end the disintegration of the traditional eighteenth-century monarchical society of paternal and dependent relationships prepared the way for the emergence of the liberal, democratic, capitalistic world of the early nineteenth century." (95)

* It was "republicanism" that destroyed the monarchical society, Wood says.  (95)  But it was a gradual process.  Wood says that in the eighteenth-century republicanism "seeped everywhere" and "eroded" monarchical society "from within, wearing away all the traditional supports of kingship, ultimately desacralizing monarchy to the point where, as David Hume observed, 'the mere name of the king commands little respect; and to talk of a king as God's vice-regent on earth, or to give him any of these magnificent titles which formerly dazled manking, would but excite laughter." (95)

* What happened basically was that republicanism was able to coexist with monarchicacal government.  (96)  So although republicans opposed monarchical society, but their goal was to "enlighten and improve monarchy, not cut off the heads of kings." (96)  This is not to ssay that Republicanism was not a radical ideology--it was--but it was not developed in this fashion--ie in the fashion of Jefferson who famously distinguished between monarchists and republicans:  "the sickly, weakly, timid man, fears the peopoe and is a Tory by nature.   The healthy, strong and bold, cherishes them, is formed a Whig by nature." (97)

* Montesquieu a key theorist of who set out the opposing priniciples of monarchism and republicanism for an enlightened age.  (97-98)

* In many ways, republican principles had already had their iimpact even on the more absolutist monarchies of the continent by the 18th century.  And England's government was even more republican.  "Already by the beginning of the century the English monarchy had lost much of its sacred aura.  The man-made dynastic alterations of 1688 and 1714 and the rationalizing of religion inevitably weakened the sense of hereditary mystique, and the restrictions Parliament placed on the crown's prerogatives and finances diminished the kings's ability to act independently.  Neither George I nor George II seemed to care about the monarchy's public image, and both kings tended to avoid displaying the trappings of royalty.... " (98)  So Wood concludes that the English who believed they lived in a "limited" monarchy in fact lived in a republican one.  (98)

* 99-100 Wood again repeats his point that republicanism worked from within, was not a doctrine of the radicals (thoguh it was a radical doctrine) but was espoused by monarchists and tories as well as whigs.  Wood puts it this way:  republicanism "thus became an important current in its own right that blended and mingled with the monarchical mainstream and influenced its color, tone, and direction." (99)  So it did not "displace" monarchism; it "transformed" it.  (99) But those who espoused it--who praised its presence in important works of art like Mozart's Marriage of Figaro or James Thompson's whiggish poem The Seasons or Jacques-Louis David's severe classical painitng The Oath of the Horatii--did not know that they were weakening monarchical government.  (100)

* Now Wood asserts "In essence republicanism was the ideology of the Enlightenment...In the eighteenth century to be enlightened was to be interested in antiquity, and to be interested in antiquity was to be interested in republicanism." (100)

* From 100-104, he shows how this tradition of ideas emerged--known as "civic humanism" or 'classical-republicanism"--from classical texts.  And he compares the republican interset in Rome in particular to the 20th century's interest in "some South Sea tribes..." (101)  Out of thsi came a literature of social criticism so pervasive that "all the great eighteenth-century British writers spoke in republican tones." (102)  So as a result classical conceptions of leadership became the present conception of leadership.  Cato and Cincero were the main models.  So that "public morality was classical morality." (103)

* Wood's definition of republicanism the begins here on 103-5.  Republicanism assumezs that man is a political being.  So public liberty or what we now call "positive liberty" involved participation in government.   Political liberty in turn ensured personal or private liberty.  So that positive and negative freedom were both wrapped up in republicanism.  Liberty was "realized when citizens were virtuous--that is, willing to sacrifice their private interests for the sake of the community, including serving in public office without pecuniary rewards." (104)  And this kind of virtue could only exist in a society of "equal, active, and independent citizens." (104)  The burden of public service thus put a great burden on individuals, both to serve and to serve in a "disinterested" manner--not uninterested, but disinterested.  Because republics required virtue, they were fragile and "extremely liable to corruption." (105)  "In their purest form they had no adhesives, no bonds holding them together, except their citizens' volutnary patriotism and willingness to obey public authority." (105)

* Although it was a radical tradition, wood notes, it "retained a traditional patrician bias in regard to officeholding."  (106)  The sense was that only those of the "better sort" (106)  should hold office.

* At the same time, the character of the leaders was also preoblematic.  Their ability as leaders also made them potential tyrants.  So the tension was between putting men capable of virtue in office, and then making sure that the remained virtuous.  "Controlling and channeling the overweening passions of these extraordinary men--the aristocratic passions of avarice and ambition: 'the Love of Power and the Love of Money,' as Benjamin Franklin called them--seemed to many to be the central poltiical problem of the age." (108)

VII - Truncated Society

* Wood starts off that the colonies only needed to bring republicanism to the surface in 1776, not invent it.  (109)  Republicanism was so engrained in English society by the 1770s, that the colonists could see themeselves as acting as good Englishmen by resisting tyranny.  (110)

* At the same time, in turning to republican principles the colonists did express the most republican and Whiggish strains of the ideology.  "For they were in fact the most republican of people in the English-speaking world.  Every visitor to the new world sensed it."  (110)  This had to do with the "conditions of their society..." (110)

1) Many colonists had no reason to feel part of "His Majesty's realm".  Many white immigrants were not from England and settled far away from centers of British allegiance.  Some settlers from other parts of the British Isles had historical greivances with the king.  (110)

2) Even many of the English were not good monarchists.  New Englanders "ritualistically recalled their seventeenth-century Puritan heritage of defiance to king and church..." (110)  But even in the South there wasn't much sense of "royal majesty" because the crown was just too far away (111)

3) Royal authority, Wood says, operated on the surface of colonial society "making the confused reality of decetnralized instituitons and localized authorities that mde up the central governance of the colonies." (111)  Religious authority was confused and this did not reinforce royal authority (111-112)

4) But the big one was: "the weakness and incompleteness of America's social hierarchy." (112)  Baiscally what Wood describes is how the local aristocracy--which lacked the dukes, marquesses, the court, and the fabulous wealth of England was not only unimpressive, but had trouble maintaining itsself in the way artistocracy should.  They had trouble for instance maintaioning their independence from the marketplace and living off of rents from the land that was what allowed the artistocracy in England to live so leisurely a life (113).   Wood goes into the diffiuclties with maintaining contorl of land in some detail 113-118.  They also had trouble living up to the classical ideal of leadership (118) and theri authority was regularly challenged dbecause it was easier int he colonies for common people to claim the status of gentlemen.  (118-119)

5) The lower part of English society was also absent in the colonies--"the great mass of destitute people that still burdened most European societies." (122)  At its highest, the proportion of poor could be as much as 10%, but this did not compare to the numbers in Hanoverian England "where as much as half the population was regularly or at least occasionally dependent on charity for subistence." (122)  By contrast, Wood says "most American farmers owned their land."  (123)  And he says this gave the colonists a "sense of their egalitrian exceptioanlism." (123)  In the colonies he says 2/3 of the opulatino owned land whereas only 1/5 did in England.  (123).  The propertyless in America tended to be either recent immigrants or the young.  (123)  The widespread state of freehold in the country was so significant because as William KNox put it freehold tenure "exludes all ideas of subordination and dependence." (quoted on 123).

* So America seemed primed for Republicanism and yet it was also backward, which meant that the lack of market relations made it harder for the colonoists to "substitute imperonsl market exchanges and a cashnexus for older personal and patriarchal conceptions; and they were more apt than Englishman to continue to think of social relationships in familial and personal terms--as expressions of the household rather than ofa market society." (124)  All in all though "the connectedness of colonial society--its capacity to bind one person to another--was exceedingly fragiel and vulnerable to challenge." (124)

VII  -- skipping

IX - Englightened Paternialism

* All throughout the eighteenth-century Anglo-American world, "traditional authority was brought into question.  Personal and social realtions were not working properly.  The social hierarchy seemed less natural, less ordained by God, and more arbitrary.  (145)

* Wood notes that by 1770s, entering students at Harvard and Yale were not ranked by social status. (145)

* He says that everywhere "ordinary people were no longer willing to play their accustomed roles int he hiearchy, no longer willing to follow their callings, no longer wiling o restrucit there consumption of goods." (145-146).

(skipping notes in most of the chapter)...

X - Revolution

* The Revolution "brought to the surface the republican tendences of American life." (169)  Wood says that the high rate of freehold meant that America was "naturally made" for republicanism. (169)  But the revolution was not simply about "bringing American culture more into line with the soicety."  it was also about abolishing the vestages of monarchy and creating "once and for all new, enlightened republican relationship among people." (169)

* The South Carolina physicain and historian David Ramsay said that people were changed from "subjects to citizens: "Subjects look up to a master, but citizens are so far equal, that none have hereditary rights superior to others.  Each citiezne of af ree state contains, within himself, by nature and the constitution, as much fo the common sovereignty as another." (quoted on 169)  So this was the basis of the idea of different human relationships.

* Key part of Wood's arguemnt comes here: this revolution was nto driven by poverty or "seething social discontent." (Here he's disagreeing with thsoe like the Progerssive hstiroians who have tried to see it that way...to see it in th elight of the French Revolution.)  The colonies provided the greatest prosperity in the world already for most people.  That prosperity "contributed to the unprecedented eighteenth-century sense taht peopel here and now were capable of ordering their own reality." (169)  As a consequence, Wood says there was a "great deal of ealousy and touchiness everywhere, for what could be made could be unamde; the people were acutely nervous about their prosperity and the liberty that seemed to make it possible." (170)  As traditional social relationships based on patronage and paternalism eroded, more people were xperience ing the "anxietiesw of freedom and indepdenence." (170)  After the 1740s, luxury was increasing and so was religious dissent, and the society was becoming more unequal.  But "social classes based on occuaption or wealth did not set themselves against one another, for no classes in this modern sense yet existed.  The society was becoming more unequal, but its unequalities were not the source of the instability and anxiety. Indeed, it was the pervasive equality of American society that was causing the problems..." (170)

* The meaning of labor was shifting as part of this.  There was for the first time the idea that labor could be good, that hardwork could lead to wealth, whereas it had always been associated with poverty and servitude.  (171) But int he colonies, hard working famers were extraordinarily free.  (171)

* Example of the touchiness in Moses Cooper of Glocester, who had worked and become a gentlemen.  But Britiain's mercantile restrictions could threaten his success.  (172)

* So the colonies bittle stegan to see the choice between freedom and slavery very starkly and they "repeatedly put into words their widespread sense that very little stood between their prosperous freedom and out-and-out oppression." (173)

* Also, in a society in which slavery was so present, they had many example.  (173)

*  Their concerns were also exagerated by the decay of traditonal forms of authority and speed of social change.  They didnt' know what form the ufture would take.  (173)

* There was also an increase in political activity, but thsi was not caused bya  push up from below, but by competitions between local gentry competing for the support of the people by invoking whig rhetoric.  (173)  But this politicization persisted.

* Royal authority tried to squash increased politicization before 1763, but failed, and then after 1763 these "efforts became hopelessly entangled in the government's attempt to reform its awkwardly structured empire." (174) And at this point "all parts of British policy" seemed to work against the colonists' increased republican expectations of liberty.  (174) At thhis point, with the republican rhetoric of corruption, the crown's actions appeared to make the crown just another "private interest" as John Adams put it.  (see 175).

* Another key assertion: "by adopting the language of the radical whig opposition and by attacking the monarchical abuse of family influence and patronage," the Americans were "tearing at the bonds holding the traditional monarchical society together."  And crucially their assault was "as much social as it was political." (175)

* The opposotion was not between poor v. rich or workers v. employers, but patriots v. courtiers.  Courtiers were those whoauthority came from above, from rank.  Patriots loved their country and were also free and indepdenent.  (176-7)

* The loyalists, about 1/2 million, fled during the reovlt at an extraordinarly high rate, and the effect of thsi was to speed the destruction of the local chains of traditional authority at the top of which stood families like the DeLancey's, the Peysters, the Waltons, and the Crugers in NY and so on.  (176-7)

* The people who took their place were unable to create the same "chains of family and patronage."  So that post-revolutioanry society was "inevitably put together on new republican terms.  Social and business links formed during the war and after were thinner and more precarious, less emotoianl and mroe calculating than they had been.  The liens of interest and influence created by the Revolution were looser and less personal, based less on kin and mor on devotion to the patriot cause or wealth alone." (177)0

* And removing those "clusterse of perosnal and familial influence" became the "idealistic goal of the revolutionaries." (177) Their emerged a "revulsion against corruption and the use of patronage..." (178)  So the purpose of the Virginia constitution eg was to "prevent the undue and overhwlmming influence of great landholders in elections." (quoted on 178).  The goal was at the same time to promote independence, so Jefferson ""proposed in 1776 that the new state of Virginia grant fifty acres ofland to every man that did not have that many."  (179)  The Revolution, Wood says, "became a full-scale assault on dependency." (179) I twas in this context that John Adams sated taht "there are but two sorts of men in the world, freemen and slaves." (quoted on 179)

* The revolutionaries did not expect that the poor would become leaders, but that "the sons of humble or ungenteel men, if they   had abilities, would, as they had, acquire liberal and gentelle crepublcian attributes, perhaps by attending Harvard or the Colelge of New Jersey at Princeton,a nd would thereby rise... "(180)

*  All the revolutionary state constitutions struck at the power of family and herditary privilege...abolishing the legal devices of primogeniture and entail... (182-3)  In this way the Revolution changed the old patterns of inheritance.  In aprticular, they recognized the rights of daughters and windows to inherit property!! (183)  Women's ability to own property was strengthened.

* The practice of servitude became anachronistic and anti-republican.  Masteres, Wood notes, became more employers, retial merchants, or businessmen. (185)  The revolution did not abolish black slavery but it did Wood insists make it "escruciatingly conspicuous in a way that it had not been in the older monarchical society... " (186)  Now it became clear that slavery was an aberration, a "peculiar institution." (186)

* KEY:  Becaiuse all citizens now thought to be equally free, there was a rdical change in the conception of state power.  The earlier talk of "paternal or maternal government, filial allegiance, and mutual contractual obligations between rulers and ruled" was gone.  New notiosn of "public power" emerged (187)  Popular consent became the "exclusive justification for the exercise of authority by all parts of the government... " (187)  "In republican America government would no longer be merely private property and private interests writ large as it had been in the colonial period.  Public and private spheres that earlier ahd been mingled were now to be separated." (187)    The local legislatureswere now "sovereign embodimetns of the people with a responsiblity to promote a unitary public interest that was to be clearly distinguishable from the many private interests of the society." (187)  So the lcoal governments created new plans for public interest.  The "carved out exclusively public spheres of action and responsiblity where none had existed before." (188)  so they made plans to improve trade and commere and roads and waterworkds and so son... (188)  They set up new authorities with paid staff paid by public taxes.  NY set up such an authority to mange steets and wharves.  The city of NY acquired the right of eminent domain and Wood says the power of the state to take private property "was now viewed as virutally unlimited--as long as the property was taken for exclusively public purposes. " (188)

* The new organizatino of public sovereign power raised the question: "wehther the people's personal rights could emaningfully exist apart fromthe people's sovereign power--the general will expressed in their assemblies.  In other words, did it any longer make senes to speak of negative lbierty where the people's positive liberty was complete and supreme?"   (189)  Indeed, "limiting popular government and protecting private property and minority rights without at the same time denying the sovereign public power of the people became the great dilemma of political leaders in the new republic; indeed, it remains the great dilemma of America's constituional democracy." (189)

title: Ethnic Diversity, Cosmopolitanism, and the Emergence of the American Liberal Intelligentsia
text:
Notes Feb 2012:

The idea here is that intellectuals like R. Bourne who laid out a "cosmpolitan ideal" in early twentieth century US were working "with rather than against, the drift of history" in laying out a cosmpolitan idea that helped constitute what Hollinger calls a "national, secular, ethnically-diverse, left-of-center intelligentsia." (134)  That liberal intelligentsia he says had become prominent in American life by the 1940s with its obvious leaders being Edmund Wilson, Lionel Trilling, and Dwight Macdonald (literary); David Riseman and Daniel Bell (sociological); Reinhold Niebuhr and Sidney Hoook (philosophical essayists.)  Their "dicourse" he says was "institutionalized" in the "liberal arts divisions of major universities" and in jouranls like the New Republic, the Partisan Review, Commentary, the Nation, and then eventually in the New York Review of Books and the New York Times Book Review.  Hollinger thinks that this group maintained its powerful influence througout the 1940s, 50s, and 60s, and that it was so powerful that all people who thought of themselves as "intellectuals" saw themelves as members of this group or its audience.  Most importantly, this libreal intelligentsia was half Jewish and half WASP.  (134)

    Hollinger defines the cosmpolitan ideal in a couple that these pole held in a couple of places, first on 135 where he describes it as a "desire to transcend the limitations of any and all particularisms in order to achieve a more complete human experience and a more complete understanding of that experience." (135)  In addition he says that the ideal was counter to the "eradciation of cultural differences" but was also "counter to their preservation in parochial form." (135)  Particular "cultures and subcultures" Hollinger explains were instead seen as "repositories for insights and experiences that can be drawn upon in the interests of a more comprehensive outlook on the world." (135)  When H revisits the definition of the ideal again on 150, he adds some other layers.  Here he emphasizes that it involved ideas about the "spiritual capacities of individuals" and their relationship to culture or subcultures:

The opportunities presented by life were felt to be broader than a choice between various particularisms (whether in the form of ideologies, religious traditions, or folkways). It was believed possible for human beings of diverse experience to put together a perspective on the world more authentic, reliable, and satisfying than any perspective generated by the intensification of a narrowly constricted range of experience. There was no reason in principle, it was assumed, why an individual could not have Whitman's multitudes within him or her and yet be able to achieve the stability required to enjoy those multitudes and to set priorities among them; similarly, it was hoped that a subculture could be complex and variegated without losings its integrity.  In other words, the cosmpolitan ideal implicitly attributed to people the ability to confront, absorb, and profit from experience not only qualitatively differnet from, but quantiatively greater than that of any given provincial existence. (150)

    For Hollinger the critique that must be made of this cosmopolitanism is that it among those who held this view it coexisted with an elitist doubt that the population at large was capable of the kind of "growth" beyond parochial points of view that the cosmpolitan ideal entailed.  The ideal was thus destined to remain the special discusive position of this liberal intelligentsia.  An understanding of the central role this cosmpoltian ideal plaid in constituting the self-conception of this liberal intelligentsia had itself been obscured from view by a focus on the theme of intellectual "alienation" from mainstream culture (ie Cowley's Exiles Return) that reinforced the distinction between intellectuals and "regular Americans." (151)  A key historiographical point of the article is that this theme of alienation has received too much attention, and is the chosen theme of many of these intellectuals themlves, but that it does not repsresnet the positive system of values that held this group together. (See 136)

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text:
p.003-5 Contrast Btw Prof. and Histoirans of 18th and 19th Century

17th Puritan clergymen and lay offiical write history.  History an "extension of scripture." (3) 18th & 19th century they didn't do it all their life.  They were "patrician." they wrote usually at the end of their life for an "unspecialized, cultiated audience."   After 1870, the professional historian.  Devoted most of his life to writing history.  Univeristy provided insituttional setting (e.g. Hopkins 1876 and transformation of Harvard during same decade). (4) Hisotrians no-longer "freelance" ; they are "servants of an institution" like the PUritans. (4)

title: Thoreau's Militant Conscience
text:
00 Summary 00

 

Read an article by N Rosenblum about Thoreau's "militancy". She defines militancy as against militarism, which would be conformity to a hierearchy, as quite the opposite: a revolt against passivity, resignation, and unoformity (87). It was in Emerson as a spiritual state, but T takes it farther making it "manifestly agressive." (87). It is wrapped up with his view that the state is totally illegitimate, even in its laws. He is totally antiinstitutional and the "State" is his target. T stood apart from that, but did not root his conscience in any universalizable maxim, but rather on his own inique genius. (98). So "Thoreau accepts nonconformity, even eccentricity, as sure proof of the essence of conscience..." (98). So that Thoreau ultimately was "not engaged in a quest for a collective ideal." (101). Three things politically in T's militancy: approval of violence in addition to passive disobediance; intolerance becausw "conviction made tolerance inconceivable." (102); and antiinstitutionalism. The latter puts emphasos on solitary rather than collective actions. (103). Thoreau's militancy is political; it is nit just a call for a reurn to purity and withdrawl; its aim is to change the world (105-6). But he provides no "alternate vision of the state or community" (106). It is instead a vision of permanent antagonism and struggle (106). Rosenblum suggests that this "militancy" is a distinct "unified stance toward the world" that appears at different times. She doesn't like it much: "It is the last resort of political-minded souls who refuse to regret their own powerlessness and incomprehension." (106

title: Canonizing Dewey: Naturalism, Loical Empiricism, and the Idea of American Philosophy
text:
Notes 11/2011

    Jewett notes the attention paid by historians of philosophy and social sciene to the rise of "value-neutrality" as a way of enhancing professioanl authority.  But  he notes that "as yet...we lack a systematic analysis of alternative epistemologies and their political functions in modern America."  (92)  In this article, he wants to talk about how the "Columbia naturalists" confronted the arrival of logical empiricism in America as a part of that attempt to tell a story about such alternative epistemologies.  (92)  

    The logical empiricists--ie originally the austrian Rudolf Carnap, his German counterpart Hans Reichenbach, and others--were "militantly scientific and politically left-wing" as were their adversaries in the Columbia naturalist movement.  Philosphically, they had an inclination toward "noncognitivism": "a theory holding that ethical judgements contain no cognitive content and thus present a fundamentally different kind of claim than do scientific statements." (93)  The Columbia naturalists, who followed the work of Dewey and Frederick J.E. Woodbridge, thought this stance on ethics un-democratic.  They thought that the logical empiricists viewed "value judgements and little more than idiosyncrasies, bearning no relation to the scientist's empirical investigations and logical reasoning."  (94)  That empirical orientation isolated philosophers from public discourse. 

In order for philsophers to fulfill their democratic responsibilities, the argument continued, they needed to recogniye that value judgements were profoundly social and publicy observable entities with future referents--in short, that these judgements expressed changes sought, states of affairs desire. (94)

Nagel attempted to forge a link between logical empiricism and American naturalism, but this attempt failed.  "W.V.O. Quine and other Harvard figures codified a new philosophical paradigm and relegated the synthetic, publicly oreinted stlye of the Columbia naturalists, along with their specific understandings of nature, science, values, and human agency. to the margins of the field." (94)  Meanwhile, the Columbia natualists continued to portray their approahc as the more "American" and "democratic."  But in a final turn, "a very different taxononmy of philosophers" became central during the Cold War: one which pitted a "non-normative 'analytic tradition' of Britain and the United States against a 'Continental Tradition' populated by Hegel, Marx, Heidegger,a nd other European critics of politically netural scholarship." (94)

    Critique:

More detailed notes

* American naturalism, J says, showed well the "intellectual convergence of liberal Protestants and the children of Jewish immigrants..." (94)  On the one hand, Randall, Schneider, Edman, Friess, and guttman were related somehow to ministeres.  J says that the "students of Dewey and Woodbridge aimed to provide an alternative to churches as a sourece of spiritual guidance." (95) He also points out that they followed in many way the tradtion of religious humanism represented by E.A. Burtt at Cornell and A. Eustace Haydon, Edward Scribner Ames, and Henry Nelson Wieman at U Chicago.  (95)  He points to the 1933 Humanist Manifesto that Dewez, Burtt, Randall, and Haydon sgined.  ((95)  But then he notes that the second- generation of Columbia naturalists worked even more closely with New York's many Jewish naturalists, such as Sidney Hook, a student of Dewey's who taught at New York University, and the Jamesian pluralist Horace M. Kallen at the New School for Social Research." (96)  These men were attacking "Catholic neo-Thomist, neo-orthodox Protestants, and other 'authoritarian' thinkers during World-War II." (96)  Pphilosophicl naturalism "took on a distinctly militant cast in Depression-era New York, and the personnel were increasingly of Jewish descent."  And by the late 1930s he says Dewey who was seen as an enemy of democray by Catholics was invovled with Hook in a "double-barrrelled attack on Catholicism and Stalinism." (96)

*  The starting point of Columbia's second-generation naturalists was Dewey's instrumental pragmatism.  (96)  This was "predicated on a reading of Darwinian biology that made a prominent place in nature for minds, values, and other 'immaterial' objects." (96)  Insofar as this view involved naturalism it was ore subtle and implied simply, as Edman put it, "a fatih in the unity of nature or substance, of which all life is a derivation, upon which all action is posited, and within which the structure of mechanism is seen to be simply a systematized technique of practice and of economical understanding." (quotd on 96)  Dewey saw immaterial entites like minds and ideals as occupying the same realm as material objecst and figured that he could take such a view in sofar as "minds were funcitons or phases of organisms, separable analytically, but not concretely, from bodies." (96)  So Columbia naturalists interpreted this kind of naturalism as empirical and not that form of naturalism taht was reductively materialistic.  (96) 

* These second generation Columbia naturalists also adopted Dewey's politics, J says.  Ie his attempt to preserve social science from becoming an "adjuct to capitalist power--as had the natural sciences in his view." (97)  As such, Dewey attacked both Lockean empiricism and the fact/value separation.  He saw empiricism as the "philosophy of the commercial middle class..." (97) It like Smith's political economy he thought sustained "economic individualism". (97) In ethics, he struck at the idea that normative commitments were "transcendent and absolute" as was maintaine by Hume as well as religious traditionalists.  This he thought made normative commitments "impervious to scientific advances, to social upheavals such as industrialization, and to empirically grounded criticism." (97)  Above all it segregated society from the "critical impact of scientific inquiry..." (97)

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.207-8 Politics and ideolgoy and social change

Sklansky now explains the ideological shifts that this social transformation produced.  Here he returns to Cooley and interestingly also his father: Thom McIntryre Cooley, who he says was a "leading exponent of the federal judiciary's sustained effort to appy the classical principles of private property and free enterprise to a society increasingly dominated by corporate capital." (207)

This led to a doctrine of "substantive due process" though which "connsitutitnoal protections of life, liberty, and property formerly reserved for individuals were gradually conferred upon business corporations. (207)

Sklansky now brings up a recent revision of the history of laissez-faire constituitonalism...which has shown that it was "guided not simply by sympathy for big business, as earlier scholars [such as?] contended, but by a deeper allegiance to the Jacksonian ideology of the free market and the neutral state."  Sklansky explains: "The sovreign self, torn form its roots in the early republic of freeholders, found a new hom in the sysnthesis of economic individualism and corporate property that is the enduring legacy of Thomas Cooley and his contemporaries on the bench." (207)

Against this background, Charles Cooley (Thomas' son) and his notion of a social self (+like minded social scientists) produced a "rival model of the relation between self and society, predicated upon the principle of 'interdependence,' as opposed to independence." (207)

Sklansky central point here though is that there is less daylight between these two positions that one would immediately assume.  Responding to the concentration of capital and wage labor, T. Cooley had disavowed older "liberal-republican precepts of natural right and social contract" henotes.  He had found in "Anglo-American common law tradition an organicist vision of a society founded upon common customs, habits, and values" and from this he develoepd a "sociological basis for the regulatory state, of which he was both a preeminent theorist and, as the first chair of the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC), a leading practitioner." (208)  HE formulated the idea of the state's "police power" to regulate corporate conduct.

It was from this set of ideas in T. Cooley's thinking that Sklansky argues Ch. Cooley--who had begun his career working for his father at the ICC--developed the new theory of social seflhood.  And here is Sklansky's central critique again: Saying that C.
