Cooley emphasized a "society governed by 'self-expression' rather than 'self-interest,'" he notes that in doing so "he also deliberately shifted the stakes of social struggle away from political and economic rights and twoard psychosocialnorms, desires, and needs, away from proprietary claims upon productive resources and toward cutlural claims upon selfhood and moral agency.  The social self that he created was therefore ironically compatible with wage labor and corporate capital in ways that hte sovereign self  it supplanted was not.  Much as Thomas Cooley's common-law rationale for the regulatory state was integrally related to his constitutional legitimation of corporate property, so Charles Cooley's social pscyhology was wedded in complex ways to the logic of corproate capitalism.  Together, Thomas Cooley's reconstruction of property and sovereignty along with Chalres Cooley's reconstruction of selfhood encapsulated the broader shift from political economy to social psychology as the master science of American society." (208-9)

title: Professions and Patriarchy
text:
Chapter 1

Witz's argument in a nutshell is as follows: Gender relations within the professions cannot be understood without the concept of patriarchy.  If one is to understand patriarhcy in the context of the professions, the best way to conceive of their realtion is through the dual-system theories which suggest a kind of harmony (rather than opposition) between patriarchy, professionalisation, and capitalism.  I.e. there is a kid of "partnership" developed her.  Hartman 1979 is her favorited theorist on this: "Capitalism grew on top of patriarchy; patriarchal capitalism is stratified society par excellence...Patriarchy...shapes the form modern capitalism takes, just as the devleompent of captialism has transofmred patriarchal institutions." (quoted o 14).  For Hartman the central mechanism is the idea of the family wage to which "she accords a pivotal role in securing th ematerial bais of male dominance in both the labour market and the family in industrial patriarchal capitalism." (15)  For Hartman, key source of aamle power in capitalism was men's ability to organize in trade unions.  Hartman believes that men's experience controlling the labor of wives and children taught them the "techniques of hierarchical organization and control" that later helped them establish similar forms of domination in the state: "In other words, a direct personal system of control was translated into an indirect, impersonal system of control, mediated by society-wide instituitons." (quoted on 21).

Critiques of Hartman (Walby 1986, 1989, 1990b and Lwon 1990) have pointed out thte fat that Hartman posits too cozy a relationship between patriarchy and capitalism which excludes the possiblity of conflict between the interests of capitalists (who might want to take advantage of cheap female labor) and working-class men (who want to maintain authority in the home.) Also Witz points out that rates of trade unionism were low in the ninteenth century, whcih would suggest that patriarchal capitalism might not have existed in the nineteenth century as Hartmann suggests.  This points to the fact that men did not only exclude women but also sometimes deployed an inclusionary strategy whereby women were allowed into jobs but shunted off into lower grade and less skilled work.  (27)  Thsi is particualr relevant in the prot-industrailzation of the late 17th and early 18th centuries when women when the family was incorporated as a labor system along with the lines of control in the family.  The shift to exclusoinsary practices occured when women came to be understood as wage-earners and not subsidiary workers. (28)

title: The Professionalization of Everyone?
text:
00 Summary Note 00 

The starting point of this article seems to be that professionalization as a term was at the time of writin g (1964) being applied very liberally to all types of occupations.  Wilensky then wants to try to understand what is in fact the process of professionalization.  He describes a somewhat regular sequence of structural developments that seemed to his research to be rather uniform.  

That process is described between 142 and 146.  Thus Wilensky writes: "In sum, there is a typical process by which the established professions have arrived: men begin doing the work full time and stake out a jurisdiction; the early masters of the technique or adherents of the movement become concerned about standards of training and practice and set up a training school, which, if not lodged in universities at the outset, makes academic connecting within two or three decades; the teachers and activists then achieve success in promoting more effective organization, first local, then national--through either the transformation of an existing occupational association or the creation of a new one.  Toward the end, legal protection of the monopoly of skill appears; at the end, a formal code of ethics is adopted." (146)

Important in understanding this article is Andrew Abbott's discussion of previous sociological literature on professionalism and professionalization in the Introduction to The System of Professions in which Wilensky's article figures prominently.  For Abbott, Wilensky (along with Millerson and CAplow) is a structuralist in which "Profession was mrerely a form of occupational control; the content of work and the expert-client relation were less important.  Professionalization here became an explanation of why the professions displayed such diverse properties; the answer was that some had not finished professionalizing." (15)  Abbott contrasts the structuralists with the functionalists (e.g. Talcott Prasons), the monopolists (Freidson and Larson) and those who saw professionalization as a form of cultural authority (e.g. Haskel and Bledstein).  (See Abbott, System of Professions 15).  Abbott's summary is really a necessary reading here in order to get at Wilensky's assumptions and limitations in relatoin to the broader literature.  A very useful survey.  He notes in particular (p.10-11) that Wilenksy does not elaborate upon what causes the steps of professionalization.  Each step in Wilensky's process Abbott points out "drawon different general views of why things happen in social life.  Schools arise functionally; they fill a need.  Delegation of taks, by contrast, arises in a historicist manner( success confers the power to delegate, which futher enhances success), while ethics codes simply coalesce inevitably." (10)   Ultimately, Abbott's critique leads to his analytical method of categorizing professionalizing theories, both form "formal" differences i.e. emplottment and presence of a central subject, versus "substantive" differences, e.g. functionalist, structuralist, monopolist etc... (see 13-14).

title: Spectacular Confessions: Autobiography, Performative Activism, and the Sites of Suffrage, 1905-1938
text:
1 Notes on Intro (6/27/10)

Just looking at this book very carefully.  Green means to examine the history of "spectacle" and "performance" in relation to the suffrage movement in England.  She explicitly thinks of this as an attempt to contribute to the rethinking "the relations between gender, literary moderenism, and modernity."  (8)  She is a literary scholar and so what is here is really a "literary history of the spectacular confessions of the suffrage campaign." (8)

FYI: In f.n. #11 she lists other books dealing witht he links between gender, literary modernism, and modernity: Fita Felski, The Gender of Modernity; Janet Lyon, "Militant Discourse, Strange Bedfellows: Suffragettes and Vorticists before the War," Differences 4.2 (1991): 100-133; Lisa Rado, ed., Rereading Modernism: New Directions in FEminist Criticism.  Those are the main ones and then seh lists others that read modernism in relation to femininity: Ann Ardis, New Women, New NOvels: Feminism and EArly Modernism; Suzanne Clark, Sentimetnal Modernism: Women Writers and the REvolution of the Word; Marianne DeKovan, Rich and Strange: Gender, History, Modernism; Briget Elliot and Jo-Ann Wallace, Women Artists and Writers: Modernist (Im)positionings; Sandra Gilbert and Susan Gubar, No Man's Land: The Place of the Woman Writer in the  Twentieth Century, 3. vols; Alice Jardine, Gynesis: Configurations of Woman and Modernity; and Lynn Pykett, Engendering Fictions: The English NOvel in Early Twentieth Century.

I'm looking at this book mainly to try to get a sense of the link between modernism, gender, and agency/selfhood... Is there anything here?  Not sure yet.  One problem is that her modernists are suffragettes; mine are academics and not primarily activisits.  She draws a distinction (p.8) between her actors and "high" modernists like Ford Madox Ford, May Sinclair, Wyndham Lewis, Virginia Wooolf, REbecca WEst, HG. Well, etc etc.  She is I think drawing a distinction between her actors and the subjects and those that the works listed above deal with I think.  I'm not sure this is ogin to help me.

Still there is something here that is similar to what I have been thinking about.  She describes her actors in contrast to "high modernists" who "wrote as detached spectators rather than as participants..."  She wants to focus on the way "feminist suffragettes produced new dicosurses of modern spectacularity." (9) Continuing: "No less than the literary figures named avoe, the suffragettes engaged dominant dicourses of modernity--especially discourses of modernism's spectacular advertisements, celebriteis, and technologies.  Feminist examinations of modernism's spectacular cutlrue, hwoever, by insisting upon both performance and critique, created a spectacular politics." (8)

There's something in this that relates to what I amt rying to say in Ch.4: the emphasis on an encounter with modernist selfhood that recognizes forms and then tries to subvert them for the purpose of weakning the limiting structures.  On p.9-11 of the Intro, Green takes up the question of whether militant suffragette was "in control of her representation, in command of the street theater of suffrage."--which is something that many studies have assumed (she cites Lisa Tickner's study and quotes from it on 9-11).  She ulimtately challenges this claim say the "Coronation Process" (a large suffrage march in 1911) met with "diverse readings" and then she shows journalist Harold Ownen's reading.  It seess it as a "feminization of modern public space" which is alienating.  Green then links Owne's account to andreas Huyssen's arguemnt that "the emergence of a modernist aethetic occurs simulatneously with its drawdrawl forma feminine mass body politic and feminized mass culture..." (11) and also with the tendency for modernism advocates to "figure its revolutionary energy through the image of woman" a point made by Janet Lyon in "Women DEmonstrating Modernism."  Green's point is that in Owen's account what has occured is that women have been triumphant but that at the same time "the radical break into the new age is not to be embraced in [his] version of history..." (11)  Her goal in the book then is to recognize how "gendered narratives of modernism's emergence appeared concurrent with suffrage activism" in a way that "exposes the feminist strategies that employed and subverted a variety of meanings attached to the feminized mass." (11)

Also useful is her thinking about "performative activism," a term which she wants to "call up speech-act theory's interest in the performative utterance that revals the word as an act; feminists theory's interest in those performances of everyday life that produce the contours of gender identity; and theatre history's interest in the shifts and changes of theatrical conventions."  (16)  All the elements seem important to me here: the mixing of the play with theatrical convention, the individual agency of the speech-act, and the spectacle as a moment in which shared female identity is created.  The tension between the last two seem particularly important.  GReen writes: "While  we consider how oppositional speech and autobiographical gestures produced individual feminist identities, we must also attend to the ways in which each individual utterance was intended to produce a collective feminist identity." (16)  So these were private utterances that also were an "expression of inter-subjective identity." (16) See quote on 16-17 about how the movment involved a discovery of identity a "real person that often remains throughout a life-time hidden under the mask of appearances..." (16)  Also interesting a quote fro Emmeline Pethick-Lawrence: satating that the suffrage campaign was "our education in that living identification of the self with the corporate whole, which means an intensification and expansion of consciousness." (16)

Green's analysis of the creation of this inter-subjectivity continues from 16 onward in ways that are quite revealing through the actualo words of the suffragists.  Their "individual" accounts inform a collective identity that the movement is helping to unfold as the quotes above indicate.  A particular interesting moment is when Green looks at the response to Black Friday  in Nov. 1910 when police attacked a group of women and allowed them to be beaten by an angry mob.  Aftewards the Women's Press created their own "evidence" in a text that was submitted to the Home Office.  Green analyzes this and shows that "[t]he women's testimony concentrated upon the parallels between these brutal beatings and a sexual assualt." (21)  The evicdence presetned first-person accounts but where the identity of the individual was protected i.e. (the info was presented by say "Miss C").  The utliamte effect Green says was that these accounts that layered "medical discourse, legal dicourse, 'experience,' and a scopic rigime in which the exposure of injruies to the feminine body would always positiont hat body within the register of sexualized dicosure, all functioned to complicate the 'tansparency' of these autobiographical accounts and to clarify that woman's body [i.e. not individual bodies] is the ground upon which struggle for respresentation in the body politic takes place." (21)  This seems particularly helpful to me because that is what one can see in the Lowell poem too: the woman is generic...she is clealry a woman in the way she is limited by the patterned conveiotns of her dress, her location in the garden, her postion of waiting for her fiance, etc.  Her identity as an "individual" one could almost say is similarly protected, whereas her problem as a woman is put at the center.  Green develops this further by looking at Joan Scott's essay "Experience"  from FEminists Theorize the Political.  SCott's issue is the "intersection between histories of marginalized subjects and the evidence of first person experience." Scott apparently argues that revisionist history is undewritten by an idea of "knowledge" "gained through vision" or "a direct, unmediated apprehension of the world of transparent objects"...This is a metaphor of "transparency" has given the legitimacy of the "experience" of previously unacknowledged historical subjects its legitimacy and has fueled the challenge to "normative history," which is seen as having an "incomplete vision."  But this is Ithink Scott thingks is a flawed challenge so Green writes that Scott argues that to not treat evidence as self-evident (quoting Scott) "we need to atten to the historical processes that, through dicourse, position subjects and produce their experiences.  IT is not individuals who have experience, but subjects who are constituted through experience." (Scott 22)  So it is "experience" that rather than being the ground of explanation is the thing that needs to be explained.  AS a theory of doing history this is great, but it is also useful for understanding the modernist consiousness that I am describing in Ch.4...this shift away from theindividual to the constiuted experience of a subjet...for the anths as for contemporary historians it is culture that is constituting experience...

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.022-23 Phase theory of history leading to this moment

Huntington has a veritable stage-theory of history here.  But it does not lead to an answer but in this case a new era of conflict of a distinct sort.

Here's the basic assertion: "Conflict between civilizations will be the latest phase in the evolution of conflict in the modern world." (22) Then he traces a history beginning with the Peace of Westphalia and ending with the end of the Cold War.  First for a century and a half after the Peace of Westphalia he says conflicts were between princes "attempting to expand their bureacuracies, their armies,their mercantalist economic strength and, most important, the territory they rulesd." (23)  He thinks that they "[i]n the process they created nation states, and beginning with the French Revolution the principle lines of conflict were bewteen nations rather than princes." (23) In RR. Palmer's words of 1793 these were wars of "poeples" (23)  This period lasted until WWI at which point "as a resutl of the Russian Revolution and the reaction against it, the conflict of nations yielded to the conflict of ideologies, first among communism, facism-Nazism and liberal democracy, and then between communism and liberal democracy.  During the Cold War, this latter conflict became embodied in the struggle between the two superpowers, neither of wich was a nation state in the classical European sense and each of which defined its identity in terms of its ideology." (23)

All these conflicts he says finally were "primarily conflicts within Western civilization" (23).  He notes that William Lind has called them "Western civil wars." (23)  But with the end of the Cold War he argues "international politics moves out of its Western phase, and its center-piece becomes the interaction bewteen the West and the non-Western civilizations and among non-Western civilizations." (23) 

Most interestingly he argues that there is a epistemic shift here between the West and its others. Basically the west loses its Other.  These Others become, along with the western states, the subjects or "shapers" of history: 
"In the politics of civilizaitons, the peoples and governments of non-Western civilizations no longer remain the objects of history as targets of Western colonialism but joint the West as movers and shapers of history." (23)

title: Introduction
text:
pp. 3-9 Ross' Definition of Modernism

 

Ross starts with the "problematic definition of modernism."  She begins the discussion with Kant's distinction bbetween scientific knowledge and aesthetic judgement.  Romantics tried to "annul the separation and reverse the hierarchy, starting a quarrel that contines to the present day." (3)  This "quarrel" continued with the "separations and relations between the scientifically oreinted successors to Englightenment reason and the modernist heirs of Romantic aestheticism..." (3)

So she starst here discussion with H. Stuart Hughes' Consciousness and Society: The Reconstruction of European Social Thought, 1890-1930 (1958).  Hughes' concern is a "cognitive revolution" focused on the prolbem of the subjectivity of consciousness.  Hughes is defending the humanist Englightenment tradition at a time in the 1950s when there is a sharp divide between positivism and aesthetic modernism.  (4)  Huges, thought, saw the 1890s generation that had effected this revolution and their ationality as emotion/irattionality.  Freud the main example.  Weber the hero who tired to hld together "the cognition of the irrational and the insistence on rigorous scientific procedures." (Huges' quoted on 5)

Huges also included a chapter on artistic modernism.  On Stein, Pound, Eliot, Joyce and Yeats...tracing their genealogy bck to French symbolists and Baudelaire.  Nietzsche and the "relativizing philosophers, psychologists, and therists of science" also influencing them.  Here Ross says Hughes' center and periphery are reversed...the above artists are the center and the philosophers, pscyhologsits and theorists of science are "adjuncts." But she says its the same problem: "the subjectivity of perception and cognition, a subjectivity that calls into question the unity of the observing subject as well as its relationship with the outside world.  The now problematic character of representation leads modern art to formal innovation and a reflexive stance."  Yet modernist art's turn to fractured subjectivity is not emotion but "rather the inward path of aesthetic ocnsicousness.  Aesthetic subjectivity, by its creative reconstruction of the world, becomes the source of whateer integrity and transcendence is available to the modern person." (6)

Aeshtetic subjectivity's "context" Ross says is understood to be the "artist's radical sense of alienation from modern society." E.g. Baudelai're evolt against philistine 19th-century city.  Nietzsche's revolt against bourgeois society.  So a turn away from "the world of democracy, bureacuratic organization, specialied functions, and industrial capitalism." (7)  a "moral and aesthetic revolut against the existing conditions of cultural-social life." (7)

Modernist's linked alienation to a "reconfiguration of historical time." (7)  They rejected the present world and argued that "historical continuity had been broken."  They imbibe historicism, an understanding of history that understands history as a "process of qualitivative change, moved and ordered by foces that ay within itself." (7)  This yields moral relativism and "risked transforming the novelty and uncertain of historical cange into chaotic flux."  (7)  If one placed the "historian in that flux" it "calledinto questoin the entire historiogrpahic enterprise." (7)  Thsu in 1890s a "crisis of historicism" emerges with increasing historical relavitivism.  But the sense of alienation brings it up in a big way: "The modernist revulstion against contemporary bourgeois society was necessarily also a rejection of the progressive historicismin which it was grounded." (7)

That in turn produced compliate understanding of the modern world and historical time.  Break in link between past, presnet, future, but sense of novelty and uncertaininty in the present in a historical world.  E.g. sense of pepetual transition or of Marxist W. Benjamin's idea of an act of historical perception that "might crystallize the revolutionary/Mesianic posibility of history."  T.S. Elliot  seeing the artists as being able to salvage "timeless mythic or mystic resources figured in the past." (8)

Or the present and its choas is an opportunity for aesthetic consicousness: "The conventional and outmoded forms of bourgeois society might even be seen as masking the utopian possiblities availabile in the forms of modernity itself--in Le Corbusier's rational orderor in the futureist' dynamic energies drawn from science and technology." (8)  Avante-gurade tempted to "reconstitute itself as an historical progression, a tradition..." (8)

Modernists often drawn into a dialectical relationship with history...(8)

But now Ross defines two modernisms:

Cognitive modernism: "turn-of-the-century recognition of the subjectivity of perception and cognition." (8)

Aesthetic modernism: This has captured the term "modernism."  It's what people mean when they say modernism.  A composite of "cognitive modernism, alienation, and aesthetic response..." (8)

Also "Modernity": "the actual world brought into existence by demoracy, capitalism, social differentiation, and science, a world against which modernists rebelled and to which the cognitive modernists of the Englightenment tradition continued to attache their hopes for progress." (8)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.084(b)  Ideas of leading male Psychs about women

Rosenberg says that after the work of Wooley, psycholoigst were not so likely to ephasize the essential differences between men and women, but that thye continued to believe that because there was allegedly less variablity among women, that they were less likely to achieve the upper registers of abiity.  (84)

Let Hollingworth, who studied at Columbia--depsite the fact that Columbia was hostile to women--challenged these basic ideas.

title: A category of the human mind: the notion of person; the notion of self
text:
p. 19 - 20  Persona as Metaphyiscal Entity

"It is Christians who have made a metaphysical entity of the 'moral person'...after they becaem aware of its religious power." (19)   And he says our "notion of the human person is still basically the Christian one." (19) Here he refers to a book by Schlossman, Persona und ... , im Recht und Christlichen Dogma (1906)

The the "notion" of the individual person became so clear that it could also be applied to what he halls non-real personalities, i.e. corporations. (19)  

Through this discussion of the Trinity the individual is perceived as a "rational substance, indivisible and individual." (20)

title: The Decline of the German Mandarins:  The German Academic Community, 1890-1933
text: p.081-083 German Mandrins provided their own accoutn of their viewpoint.  He describes these works.

title: The Decline of the German Mandarins:  The German Academic Community, 1890-1933
text:
p.083-086 Chareristic REaction against Enlightenment

Ringer says that the German mandarins reacted against "Englightenment" despite the fact ahtt Kant and Herder had named it.  The German Aufklarer he said were not "so much critics as modernizers of Protestant Christianity."  They wanted to rescuse the moral implications of Christian religion...  (83) They oten saw Enlightenment as a "West European" phenomenon.  They often accused it of being "shallow" but were more angered by what they saw as its utilitarian tendency: "a vulagar attitude in the West European tradition toward all knowledge.  They felt tha many French and English intellectuals from the seventeenth century on associated science and learning almost exclusively with the idea of practical manipulation, of rational technique and environmental control." (85)

title: The Averaged American: Surveys, Citizens, and the Making of a Mass Public
text:
p. 006-7  What she means to focus on...

Igo is speaking about the effect of new statistical studies of 
the US that sought to find the norm.  "...observers commented
quzically upon the modern mania for data and complained about being 'statisticized.'  Wheether they welcomed or decried it, they recognized a culture of surveying--and a surveyed culture--coming into being." (4)  Igo then wants to know what the awarness of this new culture involved.  She points out that these methods were not only a reaction to but helped to engender "mass society."  She notes that people have already observed this period as one in which a "truly national public was bolstered...by the popular culture of radio and film, the joining together of idfferent ethnic groups in the unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the spike in citizenship rates after the curtailing of immigration in 1924, wartime bond drives, and anticommunist rhetoric. ... What, however, of the impact of knowledge about 'ourselves'--all the more potent for its status, not as entertainment propaganda, but as truth?  Ways of knowing, although less visible than membership in civic associations and labor unions, are equally critical resousrces for fashioning public identities and political communities, and for structurin people's encoutners with the social world." (6)  Thus what she's looking at here is people's encounter with surveys, statistics etc that presented data

title: Lost Manhood Found: Male Sexual Impotence and Victorian Culture in the United States
text:
00 Summarial Note 00

Mumford traces shifting conceptions of manhood and male sexuality through what he funnily terms "impotence discourse" (34, see also 33 where he states purpose of essay) .  He notes two big shifts occuring in 1830, the time of the Second Great Awakening, and 1920.  In 1830, he argues that sexuality was divorced from reproduction (with which it had until then been linked) and impotence was understood as a "divine curse" that struck both men and women.  (34-35)  There was then a  shift away from that view which gradually linked impotence to "overcivilization" and this was the product of medical professionals and reformers.  (35)  Finally in 1920, impotence was reconfigured as a psychological problem, a problem of repressed drives.  This went along with a basic shift in the sex/gender system toward companionate marriage (35, 54-56).  This last shift Mumford argues had the "dual effect of undermining's women's sexual authority and reinforcing inequalities of difference." (36)  

Questions:
This is a good article, but I have some questions:
1) He describes at one point an "emergent model of sex difference that counterpoised the irrational and uncontrollable female body with the rational male body." (41)  This being an "emergent" ideal is interesting.  Is this really a 19th century phenomenon.  Does he mean particulalry the emphasis on body?  That could be, for he says just before that Chalres Rosenberg and Anthony Rotundo "have suggested that hte new construction of masculinity emphasized the body: they argue that the eighteenth-century ideal of 'publik Usefulness' gradually gave way to a more indivdualized 'physical ideal of manliness.'" (41)

title: The Vanishing Subject: Early Psychology and Literary Modernism
text:
Summary Note

Ryan tries to "view modernism afresh through the eyes of empiricism" (22) in this book.  What she mean by empiricism here is the "empirical" approach to psychology that she
argues generated a new approach to the self between 1880 and 1940,
especially in Germany, the U.S. and England.  This approach, which was to be distinguished from an earlier approach which presumed that the "character" of the indivdiual was visible through that individual's behavior (6-7), threatened the stability, 
consistency, and discreteness of the self as she explains in detail in her first chapter,
"The New Psychologies."  Wundt's attempt to deploy the experimental method in psychology in 1860s helped produce this shift by new focus on "senses," but ultimately these other movements moved away from Wundt.  Key figures were Franz Brentano, Ernst Mach, and William James.  Each applied a "phenomenological" method to the problem of subjectivity, which tended to undermine sharp distinction between subject and object, to see them as being linked together in different ways.  These ideas, she argues, ultimately influenced the literature of this period, and her argument is, i nfact, that this empircist approach had a greater influence on literature than Freud's psychology, which she describes as being more deeply rooted in a specific attempt to reconstitute the individual self, even if as a weaker entity.  Her description of Freud is interesting (see 16-22), basically she is saying that these other guys entertained more radical views on pscyhology, in which the self was all but gone.

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text:
p.29-30  She will Mix Positive and Negative Liberty

Negative liberty models have probem: They can't examine the social sources of the systematic nature of power systems, such as patriarchy.  

She explains this via the example of rape.  The way it is prosecuted, for instance, women that are gang raped are imagined to be raped by a series of indivdiuals as opposed to "by a collectivity, much less by patriarchy..."  She continues "...individual rapists live and operate within a cultural context that makes rape a conceivable and even acceptable act, that in effect 'enables' the action...." (29)  etc etc.  

She also points out that patriarchal ideas  of sexuality, in fact, deny that such a thing as rape even exists, for some patriarchal men, it is just men having sex with women.  

So she says a femnist approach to freedom requires, even in negative liberty models, an expansion of the concept of "external barriers." (30)  Then once one does this this opens futher questions about "how external factors shape the internal self, how restraint and opportunity form and influence desire, preference, and choice."   So she wants to explore relations btw inner and outer forms of fredom. she says (30)

She will mix positive and negative liberty: "Like classic negative-liberty theorists, I maintain that the ability to make choices and act on them is the basic condition for freedom.  However, like positive-liberty theorists, I maintain that choice needs to be understood in terms of the desriing subject, of her preferences, her will, and identity.  For subjectivity exists in social contexts of relations, practices, policies and institutions that affect and shape desires [note: social construction]."  (30)

title: Social Thought in America: The Revolt Against Formalism
text:
[55-57] [Social Problems defined by  Beard and Robinson]
Morton notes that for James Harvey Robinson and Charles Beard the "great problems of the day" which it is Morton's argument that they believed it was their duty to make their historical works address were "fell under three broad heads: the responsibilities of modern government, the war on poverty, and the progress and effects of natural science.  He gives details about their attitudes toward these three areas on 56-57.

title: Culture, 1922: The Emergence of a Concept
text:
Notes:

  • ------------p.016 CHAPTER 1 --------------------

  • 00 Summary 00 Critique: Manganaro is explicit in linking the "culture concept" = the holistic idea of culture as a "complex whole" with anthropology. E.g. "On Tylor's part, while his definition of culture as 'complex whole' provides the template for anthropology's central and defining concept... " (4 Another instance in which Manganaro generalizes regarding "modern anthropologists" holistic use of culutre: "And yet this mistake is intellectualy understandable, given the tendency in formative usages of culture toward containment--for Arnold, of anarchy; for modern anthropologists, of the disparate acts, practices and mentalities of a people into a comprehensible 'complex whole.'" (17)

  • p.001-3 Culture's Vagueness v. Institutional Value of Defining it Manganaro starts out the work typically by noting the vagueness of culture via an essay on it by Greenblatt which considers its value for literary analysis. (1) Greenblatt says it is problematic b/c too vague and then offers a more limited definition. Manganaro then notes that Greenblatt's move is in the vein of most of those that have written about culture: "[Greenblatt] effectively rehearses the veyr rehtorical position that has compelled writers since Tylor, including T.S. Eliot, Clifford Geertz, and Greenblatt himself, to continue to work with the term: that the term culture is too loose and large and needs 'definition.'" (1) Manganaro then points out that although "the battening of the term to a fixed institutional meaning becomes necessary for the legitimacy of the profession" there is something unique in that the term's vagueness makes it "institutionally productive or disciplinarily rich" to seek to limit it. (2)

  • p.001-15 INTRODUCTION

  • p.002 Culture and Humanist Decline Narratives Bruce Robbins he says has noted the link between culture and a "professional logic" relating to narratives of humanistic decline that served the claims that only a few recalled the glories of the culture. Robbins apparently has linked anthropology to the literary professions through the notion of "salvage" where the profession is "sustained by protest against the repetitious disappearance, which it thus has an interest in sustaining or constructing." (Robbins' words, 2) Thi sis from Robbins' book Secular Vocations: Intellectuals Professionalism, Culture... That link very strong in Arnold who closely linked the notions of culture's decline with its definition, i.e. "Gerald Graff makes the astute observation that once culture as concept was articulated by Arnold and those who followed him, it was already necessarily indicating its own absence..." (2) So "the very pronouncement of culture is only possible throug the articulation of anarchy" (2) See bottom 4 and also 5-6 in particular for how Arnold enables and describes lit crit "profession" via the decline of culture.

  • p.006-7 Book is an examination of culture concept AND Anglo-Am. Modernism Starts with "Victorian archtects of culture" and moves through Boas and his sduents to "modernist literary artists" such as Eliot, Joyce. Then Malinowki and modernist lit. critics like Eliot, I.A. Richards, and the New Critics Cleanth Boroks, Allen Tate, and John Crowe Ransom)... He focuses on culture as a "central idea or term" but also other key oncepts eg. myth, metaphor, narrative, irony, function... these he sees as "attends to but as displacements of and even versions of culture." (6) He will focus on the variety of usages in these preiods. (see 7, top), but also he emphasizes the continuity: "Th traffic in culture inaugurated by Arnold and tylor and made seminal to instiutitonal revolution and consolidation by Malinowski and Eliot has a common ground in Tylor's founding anthropological definiition, that is, culture as a 'complex whle' of human institutions, customs, and practices. The continuity here is in the important modernist tropes of complexity and wholeness he says: "The generativeness of tylor's founding definition, what enables cutlure's mobility in effect, is the necesssity of the interworking of its parts: complexity necessitates wholeness, and wholeneess makes possible complexity. In a consequent and common (though significantly variable) institutional turn, tribes and poems get read as complex wholes whose meaning, as decoded by institutionally based specialists, rsides in the interrelation of intricate parts." (7)

  • p.056-77  -------------CHAPTER 3-----------------------------

  • P.058 Malinowski's main disciplinary oppoent: British diffusionists

    see 58 and f.n. #9. Thes oppensn were British diffusionists Elliot Smith and William James perry.  Their so called neo-diffusionism.  Perry's Children of the Sun that focused on the "'world-wide spread of culture' from its origins in the Paleolithic Age..." (58)  Malinowski was fighting this.  Manganaro is getting this from Stocking.

     

  • p.059 Central theme of Argonauts culture's dissapearance

    M writes: "...what brackets Argonauts is word portending the disappearance of culture, words that in their sculpting of distintegration call for the salvage job of the culture reader.  Malinowski's opening lines--'Ethnology is in the sadly ludicrous, not to say tragic, position, that at the very moment when it begins to put its workshop in order, to forge its proper tools, to start ready for work on its appointed task, the material of its study melts away with hopeless rapidity' (xv)..."

    So the goal is to rescue culture...Manganaro says..."in order to make life worth living."  In last paragraph of Argonauts, Malinowski puts it in terms of WWI, need for tolerance for undrstanding the "essential outlook of others..." (quotd on 59).

    But what Manganaro points out is that this call for tolerance is in fact said to be achieved through the creation of a hiearchical conception of cultue: in particular in asserting a difference between his appraoch to culture and an "idle hunting after curios"...i.e. an amateurish approach to anthropology (60).  So Malinowski's influence he thinks has to do with his notoin of the power of fieldwork the "secret of effective fieldwork" which he called the "Ethnographer's magic".  So the use of certian rules, methods, systematic analysis...(61).

     

  • p.061-62 Holistic Theme also only apparent to professional

    Manganaro extends his theme: the professional, rather than the amateur is able to see the hole structure of the tribe.  With his ""tables of kinship terms, genealogies, maps, plans, and diagrams, proves the existence of an extensive and big organization." (quoted on 62)

    It is the professional for Malinowski that is able to grasp the whole, to generate a creative synthesis, to realize the whole... (63)

     

  • p.063-4  Similiarity between T.S. Elliot's and Malinowski's views of creative function?

    Manganaro compares Malinowski's approach to T.S. Elliot's notion ofthe poet who achieves excelence not through something new but in the "rigorous implementation of a 'mechanism of sensibility that could devour any kind of experience' and thus for whom 'experiences are always forming new wholes.'" (64)  For both Elliot and Malinowski he ays, the "process of making 'whole' is an artisinal, hard-won activity invovling procedures of the 'synthesis' or transmutation of the ordinary as well as extraordinary human experience..." (64)

    Also Manganaro sees a conection between their notions of individual...in relation to tradition.  As in Eliot's essay, the individual talen works out itssel fin relatio to the tradiotn.  LIek this, he says Malinowski was interested in how the indivdual expresses somethig not as indviduals but in "what they feel and think qua members of a given community." (quoted on 64).

  • p.003-5 Anthropology's part... He uses Stocking's comment that Arnold's conceptoiinof culture was "in some ways closer to the anthropological sense of the term than is Tylor's own use of it." (Stocking's words, quoted on 3). He's drawing hereon work by Chirstopher Herbert, "Culture and Anomie: Ethnographic Imagination in the Nineteenth-Century". The link Herbbert sees is between Arnold's notion of "right reason" as "looking forward to the anthropological notion of culture as 'that body of thought which supposedly emanated from the collectivity as a whole.'" (3) ...the tie being here fore Herbert that "right reason" comes entirely from society and has no "transcendental point of reference"> (3) Then M goes back to Tylor saying his "definition of culture as 'complex whole' provides the template for anthropology's central and defining concept" (4) and then notes that Tylor's evolutionary aspect was soon rejected by "modern anthropologists" e.g. Boas and Malinowski. (5) NOTE: It's as if he totally sidelines the significance of evolutionary theory as a temporary glitch... this appears to be very teleological.

  • p.005-6 Both Anth & LitCrit Establish themselves via Culture M's point against Greenblatt is that "...the decline and fall of literature, as fashioned by Arnold, makes the profession of literary criticism, much as modern anthropologists construct, according to James Clifford, 'the disappearnace of their objects,' those 'primitive' tribes whose survival, at least in the words of ethnography, depends upon and hence legitimates the anthropologist." (6)

  • p.007-8 1922 He says the book's "center of gravity" is 1922. The Waste Land and Ulysses were published then, and Argonauts of the Western Pacific and R-B's The Adaman Islanders. Also W.H.R. Rivers died indiating Malinowski's victory in leading British functionalist. (7-8). Furhter defenese of this year in terms of literary profession (8) and then anthropology on (9). He mentions Boas here in terms of Boas' desire to focus on "distinctiveness of each culture and the diffusion or spread of cultural traits from one neighboring cultural area to another." (9) He aruges this same conflict is "read into the arrangement and critical reception of The Waste Land and Ulysses." (9) Then also finds similar emphasis on a focus on detail, a supension of "narrative historical realm" and a plunging into "myth" and "magic" of natives in Malinowski (9)
  • p.010-11 After 1922 Here he acknowledges the variety of culture as these concepts develop in the context of attempts to professionalize. But he maintains that "culture" remains a "key figure or model common to all" and then by 1930s "commonly regarded and used as a multifaceted, organic whole, the relation of whose parts generate a comprehensive menaing that is, significantly, held to be greater than the sum of its parts." (10) As professionalization increases, his study will look more at the spread of htis model. The way models of modernist critics as "inhering in, structuring, or animating the literary text not only resemble the anthropological concept of culture but actually operate as displacements of, replacement for, the anthropological concept, not shuttled to the literary realm (and often, asin the case of Allen Tate, used as a tool againstthe influence of science in the modern age." (12) NOTE: This is very interesting in terms of the spread of culture and its jurisdiction. It spreads and then is replaced and taken over... Wow!
  • p.012-13 So while he admits that culture can "seem a thing of 'shreds and patches'" (quote is from Lowie's Primitive Society regarding culture, not the concept of culture, which M has already cited on 11) -- he also wants to suggest "some significant filiations of ideas both within and between the professions of anthropology and literary study." (12) On 13 he suggests that the an important sublogic of the idea that "gets variously worked out within and bewteeen the disicplines" is an way of interepreting the term that works against diachronic and instead "works synchronically to delve into the relams of the mythiccal and the magical, whether Malinowski's conception of myth as charter or Elito's 'mythical method.' As such magic becomes boht a province or areae of study--what people from other places and time do--and a mode of analysis." (13)
  • p.017 Eliot drawing on Anthropology Manganaro talks about Eliot's drawing upon anthropology to get to a concept of the cutlural whole or cutlure as a "way of life." Notes that Eliot had written an essay on "The interpretation of Primitive Rtiual" in grad school. (18) Much more info here too. (18-19). Then Manganaro claims that "Eliot's coneptualization of the 'local' unit indeed would not have been conceivable without the by then powerful anthropological legacy of Boas." (19) Manganaro then spends a few sentences discussing Boas' 1887 critique of Americanc evolutionists, and here he simply implies that the idea that Boas stated that social data must be considered in relation to their social context necessary implies a holistic version of this concept... or at least he seems to imply this, see 19, 3rd full paragraph.
  • p.050-55 End of Ch. is ode to Eliot Here Manganaro seems to be more positive about Eliot...here it's almost as if the tension between decay and his "brilliant suturing of antique mythic forms to contemporary 'reality' bits." (52) So M is kind of defending Eliot from those earliest critics who disliked Eliot's negativity about modernity (he talks about them on 50-51). He sees him as envisioning a "World Culture" (53) of "Greek myth, contemporary pop music, modern French verse, Elizabethan history, tarot cards, the Bible, obscene folk song, and the Grail quest,..." (53) M's seeing a more "postmodern" : that is though in Notes Eliot puts forward idea of a "World Culture", M sees Eliot's poem as most powerfully supporting a vision of the "waste land as spintered postmodern landscape..." (53) In other words, M here reads Eliot suddenly against the critique of him as an elitists, nationalistic, fascist with a negative view o fmodernity. He also downplays what he notes is the "isomorphism of culture to land" (see 50, first para. of new section and 53).

Related

  • Patterns for America: Modernism and the Concept of Culture
  • On Creating a Usable Culture: Margaret Mead and the Emergence of American Cosmopolitanism

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text:
p. 275-6  New Dynamic Model of Professions also leave out women

They also reference a new "dynamic" model of professions used by Elliot Freidson, The Profession of Medicine (New York, Harper and Row, 1970); Terence Johnson, Professions and Power (London: MacMillan, 1972); Margali Sarfatti Larson, The Rise of Professionalism (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1977).


They note also that even these new "dynamic" studies of professions left out fields in which women dominated and the major work in 1982 still remained Amitai Etzioni, ed., The Semi-Professions and their Oranizaiton: Teachers, Nurses, Social Workers (New York, The Free Press, 1969).

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.062-64  James Angell & Dewey views on Women

Angell's father the president of U. Michigan where he and Dewey and much of the U chicago psych dept. had studied as undergrads.  Angell's father supported coeducation at time it was being attacked by Edward Clarke et al.  (62).  Angell thus like the New women, his wife was one, and he admired her (64).  During debate about coeduation at U chicago in 1902, Angell "insisted on maintaining absolute equality of opportunity for women." (64)  
Dewey shared Angell's attitude.  He also married a Michigan grad.  Alice Dewey.  (65).  George Herbert Mead too, also. (65).  Thus rosenberg writes these "young philosohper-psychologists tended to accept and ecnourage talent among their women students to a degree unusual for that time." (66)

title: Antiromantic Romanticism: Sapir's Critique of American Individualism
text: Also see notes for earlier version form 1989

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1060 -  3  Women unable to afford the "American Standad of Living"

The standard of living Walkowitz says included "commodious accommodations with expensive furniture, pictures, an doboks.  For professionals , ti included as well automobiles, domestic help, membership in professional societies, and the accumulation of saving and investments." (1061)

He has excellent images showing how social workers might have fantasized about themselves, their life-style, and in relation to lower-class women.  See esp. 1062, picture of flapper woman next to a lower-class woman.

But women couldn't afford this in most cases.  They were making most of them between 90-125/ month.  Male salaries in the professional were already low, 10% than other professions.  But at the time middle-class "subsistence" income was seen as higher, between 2,000 and 5,000 in a study of Univ. of California families.  (1063) .  These salaries he says though were just below those of skilled industrial workers, they were considerably more than what sales girls at Filene's made: 15-20/ week.  (1063)

title: Social Scientists and the Culture Concept, 1930-1950: The Conflict Between Processual and Structural Approaches
text:
00 Summary Note 00 

This essay traces what Matthews refers to as a "major change in the basic assumptions of American social science which took place between 1930 and 1950" that involved the notion of "Culture" becoming "centarl, in a new and different meaning, by the even of World War II." (87)  Matthews articulates this
shift between two "ideal-type" frameworks within which he says sociologists interpreted data: the processual and the structural.  What he is tracking here then is a shift from the processual to the structural, where the structural is expressed through a new emphasis on culture.  Among these new emphases Matthews lists the rise of "interpretive apartuses" such as Freud and Marx, the "pattenred configuraitonal model of culture offered by Columbia Anthropology" (e.g. Benedict), the "equilibrium analysis of Talcott Praosn, and the "neo-Aristotelianism and neo-Thomism of Chicago humanism of chiacgo humanism" (88).  

Whereas the processual focused on the individual as the fundamental social unit, the structural tended to focus on institutions.  It understood reality as existing and as being in flux.  It ran close to American nationalism.  (88-90).  The structural by contrast emphasized the stability and "integration" of the "whole."  Matthews is particularly good at indicating other movements in the30s and 40s including the New Criticism in literature and others that paralelled Benedict's ideas (93).  He traces this new structural epmhasis first in Benedcit's theories, importantly noting that whereas Ogburn's cultural lag (rooted in the processual theory) had been "impatient with the redundancy or overelaboration of intangible culture beyond funcitonal needs, Benedict had praised its richness and achivement."  Moreover he notes: "Benedict saw customs, forms of association and artistic expression as an envelope of meaning, an essential protection against the incoherence and psychic terror produced by rapid change." (93)  He cites her "cups of clay".  Then he traces a second and more influential structuralism which is that of the strutural funcitonalists in which Durkheim is the important influence. (94-95)  Finally, he traces a thrid and later moment in which the processual view came back in a bit, e.g. the Cultural History moment that came atthe 1939 AHA and Carolin Ware'es published edited volume that resulted on "The cultural Approach to History." (96)

Finally, Matthews examines the causes of this transformation.  1) He thinks thecontext of the Depression and radical change created a need for systems that woudl be resistant to radical change. 2)  He also interstingly cites an internal pressure to critque old theories as a part of the professional process.  3) In term s of stimuli in the "broad external field of contemporary intellectual history" he cites a sense in which these people saw themselvres as "intellectuals" and thus were involved in a critique of American culture that took aim at the view which they linked to the processual theory "of America as benevolently blank plain, as ideal ground for individual opportunity and self-development."  (98-99).

title: Do Ideas Matter in America?
text:
Summary Note:

McClay's basically trying to make the argument--what a surpise--that yes ideas are important in America.  The main or most helpful part of that argument comes in the first section, p. 67-73.  He walks through the rejection of the consensus' historians idea that America was anti-intellectual.  He starts his own construction of the role of ideas with the 19th century awareness of the idea that American culture was being smothered by a dead European tradition in the form of "high culture."  (69)  He makes great use of Santayan's "The Genteel Tradition" and the idea that the gap between the high-brow and low-brow produced a "disordered relationship to the realm of ideas as entirely abstract and ethereal, rather than as useful instrumetns fo rmaking sense of practical experience." (73)  What comes next, of course, is pragmatism--"an effort to make ideas useful again." (71) McClay emphasizes the way pragmastism was influenced by Darwinian biolgoical science: "Human cognition was to be understood as an adaptive tool in the struggle for evolutionary survival, like the wings of a bird or the clas of a cat, and ideas themselves were compared to species whose viability can be evaluated only by testing their ability to survive in action.  Thus, intellectual life was a ceaseless flow of challenges and adaptions, with absolutes nowhere in sight.  Equally notable, however, was James's willingness to talk frankly in the language of lowbrows--to evaluate ideas in terms of their 'cash value' and their ability to produce fruitful outcomes." (72)  McClay's point is partly that pragmatism was not a radical departure from what he sees as the basic approach to ideas in America can only matter if they have a practical use...(72)--though this seems like a contradiction of his previous point via Santayana that American's couldn't see how ideas had a practical use.

But McClay's point is utlimately that the idea that ideas have no role in American life may have been that they are in fact respected only in practical form: "If we do not readily preceive the pervasiveness of ideas in American history, it is for the same reason that deep-sea fish do not perceive the existence of water.  Ideas provided the very medium within which American life is conducted."  (73)  McClay's proof of this invovles him in making the argument that Americans' always related to their own nation as an idea--ie he's supporting a version of the idea of American exceptionalism, which he acknowledges frankly (74).  I find this section a bit odd.  It seems not to fit very tightly with his good points about pragmatism.  It's one thing to trace the emergence of pragmatism as a distinct American philosophy out of the feeling that in America the gap between highbrow and lowbrow created a sense that ideas needed to be made practical again; it's another to make the general point that ideas were treated practically because of Americans' unique relationship to their national identity as an idea--which I do think is true to some extent.  The argument is a bit harsh...but maybe I could accept it.

I do accept well the idea that ideas have a kind of practical role then--or rather that those who engage with ideas most productively and convincingly somehow do so by meshing though with activity in the market and they intellectualize or philosophize the market in unique and powerful ways, e.g. Emerson's attempt to imagine the market as the "soul's economy."  Or Andrew WK even.  Market activity can have a heady significance in the US...and perhaps this works with McClay's claims about American exceptionalism: if the idea of America is linked to its business activity, then engaging in that activity can take on a heady significance??

McClay thinks then that what the consensus historians saw as anti-intellectualism is actually, very differently, "unreflexiveness." (77)  Hmmmmm

Then in the last section McClay wants to step back and look at three "clusters of ideas" that have formed the American "outlook".  He picks science, the culture concept, and liberalism.

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text:

She says this though is complex.  What is relationship between internal and external factors?  gives example if there is no strawberry but you prefer strawberry, will you stop desiring strawberry over time?

title: Consciousness and Society: The Reorientation of European Social Thought, 1890-1930
text:
001 Some Preliminary Observations

3-9: Assessment of what "intellectual history" is.  He decides that theoretically Int. History deals with "the thoughts and emotions of men--with reasoned argument and with passionate outburst alike." (3)  However, he notes that there may well be a deeper substratum in history--that discovered by the people he is studying--Freud, Marx, etc--the realm of drives and impulses.  but this cannot be what history studies, for he says history is about change and historians' impusle to study the "higher" order of events is a desire to see history as a movement and evelopment, whereas this "substratum" of drives and impulses is about repetition.  The subject matter of history then can only be "what is capable of coherent explanation in logically delimited time sequences.  And in such expalnation deed and thought are inextricably entangled." (6)  So he says: "The subject matter of intellectual history, then, is 'rationalizations' of various levels of complexity." (6)  Here Hughes is dealing with the claims of the people that he is studying re the discovery of the impulsive "unconscious" dimension of human life and its role in history.  Seems to me that this whole thrust is to acknowledge the wisdom of recognizing the existence of these forces, and yet to instist that we can find a force or pattern in history anyway--and this is a desire he finds in the thinkers he examines, though they most often fail to come up with a solution... On 6-9, he brings up the idea of there being a spirit in history or the idea that it is a rational process, both tendencies he tries to keep at an arms length without rejecting entirely.  At the end of the section eh states that the way he has chosen the subject matter and delimited his study implies "the existence of some such spriit.  The effort will be to locate--at least among a selected number of thinkers--the common attitudes that together constitute the emerging critical consciousness of the early twentieth century." (9)

9- : On the way he delimited his study.  He divides intellectual hsitory into the exploration of "high" and "low" levels of thought.  "The first refers to intellectually clear and significant statements--the second to popular effusions in the nature of slogans." (9)  What is low for him is what has "seeped down" after some "cultural lag."  (9)  His work deals with "high" ideas quite explicitly.  He breaks this down again into three categories: 1) studies of "popular ideas and practices--with the whole vast realm of folklore and community sentiments."  This he sees as like anthroplogist's ethnolgoical approach. 2) What Croce called "ethico-political" history--"the study of the activities and aspirations of ruling minorities and of the rival minorities striving to supplant them." (10) 3) "the history of the enunciation and development of the ideas that eventually will inspire such governing elites."  This type he says "proceeds on the aessumptiont hat only a small number of individual are actuallyr esonsible for the establishment and maintenance of civilized values..." (10)  The latter is the type he is diong in this study and he think ti is the via regia of intellectual history, since it is mainly on this level that ideas as such can be studied...ie he's after an arena in which "ideas in their pristine form" can be studied.  (11)

12-15: Limit of his study will be "little Europe": essentially centural Europe...excluding countries on the Western and Eastrern pereiphery.  The thinkers in this region he says in the genreation before WWI "shared a wider experience of psychological malaise: the sense of impending doom, of old practices and institutions no longer conforming to social realities..." (14)  Ie he describes here a sense of "the demise of an old society, coupled with an agaonizing uncertainty as to what the forms of the new society might prove to be..." (14) and it is this sense that has helped him delimit his study.

In this period also, there's "the end of one type of intllectual actiivty and the beginning of another." (14)  And this is really key!!! He sees these thinekrs as the creators of "great inclusive systems" and yet at the same time "they narrowed the range through which such genearl theorizing might operate and cast doubt on the future usefulness of intelletual operations of this type.  Thus on the one hand they figured as the last in the long succession of system-builders descending from Aristotle.  At the same time, by leaving their systems open and by passing on to their successors fewer solid answers than unproived hypotheses to be teseted, they introduced an era of specailization in social theory and of concentration on discrete, finite problems." (15)  So they were "humanists," but the "rigour" they introduced "preducled the formation of successors in their own image..." (15)

Central to these thinkers' "transitional world of ideas" H says was the "problem of consciousness"...ie "it was the period in which the subjective attitude of the observer first thrust itself forward in peremptory fashion--hence the title of this study." (15)  Earlier he says that "rationalists and empiricists alike agreed on an identity of view between actor and observer in the social process, and on assuming this common attitude to be that postulated by scientific investigation or utilitarian ethics." (15)  Now these thinkers started to "wonder wehther these emotional invovlements, far from being merely extraneous, might not be the central element in the story." (15)  This produced an "enormous heightening of intellectual self-consciosuenss... (16)  This self-consciousness could easily turn toward "radical skepticism" and even anti-intellectualism.  (17)  In this context, Hughes notes that he thinks the greatest thinkers of this period were those "who while fighting every step of the way to salvage as much as possible of the rationalist heritage decisively shifted the axis of that tradition to make room for the new definition of man as something more (or less) than a logically calculating animal." (17)

Interstingly, Hughes cites Kroeber's Configurations of Cultural Growth here to say that these thinekrs reprsented a "'cluster' of genius." (17)

17-20: he talks about which thinkers constitute this generation.

20: He states very clearly that he's not dealing with the "technical development" of social science.  ie he's doing an intellectual hitsory and thus is "only interested in ideas that transcend the scoep of a technical intellectual pursuit and have relevance for other fields of knowledge." (20)

25-  : He deals with the quite obvious fact hta thte conclusions fo these thinkers has influenced his own decisions in the study.  He says his "implicit notion of what constitutese history is basically Crocean," but "profoundly modified by psychoanalytic and sociological theory--things to which Croce himself was temperamentally hostile." (25) He notes also that he is American, but his "intellectual formation" has been European.  And he states that his "own position is quite consciously 'eighteenth century'" in that he thinks we are all "children of the Enlightenment, and that it is from this standpoint that civilized members of Western society--the their to a human tradition more than two centuries old--almsot necessariliy  judge the political and social movements of their own time." (27)   He quotes Ernst Cassirer on Enlightenment and self-critical analysis and says this is his own faith too.  (27) He's not disregarding the developments since the Enlightnement as "in vain" but only that "certain ethical postulates characteristic of the eighteenth century--chief among them the insistence, where possible, on rational solutions and human behavior--represent and abiding legacy of overriding importance..." (28)  Here he thinks his own interest are in-line with the people he's studied: he does not think thta these thinekrs were as hostile to the Enlightnment as they ahve sometimes been depicted. (28)  Much of their anti-Enlightenment feeling was directed, he says, not at the 18th century Enlightnement but against "its late nineteenth-century incarnation--in travestied form--as the cult of positivism." (29)

title: Antiromantic Romanticism: Sapir's Critique of American Individualism
text:
p.083-91 Move to Critique of Am. Culture

The moment of optimism ends quickly because of the war, which although it had intiially caused some enthusiasm, ultimately produced great dismay.  He describes this using Bourne again and he cites May agian who sees Bourne as a bellweather in terms of the loss of faithin "progress" (83).

He highlights in Bourne's "Twilight of Idols" a critique of efficiency  "unlinked to higher values." He also notes that Bourne is objeting to the way the "younger intelligentsia" accepted values "announced from above" and the "formulaito of opinion...loeft largely in the hands o fprofessaionl patriots, sensational editors, archaic radicals..." (quoted on 84)

[Note: I make the same move at the end of Ch.2 (as of 12/31/09) but do I hit hard enough the efficiency/bureaucracy thing?]

Bourne he says puts his "finger on anothe rproblem tha would increasingly inspire pessimism among culturla criics in the twenties: the relationship of intellectual elites to mass society and culture."  (85)  Her ehe says Bourne and Sapir are disillusione dby the war similarly, feeling allienated by the movement of mass culture.  see 85.  Sapir is not receptive to the optimisitic enthusiasm for social engineeriing and business culture that is part of the 1920s.  He dislikes Jazz (although likes Negro Spirituals).

[Note: Considering Sapir's antifeminism compared to Bourne's friendship with Parsons can we really link the two here so closely?]

Here is where he brings in Sapir's dislike for self-consciousness.  He criticiezes Hart Crane's powetry for "nerouvs excitement" (86)  and critiques the "too clever smootheness tha thas been made fashionable by Mr. T.S. Eliot." (86).  He likes poets Edwin Arlington Robinson, H.D., Emily Dickinson, Gerard Manley Hopkins, Leonie Adams...  H says he ses in them "sincerity, allied to,and made possible by, unself-conscoiusness." (86)

H uses a review of Emily Dickinson to lay out his point of view in more detail.  He also believed interestingly that "scientific thoght" was a head of popular culture.  H quotes a letter to Harriet Monroe that is important.  Part of it reads; "It is one of the most interesting ironies of cultural history that hard-headed scientific thinking (for example, in Mendelian heredity with its crhomosomes and genes; in atomic structure; in conceptions of space, time, motion, and matter) is forcing a sort of mathematical mysticism which leaves official philosophy and humanism behind as more crassly mateiral in thought than the spirit they thought they were combating as material." (quoted o 87, letter is from 1925).

But Sapir did not find this "mysiticism" in Boas whose scientific thinking wasw "incomple in expression" and "prevented by a certain fierce delicy from every declaring more than it manifestly must." (88) But he like Boas better than "our fashionable romantic biologists" (88)  He disliked Bertrand Russel who he though was at home in the romantic (pejorative) age.  (88)

He outlined a critique of emphasis on efficiency.  H uses two reviews of books about business culture in the US to get at this point, 89.  Here H links Sapir with Alexis de Tocquevill, Matthew Arnold, and Max Weber who "undestood that ht eAmerican religion of efficiency, which brought together 'our efficiency-experts and Methodist deacons,' as he once put it, was an unintended consequence of the secullarization of Protestant indivdiualism." (89)  Sapir picks up themes from these poel but develops critique of American individualism which ends up producing anonymity and stifling individual's growth and self-epxression.  (see 90).

title: The American enemy: a story of French anti-Americanism
text:
Notes February 2015

## Intro:

### Ch. 2:

* French Elite supported South, but was anti-Slavery! (80-1) Le Contitutonnel justification, liberating the slaves would mean the subjugation of six million Southerners! (80) Also the notion that slavery was doomed anyway; North was using slavery as justification to subjugate South, prevent indepdence. (81)

* Another logic: Civil War about economics, but then why should french be involved at all?   It’s an interethnic war between Anglo-Saxons and Latins! Part of a glboal racial conflict. (84) See Mercier’s 30page pamphlet Du Panlatinisme. Rogers says this was essentially same positio as French Gov’t (91), but not representative of French public opinion. (92)

* Third Republic resuscitates relatios with the U.S. after its hostility to the NOrht in the 1860s. Victor Hugo's philo-semetism cast as typical. But Jules Verne, Rogers suggets, was more typical: "Hugo was the lighthouts, Julse Verne the photographer." (92)

title: Liberalism Repatriated: Prospects of an Anthropology of Antiracism
text:
p.331-332 Context for paper

Europe now attempting to forge a "supranational polity ...while safeguarding autochthonous notions of tolerance and universalism."  (331)  Such notions are still seen he says as being been in "Western Europe" and as though in Europe such notions have been "correctly practiced." (331) He uses as evidence of that the fact that NGOs who push for these values in the world use Europe as their "bureaucratic home." (331)  Immigrants who come to Europe the find the situation a bit different: there is both reaction against tolerance (e.g. French law enforcing laïcité) and org. fighting against racism and intolerance. (331-332)

title: Ideas and Institutions in American Anthropology: Thoughts Toward a History of the Interwar Years
text: [6] [Stockings' Kuhnian view of Baosians...] Stocking outs himself here as seeking to interpret the significance of Boas' ideas in terms of a Kuhnian paradigm change... Describing the impact of Boas' ideas... "Indeed, one is tempted to go beyond 'reform' to 'revolution' and to suggest that this was one of those moments in the history of the social sciences that may, up to a point, be illuminated by the concept of 'paradigm' change. Certainly, the Boasians saw themselves as scientific innovators--paraoxically, in view of the anti-scientific current in their thinking, as the only propagators of a really 'scientific' anthropology. Their recruitment from outside, their youth, their creation and capture of institutional bases, their close community life, their tendency to rewrite the history of the discipline--in these and other 'sociological' dimensions, their innovation had a definitely Kihnian character. Substantively, the conceptoin of culture and of cultural determinism implicit in Boas' critique of evolutionism provided the basis for radically different disciplinary world view, although its implications were slow to be developed." (6) He notes that the intellectual thrust of the Boasians could be linked with the broader movement of funcitonalism (i.e. he mentioins Durkheim, Radicliffe-Brown, and British social anthropology) but it was distinct from this movement in that Stocking says that this movement believed that like causes produced like effects, i.e. "that social facts could be 'defined in advance by certain commo external charactersitics, that social 'species' could be classified in terms of 'the nature of the component elements and their mode of combination,' and that one well-constructed experiment offten suffices for the establishment of a law.'" (6) He cites Goldenweiser's review of Durkheim's Elementary Froms and Kroeber's dispute with W.H.R. Rivers as "retrodictible in terms of differences in paradigm assumption..." (though he notes in the case of Kroeber what is at issue is the "morganian current within British anthropology...and not all Boasians would have agreed with Kroeber." (6) But Stocking also argues that "oasian anthropology had only an imperfectly paradigmatic character..." (6) IT's not totally clear to me how he makes this judgement...but it seems to be the degree to which Boasian science may have had "unity" and developed in ordelry and logical way out of the assumptions that Boas' laid down... In paragraph on 6-7, Stockings' language expresses the idea that in a rather weak and not very obvious way it had unity and developed in a logical manner... Or he also notes in the next paragraph that there were "moments" when anthropological science "had something of the 'puzzle-sovling' character of 'normal science'..." (7) Perhaps a more complete paradigm would be thoroughly unified, and puzzle-solving... Then he suggests some alternative ways to think of this...including his "genetic" model... (8) But he ends his description in this section by concluding that "The history of American anthropology between the wars may hus be seen as the working out, in a changing intellectual and institutional context, of various implications of the position Boas had defined at the beginning of his anthorpological career." (9)...Which would be a Kuhnian process of paradigm change???
