title: The Age of Empire, 1875-1914
text:
Ch.4 - The Politics of Democracy

 

* After 1870, "it became increasingly clear that democratization of the politics of the state was quite inevitable." (85)  Universal male suffrage already existed in France, Germany, Switzerland, Denmark, USA, Australia, and New Zealand.  Reform Acts of 1867 and 1883 "quadrupled the electorate" in Britain.  Belgium democratized in 1884.  Norway in 1898.  Finland, 1905. Sweden in 1908.  Signs of female suffrage in Wyoming in USA and in New Zealand and S. Austrialia.( 85-86)

* Growth of electoral systems based on broad electorate "iimplied the organization of mass movements and mass parties, the politics of mass propaganda and the developing mass media..." (87)  Thsi changed the nature of politics.  Politice were "obliged to appeal to a mass electorate; even to speak directly to the masses or indirectly through the megaphone of the popular press..." (88)  And H interprets: "...as the men who governed wrapped themselves in rhetoric, the serious discussion of politics retreated to the world of the intellectuals and the educated minority public which read them." (88)  Also the rise of politial sociology: Durkheim, Sorel, Ostrogorski, and the Webbs, Pareto, Rochert Michels, and Max Weber.

* New mass movements: "rise of politico-confessional mass movements".  This process hampered by resistance from the Catholic Church.  (90-91)  His analysis of these starts on 90 and goes to 95.  These groups unfiied by religion, but also national identification.  The extreme form of these movements was the "party-cum-movement", e.g. the German Social Democrats.  This was rare, but the phenomena of this were typical.  1) Conssited of a "complex of local organizaiton or branches...integrated into a party with wider political objectives..." (92)  2) They were ideological; not just interest groups.  They represented a "total vision of the world."  Thus H compares them to the "civic-religion" that Rousseau and Durkheim thought would "bind togetehr modern societies: only in this instance it formed a sectional cement.  Religion, nationalism, demcoracy, socialism, the precurse ideolgoies of inter-war fascism: these held together the newly mobilized masses, wahterver material itnerest their movements also represented." (93) 3)  They were "global".  "They either shattered the old localized or regional fraemwork of politics, or pushed it to the margin, or integrated it into wider comprehensive movements."  (94)  H points out that it was the "party which made the notable, or which at least saved him from isolation and political impotence, rather than the other way around." (94)  So the new politicsl "did not substitute 'the people' for patronage and influence, but the organization: that is to say the committees the party notables, the activist minorities."  (94)  This was often identified by contemporaries as "oligarchy", e.g Robert Michels saw this in the German Social demcoratic Party.  So these new mass movements were "by no means republics of equals."  They were organizations that combined organization and "mass support".  H says they "were potential states." (95)

* Mass movements posed problems for the preservation of unity and existence of states: problems of division, problems of maintaining policies (e.g. the challenge to the gold standard esp. in the US), and the problem of the "legitimacy" of society when faced with mass movements calling for social revolution.  (95-96)

* The problem of legitimacy particularly problematic in the face of parliamentary inefficiency, partisan division, and the "undoubted corruption of political systems which no longer rested on men of indepdnent wealth, but increasingly on men whose careers and wealth were based on their success in the new politics." (96)

* 1880s saw emergence of mass movements.  These movements eroded the "mid-century political predominace of the liberal bourgeoisie" (98) that had also been weakened by the Great Depression in the 1970s.  (98)  Example of the stress produced by mass movments: e.g. Bismarck's inability to deal effectively with the rise of Catholic mass movement or the Social Democrats.  (99) The bourgeoisie was worried but did not feel seriously threatened.  "Civilized behavior, the rule of law, and liberal institutions were still expected to continue their secular progress." (100)  H points out that the major scandals of the day were surrounding crsies that from our 20th century vantage point seem normal, even daily, occurences.  (100-101).  E.g. Dreyfus "refusal to enquire into a singl miscarriage of justice" or Zebern in 1913 "twenty demosntrators locked up for a night by the German army in an Alsatian town" (100).

* So the "ruling classes" looked for other strategies namely their sought to bring labour and socialist movmenets (that had emerged in the 1890s) into the state.  This was achieved first in Britain when the "Labour Representation Committee" entered parliament as the Labour Party in 1906.  (102)  Such "overtures from the parliamentary centre to the extreme left" also involved a "readiness to venture into programmes of social reform and welfare" (102): e.g. Dismark's social insurance program in 1880s as a way to undercut socialist agitation.  (103)

* The legitimacy of the state?  How would this be secured.  This H says was the era in which "governments, intellectuals, and businessmen discovered the political signifiance of irrationality."  (105)  He writes; "Political life thus found itself increasingy ritualized and filled with symbols and publicity appeals, both overt and subliminal.  As the ancient ways -- mainly religious -- of ensuring subordination, obediance and loyalty were eroded, the now patent need for something to replace them was met by the invention of tradition, using both old and tried evokers of emotion such as crown and military glory and, as we have seen, new ones such as empire and colonial conquest." (105).  See 105-107

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text:
p.039-45  New Dominance for Synchronic approach to culture

Madden asserts 1) that "[t]he historical bent of Boasian anthropology had
helped to hold together the four fields as a body of knowledge." (39)  And then
also that there was gradually an increase in synchronic research that involved a liking of anthropology with other social sciences.  (39) 

One problem how to include physical anthropology in this.  From 40-45, Madden shows effort to use new toold of anthropological research  and understand the material artificat as somethign that could be understood psychologically, as a thing  connected to human behavior.  Paul Martin quote fro m1937: "...Artifacts, then, are the results of ehaivor and attitudes directed toward material objects." (quoted on 42).  

Julian Steward and Frank Setzler also though about this.  Archaeology could not just be about taxonmoy and classification.  Also needed to be about how these things fit into a general scheme.  

For Madden on 45, this all goes to show that cultual anthropologists (synchronic type) increasingly dominant. Archaeology needed to show how it fit into this.  (45).

title: The Radicalism of the American Revolution
text:
A Introduction

* The American Revolution has often been seen not to be particularly radical.  Progressive historians attempted to interpret it as radical social movement similar to the French Revolution.  Those attempts failed, Wood thinks, because the "social conditions that generically are supposed to lie behind all revolutions--poverty and economic deprivation--were not present in colonial America...the white American colonists were not an oppressed people; they had no crushing imperial chains to throw off." (4)

* Because the impulses behind the revolution were unlike those driving modern revolutions, there has been a tendency therefore  that it was not social.  "It has...been considered to be essentially an intellectual event, a constitutional defense of American rights against British encroachments ('no taxation without representation'), undertaken not to change the existing structure of society but to preserve it." (4)  Quoting Bailyn's The Ideological Origins, Wood says the American revolutionary leaders were not concerned about "recasting the social order" or with the "problems of inequality and the injustices of stratified societies but with the need to purify a corrupt constitution and fight off the apparent growth of prerogative power.'" (4) In thise sense it has been dubbed by some to be "hardly a revolution at all." (4)

* But Wood insists that "if we measure the the radicalism of the revolution by the amount of social change that actually took place--by transformations in the relationships that bound people to each other--then the American Revolution was not conservative at all; on the contrary: it was as radical and as revolutionary as any in history." (5)

* It was radical and social he says, however, in a "very special eighteenth-century sense." (5)--meaning the reason it was so often couched in purely political language was because in the eighteenth century "most people...could not as yet conceive of society apart from government. The social distinctions and economic deprivations that we today think of as the consequence of class divisons, business explotiation, or various isms-capitalism, racism, etc--were in the eighteenth century usually thought to be caused by the abuses of government.  Social honors, social distinctions, prerequisities of office, business contracts, privileges and monoopolies, even excessive property and wealth of various sorts--all social evils and social deprivations --in fact seemed to flow from connections to government, in the end from connections to monarchical authority.  So that when Anglo-American radicals talked in what seems to be only political terms--purifying a corrupt constitution, eliminating courtiers, fighting off crown power, and, most important, becomign republicans--they nevertheless had a decidedly social message." (5)

* As a resultl of the revolution, Wood writes: "One class did not overthrow another; the poor did not supplant the rich.  But social relationships--the way people were connected one to another--were changed, and decisively so." (6)

* He insisits that the revolution 'destroyed aristocracy as it had been understood in the Western world for at least two millenia." (8)  But it also did not just eliminate monarchy, it also changed what "Americans meant by public or state power" and created "an entirely new kind of popular politicas and a new kind of demcoractic officeholder." (8)  And he says most importantly, in a point he echoes on the last page of the book, that it made "the interests and prosperity of ordinary people--their pursuits of happiness--the goal of of society and government." (8)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.109- The Limits on Women's Achievment

Women were limited by not eing able ot pursue professional work in pscyhology.  Rosenberg notes that Helen Wooley Thompson and Hollingworth "bridged two worlds, one dying, the othe rstruggling to be born." (110)  she's referring to the reform activities of the pre-1920 women's movement and the post 1920 women's movemnt that "was dying, in part as a resutl of the forces in the professional world in which these two pscyhologists had been trained." (110)  "The values of indiviudalism, egalitarianism, scientific objectivity, and careerism that characterized the scholarly outlook in the emerging American university turned many women students away from the ideals of womanhood that had shaped their upbringing--ideals like selflessness, feminine purity, and social reform." (110)  The failure of the ERA ammendment to genrate support from the League of Women Voters is she says an indiateion of this split.   And she notes ater that "[a]fter 1920 it became increasingly difficult to reconcile reform with sicence, and the polarization that resulted among women persistde dfor two generations." (110)

She argues that Hollingworth was more of the new than the old in the end.  Hollingworth was critical of feminists for their "erroneous reasoning" in service of political goals.  She didn't like in particular their idea that women need ed special protection.  And she also disagreed wit htheir idea that women were superiot to men, and here Rosenberg refers to Hollingwoth's article with Robert Lowie on anthropolgy in which she noted that the idea of an all female society was a myth.  (111)

But Rosenberg argues "the new rld of science...did not offer women the uspport that the old world of social reform had." (111)

title: What Pragmatism Means
text:
General Notes

* James wants to speak of the "pragmatic method" which is "primarily a method of settling metaphysical disputes that might otherwise be interminable." (94)  In question such as is the world "one or many?--fated or free?" etc... he says the pragmatic method will ask what are the "practical consequences."  "What difference would it practically make to anyone if this notion rather than that notion were true?" (94)

* He references Charles Peirce 1878 article entitled "How to Make Our Ideas Clear" in Popular Science Monthly as the place where the philosophy was introduced and says that the idea as that "our beliefs are really rules for action" and that "to develop a thought's meaning we need only dtermine what condut it is fitted to produce: that conduct is for us its sole significance." (94)  No "thought-distinction" he continues is "so fine as to consist in anything ut a possible difference of pratice."  (95)  So that to attain a clearness in our thoughts about an object we "need only consider what conceiveable effects of a practical kind the object may involve--what sensations are we to expect from it, and what reactions we must prepare." (95) 

* He says that he bruoght the idea forward again in 1898 and made a special application of it to religiopn at "an address before Professor Howison's philosophical union at the University of California..." (95)

* The pragmatic method he says is an extension of the "empiricist attitude" he says "but it represents it in a more radical and in a less objectionable form than it has ever yet assumed."  (97) 

* He says that the pragmatist turns his back on things that "professional philosophers": "away from abstraction and insufficiency, from verbal solutions, from bad a priori reasons, from fixed principles, closed system,s and preteneded absolutes and origins." (97)  He turns twoards "concereteness and adequacy, toward facts, toward action, and towards power." (97)  James continues: "It means th eopen air and possibilities of na ture, as against dogma, artificiality and the pretence of finality in truth." (97) 

* If it were to triumph he says then there would be an "enormous change" in the "'temperament' of philospohy" (97)  "Science and metaphysics would come much nearer together, would in facct work absolsutely hand in hand." (97)

* Attacking metaphysics which he says has "followed a very primitive kind of quest" -- that is he notes following words as if they had a magical and transcendent power, ie imaginign that some word "names the univers's principle..." (97) -- he says that with the pragmatic method "you cannot look on any such word as closing your quest.  You must bring out of each word its practical cash-value, set it at work within the stream of your experience." (98)  So pragmatism ini relation to metaphysics means "The attitude of looking away from first things, principles, 'categories,' supposed necessitities; and looking towards last things, fruits, consequences, facts." (98)

* Now addressing science he notes that there has been an incredible confidence about the discoery of laws such that "men were so carried away by the clearness, beauty and simplification that resulted, that they believed thesmselves to have deciphered authenttically the eternal thoughts of the Almighty." (99)  But now as things developed it appeared that the laws were only approximations and the laws have grown numerous.  He mentions Mach and Pearson along with Sigwar, Milhaud, Poincare, duhem and Ruyysen after saying "human arbitrariness has driven divine necessity from scientific logic." (100)

* Then he says Schiller and Dewey have appeared with "their pragmatistic accounts of what truth everywhere signiffies." (100) And he describes their idea this way: "Everywhere...'truth' in our ideas and beliefs means the same thing that it means in science.  It means, they say, nothing but this, that ideas (which themselves are but parts of our experience) become true just in so far as they help us to get into satisfactory relation with other parts of our experience, to summarize them and get about among them by conceptual short-cuts instead of following the interminable succession of particular phenomena.  Any idea upon which we cna rid, so to eapk, any idea that will carry us prosperously from any on part of our experience to any other part, linking things satisfactorily, working securlely, simplifying, saving labor..." ( 100) 

* He describes a process of the formation of "new opinions" as the central process that Dewey and Schiller focused on.  He describes that process on 100-101.  The point is that a "stock of old opinions" is put under a new strain somehow because someone contradcits the ideas, or new desires emerge or new facts arise.  Then the person "seeks to escape by modifying his previous mass of opinions" but there's a conservatism, in fact James saws "we are all extreme conservatives." (101, cf compare with his notion of plasticity in "Habits."  Then a new idea comes up that can be "grafted" upon the old ideas so that the new idea "mediates bewteen the stock and the new experience and runs them into one another most felicitously and expediently." (101)  This conservatism seems key as he says a bit later "[t]he most violent revolutions in an individuals' beliefs leave most of his old order standing.  Tieme and space, cause and effect, nature and history, and one's own biography remain untouched.  New truth is awlays a go-between, a smoother-over of transitions.    It marries old opioin to new fact so as ever to show a minimum of jold, a maximum of continuity." (101)  And he notes later that the power of old truths is key: Their influence is absolutely controlling.  Loyalt to them is the first principel--in most case it is the only principle..." (102)  Because he notes it is usaally by loyalty to those patterns that one reacts to a situation. 

*  New truth is thus also additive.  A new idea becomes "true" "just in proportion as it gratifies the individual's desire to assimiilate the novel in his experience to his beliefs in stock." (103)  And in this sense it "must both lean on old truth and grasp new fact..." (103)  Thus new turth grafts itself on to the "ancient body of turth, which thus grtows much as a tree grows by the activity of a new layer of cambium." (103)

*  The truth that "rationalistically minded thinkers" refer to, are the old truths "that we find merely; truth no longer malleable to human need; truth incorrigible, in a word..."  And this is just the "dead hear of the living tree, and its being there means onlyut hat truth also has its paleonology and its 'prescription'...(103)

* Rationalist critics [rationalism = ? empiricism or idealism, both?  the one who relies on reason?] see this notion opinion and truth that focuses on how they "work"  as "coarse, lamesecond-rate makeshift article of truth." (104)   He sees them as saying that objective truth must be "something non-utilitarian, haughty, refined remote, august, exalted.  It must be an absolute correspondce of our thoughts with an equally absolute reality."  It must be what we ought to think, unconditionally."  (105)  But James would fire back that this type of mind is simply one that fails to realize facts and "conceretenees."--Indeed, the cast of mind of the rationalist is itself one of those concrete results perhaps...  The rationalist cannot recognize the "concretes from which his own abstraction is taken." (105)  Meanwhile, for the pragmatist "Truth, for him, bcomes a class-name for all sorts of definite working-values in experience." (105)

* But now a key argument: pragmatism "may be a happy harmonizer of empiricist ways of thinking, with the more religious demands of human beings." (105)

a ) Getting into this argument on 106, he gives a brief intellectual history of the divide bewteen empiricism and what he calls the "present-day fashion of idealism..." which he says those of the "fact-loving temperament" (ie tought-minded)... The old-fashioned theism was "bad enough" but w2hen Darwinisim "once for all displaced design from the minds of the 'scientific,'" then theism lost hold and "some kind of an immanent or pantheistiic deity working in things rather than above them is, if any, the kind recommended to our contemporary imagination." (106)  [It may be Josiah Royce where this is coming from...] 

b) James is concerned that this "conception" may not suplly "religious comfort" (107)  But his main point is that "no one can pretened that it doens't suffer fromt he faults of remoteness and abstractneess." (107)  It is noble but he thinks that "[i]n this real world of sweat and dirt, it seems that when a view of things is 'noble,' that ought to count as a presumption against its truth..." (107) 

c) Yet the reason pragmatism can bring this idealism closer to empiricism is because although "she" is devoted ot the facts, he says, there is no "materialistic bias as ordinary empiricism labors under." (107)  There is also no bias against "abstractions" he says "aso long as you get about amopnmg particulars with their aid and they actually carry you somewhere." (107)  So there is also no "a priori prejudices" agianst theology.  (107)  So the theological ideas will be thought "true" if "theological ideas prove to have a value for concerete life..." (107) 

d) Giving an example, he adds, tounge-in-cheek, that the transcendental idealism that he just described performs a "concerete function" in that it provides a "moral holiday"--because "since in the Absolute finite evil is 'overruled' already, we may, therofre, wehnever we eish, treate the temporal as if it were potentially the eternal, be sure that we can trusth in its outcome, and, without sin, dismiss our fear and drop the worry of our finite responsibility." (108)

title: Alain L. Locke: The Biography of a Philosopher
text:
p.011-15   Locke's early experience

The authors note that not much evidence exists.  IN a 1909 letter to his mother while in Oxford he remarked upon remembering that he had been walking along Fifth Street in Phillie as a child and had been asked to hold a horse's head--as though he were a stable boy.  Locke recalled this incident in Oxford in 1909 because he had taken up riding as a sport.  (10-11)

In a 1927 essay "Hail Philadelphia," Locke recalled that he was aware of the portraits of black predecessors who were on the walls of "the library" [Which library??] (11)

The authors suggest that Locke early-on developed a sense of elitism nurtred by pride in his own family's history as freeborn blacks.  The authors quote this : "Even when he couldn't recognize anything, each day he was taken out of the NEgro slumns into Rittenhouse Square in order that he might grow up a pure little gentlemen." (quoted on 11).

Locke had faith that he understood human nature because o fhis ability to "size people up": "Whenever I'm not quite sure that I can undersand human nature, I recall the like [his ability to evaluate people's skills] --and grow conceited again--which for al that it is my own eyes--but I soon get myself back on my pedetsal in my little niche and feel at home again." (quotedd on 11).

The authors explain that this self-confidence is characteirstic as well as his refernece to his own elistism; the uathors write that he "rather preempotrily joins his ancestors in the estheticized frame of an elevated niche." (11)

Locke's own self-reflection and awarness of his own past corroborates the author's claim.  In a 1942 account written for Harvard Alum reports he describes himsself as being born to "native Philadephias and schoolteachers; and thus into smug gentility." (quoted on 12)  He says that a "professional career was mandator, allt he more so because of the frantic respectability of the free, edcuated Negro tradition, their bulwark agianst proscription and prejudice." (quoted on 12)

The authors' suggest the content of this "frantic respectability" in an incident in which Locke's mother was described as ressed too smartly for some social function by a newspaper.  Locke was outraged at the afront to his mothers' respectability and wrote letters to the newspaper, saying he meant to "head off his [the authors'] nigger tendency of talking back in his columns..." (quoted on 12)

A fascination section drawn from some notes that Locke had made for a proposed autiobiography, reveal the character of his upbrining and in particularly his relationship with his mother.  It appeared to me to be a kind of picture of the late nineteenth-century ideal of how to raise a male child in which the mother indulges and poors affection on the child as a form of discipline.  See p.13-15.

title: The Rise of Neo-kantianism: German Academic Philosophy between Idealism and Positivism
text:
# Klaus Christian Köhnke, *The Rise of Neo-Kantianism: German Academic Philosophy between Idealism and Positivism*, trans. R.J. Hollingdale (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1991)

## Introduction

* Book is simply an attempt to pursue the historical question of "how neo-Kantianism emerged and whatled or contributed to its dissemination." (1)

* Existing appraisals of neo-Kantianism have been unsatisfactory and polemical. He describes the reaction on 3-4 bz Karl Löwith in his *Von Hegel Zu Nietzsche*, by George Lukacs, Karl Korsch, and Ernst Bloch. All have been dismissive fo neo-Kantianism. Löwith treated it as a "symptom of decline" in the bourgeois class, marked by an "unmotivated" return to Kant. (3) But Köhnke accuses Löwith's own account of being unhistorical because it was a search for useful philsophical traditions oreinted to 20th century needs. Another more political line of critique came from Bloch who accsused neo-Kantianism of reinterpreting Kant in a way that prepared the way for liberal nationalism in Germany. Here it is worth quoting Bloch: "And a school which totally dominated all the GErman universities distorted Kant, not yet into a proto-fascist, but ot such an extent into a National Liberal that the philosopher of the German Enlightenment looked like a Bismarckian drawing-room philistine. This particular falsification is called neo-Kantianism..." (quoted on 3). The DDR's  *Philosophisches Wörterbuch* similarly describes neo-Kantianism as arising out of the close association between "fuedal reaction" and the bourgeoisie...

* In general, Köhnke notes that there is a tendences to discredit neo-Kantianism "by pointing ceaselessly to what they regard as the disastrous political evolution of Germany" and so to consider neo-Kantianism in relation to political and economic history, but to do so superficially. (4) He says their accounts just don't hold water. Fro example, how do they account for neo-Kantian socialists like FA Lange? All of these accounts moreover have consistently pointed to a neo-Kantian scool, but noone has ever traced it. (4-5)

* He continues to go through all the gaps he sees on 5 and 6.

* Structure of book: Pt. 1 looks at the "prehistory" of neo-Kantianism "within the framework of variously motivated renunctiation of German idealism ont he part of academic philosophy and the reassessment of Kant that arose from it." (6) Pt. 2 gets into what he says is an already specified neo-Kantian "programmata", from 1860s to 1865 that arose from "various attempts at a theoretical re-establishment of philosophy and assertion of its autonomy or from drafts and outlines of sythenesse designed to unite old idealism with new materialism or with the new thinking of the natural sciences... (6) Pt. 3 focsues on the "actual dissemination" of neo-Kantianism. Here there is a degreeof unity, but also the basis for "a dividing up into schools." (6)

* These three phrases he says describe a process of transition from German idealism to a "golden age of neo-Kantianism". (7)

* He also notes that neo-Kantianism was "first an almost exclusively academic movement" and so its development "was in many ways dependent on that of the university in general and belongs to the historz of science to culturla history, ubut within the specific period 1830 to 1881 it was also frequentlzy dependednt on the history of chruch and state." (7)

## Part 1 The abandonment of German idealism (1830-1848)

### 1. Friedrich Adolf Trendelenburg as mediator between idaelism and neo-Kantianism

*  This chapter focuses on Trendenlenburg, a pupil of Karl Leonard Reinhold, who was the man who did a great dealto disseminate Kantian philosophy in Germany. He was born in 1802 in Eutin. He was taught Kantian philosophy in Gymnasium. Köhnke sees him as a key figure in neo-Kantianism's prehistory.  (11)

*  Trendenlenburg encounters the thought of von Berger who in his "Principle of Knowledge" interpreted philosophy as a science whose goal was to become the "common bond of all the individual sciences." (quoted on 12) Waht von Berger had decided was thtat philosphies' main goal was that of determining the "questions pertaining to the foundations of the sciences." (12)  This was a break from the main tendency of the age to see philosophy as the "science of principles" -- a pattern that was supported by Fichte's *Wissenschaftslehre* and Schelling's experiments in ntural philosophy. But von Berger had decided that philosohpy was not be derived from principle that "prescribed" the principles of each individual science, but rather "a philosophical analysis and understanding of the principles of th esceicnes that actually exist." (12) That approach -- in addition to being a rejection of sorts of idealism -- was also a modification of Kantian ideas "for a normative understanding of science was replaced by a the unconditional recognition of the individual disicplines that had in fact historically evolved: science was understood as the acts performed by different individual scientists, and legitimation of these acts was much more likely to derive from the facts of the science itself and from its traditions than from philosophical principles." (12-13)

> Note: This new emphasis on the *actuality* of a science is interesting. In Guyer's examination of neo-Kantian aesthetics there is a similar shift toward an assesment of aesthetic experience based on the actual existing expereince of art... see his "What happened to Kant in Neo-Kantian Aesthetics?..."

* Köhnke says that at first von Berger had attempted to adhere to an idealistic ocnception of "a fundamental discipline that provided the basis and explanation of everything..." (13) But ultimately he began to develop what Köhnke describes as an "organic conception of the world". It was he says the idea of **motion** that emerged as a way to "mediate between the multiplicity of individual areas of knowledge and that 'philosophy derived from a principle'' (13)   

* He describes this notion of the "organic conception of the world" -- although it is not clear where this phrases comes from --- as having a "contemplative religious temper" and a focus on "the multiplicity of things" and it gradually puhsed the idealist doctrine of the princciple of things to the background. (13): "for what now ensues is an ascent, progressing gradually and through a hierarchy of human capacities, from the physical forces of the sphere of life up to the realm of the intelligence and finally to that of faith: attempts to establish the foundations of the moral world have now been replaced by a description of the actual world." (13) So in von Berger and then in Trendenlenburg the goal is "to perceive the connection between becoming in nature and ideal becoming, to unite in though the first beginning of things with the highest aim and goal of the spirit-world." (13)

* Köhnke futher explains what he means by saying that natural and ideal then become "two variants of constructive purposive motion" that mediate theoretical and practical reason "in an act of intllectual contemplation." (13) He says that in so doing take into account a "certain experience of God" that was characteristic of objective idealism as described by Dilthey (where?) in a phrase "the Timeles that lies behind the whole evolution" . (13) But von Berger and Trendelenburg are not like Fichte, Reinhold, SChelling, and Hegel feeling that it is necessary to "found through the idea of identiical subject-object a claim to a complete theoretical comphrension of totality: they are satisfied, rather, with posessing in the concept of motion a univerally applicable *descriptive* formula for reality." (13)

* This re-orientation toward the empirical and away from the construction of totalizing systemic views occurs on von Berger as a kind of miscarriage of his attempts to see philosophy as establishing unity. Köhnke describes this miscarraige on 14-15.

* Köhnke seems to see this miscarriage as typical of the outcome of Romantic thought. Romantic attempts to construct systems seem to always rely on irrational appeals to foundational principles. That tended in turn to create miscarraige's like von Berger's which he describes as "a valid guide as to which problems were capable of breaking up the abstract formalisms of the early Romantic philosophical  systems..." (15) He describes a reaction against absolute idealism that was more widespread. There is a quote on 16 by Henrik STeffans -- whom Trendelenburg had heard speak in Berlin -- that talks about a new orientation in Romatnic thought that was less rooted in totalizing deductions of a unified system based on fundamental principle, and more on a teleological examination of the organic world. That was the approach of Schelling that challenged Fichte. The quote by Steffans thus talkks about an approach that seeks an "intuitive knowledge of all existence as an organic whole" , of "organic evolution", so a new kind of teleology... Köhnke calls it a ntural-philsophical teleology. (17) He says there emerged alongside the idealist deductive-aprioric type of sysstem of Reinhold and Fichte, and the methodistic-encyclopaedic system of Hegel a third Romantic-Weltanchaulich that challenged "the concept of system as such and its claim to coprehend totality" and instead turned to the search for teleology in actual facts.

* Köhnke says importantly for his narrative and overall argument that in this way that the irrationalism of Roamtnicism helped produce "the ninteenth century's love of facts" (17), i.e. he does not think that Romanticism only produces more irrationalism and ultimately violent nationalism. This is key to his argument in which he will give a bit more respect to neo-kantian philosophy than others who have seen it just as the beginning of the German decline into radical nationalism.  He even goes so far as to argue -- and I think this is too much -- that "This non-system, or abandonment of system, of von Berger and Trendelenburg is the Romantic system.  It is the system of emphasiyin the scientific value of individual phenomena as opposed to any kind of estblishment of principles--it is the system of positivist natural-scientific, historical, philological nd philosophical historical knowledge. It pronounces that systematic construction must be replaced by the collection of individual facts, by 'immersion' and by engagement with the multiplicity of things." (17) I think this certainly is **one** of the outcomes of Romatnicism, but it is not **the** system... (17)

* Important though is that this focus still wants to trace the link between philosphophy and empricil sceince to a divine source. There is still an interest in unity.  Köhnke quotes Bratuscheck on Trendelenburg: "In that the spirit aims more and more at the ideal, the unity of the ideal, the divine, constitutes the focus of its endeavour; the innermost core of all morality is religion, and the philosophy of religion is thus the flower of practical philosophy. If, consequently, science is always theoretically engaged in contemplation of undending nature, either directly or through self-awareness or as a practical task, and if, again, all knowledge proceeds in a practical sense out of the highest gaols of life, then an intrinsic connection must exist between all sciences; thus the philosophy which is to estblish this connection is not a mere propadeutic for th eindivididual branches of science, it must permeate them in all their parts.... " (18-19)

*  So there is a turn away from the idealist claim through a "self-engendered ego" to constitute the foundation of a "system structure." There is a continued religious focus that remains interested in unity, but also there is a "heightened interest in multipliticy of reality and the inductive investigation  of it." (19) IN thi way Köhnke says Trendleenburg nd von Berger represent a kind of shift in Romantic thought that was still interested in the spirit but tht had also "made its peace with the existing world." (20)  There is an attention to all the complexity of the world and there is a desire to apprehend a unity...

* In the next section of this chapter, Köhnke describes how Trendenlenburg formed a notion of the theory of science that was somehow an alternative and a precursor to positivist science in his *Logiche Untersuchungen*. In this work he lays out a goal to "learn from the sciences rather than seek to instruct them." (21) He seeks to recognize the individual and autonomous method of each of the scences and then trace backj from them to a "single mode of thought" or the logic that produces these individual sceicnes. (20-22)  

* Köhnke thinks that this theory of science has been misunderstood. In specifying what it is he emphasizes that it was an attempt to try to "reconcile the fundamentals of the philosohpy of identity with teh fact of the growiong multiplicity of merely positive knowledge." (22) The problem was tht each of the sciences "presupposes an identity of being and thought." (22)  So then how do you reconcile a philosphical interest in unity -- let alone a philosphy that presumes to reduce reality to principle -- with that multiplicity.? In the theory of science that Trendelenburg tried to shape a new synthesis based on attention to knowledge and interest, reduction to principle, attention to multiplicity, and the "organic conception of thw orld" ... (22)

* Köhnke says that Trendelenburg envisioned a multi-level process of inetegration. EAch discipline develops its own theory of knoweldge by "incorporating the problem of perception and the concepts of psychology. The theory of science relates the facts of autonomous individual sciences to logic. And in high philosophy a "new evaluation of the empiricaal ovecomes the previous constructionism of speculative thinking and rises to the exmaiton of the material elements  of scientific inquiry." (23)

* Trendenlenburg's ideas were influentijal in Germany. Köhnke says that his ideas dominated Berlin Univerity for an entire generation. and that he was able to influence the Prussian educaitonal system. (25) His theory of science when applied to school had the aim of preparing for the study of individual sciences and aslo his texts served as introdcutions into science in generl. (26)

* Thus Köhnke says that theory of science beceame relevant precisely "where philosohpy's older requirement for unity encountered the new requirement for specialization and accumulation of knolwedge: as an attempt at mediation between multiplicity and unity -- in terms of the history of philosphy between idealist philosophy of mind and empirical science -- it revised the philosophical apriories of the age of systems." (26)

* HIs theory of science also emerged out of another product of the greater accumulation of knowledge within this system, namely the grwoth of psychology as a distinct disicpline and its separation from logic. This had also played a role in the "miscarriage" of von Berger's attempt to develop a philosophy of unity and pure thought. Antrhopolgoical and psychological questions got in the way. That faith in pure thought was assailed by the problem of knowledge, ie it's disunity, and then also by "the effect of anthropology and psyschology had of rendering problematijc the originally self-assured ego. Deductions and constructions were not repalced by the more modest claims of psychological or logical inquiry. 'Pure thought' lost its reliability as philosophy's leading principle and method to just the extent that theindividual sciences began to find quesitonsal its characteryation as a 'human faculty'. It was above all anthropology and psychology which contested the meaning and truth-content of this claim, wahile it was at the same time precisely these sciences that offered new empirical knowledge assisting towards a better understanding of the nature of the psyche and the ego..." (27)

Great quote here I think from von Berger:

> For the history of philosophical systems teaches us that it is only too easy for the human spirit...to lose its spiritual equilibrium, as the repeated experience of error has instructed it in the impactiece of its striving and guarded it against new perils. Thus here it strays into a thoughtless empiricism which, itself capable of thought, would nonetheless like to eventuate in thoughts and conepts, there into an arrogant transcendentalism and the preciptate construction of metaphysical hoses of cards that the slightest breath of air can blow down." (quoted on 28)

* So for von Bergeer there needed to be a transformation of logic into a theory of kowledge predicated on a scientific method in psyschology and athropology. But the result of this was most concerelty the undoing of the notion of deductions from ego: "The autonomoy of deducation from the ego became untenable and, whereas it had formerlz created this foudnation alone and by its own power, philosophy's new ancillary sciences now compelled it to aprtake of knowledge acquired inductively. It opened itself to the empricial and seized old on things..."  (28)

* Trendelenburg and his theory of science is notable becuase it made the smae move for philosophy but at the same time "adhered to the idea nd concept of the unity of knowledge and of the actually existing sciences..." (28) Trendenlenbrurg was the first to point in this direction with his thoery of science.

Great quote:
> As theory of science it has...to serve as a signpost...for the sciences ... Although philosophy may have originated in unit with the other sciences...this union has long since been dissolved through division of labour, and philosophy now encounters the individual sciences dispersed and in the shape they have given themselves. It is these individual sciences that furnish the logic and metaphysics with their subject matter; logic and metaphysics find methods and presupposed principles present in the individual sciences, and their task is to discover their origin and unity." (28)

### 2. The rise of an autonomous discipline called *Erkenntnisstheorie*

* This chapter traces a different line -- the rise of a "modern theory of knowledge or epistemology" . (36)  Whereas Trendelenburg was the "architecht" of a "neo-Kantian understanding of philosophy and theory of science..." (36) The origins of this line of thought Koehnke says was Schleirermacher "whose lectures on dialectics, delivered from 1811 and published in 1839, represent the first post-Kantian attempt at a theory of knowledge foudned on both pure thought and sense-perception." (36) Koehnke notes taht th eonly historian of philosophy to see this before was Fierdrich Wueberweg, a pupil of Firiedrich Eduward Beneke and Trendelenburg. (36).

* Thue chapter has three sections.
 
 1. The first discusses the origins of the Erkenntnistheorie as an autonomous discpiline, something that was forming alreadying in the 1820s. For Koehnke to say this is a bit of a revision of the self-understanding of neo-Kantians, which claimed that this kind of approach  emerged only in the 1870s. He quotes something (there are evidently no footnotes in this book!!!) that illustrates this attitude, and it's itneresting in terms of displaying a kind of self-understanding of neo-Kantianism:
> German idealism had become bankrupt, Hegel's system had fallen to pieces, an age of anarchy, materialism, and universal philosophical decline had preceded the rise of neo-Kantianism, to which we owe the re-introduction into philosophy of the sort of epistemological inquiry which Kant began... (quoted on 37)

     In terms of getting at the content of this autonomous discipline, Koehnke has a good quote on 42: "The discipline of *Erkenntnistheorie*, the real objective of which was to be the investigation of the limits and truth-value, the forms and possibilities of knowledge, was, with regard to the formation of this philosophical concept in 1928, described by Ernst Reinhold with sufficient completeness for its futher dissemination and its establishment as a philsoohpical term to proceed sucessfully from this date." (42)

     So Reinhold in other words established the oncept of this autonomous discipline three decades before Eduwar Zeller and others "were to make the tem into the sign-manual of neo-Kantian philosophizing in the broadest sense becase inquiry into the limits and possibilities of knowledge had become a matter of wide concern an dinterest even in the era of post-idealist polemics, and above all to those directed against Hegelianism." (42)

 2. The second section deals with the key thinker here Friedrich Eduward Beneke, who was one of the earliest and most severe critics of German idealism and someone who also urged a "reconsideration of Kant." (37) I found the account of Beneke's ideas really interesting, as well as Beneke's thought itself. He rejects the idea of philosophizing from principle and polemicizes against a theory of a priori judgements; thus he critiques Kant on this account. (44) He makes this clever argument that the reason that there is recourse to prinviple in philosophical systems is that "we regard the genesis of an absolutely universal judgement by way of experience as incomprehensible." (quoted on 45) He then urges a rjection of **this** a priori assumption, and the result he thinks is a analysis that can examine "the relationship between logical forms and perceptions." (Koehnke, 45).
> The whole inquiry is from the standpoint of the purely human consciosness in fact so simle that we can discover scarcely a point to which specualation could attach its doubts and scruples. To the unspeculative mind (and fundamentally to the speculative too), being and perception are always so closely united it is incapable of thinking of one without the other. (Beneke quoted 45)
 
     Koehnke has a great quote from a handbook of history that says "The birth of this sensualist in a German city...is plainly a mistake... " (45) And Beneke had trouble in his career because his ideas ran against the idealist strain. Hegel himself attempted to prevent Beneke from finding a position. (45-46). Koehnke has  a quote on 46 from Johgannes Schulze that explains how Beneke's lectures be suspended because of the "dreadful error" in his thought that "there are no universally valid truths", a point of view that Schulzes thought "no longer possible." (46)

     VV Kant Beneke had an ambivalent relationship. He liked the part of Kant that had made a sharp critique of metaphysics and when he made "experience the condition of any kind of scientific knowledge. (50) But he disliked the idealism that had developed out of Kant's apriorism, which Koehnke says he viewed as a "faulty evolution of German philosphy from Reinhold to Hegel..." (50) Beneke, moreover, had a critique of this development that lamented what he saw as the isolation of German philosophy from the rest of the continent, see 47-48, 50-51. The following quote is useful:
> Since as early as Bacon this has -- with many interruption and retrogressions but irresistibly nonetheless -- striven for two sublime goals. Firstly that of the supersession, not of metaphysics certainly, but of the methods of metaphysics...the striving for exclusive principles which cannot be other than they are (i.e. accoridng to the decrees of the founders of systems) is to e whoolly abandoned and instead on is to lay down what really is... Kant's philosophy was fundamentally a vigorous start inthis direction which miscarried only becasue the old method was still too powerful in Germany for even so sublime and independent a spirit as Kant to be able to free himself from it entirely. But we have grown half-a-century older since then; we have beheld the monster of specuation rise up before us in the most repulsive forms; and thus it cannot be long before Kantianism in all its purity triumps over the methods of metaphysics. (quoted on 51, from his book on Kant of 1832.)

     Beneke's ideas though marginalized did ahve some influence in pedagogy, through the writing of Johann Gottlieb Dressler. Here, though, via Dressler these ideas were suspected of "materalism" by Ernst Adolf Eduard Caalinich (see bottom 53-54). But very interestingly!! Koehnke notes that it was through the critique of Beneke that the dsitinction between *Geistes-* and *Naturwissenschaften* was made for the first time by Calinich in the midst of a critique of Beneke and Dressler also:
> The word philosophy is employed in a double sense. Sometimes it is understood to mean the sciences which, unlike the natural or mathematical sceinces, apply not to something sensual or perceivable by the senses but to the inner self of man, to the world of the spirit. When the word philosophy is employed in this sense it embraces familiar sciences such as psychology, logic, aesthetics, ethics, jurisprudence and theology. These sciences aer also called philosophical sciences. In contrast to the *Naturwissenschaften* they could also be called the *Geisteswissenschaften*. (Calinich quoted on 54)  

     I.e. here Calinich is trying to bracket off these sciences into an idealistic realm, as a way of resisting the attempt of Beneke to base these in a theory of epistemology based on an awareness of sense (and of being).

 3. The third section deals with "speculative theism."

     In setting up this section Köhnke makes an important narrative claim I think. He notes following Max Wundt in 1932 that the transition from what Wundt calls the "age of specualtive systems to that of the individual sciences, from Romanticism to positivism" is hard to place. There is an account of Neo-Romanticism and a philosophy of life betwee Kant and 1830 that Dilthey helped start. (56). There is also a focus from the 1920s on a post-Hegelian philosophy. (56) And there are accounts of a "third movement" of phenomenology stemming from Feuerbach and the young Marx and of an existential strain coming out of Kierkeegard and with Nietzsche as a key figure. Karl Löwith's history tries to locate the "true ninteenth century" in this third movement. (56) From his point of view, however, there is another series of tendencies that he is tracing: namely, "pscyhologism, the transformation of logic into theory of knowledge and theory of science, the intensive analysis of the hsitory of philosophy, and an increased admissino into philosophy of knowledge derived from the ntural and human sciences -- all of them tendenceis already recognizable in the philosophy of the pre-March period which were then to come to full fruition between teh 1850s and the 1870s..." (56) These tendencies, importantly, he argues were what "'provoked' the various responses that came on the one hand from the classics Kierkegaard, Marx and Nietzsche, and on the other from the movements within academic philosophy: the one by making a break with tradition, the other by assuming the ungrateful task of undertaking a reformatory adaption of philosophy to the continual influx of new scholarly and extra-scholarly tasks." (56)  --- Note: there is a lot in these arguments: 1) It reveals the stakes Köhnke has in this study: he's trying to locate a key tradition -- a positivist one of sorts -- in the philosophical tradition of the nineteenth century, one that has gone undetected, but was not only the thing that this "third movement" of phenomenology and existential philosophy was responding to, but was also the basis of what will ultiamtely be neo-Kantianism, and tahtleads to 2) this seems to be his subtle characteriztino of neo-Kantianism yet, that it was an acaemic philospohical reaction to these tendencies that sought to adapt philosophy "to the continual influx of new scholarly and extra-scholarly tasks." (56) It's not entirerly clear to me what he means here, but I think most concretely he's referring to the emergence of this new individual sciences that fragmented the systems... to professionalization then?? Additionaly though, he argues that the latter reaction in academic philosophy is harder to recognize because it "never appeared in a pure form." (56-57) This is why he thinks von Berger and Trendelenburg have not been noticed as the root of a theory of science and Schileirmacher's *Dialektik* has not been noticed as the origin of a modern theory of knowledge (Erkenntnistheorie). (57)

    I'm skipping looking closer at this specualtive theism tradition 'cause I want to push further into his later argument...  time time time.

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.003-4  Cult of True Womanhood

Defines her gender dynamic in terms of the cult of true womanhood idea.  (see Barbara Welter essay by that name).
"...this belief system proclaimed women the natural harbors of spiritual and moral values in the wildly acquisitive seas of Jacksonian American and further apotheosized women as that half of the human race motivated only by concern for others.  In all she, woman was to serve.  She served through childrearing, charitable activities, and nursing the wounds sustained by both indivdual men and communites in battles for political and economic advantage.  To fulfill this responsibility for perserving the familial and social relationships, women were to cultivate piety, purity, submisiveness, and domesticity." (3-4)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
