He felt that it would precisely create the awareness of "sex matters"t hat it was supposed to remove.  (46)

title: From "Habit" in the Principles of Pscyhology (1890)
text:
General Notes

* First he tries to define what habits are and says that to do so immediately leads one to consider the "fundamental properties of matter." (60) 

a) The laws of nature he says are "nothign but the immutable habits which the different elementary sorts of matter follow in their actions and reactions upon each other." (60)

b) But in the "organic world" habits are more variable.  Why is this?  Because the organic world does not consist of elementary particles but compounds of elementary particles.   The habits of a compound can change "because they are in the last instance due to the structure of the compound, and either outward forces or inward tensions can, from one hour to another, turn the structure into something different from what it was." (60)

-->  Plasticity: If an object changes too quickly it might disintegrate.  Thus compounds have an inherent resistance to change that allows them to main integrity.  He gives the example of how a bar of iron becomes magnetic or how india-rubber bcomes friable or plaster sets.  That's plasticity:

...the material in question opposes a certain resitsance to the modfiying cause, which it takes time to overcome,but the gradual yielding whereof often save the amterial from being disintegrated altogether.  When the structure has yielded the same inertia becomes a condtion of its comparative permanence in the new form, and of the new habits the body then manifests. Plasticity, then, in the wide sense of the word, means the possession of a structure weak enought to yeild to an influence, but strong enough not to yield all at once. (61)

And organic matter and, he says, "especially nervous tissue," has incredible plsaticity.  So he lays out a principle that "the phenomena of habit in living beings are due to the plasticity of the organic material of which their bodies are composed..." (61)

* "Brain-matter" is a special case because it has been cutoff from mechanical and thermal changes.  "The only impressions that can be made upon them [minds] are through the blood, on the one hand, and through the sensory nerve-roots, on the other..." (61)  He now depicts a kind of flooding in and flooding out of impressions through a network of channels and suggests that habits are just discharges in this system.  So a habit is a "reflexive discharge"--or a "concatenated discharge" if complex--and its "anatomical substrarum must be a path in this system [of channels.]" (62)  So "the entire nervous system is nothing but a system f paths between a senseory terminus a quo and a muscular, glandular, or other terminus ad quem." (62)  And he images that habit formation is thus on this level the carving out of sensory paths over time, much like "either solid or liquids pass over a pth..." (62)  So certain sensory paths are gradually "scooped out and made more permeable than before..." (62)

* Once formed he then wants to say these "habits" are immensely conservative and powerful.  He gives examples of riderless cavalry horses going through their motions at the sounds of a bugle and a few others that wer less convinging.  (63)  Habit he says is the "enormous fly/wheel of society, its most previous coservative agent." (63) 

* This conservative quality is obth good and bad because it is what gives order to society (see examples on bottom of 63), but ti also "dooms us to fight out the battle of life upon the lines of our nurture or our early choice, and to make the best of a pursuit that disagrees, because there is no other for which we are fitted, and it is too late to begin again." (63)

* Now he uses this to discuss character.  He mentions the formation of professional mannerisms (64, top). He quotes Mill interestingly, saying "A 'character,' as J.s. Mill says, 'is a comppletely fashioned will.'..." (66) This point he develops further between 66-68, sounding very victorian.  What he wants to say and what he says best on 64-65 is that we must build ascetic habits, habits of what on 67-68 he calls "concentrated attention, energetic volition, and self-denial in unnecessary things." (68)      Thus he says that the "psychological study of mental conditions is thus the most powerful ally of horatory ethics." (68)

title: In Pursuit of Equity: Women, Men, and the Quest for Economic Citizenship in 20th-Century America
text:
p.010 Economic Citizenship

K-H intervenes in the discussion of citizenship by T.H. Marshall defines thee kinds of citizenship: civil, political, and social (in his Citizenship and Social Class and Other Essays).  Marshall subsumes economic rights in the civil category since he sees the right to work as the most basic civil right (something won in the nineteenth century against customs, guilds, and apprenticeship systems).  By the nineteenth-century this "principle of individual economic freedom" had become essential according to Marshall in the Anglo-American world because required my market economy.

BUT K-H thinks economic rights shoudl not be subsumed into the category of civil citizenship because it "obscures their interactive influence on political and social citizenship." (10).

She also notes that economic rights such as the right to work are different than classical rights such as political rights because theywere "negative."  The right to work is a "positive" right in this sense, and she quotes Walter Korpi in describing such rights as "proto-rights" not usually enforced by the state; they are instead "'norm-based' and socially reinforced." (10)

With this in mind, K-H points out that the right to work was not enforced for women.  Indeed, American courts "applied the notion as if women's liberties fell into a different category than those of men." (11)  E.g. iun a 1915 decision it described the right to work as the "very essence of the personal freedom and opportunity that it was the uprpose of the Fourteenth Amendment to secure."  But then nonetheless it also restricted womens' access to that right.  She quotes Senator Robert Wagner: "The right to work is synonymous with the inalienable right  to live....It has never been surrendered and cannot be forfeited.' Yet with respect to women, the idea that such restrictions were 'an offence against the liberty of the subject' dueled with the widespread belief that the liberty of women could and should be curtailed if it mjenaced the halth of the family.While rights to work for men could be counted among the fundamental sources of citizenship under liberal theory--a deeply rooted gendered prerogative--the ntoion that a public interest inhered in restricting women's work-related rights persisted in custom and law well into the 1960s." (11)

The exclusion of women from the right to economic citizenship limited womens' access to economic life.  That in turn, K-H says Patement has argued assigned women to a secondary citienzhip status given the "paramount duty of the citizen to work." (12)  She notes that this idea has been reinforced by a wide range of theorists (see 12).  She quotes Sam Gompers as well as Owen Young, the chqirman of the board of General Electric, who said: "Here in America we have raised the standard of political equality.  Shall we be able to add to that full equality in economic opportunity?  No man is wholly free until he is both politically and economically free; o man with an inadequate wage is free." (quoteded on 12).

So did this apply to women K-H asks?  She notes taht when she speaks of economic citizenship she means it in a large sense (since some use it to discuss the workers' ability to control their work situations): "I use it more broadly to suggest the achievment of an independent and relatively autonomous status that marks self-respect and provides access to the full play of power and influence that defines participation in a democratic society.  The concept of economic citizenship demarcates women's efforts to participate in public life and to achieve respect as woemn (soemtimes as mothers and family members) from the efforts of men and women to occupty equitable relationships to corporate and government services.  Access to economic citizenship begins with self-support, generally through the ability to work at the occupation of one's choice, and it does not end there.  Rather, it requires customary and legal acknwoledgment of personhood, with all that implies for expectations, training, access to and distribution of resources, and opportunity in the marketplace." (13)

K-H notes that on a theoretical level that "revaluing family roles" and making them less dependent on female labor "could provide the respect and the resources necessary to define a person as a competent actor in the public arena.  Ideally, espousing economic citizenship should not diminish caregiving as an equally enabling access route to democratic participation." (13)  She notes that in practice there have been moments when "the collective efforts of women have developed an ideology of caring into a succssful politics that enhanced community life and ameliorated disadvantaged working and living conditions." (13) She's thinking she said of Addams and the social femiminists and also Ellen Key.  But then she notes that few "individual women" have been able to achieve "public power for their caring roles, and while proclamations of the value of motherhood and family commitments have extended socail rights they have done little to provide the ground on which economic citizenship has been realized." (13)

title: Getting Spliced: Modernism and Sexual Difference
text: p.116-118 Burke's Conclusions -- She thinks that Stein, Moore, and Loy's "poetics of collage is flexible enough to express homosexual, heterosexual, and asexual modes of the links between sexuality and writing." (115) -- Pound, by contrast, is phallogocentric-- consistent with the broader tradition of western "phallogocentrism" identified by Lacan, Derrida, and Luce Irrigarray (115-116). -- She thinks that "the female modernists were involved in a revisionary project that critiques the (perhaps unconsciously) phallagocentric principles implicit in male modernism." (116) -- She thinks also that contemporary poetry--which Perloff described in this way: "...'the Romantic and Modernist cult of personality has given way to what the new poets call 'the dispersal of the speaking subject,' the denial of the unitary, authoratative ego.'" (116)--has its roots in "Stein's radical decentering of authorial perspective (as in, say, Tender Buttons) as much as or more than on Poundian logopoeia." (116) -- Finally, Burke quotes Margaret Homans to express the "assumptions shared by many feminist literary critics" about these women modernists: "Poets' themes have implications for formal and rhetorical problems, and, conversely poets use rhetoric to model solutions to those social or cultural issues that their poems may be said to be 'about'...The cultural construction of gender is at once a formal and a thematic issue. It shapes both the forms and the rhetorical modes poets have available to them and the wider social and cultural milieu that provdes their subject matter.'" (quoted don 117, from Homan's article "'Syllablees of Velvet': Dickinson, Rossetti and the Rhetorics of Sexuality," in Feminist Studies 11:3 (1985)). Burke argues thought that the process of idnetifying the formal techniques that explored these sexual relations have only begun to be identified and in f.n. #75 she lists some works. She also suggets looking at cotemp. poets who see themselves as decdenents of these 20s female writers and mentions Veverley Dahlen, Susan Howe, and Kathleen Fraser, esp. Fraser "whose own work could be said to splice feminine poetics with a logopoeic attention to language, recognizes the importance of the female modernists to this contemporary project...Burke also notes that female writers in this tradition often wrote in HOW(ever), edited by FRaser. (117-118)

title: Consciousness and Society: The Reorientation of European Social Thought, 1890-1930
text:
002 The Decade of the 1890s

*  This chapter traces a radical shift in the way in which "advanced thinkers" working "independently of one another...underwent a critical review from which there emerged the new assumptions characteristic of our time."  (33) Right at the outset he quotes Talcott Parsons' The Structure of Social Action.  Note that I know from Giddens' article "Classical Social Theory and the Origins of Modern Sociology" that Parsons is a major originator of what Giddens calls this "great divide" thesis that sociology radically changed in the 1890s.  Seems that Hughes is following Parsons on this.

* In characterizing the central thrust of thsi revolt, Hughe rejects romanticism--sicne many of these thinkers such as Sorel, Pareto, Durkheim, and Freud "though of themsevles as engineers or technicians, men of science or medicine." (36)  He also rejections anti-intellectualism, and irrationalism (35, 36).  Ultiamtely he says that the 1890s is best characterized as a "revolt against positivism" -- though this too has problems.  (37).

* But then he asks, how did positivism appear?  These writers did not use the term very specifically and used it interchangeably with othe rthings they disliked: ie materialism, mechanism, and naturalism.  Hughes specifies the intellectual construct that these thinkers opposed as emerging with the merger of positivist philosophy--originally an "intellectualist philosophy, basing itself on the convinction that thep problems of man in society were readily capable of a rational solution" (38) with Social Darwinism:

"Under the influence of Social Darwinism...the positivist creed began to shed its rationalist features: 'heredity' and 'environmetnt' repalced conscious,logical choice as the main determinants of human action.  A Hobbesian state of nature (now called 'struggle for existence') was substituted for decorous social order as the characteristic view of the relations between man and man.  The result was a kind of fatalism--the antithesis of the buoyantly optimistic attitude that had characterized the philosophers of the eighteenth century or the English Utilitarians of the irst part of the century following.  The ultimate irony of positivism was that what had started as an an ultra-intellectualist doctrine became in effect a philosohpy of radical anti-intellectualism." {NOTE: Here too, just to indicate how much Hughes may have been influenced by Parsons, he he has quoted only Parsons Structure, pp. 64. 67, 111-114.  Also keep in mind his own belief in the rationalism of the 18th century Enlightenment... } (39)

Hughes main point here is that in this intellectual context the thinkers of the 1890s were "aiming at precisely the opposite of what they have usually been accused of doing.  Far from being 'irrationalists,' they were seeking to restroe the freely speculating mind to the dignity it had enjoyed a century earlier." (39)

* Hughes argues that the broader intellectual climate of the 1870s and 1880s had been "stuffy" and that "the epoch exuded a sense of heaviness, of material excess, of confinement."  (40)

* Then in the 1890s, doubts emerged both on what he calls the "lower" and "higher" levels of intellectual activity (41).  One cause: that the "institutional arrangements of the major Western European states were againts brought into question." (41)  The "artificial, contrived characters of the regimes with which unification had endwed Germany and Italy were revealed by their malfunctioning..." (41)  In France, the Dreyfus case "acted as a stimulus tot he re-examination of the traditoinal ideologies onw hich both the defenders and the enemeies of theaccused captaied had rested their case." (41)  Social disorder, institutinoal problems, and economic crisis led to the rise of European socialism in the 1890s also.  (41)

* Because of the power of Marxism and of European socialism, the task of coming to terms with Marxism "was the first and ost obvious task confronting the intellectual innovators of the 1890s." (42)

* Now Hughes looks at the different "tasks of cultural re-evaluation" in the main Westenr and Central European nations, starting with Germany (42-51), then Vienna (51-53), then Frrance (53-61), and finally Italy (62-63).

Finally, and most importantly, Hughes sums up the "major ideas that were intiially stated in the 1890s, prepartory to their fuller elaboration in the first decade of the twentieth century." (63)

1) Most basic H says was their interest in "the problem of consciosness and the role of the unconscious." (63)  Problem implicit in Bergon's first book: Essay on the Immediate Data of Consciousness.  Bergson talked about the "depths" of consciousness and a "deep-seated self" that followed its own logic, as distinct from a "sueprficial psychic life." (64) The recovery of this "fundamental self" is the project that Freud brings to fruition in his Interpretation of Dreams.

2) Related to the problem of consciousnes: "the question of the meaning of time and duration in psychology, philosophy, literature, and history." (64)  Bergson particularly interested in this in an effort to "define the nature of subjective existence as opposed the schematic order that the natural sciences had imposed on the external world." (64)  But natural scientists themselves exploring this problem as the world they studied no longer appeared to fit the laws of Newtonian physics. (64)  Something that novelists also obdsesses with as aprt of problem of "how to recapture the immediacy of past experience in langauge that in orderanary usage could reproduce no mroe than the fragmentized reality of an existence that the logical memory had arleady stored away in neat compartments." (65)

3) Espitemology of knowledge in waht Dilthey called the "sciences of the mind."  (65) Dilthey tried to "establish rules that would separate the areas in which the human mind strove for some kind of internal comprehension from the realm of external and pruely converntional symbols devised by natural science." (65)  Croce picked this up a decade later and by 1900 it had become apparent that "the nineteenth-century program of building an edifice of historical and sociolgoical knowledge by pateiebnt accumation and painstatking verifiation no longer sufficed.  By such means it would forever be impossible to penetrate eneath the surface of human experience.  One had, rather, a choice between the exercise of the sympathetic intutiion postualted in Croce's neio-idealistic theory of history, and teh creation of sueful fictions, as max Weber was later to elaborate them, as models for cricial understanding." (65)

4) So as a consquence of this shaking of the foundation of human knowledge, so too had teh "whole basis of political discussion" been altered.  The "ratioanlsitic ideologies inehreted from the 18th century--wheether socialism or liberalism--woudl no longer suffice.  One had to "penetrate beyond" these "myths" and here the "discussion of politics" would move 'from the rhetoric of public discussion to the manipualtion of half-consciosu sentiments." (66) So H writes that the "axis of social thought" had shifted "from the apparent and objectively verifiable to the only partially conscious area of unexplained motivation." (66).  So these new doctrines were "manifestly subjective." (66)  On the flip side, since the mind had been freed from the limits of positivism and needed to rely on intutiion etc, the mind was "at lberty to speculate, to imagine, to cereate."

title: Crisis
text:
Notes 10/17/2011:

* The basic framework of the development of the concept of crisis laid out in the introduction is: The term begins among the Greeks for whom it functions in the "spheres of law, medicine, and theology" and for whom it "imposed choices between stark alternatives--right or wrong, salvation or damnation, life or death." (358)  The medical meaning is dominant until the early modern period, when in the 17th century the term is taken up into the new spheres of politics, economics, history, and psychology.  At the end of the 18th century, the theological meaning of the term comes to the fore, "but by its appplication to the events of the French and American revolutions, the apocalyptic vision of the last judgement now acquired a secular meaning." (358)  Through this application and the terms "metaphorical flexibility" it becomes a "central catchword (Schlagwort)" and in the 20th century "there is virtually no area of life that has nto been examined and interpreted through this concept with its inherent dmeand for decisions and choices." (358)

* Within the realm of history, Koselleck notes the term crisis since 1780 made possible a "new sesne of time whcih both indicated and intensified the end of an epoch." (358)  So he insists that "[p]erceptions of such epochal change can be measured by the increased usae of crisis." (358)

* He also makes a point at a couple of stages that there are emotions attached to the notion of crisis.  This is interesting vis-a-vis the historial study of emotions these days, although I don't think Koselleck is making much out of this.  (358)

 

The Greek Usage

* The Greek meaning: this is well laid out: In Greek it comes from a verb meaning to separate, choose, judge, decide.  Ie it had a juridical meaning. And in classical Greek the term was key to politics., where it meant in part to make a "decision" "in the sense of reaching a verdict or a judgement, what today is meant by criticism (Kritik)." (359) So he says that in classical Greek, crisis fused the concepts, since separated, of "subjective critique" and "objective crisis." (359)  This concept of crisis attained a "high constitutional status" in the "court" where "the individual citizen and the community were bound together." So crisis was a term that defined adn order the civic community as a legal title and legal code, and Aristotle frequently used the term in this way.  Out of this specifically legal meaning the term acquires political significance as it is "extended to eelectoral decision, government resolutions, decisions of war and peace, and, above all, to government decisisions as such." (359)  The notion of crisis becomes "necessary for the community, representing  what is at once just and salutary." (359)  So for the Greeks, they say, "'crisis' was a central concept by which justince and the political order (Herrschaftsordnung) could be harmonized through appropriate legal decisions." (359)

*  To the juridical meaning there is added a theological meaning in the Septuaginta (ancient Greek translation of the Old and New Testament.)  The idea here is that God is the Judge, a principle central to the Jewish tradition.  God's judgement thus contains the possibility of salvation, and in the notion of the Last Judgement, the notion of crisis gains meaning in relation to the end of the world at which point final judgement will finally reveal true justice. For Christians, who l,ived in antiicpation of the Last Juidgement, crisis was somehow present already in the moral conscience even though the crisis had not yet occurred.  "Even while crisis remains open as a cosmic event, it is already taking place within one's conscience." (360)

* There was also a medical meaning among the Greeks that originated in the Corpus Hippocraticum and that Galen "firmly entrenched for about fifteen hundred years." (360)  In th is realm, crisis refers both to the "observable condition" and to the judgement about whether the patient will live or die.  A distinction was made in this domain between the notion of a perfect and imperfect crisis--the latter leaving open the possiblity of a relapse of the condition.  (360)

* The term was then adopted into latin where it underwent a "metaphorical expansion into the domains of social and political language." (361)  Here, they say, it took on meaning as a "transitional or temporal concept (Verlaufsbegriff) ie indicating "that point in tmi in which a decision is due but has not yet been rendered." (361)

* They then assert somewhat mysteriously that "since then" the term has taken on a "double meaning." 1) Referring to the "objective condition" of crisis, the diagnosis of which is under debate and depends upo "the judgmeental critiera used to diagnose that condition." (361) 2) Its relationship to the concept of illness means that the term "presupposes a staet of health--however conceived--that is either to be restored again or which will, at a specified time, result in death." (361)

Note: I am thinking about the dominant influence of this medical meaning: yes it is fair to presuppose a state of "health", and also what about the way this leads to a tendency to conceive of society in terms of the organismic metaphor.  Ie crisis seems to lend itself to the functionalist conceptioin of society as organism, Durkheim et al.  Soemthign to keep in mind....

The Adoption Into National Languages

Skipping detailed notes here, but what they are doing is tracing the entrance of the concept into national languages in the 17th century.  The term, they assert, could only become influential and central after it "its tras is the Chrynsfer into national languages."  It appears first in French in the accusative "crisin".  It is applied to the "body politic" in England during the Civil War.  IE Ruydyerd uses in 1627: "This is the  Chrysis of Parliaments; we shall know by this if Parliaments life or die." (362) .  In France, Leibniz uses it to "diagnose the opporutnites and angers of the emerging Russian Empire and the Nordic War..." in which he saw ""a change of fundamental world-hsitorical significance comparable onlz to the formationof Charlemagne's empire." (363)  They trace the emergence of the term in lexica and dictionaries,noting that it enters latest into the German context, circa mid 19th century. Indeed, some Sonderweg thesis moments here perhaps? when they say that in Germany that "the term never crystallized intoa  concept sufficiently clear to be used as a basic concept in soical, economic, or political language--despite or perhaps because of--its manifold meanings." (367) But the point is that partly even in Germany the term had after the mid-18th century ceased to be lexically peripheral and "could indeed become an indicator of and contributor to a widesespread sense of radical change..." (367)

title: The Unspeakable: Discourse, Dialog, and Rhetoric in the Postmodern World
text: Saussure and Modernism Modernism, Saussure This antagonism between thinking and thought is also in Saussure. In his distinction between paradigmatic and syntagmatic coordinating signs (1966:123). Syntagmatic ordering is "linear sequence of signs wheere each sign acquires its value in opposition to preceding and following signs in discourse." (22) Paradigmatic "orderings are nonlinear and are formed outside of discourse. They are assocaited relations which are not present in the discourse itself. they are absent potentialities, mnemonic wholes in the inner storehouse of ideas that make up language. A word thus evokes everything associated with it; it is the center of a constellation of thoughts, the point of convergence or departure in a synchronous whole whose parts are indefinite and indeterminant." (22) That distinction in Saussure matches his between "static (synchrony) and evolutionary (diachrony)"...in which he divides language into axiis of simulatenous = paradigmatic and succesive = syntagmatic. (22) Synchrony and diachrony are, Tyler says, Saussure's equivalents to the quandry of quantum mechanics that "linguistics cannot at the same time describe both position and movement (structure and change) and speakers cannot at once attend equally to the sequence of ideas and their synchrony." (22) Ultimately, Tyler says, Saussure supresses one of these. The logic of associating the scholastics calleed the "logic of Lucifer" and it is just this that Saussure thinks will be linguistics key to becoming a science. "For Saussure, the synchronic perspective is the only proper one. Diachronic study yields a mass of unrelated singularities, it does not yield a system. Diachrony is merely a record of the accidental effects of speech on language, of changes in the synchronic structure produced by all the forces of social life." (23) Tyler says that Saussure's endorsement of the synchronic/paradigmatic, of langue, was an attempt to free the paradigmatic from sequentiality. Moreover it is linked to modernism he says: "It is partof the modernist program for undermining the individual, the self-mastered self, taking away its conscious control over language it speaks much as Freud took away its conscious control over the thoughts it thinks." (23)

title: The plain and noble garb of truth: nationalism & impartiality in American historical writing, 1784-1860
text:
General Notes

 

# Eileen Ka-May Cheng, *The Plain and Noble Garb of Truth: Nationalism and Impartiality in American Historical Writing, 1784-1860* (Atlanta: The University of Georgia Press, 2008)

Quick Summary:
        Cheng is in this book arguing that the historical consciousness of early ninteenth century historians was not as intellectually shallow and narrowly driven by American exceptionalism as has been commonly assumed, even she thinks by Dorothy Ross. She wants to argue that even antebellum historians were operating with a surprising complex set of theoretical and methodological principles that included conceptions of objectivity or impartiality, of history as a sort of art involving emotional sympathy with historical actors, and as a kind of moral philosophy that taught through specific examples and that put the historian in the role of the judge. She seeks to present this account in a non-teleological manner (ie she is distancing herself from the grand narratives of modernity that objective historians worked out). She achieves this in part by organizing her book thematically, rather than linearly. DR has an excellent review of this book along with one by Parker....

Critical Note:
        Some things that come to mind here: why is she not actually going through the specific claims that these historians make. It is interesting to know there approach to the concept of history, but how does this modify their take on the big questions. If, as in ch.2, history as a moral teacher is key, what sort  of moral lessons does history teach? How do the different appraoches to historical practice that these historians pursue interact with the claims that they make.

## Introduction

* There is a view of early American historians-- that they were shallow, that they glorified the revolutionaries, and that they were thoroughly impartial, and unconcerned with impartiality. Cheng thinks that's a myth. She believes that American historiography in the early nineteenth century was complex and sophisticated, and that by the 1820s in fact Amercian historians had begun to develop some of the concepts that would characterize modern historiography. Here she departs from historians like Thomas Haskell that identify the emergence of these ideas---about objectivity e.g. -- in the late nineteenth century. (2, 5)

* She is working against a kind of "Whiggish" narratives -- she cites Novick on this (4) -- among historians that has lead them to ignore historiography, and ninteenth century historioggraphy in aprticular, becuase they un self-consciously identify with the Rankean ideal that history is just an objective engagement with sources. So they ignore historiography and imagine themselves only to be doing purely objective history.

* She thinks that attention to historiography allows her to look at the notion of impartiality historically and thus to show that in fact that throughout its history the "ideal of objectivity was a powerful and malleable doctrine that could be adapted to many different social contexts and functions, which suggests that historians will find ways of adapting the ideal yet again to the challenges that confront it today." (6) So whereas Novick in his account of the threats to objectivity seemed to think that revealing the problems that historians confronted in the ideal would also show that the ideal was weak and perhaps dead, she wants to say that is not the case!  (see this argument vv Nnovick, bottom p.5).  So she says "recognizing the social and political function of impartiality does not necessarily endanger a belief in truth or the integrity of the discipline." (6)

* She also wants to demonstrate that the idea that American historians were impartial because they followed nationalist accounts of American exceptionlism, she wants to show that to the contrary "rather than obstructing the development of this ideal, nationalist imperatives paradoxcially contributed to their desire for impartial truth." (6) So she is drawing on, but also contending against Dorothy Ross's account of American exceptionalism. And she takes DR's stance to by typical of "modern" American historians. She thinks this stance is ironically exceptionlist in that it reveals exceptionalist attitudes that assume the intellectul shallowness of American intellectual history. (NOte, I don't think this is a very good critique of DR's work, for I think she pretyy much avoids that. What she is interested in showing is how complex and rigorous was the attempt to sustain an exceptionalist account of American history... ) )6-7.

* She describes the antebellum historains's notion of history on 8-11. She summarizes their notion of impartiality, which has them acknowledging that there are multiple sides to a story and then acting as a judge in saying which one is better, but often for moral reasons, because they saw history as a kind of actulization of moral philosphy. And they joined their notions of impartiality to a Rommantic conception of historical writing as a kind of artistiic endeavour that required historians to develop emotional sympathy with their historical actors, since they understood taht to be necessary to getting into the lives of those people and representing their eventy impartially.

* She describes her effot to avoid a teleologicl account of history by using a thematic organization in her book on p. 11.

## 1. "To Become a Historian": A Discipline and a Society in Transition

> Not taking extensive notes here. This chapter traces the rise of a group of historians who are functioning something like a profession, but in a less formal/ institutional / bureacuratic manner.

## 2. "Histories in Novels," "Novels in Histories": Imagination, Fact, and the Moral Truths of History

> This chapter traces the way in which these historians defined historical truth in realtion to the three most central parts of their practice: questions of fact, imagination, and moral lessons. The idea of the chapter is  basically that while many of the historians defined history in a RAnkean way as defined by the need to represent history actually as it was and to avoid the intrusion of imagination, which was for them a distoring factor that they associated with novels-- a feminine form. But there were other historians--namely Jared Sparks, and especially William Simms, who saw imagination as central to the illumination of history. Here the key was the moral concept of history. For Simms, imagination aided the historian in the task of illuminating the past in a way that allows history to teach moral lessons.

title: When Sex Became Gender
text:
Quick Note

This book looks at feminist thought from interdisciplinary sources in the 40s and 50s.  She's arguing that this thought had a kind of power indepdnetly of the feminist movement that sprang up in the 60s and 70s from which certain lessons can be learned.  The book came to my attentino because she pciks up in one chapter the fac tthat Mead had begun to work out a gender concept.

It occured to me that this book might be useful in loking more closely at the tension between Mead's thought (and a broader set of feminist thinkers) and the structural functionalism of this period.  The author brings this up in the the intro on p.7.

title: On Creating a Usable Culture: Margaret Mead and the Emergence of American Cosmopolitanism
text:
1. Introduction

* She's concerned with the self.  Right off the bat, in the first paragraph, she say "Running through Mead's work is a sustained commentary on the self and its relation to the larger society.  It is one of the arguments of this study that the self as represented is not just any individual but is in some sense both an American self and the self of America."  (1)For her there is a link between the attempt to define the self and to define the nation.  E.e. she says in the next sentence "What the nation/self might be or what it might become was the subject of much debate [in the 1920s.]" (1)

* Molloy brings up modernism and the works of Hegeman and Manganaro on p.3, but it's unclear how she conceives of modernism here.  Perhaps she defines it later.  She almost seems to confuse it with "American modernity."  She pick sup on Manganaro's differenct readings of what was modernist about culture: for Manganaro the idea of a complex whole readable synchronistically like the professional literatures and moes of reading; for HEgeman the sense of self-conscious estranement. (3-4)

* She gets into how she's thinking about the self via Charles Taylor on p.7.  She quotes a description by Taylor of a "modern self": "...a 'disengaged, particular self, whose identity is constituted in memory.'' (7)  Then she traces two themes in discussion of the modern self: "On theme, which I have called eventuation, sees 'the shape of alife simply the result of...happenings as they accumulate.'  The second, which I call actualization, sees 'this shape as something already latent, which emerges through what comes to pass.'" (7)  She sees these two themes "ramifying" through "many of the discursive forms of modernity, underpinning the emergence of both the novel and the autobiography" as weell as the social sciences and the nature-nurture debates in particular. (7-8)  Eslewhere she describes this as a tension between seeing the self as constitued by "event" or "esence" (8).

* The tension between seeing the self as constiitued either by event or essence has its paralllel she thinks in discussion  fthe nation., i.e. concerns with "origins, with unity, and the repressions of difference, with boudnaries and interiority." (8)  She notes the scholarly concern with the way the nation is narrated i nstories, hsitory books, stories, etc... (10) She esees these tension as caolescin in the race/culture debate in the 1920s.  She draws on the work of some guy named Robert Young and then Walter Benn Micahels to argue that race and culture were both essential parts of the modern discourse...i.e. they were part of the same tension between event and essence in understanding the origin/unity of the nation/self. (9-10)

* On 11, she gets out another focus of her work: "how the modernist ideas about culture were transformed into vernacular understandings of culture through the vehicle of Mead's work." (11)  She sets this focus agains that of Manganaro and HEgeman who she sees as focusing on the concept of culture and the "texts that ciruclted within rareified or professional fields..."  IN this respect, she sees her book as more closely linked to Micahaels "in its emphasis on something less well defined than a concept..." (11)

* She will deal with MEad's major ethnographies and she will trace a growin "disillusionment with 'culture'".  (13)  In Coming of Age, she argues, culture "significes the possibilities for change or for more-fulfilling ways of life." (13), but by the time she  writes Sex and Temperament "culture is fullya rticulated as that which creates deviance by not allowing individual, innate temperament to develop accoridng to its natural predilections and potentialities." (13)  [NOTE: My interpretation differs sharply here.  I see culture as already limiting in Coming of Age, but in a way that is so powerful that it limits the selves of Samoa so that they actually think that they are free and possess a molding power...that is it determines even how they understand their own actions in a way that is distorted.  Then, overall, my argument is different because I see MEad and Benedict as locating individuality in deviance...this is the sign that there is some individaulity left!]

 

* If Taylor defines the modern self as one constitued in a "story," Med's story in her ethnographies "was the most compelling of all-the self's transition from childhood to adulthood, and the struggles that shape that transition." (14)  RE CArolyn STeedman's notion of "personification" and the "figure of a child" as a focus that has to do with self-formation this is a powerful argument.  So Molloy sees Mead as tracing in her work a "personficiation of the self's journey from childhood to adulthood." (15)  So she sees Mead's interest in the Manus boy or the Samoan girl or the deviant as a way of studhing the "problem of 'coming into being' not only in their own culture but more importantly in America." (15)

* In addtion she says "sex is the ynchpinin each of these narratives..."  (15)  But it is not clearl what she means by sex...sexuality?  or sex identity?  Also, are the ethnographies really "narratives".  When I read them, they did not seem to be so...although she does tell the stories of different individuals...

title: A Franz Boas Reader: The Shaping of American Anthropology, 1883-1911
text:
p. 284 Culture already "manifest" in Boas' thought 1905?

Frank Speck letter that Stocking has included he thinks shows

title: The Naturalized Female Intellect
text:
p.210 She will explore concepts of nature through ideas on female intellect

Soimplified understanding of "Nature" in Science Studies. Daston asays that the "context-dominated science studies of th elats decade" used naturalization very heavily as a way to explain connection between science and social context: "Galileo, for example, 'naturalizes' the shaky political legitimacy of the Medicis by christening th newly discovered moons of Jupiter in their honor..." (210).

She thinks that this use of naturalization projects a "recent conception of nature" that based on a strong boundary between nature and culture, back onto the past.In the early-modern period, she says, the conception of naturte was changing from "essences to matter, from what is desirable to what is inevitable, from the sovereignty of reason to that of physical necessity."  (210)

She will reinterpret it through looking at "early modern conceptions of the female intellect..." (210)  This is a good way to look at the shfiting conception of nature she says because women's way of thinking was attributed to gender (as is the case withi gender); because the "political and social implications" of women's intellect were heavily debated; and because throughout this period the basic "content of beliefs" about female intellect remained the same: "It is thus possible to isolate and track these naturalist expalnations as a pure exercise in changing forms and standards of explanation per se, without addressing the conflating issue as to how new explananda might have influenced the course of these changes." (210)

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text:
p. 131-132 bBenedict's Influences

Apparently Stocking says in his "Ideas and Institutions" essay that Benedict was influenced by Jung and by Gestalt Psychologies, as well as by reading of Spengler and Dilthey.  Hanlder cites Stocking's essay, p.16).

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text: p.042-43  G. Stnley hall and Edward Clarke opposed female education.

title: The Naturalized Female Intellect
text:
p.213-214 Early Modern theories of mind not concerned with variation

Early modern theoiesof mind were not concerned with individual variation along the multiple specific categories upon which they discussed intelligence (see top of p.213, before section).  They wer emore interested in uniformities and "shared mechanisms." (213)  This was partly rooted in Christian theology which indciated that "[s]ouls, and therefore minds, come only in one kind..." This was a belief that had been held since Augustine and which was reinforced by Aquinas. (214)  These men did not think much of female intellect but insisted that "rational minds have no sex..." (214)

title: The Culture of Time and Space, 1880-1918
History: Professional Scholarship in America
text:
p.011 - 14  Herbert Baxter Adams  & Henry Adams

Herbert: 
architecht of AHA.  He "fostered the union of professors and patricians" Higham says.  (Is this true?  I thought he rejects their bid for alliance, did Haskell say this?) (11)  He was a New Englander, puritian stock, but not related to the elite Adamses.  His public service "epxressed itself through his connection with the U.S. Bureau of Education, for which he wrote and edited a long series of pamphlets on the histroy and current state of American education." (12) He schemed to start an academy in Washington to train "professional civil servants much as West Point and Annapolis trianed officers." (12) Adams enjoyed the elitism of Eastern society.  (12) Under his auspices the AHA (run by professionals) regualrly selected patrician scholars or other distinguished people as president (13) He also attempted to attach the AHA to the government, seeking in 1889 to gain a federal charter for the AHA. On this:

"This unusual act of incorporation fixed the principal office of the Associaiton permanently in Washington, and authorized it to report annually to the Smithsoanian Institution.  the latter was directed to transmit to Congress the AHA's proceedings and its reportsonthe condition of historical study in America.  Adams thereby secured at goverment expense both office space and the printing of his annual reports.  More important, he opened a channel through which the aristocracy of culture might, in historical matters, exert a vigorous, uplifting ifluence on national policies." (14) 

But this failed Higham says: "In America, unlike Adams' beloved Germany, professors and other guardians of culture did not succeed in establishing a sold parternship with the state.  During the Jacksonian period the intellectual class in American hda lost its political eminence, and all efforts to recover that eminence in the late nineteenth-century were unavailing.  In the early 1890's commitees of the American Historical Association began memorializing Congress to take heed of the nation's scattered and neglected historical records.  The scholars wanted a unified management of the national archives; they also pleaded for a Historical Manuscripts Commission tha towuld-- like the British agency of that name -- inventory important papers in private hands.  Congress did nothing.  Any prospect that it would seriously notice the annual reports it still receives fromthe Association soon vanished.  The arrangement continues today as a useful economy in scholarly printing expenses and as a memorial of the forgotten hopes of Herbert Baxter Adams." (14) 

Henry:
Henry Adams also tried to start a link between government and patrician intellectuals in 1880s by establishing a asalon in Lafayette Squarein 1877.  But the captial did not become "a genuine capital in the sense in which almost every European country had a national center of wealth, knowledge, intellect, fashion, and political power." (15)  Henry's salon circle thus contracted ...

title: Alexander Goldenweiser's Politics
text:
Quick Summary 7/9/10:

Kan's article has a lot of good info on the political attitudes toward communism and the Soviet Union of Goldenweiser, Boas, and Leslie White.  It's useful in this way.  He shows that Boas had a hard time criticizing the Soviet Union durin ghte 1930s, at the same time as he was open in his opposition to the Nazis.  Goldenweiser was more critical of the SU.  This article has a lot of info that could be mined for my work later on, esp. if I try to do more on Goldenweiser later.

Professionalization re Abbott and Parsons

 Abbott cites this guy.  see p. 86-87 of System of Professions.  Larson he note emphasized "professional pwer in exculsive terms, as power at other's expense." (87). title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text: p.084 CHAPTER 4: TOWARDS A SEXLESS INTELLIGENCE

title: The Naturalized Female Intellect
text:
p.217-220 Causes of Female Intellect

Both 17th and 18th century explanations were tied to differences in bodies, but the expalanations changed in this period.  In the late 17th centjury, explanations by "complexion" were still common, but they were "gradually supersided in discussion of gender differences by appeals to the relative 'delicacy' of female organs." (217)

"Thus the Sieur de Saint-Gabriel called on the authority of 'the Philosohers and the Doctors' to supprt his claim that because of the 'tenuousness of their skin and the delicacy of their flesh' wome had 'more vivactiy of understanding, having a more subtle imaginations.'" (217)

This was a "bizarre twist" of the Aristotle's linking of masculine form over feminine matter to elevate form over matter and to associate the former with men and the latter with women in his De generatione animalium.  But in the late seventeenth century version of this the female was opposed to "gross matter."  (217)  Thus here ther ewas a kind of defense of women based on their delicacy and their openness to the "impressions of science":

"As for delicacy, apparently those who make this a subject of accusation to them [women] have nto followed Aristotle's opinion: they would then have kjnown that the most delicate temp[erament is the least charged with matter; the most pure and best suited to be penetrated by the lights of the mind; the best preapred for the beautiful images and the impressions of science." (217)

Complimenting female delicacy was male "strength, both of body and of mind." (217)  And in the 18th century, writers who DAston said hoped to restrict the "influence and educational opportunities of women converted 'delicacy' into 'weakness' and made it the key to the feminine character, intellect, and social situation." (218)    "Thus jurists pronounced men 'by the prerogative of their sex and by the force of their tempearment' to be 'naturally capapble of all kinds of employment and engagements,' while simultaneously excluding women, 'due to the fraigilty of their sex and their natural delicacy.'" Here she is quoting d'Alembert an Diderot.  (218) BAsed on the idea that they were weak, authors now argued that housework and child care was the necessary role of women.  See p.218 for examples.  She cites Pierre Roussel as the most extereme.  Roussel she says "litearly bodied out Rousseau's claim that 'the male isonly a male now and again, the fameale is alaways a female or at least all her youth; eeryting reminder her of her sex; the performance of her functions required a special constitution.  According to Roussel, not only the reproductive organs, but also the skeleton, ligaments, tissues, nerves, and vessels are 'marked by the differences that display the functions to which woman is called, and the passive state to which nature destines her.'  Female orans are, Roussel claimed, soft, delicate, small, and elastic in comparison to those of male, and from this fundamental distinction he read off all the cliches of feminine intellect and cahracter.  The mobitliy and sensitivity of her tender organs endwo woman with the ability to seize at a glance 'an infinity of nuances, of items of detail, and relkationships that escape the most enlightened man"; her morlaity is dictated by sentiment and compassion; her good memory, mental agility, and animated conversation repair th eomissions of the long studies her fragile frame cannot support without draining her 'vital forces'" (218)

The link between the traits Roussel desscribed and female anatomy were not new.  Waht was new here was the "doctrine of the physical weakness, in conjunction with the ever more insistent emphasis on women's confinement to the home and hearth because of that weakness..." (219)

This shift put the copmplemenatrity between male and female  on a "new axis, that of the abstract versus the concerete." (219)

The limited sphere of the home "implied limited experience and limited activity, and experience and activity came to be seen as increasingly important to intellectual develkopment i the last quater of the eighteenth century."  So this meant that "the old female bastion of memory and imagination could nto withstand the call to braoad experience and vigorous activity: the 'sedentary and soft life' of women could at best foster an imagination of pretty scenes and tender emotions,b ut this paled beside the imagination of the 'always active man...nourish on moutnain peaks, at the edge of volcanoes, at sea, in battlefields, or in the midst of ruins.'" (219)  This emphais was increased by the aesthetic of sublime.

Even Wollstonecraft supported these assumptions.  She had rejected Rousseau's "double standard of virtue for the two sexes" but she accepted that men were stronger and linked bodily to meantal vigor...she admitted all this but then exhorted women not to exacerbate the situation by inactivity and by allowing themselves to be "deluded by the conveitonal opinion that delicacy added to their charms." (219) Daston argues that Wolstonecraft "in her descripton of these infirmities and her assocaition of them with physical weakness and hte narrow exepreince apparently dicated by that weaknes...closely resembled those of such writers as Roussel and BAbanis, for whom sexual cahracter admitted only of slight modification..." (220) And she also agreed taht women's weakenss => limited sphers =>  made their field of experiences only "social relations" that taught "effects and modifications" but not "simple principles" and that this utlimately "barred them from the abstract, general principels necessary for sicence and for justice." (220)

Now the abstract v. concrete dynamic emerges and it was in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries made clear:

"In the late eitghteenth and early nineteenth centuries the age-old oppositions between female memory and imagination versus male discursive and speculative reason were reformulated and condensed into an oppostion between the female grasp of concrete details and the male mastery of abstract principles.  Kant for example firmly discouraged women from deep study in metaphysics and mathematics on the grounds that their 'beautiful understanding [schoner Verstand]' was incompatible with 'abstract speculations or knowledge, which are useful but dry.'  Rousseau's formulation was characteristically preemptory: 'The search for abstract and speculative truths, for principles and axioms in science, for allt hat tends to wide generalisation, is beyond a woman's grasp; ...works of genius are beyond her reach, and hse has neither the accuracy nor the attention for success in the exact sciences; as for the physical sciences, to decide the relations between living createres and the laws of nature is the task of that sex which is more active and enterprising, which sees more thing, that sex which is possessed of greater strength and is more acccustomed to the exercise of that strength.'  (220)

title: Politics and the Sciences of Culture in Germany, 1840-1920
text:
Woodruff Smith, Politics and Sciences of Culture in Germany, 1840-1920.

 

Notes 5/2013:

> Some Comments: A key problem with this book is simply its lack of quotations. He never lets the actual authors speak. It is all his own summaries. This highlights a deeper functionalist approach to ideas that is often accurate, but severely lacking in that it never gets at the deeper motivations of these people. There are just ideological "patterns" responding in that functionalist manner that one would expect. On another level a core argument here is that the form of cultural science set up by Waitz, Virchow and Bastian in Berlin in the 1870s and 1880s was "neoliberal", but he barely defines this idea. Perhaps he was writing before the term really took off in contemporary discourse. What he seems to mean is simply the attempt to reground the liberal conception of the "abstract self" on more scientific and accurate ground. That  might have been neo, but it's now what we mean by neoliberalism today. And he never carefully defines his usage so as to avoid confusion.

## Introduction

* Author wants to use an approach to ideas inspired by Kuhn. (6)

* Playing on a Kuhnian idea the author wants to construct his study with
an awareness of certain underlying "structures" of ideas. (7-8)

* What is the neoliberal part here? This seems unusual... 11

## Ch. 1 " The Liberal Theoretical pattern in Nineteenth-Cencuty German Social Science

* After 1815 conservative resurgence, what had survived if liberalism was a kind of moderate liberalism typified by profs Welcker and Rotteck. Their moderate liberalism rested on a certain approach to reform that Smith says we today would call modernization. (15)

*  The modernization need emerged interaction to a recognition that the reforms instituted by the French need to remain in place and be administered and that Europe was moving in the direction indicated by
Britain... Experts were needed to manage this transformation. Authorities thus tolerated liberal profs. Since they seemed to be the ones with knowledge of how to manage the necessary changes. (16)

* Their stance was basically nonrevolutionary, emphasizing free speech, education of governments and public opinion and the need for informed
consensus. (16)

* Good summary here of their basic social vision and its underlying assumptions, which Existed until 1848 sS says. S also says that before that a "paradigmatic pattern of substantial power and attractiveness" had developed alongside the basic liberal ideology. (18)

* Now it gets good. S says that what made liberals think they possessed a common ideology were a common set of  "assumptions, concepts and
inferences...about the appropriateness of the language they all spoke." (19) They used this "language" to give events and ideas meaning. It was also this set of assumptions that came to  characterize German social science. Liberals wre ware of these sets of ideas. (19)

* This is important too. Liberals in Germany were peculiar in their tendency to emphasize the need to pay attention to historical hermeneutics. But they tended not to develop the more radical historicism gestured at by W. Humboldt. (20)

* Smith says in determining the outlook of these liberals he will put philosophy in the background, noting that very often it is the influence of philosophy that is highlighted and not unjustly in every case. But he wants to focus on political ideology. [Of course, I would say that there is no exclusivity between the philosophical and the
political ideological. (21)

* He thinks the layer of assumptions isthe most important part, and he refers to "formal ideas", vocabulary, metaphors, imagery. (21)

*  The Staatslexicon Liberals, ie not Humboldt, employed heavily abstract model of the self., modeled on an implicitly male rationality.  (23) this idea however raised problems: how could the idea that humans were "rational machines" be useful? It seemed to require ways of distinguishing between rational and no rational behavior. Could or should individual differences be taken into account. (23) social science emerged partly as a way to answer such questions without loosing site of the rational self as ideal. (23) Various solutions: 1) establish some underlying psychic capacities, ie experimental psych. (23), 2) social statistics, ie common observable phenomenon.

* The study of culture Smith says "came to engulf" the study of education. And he says was a "corrective to the model of the abstract
individual. " (25)

* The culture concept Smithbexlains emerged out of the thought of Herder and Montesquieu. It was a reaction to the question of how to explain the diversity in the world given Europeans sense that human universals in ideal education and behavior existed. Herder helped with this emphasizing the special character of individual people's or nations. Volksgeist was the word he used, and also Kultur. But he also Smith wants to say erected his ideas in a liberal frame, ie he did not challenge the idea of an abstract rational individual. Ie people may be educated differently, and so they may seem different but they are under neath fundamentally rational cognitive beings. (26) herder's though led on many directions, in part to conservatives and also to W.
Humboldts hermeneutics. But smith thinks the culture idea primarily emerged in a liberal context. (27) (25-27)

* Here Smith goes through some stage theories of historical development that were important to liberals in Germany. (31-32)

## Ch.2 The Crisis of Liberalism and the Emergence of Cultural Science, 1848-1862

* Smith argues in this chapter that the 1848-1849 political revolution changed the nature of liberal social science, bring the notion of cultural science to the fore. (35)

* 1848 highlighted the lack of consensus among liberals, such that they could no longer assume that consensus emerged from the abstract individuals rationality. (37)

* There elm of nationalism also reared its head. It was no longer easy to imagine the cultural foundations of nationalism, and for German
liberals influenced by Herder this was important. (38)

* Riehl, a moderate liberal who reacted conservatively to the revolution of 1848, turned to certain study of culture, and in doing son rejected the idea of the abstract individual. He focused instead on cultures and how they determined the individual. (43) Riehl did not however treat national cultures as uniform, but he saw them as layers on top of other regional and local formations. The classes or Stände also had their own cultures. (43)

*  Within this rather complex picture Riehl developed a theory of stability and change having to do with the interaction between these various cultural levels. (44) it was his desire to act as a scientist and to develop a nomothetic model of equilibrium that Smith thinks continues to link Roehl to the liberal line despite his conservative turn.

* Waits reaction to the 1848 revolution was also to move toward culture. But he did not reject the individual as the focus. He had had a psychological focus already which treated the individual as the
necessary locus of research, but he also thought that education was important as a mechanism through which people acquired ideas. In response to 1848, he became interested in the question of why people rejected liberalism, and the answer he gave was that the educational psychological ideas used in education were flawed. Here he took up a kind of neo Kantian line, mixing materialist with more transcendental approaches. He followed Herbart in downplaying the distinction between the material and the ideal. There were he thought certain basic capacities such as reason , judgement, moral sense and so on, and which also mixed with characteristics like feeling, that determined self interest, and finally these basic capacities were organized by concepts, meaning in this case "a constantly evolving array of mental phenomena that arose from interaction among the various elements of the individual's mind and between the mind and the external world."  (48)

* Here Waitz pushed back against he idea of the individual acknowledging that the ideas that'd opts have, the concepts, are very often not "theirs". This was still not a rejection of the idea. But it was to say that one could not consider the idea of individual motivation without considering the cultural level. (49)

* The problem was however to try to separate or distinguish the cultural  from the natural/universal. Waitz disagreed with Herbart for example in thinking that it was sufficient to do individual studies to determine the difference. One had to do empirical ethnological work to see how universal certain capacities, characteristics and concepts in
fact are. (49)

## Ch. 3 "The Contexts of Cultural Science"

* Key point here for the point I want to make about The context of Boas thought. This thing I picked up from Kuno Fischer's text, this idea of the knowledge of the globe, and its expansion, somehow marking the expansion of a new form of theoretical and even moral knowledge. Here Smith touches on this by talking about the contribution that Alexander Humboldt made to the a kind of psrigmatic understanding of geography,Los importance. Smith describes the idea being that geography would be the "matrix" into which other sciences would fit,
that would make a recognition of interconnections possible, and that
would... (58)

* Then comes Ritter who turns this "paradigm" into a "Kuhnian 'normal' science," by attempting to lay down a more systematic framework for accomplishing what Humboldt had desired. He called this a "comparative anatomy" of the Earth's surface.

*  The fragmentation of philosophy as a profession was seen as negative because it threatened  the of humanist Bildung that had come to be almost universally important in Germany. (72)

* This is seemingly relevant to the shifts in Bildung that Mosse claims, ie that the meaning of Bildung shifted at the end of the nineteenth century so that its humanist claims began to seem empty. It's standard more the style of certain elites than anything else...and in this context there was also a turn toward a kind of romantic feeling. (73)

* Here Smith lays out a career pattern for people interested in the cultural sciences that totally fits Boas. A peripatetic period after the dissertation, the need to work in One of the centers of such study. Ie Berlin or Leipzig. A difficulty finding jobs or the need to lecture for free. The desire to make a name for oneself either by challenging established scholars and making unorthodox challenges, or by taking exotic trips. (74-75)

## Ch. 4 The Crisis of Liberalism and the Emergence of Cultural Sceince, 1862-1885


* Darwinism had great appeal to liberals in the 1860s and 1870s. It promised to overcome tensions  between moderate and radical forms of liberalism by describing change and reform in terms of equilibrium. Ernst Haecker and F Ratzel were in
particular supporters of Darwinian theory. Nastiam and Virchow resisted it. (91-92)

* Not a word about Jews here!?

* Sounds similar to Boas' study on the plasticity pf frm. (97)

* Smith sees in Ratzel and Virchow how a specific anti modernist critique that he differed from that of say Nietzsche. He doesn't lay it out here, but points in a footnote to ch. 7. He says what made this
critique unique was that it was based on the notion of culture. (98)

## Ch.5 Berlin Ethnology as Neoliberal Cultural Science


* Virchow and Bastian opposed Germany's expansionary colonial program of the  1880s. But they were willing also to coordinate with colonial
authorities to acquire data. (104)

* The two also created a network of younger scholars, Privatdozenten, that were focused in Berlin. They included Franz Boas, Felix Von
Luschan, and Karl Von den Steinen. (104)

*  The methodological vision of this new professional setting did not include the necessity of field work. The academics were simply the master theorizers of a vast number of amateur collectors... (104)

* What Smith is describing as the neoliberal pattern of cultural science developed in Berlin by Bastian and Virchow was defined by a certain take on the key themes dominating the general liberal pattern he describes, ie the abstract individual, the idea or aim of a nomothetic science, and the ideas of equilibrium in social change. (106)

* Very good point here. That there was a risk in trying to define the individual as Bastian hoped to by defining through the Naturvollker a 
basic set of psychological traits present in all humans. The risk was that what was good about the abstract individual --namely, its easy correspondence to liberal political theory -- would be lost with what might appear to be a rather "disembodied collection of psychological
traits. " (107)

* One solution was to link such traits to national cultures, but this was unacceptable to the neoliberal anthropologists of Berlin. Smith guesses this solution would have cut too strongly against the liberal pattern of thought. So instead he says they tended to focus on the "relationships among what was universal in the composition of the
individual, what was learned by the individual from his or her culture, and what was unique to a person." That added up to a strong emphasis on comparative ethnology. (107)

* Bastians theory of diffusion provided a way to reconcile the multitude of forms with the abstract principle of the individual. (107)

* Very weird claim here, that "neoliberal anthropology in Germany displayed many similarities to evolutionism in Britain..." Smith does
not seem to have defined neoliberalism here, nor do his actors, who he never quotes, use the word. So what exactly does he mean by neoliberal. It seem like an anachronism. (110)

* He admits having trouble defing what this Berlin neoliberal liberalism was, and in the end just says it was an attitude that meant that one needed an ethnology to ground some notion of the individual, and that further there was a confidence that what would result could be squared with the individual's physical qualities and tha be made the subject
of a kind of science that could predict. (110)

* Here talking about the heirs of this neoliberal school, S notes a lack of talent among people like Luschan, and overall a lack of appeal of
their work. So there was no powerful intellect to counter the assault that came next. (112)

* The assault came from Graebner and Ackermann in 1904 when they laid out a new diffusionism view that was explicitly positioned against what Smith calls the neoliberal school. (112-3)

* Smith sees Boas as the main exponent of the neoliberal school in the 20th century, besides Diedrich Westermann and Richard Thirnwäld. But
Boas also cannot simply be sen in this light as he was in Berlin for a short time and in addition to his concerns about antiemetism had no reason to think that Bastian saw him as a promising scholar. (113)

* Smith insists that despite the differences Boas thought retained the mark of the neoliberal school. Smith describes him as a liberal whose liberalism was strengthened by his move o the U S. but more compelling is that smith notes his "emphasis on accurate data collection, on resisting the temptation to theorize too early, and on understanding the psychology of the individual as the chief aim of cultural science" as reflections of the "theoretical pattern " in which  he was trained. In his emphasis on fieldwork and on relativity, though, Smith thinks
Voas went far beyond his teachers. (114)

## Ch. 6 Voelkerpscyhologie

* Voelkerpsychologie started in the 1850s as a "response within the framework of the liberal theoretical pattern to the crisis of liberalism and of social science." (115) In the 1860s it was closely connected to what Smith calls neoliberal anthropology. (115)

* Waitz was a key node of this science. He was motivated by an interest in combining pscyhology "with its traditional focus on the individual and its characteristic method of reasoning from the pscyhologists' introspection" with comparative ethnology. (116)

* Waitz however died too early to contribute much to Voelkerpscyholgie. Smith says Bastian is a key exponent also. Bastian had travelled widely and thus come into contact with many many different peoples aroudn the world. He was a liberal Smith says -- or rather a "neoliberal" whatever that means for Smit -- in that he wanted to use his work to support the traditional liberal theroetical pattern that empahsized the individual, and nomothetic science. His research was built around the goal of discovering fundamental laws, but doing so after "the direct observation and comparative analysis of a wroldwide sample of human phenomena." (117) He rejected the Montesquiueian or Herdeerian pattern of linking certain patterns of thought and behavior to physical enviornement. Bastian Smith says believed that a great many infleunces fed into the human mind producing different forms of conscisouness. His resarch frame focused on the individual as was typical of the librerals. He traeted the idea of the abstract individual, however, as a hypothesis of a "pscyhic unity of mankind" -- a kind of "pscyhological foundation that was the same in everyone", as Smith puts it. But to establish this unity was not easy, and ultimately Bastioan's appraoch was to attempt to demosntrate the existence of certain "elementary ideas", that is a uniform structure of ideas (resting on this pscyhic unity of mankind) (118). Interestinglyh, also Bastian thought that these elementary ideas were unconscious. (119) Bastian was also not an evolutionist, but he retained the distinction beteween Kulturvoelker and Naturvoelker. But ultimately Bastian, Smith thinks, did not convincingly establish the existnce of the elementary ideas, in part because he had a poor system for cross-cultural comparison, since he regarded all cultural systems a morally equivalent. (119-120)

> Smith has a noite here on how fucntionalism was more effective in setting up such comparison. (120). Smith himself seems functionalist.

* Smith likes Wundt's attempt at Voelkerpscyhologie much better. I think becaues it appears to him more functionalist. Wundt had two levels of mental phenomena:

    1) "such elements as relationship between sensations (forms of energy arising from contact between the nervous system and the external world) and feelings, which were seated in the mind itself. These relationship were grounded in physiology." (124) These were the most basic pscyhological characteristics of indvidiuals, and what is interesting is that Wundt famously created a method of 'introspection' through whcih he though people might give information about such basic elements by being trained in observing their own mental experiences. (124) The point of establishhing these basic patterns of relationships among sesnations, feelings and other more complex forms of pscyhic energy was to estaliblish their uniformity in all people thus refinforcing the "neolliberal" desire to "repalce the inadequate model fo the rational individual at the center of the liberal theoretical pattern with a more sophisticated, accurate, and useful picture of the individual mind derived from empirical research... " (124)

    2) Yet Wundt also thought that there were other phenomena not definable iwthin the lab or through introspection. These were higher metnal processes that involved language and which allowed people to function in groups. Wundt did not think, though, that one could apply empirical science ot thiese forms. You neeeded Volkerspcyhologie. You had to understand their genesis and development from more basic and unviersal psychic phenomena. He looked to cultural study -- focusing on law in particular -0- worldwide that migh tunover the way in which cultures develop and how differences between them begin to appear.

* Wundt's ideas did not however remain the same. At first saw culture in what Smith describes as the "standard neoliberal way, as a concept that could be used to explain variations in human behavior, resistance to progress, and so forth." (125) But then at some point Wundt -- who like Bastian was not interested in the processes of socialization and education that might make culture fungible andx who focused instead on the "mental patterns themselves (125) -- turned to a viewpoint that treated the "mental structures of individuals [as]...literally part of the larger culture." (125) That is, he conceived of culture as itself an "active psychic force that had coherence in itself and that to a large extent defined the very individiuals who participated in it." (125) That is, Wundt was doign something similar to what Benedict and Mead did too eventually... 

## Ch. 7 Bauer, Volk and Kultur: The Paesant as the Foundation of Culture

* This chapter looks at an alternative take on culture to the one that the "neoliberal" anthropologists developed, namely that of the more conservative cultural thinkers like Riehl and Ratzel for whom the paesent and agriculture were key to culture. In German, Kultur can mean agriculture or culture and for these thinkers that link was axiomatic. The paeseent was the basis of culture, specifically the German paessent. (129)

* The roots of this view lay in part in the early 19th century romantics enthusaism for the  countryside. But also this agrarianism was not set against Vormaerz liberalism in Germany. The Two worked together well. Smith describes on 130-1. He compares two articles from teh Staatslexicon also to show two lines of development, one by Karl mathy, more liberal, and the other by Welcker, a modern liberal, but one who laid out a view of the paesent that showed ideas that ultimately became typical of conservatives like Riehl and Ratzel later on. (131-133).

 

...

 

## Ch. 8 The Diffusionist Revolt

* Diffusionism developed in the German context as a revolt against the "neoliberal" pattern that Smith has described. It came out of Bastian, but it was really developed into an alterantive in the hands first of F. Ratzel, Froebenius, Graebner, and Wilhelm Schmidt.  (140)

* The source iin Bastian was due t his argument that the culture of a Volk, i.e. the "system of folk ideas developed from universal elementary ideas--was a result of adapation to particular geographical areas with distinctive environmental conditions." (140) So part of Bastian's study was of the paths of cultural traits into certain geographical contexts and a astudy of the ways in which those ideas were then taken up into the new context and ultimately became part of the new Volk's culture. (140-141) So Bastian's work involved a tracing of trait transfer plus a mapping of "cultural provinces" (141), but this was not a central part of his theoretical project -- though it was takne more seriously by Richahrd Andree and Franz Boas, two of his followers. (141)

* What Ratzel did was emphasize this set of ideas and placed them in a different theoretical framework that Smith says had "radically different political connections, including links to agrarianism." (141) He began that proccess in his early 1882 work *Anthropo-Geographie. Here he self-consciously tried to the kind of human geography that A. Humboldt and Ritter had aimed at. He believed that unlike Ritter and Humboldt he had the right theoretical frame of a modified Darwinism. His version of Darwinism came from Moritz Wagner's theories of migration, also based on Darwin. Wagner liked Darwin's notion of natural selection, but though he'd ignored humans' tendency to spread across the globe, which Wagner viewed as a law. And he assumed that as a people spread out, the more change and diversity that people would hsow. Ratzel took up Wagner's ideas as a way to ground what Smith calls a "holistic huma geography" and to justify a "migrationist colonilaism." (142)  "Restless movement is the signature of mankind." he said (142) And he began to see "the interactions of human groups with various features of terrain,c limatte, and vegetation essentially struture society and history."
