(142) That is, he laid out aview in which in Smith's words "competition between human groups takes place in a spational dimension; the most fundamental struggle is for space itself." (142) 

* So Ratzel's study was based on a study of diffusion. He assumed that he knew the basic framwork of hsitory i.e. migration and adaption in a competetive context -- but he needed to know the details. So he developed a method of diffusionist determination in which he assume that "if different peoples, physically separates from one another, made material objects in much the same way, it was probably evidence of previous cultural contacts between them." (142) Then combining Wagner's theories with philological techniques he argued that "high levels of similairty between individual cultural traits (e.g. in shaping bows) and large numbers of similar traits shared by peoples of different regions were firm evidence of the paths of cutlural diffusion." (142) Finally, the coexistence in some geographical space of a great number of similar traits indicated a "Kulturkreis." (142) Then finally, he assumed that there was a link between metnal traits and physical traits, such that the discoery of such kulturkreise indciated the distinctive patterns of a particular Volk. (143)

* Implications of Ratzel's thoery vv political liberalism:

    1) individualism: Ratzel was not much interested in the abstract individual, although he accepted certain parts of the model. His theory Smith says depended on being able to predict the rational response of different groups and those reponses had to result to some extent from "individual rationality." (143)  Yet he undestood rationality very differently than other neoliberals like Bastian did -- who took it as the central object of study. For Ratzel, Smith says, the issuew as varily transparent. "Human rationality was only an extension of the general mental capabilities of higher vertebrates (which allowed Ratzelto apply 'laws' of animal life and movement ot humans -- if only by implication.)" (143) In fact, Ratzel was interested in groups, but not for the neoliberal reason that "culture influenced individual thought..." (143) Ratzel reversed the liberals thinker here, inferring the characteristics of the indivdiual's mind from the individual's behavior in groups. Smith writes: "The most important point about the relationship between the individual and the group was that, far from reflecting the manifold capabilities of the individual, the group (or society as a whole), thorugh the division of labor, made up for the very real deficiencies of the average person." (144) Thus it was a key assumption of Ratzel's thought that humans are naturally uncreative. (144) The only creative types in Ratzel's though bear comparison to the type of creative individuals envirioned in Nietzsche, but Ratzel was just not interested in these types. (144) He was more interested in how once such innovations occur they are adapted by others. He saw adaptions as occcuring most commonly in confrontation with environment, and he saw innovastions as mostly technological, tools or weapons, and sometimes forms of political organization. (144) He viewed cultures then as aggreations of traits. Indeed, Smith says that what Ratzel had done really was to repalce the individual with a new abstration: the trait. (144) He was bothered however by the fact that he could never define the deeper force, "some life force beneath the trait aggregations that gave them meaning." (144) Some of his followers , esp. Leo Frobenius, tried to define this force. But in the "main line of German diffusionist theory" i, li.le. Ratzel to Graebner to Wilhelm Schmidt, culture were conceived as collectsions of traits. (144)

    2) nomothetic science:  (144-146)

    3) social change and equilibrium: 146-. Here the pattern was different than the liberals. His theory "substantially shifted the weight of theory toward a complex historical view in which universal stages of cultural development were subordinated to unique patterns of cultural diffusion." (146) This is why he was less interested in innovation than in adaption and trait transmission. Because what determine the survival of certain speces/volk was the qualitiy of their traits for adaption. Here though the possibilities were complex because even when a people migrated and essentially conquered they could still be "absorbed" by the conquered. In which case, in Ratzel's mind their Volk had lost in the end. But Smith says for Ratzel teh most succesful Volk were those who "move into a new region and take over, impressing themselves and their culture on the area beecause the array of traits they bring with them allows them to adopt readily to new circumstances." (146) In this case, they may acquire some new traits, but mostly there has been a kind of transplanting... (146) thus Ratzel tended to refer to successful migrant poulations as "colonizers" and he argued that they all shared some common traits: strong agriculture, effecive political organization, military and agritculaturla technology and so on. (147) Ratzel also considered transmission through trade, but downplayed it; for him, it played more of ar ole in shpaing a pople,e than in allowing them to transmit their traiuts. (147) Smith summarizes: "Migration and adapation, supplemented by occassional innovation and diffusion by trade, are therefore the wellsprings of history. Progress does occur, but not inevitably or in universal stages. It occurs through the aggregation of superior traits by certain peoples, who spread themselves and their cultures over wide areas, absorbing other traits and innovations into their cultural being without losing its essence." (147) These essences, Ratzel though, were recoverable. Even if a people got separated, they might develop differently, but their commonalities woudl continue to be traceable. (147)

* interestingly Ratzel was not a racist, since he assumed that biological mixing wold always tak eplace. Smith asserts that he was less racist, for example, than Virchow. (147)

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text: p.73 Marx, Gender and Social Construction Marx believed most often to be a positive libertarian. b/c/ he saw "systemic and institutional phenomena, particularly capitalism, to be the key barriers to freedom..." (73) After the revolution, though, Marx's vision of freedom she says is almost "libreral" (meaning negative freedom?) (73) But then she points out that Marx did not analyze the "role of women in communist society, particularly the double day that will result from Marx's failure to address gendered division of labor in the family, suggests that this free individual, the subject of liberty, is male for Marx as well." (73)

title: Interior States: Institutional Consciousness and the Inner Life of Democracy in the Antebellum United States
text:
# Christopher Castiglia, *Interior States: Institutional Consciousness and the Inner Life of Democracy in the Antebellum United States* (Durham, London: Duke University Press, 2008)

 

## Introduction: Interiority and the Problem of Misplaced Democracy

* The context in which he places the books is a debate about the decline of American democracy taht includes Robert Putnam's famous bowling alone essay, as well as a set of other texts that cite a demise of democracy rooted in a decline of "citizens' capacity to organize themselves for collaborative negotation and public action to rectify injustice and improve associational life in way that take account of divergence expectations and experiences." (1) -- i.e. a decline in democratic agency; that is, a decline of democratic agency in a conception of democracy in which the word indicates an **end** and not a form of government (see f.n. #2, where C quotes Lummis on this).  He cites texts by Crenson and Ginsberg, *Downsizing Democracy*, Lummis, *Radical Democracy* and Smith, *The Politics of Deceit*.

* These critiques rely on what C calls an "uncomplicated interpellative model of trickle-down ideology." (1) C's critique si that although privatization is important he doesn't think that it has succeeded in ending democracy... Rather he says it has been "misplaced." What he means by that is that the "we have been encouraged to misrecognize the location of the social, finding it, not in assocaition with others, but in the turbulent and conflicted interiors of our own bodies. The bodily interior has become misunderstood as a social space, as *the* social space of modernity, and it is exclusively within that interior state that citizens are encouraged to develop democratic innovation and the skills of negotiation across differences." (2)

* He sees it as something that developed in the ninteenth century. What he wants to call the "nervous state"  -- "with its battles between appetite and restraint, desire and deferral, consciousness and unconsciousness" -- was developed thruogh "centuries of public and pscyhological reform, in social terms" to the end that this nervous interor state became "a microcosm of the equally riven sociality of nineteenth-century America." (2) This process meant that "citizens" were taugh to preceive "vigilant self-scrutiny and self-management as effective decmoratic action." (2) Thus he concludes that it is not that citizens have "lost" the capacity to act democratically; they have "misconceived the realm where that action can achieve its purported ends. While democracy may not be lost, then, it is certainly misplaced." (2)

* C says that the "interpellative model" -- whereby the citizen in living in a state bound by modern legal ideas about individual rights is assumed to have a centered subjectivity -- does not acknolwedge the complexity of subjectivity. He refers to a "gap" between the classic interpellative model -- ie the citizen responding ot the politice officer ont he street -- and the internal emotional and pscyhological apparatus that makes that possible. He cites Louis Althusser here and also other "theorists of subjectivity" including Foucault, Giles Deleuze,  Judith Butler, and Jameson. His point is this subjective dimension cannot be ignored.

* Settting up his model he describes two dynamics, one is "interiority" and other is institutionalism:

1.  Not doing this himself, he argues (in Ch.1) that the American "Founders" were among the first to seek to "join deep interiority and civic order" to produce what he says Foucault called "disciplinary democracy". What does this really  mean? He says that what they did was to develop a "philosophy of centralized *feelings* modeled on historically familiar modes of beloning (families, churches, and above all friendships)" that were however now coneived as "metaphorical--rather than embodied and local--simulacra of the government." (3)I  So this is **interiority**. He is not arguing that interiority began here but that this was a development. He emphasizes here that his idea is that the individual was not simply a private realm of desire affect and apetite, but that this interority was "a realm of disruption and attempted order that, mirroring the often tense struggles between popular demand and juridical control, may be called an *interior state*." (3) So his point is that the antebellum interiroity **was not** the reuslt of the subject being "interpellated" into a "unitary subjectivity" but rather than this interiority was "overpopulated and--as any large population will be--riven by conflicitng demands and anspirations." [So the individual was a population??] This reflected he thinks the shifts in North American society in the 18th and early 19th, defined by diversity, colliding "ideological regimes" and forms of social association. The divisions of this interirotiy were mirrors of divisions that were in their origin social. (4-5) The development of this interior, he notes, created a site of negotiation "contradicitions and conflicts" between the numerous ideologies and modes of association that "belied the coherence of national or market interests" (4) and were effectively "beyond the stat'e power to regulate." (4) Yet on the other hand the productio n of a social interiror gave rise to "vigilant and habitual self-managment" as a "first step in the ideological production of the modern security state." (4) This self-management project, on the other hand, he insists was necessarily a failed project because noone believed that the "divided interiors of the antebellum citizen could be integrated once and for all into an oirderly and unified whole, a pscyhic *e pluribus unum*." (4) Reference or "production" of the unconscious indicated an awareness of forces that would disrupt that project. Yet interiority suggest he says that the goal never was to "regulate once and for all the unruly interirors of the citizen nor to keep citizens from developing skills of negotation, but to gove thise skills a virtual arena in which to operate..." (4) That also made this kind of "democracy" a mobile enterprise. That is, he says, that interiority made it possible for democracy to break out beyond traditional borders of localities. He describes interiority in a way as a kind of social protection inside the self: "In a period when citizens traveled with unprecedented frquenecy, the mobile sociality provided by antebellum interiority became a necessary check on disorientation and alienation and, in the process, enabled the state's expansion across national borders without sacrificing the *feel* of a still intact democratic integrity." (5)  So interiority ==> mobility...

2. **Institutionalism**: This was an ideology that arose in response to French and Haitian revoltuions. This was a corollary to interiority that created a "semblance of permanence". (5) It claimeed to be capapble of crarrying "current social interests unhindered into the future." (5) It "deferred temporally what interiroity displaced spatially." (5) That is, by focusing people on a "perpetually receding horizing of futurity" , it made the achievmeent of democracy now impossible, and it divided people by their orientation toward teh past (ie the nostalgic, unproductive, and mealancholic) from those oriented twoard the future( the productive and energetic.) (5) So although it focused on the future, it created in practice an "immobility of de-historicized stasis." It imagined not a "better future" but a future that exactly replicates the present. It credited agencies with agency -- the agency necessary to recereate their existence int he future. Thus it negates the agency of the individual. It produced a view of the individual as "passionate" and thus also apolitical -- passionate and therefore dangerous to the order and incapable of constructive political action. It advocates partiality. So while interiority alienated individual from public  spaces of social debate, institutinoalism put them in a position wehre they were regulating their "turbulent interiors" which in its view of them were also what made them "unifit for civic participation." "Citizens became administartors, in short, of themselves." (6)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text: p.174- Critique of Feminism But utlimatley Parsons focus on the links between sexual classification and power cause her to sour on the prospects of the women's movmeent: "Men will cede to women only what by ceding gives them as assurance of power, like making an allowance to a wife or educating a daughter to citizenship or they will cede only what they consider has ceased to give mastery--just as they are now ceding the vote or theccleesiastical profession." (quoted on 174). Noting also that feminism had failed to yeild any female influence over men. (174) She deploredalso the use of sexual difference among women e.g. the woman's Peace party see quote on 175. She did not think suffrage or economic independence enough... what was needed was a "subodination of sexto personality far more sweeping than we deream of today came to be." (quoted on 176, fro mSocial Rule?). WWI dashed her hopes finally. She made a "break with pbulic life" (176).

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text: p. 482 - 3 Boas and Metadiscourse of Modernity They do not think that Boas invented the "textual construction of Others." (482) That project they think was "precisely as old as modernity itself" and that it had always been "utilizing a rhetoric of traditional and modern that played a key role in constructing the modern subject and granting it a sense of novelty and an historical trajectory." (482-3) Key to this project was, its attempt to establish a "social opposition between traditional and modern worlds," (483) was the fact that the texts it produced obscured their own "rootedness in modernist discursive practices and interests" and instead sought to generate an "aura of authenticity and verisimilitude." (483) Boas then like "his predecessors" in this tradition "argued for the importance of preserving cultural traditions by textual means without questioning the inevitability of their passing from the living repertoire of the people from whom they were recorded." (483) They think however that Boas "refitted" this "well-established metadiscursive project" so that it would "suit the particular brand of modernist angst that characterized the life of intellectuals and particularly social scientists at the turn of the century." (483) What angst do they mean exactly???

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text:
p. 503 - 5 Gap Between Acknowledgement of Native Suffering and Collected Texts

In prefaces, Boas described the suffering of the Indian population from racism, poverity, disease, exploitation, violence.  But these problems appear as obstacles to the gathering of texts.  So in the Chinook texts he notes the inability to collect certain texts due to people's suffering. (503)

But Boas never links such comments with certain texts, that might elucidate such problems: "They relate almost without exception to pre-contact events; the warfare texts are all traditionalized, set at substantial temporal and cultural distance from the present, and there is only a passing reference to a recent epidemic in what is framed as a shamanistic dream narrative.  Boas does not use these texts in linking images of 'authentic' Native American cultures with the scenes that he descrbies so tersely in the prefaces..." (504)  Warfare stories in general were less interesting to him than "animal stories, origin myths, tales of supernatural beings, migration legends, accounts of material culture, the life cycle, ritual, religious bliefs, and the like--that is, the more canonical genres of putatively authentic folk expression established by the philological program of Herder and the Grimms.  It was these genres that wer held to reveal the cultural inheritance and hsitory of apeople." (504)

The authors note on th eother hand that i might have been hard for people to talk about suffering, but the authors note that Boas did not try. (505)

One instance is when Boas records a speech by a chief when the Canadian Gov't was trying to supress certain dances and ceremonies.  And the chief wants to know if Boas has come to help them, in which case he will be not allowed in...  (505)

title: "The Foundations of All Future Researches": Franz Boas, George Hunt, Native American Texts, and the Construction of Modernity
text: p. 507 - 511 Further examinations of Boas' approach - Genre: Boas did not want to distinguish between different types of genre in prim. texts, say historical v. mythical. They see this as being another strategy for bolstering the authority of the text... (507-8) - Boas's theory of aesthetics emphasized the unconscious nature of creative production. See Primitive Art (1927), p.155: "The mental processes of artistic production do not take palce in the full light of consciousness. The highest type of artistic production is there, and its creator does not know whence it comes." (Primitiv Art 155, quoted here on 508-9). Boas the authors say seemed to think that natives could be conscious of art as an object, but not of the process that had led to its creation.(509) He also did not link art to necessity; it required leisure. (509) But creation was individual, and the authors cite Boas's quote about an eskimo sitting for hours of a fishing whole, and here having new songs come to mind. But on the whole Boas saw instances of creation as rare...diffusion the most common thing. Moreover, narratives "provide an emotional rather than cognitive hold on 'the events of human life,' such that daily experiences are imaginatively transformed through wish fulfillment and the 'materialization of the objects of fear.'" (509) That is, the authors note that if, as they argued earlier, Boas believed stories to reveal a "picture" of the way a people saw things, that was not an "accurate picture" of a reality: "...Native American self-consciousness does not 'exhibit clearly' or provide 'an accurate reflection' of everyday life." (510) To get at this the authors drop two excellent quotes from his Primitive Art that develop the idea further. Boas's aesthetic theory held that meaning was not consciously given to objects during the act of (individual) creation, but rather narratives gained meaning when they were in circulation, when they were diffused, but the meaning they gained was not an accurate one. He wrote: "The narrative is given an interpretive significance that is quite foreign to the original tale..." (quoted on 510, from Primitivr Art 336-337). That is native texts are "simply unrealiable" the authors say as historical interpretattions. So they raise the question: "The tellers simply lack the ability to use narratives in interpreting their own history, in that adventitious meanings, style of interpretation, cultural interests, and symbolic explanations distort conscoiusness of historical events." (511) So: "What sort of authority is then attributed to Native Americans?" Their answer is that the authority is limited in terms of the "authority over the reception of these texts" (511) because the role of anthropologist and the informant are erased...so the statements are still statements of infomrants which are significanct, but they have no control over the way those texts are understood/received.

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text: p.068-86 Ch.4 The Historian and His Audience

title: A New Look At Nineteenth-Century Historical Consciousness From the Modern/Postmodern Divide
text:
# Dorothy Ross, "A New Look At Nineteenth-Century Historical Consciousness From the Modern/Postmodern Divide" Modern Intellectual History,  9, 2 (2012), pp. 451-462.

> I am reading this primarily to try to get a grasp on the language that DR is using for modernism and postmodernism and her sense of the state of these terms of art, since she wrote in reponse to my Manifold Origins article that I needed to lay off these terms because they are "counting for less" in the historiography.

* This is a review of two new book that "revise long-standing narratives of a shallow historical consciousness among nineteenth-century Americans" (451). But DR thinks the books at the same time "raise important questions about our twenty-first century historical practice." (451) With the latter she is referring to what she sees as "the mix of modernist and postmodern interpretive strategies historians are using in our own compound moment." (459)

title: Age of Fracture
text:
General Notes Rodgers' Atlantic Crossings

Chapter on Economic Thought

* R describes how the old Keynesian theory broke down in he 70s. The stagflation was unusual precisely because it did not fit classical Keysian models, specifically the Phiilips Curve that showed a trade off between inflation and unemployment: high inflation "buying" low unemployment. Stagflation defied that rule, which had been based in empirical research. The fjnancial crisis of the 70s then led to a "crisis in ideas" and the intellectual authority of the Keynesian system.  Rodgers notes that ultimately the Phillips curve returned after the end of the 70s financial crisis with the Reagent tax cuts functioning as stimulus.  But nobody knew why it had failed to explain the behavior of the market during the crisis. (47-50)

* The crisis of Keynsianism allowed for he rise of monetarism whose greatest exponent was Milton Friedman. R describes his ideas on 50-56. His theory was that the shift in prices was determined solely by "shifts in the growth rate of the volume of circulating money." (51) As R puts it, "[I]n this radically simplified model of aggregate economic behavior, state, society, and institutions all shrank into insignificance within a black box that translated money inputs directly into price outputs." (51) Not sure why Rodgers does not hit this point but the tradeoff between unemployment and inflation is gone here...and somehow the sense that there is a tradeoff at all. This model was taken up by both the Brits and Americans. The Fed under Volker began advertising money supply targets. But monetarism also failed to be predictive with the relation between money supply and price outputs not behaving as expected.  By 1982, the Fed had essentially anandoned the theory and returned to "discretion and rules of thumb." (55) While the Fed inverse stated that they had given up applying monetarism, Thatcher's ministers declared that they had given up in 1986. (55)  R's judgement in the end is that monetarism "turned out to be a bulldozer that could level a building but could not erect one. (55) It helped transfer responsibility for management of he business cycle from Congress to the Fed. And the idea of a "natural" rate of unemployment that Friedman had pushed helped to destroy dreams of full employment. (55)

 * The chapter then goes on to describe three shifts that defined the "struggle over ideas and paradigms" that formed the new economic body of ideas: 1) the invasion of economic ideas into the legal profession that moved law away from a focus on blame, social justice, etc, and instead toward econoimcally ionspired notions of "aggregate good" which involved letting the market do its work, see 56-64; 2) rise of "rational expectation" economists in the university, esp. Robert Lucas, whose challenged the idea that any management of the economy was possible at all because economic actors were always anticipating regulation, (something Friedman had suggested vv monetary policy). This created a howl new vision of economic actors as lightning-fast calculators, able to judge economic policy in terms of its teime effects vis-a-vis money, ie how it would influence inflation. (63-68); 3) and then the "supply-side" advocates centereda t the Wall Street Journal (Robert Bartley, Jude Wanninski, Jack Kemp, and Irving Kristol) whose arguments did not sell university economists, but who gave fuel to a massive anti-government and anti-tax set of ideas and moved economics popularly completey away from the idea that economics was a science rooted in limits and scarcity, and instead supported the idea of the market as a source of boundless opportunity. 68=73.


Chapter on Power

This chapter attempts to assess the shifts in analyses of power on both the left and the right since the mid-60s.  It's argument, as with the rest of the book, is that there is a "fracturing" of awareness, meaning when it comes to power that power is no longer considered in relation to classes and institutions and that through the concept of culture its presence in our lives becomes more pervasive in our lives and more precise in its method of controls.  A phrase Rodgers uses regularly is the "microphysics of power," which is incidentally a phrase I also heard Victoria De Grazia use once in describing the ethical focus of her generation of historians.  Rodgers puts it this way in tthe intro to the chapter: "Down some of these winding paths, power fragmented, its bloc categories fracturing into smaller, individually situated micropolitical acts.  Down others, power grew more diffuse, pervasive, and subtle."  (79) 

The most dominant reading of power mid-century, R says,  was "interest-group pluralism" (81)  Idea here was that big organized social interests clashed publically for power.  The biggest interests were big business, big labor, and big gov't.  But also "old and entrenched ethnic elites, new immigrant voters and their political machines, regional and sectional interessts, small business owners, agricultural and mining interests, commerical and manufacturing groups..." (81)  This created a "constantly shifting configuration of organized social and economic intersts." (81-82). The multiplicity of interests is what made Democracy work, according to Robert Dahl in his 1961 book "Who Governs?" So what puralists braggeda bout was not that they had "disaggregate interest groups or to abolish power" but that they had set "power against power, interests against interests, they had constructed a balance of competing and countervailing forces whose very tensions kept the system whole." (82)

This theory of power began to fray in the 60s in the midst of the intensified social conflicts.  As more and more people began to feel "that they were on the losing end of power struggles that had suddenly gone out of control," a new theory emerged that focused on "hidden concentrations of power." (82)  The left focused on a line in Trotskyite Marxism that focused on the "bureacuratic managerial class taht, wresting power from the owners of money and property, was said now to manage and direct the key institutions of late twentieth-century capitalism." (82) Also a line of analysis focusing on the "therapeutic state" that was parituclarly present in Lasch's Culture of Narcissism. (82)  This line of analysiss was embraced by those on the political right!!  By Iriving Kristol in his op-ed contributions to the Wall Street Journal; by Robert Bork, who blamed his failed bid fot he Supreme Court on this "new class.";b ythe conservative sociaoloigist Peter Berger who, echoing the Communist manifesto, spoke in 1978 of "the spectre of the New Class." (83)  This was a strange shift beecause conservatives had long denied structural class divisions.  It was partly a product of leftist intellectual moving right, e.g. the ex-Trotskyite James Burnham who introduced the new class theory into Buckley's National Review.  But while it was corporate manager's that had been at the center of the new classs theory originally, conservatives focsued on "modern societiy's still larger array of knowledge and symoblic workers: professionals, educators, cultural produceers, and technocrats." (83)  These people the analysis went "found its interests in the big and growing state." (84)  Throught eh state they attempted, as Kristol put it, "to supersede economics by politics" (84)  This was a stripped-down versin of Marx that "gave voice to an intuitive sense, running below conserative talk of the primacy of ideas, of the determinvative effects of social postiion and of economic interests." (85)  It helped explain the radical politics of them explain the rise of radical politics amoung well-educated 60s youth, as well as the power of th eliberal voice in the universities and in the media.  And it introduced a new notion of class interest into the right's rhetoric. 

A second analysis of power on the right emerged from game theory and rational choice.  (85-90)  If the new class theory introduced a langauge of power into right rhetoric, this line of thought fractured the right's conception of power.  "Dispensing with aggregates, it bore down on the dynamics of self-interested individual political action, remapping the world of politics and legislative action as a filed of individual preference-satisfying behavior." (85) thinkers like Wiliam Riker, james Buchanan, Mancur Olson, applied game theory and rational choice to political actors, depicting them as always trying to maximize personal power and benefits.  The conservative strain here came from the pessimistic reading of the results, R says, (86)  All the models--"the prisoner's dilemma, Olson's free-rider problem, Garrett Hardin's tragedy of he commons, where existence of af ree resource meant that no had a stakke in prevening that resource from being exhausted" (86)--"yielded, by their implacable logic, suboptimal results." (86) And thus under the weight of these analyses Rodgers says "the idea of governance as an experession of the public good all but evaporated." (87)  "'New Class' theory gave conservatives a structural expalantion for why they felt so marginalized in the early 1970s.  In the application of interest-maximizing individual behavior to politics, by constrast, the aggregates did not clash, as they had for Berger and Kristol, but fractured out into myriad individual pieces." (87) 


A key part of Rodger's argument is that the move toward "subtler and more insidious understandings of power" (106), in which power is everywhere and nowhere, impossible to locate, comes from all sides, from the left and the right, and from different even ostensibly  opposed lines of thought. 

On the left, the concept of culture was central and R analyzses the terms development from 94, which as he discusses it emerged out of the new labor history, spawned by Thompson, which had already fractured around its detailed examination of the different lines of resistance in workding class communities.  Into this study, culture emerged as something other than "ideologies, or superstrcutures of ideas (as orthodox Marxists had thought of them)"; it was "more malleable, pervasive, elusive, and yet paradoxically, power-saturated." (94)  But if culture could be seen as a source of power from the bottom up, it could also be seen as the reverse, and that's how it came to be seen by those who adopted Antmnio Gramsci's notion of hegemony.  R also contrasts Thompson's work with Genovese's Roll, Jordan, Roll, as a book that focused on cutlure but as a source of domination.  (96-97).

As the focus on culture expanded, it invaded language itself.  Pocock's analysis treated "'languages' as ideologically charged systems of meaning." (98)  British labor historians began to see language not as a "transparent register of social experience but a thing of structure and power in its own right.  Language 'is an independent non-referential system,' Gareth Stedman Jones was writing by 1980. It 'set[s] the limits of what can be thought or apprehended at a given time." (98) Then in cultural theory ther was a turn toward "lingusitic structuralism" driven by Geertz, who had begun his career working with modernization theory.  In the mid-60s he moved away from the social scientific language of structure and development toward the ethnographic practice and anthropology's "litearry threads." (99)  Geertz's new prose was more modest R notes when compared to the "imperial pose of the structuralist social sciences..." (99)  "Cutting culture down to size, the Geertzian move was to take an event, a recurrent ritual, like the betting play at a Balinese cockfight that his mose widely read essay made famous, and, weaving reportage and academic concepts so artfully into 'thick description' of the even-as-text that they could not be pried apart, 'draw large conclusions from small but very densely textured facts.'" (99)

R notes that this form of analysis "brushed by" readings of societies as "system of produciton and exchange, systems of authority and behavior rules, systems of social differentiation and inequality, structures of cosmic belief and ideology..." (99)  There were, R says, "no structural foundatinos in Geertz's system: nothing but a play of texts, meanings, and semiotics all the way down." (100) This mode of interpretation became very powerful inthe 1980s and weakenedd th structural social history of the past.  It was a turn away from institutinos and structures, a "thinning of the social" as William Sewall called it.  (100)  What fueled this turn R thinks was a generation taht "had grown up in the wake of th media revolution of the post-World War II era, in a sea of texts and meanings, amid a symbolic bombardment that was now part and parcel even of politics," and for such people the notion that "culture floated insubstantially on top of more basic structures of economic or demographic power made less and less intuitive sense.  Power lay in meanings, in the very ability of cultural form to give shape to the welter of experience, to spin reality into its forms." (101)  When Geertz took a look at power in the 1970s "it was to virtually dissolve the distinction between power and thought." (101) Geertz looked at it in ihs sutdy of precolonial Bali, depeicing a society "saturated with power relations." (101)  Specifically he looked at it in his study of Negara.  (101) Power in his analyssis resisded in "meaning istelf, in the very tremulous stuff of culture." (102)  And this was a new conception fo pwoer on the left.

Next R looks at Foucault's analysis of power.  F didn't talk about cutlure, wasn't in his vocabulary, but he did the same thing with it.  At its starts it was in institutions, but by his later writing "power had seeped out of the sites and structures until it was everywhere." (104) Geertz objected to Foucautl's pessimism, "to the way in which each moment of apparent progress led only to new forms of unfreedom, like stairways in an Escheer drawing that folded back upon themselves."  (104) For R, though, Foucault and Geertz might ahve bene opposed, their "dematerialization" of power was similar.  "'Culture' was not in Foucault's vocabulary; power was to be found not in consciousness or ideology, he instisteed, but in tactics and strategy.  But in their rejection of structures, their disaggregation of power, their stress on the power/knowledge juncture, Foucauldian readings of power entered a field already primed to receive them...." (107)

A very good passage here suming up and critiquing:

    "Power had moved decisively into the spheres of culture, ideas, everyday practices, science.  But if power relations were everywhere and saturated everything, not only investing in individual subjects but producing them, if power were indistinguishable from resistance, incapable of being held by any identifiable group or institution, unlinked in any sense to 'agency,' had not the long, complex search for power's ever more subtle faces succeeded, at last, in finding nothing at all?" (107)

## Chapter 6 -  Race and Social Memory

* This chapter begins two that show the fragmenting of concepts and categories that had undergirded identity up until the 1970s. By the end of the chapter on race, the concept of "race" that Gunnar Myrdal had in his key 1940s book An American Dilemma described as a "social and conventional" category was being treated as something "unstable" and "decentered" by Omi and Howard Winant, see p.137 for the juxtaposition. As Rodgers puts it, "the terms in which justice and race were eing overly deated [for instance in the afifmrative action debate] had shifted from the historical and social condsiderations of the early 19870s to a new, more abstract terrain." (136) And ultimately, Rodgers tihnks that this new sense of multiplicity and hybridity in identity risked makign race seem unreal. He quotes Gates on 142 warning fo this: "Race was 'a text (an array of discursive practices), not an essence,' a braid of memory made no in 'blood' but in history and in culture. Gates cautioned against 'the treachersous non sequitur that mous us from 'socially constructured' to essentially unreal.' In acknowledging, that 'everything' is socially constructured,' we should not 'rol up hsitory behind us like a carpet.'" (142).  But this is what Rodgers thinks occurred. He ends the chapter: "'Identities are the names we give to the different ways we are positioned by, and position ourselve in, the narratives of the past,' Stuart Hall wrote. but from Roots' vividly imagined brad of memory and racial solidarity in the 190s, the growth of more complex understanidngs of identity was also the retreat of history. A culture reshaped in the choices oand present moment preoccupations of a market saturated society had transposed the frame of teh argument. In a liberation that was also the age's defecit, a certain loss of memory had occured." (143)

* In this chapter, as in the others, Rodgers tries to show how this general trend happened from multiple political directions. Blacks' own narratives shifted to undermine the starting point in which race was a clear and obvious factor in opression and then also a source of pride. So he traces a line from Alex Haley's Roots, James Baldwin's sense of the  "iron curtain" of race (112), Toni MOrrison's sense of the special sound and feeling of black experience (116-117) to William Julis Wilson's controversial 1978 book The Declining Sifnificance of Race.(113-125). 2) Then he shows the rising awareness of race for whites and reverse racism and the conservative attack on affirmative action that emphasized the ideal of "color blindness." (125-137). Then he traces the undermining of race in "progressive African-Ameriacn intellectuals" -- the undermining of the ocncept's "ontological status." (137-142

## Chapter 7 - Gender and Certainty

* This chapter takes up debates about the identities of men and women that Rodgers thinks were the most important battles fought out in what James Davison Hunter in 1991 termed the "culture wars" in his book byt hat title. (145). Essentially it builds on the trend that he finds in his chapter on race, but cuts at identity ostensibly on a much deeper level, where again he finds that there is as the battles develop, a complete emptying out of any certainties about gendered identity -- and this is both the result of how feminism develops once it moves into the university, where taking up French poststructuralist theory, it treats gender identity as primarily discourses, and then how the debate about idnetity is fought out between conservatives and feminists. The latter debates could confirm the poststructuralist feminists' claims about the deep linguistic binaries that undergirded language. Rodgers writes after analyzing Allan Bloom's The Closing of the American Mind and its spin offs, ie William Benne's De-Valuing America, Gertrude Hemmelfarb's Demoralization of Society, Lynne Cheney's Telling th e Turth and Michael Novak's Awakening from Nihilism, all fo which posed a trade-off between certainties and an abyss of realtivism and choice:

> "Leave the gruond of moral reasning where things were fixed in nature for a world of choices, contexts, and competing perspectives, the argument went [in these books], and all that was left was the play of power and identity politics. If poststructuralist claims about the deep binaries seated in language needed confirmation, they might have found it here. To stake one's claims in certainties was to frame the alternative as an abyss of nothingness. Encounter with truth, on the one hand: the qucksands of realtivsim on the other." (177)

On the opposite side and the target for Bloom was Rorty,who stood accused for being "the man who killed truth" as the BBC put it (177). But Rorty was not in fact an amoralist; rather in his view "the hard work of ethical life was done not in the abstract but in the concrete and the particular: in arguemtns over wages and health care, he wrote, not indebates about the commodification of labor or the underlying nature of 'man.'" (177) Rorty wrote: "Solidarity has to be constructed out of the litle pieces, rather than found already waiting, in the form of an ur-language which all of us recognize when we hear it." (177) So Roders concludes here that identity had now become radically unstable even at the most basic (male/female level). After a quote by Jodi Dean that gets at this he writes: "All these identity were set in prescripted discourses and fragmented subject positions. They were, simultaneously, open and unstable, multiple, disruptive. {para} Every solidarity, the period showed, was open to fissuring." (178) Interestingly he ends the chaper sugggesting taht this jostling and desconstructing about identity "had not felt like facture. It had felt like war." (179). It seems he means when all certainties are borken? and this is reference to the "cutlure wars."

* There is a certain tone of condecension towards the feminists her I think, and an unwillingness to consider the positive possibilities of their deconstructions. Did their critqiues only fracture and fragment and create a stark division between relativistic chaos and stark certainties? Is that all that these ideas can do? When he describes why the feminists now in the academy turned to poststructuralist thought on 162 he sounds condescending to me. "The langauag eof 'theory' gave women newly entering th graduate schools and literature departments an intellectual claim [as if without theory they would not have had oen?], a language of textual virtuosity, a voice that could not be dismissed as closeted in the identity politics of a women's studies program." Some truth here, but mixed with a certain sense that the dieas were only important to these women because of their ability to grant power! "Above all, iin its pessimism, poststructuralism offered a new kind of power--not to speak as women (and in the process reinforce the very categories of women's suboridnation) but to destabilize the ways in which 'female was submerged, made marginal to, and always under the domination of 'male.'" (162)

* Also very useful in this chapter is the description of poststructuralism and the distinction between poststructruralism and postmodernism (often seen as the same thing) on 156-158.

> 'Postmodernism, 'with which poststructuralism was sometimes conflated, was an understanding of contemporary culture that stressed its decentered, fragmentary, surface-obsessed, patchwork character. In the hands of critics like Frederic Jameson, postmodernism was a Schumpeterian reading of culture, in wihch the market forces of commodification and creative destruction left nothing, even identity, stable. Poststructuralism began from the opposite premise: the extraordinary capacity of lanague to disguise and control the radical isntability at language's heart. Poststructuralism offered not a theory about language's already existing order, but in Joan W. Scott's words, 'a theory about how categories are constructed to apepar closed or fixed when they are not.'" (158).


## Chapter 8 - Little Platoons of Society

* After two chapters, examining the large shifts in identity politics in the realms of race and then sexuality -- where there is a move away from simple models, in which race or sex is interpreted in realtion to large social structures and institutions (class, or paternity, or slavery...)  This chapter looks at what kinds of discourses on society did emerge.  It is complex, but the big point is that there were still a lot of discussions of society.  The Thatcher comment did not represent her thinking or the thinking of the period on any side of the debate.  "Society had not disappeared from the general stock of concepts and desires.  But like other concepts of the age it had grown thinner and more fragmented as older meanings fell out of it.  Rawls's assumption that to think about justice was to begin by imagining what each owed to all across the moral community of the nation had the air of an antique piece.  The idea of equality had lots its urgency.  What society conjured up now was something smaller, more voluntaristic, fractured, easier to exist, and more guarded from others." (220) 

* The last quarter of the 20th century was a "renascent era for political thoery." Mid-century was dominated by sociology and social psychology and by a focus on "the production of social roles and personality and the relentless pressures of mass conformity." (182). Rawls text was the key new work, and he analyzes it on 182-185. Key point here is that Rawls argument was 100% grounded in the "analytical vocabulary of economics and raitonal choice." (183) -- the intellectual trends that had stirpped economics of its focus on history, structure, and scarcity and moved the focus onto the lighting-fast calculator of rational expectation economics etc. So rawls' vision was itself thin and offered no"overarchind idea of th epublic good beyodn the interests of his imagined social contractors" who would support a welfare state because they never knew if they would need the aid of redistributionist policies if born disadvantaged. But it was still to much and ultimately it was critiqued by both the left and the right. His social contract idea which Rodgers says was still "forged in a sense of mutla obligation of each to all" was repalced by "smaller, more inttimate, but also more partial understandings of society." (185)

* The sources were mutliple as usual. There was ont he one hand critiques that emphasized stronger social bonds; he mames E.o. Wilson's On Human Nature (ie sociobiological arguments) and the "liberation theology" that came from South American left Marxism and infused the Catholic Lef int he US culiminating in the pastoral letter on the conomy Economic Justice for All that the American Catholic Bishops put forth in 1986. (185-186).

* Another main strain was the liberatrian politics. He uses robert Nozick's Anarachy, STate and Utopia as the key text. Nozick's ideas had partly came out of a course "Capitalism and Socialism" that Walzer and Nozick presented in 1971 at Harvard and wich became a kind of "verbal duel." (187) Nozick rejedcts Rawls' image of obligation and society; he rejects the "very effort to imagine the pattern of justice in advance." (187) The book "dazzkled" Rodgers said because of "the radical thinness" to which Nozick cut down Rawls' obligations. It presented an image of a society without a state, with a "multitude of different , paraellel communites, waxing and waning as individuals joined and left..." (188) Libertarians were not always accepted by the conservatives, but both libertarians and conservatives agreed that "equality was a faltal ambition for a just society.": ( 189) Key to Nozicke's argument hhowever was the idea that if a society started out as just (if the distribution of resources was just) then the historical processes that developed and cahnged that society could not bring the society to a point of being unjust. (see 188) Rodgers  notes taht Nozick considered ina  footnote scnarios in which the "original shares of social goods were not just" in which case the further developnment of thes coiety could not wash away the taint, but Noziick left the line of thinking and analysis. Nozick was not interested in analyzing the issue of rectification, so he left it wiuthot answer. (190-191).

*Another source was the new empahsis on "more intesnely bound communities" and this was not a conservative lline! This form of thinking took multiple forms: "civic republicanism, communitarianism, the new citizenship, the civil society movement, the revival of civic virtue." (191) First it came out of the 1960s left wehre it developed from the "direct-action political communities" of African-American acitivites, in the "cooperatives, cauccauses, affinity groups, community organizing projects, and consciousness-raising meetings..." and so on. Civic republicanism tried to find an atlernative commitment to 'self-denying civic virtue" in the Revolutionary era, ie a line that ran counter to Madison's Federalist No. 10. (192). Robert Bellah traced these two competing langauges in a must-read book of the 1980s, Habits of the Heart. bBut most important book on this was Michael Walzter's Spheres of Justice, which was also born out of the course that he and Nozick had given and a critqiue fo Rawls. Walzer thought Rawals project wrong because it imagined that "justice ccould be formulated outside the particular community and particualr relationships within wihch people actually lived." (193) Walzer offered a defnse of the welfare state in his work, but Rodgers insisties that that defense was "less prominent than his desire to demassify it, open it up for more active forms of assocaitional and communcal participation, to bring it closer to the grtuond of real, pluralistic civic life." (194) By implication the welfare state could only be savied by "bringing [it]...ito more vital connection with the real moral community of actual social life..." (194) Hence here is a more intimate, samller and more fragmented vision of society coming from the progressive left.

* Conservastives were at first warry of civic republicanism and communitarianism. They did nto like the historical claim seeking to locate an itellectual tradition runnign counter to the revoluationary elite. (194), but utliamtely they found reasons to pick up some of the ideas. Peter Berger and Ricahrd Jone Neuhaus at the American Enterprise Institute tried in their "mediating structures project." (195) Another sign of appropriation o fthese ideas on the conservatives ide was the use of the term "virtue" by conservatives. For civic republicanism the ideas was sacrifice of the self for the public weal. fFor conservatives it became a reference to "ethical certainty" a slogan to jsutify "harder-edged moal" in schools,a counter to soft relatvism. (196) Simiarlly, the resistance movements that sprang up in Central and EAstern Europe provoked the emergence of the "new citizenship project" at the Bradley Foundation, supported by Micahel Joyce. This reimagined citizenship as working on smaller levels and in "civil society": ie in churches and daycare centers, and charity and homeless centers etc. It assumed that the "national community idea", as William A. Schambra put it, was a "dead end." The natijonal community these conservatives argued was jsut a "Trojan horse for the intrusion of the invasive therapeutic state." (197) Real community was "local,small-scale and participational." (197) Conservatives her picked up Edmund Burke's phrase the "little platoons" of society. Burke had meant that from these smaller sites of obligation grows the national patriotism. Now the conservatives clipped off the last part. (197) 

## "Wrinkles in Time"

* The idea here is that a new sense of historical time emerged in this era of fracture: "As the very language for society threatened to break into fragments, the past became a sphere onto which desires for community and cohesion could be projected. A truly changeless society would have no need to dwell on its history,. In contrast, a sense of living within a fragmenting and accelerating time made history a point of acute importance." (221) Looking at the willingness of Reagan's speechwriters to evoke a "celluloid film of American hsitory" in which as Reagan put it at the Rededication of teh Stateue of Liberty in 1986 a "common thread that binds" everything led to a notino of history as an "unborkenline of reassurance." (222) Here Rodgers says history did not "unfold step by step, organizing the chaotic patterns of causation and change, explaining the past's continuous, irreversible pressure on the present. In this atlernative vein, the boundary between past and present virtually dissovled. History's massive social processes disappeared. One traveled between past, present, and futrue in the momentary blink of the imagination, through a wrinkle in time." (222-223)

* He finds one indicating of a sense of compressed and accelerated time in Alvin Toffler's Future Shock (1970) and then in his Third Wave (1980). In the former there was a "radical compression" of time; int he second "history's processes crashed into one another in a perfect storm of simultaneity." (224) These boks were best sellers. (224) Legal conservatives in another example "who had once defended continuity and traition, began to argue that the courts hsould vault ofer history inone umpe, back to the orgiianl meaning of the Constitution." (224) In post-soviet world, experts and managers believed that the shfit to market economies could happen simultaneosuly rather than "within hsitorica time." (224)

* He refers to the study of history in this period, which after a period of consensus hsitory at mid-century (driven in part by the closed immigratino), had by the time of the 1976 Bicententiall of American Indepdnecen fragmented. The question  was how to provide a unified story and inthe end this did not work so well. (226-229) 

* In this context he brings up the Reagan speechwriter's "drilling through the messiness of hsitory through a wrinkle in time..." (229). But it was not just a speechwriter's trick he says:

* One sourcew as the "aesthetics of postmodernism." (230) in architechture and art. This style used pastiche and juxtaposition. (230) "Everything fractured in postmodern aesthetics" Roddgers says.

* Another source was the new "originalism" interpretation of the constitution. Rodgers gives an account of it from 232-242. He emphasizes that the idea had echose but no systematic paraellels before it emerged out of a radical arguement on the fringe.  He cites a case that was the work of Raoul Berger, a law proefssor and self-trained hijstorian, who had written about the history fo the 14th ammendment in which he rejected Brown based on the idea o the intention of the framers. Berger's arguemtns captured support in conservative circles and led utlimately to a couple of decisions Jaffe and Smith that use the ideas. These decdision were overruled but REhnquist in the process while not accepting the argument made in these cases made a similar arguemnt based on intent, throwing out the "Wall of separatino" idea that had been the basis of church-state seapration ideas since the 1940s, and had been taken from a Jefferson letter.   Rodgers thinks it "brought a tangle of trheads to the surface: the vulnerability of the Warren Court's vneutres into new realms of rights declaration; the multiple, rival American hsitories in circulatino; the countermobilization of expertise which the conservative foundations were now able to bring to bear against the legal and edcuational estabilshments; and the sectional revialries running so strongly through politics." (236) Regan's new attorny general in ? then in this context said the administration would support "jurisprudcent of original intention." (237) Robert Borkthen becomes a key exponent of this controversial view. (Which Ackerman complicates in his 1991 We The People saying that there may have been multiple originary moments.) (239)  Rodgers ums up saying that "originalism was a project for breaking the law's continuity..." (240) It was based not in a "desire to go back ot any actual past but a desire to esscape altoghether from time's sliperiness--to locate a trap door thorugh which one could reach beyond history and find a simpler place outside of it." (241) This died downin the 1990s he says but for "over a decade, the idea of penetrating time, folding history over upon itself so that one could slip out of its complexities, had been a powerful intellectual project." (241)

* Next section focuses on the "End of History" argument of Fukuyama that were brought about by the end of the Soviet Union. The idea of the Soviety Union of the Cold War was that Communism was incapapble of change; that was "axiomatic" Rodgers says. (242-244). Therefore the SU would just be washed away, so the perestoika was perceived not as real reform by conservative itnerpreters; it was seen assomething engineered to fool the west by the Kremlinm. (245). Here  Fukuyama's article appeared in 1989 heralding an "end of history" -- which in Rdoger accounts invovles a sudden "lurch" or "leap" into a post historical stage. This, he tihnks, fits with his wrinkle in time idea -- but I think there is somethign mroe going on here. Fukuyama's "endism" was hyped partly because it "followed on th heels" in the media of Paul Kennedy's "declinism" about America's imperial overreach. (246) Rodgers ays it "tapped with extraordinary force the otions of folded and short-circuited time that ran through late-twentieth-century social thought. It promised a great leap forward across institutions and inertia into a 'universal homogenous state' of markets, property, science, personal liberties, and democracy." (247)

* Then Rodgers has a section on those who planned the "transition" in Eastern Europe. Again here he finds a historical vision of change which is really predicated on a drilling thruoght time. Jeffrey Sachs a ckey player. Rodgers uses the wrod "vaulting" to describe the vision. (247-254).

* Then in the conclusion he does something funny I think, seeming to embed the new sense of time in the market ideology that he described emerging out of the "Rediscovery of the Market." He says "the new model sof time and change reflected a widespread sense of the naturalness of the market--not merely their utility, or their astonishing capacity for productivity and innovation, but their very congruence with human nature itself." (254) I see why he's tying this back in, but he seems to subordinate the time issue ot the market ideology too much for my taste, and in any case he needs to explain the link more carefully. This is important! Does the market really create this sense of time? If so, how? Or does the sense of time reinforce the market ideology? -- which I might be more inclined to believe.

title: Camelot at Yale: The Construction and Dismantling of the Sapirian Synthesis, 1931-1939
text:
p.362 Events at Yale after Sapir's death in 1939

Sapir suffers first heart attack; decline of his control

while teaching at the LsA sSummer Institute of Lingusitics in Ann Aror in 1937.  This DArnell aruges "was the beginning of the disintegration of this [Sapirian] synthesis." (362)  Leslie Spier too over the chairmanship of anth at Yale while Sapir went o sabbattical in 1937-38, Seh Sapir was in NY under medical care. He died in February 4, 1939 after returning to work in fall 1938.

After his death Spier resigned as chairman was was replaced by George Peter Murdock (who Darnell has explained on 361) was a protege of Albert Keller (in-turn W.G. Sumner's heir at Yale who had been snubbed by James Angell when he brought Sapir to Yale and promised him an independent Anth. Dept., while Murdock was teaching physical anthropology in the Sociology Dept.)  (see 361).  Murdock served as chairman for 4 years and in that time shifted the ofucs onto arcdhaeology.  Both Sapir and Murdock had agreed that anthropology's focus was ethnology, but Darnell says "they envisoined differedkinds ofethnology." (362). "Murdock aimed at a worlwide comparative database, permitting quantitative, scientific generalizaitons.  His aspirations were epitmoized in the Cross-Cultural Survey established in 1935, which was the forerunner o fthe Human Relatoins Area Files." (362)  That is Murdock pushed Yale ethnology byeond N. America, a process she say was faciliated by WWII.

Darnell then brings up Anti-semintism issue in relatoin to Sapir.  She says that "Stories of anti-Semitisim and Sapir's exclusion from the Yale faculty club (actually graduate club) aboundin the oral tradition of American anthropology..." (362) She thinks this underscores a reticence to examine the transition of anthropology at Yale after Sapir's death... That's what she wants to explore in the article.

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text:
p. 139-140 Non-Personality in Modernism.

Despite Benedict' desire for more richly active forms of identity, the one Handler says she ultimately finds is an objective personality of the scientist.  Through this she achieves "hardness" -- though is it really hardness? -- that she couldn't achieve in her poetry he says.  He uses a Joyce quote to explain this non-personality.

"The personality of the artist, at first cry or a cadence or a mood and then a fluid and lambent narrative, finally refines itself out of existence, impersonalises itself, so to speak...The artist, like the God of the creation, remains within or behind or beyond or above his handiwork, invisible, refined out of existence, indifferent, paring his fingernails." (quoted on 140 from A portrait
of an artist...)

title: Sociology and Scientism: The American Quest for Objectivity, 1880-1940
text:
Bannister Notes

Intro

- 1920s saw objectivity get new life. The idea had originally come from Comte and had been important at sociology's founding in the 1880s. But now objectivity was more specific: would only study the "observable externals of human behavior, thus carrying to a logical extension the strict inductionism of sensationalist psychology." (3). This meant no more recording "feelings, interests, or wishes" that had been common among prewar sociologists. (3). B notes that ontologically this rested on a distinction between objects that were "accessible" and about which knowledge could be had and objects that were not. (3). Epistemologically it rested on experience as a keuy basis for knowlege. (3). It relied upon Lrigorous methods" and although this involved discussion od the case stufy, participant observation, and comparative method, statistics became most common. Above all, it equated objectivity with total neutrality. (3)

- Two versions of "objectivism": nominalist (Ogburn, Chapin) and realist (Luther Bernard). Nominalists see "society as the name for the collective responses of individuals" and so they thought sociology could simply statistically measure and tabulate "environmental change and...responses to change." (6). Social class then was simply a set of preferences for home funishings in one of Chapin's studies. For the realists the emphasis was on providing an "objective standard of social control" and so clear standards for social reconstruction. Bannister says these represent the two main components of Comtean thought: the passion for quantification as a path to "positive" knowledge and the Comte's "utopian" program. (6)

- These two camps established nodes of power in the 1920s but began to fight in the 1930s, ultimately makng way for Parson's "grand theory". (6-7)

-

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text: p.007-8 Anthropology in US serving needs of new nation Patterson frames the purpose of anthropology in the early republic in relation to the needs of the new nation in defending itself against the claims of Europeans like Georges Louis Leclerc and comte de Buffon who "asserted the inferiority of the New World, its inhabitants and their societies." Benjamin Franklin, James Madison, Thomas Jefferson all attepted to refute Buffon and those wh o follwed his arguments. Buffon text was his 1749 Natural History. The critics of Buffon in the US were affiliated with the American Philosophical Society that had been founded in 1743. (8) What rational develops? Rejecting Bufon's argumeent that the "New World" and its inhabitants inferior in "nature", Jefferson for eample in Notes on the State of Virgina argues that "nature" was the same in both places. Paterson says he puts forward a theory of nature like that of the "Enlightenment writers" (9) Humans themselves the same, differences form as resutl of environment and civlizational "stage" reached.

title: Voelkerpscyhologie and German-Jewish Emancipation
text:
Notes 5/2013

 

Read this article quickly, may reread. My brief summary is that Bunzl is here trying to show the centrality of German-Jewish emancipation themes to the way in which Lazarus and Steinthal formulated the discipline -- the two of them being key originators of the science. Previous examinations of the origins of the science have totally ignored the importance of emancipation (49-50). The analysis of the experience of emancipation by German-Jews is useful, see 60-68. Between 68-78, Bunzl shows how the politics of emancipation and interpretation of the Jewish "Geist" entered into Lazarus and Steinthal's formulation of the discipline. Then finally, the discipline does not take off. It's formulation is somehow outmoded when compared to the more sophisticated forms of cultural analysis established by the Berlin cultural scientists, Bastian, etc. But then also Bastian does not believe that languages are a reliable source of cultural analysis (78-79. It's Boas that carries it on to some extent -- and indeed he uses the phrase genius of a poeple -- and he has contacts with Steinthal and his student Benno Erdmann. (82) But also Boas' work "resembled" that of Lazarus and Steinthal in that he discounted race and focused on pscyhologicalan d historical processes, on "languag,e mythology, and art..." (82) And Boas' "overarching universalism..." (83) -- But thi spoint is not well worked out by Bunzl! He relies on Cole, Liss, Stocking, etc...  Then finally, on the last few pages he says Boas was not really like Lazarus and STeinthal in o ne key respect, that they did not take relativism seriously. (84-85).

The problem with this artilcle is similar to what I've noticed at other times in Bunzl. There's too much emphasis on rooting the Boasian line in a hermeneutic tradition in Germany, i.e. in th eline that extends from Herder to Humboldt (both of them) to the liberal anthropologists Bastian, etc, and in this case Lazarus and Steinthal, and then to Boas -- he being the missing link to the present that was necessary because German anthroplogy took the turn to the likes of Ratzel, Graebbner et al... i..e the Sonderweg.  It's relevant also that even though Lazarus and STeinthal are linked in here, that Bunzl makes it lcear that he's not challening that basic lineaage that goes through Bastian, Virchow, and the liberal anthropologists,, see fn# 120. What he suggests ther eimportantly is that the Lazarus and Steinthal link is just another node, and itmay be significant vv the four-field construction of Boasian science, i.e. he thinks that perhaps "Boas's four-field vision fused the ghree fields of Bastian and Cichow's scientific design with the humanist field pioneered by Lazarus and Steinthal..." (83)
