title: A category of the human mind: the notion of person; the notion of self
text: p. 18 - 19 Person as "moral fact" He thinks the Stoics helped develop the conception of the self into a moral idea. their "volutnarist and perosnal ethics were able to enrich the Roman notion of the 'person'..." (18) He cites a greek work that has same meaning as persona and says rrom 2nd Century B.C. that it came even more to mean something like character than or true face than it did mask, the "innermost nature of this 'person'." (18) But the word could also could indicate in other contexts the artificial or the "role-player" So in his notaiton personnage is the role player, the authentic is person or personne. (18) But latin and greek moralists betwee 200 -- 400 a.d. do something. Referring to the greek work again he says "is no longer only a persona...to its juridical meaning is moreover aded a moral one, a sense of being conscious, independent, autonomous, free and responsible. Moral conscience introduces consciousness into the juridical conception of law." (18) Mauss refer to Le Progres de la Conscience by M. Brunschvicg. The end i s that "self-consciousness (conscience de soi) has become the attribute of the moral person." (19)

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
0 p.xii "Female Dominion"

She wants to explain the "continuity [in white female reform efforts] by identifying an interlocking set of organizations and agencies that I have chosen to call a female dominion in the mostly male empire of policymaking." (xii)  Their territory of control was child welfare policy.  The important organizations were the Children's Bureau of the Dept. of Labor (creatd in 1912).  Women from this bureau went on to form state agencies that worked in concern with voluntary female organizations.  Educational branch was the School of Social Service Administration at U Chicago.  whihc trained women "specifically for the dominion's work." (xii) And the Women's Join Congressional Committee which Muncy calls the "lobbying auxliaiary" and which "offered critical support with federal legislation..." (xii)  

Finall it is important to note that she says "[b]y using the metaphor of dominion, I want to evoke a combination of autonomy and circumscription." (xiii)

NOTE: Muncy is really using the model of professions that sociologists have developed.  Work, education, and lobbying the three parts of a profession.

title: The Will to Believe
text:
General Notes

* The essay he delcares at the outset will be a "essay in justification of faith, a defence of our right to adopt a believing attitude in religious matters, in spite of the fact that or merely logical intellect may not have been coerced." (69) He notes that he has always defended this to his students who have always maintained he was wrong.

* First he lays out a distinction between live and dead hypohteses: "just as electrecians speak of live and dead wires, let us speak of any hypothesis as either live or dead." (70)  What he means is that there are certain choices that people face with regards to belief that are not actually choices because one side of the belief involves a choice that is essentially "dead" for them because makes no appeal to their belief.  A hypothesis is alive if it is "among the mind's possibilities." (70)  Then based on this he defines three types of choices: 1) living or dead, 2) forced or avoidable, and 3) momenutous or trivial.  (70-71)

* Then he wants to consider the "actual psychology of human opinion." (71)  Brings up Pascale's wager and notes that it seems silly or even vile--he quotes several people (Clough, Huxley, and Clifford) to the point that it is wrong to, in the words of Clifford, "to believe anything upon insufficient evidence." (74) But he differs.  What we believe is not determined by logic or reason, he says, says it again on 76 last paragraph.  The only things, he says, that we are uncapable of believing are dead hypotheses. 

It is only our already dead hypotheses that our willing nature is unable to bring to life again. (74-75)

What made a certain hypothesis dead he says was some "previous action of our willing nature of an antagonistic kind."  (75)  By willing nature, though, he does not only mean "deliberate volition" but also "all such factors of belief as fear and hope, prejudice and passion, imitation and partisanship, the cirucmpressure of our caste and set." (75)  (ie "culture" ??) 

* As a sub point he states the principel that "as a rule we disbleieve all facts and theories for which we have no use." (76)  He gives as an example the tendency of scientists (he uses scare quotes) to refuse to investigate telepathy. Elsewhere a bit later he pionts out that the whole theory of rational knowledge that the subject has of the object, the idea of "objective evidence" which he attributes to the scholastics is something that modern believers in "objective evidence" don't actually take part in--they simply "believe" in objective evidence and on the flip side, "They believe so completely in an anti-Christian order of the universe that there is no living option: Christianity is a dead hypothesis from the start." (79)

* Having explained this pscyhology of belief/opinion he then says that it ought not be seen as a pathological or reprehnsible situation; rather it is "a normal element in making up our minds." (77) 

* He lays out his thesis: "Our passional nature not only lawfully may, but must, decide an option between propositions, whenever it is a geniuine opion that cnanot by its nature be decided on intellectual grounds; for to say, under such circumstances, 'Do not decide, but leave the question open,' is itself a passional decision,--just like deciding yes or no,--and is attended with the same risk of losing the truth." (77)

 

 

* Key part of the essay: that there are certain opinions where it's not possible and indeed it is inevitable that they'll be decided by our "passional nature." (84).  James put's it this way: "I have said, and now repeat it, that not only as a matter of fact do we find our passional nature influencing us in our opinions,but that there are some options between opinions in which this influence must be regarded both as an inevitable and as a lawful determinant of our choice." (84)  On 85 he puts this a bit differently in terms of time, ie are there certain "forced options" in our speculation and can we in these ases "always wait with impunity till the coercive evidence shall have arrived?" (85)

* Moral Questions are one such instance in our speculative life he insisits.  He goes through this on 86-87.  "The question of having moral beliefs at all or not having them is decided by our will." (86)  This is true also in personal relations, such as friendship.  One cannot way for proof that someone is trustwrothy or that they like you...it's a matter of the "heart" or a "desire for a certain kind of truth..." that makes the difference.  (86)  Same also with the "social organism" he instists: "Wherever a desired result is achieved by the co-operation of many independent persons, its existence as a fact is a pure consequence of the precursive faith in one another of thos immediately concerned."  (87)  He gives a good example where the lack of that desired result is destructive to communal action: ie a train can be robbed by two highwaymen because the passengers fear that noone will back him up if he does something. 

* So: "There are, then, cases where a fact cannot come at all unless a preliminary faith exists in its coming.  And where faith in a fact can help create a fact, that would be an insance logic which should say that faith running ahead of scientific evidence is the 'lowest kind of immorality' into which a thinking being can fall.  Yet such is the logic by which our scientifici absolutists pretend to regulate our lives!" (87)

title: The Origins of American Social Science
text:
[Dorothy's use of intentionality in her study]
In the "Introduction" to her book Dorothy uses the word "decision" to describe the development of exceptioanlist American social science:  "A Still higher poing of scientific apirations was reached in the 1950s, when quantitative modleing, sytems of analysis, funcitonalism, and behavioral science gained wide currency, but the decision to seek out a ntural scientific path and the undelrying view of the social historical world asd a relam of natural process had already been forgted by the 1920s."  (xiv) I noticed also that she uses this word "decision" in her short entry on "American Exceptionalism" in A Companion to American Thought.  
I wondered what was at stake here.  The answer is twofold as I see it.  Firstly, it  is wrapped up with her methodological approach.  Secondly, it is tied to her own goals in writing about exceptioanlism.  
A few pages later when she is immersed in an explanation of her method she describes her approach as "intellecutal history which seeks to reconstruct the discourse within which social scientists worked."  At the end of this sentence she cites that her understanding of discourse comes from essays by Pocock and Hollinger on method.  Then she has the following sentence: "I understand discourse as conversation, developed over time, centering around certain problems, setting the terms of discussion over time, centering aroudn certain problems, setting the terms of discusison for those who enter itno it, and at the same time responding to different intentions of participants."  (my italics) (xviii-xix).
1) These two words "decision" and "intentions" are linked.  Dorothy is therefore giving an emphasis in her anlaysis to the intentions of her actors in theri writing.  This focus on intentions is I think modeled on Pocock and others' theorization of a model of discourse as being split between a language and various instances of speech acts in which the language is deployed strategically in a context to achieve a certain result.  DR epxlains this on xix.  In my own work, I think I have deemphasized intentionality a bit, trying to give a picture ina ny case of the characters as being a bit more awash in meaning.  That is consistent I think with the greater emphasis on a culture and on discourse as blinding things, on semiotic complexity as a result of polysemy.  As well as a sense that a speech act model does not really work very well in the early twentieth century in which discourses have become so complex, in which one might say the public sphere is in the process of shredding... 
2) The relation between her focus on intentionality and her goals became evidence on xxi when she talks about her  purpose in writing: "My larger purpose, for which I hold out less hope of success, is that by demonstrating the eextent to which social sciencei choices were rooted in history, I can suggest that those choices are open to rexamination.  Social scientists may have had 'good reasons' for choosing their scientistic path, but they were reasons consistently hemmed in by their historical intentions." (xxi)  Thus the pay-off of focusing on intentions is to suggest that social scientists were responsibly for the way their sciences were formed, and if they were responsible those intentions might be modified in the futre and other reasons for action developed....

title: Gender, Professional Knowledge, and Institutional Power: Women Social Scientists and the Research University
text: 00 Summarial Note 00 Article examines as case-studies the careers of different women at different universities in the the US in the 1920s and 1930s. Several basic conclusions come from these case studies: Most importantly, that there were severe limits to the openness of these institutions to women. The idea, therefore, that these institutions were open to women on a "meritocratic" basis is thus not so true: "There is no question that women were excluded from and marginalized in the 'meritocratic' modern university in the United States in the first half of the twentieth century." (67) Then a series of small conclusions are yielded: -- Everything varied by "institutional location." Dzuback summarizes her case studies this way: "In these cases it [limits of power for women] ranged from the extreme marginal position of the Harvard women to the near integration of the Berkeley women." (68) -- Philanthropy was key to the success of women's careers. Funds from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial fund for instance heped provide funding in different ways to many of the women in Dzuback's studies. (68-69) -- Support from male colleagues was also "critical to women's ability develop institutional power." ((69) -- Finally, Dzuback also finds that in many of her case studies, these women academics were at oddes with the growing scientism in social science after World War I> (70). One striking example of this that she gives is the work of Sophonisba Breckinridge and Edith Abott at The University of Chicago, where they opposed the socio-ecological model of the "Chicago School" social scientists. (67).

title: In Pursuit of Equity: Women, Men, and the Quest for Economic Citizenship in 20th-Century America
text:
p.003-6  The book's topic

Early twentieth century it was commonplace to distinguish between men and womens economically based on a conception of their different roles in thef family.  E.g. 1937 US Supreme Court sustains a Georgia law that allowed women to pay a lower poll tax"in view of the burdens necesssarily borne by them for the preservation of the race." (3)  Similarly, 1948, the Supreme Court upholds a Michicgan prohibition agains women working as bartenders unless they were the wives or daughters of the (male) owners of the bar.  The presumption was that in this case the men would look after the moral virtue of the women.  (3)

These decisions were normal at the time.  They fit into the general feeling that most men and women agreed upon until perhaps the 1960s that "the normal order of family life properly subsumed women within its boundaries, rendring their needs and desires as well as rights and obligations secondary to those of husbands and children." (3)

That general attitude governed traditional economic practices and institutiosn that we might describe as "traditional": "the sexual division of labor; disparate wages for male and female jobs; the feminization of poverty; protective labor legislation for women only; women's dependence on government welfare."  (3)

These practices K-H says were for many not thought to be "unfair or unjust" becasue they sustained a "comforting vision of family life and social order." (4)  If women were thus prevented from education or economic independence that was ok because they posessed a "protective umbrella to which men could not lay claim." (4)

BUT then in the 1930s, when the government began to construct a system of public benefits and tax incentives, they linked these policies not to family membership but to wage-work (benefits like old-age pensions, unemployment insurance, etc.)  This created two types of citizenship: one rooted in family membership and the other in wage-work.   At this time 85% of families had a single breadwinner and most marraiges tended to last the entire lifetime of an individual.  This reinforced the presumption that mostly male heads of households shoudl receive special benefits, an assummption that was buitl into a network of government policies.  It also reinforced the idea of a "family wage".  These special benefits began in the 1930s and were expanded after WWII.

So as the US begins to define its version of what T.H. Hulme defines as "social citizenship" that it links it to (male) wage-work and not citizenship or residency as is the case in most European countries.  And this pattern rests on the presumption that it is "fair" to assume that women will draw their livelihood from the family.

Such social policy left out those who did not fit the presumed demographic prrofile, including never-married women, divorced and deserted women (i.e. female heads of families), and African-American families whose male heads of household could not get work.  During WWII, married women who took jobs also found themselves in an "anomolous position as family members with paid employment." (5)  "Those who claimed social beneifts that accured to the fully employed seemed to be violating the standards of an employment-based citizenship." (5)  Women then began to notice the pattern of exclusion and by the 1960s, the idea that tax breaks or social beneifts should bre tied to gender and marital status did not seem quite that fair anymore.

That comes to the topic of the book:

"This book aims to explore how particular ideas of fairness became embedded in American social institution in the twentieth century.  It investigates how these institutions came to reflect claims to normalcy and to shape them.  It argues that gender-racialized gender--constitutes a central piece of the social imaingary around which social organization and ideas of fairness are constructed and on which social policies are built. And it tells the story of how gendered habits of mind--which I sometimes called the "gendered imagination"--framed discussion of what was possible and shape the politically plausible." (5-6).

The books builds on her earlier book on A Woman's Wage that explored the idea of a family wage.  (7)  She saw this "male sense of entitlement in jobd and wages" as permeating "economic life, reflecting and perpetuating the social organization of families, labor market opportunities, and the relationships of men and women in and outside the work place."  (7)  Specificailly it seemed to shape conceptions of "individual liberty" that were not presumed to have breen of value for women: "Ideals of service and sacrifice to children, parents, and spouse ahve often been though to render liberty for women irrelevant and women's search for individual rights 'selfish.'  Under this rubric, many Americans and their legislative assemlbies have felt free to treat women differently from men in many respects: refusing them the righ tot vote, to serve on juries, or to receive econoimc and social benefits in the same way as men." (7)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.147 General role of Anth

Psychologists had aruged that feminist raits were rootedin "social expectation." (147) undermining the idea that evolution had produced innate differences in the mind. (147)  But reformers were hesitant to grasp idea that one should therefore remove the division of labor.  "To interfere with this sexual specialization, many feared, was to risk returning to a simple and less highly evolved epoch by undercutting this most basic of social divisions." (147)  

Therefore it was important when anthropolgosits began to critique the genreal theory of cultural evoluiton.  (147)

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text:
p.018-19  Struggle over Anthropology at Chicago mid-1920s

Madden says that the sociologists at Chicago wanted to "carve up anthropology so that each subfield of sociology would have an anthropological component."  (18)  Fay Cooper Cole and R. Redfeld realized that anthropology at Chicago needed autonomy after a dispute between Benjamin Fairs a sociologist and Cole over the methods of Leslie White's dissertation.  (18) 

1929 - Univ "granted Cole and Redfield an indepdnent anthropology department." (19)  

1930 Sapir leaves for Yale.  Cole and Redfield the only fully-time faculty.  But there is money... Both the UNi and anth. dept. ahve close ties to the Rockefeller Foundation.  "Cole was able to secure $75,000 grant from the Foundation to support the department in the early thirties.  He also convinced Adolph Lichstern to leave a segment of his estate to chiacgo anthropology i 1931, otaling some $300,000.  With these large sums of money available, through the 1930s,  he built the most prominent department of anthropology in the United States." (19)

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.205 Charles Cooley and the "looking glass self"

It seems that Sklansky finds in the thought of Charles Cooley the crucial shift to a particulary extreme conception of the "social self" that was also theorized in his account by John Dewey, George Herbert Mead.

He also mentions James Livingston here on the idea of a 'cultural revolution' of the late nineteenth century and early twentieth centuries, in which an older understanding of self and society was decisively undermined." (205-206)  The Livingtson book is Pragmatism and the Political Economy of Cultural Revolution, 1850-1940.

In any case, Sklansky stars the chapter by noting that Cooley was "prodigously self-conscious" of what other people thought of him and that he assumed that this was also what selfhood meant.  (205) Cooley thus defined a "looking-glass self" and Sklansky quotes him here: "As we see our face, figure, and dress in the glass, and are interseted in them because they are ours, and pleased or otheriwse with them according as they do or do not answer to what we should like them to be; so i imagination we perceive in another's mind some thought of our apperance, manners, aims, deeds, characters, friends, and so on, and are variously affected by it..."  And: "We always imagine, and in imaginign share, the judgements of the other mind." (quoted on 205)

Sklansky writes then: "[Cooley's] pathbreaking studies of such 'imaginative sociability' entitle him to primary credit [of course Sklansky doesn't think this is good] for that master creation of modern American socail science, the 'social self.'" (205)

title: The Problem of American Exceptionalism: A Reconsideration
text:
Summary Note

This article serves as a survey of the problem of American Exceptionalism in the historiography of the United States.  From the 1970s onward Kammen argues that historians of the United States have been critical of "American Exceptionalism", which he defines as "the notion that the United States has had a unique destiny in history, or more modestly, a history with highly disctinctive features or an unusual trajectory" (6) This had meant more practically that they have been averse to making claims about the uniqueness of U.S. experience, society or institutions.  Kammen proposes to appraise the history and decide whether it is justified.  His tendency is to suggest that in fact one should not wholly avoid claims of the uniqueness of U.S. history and he shows at various points that even those scholars such as Eric Foner, Ian Tyrell, Sean Wilentz, Akira Iriye,  and C. Van Woodward that have made such claims have also in their work at times described certain elements of U.S. history as unique or distinctive.  One part of his article is to note that comparative history has been avoided or where it has been heeded the empahsis has been upon describing similarities and downplaying differences. He also points out that few skeptics of AmEx have noted the idea that to look at subnaitonal units might help get a handle on AmEx (3).  Much of the analysis of the disctinvnes of the U.S. that Kammen finds compelling has to do with U.S. political parties, labor groups, the power of business elites vis-a-vis the government, etc.  On Business elites see e.g. p.5.. .He summarizes claims of distinctiveness in the second to alst sectio 16-24.

I find this article weak analytically.  His definition of AmEx is vague and inconsistent.  It's quite a different thing for AmEx to be a simple claim that there is something distinctive about U.S. history and the idea that it has a special mission.  Also throughout the article AmEx seems often to be reduce simply to any claim that there is something distinctive at all about U.S. history, but in my estimation that is not what AmEx is at all.  My sense of what AmEx is connectss most closely to what he describes as "Americanism" or the "meaning of America."  (10-11, 26-27)  That is, the idea that the notion of America stands in somehow for history.  He comes close to it when he says that "The 'meaning of America,' so rich with moralistic implicaitons for the future, and for people not fortunate enough to be Americans, perhaps sered as a surrogate for history." (26)  But Kammen doesn't quite get it, and he seems not to have engaged with DR's work at all (was it not published yet?).  He discusses her on 26, but then has no citation in the footnote #72.  He seems to conclude with this idea at the top of Section IV that "we are obliged to acknolwedge the swiftly spreading perception that 'every country is different'..."  But that is just not a claim that opposses AmEx.  I don't think that to claim that the U.S. has unique features in its history (which from a historistic point of view is almost an assumption) but rather that AmEx is a form of antionalist ideology.  He gets at this on 26-27, but it's sort of an aside...

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1053 "Ideology" of Professionalism Obscured Conditions

His point here is that for some professions, he mentions law, professionalism was effective in serving practiioner's interests, "effectivley controling entrance into the field." (1053). 

Not so for Social Work -- and for women in general --  "For women...professionalism as an ideology and an identity obscured shifting working conditions job autonomy and middle-class living standards.  Professionalism stil lshaped how these owmen oranized and defined themselves, but women in professions such as social work found achievements illusory and problematic."  (1053)

title: The strange death of the authoritarian personality: 50 years of pscyhological and political debate
text:
Notes:

 

  • The strange death of the authoritarian personality: 50 years of pscyhological and political debate

    Type Journal Article
    Author Martin Roiser
    Author Carla Willig
    Volume 15
    Issue 4
    Pages 71-96
    Date 2002
    Date Added 9/2/2009, 11:29:31 PM
    Modified 9/2/2009, 11:29:31 PM

    Tags:

    • Authoritarianism
    • Authoritarian Personality
    • Critical Theory
    • Fascism
    • Psychology
    • The Self

    Notes:

    • 000 Critique 000 I think their attack on the focus on "perosnality" is interesting. I was thinkin gthis in response to Geyer's idea that there were different contradicting publics proposing different forms of identity in Weimar Germany, that people were trying to sift through these in his piece on "Resisistence Studies." Was it then the multiple and unstable idientities that was the problem? Does the "modern self" need to be premised on a singular and stable model? The authors propose a preventative and dynamic and never-ending awareness of certain attitudes that when they come into existence might be combated. But then this is a rather compromised solution. On the other hand, if one doesn't compromise does this mean that one needs to posit once again a singular "healthy personality structure" as Adorno et al put it in The Authoritarian Personality"??

    • (1) p.073 Early studies by Frankfurt Institute of Social Research into Fascism & personality Studies carried outin 1920s (they cite Fromm, 1984, The Working Class in Weimar Germany) this study they say "described a minority as having authoritarian attitudes." (73) Then citing Horkheimer, Fromm & Marcuse, 1936 Studien uber Autoritat und Familie, linked these attitudes to (non-german) family structure more generally part of "advanced industrial society." (73)

    • (2) p.073 Continuance of Research in U.S. Nazis closed Frankfurt Institute and many fled to U.S. There they continued work on authoritarian personality. Study in 1930s showed anti-semitism in U.S. among 1/3 of workers. They didn't publish for politial reasons. Then after the war they were able to expand the project and that led to the publication of <

    • (3) p. 073 - 074 The Authoritarian Personality Published 1950, this book argued sesenailly that °the human raw material for a revival of fascism was present in contemporary America." (74) Inquired in particular into the "authoritarian personality". They designed four scaled: Anti-Semitism, Ethnocentrism, Political and Economic Conservatism, and the fourth "Potentiality for Fascism." (73) This last they say focused on "personality rather than attitude." It was called the F-Scale and its 9 components listed on p.74. table 1: They are Conventionalism, Authoritarian submission, Authoritarian aggression, Anti-intraception, Supersitition and Stereotypy, Power and toughness, Destructiveness and cyncism, Projectivity, and Sex... The method. Questions were asked and answered on a scale from +3 to -3 (then transferred ontol a scale of 1-7, with 7 as most authoritarian and 1 as least.) Type of questioning called a Lickert (as opposed to Guttman) scale. Described as folows: "A scaled of this kind asked Americans to indicate how close to them they would allow people of particular races and nationalities to come: to their country, state, county, neighbourhood, street, and so on." (73) Initial study applied to 2,000 people in California. In addition 80 individuals that scored high and low on Ethnocentrism were interviewed about "upbringing, family relations and career aspirations." (74) And these 80 were given Thematic Apperception Test. Findings then indciated a "number of types, groups of subjects, who showed consistent patterns of scores on the various tests and indicative characteristics in the interviews." And they focused on the "authoritarian perosnality types" in the study. "which "scored high on scales of Anti-Semitic, ethnocentric and conservative attitudes, despite the variety of content, and also scored high on the F-scale itself." 74) (74-5)
    • p.75-8 Reception of Study In 40s Am. social psych. community receptive. They were interested in prejudice and conformity. In particular those psychsthat belonged to "the Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues (SPSSI) whose publication, the Journal of Social Issues, together iwth the Journal of Abnormal and Social Psychology, had an almost campaigning approach." Notes work on "action research in Times Square" and "how to confront the anti-Semitic bigot in public situations." (75) Also works like Achieving Inter-cultural Understanding and Co-operation in a Democracy (1953) by Saenger Criticisms of study focused on methods and how certainly such a "authoritarian persaonlity" could be said to exist. E.g. M. Smith reviewed it and thought it useful, that it showed that "there is something there" but they needed better instrumetns to detect it... (75-76) In England Henry Dicks who had been studying "personality traits and national socialist ideology among German prisoners of war" (76) early came to know about the study. Dicks then went to work with Edward shils at U.Chicago. (76) In 1965 Roger Brown summarized in his Social Psychology the social and political importance of the study. Noted that it had entered popular culture and the popular equivalent of "authoritarian" was "bigot." As such he argued that it had "become part of popular culture and a force against racial discrimination." (76) Hofstadter also picked up the idea in his The Paranoid Style in American Politics (1966)...he took from it the notion of "pseudo-conservative" and quoted the book directly. The quote was: "The pseudo-conservative is a man who, in the name of upholding traditional American values and institutions and defending them against more or less fictional dangers, consciously or unconsciously aims at their abolition." Hofstadter contrasted such pseudos- from true conservatives who he described as "temperate and compromising...in the classical sense of the word..." (76-77) Authors argue that what then came to be known in the 50s as "McCarythism" bore, at leaqst in account of Richard Rovere's study, a "striking resemblence to those [traits] that emerged from the [The Authori. Pers.}" (77) Thus as wartime alliance with Russians forgotten and as "'international communism' was replacing fascism as the perceived threat to world peace" the ideas of the study seemed perhaps to apply to the new attitudes developing twoard the Russians and the communists. But the authors note that Sanford for one, even in midst of the Univ. of Calif. that was requring employees to take a loyalty oath, that such attitudes were not necessarily authoritarian... (78). But Sanford and 45 others did not sign, and then Sanford and Edward Tolman were dismissed, and then reinstated in Nov. 1952 after a court case. The authors then write, however, "[w]hile the attack on individuals was rapid an ddirect, the critique of ideas was extended and more complex." (78)

      Tags:

      • 1940s
      • Intellectual History
      • Richard Hofstadter
    • p. 78-87 Critiques and Left-Right Authoritarianism As the argument developed, basically the notion of the authoritarian personality was co-opted/critiqued by a group of psychologists that are a component of neo-conservatism. Most importantly, E.A. Shils posited the idea in a book ed. by Richard Christie and Marie Johoda entitled "On the Method and Scope of the Authoritarian Personality" (1954). Shils ' article entitled "Authoritarianism, Right and Left" argued there was a left-authoritariansim, that it was similar or worse to right-authoritarianism. Shils critiqued the political spectrum of the Authoritarian Personality as too linear, going from fascist to "complet democrat". The authors write: "...for Shils, the 'complete democratics' of the study were crypto-communists." (80) And: "Shils proporsed to aggregate the categories of right-wing and left-wing authoritariansim, stressing what he saw as their essential similarity." (81) This move by Shils was important...it elevated communism to the new enemy, positied its similarity in these psychological terms, to fascism, and prepared the ground for the "End of History" that would come after 1989... In '93 Stone and Smith noted the political significance of this dev.: "Many former liberal commentators and social scientists caught the spirit of the times and perceived the threat posed by Communism. Among the intellectuals so affected were Norman Podhertz, Daniel Bell and, most notably, Edward Shils...The term 'neo-conservative' came to be applied to these former liberals." (80) But authors' note that Shils' category had little empirical basis in his original articles. (bottom 81) In section "The search for the Left Authoritariansim" 82-84 a aseries of empirical projects attempt to "discover" this left-authoritarian personality, but it is not easily found apparently. Hard to study too also b/c in U.S, ironically, lefties b/c of McCarthyism too scared to be identified as such , see 82 for their note. Defense of the argument of Authorit. Personality came from Bob Altemeyer, Canadian, who "developed a Right-Wing Authoritarianism (RAW) scale to explore three attitudinal clusters: authoritarian submission; authoritarian aggression; and conventionalism." And he designed a scale to measure left-wing, but then concluded ultimately that this left-wing authoritarianism could not be discovered: "Is there an authoritarian left? No, not if you are talking about Shils' left, not if you require evidence. Lots of people have looked in several different ways in several different countries for this creature of lore. But no one has found it yet." (quoted on 85). And the authors say that "Altemeyer's work is clealry in the tradition of The Authoritarian Personality..." (85) They quote him in '86 essentially repeating in 1996 the claim that authoritarianism could happen in the U.s. too... After fall of the wall, there was a search in the ex-communist countries, but there too much of the authoritarianism seemed to be right-wing they argue... (86-87)

      Tags:

      • Neo-Conservatism
    • p.87 The "end of History" and the Authoritarian Personality The authors' first note that the original authors of Authoritarian Personality believed the problem to be exposed to historical contingency. The authoritarian person Horkheimer wrote as "an 'anthropological' species...[that] seems to combine the ideas and skills o fthe highly industrialised society with irrational or anti-rational beliefs." (quoted on 87) The authors therfore write "any change in the political economy of industrial society should be examined for its impact on the human psyche generally and authoritarianism in particular." (87) The authors' note Fukyama's argument and the idea that there was a world-wide liberal revolution. They point out that Fukuyama also implicitly invoked an argument about psychology. He wrote: "no democracy without democrats" (88) But he had only the outline of a perosnality type through the classical theorists e.g. Hobbes' man in state o fnature on up to the "last man" at the end of history. Others developed it, including the JJ. Ray who was the last advocate of the existence of left-wing authoritarianism. He wrote in "The Death of Authoritarianism: Psychological Parallels ot a Political Phenomenon" that this peronality type was disappearing even in communist regimes where even "Communist Party members were now denying authoritarian attitudes in their questionnaire response." (88) The autors though think that this idea of the "Ne World Order has not fared well" due to "choas in the countries of the former Soviet Union and in the newly industrializing countries of the third world. The concept of world-wide revolution has proved problematic." And they add the neo-libera economics are now "associated with a renewed political authoritariansim." (89)

      Tags:

      • Francis Fukuyama
    • p.89-93 Contiued research The authors then argue that there has been continued reseach, that despite the statement that the authoritarian personality was dead, it has not died. And it seems to continue to be discussed. The critique they ultimately endorse is that the original book focused too closley on "personality" that is they say on "character" as opposed to "cummulative and attitudinal" dimensions that would stress the ability to understand why authoritarian personalities may turn to the exercise of fascism and when and, most importantly, how it can be countered. (see esp. 91-93) Imp. for this conclusion is the point also that the original book did little to get at the question see 91. In the original book they had written only in terms of prevention in terms of encouraging a "healthy personality structure..." But what would this be? What is a helathy personality structure? What is a personality structure? Is ther eonly one "healthy personality structure"????

    Related

    • p. 110 - 111 Mead's Notion of Freedom (her Liberalism) Sullivan says she only described it negatively. It wasn't a prodc

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text:
p.186-187  Temperament, Sources

186: IN 1933 Mead app. not yet aware that sex differences were not innate...  

In "Summary Statement of the Problem of Personality and Culture" from 1933 she still stated that these ideas were right.  Still working with maternal and paternal (M and F).  

186-187: In stating the problem of "reproducing one's kind" she says that in addition to process of conception, physical shape etc, Temperament is important.  

187: Temperament.  Mead was probably drawing on  William McDougall who she mentions in Summary Statement.  She knew him as studend at Barnard while earning her masters sullivan says.  His theory of temperament is McDougall, An INtroduction to Sociology (pub. orig. 1908)others... An outline of Psychology 1923; an outline of of abnormaly psych. (1933)...   McDougall used the word ""to refer to those psychologicla and emotional propensities or tendencies that arise directly out of the person's innate biological inheritance..." (187) Building on Jung, introver and extrovert were his primary examples. 

Jung had also written of this (this is the primordial self that Sapir speaks of?) and Jung had seen them as being rooted in biology.  Because they were "little affected by 'conscious judgement or intention' yet are 'universal psychological phenomen[a], must in some way or other have biological precursor[s]" (187)  (From Jung, Pscyhological types or the pscyhology of individuation, 414 in 1923 ed; orig pub 1921.)  And Jung also thought they overran the sex distinction.  Jung wrote: "Furthermore, these types over-rdie the distinctions of sex, since one finds the same contrasts among women of all classes..." (187) (see p.413, of 1923 ed.)  

Mead wrote then  in the Summary Statement that family inheritance was operational and not "sex inheritance"  (187)

title: Professions and Patriarchy
text:
Summary Note

Witz has noted a gap in the scholarship on the sociology of professions.  She puts it clearly:

"The 'sociology of professions' has a somewhat dated and staid aura about it, perhaps most associated with fairly turgid and 'Whiggish' accounts of professional men (cf Carr-Saunders and Wilson 1933, Reader 1966).  The traditional sociology of the professions was thoroughly criticized by Johnson (1972) as long ago as the early 1970s for uncritically reproducing at the level of sociological knowledge professionals' own definitions of themselves as possessing distinctive characteristics that marked them off from the ordinary run of managers, administrators, clerical workers, and the so-called 'semi-profesionals' such as radiographers, nurses, and physiotherapists.  More recently, much attention has been paid to the relationships between professions and the class structure, and this focus has led to a radical recasting of sociological approaches ot the study of professions.  But within this new critical theory of the professions, little attentions has bene paid to the relation btween gender and profesisonalisation." (1)

She notes that there has been a link between professionalisation and gender.  She notes in particulary Etzioii's 1969 book on the "semi-professions," but later work she notes has deployed rather simple ocnceptions of gender that "rely on explanations whic hrefer to the gendered attributes (such as women's association with 'caring' work) in order to read off the subordinate realtion of, say, nursing to medicine." (2)  Such accounts see gender as static and leave untheorized certain "gender-specific attributes, attitudes and 'problesm which women 'bring to' professional employment." (2)

That leads to a tendency to look at thechallenges women face in "adjusting to typically male career patterns" when joiing male-dominated professions: namely, the dual-role problem of being mother and professional.

In seeking a more complex understanding of the relationship between gender and the professions, Witz says the concept of patriarchy must be introduced.  She notes that the concept has been much debated but that it is now used by "contemporary feminist scholars more braodly to refer to ender relation in which men are dominant and women subordinate.  It therefore describes a societal-wide system of social relations of male domainnce (cf Millet 1972, Hartman 1979, 1981), not simply those in the family/household." (3)  So against patriarchy's critics (Bradley 1989, Crompton and Sanderson 1989, Acker 1989, and Rowbotham 1981) she thinks it is useful in examining the complexities of gender relations in the modern system of professions. (3)

In Part I of the book she wworks out how patriarchy relates to the professions.  In Chapter 1, she states her belief that the dual-system theroists are best able to conceptualize women's position in the professional labor market.  Chapter 2 seeks to understand why and how "the generic concept of profession is also an impliitly gendered one" (5).  In Part II, she looks at differnet historical cases.  The most interesting for me is her examinaaiton of radiography where she notes men failed to exclude women.

Witz makes a lot of use of a line of analysis of occupations stemming from Johnson and expanded by neo-Weberians that understand professionalisation as a means of controlling an occupation.  It seems to me that this line is also influencing Abbott, but would need to check.  Abbott's jurisdictional dispute theme is almost present in Witz's anslysis but not as well worked out here.  See for examqple p.47 when she talked about "occupational imperialism" which I believe Abbott also discusses.  Or her discussion of "demarcationaary strategies" and "inter-occupational control" on 46.

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.42 Torn Countries and Homogenous Ones

Homogenous ones usually pursue band-wagoning.  Torn ones, ones that "have a fair degree of culturla homogeneity but are divided over wheter their society belongs to one civilization or another." (42) are interesting.  Turkey is a classic case.  He notes that it applied to the EU, that it has this secular "western" background, that it allied with the WEST i Nato and in the Gulf War, but its elites see it as essentially Muslim.  He quotes Prsident Özal who said °we are Muslim and they are Christian and they donàt say that." (42) He notes also that b/c of fall of S.U. Turkey sees a chance to revive Turkic civilization and now encouraged b the west, "Turkey is making strenuous efforts to carve out this new idenity for itself." (42) 

 Mexico is another exampel but not as severely, though impotantly for the U.S.  (42-3)

Russia now again has become a torn country 43-4. 

Requriements for redefining civilization: elites onboard, public on board, acceptance by domiance gorups in "recipient civlizatoin" (44-45)

Larson refers in a cpule of places to the phonemonon that Abbott calls in System of Professions "degraded recruitment" that process as larson puts it by which "[r]outinzied skills are delegated downward, while skills that are reocgnized as higher concentrate at top levelsin the ideal-typical model of modern managment." title: The American Woman's Pre-World War I Freedom in Manners and Morals
text:
p. 324-5  New Ideal of Female Figure: The 1914 Girl

A 1914 Girl described in a April 7, 1910 edition of the Boston American: "The '1914 Girl' with her 'slim hips and boy-carriage' was a 'slim, boylike creature.'  The 'new figure is Amazonian, rather than Miloan.  it is boyish rather than womanly.  It is strong rather than soft.'" (324)

Dress styles he says demphasized hips and bust and permitted large
waist.  1912 women began to "tuck-under" their hair with a ribbon.  by 1913-1914 Newport laides like actress Pauline Frederick or Irene Castle were wearing short hair.

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1069 - 1074  Professional Woman

So here Walkowitz presents his construct of the Professional Woman , which he says reflects the "dissonance created for female social workers by their negative image in mass media and the contradictory circumstances associated with their professional work, and... emerged from the multiple culturla exchanges between workers clients and their public audience." (1069) 

She possessed he said "some mal eattributres, but she was careful not to appear to compete with or threaten men." (1069)  Instead, she maintained her status by trying "to keep less qualified {page} women out of the field." (1070) 

He notes the AASW's effort to conter bad press in the movie "It" and that they did so by celebrating "male" values of objectivity. (1070) 

He then looks at self-representations.  and here he says "Their unstable, and contested ideas of gender and professionalism suggest the confusion and pain with which some caseworkers respondedot the image of the female social worker as an aggressive, ambitious New Woman.  The stories make clear tha tfeamle social workers felt torn between their roles as women and rpfessionals, each of which emboied in different ways the qualities of 'good ' social work.  They also were frustrated by their inability to afford the accouterments of middle-class status." (1070)  

So he finds a series of different profiles.  A woman who is scatter-brained but can learn from her boyfriend how to organize herself, and then she has a good sex life with him. (1070-1)  Women who are organized but have trouble meeting men.  They are "too smart, too intimidating to potential male suitors." (1071)   And they don't have enough money to set up a home that can attract "'comfort-loving' desirables." (1072) and they have become "narrow, self-absorbed individuals" unable to talk about general things with "outsiders" (1072).

Note that the authors in f.n. #44 praise Abbott saying, "His work has been very useful in deelopoing our pserspective on the female-dominateed professions." (296)

title: Graphs and Legends: Raymond Williams tried to save culture from a priestly elite. Can the same be said of the digital humanities?
text:
Moretti, Graphs, Maps & Trees

 

## 1. Graphs

    •    He opposes the treatment of every article fact in its individuality. He thinks Literary canons are "collective systems", must be understood as whole. (4) His "graphs" are one way to do that.  He sees this as a "more rational literary history". (4) Quotes Braudel.
    •    Three layers of time, drawn from. Braudel quote: event, cycle, the longue duree. The middle level, cycles, that literary historians deal with less, is really genre, which he calls Janus-faced things, part history, part form. (14) Cycles, genres, are "temporary structures within the historical flow." (14)
    •    Following some genres, he wonders is there a consistent lifecycle of genres? (18) The answer is he finds yes: "Normal literature stays in place for twenty-five years or so." (20) So there is a rhythm, but why? He thinks the key in some cases is the simultaneity: one form fails to deal with the historical situation. But when several forms vanish at once, it must be the audience disappears. So generations! (20-21)
    •    Important methodology fn on 25, #14. That a quantitative study is also profoundly formalist because the form is what establishes some homogeneity in the data. (25) Interestingly, he then points out the asymmetry between the "quantitative explanandum and the qualitative explanans" that leaves you "with a clear problem" but no solution. He suggests admitting that we have questions for which we have no answers , especially because it is possible that we turn people off by talking about themes about which we only have answers. (26)
    •    Finally, what he does conclude is that what his quantitative data shows is that "the novel" is itself not singular. It is a "system" of rhythmically developed forms. So it's a theory of diversity that his analysis reveals. (30)

 

## 2. Maps

* Question: are maps useful in literary history? He

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text:
p.050-53  Anth on Brink of WWII

Again madden's very useful analysis of specific institutional situations. 

@ Yale --> Sapir had been uanble to find funding for his projects.  He was in ill health towards the late 1930s and died in 1939.  "Institute was dominated by the young behaviorist psychologists determined to test Freudian psychoanalysis empirically, and the behaviorists accepted Murdock's structuralist approach more readily than Sapir's intuitive approach to cultural research." (50)

@ Chicago -->   Cole trying to "codify loosely the discipline of anthropology as a four-field body of knowledge." (50).  In 1937 he restructure the anth dept to include specialists in all four-fields.  (50)  Walter Krogman (physical anthropology); himself as archaeologists; Redfield (cultural anthropologist) and Harry Hoijer (linguist.).    But this was not a systematic unification Madden insists. (50).  More significant was the "Division of the Social Sciences" within the College of Arts and Sciences.  (50-51).  

Funding-->  Large institutions had "complex relationship with anthropology."  They wanted interdisciplinary work, but anthropologists were able to "pry" money from them enough to hold together the four-field model.  (51) 

But Ethnology increasingly dominant Madden inssists.  And yet despite this dominance also eclectic still.  Even Mead's call for a science that could set people free in And Keep Your Powder Dry he thinks emphasized what Robert Merton had called "middle range theory" -- theory that does not present a broad paradigm but deal siwth specific premises tailored to each project.  (52-53).

title: Über das Verhältness des transscendentalen zum metaphysischen Idealismus
text:
Notes September 2014:

* Lehmann starts out by saying that what Kant had said over the thing-in-itself (Dinge an sich), namely that the thing-in-itself was the ground of the appearance of the objective world, had a primarily epistemological meaning. And yet he notes that it is in fact it is a the expression of a metaphysical conception, which can be seen as the quintessence of a kantian metaphysics. (346)

* So there is not so much of a surprise, he thinks, that post-kantian metaphysics has mostly been lnfluenced by this element of kant's philosophy. (346)

* He describes German philosophy as developing out of Kant in this way, until it reached Schopenhauer, at which point it took a turn that seemingly led it back to its point of origin. And this shift, in Schopenhauer, demonstrated he says what changes (Wandlungen) the basic principle of the critique of reason needed to suffer( erliden) in order to become the basis for a new dogmatism ("ehe sie als metaphysische Grundzuege einer neuen dogmatischen Weltanschauung reproduciert werden konnten." (346-7) That in fact he says was Schopenhauer's method, in so far as he had one, namely the "transference of the epistemological concepts of Kant into the metaphysical..." ("in einer durchgängigen Uebertragung der erkenntnisstheoretischen Begriffe Kant's ins Metaphysische" (347). He says that when it came to Kant, Schopenhauer's philosophical system consisted of a series of such hypostatizations of epistemological concepts and opinions ("sine philosophisches System, soweit es sich an Kant anschliest, besteht aus einer Reihe von derartigen ypostasen erkenntnisstheoretischer Begriffe und Anschauungen.") (347) Behind this accusation of hypostatization is the idea that this was a key part of Kant's critique of reason, that one should *not* hypostatize ideas! See here: http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2009/entries/kant-metaphysics/#HypSub

* Given this he notes that if the "scientific principles of the critique of reason" ("die grossen wissenschaftlichen Grundgedanken der Vernunftkritik") are not to be lost than there will be a need to go in a very different direction and in fact to start again, "von neum zu beginnen." (347)

* So here is where Lehmann locates neo-Kantianism: "Der Neu-Kantianismus, welcher diese Aufgabe ergriff, hat sich vornerhin mit derselben Entscheidenheit der erkenntnisstheoretischen Seite der Transcendentalphilosophie zugewandt, mit welcher die bisherige Speculation sich an die metaphysische gehalten hatte." (347) Or: "The neo-Kantianism, which seized this task, seized the epistemological side of transcendental philosophie with the same determination that the previous speculation (?, is this a reference to Speculative philosophy) had sized upon the metaphysical." (347)

* He thinks that a metaphysical dogmatism, which entered into Kant's system against Kant's own will, is basically inconsisent with the ends of the critique of reason, the "Endbasichten der Vernunftkritik." (347) And he thinks that the teaching of the thing-in-itself ("die Lehre von Ding an sich") is the weakest part of Kant's philosophy, and yet it is this part of Kant's thought that was of the great service to Schopenhauer. (347) In fact, he sees it as the "chief task" ("Hauptaufgabe') of modern Kantian philosophy to "excise: the concept of the thing-in-itself from the critique of reason. ("Den Begriff des Dinges an sich aus der Vernunftkritik zu entfernen, durch Ausmerzung dieser wunden Stelle den Reultaten der Transcendentalphilosophie wissenschaftliche Exactheit und dauernde Unerschütterlichkeit zu verliehen, darf man denn auch geradezu als die Hauptaufgabe bezeichnen, die sich die moderne Kantphilosophie gesetzt hat." (348) His language gets quite good here. The goal is he says is "to change the course of the fundamental teachings of the critique of reason in such a way that disposes of all the metaphysical slag/scum, and in this way to secure the epistemological results..." ("den Grendlehren der Vernunftkritik eine Wendung zu geben, die sie aller metaphysischen Schlacken entledigt, und eben hierdurch ihre erkenntnisstheoretischen Resultate dauernd sicher zu stellen.") (348)

* Here again he says it was this task, in part throuhg essentially kritical and negative means  ('zum Theil wesentlich kritischem und negativem Wege"), that neo-Kantianism took on. (348). "One searched for a point from which one could develop Kant's ideas in order that all the residual dimensions of his teaching would fall away." ("den Rest seiner Lehre fallen zu lassen.") (348) By the residuum here I assume that he's referring to the metaphysical dimension, die Lehre vom Ding an Sich." 

* He sees this effort as starting importantly with O. LIebmann's book "Kant und die Epigonen". The goal of this book is to separate the durable from the non-durable in Kant's philosophy. (348) He notes that even H. Cohen, who he describes as having hoped to remain truer to the form of his philosophy that Kant himself gave it, still ended up throwing out the concept of the thing-in-itself, which in fact was only mentioned once in the critique of reason. (348)

* Yet he points out that it has ow become clear as a result of these efforts by neo-Kantians that the problem of modern philsophy is by no means easy to solve. The metaphysical concept is so grown together ("verwachsen") with Kant's system that it is impossible to cut it out without "rebuilding the entire structure." ("ohne den ganzen Aufbau von Grun aus umyugestalten.") (348) He uses as an example the fact that the most significant ('bedeutendste") of all the neo-Kantians, F.A. Lange, had found it useful in his "reproduction of Kant's fundmantal teachings" to include/carry over/continue (hinuebernehmen) the concept of the thing-in-itself. (348) And he notes that it is also for this reason that those who have opposed Kant have doubted that his philosophy can do without it, and in fact, he notes that all those who have opposed Kant ahve suggested that all those who have tried to work through Kant's teaching on the thing-in-itself to estalbish the possibility of expeirence, have in fact demonstrated its impossibility. He cites here E.v. Hartmann in particular. (348-349)

* Then he has some sentences where he seems to say that the thing-in-itself is not the "essential seed" ("eigentlichen Kern") of the critique of reason. And that even for those who think that the thing-in-itself is essential, it is still not the case that "metaphysical idealism" is the consequence of "transcendental idealism." (349)

* Then he seems to begin an exercise where he wants to go through the logic in a bit more detail. He wants to reflect a bit on each of the "oppositional claims" ("gegnerischen Behauptung").

 

* First he lays out what he thinks is a general understanding of Kant's funamental metaphysical point of view. This comes on top of 350 and it reads very well for me:

Die ganze sogennante reale Welt mit allem, was in ihr bleibt und vergeht, ist das "Product unserer Sinne und unseres Verstandes", erbaut aus dem Stoffe der Empfindung, gestaltet durch die Formen unserer Anschauung und unseres Denkens; ja auch was wir unser Ich zu nennen pflegen, der anschauende und denkende, fühlende und wollende Mench ist nichts als Phänomen von einem tief in ihm selber leigenden, nie erkennbaren, weil selbst nur immer erkennenden Bewusstsein. Aber doch ist diese Welt, aber doch ist der erkennende Mensch kein blosser Schein, keine "absolute Illusion", vielmehr liegt alledem etwas völlig Reales, an sich Wirkliches, zu Grunde, von keinem Werden und Vergehen berührt, aber auch von keinem Erkennen zu erreichen. (350)

* Yet the issue that arises from this viewpoint is the question about what "bridges" these two worlds -- i.e. the world of appearances and the unknowable world of reality that lies behind, i.e. the thing-in-itself. How can we link our thinking to that which underlies our thinking but which we cannot think. "[können wir durch unser Denken verbinden, was unserm Denken nich errichbar ist? und wenn wir es nicht können, wer gibt uns das Recht von jenem ewig Unerreichbaren auch nur zu behaupten, dass es existiert?" (350)

* Kant believed the bridge lay in fudnamental concepts which he linked to sensory perception. The "stuff" of our conceptions (Anschauungen) is given form by the spontanous function of thought, and it is through this process that the "objective" or "empirical" world is constructed ("gebildet"). (350) Therefore the impressions or conceptios of the world that we have are neither entirely objective or subjective. They can't be "explained" in that way. They must be "gewirkt" in relation to the "thing-in-itself." (350-351)

* But this was the weak point. Because Kant had here laid out a situation in which a "Verbindungsform" (namely the relationship of our though to the empirical world), which he himself had understood to be subjective, stood as the basis upon which to establish the existence of the thing-in-itself. And this was thent he point of attack for opponents of Kant who then argued that it was "inadmissable" by means of sensory impressions to establish a causality that leads to the "Real". ("dass es unstatthaft sei aus ser Dinnesempfindung vermittlest der Causalität das an sich Realze abzuleiten.) And then from here they drew the conclusion that the real consequence of transcendental philosophy was that sense ipressions are entirely subjective. And this conclusion was the "Ausgangspunkt" for the entirely following development of idealistic philosophy.  (351)

* And this led also to the stand point of what "theoretical egoism" (??) that developed among Kant's followers and most famously Fichte. Fichte's point of view was that one could only take up one form of indepedent being, either that of the subject or that of the subject, and not an autonomy that is changing and based on both ("nicht aber eine wechselweise Selbstätigkeit beider."). (352) To build a subject on the objective world corresponded for him to matieralism, and yet this point of view made it impossible to explain consciousness (Bewusstssein) and knowledge (Erknenntniss). And yet on the other side it was already clear in Kant's categories and in the paralogisms (???) that the empirical world is only accessible if one moves from the subject outward and does not leave the self. But Fichte, he notes, put postitively what Kant put negatively. Kant said:

dass wenn ich das denkende Subject wegnähme, die ganze Körperliche welt wegfallen muss (quoted on 352)

But Fichte put this:

Sowie das Ich nur für sich selbst sei, ensteht ihm zugleich notwhendig ein Sein auser ihm. (quoted on 352)

 

* He then has this excellent summary of different explanations of "Vorstellung" i.e. imagination or understanding. Sensualism he says saw Vorstellungen as the effect of the objects. Transcendental philosophy saw it as the product of the thing-in-itself and the form of our intellect. Theoretical egoism saw it as the consequence of the subject. All three he says make the same mistake that they imagine that they could establish an absolute relation between the subject and the object. (352)

* But here is where Schopenhauer came in, noting the unresolvable causal link between subject and object, and he then rethinks Vorstellungen as that experience of the subjet wherein that relation between subject and object is totally decomposed, so that Vorstellungen has two parts, subject and object. But for Schopenhauer this leads to a relativity of the world as imagination/understanding. His phrase was "diese gänzliche und durchgängige Realtivität der Welt als Vorstellung.") (353) So for Schopenhauer there is really no true reality that is not divided into these two broken parts, the subject and object. So that he's not convinced of the existence of the object, like Ficthe, or the subject! And in this way he says Erscheinung is made into Schein, i.e. appearances into make-believe. (353). With Schopenhauer he ultimatelz says the concept of idealitaet has essentially posisted a second reality...and then in thi sway he suggests that transcendental idealism became something like a very dogmatic realism that had little relationship to the contents of the critique of reason ("einen sehr dogmatischen Realismus, der zum Inhalt der Venuftkritik keine wesentlichen Beziehungen mehr hat.")  (353-4)

* So at this point he says it must seem as if, if one follows out this line of thought that Kant's critics traced, that the critique of reason with the teaching of the thing-in-itself ("Lehre von Ding an sich") cancelled or overcame itself. That this whole structure, which Kant had intended as a bulwark against metaphysics, collapsed as soon as the metaphysical component was withdrawn.  But this whole train of consequences ("Consequenzug") itslef relies one conlusion/set of conclusions, the proof of yet has yet to be examined. So he wants now to examine that. (354)

* Now he traces this. Kant believed that you could not establish the form of concepts as something originating in the subject itself. This subjective element was not sufficient ("hinreichend") to explain the fact of concepts. The explanation of of these concepts required the recognition of a sphere completely outside of the subjective sphere, the impact of which on the subject precipates the process that we call sensory perception ("Sinnesempfindung.")

* Now the post-Kantian philosophers saw the inadmissability of this derivation, and they argued that since sensory perception came just as little from a real world of "things-in-themselves" as from the objective world, it must therefore come be explainable through the subject. (353) He wants to hold off on whether this was a good understanding of the l aw of causation for the moment, and intead look at what warrants this conclusion ("Schluss"). (353-354)

* First he defines the point of view more carefully: My summary/translation: So the idea here was that thinking is a process that goes on totally within the subject, that it is a function of understanding "Verstandnes", and as such is something spwaned or generated ('hervorgebracht") only in the subject and conditioned by the forms of thinking. And so also the forms of sensory impression ("Empfindung") are based entirely in the chracter/nature of the subject. So that all that is in the Subject that has being has its origin in the nature of the subject, and that all that in sensation is not fixed but has a changing content ('wechselnder Inhalt")  also has its origin entirely within the subjective domain. (this whole summary on the top of page 355).

* Then he goes into a long two page story involving a quoation from Kant in which Kant describes how we could imagine that the world was so constituted that we never really saw the sun, and so that the change from day to night would be understood without the rise of the sun.  And in this case, in this "situation of things" ("Zustand der Dinge") it is possible that the philospher might never intuit the existence of the sun because it isn't really a thing, but in fact it is still possible through the acceptance ("Annehmung") of a hypotheses from some cloud body such a phenomenon to explain. (355) Then Lehmann works through this example in a bit more detail over the next few pages (355-357). What he concludes is that in this case the best the kind of knolwedge that is arrived at is really just a kind of analogical conclusion ("Analogienschüsse") and thus  it is in the best case a mere probability ("blosse Warscheinlichkeit"). So this is I think a way of playing out starting with a statement from Kant the post-Kantian idea that perhaps our sensory perception and our concepts originate in the subject, and the result he finds is that this is just probability, not real knowledge.

*But then he says, well, maybe this isn't really what the idealists were arguing at all. Maybe their point was really that our sensory perceptions do not originate from the objective world or from the subjective. This it seems is the line where idealism just appears to lead straight to a total illusionism, as his Hartmann had said : "die streng logische Consequenz jeses erkenntnisstheoretischen Idealisms der absolute Illusionismus" sei." (358).

* He goes through this a bit vv Fichte, and then on 359 says that really idealism has a lot in common with realism (here I think he means those who see sensory perception and subjectivity as determined by the object): both he says make use of a false law of causation. So he's pushing away (in a way typical of neo-Kantians) from both a pure realism and a pure idealism. Both he thinks do not emerge necessarily out of the critique of reason. (see 358 - 359).

* But then he wants to raise a doubt. Given that both the post-kantian idealists, and in fact Kant himself recognized this contradiction or inconsistency: i.e. the difficulty of building a bridge between subject and object. Is there then a hidden cause here that explains somehow why the idealist philosphy and its set of conclusions become so widely recognized? ("Sollte hier nicht noch ein Grund verborgen sein, der es, wenn nicht berechtigt so doch yum mindesten begrieflich erscheinen lässt, dass das grössere Recht der idealistischen Schlussfolgerung so allgemein anerkannt worden ist?" (359) His answer is that if we look at the motives of the idealists that yes there is such a cause or reason, but it is a historical one and not a factual "sachlicher" one. (359)

* When Fichte tried to establish the forms of connection and conception out of the nature of the subject, he was directly contradiction Kant, who had clearly stated that this was not possible. Yet Kant ("der Vernunftkritiker") did not link sensory perception fo the subject because he had linked sensory perception to the thing-in-itself. That is, it was Kant himself who provided the impetus ("Anstoss") for idealism because he himself stepped over the limits of knowledge ("Grenzen der Erkenntniss."). (360)

* The key part here in Kant's thought was his "trascendentl deduction of the the categories." Here he attempted to show how the Categories, these a priori concepts that could be grasped or conceived out of the world of objects ("Gegastaende"), also were useful and valid pure concepts of understanding that derived from the fudnamental nature of human kowledge and understanding. In order to establish this, Kant had to dissect Erfahrung/experience into its three elements: intuition (Anschauung), the Categories (Kategorien), and self awareness (Selbstbewusstsein). So he creates a whole new theory of experience, which he then names "transcendental" and sets it against the notion of "empirical deduction" and also he identifies its purpose using the definition that in the introduction to the critique of reason he defined as transcendental, namlely that they can prove how are concepts of objects are a priori.

I think what Lehmann is getting at here is what Scott Edgar in his article "The Limits of Experience and Explanation: F.A. Lange and Ernst Mach on Thigns In Themselves" as one of the key problems in Kantian philosophy that the neo-Kantians never resolved. The problem was that they wanted to believe (with Kant) that things in themselves could be inferred as the cause of our sensations, as the reason we have sensations in the first place. On the other hand, they also believed that our concept of cause itself is itself pscyhologically conditioned. These two ideas contradicted each other. If causality is a subjective thing, then we cannot say that our sensations are caused by things in themselves.

Lehmann does not say this specifically but it seems as though he is working through the same issue. His point is that the post-Kantian opponens of Kant noted this problem.

* Then on 362 he says, though, thtat the problem with the post-Kantian critics was that they only saw that contradiction in the chapter on Phenomena and noumena, and they failed to realize that the same contradiction is wrapped up with the deduction of the Categories ( as I thin he showeed on 360 in his discussion of Kant that is so hard to read). Instead they simply adopted the idea and enlarged it like Fichte, or they tried to supersede or replace it with a simplyer and more natural scientific and more valid although still problematic like Schopenhauer did. (362, first paragraph).

* What Schpenahuer did he says was to just saz that the relation between subject and object had nothing to do with the principle of causation. ("dass zwischen Subject und Object gar kein Verhaeltniss nach dem Satz vom Grunde stattfindet.", Schopenhuaer quoted on 362)   But to do this Schopenhauer had to work with the same inconsistency as Kant, or what he defined as the apriority of the casuality principle "Aprioritaet des Causalitaetsbegriff" (Schopenhauer quotedon 362), i.e. that it was known apriori.

* Now here he make an interesting jump. What Schopenhauer ultimately points to is the way our conception fo causality is significantly intuitited through knowledge that is the result of impression of the real world. As he puts it: "dass schon yur Bildung unserer Anschaungen das Causalitaetsgesetz ein wesentlicher Factor ist, dass nach seinem eigenen Ausdruck 'die Anschauung der wirklichen Welt durchaus Erkenntniss der Ursaache aus der Wirkung ist'" (362, bottom). But this idea has been confirmed mostly, he says, by empiricical research from the last decades -- that he calls brilliant and pleasing -- but which h e says confiirmed the transcendental knowledge much less than it confirmed the Kants deduction of the categories. (362-363) It seems here that he is speaking of empirical psycyhological research, but we shall see.. In any case, he know literally speaks of the "Schopenhaurisch derivation of the outer world out of sensory perception" and says that Schopenhauer attempted to "base causality not only consistently on the latter [the sensory perception of the outer world], but in fact also the perception not simply as a process of understanding, but as an excitement of the sensory organs, and established this as "real." ("Den diese Schopenaur'sche Ableitung der Aussenwelt aus der Sinnesempfindungen und der Kategorie der Causalitaet begruendet sich nich nur durchgehends auf diese letztere, sondern fasst auch die Empfindung selbst nicht als Vorgang im Verstande, sondern als Erregung der Sinnesorgane, setzt somit auch diese als real voraus." (363) Then he says it explicitly that Schopenhauer's intervnetion here was "significant" ("bedeutungsvoll") for empirical pscyhology as well as for the psychology of sensory organs, but he repeats what was validated here was not the transcendental nature of experience. But rather

title: Lost Manhood Found: Male Sexual Impotence and Victorian Culture in the United States
text:
p. 37 -  19th Century: Separation of sexuality and reproduction 

Over nineteenth-century things shift.  Advertisements move toward cures for impotence, things designed to "increase desire"  or "cures sexual weakness." (37)

Mumford links this to a "historical separation of sexuality from reproduction." (37)  This the resultsof rising use of abstinence, contraception, abortion by northern middle-class whites, who "cut their rate of fertility y half." (37) 

Out of this came also a new moral distinction by Protestants between sex for reproduction and sex as expression of romantic love. (37)   This further produced new focus on non-procreative sexual acts, e.g. the works of physician Benjamin Rush or reformer Sylvester Graham.  They are asking about the conseuqnces of nonreproductive sexual activity.  Imagine it can causes "debility" a depletion of the nervous system.  Rush formulated this as being caused either by too little or too much stimulation.  (38)  This new "scientific conception" of impotence, linking sexual activity to physical and nervous debility formed between 1810-1850 by Rush, Graham and frenchman an dphysician Claude-Francois Lallemand. (38-39)

Thisconception of debility is also linked to the movement of young men to the city.  (39-40)

title: A history of experimental psychology
text:
# Edwin Boring, *A History of Experimental Pscyhology* (New York: Appleton-Century-Crofts, c1950, originally published 1929)

> Note Sesssion 10/12: Reading for Mainfold Origins Project, trying to understand what Paul Guyer called the "pscyhological aesthetics" of Fechner, and also trying to get a better sense of the psychological roots of neo-Kantianism in say Helmholtz.

## Ch. 13 German Pscyhology before 1850: Kant, Herbart, and Lotze

* German pscyhology and the "new psychology" rooted somehow in Leibnitz. Boring doesn't specify how here. (246)

* Kant: Kant had been a discipline of Leibnitz and his interpreter Chrstian Wolff. (247) His effect on pscyhology Boring says was 1) that he "favored *subjectivism*, keeping alive the aith in the importance of thosem ental phenomena which can not be reduced to brain or body processes." (247) and 2) he supprted *nativism* in theories of space: ie that space and time are *a priori* intutitions and not properties of the external world. (247) Kant was trying to reach a compromise of sorts between Hume's skepticism and Berkeley's nominalism. Boring says "He undertood to place the contributions of the mind intheir proper sphere over against the things-in-themselves, those 'outside' object which the mind can never know directly." (248) His *categories* were furnished by the mind in making sense of the data of expereince; he named 12 categories for instance unity, totality, reality, existence, necessity, and so on. And he treated space and time as Anschaung, frequently translated as intutition, but themeaning better communiactd with the German word because it "implies that the spatial arranement of objects is given in perception." (248) Finally, Boring says that what Kant was doing was "re-estabilshing Cartesian *dualism* for pscyhology," which had been threatened by British empiricism. He sees Kan't sinfluence as making it "natural" for Herbart, Fechner and Wundt to "take the mind for granted" and to set up experimetnal pscyh as an attempt to "systemize itself as a science of consciousness." Elsewhere in France and America it was easier he thinks for psychology to become "objective."  Kant's *nativism* also very influential (249)

* Herbart: Herbart was following up more directly on Leibnitz than Kant. He had been influenced by Kant as a young man but rejected his doctrines in his doctoral degree in Goettingen. Herbart then took Kant's chair in Koenigsberg in 1890 (Kant died in 1809). His pscyhology: he denied that pscyhology was an experimental science; instead, he deemed it a science grounded in math and metaphysics. That is, he also saw philosophy and metaphysics as wihtin the purview of *Wissenschaft*. (251) It's basis in metaphysics and in mathetmatics is what made pscyhology distinct from physics, which was an experimental science in his view. (252) Herbart's pscyhology was however mechanisistic. (253) Herbart' sbasic unit was the idea or *Vorstellung*. Ideas had an intensity or force (*Kraft*) that had to do with their clearness.
