Ideas also strove to preserve themselves; that is, they are also active in his conception. And they can be "inhibited." He wrote: "Every movement of ideas is confined between two fixed points: their state of complete inhibition, their state of complete liberty." (quoted  on 255). Due to this conception of ideas as active, Boring says "Herbart is seen to be a dynamic psychologist, ftting into a line of successino from Leibnitz to Freud." (255) Herbart's notion of inhibition was key because it began a ilne of thinking about the "unconscious." For Herbart, ideas were not destroyed by being inhibited. They just ceased to be a reality and became instead a tendency. He also posited the idea of a "limen of conscisouness"; thatis, a "limit that an ideas seems to overleap in passing from a state of complete inhibition to a state of real idea." (quoted on 256) All this gives a picture of the mind that Boring describes: "It is plain that the composition of consciousness at any moment si the resultant of the mechanical interplay of many ideas. Of all those ideas below the limen, only those taht fit in with the unity of consciousness find so little resistance that they can rise above. Thus we have the appearance of the conscious idea of 'selecting' from amon thsoe that are unconscious the ones taht are consontant with thesmelves." (256) Here Herbart uses the Leibnitzian concept of *apperception*: an idea that rises to consciousness for Herbart, as with Leibntiz, is *apperceived*. Apperceiving is the rising to consciousenss of an idea as well as its "assiimialtion to ta totality of consciouss ideas, which Herbart called the 'apperceiving mass.'" (257) Based on all this Boring states that "Liebnitz foreshadowed the entire doctrine of the unconscious, but Herbart actually began it." (257)

** Skpped the section on Lotze **

## Ch. 14 Gustav Theodor Fechner

* Fechner, Boring wants us to understand, gave birth to the "embryo" of experimental pscyhology. It was not all new because there had been born already a pscyhological physiology in Johannes Mueller and E.H. Weber. And a philosophical belief in a physiological psychology: Herbart, Lotze. (275)

* Fechner's contribution, according to Boring, was primarily in devising new methods for measuring in experimentation. (293) and in his formulation of psychophysics as a science as "an exact science of the functional relaations or the relations of dependency between body and mind." (quoted on 286)Theidea came out in his *Elemente der Pschyhophysik*. (282, 286) Boring notes that Fechner also founded "experimental esthetics" in his *Vorschule der Aesthetik*. This was the b"beginnign of the use of the mthod of impression in the experimental study of feeling and estehtics." (282)

* Boring goes into detail on Fechner's pychophysics after 284. It was a lot of equations that I don't think I need to follow. But equestions!! that being the point. He also note that Fechner's also distinguished between inner and outer psychophysics. Inner psychophysiscs was more on "inner psychophysics" that is "the relation between mind and excitation mot immediate to it"  (292) Outer pscyhophysics dealt more with the relation between mind and stimulus.

## Ch. 15 Hermann von Helmholtz

* Helmholtz was born in Potsdam in 1821. His main contribution was not necessarily to psychology. His greatest contribution was in the "experimental pscyhology of sensation" that he prenseted in *Optik*. (302) Theother important work is *Tonempfindungen*. Boring says that the impact of the publiication of thse books in the 1860s was bery big. Boring puts it this way: "Fifty years before, physiologists had much to say about vision and hearing, the hsitoric sensses which Newton discussed, and little abut the other senss. Then E.H. Weber wrote the first thoroughgoing psychophysiology of the cutaneous and other bodily sesnes (1834, 1846). Now Helmholtz, like Newton in having the physicist's point of view but writing when the meaning of psychology was becoming a little more obvious, was placing vision and hearing again in the van among the senes about which enough was known to permit the writing of scientific texts. Fechner showed the psychology could employ the scientific method of measurement. Helmholtz showed what could be done in research and in the accumulation of facts in the two leading sense-departments. the movemnt toward a pscyhological science was already under way." (303)

* Helmholtz, Boring notes importantly, was still someho wnot an experimetnal psychologist because he "thought of psychology as essentially physiological, and of physiology as essentially physical." (303) He saw pscyhology in other words as an exact science rooted in math. (303)

* Because of this empirical-experimental focus, Helmholtz stands more closely to the British empriicists than to the German one that extends fro Liebnitz, to Kant, to Fichte. (304) Helmholtz ultimately then rejected the tendency in this line to believe in intutitionism, aka the doctrine of innate ideas, or a prior judgements or native categories of understanding. (304) Later this became a conflict between geneticism (those who rejected intutitionism) and nativism (those who accepted it). That is, Helmholtz, Lotz, and Wudnt against Hering Mueller and Stumpf. (305)

[Note: this is where we can begin to see the start of the specifically neo-Kantian forumlation, a desire to ground mind in a scientific account of human physiology...??]

* Helmholtz rejected the doctrine of "nativism" -- the idea that space and time are native to our perception -- which is linked with Kant and which Ficthe had also made central to his philosophy. Boring quotes Helmholtz at length on 305 in his rejection of that theory, and the description of his alternative: the empiristic theory. The basic idea was in Helmholtz words that "no other forces are necessasry for their origin beyodn the known faculties of our minds, even though these forces themselves may remain entirely unexplained." (305) What this meant essentially is that the axioms though which we perceive are themselves products of our experience. E.g. Helholtz thought that "sphere-dwellers" would have differen geometric axioms since for them for example the axiom of parallels would not hold because any two straight lines would necessarily converge at some point. (306)

* Helmholtz also had a notion of the "unconciousns" that was the doctrine of unconscious inference (*unbewusster Schluss*). Boring explains this as having two key ideas: 1) that "perception may contains many experimental data that are not immediately represented in the stimulus" and 2) that "these aspects of the perception that do not immediatley represent the stimulus are, in a sense, additions which accrue to the preception in oaccordance with its development in past experience." Ie these are "inferences" that are however unconcious. Boring provides a quote from *Optik* describing the idea on 309.Boring then describes the parts of this idea in detail on 310 and 311.

* Perception. Helmholtz distinguished between a sensory pattern that is based entirely on the "stimulus-object" , which he called Perzeption and thought very rare, between experiences of things that are mixed with an "imaginal incredment, dependent upon meory and induced by unconsiocus inference, which he called *Anschauung*, and finally impressions totally disconnected from stimulus from outside = *Vorstellung*. (312) Here Helmholtz like Mill and those before him want to say something about the "object." For Helmholtz the object was "nothing more than an aggregate of sensations, an aggregate which has been formed in experience because the sensations ahbitually occur together, and which is not analyzed into its sensory constituents except by a special act of attention." (312)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
Histories of the Other
text:
[Summary Note]
Hegeman reviews two histories of Americanist anthropology.  She generally likes Patterson's book more than Darnell's because Patterson examines the history of anthropology in terms of its relationship to and implication in U.S. history.  His study i.e. is "situated squarely within both the larger social and cultural concerns of the US and the institutiosn and funding soruces the allowed the disicpline to flourish."  
By constrast, Darnell's study is less to Hegeman's liking because it is less focused on contextualizing anthropology in relation to U.S. history as it is in examinging the Boasians and less so their broader context in order to use them to "assert the continuites that exist in the project of North American anthropology..."  I.e. the Boasians are ancestors, and as Hegeman divines partly her historiographical agenda is to use disciplinary history to "correct the tendency among anthropologists to emphasize the theoretical and topical novelty of their current research at the expense of historical self-awareness and contextualization." (628)  In particular, she's trying to work against the reflexive anthropology of the mid-1980s assocaited iwth aworks like Marcus and Fischer, Anthropology as Cultural Critique or Clifford and Marcus, Writing Culture who focused on writing practices of anthropologists, their connections to quesitons of power an dauthority, the status of ethnographic knowledge, and relationship of anthropology to other genres such a autobiography, memori, travel narrative, etc etc.  She tries to show that the Boasians too were concerned with these problems and dabbled in similar experiments, and then accusses the reflesive anthropologist of the mid-1980s with "postmodern nihilism."  (629)  For Darnell, the most experimental of the anthropologists is Sapir.  (629)
Besides the larger criticism, Hegeman points out that one signficant problem with Darnell's analysis is that she glosses over the different nature of the mid-1980s anthropological project and the Boasians'.  She takes Hegeman to be saying that the Boasians were "moral relativists" and agrees with her, but Hegeman wants to distinguish between moral relavtivism and epistemologcial relativism whcih was the concern of the mid-1980s reflexive anthropologists. (630).  She notes how this emerges in Darnell's analysis in particular in her analysis of Radin's Primitive Man as Philosopher (1927)...here the epistemolgocalo relativity was more present, but Darenll minimizes that aspect of the work and instead focus on the them of "cross-cultural inquiry." (631-2)
What however is most interesting about Hegeman's analysis is the way she situates her study.  She frames her discussion of the two books by the suggestion that discplines are like cultures.  That is just as anthropologists study others, so a historian studying anthropologist can be seen as studying an other.  These histories are doing just this, and her preference for Patterson's study is that he does not seek to artificially unify the discipline.  That is Patterson's study of the other may fit with the kind of anthropology that Hegeman prefers, that is one that does not attempt to reconstruct a unified and coherent culture of th eother, but demonstrates as she says of Patterson's study "emphasizies a more contentious and complex history...[focusing] on the fact that anthropologists working in the US were citizens, patriots, radicals, conservatives, technocrats, bureaucrats, academics, and intellectuals." (636)  
Other thoughts:

title: Lost Manhood Found: Male Sexual Impotence and Victorian Culture in the United States
text:
p. 34 Male sexuality not "transhistorical" phenomenon.

Notes failure in focus on female sexuality by historians (citing e.g. Nancy Cott 's essay on "Passionlessness" and Degler's "What Ought to Be and What Was: Women's Sexuality i nthe Nineteenth Century" and Carroll Smith-rosenberg's Disordrly Conduct).  

Says this gives impression that male sexuality is transhistorical.  It is not, and he places himself in line critique from" antebellum female moral reofrm critique of male licentiousness" to 1970s critique, that has also made same point.

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text: p.023 Amartya Sen's argument significant for feminism "...because if generalized conditions lik poverty can be established as a barrier to freedom, perhaps patriarchy can be similarly established." (23) She then moves through theories of Philip Pettit who defines freedom in terms of "non-domination." (26-28) But she rejects his idea that domination can exist without interference (27). "For unless there is some actual interference, some material instances of the power of the dominant figure...has to interfere, the power of domination will weaken. If the dominus never interferes with the actions of the dominated, the vigilance and self-restriction of the dominated will wane, boundaries will be tested and stretched..." (27) Her example is that women are afraid to go outside b/c they know that women actually have been raped (27-28)

title: The American Woman's Pre-World War I Freedom in Manners and Morals
text:
p. 330 - 333 Efforts to control morals evidence of shifts


McGovern also aruges that evidence of the shift in morals can be seen in efforts during hte Progressive Era to control them.  (330-1)  See examples on 331-333.

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.026-27 Notions of Common Good...

And yet Sklansky notes that there were also ideas about common interest or good propounded in the Revolutionary Era that exceed thefocus on enlightened self-interest.  He cites Rev. Nathaniel Niles' "Two Discourses on Liberty" (1774).  Niles had orthrodox Calvinist view that that property was given to mankind commonly and then certain parts apportioned to different individuals.  But inusing this land these individuals should keep an eye on the good of the community.

Another more radical example: Joel Barlow,part of a literary circle known as the "connecticut Wits", served as epic poet and army chaplain in the War of Indepednece.  Barlow, like Niles, also "suboridinated individual property rights to the supreme authority of society as a whole." (27)

Sklansky's point here is that "[t]he revolutionary implications of natural right and social contract, both at the core of American political economy, appeared to lead him [Barlow] beyond the proprietarian premises of the classical social science itself." (27)  And that "the ideology of equal rights on the one hand and the identification of political rights with access to the means of production on the other fueled a growing struggle over social inequality." (27)

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text:
p. 276 Women's History has also let out women

They note that the absence may have to do with ambivalence about women historians' own professional success.  "...the failur eot tackle head-on hisotical issues in female professionalization may well reflect the ambivalence of women historians about the meaning and consequences of professionalism in their own personal lives.  In fact, the contemporary feminist push for professional opportunites has all the characteristics of a love-hate relationship.  Women rihglty demand equal access to and treatment in professiona life, yet when professional success arrives often question both the social relations and the values implied by their new status." (276)  

It may also have to do with focus on writing history from the "bottom up" -- which has come from the Annales, E.P. Thompson and the "new social history." I.e. focus on working classes so as not to give women's history a Whiggish charater. (276)

title: Reading Obama: Dreams, Hope, and the American Political Tradition
text:
2. Chapter 1

* Kloppenberg thinks that Obama has the best grip on "America's past than any president of the United States since Theodore roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson," i.e. Progressive Era presidents!  Is this really true? (2)

* K thinks that Obama's ideas have confused political observers beacuse they don't understand that he is a "hybrid of old an dnew"--that his ideas are a prodcut of a deep engagement with American history and politics. So if we want to understand him then we have to understand "how he sees the present in light of the past, and also how he envision the future in light of his own--and his nation's--place within a global community tht has undergone dramatic and unprecedented cultural transformations." (3)

* K refers to Obama's December 9, 2009 Oslo Nobel speach where he refers to the fact that the rise of transnational institutions, human rights, and globalization has caused people to "fear the loss of what they cherish in their particular identities,--their race, their tribe, and perhaps most powerfully their religion." (3) K adds that this is a tension betweeen "universal against particular"  which is "the central dynamic of the twenty-first-century world." (3)

* K thinks that Obama's first twoo books "provide a blueprint for American politics." (3)  Audacity of Hope he thinks "provides a diagnosis of contemporary American problems and offers a roadmap of political possibilities."  (7)

* In Dreams K notes Obama had originally thought to write about race relations in America, but he was then "pulled toward rocker shores" (Obama's words, 8).  He looked at the "tangled roots" of his own identity and what he found did not provide much consolation K says.  His look into his past provided no "degree of stability, let alone tranquility." (8)  "Instead, both America and Africa presented endless challenges and puzzles, the 'rockier shores' on which his and his relatives' fantasies ran aground." (8)  K writes nicely here on 8-9 about how O's questions upset his family narratives, created eddies and pools etc...and"undertwos taht upset his equilibrium, coplicated his own sense of self, and, even more treacherously, disrupted th epersonal and cultual narratives that had inspired him as a child." (9)The book also is part memoir and by Obama's own indication a kind of "mdiation on central themes of his life.." (9)  This space between fiction and nonfiction reinforces the sense of instability and complexity in the self that is the main theme of the book. (9)\

-->  Note: getting into discussion of Audacity, K refers to O on top of 10 as a "progressive."

* The experience of being stranded and uneasy also generated by his epxerience of politics as a community organizer wehre he found his own ideals "bouncing off the hard surfaces of self-interest and political partisanship." (10)

* K says he will put Obama's in two contexts "in order to illuminate the cultural framework within which he came of age, the historical patterns that have shaped his sensibility."  (10)  His story is an American tale on the one hand, K says, but also "a journae lived at a time of deep cultural self-examination and contestation, w hen thinkers were seeking, finding, and then rejecting foundations of many different kinds." (10)

* K traces Obama's experience growing up in Hawaii with white grandparents and how this led him to an awareness of the doubleness of his identity that K likens to that of the Ellison's Inivisible Man whose central character refuses to decline into despair.  (14-15) Obama instead realizes that the asnwer must lie in the transcendence of hatred.  But he was also isolated in this quest...he lived with a white family but because "of his invisibility, Obama would never be known by whites as he could know them.  As he became aware of that condition, and his double consciousness, he began to understand his predicament.  Even though he was surrounded by a loving family, Obama 'realized for the first time taht I was utterly alone.'" (16)

* Then at Occidental, Obama is exposed to the great political thinkers in a calss with the political scientsist Roger Boesche...O says in Audacity that he wanted to study political philosophy because he was "looking for both a language and systems of action that could help build community and make justice real." (quoted on 17).  Buty he struggled with the "iconoclasm" and waht K describes as "valueless, post-Christian nihilism" of thinkers like Weber and Nietzsche and then on the other hand the struggle to "make justice real."  This tension K argues was a key tension driving Dewey and James to formulate their philosophiacl pragmatism. (17).  Obama was also exposed at Occidental to post-colonial and anti-imperial thinkers likes Frantz Fanon so that he could consider himself "alienated from white America." (18)  At Occidental he also began to develop an identity fro himself as a writer (19)  He also became more political and became involved in the "Sotuh African devistment campaign and the Committee in Solidarity with the People of El Salvador..." (19)  He was not impressed when a friend of his declaered hereself not black but "multiracial"; K writes: "She was running away from the hard fact of race in America.  Whatever individuals might think of themselves, to whites they were black.  So was Obama..." (19)  It was at this stage that friends began to call h a sign im Barak and not Obama, and he "accepted it as a sign of his authenticity." (19)  He was being pushed also by others to accept more respoinsibility.  A friend of his whom he calls Regina told him to take off the "armor of uncertainty" "that shielded him from his fear that he berlonged to niether the black nor the white world." (21)  And K writes he also felt he was being pushed by

"his teachers, his mother, his grandparents, by unknown people in South Africa, CEntral America, Indonesia, and across America forced to uendure poverty and injustice.  All were demanding more from him.   'They all asked the same thing of me, these grandmothers of mine.'  They asked just waht the grandfather in Invisible Man demanded.  theyw anted him not just to survive or endure, they demanded that he shoulder a burden that he did not ask for, but that feell to him nevertheless, a responsibility to affirm the principle.  But there was a problem.  Obama was attracted more to the questioners--to Emerson, Nietzsche, James, and Niebuhr--than to those with the dogmatic certainty animating political activists.  How could he reconcile his own dobuts with his grandmother's pleas?" (22)

* At Columbia--an exchange with Occidental--Obama felt marginalized from student life at the College, was "growing more attuned to the issues attracted student protests and tot eh problem of poverty that continued to plague American cities," (24) and also found that the radicalism associated witht he earlier generation of civil rights had in his words "shattered into a thousand fragments." (quoted on 24).

* He next goes to do commmunity organizing in Chicago's South Side.  He was 25 at that point.  He is recruited by Gerald Kellman to work in the Devloping Communities Project, which is an offshoot of the Calumet Community Religious Conference.  He learns community organizing techniqes from Kellman, from Mike Kruglik and Gregory Galuzzo.  According to Kruglick K says Obama's "core beliefs" were already formed at that point:

...[he] knew from experience--and from reading St. Augustine and Niebuhr--that humans are prone to selfishness.  He knew that the promise of American demcoracy had been squandered by plutocrats and that progressive reformed has tried but failed to redeem it.  He knew that political ideas such as liberty, equality, and justice are always at risk because of the pervasiveness of evil and the tragic disconnect between noble intentions and unanticipated consequences.  He knew from Madison and Tocqueville that American politics begins with individual interest, and he knew from the Federalist and Democracy in America that democracy can work only if poeple create institutions, associations, and political strategies to transform self-interest into the public good.  He knew about affirming the principle, but he knew that a gulf separated individuals' existential choices from effective political mobilization. Obama arrived in Chicago with a mantra he said he had learned from Martin Luther King, Jr.: Love without power is mere sentimentality.  Power without love is dangerous.  Love plus power equals justice.  Obama wanted to learn how to do the sum....(26)

K says that this mantra was the same one taughtr by the "father of community organizing," Saul Alinsky.  Obama learned a version of Alinsky'sp rinciples from Kellman, Kruglik and Galuzzo.  Alinsky's ideas came from his training with the Chicago sociologists Ernest Burgess and Robert Park, and from the idea of expanding John L. Lewis ' "confrontational strategies" to communities and not just the shop floor.  Lewis had used his ideas to build the Congress of INdustiral Organizations.  Alinsky saw these ideas could be used to empower communities.  K gives a description of the technique of an organizer that came from Alinsky and which Obama excelled at: a good organizer will not try to bend people's ideas to his interests, but "takes the time to listen to many comments, rephrases questions, and waits until the indivdiuals in the group begin to see for themselves waht they have in common.  A skilled organizer then patiently allows the animating principles and the plan of action to emerge from the group itself." (28)  Obama however was frustrated by organizers' distrust of politics and could not understand why "alliances across denominational ines or racial lines proved so difficult to sustain." (29)  K connects this to Madisons' frustration with "factions." (29)

* In an article entitled "Why Organize? Problems and Promise in the Inner City" published in Illinois Issues in 1988 Obama alid out a point of view that only "a combination of electoral politics, economic development, and community organizing could address this multidimensional crisis..."  (32)  K says he advanced an argument similar to Tocqueville's: that "[w]e must find a way to 'knit together the diverse interests' of people's 'local institutions.  This means bringing together churches, block clubs, parent groups and other institutions in a given community.'" (32)   This had to be doen through public participation and so Obama wrote, again paraphrasing Tocqueville K says, that getting people involved inc ommon projects "enbles people to break out of their crippling isolation from each other, to reshape their mutual values and expectation and rediscover the possibilities of acting collaboratively--the successful prerequisites of any successful self-help initiative." (32-33)

* Obama had already joined Jeremia Wright's group when he wrote this article. (34)

* Obama's next movew as to go to law school.  He said he wanted to learn about "''interest rates, corporate mergers, the legislative process'; about businesses and banks and real estate." (36)

* From 37 to the end of the chapter, K goes deep into the intellectual climate at Harvard law school with the basic point of suggesting that it was dominated by a contemporary pragmatist philosophical approach to law--the latter day version of the legal philosophy of Louis Brandeis and Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. who "believed that law is a product of history and culture, a set of rules designed to facilitate social interaction based on changing values and aspirations.  they denied that law rests on bedrock, a stable foudnation of unchanging principles.  But they disagreed with 'crits,' as the advocates of critical legal studies were called, abut the futility of trying to use the law as a lever for social change." (39) The notion of a pragmatist  in law had become muddied since the time of Brandies and Holmes.  New Dealers usually saw themselves as descended from the pragmatists.  Subsequently some conservatives had begun to call themselves pragmatists--ie. Richard Posner who "reasoned that if pragmatism destabilizes inherited truths, the ostensibly netural mechanism of the free market provides the best way to resolve the resulting confusion." (40)  At the same time, some literary critics drawing on Derrida i.e. Stanley Fish studied law as a kind of literature.  Many ont he left "considered both Posner's and Fish's hijacking of the term pragmatism a travesty, a repudiation of the egalitorian commitments and democratic activism of James, Dewey, and their folloewrs int he progressive and New Deal Coalitions." (40)

K's point is that Obama found himself in the middle of these disputes when he entered Harvard Law School in fall of 1988.  Obama then worked first as a research assitant to Professor Laurence Tribe in 1988-1989, then served on the editorial board of thslslye HLR in 1989-1990, and finally was president of the HLR in 1990-1991.  During these years K argues the HLR reflected the intensity of these debates.

He notes that progressives in law also drew upon a new set of ideas comign out of American history and political theory known "variously as civiv republicanism, communtiarianism, and deliberative democracy" that transformed "legal scholarship in the 1980s." (41)    K writes: "Legal scholoarls attracted to these ideas counterposed the importance of the public interest--a coneption of a shared, common good, emerging through the proess of lively debate between champions of competing point of view--to the ideas of both conservatives and radical lieftists of the Marxist and poststructuralist persuastions." (41)  While some conservatives described the Constitution as having and original meaning" and leftists "dismissed the law as a tool of oppression used by rich whit e males to preserve their power," these thinkers put themselves betwen these poles.  Many of Obama's teachers at Harvard participated in these debates.  K also mentions Gordon Wood's The Creation fo the American Republic, 1776-1787 as a key text here (published 1969).  He says

"Wood demonstrated convincingnly, through an exhaustive examiantionof the evidence, that the architects of the United States were animated by a passion for civi virtue as well as liberty. They not only sought independence from Britain to establish freedom for individuals; in addition, they prized equality and jsutice as the ends of government, and they framed the United States Constitution for the purpose.  Wood concluded his analysis by claiming that the promise of civic republicanism, which required individuals to balance self-interest against he interests of the community, was betrayed almost immediately by a rapacious individualism that quickly supplanted virtuous citizens' concern with the common good." (42)

Woods' ideas and the growing lit on civic republicanism in the 1970s and 1980s seeped into other disciplines such as poli sci sociology, and law...meaning then also that conservatives "had to reckon with new challenges" when claiming the primacy of individual rights. (43) Added to the new understanding of civic republicanism, ther were other scholars that showed that John Locke was "a more fervant Calviinst than he was a prophet of rights consciousness" (43) and other scholars (social hsitorians) like Gary Nash, Alfred Young, Linda kerber and Mary Beth Norton showed that blacks, women, and poor whites played a key role in "winning indepednence and creating a new nation." (43) K sums up: "The United States, according to his line of argument, was designed fromthe swtart to bea  democracy in which people would deliberate together to discover the meaning of justice and advance the common good..." (43)

Obama encountered thi sfirst in Boesche's class at Occidental... These ideas were then strengthened, K argues, by his legal education.  He goes through HLR articles in the years that Obama was involved and finds a definnite preference for civic republicanism and deliberative democracy.  (44-55)  This was particularly the acse int he year that Obama headed the HLR.  K states this explicitly on 55: a "persistent emphasis on the potential of philosophical pragmatism, civic republicanism, and deliberative democracy as the best methods for resolving differences during the year of Obama's presidency..." (55)

Of particular interest is K's analysis of an article by Laurence Tribe entitled the "The Curvature of Constitutional Space: What Lawyers Can Learn from MOdern Physics" that appeared in November 1989 in HLR and in which Obama worked along with Tribe to write.  The article is based on the principle that the law must first protect the intersts of the least advantaged and then on the idea that law is not rooted in an "Achimedian point."  It encoruaged lawyers to examine the "'social meaning of what the state has done,' because 'the state enacts an image of order' that is coercive.  In other words, it inevitably curves the space around it." (61)  Another book published by Tribe and Dorf i n1991, On Reading the constitution, further indicated the influence of philosophical pragmatism.  (62-63).  And K notes that Obama had already recived these ideas through Ralph Ellison's novel Invisible Man that he had read as a young man; through his encoutner with Alinsky's ideas (Alinsky had gotten it from Robert Park, see 65).

* Throughout this chapter, K refers to Obama's personal capacity and predilection for a kind of compromise and deliberation and problem solving that mirrors the philosphical pragmatism that he was being exposed to.  E.g. p.74-75; p.57 when he describes why Tribe selected Obama to help him with the article; p.48-49 when he describes how Obama's letter to HLR helped resolve a debate about affirmative action... and so on.

* After law school, Obama continues to pursue these concersn through the Saguaro Seminar that dealt with some of the issues surroudning how to incraese public engagement that Obama had identified in "Why Organize" in 1988.  (73-78)

* Ultimately K's point is: "To understand Obama's attitude toward American politics and his long-term commitment to breaking the logjam of American party politics, it is not enough to trace his sensibility to his formative years in Indonesia and Hawaii; to Los Angeles, New York and Cambridge; to Illiinois and Keny.  It is equally crucial to locate him within the frameworks of civic republianism and communitarian discourse, within the tradition of philosophical pragmatism, and in relation to the cluster of complex ideas that emerged in the 1960s and 1970s." (78)  By the latter, he his rferring to antifoundationalism, particularism, perspectivalism, and historicism... (78)  Obama encountered them first in his own life having to cope with "the contrast between the attitudes of his mother and his stepfather while living in Indonesia." (79)  Then as a lawyer and political activist.  "Whereas many Americans are upset--disoriented--by the idea that values vary over time and across cultures, Ovbama found that way of thinking congenial because it made bretter sense of his own experience, conformed to his emerging understanding of American democracy,a nd gave him valuable tools for daling with the philosohpical and political puzzles he was trying to solve." (79)

K defineswhat he means by these terms and describes the broader intlletual context on 79-80.

title: Uncertain Victory: Social Democracy and Progressivism
text:
Notes Feb 2012 // For Pragmatism Course:

Introduction

* Kloppenberg is trying to examine a "transatlantic community of discourse in philosophy and political theory."  (3)

* He wants to clarify with this work the "philosophical origins of social democratic and progressive theory" which he thinks "remain obscure" compared to the well worked out "chains linking Marxism to idealism and liberalism to empircism..." (3)     As a result he says these traditions of social demcoratic and progressive thought "which diverged from the socialist and liberal traditions twoard the end of the nineteenth century, appear to be simply unstable accomodations to the new realities of organized capitalism in an urban-industrial environment." (3)

* He tihnks that these were not just "ideological expressions prssend into service to ratioanlize politically attractive positions" but they were "elaborated, extended, and applied ideas about knowledge and responsibility articulated by a generation of renegade philosophers." (3)

* These "renegade philosophers" he also calls the philosophers of the via media who were searching for alternatives to the "idealist and naturalist philosophies" that dominated nineteenth century thought.  They were Wilhelm Dilthey, Thomas Hill Green, Henry Widgwick, Alfred Fouillee, William James, and John Dewey.  What held this thinkers together?  He explains here:

They denied both mind-body and subject-object dualisms inherited from Descartes, and they considered both passive sensations and active decision essential and inseparable aspects of experience.  Knowledge, from their perspective, can neither be abstracted from nor entirely reduced to the historical circumstances of individual lives.  Truth must be cut free from notions of eternity and necessity and grounded instead in human experience, never definite and subject always to revision.  These mavericks insisted that ideas emerge from, and must be validated in, neither language nor logic but life.  Theirs was a profoundly historical sensibility, imbued with the belief that meaning is woven into the fiber of experience, that becoming rather than being is the mode of human life, and that people make rather than find their values. (4) 

Kloppenberg calls this "cluster of ideas" a "radical theory of knowledge" because it substituted an acceptance of contingency for certainty in epistemology. 

* In the realm of ethics, he says, the revised both Kantian and utilitarian models "by recognizing rules and results as complementary in moral reasoning."  (4) He thinks that Sidgwick in his Methods of Ethics elaborated these ideas most clearly and he will call this ethical theory an "ethics of rational benevolence." (4) 

* The political writings of these thinkers he says lack the "acuity" of their other work. He suggest that they were "left behind" when Germany, France, England and the United States "reconstitued themselves as urbanized and mechanical nation states." (4)  They had matured prior to the 2nd industrial revolution.  He says they were consumed by an awareness of the incompatabiltiy of the older set of values for new new economic and sociopolitical cirucmstances, and yet they were consumed by certain anxieties about the new age.  And ulimtastely they failed to outline an alternative.  See description of alternatives on 5, top of page.  Very good!

* It was a set of thinkers who emerged twenty years later that would do that: he menas the progressive and social democratic thinkers of the 1890-1920 period.  These were English Fabians Beatrice and Sidney Webb, German revisionist Eduward Bernstein, French socialist Jean Jaures, and the prominant radical sof the American social gospel movement, Richard Ely and Walter Rauschenbusch.  What tied these thinkers together he seems to think was a bit less coherent and differetn in each national context (think of Rodgers) but consisted of 1) a siimilar location of the foundation of knowledge in experience and a tendency to see history as a better source of judgement than ideology: 2) a desire to extend the principles of democratic equality to the social and economic spheres from the civic and political; 3) they championed gradual reform rather than revolution; 4) they "although they embraced socialism as an ideal, they emphasized he connection between their goal and the means necessary for its realization, and for that reason they concentrated more on proximate reforms than on ultimate ends." (6)

* His motivation for examining these political theorists is to "disconnect their ideas from certain developments [in the welfare state] they could neither anticipate nor prevent."  (5)  Ie he wnats to salvage the coherence of their vision from the critiques of those who point out the misshaped  nature of various welfare states, which are the result of the missue or misunderstanding of these ideas.  (5) So this is in part an act of "reovery" as he calls it on 6. 

 

2. Radical Theory of Knowledge

 

I. Immediacy of Lived Experience

* The philosophers of the via media rejected traditional philosphy's "search for apodicticity..." (65)  Rejected  Cartesian mind-body dualism and "acknoowledged the continuity of consciousness, the experience of freedom, and the provisional quality of the self." (65)  Knowledge as an undending experiment.  etc etc.

" Key here was a understanding that traditioanl epistemological questions were wrongly configured.  They denied the "ontological gap" that was tradtionally understood to distinguish subject from object, mind from body.  Those dualisms, they argued, were simply based in the differences between consciousness, lived experience (Dilthey), pure experience (James) etc, and what was beyond consciousness , ie "everything that we do not experience from the inside.  (65)  Ie what existing philosphers had treated as a real difference, they argued was based in a miscontrual.  In rejecting the mind-body dualism, they were esse ntially saying that reality wasa not broken into two parts, but instead that it "merely yields different answers to questions posed from different perspectives.  The world of our immediate experience appears to us different from everything else merely because we are inside it, not because it is metaphysically or ontologically distinct from the rest of existence." (65) 

* James' Principles of Psychology K describes as a first "faltering step" in the direction of "ideas that integrated their isnights into the unity of subject and object in expeirence with their argument that valid knowledge could be derived from nature and from lived experience."  (67)  He is work tried to balance a faithfulness to science and to "lived experience", but threatened to pull  them apart.  James kept in view here both a materialist sense of scientific causality, but allowed also for consiousness.  He wrote: "We may fairly write the Universe in either way, thus: ATOMS-producing-consciousness; or CONSCIOUSNESS-produced-by-atoms.  Atoms alone, or conscoiusenss alone, are precisely equal mutilations of the truth." (quoted on 67).  Then also he was trying to balance a rejection of absolute idealism with view that could see the real expeirence of non-materialistic things.  (67-68)

* Psychology was useful to James and also Fouillee, who both followed each other's work, because as Fouillee put it, "Psychology is the only science of initial and immediate experience...whcih begins with what is given without postulates..."  ie it begins with what is given.  (69) 

* Between 1895-1896, James began to reject the notion of consciouesness (ie after finishing his Psychology) and experimented with other words, finding utlimatel the word "field" to be useful. He liked it because it avoiided the dualism and "skirted the equally misleading notions of consciosuness as eithe rpure ego or material substance." (69)  This focus on consciousness as a field James admitted "results in an almost maddening restlessness," but he believed K writes that it was a way back to "concreteness."  The key principle was that in this context of the field of pure experience one could focus on what we mean by knowing and the principle of truth this tended to genereate was that "nothing is postulated whose nature is not fully given in experience terms..." (69)

II. Consciousness of Continuity and the Continuity of Consciousness

* So these philosophers of the via media denied the idea of atomism--ie that the mind experiences distinct bits of information and then combines them internally.  Their idea waws instead that we "experience relations".  But if so, are these "elements of expeirence combined orginally and immediately in and by consciousenss, or are relations instead outside of us and an integral feature of the reality we experience? " (73) 

* K says that Dewey, Fouillee and Dilthey combine T.H. Green and James' ideas.  Green's focus was on "the role of consciousness in relating th various aspects of experience" and James' was the notion of "stream of consciousness",which K describes as b eing about the "relatedness of experience" itself.  (73)

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text:
p.020- John Franklin Jameson

Jameson serious about the professional classes tranformation of historical scholarship.  Zealous about German methods.  Wrote a lot as a young man and then quit history at 40 (may have been due to feeling of inadequacy).  But also a result of his sense that the period did not suit the "great individual".  Saw scholarhsip "advancing 'more by extensive accumulation and critical shifting of the evidences than by new endeavors toward their interpretation.'" (22) He had been head of AHR and Historical Manuscripts Commission while at Brown.  But needed more insittutional support to achieve advances in documenation and bibliography.  Carnegie Institution of Washinton, founed in 1902 provided the opportunity.  Jameson's projet continued under auspices of Carnegie Instiution until 1928.  See account of this 22-25.

title: Autonomy in Moral and Political Philosophy (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
text:
Section 1.1 - Basic Distinctions...

Moral autonomy "capacity to impose the (objective) moral law on onself, and, following Kant, it is claimed as a fundamental organizaing principle of all morality."

"Personal autonomy" - "a trait that individuals can exhibit relative to any aspects of their lives, not limited to questions of moral obligation."

One caqn also talk of either "basic" or "ideal" autonomy -- the former being a "minimal status of being responsible" which one must assume most adults to possess.

title: Cosmopolitics: Thinking and Feeling Beyond the Nation
text:
# Bruce Robbins and Peng Chea (eds.), *Cosmopolitics: Thinking and Feeling Beyond the Nation*  (Minneapolis: The University of Minnesota Press, 1998)

> Note Session: I am reading this in order to get a sense of the recent take on cosmopolitanism. James Clifford said that it was the "latest words." Of course, he's quoted in the book.

## "Introduction Part I: Actually Existing Cosmopolitanism" by Bruce Robbins

" I didn"t read this essay very closely as I found it kind of shallow and loosely worded. The best point I thought came in the first few pages where he tries to characterize a shift in th way we talk about cosmopolitanism. The key point was that the term is now associated with a "new cast of characters." (1) The  ideas is that before it was linked with a list of people that quote Paul Rabinow from the Writing Culture book he describes as Jews, Christians, aristocrats, homosexuals etc, often as a way to denigrate such charachters. NOw it is associated more positively with "North Atlantic merchant sailors, Caribbean au pairs in the United States, Egyptian gues workers in Iraq, Japanese gaijinlovers..." (1) Here he quotes Clifford to say that the status of traveller should be given to the "host of servants, helpers, companions, guides, beaers, etc." (1) who made Victorian travel possible. (1)

* This "change in personell" (1) means a change in definition:

>Understood as a fundamental devotion to the interests of humanity as a whole, cosmopolitanism has often seemed to claim universality  by virtue of its independence, its detachment from bonds, commitments, and affiliations that contrain ordinary nation-bound lives. It has seemed to be a luxriously free-floating view from above." (1)

It ist this view that is being rejected. He quotes several people here to get at what this means. The key people here: Rabinow, Arjudn Ap[padurai, Binata Parry, Arnold Krupat, DAvid Hollinger, and MItchell Cohen, Homi Bhaba, Anthony Appiah, and others. Basically, the point here is that the narrow definition of cosmopolitanism is not interesting. Their needs to be a focus on plural cosmopolitanisms that emerge in rooted contexts out of a reality of transnational mutual dependencies and connections produced by global capitalism, and which can in fact operate to support the state (see p.8). This implies what Robbins calls at one point "the term's scaling down, its pluralizing and particularizing." (3) He says it well again here: "Another way to put the contrast is to say that instead of an ideal of detachment, actually existing cosmopolitanism is a reality of (re)attachment, multiple attachment, or attachment at a distance." (3)

* Also key here to Robbins seems to be the way this cosmopolitanism is bound up with a critique of what he calls the "romantic localism" of parts of the left that "feelts i t must counter capitalist globalization with a strongly rooted and exluvie sort of belonging." (3)

## "Introduction Part II: The Cosmopolitical--Today" by Peng Cheah

* I found this essay a bit stronger out of the gate and throughout than Robbins, even as an introductory essay. He lays out the goal of the book much more clearly at the outset. Rigth off the bat he gives a descritpion of the recent cahnges that have made "globalization, transnationalism,, even postnationalism" keywords. These are summed up this way: "the accelearated pace of globalization--the intesnsification of international trade, fiscal and technology transfers, and labor migration, and the consoliation of a genuiniely global mode of production trhough subcontracting--in 'advanced post-Fordsit' or 'late capltism,' the transnationalization of military commerical structures through NATO, and the rise of global hybrid cultures from modern mass migration, consumerism, and mass comunications in the past two decades have combined to create an interdependent world in which the nation-state faces imminent obsolence as a viable economic unit, a politcally sovereign territory, and abounded cultural sphere." (20)

* BUT Cheah points out it is not clear what the laternvie are or whether they can be realized. And that is he thinks the point of the book: "to explore the feasibility of coscmopolitanism as an alternative to nationalism in our contemporary area,..." (21)

* He summarizies the perspectives taken in the book: 1) Allen Wood, Kwame Anthony Appiah, and Jonathan Ree he says make philosophical arguemnt "for cosmpolitanism as an ideal project and a style of practical conscousness that overcomes nationalist particularism." (21) 2) Louisa Schein, Bonnie Honig, Brucie Robbins, Scott Malcomson, and Aamanda Anderson focus on "transcultural encounters, mass migration, and population transfers between East and West, First and Third Worlds, North and South." (21) 3) Then there is Clifford, he says, who talks about "discreptant cosmpolitanism" and argues that cosmopolitanism is not longer ideal, but "a vareity of actually existing practical stances." (21) What unifies these accounts he says is a sense that "contemporary transnationalism" provides the "material conditions for new radical cosmoplitanisms from below." (21)

* In the next section, which I won't go into in detail he does a very useful analysis of Kant and Marx's take on cosmopolitanism. His points are historical. Kant he thinks was developiong a theory of cosmopolitanism at a time when nationalism as an ideology was not yet on the scene. His context was the "interstate system of anarchy established by the Treaty of Westphalia after the breakup of the vast religious political communities of the medieval period." (24) Interestingly, Cheah points out we might be able to see some links between that moment of interstate anarchy and the present 21st century state of the international system. (24) In any case, Kant's cosmopolitanism was then an attempt to set up a "cosmopolitical right asserted in the name of a common humanity...to provide an ideal institutional framework for regulating the anarchic behavior of states." (24)  So his cosmopolitanism is not anti- or pro-nationalism. It is pre-nationalist, and an attempt to reform state absolutism. So it's not even an idel that suggests detachment from national entities. Rather it supports "a form of right based on existing attachments that bind us into a collectivity larger that the state..." This right can be asserted against the state because the states themselves, through commerce, an dieal that does not support war, involves a "collectively" in which states are already involved. (24)

* What Kant missed was nationalism, which Cheng explains also asserted certain "rightful" limits to state power. At this juncture, he notes wisely, the goals of European nationalism and cosmopolitanism are closely linked! He says "indistinguishable", which I think can't be right. But he has a good quote from Mazzini from 1861 that shows his point. (24-25)

* He also usefully points out that what he's talking about here is a point before the tightening of the hyphenated relationship of state and nation, where nationslim was more like cosmopolitanism. (25)

* Next he turns to Marx"s take on cosmopolitanism and nationalism. The historical point here is that Marx has seen the rise of nationalism, whereas Kant hadn't. So between 1795 when Kant wrote "Perpetual Peace..." and 1848 when Marx wrote the Communist Manifesto something had changed. He notes Marx"s ambivalenc eabout both cosmopolitnaism and nationalism. Cosmopolitanism was linked with the expanding global reach of bourgeois capital and exploitation, but it was also the condition for emancipation. Likewise, nationalism represented a kind of link to the land that was not just the subordination of land and labor to the rule of capital. So Chenge says he sees it something like religion as a false form of consciousness. (27) But in the end Marx dismisses nationalism and leans toward a cosmopolitanism of the worker, since the "worker has no country." (quoted on 28).

* Cheng thinks that Marx too easily equated natioanlism with the state, or rather that he linke dthe ideological content of nationalism too closely with the "ecnonimc and cultural natinoalism of European states..." (28) Cheng thinks he imagines the hyphenated relationship between nation and state to be immutable, whereas for Chenge it is not. He brings this up in the context of Marx's other failure--which he says was responsible for the falling apart of the Second International--and then he says that the most important reevaluations of Marx's theory here have come from the consideration of the anticolonial struggle. He finds Lenin poking a whole in Marx's assesment of nationalism, seeing in resurgent colonial nationalism asomething healthy (29), and he ends with a quote by Sun Yat-Sen to the extent that ex-colonies can't consider cosmopolitanism untilthey have deeloped their own strong nationalisms. Yet this is a claim it seems to me still soundly in the Marxist teleology tha tmoves through various forms to the cosmopolitanism o fthe worker.  (30)

* In the next section which I won' t take notes on as closely, he goes into some of the attempts to consider the contempoary moment. Based on his previous section he points out that the way to consider the capacity of contempoary "cosmopolitics" must come through an interrogation that does not simply seek to expose nationalism as a "derivative discourse" of capitalism, or one that condemns cosmopolitnaism as "uncommitted bourgeois detachmnent." (31)

title: Vigorous Male and Aspiring Female: Poetry, Personality, and Culture in Edward Sapir and Ruth Benedict
text: "Hardness" and Personality Handler roots his anlaysis of "hardness" in relation to personality in the cutlural criticism of T.J. Lears and Warren Sussman. He starts from Susmann's notice of the rising importance of the notion of "personality", the shift from "building character" to the desire to "develop personality." He uses Lears to say that this was the indivdiuals' desire to counter the "weightlessness" of modern times. A desire for the "real." Ezra Pound he uses as an example writing to Harriet Monroe in October 1912: "I go about this London hunting for the real..." (quoted on 98). Handler says for Pound and the imagists hardness was about "sincere self-expression". Pound's dictums were: "I.Direct treatment of the 'thing' whether subjective or objective,' and '2. To use absolutely no word that does not contribute to the presentation'" (quoted on 98). The "thing" could either be a feeling or something in the "objective" world. T.E. Hulme also expressed this ideal: "The great aim is accurate, precise and definite description. The first thing is to recognise how extraordinarily difficult this is. It is no mere matter of carefulness; you have to use language, and language is by its very nature a communal thing; that is, it expresses never the exact thing but a compromise--that which is common to you, me and everybody. But each man sees a little differently, and to get out clearly and exactly what he does see, he must have a terrific struggle with language." (quoted on 98-99 from "Spectulations" (1924) Croce also in 1902 "Aesthetics as Science of Expression and General Linguistic saw this as the problem of achiveing what Handler terms "direct intiution of reality". (99) Handler sums up: "Hardness, then, in the aesthetics of the new poetry, referred both to technique and to the artist's vision; it suggested that real art depended on the discovery of a personal reality, a reality penetrated, understood, embraced, and expressed by the self, standing alone." (99) Is that so accurate, this then would be an entirely solopsistic selfhood. That's not what Sapir was driving at e.g. I think. Certainly not Benedict I don't think.

title: Lost Manhood Found: Male Sexual Impotence and Victorian Culture in the United States
text:
p. 54 - 55   Women Seen as Cause of Sexual Impotence in Men	

Dr. William Robinson wrote in 1912 a book on sexual impotence in which he saw women as heping to increase incidences of sexual impotence in men.  I.e. frigidity in women caused sexual impotence in men.  And they specualted also that frigidity in women was actually also latent homosexuality.  (54) 

Ultimately, women were also seen by 20s, e.g. New Woman and Flapper, as sexually active and expressive, but women were now sexualized and those who were not were stigmatized as "frigid." This Mumford observes helped "to legitimate men's sexual claims on women." (56)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text: p.156-162 Parsons work on Family Her book The Family (1906) was result of course that Giddings allowed her to teach on Family Organization. (156). She arranged her ethnoloical sources in an "evolutionary sequence" lke most writers on the subject at the time. (156) . It led from primitive savagery through matriachry and patriarchy to the monogamous family., what she called the "modenr simple family." (156) She noted many anthropologists belief that the matriachy predated the patriarchy in this sequence, but also cast doubt on the conflusions of male ethnologists (156) . She accepted the view that the modern family was the most advanced. (157) : prolonged childhood, lengthy education, freedom from migration weakened kinship ties, more freedom for indivdiual development and selfrealization. (157) But she thought hte modern family still maintianed patriarchal vestiges. She believed women were bound in a number of ways by patriachal strictures: poor education, inability to education their children. (157-8). Most of the text was dry and removed, but for last 8 pages which caused a scandal and caused her newly elected husband's opponents to criticis the book as "barbarous" and a "debasement of marriage." (158) Parsons basically did not think that education of women was enough. she attacked what Veblen had noted as the producer husband and the consumer wife. She thought women needed to produce. (158-160). She also translated Gabriel Trade's The Laws of Imigation while working on the Family. She applied his theory of a notion of tricke-down influence of progress from elites to lower classes, to women. E.g. she had written in "Higheer Education of Womena nd the Family" that tenemant house-wives or farmer's wives were more "primitive" in that they are "even more subject to marital mastery than their leisure-class sisters." (quoted o 160)> SAnd then "As, Gabriel Tarde has pointed out to us, it is only people at the top of the scale who have enough social prestige to negotiate radical changes.":(quoted on 160)> She also attacked Victorian condemnation of sexuality. Thinking that it also weakened women's development of personality. (160). Most radical ideas was that to "trial marriage" (161). New York Times condemdned the book for its subversive tendencies also (162).

title: Of Feys and Culture Planners: Margaret Mead and Purposive Activity as Value
text: p. 104 - 6 Stability of "temperament" Sullivan describes Mead's approach to culture and personality, heavily influenced by an awareness of the biological ground of personality in temperament, an idea which she drew from William McDougall (who had drawn on Jung's Psychological Types). Sullivan gives a description here, like the one he gave in his other article. See Related link on this note. But here heputs it more clearly and succinctly. And he draws out the following important point which is helpful to me in terms of my project of describing these nathropologists attempts to re-construct selfhood: "While Mead noted Euroepan attmepts to maintain such 'culturally achieved balances' under the rubrics of race and caste, the important conclusion of this reasoning was that a given temperamental type could become a general characteristic of a population and influence the ethos of its society." (104-105) He notes that different temperaments had different strengths, and he quotes her as characterizing male/female temperaments thisway: "Because the balances achieved differed, the temperaments,with their respective strengths and weaknesses, differed as well. 'Fluidity of habit,' Mead wrote, 'is the refuge and strength of F[emale] types,' while 'fixed haibts and a persistent and obstinate activity' were 'the refuge and strength of M[ale] types."(105) Again he deals with this notion of stability of these types that Mead had elaborated on 106, especially the bottom paragraph. The idea was that stability could be achieved through a "'repeated preocess of hybridizaiton and isolation' wherein temperament and character attain an ongoing pragmatic cultural unity." (106) Behavior would vary depending on which type had been made dominant. At the end this produced a "variable structural set [of]...contrasting and dialectically related types..." which Sullivan says satisfied Mead's search for "systematic variation by comparing and contrasting the various implications for what she called 'the individual's relationship to culture.'" (106) Sullivan finally describes that he thinks this approach to the "person" was one in which the person is "not so much a collective representation as he or she is the product of a pragmatic encounter that gives shape to both the person and the culture involved." (106) He goes on to describe how this entailed the body being "shaped by ongoing cultural processes" (106) such as the "selection of preferred body type and temperament" and its being acted on by culture, e.g. during child rearing. Sullivan says then that the person "experiences a locally specific process of embodiment." (106) Sullivan's description here as can be esen in f.n. 12 is building into this definition ideas from other people, he cites Mauss's essay on the persona and the self, Geertz's essay on the person in Bali from Interpretaiton of Cultures, and Csordas, ed. book on "Embodiment and Experience" .

title: The Clash of Civilizations?
text:
p.025-28   Reason for civilizational clash

1) Important argument: he belives the clash will happen b/c "civilizations are not only real; they are basic." (25) In other words, b/c 1) these ideas are built into daily life in terms of attitudes toward "relatoins between God and man, the individual and the group, the citizen and the state, parents and children, husband and wife, as well as differing views of the relative importance of rights and responsiblities, liberty and authority, equality and hierarchy." (25)  2) b/c such ideas are ingrained due to the fact that "These differences are the product of centuries." (25)  They are he says "far more fundamental than differences among political ideologies and political regimes." (25)

2) b/c of increased interaction between poeple in the world which intensifies "civilization consciousness and awareness of differences between civilizations and commonalities within civilizations." (25)

3) Economic modernization and social change is stripping people of local identieties he says.  Religion is filing a gap he says and religions is a braoder category. (26)

4) Peak of the power of West causing return to "roots" in the East, i.e. the "Asianization' in Japan, the end of the Nehru legacy and the 'Hinduization' of India, the failure of Western ideas of socialism and nationalism and hence 're-Islamization' of the Middle East, and now a debate over Westernization verus Russianization in Boris Yeltsin's country." (26)

5) Again culture: such difference he says are "less easily compromised and resolve than economic ones..." (27)

6) Ecnomic regionalism, intraregional trade is on the increase 51 to 59 % in Europe btw 1980 and 89; 33 to 37% in East Asia; 32 to 36% in N. America.

title: The Unspeakable: Discourse, Dialog, and Rhetoric in the Postmodern World
text: Stephen Tyler on Culture Now here is another key moment (that raises Habermas' notion of communicative action). Tyler writes: "The communicative context includes, makes possible, and is itself the result of agreements that allow disjunction for some purposes in some contexts, while prohibiting disjunciton of the whole field of signifer/signified at once." Ironcially, Tyler says that this seems to affirm Saussure's statement that the "signified and the signifier are held together by the 'social fact of language' (1966:113)..." (17) So "arbitrariness" he says also has its countepart in the "given...conventions understood as if they were both natural and the product of intentions mediated by conversation and discourse." (17-18) Arbitrariness then he thinks is not the "imposition of culture on nature, nor a reflection of nature within culture; it is the naturalness of the cultural, which is neither a closed system of self-reflecting signs nor of signs reflecting a foundational nature." (18) He puts this in other words by saying that arbitrariness requires conventions, and is in fact "made by the intersection of person, will, and representation..." (18) Person, will and representation, on the other hand, can be understood by othe rnames: "culture, society, and individual, repsectively. The category 'person' is the speaker/hearer, the symbol of culture. The category 'will' is convention/intention, the index of society. The category 'representation' is signfier/signified, the icon of the individual." (18) Here he references a 1978 book by himself, The Said and the Unsaid. (18)

title: With science as his shield: Teaching race and culture in American public schools, 1900--1954
text:
00 Abstract 00 
This dissertation is a history of the social construction of race in American schools in the early 20 th century. As racializing national institutions, public schools taught specific definitions of the race concept and they also inscribed certain racial knowledge and behavior as symbolic markers of the educated American citizen. This analysis begins with a reform effort led by anthropologist Franz Boas in the late 1930s. Facing the threat of Nazi Germany, Boas launched an initiative to reform how American schools defined race. Boas argued schools used scientifically inaccurate, racialist, and dangerous conceptions of race in everyday pedagogical practice. Boas concluded schools fueled racial prejudice in America and made the nation vulnerable to the influence of Nazi propaganda. Drawing on dominant anthropological models of racial difference, activist social scientists taught that individuals of any background were potentially equal. Importantly, anthropologists insisted that the dynamic concept of culture was a far more useful concept for explaining human diversity than the biological concept of race. The Boasian concept of culture lost traction as it was translated by educators for use in American schools in the 1940s. Poorly trained in social science theory and struggling to mediate volatile race relations in their classrooms, teachers softened the Boasian critique of racism into "palatable" lessons. In most cases teachers simply grafted the language of racial egalitarianism and cultural relativism onto existing models of racial hierarchy. By the end of the war educators consolidated a previously disparate group of white racial minorities into a singular and cohesive "white" race, while interpreting Americans of African and Asian descent as not only biologically or racially different, but as culturally separate as well. Racial discourse in American schools shifted again in the postwar era, as teachers adapted tolerance education to conform to new psychological models of racial prejudice. The result was that teachers deliberately silenced the discussion of race in the classroom insisting that all students exhibit "good manners" when speaking to or about racial others. This universalizing psychological approach is shown to define the history of later 20 th century efforts to confront racism in American schools.

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text: p.046- Ralph Linton, Abram Kardiner & New Culture & Personality theory Between 1937 and 1939 a new group came together (at colubmia?) involing Ralph Linton and Abram Kardiner that put forward a new notion of culture and personality. Kardiner was a psychologist that had been trained in Boasian anthropology. He taught a course at the New York Psychoanalytic Institute throughout the 1930s on relatoins between culture and personality. He had coordinated with Cora Du Bois in 1936 (she had worked with Kroeber and Lowie at Berkeley) and they had presented a critique of Freudian ideas about psychology. But in 1917 Du Boid left and Linton, Sapir and Kluckhohn were on the scene. In this context a new personality and culture theory emerged that gave a specail role to the idea of the Freudian ego as "an adaptive structure mediating between culture and individual desire." (46). This came out in Kardiner's 1939 <>The Individual and His Society that put the indiviudal at the center. Madden finds that this focus ont he individual as a "meeting ground" for the ideas of different professions in Mead's Competition and Cooperation also. (46-47) Linton, who had once been more Boasian, also followed Kardiner. Madden argues that Linton argued that "cultures contained 'basic personality structures' that represented the 'constellation of personality characteristics which would appear to be congenial with the total range of institutions comprised within a given culture.'" (47) Madden compares this to Benedcit's notiion of patterns, but notes that Linton thought multiple "personality structures co-existed within a single culture." (47) Madden also compares this idea to Sapir's notion that each individual represnted at least one subculture, which he had quoted earlier on p.27. Linton felt that this new personality and culture theory made the "old" one obsolte. [Note: what was the "old" one?] (47-48). Kroeber Madden noted felt that this new theory "fell outsidethe obdns of anthropology" (Madden's words, 48). For K quote see 48-49. Madden roots Kroeber's objection in terms of a commitment to what Madden has called "expertise" which is to say a focus on knowledge in the four-fields, rather than theory. I think he gets Kroeber a bit wrong here. Kroeber was not opposed to theory , but wanted theoretical understanding of cultural history.., one yes that was empirical... but not opposed to theory as such as long as it was grounded in empirical analysis.

title: A Franz Boas Reader: The Shaping of American Anthropology, 1883-1911
text:
p. 283-286 Timeline Boas's Prof Strategy

1887, ater debate w/ Mason & Powell, attempts to revive the American Ethnological Society in New York, but fails.  Then forms ties with the New England based Folklore Society.  Contributes regularly to their journal which he edits fors seventeen years between 1908-1925. (283)

Stocking writes: "Boas ultiamte success depended on his connections with certain important subcultural mileux in New York and Boston. "  Boas uncle Abraham Jacobi, prominent in the New York German-Jewish community, had married a daughter of the publisher George Putnam.  While at Clark, Boas formed a freindship with "one of hte New England Putnams, Professor Frederick Ward Putnam of Harvard's Peabody Museum, who was at this point perhaps the most influential American anthropologist outside Washington, and who, significantly, had always remained somewhat skeptical of the assumptions of cultural evolutionism."  In the 1890s, Boas followed Putnam from the Chicago Fair to the American Musem of Natural History.  Though Stocking says Putnam maintaind his position at Harvard.  Big break came in 1896: "The turning point, of course, was the appointment Boas received early in 1896 through the combined efforts of Jacobi and Putnam as lecturer in physical anthropology at Columbia University.  Together with the position he had just accepted at the American Museum as assistant to Putnam, the Columbia appointment provided Boas with a firm institutional base."  (284)  most significantly, Stocking notes, the tie to the University gave Boas an advantage over the Washingotn crowd who lacked such ties.  (284-285)

Boas relationship with Putnam begins to be attenuated when California dept. is founded under Putnam's direction.  Phoebe Apperson Hearts helped establish the California dept.  (284)

1905 He resigns from AMNH after ocnflict w/ Herman Bumbus, the new director.  (285)  

After Resignation from museum he directs efforts to the "southern portion sof the New World." 

He is head of AAA at this point and though his attempt to "limits its membershi pto professionals had been defeated by the Washington anthropologists," his influence had brown by 1907.  

1909 Distpue w/ Charles Walcott, secretar of the Smithsonian.   Boas not offered position as chief of BAE.  Stocking thinks he wouldn't hav taken in but he was mad..  Then Boas finds out that there was an accusation that money transfered to him under McGee's administratin were not clean somehow.    (285-286)

1910 This "southern strategy" "achieved partial fulfillment with the formaiton, in cooperation with German scholars, of the Inernational School of American Archaeology and Ethnology in Mexico City, see Boas, "The International School of American Archaeology and Ethnology in Mexico" Sciences 21: 188-183.

1911-1912 He spends academic year as director of Mexico school.  

But the war cuts the life of school short; focus returns to North America.

title: The Ideology of the Aesthetic
text:
General Notes 4/11/12

* The concept of interpretation, which is currently gruonded in a self-conscious attention to "heremeutics", is grounded in an ideology of aesthetics that he characterizes as an "apparatus of power in the field of culture" that "determined the political meaning and function of 'culture'" and which, although it appears to be about art, is really "a whole program of social, psychical, and political reconstruction on the part of the early European bourgeoisie..." (327)

title: A Four-Fold Humanity: Margaret Mead and Psychological Types
text: p.185 Biology/Psych had a place in her Theory Sullivan asserts against Freeman and those who have attacked Mead for being a cultural determinist that her ideas were not "without an important explicit place for evolutionary biology and genetics." (185) This thesis is demonstrated throught this paper.

title: Cosmopolitanism: Ethics in a World of Strangers
text:
Notes 11/2011

Summary Notes:

    Appiah's def'n of cosmpolitanism seems to be of the same ilk as that layed out by Seyla Benhabib at least in that it is rooted in a sense of the importance of the dialogical tension between univeral principles and local beliefs and the need to enter into conversations between those two levels.  He is perhaps less sure about the emergence of a consensus about universal "human principles" as Benhabib, but he is no antifoundaitonalist.  He also seems to have some taint of the kind of cosmpolitanism that Waldron espouses and which is rooted in a belief in the variability of human identity. 

    Liss has a good review of Apiah's book, which is sharply critical.  She first of all links Appiah's "partical cosmpolitanism" -- a phrase of his on xvii -- to Boas, Bourne, and W.E.B. Du Bois, citing Bourne's essays on Transnational America and her essay on Boas and Du Bois, and then she also points out that Appiah belongs to a more recent generation of scholars in this lineage who have "formulated varieties of cosmpolitanism, including 'rooted cosmpolitanism' and 'cosmopolitics.'' (Liss, Review in Rethinking History, v.13, no.3 2009, 420.)  The overall point of her critique seems to be that she likes his emphasis on cosmpolitanism as rooted in the challenge that universal principle poses to local identities and vice versa, but that he conceives of the tension between these two poles as too easily bridgeable.  She thinks he too easily dismisses anthropologists as non-cosmpolitan because they are suspicious of universal principle -- a stereotype she thinks -- and she suspects that Apiah is guilty of using anti-relativism as a kind of scare tactic in the way that Geertz identifies in his "Anti-anti-relativism."  (Liss, 421)  When Appiah dsicusses the kinds of obligations that we have to strangers, which is a major part of his argument, she thinks he does not focus explicitly enough on the major kinds of predicaments we face:

I would have liked Appiah to address more
explicitly the kinds of predicaments we face. For instance, how do people address traumatic histories and the very contentious political and cultural legacies that develop from them?8 In more immediate problems, such as starving children, war, or genocide, the real difficulty, as he acknowledges, is
not the danger that we do too much but that we don’t do anything. Samantha Power addresses inaction in A problem from hell: America and the age of genocide (2002). More recently, she has written on the dangers that the war in Iraq poses for the moral authority of the USA and the possibility of future interventions in international crises. Strikingly, these troubles seem to pose more serious challenges than those Appiah addresses. (422) 

 

 

 

Introduction:

* He starts out talking about how the world is coming closer together, ie "getting smaller".  This has to do with interlocking systems of production and also things like the interweb.  So the he asks what ste of ideas can be used to deal with it.  He dismisses globalization and multiculturailsm and then comes to cosmopolitanism. He, like Brian Milstein, tracaes it to the Cynic.  He puts at its center, like so many people, the same tension between universal and particular.  In his case it is put in terms of ethics:
