So there are two strands that intertwine in the notion of cosmopolitanism.  One is the idea that we have obligations to others, obligations that stretch beyond those to whom we are related by the ties of kith and kind, or even the more formal ties of a shared citizenship.  The other is that we take seriously the value  not just of human life but of particualr human lives, which means taking an interest in the pratices and beliefs that lend them significance. (xv)

Like Hollinger in his Cosmpolitanism & Solidarity, cosmpolitnaism is also not like universalism in that it sees that there is something to belearned from difference.  (xv) 

* He also notes that the cosmopolitanism has a negative side.  The cosmpolitan can be someone who forsakes his kin for the abstraction of humanity.  Ie here he is chanelling Burke's critique of Rousseau as "A lover of his kind, but a hater of his kindred." becuase R gave u p his kids to an orphanage.  (xvi) He notes that the haters of cosmpolitans eg Hitler and Stalin he is glad to oppose (xvi-xvii)

* He likes a passsage in George Eliot's Daniel Deronda from 1876.  Deronda was raised in England as a Christian but disovers his Jewish ancestry as an adult.  He commits himselof to the "furtherance of his 'hereditary people'" but without rejecting his human identity.  He sees the Jewishness as an "added soul".  He wished he had been brought up Jewish but he also would have wanted a broad perspective.  And he said elsewhere in the novel "I want to be an Englishman, but I want to understand other points of view.  And I want to get rid of a merely Engliish attitude in studies." (xviii) 

* I think this initial discussion is revealing of his point of veiw, but also ultimately at the end he makes some other revealing statements about his point of view.  He thinks that the "foreigness of foreigners, the strangers of strangers" is a real enough phenomenon--he has just been talking about the post september 11th context--but that "we've been encouraged, not least by well-meaning intellectuals, to exaggrate their significance by an order of magnitude." (xxi)  He think that it is IS an error to not talk about "objective" values, but that local values are also necessary.  This seems similar to what Seyla Benhabib is saying, and he like Benhabib also uses the "model" of "conversation": "The world is getting more crowded: in the next half a century the population of our once foraging species will approach nine billion.  Depending on the circumstances, conversations across boundaries can be delightful, or just vexing: wha tthe mainly are, though, is inevitable." (xxi)  This resembles the point Hollinger said so many of the new writers on cosmpolitanism are saying, that if you don't go to meet the world, it will come to you anyway.

Ch. 1

*  This chapter uses Richard Burton to get at the notion of the world and meaning in terms of  shattered mirror, each piece being one part of the larger truth, but giving an oblique view of the whole.  So that from Burton, who was a racist, you get the idea that you can find a bit of the truth everywhere and the whole truth nowhere. 

* He then notes that this doesn't really help with the bigger problem that there are irresolvable conflicts that emerge between differnet points of view. 

Ch. 2 Escape from Positivism

* He starts out by going through the notion of cultural relativism presented by cultural anthropologists, but then in the section "Exile of Value" he wants to argue that modern "profesisonal relativism" wasn't simply an outgrowth of classical skepticism but instead emerged out of Positivism.  He gives an analysis here that is compelling but reductive. He doesn't mention many positivist thinkers, mainly Hume.  No Comte I don't think.  So I was a bit ocnfused by what exactly his positivism is...17-25.

* Then in the section "Values Reclaimed" he pushes back, saying that he thinks positivism had it wrong.  Becuase they misunderstood values.  In his account of positivism, values are simply a reflection of human desires...the values or beliefs are the way to satisfy the desires.  (This sounded more like utitliariansim and associational pyschology to me, hence HUme ?) .  He wants to reverse things.  Desires are responses to values he thinks. "Values guide our acts, our thoughts, and our feelings.  These are our responses to values." (25)  Ultimately this takes him to the idea of stories, where he sees these values as being elaborated and, more i mportantly, discussed, where the language of values is negotiated and coordinated.  (Does this hold for myth for him?) He brings up the film Osama from 2004 that deals withthe Taliban as an example of where he thinks ther eis a discussion going on about values.   This gets him to the piont that I think is most robust here and fits with his notion of converation.  The convesration happens within stories for him it seems and it is this conversation that can get us to the universal truth:

Folktales, drama, opera, novels, short stories; biographies, histories, ethnographies; fiction or nonfiction; painting, music, sculpture, and dance: every human civilization has ways to reval to us values we had not preivously recognized or undermine our commitment to values that we had settled into.  Armed with these terms, fortified with a shared language of value, we can often guide one another, in the cosmpolitan spirit, to shared responses; and when we cannot agree, the understanding that our responses are shaped by some of the same vocabulary can make it easier to agree to disagree.  (30)

title: Franz Boas and the Humboldtian Tradition: From Volkgeist and Nationalcharakter to an Anthropological Concept of Culture
text: [Summary Note] Bunzl's article provides in its bulk a pretty thorough basic summary of the Germano-Romantic tradition of thought (as I call it) from the time of HErder, Kant, and the Humboldt brothers into the late 19th century anthropologists like Theodore Waitz and Adolf Bastian. It is useful. Bunzl essentially accepts the account of this tradition laid out by Isaiah Berlin as he refers to these ideas using the title of Berlin's famous essay: "The Counter-Enlightenment." (20) But Bunzl also at the same time emphasizes that this tradition was committed to a version of cosmpolitnaism. (20-21) And at one point he asserts that "Waitz reasserted the unique combination of universalism aqnd particularism exemplified in the anthropology of Herder and Wilhelm von Humboldt; like them, he saw the separation of humanity into distinct peoples as an affirmation of commun humanity." (46) The remainder of the essay is dedicated to demonstrating the connection between Boas' ideas and htis tradition. He does this quite effectively in the section "Boasian anthropology: From Museum Debates to the Cosmographical Critique of the Comparative Method." (52-63) His main assertion comes on 61 when after discussing Boas' "Limiations of the Comparative Method of Anthropoloogy" (paper given in 1896 at the AAAS critiquing the evolutionists) he quotes Boas at length and then says: "Boas here tied together the theoretical currents of historicist Counter-Enlightenment thinking: first, the skepticism of finding natural laws governing human behavior; second, the rejection of psychic unity of humanity, operating according to rational principles regardless of space and time; third, the focus on the individuality and diversity of phenomena as opposed to their similarity and unvierality; finally, the emphasis on actua hsitorical development in place of ocnjectures and speculatoin, on induction as opposed to deduction." (61) One particularly valuable thing I realized while reading this article (which Bunzl notes but does not draw out) is that the fact tat Boas did not in fact completely reject the evolutionists desire to ascertain laws is significant also in terms of the fact that in Boas' very early "The Study of Geography" (1887) in which Boas describes Naturwissenschaften and Geisteswissenschaften as two "desires of the mind" (affective and aeshetic) that this is significant in that it what Boas has effectively attempted to do here is bridge these two traditions by arguing that they are fundamental modes of inquiry to all human minds. I don't htink anybody has really noted that about this text, but it is significant in that it demonstrates Boas' desire to mediate between these two traditions... It is also interesting perhaps that he does this in a somewhat psychological manner, describing these modes of inquiries ase "desires"... Bunzl's article is good...the only thing that I migth criticize it on is its desire to see Boas' turn toward culture as entirely linked to and emerging out of this "Humbuoldtian tradition" (as he calls it) of thought. One of the things my War Chatper will do for instance is point out that culture emerged not so much out of his commitment or engagement with this tradition but his need to come up with a rhetorical response to the war...and to what he perceived as the destruction of the intellectual project which is best captured not by a strong commitment to the Humbolditan tradtion but rather to the ability to bridge that tradition and the more positivistic Anglo-French that one can see in "The Study of Geogrpahy."

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text:
p.015 Characterization of pre-1920 Professional Structure of Anth

"Though Boas and many of his early students conducted much of their research in universities, prior to 1920, only about half of the anthropologists in the United States worked in universities.  Many anthropologists worked in museums.  Often local private philanthropists funded museums, and much of the funding for anthropological research came from small, local organizations or individuals.  Early in the twentieth century, departments of anthropology at universities in America were closely connected with local museums, and anthropologists working in academic institutions received funding from individual philanthropists also.  Boas and the students in the departrment of anthropology at Columbia in which he worked received substantial financial support for research from one women[sic], Elsie Clews Parsons.  In 1906, Alfred Louis Kroeber, Boas' student, established an anthropology department at the University of California at Berkeley with funds from another woman philanthropolist, Phoebe Hearst." (15)

title: Verging on Etra-Vagance: Anthropology, Hisotry, Religion, Literature, Arts...Showbiz
text:
(3) p.24 Benedict, Mead, Belo as "scientists"

His notion of Ultra-Objectivity allows him to say that 
Mead andBenedict are scientists...of a sort.

He writes: "Ruth Benedict, Jane Belo, and Margaret Mead--following from Fanz Boas--considered themselves scientists of sorts, as do I."  (24)

And from here he dismisses the binary opposiitin between Freemand and Mead as ridiculous.  This is another polemic "waged in the name of 'objectivity.'" (24)

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text:
p.006-10  Positive Lib. Analysis

Positive liberty.  She says it "expands" on neg lib.  It focuses on the "'positive' provisions of the conditions necessary to take advantage of negative liberties..." (7)

Pays attention to context--in fact, though some neg. lib. theorists have worked this init. def.  into neg.  lib.e..g seeing poverty as an 'external barrier'...(7)

But what neg. lib cannot think of is idea of 'internal barriers' i.e. immediate desires whcih interfere w/ more noble, higher, or 'second order desires' (7) which represent the "true self" of the indivi. 

So Berlin an dother neg. lib. theorists play down, in other words, the idea that the self can be divided against itself that it can have conflicting desires. (8)

She give an example.  She wants to quit smoking but she gets in a fight with her department chair which provokes her to give into her desire to smoke, a desire which most would agree makes her less free...

So in the case that she gives into the lower order desire to smoke she is no longer free, she is not "exercising" her freedom.  Not pursuing her true self in its desire to quit smoking.  "For this reason, Taylor calls positive liberty an 'exercise concept' of freedom: people must exercise their full capacities if they are to be considered free." (8)

But this idea that one's own desires can be conflicted leads to the other idea that somebody else might at a certain moment whne you are giving into lower order deires, know what is better for you, and traditionally that "someone" is the state...i.e. positive lib can justify totalitarianism or male patriarchal attitudes toward women. (8)

Taylor proposes a solution to this, that avoids the "totalitarian menace" -- i.e. he think that each individual can be consicous of higher an dlower order desires in himself and know how to work toward those higher order deires. (9-10)  He gives example of not wanting to yell at woman with whom he has an important relationship...

But Hirschman (9-10) thinks that Taylor oversimplifies pos. liberty in manner of neg. liberty: avoiding the way context constructs higher and lower order desires.  Taylor she says treats these desires as emerging spontaneously from himself, from the "highly individuated subject." (9)

title: The Naturalized Female Intellect
text:
p.211-212 Conceptions of Intelligence

Daston Speaks of a "modern conception of intelligence" that is generalized and morally neutral, quantifiable.... This conception she says emerged by "fits and starts." (211). Moralized intelligence for instance "survived the definitive quantification of intelligence albeit not for very long..." (211-212) E.g. Catherin Cox's 1926 attempt to estimate IQs of Copernicus Voltaire, Goethe, and JS Mill "which included a character rating of, inter alia, their 'degree of sense of humor,' 'trustworthiness' family affection,' 'pure-mindedness,' and 'neatness'." (212). Daston asays that Cox's ideas were last gasp of "an ancient tradition of moralizing the intellect. Whereas mid-twentieth-century psychologists in principle divorced personality and character, in the nineteenth-century there was no attempt to make that distinction. "for examle Darwin identified genius with 'unflinching, undaunted perseverence'; Galton claimed that 'natural ability' was compounded of capacity, zeal and ' an adequate power of doing a great deal of laborious work'" (212). Important categories: Sensitivity: (sensibilite' / sinnlichkeit). It referred to "both perceptual and emotional sensitivity to impressions. Thus sensibility was at once the precondition for empirical knowledge and for the reasonable emotoins of charity and compassion, which bound society together." (212) Reason: "more closely identified with morality, for it was through the 'natural light' of reason that, according to jurists, humans came to recognize all forms of truth, including 'the eternal distinction between good and evil, the inviolable rule of justice [that] receives without difficulty the approbation of every man who refelects and who reasons.'" (212) Qutoe by D'alambert and Diderot.

But most importantly folink r the ideas about women: reason also required certain moral values (that is, as well as generating them).  IT required patience nad concentration and, DAston writes, "[m]ore than one early modern author disqualified women from philosophical contemplation on the ground that they lacked the self-discipline and stamina to follow long demonstrations and intricate arguments: 'It is true that women ordinarily have less application, less patience for reasoning insequence, less courage and resolution than men.'"  (212)

The "interdependence between moral and intellectual traits opened a channel through which social norms and cultural Values could flow..." (212) [Note: the doctrine of inherited consequences did the same thing in the nineteenth century...]

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
0 p.xi Historiographical Context

Women reformer's persistence in 1920s, after end of Progressive Era.  Historians have for a while recognized women's persistent reform efforts in the 1920s, after the Progressive Era.  E.g. Clarke Chambers' Seedtime of Reform: American Social Service and Social Action 1918-1933 (1963) (whose book had lots of women but didn't note that fact much).  Only after feminists in the academy was it acknolwedged.  J. Stanley Lemons, The Weoman Citizen; and then Ware's Beyond Suffrage and Molley Dewson biography.  In relation to these texts, Muncy wants to provide an "explanation for the dogged determiination of middle-class white female reformeres." (xii).

title: American Moderns: Bohemian New York and the Creation of a New Century
text:
p. 226  Brief Desc. of Sexual Modernism

Belief that women's moving out of the home and sheding their feminine characteristics.  An idea associated with the word Feminism which came into use in the US at this time in the 1910s.  Belief in what she calls "sexual democracy" -- desire to escape from "female-dominated home, male-dominated world." (226) Belief that "the "generative powers of communication" in modernity (what is that??) would put an end to the "battle of the sexes" and would lead to "transcendent friendships unimaginable to earlier generations", the 'true companionship and oneness' of men and women that Emma Goldman preached in her lectures on love." (226)

She also describes it as a an American phenomenon.  (226)

title: The Dainty and the Hungry Man: Literature and Anthropology in the Work of Edward Sapir
text:
p.052-58   Early Development of Sapir's theory

Last Boasian work: "Time Perspective in Aboriginal American Cutlure," published in 1916.  That year Handler thinks was a turning point.  That same year he publishes a paper on Australian composer Percy Grainger and on Americaan culture in response to John Dewey.  In 1917, more writings outside the realm of anthropology: "two reviews of psychoanalytic works, reviews of a series of novels and of a musician's biography, and two essay on literary thoery, all published in the Dial." (53)  Between 1918 and 1921, H notes, that Sapir's writing of such works more or less equaled his anthropological works.  He was publishing in the Dial, Freeman, New Republic, and Nation.  In 1922 his writing of this sort outnumbered his anthropological works.  After that his writing of suchworks dwindled and then his last literary review appearedin 1928.  His poetry publicationfollows a similar pattern.

What he was rethinking here was Boas' paradigm.  He had initially enacted a stricly Boas' model at Ottawa.  (53) HIs major theoretical contribution was the "Time Perspectives" piece in 1916, for descp see 54.  Handler sees it as "uncharacteristic." (54)

Expression of dissatisfaction with Boas' paradigm begins in 1916 letters to Lowie.  He cites 1980 by Richard Preston that Sapir was stimulated by friendship with Radin who in a long letter of 1915 had "castigated Boas for his methodologicaltimidity and lack of historical imagination." (54) Radin thought "Boas was far too concerned iwth reconstruction chronological accounts of the development of primitive culture and with 'certain general factors, like dissemination, convergent evolution, independent origin, etc.'" (Handler's words with Radin quote, 54)

Sapir seemed to echo Radin in his 1916 letters to Lowie.  (55)

Handler quotes at length Sapir explaining why he engages in music and his dissatisfaction wththe profession.  Hander's analysis on 56-57.  He captures the dualities, tradeoffs, and binaries that Sapir lays out and connects it to Boas' aesthetic v. affective division in humn sceince.  He brings up that around 1920 anthropology was being taught by Goldenweiser who was beocming interested in "wholes" and on the other hand Parsons who taugh it as an "enourmous mass of little bits of material, carefully labeled by time, palce and tribe..." (Mead's words I think from Mead, 1959 book Anthropologist at work, p8)...Handler ssums it up: "there was the duty to study culture elements and a desire to discover culture wholes--an inuman science in place and a human sicence on the horizon." (58)--by saying "inhuman" Handler is referring back to Sapir's description of the discipline as "unhuman".

[Note: I think Handler misses the bureaucratic component here.  This is about dissatisfaction with anthropology as a professional science.  How else could Sapir refer to Anthropology as "unhuman"!--a science that studies human in the broadest sense?]

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text: 000 Introduction 000

title: The Problem of the Convergence of Industrial Societies: A Critical Look at the State of Theory
text:
[Summary Card]
Weinberg's article gives a very (very!) brief history of two centuries of convergence theory, and then attempts to examine contemporary (1969) modernization theory to discovery the ideas about convergence that persist therein.  Weinberg states on p.4 that he will make an attemp to "salvage" the concept as "worthy of more attention."  What he finds is that although contemporary modernization theory often denies convergence, its theories often resemble the assumptions of 18th and 19th century convergence theory.  Weinberg details this on pgs. 9-13.  In the end, he suggests that convergence theory might be salvaged if it were put on a more empirical basis.  The problem with modernization theory as with older convergence theory is that the deductive method produces abstractions which seem arbitary and assume that convergence ends with the state of modern industrial society in the west as it exists at the itme of the writer.  Weinberg writes: "Too littl ethus explains too much." (12)
This article is useful not only because of its critique of modernization theory a la Parsons, etc, but also because it provides some very very brief but useful summaries of the basic tenets of modernization theory, and also includes extensive citations of that theory.  Besides all that,  Weinberg's idea that the hypothesis that a process of convergence is occurring in history might survive an exposure to extensive empirical data is somewhat useful, especially if we free ourselves of the idea that our the contemporary state of society is the end-point of convergence, is a point well-taken.  This insight may also make

title: Autonomy in Moral and Political Philosophy (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
text:
Section 3.2 - Identity and Conceptions of the Self

Autonomy as described in the article attaches to individuals, not groups.  So critics claim that autonomy is problematic becuase it ignores that "we are all not only deeply enmeshed i nsocial relations and cultural patterns, we are also defined by such relations." (See Sandel 1982, 15-65)  Language is a particulaar important example, since it is a social product.... "In any nmber o way we are constitued by factors that lie beyond our reflective control but which nonetheless structure outr values, thoughts, and motivations." (She cite Taylor's The Ethics of Idenitty and also Bell here).

This also brings up the quesiton of the "relation of the self to its culture."  This becomes important in discussions of cultural rights and naitonslism, because such a def'n of autonomy "exludes those indivdiudals and gorups whose self-identity and value commitments are deeply constituted by cultural factors from the protection of liberal princpiles and policies." And also it "forestalls moves to rpove state protection for cultural forms themselves..."

title: The Invention of Leisure in Early Modern Europe
text: 00 Summary Note 00 Burke is revisiting a focus of research that had begun in the 60s about leisure. He starts out the essay reviewing the arguments and the main propositions that began with the initial set of studies, and then he proposes some points in support of the thesis that "leisure activities of different kinds, whether for children or adults, males or females, came to be viewed as less and less marginal from the late Middle Ages onwards." (144) In tracing the general argment, Burke emphasizes the idea that the recent work has been based on the idea "of a fundamental discontinuity or great divide between pre-industrial and industrial society....[that] in medieval and early modern Europe, as in other pre-industrial societies, the modern idea of leisure was lacking. The modern distinction between theideas of work and leisure, like the regular alternation of work an dleisure, was a product of industrial capitliasm. Pre-industrial societies had festivals (together with informal and irregular breaks from work), while industrial societies have leisure, weekends, and vacations. The emergece of leisure is therefore part of the process of modernization." (137, here he cites M.R. Marrus, The Emergence of Leisure, 1974). He admits then that it is hard to defend the idea of a continuous history of leisure without "rupture," but as indicated in the ittle, he thinks that leisure began to be defined in this other way in the ealry modern period. Between 138-142, he does an etymologyical analysis in several languages, esp. french, latin, italian, and english. He finds that the word leisure was not so much in use as was the word pastimes... Then though he notes a debate in which the likes of Ben Jonson, Milton and Marvell in the England defended "traditional holidays and pastimes, which were under threat for a mixture of religious and economic reasons." (143) Some reformers though of pasttimes and wasted time or in terms of the sin of ideleness. (143) He notes then that a medical discourse on ozio onesto also emerged citing the need for "refreshment" through sleep, games, music and other recreations. (144) That is how he leads up to the rest of the paper wherein he lays out seven points in support of the idea that leisure had begun to be develpoed in the early modern period. In laying out these points, however, he basically reinforces the basic point that had been develloped before, that is even as this concept of leisure is developing it 1) supports a new sharp division between work and labor, and 2) leisure activities are subject to useful or "rational" recreation. He does however suggest that the notion of free time may originally have been a locus of "reaction" agains the increasingly regulated nature of society in the early modern period (i.e. the development of the notion of "discipline" as Foucoult described It), bu tthat as free time itself became more organized and regulated "people became more conscious of it as a separate domain, rather than as a pause between boutsof work. As work became less playful and working hours were more sharply defined, there was more need for the non-utilitarian activities we have come to call 'leisure.'" (150) One feature of Burke's analysis is also to highlight the notion of leisure's initial emergence among elites. For example, when the academies arose in italian cities in the 16th and 17th centuries, it seems that these instituions wer eseen as promoting a new form of lesiure. That he says is indicated by the "names of some of these upper class discussion clubs, including the 'idlers' (Oziosi) and the 'unemployed' (Sfaccendati)." (147) At the end of his essay, after having pointed out that the regimentation of work, helped produce the increasingly importance of the notion of leisure among all classes, Burke thus writes; "In that sense, we owe our concept of leisure to the poeple hwo, long before the Industrial Revolution, were obsessed with making others work." (150)

title: Organizing Knowledge and Behavior at Yale's Institute of Human Relations
text:
p.227 Wissler at Yale Institute of Psychology

Clark Wissler had found a place for himself in Yale's Institute of Psychology founded in 1924 with funding from the Rockefeller Memorial.

title: Of Feys and Culture Planners: Margaret Mead and Purposive Activity as Value
text: p. 102 Culture Planners? Sullivan thinks she meant by culture planners the members of Veblen's "Soviet of Technicians" from his Engineers and the Price System. He notes that Mead's parents had studied with Veblen at chicago. Also notes Mead's later association with Howard Scott & Technocracy Inc. (102)

title: Imagining Totality: Rhetorics of and Versus Culture
text: 00 Summary 00 Hegeman evaluates the wisdom of "jettisoning" the word culture in this article. Her biggest argument, which she achieves through a thorough analysis of Walter Benn Michaels critique of the term, is that many of those who would like the term not to be uses, and i particular Michaels, implicitly equate culture with the "totality" of what we believe. Thus by making it something we cannot discuss in their mind they prevent us from imagining the totality. Thus her defense of the term culture is that it 1) helps us thinking about totality and 2) that in thinking about it we might realize that such totlaities are provisional. Here' s they key quote: "In other words, I am not sure that we are entirely "beyond" thinking in terms of totality. Nor do I consider totalizing knowledges illegitimate as ways of thinking. Postmodern "anti-totalizing" positions usefully teach us not that we are confinied in our knowledges to the local and to the personal, but rather that the totalities we propose are provisional--that total knowledge only exists in the moment before we shift our perspective or take into account the next bit of evidence, the next voice." She also points out that Michaels' argues from a particular vantage in the US where nationalism has become a negative project; whereas she point out via an essay by Arif Dirlik, Culturalism as hegemonic Ideology" and a book by Partha Chatterjee," The Naiton and its Fragments: colonail and Postcolonial Histories" that "particularly in postcolonial contexts, nationalism has strong anti-imperialist and (like cultural politics) should not be simplistically dismissed as political a political evil." see f.n. #35.

title: The Cultural Return
text:
On Aesthetics

* Most interestingly, she says that in the academy this return of master narratives has produced a "renewal of interests in aesthetics, ethics, and even theology." (4) There's a return she says to "literary formalism" and in general a rejection of interdisciplinary muddiness and a demand for disciplinarity clarity.  These demands come along with polemics against "culturalism" and historicism and "content analysis." (3)  She notes that "cultural studies" is usually labeled as the "imperialist" disciplinary villian.  And "[t]othis overreaching, relativistic, anarchic, and hypocritically market-oriented cultural studies is opposed a newly sober, properly disciplined study of the good, the true, and the beautiful." (5) Hence aesthetics...

(Key here I tihnk is that I think for Hegeman aesthetics is understood as a particular ideology of justification of the liberal-bourgeois order... as in Eagleton's article on the subject...? 

* She traces this return to aesthetics on 5-6 /  Alexander Alberro sees it as a response to a contemporary moment defined by a series of "catastrophes" in the face of which it is somehow unsurprising that there has been a call by writers for a "pathos-infused, humanist aesthetics." (5) Alan Badiou sees it as a failure of the left after teh collapse of revolutionary marxism, where the left has adopted the "principles of the established 'Western' order" instead of seeking out "terms of new politics of collective liberation..." (5)

* The reaction to a sense of crisis that is propelling a return to aesthetics she think si also evident in "calls for the return to the aesthetic, where beauty is aligned with a realm of pleasure neglected by the modernist (and political) emphasis on the sublime." (5) She cites Wendy Steiner's Venus in Exile.  But also "more complexly" she points to an arguemnt by Chris Castiglia and Ross Castronovo about how cultural studies "debunked" traditional essentialized identities but did so "without supplying in their stead grounds for collective life that are affectively satisfying as well as theoretically plausible." (quoted on 5)  Castiglia and Castronovo see the tIntroductionurn to aesthetics as a respond to this "putative failure" in that it "traffics in affective sensations that promise--wtihotu necessarily providing--post-identity or non-normative forms of collectivism." (quoted on 5)  Castiglia and Castronovo Hegeman points out are interested in "resolving the individualism of aesthetic experience with collectivity: that is, in renegotiating the relationship between aesthetics and politics." (5-6)  She thinks this is pretty typical of the new calls for a consideration of aesthetics, much as she says those (e.g. Nussbaum) calling for a return to ethics are interested in "bridging the gap between humanist universals and the particularities of identity and subjectivity." (6)

title: From Experts to Social Scientists: The American Anthropologists, 1929-1963
text:
p.016 - 18 Shifts in funding structure 1929 and after... 

1929 Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial merges with Rockefeller Foundation; Ruml retires, later to take position at SSRC.  (16) 

Rockefeller foundation was less willing to support social scieinces: "Before the fondation had merged with the Memorial, medical professionals controlled the activities of the Rockefeller Foundation, and the institution was willing to support social scientific research." (17)

This fact plus the crash of the stock market meant that there were limited funds available to social science and after 1934 "Foundation officials abandoned most of their direct support of social scientific institutions." (17) 

Nonetheless, through the 1930s the SSRC depending "almost exclusively on Rockefeller money." (17)   And the "agenda of the Rockefeller Foundation and Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial indicated clearly to anthropologists that in order to receive funds for research, anthropologists had to cooperate closely with other social scientific disciplines and be more rigorously 'scientific.'" (17)

title: Of Feys and Culture Planners: Margaret Mead and Purposive Activity as Value
text:
p. 111 - 114  Mead & Progress

Sullivan then analyzes Mead's correspondence mainly with Gorder but also Dollard and concludes convincingly from these sources that Mead perceived "Progress" to be a positive notion.  But here Progress was built upon instability or a lack of self-fulfillment that is a product of the culture (i.e. the non-Balinese culture, the non-fey culture, the N[orth] or S[outh] culture) and which then required that a gap be filled...that is the gap could be filled with "art"... and not just social institutions which created provisions for self-fulfillment... 

The "culture planner" also played a role here.  The culture planner helped push unbalanced people into a focused concentration on their work, but that focused concentration on their work was NOT the kind of concentration that the Balinese possessed which Sullivan shows Bateson made clear in a quote quoted on 114.  

This is excellent analysis here.

Laslty on 114, Sullivan notes that when Mead was still enthusiastic about "Progress" and that when she returned to the US in the midst of WWI she "easily eit into wartime work; her concepts of culture, personality, and temperament offered a useful conceptual scheme that scholars might use to frame the research they produced to fulfill the demands of the U.S. government for knowledge of allied and enemy cultures." (114) -- i.e. knowledge using these kinds of dichotomies between static, equilibrated, fey cultures and unstable, dynamic, and un-equilibrated cultures in which the culture planner played a necessary role.

title: Social Thought in America: The Revolt Against Formalism
text:
[126] [NY Times article on Beard's resignation from Columbia]
Editorial in the NY Times on October4 10, 1917 when Beard resigns from Columbia critizes him for criticizing the writers of the consistution as having class-interest, and for being associated with a school they associate with ideas "borrowed from Germany" i.e.  "economic determinsim."  
"Columbia...is better for Professor Beard's resignation.  Some years ago Professor Beard published a book [Economic Interpretation of the Constitution] in which he sought to show that the founders of this Republic and the authors of its Constitution were a ring of land speculators who bestowed upon the country a body of organic law drawn up chiefly in the interest of their own pockets.  It was pointed out to him at the itme, with due kindness but frankly, that his book was bad, that it was a book no professor should have written, since it was grossly unscientific...It was the fruit of that school of thought and teaching...borrowed from Germany, which denies ot man in his larger actions and capacity of noble striving and self-sacrifice for ideals, that seeks always as the prompting motive either the animal desire to get more to eat or the hope of fillin ghis pockets.  If this sort of teaching were allowed to go unchecked by public sentiment and the strong hands of University Trustees, we should presently find edcuated American youth applying the doctrine of economic determinism to everything from the Lord's Prayer tothe binomial theorem." (Quoted on 126).

title: The Dainty and the Hungry Man: Literature and Anthropology in the Work of Edward Sapir
text:
p.065-

Now Handler connects Sapir's discussion of art more concretely to Sapir's theory of culture.

He starts with Sapri's review of Lowie's Primitive Society.  Sapir appreciates it as the epitome of the Boasian school, which is defined by "inducvie historical research,, which it opposes to evolutionary speculation and psychological reductionism: 'We learn to see a given primitive society...as a complex of historical processes that is only to be unraveled, and then in insigifant degree, thorugh a minute weighing of the concrete, interacting features of that society and through the patient following out of the numerous threats that inevitably bind it to its geographical neighbors." (quoted on 65-66)

H also notes what he calls Sapir's sense that the "historical process is huma rather than superorganic."  He quotes as evidence: "No one that has watched the gradual, tortuous emergence of a social instituiton from the warp and woof of circumstance can feel it in his heart to say that he is but beholding the determinate unfolding of....whatever psychological concept be accepted for guidance." (quoted on 66, from 378 in Sapir's text).  [Note: I notice two things here, one that he invokes the heart/intuition as guidance for the interpreter, and then that he mentions a "psychological concept" guiding the emergence of social institutions...what does he mean?]

H next treats Sapir's review of Parsons edited text American Indian Life.  Sapir likes it because it shows the perspective from the those who live it.  Sapir had defined cutlure in the Lowie review as "the fine art of living" and praised Lowie fro retaining a "Humanness of attitude" (quoted 66).  So Sapir saw the volume as improvement because it did not stop at the surface but explored the "individual consciousness". H suggests tthat Sapir had linked his conception of the ethnologist with the ideal he had set out for "realism in prose iction." (66)

Then he moves to "cutlure, Genuine and Spurious," which he says was "almost certainly" completed by 1918.  He say it "contains the first rigorous definition of the Boasian conception of culture as the genius of a people, seein in terms of the patterning of values." (67)  Drawing on Kroeber and Kluckhon's 1952 clasifcation, he notes that this was the first expression of "what came commoly to be known as 'cutlural integration.'" (67) He notes Sapir's dismissal of the term as anything but an abstraction and then goes into his cahracterizaiton of a genuine culture (67-69) Genuine culture is consistent and eschews what Boas had called "secondary rationalizations" (see pl67 in 1911 Mind of Primitive Man) which for Sapir are "the dry rot of social habit, devitalized..." (p.315 in H's version of Genuine Spurious).  And then he identifies the idea that the genuine culture works from "the individual to ends." (quoted on 69).  That creativity is "the ending of form tone's will, not a manufacture of from ex nihilo." (quoted o 69)

H observes accurately that "the romantic formulation of the idea of the cutlural harmony or integration would gie way to the epistemological doubts [with which Sapir started the article] express in his argument agains the superorganic.  Sapir came to insist that culural wholes are analytic constructions, not real objects.   When anthropologists pseak of 'a culture,' they refer to a pattern or system that they themselves have constructed in the analysis of their data.  Cutlure in this sense is a modela bstracted from human interaction." (69)  More on this reaction on 70, that the "true locus of cultre is in the interactions of specific individuals and, on the subjective side, in the wrld of meaning which each one of htese individuals may unconsicously abstract from himself from his particiaption in thsese interactions." (from Cutlra Anthropology and Psychiatry, 515) (70)

H's reasonable summary aobut the links between Sapir's art and anthropology is here: "In both, Sapir's first goal is to understand subjective realities and experiential tuth as individuals know them.  In both, he concludes that an excessive concern with out realism--ont he part of the omniscient narrator or the anthropologist who reifies culture--produces a distorted view of reality, however much it prenteds to objectivity.  In boht, he favors instead a focus on the interaction of subjectivities, on multiple inner points of view.  Finally, in both his art and his anthropology, Sapir treats formal givens--artistic conventions or cutlural values--as means to self-expression rather than constraints upon individual freedom." (70)

title: Aesthetic Judgement
text:
General Notes 4/11/12

* Beauty and ugliness a big part of human life and so philosohpers have tried to understand those "judgements" and "experiences" and understand whether they were "legitimate."  Since 18th century, much thinking on the subject had put forward a notion of "the aesthetic" and then in the 20th century this concept came under sharp critique.  Zangwill thinks that this hostility to the aesthetic may have roots in "broader cultural Puritanism, which fears the connection between aesthetic and pleasure." (1) -- although this seems to be his particular take as perhaps someone interested in what Hegeman in her Cultural Return critiques as a return to the aesthetic. 

...

 

I've sort of skipped through this article because for my present purposes it seems too ideological in the way Hegeman would suggest -- ie demanding a return to a humanist aesthetics. 

His reading of Kant downplays the autonomy that Kant gave to the aesthetic realm rather strongly, choosing to elevate Kant's idea that there was a kind of universality in the objectified judgements of "taste".  See p.2-5, and his section on Disinterrestedness.  Also comments about the problematic claims of "relativists" on 7-8.

See Hegeman's Cultural Return, e.g. 5-6 for an account and critique of the return to "aesthetics."Also in a more general sesne the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy on "Kant's Aesthetics and Teleology" has at the start of section 2.8 on "Aesthetics and Morality" a brief description of the fact that the dominant interpretation has been to see Kant as granting relative autonomy to aesthetic thought, but that there are also those who "take the demand for universal validity made
by a judgment of beauty to amount to a moral demand, so that Kant's argument for the universal validity of such judgments depends on an appeal to morality." (26)

title: The Metaphysical Club: A Story of American Ideas
text:
Notes taken December 2012

Summary Note:

    Menand roots Pragmatism deeply in the Civil War.  For instance, for Oliver Wendel Holmes, the Civil War rids him of his strong faith in beliefs and teaches him to see strong belief as a sure path to violence.  Menand's ethical evaluation of Pragmatism is ambivalent: he clearly admires its subtlety and sensitivity and shares its recognition of the limits of ideas, but he also is unsure of its usefulness for us today.  It is on the one hand, as he notes in the Preface, a philosophy that supports that sense of "perpetual upheaval" upon which capitalism thrives; but it is also a philosophy born of a very different time: out of the indivdiualistic spiritual energies of the Second Great Awakening, out of the debate over Slavery, and out of the Civil War.  This idea that it is a philosophy somehow foreign to us or born out of cirumstances foreign to us seems to dominate the book in a way.  Perhaps it is only because Menand is such a good writer and is capable of evoking a feeling of this time that one gets the sense that Menand does in fact think this philosophy is born of another and very different time.

Preface

* M sets up significance of his pragmatic thinkers: Oliver Wendell Holmes, William James, Charles S. Pierce, and John Dewey in relationship to the Civil War.  This war he says allowed the Republican congress to dictate policy during and after the war.  The result was that "[f]or more than thirty years, a strong central government protected and promoted the ascendance of industrial capitalism and the way of life associated with it -- the way of life we call 'modern.'" (x) At the same time, however, the violence of the war seemed to suggest a failure of democracy and also a "failure of culture, a failure of ideas." (x)  M compares the Civil War's impact on "culture" to that of WWI: it seemed to invalidate the assumptions of that culture that existed before the war.  So he thinks that the Civil War swept away the South's slave culture, but also the North's "intellectual culture."  The struggle to come up with a new set of ideas is the story he is telling about pragmatism.  (x)  And these were "modern" ideas -- ie. ideas linked to industrial capitalism and the way of life that it entailed.  (x)

* He gives a brief general description of what he sees as holding these thinkers together: namely, an "idea about ideas." (xi):

They all believed that ideas are not "out there" waiting to be discovered, but are tools--like forks and knives and microchips--that people devise to cope with the world in which they find themselves.  They believed that ideas are produced not by individuals, but by groups of individuals--that ideas are social.  They believed that ideas do not develop according to some inner logic of their own, but are entirely dependent, like germs, on their human carriers and the environment.  And they believed that since ideas are provisional responses to particular and unreproducible circumstances, their survival depends not on their immutability but on their adaptability." (xi-xii)

* He makes a sharp but limited critique of this approach to ideas.  He notes that it was an approach to ideas that was non-ideological in that it prevented them from either "justifying the status quo, or dictating some transcendent imperative for renouncing it" (xii).  He sees it as a kind of "skepticisim" which he says helped people "cope" with life in a "heterogenous, industrialized, mass-market society, a society in which older human bonds of custom and community seemed to have become attenuated, and to ahve been replaced by impersonal networks of obligation and authority." (xii) It was a philosphy that said something abut the limits of ideas as well as their use.  His critique is then that such skepticism also supports the "continual state of upheaval that capitalism thrives on." (xii)

Epilogue

[Note: Dewey's Experience and Nature, M says, used the word experience exactly as Holmes had in his opening paragraph of The Common Law: ie to mean "Culture." And apparently Dewey said later that he wished he'd called the book Culture and Nature!!. (437)]

* The epilogue is structured around the idea that these thinkers' ideas fell out of fashion during the Cold War. M uses the death of Dewey in June 1952 and the explosion of the nuclear bomb five months later as the events which mark that transition.  Then he asks why did this happen? 

* One answer which he says is "simple"--but which doesn't seem that way to me--is that their ideas "became identified with the work of disciples whose stature was a lot less intimidating and whose claims struck many people as a lot more controversial." (438).  This is for me a very oblique sentence.  What does he mean by "intimidating"?  He gives the example that Holmes' critique of formalism was taken up in the 20s and 30s by a school of jurisprudence known as Legal Realism "whose representatives made assertions about the poltical bias in legal principles (while dropping entirely Holmes' opposition to judicial activism) that went beyond anything in Holmes." (438)  He notes also how Dewey's ideas were taken up to focus on "child-ceneredness" in progressive education that during the Cold War was seen as lacking in "discipline and rigor." (438)  So this seems like the ideas were used crudely and in a narrow and simple way?  But then he gives other examples that seem to point to somethign else.  For example, he says that the "therapeutic side" of James thought that "philophy can be motivational" that was a product of his struggles "with indecision and depression" "did not surive a transplant from a culture in which emotional restraint was counted a virtue to one in which emotional released was considered a panacea." (439)  This seems like a different problerm: ie that the ideas had lost their footing in the shifting ideas of the different periods?--something that certainly would itself be a subject of discussion for the pragmatist? So this is a confusing argument...

* Then he notes that in the pragmatists' own conception as "modernsits" it was reasonable that their ideas would be superceded, but he doesn't think that this what happened.  Their ideas did not go out of fashion because they were "unique" he says but because they were seen as "naive" and "dangerous" in the context of the Cold War. (439)   So he puts a lot of weight on the Cold War as the event causing the pragmatists' ideas to lose resonance.  He says then that he thinks that their philosophy elevated above all others the notion of tolerance.  He says not tolerance as in religious tolerance but "the tolerance, say, of a piece of steel." (440)

The pragmatists wanted a social organism that permitted a greater (though by no means unrestricted) margin for difference, but not just for the sake of difference, and not even because they thought principles of love and fairness required it.  They wanted to create more social room for error because they thought this would give good outcomes a better change to emerge.  They didn't just want to keep the conversation going; they wanted to get to a better place. (440)

M stress that this was view that made compromise important.  The compromise involved an exercise of tolerance that ultimately provided the moral justification for the dominant ideas/view that would emerge:

Though we may believe unreservedly in a certain set of truths, there is always the possibility that some other set of truth might be the case.  In the end, we have to act on what we believe; we cannot wait for confirmation from the rest of the universe.  But the moral justification for our actions comes frmo the tolerance we  have shown to others ways of being in the world, other ways of considering the case.  The alternative is force.  Pragmastism was deseigned to make it harder for peole to be driven to vioelnce by their beliefs." (440)

The desire to avoid violence had come from their experience in the Civil War.  It was a way of makingB441) demcoracy non-violent again; it was a triumph of "unionism" he says (, by which I think he means the more conservative side of the anti-slavery movement that led up to  the Civil War: ie not the Abolitionists.  But all of this doesn't exactly fit with the Cold War mentality which he says was a "war over principles." "The notion that the values of the free society for which the Cold War was waged were contingent, relative, fallible constructions, good for some purposes and not so good for others, was not a notion compatible with the moral imperatives of the age." (441)

* M notes that the movement for civil liberties of the 50s and 60s was a movement that was based on the "belief that every individual has an inalienable right to those freedom by virtue of being human--precisely the individualism that Holmes and Dewey felt they needed to discredit." (441)  He notes that MLK was no Pragmatist and that "it is a question whether the movement he led could have accomplished what it did if its inspirations had come from Ddewey and Holmes rather than Reinhold Niebuhr and Mahatma Gandhi." (441)

* Now pointing to the more recent present he notes that as soon as the Cold War ended "the ideas of Holmes, James, Peirce, and Dewey reemerged as suddenly as they had been eclipsed." (441) They suited the post-Cold War world in which there were a multiplicity of point of view and competing belief systems.  Although I wonder whether he has in saying this undrestood the impact of the september 11th attacks, which seemed to have returned many in the U.S. at least to a Cold War hard-core principled metnality.  But perhaps he is write when he says that there is a sense that no value system can finally be the right one and that pragmatism is suited to this condition.  There has he thinks been also an elevation of an idea in political theory "that democracy is the value that validates all other values.  Democratic participation isn't the means to an end, in tihs way of thinking; it is the end." (442) 

* But in his last words he questions whether these ideas will be important for us.  He says it is not yet clear, but that in fact we are a long long way from the world of these thinkers.  (442)

Pt. 1

* Menand situates Oliver Wendell Holmes in the context of his father's moral conventionalism, the politics of slavery, and hsi reverence for Emerson.  This is a complexly told story.

* A key point in the analysis comes when Holmes has volunteered for the Union Army, which he had done partly out of a comitement to anti-slavery politics.  Then he is involved in an early battle that was catastrophic and in which he nearly died.  Two thigns happened there.  Menand says he "road tested" his beliefs.  The results are contained in a quote on 37.  Menand thinks he had found that "he did not require a religious faith.  Uncertainty--'I am to take a leap in the dark'--turned out to be all the certainty he needed." (37)  Holmes also marvelled at thew ay his mind adapted itself to the what seemed to be the fact of his imminent death and then readapted to the fact that he woud llive.  Menand writes, partly quoting Holmes: "'How rapidly the mind adjusts itself': the test of a belief is not immutability, but adaptability.  Our reasons for needing reasons are always changing." (38)

*  From this point, Menand explains that Holmes had developed a new perspective, and he suggets at various stages that Holmes carefully redacted every piece of evidence in his letters and diaries that suggested at his earlier self: the one that was rigidly dedicated to heroic/transcendental ideals.  "The letters to his family that survive never refer explicitly to the beliefs that led Holmes to go to war in the first place; and although Holmes expressed pride in his sense of o dutay and in his own actions when they demosntrated courage, the cause fo whcih he is fighting is virtually unmentioned.  HOlmes carefully erased every connection between his experiences as a soldier and his views as an abolitionist.  This is not because he cahnged those views.  It is because he changed his view of the nature of views.  Itwas the great lesson the war had taught him, and he took pains, in later life, to make sure the record reflected it." (38)

* A key figure in Holmes' experience of the war as Menand tells it is a man named Henry Abbott who was somebody who doubted his capacity to fucntion heroically ion the war, but once the war began fucntioned with outstanding bravery.  His political views were such that he was anti-salvery and served more out of a sense of miltiaristic duty.  (40)  Holmes' didn't share Abbott's political views, but as he witnessed Abbott's heroism, and as he moved away from a sense that the conviction of moral right could justify war, as he began to view war as a "hideous human waste" (43)  as Menand puts it, then he also started to value Abbott's "professionalism and discipline" as a solider, "to admire success more than purity of faith." (44)  Menand includes a letter to Holmes' father who was still sanctimonious about the rigteousness of the North's cause and he dismisses it.  In a quote on 44-45, he sees war as "slavery's parent".  Menand thinks in other words that the horror of the war had begun to seem to be the consequence of convictions too strongly held. 

* But Menand makes some interesting point about the relationship between Holmes' rejection of the strong moralism and humanism that he had held as a young man and which was as Menand sees it typical of the pre-war Boston world (reminder, he sees the Civil War as creating a rift with the pre-war cutlure of Boston).  For Menand this shift "mirrored a generatinoal shift":

   Holmes's rejection of the intellectual style of prewaqr Boston mirrored a generational shift.  To many of the men who had been through the war, the values of professionalism and expertise were attractive; they implied impersonality, respect for institutions as efficient organizers of enterprise, and a modern and scientific attitude--the opposites of the individualism, humanitarianism, and moralism that characterized Northern intellectual life before the war.  (59)

Menand qualifies this statement in relation to Holmes, however, stating that Holmes had not abandoned moral certitude for duty; rather he "narrowed himself in order better to expand." (59)  He had not given up hope of a "glimpse of the infinite." (59)  This is key. It means, in other words, that Holmes hoped that professionalism would oopen a path to the universal as he wrote Emerson, Menand notes, in 1876.  See quote on p.59.  Menand says that in a sense Holmes had become the "Emerson of professionalism--or as he [Holmes] sometimes called it, 'jobbism.'" (59)  Menand quotes Holmes in a speech in 1886 on "The Profession of the Law":

If this universe is one universe, if it is so far thinkable that you can pass in reason from one part of it to another, it does not matter very much what the fact is .  For every fact leads to every other by the path of the air. (60)

Menand quotes Holmes twice about his notion of intellectual heroism which has to do with finding a path in the wilderness, which has no clearly marked apths.  (60-61)  Menand writes: "In their dedication to the task at hand, human beings make, by their deeds, tracks in the wilderness.  The wilderness itself is trackless." (61) 

* The problem for Holmes, however, was that his idea about ideas, as the war had taught it, was that "certitude leads to violence." (61)  For Holmes, it was the abolitinooists' attitudes that served as the main example of that danger, even though hne admitted that there were people who were more subtle in their thinking among the abolitionists.  (62)  But Holmes believed that everyone was like the abolitionists essentially.  But the force taht could mitigate these "competing conceptions of thew ay life shoudl be from overheating and leading to violence is democracy." (64) 

* Re the politics of socialism v. liberalism, Menand says that Holmes' "personal symathies were entirely with capitalists." (65) His first major dsent in the U.S. Supreme Court was in Northern Securities v. United States (1904) where he defended J.P. Morgan and james T. Hill against antitrust legislation. (65)  Menand says that the key to understanding Holmes' civil liberties and his poltiics was that "he thought only in terms of aggregate social forces; he had no concern for the individual." (65) He wrote "Every societies rests on the deatrh o f men." (quoted on 66).  Menand thinks that he simply had no faith in "individual human agency" and viewed men like Rockefeller as those who simply had a better grasp of "social tendencies" (66)

* So then Menand's interpretation runs counter a bit to  the legend of Holmes as a hero for progressive era reformers like Lippman and Brandeis.  Holmes did emerge as a defender of reform and labor, but it was in the service of his interest in disintersted professionalism, on the one hand, and the idea that one should not be dogmatic, ont he other.  "It has given me great pleasure to sustain the Constitutionality of laws that I believe to be as bad as possible, because I thereby helped to mark the difference between what I would forbig and what the Constitution permits..." (quoted on 67, a letter to John T. Morse.)   Menand wirites that "he believed taht every social itnerests should ahve its chance." (67)

Pt.2


* William James -- very indecisive.  Some biographrers blamed his father's "mixed signals" (75) for James character.  But Menand thinks: "James believed that risk-assuming decisiveness--betting on an alternative even before all the evidence is in--was the supreme mark of character.  He thought that the universe would meet such a person halfway.  But he also thought that certainty was moral death, and he hated to foreclose anything." (75) Net result was that he developed a "self-conscious impulsivity", regularly changing his mind. (75): "In 1903 he began the process of trying to decide to retire whether to retire.  His diary for the fall of 1905 reads: October 26, 'Resign!'; October 28, 'Resign!!!'; November 4, 'Resign?'; November 7, 'Resign!'; Nobember 8, 'Don't resign'; November 9, 'Resign!', November 16, 'Don't Resign!', November 23, 'Resign'; December 7, 'Don't Resign'; December 9, 'Teach here next year.' He retired in 1907." (75-76). Santayana, who had James as a teacher and then colleague at Harvard and was ambivalent about him, wrote: "He was so extermely natural that there was no knowing what his nature was, or waht to expect next; so that one was driven to behave and talk conventionally, as in the most aritificial society." (77)  James put it htis way: "...every gush of feeling should be followed by adequate action." (77)

* James' family were not part of Bost Brahimn society--being descended from Irish immigrants on both sides--but they enjoyed great socails uccess. (77)

* James' grandfather, also William, was a "classic product of the Second Great Awakening. (79)  Henry James, Sr. was a bit of a black sheep in the family and his father who was rich left him a yearly allotment of 1250, much smaller than his siblings.  He sued and eventually got control the full sum he was due.  He then had leisure for life and also made possible the "unusual" education of his sons Henry Jr. and William.  (79)  During the period that thew ill was in question, Henry was roaving around upsate NY drinking and gambling and then at somepoint while living in Bufallo was reborn at about the same time when he got access to the sum of his inheritance.  Henry's religious thought taken from the Burned-over District was twofold :"an infactuation with the religious impulse and a deep aversion to religious institutions." (81) His second conversion was to Swedenborgianism following a nervous breakdown he suffered in 1844 in which he saw, in his words, "some damned shape squatting invisible to me within the precincts of the room, and raying out from his fetid perosnality influences fatal to life." (quoted on 82)  Swedenborg had an explanation for this event which had undone Henry Sr.'s sense of self-posession, Menand says.  But what he saw in it Meandn saws was "what he saw in every religious teaching eh was influenced by: an injunction to esshew the forms." (82) Given his interest in the eschewing of forms, Henry Sr. was also drawn to Transcendentalism and knew Emerson, having met in NY in 1842.  (Emerson apparently blessed William while visiting the James' house.)  (82-83) Henry Sr. also wrote copiously, although usually funding his own publications.  Menand says: "James [Henry sr.] was an idiosyncratic thinker at atime--the decades before the Civil War--when the landscape swarmed with idiosyncratic religious movements.  He belonged to a way of life and a way of thinking about life that he war and modern science rendered obsolete..." (84)

* Because Henry James Sr. belonged, M thinks, to a way of thinking that the War "rendered obsolete" the questino of his influence on the post-War generation, post-Darwinian thinkers, including William, complex... James himself wrote "All my intellectual life I derive from you." from London as his father lay dying in Cambridge in 1882.  He rpeated this sentiment many times Menand says. (84)  Menand describes Henry James Sr. as a Platonist: "He believed (following Swedenborg) that there are two realms, a visible and an invisible, and that the invisible realm is the real one.  From this premise, theusual conclusions follow : humankind is now separated from the true and the real; its destiny is to arrive at the consummation intended for it by God; philosophers here ot help the rest of us understand what the consumation is." (85)  M says that Henry Sr. reading of this set of ideas was influenced by Swedenborg and by Charles Fourier, a thinker whom Swedenborg was often paired with in the 19th century. (85)  In particular, Henry saw "indepenent selfhood", a belief in it, as an impediment to achieivng a redeemed state.  (85) 

* For William James' the monistic platonism of his father was totally alien-- that "monistic belief in the unchanging reality of an unseen world, indifference to temporal moral distinctions, and anti-individualism..." (88)  James intended pragmatism as a method to subert that "block universe" as he put it, (quoted on 88).  He hated the idea of "undifferentiated oneness" M says; and spoke of a "pluriverse." (88)  And he was very invested in the power of "individual agency" -- so much so M says that Dewey criticized him for it.  But James was, M says, also a "kind of super-Protestant".  He "intended pragmastism as an argument, in philosophy, for discarding obsolte virtual ritual and rejection the authority of prior use."--ie the kind of thrusts that Protestants made. (88)  In this sense, there was continuity between W. James and his father's thinking -- if James' pragmatism struggled against the "block universe" of his father and was thus part of a "disestablishmentarian impulse in American culture--an impulse that drew strength from the writings of Emerson, who attacked institutions and conformity, and from the ascendancy, after the Civil War, of evolutionary theories, which drew attention to the continegency of all social forms," (89) it was also a prodct of the "s[plintering of American Protestantism into multiple religious and quasi-religious sects over the course of the century--the protestantization, so to speak, of Protestanism." (89)  Here there is more continuity with Henry Sr.'s thinking.  And M points out that in many ways James was captivated by the spiritualism that emerged out fo this splintering of protestnaism. E.g. he was fascinated by the "mental states that suggested the existence of an extrasensory realm." (90)  He used hypnotism as a psychologist; experimented with drugs; submitted himself to "mind-cure" methods, and publicly defended their methods.  etc etc.  He believed he wrote near the end of his life: "There is a continuity of cosmic consciousness against which our indivduality builds but accidental fences, andi nto which our several minds plumge as into a mother-sea of reservoir.  Our 'normal' consciousness is circumscrbied for adaption to our external earthly environment, but the fence is weak ins pots, and fitful influences from beyond leak in, showing the otehrwise unverifiable common connection." (quoted on 91) James' turn to an interesting in spiritualism intensified as he was finishing his first book The Principles of Pscyhology (1890).  He talked about an awareness of "split-up selves" in a letter to his sister who was dieing from brteat cancer in London in 1891.  (91) James himself understood this turn as a reversion to his father's interest in the spiritual.  He however also saw his father as from a different generation, writing to his wife after his father's death: "he was full of the fumes of the ursprünglich [primordial] human  nature; tings turbid, more than he could formulate,  wrought within hiim,..." (quoted on 93) So there is continuity there. 

[A very interesting note here-->that Henry Sr.'s reponse to the Fox Sisters was that they were of coruse communicating with spirits but that peopel should stay away.  Spirits were like gossips and troublemakers.  He wrote: "They first arrest our attention by talk of those we have loved....they gradually inflme our ascetic ambitions, our ambition after spiritual distinction: and finally having got a secure hold, who knows though what pools of voluntary filth and degradation they may drag us?" (quotede on 92)  M notes that this conception was "actuallky  much closer to the Fredian idea of the subconscious and to eh premises of pscyoanalysis--which is one of the places where the therapeutic ccurrent int he spiritualist movement was ultimately directed--than his son the psychologsit was." (92) ]

* Chapter "Brazil" deals with Aggasiz, his naturalism and his racial polygenism (he was a follower of Samuel MOrton) and how he resisted Darwinism.  M's analysis of Darwin's thought points to Darwin as an advocate of the role of chance in determining human forms: "chance determines their [variations] adaptive utility." (122)  "The 'selection' of favorable characteristics is therefore neither designed nor progressive." (122) Thus M says natural selection explains why changes occur, and how they occur, but "does not dictate what those changes shall be.  It is a process without mind." (123)  The world in Darwin's concetpion, then, was "characterized by chance, cahnge, and difference..." (123) It was a view of the world that not only departed from the view which related all individual differences to a "general type" that was fixed, dterminate, and uniforjm, but it departed from the languges oftypes and essences entirely by focusing on "interacting individuals." It adopted the langauge of statistics and probability. (124)  This was a challenge to Aggfazi's view of ntural history but also his scientific method.  Agassize resited it at every turn: p.124-128.  In particular, he could not, M says, separate "the phenomenal from the transcendatal: his entire system was tied to the belief that all observable order i nature is prima facie evidence of a supernatural intention."  (128)  Where Darwin did not believe that the word species spefied actually types, but rather a term of convenience used to refer to a set of indivduals that resembled each other (see 123), Aggasiz  believed that species were "categories of thought embodied in individual living forms,' and that natural history was ulimately 'the analysis of the thoughts of the Creator of the Universe, as manifested in the animal and vegetable kingdoms.'"( 128)  After 1860 this viewpoint left Aggasize alienated in Cambridge. (128)

* Section 4 of the Brazil chapters shows James' reaction to Aggasiz and to Darwinism.  TJames had gone an expedition with Aggasiz to Brazil. The point generally was that James was a Darwinian, but not a Darwinist.  Ie he did not view Darwin's theory as a law, and he critiqued Huxley and Herbert Spencer's use of it, while seeing more value in it than Aggasiz's view of natural history.  (141)  The point here more genearlly is that James read Darwin in a way that emphasized the openness of the theory.  He thought people had misread the book in two ways:

1) They had read it as sayign that science was indepdnent of the society's interest or value.   The usual critique of anti-Darwinists is that they confuse science and belief, but for James the problem was that their was a disjunction, as with Aggasiz who's "science wasn't theoretical and his theory wasn't scientific." (141)  Ie they collected data without a hypothesis to guide them.  The advantage of Darwin's theory in James' view was that it was a theory/hypothesis that was seeminly prepared to deal with what observation revealed about nature: namely, that it was full of contingency and chance, or what James referred to as caprice.  In a review of Darwin's book on The Variation of Animals and Plants under Domesication, James wrote: "the only 'law' under which the greater mass of the facts the author has brought together can be grouped seems to be that of Caprice,--caprcie in inheriting, caprice in transmitting, caprice everwhere, in turn.  To look for laws at all in the chaos seems absurdly presumptious." (142)   The advantage of the theory, that James viewed as descriptive and historical and not psychological, was that it anticipated the idiosyncracies in nature and its theory was reinforced by the mounting evidence of such idiosyncracies. (142)

2) The ssecond error was that many and esp. Spencer believed that evolutionary science could "lay a foundation for norms--that natural selection serves as a kind of 'bottom-line' aribeter of merit." (142-3)  It tries to make the "logic of evolution the logic of human values." (Menand quotes, 142-143).  For James, evolutionary thinking was just one hypothesis, "good in some situations, not so good in others, and not...a basis for human values."  (145)  M quotes James on 144-145 in a review of Darwin's The Variation of Animals... seeing a tendency in James to be comfortable with a hierarchical coneption of race and also doubting that people's views on race were at all scientific. (144-145).  Indeed, in James' view the point of Darwin's theory [and this is like Kroeber!!] is that at some point evolutionary theory had given humans minds thereby realeasing them from, as M puts it, the "prison of biology." (146)  [Kroeber said we had then become "inscribable."] We made choices and created value systems!! 

* Ultimately this view of science and Darwinian thought shaped James' view of the Civil War.  Unlike Henry Adams--M points out had used evolutionary theory "for fun" even though he regarded it as unproved--who saw the war as part of a struggle for survival, James saw it as having another layer.  M writes that if it was just a struggle for surival than it had no more importance than what beak was selected for among finches.  But because it was a human war, it was moral!  (14 6) His brother Wilky had been terribly wounded in the war.  When  James was asked to give a speech for a memorial erected in Boston to Robert Gould Shaw,t the man who led teh fifty-fourth and died at Fourt Wagner, James was thinking of Wilky M thinks, and what he said was that what as heroic was not the fight, fo rhtat was just an animal isntinct, but rather the civic courage that Shaw and his brother showed.  (147-148).

Pt. 3 (Charles Peirce)

* William James new Charles Peirce at the Lawrence Scientific School and found him provocative.  Peirce was a college graduate (unlike James) and a prodigy in science, mathematics, and philosophy.  Charles Peirce did not distance himeself from the views of his father, Benjamin Peirce.  Menand describes this put Charles Peirce in a particular position: that of "adapting the worldview of science before Darwin to post-Darwinian thought--adapting, that is, a view predicated on the presumption that there is certainty in the universe to views predicated on the presumption that there is not." (152)  Menand writes that the "task was impossible" but that in the process of failing at that--a failure reinforced by proefssional difficulties and "temperamental idiosyncracies"--he left many brilliant insights.

* His father's views: B. Peirce viewed mathematics as the most important science.  He was also one of the first internationally recognized American mathematicians.  For Peirce the world was knowable because our minds were designed to know it and with reference to this belief Peirce called himself an "idealist" (156) E.g.:

In every form of material manifestation...thre is a corresponding form of human thought, so that the human mind is as wide in its range of thought as the physical universe which it thinks.  The two are wondrfully matched. (156)

Within this belief, he viewed mathematics as the fundamental language of all forms of inquiry, scientific or otherwise.  (156)  E.g.:

Mathematics is the science which draws necessary conclusions...It deduces from all its consequences, and develops them into the suitable form for comparison with observations, and thereby measures the strength of the argument from observations in favor of a proposed law or of a propose form of application of a law. (155-5)

Menand explains this well on 155.  Basically, the points is that Peirce believed that our lack of understanding of a single law had not to do with the lack of a law, but with the imperfection of our observations.  In relation to this problem, math was the "language in which hypotheses can [could] be formulated most accurately, and their limits thereby ascertained.  Mathematics tells us, based on what we do know, what we are entitled to infer about what we don't know." (155)

* These beliefs about the fixity of the world and humans' capacity to understand it were similary to Aggasiz's and the two were friends.  Indeed, by the 1840s, Aggasiz and Peirce along with others Alexandar Dalles Bache and Charles Henry Davis had become a force shaping the development of science.  They took over the Association of American Geologists and Naturalists in 1848, makign membership more selective, and changing the name to the American Association fo rthe Advancement of Science. (156-158).

* C. Peirce was Benjamin's second of five children.  Suffered from facial neuralgia and used opium as a painkiller.  Later in life he used morphine and cocaine.  He had a personality that he characterized as reckless selfish indulgent etc and much of his lfie was a cycle of indulgence and self-rebuke.  (159)  He was, like his father, opposed to abolitionism and hated the radical republican senator Charles Sumner.  (161)

* Menand tells a long story about the so-called Howland Case or Robinson v. Mandell in which Benjamin was called as an expert witness to try to discover whether Hetty Robinson had falsified as will document in order to acquire more of an inheritance.  They used a statistical method and the "law of errors" to try to discern the answer.  The answer that the Peirce's gave was irrelevant, but the case remained controversial because of their use of this new seemingly disinterested mathematical "law of errors" that many people found "distressing" Menand says.  (163-176)

* The "law of errors" M says was "one of the most far reachign inventions of the nineteenth century" and central to Charles Peirce's thought.
