(176)  This law was rooted in the convergence of probabiliyt theory andstatistics.  The law of errors held that statistics were probabalistic.  This is explained on 177-182.  If you make a series of measurements there are discrepancies.  But if you don't know the cause of the discrepancies then you don't know which measurements are accurate and which are not.  But Abraham de Moivre discvoered in 1738 that when you throw a pair of die you will get a triangular curve with 7 has the highest point and declining on either side (because the sum 7 is reached by the greatest number of combinations of outomces on the die (1+6; 2+5; 3+4).  "The basis of the law of errors in astronomy was the discovery that multiple observations of a star tended to conform to a bell-shaped curve (not triangular because an infinite number o fresults is possible)--as does any group of measrements of a fixed object." (179) Therefore a series of attempts to measrue the location of a star will form a mean and that mean is the most likely location of the star. 
This theory was developed by Carl Friedrich Gauss, Adrien Marie Legendre, and Pierre-Simon Laplace in the 18th century and early 19th century.  Laplace got most of the credit.  The upshot of the theory, as M puts it, was that it "did not ignore errors; it quantified them." (182)  This was how the Peirce's used it in the HOwland case.  They asked what are the chances that we are wrong in assuming that Howland traced the signature?  What in other words was the chance that she produced a very similar signature by chance?  The answer he thought was 5 to the 30th.  (see 171-172).  The power of this as Menand put it was that "[b]y uncoupling the idea of precision from the idea of a single absolute value" statistics made greater precision possible.  Statistics "conquered uncertainty by embracing it." (182) An even greater significance of this law was that there was an order underlying seemingly random events, and Laplace for example believed that such probabilistic statistical thinking could be applied to human life as well as the physical natural world.  (183-184).

* It was a frenchman Adolphe Quetlet that took up the project of using statitics to think about human life starting in the 1820s.  He applied statistics to murder rates, finding taht the nubmers of murders were relatively constant.  Higher and lower totals each year were "errors".  He wrote a book Sur l'homme et le developpement de ses facultes in which he showed patterns--this was "social physics" he said.  ( 187-188).  The two points he drew out were 1) that because of such patterns the moral responsiblity for crime lay not with the individual but with the society (188); 2) the idea of the l'homme moyen, the average (or "mean") man.  (188-189), who he noted was to the nation the way the "center of gravity was to a planet." (188).  Quetlet also used this theory to determine the average chest size of Scottish men...deducing that there was such a chest size.  The cause of the mean he found were the envirionmental conditions of the scottish nation, he assumed.  Thsi explanation challeneged the polygenist racialism of Samuel Morton and Aggasize because it treated the existence of "types" acs the prodcut of social and environmental conditions and not as providential types. Indeed, Quetlet applied his theory to racial types and found that "major features of the human species" were "pretty much the same." (190)

* Quetlet's findings were often ignored, but Thomas Buckle picked them up, applying them to British social forms in the History of British Civilization ( 1857)...this was in his view history written from a statistical piont of view . ( 191) Statistics afforded Buckle the license to view history as totally deterministic.  He saw marriage rates and corn prices as determined by patterns. (194) But he also used it nationalistically to justify British civilaition--and European--as the best.  (194-5)

*  There were a couple of consequences of this way of thinking: 1) It removed all political social responsiblity of Euroepans for non-Europeans...  Ie African Americans' positions could be scene as the product of statistical patttern somehow inherit to their "national type." 2) It made the world seem ordered.  Darwin's popularity was in line with this tendency: his theory seemed to suggest order underlying chance.  Thus this way of thinking was used to justify the status quo,and most of the hard-core statistical thinkers were economic laissez-faire liberals.  Buckle praised Adam Smith's The Wealth of Nations copiuosly, and Spencer titled his jsutification of laissez-faire Social Statistics (1851).  IE what statitics seemed to prove, M says, is that the "market was not , as people like Matthew Arnold complained, an invitation to anarchy." (195)

Pt. 4 (Dewey)

title: The Making of a Feminine Professional Identity: Social Workers in the 1920s
text:
p. 1065 - 1069 Interpretation of Prof. Social Workers as heartless

Here in these pages, Walkowitz uses a bunch of literary sources to show how the social workers was re-conceived as a "heartless investigator." (1065).  Sinclair Lewis' novel Ann Vickers, which is a "moral tale of philanthropy, professionalism, and gender roles gone awry." (1067)  And has a "unmistkable nostalgia for the Good Mother." (1067)

title: The Making of the Modern University: Intellectual Transformation and The Marginalization of Morality
text: p.010-15 Historiograpical Position She describes existing narrative of higher ed in the US that postied a revolution in higher ed at the end of the nineteenth-century. (10-11) There has been a revisionist movement in relation to this narrative, mainly focusing on the Pre-Civil War period: taking issue with the negative assesment of colleges. She will deal with the later nineteenth-century where there have been fewer revisionist movements: "This book extends the revisionist scholarship to institutions that were at the forefront of university reform. It demonstrates that reformers at institutions such as Harvard, Johns Hopkins, University of Michigan, and the University of Chicago sought to preserve one of the key values of the classical college: the unity of moral and intellectual purpose." (11) In this way she says here work presnts an alternative narrative to Vesey's The Emergence of the American University. She thinks he misses that the reformers still believedin unity of truth, and she doesn't like his classification of reform visions. She also doens't like his assumption that the reformers were secularizers. She agrees with George marsden on this (12-13)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.038 -  39 Gilman 

Also like Ward believed that men had "studented women's physical and mental development through their benighted approach to sexual selection; but unlike Ward, Gilman belived that men's failure to share in the development of what had come to be regarded as female qualities was as much to be regretted as women's failure to share equally with men in the development of men's much vaunted reason." (38)  She depicted this in "Herland" a female utopia wher women cooperative cultiavted fields, collectivley raised children etc... (38-39)

title: The Victorian Connection
text:
p. 81-82 Victorian Connection 

So what was this "Victorian connection"? Hall emphasizes that in the 19th-century these people were the exception within "Anglo-American" culture that was still domainted by those who believed very fervently.  Members of the Victorian connection had experienced a "loss of faith" he says.  But they were searching for a realm of Truth and they found some answers in a Liberalism that "preferred democracy  to any aristocratic system, but which also insisted on leadership by a moral and intellectual elite." (82)  Hall describes them as an Avante-Garde.  (82)

title: The Making of the Modern University: Intellectual Transformation and The Marginalization of Morality
text: p.003-8 Rejection of standard curriculum. shift in late ninetheenth-century toward "modern and practical subjects." , but not a rjection of the "unity of truth." reformers "hoped to create new institutional forms that would embody their belief that truth incorporated all knowledge and was morally relevant, and also provide the basis for scholarly progress." (3) these efforts led to series of attempts: "the religious stage, 1880-1910; the sceintific, from about 1900-1920; and the humanistic and extracurriculary, roughly 1915-30." (4) these efforts failed though. furhter intorductory explanation on 4-8.

title: In Pursuit of Equity: Women, Men, and the Quest for Economic Citizenship in 20th-Century America
text: p.003-18 INTRODUCTION

title: Metahistory: the Historical Imagination in Nineteenth-Century Europe
text:
Notes taken for Meta Crisis Paper 4/12:

From his Preface:

* 19th century historical thought he says was "working out of the possibilities of tropological prefguration of the historical feild contained in poetic language in general." (xii)  Tropological has to do with moral tropes and figurative language.  Trope is figurative non-literal use of words, ie "it was a cakewalk." 

* White thinks it was the working out of these possibilities that produced an "Ironic condition of mind."  ie a "crisis of historicism".  (xii) And that ironic condition of mind has prodcued in turn a kind of "theoretical torpor" in professional historigoraphical writing and a "numerous rebellions against historical consciousness" in the literature, science and philsophy of the 20th century.  (xii)

(Skipping here to Ch. 7, ie first chapter in pt.3, "The Repudiation of 'Realism' in Late Nineteenth Century Philosophy of History")

Ch. 7: Historical Conscioisuness and the Rebirth of Philosphy of History

* Chapter is about rejection of "realiism" and rebirth of "philosophy of history".  First three pages about how philsophy of history was regarded as too fanciful and philosophic, full of distortions in much nineteenth century historical thought.  Hegel reversed this, or tried to, but Hegel's distinction not taken up.  Inistead more central a line tht distinguished between 1) "true" history, 2) "philosophy of history" (what had to have happened), and 3) doctrinaire history (what ought to have happened). (267-268) 

* Then White traces a "main line" (269) of historical reflection that ordered historires according to ratioanl traditions o rideological positions.  He's talkking about sureys of history by Feuter, Gooch, and Croce.  (268-269)  What these surveys all avoided were the Critiques of Marx and Nietzsche.  They acknowledged the failure of philosophy of history to provide general laws or even rules for historical method. (270)  Fueter for example "looked forward hopefully" to a historical work that would do "what Darwin's work had done for biology and ethnology, while Gooch stressed the work yet to be donein drawing the different traditions of historiographical work together, so that general scientific principles of historical analysis might be constructed." (270)  But only Croce, White said, was able to recognize that if philosophy of history was "unable to serve as the general science or theory of historiography" then the princples would hav eto come from the historiographical tradaitions istelf, that had been generated White notes by "the nineteenth century's hostility to modern science, philosophy, and art..." (270)--ie from historicism?? 

*  He sees an early attempt to do just that by the Prussian historian J.G. Droysen in 1868 in his Historik: Vorlesungen über Enzklopädie und Methodologie der Geschichte.  The goal of the book White says was to do "what Aristotle had done in his Topic for dialectic, in his Logic for demonstration, in his Rhetoric for oratory, and in his Poetric for literary art."  (270)  White thinks that he "anticipated the 'crisis of historicism' into which historical thinking would be plunged by the very success of nineteenth-century historiography and the kinds of second thoughts about history's claims to the status of science advanced by thinkers like Feuchte, Croce, and Gooch in the decade preceeding World War I."  (270)  Droysen like W. Humboldt and Ranke in the first half of the nineteenth century, Droysen saw historiography as being its own autonomous field of study distinct from positivistic science, idealistic philosophy, and romantic art.  But he was writing in an atmospher ein which positivism had been given new life by Darwin and could not be simply viewed as the product of an "outmoded enthusiasm for rationalism and mechanistic modes of explanation..." (271)  At the same time , Romantic art through realism in the novel had softened itself and so was less of a threat.  The principle threat thus seem to come from calls for the "scientization of history" from Marxists, positivists, and social darwinists. (271)  So it made sense that his response was to admit of the similarity of history to art as a way to "assert at once the objectivity of historiography and its difference from the science of his own time." (271)  In doinig so, he was able, White says, to account for the "different interpretations of the same set of events which a half-century of 'objective' historiography had produced, while at the same time asserting their status as real contributions to knowledge." (271)  He thus insisted that "historians necessarilz give partial and fragmentary accounts of the past, depending on the way they cut into the historical field..." but he said the ways they cut in were limited to four types "each of which illuminated a different area of historical existence..." (271)  White describes Droysen's scheme on 271-273. Basically, he divided the process of writing history in to three parts: selecting materials (methodik, ormethod of investigation), systematic analysis of materials (systemik), and the techniques of representation (topik).  The last was where the payoff came and he laid out four modes of represetnation: Interrogative, didactic, discussive, and recitative... . (272)  He preferred the recitative which was he said "to set forth the results of investigation as a course of events in imitation [Mimesis] of its actual development.  It takes the results [of investigation] and shapes them into an image of the genesis of the historical facts upon which the investigation has been at work..." (quoted on 272, bracketed insertions by White).  But he did not mean that this was an allowing of the events to speak for themselves because they were dumb without the interpreter and he thought that it was not the historian's  goal to be objective, but rather the process of "seeking to understand." (272)  Understanding itself manifested itself in four forms: biographical, monographic, catastrophic, and pragmatic.  (272) 

* This whole presentation of Droysen, though, is just a way to set up that this "fourfold" schema that keeps cropping up is not surprising.  It can be explained White thinks by the fact that the whole of nineteenth century intellectual cutlure can be broken down into Romanticism, Idealism, Naturalism, and Symbolism, and each of the categories within this rconceptions of history represent the "different world views represnted by these movements projected onto the problem of historical knowledge and extended to the historical field so as to produce four conflicting coneptions of history which the analysts of the age attempted to characterize in their own various schemata of classification." (274) 

* But then what White wants to do is get beyond these to "another mode of characterization that will identify their shared preconceptions, so as to show them to be members of a single family of values and atittudes toward history, and at the same time to illuminate the differences of stress and subordination among them that make them different phases of, or variations on, the single tradition.  of thought they represent." (274) IN order to do that he wants to return to his "original formulation" of historical thought as a probem of how to "construct a verbal model of the historical process..." (274)  So that means there are four new levels: lixicon, grammar, syntax, and semantic.  (274)  So histories are attempts to use language to "constitute different universes of discourse in which statements about the meaning of history in general or on different segments of the whole historical process can be made." (274)  Given that, White notes that he thinks the importance a given historian gives to "one or another of the different operations necessary for the constituting of a comprehensive 'language of historical discourse'" (274) will also generate "different conceptions of the historian's task...." (274)  This is his way of begijnning to get behind or under the assesment of the values and models used by nineteenth century historians.  So he says if a historain concentrates on the "lexical level" that might be considered as one extreme that would tend to produce chronicles.  (274-5).  If a historian, on the other hand, pushes "too rapidly through to the detection of the ultiating meaning (semantics) of the whole historical field" this will tend to produce philosophies of history.  " (275)  From this he says that if he sees lexical operations on one pole an semantics on the other than the ninteenth century emphasis on "true" history "would have to be located somewhere between these two extremes, on the grammatical level, where general classifiatory o perations predominate and representation of the synchronic structure of the historical field is aimed at, or on the syntactical level, where the dynamics of the field considered as a process would be the principal object of analysis and representation of the diachronic dimensions of historical being would be apprehended." ( 275)  He restates this a bit more on 275.

* The point of setting this model up is to say that what the nineteenth century historians who favored "true" history meant was a kind of history that was "a kind of discourse which falls between the emptiness of chronicle" and philosophy of history. Ie: "any account of the past in which the events that occupied the historical field were properly named, grouped into species and classes of a distinctively 'historical' sort, and futher realted by general conceptions of causation by which changes in their relationships could be accounted for."  (275) This modle presupposed an "idea or notion of the nature of the historical field and its processes" ie it implied a philosophy of history.  But this philosophy of history would be present only in a "'displaced' , sublimated, or sublated" form.  There were then critique sof specific accounts that would accuse those accounts of being "ideological" ie of having a philosophy of history.  But because there was no way to arbitrate between the different modes of explanation or emplottment (ie the ones that he provides), then there was only a sense of the "richness" of the field in relation to the variety of accounts.  And historiography derived integrity only from "its resistence to any impulse either to move to the level of outright conceptulization of the historical field, as the philsopher of history was inclined to do, or to fall into apprehensions of chaos as the chronicler did." (276) 

*  In relation to that characterization of history, philosphy of history was preceived as a threat because it "impelled to make explicit the explanatory and narrative strategies that remain implicit in the work of the professional historiographer." (276)  This point was brought home by both Marx and Nietzsche!  who critiqued professional historiography savagely, noticing that its disciplinarization meant a banning of certain "kinds of explanatory concepts on the one hand and the use of certain modes of emplotment on the other." (276)  This made Marx and Nietzsche particularly radical because unlilke say Comte or Buckle, who "sought to import ideas and techniques of representation from the fields of art and science into history," (277) Marx and Nietzsche were challenging the "conceptions of art and science from which the entire high culture of the nineteenth century received its form and on the basis of which it preconceived the problem of relating sceince to art." (277)  They were suggesting that it had become "rule-governed" (277) and based on orthodoxy.  (277)   What they were doing, White insists, was taking up Hegel's "injunction to transform the insights of the different kinds of Reflective history into a basis for a genuinely Philosophical history , a history which now only knows something about the historical process but knows how it knows it, and is able to defend its way of knowing in philosophically justifiable terms." (277)  Analysis re Hegel continues onto 278.

*  But what they achieved he thinks was "little more than a theoretical justification for the alternative modes of historical reflection worked out by Michelet, Ranke, Tocqueville, and Burckhardt considered as members of a single tradition of lingusitic practice." (278)  What he seems to mean is that they just worked out a justification of a different historical tradition that was ensnared in the same modes of representation and eplotment.  He says that Marx's real goal was to "show how the divisions and conflicts of  history can be sublated in such a way that the next stage of human development can be realistically conceived as a field of Synecdochic unities.  In short, Marx's purpose was to translate Irony into Tragedy and, ultimately, Tragedy into Comedy." (278)  Nietzsche by contrast viewed Comedy and Tragedy ironically he says.  He unmasked their myhtic nature and the mythic nature of science wso as to unmask the will, where there was nothing but an ironic condition of chaos and uncertainty, and he wanted to emplot history, White says, as "a drama of human self-transcendent and invidiual redemption, though the redemption was not from an iron-bound 'nature' or to a terrifying transcendental deity, but from man himself, man as he has been in history, to man as he might be in his self-reconciled condition." (279)  Both Marx and Nietzsche were imagining a "liberation from history that was simultnaoeusly a liberation from society." (279)  But in Nietzsche's case that was not a "revived human community; it was, rather, a purely individual, possible for the Superman but denied to the herd..." (279) He notes that they were both "supreme optimists" wheras Ranke and Tocqueville or Bourckhardt had no room for optiism.  Finally, Marx focused on the mode of explanation that ought to be used; whereas Nietzsche focused on the mode of emplotment...(279) But for neither of theme was there any kind of f value´-free grond for explanation or emplotment...

title: Works and Wives: On the Sexual Division of Textual Labor
text:
00 Summarial Note 00

This essay examines the division of textual labor between husband and wives in late twentieth-century anthropology.  It finds that there is a persistent pattern of women aiding their anthropologist husbands.  They also examine their textual strategies: the men's being analytical and the women's "experiential."  They undermine their authority.  I haven't read the article too closely, especially with regard to the textual strategies.

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.057-62 Dewey and   Origins of the "New Psychology"

Hume's ideas that the mind was merely passive receiver of "impressions."  Troubling to many.  But philosophers in 1880s and 1890s were willing to deal with this idea.  Of mind as a "passive machine."   They went to Germany, influenced by Wundt, to focus on an empirical study of what the mind did (and not just on a debate about what or was not innate in the mind).  Measured sensation, preception, reaction times, attention, feeling... (58-59).  G. Stanley Hall one of the first.  Dewey encountred G. Stanley Hall and these ideas that Hall broughtfrom Germany impacted him.  at a time when he still held his religious views.  But Dewey was still troubled by idea of mind as mere passive thing.  He was ealry on influenced by Hegel,b ut he "gradually ...came to believe that his view of the mind as at one with its environment did not need the vocabulary or metaphysics of hegel to ifnd expression..." (60) He drew on Darwinism and the analysis of humans a part of nature.  This combination of Evolutoinoism, Hegeliansim, and empirical New Pscyhology freed him from his religious belief.  He had abandoned Congregational Church by the time he left Michicagn.  Dewey's peers Geroge Herbert Mead, James Tufts, and James Angell also pushed him towar empiricism and then ultimatley to see the world in organic terms., to sutdy the mind in its social context.  (61)  So he and his colleagues did not conceive of the mind in universal terms (62)   One relevant outcome for this book: "The withering skepticism of the German experimentalists and adaption of the Darwinists provided ammunition, in the hands of those incluineed to use it, for criticizing the social context in which minds deeloped, as well as for supporting the belief that minds are capable of rising above their social context." (62)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.086-91 Women at Columbia University

Leta Hollingworth was one of the few women to struggle for a Columbia doctoral degree in psychology.  She began in 1911. Women were not welcome at Columbia in particular (compared to western colleges where Hollingworth and her husband had attended.)  In 1891, Columbia turstees had modifed their ban on women in the shcool "delegating indivual graduate faculties the power to eroll women as auditors." (86)  The faculty of political science voted to not allow women, but the philosophy faculty which offered psychology courses had allowed female "visitors" to audit.  Margaret Floy Washburn in this way "visisted James McKeen Cattell's laboratory in 1891-2," although she had left to Cornell after she relaied that she would not be albe ot earn a degree.  In 1893, Barnard opened as an undergraduate college in 1889 and offered some graduate work "with the help of a few moonlighting professors," (86) but it was not until 1898 when Teachers Colelge became part of Columbia that the university offered graduate work in educational psyhology, and then in 1900 when Colubmia took over all graduate work from Barnard that women became "regular students in Columbia's graduate degree programs." (86)  By 1906 women made up half of the student body in the faculties of philsophy and one third in all other faculties, includiing poli sci and pure science in which women were barred from certain classes.  In some instances, school chose to teach certain classes twice for menand women feeling that certain subjects cold not be discussed fully with women presenct (87).  IN 1906, 160/year were enrolling in adanced philosophy, spychology, and anthropology courses.  (87)  Only two had earned a PhD however.  Of the twelve fellowships avaialble, none were open to women.  Of the thirty two fellowships for tuition alone ($150), women could apply for only four.

In addition, Columbia faculty and adminstration had no faith in woen's intellectual abilities.  Dean Perry, the dean of philosophy, for example worte the following:

"In most cases the women make good students, and some of them the best we have had i the School of Philosophy...but on the whole, I think, a smaller proportion of them than of the men are capable, either by natural endowment or opportunity, of undertaking really advanced or original work, and the porportion of them who reach the doctorate is almost pathetically small." (quoted on 880.

James McKeen Cattell was also opposed to women's educaiton and wrote about his opposition in the magazine Popular Science Monthly in 1909.  Referring to the rising number of women employed as teachers (he said 400,000 in the US)  he wrote: "The vast horde of female teachers in the United States tends to subvert both the school and the family." (89)

Some of the younger faculty, such as Edward Thorndike, were more "temperate in their views about the evils of educaitng women..." (90)  Rosenberg points out the difference in that thornike wanted to promote Naomi Norsworthy, the first woman graduate studnet in Psychology.  In 1902 he had appoited her to assist him at Teachers College.  Thorndike perceived her role as taking off the burden of teaching from him (as he said in a letter to William James) (90).  Six years later he wanted to promote her to assistant professor and Cattell objected.  Thorndiek in tur argued that Teachers College "had special needs that coudl be best met by women.."  The school was both graduate school and proessional school he described in quote on 90 and Norsworthy and women in general were best stuied to each "in certain lines (e.g. elementary  methods, kindergarten, domestic art)..." (quoted on 90).

title: Class Expression versus Social Control? A Critique of Recent Trends in the Social History of 'Leisure'
text: 00 Summary 00 Jones is making a critique of the trends in Social History's analysis of the Leisure. Primarily, he is irritated in the way it has been used to emphasize the rationalization and organization of leisure (in contrast to what are often described as "traditional" means of entertainment) as an unintentional product of the activities of bourgeois elites, in ways that neutralized the political development of a revolutionary culture among the working classes. Here is Jones description: "The greed and private vices of capitalists, unbeknownst to them, create increasingly effective mechansims of dousing, channelling or diverting the class consciousness of workers, since the most effective agency of social control is the capitalisation of the leisure market. What ever the status of this argument, it is certainly not marxist, for, like Adam Smith, it restricts capitalism to the market place; and it assumes that ideologies prevalent within the working class will not, in any fundamental sense, be articulations of their productive relationships within capitalism, but the restult of their position as a consumer of leisure." (165) Jones identifies the problem in terms the sloppy use by social historians of the sociological term of "social control," and he analyses the construction of this term first by E.A. Ross and then Talcott Parsons. He then connects the whole notion of social control as it is used to the idea of bourgeois hegemony (Gramsci e.g.). "...social control invites us to think o f a process of 'incorporation,' accomodation', 'bourgeoisification'; or if one wishes to stress some revolutionary credential, one might call it ' bourgeois hegemony'..." (168) And the problem with such temrs he says is "that although they may register some moral distance from the apologetic complacency of functionalist theory, they in now way break form its theoretical linkages." (168) The problem he identifies is partly enabled among historians he thinks by studying leisure in isolation from work. That is he think that the battles over lesiure were often "epilogues" of battles over work in the 19th century. (169) IN other words, leisure shifted as work patterns shifted. And he points out that here it was complicated b/c just as worker movements were not necessarily opposed to rationalization of production, they were also not consistently opposed to rationalization and organization of lesiure activities. The second critique is the overpoliticization of leisure. He thinks that leisure was in fact about enjoying oneself, so not necessarily seen by workers as an important site of political resistance. (170)

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
text:
p.01-12  Book's Argument as presented in Intro

Sklansky's book is an analysis of a "shift in American social thought that played a defining part in the development of industrial capitalism." (1)  Begins with antebellum critics of "conventional views of selfhood and society" (1), moves through postbellum large-scale industrialization and cultural crisis it provokes which is "seen in popular demands to reform th emonetary system, elite attempts to reorganize the system of poor relief, and espeically efforts across the political spectrum to reconceive the system of potlicia economy born of the Revolutionary Era." (1)  Finally, moves to  creation of professions and a new "social economics" and new view of common law.  (1)

What shift is sklansky talking about?  He's talking about the shift away from a theory of selfhood and society, a "science of society" as he calls it, that defined selfhood and citizenship in relation to property ownership.  He describes this "science" succinctly on p.5.  What emerges is increasingly a tendency to seek to "transcend" this science and to redefine selfhood as a distinctly "social" thing, not linked to property ownership and individual sovereignty.  As Sklansky puts it in relatoin to the calls by followers of Henry Care during the Civil War who called for "access to cash and credit instead of equal rights to factories and fields, "[s]uch claims entailed rethinking the basic principle of classical political economy that the distribution of income depended upon the destribution of the means of production, not the means of exchange." (7)  He explains this transition in detail on 5-8.

Sklansky criticizes this transition.  He's trying to point out the pitfalls of this kind of progressive thinking.  A big part of his critique is rooted in the eclipse of discussion of economic inequality in the late twentieth century that he describes on 1-2, a time in which many suggested that the categories of wealth and income, of class, and social equality had become meaningless in the context of globalizaiton and talk of the "new economy." He compares these claims to the period that is the subject of his book, noting that such claims might have seemed familiar to those of the Gilded Age.  "..then, as now, the political and economic reconstruction underway was so profound as to appear to undermine the very concepts of property and power that had so long informed egalitarian calls for redistribution." (2) And it is this sense of the idea that conditions had led to the transcendence of categories that were the basis for calls of equality based on property that he is wary of.  He's making a plea for the preservation of such ideas.  He's maybe sympathetic with Marxist theory (as seen for instance in his concern that economics departed fromthe notion of "natrual" or use value, p. 9).

There is a tenous balance in this book.  He (in a way that I also assocaite with Habermas' analysis of the Public Sphere) also notes the negative-postivie valence of these shifts.  He notes that historians have vindicated the suspicion of an "avante-garde of abolitionists, feminists, trade unionists, and osical scientists" who felt that "attacks upon the commodification of labor as well as consumer goods seemed inextricably bound up with a doomed defense of patriachal privilege against the socializing force of the free market." (4)  That is these defenses of the conventional view of selfhood and society as rooted in property ownership and individual soveriegnty were seen increasingly as reactionary.  This verdict he says has been upheld by contemporary historians: "By eroding the asis of individual autonomy in men's mastery of their households, the argumetn goes, capitalist develpoment led poeple to define themselves in less individualistic, paternalistic, and parochial terms, fostering more inclusinve notions of personal identity and social solidarity." (12, see also his f.n. 11, he cites Sacvan Bercovitch too).  It's this idea of the liberating effects of commercialism and the new notions of selfhood associated with it that he dislikes because he thinks this analysis elides and makes impossible any "systemic challenge to capitalist imperatives." (4)  It celebrates the "subversive power of corporate and consumer consciousness" but without noticing the ways "in which the irreverent, protean, footloose spirit celebrated...has sustained market relations in the very act of subverting them..." (4)  So the blaance of his arguemnt is evdient int his sentence: "A central premise of htis book, however, is that nineteenth-century concerns about property and sovereignty amounted to something more than fear of progress, while twentieth-century notions of interdependence and social selfhood represented something less than an unambiguous advance upon outdated ideals." (4)

title: Blind Date
text:
Some Brief Notes 7/28/2011:

Read Louis Menand review of the new version of Multiculturalism: Examing the Politics of Recognition that is built around Taylor’s essay on the Politics of Recognition.  A very good article.  The main point of the article is that the point of the book is to bend liberalism to multiculturalism, whereas Menand thinks that the lesson it provides is that this is not doable.  The dry, procedural, value-less character of liberalism is incommensurable with multiculturalism’s rich and emotional investments with “culture.” “Culture is appealing to liberals because it sounds like a rich, vibrant, human thing, all loaded up with values, but without any of the supernatural connotations of the terms like belief or faith or the inner life—terrifyingly unglamorous things liberalism would, of course, be caught dead before going out with.”  (81) So Menand thinks the courtship that this volume is trying to encourage between liberalism and multiculturalism is going to fail, and he finds that view seconded most soundly by Appiah’s entry in the volume—although all the authors reject Taylor’s proposals. 

Appiah’s and Menand’s problems ultimately lie with culture.  The first point that Appiah puts well in a quote that Menand uses is that: “Between the politics of recognition and the politics of compulsion, there is no bright line.”  (quoted on 79).  In other words, people are usually defining themselves against and not with their culture, and this is a point that is, Menand observes, consistent with the dialogical conception of identity that Taylor espouses.  (79-80).  

The second problem is with the ambiguity of the concept of culture itself.  Here Menand’s writing is really good.  His point is twofold: Yes, humans produce culture, but it has not particular “valence.”  Despite this, when culture is taken up philosophically it acquires a “discreteness found nowhere in experience.” (80)  There was a rush to de-reify the individual (Taylor’s monolog notion of identity) and yet in the process, he observes, “political thinkers have ended up reifying culture instead…and have inserted culture into the spot individual once occupied.  Individual become culture-bearers, and thus rights (possessed by individuals) become obligations (extended to groups.)” It’s not clear to Menand why this is better, as he notes “[g]roup allegiance is not a sentiment with a terribly attractive history.” (80)  Second, and more to the point, culture is unstable in modern societies.  I love Menand’s quote here:

“Modern culture is not like a mosaic; it’s more like a Rubik’s Cube.  The only thing prescriptive to be said about it is that the greater the number of people who have access to it, the greater the number of interesting and unpredicted combinations it will be possible to produce.  But we are never likely to get anything like a generalizable pattern; for putting several items together in one place always involves rearranging the items everywhere else.” (80)

A very good image! for a point already made everywhere about the complexity and instability of culture.

title: The Radicalism of the American Revolution
text:
B Part I -- Monarchy

1. Hierarchy

Idea here is that to understand "the extent of the change that took place in the Revolution" Wood will have to describe "the old colonial society that was subsequently transformed." (11)

* Colonial society, W says, despite all the 17th century transformation was still "traditional in its basic social relationships and in its cultural consciousness." (11)  This meant that the household, society, and the state--private and public spheres--scarcely seemed separable." (11)  So as a result "authority and liberty flowed not as today from the political organization of society but from the structure of its personal relationships." (11)

* Colonists still embraced notions of "order and stability" attached to "monarchical society".  (11)

* What did that mean?  Meant being a subject of the king.  And the "allegiance the English subject owed his monarch was a personal and individual matter.  Diverse persons related to each other only through their common tie to the king, much as children became brotehrs and sisters only through their common parentage."  As William Blackstone put it, the king was the "pater familias of the nation."  (11)  Wo,od says as this came to be understood theoretically by the colonists this implied "a society of dependent beings, weak and inferior, without autonomy or indepedence, easily cowed by the pageantry and trappings of a patriarchal king.  The whole community, said Benjamin Franklin in 1763, is regulated by the example of the king." (12)

* Yet the colonists as well as the English in general were in some ways not good monarchical subjects because of the way in the period following the Glorious Revolution of 1688, the English had "becoming increasingly aware of the marvelous peculiarity of their limited monarchy...Representation in the House of Commons even allowed for the participation of His Majesty's subjects inthe affairs of government.  It was a constitution specially dedicated to liberty." (13)  Wood downplays the difference between the colonies and the English back "home" in this respect--both thought of themselves and in some real ways were "freer" than the members of other European monarchies.  He describres on 14-15: working people in England might more freely emulate their betters in aw ay that in France was impossible.  Laboring men and women Wood says "wore knee breeches and perukes, bonnets, and panniered dresses." (15)  This couldn't happen in France e.g.  (15)

* Yet "however superficial and hollow" (15) Wood says, the colonists still lived in a "monarchical society." (15)  And he says that by the mid-18th century "royal authority in the colonies was more deep-rooted and more effective by mid-century than ever before." (17)  Trade operated within the "British navigation laws" despite smuggling.  There were also more succesful royal governors by mid-century: eg William Gooch and francis Fauquier in Virginia and Willim Shirely and Thomas Pownhall in Mass. (17)

* Religion, and especxially Anglican Church, tended to bolster allegiance to the king. (17-18)

* But royal authority was powerful at mid-century msotly because "the theoretical underpinnings of [the colonists] social thought still remained largely monarchical." (19)  Know Wood goes into a long an excellent description of the way in which the vision of "social hierarchy" in a monarchical soceity looked: 19-20.  Monarchy is a hierarchy that is acceptable because inequality is "offset by the great emotional satisfactions of living in a society in which everyone, even the lowliest servant, counted for something." (19)  This hierarchy constitutes a holistic order in which everyone had some purpose.  And Wood says in the 18th as much as in the 17th century it was still hard for the colonists "to imagine a civilized society being anything but a hiearchy of some kind..." (19)

* Much more good detail about how hierarchy was reinforced in the colonies as an experience, including eg Yale students needing to remove their hats at varying distances from superiors of various types.  (21)  See 20-23.

* Then also on 23, a long quote by Henry Fielding's cominc novel Joseph Andrews (1742) in which the social hiearchy is perceived as a "kind of ladder." (23)

II. Patricians and Plebians

* There was Wood says one great "horizontal division" in this hierarchy: "that between extraordinary and ordinary people, gentlemetn and commoners." (24)  This division maintained even in the 18th century despite things becoming more muddled.  "There were the few who were sometimes called 'the reverend' or 'right reverend,' the honourable,' or "excellent,' or 'noble,' or 'puissant,' or 'royal,' and ther ewere the many who were often called 'the Mob,' 'the Vulgar,' or culture, even the one betwe'the Herd.'" (25)  Wood says this social division "overwhelmed all others in the culture, even the one between free and enslaved..." (25)

* In the English-speaking world, Wood says, 5% of popuation was part of aristocracy.  In colonies, slightly higher: 10%. (25)

* "Aristocracy"--which earlier had referred to a particular form of gov't--in 18th meant popularly the "entire patrician order" (25): "At its top was the king.  Below him were the peers of the realm, rarely numbering more than two hundred at any one moment in the eighteenth century.  These dukes, mrquesses, earlys, viscounts, and barons had huge estates and hereditary titles, and in the case of the English peersat least, autonomatically sat int he House of Lords...Baronetcies, too, were inheritable but gave the older no right to a seat in the House of Lords.  Below these were several titled ranks of knights and esquires.  The entire aristocracy was bottomed on the large body of gentry, the lowest social rank entitled to bear a coat of arms." (25)

* A key identity was that of "gentlemen."  The term even applied to the king.  He describes the term on 28-30.  Their views on the "common people" on 27.

* What made the English aristocracy more open was that the legal access to the category of gentlementw as less controlled in eighteenth century.  (26)

* The common people, however, largely accepted their position, were even proud. And Wood notes that to understand the "distinctiveness of the premodern world" it is necessary to realize this acceptance of their position.  Then the radical chagnes in the "consciousness of humility" that the Am. Revolution caused can be appreciated. (30)

* In the colonies, the only aristocracy that the colonists would have known was the "gentry."  Tehy rarely saw anyone with a title.  (30)  But Wood thinks this didnt' make "their aristocracy any less distinctive in their minds." (30)

III. Patriarchal Dependence

* Most relationships in this hierarchical society were "paternalistic."  (43) The model was the family; it was the "'measure of that Obediance which we owe to those whom Providence hath placed over us.'"  (43)  Thus: "The language of paternalism and filial obligation still provided the common metaphors eighteenth-century Englishmen on both sides of the Atlantic used to describe their hierarchical experiences." (43)

* Colonial society in particular was organized around the family.  The original Puritan settlers had referred to the family as a "little Commonwealth."  (44)  And the family was not just those living under one roof, but all those depenence on the patriarch who was the only person to deal with the "larger world." (44)  A Clergyman in 1754 that W quotes could then imagine that the Civil State was "'furnish'd with Members from private Families...." (44)

* 44-48, Wood gives details about the way certain families were organized in the various colonies, the names of those families, and also the way land, which was the basis of their power was passed through the same principles used in the home country: primogeniture and entail...

* Family also the basis of all politics and business.  Wood notes that the colonists often used "family names--the De Lanceys in New York, the Ogdens in New Jersey, the Wentworths in New Hampshire--to designate political groups." (48) This because positions of power handed down through these tightly-knit families of the landed gentry.  Great continuity: e.g. in teh half century before the Revolution in NJ, 70% of the reps elected to NJ assembly were realted to previously elected legislators.  (48)

* From here, Wood goes into a discussion of legal unfreedom.  The implication of paternalism is that those under the patriarch--both women and children--were not free--a principle rooted in Filmer's ideas (48-50).  This meant also that many young men who had yet to acquire land--esp as land became scarcer--were unfree (50).  Then there was the practice of black slavery (51).  And then Wood points out that in fact many whites, usually young men and women, were not free either due to the practice of indentured servitude.  (51)  Estimates were that 1/2 to 2/3 of all  immigrants to the oclonies came as indentured servants (51).

title: The American Woman's Pre-World War I Freedom in Manners and Morals

title: The Quest for Jewish Assimilation in Modern Social Science
text:
Notes 5/2013:

> Based on the material on Boas in Ch. 5, his interpretation of Boas is unsurprising in its tendency to see Boas as basically operating within a kind of Herderidan-Humboldtian tradition of hermeticaly sealed cultural groups. E.g. he says on 104: "Boas's cultural anthropology relates to anthropological groups; Simmel's relates to social forms as consisting of individuals." (104) I really like what he sees in Simmel in Ch.5 (which is all I have read as of yet). But what he sees in Simmel there is much like what I'm trying to find in Boas... a vision of culture built on fragments. 

### Ch.5 The Aesthetics of Jewish Assimilation

* This chapter is basically from a certain point of view examinign the particular contents of Simmel's individuallism. M-R notes on 86 that indvidiualism often has its own history and is understanding in specific ways.

* Key for Simmel's individualism is the notion of form. What is form for Simmel? Form was already in Germany a key word. "it was at the same time both a generic philosophcial term and one deeply charged with political-ideological meanings, danding for everyt that is essential: state, church, people, culutre, society, law, or life itself." (86) For Hegel, the state was this higher form. Goethe talked about "INNER FORM." Weber and Simmel take a "formal" approach to form, one that he notes is closedly tied iup with a notion of disenchantment. (87) For Simmel, there is always a "fundamental discord between content and ofrm." That discord is in turn the "driving force of individuation." Simmels' sociology, M-R, says is about showing how "a contingent interest (content) becomes petrified in a (social) form." (87) That is social form alaqyas exists "autonomously from the interest that brought it into being." (87) Here Simmel's notion of form is like Marx's second nature, but unlike Marx who thought this state of alienation vv such forms could be overhwlemed, Simmel treats it as a permanent human condition, such that "individuation" is a fundamental part of life and funamentally nonharmonioous. (87)

* Simmel is unlike Durkheim in that Durkheim deals with collectivies and not forms. He thinks that the collective is built up out of individuals and yet individuals also find their salvation in collectivities. For Simmel that is not the case. Taht is, Durkheim has a kind of "ontological individualism" in which only inidividuals exists (and are teh basis of collectivities). Simmel's is a methodological individualism -- where all must be "explained in terms of individuals" -- plus ontological indivdualism. (87-89) For Simmel individuals get "entangled in existing forms..." (89)

* A bunch of good stuff about Simmel's relationship to Marx and hsi use of the idea of divisino of labor. Simmel kind of universalizes the notion of division of labor? Because it is for him not just about labor but as Durkheim himself noted about the "process of individuation in general." (91) Divison of labor is just a subcase of that general pulse. (91)

* Here is where M-R's argument gets really good. in a section "Simmel As Anti-German". In the first part, "From Whole to Fragments": From Louis Dumont's German Ideology, M-R takes German Ideolgoy to be "community holism + self-cultivating indivualism." (92)  His idea is that Simmel "systematically destabilizes" Bildung and Kultur. (92)

* He sets Simmel as operating within and against a Romantic tradition for whom Karl Philip Moritz was central, an aesthetics of totality. (93) The idea is that somehow in the contemplation of a work of art one is taken to something bigger than oneself. That is what the beautiful indicates. So that the concept of beauty isl linked to subordination. (93) But a certain kind of subordiation that unlike the subordation to an external god, is internal in nature. (93)

* But Simmel he said denies that society was an "absolute entity." (93) He iddi this by "insisting uon the supremacy of the itnerconnecting parts." [Think already of the supplanting of focus on form rather than colectivities... ] Society is not the a whole of hwoles.; yet in his "Sociological Aeshetics" it is definitely an aesthetic object. What Simmel's focuson the interconnecting parts does is also treat this aesthetic object in terms of assymetry and this M-R thinks is part of a "conscious confrontation with traditional definition of beauty as forder, symmetry, and definiteness." (94) M-R Notes that the likes of Ratzel and Voltaire saw Jews as aesthetically defiicient in terms of the calssic aesthetic qualiteis; i.e. "taste, delicacy, p[roportion." (94) As such, what Simmel does might even be called "jewish aeshthetics." He describes a progression from an acceptance of meaningless, to a will to symmetry, to a return to the irregular and assymetrical. (94) M-R writes of Simmel:

> "Simmel's imagery and concepts thus tie together aesthetics, society, and moderniusm through his unqiue notion of the individual. From whole to part, from totality to fragment, from hierarchy to web, from harmonious to disharmonious, from the part's subservience to the whole an aesehtic salvation in it, to no subservicence -- and no salvation." (94)

* And: "Simmel insists on society in terms of fragments that can only aggregate together but do not constite a whole." (94) 

* All this empahsis on fragemnts goes against what Dumont has called the German Ideology with its emphasis on the whole. It goes against Goethe's motto: "Always aspire ot the whole: if you yourself cannot become a whole, fasten yourself to one, as a limb to its service." (quoted o 94). 

* So Simmel is subverting this deeply felt Romantic urge. He's undermining the German emphasis on thewhole, the Lutheran desire for salvation. (94) 

> Note: Of course, M-R uses this formulation of German Ideology, but shoudl he???

 

* Pushing further now in a section "Simmel against Bildung." Tehre's a strong link between Jews and Bildung, see f.n,. #70. What Simmel has to say about Bildung is thus refering to Jews' attmepts to use it as a basis for asssimilation M-R thinks. Basically, what M-R thinks Simmel is doing is to try to use Bildung and Kultur in a way that returns them to "their origin in Kant, as an unreliazable potential rather than as an accomlished realty." (95) This the goes against in particular Hegel's use of Bildung as a "complete realizable process." (95)

* Dumon apparently has said that for Kant Bidlung was a "ssort of horizon of thought, a regulative ideal that three of Kant's most distinguished successors turned into a realizable goal." (95)

* Simmel by contrast affirms that "individuailty is not a restriction of the infinite but its expression and mirror." (This is either Dumont or Simell, quoted on 95.) M-R addsd "Self-cultivation is by necessity an incomplete process." (95) In f.n. 75 he refers to Dumon p.81, Simmel's "The Individual Law" and his treatment of it in an essay "From Autonomous Subject to Free Individual in Semmel and Lacan," Journal of the History of European Ideas, 31 2005 (1) , 103-127.

* Going further he explains Simmel as a modification of Kant's notion of freedom, minus the empahsis on universality. So.

a. Kant

Kant made freedom core to his ethics, and his concept of freedom secured individuality: "He defined freedom negatively as the [individual's] independence from the sensible owrld and positively as the obedience of the will ot the moral laws of practical reason." (95) Thus reason is a universal principle that "bridges individuality and universality," allowing man to "project himself into a universal order." That is why obedience to moral law = freedom. (96)

b. Simmel

In "The Individual Law," Simmel rejects the universality in all of this, in an attempt to save the "Kantian-Fichtian (modern) subject." (96) He sees Kant and Fichte as dealing with  a "purely moral commuinity" or *Eins* . , i.e. a "universally sycnretized subject" -- in M-R's phrasing. But then he opposites this by 1) saying that the human being is a "differntiating creature" (*Unterschiedeswesen*)" (96) and 2) by saying that Kant and Fichte see a sick society as one fragmented, and a healthy one as universal. He wants to reverse this, health is the fully individual condition. (96)

* Vv Bildung as salvation, which M-R thinks is linkned into the "Christian symbolism" underlying Bildung -- but is that all really there? -- that what Simmel is doing is denying that Biludng can bring salvation; to be more precise, he is saying that Bildung brings individuation, but not redemption/salvation, no deep peace of mind. (96)
