title: From Salvation to Self-Realization: Advertising and the Therapeutic Roots of the Consumer Culture, 1880-1980
text:
p. 015 G. Stanley Hall and the Therapeutic Ethos and Leisure

"At the most obvious level, the therapeutic injunction to 'let go' eased adjustment to the rhythms of life under corporate capitalism. Hall, for example, assumed that modern world would be degrading and that workers therefore needed regular bouts of revitalizing leisure. 'Everyone, especially those who lead the drab life of the modern toiler, needs and craves an occasional 'good time,' he acknowledged. 'Indeed we all need to glow, tingle, and feel life intensely now and then.' According to therapists like Hall (and social theorists like Lippman), liberation should occur in homeopathic doses..." (15)

title: The Victorian Connection
text:
p. 88-   Victorian Connection, Liberalism, and Problems of Democracy and Authority

Mill's idea was that human minds could "distingusih truth from falsehood." "Hence the imperative of free inquiry, of speculation and argument without restraint, for free inquiry would ensure that reform eventually occured, that man would gain emancipation form all false and restrictive systems, whether moral or social."  (88)  Hence the frustration with orthodox religion and the hierarchy of the Church of England.  (88)  

To this fear of hiearchy and orthodox belief, was added the fear of democracy and the masses which Mill got from reading Toqueville when he waas "startled by the revelaiton of the possiblity of a tyranny more efficeint than that of any despot." (Mill's words, quoted on 88-89).  Hall argues that the antidote that Mill conceived to this was "a political system in which power rested with the 'few' who were trained to use their minds  and had the courage to stand apart form the masses.  A democrat in principle, Mill spke incrasingly after 1840 in favor of elitist rule." (89)  

These same concerns were held, Hall says, by other Victorians in Britain and the U.S.  "These lines of cultural criicsim converged upon th Victorians who came of age in the 1850's -- Arnold and Ruskin in England, Olmsted nad Norton in America." (89)  See quotes by Olmsted and Norton on 89-90.  Note it might e worth reading Thomas Wentworth Higginson's essay "A Plea for Culture" (90)

On this basis, their suggest for reform were as follows; "Mill urged proporational representation as the cure for the loss of independence and individuality.  Such a scheme, he believed, would permit uuniversal suffrage but in a way that ensured expression of every point of view.  Other suggestions included imposition of an educational qualification for the franchise, limits on the amount of money a candidate for coffice could spend on an election, and replacement of political patronage with a system of competitive examinations fr filling state offices.  On both sides of the Atlantic, civil service reform became a major demand of the liberals, merrging with their general interest in placing public administration upoon a scientific basis." (90) 

Hall makes the point however that although Victorian liberals emphasized publi service and saw themselves as the educators of the public, they also did not rely on working throuhg public instituitons. "to say that the Victorian connection believed in public services does not mean, however, that its members proposed to work through the state or its institutions.  According to Mill and Arnold, moral and social force sprang from truth, and truth could never fully coincide with or e embodied in any institution.  Only by teaching truth directly would the reformer succeed....Hence these intellectuals kept their distance from all political parties and the state.  Not unlike the Puritan ministry, they assumed that the act of sincere speech or writing would secure them the authority needed to accomplish their agenda of reform." (91)   I.e. their intellectual authority would spring from truth and not from their instituitonal status...from their ability to discern truth from falsehood that is... thus intellectual authority for them was tied to this idea of subjectivity that the self oculd in fact distinguish truth from falsehood, as well as their special ability to do this as opposed to the masses.

title: Multiculturalism without Culture
text:
p. 8 - 9 Her critique of culture

"In developing this argument, I query what I see as one of the biggest problems with culture: the tendency to represent individuals from minority or non-Western groups as driven by their culture and compelled by cultural dictates to behave in particular ways. Culture is now widely employed in a discourse that denies human agency, defining individuals through their culture, and treating culture as the explanation for virtually everything they say or do. This sometimes features as part of the case formulticultural policies or concessions, but it more commonly appears in punitive policies designed to stamp out what have been deemed inappropriate or unacceptable practices. When, for example, European governments decide that the best way to protect young Moroccan, Turkish, or Bangladeshi women from being forced into unwanted marriages with strangers from their parents’ country of origin is to ban marriages with overseas partners for anyone under the age of eighteen, twenty-one, or twenty-four, they represent young women from these groups as incapable of agency. They operate on the (highly stereotypical) assumption that all parents from these cultural groups are coercive and all young women are submissive, and hence, that any marriage arranged with an overseas partner should be regarded as forced. I argue that a more careful understanding of culture provides a better basis for multicultural policy than the overly homogenised version that currently figures in the arguments of supporters and critics alike. A defensible multiculturalism will put human agency much more at its centre; it will dispense with strong notions of culture."

title: The First Boasian: Alfred Kroeber and Franz Boas, 1896-1905
text:
p.527  1905 AAA meeting in San Fran

Kroeber intervened to get the AAA meeting in San fran.  He prevailed as Putnam sided with him.  AA report noted that the meeting was notable "proving as it did the truly national character of the organizaiton..." (quoted on 527).

title: Sincerity and Authenticity
text:
Some Notes:

COMMENT: On Trilling's Use of Culture It is sometimes more ethnological, as in cultural difference: p. 1-2, where it is set against the sense that there is something universal about humans. Sometimes it is Arnold's high culture, as in when it is a thing which advocates those ideas which "authenticity" tended to de-legitimize (12). It is also normative social structures associated perhaps with the 19th century, as in when authenticity involves moving down through a "cultural superstructures" toward the heart... (13)

p.003-6 Basic Def'n Sincerity Sincerity he suggests may represent a new dimension of the conception of the self in Europe, which has however been important for 400 years. He writes: "...I propose the idea that at a certain point in its history the moral life of Europe added to itself a new element, the state or quality of the self which we call sincerity." (4) What is Sincerity? Briefly: "...a congruence between avowal and actual feeling." (4) He defines it futher first with Shakespeare's Hamlet (4-5) and then Matthew Arnold's discussion of the difficulty of finding the true self: Below the surface-stream, shallow and light Of what we say we feel--below the stream Aslight, of what we think we feel--there flows With noiseless current strong, obscure and deep, The central stream of what we feel indeed (quoted on 6, from?) Then brings up Freud who he said some 30 years later "took the first steps twoard devising a laborious discipline of research to discover where it might be found." (7) So then the more robust def'n of sincerity is: "..the avoidance of being false to any man through being true to one's own self..." (7) And this is something that takes work to achieve...

p.006-12 Decline of Sincerity; Rise of Authenticity He talks now about how sincerity lost its positive importance. Modern artists conceived of themselves not as "selves" but as "personas" -- they deined personality -- and this created awarness of "roles" -- which he connects to an emphasis that one has no choise to play roles, see f.ln. 1 on p.11 -- and then below all those "roles", "authentic" self: "In shoft, we paly the role of bieng ourselves, we sincerely act the part of the sincere person, with the result that a judgement may be passed upon our sincerity that is not authentic." (12) So authenticity comes to mind. He says And he describes it this way: "...I think that for the present I can rely on its [authenticity] suggesting a more strenuous moral experience than 'sincerity' does, a more exigent conception of the self and of what being true to it consists in, a wider reference to the universe and man's place in it, and a less acceptant and genial view of the social circumstances of life. At the behest of the criterion of authenticity, much that was once thought o make up the very fabric of culture has come to seem of little account, mere fantasy or ritual, or downright falsification. Conversely, much that culture traditionally condemned and sought to exclude is sought accorded a considerable moral authority by reason of the authenticity claimed for it, for example, disorder, violence, unreason." (13) And after quoting Yeats regards the need to get to the "foul rag-and-bone shope of the heart," (13) : authencity "implies the downard movement through all the cultural superstructures to some place were all movement ends..." (13) All this implied a very different idea of how to be, than had sincerity.

p.013 - 25 Sincerity as a Way of Being and the Individual Here is a history which I have just skimmed regarding the notion of sincerity, and its connection to the demarcation of the notion of the "individual." And a def'n of what this individual is.

title: Conventional Iconoclasm: The Cultural Work of the Nietzsche Image in Twentieth-Century America
text:
00 Summary Note 00

Ratner-Rosenhagen's goal here is to analyze popular concetions of Nietzsche and his thought in the United States in the twentieth-century.  In a brief thoeretical discussion at the start of the article, she tries to add to "reception history" (which she likes because of the way it shifted attention away from texts to what people "do" with them 733) by suggesting that one needs also to look at the way people viewed the authors of those texts.  So in the article she spends much more time looking at the way people in the United States evaluated Nietzsche in relation to fairly conventional and shorthand assesments of his ideas.  Americans' interst in Nietzsche she argues was related to "what historians have identified as the modern quest for authenticity" (736)  She draws on Lears' ironic thesis about anti-modernism--that the antimodern impulse drove Americans to accept a therapeutic ethos of individualism--to argue that "Nietzsche' authentic experience over the course of the century helped ease accomodation to the very liberal, secular, materialistic culture that they took as their enemy." (736) Lears, she notes in f.n. #13, drew his language of "weightlessness" tc from Nietzsche in part.  Other American readers, she noted, simply "transformed his nuanced vision of expressive individuality into a conventional celebration of atomistic individalism in the Americna liberal tradition." (736)--that despite the fact that Nietzsche had challenged the idea of an undivided self.  (737)  It's the second sectin of the paper where she really goes into the different analyses of Nietzsche's "image"--someting she notes fascinated Americans more than his writings.  Those concerned with cultural philistinism loved Nietzsche's Ubermensch--e.g. Mencken & Brooks 739-740. The appeal of the Ubermensch had fallen away by 1941, though.  HIstorian Crane Brinton in a 1941 study pilloried Nietzsche and tried to link him to Nazism, and perceived Nietzsche's "disdain for conventional life" as "pathological, not heroic." (742).  The causes: he had been "doted on by the 'women folk'" (742); he had not played sports.  She describes a whole series of examinations of his character/biography both by admirers and critics (743-5)  A great section in an analysis by Will Durant esp. labels the source of Nietzsche's problems in his "feminine fragility" (748-9).  Others liked the way Nietzsche had emerged his life experience and philosphy (749-750).  Still others found in his work a redemptive sourge and energy (750-51).

I like her analysis, but I am inclined to ask, so what?  The article simply confirms basic stereotypes about Americans' anti-intellectualism. It reveals a series of variations on the way in whiche Nietzsche's ideas were received and his image constructed, but what is revealed is all somehow what you might expect--though it is good to have it documented.  But in the end her conclusion seems rather pedestrian.  She ends the essay pointing out the obvious: "By exploring the idea of Nietzsche without sufficiently examining his ideas, many Americans simultaneously created and reconciled themelves to the very hostility to independent thought that they worried characterized American modernity." (754)  So she begins trying to break out of the elitist mode of intellectual history by examining reception and perception of Nietzsche himself by the general public, but then she criticizes that non-intellectual public for being non-intellectual.  That doesn't seem fair; if she's going to take them seriously she should take them seriously.  The article seems unfocused.

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text: p.007 Prof. historian caresa bout "collective inquiry"

title: A Social History of Anthropology in the United States
text:
p.036 Timeline of Institutional Change in Anth

Bewtween 1879 and 1900 he says all of the indivdiual earning livliehood from anthropology "were employed by one of three government agencies: the Smithsonian Institution, the National Museum and the Bureau of Ethnology." (36)   But by 1910 things had shited from museum and government to the universities.

title: AHR Roundtable: Historians &  Biography: Introdution
text:
p.577 Methodological appeal of Biography

Nasaw sugests that biographay may become "a favored one for twenty-first-century historians because it offers a way of transcending the theoretical divide between empiricist social history and linguistic-turn cultural history without sacrificing methodological or epistemological gains of either."  (577)

He then brings up a comment by Spiegel in a commentary on Geoff Eley's A Crooked Line where she suggests an attempt to move  beyond the cultural (liguistic) turn has found many "historians deploying a (largely implicit) concept of 'social phenomenology' in which, as the German sociologist Andreas Reckwitz explains, 'The aim of social analysis is to take over the "subjective perspective."'" (quoted on 577)

This is "neo-phenomenology" that stives for what Spiegel calls an "actore-centered perspective" which in consistent with the idea in Kessler-Harris' contribution "Why Biography?" in this roundtable, i.e. a focus on the agent's own understanding of the situation where in that perception "is mediated and perhaps constrained but not wholly controlled by the cultural scaffoldig of conceptual schemes within which it takes place." (quoted on 577, see kessler-Harris, p.412 in this issue).

But Nasaw points out most of those focusing on this actor-centered perspective also stop short of grantin gactors autonomy.  Historains also look  beyond the perspective of their actors to thigs that their actors may not have known or seen.  Interstingly, Nasaw find confirmation of this in statements by the Marxist E.P. Thompson, and then Marx himself, see 577-578.

title: The German Idea Of Militarism : Radical and Socialist Critics, 1866-1914.
text:
p.006-7 Categories & Description of Def'ns of Militarism

Four types of militarism: pacifist, liberal, Marxist, and realist.  First three predicted a world without wra.  Realists did not. Definitions on p. 6 (see old hand-written notes).

In liberal version, Spencer equated industrial society with the forces of peace and progress and set up dichotomy between "military" and "industrial" societies.

That sociological approach merged with Marxist thought afte rdeath of Marx and Engels.  But the Marxists postponed the coming of age of peace to the period after the decline of industiral capitalism.

All of these programs have failed and that would seem to provide much support for the realist position.  "But by reducing war to a matter of political expediency realists also leave out of the equation precisely the questions of subordination and violence which transform human beings into blind instruments and which ever since Kant spoke aobut the 'Kingdom of ends', of treating all human beings as ends in themselves, have been so central to the debate." (7)

pp. 7-10, Stargardt goes into detail showing the connections and overlaps between the four understandings of militarism.  My interest now is in the liberal.  What sets it apart he says is its focus on the domestic space, on the problem of protecting civil society from the state and the military.  That line of thought goes back to civic republicanism in Italy and winds it way into English, Dutch, French and German englightenments and then to socialist writers.  See p.10, top.

But Star. notes that a less radical form of liberal antimilitarism emered after the state-building efforts of the late 19th century and the disillusionment of WWI.  "In this verison it mattered relatively little whether the army was a permanent professional or a part-time citizen force so long as it oculd e held responsible to a civilian government and respected the independence of civil society." (10)  This he says was the position of the "Young" liberals during the constitutional conflict between Bismarck and the Prussian Chamber.  And under this point of view as well "the balance between military and civil authority becomes an issue of jurisdiction, legal norms and sanctions." (10)

title: American Moderns: Bohemian New York and the Creation of a New Century
text:
p.249 - 251 Description of Creative Partnerships

Important part of sexual modernism were what Stansell refers to as the ideal of "...playful, inventive partnerships."  (249)  On 226 this: "...transcendent friendships unimaginable to earlier generations", the 'true companionship and oneness' of men and women that Emma Goldman preached in her lectures on love." (226)


This she describes as the invention of "heterosexuality" in the 20th century.  New emphasis on the importance of heterosexuality.  Homosexuality only "eliptically allowed." (251)  

Also! Professionalism is a key part of creative partnerships.  These are creative partnerships between professionals.  Stansell refers to these as "the proliferation of professional relationships." (250).   Also see her desc. of Reed & Bryan's relationship 252-258: professional tensions between men and women, the varying opportunities for women, the authrotiy of men, and professional jealousy are all part of this.  

Such partnerships reveal partnerships also to be of ambivalent nature; they are also the way for women to get access to the professions.  Cf. Stansell's comments on the base of Reed and Bryant's relationship (252-253); Bryant's failure to get to Paris during WWI b/c women barred from rront lines by French, and only Inez Haynes who was Bryant's nemesis get's there by going with her hsuband Will Irwin. (256)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text:
p.054 Interest in pscyhology

The New Women went to U Chicago to study to be teachers, but they also ecame intrested in the new psychology.  Rosenberg writes that Dewey made it "seem particularly relevant to their concerns.  Dewey championed the New Psychology, which was divorced from religion and metaphysics and devoted to the study of the mind; and he won over a number of women students to his cause because he and his colleagues were the first social scientists willing to ask the question which in 1900 seemed most pressing to Chicago's women: were the mental traits of males and females as differentas most researchers bleieved them to be?" (55)

title: The Decline of the German Mandarins:  The German Academic Community, 1890-1933
text:
p.090-097 Description of Tradition of German Idealism

Ringer describes 1 of the 2 theories that he thinks were the most imporrant "formal elements in the mandarins' scholarly heritage": Idealism and the German historical tradition.

Idealism, rooted in Kantian criticsm, struck at "common sense" view of experience.  Common sense point of view describdedin one paragraph on p.91, sees the "things" in the world as real objects imprinted upon our sensory system.  The things we senses are thus part of a "natural order of objects and movements." (91)

Kantian criticsim goes against this.  Based o na problem: how do we know that the objects we sense are related to actual external objects?  Thsi is a logical problem, not necessarily a question of fact or metaphysics.    We have no direct experence of the object, just different "sensations" at different times that we gropu around "constructed references: objects." (91) So a series of quesitons arise: "How can we do that?  What accounts fo the apparent cohernece and objectivity of our experience?  Where do we get our sense of time and space, without which we could not organize our perceptions?"  (91)  The answer to this logical problem is that it is "logically impossible to treat our perceptions as ordinary effects of external reality."  (92)  Ther eis an "unbridgeable gap between experience and the thing itself." (92)  Ernst Cassirer calls this the "probelm of terminism."  This does not mean that you should not coduct empirical investigaiton but you must, if you will be a Kantian, acknowldege th efollowing: "First, we must admit that certain a prior elements, certain categories of a logical character, must necessarily be presnet in our experience, giving it its organized objective quality.  Secondly, we must resist the temptation to equate our ideas with things, and relationships between ideas with relationships betwen objects.  In short, we must not fall back into the common-sense views..." (92)

So this means that the German mandarins were well-armed against "the implicit metaphysics of certain nineteenth-century scientisms." (92)  There was he says a "generalized suspicion of the common-sensefallacy" that led many German mandarins to distrust empirical research. (92)  The Kantian critique tended to turn the process of verification toward a technique that focused on an "internal" operation rather than an examinaiton of the "external" world.

But there is also another "tendency" in idealism that Ringer describes: the tendency for the tradition to posit "an absolute Ego or universal spirit." (93) This came about as the mandarins "continued to work with some analogue of thd iscarded comparison between thought and thing," without every going os far as to describe reality as an "illusion or a well-made dream." (93)  In an attempt to preserve a correspondence between our thoght and reality, some postualted an "abstract mind or spirit." (93)  "the Kantian categories and all the norms of right thinking which insure the order and certainty of our expeirence cannot be regarded as empirical, psychological properties of this or tht individual mind.  They are necessary axioms of all knowledge, and it is therefore tempting to atribute them to something like a transcendental consciousness."  (93)  This transcendental coscoiusness Ringers says was a "purely logical construct", but could aquire a "quasi-religious" meaning." (93)  And he notes that German Pietism and philosphical Protestantism could underwrite that sort of interpretation.  That dimension could be further enhanced by the fact tat the mandarins intended for their Idealism to be absorbable by nonpprofessionals.  Some described it as a worldview with its roots in Plato and which had a practical-ethical component, an emphasis on the ocnsciousness and its "freedom and action" (see Windelband quote on 94)  (93-94)  This sense of a transcendental onsicousness also evident in the German word Geist which stood for the "collective thought of mankind and sometimes for a transcendental consciousness.

Idealism was particular powerful in humanisitc and historical studies...in the Geistwissenschaften...the german classificaiton of such disicplines that seemed to imply a Idealist pointr of view.  That prhase had atenecedents, that went all the way back to Mill or even Descartes, but whicn in Germany Weber had traed to Hermann von Hlemholtz, the German psycho-physicist of the mid-19th century.  Hegel also promoted its usage and Welhelm Dilthey gave it a clear definitionin the 1880s, describing what he called "objective gesit" as "the whole rangeof man's past cultural achievements that are accessible to use in theform of literature, conventions of language, works of art, codes of law, and other documents or remnants of whatever kind." (Ringer's words, 97)

title: Sources of the Self: The Making of the Modern Identity
text:
p.115-116 Plato (Reasoned) Self-Mastery

 

In the Western tradition, beginning with Plato: "We are good when reason rules, and bad when we are dominated by our desires." (115) The good man is "master of himself" or kreitto autou.  Plato also sets up a higher and lower soul "to logisikon" v. "to epithumetikon".  "The good sols enjoy order (kosmos), concord (xumphonia), and harmony (harmonia), where the baad are torn every which way by their desires and are in perpetual conflict." (115) So: "The mastery of self through reason brings with it these three fruits: unity with onself, calm, and collected self-posession." (116)

title: Social Thought in America: The Revolt Against Formalism

title: The Making of the Modern University: Intellectual Transformation and The Marginalization of Morality
text:
p. 008-9 Methodology

She mentions Hollinger and Bender and then notes that she has attempted to blur (morethan Hollinge rand Bender) the distinction between text and context, intellectual and institutional history.  

Good basic desc. of methodology here read if needed.  It seems close to the methodology that I am using in my work.

title: The Case for Contamination
text:
General Notes 1/2012

This article is somehow an excerpt of Appiah's book on Cosmopolitanism.  It seems to go about material located in the chapter on Contamination specifically,  and it is somehow much sharper and easier to see what Appiah's arguments are.  Appiah's point here is to attack the ideal of cultural preservation in particular as he saw it expressed in a convention on the "protection and promotion" of cultural diversity that was approved at the UNESCO General Conference in Oct 2005.  He wants instead to suggest the importance of cultural contamination:

When people speak for an ideal of cultural purity, sustaining the authentic culture of the Asante or the American family farm, I find myself drawn to contamination as the  name for a counterideal.  Terence [an African slave named Publius Terentius Afer born in Carthatge taken to recome 2nd centruy B.c., he ha smentioned in paragrah before] had a notable firm grasp on the range of human variety: 'So many men, so many opinions' was one line of his.  And it's in his comedy "The Self-Tormentor that you'll find what may be the golden rule of cosmpolitanism - Homo sum: humani nil a me alienum puto, "I am human: nothing human is alien to me."  The context is illuminating.  A busybody farmer named Chremes is told by his neighbor to mind his own affairs; the homo sum credo is Chreme's breezy rejoinder.  It isn't meant to be an ordinance from on high; it's just the case for gossip.  Then again, gossip - the fascination people have for the small doings of other people - has been a powerful forc for conversation among cultures. (section 6)

The impetus for the protection of cultures is in part driven by a concern for homogenization and "cultural imperialism", but in Appiah's case cosmopolitanism does not imply homogenization.  Here he has contrasted cosmopolitans with jihadists who he sees as "counter-cosmopolitan" universalists and absolutists.  What contrasts them from cosmopolitanisms is not that they believe in universal truth, for cosmopolitans believe in that too, but their appraoch to truth and tolerance:

To say what, in principle, distinguishes the cosmpolitan from competing univeralisms, we plainly need to go beyond talk of truth and tolerance.  One distinctively cosmpolitan commitment is to pluralism.  Cosmpolitans think that there are many values worth living by and that you cannot live by all of them.  So we hope and expect that different people and different societies will embody different values.  Another aspect of cosmopolitanism is what philosophers call fallibilism -- the sense that our knowledge is imperfect, provisional, subject to revision in the face of new evidence. (section 4)

He heads off the criticism that "liberal pluralists" (same as cosmpolitan??) self-refute when they are "intelerant of radical intolerance" but for him that is a "mistake".  On the one hand, he thinks that one can care about indivdual freedom while understanding that it will not always have the same "contours" everywhere.  But the also wants simply to assert that individual freedom is not for everyone, ie the counter-cosmopolitans. 

He is willing to admit further that "liberty and diversity may well be at odds".  He comes to this point after explaining how Muslims react hostily to Western mores governing men and women in public.  But he think that here too cultural preservation is "not  helpful."  Here his point vis-a-vis cosmpotlianism deepends and also becomces more like what I want to say about Boas' cosmpmolitanism.  What he calls "living cultures" do not "evolve from purity into contamination"; the change was more "gradual" he says, or in fact he suggets they were always contaminated.  It is a movement from "one mixture to a new mixture," and this process take place away "rules and rulers" in "the conversations that occur across cutural boundaries." (section 5)  His key point about these "conversations"--indeed the word is a bit misleading--is that they are not mediated by appeals to reason.  He gives an example of the way movements against the binding of women's feet took hold in Chian in the 1910s and 1920s.  His poitn is that this other set of ideas "took hold".  He writes: "The appeal to reason can explain neither the custom nor its abolition."  In another example, he speaks of middle-class women going to work in the West.  Here too reason had a smaller role than one would assume.  Here he makes his poitn wrly: "The arguments that kept the old pattern in place were not--to put it mildly--terribly good.  If the reasons for the old sexist way of doing things had been the problem, the women's movement could have been done in a couple of weeks."

It is this process of things taking hold that I suspect Boas gave some more meat too!!

title: The World After the Russia-Georgia War
text:
(( Summarial Note ))

This article presents fairly clear the logic whereby one views the emergence of an emerging conflict not between the west and the rest, but between a series of world powers who refused to be "assimilated" into the existing  geo-political order: 

"Moreover, as Richard Sakwa observes, "the international system today does not have a mechanism for integration of rising great powers" - whose terms of integration have to be negotiated, not dictated from Washington or Brussels."

This also implies a failure of the US to force get Russa to "assimlate.": 

"Washington and its closest allies, having failed to integrate Russia by assimilating it - i.e. transforming it into a liberal-democratic market state that would follow the Washington consensus and join the America-led liberal world order - are now trying to contain Russia by expanding Nato to Georgia and Ukraine; planning to erect ballisitic-missile defences close to Russia's borders; and vying with Russia over the route of energy pipelines."

Contrast this then in a textual way with Huntington's article on Clash of Civilizations.  The authors also mentions another article which argues against Huntington's clash of civilizations argument: a Rand report by Zalmay Khalizad & Iran Lesser, "Sources of Conflict in 21st Century: REgional Futures and U.S. STrategy."

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.055-56  Some modification of Settlement Culture

Muncy makes intersting points here regards to interaction between gender and professionalization within the female dominion.  She notes that the Child Bureau could not reproduce settlement house's informal culture.  The lines of power and strucfcture were "formally delineated."  The women occupying certain positions were ambiitous.  Job market  and governemntal structure Muncy says modified female professional culture.  Also bureaucrati cprocedures that led Lathrop to enforce a code of conduct in May 1918 that woud limit personal conversation.  (54)  But Muncy notes "that bureaucratic structure did not utterly control the working lives of women in the Children's Bureau; it acted as a tube through whh female professional culture was forced and thereby modified." (55)  Professionalization she notes in fact made some settlement house traditions more efficient and notes the new use of advanced publicity tecniques (pamphlet's, press releases, radio spots, etc) to get out and popularize information about childbirth and childrearing.  Massive sales of pamphlet's written by Mary Mills West on prental care, infant care, etc... (see 55-56).  Here Muncy notes that women were taking full advantage of new publicity and propaganda techniques that she argues had not acquired the negative connotation.  (56)   They nurtured close relationship with the press, magzines likes Ladies' Home Journal, Woman's World, The Survey and Newspapers like the Atlantic Tri-Weekly Journal, the Delineator, and the East Tennessee News.  (57)   Lathrop also took advantage  of links with volutnary organizations and drew them under her leadership, drawing in female volunteers all over the nation , e.g. on birth registration drive.  (58-60)  Also increased legislative power (61-2)

title: 'The Value of Person Lies in His Herzensbildung': Franz Boas' Baffin Island Letter-Diary 1883-1884
text:
More notes from ?
#Douglas Cole, "'The Value of a Person Lies in his Herzensbildung': Franz Boas' Baffin Island Letter-Diary, 1883-1884" in *Observer's Observed: Essays on Ethnographic Fieldwork* (Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press, 1983), 13-52.
* P.3 dec 23, he refers to a Inuit custom as beautiful.  And then compares their society with his own... This is the letter where he refers to here's idling and where he halos seems to refer to the "relativity of cultivation" 
* P. 33 also he notes that he can still not understand the Inuit when they are telling stories.
*P. 35 He complains about not being able to speak a "sensible word" with the Inuit. So he feels that it is hard "not to have any one with whom to speak a sensible word, no one who is in any way close to you." He gets into this because it is New Year, dec31, and he imagines how Marie is around "among your people...among those whom you love." 
* P. 36 Jan, 21, Tininixdjuax.  He is noting how the Eskimo have come to believe tht he is the cause of a disease going around. Cole describes the situation here, indeed the likely possibility that the disease came with the germania and the Catherine. The Eskimo then decide at the behest of a shaman apparently that Boas not be allowed into their igloo. (36) Boas reaction was that this "hostility" ought not be "allowed to prevail". (36) this reaction is interesting. Clearly, it does involve a kind of arrogant reaction to what Boas could see still as superstitious belief, even though it probably was not. But there is also a more complex background here. One has to think of the fondness Boas had developed for the igloo, for the experience of entering them after being very cold.  He says this in the letter from Jan. 22, on 36-37, where the point is in fact that his point of view has shifted in the way that Cole notes oin his editor note on p.21, ie this is the kind of shift in the appreciation of what is beautiful that I am getting at in my Mamifold article. 
* P.37 the quote re igloo's being beautiful, related to Cole's note on 21, form letter Jan. 22: "You have no idea how anxiously one looks for the appearance of the icefoot on the horizon, and then when one is near to land with joy one greets the sign of an iglu. It is impossible to tell how comfortable and beautiful it seems when one enters into these dirty, narrow spaces, at the appearance of which I at first turned away in horror..." (36-37)
* P. 37 Also in this Jan 22 letter is an important reflection on not wanting a "German professorship." With what is here alone it is hard to know exactly what Boas means. He talks about the idea that he would be "restricted to my science and to teaching". Does he mean that he would be restricted to physics and teaching? for which he now says he has "little inclination." (37) But then he says that in the United States he can further the "ideas for which I live." but which ideas? Scientific ideas? Maybe but maybe not beau as a bit further along he says: "What I want to live and die for, is equal rights for all, equal possibilities to learn and work for poor and rich alike! Don't you believe that to have done even the smallest bit for this, is more than all science together? I do not think I would be allowed to do this in Germany." (37) So there is no reference here to his being blocked as a Jew. The clearest reference is to a restriction to his science, whatever that means. But perhaps it need not be said to Marie because she knows already, or on the other hand why would he not be free to reference the role of his Jewishness in is calculation with Marie? I need to look in Cole's biography because I think he has a reference from Boas to the Jewishness problem in this calculation....
* Also interesting here is that he moves on after this to a reference to a harsh reality. He refers romantically tomMarie and how she will help him and give him strength to do all this, an dthen he writes: "But I must return to harsh reality! The activities of the Eskimo, the howling of e dogs, the screaming of the children, all in this small iglu , call me back." obviously this is just a transition out of the letter, but the juxtapositions are interesting between a discussion of ideas, even ideals, and love for Marie, and then a reference to. Harsh reality that again does not seem so bad. Chaotic perhaps but it is happening in e small iglu, which he has fought to regain entrance into, and he is "called" back, not forced back.
* Also then at the end of this Another relativity reference. He has referred to the situation in the iglu, then he says he wonders what she is doing, and again the theme from before and discussion of new years activity on 34-35, the theme of her being among her people: "At least you have the advantage of being able to speak with them [whatever company she is keeping]. I have, however, sometimes found that what one hears in "society" is worth [no more for me than] the conversation of these people here." (37-38) here the second brackets are Cole's.

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text:
p.015 Failure to bind patricians and academicians...

Higham describes it in terms of "authority": "In the absence of a political system capable of binding the patrician intellectual and the academic teacher to a common center of authority, the two groups eventually drifted apart." (15)  

Effects:
After 1890s # of amateur historians declines.  And he says: "A similar disengagement evidently occured in other fields of cultural endeavor.  One thinks of Edith Wharton's literary isolation in upper-class New York, hder descriptions of delicate American dilettantes in Europe, and her own nostalgia." (15)  Higham thinks that the "aristocratic revival" of a post-civil war period had dissipated by the end of the century and that in the "increasingly demcoratic atmoosphere of theProgressive Era the aristocracy of culture very largely went to pieces; and many o fits patrician elements became--like Henry Adams himself in his late ryears--peevish, precious, and aloof." (16)

title: Getting Spliced: Modernism and Sexual Difference
text:
p.107-111 Mina Loy (and Stein) v Pound

Burke argues that whereas Pound's model of intellectual activity involved the "poet-sculptor's forceful mental imprint upon matter, both Loy and Stein were more concerned with the physical properties of language as the 'belle matiere' itself." (107)

But whereas Stein's vision of "psychosexual and syntactic connections" had been positive, Loy's was negative.  She had been experiencing difficult times.  So in contrast to Stein's G.M.P and Tender Buttons, Loy's 1915 Love songs "embodies a disillusioned vision of psychosexual relations that reflects theri period of consumption, during the first year of the Great War." (107)

Futurists had taught her that "the poetic image was what the mind determined it to be: it had no fixed objective reality. It might or might not be mimetic or representational, and more likely than not, it resembled those unstable mental pictures being discussed by the new theory of psychoanalysis." (108)  

The reality Loy conjured, unlike Pounds where the male mind imprinted on female matter, "suggets, rather, a model more like a painterly verison of the Freudian unconscious, in which images and meanings lie dormant yet accessible to the artist through a creative process that is a kind of self-analysis." (108)

In Aphorisms she called this "mental spatiality." (108)

She then analyzes some of Loy's "Love Songs" showing the way Loy's formal technique subjects the "familiar images and language of romantic love" to inspection and ultimately mocking and distancing herself from the prospect of male-female marriage or union.  (108-111)

title: Verging on Etra-Vagance: Anthropology, Hisotry, Religion, Literature, Arts...Showbiz
text: (5) p. 25-28 (Ch.1, Section "Über Benedict") Boon argues here that Benedict's book, to the reader, is built most strongly around the Appolonian/Dionysian dichotomy that she takes from Nietzsche. For instance, he argues "Neither Benedict's schemes of multiple variations nor her unfortunate diagnostic labels for Dobu and Kwakiutl dispel readers' fantasies that her shifting text--actually covering many sides of social organization and ritual practice--simply fleshes out a singular dualism, filched from a mad philosopher." (29) The point he makes on the pages between 25-29 is that the reader's "recollection" of reading gives the impression of an integrity in her account of these "cultures" that is not actually there, and that the apparent integrity is actually only held together by the reader's awareness of Nietzsche's dichotomy. But his point is actually not then to proceed to a "true" account of things, but to inquire into the "manifest strategies behind Patterns of Culture and to fragmentary ritual practices featured in Benedict's semi-thick descriptions." (30)

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text:
p.003-6 Negative Liberty Analysis

Negative and positive liberty are still the most important conceptual divisions of liberty...

She examines the notion of negative liberty through major theorists Berlin, Taylor (a critic).

Neg. lib.  defines liberty as absence of external barriers to ones desires. 

In that it supposes that desires must be conscious it "draws clear-cut lines between inner and outer, subject and object, self and other." (4)

So Taylor calls it "tough-minded" b/c of emphasis on indiv. responsiblity and "choice" and accepting consequences of choices. (4-5)

But one must not actually choose to pursue desires, rather one must have the opportunity to do so in order to be free.  (5)

title: Autonomy in Moral and Political Philosophy (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
text:
Section 1.2 - Conceptual Variations

A theory of authonmoy is "simply a construction of a concept aimed at captruing the gneeral sense of 'self-rule' or 'self-government'..."

Two componentss to self-rule: "the independence of one' sdeliberation and choice from manipulaiton by others, and the capacity to rule onself."  The second implies a discussion of the first and so is more primary.

Two further "families of conditions" in conceptions of autonomy often iscussed: competency conditions and authenticity conditions.  The former the "capacity for rational thought, slef-control, and freedom form debilitating pathologies, systemiatic self-deception.."  The latter the ability to "reflect upon and endorse (or identify with) one's desires, values and so on."

The above conception is the basic definition and is influential, and then there are variations which she goes through...not going to talk abou thtem all.  But will mention some in my notes.

Impotant and most prominant objection is that the idea of "identification" with one' s own desires is problematic.  One can identity with oneself someting bad with out judging, i.e. simply acknowledging.  One could acknowledge something about oneself without approving of it.  Is that a state of autonomy?  This question creates a distinction between "procedural independence" and "substantive independence," the latter would suggest that one cannot be considered autonomous in certain "constrained life situations" merely based on having made free and autonomous (procedurally independent) decisions to arrive at that state. Substnative independence "threatens to rob the attribution of autonomy of any claim to value neturality..."

Another objection strikes at the idea that "second-order" reflection can be trusted as a model of verification even in cases in which it "approves" of first-order aspects of the self.  Such "high level judgements" may have no "greater claim to authenticity than their first order cousins."

A related critique is that the stress on higher level reflection/judgement implies a kind of hyper-intellectualism. "Connections to values, deisres, and perosnal traits ore often gorunded in emotial and affective repsonses, ones connected with care, commitment and relations to other."

title: Antiromantic Romanticism: Sapir's Critique of American Individualism
text:
p.091-95  Critique of efficiency/business Cult is in Anth thought

H now turns to look at how Sapir's critique of mass democracy, efficiency, and business culture influenced his anthropology thought.  He says the corollary was his "personality-in-culture" studies.  He raises once again Murray's quesoitn about Sapir: did he reify the individual.  Again H suggest that the answer is no: "it is also possible to see Sapir as placing emphasis on the soul's making, as it were, its ongoing efforts to shape self-expression in its struggles with artistic media and techniques." (91)

H refers back to previous material here noting that in his Dickinson review Sapir spoke of "'the intuitive hunger of the soul for the beautiful moulding of experience actually felt,' of 'unhampered intuitive living'" ( quotedon 91) And he brings up the "Twilight of Rhyme" piece the idea that the "perfection of form is always essential" and that every artist/cutlure "must solve the prolem  [of form] ever anew" (quoted on 91). H's point is that here Sapir is spekaing of an artist as an individuality but also is stessing "the artist's experience transmuted into art thorugh an active and ongoing engagement of the individual creativity and traditoinal aesthetic forms." (91)

Now he tries to connect this to Boas' and to romanticism.  Here he goes all wrong I think.  He cites Boas' reference to romantic ideal of "indivdiuality" and to Goethe in "The Study of Geography" (92); then he notes that the romantics were critical of the reductionism of what they saw as Enlightenment thought.  All this is true.  Then he intepretes Boas' attackson race as a critique of scientific abstraction cum reductionism. (92)  That's tenous... then he suggests that Sapir "felt compelled" to critique Kroeber's superorganic as a reducitonist abstraction.  (93) This is too simplistic I think; the connection is not such a straight line.  It is not that this point is wrong, but that it's not just romanticism.  The problem may come earlier i the essay, in the frame of antiromantic-romanticism and the way he explains it by rooting it in romanticism even thought he identifies it with Wyndham Lewis--a modernist!  The same problem is evident in his attempt to conflate Arnold with Bourne with Sapir...he's not sensitive to the differences even though yes they are moving in the same line... from romatnicism to modernism etc...

Where he takes this in terms of the individual as monad thogh is certainly right: that Sapir's view ofthe individual is probalby not that of the "self-contained moad" as Murray charges, but of "individuals multiply defined,a s it were, in terms of their participation in a range of varying social relatoins." (95)

I would just ask whether this is a description of the individual that actually satisfies Sapir.  It's this complicated description of the individual that is precisely what is so modern about SApir, because he builds it up on a complex psychological view of personality as a relational structure... but does this satisfy Sapir???

title: Women in the Professions: A Research Agenda for American Historians
text:
p. 275 Survey of historical literature on Professionalism

Authors note imp. book on professionalism which place the professions as a "linchpin in much larger historical arguments." (275)
They note Durkheim's 1902 book.  Books by David Rothman, Burton Bledstein, Robert Wiebe, and Christopher Lasch.  The effect has been to make the study of professions no longer merely "sociological." (275)  

BUT all these studies left out the gender dimension.

title: The Soul's Economy: Market Society and Selfhood in American Thought, 1820 - 1920
From Salvation to Self-Realization: Advertising and the Therapeutic Roots of the Consumer Culture, 1880-1980
text:
p. 007-8 Lears' Analysis of the Loss of Selfhood

Lears introduces it like this: "As more and more people became enmeshed in the market's web of interdependence, liberal ideals of autonomous selfhood became ever more difficult to sustain." (7) He continues: "For entrepreneurs as well as wageworkers, financial rise or ruin came to depend on policies formulated far away, on situtations beyond the individual's control. And by the 1890s, as Alfred D. Chandler and host of economics historians have made clear, the large bureaucratically organized corporation was becoming the dominant model for businessmen who sought to organize the national market. Jobs were becoming more specialized, more interdependent; personal autonomy was becoming more problematic. Itwas not surprising that believers in self-made mahood grew uneasy. Even the privileged ones fretted over "Our Lost Individuality" as they pondered the coming of a mass society. 'We are aa mass,' an Atlantic writer complained in 1909. 'As a whole, we have lost the capicity for separate selfhood.'" (8) He then invokes Susman's theme of a turn toward personality as a shift from building "character" and mastering one's physical environment to poise, confidence, and charm. Then he invokes Riseman and a turn toward "masks" and role playing: "As success became more dependent on evanescent 'impression managment' selfhood lost coherence. The older ethic had required adherence to an internalized morality of self-control; repressive as this 'inner-directoin' had been, it helped to sustain a solid core of selfhood. The newer ethic of ''other-direction' undermined the solidity by prsenitng the self as an empty vessel to be filled and refilled according to the expectations of others and the needs of the moment. Afte rthe turn of the century, success manual sincreasingly prescribed wthat the sociologists David Riesman has called 'modes of manipulating the self in order to manipulate others.' The successfull man or woman had 'no clear core of self' (in Riesman's words0, only a set of social masks." (8) He then notes that this idea had been around but ther ehad before been the assumption of the "existence of a 'simple, genuine self.'" (8) But now there was a turn toward imagining other kinds of selves that had no such character. He notes but does not detail the work of George Herbert Mead and William James as examples. He quotes Howells; "...the huma personality seemed like an onion which was 'nothing but hells, that you keep peeling off, one after another, till you think you have got down to the heart at last, and then you have got down to nothing.'" (8)

title: Verging on Etra-Vagance: Anthropology, Hisotry, Religion, Literature, Arts...Showbiz
text: (1) p. xiv Like Stephen Tyler's Unspeakable, Boon's book claims that he has developed some alternative an not entirely serious textual method: "This book follows suit, along disputatious paths of interpretive theory, semiotics, area research, fieldwork, media, studies and cultural critique. Even in our 'postmodern' day of disciplinary diveristy, aspects of ethnography, travel tales, hybrid histories, novelistic discourse, and composite arts still resonate with Thoreau's perplexities and enthusiasms. Remembering the chances Thoreau took, I have cultivated a hyphenated genre of essay-études offer nondogmatic ruminations that twist, dart, and swerve with the subject studied; their boundaries remain porous, syntax shifting, pedagogy nondidactic (mostly). Analogies could be drawn with musical études that fluctuate among keys--those of Scriabin, say. Such wriitng hopes to be me halfway by equivalent acts of reading; it reamt hat reading-writing might become, intermittently at least, ensembled." (xiv)

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
00 Summarial Note 00 

This article examines the experience of what the author defines as an "
early" generation of female anthropologists in the US.  By "early" she means women born prior to 1885.  Her case studies are: Erminnie Smith, Alice Fletcher, Matilda Stevenson, Zelia Nuttall, Frances Densmore, and Elsie Clews Parsons.

The overall tone of the article is positive, tracing an ever greater recognition of women's work in anthropology and an ever-increasing quality of their work.  She draws some general conclusions (the evidence for which did not seem to me to be fully in the body of the paper) on 78-81.  Main points are:

--That women did not confine themselves to data seemed appropriate to women, like children or something.  (78)  

-- She sees the disbanding of the Women's Anthropological Society in 1889 as a recognition of the universal significance of women's work.  [But would women have been stronger in the profession had they retained an organization?] (78)

-- But women in early years were present in the field b/c it was though that they could access data not available men.    Here she explains women conformed to traditional Victorian sex standards.  (78-9)

-- She notes also the persistence of gendered criticism by men of women in anthropology.  Women who did not conform to ninteenth-century norms were "either 'bad women' or so intellectually gifted that, proverbial exceptoins to the rule, they were accorded respect and egalitarian treatment by men.  Women who succeeded were by definitino notable for their intelligence and unconventional aspirations, but in most cases these traits were not enough..." (79)  Not enough for what???

-- All the women, she notes, "had advantages of family welath, social status, and an interest in education that allowed them greater latitude of behavior than if their families had been ppoor and ignorant." (79)

title: Works and Wives: On the Sexual Division of Textual Labor
text:
p. 269 Corporate life and the Working Wife

"If, as Claude Levi Strauss has suggested, anthropology is an adventure and anthropologists are adventure's bureaucrats, than anthropology may simply be another manifestation of Western corporate life.  The wives of policemen, diplomatcs, colonial officials and colonists, sodliers and sailors, and corporate executives in Britain have been studied and often found to be incorporated into their husband's careers." (269)

The find this to be true in anthropology too.  They cite a book called the Incorporated Wife (1984).

title: American Moderns: Bohemian New York and the Creation of a New Century
text:
p. 270-272 Sexual Modernism & Troubled Masculinity

A sharp and concise discussion of men's lack of confidence and trouble with masculinity within what Stansell has called Sexual Modernism.  

-- Given that feminism and the New Woman -- whom the Bohemian men supported -- were seen within sexual modernism as the bearers of modernity, the men were unsure of their own significance.  Stansell notes that though the men supported the New Woman, they had grown up at a time "in which the depleting effect of feminization the nation's cultural and intellectual life was taken as fact."  (270) She notes then that they "faced the question of how to be culturally potent at a moment when women seemed to be the bearers of change."  (270)  She explains that in the 1890s bohemians had deployed the man-about-town image, with colonial traveler and western explorer swagger, but then in 1910s it became difficult: "...its men were not always cast in a leading role in the theater of the new.  The stage belonged, above all, to the self-proclaimed heroines in the story of emancipation, the rebel girls, the Emma Goldman fans, the writers of racy vers libre, 'all of the girls [who] felt that they were young women o f genius condescending to enjoy life among this gypsy rabble.'" (270-271)

-- One "recourse was to idealize the manood of the proletariat." (271) Wobblies seemed to possess a stable masculinity.  Max Eastmen, e.g., had disguised himself as a hobo after college and rode the rails.  Also the "tramp" --- She refers to this in Chaplin's The Tramp (1914). (271)

-- Another was "homoerotic humanism" a phrase coming from literary historian Paul Fussell on Wilfred Owen...this "infused the generation of young men in Europe who went off to war." (271)

-- Excellent quote from Floyd Dell in terms of the reversal men were experiencing her...she suggests that they became a "docile interolocutor" as women took the stage of "the new" as she calls it.  Floyd Dell recalled modelling for  aJackson Park sculptor: "...'I shall never forget the sensation of sitting on a model and being stared at by a handsome sculptress.  A man is used to having a prolonged meeting of his eyes with a girls' mean something; and it is hard to get used to meeting a girl's wide-eyed, impersonal stare.' The habit of a masculine lifetime bridled at looking at a woman with sexual interest and receiving nothing in return.  'I became uneasy and almost afraid -- I wanted to look away , but that seemed cowardly and evasive.'" (272)

But stansell hints that they will strike back.

title: The Professions and Social Structure
text:
00 Summary 00

This article presents an approach to understanding the significance of the professions in the structural-functionalist vein.  Prasons' ideas on the subject
were influential (though I don't have a good sense of how and why).  

Parsons analyzes the internal structural system of meaning and decision making within the professions, especially as it pertains to the question of whether or not professionals operate "altruistically" as opposed to businessmen who act "acquisitively."  Parsons conclusion is that this distinction is a false dichotomy both for businessmen and for professionals.  The argument in other words is that the more complex rendering of the relationship between individuals and institutions in terms of individual decision making that Parsons presents is also relevant for business, and thus that the study of the professions is also useful for understanding the "occupational structure" of modern society more generally.  (See pgs 465-467).


So then how  does Parsons understand this relationship between the individual an the institution in the professions?  This is really crux of his argument in general because even though he's saying that business institutions and professional institutions are not what we assume them 
to be (i.e. respectively selfish and altruistic), the model he evolves in 
describing the professional occupational structure is the model he would
also seek to apply to the business world.  

His model of professionals is as follows.  While they are not altruistic, he says, their motives are primarily unique in hi sdescription in that they are not defined by what he terms "traditional"  means (his primary example being kinship bonds).  Firstly, he believes that they are defined instead by
a "continual and subtle pressure to be rationally critical, particularly of ways and means." (459)   Secondly, he presents the nature of intellectual authority as he sees it among professionals.  That authority he says is limited by "specificity of function".  That is, one only exercises authority in a 
specific "'filed' of knowledge and skill." (460) So this menas that also "[c]ommerical relations in our  society are predominantly functionally specific, kinship relations, functionally diffuse." (461) Another example, is
the ability of a certain professional to gain access to a private realm when 
functioning in a bureaucractic "office" but  not in his "private" capacity. (461).
Thirdly, professionals deal with people in abstract terms.  To the professional people are "cases" or "clients" or "customers" not "total personalities." (462)  [Simmel makes a similar point aobut modern society.]
Lastly, Parsons argues that professionalism emphasizes "universalism" and judges merit on these terms. (462-3)  Thus it is independent of status as it functions in kinship groups or what he refers to as "primary group relationships." (463)  Thus professional instituions seek independence from "social structures where particularism is dominat..." (463)  (462-3) 

Based on this analysis then he begins to blur the lines between acquisitiveness and altrusim in the professions first (463-465) and then
trying to suggest that thi smodel actually helps to characterize the whole
of modern society better than an acquisitive model of "capitalism" (466-7).

title: Ruth Benedict and the Modernist Sensibility
text: p.138 Contradiction of Modern Social Science Handler on Modern Social Theory Handler thinks that modern social theory "(dating at least from the 18th century) swings between reified conceptions of the individual (as in utilitarianism) and reified conceptions of society and culture (as in most twentieth-century sociology and anthropology)." (138) Like Terry Eagleton in "Capitalism, Modernism and Postmodernism," Handler also critiques modernist social theory for avoiding the political and structural realities that generated the problems they sought to escape by chasing after either a reified view of culture and society or (more typical of the 19th century) of reified individual. He writes: "The modernist's quest for what Sapir called genuine culture was motivated in part by their perception that an atomistic, rationalistic science had destroyed tradition. But the modernists' genuine culture cannot, in the final analysis, be discovered by a social science that constructs cultural wholes on individualistic principles. Indeed, embodied in governmental policies, modernist social science paradoxically leads away from holism to the routinization of all aspects of social life, bureaucratically fragmented and administered." ( 138)On this he also cites his 1988 book. Like Sapir, who Handler woudl probably say just pursued the individual, Benedict also didn't get these underlying political realities according to him. She tried to avoid them by pursuing an "individualizing vision" of cultures that saw cultures, famously, as if they were personalities. This worked against, however, the hermeneutic and comparative tendency that he mentioned on p.135. Essentially, then, he's accusing her of seeking a view in which the individual could find pleasure in giving in to the corporate hierarchy. You can see this clealry in these lines: "In Patterns of Culture, Benedict discovered the authentic, holistic cultures she sought and from which the modern world excluded her as a participant. She describes the Apollonian, anti-individualistic Pueblos with an almost utopian longing, for in them, apparently, the surrender of individuality to society is not even problematic." (138-139) Handler thinks Benedict's notion of detachment is wrapped up in this position she charts out. Look carefully at this paragraph on 138-9. If Benedict sought society's in which giving in to the whole was not a problem, then Handler says she was willing to admit that individuals in such societies were "unself-conscious in their individualism." (139) That unself-consciousness he think would not have been consistent with Sapir's emphasis on sincerity, which he thinks implies, self-consciousenss [Except that Sapir was saying that the culture, not the individual, was sincere; the indiviudal self was just active on the social forms]. In any case, regarding Benedict he writes: "Sincerity imples self-consciousness, and Benedict sought worlds in which meaningfulness and participation could exist without such awareness. The Northwest Coast potlatcher could pursue megalomaniacal successes unhindered by modernist self-doubt." (139)

title: Sociology and Scientism: The American Quest for Objectivity, 1880-1940
text:
Dissertation Revision note upon reading Bannister

Could add a historiographical point probably to chapter 1 that would position the Boasian anthropologists in relation to the sociologists. The point would be something like this: "While the 1920s sociologists turned to extreme forms of objectivism in an attempt to totally exclude the subjectivity of the scientists, the anthropologists embraced a radical form of self-reflexive subjectivity.". 

That statement could come after a paragraph in which I really stress hard the way sociology had turned to social control. Perhaps I already do this, but iif so I also shopuld cite Banister and the Rodgers article "In search od progrssovism" that he cites, see pp. 5 and fn#9.

Note that Bannister says that for Ogburn and Chapin--his "nominalist" objectivists-- "'society' was essentially a name for the collective response of individuals...", (6).

title: The Subject of Liberty: Toward a Feminist Theory of Freedom
text:
0 p.ix-x  Social Context, Feminism and choice

She says that feminists have shown that "some contexts are better than others at providing women with geunine alternatives from which they can choose." 

So says she will use these "lived experiences of women to demosntrate how existing freeom theories fail to challenge the duality of internal and external dimensions of freedom; and I argue that attending to women's experiences requires political theorists to rethink the relationship between these two dimensions." (x)

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text: p.033 Close ties between Chicago Sociologists and Hull House

title: History: Professional Scholarship in America
text:
p.073 New Audience after WWI

Higham describes a new audience after WWI.  Interesting description.  Noteable is that it is a fragmented audinece of professionals with leisure time
seeking integrative undrstanding: 

"After World War I a new audience for the serious writer emerged in America, and it has been gaining maturity ever since.  It has neither the homogeneity nor the assurance of a position and tradition that belong to the aristocracy of culture.  That older audience was unified by its consiouscness of itself as a social class with certain well-defined responsibilities, and it also shared common intellectual interests shaped by the standard educational curriculum that prevailed through most of the nineteenth century.  The new audience, much more fluid and diversified, rests on a broader basis.  It has grown from the extraordinary expansion of higher education in recent decades, from the multiplication of specialized white-collar occupations, and from a concomitant increase in leisure time.  its intellectual interests reflected the multifarious content of modern higher education and the immense variety of opinion-making agencies.  It seeks knowledge nto out of a moral imperative but out of a need to integrate and understand its discordant experience.  The current 'cultural explosion' is only the most recent manifestation of the rising level of taste and activity on the part of this hungry and restless audience." (73)

Yale, became indep fro msociology in 1930 and Sapir joined in 1931.  joining George Peter Murdock, who had studied in Yale sociology and was more of a sociologist.

title: My Promised Land: The Triump and Tragedy of Israel
text:
Notes on Shavit's "My Promised Land"

12-14: Deals with why his great grandfather does not really "see" the Palestinians.

16: Zangwill gives impassioned speech c1904 about Israel, addressing directly the Arab population's existence.

18-19: First attempt at dealing with the colonialism charge vv Zionism and Israel. Yes it looks like colonialism -- safari suits, cork hats, Thomas Cook tents, the language of his grandfather in his journals -- but then these people have a different goal. They are not he says seeking "the glory of Britain, but to save persecuted masses." (18) So Shavi concludes these are not "agents of colonial power." (18)

##Chapter 2

26-27: Emphasizes the importance of the Kishinev pogrom in the Ukraine in April 1903 in terms of provoking a sense of urgency and ultimately beginning a kind of hardening such that Zionists who could not envision removing existing populations started to be able to envision just that. In 1903, Herzl explored the possibility of buying land in the Harold Valley owned by the Sarouk family of Alexandria, and resettling vicitms of European antisemitism there. But this would have rewuired forcibly removing the Palestinian villages who were serfs on the Sarouk families land. In 1903, this was unthinkable. (26) Later in the 1920s, after the Great War and the Great Revolution -- events during which pogroms were everywhere and Jewish suffering in Europe intense -- this changes. Shavit speaks ofa new "breed" of Jew: muscly, manly, etc. Initial description on 28.

27: Interesting assertion that of the one million Jews that fled Eastern Europe, those whobeent to America "wanted a life" while those who made aliyah "wanted utopia". Only 35k went to Israel.

27-29: These "post-Kishiniv" immigrants "travelled to Palestine in order to find salvation, both for the nation and the individual, by adopting a humane and environmentally friendly socialism." (27) They founded a commune that failed: Degania. Later after the Great War the need fora new solution in the face of widespread pogroms in Europe les to a new vision of settling Palestine forming "communist colonies", not small and intimate but "large, rigid, and almost Bolshevik." (28) "The idea was now was to win the land by forming a tough, determined, semimilitary Labor Brigade." (28) What is happening here? The new energies generated by the war, the pogroms, the revolution, coming together with the opportunities created by the Balfour Declaration, the British Mandaten, and the Sarsouk transaction make it possible for the Jews to reenvisin their identity and to "enter the valley--to build and transform themselves in a valley inhabited by others." (29)

40: Engages the historical debates about nationalism v. Socialism in Ein Harod. Was socialism just the cunning way to settle the valley, one that also provided moral legitimacy? All just to "obscure its colonialist, expansionist nature." (40)

##Chapter 3

65: Important sentence. Context is that in Rehovot there is a balance of capital, nationalism, etc. Social democrats of working class and liberals of landowning class agree: "Both want Zionism to be rooted in the land and to grow from it gradually and naturally. There is no talk of taking the land by force. In their different ways they all want Zionism to be a natural identity a building process. They want to merge the healing of a people with cultivation of the land." (65) cf this sentence with the bit about Ein Harod, the idea of Jwws returning to cultivation, and in sondoing ceasing to be the objects of history and becoming subjects, 35.


## Chapter 4: Masada, 1942

This chapter is crazy important I think. It's where he deals with the transformation of Zionism (into something more harsh and aggressive) in response to the emergence of Arab-Palestinian nationalism and then utlimately the Holocaust. The chapter is todl in relation to Gutman's march with some young soldiers up to Masada, which will become the most important symbol of this new form of Zionism.

96: Totally key quote about the shift, but coming at the end, when the knowledge of the Holocaust exists: "For spiritual leaders like Tabenkin, Katznelson, and Gutman, the significance of th Holocaust is threefold: It is a human catastrophe on a scale not seen since the Middle Ages. It is a Jewish catastrophe on a scale not experienced since the destruction of the Second Temple. And it is a Zionist catastrophe unlike any other. For Zionism, the implications of the Holocaust are devastating. Gone are the great Jewish Nasses that Zionism was designed to save. Gone is the great human reservoir that was to save Zionism. Gone is Zionism's raison d'etre. For even if Hitler is defeated, he might stil leave behind him a defeated Jewish people. With no Eastern European demographic backbone, Zionism becomes a bridgehead that no reinforcements will ever cross, protect, or hold." (96) When I discussed this with Adi, he said, "Yeah, but you could also say that without the Holocaust Israel would never have been founded." True also, what a horrible paradox!

## Chapter 5: Lydda, 1948

This chapter is also important. I felt that Shavit lost his balance a bit. Lydda is a city in the middle of Israel, near Tel Aviv, near an airport. It was a heavily Arab city, and because of its location it was a place where there really could be no Arabs. In 1948, the early form of the IDF drove out the Palestinians there, sending them in a column toward Jordan. It was the result of no expulsion order, because that was something that the Israeli leaders were aware they could not do, but there was a brutal massacre of Palestianians in a Mosque, and then a suggestion that they leave, or else...

123-124: No expulsion orders.

131: Here Shavit reveals his politics a bit, criticizing "bleading-heart Israeli liberals..." Who to his mind "conddemn what they [the IDF, Gutman, Ben Gurion etc] did in Lydda but enjoy the frutis of their deed." Adi told me that he really hates Shavit because he pushed a ground invasion in Lebanon in the second of the recent Lebanon wars, mostly in Adi's mind because it would provide the "sense" of victor. Thirty Israeli soldiers died.

## Chapter 5: Housing Estate, 1957

Here he interviews various survivors of the Holocaust, and then

 

148-151: Description of the post-Holocaust migration to Israel 1945-1951: 750K, 685K in first 3 1/2 years. This description is important. Many of the immigrants are resettled in abandon Palestianian houses and towns. Others in British garrisons. And then ultimately in refugee camps. Then the state of Israel takes action, starting in 1952, such that things do get much better. Isarel becomes a social democracy. And Shavit describes taht this way: "The newborn state was one of the most egalitarian democracies in the world. The Israel of the 1950s was a just social democracy. But it was also a nation of practicality that combined modernity, nationalism, and development in an aggressive manner. There was no time, and there was no peace of mind, and therefore there was no human sensitivity. As the state became everything, the individual was marginalized. As it marched towards the future, Israel erased the past. There was no place for the previous landscape, no place for previous identities. Everything was done en masse. Everything was imposed from above. There was an artificial quality to everything. Zionism was not an organic proccess anyore but a futuristic coup. For its outstanding economic, social and engineering achievements, the new Israel paid a dear moral price. There was no notion of human rights, civil rights, due proccess or laissez-faire. Therew as no equality for the Palestinian minority and no compassion for the Palestinian refugees. there was little respect for the Jewish Diaspora and little empathy for the survivors of the Holocaust. Ben Gurion's statism and monolithic rule compelled the nation forward." (151)
