201-203: Describes how the Settlemetns were a resonse to the two wars, the Six Day War, and then the Yom Kippur War. The first gave a sense of popwer, and the second of defeat.

 

203-206: Interview with Gush Emunim who is key for the settlers movement. On 204, a good definnition of the ideology of Greater Israel.

 

215: Clue to the role of anti-Americanism on the right, where Shavit writes of the attitudes of Etzion, one of the settler movement people in Ofra, about Israel. "The Israelis of the plans are not standing by the Land of Israel. Retreat is in full motion, and it seems clear that Judea and Samara might fall. Americanism is the new Hellenism and its making Israel un-Jewish, weak, hollow, and rotten. Israel can only be saved by a new idea or a deed or an event htat will tranform history." (215)

title: Panopticism and Publicity: Bentham's Quest for Transparency
text:
Random Note 1: Romanticism as basis for critique of equal distribution of resources

Part of Rosenblum's argument about the usefulness of the romantic challenge to liberalism is that romanticism cannot be dismissed as "unrealistic." She writes:

"'Another liberalism' is not romantic in the dismissive colloquial sense of being unrealistic.  Romantic recastings of liberalism may not address immediate political issues or prescribe political action, but they do offer a perspective from which to cosider quesitons such as material distribution.  Evaluating the material conditions for free self-expression, for example, is a legitimate project for political theory--and no mor eor less difficult than evaluating the material bases for democratic equality or mutual respect."

This argument I think is very strong.  One, it seems to echo Walter Benjamin's qualification about historical materialism's concern with the material things: namely, that it does not eschew the significance of spiritual problems.  In Section IV he first quotes Hegel and then makes is point:

"Secure at first food and clothing, and the kingdom of God will come to you of itself. – Hegel, 1807...The class struggle, which always remains in view for a historian schooled in Marx, is a struggle for the rough and material things, without which there is nothing fine and spiritual."

 

At the same time, Rosenblum's argument challenges the presumption behind Sklansky's objection to the new thinking about the social self: that the focus on self-realization prevented attention to the problem of the material distribution of resources, etc.

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.049-50  Lathrop used gender as standard for hirinig

Explains that Lathrop used gnedere explicily as a standard for hiring, a way to exclude men.  She did this in some instances, e.g. for field officers, by deploying Victorian standards that men cold not ask women about personal issues.  (50)  By March 1919, ony 14 men out of 169 staff members.  (51)

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
p. 032 Lous Aggasiz & Ass. for the Advancement of Science open to Women

She claims that Louis Agassiz had "welcomed women to his public lictures and later to his classes at the Penikese Island." She cites Lurie's biography, "Louis Agassiz, A Life in Science (Chicago, 1960), pgs. 166-67, 200-01, 380-81.

title: Creating a Female Dominion in American Reform, 1890-1935
text:
p.040-47 Formation of Child Bureau

Muncy emphasize here the way women ustilized theirown networks fist in making the creation of such a deparment a riority after 1903.  She notes thatthey also needed to rely still on male support but that "[o]n issues regarding children, powerful men listened towomen and were willing to act on female advice." (41)  When the issue became the subject of a special conference as a result of Roosevelts attempts to push the bill...the 
Conference on the care of Dependent Children" (42) , female reformers were there in great numbers 30 out of 215.  Addams and Wald delivered two key addresses.  Key pages here and very interesting are 44-45 where she discusses the disagreements between the feamle reformers and the male majority at the conference over the 1) the role of the government (top of 44) and 2) the proper role of science (bottom 44).  Men believed such an organization overstepped constiuttional limits on a governmental agencies and that social sciences should not be explickitly political (she cites Furner here).  

Muncy explains the women's refusal to "divorce social investigation from political engagement." (45) She argues as she did earlier that women had a "gender-specific need to reconcile their professional goals with Victorian ideals of womanhood, and htis need produced a version of professionalism and a justification for public participation peculiar to women [profssionals]." (45) She speaks then of an insistence especiallyin Wald about the "bureaucratic union of research and advocacy..." (45)   Further, Muncy connects the efforts of female reformers to Kloppenberg's description of the search for a via media between 19th century socialism and liberalism.  (45)  Within this search though Muncy thinks that gender may have played a part in causing a tendency to imagine the stronger role of the govenrment.  (45-46)

title: Women in Early American Anthropology
text:
p. 033-34 She claims that the men in anthropology recognized Women's role

She cites the fact that it is "generally known that Franz Boas recognized the particular contributions women could make to anthropology and welcomed women students who were willing to prove themselves capable of the standards of scholarship he exacted." (33)

More interesting she notes that E.B. Tylor also indicated a role for women in a lecture to the Anthropology Society of Washington in 1884 after he had toured the west where he had visited James and Matilda Stevenson.    What is fascinating here is that Tylor projected the Victorian role of man as head of house and wife into the field as useful.  (33-34, quote on 34).  The speech is E.B. Tylor, "How the Problems of American Anthropology Present Themselves to the English Mind," The Anthropological Society of Washington, Transactions, v. III, 1885, 81-95 quotation on 93; and it was first printed in Science, IV (1884): 545-51.

title: Beyond Separate Spheres: Intellectual Roots of Modern Feminism
text: p.146-177 CHAPTER 6 THE PRIMITIVE SIDE OF CIVILIZED CULTURE

title: Reading Obama: Dreams, Hope, and the American Political Tradition
text:
1. Introduction

 

* Kloppenberg talks about watching the 2008 election while teaching about the American political tradition at Cambridge, UK and while having "anxieties about the American future..." (x)  And then reading Obama's books Dreams of My Father and The Audacity of Hope and becoming "convinced that these books illuminate certain neglected aspects of the present than I had seen in any of the commentaries on the election." (x)

* K says that Obama is the product of three "distinct developments."

1) He thinks that it was the "history of American democracy"--meaning the REvolution all the way to the Civil Rights and Women's Movmeents--that "produced the institutions and the cultural characteristics that made possible Obama' rise."  (x) At the same time, K thinks that the "immediate circumstances"  of the ecnoomic recession that helped get Obama elected "have now becomethe single greatest obstacle impeding the realization of his most ambitious plans." (x)  His analysis of the situtation is that the economic crisis "resulted directly from the policies of deregulation put in place during the preceeding two decades y his predecessors Bill Clinton and George W. Bush." (x)  And yet many Americans blame Obama for failing to "restore prosperity" while they also criticize him for "the steps he took, the stimulus package and bank bailout, which most observers agree helped prevent an even deeper crisis."  And here is the real lament: "So incoherent is American public ebate that Obama's critics simultaneously blem hime for an economic situation he did nothing to cause and oppose larger infusions of money into the economy through much greater government spending, the only option that might directly address the problem."  (xi)  Kloppenberg thinks--is this a Deweyian and Progressive position?--that the "impasse" that the nation is in "stems directly fromthe American people's limited access to power--and their equally limited access to responsible sources of information about how the economy works." (xi)  K thinks that only because "shrill, partisan simplifications domiante public debate" Obama's cautious approach has made the right angry and the left dissatisfied.  He thinks taht Obama's book The Audacity "explains the short-circuiting of American democracy in the tweneith century and illuminates the reasons why he faces such ntractable political as well as economic problems as president.  His conundrum, as he understands, is the product of long-term, unresolved problems in American history." (xi)

2) He thinks that "philosophical pragmatism" has "provided a sturdy base for Obama's sensibility." (xi)  He defines philosophical pragmatism (as against vulgar pragmatisim meaning simply "an instinctive hankering for what is possible in the short term" (xii)) as a tradition taht "embraces uncertainty, provisionality, and the continuous testing of hypothees through experimentation." (xii)  This is the philsoophy rooted in James and Dewey and he says that "[t]he close connection between the philosopy of pragmatism and the culture of democratic decision making illuminates crucial dimensions of Obam's thinking..." (xii)  He notes the idea that philosophical pragmatism is not necessarily useful in times such as these when so many people are reaching back towards absolutism in moments of uncertainty... (xii-xiii)

3) He thinks taht Obama's thinking "reflects the intellectual upheavals that occured on American campuses during the two decades he spent studying at Occidental College, Columbia University, and the Harvard Law School..."  I think K is referrign here to the postmodern critiques of absolutism among other things?  He referes to Obama encoutnering a tension between "universality and particualrity..." (xiii-xiv).

title: The American Woman's Pre-World War I Freedom in Manners and Morals
text:
p. 320 Change in Women's Work he said came 1900 to 1910

"The great leap forward in women's participation in economic life cam ebetween 1900 and 1910; the percentage of women who were employed changed only slightly from 1910 to 1930.  A comparison of the percentages of gainfully employed women aged 16 to 44 between 1890 and 1930 shows that they comprised 21.7 percent of Americans employed in 1890, 23.5 percent in 1900, 28.1 percent in 1910, 28.3 percent in 1920 , and 29.7 percent in 1930."  Source here is Sophonisba Breckinridge, Women in the Twentieth Century: A STudy of Their Political Social and Economic Activities (NY, 1933).

Also married women, in upper middle classes, who were encouraged to get rid of maidds and use appliances. (320)

title: The Averaged American: Surveys, Citizens, and the Making of a Mass Public
text:
p. 011 New focuson the "Average" or "Typical"

Where there had once been a focus on "genderates, deliquents, defectives" now there developed a new focus on the avearge Americans.  There had often been an implicit invocatoin of the "norm" in understandings of pathologies, but "rigorous inquiry for its own sake into the typicality of everyday practices and opinion was a twentieth-century enterprise.  Investigators would succsfully colonize new realms, from routine habits to social and political attitudes to the most intimate areas of personal experience." (11)

title: Anthropology and Antihumanism in Imperial Germany
text: p. 01 Crisis of Humanism / Humanism - Humanism (and human sciences) grappled with methodological and ideological crisis as "colonial expansion drew Europe into global cultural, economic, and political structures, as popular urban cultures challenged the monopoly of academic elites, and as natural science demanded to be recognized as a comprehensive worldview." (1) - Humanist project - "of interpreting textual monuments of European history had for centuries served European as a privileged mode of understanding what it mean to be human and as a hegemonic ideology and civic identity." (1) - was by late 19th-century in trouble. (1) - Critics pointed to its "narrow focuson Europe, its elitism, and its desregard of natural sciences." (1) - But its defenders "emphasized the utopian potential of hermeneutic interpretation, in which the humanity of both interpreter and subject of interpretation is recognized and elevated." (1)

title: Reading Obama: Dreams, Hope, and the American Political Tradition
text:
Thoughts While Reading

p. 158, bottom.  K makes reference to constitutional lawyers and political theorists who are "rediscovering" from Madison, Jefferson, and Paine that "representative democracy" is  "distinct variant of democracy that values persuasion over the rigid, unyielding defense of preferences or interests."  Does this work when he doesn't name the scholars or claims that they are making a "discovery"?  Will the public find this convincing that one can make a "discovery" in the context of such ideas?  Doesn't that even work against K's own pragmatic philosophy since it suggests the discovery of an absolute??

p. 164.  K really seems to come clean on his sense that philosophical pragmatism is good for representative democracy here.  He dislikes invocations of tradition or timeless truths because sometimes our old "understandings no longer conform the facts of our lived experience..."

p.164-172.  Important discussion of Obama's strategy in the healthcare debate the leads into a discussion of the usefulness of philosophical pragmatism...or rather whether it is inadequate because it does\ not lead to any particular solution but is open-ended...

p.172.  Importatn distinction.  He's not arguing from philosophical pragmatism to Obama's politics...the former K says does not imply the latter.  But rather he is "arguing instaed from Obama's writings back to the philosophy of pragmatism in order to show the congruence between antifoundationalism, historicism, experimentalism, and democracy in his way of thinking."

p.183.  K gives a bit too simple interpretation of the ideological shifts before and after the 1970s and the links to economic inequality.  I.e. NOw there is a "bipartisan consensus...about the desirability of lowering taxes and aroudn the theory--disproved by the catastrophic recession that began in 2008--that state regulation of the economy is less efficient than reliance on free markets." (183)  That shift he thinks as increased the gap between rich and poor.  That same gap sharnk he notes between the New Deal and the oil crisis of 1974.  "It shrank not by accident or through siple economic growth but because of four deliberate strategies: (1) progressive taxation, (2) economic regulation, (3) support for unionization, and (4) massive investment in higher education." (183) In the aftermath of the Reagan revolution, K says, all these strategies have "been deemed inconsistent with American principles." (183) And "at least partly as a consequences, inequality has soared to level unseen at least since the late nineteenth century and perhaps unprecedented in American history." (183)

p.189-193.  Sharp criticism of Obama--namely that it is not yet clear whether he will actually push for the kind of progressive visions that he lays out in the Audacity of Hope...

p.193-194.  This is followed sharply by approval of Obama's recognition of the huge gap in inequality in the United States--a theme that he describes as part of a "venerable Aemrican vernacular egalitarianism, the langauge of John Adams and Thomas Jefferson; of Jane Addams, Louis Brandeis, and Woodrow Wilson; and of John Dweey, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson." (194)

p.197-198.  K asserts that the critique of inequality--that Obama participates in--is an essentially American value rooted in the Revolution.

I think this analysis of the critique of inequality could be made much much stronger and consolidated.  It appears at several points in this chapter--the chapter itself goes on a bit too long and needs a clearer structure I think,...
